editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE ECCLESIASTICALL HISTORIE OF GREAT BRITAINE DEDVCED BY AGES, OR CENTENARIES FROM THE NATIVITIE OF OVR SAVIOVR, VNTO the happie Conuer≈øion of the Saxons, in the ≈øeuenth hundred yeare; whereby is manife≈øtly declared a continuall Succe≈ø≈øion of the true Catholike Religion, which at this day is profe≈ø≈øed & taught in, and by the Roman Church.
WRITTEN BY RICHARD BROVGHTON.
THE FIRST TOME.
CONTAINING THE FOWER HVNDRED FIRST YEARES.

div.p: AT DOWAY, By the Widowe of MARKE WYON, at the ≈øigne of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
M. DC. XXXIII.

div.head: TO THE MOST ILLVSTRIOVS, RIGHT HONOVRABLE, AND VERTVOVS LADIES, THE LADIE CATHERINE DVTCHESSE, AND DOVVAGER OF BVCKINGHAM, SOLE DAVGHTER AND HEIRE TO THE RIGHT HONOVRABLE FRANCIS LATE EARLE OF RVTLAND, AND THE LADIE CECILIE COVNTESSE, AND DOWAGER OF RVTLAND.
div.p:
DEEM it not I be≈øeech you (MOST ILLVSTRIOVS NOBLE LADIES) any the lea≈øte di≈øparagement to your NOBILITIES, or blemish to your VERTVES, that your humble ≈øeruant, and Secretarie, hath pre≈øumed to ioyne you, within the narrowe ≈øtraites, and precincts of one, and that ≈øo short an Epi≈øtle, whom both terrene Dignities and heauenly Ble≈ø≈øings haue ≈øo happily vnited in one mo≈øt Noble STOCKE and LINAGE. He is not ignorant that the SPLENDOR of a DVTCHESSE cannot commonly be paraleld by the DIGNITIE and TITLE of a COVNTESSE: yet when he coÃÑ≈øidereth the RENOWNE of a COVNTESSE de≈øcended from mo≈øt antient and Noble Families, Daughter to the Noble, and by Name and Di≈øcent mo≈øt antient S. Iohn Tufton of Tufton, and before shee was wife to her mo≈øte Noble Father, wife to the noble heyr of the greate and antient L. Hungerford should any whitt eclip≈øe, shadowe, or ob≈øcure the RADIANT BEAMES of a DVTCHESSE‚ñ™ but rather by adding Splendor to Splendor,
make both more GLORIOVS and RESPLENDENT.

Moreouer he apprehendeth a mutuall and long AFFECTION euen from the yonge yeares of the one betwixt MOTHER and DAVGHTER, as al≈øo the vnited hearts of WIFE and DAVGHTER, both embracing the mo≈øt Noble Earle of Rutland of famous Memorie, the one with the LOVE of a WIFE towards her HVSBAND, the other with the AFFECTION of a DAVGHTER to her deare FATHER: Who≈øe LOVE to requite, he with his owne hands ≈øtiled your GRACE, his DEARE DAVGHTER; and your HONOVR, his DEARE WIFE of whome he further gaue his mo≈øt ample Te≈øtimonie and in the≈øe words: I WILL SAYE THAT THERE WAS NEVER MAN HAD A MORE LOVING AND VERTVOVS WIFE THEN SHE HATH BEENE TO MEE. And as your LOVE hath beene GREAT to this mo≈øt honourable Earle, who was Di≈øcreet in his words, Prudent and iu≈øt in all his Actions, Charitable to the Poore, Affable to all, Faithfull to his Countrie, Gratious to his Soueraigne, Con≈øtant in his Faith and Religion, mo≈øt beloued and honoured of all; and then whome noe Noble man of England was more affected, or more Generally honoured in his life, or more Bewayled and lamented after his death; So your VERTVES doe shine in this world with a mo≈øt re≈øplendent LIGHT, and are the DIAMONDS and PEARLES which adorne the RING of your Auncient NOBILITIE. And the≈øe his, and your Heroicall VERTVES, being grounded on the ROCK of a true FAITH, as they haue made the Earle, ≈øo they will make you CONSTANT SVPPORTERS of holy CATHOLIKE RELIGION; The≈øe being fixed to the ANCHOR of HOPE, as they haue guided him, ≈øo will they direct you to the quiet HAVEN of eternall FELICITIE. Yea it is verily to be hoped that he by the≈øe VERTVES, is there alreadie arriued, whil≈øt the one of you like a PHAROS, and the other like the CYNOSVRE with the FLAMES of CHARITIE, doe giue LIGHT vnto others, in this time of DARKNES.

Wherefore (MOST VERTVOVS LADIES) to whome after the mo≈øt Noble Earle (to whome this WORKE was fir≈øt de≈øigned, and for whome before his death it was ≈øett on the PRESSE) can I more worthilie dedicate the≈øe, CENTVRIES OF OVR ECCLESIASTICALL HISTORIE, then to the≈øe, in whome the Noble Earle ≈øtill in renowme SVRVIVES? If you e≈øteeme NOBILITIE ioyned with SANCTITIE, behold here LVCIVS, HELENA, and CONSTANTINE, three great SAINCTS,
three great PRINCES, and all great PROMOTORS and ESTABLISHERS of the RELIGION, which you imbrace. If you take plea≈øure to ≈øee the DAMASKE ROSES of MARTYRDOME, here is an ALBAN our PROTOMARTYR, here is an AMPHIBALVS with many more, all ≈øtout and valiant CHAMPIONS, Who haue ≈øealed the TRVETH of our FAITH with there deare≈øt BLOOD: They all were once PILGRIMS in this VALE of TEARES, as you both now are, but now they are glorious COVRTIOVRS in the Triumphant HIERARCHIE. If you followe theire STEPS, and imitate theire VERTVES and CONSTANCIE in FAITH, you may haue great CONFIDENCE to be Partakers of the like GLORIE: and in the meane time, your NAMES being prefixed before their HEROICALL ACTIONS, may impetrate theire PATRONAGE in all your corporall and Spirituall NECESSITIES; and I shall pray to THEM, and to all the SAINCTS, and by THEM to the SAINCTE of SAINCTS to be≈øtowe on you here all TEMPORALL, and in HEAVEN all ETERNALL FELICITIE.

closer.signed: YOVR GRACES AND YOVR HONOVRS Mo≈øt humble and deuoted Seruant R. B.

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE READER.
div.p: AMONG all Writers, things written, or to be written what≈øoeuer, none haue bene, or can be in any time, or place, or by any per≈øon more v≈øefull, or nece≈ø≈øary then ≈øuch, as haue truely written, bene or shall be written of the true office and dutie of all men, of all E≈øtates and conditions to God, and his hig ‚Ä¢ e≈øt ruling Powers; this being the cheife≈øt end of all men in this world to doe and performe ≈øuc ‚Ä¢ dutie. This is the end of all good Lawes and Lawemakers. Hi≈øtories, and Hi≈øtorians, diuine, and humane, to giue and leaue direction both in pre≈øent, and to Po≈øteritie to all men, how to liue in dutie to heaueÃÑly and terrene Authoritie. And to take the worde Hi≈øtorie, Hi≈øtoria, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , in the mo≈øt true and proper ≈øence, meanind and etymology, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , ≈øpectare vel cogno≈øcere, to beholde or knowe what they write. The holy Prophets, Apo≈øtles, Euangeli≈øts, and other holy Writers of holy Scriptures, beholding and mo≈øt certainely knowing of God, by diuine reuelation what they committed to writing, are mo≈øt properly and truely the be≈øt Hi≈øtorians, and their Writings mo≈øt properly be≈øt and true≈øt Hi≈øtories: and next to them the true Narration or Hi≈øtory of their Traditions, and holy doctrine and teachings which were mo≈øt true and certaine, taken from the mo≈øt auncient and approued Antiquities, Antiquaries and Regi≈øters ef tho≈øe things where they were performed, And in times and places of Controuer≈øies, Contentions & Que≈øtions about Religion, noe Hi≈øtory, Narration, or Expo≈øition, as Hi≈øtory ≈øignifieth of Eccle≈øia≈øticall affaires, can be more requi≈øite, or nece≈ø≈øary to knowe, and truely finde true Religion, to receaue and profe≈ø≈øe it.

Wherefore ≈øeeing all true Chri≈øtians confe≈ø≈øe, and agree, that this holy Lawe, Religion, Religation, and Dutie was truely taught by Chri≈øt, and his holy Apo≈øtles, and Di≈øciples, and, as in many other Kingdomes, and Countries, ≈øo in this Noble Kingdome of greate Britaine, by his greate≈øt Apo≈øtles, and Di≈øciples, S. Peter, S. Paule, S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia that buried Chri≈øt, and others then, and after mo≈øt holy and learned true Apo≈øtolike men: and nothing is more common, and frequent in the mouthes, and penns of the learned then that the Britans receauing this mo≈øt true and holy Religion, neuer left, lo≈øt, changed or altered it, not when they left, or lo≈øt the greate≈øt part of their Country in the ≈øix hundred yeares of Chri≈øt, nor long after; And all Writers agree, that neuer any Here≈øie except the Pelagian, of which it was happily freed by our renowned Apo≈øtles and Prelats S. German, S. Lupus, S. Seuerus and S. Dauid, tooke roote in Britaine for a longe time after.

By which we are a≈ø≈øured by all accompts, that the Church of Britaine enioyed many glorious Apo≈øtles, Apo≈øtolike Saints and others, teaching, preaching, and profe≈ø≈øing with the Church and Chri≈øtians here the mo≈øt holy and vndoubted true Religion of Chri≈øt in all Articles, both now que≈øtioned and others, as all our Rulers ≈øpirituall and temporall, Kings and Subiects, Britans
and Saxons did, thereby giuing and duely to this renowned, and greate≈øt Iland, the name and Title of the mo≈øt Noble and Holy fir≈øt Chri≈øtian Kingdome in the world. To renewe and illu≈øtre who≈øe honor and glory, therein (lately too much by ≈øome ob≈øcured) and shew the way of truth to all that be now wandring in error, and want direction, to know the holy true Religion of tho≈øe happy times in this Nation, that if they will not be willfully erring and ignorant, they may ea≈øely and plainely knowe it, and ≈øecurely embrace and profe≈ø≈øe it, as their holy, and Religious Aunce≈øtors and Predece≈ø≈øors did. This dutie hath cheefly called vpon me to write this Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hi≈øtory, of our Noble Britaine, deducing it from the Natiuitie of our ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour Chri≈øt Ie≈øus vntill the happy, full Conuer≈øion of our Aunce≈øtors the Saxons in the ≈øeuenth hundered yeare, after which time our Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hi≈øtories are plaine and perfect, not needing helpes, or Additions.

And this which I haue taken in hand, e≈øpecially the fir≈øt 600. yeares, are the mo≈øt difficulte Worke Britaine had to be performed in this kynde, mo≈øt or many of the Antiquities and Monuments of tho≈øe times by many outrages of enemies to tho≈øe holy dayes, par≈øons, and proceedings, de≈øtroyed, con≈øumed, concealed, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, defaced, or abu≈øed, and tho≈øe that from many difficulties, and dangers be ≈øtill pre≈øerued, are not without greate fauour, labour, diligence and co≈øt to poore Students, e≈øpecially Catholiks to be obtained. Yet I a poore Catholike Student in holy learning from my young yeares, vnto my now old Age, may boldly confe≈ø≈øe, which this Hi≈øtory it≈øelfe will proue, that I haue ≈øeene, & diligently peru≈øed the mo≈øt & be≈øt Monuments, and Antiquities extant, or their true Copies, which I could learne of, know and procure, requi≈øite and v≈øefull for ≈øuch a Worke, and therefore at the entreaty and de≈øire of diuers my learned friends, hauing better opinion of my ≈øtudies and reading, then I dare affirme of my ≈øelfe, haue taken this greate charge in hand, and wholly performed and ended it, written in our English tongue, becau≈øe principally of England, and to English men.

Io≈øeph of Aramathia, be≈øides them which continued with him at Gla≈øtenbury: and many of them married with Britans continuing Chri≈øtianitie heare in their children, and po≈øteritie, vntill the generall Conuer≈øion of Britaine, vnder the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian Kings, Lucius, and Donaldus. 124

Io≈øeph of Aramathia is termed Apo≈øtle by ≈øome holy Fathers, the renowned ≈øanctity of him, and his companions, together with ≈øome particular points of their holy Religion, now denied by ≈øome, but euen from their time to this, Miraculou≈øly approued. 135

Chap. xxix. Wherein is shewed how our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries and others of England vehemently contending to proue that ≈øainct Paule the Apo≈øtle preached heare in Britaine, doe proue no ≈øuch thing, by any Authorities they alledge for his being heare. 139

Chap. xxx. How it is very probable, that ≈øainct Paule preached heare in Britayne although not vntill long after that ≈øainct Peter and his Di≈øciples had fir≈øt heare founded the Church of Chri≈øt. 144

Chap. xxxj. Concerning the time of S. Pouls comming into, and preaching in Britaine. That it could not be vntill the later end of the Empire of Nero, a litle before the Martyrdome of ≈øainct Poule, and was heare, but a very short time. 147
Chap. xxxij. Of our holy Chri≈øtian Britans in Rome at this time, and cheifely of Lady Claudia, and her holy family. 153

Chap. xxxiij. Of S. Peter his returne from Britaine to Rome, and fettling the Apo≈øtolike Papall power there. His greate care of Britaine: and our Chri≈øtian Britans dutifull loue, and honor to him. 161
Chap. xxxiv. Entreating of the time of Pope Linus, Ve≈øpa≈øian Emperor, and Marius King of Britaine: and of our Chri≈øtians in tho≈øe dayes, both at Rome, in Britaine, and other places. 165

Chap. xxxv. Of the ≈øtate of Chri≈øtian Religion in Britaine in the time of Pope Cletus, King Marius, or Coillus: and how we had heare in Britaine a continued Succe≈ø≈øion both of Prei≈øts and Bishops all this first hundred of yeares. 169

Chap. xxxvj. Of the ≈øtate of Eccle≈øia≈øticall affaires in Britaine in the Papacy of S. Clement, Empire of Traian and Reigne of King Coillus, vnto the end of this fir≈øt hundred of yeares of Chri≈øt. 173

list.head: THE SECOND AGE.
list.item:
THE I. CHAPTER. VVHerein is related by all Testimonies of Prote≈øtants, and others, how in the Papacie of S. Anacletus, this kingdome was diuided into Prouinces for Chri≈øtian Primats and Bishops, and that the≈øe Bishops and holy Prei≈øts were Ma≈øsing ≈øacrificing Prei≈øts, and con≈øecrated by ≈øuch forme and manner of Con≈øecration, as the pre≈øent Roman Church now v≈øeth, as likewi≈øe all our Primatiue Brittish Bishops and Prei≈øts were: and diuers ≈øuch ≈øent into the≈øe parts by this holy Pope, as ≈øainct Peter, and Clement
had giuen charge before. 185

Chap. II. How in the Papacie of ≈øaint Euaristus, and Empire of Traiane, the ≈øame holy Pope ≈øent a Legate to our King in Britaine to exhort him to Chri≈øtian Religion, and the benefite thereof, Traian commanding that Chri≈øtians should not be per≈øecuted. 192

Chap. III. Of the ≈øtate of Britaine in Eccle≈øia≈øticall Affaires in the time of ≈øainct Alexander Pope, Adrianus Emperour, and Coillus, or Lucius his ≈øonne King heare. Their affections to Chri≈øtian Religion, and of diuers Apostolike men ≈øent from the See of Rome preaching heare. 195

Chap. IV. Of the Eccle≈øia≈øticall e≈øtate of Britaine in the Popedome of Saint Sixtus, the re≈øt of the Empire of Adrianus, and beginning of Antoninus Pius. How many learned Britains were conuerted, and conuerted others, to the faith of Chri≈øt in this time. 200

Chap. V. Of the greate encrea≈øe of Chri≈øtians in Britaine in the Papacie of ≈øainct Tele≈øphorus and ≈øainct Higinius, and how King Lucius him≈øelfe did now either actually receaue and priuately profe≈ø≈øe the Chri≈øtian Religion, or made promi≈øe thereof. 208

Chap. VI. Wherein is entreated what learned and Apo≈øtolike men they were which preached in this time in Britaine, and conuerted King Lucius, and very many of his people. Such were ≈øainct Timothie, ≈øainct Marcellus, Man≈øuetus, Theanus with others. 212

Chap. VII. Declaring many Human lets and Impediments, hindering King Lucius, and his Noble Britans ≈øome yeares from publikely profe≈øsing Christian Religion, which ≈øecretly they embraced: and the occa≈øions of diuers mi≈øtakings eyther of Hi≈øtorians, or their Scribes, in the Date, times, & Titles of letters written about the Conuer≈øion of Britaine to the faith of Chri≈øt. 219

Chap. VIII. Of the Holy Pope S. Pius, and our renowned Chri≈øtian Britans by their Mother S. Claudia, S. Pudendentia, ≈øainct Nouatus, ≈øainct Timotheus and ≈øainct Praxedes with their holy families and friends in Rome. 223

Chap. IX. Of S. Timothie still preaching in Britaine, his dispo≈øing his teÃÑ porall goods in Rome for entertaining and releeuing per≈øecuted Prei≈øts and Chri≈øtians, his hou≈øe there being dedicated a cheife Church, mo≈øt Chri≈øtians re≈øorting to it. And other Apo≈øtolike men ≈øent from Rome into Britaine in this time. 227

Chap. X. Of the last holy labours of S. Timothie in Britaine, his honour with S. Denis the Areopagite, his returne from hence to Rome, and Martyrdome there, and Martyrdome of S. Pius Pope in the ≈øame place. 231

Chap. XI. Of the holy Popes next ≈øucceeding Sainct Pius, and their Religion. The fauorable Edict of Marcus Aurelius Emperour for defence and protection of Chri≈øtians and the Chri≈øtian Lieutenants Trebellius and Pertinax, with the forhidding the Druids Religion, occa≈øions of the publike receauing and profe≈øsion of Chri≈øtianitie in Britaine by King Lucius and his ≈øubiects. 234

Chap. XII. How the Religion of the Druides in Britaine made ≈øome binderance for the generall receauing of the lawe of Chri≈øt; But conuicted to be abominable Idolatrie, and Super≈øtition, the Profe≈ø≈øors of it generally embraced the faith of Chri≈øt, dete≈øting their former Infidelities and Impieties. 240

Chap. XIII. Of Pope S. Eleutherius, and how in his Papacie, and by his Papall order and power Britaine had the honour to be the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian kingdome in the worlde, and elde≈øt daughter
of the mother Church of Chri≈øt, King Lucius by his Emba≈ø≈øadors and petition to the Pope of Rome ≈øo obtaining. 247

Chap. xvj. Wherein is related, how King Lucius did not onely ≈øue vnto the Pope of Rome by his Emba≈ø≈øadges, for the generall ≈øettling of Chri≈øtian Religion in Britaine, but for ciuill and temporall lawes al≈øo to be allowed by him to rule heare in Temporall affaires. 252

Chap. xv. The mi≈øsion of the holy Legats ≈øaincts Damianus, Fugatianus Bishops, and diuers others from ≈øainct Eleutherius Pope of Rome, at the reque≈øt of ≈øainct Lucius King heare in Britaine, by Authoritie to plant, and ≈øetle heare the true Chri≈øtian Religion. 260

Chap. xvi. How the≈øe holy Roman Legats by Power and Commi≈øsion from the Pope, and Apo≈øtolike See of Rome, conuerted and confirmed vnto, and in the faith of Chri≈øt, all manner of Par≈øons in all places of Britaine, whether the Nobilitie, Flamens, Archflamens, or of what Order or degree ≈øoeuer. 266

Chp. xvij. How in Britaine the≈øe holy Legats placed Archbishops & Bishops in our Cities, Archbishops in the places of Archflamens, and Bishops for Flamens. And how by all writers, ≈øuch dignities were among the auncient Pagans, both in Britaine and other Nations. 272

Chapt. xviij. In what Places of Britaine the≈øe cheife≈øt coÃÑmanding Archflamens were, to witt at London, Yorke and Caerlegion, and how the≈øe Roman Legats placed for them Archbishops, with their ≈øeuerall commands, and Iuri≈ødictions, ≈øome of them by the Apo≈øtoli ‚Ä¢ e power extending, and coÃÑ manding ouer Prouinces and Countries not temporally ≈øubiect to King Lucius of Britaine, or the Romans, but rather enemyes vnto them in ciuill affaires. 279

Chap. xix. Of the Epi≈øcopall Sees and Cities, of the Inferiour Bishops ≈øubordinate to the Archbishops, which where, and how many they were, ordained by the≈øe Roman Legats, and continued Bishops Sees in the Romans and Britans time. 285

Chap. xx. How S. Eleutherius Pope did not onely by his Papall Authoritie establish and ≈øettle Religion, & Eccle≈øia≈øticall thiÃÑgs heare, but directed what temporall Lawes were to be v≈øed, appointed the bounds and limits of this kingdome, ≈øending and allowed Crowne to our King: and ≈øuch Lawes & Order continued heare in many Ages after. 295
Chapt. xxj. Of many Archiepi≈øcopall, Epi≈øcopall and other Churches, and Mona≈øteries both of men and women founded, and ritcly endowed and priuiledged in this time. 304

Chap. xxij. How after the≈øe Roman Legats had fully ≈øettled the affaires, and estate of our Church heare, they went againe to Rome to procure the Pope there to ratifie and confirme what they had done, which he did, and they returned hither againe with that his Confirmation, and many other Preachers then ≈øent hither from Rome. 311

Chap. xxiij. Of the Archbishops of London, Yorke and Caerlegion in this time in particular: & many other inferiour Bishops, and the Roman Church Di≈øcipline heare al≈øo ≈øetled by Papall Authoritie. 316

Chap. xxiv. Of the comming of the≈øe holy Legats to Gla≈øtenbury, their holy labours, deeds and long aboade there, their renewing there the old Religeous Order of S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, and his brethren, greate priuiledges and indulgeÃÑces by theÃÑ procured to that holy place, the glory, honour and renowne thereof, in the whole Chri≈øtian world. 322

Chap. xxv. Of the greate honour, and Renowne of our old Brittish Apo≈øtolike Order of Religion, from the comming of ≈øainct Io≈øeph of Aramathia, in the yeare of Chri≈øts Natiuitie 63. (without any di≈øcontinuance, or Interruption by ≈øome, and very short time after his death by all) many hundreds of yeares in greate perfection without any change or alteration, (to be named a Mutation of Mona≈øticall Rule) being the Mother or Nur≈øe of Mona≈øticall holy life to many Nations, and Religious Orders in them: by which al≈øo many CouÃÑtryes to Chri≈øt were conuerted. 328

Chap. xxvj. That diuers of the Britans which liued in that part of Britaine, then called Albania now Scotland, were conuerted by the ≈øame meanes, and manner by the≈øe Roman Legats, as the other Britans of Loegria and Cambria were at that time. 333

Chap. xxvij. Of diuers bookes or writings of ≈øainct Phaganus, Damianus, Eluanus, Meduuinus, and others: Charters and Immunities of Pope Eleutherius, and King Lucius: the Scripturs heare receaued in the old Latine Tran≈ølation, and the ≈øame Canon of them, which Catholicks now ob≈øerue, and followe. 337

list.head: THE THIRD AGE.
list.item: THE I. CHAPTER. VVHerein is deliuered, that ≈øainct Victor being now Pope, Seuerus Emperour, and ≈øainct Luciu ‚Ä¢ yet King of Britaine, but shortly dying, ≈øainct Victor was Supreame in gouernment of the whole Church of Chri≈øt, in A≈øia, Afrike and Europe, and particularly in Britaine, which ≈øo acknowledged, and receaued from him the true ob≈øeruation of Ea≈øter, as it had done with other Catholike cu≈øtomes, from ≈øainct Eleutherius before. 343

Chap. ij. Of the time, and place of King Lucius his death; That he did not die, or was martyred in Germanie. Neither had he any Si≈øter called Emerita martyred there. It was an other Prince of Britaine after this time. This our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King Lucius died at Glouce≈øter in Britaine. 346

Chapt. iij. How notwith≈øtanding the death of King Lucius without Heire to ≈øucceede in the gouernment of the kingdome, the Brittans per≈øeuered con≈øtantly in the Chri≈øtian faith: and the Scots by Preachers ≈øent from ≈øainct Victor Pope of Rome at the entreatie of their King Donalde receaued the faith, and as the Brittans continued in it vntill the Prote≈øtants time, euen by their owne confe≈øsions. 350.

Chap. iv. That allthough the being of the Scots in Britaine in the time of ≈øainct Victor is vncertaine, and not proued, but rather otherwi≈øe, yet the Inhabitants of the part now called Scotland, Britans or who≈øoeuer, were conuerted in King Lucius and this time. The Bishops of the conuerted Scots were euer true Bishops, and they euer obedient to the See of Rome 354

Chap. v. How the Emperour Seuerus, which came into Britaine and ruled heare King, after Lucius, was of the Regall Race of the Britans and true heyre to the Crowne heare, and ≈øo of others reigning heare after him. 362

Chapt. vj. Of the ≈øtate of Chri≈øtians e≈øpecially, in Britaine in the time of Seuerus, vnder whome allthough in ≈øome parts there was greate per≈øecution of Chri≈øtians, yet not heare in Britaine, but the Christians were heare in quiet without affliction. 365

Chap. v ‚Ä¢ j. How in the time of Ba≈øsianus ≈øonne of Seuerus being Emperour ‚Ä¢ e
was both in Britaine, whence he was di≈øcended, and other places: he was a friend to Chri≈øtians, and Per≈øecutour of their Per≈øecutours. How ≈øainct Zepherine the Pope then ≈øent diuers Apo≈øtolike men into Britaine. 369

Chap. viij. How very many Kings with variable proceedings Ruled heare in Britaine before Con≈øtantius Father to the greate Con≈øtantine by ≈øainct Helen our Brittish Lady: yet the Chri≈øtians heare were quiet from Per≈øecution, in all or most of their time. 372

Chap. ix. Of the Popes of Rome in this time, how by all writers, euen the Prote≈øtants them≈øelues, they were holy men, and both they and other learned holy Fathers in this time, were of the ≈øame faith and Religion, which the pre≈øent Roman Church and Catholiks now profe≈ø≈øe, and Prote≈øtants deny and per≈øecute. 377

Chap. x. Of ≈øainct Mello, or Mellon a Britan, ≈øent Archbishop by Pope Stephen from Rome to Rhoan in Normandy. Of ≈øainct Mellorus a Noble Brittish M ‚Ä¢ rtyr, and a Prouinciall Councell of Brittish Bishops heare in Cornewalle in this time. 386

Chapt. xj. Containing an abbreuiate of ≈øome Roman Emperours, and inuincibly prouing that the mo≈øt holy Queene and Empre≈ø≈øe S. Helen, was a Britan of Regall Race, the onely true and lawfull wife of Con≈øtantius Emperour: and Con≈øtantine the Greate their true lawfull Sonne and Heire, borne in Britaine. 391

Chap. xij. Of the other three children, of Constantius and ≈øainct Helen, and particularly of two of them ≈øainct Lucius and ≈øainct Emerita, renowned and glorious Martyrs for holy Chri≈øtian Religion, among forreine Pagans, S. Lucius an holy Bishop preaching it to them in Germany. 401

Chap. xiij. That ≈øainct Helen was all her life an holy and vertuous Chri≈øtian, neuer infected with Iudai≈øme, or any error in Religion. And that Con≈øtantius her Husband long liued and dyed a Chri≈øtian, and protected both Britaine and other Countries vnder him from Per≈øecution. 406

Chap. xiv. By what wicked plotts, practi≈øes, and deui≈øes Diocle≈øian and Maximian began and pro≈øecuted their wicked Per≈øecution of Chri≈øtians in Britaine and how Con≈øtantius was innocent, and free therein. 413

Chap. xv. When, and by whome, the Per≈øecution, called Diocle≈øians Per≈øecution, began in Britaine: long before the Martyrdome of ≈øainct Alban and many heare then martyred before him: and in what ≈øen≈øe the Title Protomartyr, or prioritie in Martyrdome is yet duely giuen to him. 417

Chap. xviij. How ≈øainct Amphibalus a Brittish Bishop, and many holy and learned Prei≈øts of the Britans in this Per≈øecution went to the Scots and Picts, were reuereutly receaued of them, and preached; liued and continued there in greate Sanctitie, and left greate Succe≈øsion of ≈øuch, there after them. 429

Chap. xix. The returne of ≈øainct Amphibalus from the Scots to the Britans: his comming to the hou≈øe of ≈øainct Alban at Verolamium, and preaching vnto him: the miraculous vi≈øion, and Conuer≈øion of ≈øainct Alban, their exceeding zeale & deuotioÃÑ, & deliuery of S. Amphibalus at that time. 433
Chapt. xx. Of the holy and mo≈øt con≈øtant faith, deuotion, charitie, ≈øufferings, miracles and Martyrdome of S. Alban. 438

Chap. xxij. Of very many conuerted to Chri≈øt, by the miraculous death of ≈øainct Alban, and after going to ≈øainct Amphibalus to be fully in≈øtructed by him, ≈øuffered Mattyrdome, and being a thou≈øand in number, were diuers from the 1000. Martyrs at Lichfeild, and tho≈øe neare Verolamium. 445
Chap. xxiij. The Martyrdome of ≈øainct Amphibalus, and many others with him, o ‚Ä¢ at that time and place, and wonderfull numbers conuerted then to Chri≈øt, by the Miracles then there shewed. 447
Chapt. xxiiij. How by Coilus being King, and preuayling again≈øt the Roman Per≈øecutours, and their adherents heare, the Per≈øecution in Britaine cea≈øed. 450

list.head: THE FOVRTH AGE
list.item: THE I. CHAPTER. OF the greate peace, and quiet the Church of Britaine enioyed, during the whole life, and Reigne of Con≈øtantius Emperor, and King heare in Britaine; and Con≈øtantine his ≈øonn√® by ≈øainct Helen was heare brought vp in Chri≈øtian Religion. 457. or 475

Chap. v. The miraculous Bapti≈øme of Con≈øtantine at Rome by S. Sylue≈øter Pope. He was an holy and Orthodoxe Emperour to his death, and both in the Greeke Church and with tho≈øe of the Latine honored and ≈øtiled an holy Saint. 474

Chap. viij. The generall e≈øtablishing, endowing and honoring of Chri≈øtian Religion, Bishops, Prei≈øts other Clergy men, cha≈øt and Religious par≈øons in all places of the Empire by Con≈øtantine. 486
Chap. ix. Con≈øtaÃÑtine did not prolonge his Bapti≈øme ≈øo long as ≈øome write. He was not baptized, by an Arrian Bishop, neuer ≈øell into Arriani≈øme, or any Here≈øie. 489
Chap. x. The vndoubted truth of the donation and munificent enritching of the Church of Rome by Con≈øtantine the greate Emperour. 497

Chap. xj. Of the ≈øettling of the Imperiall
Seat at Bizantium, or Con≈øtantinople, and Conuer≈øion of, or ≈øetling the Chri≈øtian faith in many Nations by the helpe of our Brittish Emperor Con≈øtantine. But Ireland not then conuerted. 500

Wherein Maximus our King and Emperor is cleared from many imputations, and ≈ølaunders e≈øpecially concerning true Catholike Religion, which he both profe≈ø≈øed in him≈øelfe, and maintained in others, all the other Emperors and Popes were of the ≈øame Religion the Roman Church now profe≈ø≈øeth. 570

Temporis Annales Lucem, Monumentaque Patrum,

Expungunt vetera, & fingunt noua Saecula. Quare?

div.head: TO MAISTER RICHARD BROVGHTON, whome Venerable Age, Equall learning, and Tryed Vertue rancke among≈øt the Worthies of our time. Vpon his Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hi≈øtorie of Great Britaine.

lg.l: AMong≈øt the VERTVES which a STORY crowne,
TRVTH ≈øtand's at HELME: (whole Ages done)
It makes men, like an other Sunne,
See what they were in THEIRS: Noe Smile, no Frowne,
Noe fawning hopes, noe ba≈øe vnmanly feare,
Noe ≈øelfe ≈øought glory, noe applaw≈øe
Ought to diuert vs from the LAWES
Of this for≈øaken GODDESSE. Hence forebeare‚ñ™
Profaners of ≈øuch good: See heare a SIRE
Of th' old frame, who dares not write
Thinges fal≈øe; noe if he might;
Omitt what's true: Ble≈øt be ≈øuch holy FIRE.
See, ≈øee and blush, Truth-killers, view this Booke,
In which a Miracle appeares,
Times pa≈øt reuiu'd to freshe≈øt yeares,
And ≈øo a licke to what they were they looke,
That should their Owners liue and reed, they'd ≈øweare
THESE DEEDES WERE OVRES; THES ‚Ä¢ TIMES. Then pray
Their I≈ø≈øue read them through, and ≈øay,
NOE FORGD VNTRVTH, NOE FALSITIE IS H ‚Ä¢ R ‚Ä¢ .
GArrula nunc ≈øileat VETERVM male≈øana FVRORVM
Lingua, REPRODVCI quae canit orbe NIHIL.
Nunc ANTIQVORVM taceat lis alta SOPHORVM
Quae mal√™ PRAETERITVM po≈ø≈øe redire negat:
Ecce REPRODVCIS VETERVM NOVA SAECVLA; quaeque
Tempora BRVTIGENIS, praeteri√™re, manent.
Reddita, no≈øtra ≈øibi e≈øt nunc ANGLIA; Teque BRITANNI
Prae≈øide, quem cultum de≈øeru√™re, tenent.
Saecula SATVRNI per te Rediuiua priorem
Iactando vultum, quem tenu√™re, ferunt.
If what PYTHAGORAS held of Soules were true.
I'de ≈øweare BARONIVS Soule had place in you.
PIts had≈øt thow been ≈øo curteous to haue ≈øayd. See the worthy pray≈øes of M. Broughton in D. Iohn Pits de illu≈øtribus Angliae Scriptoribus aetat. 16. ann. D. 1612. num. 1071.
Le≈ø≈øe of this Authors former woorkes, th' had≈øt made
Me happy with thy ≈øelf; wher now the pray≈øe
Thahs' giuen to Brougkton bringes to the the Bay≈øe,
Who ha≈øt already ≈øoom'd vp all that can
Pray≈øe-worthy be, in him, or any man.
Shall thy this glorious woorke for feare of theaft
from they fore-≈øtawling pray≈øe, of pray≈øe be reaft?
Noe; nor will I bee houlding be to thee
For aught I ≈øay; but thow shalt enuey mee.
Whoe liue to See a woorke that now affoords
More then thy Art could haue expre≈øt in woords
Then heere to Broughtons Glory, Pits' be don
Our ≈øtri≈øe; thow ≈øaw≈øt his STARRS, but I his SOONNE.

div.head: ILLVSTRI, PEREXIMIO AC ERVDITISSIMO DOMINO D. RICHARDO BROVGTON IN ANNALES ECCLESIASTICOS MAGNAE BRITANNIAE.

lg.l: PEr te ROMA viget, per te colit ANGLIA ROMAM,
& Britoni nomen Pontificate ≈øube≈øt.
Condidit in Latio Romanam Romulus vrbem,
Per te e≈øt ANGLIACIS condita ROMA plagis.
WHere STARRS doe shine, we loue the night of AGE
Embrace mens years, when TIME is VERTVES PAGE
GREY HEADS are CROWNES: 'tis honour to be old;
A SILVER haire becomes a WORKE of gold:
What glory then to thee, who≈øe Ne≈øtors, face,
Beares GREENE with GREY, an ag'd, and youthfull grace?
The ≈øerpents skin is ≈ølipt, then young againe,
Since able now to ≈øtrike to high a ≈øtraine;
But re≈øt, and ≈øleepe, and let thy pray≈øes fly;
I need not bid him liue, who cannot dy;
Or if they ≈øtate be mortall, 'tis a lott
That Nature gaue, and therefore feare it not:
DEATH will be LIFE to thee, when FAME shall cry:
Who liu'd, an Eagle, did a Phenix dy.

div.head: TO MAISTER RICHARD BROVGHTON vpon his learned Hi≈øtorie of the Church of ENGLAND.

lg.l: THou ≈øpeak'≈øt of Ages Broughton, and thy Lines
Mea≈øures pa≈øt times with new reuiuing, ≈øignes
Of better dayes; for in thy aged gla≈ø≈øe
Our yeares are taught, as did the old, to pa≈ø≈øe.
So each Age, by the writ de≈øires to be
The ≈øubiect of thy pen, that we may See
How each with ha≈øt ≈øucceeds the other's pace;
Striuing with gratefull force to haue it's ca≈øe
By the decided; and thou be≈øt iudge ≈øit‚ñ™≈øt
And each to each in this faire tome reknit‚ñ™≈øt.
And wer't not to loo≈øe thee, Broughton, the day
Wherein thou liu'≈øt, would ≈øtraight in ha≈øt decay
To be made famous by th' expre≈ø≈øion
Of thy mo≈øt faithfull pen's relation.
But may the Ago liue, and thy Ages bee
Of Ages all the be≈øt Epitomie.

div.head: IN LAVDEM HISTORIAE ECCLESIASTICAE AB Eruditi≈ø≈øimo viro RICH. BROVGHTONIO Eruditi≈ø≈øim√® con≈øcriptae.

lg.l: LOnga retro ≈øeries! ce≈ø≈øit quamplurimus annus,
Spon≈øaque florentes luxit anilis opes.
Qu√†m ben√® ≈øpon≈øa Dei calamo Broughtone ≈øuperbit
Scripta tuo? veterum qu√†m bene ge≈øta doces?
Te pingente vetus viget ecce Eccle≈øia, crimen
Per t ‚Ä¢ gens videat, lugeat, & vigeat.

div.head: To his Renerend, Worthie, and mo≈øt learned Countriman Mai≈øter RICHARD BROVGHTON vpon his Eccle≈øia≈øticall Annall's.

lg.l: GReat BROWGHTON, all thy workes haue made the, GREAT,
But this la≈øt Peece claimes yet a higher Seat.
In doing this, thou ha≈øt out done thy ≈øelfe,
Re≈øtor'd our ≈øicke Church to her former health:
Reuel'd a world of Reuolution's made
By heauens faire Orbes. What ere Obliuion's shade
Had ruined: and in the doing lo≈øt,
Thou ha≈øt repayred at thy deare Memorye's co≈øt.
Yea the whole SVMME OF BRITTISH MOTION
Renew'd reduc‚ñ™d to pre≈øent Notion.
Philo≈øophers that hold NO ACTE THE SAME
CAN TWICE BE DONE, mu≈øt needes adore thy NAME.
Thy ≈øo diuining, ≈øo pre≈øageing NAME,
Who≈øe euery lettre is a TRVMP of fame
To ≈øound Gods Church. Thou hai≈øt BROVGHT back whole Ages,
The ≈øame, to act ON oures, and future ≈øtages.
Thou ha≈øt enforc'd great Rome with much a doe
To know that wee haue OVR BARONIVS too.
Liue till thy bOOKE die; laugh at Enuys dart;
And glory in thy AGE-REVIVING ART.
DOcta SOROR Latium, magnis licet inuidet AVSIS
Et dolet Angliacos tanta referre modos:
In laudes Broughtone tuas tamen ire ≈øuperbit,
Miraturque Tuum, quod cupit e≈ø≈øe Suum.
Ne dubites, en Romano te more ≈øalutat,
Atque NOVENA INGENS FRONDE coronat OPVS.

div.head: AN ANAGRAME ON THE SAME. RICHARD BROVGHTON. RI ‚Ä¢ H HARD BROVGHT ON.

lg.l: RICH is thy worke: in times be≈øt iewels RICH.
Pure gold in euery Stitch.
HARDE too. What wonder? all faire things are HARDE.
Faire ≈øame bee thy rewarde.
BROVGHT backe from death. Who ere the like hath BROVGHT?
This pa≈øt our Ages thought.
ON then; lea≈øt wanting thee, times goe not ON.
THEE times relies vpon.
I can not ≈øpeake thy WOORTH yet I de≈øire
To be among≈øt thy PRAYSERS and ADMIRE.

div.head: THE ECCLESIASTICALL HISTORIE OF GREAT BRITAINE.
THE FIRST AGE.
THE I. CHAPTER.

argument.p: TREATING GENERALLY OF THE NATIuitie of Chri≈øt, in the time of Augustus Emperour of Rome, and Kymbelnie King of Brittayne: And how it came to the knowledge of the Brittans.

div.p:
1. AFTER Iulius Ce≈øar, the fir≈øt Emperour of Rome, who had made this kingdome of Brittayne tributary to the Romans, and carried many Ho≈øtages and Pri≈øoners from hence, to Rome, was ≈ølayne and his next Succe≈ø≈øour Augu≈øtus, the ≈øecond Emperour, (≈øay our Antiquaries, auncient and late, Catholiks and others,) by the will of God had e≈øtablished mo≈øt ≈øure peace through the world, our Redeemer
The ble≈ø≈øed birth of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus Redeemer of the world. Ranulph. Higeden. hi≈øt. l. 4. c. 6. Stow. Et howes hi≈øt. tit. the Romans, in Ce≈øar Augu≈øtus. an. 1. Chri≈øt. Matth. We≈øtmin≈øt. chron. an. gratiae 5. Galfrid. monum. hi≈øt. Britt. l. 4. c. 11. Virun. l. 4. Io. Harding. f. 30. Stow. & howes. ≈øupra. Matth. We≈øtm. aetat. 5. an. 9. 10. Theater of Brit. l. 6. Raph. holin. hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 3. p. 32. Hector. Boeth. Scotor. hi≈øt. l. 3. veremund. hi≈øt. Scot. Grim ≈øtoÃÑ in Scot. in Metellan. Stow. hi≈øt. in Ca≈ø≈øibelan. and Octau. Augu≈øtus. Io. Bal. l. de Script. centur. 1. in Gilda Cambr. & Claudia. Mat. Pa ‚Ä¢ ker. antiquit. Brit. p. 2. Theater of Brit. pag. 202. Mat. We≈øtm. an. 44. Golfrid. hi≈øt. Brit. l. 4. c. 9. Bal. ≈øupr. in Androgeo. Fabian. hi≈øt. in Kimbeline. & Guido de columna. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 3. p. 32. Dion. l. 59. Stow. hi≈øt. in Guider. Galfrid. hi≈øt. Brit. l. 5. c. 18. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. p. 51. Stow. hi≈øt. in Coil. Hector Boeth. Scotor. hi≈øt. l. 3. f. 36. p. 2. Strabo l. de Situ orbis. Hect. Boeth. ≈øupr√† fol. 37. Ie≈øus Christ, true God and man was borne in the 42. yeare of his Empire, in the fift yeare of the Reigne, of Canobelyne, or Kymbeline in this Kingdome of Brittayne; and as our ≈øcottish hi≈øtoriaÃÑs ≈øay, Metallanus ruled then among the people, called Scots. A litle before which time, by the greate prouidence of God, to make this our Brittayne more timely, and particularly partaker of ≈øuch heauenly Tideings, before other nations, Augu≈øtus intending an expedition again≈øt this kingdome, Amba≈ø≈øadours came from Brittayne to Rome entreating for peace, ≈øwearing fealtie in the Temple of Mars, offering guifts in the Capitole to the Gods of the Romans, and ≈øubmitted parte of the Ile to Augustus. They gaue him for ≈øecuritie, ≈øo many and greate Nobles of this Nation, for pledges, and ho≈øtages, that all here were ≈øo quiet, that one bande of Souldiars, and a fewe hore≈øemen were ≈øufficient to keepe the Ile in the Roman po≈ø≈øe≈øsion.

2. And by ≈øuch meanes the Romans did euer here ≈øecure them≈øelues, of the Brittans, from their fir≈øt Inua≈øion by Iulius Cae≈øar, carrying away from hence, and keeping them at Rome, for their glory, honour, and quiet, not onely many of our cheife Nobilitie, men, women and children, but of the regall race, and blood, and Kings them≈øelues. Among which we finde, that Androgius ≈øonne and heyre to King Ludd, liued and died there. Ca≈ø≈øibilane his vnkle, who was ≈øubdued by Cae≈øar, giue ho≈øtages, and made this kingdome Tributary to the Roman Empire. Theomantius his Nephew, and Succe≈ø≈øour in the Kingdome, payed tribute to the Romans, which Ca≈øsibilane had graunted, and reigned quietly. And his Sonne Cunobeline King after him (his Father) was one of his Fathers ho≈øtages in Rome, in his time, and was kinghted there. Adaminus ≈øonne of King Cunobeline, was kept at Rome by Caius Caligula, Emperour. His Brother Guiderius, (if he was King here at all) reigned but a verie shorte time. Aruitragus next King of Brittayne, Married the daughter, or neare kin≈øwoman of Claudius, the Emperour, and had by her, his ≈øonne and heire Marius, & Succe≈ø≈øour in this kingdome. Coillus his ≈øonne, heire and next King here after him, was, ab Infantia Romae enutritus; brought vp at Rome from his Infancie. King Lucius his ≈øonne, and heire, and our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian in Britaine, had the like dependances from thence, and by that happy meanes, and occa≈øion, together with his kingdome, receaued publikely the faith of Chri≈øt from ble≈ø≈øed Eleutherius, Pope and Bishop there.

3. Neither was this greate league of amitie onely betweene Rome, & ≈øuch parts of Britaine, (which English inhabite now, and longe haue done,) but with the whole Iland of Britaine, and other parts about it al≈øo; as the Scottish hi≈øtorians doe plainely write, contending, That the Emperour Augu≈øtus and Senate of Rome did not onely ≈øend Amba≈ø≈øadours to King Kymbeline to congratulate his being King of Britaine: but al≈øo (as The≈øe writers ≈øay) to Metellanus, King of the Scots, to ≈øignifie their loue to him, and the greate peace the Emperour had then e≈øtablished in all the world; whereupon Metellanus to make this loue of the Romans more ≈øure vnto him, ≈øent vnto Augu≈øtus Cae≈øar and the Capitall of Rome guifts, in his owne name, and the Scottish nation: by which he obtayned the firme frendship of the Senate, and people of Rome, which remained to him and the kingdome many ages after: Augu≈øto Cae≈øari dij≈øque penatibus in Capitolio donaria ≈øuo Scoticorumque gentis nomine offerenda. Vnde firmam Senatus populique Romani a≈ø≈øentitus est amicitiam, quae illi regnoque multos deinceps annos perdurauit. And King Metellanus liued in this greate peace, and amitie vntill his death, which was in the 29. yeare of Chri≈øt and the 14. of the Emperour Tyberius.

Which loue of the Romans, then commaunders of the wotld, although by that title it ≈øwaied with it, a kinde of ≈øubiection of this whole kingdome to the Roman power: yet it was an happy temporall ≈øubiection of the Britans, The t ‚Ä¢ mporall dep ‚Ä¢ ndanc ‚Ä¢ of Britain ‚Ä¢ , to the Romane Empir ‚Ä¢ , occa≈øion of the greate≈øt ≈øpirituall good thereof. then ≈øtraungers in effect with all the world be≈øides, to be in ≈øuch amitie, although with dependance, to the Empire and Emperour of Rome, where, and where onely, or principally they might „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ way to be deliuered from ≈øpirituall bondage, and thraldome in ≈øoule, „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ franchized them to be Municipes and free-men of the priuiledges of the heauenly Empire by holy Religion, which an auncient Father calleth by this ≈øtile: To be cho≈øen eternall Con≈øuls Prudent. him. 2. de S. Laurent. S. Leo. 1. Serm. 1. de SS. Apo≈øtol. Petro & Paulo. of the celestiall Rome. For as that mo≈øt renowned Doctour, Pope, and Saint hath written: Quae v≈øquam gentes ignorarent quod Roma didici≈ø≈øet? what nations in any place could be ignorant of that which Rome had learned? for the confluence of
mo≈øt Nations, vnto Rome, at that time was ≈øuch, that they mu≈øt needs be acquainted, e≈øpecially with ≈øuch ≈øtraunge and wonderfull euents, as theÃÑ chaunced there, or were ≈øent, froÃÑ other contries, e≈øpecially from Iury, where Chri≈øt was borne (then ≈øubiect to the Romanes, and gouerned by their pre≈øidents,) truely delated and tran≈øported thither: and of all people our Britans here, (many of their cheife nobles and others from all parts of the land at that time, re≈øiding there) could not be ≈øtraungers to ≈øuch affaires, whereof Tertullian, Nicephorus, and others ≈øpeaking of ≈øuch ≈øtate of things in Tiberius time, giue Tertullian. in Apologetic. Nicephorus hi≈øt. l. 2. cap. 8. Acu≈øtome, and dutie among the Romans, to haue all ≈øtrange euents related to the Emperour at Rome. this certaine rea≈øon: Con≈øuetudo √† plurim is annis obtineb at, vt qui praefecturas aut prouincias ≈øortiti e≈ø≈øent, res nouas quae ≈øub eis accidi≈ø≈øent ≈øingulas, ≈øummum Imperium habenti Cae≈øari ≈øignificarent, vt illum nihil pror≈øus lateret: It was in Tyberius time a cu≈øtome many yeares old, that the Pre≈øidents and Rulers of Prouinces should ≈øignifie to the Emperour, all new things, that chaunged vnder them, ≈øo that nothing at all could be vnknowne to him.

5. Therefore this cu≈øtome being ≈øo old, √† plurimis annis, in the time of Tiberius immediate Succe≈ø≈øour to Augu≈øtus, towards the later end of who≈øe Empire, Chri≈øt was borne into the world, It mu≈øt needs be a cu≈øtome, and lawe of the Empire at that time, and all new things by it to be ≈øo certified, that nothing at all could be vnknowne. The ≈øtrange and miraculous things which theÃÑ publikely happened at Chri≈øts Natiuity, (≈øuch as the world had not ≈øeene, or heard before) could not be left out; and this bounden dutie belonging onely to the Emperour of Rome, mo≈øt re≈øiding there, and no where els ob≈øerued, and our Britans onely pledges, ho≈øtages, and continuers there, being ≈øtraungers to other Nations, mu≈øt needs deriue, as from a faithfull fountaine, their cheife≈øt, and be≈øt forraine Intelligence of ≈øuch things from thence. How ≈øtraunge and greate fore knowledge, God had prouided for them of the ≈øame happy bu≈øines here at home, I will al≈øo declare hereafter.

div.head: THE II. CHAPTER.

argument.p: CONTAINING DIVERS PARTICVLAR WONderfull things, (at, or about the time of the Birth of Chri≈øt) at Rome; or in other places which came thither by true relation; by meanes whereof our Brittans at Rome, and they in Britaine from them, tooke ≈øoone notice of his Natiuitie.

div.p:
1. ORDER requireth that I should ≈øpeake ≈øomewhat of Io. Herold. in Martin. Polon. in Octauiano. Ran. Higeden. M. S. hi≈øt. l. 4. c. 2. 3. Herdin. Schedel. aetat. 5. fol. 93. Suetonius in Augu≈øto. Lactant. firm. Augu≈øtin. l. de ciuitat. Mart. Polon. hi≈øt. in Octauiano Augu≈øto. tho≈øe things, yet Will I confine my ≈øelfe to ≈øuch as belonge to to the hi≈øtory of this nation, and then ≈øerued for the In≈øtruction of our Britans at Rome, and others at home from them: for to ≈øpeake of all would make a volume in hi≈øtory. Many of our English Prote≈øtant Antiquaries and others, both Pagans, as Suetonius, & Chri≈øtians, te≈øtifie, That Augu≈øtus Ce≈øar the Emperour being vrged by the Romans to be made a God after the heathnish manner then, at or about the very time, when Chri≈øt was borne, before he would con≈øent vnto it, con≈øulted with Sybilla Tiburtina, then renowned for her Prophe≈øies: Sibillam Tiburtinam ≈øuper hoc con≈øuluit, quae po≈øt trium dierum ieiunium respondit, in hunc modum.
Iudicy ≈øignum: tellus ≈øudore made≈øcet. De coelo Rex adueniet per ≈øecla futurus. Quorum ver≈øuum capitales literae hunc reddebant ≈øen≈øum. Ie≈øus Christus Dei filius Saluator. Et illico apertum e≈øt caelum, & nimius splendor irruit ≈øuper eum, & vidit in caelo pulcherrimam virginem stantem ≈øuper altare puerum tenentem in branchijs. Et miratus e≈øt nimis, & vocem dicentem audiuit: haec ara filij Dei e≈øt. Qui ≈øtatim proijciens ≈øe in terram, adorauit. Quam vi≈øionem Senatoribus retulit, & ip≈øi mirati ≈øunt nimis: After she had fa≈øted three dayes, Sybilla an≈øwereth in tho≈øe Achro≈øticall knowne ver≈øes, who≈øe fir≈øt letters make this ≈øen≈øe: Ie≈øus Chri≈øt the ≈øonne of God our Sauiour. And pre≈øently the heauen opened, and an exceeding brightne≈ø≈øe fell downe vpon the Emperour, and he ≈øaw in heauen a most beautefull virgin standing vpon an Altare, holding a child in her Armes: and he meruayled exceedingly, and heard this voyce ≈øaying. This is the altare of the ≈øonne of God. Whereupon pre≈øently prostrating him≈øelfe vpon the grounde he adored. Which vi≈øion he related to the Senators, who meruaylou≈øly wondered at it.

2. And this miraculous preaching of Chri≈øts birth ≈øo farre of, then at Rome, was ≈øo much more publike and generall. That at, or a litle before this time, the ≈øame Emperour as Suidas witne≈ø≈øeth, in their, then, greate≈øt ≈øacrifice, was Suidas in Augu≈øto. told by their oracle that an Hebrewe child commaunded their Gods (as they terme them) to ≈øilence: whereupon Augu≈øtus ab oraculo reuer≈øus, in Capitolio aram erexit, Romani≈øque literis in≈øcrip≈øit: haec Ara est primogeniti Dei Augu≈øtus returning from the oracle, erected an Altare in the Capitol, and made this In≈øcription vpon it, in Roman letters: This is the altare of the fir≈øt or onely begotten ≈øonne of God. Our English Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians with others proceed to Io. Herolde in Martin. Polon. dedic. to Queene Elizabeth of England. Martin. Polon. in Aug. Etalij. more ≈øuch publike te≈øtimonies concerning Chri≈øt, at Rome, at that very time: hoc ip≈øo die quo natus e≈øt Christus trans Tyberim fons olei emanauit: ac per totum diem largi≈øsimo riuo fluxit. Tunc etiam circulus ad ≈øpeciem caele≈øtis Arcus, circa ≈øolem apparuit. Etiam ≈øtatim vt virgo peperit, illa ≈øtatua aurea corruit in Romuliano Palatio, quam Romulus po≈øuerat, dicens. Non cadet donec virgo pariat. The very day on which Chri≈øt was borne; beyond Tyber at Rome, a fountaine of oyle flowed, and ran with a mo≈øt large ≈øtreame all the day. Then a Circle like vnto an heauenly bowe appeared about the SuÃÑne. Al≈øo pre≈øently ≈øo ≈øoone as the Virgin brought forth her ≈øonne that golden ≈øtatua in the pallace of Romulus fell downe, which Romulus placed there (aboue 700. yeares before:) ≈øaying it shall not fall, vntill a virgine be brought to bed of a child.

3. Vpon the≈øe, and other ≈øuch motiues, this Emperour was ≈øo fully per≈øuaded of the Me≈ø≈øias then borne, that he highly reuereÃÑced all te≈øtimonies thereof, among others, the Prophe≈øies of the Sibils (which an ≈øo cleare for allmo≈øt all my≈øteries of Chri≈øt, as his Natiuity, life, Pa≈ø≈øion, Re≈øurrection, A≈øcen≈øion, with the re≈øt, as if they had beene pre≈øent witne≈ø≈øes, rather then Prophets and Euangeli≈øts of the≈øe things) he ≈øo re≈øpected, that as Suetonius a Pagan Suetonius in Augu≈øto. witne≈ø≈øeth: Quicquid fatidicorum librorum Graeci Latinique generis, nullis, vel parum idoneis authoribus vulgo ferebatur, ≈øupra duo millia coÃÑtracta vndique concremauit: ac ≈øolos retinuit Sybillinos: hos quoque delectu habito: condiditque duobus forulis auratis ≈øub Palatini Apollinis ba≈øi: he gathered together all Bookes of ≈øouth≈øaiers Greeke and Latine, and he burnt aboue two thou≈øands, who≈øe Authours were either vnknowne, or of litle credit: he onely pre≈øerued the bookes of the Sybills, making al≈øo the be≈øt choice of them, and the≈øe he layed vp in two guilded che≈øts wnder the ba≈øe Herod. ≈øupr. in Martin. Pol. an. 1. Chri≈øti, & a condita vrbe 752. of Apollo Palatinus And was ≈øo coÃÑuinced in his vnder≈øtaÃÑding by the≈øe meanes of the truth of Chri≈øt: That, as our Prote≈øtant writers with others, write,
when the Romans came to him and ≈øaid: Te volumus adorare, quia Deus e≈øt in te: ≈øi hic non e≈ø≈øet non tibi omnia tam pro≈øper√® ≈øuccederent: we will adore thee, becau≈øe God is in thee: if he were not here all things could not ≈øucceede ≈øo pro≈øperou≈øly with thee: yet he being the greate≈øt Conquerour, that euer was in the world, and was neuer conquered, or ouerthrowne in battayle; Quum ip≈øum pro Deo colere vellent Romani, prohibuit, nec ≈øe Dominum appellari promi≈øit: When the Romans would haue worshipped him for a God, He forbad it, and would not ≈øuffer him≈øelfe to be called Lord.

4. Thus farre was this Romane Emperour, and con≈øequently many other Romans, and Britans of this Nation then (as before) remaining at Rome, which could not but take notice of ≈øo publike, and manifold inforcing motiues, and miracles for acknowledging the natiuity and coming of the Me≈ø≈øias, taught and illuminated for this heauenly truth; And much more and inuincibly were they moued, when they were according to the remembred cu≈øtome, vndoubtedly certified, and a≈ø≈øured from King Herode, and others in Hieru≈øalem, that at the very ≈øame time, when the≈øe miraculous wonders happened at Rome: There were then reuealed vnto them there, the miraculous Conception, and birth of Sainct Ihon Bapti≈øt, and Zachary both his ≈øilence and Prophe≈øie: The Angels Iubily, and ioy in the Natiuity of Chri≈øt: The wonderfull ≈øtarre which then appeared, The coming of the Magi to Hieru≈øalem, and Que≈øtion there; where is he that is borne King of the Iewes, we haue ≈øeene his ≈øtarre in the Ea≈øt, and are come to adore him. The Amazement of King Herode, and all Hieru≈øalem with him about this. The publike An≈øwere of the Prei≈øts therevpon that the Me≈ø≈øias was to be borne in Bethleem of Iuda. The pilgrimage of tho≈øe holy Kings, their guifts, and adoration, vnto him there: his pre≈øentation in the temple: The reioycing and prophe≈øie of Symeon: And ≈øoone after the martyrdome of ≈øo many thou≈øands of Infants by King Herode. All or mo≈øt of the≈øe Euents for certaine were both by the remembred cu≈øtome, and duty otherwi≈øe certified to the Emperour by King Herode, and the Rulers there.

5. And not onely thus, but by many other meanes, both of the Iewes of Rome repayring to Hieru≈øalem, and many ho≈øtages of Iury kept then at Rome, among which as our Prote≈øtants with others tell vs, were the ≈øonnes of King Herode‚ñ™ who both for duty, and loue to Cae≈øar, and the Senate could Stow hi≈øtor. Ab≈øtract of memorab. Antiquities in Herod Sonne of Antipater. not conceale any thing froÃÑ them, for as a Prote≈øtant antiquary writeth: He was by the Senate of Rome declared & called King of the Iewes. He was very well beloued of the Emperour Augustus, who to augment his kingdome, gaue him Samaria, with the cities and Ca≈øtels. And the≈øe things were certified ≈øo well to Rome, that Sainct Leo S. Leo Serm. 2. Epiphan. writeth: I am tunc caeli enarrauerunt gloriam Dei & in omnem terram ≈øonus veritatis exiuit. Quando & Pa≈øtoribus Exercitus Angelorum Saluatoris editi Annuntiator apparuit, & Magos ad eum adorandum praeuia ≈øtella perduxit: vt √† ≈øolis ortu v≈øque ad occa≈øum, vere Regis generatio coru≈øcaret, cum rerum fidem & regna Orientis per Magos di≈øcerent, & RomanuÃÑ Imperium non lateret: Euen then the heauens declared the glory of God, & the ≈øound of truth went fourth on all the earth. When both an army of Angels appeared to publish, that our Sauiour was borne: and a ≈øtarre going before the Magi brought them to adore him. Which preaching froÃÑ heauen ≈øo coÃÑuinced the world, that the PagaÃÑs them≈øelues confe≈ø≈øed, It shewed the birth and coming of God into the world: among whom one of them in the name and opinion of many, and be≈øt learned of them writeth of that miraculous ≈øtarre: denuntia≈ø≈øe aduentum Dei venerabilis Calcidius l. 2. in Timaeum Platonis. ad humanae confirmationis rerumque mortalium gratiam: quam ≈øtellam cum nocturno tempore in≈øpexi≈ø≈øent Chaldaeorum viri ≈øapientes ≈øignifica≈ø≈øe dixerunt recentem ortum Dei: That it did shew the coming of God to be worshipped for the cau≈øe of mans perfection and mortall things: which starre when the wi≈øe men of the Chaldeans did behold, in the night time, they ≈øaid, It ≈øignified the new birth of God. The like doe Philo. l. 3. Chronogr. an. 3. Herodis. Macrobius l. 2. Saturnal. Dion. Ca≈ø≈ø. in vita Augu≈øti. Suidas in Augu≈øto. Nicephor. l. 1. hi≈øt. Eccle≈øia≈øt. c. 17. Eu≈øeb. de praepar. Euangel. Philo the Iew, Macrobius, Dion, and Ca≈ø≈øian Pagans, be≈øides the Scriptures and Chri≈øtian writers, te≈øtifie of the martyrdome of ≈øo many thou≈øand Innocents by Herode, and the relation of that, as of ≈øuch other euents, made pre≈øently to Augu≈øtus the Emperour at Rome. Who al≈øo about this time offering to his Pagan God Apollo Pithius, their Hechatombe, greate ≈øacrifice of an hundred Oxon, could receaue noe other An≈øwere but this, that an Hebrewe child that ruled the Gods, was borne, and their Oracles put to ≈øilence, wherevpon the Emperour builded in the Capitoll a greate Altar with this Latine In≈øcription: Ara primogeniti Dei: The altar of the onely begotten ≈øonne of God. Then all the≈øe things thus happening, at, and about the Natiuity of Chri≈øt were thus truely and faithfully deliuered at Rome, and ≈øo came to the knowledge of our Britans there, and from them, and the Romans al≈øo, both to the Romans and Britans in this kingdome: So did other my≈øteries concerning Chri≈øt, e≈øpecially of his flyeing into Egypte then ≈øubiect vnto Cae≈øar Augu≈øtus, and the Pre≈øidents there keeping the ≈øame lawe and cu≈øtome of giuing intelligence vnto him.

Palladius in vita Apollinis. there te≈øtified by the auncient Fathers Sainct Epiphanius, Dorotheus and diuers others, could not, might not be concealed. And wheÃÑ longe agoe their King Ptolomy demaunded the cau≈øe, They An≈øwered it was a my≈øtery deliuered to them from their Aunce≈øtours, which they receaued from the holy Prophet. And according Origen. in Exod. Pallad. Hi≈øt. Pan. in vit. Apol. Sozom. l. 5. hi≈øt. Eccle. c. 20. Ca≈ø≈øio. l. 6. c. 42. Nicephor. l. 10. c. 31. Guliel. Ei≈øeng. cent. part. 1. di≈øt. 3. volater ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n. coÃÑ ment. l. 13. Petr. de Natal. l. 3. c. 218. If. cap. 19. v. 1. Pallad. hi≈øt. ≈øup. to this, ≈øo ≈øoone as our Sauiour was brought into Egypt, a contry (as Origen and others write,) mo≈øt full of Idols, they all fell downe, and were broken in peeces. Diuers write that S. Aphrodi≈øius (≈øent Bishop into France, by Sainct Peter) was prefect of Egypt then, and moued by that miracle. S. This was al≈øo foretolde by the Prophet E≈øay, who by our Prote≈øtants tran≈ølation, writeth of this time: The Lord shall come into Aegypt, and the Idols of Egypt shall be moued at his pre≈øence. Wherevpon Palladius in the life of Apollo (≈øaith) he had ≈øcene a Temple neare vnto Hermopolis, in which when Chri≈øt with the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary his mother, and Io≈øeph came into Egypt, at his entrance into the city,
all the Idols fell downe pro≈øtrate vpon their faces on the earth according to the prophe≈øie of E≈øay. And S. Epiphanius in his booke of the liues, and deaths of the Epiphanius l. de vita & interitu Prophetarum. Prophets, shewing how be≈øides tho≈øe things, which be contained of them in holy ≈øcripture, many or mo≈øt of them did al≈øo further prophe≈øie to the people where they liued, of the coming of Chri≈øt, and the miraculous ≈øignes, and tokens of that time, as namely Ieremy, Azarias, Heli≈øaeus, Ezechiel, O≈øee, Ionas, Abacuc. He writeth of the Prophet O≈øee: ≈øignum dedit, & prodigium, Dominum Epiphan. ≈øupr. in vita O≈øee. ≈øcilicet venturum caelitus, caeterum hoc fore indi cium aduentus eius, ≈øi quercus illa in Selom findatur √® ≈øeip≈øa in portiones bis ≈øenas, & fierent totidem quercus; & accidit ita: He gaue for a ≈øigne and wonder that our Lord should come from heauen, and this to be a ≈øigne of his coming, if an oke tree which was in Selom should cleeue a ≈øunder from it ≈øelfe, into twelue parts, and be made ≈øo many oke trees; and ≈øo it came to pa≈ø≈øe.

The≈øe and ≈øo many other mo≈øt ≈øtraunge and miraculous things, of that time, remembred in hi≈øtories, mo≈øt euident ≈øignes, and demon≈øtrations of the miraculous birth of Chri≈øt, being according to the cu≈øtome, and Imperiall decree, exactly certified by the pre≈øidents of all prouinces where they hapened, to Augu≈øtus the Emperour, at Rome, where ≈øo many Britans were of this nation, Galfrid. monum. lib. 4. hi≈øt. cap. 11. Theater of great Britaine l. 5. c. 6. Guido de ColuÃÑ na apud Fabian. in hi≈øt. in Cunob. Fabian. ib. of greate≈øt dignity, learning, and wi≈øedome, as King Kimbeline him≈øelfe, at, or about that time, many both his noble attendants, and ho≈øtages, and Druids that ruled in matters of religion, and were our mo≈øt learned men to in≈øtruct them there, were pre≈øent, or re≈øident, and for their ≈øingular ≈øtraungnes being noted and ob≈øerued by all, as concerning all in the greate≈øt que≈øtion of their ≈øoules, could not be ≈øingularly or carele≈ø≈øely pa≈ø≈øed ouer by ≈øo many worthy, & wi≈øe≈øt Britans alone. They alone could not be ≈øtraungers, and vnacquainted with the preachings, and prophe≈øies ≈øo publike and manife≈øt to all, as they were, for if we may beleeue Pagans or Chri≈øtians, Catholike or Prote≈øtant writers. For thus it is related. This Sybilla indued with the ≈øpirit Matth. We≈øtm. aetat. 4. cap. 14. Prote≈øt. annot. ib. in Merg. & Iudic. Seba≈øtian. Mun≈øter. Co≈ømograph. lib. 2. Hertman. Schedel, chronic. aetat. 3. fol. 35. Augu≈øt. ≈øerm contra Iudaeos. Lactant. Eu≈øeb. of prophe≈øie, preached in Macedonia, Hero≈øtaia, Agalguldea, Cilicia, and Galatia. Then she went into Ethiopia, Gabaon, Babylon, Africke, Lybia, Pentapolis, and Pale≈øtina. Audientes igitur Romani famam eius, nuntiaucrunt haec omnia Imperatori. Mittens ergo Imperator (decernente Senatu) ad eam legatos, cum magno honore vocatam, fecit eam adduci Romam: Therefore the Romans hearing her fame, told all the≈øe things to the Emperour. Whereupon the Emperour. (The Senate ≈øo decreeing) ≈øent Amba≈ø≈øadours vnto her, and brought her with greate honour to Rome. Where she was publikely and honorably entertained. Where she as publikely preached and foretold all the my≈øteries of the coming of Chri≈øt, as if she had beene a pre≈øent witne≈ø≈øe. AmoÃÑg the re≈øt, telling that his name should be Ie≈øus, she ≈øaid: Mulier de genere Hebraeorum nomine Maria habens ≈øpon ≈øum nomine Io≈øeph pariet, & erit Virgo, ante partum, Virgo po≈øt partum. Qui ergo na≈øcetur ex ea, erit verus Deus, & verus homo, prout Prophetae praedicauerunt: adimplebit legem Iudaeorum irreprehen≈øibiliter, & adiunget ≈øua propria in ≈øimul, & regnabit in ≈øaecula ≈øaeculorum amen. Na≈ø ‚Ä¢ ente eo exercitus Angelorum a dextris & a ≈øim≈øtris erunt, dicentes, Gloria in excel≈øis Deo, & in terrapax hominibus bonae voluntatis: eo autem baptizato √† Ioanne praece≈ø≈øore ≈øuo, veniet vox de≈øur≈øum dicens. Hic e≈øt filius meus dilectus, in quo mihi complacui, ip≈øum audite: erant autem ibi ex Sacerdotibus Iudaeorum audientes haec verba, & Indignati dixerunt ad ‚Ä¢ am. I≈øta terribilia ≈øunt, ≈øileat haec Regina: Respondens Sybilla dixit: ‚Ä¢ Iudaei nece≈ø≈øe e≈øt ita fieri, ≈øed vos non credetis in eum: A woman of the race of the Hebrewes
named Mary, hauing a spou≈øe called Io≈øeph, shall bringe fourth a child, and she shall be a Virgin both before and after her child birth. Therefore he that shall be borne of her, shall be true God, and true man as the Prophets haue foretold. He shall irreprehen≈øibly fulfill the law of the Iewes, and adde al≈øo his owne. And he shall Reigne world without end. Amen. When he is borne, there shall be armies of Angels, both on thc right and left hand ≈øaying: glorie to God on high, and vpon earth peace to men of good will: when he is baptized by Ihon his foregoer in water, there shall come a voyce from aboue, ≈øaying: This is my well beloued ≈øonne, in whome I am well plea≈øed, heare you him. And there were ≈øome of the Prei≈øts of the Iewes hearing the≈øe things, and being angry ≈øaid vnto her. The≈øe are terrible things, let the Queene keepe the≈øe ≈øecret or in ≈øilence. And Sybilla an≈øwearing ≈øaid. It is needfull to be ≈øo, But you will not beleeue in him. Then followeth: how the Iewes should put him to death, buffet, spit vpon, and whip him. Should giue him gall and vinegre, Crucifie him vpon a tree and put him to death. He should ari≈øe the third day, appeare to his di≈øciples, in≈øtruct them in his law, and ≈øend them to preach it in all the world, and in their ≈øight a≈øcend to heauen, and of his kingdome there shall be no end.

9. The Authours ≈øay this was Sybilla Tyburtina, the ≈øame which by that name prophe≈øied as before to Augu≈øtus, and the te≈øtimony that the Emperour ≈øent for her and ≈øo honorably intertained her, ≈øo conuinceth, for before Augu≈øtus there was no Emperour but Iulius (Emperour but three yeares and three moneths) who by no hi≈øtory had ≈øuch conference with any Sybill, and by the words of this Sybilla it is plaine that it was Augu≈øtus Cae≈øar, for she giueth his conque≈øt of the world, a ≈øigne of the Natiuitie of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus. In diebus illis erit Cae≈øari Augusto regnum & regnabit in Roma, & ≈øubijciet ≈øibi omnem terram. Which happened a litle before the birth of our Sauiour. Therefore this thing being ≈øo publike, as it was, The Sybilla ≈øo renowned in ≈øo many nations, ≈øo ≈øolemnely ≈øent for by the Emperour and decree of the Senate, ≈øo honorably entertained at Rome, and there publikely prouing both again≈øt the Iewes, and Gentils, that the Me≈ø≈øias of the world was then to be borne with ≈øuch ≈øignes, and circum≈øtances, that cannot deceaue vs, but confounded all oppo≈øites; we may not exclude our noble, and learned Britans, which were then at that time in Rome, from that happines: And if we may follow our british hi≈øtories, Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter a man as Prote≈øtants tell vs excellent for hi≈øtorie and ≈øupputation of yeares quantum ad hi≈øtoriam, in recta annorum Io. Bal. l. de Scrip. centur. 3. fol. 143. in Matth. florileg. Galfrid. monum. hi≈øt. l. 4. c. 11. Ponticus Virunnius hi≈øt. Britan. l. 4. ≈øupputatione ≈øingularis, and our late Prote≈øtant writers by computation of time, our King Kimbelinus was then in Rome: for we are told: Po≈øt Tenuantium ad culmen Regale Kimbelinus filius ≈øuus miles strenuus, quem Cae≈øar Augustus nutriuerat, promotus e≈øt. After Tenuantius Kimbeline his ≈øonne a valiant knight whom Augustus Cae≈øar had brought vp, was promoted to the kingdome of Britaine. In tho≈øe dayes our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt was borne. Kimbeline was but yong when Augu≈øtus fir≈øt (quem Augu≈øtus Cae≈øar nutrierat) brought him vp: and he ≈øtayed in Rome ≈øo longe, that as diuers before, and Pontius Virunnius al≈øo affirmeth, Augu≈øtus made him knight, quem Augu≈øtus Cae≈øar nutrierat & armis decorauerat. Ponticus Virun. ≈øupr. l. 4. And if we follow this exact ≈øupputator of times Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, he was come from Rome to be King here but fiue yeares before the birth of Chri≈øt. Anno Dominicae Incarnationis quinto, Kimbelinus Rex Britanniam Matth. We≈øtm. An. Dom. 5. decem annis tenui≈ø≈øet. So likely he was in Rome, when the≈øe things concerning the Natiuity of Chri≈øt were ≈øo certainely, and publikely foretold, and proued in Rome. And mo≈øt certaine it is, by all hi≈øtories of our noble and renowned
british ho≈øtages re≈øidence in Rome, all the time of Augu≈øtus Cae≈øar, and after, that we had many worthie Britans there, eare and eye witne≈ø≈øes to know the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages by them≈øelues, and te≈øtifie them to their contrimen and freinds at home.

div.head: THE III. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF DIVERS PARTICVLAR MOTIVES, preparations, and dispo≈øitions at home, for the inhabitants of Britaine, to learne out, knowe, and embrace the Natiuitie, and Religion of Chri≈øt.

div.p: 1. AND if we returne now from Rome and our Britans there, and vi≈øit this kingdome of Britaine, the inhabitants, and many of their proceedings here, in ≈øuch affaires, ≈øo farre as our decayed and worne out antiquities will giue vs leaue, we shall finde an agreeing Sympathy, and concordance of ≈øuch things at Rome and in Britaine, that hee will ≈øeeme a dull Expounder of Euents, who would not, or could not conclude from thence, that the Me≈ø≈øias and Sauiour of the world was then borne into it. Our Prote≈øtant Theater writers following Po≈øtellus, tell vs, of the druides, which ruled in ≈øpirituall and religious matters then in this kingdome: Their offices were mo≈øt employed about holy things, and Theater of great Britaine l. 6. cap. 9. ¬ß. 10. their doctrine cheifely con≈øisted in teaching the immortality of the ≈øoule, the motions of the heauens, the nature of things and the power of the Gods, yea and Po≈øtellus from others will inforce, that they prophe≈øied likewi≈øe of a Virgins Conception. The≈øe were the helps, ≈øaith Tertullian, that cau≈øed the Britans ≈øo ≈øoone to embrace the doctrine of Christ. Thus write our be≈øt learned English Prote≈øtaÃÑt Antiquaries with greate priuiledge. Which inference of the Britains ≈øpeedy conuer≈øion to Chri≈øt, although I doe not remember in Tertullian, but is perhaps added by the≈øe men, yet the effect of that illation is contained in Tertullian, when he placeth the Tertullian. contra Iudaeos. Plin. Strab. Tacit. apud Boeth. l. 2. Iul. Cae≈øar. commorer. Gallic. l. 1. Theater of Brit. ≈øupr. l. 6. Holinsh. and Stowe hi≈øt. Hector Boet. Scotor. hi≈øt. l. 2. fol. 23. Britans among the fir≈øt Chri≈øtians. That which is alledged from Po≈øtellus. And others of the Druides prophe≈øies of Chri≈øt, is further confirmed by other vndeniable authorities: for graunting (as Iulius Cae≈øar. Plinius, Strabo, Tacitus, and after them, British, English, Scotish, French, and other hi≈øtories doe witne≈ø≈øe) that the cheife Schooles and Doctours of the druides were here in Britaine, from whom they of France receaued in≈øtruction and direction. Druidum religionem a≈ø≈øeuerant ortam in Britannia, inde in Galliam tran≈ølatam.

2. We are a≈ø≈øured that this prophe≈øie and doctrine among the Druides that a Virgin should conceaue, and bring fourth, ≈øuch a wonderfull child, as our Sauiour was, was ≈øo publike, and of ≈øuch credit, and authority, in the≈øe parts, that by regall, and highe≈øt power and commaund, Churches were builded, and dedicated in honour of that my≈øtery, longe before the Ble≈ø≈øed Virgin
‚Ä¢ egende de l'Egli≈øe de Chartets. Fran√ßois. Bellfore≈øt Co≈ømograph. l. 2. p. ‚Ä¢ 03. & in Indice. D. Druides. Mary was borne. It is related by the auncient Annals, and Regi≈øter of the mo≈øt auncient Church of the city of Charters in France, Francis Bellefore≈øt, and other hi≈øtorians, in this manner: Druides, ils croyoient qu‚ñ™il deuoit naistre vne Vierge en terre, laquelle enfanteroit le ≈øalut des hommes: The Druides did beleeue that a Virgin should be borne on earth, which should bringe forth, the ≈øaluation of
men. This cau≈øed Pri≈øcus Prince of Charters, to make an Image of a Virgin, Franc. Bellefor. Co≈ømograph. l. 1. col. 110. Hector Boeth. hi≈øt. l. 2. f. 22. 23. Ex Veremund. Campobel. & Cornel. Hybernic. holding an Infant in her Armes, which he placed among the ≈øtatues of the Gods of the Gentiles. To which he offered ≈øacrifice. Which gaue occa≈øion to the re≈øt of the contrie to doe the like, and gaue Reuenewes to the temple ≈øacred to this Virgin, and offerings before she was borne. And this opinion continued there with them, vntill after the death, re≈øurrection, and A≈øcen≈øion of Chri≈øt, the ≈øonne of God. And when S. Sauinian, and Potentian were ≈øent into tho≈øe parts, by S. Peter, they found the people about Charters, Orleans, and tho≈øe places, honouring the memory of the Virgin, which should bringe forth the ≈øonne of God, and in honour of her made a temple many ages: plu≈øieurs ≈øiecles, before Christ was incarnate, And ≈øo founde no difficulty to bring them to the faith of Chri≈øt, and dedicated this Temple, to our ladie: as al≈øo S. Aduentine a di≈øciple al≈øo of S. Peter the fir≈øt Bishop of Charters did the like. And the constancie of the≈øe there conuerted: was ≈øo greate, That when Quirinus Procon≈øul of France per≈øecuted the Christians there, he ca≈øt many of the faithfull Chri≈øtians into a well within or vnder the ≈øame Church, which is called the pit of valiant Saints.

3. The like we mu≈øt needs coÃÑclude of the Druids of this kingdome, who in re≈øpect of tho≈øe in France were Ma≈øters and Superiours, and the Religion of tho≈øe there deriued from them of Britaine; who≈øe cheife Seate being in the I≈øle of Man, had ≈øo auncient a re≈øidence there, that it was giuen them either by King Io≈øinas, or his ≈øonne and immediate Succe≈ø≈øour Finnanus, an hundred yeares before Chri≈øt was borne. And ≈øo greate knowledge of the true God and worshippe of him was in this Kingdome at that time, that King Io≈øinas ouerthrew Idolatry, and by publike decree commaunded the onely true God of heauen to be worshipped. Viuentis Dei coeli cultuÃÑ authoritate in≈øtituit. And although his ≈øonne King Finnanus did permit, or allowe idolatrie after, Deorum ≈øimulachra re≈øtituit omnibus veneranda: yet he did not forbidd, but permitted and ≈øuffered all that would to worshippe the true God onely, as his father Io≈øinas had ordained. Hand tamen viuentis Dei caeli cultum patris authoritate in≈øtitutum, abolendum decreuit, cuique faciens pote≈øtatem, Deo quem elegerit, libandi.

4. The Scottish hi≈øtories a≈øcribe this reformation to two learned men, whome they take to haue beene Prei≈øts of Spaine, driuen by tempe≈øt in ≈øayleing vpon this coa≈øt. And we finde that in the time of King Salomon Spaine being tributary to him, many true beleeuers, and expecting the coming of the Me≈ø≈øias, were in the Kingdome of Spaine, and among the≈øe his noble Ald. Minut. l. de In≈øcripi. vrb. Hi≈øpan. 3. Reg. c. 5. ≈øeruant Adoniram, very honorably mentioned in holy Scripture in the third booke of Kings, ≈øent for that tribute died and was buried there with this in≈øcription Hebrwe: This is the graue of Adoniram Seruant of King Salomon, which came hither to exact tribute, and died here. Hoc est ≈øepulchrum Adoniram, Serui Regis Salomonis, qui huc venit, vt exigeret tributum, & mortuus e≈øt. Aldus Manutius an eye witne≈ø≈øe, thus te≈øtifieth. And that the body was pre≈øerued with Bal≈øamum. And we reade that ≈øome of them expre≈ø≈øely beleeued in Chri≈øt to come, and prophe≈øied of him longe before he was incarnate. For we find that in the yeare 1230. a Iew at Tolletum in Spayne digginge in the grounde, found a Zi≈øtus Senen. Bibliothec. in Chri≈øto. ≈øtone in which there was a mo≈øt old booke, in which amoÃÑg other things, this was written: in the third world, or third age of the world, the soÃÑne of God shall be borne of the Virgin Mary, and shall ≈øuffer for the ≈øaluation of men, and that this booke should be fouÃÑd at that time, to wit in the time of Feranda the virgin Ca≈øtile and pre≈øently
the Iew with his whole family was baptized. In tertio mundo filius Dei na≈øcetur de Virgine Maria, & pro ≈øalute hominum patictur.

5. Neither did this knowledge of the true God by the Scots take the fir≈øt beginning, at that time, of King Io≈øinas, but carrieth as great antiquitie with them as that nation doth, If we may beleeue Their be≈øt Hi≈øtorians, which Hect. Boeth. l. 1. Scot. hi≈øt. fol. 1. 2. Rich. Stanny≈ø. hur≈øt. in hi≈øt. Hibern. holinsh. hi≈øt. of Scotl. Buchan. Rer. Scot. l. 2. Io. Harding. Chronicle c. 50. f. 42. Et Melkinus vel Meto. apud eundem ≈øupr. deduce their name and Originall from Scota a daughter to King Pharao of Egypt, that per≈øecuted the I≈øraelites in the time of Moy≈øes: for she being married to Gathelus and Driuen with her husband, and company out of Egypt, by the greate punishments God then impo≈øed vpon that nation, they were ≈øo fully per≈øuaded of the maie≈øty of the true God of I≈ørael, and the truth of the preaching of Moy≈øes, that for a memory, & holy relike of him, they brought with them (as both continued tradition, and diuers hi≈øtorians, verie auncient te≈øtifie) the ≈øtone whereon Mo≈øes preached very miraculous, one writeth thus:

lg.l: Which ≈øtone was holy as ≈øome men then did teach,
And did miracles, ≈øo was the common speach:
In honour it was had, both of great and ≈ømall,
And holden for a relike mo≈øt ≈øpeciall.
This ≈øtone was called the Regall of Scotland,
On which the Scottish Kings were ≈øet
At their coronoment, as I can vnder≈øtand
For holine≈ø≈øe of it, ≈øo did they of debt
All their Kings vpon this ≈øtone was ≈øet,
Vnto the time of King Edward with long shanks,
Brought it away againe the Scots vnthanks
At We≈øtmona≈øtery it offered to Saint Edward.

div.p: Which is confirmed by the Scottish hi≈øtories teaching how they brought this Hector Boeth. Scotor. hi≈øt. l. 1. fol. 2. & l. 13. fol. 309. ≈øtone out of Egypt to Portugall, from thence to Ireland, and then into Scotland, where it remained vntill King Robert his time, their King being crowned ≈øitting vpon it, vntill King Edward the third of England brought it with many others cheife≈øt Iuells into England, and they ≈øay it was a propheticall ≈øtone to, that where≈øoeuer it was found, it forshewed the Scots should reigne there, and thereupon had of old this in≈øcription.

q.l: Ni fallat fatum, Scoti quocunque locatum
Inuenient lapidem, regnare tenentur ibidem.

div.p: Which is now fulfilled in King Iames, reigning here, as it was by the Scottish long ≈øince, in Portugall, Ireland, and Scotland, in all which places they ≈øay the Scots haue reigned.

6. So we ≈øee that the inhabitants of this kingdome from the beginning in many per≈øons had knowledge of the true God, and foreknowledge of Chri≈øt, and not the Scots onely but Britans al≈øo; for what was the opinion and fore≈øight of the Druides concerning the true God and Me≈ø≈øias to be borne of a Virgin, mu≈øt needs be the doctrine and religion a≈øwell of Britans as Scots, the ≈øame Druides being teache ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , Ma≈øters, and Rulers to both tho≈øe peoples in religious affaires. Neither did this their beleife of the true God, and Chri≈øt to come, faint, or diminish in the inhabitants of this Iland, after the death of King Io≈øinas, who commaunded, and Fynnanus that allowed and permitted the worshippe of the true God, no King in this Iland for any thing we finde in hi≈øtories, British or Scottish, euer forbidding, but at the lea≈øt con≈øequently permitting what was commaunded or allowed before in ≈øuch things. But the
