nearer the time of the natiuity of Chri≈øt approched, the ≈øignes and motiues, to embrace it, rather encrea≈øed, then diminished, vntill this nation actually, and generally receaued the true faith, after the A≈øcen≈øion of Chri≈øt, with the fir≈øt conuerted Gentiles, as will be manife≈øt in this hi≈øtory. And here I end the time Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 15. Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. Florent. Wigor. an. 16. Hector Boeth. in Metel. hi≈øt. Scot. & alij. of Augu≈øtus the Emperour, Kymbeline continuing ≈øtill King in Britaine, and Metellanus among the Scots, as they write in the 15. or 16. yeare of Chri≈øts Natiuity.

div.head: THE IV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: Of THE TIME OF THE EMPEROVR Tyberius.

div.p: 1. IN the dayes of Tyberius, the next ≈øucceeding Emperour. The true knowledge of Chri≈øt was more clearely manife≈øted vnto the world, and among others, to ≈øome Britans of this nation, e≈øpecially ≈øuch as then liued in Rome. For as in the time of this Emperour our Sauiour began, and ended his preaching, and ≈øuffered his pa≈ø≈øion, for our Redemption: So the≈øe things in ≈øuch order as they were accomplished, in the land of Iury, they were pre≈øently and truely delated and ≈øent to the Emperour at Rome, and others there, as many Prote≈øtant both of England, and other nations, with other Antiquities agree. They of Prote≈øt. praef. in Mat. We≈øt. Bal. centur. 3. in Ranulph. Hygeden. & Matth. Flori. Matth. We≈øtm. an. D. 37. Ranul. Hygeden. in Polych. l. 4. c. 4. Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. in Tyberio. Metho. hi≈øt. Et apud Marian. ≈øupr. England much recommend vnto vs Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, and Ranulphus Higeden, e≈øpecially as they haue publication and allowance by them. Yet the≈øe Authours both in their printed and manu≈øcript hi≈øtories con≈øent in this, with others, that Tyberius was truely informed at Rome of the miraculous life, and preaching of Chri≈øt, long before his Pa≈ø≈øion. And being afflicted with a lepro≈øie was ≈øo confident in the heauenly power of Chri≈øt, e≈øteeming him then at the lea≈øt for a great Prophet, Saint, and worker of miracles, that he ≈øent with greate ≈øolemnity Volu≈øianus to Hieru≈øalem to entreate Chri≈øt Ie≈øus to come with him to Rome to cure him, of his incurable malady. But the Iewes had cau≈øed Pilate to put him to death before the Amba≈ø≈øadour came thither.

2. The Magdeburgian Prote≈øtants with others, haue published to the world an Epi≈øtle of Lentulus, out of the Annals of the Roman Senators, to this Magdebur. cont. 1. l. 1. cap. 10. col. 354. epi≈øt. Lentul ‚Ä¢ ad Tyber. Imp. Emperour Tyberius before the death of Chri≈øt, thus beginning: apparuit his temporibus, & adhue e≈øt, homo magnae virtutis nominatus Chri≈øtus Ie≈øus, qui dicitur √† gentibus Propheta, quem eius di≈øcipuli vocant filium Dei, ≈øu≈øcitans mortuos, & ≈øanans omnes languores: There appeared in the≈øe times, and ≈øtill is, a man of greate vertue, named Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, who is called of the gentiles a Prophet, whom his di≈øciples call the ≈øonne of God, ray≈øing the deade, and curing all di≈øea≈øes. And pre≈øently vpon Ege≈øippus Anaceph. de morte Chri≈øti. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 33. Florent. Wigor. an. 38. Tertull. Apolon. c. 5. & 21. Eu≈øt. hi≈øt. l. 1. cap. 24. Oro≈ø. l. 7. c. 4. the death of Chri≈øt, as it is proued, both by our owne, and forreine Antiquaries, auncient and later, Greekes, Latines, Catholiks and Prote≈øtants, Pontius Pilate wrote vnto Tiberius the Emperour at Rome, of the Pa≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt in this manner. De Pa≈øsione Dominica Pilatus Tyberio Cae≈øari ≈øcrip≈øit in hunc modum. Nuper accidit, quod & ip≈øe probaui, Iudaeos per inuidiam ≈øe ≈øuo≈øque po≈øteros crudeli damnatione peremi≈ø≈øe. Nam cum promi≈ø≈øum haberent patres eorum, qu√≤d Deus illis mitteret de caelo ≈øanctum ≈øuum, qui eorum merito Rex diceretur, & hunc ≈øe promi≈øerit,
per virgineÃÑ ad terram mi≈ø≈øuruÃÑ; I≈øte me prae≈øide, HebraeoruÃÑ Deus cum veni≈ø≈øet, & vidi≈ø≈øent euÃÑ caecos illumina≈ø≈øe, lepro≈øos muÃÑda≈ø≈øe, paraliticos cura≈ø≈øe, daemones ab hominibus fuga≈ø≈øe, mortuos ≈øu≈øcita≈ø≈øe, ventis impera≈ø≈øe, ≈øuper mare ≈øiccis pedib ‚Ä¢ s ambula≈ø≈øe, & multa alia mirabilia feci≈ø≈øe, cum omnis populus IudaeoruÃÑ hunc Dei filiuÃÑ dicerent, inuidiaÃÑ contra eum pa≈øsi ≈øunt Principes SacerdotuÃÑ, mihi
que traedideraÃÑt, & alia pro alijs mentientes, dixerunt illuÃÑ Magum e≈ø≈øe, & contra legem eorum agere. Ego autem credidi ita e≈ø≈øe, & flagellatuÃÑ tradidi arbitrio eoruÃÑ. At illi crucifixeruÃÑt eum, & ≈øepulto ei cu≈øtodes adhibueuÃÑrt. Ille vero militibus meis cu≈øtodientibus euÃÑ die tertia re≈øurrexit. Sed intantum exar≈øit nequitia eoruÃÑ, vt dareÃÑt eis pecuniam, dicentes: dicite, quia di≈øcipuli eius corpus ip≈øius rapuerunt, veruntamen milites cum accepi≈ø≈øent pecuniam, quod factum fuerat, tacere non potuerunt, nam & illum re≈øurrexi≈ø≈øe te≈øtati ≈øunt, & √† Iudaeis ≈øe pecuniam accepi≈ø≈øe, & ideo ≈øugge≈øsi hoc, ne quis aliter referens, mentiatur, & exi≈øtimet credendum mendacijs Iudaeorum: Pilate wrote vnto Tyberius Cae≈øar of our Lords Pa≈øsion in this manner. It lately chaunged, which I haue made proofe of. That the Iewes through Enuey, haue de≈øtroied them≈øelues, and their posterity with cruell damnation. For when their Fathers had a promi≈øe, that God would ≈øend vnto them his holy one from heauen, who worthely should be called their King, and promi≈øed him to be borne of a Virgin to the earth. This God of the Hebrewes when he came, I being pre≈øident, when men bad ≈øeene him to cau≈øe blinde men to ≈øee, to haue clean≈øed the Lepors, cured the di≈øea≈øed of pal≈øeis, to haue driuen deuils from men, to haue rai≈øed the dead, commaunded the winds, to haue walked vpon the ≈øea, with his feete, and to haue done many other meruailous things, when all the people of the Iewes ≈øaid he was the ≈øonne of God. The principall of the Iewes were malitions again≈øt him, & deliuered him vnto me & deui≈øing many lies, ≈øaid he was a MagicieÃÑ, and did again≈øt their lawe. And I beleeu ‚Ä¢ d it was ≈øo, & hauing whipped him, deliuered him to their will. But they crucified him, and being buried they appointed keepers vnto him. But he aro≈øe againe the third day, my ≈øouldiers keeping him. But their iniquitie ≈øo flamed out, that they gaue money vnto theÃÑ, ≈øaying: ≈øay you, that his di≈øciples t ‚Ä¢ oke him away. But the ≈øouldiers wheÃÑ they had receaued the money, could not conceale that which was done: for they both witne≈ø≈øed; that he aro≈øe againe, and that they had receaued money froÃÑ the Iewes. And therefore, I haue ≈øugge≈øted this, least any man relating it otherwi≈øe should make a lie, and thinke we chould giue credit to the lies of the Iewes. Hitherto the very words of the Bal. in Flor. wig. & Matth. Floril. Magdeburg. ceÃÑt. 1. l. 1. c. 10. col. 354 Tertull Apolog. aduer≈ø. gentes. Naucl. in Chron. volum. 2. gener. 2. p. 512. &c. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gl. Prote≈øt. in Matth. We≈øtm. an. Do. 37. And Ranulp. Hyged. Polycronic. l. 4 epi≈øtle of Pontius Pilate him≈øelfe to the then Emperour, not onely allowed by our English Prote≈øtants and other our Authours, the greate≈øt Chronographers of their time, by their Iudgment, but word for word ≈øo iu≈øtified by the german Prote≈øtents, by Tertullian, and almo≈øt all auncient writers, and others treating of that Age approuing it.

3. And Tyberius the Emperour hauing ≈øent Volu≈øianus (as before) to inuite chri≈øt to come vnto him to heale his lepro≈øie. Chri≈øt being put to death before Volu≈øianus his coming thither, he brought froÃÑ theÃÑce with him, as our Prote≈øtaÃÑts Authours of EnglaÃÑd are witnes, that miraculous image of chri≈øt which he gaue to S. Veronica in an haÃÑd kerchour, wherwith he wiped his face, going to his Pa≈ø≈øioÃÑ, & with greate reuereÃÑce pre≈øented it, to this Emperour, at Rome, & he as reuerently receaued it: for ≈øay thes Authors: Cae≈øar pannts ≈øericis viam sterni fecit, & imaginem ≈øibi prae≈øentari praecepit. Qui mox vt eam fuit int ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tus, pri≈øtinam a≈ø≈øe cutus est ≈øanitatem. Et haec imago, v≈øque hodie Romae in Eccle≈øia Apo≈øtolorum, Principis, populo demonstratur, quae & √† portatrice, √† quibu≈ødam. Veronica appellatur Cae≈øar cau≈øed the wa ‚Ä¢ to be ≈øpred with clothes of ≈øilke, and commaunded the image to be pre≈øented vnto him. Who pre≈øently as he had beholded it, obtained his former health. And this image euen to this day, is shewed to the people in the Church of th ‚Ä¢
Prince of the Apo≈øtles at Rome, and is called by the name of her that carried it Veronica. And although Pilate, as before, had ≈øo excu≈øed him≈øelfe, and Acknowledged Magdeb. cent. 1. lib. 2. c. 3. Nicep. l. 2. c. 10. fore to. 1. in Tiberius. Chri≈øt for the Me≈ø≈øias, vnto this Emperour: yet ≈øay the German Prote≈øtants, Narrat Nicephorus Pilatum ideo maximis Romae affectum e≈ø≈øe contumelijs, qu√≤d Maria Magdalena Romam adierit & Saluatoris res ibi retulerit: Nicephorus maketh narration that Pilate ≈øuffered mo≈øt greate reproches at Rome, becau≈øe Marie Magdelen went to Rome, and there related the things of our Sauiour: in Tyberius time. Whereby Tyberius was ≈øo moued and conuinced for the acknowledging Matth. We≈øtm. And Ran. Higed. ≈øupr. Tertull. in Apolog. Gyld. l. de conque≈øt. & excid. Britan. Freculph. l. exouien. to. 2. chron. l. 1. c. 9. of the truth of Chri≈øts doctrine; That the≈øe English Authours thus confe≈ø≈øe with S. Gildas, Tertullian, and many others: Tunc Cae≈øar, cum ≈øuffragio magni fauoris retulit Epi≈øtolam ad Senatum, po≈øtulans vt Chri≈øtus Deus haberetur. Sed Senatus con≈øecrationem Chri≈øti recu≈øauit, indignatione commotus, quod non ≈øecundum morem prius epi≈øtola ≈øibi delata fui≈ø≈øet: Cae≈øar with his voyce of greate fauour related the epi≈øtle of Pilate to the Senate, reque≈øting that Chri≈øt should be accompted God. But the Senate refu≈øed the con≈øecration of Chri≈øt, moued with indignation, becau≈øe the epi≈øtle was not fir≈øt deliuered to them as the cu≈øtome was.

4. S. Chri≈øo≈øtome in diuers places relateth this hi≈øtory, and proueth that both Pilate vnder whom Chri≈øt was put to death, Tiberius the Emperour, & the whole Senate at Rome vpon their certaine knowledge there, of his wonderfull life and miracles, were conuinced in iudgment that Chri≈øt was God, And the Senate onely, and vpon meere worldly re≈øpects, re≈øi≈øted again≈øt it. Quum igitur facta Chri≈øti renuntiata e≈ø≈øent per nuntios, rogauit prouinciae prae≈øes, S. Io. Chri≈øo≈øt. Hom. 66. ad popul. Antioch. & hom. 28. in c. 12. Epi≈øt. 2. ad Cor. num illis videretur, ip≈øum ≈øuis ≈øuffragijs creare Deum. Hic enim hanc habebat pote≈øtatem, Deos creandi & decernendi, cum igitur ei omnia Chri≈øti opera renuntiata fui≈ø≈øent, mi≈øit gentis princeps interrogatum, an eis videretur & ip≈øe Deus decernendus. Illi vero non annuerunt, indignantes & aegre ferentes, qu√≤d ante decretum & ≈øententiam ≈øuam, effulgens Crucifixi virtus omnem terrarum orbem in ≈øui traxi≈ø≈øet venerationem. Hoc autem & ip≈øis nolentibus di≈øpen≈øatum e≈øt, ne mortali decreto, Chri≈øti praedicaretur diuinitas, nec vnus de multis e≈ø≈øe videretur, qui ab eis fuerant In≈øtituti: When all the Acts and miracles of Chri≈øt were related by the Me≈ø≈øengers of the Pre≈øident to the Senate at Rome, the Pre≈øident of the prouince (Pontius Pilate) demaunded of the Senate, whether they would declare him to be God, for the Senate had this power, of making or decreeing Gods. Therefore when all the workes of Chri≈øt were brought vnto him, The Prince of the nation did ≈øend to demaund, whether it was thought plea≈øing to them, to haue him declared for God. But they did not con≈øent vnto it, being angry, and taking it ill, that before their decree and ≈øentence, the refulgent power of Chri≈øt crucified, had drawne all to his worshippe. And this was dispo≈øed of again≈øt their wils, that the diuinitie of Chri≈øt should not be preached by the decree of mortall men, nor Chri≈øt should be accompted as one of tho≈øe many Gods, which were ordained by them. By which it appeareth, that the Pre≈øident did not write onely to Tyberius the Emperour of the≈øe things, but to the Senate al≈øo, ≈øending diuers me≈ø≈øengers vnto them, per nuntios, about it, and to wish them to declare him for God, which the world in greate multitudes had already acknowledged ≈øo to be. Which the Senate could not vpon ≈øo many & vnfallible te≈øtimonies and motiues deny to be true. But they were angry that he was ≈øo receaued without their allowance, an in ≈øo much as they were able, were enemies to his worship, which redounded to the true and greater honour of Chri≈øt, as the ≈øame holy father writeth, to winne the whole world to worshippe him by his owne effulgent vertue and power, not onely without their helpe, or furtheraÃÑce, but maugre & in di≈øpite of the greate≈øt humane
re≈øi≈øtance, and oppo≈øition of the Romane Senate.

5. Oro≈øius al≈øo with many others ≈øo write, that Pilate wrote both to Tyberius the Emperour, and Senate, of the miracles which Chri≈øt or his di≈øciples publikely wrought in his name, and that the people were thereby ≈øo conuinced Oro≈øius lib. 7. c. 4. that he was God, that they ≈øtriued who should ≈øoone≈øt, and mo≈øt honour him. Pilatus prae≈øes Pale≈øtinae prouinciae ad Tiberium Imperatorem, atque ad Senatum retulit, de pa≈øsione, & re≈øurrectione Chri≈øti, con≈øequentibu≈øque virtutibus, quae vel per ip≈øum palam factae fuerant, vel per di≈øcipulos ip≈øius, in nomine ei ‚Ä¢ s fiebant, & de eo quod certatim cre≈øcente plurimorum fide Deus crederetur. And as Sabelicus Antonius Sabel. l. 2. Ennead. 7. with others writeth, diuers haue deliuered, that Pilate him≈øelfe did truely repent him of deliuering Chri≈øt to the Iewes, was actually a Chri≈øtian, and obtained pardon of his ≈øinnes. Non defuerunt qui traderent Pilatum ≈øuae impietatis paenitentiam egi≈ø≈øe, merui≈ø≈øeque adeo veniam. And that in this beginning of the Freculphus Lexouien. Epi≈øc. l. 1. cap. 9. Gho≈øpell the faith of Chri≈øt might be euery where receaued, without let, or contradiction, as the auncient learned Father Freculphus writeth, God put it into the minde of Tyberius the Emperour to giue it way, and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe the per≈øecution of the Senate. Quod profecto diua prouidentia iam tunc Cae≈øaris ≈øen≈øibus inge≈øsit, vt ab≈øque vllo obstaculo in ip≈øis dumtaxat initijs Euangelij ≈øermo v≈øquequaque percurreret. And as our learned contryman S. Gildas with others witne≈ø≈øeth, S. Gildas lib. de Excid. & conqu. Brit. c. 6. threatned death to tho≈øe should accu≈øe Chri≈øtians: Tempore ≈øummo Tiberij Cae≈øaris, ab≈øque vllo impedimento Chri≈øti propagabatur religio, comminata, Senatu nolente, √† Principe morte delatoribus militum eiu≈ødem. Which is proued, and confirmed by all ≈øorts of writers. Tunc Senatus edicto constituit, Christianos ab vrbe e≈ø≈øe exterminandos. Sed Cae≈øar hoc indignatus‚ñ™ accu≈øatoribus Chri≈øtianorum mortem comminatus est: Then the Senate ordained by an edict, that Chri≈øtians Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 37. Ranulph. Higeden. in Manu≈øcript. Polichronic. l. 4. c. 4. Manu≈øcript. antiq. Gallic. in Tiberio. Fore tom. 1. Act. p. 30. Fr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lph. ≈øupra. should be driuen forth of the citie. But the Emperour being therewith offended, threatned death to the accu≈øers of Chri≈øtians. And not content with this: ex illa die (≈øay the≈øe Authors) caepit immutari laudati≈øsima Cae≈øaris prius modestia, in poenam contradictoris Senatus. Nam adeo crudeliter de≈øaeuit in Romanos, quod vix aliquem eorum reliquit incolumem. Sicque contigit, vt qui Chri≈øto spreuerant duce ≈øaluari, √† Cae≈øare proprio punirentur; froÃÑ that day (of this edict of the Senate again≈øt Chri≈øtians in Rome) the former mo≈øt commended modestie of Cae≈øar began to be chaunged, into the punishment of the contradicting Senat, for he was ≈øo cruell again≈øt the Romans that he ≈øcarcely left any of thom ≈øafe. And ≈øo it came to pa≈ø≈øe, that they which had de≈øpi≈øed to be ≈øaued by Chri≈øt our Capitaine, were punished by their owne Emperour.

6. The onely pretence of excu≈øe of the Senate again≈øt ≈øo many miracles, and inuincible arguments, that Chri≈øt was the true Me≈ø≈øias, and ≈øonne of God Tertullian Apologet. proued to them and acknowledged by the Emperour, Romans, Britans and other inhabitants at Rome at that time, was this: vetus erat decretum (as Tertullian and other write) ne Deus ab Imperatore con≈øecraretur, ni≈øi a ≈øenatu probaretur: It was an old decree, that a God should not be con≈øecrated by the Emperour, except he were approued by the Senate. For: in Pontificum libris ita ≈øeruatum e≈øt: ≈øeperatim Naucl. in chron. volum. 2. g. ner. 2. p. 512. Libr. Pontific. Rom. Paganor. nemo ≈øit habens Deos nouos, ≈øiue aduenas: ni≈øi public√® a≈øcitos, priuatim colunto, diuos qui coele≈øtes ≈øemper habiti, colunto. Con≈øtructa √† patribus delubra habento, ≈øo it was kept in the books of the high Prei≈øts: let no man ≈øeparatly haue new or straunge Gods: except publikely allowed, let them be priuately worshipped let tho≈øe Gods which were alwayes accompted cele≈øtiall be worshipped. Let them he had for teÃÑ ples that were builded by the Fathers, where we ≈øee, that the Senate it ≈øelfe could not by their Pagan lawe, make any decree again≈øt the priuate, but onely publike
worshipping of Chri≈øt, but, priuatim colunto, that Chri≈øt might priuately be worshipped, euen then in Rome notwith≈øtanding their edict. Which yet tooke noe effect at all, The Emperour di≈øabling it. And both our Englishand Magdebur. cent. 1. l. 1. col. 354. l. 2. col. 24. Fore to. 1. Act. and Mon. in Tiberius. Nicholas Vignier Biblioteque hi≈øtoriale p. 699. other Prote≈øtant Antiquaries, and mini≈øters doe thus relate this matter: when Tyberius Ce≈øar, hauing receaued by letters from Pontius Pilate, of the doings of Chri≈øt, of his miracles, Re≈øurrection, and A≈øcen≈øion into heauen, and how he was receaued as God of many, was him≈øelfe al≈øo moued with beleife of the ≈øame, and did conferre thereof with the whole ≈øenate of Rome, to haue Chri≈øt adored as God: but they not agreeing thereunto refu≈øed him, becau≈øe that, contrary to the lawe of the Romans, he was con≈øecrated, ≈øaid they, for God, before the Senate of Rome had ≈øo decreed, and approued him. Thus the vaine Senate following rather the lawe of man then of God, and which where contented with the Emperour to reigne ouer them, were not contented with the meeke King of glory, the ≈øonne of God, to be their King. And therefore after much like ≈øorte to the Iewes, were ≈øcourged and intrapped for their vniu≈øt refu≈øing, by the ≈øame way which thy did preferre. For as they preferred the Emperour, & reiected Chri≈øt, ≈øo the iu≈øt permi≈øsion of God did ≈øtyrre vp their owne Emperours against them, in ≈øuch ≈øorte, that both the Senatours them≈øelues were almost all deuoured, and the whole citie mo≈øt horribly afflicted, for the space almo≈øt of 300. yeares together. After the Pa≈øsion and Re≈øurrection of Christ this fore≈øaied Tyberius Nero liued 6. yeares, during which time no per≈øecution was ≈øtirring in Rome again≈øt the Chri≈øtians, through the commaundement of the Emperour.

7. And to come home into our owne Contry, of Britaine, we shall not onely finde all tho≈øe preparing di≈øpo≈øitions to Chri≈øtian Religion, rememored before, in the time of Augu≈øtus, the worshipping of one onely true God, the birth of Chri≈øt, to be borne of a Virgin, with Churches founded to that honour, ≈øtill ob≈øerued by many, and tho≈øe the wi≈øe≈øt, be≈øt learned, and of mo≈øt integrity of life, and conuer≈øation: But the time of the≈øe figures being now accomplished, tho≈øe profe≈ø≈øours came nearer to Chri≈øtianity. S. Martiall writeth, S. Martial. epi≈øt. ad Burdegalen. cap. 2. that he found in his time Temples and altars dedicated by the Druides, Ignoto Deo; to the vnknowne God. Which he in the Apo≈øtles time interpreteth of Chri≈øt. There were al≈øo ≈øo many in this kingdome then liuing in perpetuall cha≈øtity, in honour of Chri≈øt a virgin, borne of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, that as Opimerus Opimerus chronograph. in Tyrio Cae≈øare. writeth, in one Iland of this our British Sea, in In≈øula in Britannico mari, belonging to this kingdome, there were ≈øeuen cheife Rulers in Religion, which he calleth by Bishops names, Anti≈øtites, that liued in perpetua virginitate; in perpetuall virginity. Likely to be the ≈øame British Iland, whereof Plutarch the Pagan Philo≈øopher, and after him Eu≈øebius, writeth, all who≈øe Plutarchus lib. de Oracul. Eu≈ø. l. ‚Ä¢ . praeparat. Euang. cap. inhabitans by the Britans were accompted holy Saints: vbi incolae omnes ≈øacro≈øancti √† Britannis habentur. We may adde vnto the≈øe, and from the ≈øame approued Authours, and others, that as in diuers other nations, and places, drowned in the damnable errours of the Pagan Idolatries, in worshipping hellish deuills, in the place of God, the≈øe wicked ≈øpirits being now conquered by the death and pa≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt, & thereby ≈øeing their kingdome to be at an end, and de≈øolate, did manife≈øtly te≈øtifie the ≈øame by their ≈øilence, and for≈øaking the Idols, and Oracles, when before they gaue an≈øweares, and were honoured, Plutarch. ≈øupr. Sueton. Et alij. as the Pagan writers them≈øelues euen in whole bookes of that ≈øubiect, are witne≈ø≈øes: ≈øo here in our British Iland, though ≈øo farre di≈øtant from the locall pa≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt, the deuils which were adored here, for Gods, both felt the power, and vertue thereof, and inforcedly confe≈ø≈øed it in as manife≈øt termes, and ≈øignes as they which were honoured nearer to Hieru≈øalem, or rather
more expre≈ø≈øely, and plainely then they did. For in other Regions not ≈øo remote from Iury, they did ordinarily onely confe≈ø≈øe it by their ≈øilence and cea≈øing to be worshipped, But in Britaine they made manife≈øt, ≈øo much as they could, that the death of Chri≈øt had not onely depriued them of that morall life and beeing, which they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the idolatrie and fal≈øe honour yeelded vnto them by their worshippers, but that the Pa≈ø≈øion and death of Chri≈øt was a kinde of death, euen to their naturall e≈ø≈øence, and liuing, making therevpon a shew to their ≈øimple worshippers, that they did altogether cea≈øe to be, and liue, valuing a dishonorable life to be wor≈øe then death.

8. Plutarch, Eu≈øebius, and others from the te≈øtimony of Dimetrius an eye witne≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe, with hundreds, or rather thou≈øands of Britans here, with him, ≈øeing, ob≈øeruing and witne≈ø≈øing the ≈øame matter, thus relate this hi≈øtory, in the name, per≈øon, and words, of the ≈øame Dimetrius, a gretian, trauayling, and pre≈øent here in Britaine, at that time, in the≈øe termes: nauigaui ip≈øe auxilio Plutarch. lib. de Oraculis. Eu≈øeb. l. 5. praeparat. Euan. c. 9. Regis, videndi gratia, ad proximam Britanniae In≈øulam. Cumque ibi e≈ø≈øem magna tempestas in aere commota, nimbis & fulminibus omnes exterruit. Quam rem accidi≈ø≈øe In≈øulares dicebant, quia ex daemonibus aliquis deficeret. Sicut enim lucerna, dum ardeat, ‚Ä¢ emini noceat, extincta vero multis: ≈øic magnas animas aiebant, propitias e≈ø≈øe, dum viuant: dum ver√≤ extinguantur, aut corrumpantur, aut cum nimbis & grandine, vt mod√≤, pestifero cuncta replent veneno: I ≈øayled to the next Iland to Britaine, and when I was there, a greate tempe≈øt being rai≈øed in the ayre, terrified all men with showers and lightnings, which thing the Ilanders ≈øaid did chaunce, becau≈øe one of the deuils did dye. For as a candell ≈øo longe as it burneth, hurteth no man, but being extinguished offendeth many: ≈øo ≈øaid they, greate ≈øoules are fauourable while they liue: but when they are extinguished, they either are corrupted, or fill all places with ≈øtormes, & hayle, as they doe now with pestiferous poy≈øon. Thus farre Plutarch: which Eu≈øebius, ‚Ä¢ iting, addeth thus immediately, from him≈øelfe: haec Plutarchus: animaduerendum Eu≈øebius l. 5. praeparat. Euang. c. 9. autem arbitror diligenter, quo tempore daemonis mortem fui≈ø≈øe dicit: quippe Tyherij tempore, Saluator & Dominus ne≈øter cum hominibus conuer≈øatus, omne daemonum genus ab humana depulit vita. Habes igitur a ≈øummis apud GeÃÑtiles viris, non alio tempore vnquam, quam temporibus Saluatoris nostri daemones extinctos fui≈ø≈øe: Thus Plutarch, and it is diligently to be con≈øidered, at what time he ≈øaith, the death of the deuill chaunged; For in the time of Tyberius, our Sauiour and Lord conuer≈øing with men, driue all kinde of deuils from mans life. Therefore you haue it from the cheifest men among the Gentils, that the deuils were not extinguished at any other time, then in the times of our Sauiour.

9. By which it is made euident in naturall knowledge, That the learned Druides and other Philo≈øophers here in Britaine, acquainted with all the≈øe things, at home, and vnder≈øtanding by frequent and certaine relation from Rome, the mentioned miracles, and proceedings concerning Chri≈øt, and his holy Religion (as the≈øe Prote≈øtants haue before declared) and knowing by naturall ≈øcience in Philo≈øophy, that deuils and intellectuall ≈øpirits are immortall, and cannot dye, which they confe≈ø≈øed after their pithagoricall manner, of the ≈øoules of men, & this imagined death of deuils neuer was heard of, vntill the time and pa≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt, They could not but conclude, that he had triumphed ouer them, and put them to ≈øilence, and was, that ≈øonne of the virgin, vnknowne God, ≈øonne of God, God of heauen and earth the liuing God, maker, and creatour of all things, whom they had ≈øo longe expected, to be reuealed to the world, and many of them, in ≈øuch manner as is related before, ≈øo longe time had worshipped, prayed and ≈øacrificed vnto. Which gaue ≈øo
open way, that before other nations ≈øo many of this I≈øland tooke ≈øuch painefull iourneys to be truely in≈øtructed herein.

div.head: THE V. CHAPTER.

argument.p: FVRTHER CONTINVING THE EXTRAordinary preaching and reuealing of Chri≈øt at Rome, by meanes whereof among many others, diuers Britans were conuerted in the dayes of Tyberius.

div.p:
1. MANY other extraordinary, powerfull, and mercifull meanes were v≈øed by Chri≈øt at this time in Rome to moue the Romans and our Britans there, and by them, tho≈øe which were here in Britaine, to beleeue in him. Sainct Clement afterward Pope, and then liuing in Rome giueth te≈øtimony, that the miracles and preaching of Chri≈øt were publikely and wonderfully proued there in this time of Tyberius, and ≈øo inuincibly, that diuers meetings and a≈ø≈øemblies were there held about the≈øe affaires, and many went from thence into Iury to S. Peter, and the Apo≈øtles to be in≈øtructed in this truth, among whom both he him≈øelfe, and his vncle al≈øo S. Clement Romans were two, and among the≈øe there were ≈øome al≈øo of this nation of Britaine, as hereafter. Thus he writeth: fama quaedam ≈øen≈øim in Imperio Clemen. Rom. l. 1. Recognit. Metaphra≈øtes in vit. Barnabae Berg. Chron. l. 8. Gul. Ei≈øengren. c ‚Ä¢ n≈ø. 1. Magdeburg. centur. 1. l. 2. c. 2. col. 22. Tyberij Cae≈øaris, initio ex orientis partibus ≈øumpto, peruenit ad nos, & per ≈øingula conuale≈øcens, velut √† Deo bonus quidam nuntius mi≈ø≈øus, vniuer≈øum replebat orbem: nec patiebatur diuinam voluntatem ≈øilentio tegi, Diffundebatur namque per ≈øingula loca adnuntians, quod e≈ø≈øet quidam in Iudaea, qui ≈øumpto √† tempore veris exordio, regnum Dei euangelizaret Iudaeis: idque percepturos diceret eos qui mandatoruÃÑ ≈øuorum, & doctrinae in≈øtituta ≈øerua≈ø≈øent. Vt autem ≈øermo eius fide dignus ac diuinitatis plenus e≈ø≈øe crederetur, virtutes multas & ≈øigna ac prodigia mira efficere iu≈øsione ≈øola, dicebatur: Ita vt tanquam √† Deo pote≈øtatem habens, ≈øurdos faceret audire, & caecos videre, & claudos erigere: atque omnem infirmitateÃÑ cuncto≈øque daemones ex hominibus effugaret: ≈øed & oblatos ≈øibi mortuos ≈øu≈øcitaret: lepro≈øo≈øque eminus videns curaret: & nihil omnino e≈ø≈øet, quod ei impo≈øsibile videretur. Haec & horum ≈øimilia proce≈ø≈øu temporis, crebris iam rumoribus, ≈øed manife≈øtis quodammodo aduentantium ex illis partibus nuntijs, firmabantur: & ip≈øa iam per dies ≈øingulos rei veritas pate≈øcebat. Denique in vrbe per loca conuentus fieri, & de hoc ≈øermone tractari: atque in admiratione res haberi caepit. Qui≈ønam is e≈ø≈øet, qui apparuerit, vel quid nuncij √† Deo hominibus detuli≈ø≈øet: donec ≈øub eodem anno vir quidam adstaÃÑs in vrbis loco celeberrimo, proclamaret ad populum, dicens. Audite me ciues Romani, filius Dei in partibus ade≈øt Iudeae, promittens omnibus volentibus audire ≈øe, vitam aeternam: Si quis tamen ≈øecundum voluntatem eius, √† quo mi≈ø≈øus e≈øt, Dei Patris actus ≈øuos direxerit: propter quod conuertimini √† malis ad bona, & a temporalibus ad aeterna. Agno≈øcite vnum e≈ø≈øe Deum, coeli terraeque rectorem, in cuius iu≈øtis aspectibus, vos iniusti mundum eius inhabitatis. Sed ≈øi conuertimini, & ≈øecundum voluntatem eius agitis, ad futurum ≈øeculum venientes, & aeterni effecti, ineffabilibus bonis ac praemijs perfruemini. Erat autem viri≈øte qui hoc loquebatur ad populum, ex orientis partibus, natione Hebraeus, nomine Barnabas, qui ≈øe etiam vnum ex eius di≈øcipulis e≈ø≈øe diceret: mi≈ø≈øumqu ‚Ä¢
ad hoc, vt volentibus indicaret. A certaine fame by litle and litle in the Reigne of Tyberins Ce≈øar, taking originall in the parts of the ca≈øt, came to vs (≈øaith this great learned philo≈øopher, and after holy Pope of Rome) ≈øtill waxeing ≈øtronger as a good me≈ø≈øenger ≈øent from God, filled all the world: neither ≈øuffered the diuine plea≈øure to be couered: for it was diffu≈øed through all places, shewing, that there was one in Iury, who taking his beginning in the ≈øpringe time, preached the kingdome of God to the Iewes, and ≈øaid they should receaue it, who should keepe the ordinances of his commaundements and doctrine. And that his ≈øpeach might be e≈øteemed, worthie to be beleeued, and full of diuinitie, he was reported to worke many miracles, and ≈øignes, and meruailous ≈øtraungs wonders, by his onely commaundement: ≈øo that hauing power from God, hee made the deafe to heare, and blinde to ≈øee, and lame to goe vpright, & driue away all infirmitie and all deuils out of men: and but ≈øeing lepers a farre of cured them, and there was nothing at all, which might be thought vnpo≈øsible for him to doe. The≈øe things and others like vnto the≈øe, were confirmed with often relations, and in a maÃÑner manife≈øt me≈ø≈øages of men coming out of tho≈øe parts. And now the truth of the matter daily was made manife≈øt. Finally a≈ø≈øemblies were made, and held in the citie in diuers places, about this bu≈øines: and the matter began to be had in admiration. Who The coming of Chri≈øt, publikely preached in Rome before his pa≈øsion. he should be which appeared, or what me≈ø≈øage he had brought, from God, to men: vntill about that yeare a certaine man ≈øtanding by them in a mo≈øt frequented place of the citie, cried out with a lowde voyce to the people ≈øaying: O Citizens of Rome, Harken vnto me. The ≈øonne of God is in the partes of Iury, promi≈øing euerla≈øting life, to all, that will heare him, and direct their actions, according to the will of God, his Father, from whom he was ≈øent, wherefore be you conuerted from euill vnto good, and from temporall to eternall things. Acknowledge that there is one God Ruler of heauen and earth, in who≈øe iu≈øt ≈øight, you being vniu≈øt inhabite his world. But if you be conuerted, and doe according to his will, when you come to the world to be hereafter, you shall be made eternall, and shall enioy his vnspeakable good things, and rewards. This man who spake the≈øe things vnto the people came from the parts of the Ea≈øt, was by nation an Hebrewe, by name Barnabas, who ≈øaid he was one of his di≈øciples, and ≈øent to this end, to declare the≈øe things, to tho≈øe that would embrace them.

2. Hitherto this holy and learned Romane in that very time and a witne≈ø≈øe to the≈øe things, hearing and ≈øeing them performed. Whereby we learne the extraordinary loue of Chri≈øt to that city of Rome, which he had cho≈øen for the re≈øidence, and See, of his cheife Apo≈øtle S. Peter and his Succe≈ø≈øours vnto the end, That in his very life before his pa≈ø≈øion, as the words of this Sermon witne≈ø≈øe: filius Dei in partibus ade≈øt Iudeae: the ≈øonne of God is now pre≈øent in the parts of I ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y, he would ≈øend a particular notice, and warning vnto the Romans being GeÃÑtiles of his coming, which for any thing we reade in ≈øcripture or other antiquities, he did not, to any other citie or nation of them vntill diuers yeares after his Re≈øurrection and A≈øcention into heauen. And yet here this holy di≈øciple began his Sermon with the≈øe words: Audite me ciues Romani, filius Dei in partibus ade≈øt Iudeae: Harken vnto me √¥ you Citizens of Rome, the ≈øonne of God is pre≈øent (as this time of his preaching) in the parts of Iury. And Clem. Rom. l. 1. Recognit. ≈øupr. Magdeburgen≈øes 2. col. 22. pre≈øently after, he had deliuered this heauenly Amba≈ø≈øage, vnto the Romans, being by the circum≈øtances of the place onely ≈øent as Herald vnto them of Rome, he returned vnto Iury againe. Yet his shorte ≈øermon and abode there, with the other remembred motiues, wrought ≈øuch effect, that diuers Romans, Diuers Romans and Britans al≈øo then at Rome, conu ‚Ä¢ rted at this time. and others, ≈øtraungers then in Rome, went into Iury to be in≈øtructed in the certaine truth of ≈øo ioyfull things, among whom was this S. Clemen him≈øelfe, as he there relateth, and was conuerted by S. Peter. So likewi≈øe did
an other S. Clemente his vncle, fir≈øt Bishop of Treuers. So did diuers of Catalog. Epi≈øc. Treuer. in Clem. 1. Greg. Turon. n l. in glor. Martyr. cap. 12. France, among whom Gregorius Turonen≈øis placeth a noble Matrone, who going to ≈øee Chri≈øt, brought home with her part of S. Iohn Bapti≈øte his blood newly put to death. And we mu≈øt needs thinke that among the≈øe were diuers of this noble kingdome of greate Britaine, conuerted by this extraordinary calling of the Romans, at that time: for of all the people of Britaine, they which then, (before the Scots ≈øeating their ≈øelues there) inhabited that part, after named Scotland, in no wi≈øe ≈øubiect to Rome, had the lea≈øt re≈øorte thither; yet we finde in many antiquities that S. Man≈øuetus borne there, natione Scotus; by later denomination went ≈øo longe a iorney with others to be in≈øtructed by S. Peter in the dayes of Tyberius, longe before S. Peter came to make abode at Rome, and was both baptized by him, and ≈øo fully in≈øtructed Catal. Epi≈øcop. Tullen≈ø. and profiting in Chri≈øtian Religion, that he was by S. Peter made Prei≈øt, and Bishop al≈øo and ≈øent by him into the≈øe parts, before he him≈øelfe made his re≈øidence at Rome, euen in the Regine of Caius Caligula Emperour, except diuers hi≈øtorians deceaue vs.

3. Much rather, then, may we thinke, that among the other Britans, by ≈øo Gulielm. Ei≈øengrenius centen. 1. many occa≈øions at that time tran≈øported and going vnto Rome, and inhabitants there, diuers were ≈øo conuerted: among which I doubt not to marshall the noble British Chri≈øtian parents of our glorious contry woman lady Claudia called al≈øo Sabinella or Pri≈øcilla, who at this time, or ≈øoone after were there conuerted to the faith, and were entertainers of S. Peter him≈øelfe, and The British noble parents of lady conuerted, at, or about this time, with an other rea≈øon from S. Ambro≈øe of the RomaÃÑ Britans ≈øo ≈øoone conuer≈øion. S. Paul with others when they came to Rome. S. Ambro≈øe yeeldeth vnto vs an other rea≈øon, why Romans, Britans, and others which liued at Rome, did ≈øo ≈øoone, and ea≈øily embrace the Religion of Chri≈øt ≈øaith he: con≈øtat temporibus Apo≈øtolorum, Iudoeos propterea qu√≤d ≈øub regno Romano agerent, Romae habita≈ø≈øe, ex quibus hi qui crediderunt, tradiderunt Romanis, vt Chri≈øtum profitentes, legem ≈øeruarent, Romani autem audita fama virtutum Chri≈øti, faciles ad credendum fuerunt: It is euident, that in the time of the Apo≈øtles, the Iewes becau≈øe they liued vnder the regiment of the Romans, dwelt at Rome, among whom they which beleeued, deliuered Ambro≈ø. praefat. in Epi≈øt. ad Rom. vnto the Romans, that profe≈øsing Chri≈øt they should keepe the lawe, and the Romans hearing the ≈øame of the miracles of Chri≈øt, were ea≈øely induced to beleeue. By which we may informe our ≈øelues, that as the Iewes, becau≈øe they were vnder the gouernment of the Romans, many of them liued at Rome, ≈øo did many of our Britans, by the ≈øame rea≈øon: And as the Iewes which were mo≈øt backward in beleeuing in Chri≈øt, to be ≈øo foreward at Rome, that they gaue incouragement to the Romans to beleeue in him, and the Romans by the fame of Chri≈øts miracles, did ≈øo ea≈øely come to be conuerted: So the Britans which were there re≈øident being a≈øwell as the others acquainted with tho≈øe holy and inuincible true motiues of beleife in Chri≈øt, would not ≈øingulary remaine in Incredulity: e≈øpecially when they had not onely the Examples of the Iewes, and Romans to follow in admitting the religion of Chri≈øt in Rome, and warrant, and protection from the Emperour, that they might without all daunger performe it: But were a≈ø≈øured there, by many and mo≈øt certaine me≈ø≈øages from Hieru≈øalem, that immediately vpon the A≈øcen≈øion of Chri≈øt, and de≈øcending of the holy gho≈øt vpon the Di≈øciples, at one Sermon of S. Peter, three thou≈øand ≈øoules were conuerted vnto Chri≈øt, of all nations vnder Actor. c. 2. heauen; Parthians, and Medes, and Elamites, and dwellers in Me≈øopotamia, and in Iudaea, and Cappadocia, in Pontus and A≈øia, Phrygia and Pamphilia in Egypt and in the parts of Libia about Circne, and ≈øtrangers of Rome, Iewes and Pro≈øelites; all
the≈øe as the Scripture recounteth then being people of all the then-knowne parts of the world, A≈øia, Afrike, and Europe, and hearing S. Peter miraculou≈øly preach in ≈øuch manner, that they all vnder≈øtood him, in their ≈øeuerall languages, were at that time conuerted.

4. So that if either ≈øo many miracles of Chri≈øt, and his holy Apo≈øtles, or examples of all the≈øe nations, ≈øo many that the holy ≈øcripture ≈øtileth them all nations vnder heauen (which no man may deny) might moue our Britans at Rome to follow them therein, they al≈øo then performed it. And this onely by that happy meanes, in that re≈øpect, that they then dwelled at Rome, where they obtained mo≈øt certaine and ≈øpeedy intelligence of the≈øe things. And among all the≈øe people of the named nations conuerted by S. Peter at that time, we finde not by any hi≈øtory or antiquity to warrant vs, that the inhabitants of this kingdome of Britany either dwelling here at home in this land, at Rome or els where in the vniuer≈øall world, had any commerce, or conuer≈øation with any of tho≈øe nations pre≈øent at that heauenly ≈øermon, or witne≈ø≈øes of the miracles of Chri≈øt or his di≈øciples to in≈øtruct them in the≈øe things, But onely with the remembred ≈øtraungers of Rome, Iewes and Pro≈øelites, which then liued there in Rome, as our Britans did. And from and by this conduct and fountaine of grace onely for the ≈øame rea≈øons did the water of life i≈ø≈øue and flow ≈øo fa≈øt and farre into this kingdome in that very time of Tyberius the Emperour, ≈øoone after the death of our Sauiour, as our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries of England thus deliuer vnto vs: There are who vpon a very good grounde from the words of Gyldas, the mo≈øt auncient of our British hi≈øterians, will haue the Theater of great Britaine pag. 202 ¬ß. 5. Gild. de conq. Britan. ≈øunne of the Gho≈øpell to haue ri≈øen in this our we≈øt, and this I≈øland of Britaine to haue enioyed the very morning of his a≈øcent, the brightne≈ø≈øe thereof peirring through the mi≈øtie clowdes of errour, and shining here in Britaine euen in the dayes of Tyberius, towards who≈øe end, Chri≈øt ≈øuffered his death, and by who≈øe Indulgence towards Chri≈øtians, their profe≈øsion was propagated farre and neare. Which A≈ø≈øertion the ≈øaid Gyldas doth not deliuer coldely, or doubtingly, but with greate confidence, and relying vpon good grounds, as it appeareth when he ≈øaith ≈øcimus, we know for certaintie, that this was in the later times of Tyberius, which was immediatly after our ble≈ø≈øed Samours Pa≈øsion.

5. An other English Prote≈øtant Antiquary writeth: It may appeare that the Chri≈øtian Religion was planted here (in Britaine) in this land, shortly after Christs Holinshed hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 5. Franc. Ma≈øon ep. dedicat. Franc. Ma≈øon Con≈øecrat. lib. 2. cap. 3. pag. 51. time. An other directed as he ≈øaith, by the pre≈øent Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury, is ≈øo earne≈øt vpon the words of Gildas, or malice to Rome, that thus he ≈øpeaketh: Tyberius died in the yeare of Chri≈øt 39. according to Baronius. Where vpon it followeth, that Britaine receaued the ghospell, fiue yeares at lea≈øt before either Paul or Peter came to Rome. By which it is euident by the≈øe Prote≈øtant writers of England, that they are confident, that diuers of this nation receaued English Prot ‚Ä¢ ≈øtaÃÑts from S. Gildas and otherwi≈øe proue, that Britaine rec ‚Ä¢ aued the faith of Chri≈øt ‚Ä¢ n Tyb ‚Ä¢ rius his time and by meanes of Rome. the faith of Chri≈øt, ≈øoone after his A≈øcen≈øion in the time of Tyberius; which could probably be effected, by no other way, or mediation, but by Rome, where many Britans then liued and inhabited, and (as before) where and whence onely they could take notice, and knowledge of ≈øuch things. Which may ≈øufficiently be coÃÑuinced euen out of that place of S. Gildas, wherevpon the≈øe English Prote≈øtants doe ground them≈øelues, and as they are both published, and vrged by them, being the≈øe: Interea glaciali frigore rigenti In≈øulae, & velut longiori terrarum ≈øece≈ø≈øu ≈øoli vi≈øibili non proximae verus ille non de firmamento Gildas l. de conq. Britan. c. 6. ≈øolum temporali, ≈øed de ≈øumma etiam coelorum arce tempora cuncta exce
‚Ä¢ ente, vniuer≈øo orbi praefulgidum ≈øui coru≈øcum ostendens, tempore vt ≈øcimus, ≈øummo
Tyberij Cae≈øaris, quo ab≈øque vllo impedimento, eius propagabatur Religio, comminata, Senatu nolente, a principe morte, delatoribus militum ciu≈ødem, radios ≈øuos primum indulget, id e≈øt ≈øua praecepta Chri≈øtus: In the meane time he who is the true ≈øunne, not onely from the temporall firmament, but from his high tower of heauen exceeding all times, shewing his bright shinning to the whole world, in the later time of Tyberius Cae≈øar, in which without any Impediment his Religion was propagated, death being threatned by the Prince, again≈øt the Senates will, to the Accu≈øers of his Souldiers, Christ doth fir≈øt afford his beames, to wit, his precepts, to the Iland ≈øtiffe with fro≈øen colde, and by a longe ≈øeparation of the earth ≈øeperated from the vi≈øible ≈øunne. Where we ≈øee, that if our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries haue delt ≈øincerely with S. Gildas, he is both a witne≈ø≈øe, that this Iland of Britaine, which is that he there de≈øcribeth, did both take knowledge of Chri≈øt, the true heauenly ≈øunne, and benefite of his cele≈øtiall light, in the later time of Tyberius, where he ≈øuffered for redemption of the world, and that Emperour threatening death to the accu≈øers of them which should receaue him for the Me≈ø≈øias, did giue occa≈øion, that the faith of Chri≈øt was ≈øo ≈øoone preached, and embraced in this ≈øo remote, and colde a Region, then ≈øubiect to the Empire of Tyberius.

6. Therefore we cannot by this auncient Authority deui≈øe any better meanes, how the religion of Chri≈øt was then fir≈øt planted here, but as I haue proued before from Rome, the re≈øidency of that Emperour, where the≈øe my≈øteries of Chri≈øtianity were fir≈øt reuealed, authentically examined, allowed, and confirmed: where that commaunde and priuiledge of the Emperour for Chri≈øtians was decreed, and published, and where, or whence onely, the inhabitants of this nation by their dwelling and continuing there, or receauing continuall intelligence from thence, could learne, or come to the notice of the≈øe things. Neither can the Prote≈øtants of England contending thus, that there were Chri≈øtians here in this time, be of any other opinion, for they doe not, yea cannot a≈ø≈øigne any one other, but ≈øuch as were ≈øent from S. Peter, when he was come to Rome, are from him, and by his authoritie before he was ≈øeated there, that preached the faith of Chri≈øt in this I land either in that time, or aboue twenty yeares after: for they finde not any other vntill the coming of S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, who buried our Sauiour, and came not hither vntill the 63. yeare after his natiuity, and the time of Tyberius the Emperour his death 24. at the lea≈øt. Longe before which time, the Britans had both learned Prei≈øts, and al≈øo Bishops ≈øent hither, or con≈øecrated here, by the ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtle S. Peter.

7. And if S. Man≈øuetus, of whome I haue ≈øpoken before, as the Germane hi≈øtories a≈ø≈øure vs, was con≈øecrated by S. Peter, and ≈øent, or went ≈øo farre a Catal. Epi≈øcop. Gullen≈ø. in Lothoring. Arnold. Mirm. in Theatr. Conuer≈ø. Gent. Gal. E ‚Ä¢ ≈øengren. cent. 1. part. 1. di≈øt. ‚Ä¢ . fol. ‚Ä¢ 6. Pet. de Natal. l. 11. c. vlt. Franc. Bellefor. Co≈ømogr. l. 2. col. 263. Ant. Demochar. l. 2. c. 33. de Mi≈ø≈ø. contr. Caluin. Iorney to him, in the ea≈øterne contries for that holy purpo≈øe, whether he went out of this kingdome with direction, or from the city of Rome, with in≈øtruction giuen him there yet he being ≈øent and directed to goe ≈øo farre, to Peter, and con≈øecrated by him, and by him againe directed, and ≈øent an Apo≈øtolike preacher and Bishop, into the≈øe parts, we may not be ≈øo alienated from that mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtle, but to giue him this his due, to acknowledge, That he or they, who directed this our contryman, to S. Peter, aboue all others, was, or were al≈øo fir≈øt directed by the ≈øame S. Peter, in ≈øuch things. And thus hauing the cheife Apo≈øtle of Chri≈øt, & highe≈øt Ruler in ≈øpirituall things, taking notice, care, and charge of this kingdome in this his time; The Emperour our frend and fauourer, giuing all allowance, and noe prohibition to Chri≈øtianity, and by ≈øo many extraordinary motiues as are before remeÃÑbred,
≈øo greate a feruour and forwardne≈ø≈øe of the inhabitaÃÑts here to receaue the faith Our Kings of Britaine were rather freinds and furtherers then enemies to Christian Religion in this time. of Chri≈øt, there could now no impediment be found to hinder it, except in our owne Kings, which was not ≈øo; for concerning our gouernment here in Britaine, if Aruiragus was then King here, as ≈øome hi≈øtorians ≈øeeme to teach vs, he was a frend and no Enemy to Chri≈øtian religion, as we shall ≈øee hereafter: Or if Cunobile yet liued, as diuers of our Prote≈øtant writers doe ≈øeeme to thinke, vpon the authority of Dio Ca≈ø≈øius, reporting that Adminus the ≈øonne of Cunobeline being bannished out of Britaine, by his Father, was receaued Dio. l. 59. Stow. and howes hi≈øt. in Caius Caligula Theater of great Britaine l. 6 cap. 4. into protection by Caius Caligula, the fourth Emperour: yet this hindereth nothing; for all hi≈øtories, and antiquities are witne≈ø≈øes, that notwith≈øtanding the recited difference betwene the Emperour Tyberius and the Senate, about the honour of Chri≈øt, and liberty of Chri≈øtians, whether it was Cunobeline, Guiderius, or Aruiragus which then reigned here, he ≈øtood in termes of amitie, and peace with the Emperour, and re≈øi≈øted not that his edict, but rather was a fauourer, and frend vnto it. Which our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries incline vnto grounding them≈øelues vpon the authority of Cornelius Tacitus, Theater of great Britaine l. 6. c. 4. ¬ß. 4. p. 191. in this Manner: In Britaine Tyberius neither maintained garri≈øon, nor attempted alteration, and thereby as it may be thought, their owne lawes and Princes bare ≈øway among them≈øelues, how≈øoeuer the cau≈øe of Tribute was ballized, if not in Tacitus Annal. l. 2. c. 5. ≈øubiection, yet were well affected to the Romans, as appeareth by Tacitus, in the kinde intertainements, and in releeuing their shipwracked ≈øouldiers, that by Cro≈ø≈øeinge the ≈øeas, were by tempest dryuen vpon their coa≈øts, and courteou≈øly ≈øent them thence, by their petty Kings vnto Germanicus, their Generall.

8. Neither doth the British hi≈øtory gaine≈øay this opinion, although the Theater writers immediately after the la≈øt recited words, doe adde: Notwith≈øtanding Ieffory of moÃÑmouth ≈øeemeth to affirme the coÃÑtrary, that bringeth fourth the the Reigne of one Guiderius, and the valure of Aruiragus, the ≈øonnes of Cunobeline, to withstand the Romish, commaunde, and vtterly to refu≈øe the payment of the Tribute, banding both again≈øt Tiberius, as al≈øo again≈øt Caligula, and Claudius, the Emperours ≈øubceeding. Which deniall of the Tribute Guiderius or Aruiragus to either Caius Caligula, or Tyberius, is not affirmed by the writer of the Brittish hi≈øtory, which the≈øe men name Geffory of monmouth, who truely tran≈ølated Galf ‚Ä¢ id. monum. hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 4 c. 11. Ponticus Virun. Brit. hi≈øt. l. 4. it. For this Authour ≈øaith fir≈øt: po≈øt illum (Tenuantium) promotus e≈øt ad Culmen regale Kymbelinus filius ≈øuus miles ≈øtrenuus, quem Augu≈øtus Cae≈øar nutrierat. Hic in tantam amicitiam Romanorum inciderat, vt cum po≈ø≈øet tributum eorum detinere, gratis impenderet. In diebus illis natus e≈øt Dominus no≈øter Ie≈øus Chri≈øtus: After Tenantius his ≈øonne Kymbeline a valiant knight, whom Augu≈øtus Cae≈øar had brought vp was preferred to the kingdome. He loued the Romans ≈øo much, that when he might haue deteined their Tribut, he freely payed it. And in the next chapter, where he bringeth in Guiderius, and Aruiragus, cap. 12. ≈øupr. he addeth: Expletis vitae ≈øuae diebus. ce≈øsit regni gubernaculum Guiderio. CuÃÑ ergo Tributum quod appetebant Romam, ip≈øis denegaret: ≈øuperuenit Claudius, qui in Matth. We≈øtm. an. D. 44. Stowe and howes hi≈øt. in Claudius Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 3. in Theomantius c. 18. Strabo in Geograph. in Brit. Imperium ≈øubrogatus fuerat: when Kimbeline was dead, Guiderius ≈øucceeded in the Kingdome. Therefore when he denyed the Tribute, which the Romans demaunded, Claudius came hither being then Emperour, which is that, the Brittish hi≈øtory hath of this matter, and al≈øo Ponticus virunnias word by word, which was in the fourth yeare of Claudius, ≈øeuen yeares at the lea≈øt after the death of Tyberius. Therefore it is euident, by all accompts, that during the life of Tyberius, there was no breach, but a continued amity betweene him and the Britans, And ≈øo his Imperiall fauourable edict for all Chri≈øtians, was not, could
not be contradicted, but receaued, and approued in this kingdome, by the Britans here. And yet if the Kings of Britaine had denied their Tribute vnto Tyberius, this would haue proued nothing, but they were yet rather frends, then enemies, maintainers, then per≈øecutours of Chri≈øtians; which is euident in that King Aruiragus, who at ≈øuch time, as the Roman Emperour Nero was a per≈øecutour of Chri≈øtians, and Claudius before him, yet this Brittish King was ≈øo greate a frend and fauourer of the Religion of Chri≈øt, that euen by our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries them≈øelues, this nation was in their dayes, an harbour Theater of great Britainel. 6. Godwin. Conu. of Britaine. Leland. in Arth. antiq. Gla≈øcon. Capgrau. in 5. Io≈øeph. Aramat. Stowe Howes hi≈øt. in Aruiragus. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Engl. in eodem of Canelden in Belg. Hardinge Chron. in Aruiragus. Arnoldus Nurman. theatro Conuer≈ø. Gent. Gulielm. Ei≈øeng. centent. 1. Petrus de Natal. l. 11. Anton. Democh. l. 2. contra Caluin. c. 33. and receptacle, for ≈øuch Chri≈øtians, as fledde hither from their per≈øecution. And this King did not onely permit them to enioy peace, and quietne≈ø≈øe, but releiued their nece≈ø≈øities, allowing them publike profe≈ø≈øion of their holy religion, euen in Churches and oratories, priuiledged by his authority, and was ≈øo farre from being a per≈øecutour, that diuers haue written (of which hereafter) that he him≈øelfe was al≈øo a Chri≈øtian.

9. By which and other ≈øuch, or more heauenly motiues it came to pa≈ø≈øe, that I may boldly write, this natioÃÑ of Britaine had diuers Chri≈øtians euen in this time of Tiberius. Among whoÃÑ that litle te≈øtimony of ≈øo holy & auncient antiquities (which by iniury of times is left vnto vs,) will giue me warrant to write that S. MaÃÑ≈øuetus borne in this kingdome was one, & (no other natioÃÑ clayming them) not vnprobably his holy Succe≈ø≈øours, & A≈ø≈øociats S. Amon, and S. Alcha: e≈øpecially if we follow tho≈øe Authours which ≈øay, That S. Man≈øuetus was ≈øent as an Apo≈øtolike man, & A≈ø≈øociate to S. ClemeÃÑt, vncle of S. Clement the Pope, fir≈øt Bishop or Archbishop of Metz, by S. Peter the Apo≈øtle, in the time of Caius Caligula Emperour in the 40. yeare of the Natiuitie of Chri≈øt: anno & quod excurrit quadrage≈øimo, S. Petro Pontifice Maximo, Caio Caligula Imperatore. About the 40. yeare of Chri≈øt in the time of S. Peters Papacie, and Empire of Caius Caligula. Wherefore we mu≈øt needs graunt, he was a Chri≈øtian ≈øome time before, for neither Catechumens, Neophites, or newly coÃÑuerted were allowed to ≈øuch functions, And ≈øo he was a Chri≈øtiaÃÑ in the time of Tiberius, which was the ca≈øe al≈øo of S. Clement ≈øent with him, conuerted by S. Peter in that time of Tyberius, as is before remembred. And if S. Man≈øuetus borne in the furthe≈øt and more northerne, and remote parte of this Iland, and therefore termed natione Scotus, trauailed ≈øo farre, from hence as to Antioch, or tho≈øe ea≈øterne Arnoldus Mirm. & Gulielm. Ei≈øengren. ≈øupr. Franc. Bellefore≈øt Co≈ømograp. l. 2. col. 263. Cat. Ep. tull. parts, beyonde, or about Hieru≈øalem, to be then in≈øtructed, by S. Peter, before he came to Rome, or any we≈øterne nation, as the≈øe authorities haue told vs; we may not be ≈øo regardle≈ø≈øe of the honour of this kingdome; but to thinke that many of the≈øe nearer parts in Britaine, at home, and others at Rome, vndertooke either by theÃÑ≈øelues, or with this holy Saint, that happy pilgrimage, to that mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtle to be in≈øtructed in the faith. Concerning ≈øome of them which probably went out of Britaine about that time I haue ≈øpoken & among them that were then re≈øiding at Rome, and went from thence, or in this time were conuerted there, not without probable rea≈øon, I reckon the ble≈ø≈øed parents of S. Claudia, Chri≈øtians before S. Peters coming to Rome, to be re≈øident there, and his entertainers there, before Claudius the Emperour came into Britaine, to leade them, or any ≈øuch, ho≈øtages, or captiues thither, as I shall proue hereafter. And this giueth ≈øome particulars of that which diuers Gildas epi≈øt. de excid. & conq. Brit. cap. 6. Theater of great Britainel. 6. c. 9. Prote≈øtants would deduce from Gildas, in generall of this our Britaine, that it receaued praecepta Chri≈øti tempore ≈øummo Tyberij Cae≈øaris: the precepts and Religion of Chri≈øt in the later time of the Empire of Tyberius. As our Prote≈øtant antiquaries haue both published, and plainely expounded him before, in their
publike worke the Theater of greate Britaine compo≈øed by their common labours and con≈øents. Be≈øides which, an other both reputed a Bishop, and learned hi≈øtorian among them thus affirmeth, there be many te≈øtimonies to ≈øuch Godwin. Catal. in Yorke 1. Paulinus. purpo≈øe: there be manifold testimonies of very credible Authours who witne≈ø≈øe, that the faith of Chri≈øt was receaued in diuers particular places of this Iland, pre≈øently after the A≈øcen≈øion of Chri≈øt, or the lea≈øt while the Apostles yet liued. Their fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop ≈øaith: ab ip≈øis Eccle≈øiae Incunabilis, hanc In≈øulam in fide Chri≈øtiana Matth. Parker Antiquit. Brit. pag. 2. fui≈ø≈øe in≈øtructam: That this Iland was in≈øtructed in the faith of Chri≈øt euen froÃÑ the cradle, or fir≈øt infancie of the Church. And this is their commonly receaued opinion.

div.head: THE VI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THAT S. IAMES THE APOSTLE, WHO IS commonly ≈øaid to haue preached in Spaine in this time, did not preach in Ireland, as ≈øome write: yet his preaching to the Iewes in Spaine might prepare the way for the ≈øpirituall good of ≈øome in Britaine, although none of them conuerted by him.

div.p: 1. DIVERS hi≈øtorians write, That S. Iames the Apo≈øtle, ≈øonne of Zebedeus, and brother to S. Ihon the Euangeli≈øt, preached in the we≈øt part of the world, wherein Britaine is (among Co≈ømographers) accompted to be ≈øcituated, in this time of Tyberius, and ≈øo may ≈øomewhat belonge to our hi≈øtorie, e≈øpecially if we should followe ≈øome late Prote≈øtant writers, which would extend his preaching into Ireland ≈øo neare vnto vs in this time, whereof we now treate. Which if it be true, we may not pa≈ø≈øe it ouer with ≈øilence; for Irelande hauing bene the auncient contrie of the Scots, euen tho≈øe of this kingdome, Some men perhaps The Authoritie whereoÃÑ they build, which write S. Iames the Apo≈øtle preached in Irland in≈øufficient, and mi≈øtaken by them. might thinke, that S. Man≈øuetus came to the knowledge of Chri≈øt by that meanes, though I doe not finde any Prote≈øtant we haue, to write of this holy Sainct. But that which is ≈øaid before, that he was di≈øciple to S. Peter will keepe vs, from that errour. They which would bringe S. Iames into Ireland, ground vpon Vincentius. The likene≈ø≈øe of the name Hiberia cau≈øed perhaps the errour that he was in Hibernia: Ireland, for almo≈øt all hi≈øtories of the Irish and other nations are ≈øilent of that Apo≈øtles being there. I≈øidor. hi≈øpal. l. de Patrib. non. te≈øt. V ‚Ä¢ terbien. Chro. part. 14. Petr. de Natal. l. 6. c. 133. Antonin. part. 1. titul. 6. cap. 7. Loys de Mayerne Turquet hi≈øtoire generale d'E≈øpane. Philip. Bergone. Holin ‚Ä¢ h. or Stanish. hi≈øtor. de≈øcript. of Ireland.

2. Yet for his preaching in Spayne, Hiberia, we haue many Authorities, be≈øide the hi≈øtories and tradition of the Spanyards. When otherwi≈øe there is no ≈øuch te≈øtimony for his being in Ireland, & the Irish them≈øelues do deriue their fir≈øt preaching, or teaching the faith of Chri≈øt among them, from ≈øuch as came out of this Britaine thither, or from S. Patrik ≈øent thither by S. Cele≈øtine Pope of Rome, about the yeare 430. And is named the Irish mens Apo≈øtle. And although Holinshed, or Stanishur≈øt the writer of that part of the Irish hi≈øtory doth ≈øay:
‚Ä¢ e finde that immediatly after Chri≈øts time, S. Iames the Apo≈øtle and others tr ‚Ä¢ uayling into the≈øe we≈øt parts, did fir≈øt in≈øtruct the Irish people & teach them the glad tydeings of the ghospell, ≈øo that diuers amongst them euen the ‚Ä¢ were Chri≈øtened and beleeued: Yet he bringeth no other warrant for that a≈ø≈øertion
of his, not ≈øo much as naming Vincentius but teacheth after how it was conuerted by S. Palladius and Patricius, and others out of this Britaine, neither is any one Chri≈øtian of that nation to be named, before that time: Which will hardly be found to be true of any nation, that receaued the faith ≈øo longe before, as Vincentius ≈øuppo≈øeth, if he meaneth Ireland: which he doth not, but Vinc ‚Ä¢ ntius doth not affirme that S. Iames preached in Ireland but in Hiberia, Spayne. onely Spaine, as is euident in his ninth, and ≈øeuenth chapter where entreating of this S. Iames, he ≈øaith, as the auncient French (in which he wrote) manu≈øcript, which I follow doth giue me warrant that S. Iames the Apo≈øtle did not preach in Hibernia, Ireland, but onely in Hiberia, Spaine: his words tran≈ølated be the≈øe: when the Apo≈øtles were ≈øeperated into diuers parts, and contries, Vincent. ≈øpeculhi≈øtorial. l. 9. c. 7. Manu≈øc. GallicuÃÑ antiq. Guliel. Ei≈øengren. centin. 1. fol. 163. Cali≈øt. 2 in vit. S. Iacobi. Breuiar. Rom. in fe≈øt. eius 25. Iul. Antonin. part. 1. tit. 6. c. 7. Mantuan. in fa≈øt. Petr. de Natal. lib. 6. c. 133. Viterbien. Chron. part. 14. I≈øid. in Iacob. Holinshed de≈øcription of Ireland. p. 52. Loys de Mayerne hi≈øt. generale d'E≈øp. l. 4. p. 179. Iames the Apo≈øtle of God, preac ‚Ä¢ ed the worde, of God es partes de Hiberie, in the parts of Hiberia, Spaine, where he cho≈øe ≈øeuen di≈øciples: And then immediatly follow the names of his Spanish di≈øciples, as they are al≈øo related by the Spanish hi≈øtorians. And this is all he writeth of this matter and the preaching of that holy Apo≈øtle. Therefore it cannot be imagined by any thing written by Vincentius, except my Manu≈øcript deceaueth me, that he euer preached in Ireland. And this English Prote≈øtant hi≈øtorian, who hath ≈øo relied vpon Vincentius, proueth as much, from the Irish Antiquities, and Antiquaries them≈øelues in the≈øe words: The Irish writers them≈øelues affirme, that their contry, was rather ≈øtill e≈øteemed as one of the vnchri≈øtened Ilands till about the yeare foure hundred twenty & ≈øixe, while≈øt Cele≈øtine the fir≈øt of that name gouerned the See of Rome, Who ≈øent S. Patrike thither. And his preaching in Spaine it ≈øelfe is not ≈øo certaine by the writers of the Spanish hi≈øtory. Among whom Louys de Mayerne in his hi≈øtorie generale d'E≈øpagne writing from the Spanyards them≈øelues, affirmeth, that the doctrine of Chri≈øt was knowne in the time of Tyberius, but ob≈øcure, who was their Apo≈øtle. And after proueth how the Spaniards which ≈øay, S. Iames was there, ≈øay al≈øo: that he conuerted but nine per≈øons, and returned into Iury, and liued all his life after in Hieru≈øalem, and the places adioyning. And ≈øo no time is left for his Irish Iorney, ≈øuppo≈øed as before, being beheaded by Herode in the third yeare of Claudius the Emperour. And S. I≈øidor him≈øelfe a Spaniard (if Authour I≈øidor. Hi≈øpal. l. de vit. & mort. Sanctorum c. 73. Philipp. Bergom. ad An. 43. Breu. Rom. in fe≈øt. S. Iacobi. 25. Iulij. of that booke of the life & death of Saints) carrieth him no further theÃÑ Spaine: ≈øo Philippus Bergomen≈øis with others, and the whole Latine Church in the publike office of his fe≈øtiuitie, Is ≈øo farre from allowing any further limits to his preaching then Spaine, in the≈øe we≈øterne parts, that it doth not warrant vnto vs, that he was in Spaine, but onely ≈øaith, that the Tradition of the contrie of Spaine is ≈øo. Iacobus po≈øt Ie≈øu Chri≈øti A≈øcen≈øum in coelum, in Iudaea & Samarta praedicans, plurimos ad Chri≈øti fidem perduxit. Mox Hi≈øpaniam adij≈ø≈øe & Magdeburgen. Cen ‚Ä¢ ur. 1. l. 2. c. 2. col. 22. 23. Francis Burgoin. hi≈øt. l. 2. c. 1. ibi aliquot ad fidem conuerti≈ø≈øe illius prouinciae traditio e≈øt.

3. And that Hiberia, Spaine, should be gathered onely from Vincentius, and not Hibernia, Ireland, it is made cleare, by the like mi≈øtaking of the Magedurgian Prote≈øtants, who ≈øetting downe, who they thinke preached in this part of the world, in bringing Vincentius to ≈øay S. Iames preached in Ireland quite thru≈øt him out of Spaine it ≈øelfe, leauing it to S. Paule, and yet that doubt fully. In Hispaniam Paulus ≈øe permittit Iturum e≈ø≈øe, Rom. 15. verum an eo peruene
‚Ä¢ t, incertum e≈øt. In Hibernia Iacobum vn√† cum alijs quibu≈ødam docui≈ø≈øe, Vincentius ≈øcribit lib. 8. c. 7. Paul promi≈øeth that he would goe into Spaine in his epi≈øtle to the Romans. But whether he came thither or no, it is vncertaine, Vincentius writeth that Iames with ≈øome others taught in Ireland. So that the errour of the≈øe men in this matter, doth ≈øo much as it can, again≈øt the tradition of the Spanyards, depriue them of that holy Apo≈øtle, and yet for his being in Ireland proueth nothing
at all for as all men know, Hiberia, and Hibernia, be quite different Contries, and Hiberia (Vincentius his word) is neuer taken for Ireland but for Spayne. Therefore who≈øoeuer would with the Magdeburgian Prote≈øtants chaunge Vincentius his Hiberia, into their owne (in this ca≈øe) Imagined Hibernia, which Vincentius doth not name, mu≈øt needs by his authoritie, the onely or cheife ground they haue, depriue both Ireland and Spaine of the pre≈øence of S. Iames. For Vincentius onely nameth Hiberia to be the place where this Apo≈øtle preached, which by no po≈ø≈øible con≈øtruction can comprehend both tho≈øe Contries ≈øo diuided. And the Di≈øciples which he had, being very fewe, Guliel. Ei≈øengr. cent. 1. in Hi≈øpa. Antonin. part. 1. tit. 6. c. 7. Petrus de Natal. lib. 6. c. 133. Loys Maycrne hi≈øt. gener. ≈øup. Vincent. in ≈øpecul. hi≈øtorial. l. 9. c. 7. & cap. 6. Breu. Rom. 25. Iulij. Martyrol. Rom. 25. Iulij. were onely Spaniards there borne, & not any one of any other Nation, Scotland, Ireland, or what≈øoeuer, as is euident in all writers of his life and death, euen by Vincentius him≈øelfe, whom the≈øe Prote≈øtants haue cited before, who neuer nameth Man≈øuetus, or any ≈øent into the≈øe parts, of Ireland, Scotland, or Britaine. So the publike Church Seruice in the fea≈øt of that Apo≈øtle with the re≈øt. The old Roman Martyrologe ≈øpeaketh of his body carried to Spaine not of his preaching there. That place which the≈øe men cite from VinceÃÑtius in the 7. chapter of his 8. booke, hath not one word either of Hiberia, or Hibernia, or S. Iames, but ≈øpeaketh of S. Ihon Bapti≈øte his preaching and life.

4. Therefore the whole current of our late English Prote≈øtant Antiquaries (whoÃÑ I am ≈øtill to be directed by,) perceauing perhaps how vnadui≈øedly their Brethren of Magdeburge, Francis Burgoinge, and Holinshed haue carried them≈øelues in this bu≈øines, hath quite for≈øaken them, running in an other channell, and neuer remembring S. Iames among tho≈øe Apo≈øtles, from whom this kingdome by any meanes receaued the holy Religion of Chri≈øt. For Vincentius writeth no ≈øuch thing, but quite oterwi≈øe, that he onely preached in Hiberia, Spaine, and from thence returned to Hieru≈øalem againe. His words in the old Manu≈øcript Copy, are the≈øe: Quandles Apo≈øtres ≈øe ≈øeparirent en diuers Vincent. ≈øpecul. hi≈øtorial. manu≈øcrip. Gallic. antiq. l. 7. c. 7. parties & contr ‚Ä¢ es, Iacques Apo≈øtre de Dieu pre≈øcha la parolle de Dieu ≈øans poeur √©s parties de Hyberie la o√π il e≈øleut 7. Di≈øciples, Torele, Second, Inladette, Cilefont, Eufra≈øe, Celee, Y≈øichoe, & annon√ßa leur erreur, & ≈øema en eux la parolle de Dieu, qui longuement auoit est√© fans fruict, & quand le dernier iour approcha, il les mena auec luy en Ieru≈øalem, & la reccut le martyr: Which tran≈ølated into English, is thus: When the Apo≈øtles, did disper≈øe them≈øelues into ≈øeuerall partes and Contries, Iames an Apo≈øtle of Chri≈øt did preach the word of God without feare in the Contries of Hiberia (Spaine) where he did chu≈øe 7. Di≈øciples Torquel, Second, Inladette, Cilefont, Eufra≈øe, Celee, Y≈øichoe, and did announce their errours, and ≈øow in them the word of God, which longe time remained without fruit. And when the la≈øt day did approach, he Hymn. Eccl. Tolet. de S. Iacobo apud Baron. annot. in Martyrolog. Rom. die 25. Iul ‚Ä¢ j. Baron. annotat. ≈øupr. in Iacobo. Arnoldus. Mirm. Theat. Conuer≈ø: Gent. in S. Iacobo fratre Ioa. Act. c. 8. 9. 10. &c. Theater of greate Brit. l. 6. pag. 202. c. 9. Act. 15. v. 7. ledde them with him to Hieru≈øalem, and there receaued martyrdome. Hitherto the very words of Vincentius: whereby is onely expre≈ø≈øed, that he preached in Spaine, and from thence returned to Hieru≈øalem againe.

5. The ≈øame is te≈øtified al≈øo by the auncient publike hymne of him, v≈øed in the Church of Toletum, in Spaine, made by S. I≈øidore. Though many thinke he neuer preached at all in Spaine. And if he did as Baronius well proueth, it was onely to the Iewes which were there, (and not in Hibernia, Ireland) his contrimen, for the time of the Decree of the Apo≈øtles for preaching to the Gentiles, was not yet made, this being as the Spaniards ≈øay, in the 37. yeare of Chri≈øt, within 4. yeares of his A≈øcen≈øion, at which time, and after, they only preached vnto the Gentiles, as the holy Scriptures them≈øelues are witne≈ø≈øe in diuers places. And the Prote≈øtant Authours of the Theater ≈øay: that Go ‚Ä¢ had cho≈øen S. Peter, that from his mouth the Gentils might heare the Gho≈øpell and
beleeue as him≈øelfe alleadgeth. And his owne words are the≈øe by Prote≈øtants tran≈ølation: God made choy≈øe amonge vs, that the Gentiles by my mouth should heare Io. Bal. l. 1. de vit. Pontif. Rom. in Petr. ex Mant. l. 6. de fa≈øt. Philip. Pantal. chron. an. 38. Petr. epi≈øt. 1. cap. 1. v. 1. Iacob. ep. c. 1. v. 1. the word of the ghospell and beleeue. Therefore S. Peter, and not S. Iames was the fir≈øt preacher to the Gentiles, And our be≈øt learned Prote≈øtants doe proue, that S. Peter did not preach formally to any nation, of the Gentiles, nor to the Gentiles in Bythinia, Capadocia, Pontus, Gallatia, or any other place, vntill after this, but to the Iewes onely dwelling there:

q.l: Quotquot erant illis Iudaea ab origine regnis,
Edocuit Chri≈øtum, veterique reduxit ab v≈øu.

div.p: Which both S. Peter him≈øelfe and S. Iames te≈øtifie in the beginning of their Epi≈øtles. And were it not for the authoritie of tho≈øe which write that S. Peter did coÃÑ≈øecrate tho≈øe ≈øeuen Di≈øciples of S. Iames making them Bishops and ≈øending them into Hiberia, Spaine, we might thinke the Hiberia where Sainct Iames preached was the Hiberia, in, or neare Armenia, a place farre more neare and likely for him to preach in, then this we≈øt Contry of Spaine is. For there al≈øo is a Nation then named Hiberia, or Iberia, and the people thereof Cooper. v. Iber. Abrah. Orte ‚Ä¢ ius in Catal. nomin. antiq. in Iberia & in de≈øcript. A≈øiae. Iberi or Hebres, as the Spaniards al≈øo were called, as both Prote≈øtants and others te≈øtifie, the Georgians now are dwelling there, being a Contry of A≈øia neare Pontus Euxinus.

6. And to giue all contentmeÃÑt that may be in this matter, it doth not ≈øeeme altogether vnprobable: (e≈øpecially the auÃÑcient Scots now called Irish, inhabiting of Irelande, and the Scots of Scotland, being aunciently one and the ≈øame people with the old inhabitants of ≈øome of the maritane parts of Spaine now Portugall as both Scottish, Irish, and English hi≈øtorians al≈øo informe vs,) That S. Iames the Apo≈øtle preaching in Spaine neare vnto, or among the Hector. Boeth. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Irl. Mat. We≈øtm. aetat. 5. c. 5. people of Spayne, from whom diuers of our Scots and Irish are come, ≈øome fame of his preaching though short, and miracles there, might come from them to the Scots their Contrimen, mixed with our Britaines here, and by that heauenly doctrine, which ≈øeemed vnto them litle or nothing to differ from that which had longe before more darkely beene taught among them, before the coming of Chri≈øt, and hearing that S. Iames was returned vnto Iury, and Hieru≈øalem againe, and the cheife≈øt Apo≈øtles, Doctours, and Teachers of that holy Religion, were there, But diuers both Scots, and Britans, which then dwelled together, and as before were of one and the ≈øame minde in ≈øpirituall things, vndertooke that pilgrimage and ≈øacred Iorney: and there meeting with S. Peter, the cheife≈øt of that ble≈ø≈øed company, and fir≈øt preacher Hect. Boeth. in de≈øcr. Scot. Reg. fol. 4. 5. Hieron. l. 2. contr. Iouin. Abrah. O ‚Ä¢ tel. in Co≈ømog. B ‚Ä¢ libald ‚Ä¢ n Co ‚Ä¢ mog. Mun≈øt. in Co≈ø. Cooper. v. Scotia Calepin. v. Scot. A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . lib. de mund. Th ‚Ä¢ odor. H ‚Ä¢ ≈øt. ‚Ä¢ cc ‚Ä¢ e≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t. Claud. P ‚Ä¢ o ‚Ä¢ om. Geog ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ p. l. 2. c. 2. Claud. Panyger. to the Gentiles, were in≈øtructed by him in the faith of Chri≈øt. And this S. Man≈øuetus being ≈øtiled both by Antiquities and later writers before to haue beene natione Scotus ≈øufficiently conuinceth he was either a Britan or Scot of this Iland of Britaine, for although all tho≈øe three people before remembred were ≈øometimes named Scoit, as Hector Boethius, and diuers others doe witne≈ø≈øe: yet to haue beene con≈øtantly and ah≈øolutely named Scots, was and is peculiar to tho≈øe of this Iland. Scoticum nomen ob eminentem prae caeteris virtut ‚Ä¢ m, ≈øolum nobis etiam nunc ≈øupere≈øt, quum & in Hi≈øpania & in Hibernia vetu≈øiate interierit. And it was ≈øo aunciently decayed both amoÃÑg tho≈øe inhabitants of Spaine and Ireland that euen in the time of the Apo≈øtles, and before, it was almo≈øt proper to them of this Iland.

7. That which we call now Ireland was in the time of Ari≈øtotle or the auncient Authour of the booke, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ of the world among his workes called I ‚Ä¢ rna. So doth Theodoret name it. Claudius Ptolomaeus calleth it Iuernia,
or Hibernia. And Claudianus Hyberne: Scotorum Tumulos fleuit glaciali Hiberne, ≈øo that we ≈øee, the name Scotia Scotland appropriate to our northren part of Britaine; and this whole Iland by ≈øome, was named Scotia. For Commentar. in Claud. Ptolom. as Pirckeinerus, or who≈øoeuer the Commentor vpon Claudius Ptolomaeus was, all this Iland hath beene called by ≈øome Scotia, Scotland. Anglia nunc dicitur vulgo England, prius Loegria, Deinde Scotia, vulgo Scothland, Albania prius, & Caledonia, Rufo Britannia ≈øecunda. And among all hi≈øtorians Latine, French, Spannish, Scottish, English or what els, The northren part of Britaine is ab≈øolutely called Scotland, and ≈øo hath euer beene, ≈øince the name Albania, or Britannia cea≈øed there. And if Ireland hath bene at any time named Scotia, Scotland, it was onely among the Scottish, or Irish writers, and ≈øuch as followed them therein, tho≈øe Irish hi≈øtorians willing to giue that denomination vnto it, becau≈øe many of the Scots with other people dwelled there; when the true name, and among ≈øtraungers was not ≈øo, but as I haue declared before, from auncient hi≈øtories; and to ≈øpeake in a Prote≈øtants words therein Authour of the Booke of E≈øtates in Ireland Edw. Grym≈øt. e≈øtate of the King of great Britaine. p. 22. following good authorities, thus he di≈øcribeth it: Ireland which ≈øome of the auncients called Hibernia, others Iuernia, Iuuernia, and Ierne, and Ogigia, and by the Irish them≈øelues, Erim, called by Ptolomee litle Britaine, lyes betweene Britaine and Spaine. Where we ≈øee, the name Scoland is neuer attributed, ≈øimply, vnto it, by the≈øe Authours Iudgments either by the Irish them≈øelues, or other writers, late or auncient. And, as all men know, The ≈øentence of Hector Boetius is, that the name of Scots and Scotland hath beene of late proper to them of this our Britaine, and quite cea≈øed and di≈øcontinued both in Spaine, and Ireland; Arnoldus Mirman. Theatr. conuer≈ø. gent. Gulielm. Ei≈øeng. Centen. 1. part. 1. di≈øtinct. 3. fol. 56. Petr. de natalib. l. 11. cap. vit. Ant. Monchiacen. Demochar. l. 2. de Mi≈ø≈ø. contra Caluin. cap. 33. Franc. Bell ‚Ä¢ for. Co≈ømograph. l. 2. col. 2. col. 263. Catalog. Epi≈øc. Tullers. and yet they which terme. S. Man≈øuetus natione Scotus: a Scot by nation, are late writers, as Arnoldus Mirmannius, Gulielmus Ei≈øengrenius, Antonius Democharez, Franc ‚Ä¢ s Bellefore≈øt, and others ≈øpeaking after the vulgar manner of nameing Scot and Scotland in their time, of which onely they ≈øpeake, not entering into any controuer≈øie, what people haue beene called Scots, but are ≈øuch as call no other Scots or Scotland, then of our Britaine.

8. So that the truth which is affirmed in this matter, is onely this, that S. Man≈øuetus di≈øciple of S. Peter the Apo≈øtle, and by him ordained the fir≈øt Bishop of Tullum, Toul, in Lorraine, was by nation borne in that part of Britaine, which now, and euer of late for many yeares, is and hath beene called Scotland: But whether he was a Britaine or a Scot tho≈øe Authorities doe not determine. But it will more fully appeare hereafter that he was by birth a Britian, that part of this Iland at that time being part of Britaine, and longe after; which among others Martial the Poet maketh manife≈øt for that time: for ≈øpeaking of the inhabitants of that part of this kingdome, which now is called S. Man≈øuetus di≈øciple of S. Peter the Apo≈øtle was a Britain. Scotland. To Quintus Ouidius, that was to trauaile thither, from Rome, he calleth them Britans of Caledonia.

q.note: The contry now called Scotland was part of Britain ‚Ä¢ in this time, and longe after.

div.p: And it should ≈øeeme by Martial, that this Quintus Ouidius him≈øelfe was a Britain of this nation, and perhaps of the kindred or retinue of lady Claudia, for he doth not onely ≈øpeake of his longe Iorney from Rome, to our North part of Britaine, as before, now Scotland, but in the ≈øame place ≈øetteth downe, that he was to returne againe into Italy, from hence, and make his abode at Martial. l. 10. epigram. 44. ad Quintum Ouidium. Martial. ≈øupr. epigr. 44. Sabinam where the how≈øe of our Contry woman lady Claudia, and her Husband Pudens was.
div.q: Sed reddar ‚Ä¢ tuis tandem man≈øure Sabinis.
div.p:
But this hereafter, when I come to that time. But this ≈øufficiently conuinceth
both that the northreÃÑ inhabitants of this kingdome in tho≈øe dayes were called Britans, and that there was entercour≈øe betweene Rome, Romans, and them e≈øpecially when we ≈øee an old man, fitter to ≈øit by the fire, then to take ≈øo longe a iorney, as the Poet there de≈øcribeth him, not onely to goe to the remote≈øt places of this kingdome from Rome, but to make his returne into Italy againe. And here I end the dayes of Tiberius, leauing Cunobeline ≈øtill King in Britaine, or Guiderius newly begun his Reigne.

div.head: THE VII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE TIME OF CAIVS CALIGVLA, Emperour; and ≈øome Chri≈øtian Britans of this nation, probably both at Rome, and in Britaine in his daies.

div.p:
1.
