Matth. we≈øt. an. 209. 198. and others. more hereafter, or the cominge of ≈øainct Io≈øeph of Aramathia, and his Religious Companions into this kingdome, in the dayes of Nero, or the generall Conuer≈øion of the kingdome of Britaine vnto the Trenches of Seuerus in the time of King Lucius by Pope Eleutherius, all the≈øe were longe before the Conuer≈øion of the Scots in the time of their King Donaldus either by Pope Victor, or Zepherinus, as Hari≈øon rather ≈øuppo≈øeth, the fir≈øt time which is a≈ø≈øined by any, being in the 203. yeare of Chri≈øt: and if it was vnder Pope Zepherine, it was after that time, for he was not cho≈øen Pope vntill the yeare 209. before which time or the beginning it ≈øelfe of the Papacy of ≈øaint Victor, which was in the yeare 198. this our Britaine on this, ≈øide (the remembred diui≈øion) had generally and publikly receaued the faith of Chri≈øt. And the very words of Tertullian, liuing and dying before this Conuer≈øion of Scotland,
within the fir≈øt two hundred yeares, by the≈øe Prote≈øtants before, and writing that his booke, aduer≈øus Iudaeos, longe before, and yet ≈øaying, that the places of Britaine, which the Romans could neuer conquere, or come vnto, Britannorum Romanis inacce≈ø≈øa loca: did acknowledge Chri≈øt and his name did reigne in them, before he wrote, doe manife≈øtly conuince it to be ≈øo. For Tertullian liuing and writing in Afrike, could not po≈ø≈øibly take notice of things done here in an Iland ≈øo farre of, pre≈øently after they were fir≈øt effected: and by no meanes, could either he, or any other writer ≈øpeake of things done ≈øo longe after, truely to repart them done ≈øo longe before, If he had bene the greate≈øt Prophet that euer was. Therefore both the Te≈øtimony of him, and Peter Cluniacen≈øis al≈øo mu≈øt needs, (to be true) haue relation to the≈øe dayes of ≈øainct Man≈øuetus, and his A≈ø≈øociats, or others liuing in tho≈øe times, and ≈øent hither by ≈øainct Peter. Or els how can we allowe, and commend the ≈øpirituall loue and charitie of ≈øainct Peter that mo≈øt glorious Apo≈øtle, whom we may not controle, or of this holy ≈øainct our Contryman made Prei≈øt, and Bishop by him to this his mo≈øt beloued contry, if he had continually ≈øtayed at Tullum, ≈øo farre hence, or there abouts, neuer coming hither to releeue the extreame ≈øpirituall needs, di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, and mi≈øeries of this his natiue contry, except others were then a≈ø≈øigned by the ≈øame Apo≈øtle to ≈øupply and performe that charge? In ≈øuch a ca≈øe the Order of Chri≈øtian charitie had otherwi≈øe ≈øent him hither, and ≈øo required both of ≈øainct Peter and this his di≈øciple, to preferre this Nation in their heauenly loue. That ≈øpirit which moued holy Moy≈øes to ≈øay to Exod. c. 32. v. 32. God: Aut mi≈øerere populo huic, aut dele me de libro quem ≈øcrip≈øi≈øti: Either take mercy vpon this people (my contry men) or blot me out of the booke, which thou ha≈øt written. Rom. c. 9. v. 3. That which inforced and inflamed ≈øainct Paul to write: I could wish (≈øo our Prote≈øtants tran≈ølate) that my ≈øelfe were accur≈øed from Chri≈øt, for my brethren, my kin≈ømen according to the flesh. Yea the order and lawe of holy loue bound, and tied with the chaines thereof the whole Colledge of the ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtles to ≈øtay ≈øo longe in Iury, among their brethren there, before they preached vnto the Gentiles. And Chri≈øt him≈øelfe ≈øaid, he was ≈øent, ad oues quae perierunt domus I≈ørael: to the lo≈øt sheppe of the hou≈øe of I≈ørael: and preached mo≈øt to the Iewes of who≈øe nation he had receaued his Incarnation. Matth. 15. Camden. in Belgae. edit. an. 1586. Selden. in Analect. Girald. Cambr. l. de ≈øedis menou. dignitate. Ioh. Pri≈ø. defen≈ø. hi≈øt. Britannic. p. 73. 74. Parker. antiq. Britanni. Anton. Sabell. lib. de occid. Imper. & alij.

8. Therefore be≈øides all the Prote≈øtaÃÑts of EnglaÃÑd before recited, their cheife≈øt Antiquary coÃÑcludeth that it is a thing certaine, not to be que≈øtioned, or doubted of, but the Britans did receaue Chri≈øtian Religion, euen in the very infancy & begining of the Church of Chri≈øt. certum e≈øt Britannos in ip≈øa Eccle≈øiae Infantia, Chri≈øtianaÃÑ Religionem imbibi≈ø≈øe. So M. Selden and others before alledged. And though S. Man≈øuetus be called natione Scotus, yet this nothing preiudiceth the preaching of the faith to the BritaÃÑs, in the North part of this IlaÃÑd by him, or others of his holy coÃÑpanions. For long after this time all or the greate≈øt part of the inhabitaÃÑts of that Northren CoÃÑtry of Britaine, were knowne BritaÃÑs & not Scots, as is euideÃÑt by all antiquities of this natioÃÑ, & the preuayling of the Scottish nation there, fir≈øt gaue the denominatioÃÑ of Scotland to it, loÃÑge after being then, euen by the Romans, called Britaine. For as both auncient and late, forreine and dome≈øticall antiquaries agree, this Iland was longe time after the dayes of ≈øainct Man≈øuetus diuided into fiue di≈øtinct Prouinces, and yet euery Sainct Man≈øuetus made Preist and Bishop by. S. Peter, pr ‚Ä¢ ached in Britaine. one called, Britannia. Britannia prima. Britannia ≈øecunda. Britannia Flauia. Britannia Maximia. Britannia Valentia. Which la≈øt was that, which was aunciently Albania, and after abu≈øiuely (becau≈øe the Scots po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed it) Scotland. Quinta, Valentia, Albania ≈øcilicet, quae nunc abu≈øiu√® Scotia dicitur. And although this
holy Bishop of Britaine is ordinarily called in hi≈øtories the Bishop of Toul in Lorraine, where, and where about he ≈øeemeth much to haue conuer≈øed, and preached after he was promoted to Epi≈øcopall order by ≈øainct Peter; yet this hindereth not, but that (as before) he ≈øpent much time, & labour in that kinde, as nature and charitie bound him, in this his natiue contry: which is te≈øtified in plaine termes both by Methodius that mo≈øt auncient writer, and ≈øainct Marianus Scotus, his owne contriman of this Iland, who ≈øpeaking of diuers Apo≈øtolike Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. in Nerua col. 254. Method. apud eund. ≈øupr. men of that time, whom they call, In≈øignes ≈øanctitate, & gratia pollentes: renowned men excelling in ≈øanctitie and grace, among whome they name both this our holy Bishop, and ≈øainct Clement his a≈ø≈øociate, they ≈øay of them: non ≈øol√πm propria prouincia, ≈øed & in extremis (al. externis) & vltimis indu≈øtrij & illustres regna Tyrannorum vicerunt: They were not onely indu≈øtrious, & renowned for preaching in their owne contries, but al≈øo in extreme, (or externe) and vttermo≈øt nations, ouercame the kingdomes of Tyrants. Where it is euident by the≈øe two greate witne≈ø≈øes, that this mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Bishop of Britaine preached here in his owne contry, propria prouincia at that time. And thus I end the Empire of Caligula, Guiderius reigning in Britaine.

div.head: THE VIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE TIME OF CLAVDIVS. AND HOW by our Prote≈øtants te≈øtimony one of the twelue Apo≈øtles then preached in Britaine.

div.p:
1. NOw we are come to the time of Claudius, when both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants a≈ø≈øure vs, both that the Apo≈øtles formally preached vnto the Gentiles, and there were many Chri≈øtians in this our Britaine: But before we proceed further, to auoide all ambiguitie, or errour, that might chaunce in the≈øe matters, in the iudgment of Prote≈øtants, let vs fir≈øt craue their be≈øt a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and direction by ≈øome certaine grounds, and maximes in hi≈øtory, as infallible rules truely and plainely to ≈øquare our narration by, lea≈øt we be deceaued. They Certaine hi≈øtoricall grounds, and Maximes giuen by our Prote≈øiaÃÑt Antiquaries, to kn ‚Ä¢ we what Ap ‚Ä¢ ≈øtles fir≈øt preached in Britani ‚Ä¢ . propo≈øe ≈øome fewe for mo≈øt certaine and vndoubted generall verities, which will ea≈øily leade vs to many vndoubted particular conclu≈øions. Fir≈øt they ≈øay, which in ≈øome ≈øort is remembred before, that this kingdome of Britaine receaued the faith of Chri≈øt ≈øoone after his A≈øcen≈øion. Secondly, that this holy Religion was preached here, by ≈øome one at the lea≈øt of the Apo≈øtles. Thirdly, who they are in particular of that mo≈øt holy number and order, of whom mention is made in hi≈øteries to haue preached in this nation. Fourthly that in the time of Claudius, of which we now intreate, diuers Chri≈øtians came hither from Rome, when he per≈øecuted them there. Fiftly that ≈øainct Paul came not to Rome, or to any of the≈øe we≈øt parts vntill longe after the death of Claudius, in the reigne of Nero: Sixtly, that ≈øainct Simon Zelotes, whom ≈øome write to haue preached and bene martyred in Britaine, was put to death in Per≈øia, with ≈øainct Iude. Seuenthly, that it was the 63. yeare of Chri≈øt, before ≈øainct Io≈øeph of Aramathia, that buried our Sauiour, came hither with his religious companions. La≈øtely, that ≈øainct Peter, that great Apo≈øtle was
one of tho≈øe three Apo≈øtles, ≈øainct Paul and ≈øainct Simon Zelotes the other two which are reported in hi≈øtories to haue preached heare. All which a≈ø≈øertions Theater of great Britanie lib. 6. Camden. in Britan. Stowe. And howes hi≈øt. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Engl. Godwyn Conu. of Brit. & Catal. of Bishop. Prote≈øt. Comm. Booke. Parker. antiquit. Britan. Ma≈øon Booke of Ordin. with others. are taught by the cheife≈øt Prote≈øtant antiquaries, and hi≈øtorians of England, in their common booke of their religion, their Theater and other writings, of mo≈øt credit with them, for vndoubted hi≈øtoriall verities. By which it euidently will be concluded, by their owne graunts, and directions, that ≈øainct Peter was the onely Apo≈øtle, that fir≈øt brought, or ≈øent Chri≈øtianitie into this kingdome. Which is particularly al≈øo proued before, in the ca≈øe of S. Man≈øuetus, the fir≈øt Prei≈øt and Bishop which was borne in this Iland which any hi≈øtories, I reade, make mention of, yet con≈øecrated by S. Peter, ≈øent and directed by him with others of his di≈øciples into the≈øe parts.

2. But to make all the≈øe things ≈øo euidently true, euen by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, that no man with any pretence of probabilitie, shall be able to make contradiction vnto them, They shall all and euery of them be particularly and Inuincibly proued true, by the≈øe meÃÑ them≈øelues. The fir≈øt, of the faith of Chri≈øt, receaued heare, ≈øoone after his A≈øcen≈øion, and in the time of Tyberius is verified before, from the≈øe Prote≈øtant Authours: To which I add this their Te≈øtimony againe: The Apo≈øtle him≈øelfe ≈øaith: the ≈øound of the ghospell went through the earth, and was heard vnto the ends of the world. Which his ≈øayings cannot more Theater of great Britaine l. 6. c. 9. Rom. 10. v. 18. fitly be applied to any other Nation then to vs of Britaine, who≈øe land by the almightie is ≈øo placed in the terre≈øtriall Globe, that thereby it is termed of the auncient the the ends, and deemed to be ≈øituated in an other world. And againe: Immediately after Christs death, doth Gildas fa≈øten our conuer≈øion, where he writeth, that the glorious Gho≈øpell of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, which fir≈øt appeared to the world in the later time of Tyberius Cae≈øar, did euen then ≈øpread his bright beames vpon this fro≈øen Iland of Britaine. The Gildas. de excid. Brit. like te≈øtimony they reiterate in an other place, Which I will cite hereafter; and according vnto this, runneth the whole current of their writers of antiquitie from the highe≈øt and greate≈øt to the loue≈øt and meane≈øt among them.

3. Their fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop Matthew Parker in his Intituled Antiquitates Britannicae, The Antiquities of Britaine, proueth it from Antiquities in Matth. Parker. antiquit. Brit. p. 1 the≈øe words: primam Chri≈øtianae Eccle≈øiae originem & in≈øtitutionem in In≈øula Britannica, ex antiqui≈øsimis patrum ≈øcriptorumque te≈øtimonijs repertemus nor modo peruetu≈øtam eam fui≈ø≈øe, ≈øed etiam ab ip≈øo primum per Apo≈øtolos propagato per orbem Euangelio initia duxi≈ø≈øe & accepi≈ø≈øe incrementa: we shall finde out of the mo≈øt auncient testimonies of the Fathers and writers, That the fir≈øt beginning, and institution of the Chri≈øtian Church in the Iland of Britaine, was not onely very auncient, but to haue had beginning and receaued increa≈øes euen from the time when the Ghosppell was fir≈øt propagated in the world by the Apo≈øtles. And he yeeldeth his rea≈øon immediatly in this maÃÑner. Gildas enim Antiqui≈ø ‚Ä¢ imus inter eos qui fide digni ≈øunt, Britannicaru ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ rum ≈øcriptor, tradit Britannos iam inde ab ortu Euangelij Chri≈øtianam „Äà‚óä„Äâ fid ‚Ä¢ m: for Gildas the mo≈øt auncient writer of Brittish matters among tho≈øe that „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ edit, doth deliuer that the Britons receaued the Chri≈øtian faith euen from Engli ‚Ä¢ h Prote≈øtaÃÑts mi≈øtake the te≈øtimonie of Gildas about the time of the faith of Chri≈øt receaued heare. the ri≈øing vp of the ghospell. The Prote≈øtant Bishops and others, Authors of their greate Theater of greate Britaine giue te≈øtimony vnto this, in the≈øe words: There are, who vpon a very good ground from the words of Gildas, the mo≈øt auncient of our Brittish Historians, will haue the ≈øunne of the ghospell longe before the coming of Io≈øeph of Aramothia hither, to haue ri≈øen in this our w ‚Ä¢ ≈øt, and this Iland of Britaine to haue enioyed the very morning A≈ø≈øent, the brigtne≈ø≈øe thereof per
‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ g Theater of great Britaine l. 6. c. 9. ¬ß. 5. through the mu≈øt ‚Ä¢ cloudes of errour, and shyning heare in Britaine euen i ‚Ä¢ the „Äà‚óä„Äâ of Tiberius, towards who≈øe end Christ ≈øuffered his death, and by who≈øe Indulgence
towards Christians, their profe≈øsion was propagated farre and neare. Which a≈ø≈øertion the ≈øaied Gildas doth not deliuer couldely or doubtingly, but with great confidence, and relying vpon good grounds, as it appeareth when he ≈øaith, Scimus &c. we know for certainety, that this was in the later times of Tiberius which was immediatly after our ble≈ø≈øed Sauiours Pa≈øsion. Their Prote≈øtant Bishops Bale and Godwyn ≈øay: The Britans receaued the doctrine and di≈øcipline of their Church from the Apoles of Chri≈øt. The religion of the Britans was that which the Apo≈øtles by the commaundemeÃÑt of God deliuered to the Churches of the Chri≈øtians. And continued in the Country of the Britans from the Apo≈øtles tyme. Their mo≈øt renowned Antiquary Sir Camden Clarentieux among Harolds is of the ≈øame opinion, in diuers editions. D. Fulke ≈øaith: The Britans continued in the faith of Chri≈øt, from the Apo≈øtles Godwyn. Conu. of Britaine p. 43. 44. Balaeus l. 2. de Act. Rom. pont. in Gregor. 1. Camden in Britan. Fulke An≈øw. to counterf. Cath. p. 40. Powel Annotat. in l. 2. Giraldi Cambren. Itiner. Cambr. c. 1. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Engl. c. 21. p. 102. Selden in Anal. Gildas epi≈øt. de Excid. & Conq. Brit. cap. 6. time. An other addeth: The doctrine of the Britans and their worship of God was pure and from the Apo≈øtles them≈øelues. Holinshed ≈øaith: the Britans Chri≈øtianity neuer failed from the Apo≈øtles time. In like manner write diuers others, needle≈ø≈øe to be recited: And mo≈øt of them ground vpon the Authoritie of S. Gildas, as ≈øome of them haue plainely before expre≈ø≈øed.

4. Therefore for better ≈øatisfaction of the Readers I will cite at lardge the words of that holy Auncient British writer, as our English Prote≈øtants haue published him to the world, and ≈øome Manu≈øcripts al≈øo haue. The≈øe they are: Interea glaciali frigore rigenti In≈øulae, & velut longiore terrarum ≈øece≈ø≈øu ≈øoli vi≈øibili non proximae, verus ille non de firmamento ≈øolum temporali, ≈øed de ≈øumma etiam caelorum arce tempora cuncta excedente, vniuer≈øo orbi praefulgidum ≈øui corru≈øcum o≈øtendens (tempore vt ≈øcimus) ≈øummo Tyberij Cae≈øaris, quo ab≈øque vllo impedimento, eius promulgabatur Religio, comminata Senatu nolente √† Principe morte dilatoribus militum eiu≈ødem, radios ≈øuos indulget, id est, ≈øua praecepta Chri≈øtus. In the meane time, to this Iland ≈øtiffe with for≈øen could, and farre di≈øtant from the vi≈øible ≈øunne, That true ≈øunne which is Chri≈øt, doth vouch≈øafe his beames, that is to ≈øay his precepts, shewing to the whole world his glittering brightne≈ø≈øe, not onely from the temporall firmament, but from his high Tower of heauen, exceeding all times, in the latter time of Tyberus Cae≈øar, without any impediment his Religion was propagated, the Prince threateing death, to the accu≈øers of his ≈øouldiers, again≈øt the will of the Senate. Hitherto the very words of S. Gildas, as he is published by Prote≈øtants. Who freely acknowledge, that clau≈øe of the time of Tyberius to be wanting in other copies of that holy writer, as namely in that, which was put forth by Polydor Virgill, and others. And the very fir≈øt word of this narration: Interea, Prote≈øtant Ann. in Prologum Gildae in Marg. & in cap. 14. in marg. in the meane time: doe ≈øeeme plainely to conuince, that they are no part of S. Gildas, e≈øpecially in that ≈øence, that he thought this kingdome to haue receaued the faith of Chri≈øt in the time of Tyberius, but in the dayes of Claudius. For they being of a Relatiue nature, and hauing relation to that which went before, they mu≈øt in due con≈øtruction of nece≈ø≈øitie proue, that this receauing of Religion interea, in the meane time was when things la≈øt and immediately ≈øpoaken of before were done. Which were, the ≈øubiection of the Britans the ≈øecond time to the Romans, Which was in the time of Claudius coming hither in the fourth yeare of his Empire, and of Chri≈øt the 44. which our Prote≈øtants Matth. We≈øtm. an. Do. 44. & 4. Claudij, Stowe, Holinsh. Camden with others. Prote≈øt. annot. in c. 5. Gildae. Prote≈øt. annot. & tit. in c. 6. Gild. notes vpon the≈øe places of S. Gildas doe make mo≈øt manife≈øt. For the chapter which goeth immediatly before the recited Authoritie is, thus by them intituled: De ≈øecunda gentis ≈øubiectione: of the ≈øecond ≈øubiection or ≈øubduing of this Nation to the Romans. Which was in the beginning of the Reigne of Claudius, and then immediately followeth the next chapter, wholy before recited, and by the≈øe Prote≈øtants intituled. De religione. Of religion receaued heare.
Therefore if the Religion of Chri≈øt was receaued by the Britans, by Gildas onely, Interea, in the time when they were ≈øubdued by Claudius, it cannot be S. Gildas doth not affirme that the Britans receaued the faith in Tiberius time, but in the dayes of Claudius. gathered from him, that they receaued it ≈øooner. Otherwi≈øe it was not receaued, Interea, in that time, the words of the holy hi≈øtorian. But how≈øoeuer that Authoritie is to be vnder≈øtood, It proueth at the lea≈øt, to the greate honour, of this kingdome, that it receaued the faith of Chri≈øt in the beginning at the lea≈øt of the Empire of Claudius. Which George maior and other his Prote≈øtant followers doe rather approue, in this tenor: that immediately after Chri≈øts Re≈øurrection vnder Claudius, the light of the Gospell was kindled in Britaine. And this Georg. maior in Praefat. Stowe & Howes hi≈øtor. in Agricola. Theater of Britaine. l. 6. c. 9. Godwyn Conu. pag. 1. 2. Stowe and Howes hi≈øt. in Agricola. Godwyn ≈øupr. pag. 2. mu≈øt needs be by ≈øome one of the 12. Apo≈øtles, or their Di≈øciples, by the ≈øentence of the≈øe Prote≈øtants, a≈ø≈øuring vs, fir≈øt in the≈øe words ≈øoone after the A≈øcention of Chri≈øt, the holy Apostles being di≈øper≈øed through out the earth diuided the Prouinces among them, by lot to preach the ghospell in. And againe: It is deliuered plainely by ≈øondry auncient writers, that Britaine fell in diui≈øion among the Apostles. And ≈øo of nece≈ø≈øitie it mu≈øt needs receaue the faith of Chri≈øt, either immediatly by ≈øome one of that mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed company, or mediately by their Di≈øciples, or both, which is mo≈øt probable in ≈øo greate a bu≈øines, exceeding the labour of one, and not performed onely by the ≈øchollers and Di≈øciples, ≈øeeing by the≈øe Prote≈øtants grounding vpon auncient writers, it fell out to the diui≈øion, Britaine receaued the faith from one of the 12. Apo≈øtles by Prote≈øtants. and portion, of one of the cheife Ma≈øters in this ≈øacred worke, one of the Apo≈øtles of Chri≈øt him≈øelfe. Which the holy Prophet ≈øeemeth longe before to foreshew of this Iland, one of the greate≈øt and mo≈øt remote, longe from Hieru≈øalem, when ≈øpeaking of the Apo≈øtles in the per≈øon of God, he ≈øaith, as Prote≈øtants I≈øai c. 66. v. 19. tran≈ølate him: And I will ≈øet a ≈øigne among them, and I will ≈øend tho≈øe that e≈øcape of them, to the Nations, to the Iles a farre of, that haue not hard my fame, neither haue ≈øeene my glory, and they shall declare my glory among the Gentiles. Which, diuers Prote≈øtants and not vnworthily apply to this Iland, one of the Theater of Brit. l. 6. Godwyn. ≈øupr. Magdeburgen. Centur. 1. l. 2. c. 7. col. 518. Eu≈øeb. l. 3. hi≈øt. c. 1. Mu≈øculus ib. Prochorus hi≈øt. c. 1. in tom. 7. Biblioth. patr. S. Leo ≈øerm. 1. de Apo≈øt. Petro & Paul. I≈øidor. l. de vita & obitu Sanctorum c. 83. 71. Freculph. Lexou. To. 2. Chronic. l. 2. c. 4. Antiquit. Gla≈øt. apud Capgrau. in S. Patricio. & al. Hartman. Schedel Chronic. Chron. f. 202. p. 1. Nicephorus hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 3. c. 1. greate≈øt in the world, and furthe≈øt di≈øtant from Iury, where this Prophe≈øie was vttered.

5. And this diui≈øion a portition of the world among the Apo≈øtles to preach and publish the gho≈øpell in, is as the≈øe Prote≈øtants before doe warrant vs: as al≈øo that Britaine (as needs it mu≈øt, being one of the greate≈øt Ilands of the world) fell in this diui≈øion among the Apo≈øtles, Is plainely deliuered by ≈øoundry auncient writers. The Magdeburgian Prote≈øtants tell vs that Eu≈øebius ≈øaith it was a Tradition that the Apo≈øtles diuided the Prouinces of the world by lott among≈øt theÃÑ. Quod Apo≈øtoli inter ≈øe ≈øortiti ≈øunt orbis terrarum prouincias. And Mu≈øculus in his tran≈ølation of Eu≈øebius is witnes, from Eu≈øebius that it was the Tradition of the Church; ≈øicut traditio
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
continet. Which is confirmed by S. Prochorus one of the ≈øeuen Deacons, made by the Apo≈øtles, as we haue his works. S. Leo ≈øaith: That the Apo≈øtles vndertooke to preach the Gho≈øpell to the world diuiding it, into parts among them: diui≈øis ≈øibi terrarum partibus. S. I≈øidor, or who≈øoeuer, that auncient Authour of the booke, de vita & obitu Sanctorum, among his works, & Freculphus Lexouien≈øis writeth ≈øo al≈øo, and excludeth S. Paul from any part in this ordinary partition, being after called an extraordinary Apo≈øtle: Paulo cum caeteris Apostolis nulla ≈øors propria traditur. So we reade in the auncient Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury Abbey. Hartmanus Schedel ≈øaith of the Apo≈øtles: totum orbem per Prouincias inter ≈øe partiti ≈øunt: The twelue Apo≈øtles parted the whole world among them by Prouinces: So Nicephorus in many places: Apo≈øtoli ≈øicut diximus per omnem disper≈øi terram, Prouincias orbis ad Euangelium praedicandum ≈øorte partiti ≈øunt: The holy Apostles diuided among them
by lot the Prouinces of the world to preach the ghospell. Thus our English Prote≈øtants, Godwyn, Stowe, Howes and others. Godwin. Conu. of Britaine. Stowe & Howes hi≈øt. in Agricola and others. Breuiar. Roman. in vit. S. Philipp. Apo≈øt. 1. Maij & S. Matt. 21. Sept. Ioa. Whitgift. An≈øwer. to the Ad. and def. Bil≈øon again≈øt the Purit. Barl. Ser. of Bish. Bridg. def. of the Eccl. gouern. Covel. def. of Hooker. Downam. l. 4. c. 4. of Bishops.

6. And to make all ≈øure, the Church of God in the publike offices of the holy Apo≈øtles, S. Philip on the fir≈øt day of may, and S. Matthew the 21. of September propoundeth the ≈øame for a certaine truth vnto vs. Neyther doth the rule of our Prote≈øtants Religion, their communion Booke, impugne it, and ≈øo none doe contradict it. And our Parlament Prote≈øtants of England, ≈øuch as ≈øtand for the dignities and functions of Bishops, again≈øt the Presbyterian Puritans, ≈øuch as their Bishops, Whitgift, Bil≈øon, Barlow, Bridges, and others, make a rea≈øon of this diui≈øion, not onely the better to deriue true doctrine, but Iuri≈ødiction al≈øo vnto Bishops ≈øucceeding them both in doctrine, and Epi≈øcopall power. It is manifest (≈øay the≈øe men) that the Bishops haue receaued, and deriued their authoritie from the Apostles, who≈øe ≈øucce≈ø≈øors they are, not onely in re≈øpect of doctrine, but al≈øo in the gouernment of the ≈øeuerall Churches, not onely Dioce≈øian Bishops but Archbishops ≈øuch as Metropolitans are, were from the Apo≈øtles time. And they exemplifie who the≈øe were in many places, where the Apo≈øtles preached. And yet this nothing hindereth any thing I haue written before, of diuers Britans of this Nation conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt before the time of Claudius, for I shewed that to haue bene the great & extraordinary grace, and fauour of Chri≈øt to tho≈øe per≈øons; now I entreate of the ordinary calling, and Conuer≈øion of this Country, among others by the publike con≈øent, and agreement of the Apo≈øtles, which although it was before the calling of S. Paul to be an Apo≈øtle, yet I do not thereby goe about to exclude him from this holy worke, wherein, being extraordinarily called, he laboured as extraordinary and probably al≈øo honored this Nation with his pre≈øence, although after it had receaued the faith of Chri≈øt: The diui≈øion of the world being among the 12. Apo≈øtles before S. Paul his Con≈øecration.

div.head: THE IX. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN IS PROVED BY PROTESTANT Antiquaries, that among the three Apo≈øtles S. Peter, S. Paul, and S. Symon Zelotes which are thought by any Antiquaries to haue preached heare in Britaine, it was not S. Paul which fir≈øt preached heare, but S. Peter.

div.p:
1. NOw therefore being thus warranted, by ≈øo generall a con≈øent, and harmony of cheife Prote≈øtants, that the Faith of Chri≈øt was ≈øo ≈øoone preached in this Iland by ≈øome or other of the holy Apo≈øtles, there is no difference coÃÑcerning the vndoubted truth of that ≈øacred ReligioÃÑ, whether it was by S. Peter, Paul, Andrew, Iames, Ihon, or any of the re≈øt, all of them after the coming of the holy Gho≈øt, being as infallibly confirmed in grace, and truth, as S. Peter, or who≈øoeuer in any opinion was cheife≈øt among them: yet in other re≈øpects it is not vnworthie a short inquiry by the≈øe men Needfull to knowe who was our fir≈øt Apo≈øtles. who in particular it was. Fir≈øt becau≈øe in the end of this fir≈øt hundred of yeares I shall deliuer in particular ≈øo farre as the≈øe Prote≈øtants my Directours will giue me leaue, what Religion it was, which euery of our Apo≈øtles and Ma≈øters in Chri≈øt taught and deliuered to this Nation: for knowledge whereof, the knowledge who they were, is fir≈øt to be required. Secondly in that re≈øpect, we shall be tied with a more ≈øtrict, and binding obligation, of dutie, and
debt, to render our mo≈øt obedient, and re≈øpectiue filiall ob≈øeruance of religious children, to that our worthie father in Chri≈øt, who trauailed ≈øo farre, and paynefull a iorney, from Hieru≈øalem to this Nation, to make vs, his regenerate children, with ≈øo many and difficult labours: for as S. Paul writeth to his Children the Corinthians, in like ca≈øe: though you haue ten thou≈øand In≈øtructors in Christ, yet yee haue not many fathers, for in Christ Ie≈øus I haue begotten 1. Cor. c. 4. v. 15. 16. you, through the ghospell. Wherefore I be≈øeech you, be followers of mee. Thirdly and la≈øtely, to be breife, the more honorable that Apo≈øtle was, by ≈øo much the honour of this Nation is more increa≈øed, and our dutie to him the greater. For to ≈øpeake with a Prote≈øtant Bishops tonge: we should accompt it a greate glory to our Nation, to deriue the pedigree of our ≈øpirituall linage, from ≈øo noble and excellent Godwyn Conu. of Britaine. p. 6. a Father as S. Peter. For the more ea≈øier finding forth whereof, this very man with many others his brethren in Religion, giueth vs direction in the≈øe English Prote≈øtaÃÑts confe≈ø≈øe, there is no mention in hi≈øtories but of 3. Apo≈øtles, S. Peter, S. Paul, and S. Simon, to haue preached heare. words: I finde mention of three onely of the Apostles to haue bene in our Britaine, to wit, Peter, and Paul, and Simon Chananaeus called al≈øo Zelotes. Like is the te≈øtimonie of their Bishops in their Theater, their fir≈øt Archbishop in his Antiquities, their Bishop in his Catalogue of writers, their cheife Antiquaries Camden, Harri≈øon, Holinshed, Stowe, Howes, Powel and others, neyther doth any hi≈øtorie or Antiquitie to my reading and memory make mention of any other. Therefore if we ioyne this to that, which the≈øe Prote≈øtant Ma≈øters Godwyn ≈øupr. pag. 2. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. c. 9. Bal. praef. in l. de ≈øcrip. Parker. antiquit. Britan. pag. 2. Camden in Britan. Harri≈øon de≈øcript. of Britan. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Engl. Stowe and Howes hi≈øtor. Powel annot. in Girald. Cambr. haue taught vs in the precedent Chapter: That this Nation receaued the faith by an Apo≈øtle either in the time of Tiberius or Claudius, this que≈øtion is ≈øoone decided, for it will euidently appeare vnto all men, not wilfully blinded with malice, or vnexcu≈øable ignorance, that by the≈øe Prote≈øtants owne Rules, and directions in this matter, it could onely be S. Peter who fir≈øt taught the faith of Chri≈øt in this kingdome; and heare in≈øtituted vnto vs, our Hierarchicall Order, and Succe≈ø≈øion of holy Bishops, and Prei≈øts, in the≈øe later neuer yet interrupted, and for ≈øacred Bishops neuer vntill the late vnhappy times of Queene Elizabeth.

2. Concerning S. Paul one of the onely three ≈øuppo≈øed to haue preached, he could not po≈ø≈øibly be the fir≈øt Apo≈øtle, that came, or ≈øent preachers hither. For no Prote≈øtant or other bringeth him neare vnto the≈øe we≈øterne Nations, vntill diuers yeares within the Reigne of Nero. The Theater writers S. Peter preached heare fir≈øt. Our Epi≈øcopall Hierarchie in≈øtituted by him, did ‚Ä¢ ontinu ‚Ä¢ without interruption, vntill Queene Elizabeth her Prote≈øtant per≈øecution, and his Prei≈øtly order neuer interrupted ≈øtill continueth. ≈øay, it was the tenth yeare of Nero, which was the 64. yeare of Chri≈øt, before S. Paul came to the we≈øt. But though the≈øe Prote≈øtants (to take no aduantage of their errour) are deceaued in ≈øome few yeares of that his trauayles, yet the holy ≈øcriptures with all writers, Prote≈øtants and others, are ample witne≈ø≈øes, that diuers yeares of Nero his Empire were pa≈øt, before he came to Rome, the fir≈øt we≈øterne place he re≈øted in, and then a Pri≈øonner two yeares togeather. So he could not po≈ø≈øibly be that fir≈øt Apo≈øtle, by who≈øe holy meanes and labours we had many Chri≈øtians of this Nation longe before, in the time of Claudius at the lea≈øt, as the≈øe Prote≈øtants before haue proued, diuers yeares before the beginning of Nero his gouernment. Be≈øides, the≈øe Prote≈øtants doe a≈ø≈øure vs, that Britaine fell in the diui≈øion of the world among the twelue Apo≈øtles, S. Paul could not be the fir≈øt that preached in Britaine. following the auncient Fathers in that matter: of which number S. Paul was not, but extraordinary called to be an Apo≈øtle as S. Barnabas al≈øo was, and in that ≈øence left no ≈øucce≈ø≈øours eyther in this Nation, or els where, to whom we may or can adheare, eyther for a Hierarchicall Succe≈ø≈øion, or Epi≈øt. ad Rom. Act. Apo≈øtol. other matters in Religion. And S. Paul him≈øelfe putteth vs out of all doubt, that he was not pre≈øent with the re≈øt of the holy Apo≈øtles, when this diui≈øion
of the world was made, among them. For longe after that time writing to the Galathians, he ≈øaith: Neyther went I vp to Hieru≈øalem to them, which were Apo≈øtles Galat. cap. 1. v. 17. 18. 19. before me, but I went into Arabia, and returned againe vnto Dama≈øus. Then after three yeares, I went vp to Hieru≈øalem to ≈øee Peter, and abode with him fifteene dayes. But other ef the Apostles ≈øawe I none, ≈øaue Iames the Lords Brother. Thus S. Paul, as our Prote≈øtants by our Kings allowance tran≈ølate him. Therefore mo≈øt certaine it is, he was no partie in this diui≈øion, of which the≈øe Prote≈øtaÃÑts haue thus informed vs, wherein this kingdome of Britaine fell out within the diui≈øion of one of the twelue Apo≈øtles. And except all men of learning, Protete≈øtants and others be deceaued, in teaching that S. Peter fir≈øt conuerted the Romans to the faith of Chri≈øt, S. Paul giueth to him, the honour of that Chri≈øtianitie which the Britans had: for writing to the Romans he ≈øaith, I Rom. 1. v. 8. thanke my God through Ie≈øus Christ for you all, that your faith is ≈øpoaken of throughout the whole world. Therefore except the Romans did not receaue the faith from S. Peter, which no man will, or with any probabilitie, can affirme, or Britaine then was no part of the knowne world, a thing euidently vntrue, being then both knowne, and in a great part ≈øubiect to the Roman Empire. It was neyther S. Paul, nor S. Simon Zelotes, but S. Simon Peter, that eyther by him≈øelf or his holy Di≈øciples fir≈øt preached heare. And this might ≈øuffice in this Que≈øtioÃÑ, but inteÃÑding to make all things coÃÑtrouer≈øed in the≈øe matters vndeniably manife≈øt, I will re≈øerue tho≈øe later labours of S. Paul, which a litle before his death, & not before, he be≈øtowed in this kingdome to their proper place.

3. I will now re≈øolue the doubts of S. Simon Zelotes his pretended preaching in this Iland, and proue euen by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, that he neither preached in this our Britaine, nor neare vnto it. But this was peculiar to S. Peter & his Di≈øciples ≈øent by him. For as the greate Prote≈øtant Antiquary freely confe≈ø≈øeth. If S. Paul was heare, It was after his impri≈øonment the ≈øecond time at Rome Camden. Brit. in Belgae. vnder Nero: po≈øt ≈øecundam Romae incarcerationem. And it could not po≈ø≈øibly be before, the Scriptures them≈øelues giuing warrant thereof. So the Magdeburgian Magdeburg. CeÃÑ tur. 1. l. 2. c. 2. Prote≈øtants with others. Paulum a priore captiuitate Roma dimi≈ø≈øum Britannijs Euangelium praedica≈ø≈øe: that S. Paul preached the Ghospell in Britaine after he was dimi≈ø≈øed from his fir≈øt captiuitie in Rome. Which our English Antiquarie before calleth his ≈øecond impri≈øonment, in re≈øpect of his former impri≈øoning before he came thither. And S. Paul was neither one of the twelue to whom the Math. cap. vlt. v. 19. Marc. c. 16. v. 15. Luc. cap. vlt. v. 47. 48. AcÃÑt. c. 9. c. 11. CoÃÑuer≈øion of the world was fir≈øt committed by Chri≈øt, neither pre≈øent, nor yet con≈øecrated by impo≈øition of hands, when the other Apo≈øtles had made this diui≈øion, as the ≈øcripture witne≈ø≈øeth: And though he was called, Apo≈øtle of the Gentiles, Yet he, after his conuer≈øion, preached with Barnabas vnto the IeÃÑwes onely, vntill in the 13. chapter of the Acts of the Apo≈øtles after this time, as appeareth in tho≈øe their words to the contradicting Iewes: Then Paul and Barnabas waxed bolde, and ≈øaid it was nece≈ø≈øary, that the word of God should first Act. 13. 46. 47. 48. haue bene ≈øpoakeÃÑ to you, but ≈øeeing yea put it fro you, & Iudge your ≈øelues vnworthie of euerlasting life, loe we turne to the GeÃÑtiles. For ≈øo hath the Lord coÃÑmaunded vs, ≈øaying, I≈ø. 49. v. 6. I haue ≈øet thee to be a light of the Gentiles, that thou shoulde≈øt be for ≈øaluatioÃÑ vnto the ends of the earth. And wheÃÑ the GeÃÑtiles heard this, they were glad, & glorified the word of the Lord. And the word of the Lord was published throughout all the RegioÃÑ. And fal≈øe it is, which our English Prote≈øtaÃÑts in their Theater ≈øay: that huge multitudes of Theater of Brit. l. 6. c. 9. ¬ß. 5. Act. 11. v. 19. Chri≈øtians disper≈øed them≈øelues into all parts of the world vpon the martyring of S. Stephen at Hieru≈øalem. For we are warranted by the ≈øcripture it ≈øelfe, that the≈øe preached onely to the Iewes. The words of our Prote≈øtants Tran≈ølation are
The≈øe: They which were ≈øcattered abrode vpon the per≈øecution, that aro≈øe about Steuen, trauailed as farre as: Phenice, and Cyprus, and Antioch, preaching the word to none, but vnto the Iewes onely. Where the quite contrary of this Prote≈øtant A≈ø≈øertion is euident, out of the Scripture by their owne Tran≈ølation: That neither the whole world as yet, nor the Gentiles were preached vnto, by the≈øe di≈øper≈øed Di≈øciples in that per≈øecution, S. Peter being (as they haue told vs before, & the ≈øcripture al≈øo witne≈ø≈øeth) the fir≈øt of the Apo≈øtles, which preached to the Gentiles.

div.head: THE X. CHAPTER.

argument.p: HOW S. SIMON ZELOTES NEVER PREAched in this our Britaine, euen by the best te≈øtimony of Prote≈øtants, and others: nor any Symon an Apo≈øtle, but S. Simon Peter, and perhaps S. Simon Lepro≈øus, or ≈øainct Nathaniel, by ≈øome called ≈øainct Simon.

div.p: 1. CONCERNING S. Simon Zelotes, one of the twelues Apo≈øtles of our Sauiour, to haue preached here; I finde a Prote≈øtant Antiquarie ≈øo de≈øirous to haue it ≈øo bruted vnto the world, that he careth not what or how many ab≈øurdities he coÃÑmitteth, in ≈øo breife a relatioÃÑ; fir≈øt ≈øuppo≈øing for a thing certaine that S. Philip the Apo≈øtle preached in this Gallila, FrauÃÑce next vnto vs, which wheÃÑ I come to S. Io≈øephs time I will proue to be vtterly vntrue, afterward, imagining his ≈øending S. Willian HarrisoÃÑ de≈øcription of Britaine p. 23. Io≈øeph froÃÑ theÃÑce, more incredible theÃÑ the other, he addeth thus: Hereby it came topa≈ø≈øe that the ≈øaid Philip vpoÃÑ good deliberation did ≈øend Io≈øephus ouer, and with him Simon Zelotes to preach vnto the Britans, and mini≈øter the Sacraments there, according to the rites of the Churches of A≈øia, and Greece. Thus this Prote≈øtant Antiquary, where fir≈øt, whereas all prote≈øtants deny all prioritie of power among the Apo≈øtles, he maketh ≈øainct Simon Zelotes, an Apo≈øtle, equally as ≈øainct Philip was, not onely to be ≈øubiect to ≈øainct Philip, to be ≈øent by him, but al≈øo inferiour to ≈øainct Io≈øeph, probably no Cleargie man, who by all, was cheife≈øt among them, and was ≈øo appointed by him that ≈øent them. Secondly, he maketh S. Simon the Apo≈øtle not onely inferiour to S. Philip the Apo≈øtle, and S. Io≈øeph, but to S. Philip the Deacon; for as a Prote≈øtant Bishop, and Antiquary perceauing the improbabilitie of S. Philip the Apo≈øtle his preaching in our neighbouring Gallia, Fraunce, ≈øaith, and citeth others to the ≈øame purpo≈øe, that it was rather Philip the Euangeli≈øt one of the ≈øeuen Deacons, that preached Godwyn Conu. of Britanie p. 9. ther, and if any Philip ≈øent S. Simon and Io≈øeph from this Fraunce into Britaine it was he. But if the≈øe were no ab≈øurdities, yet this will not helpe vs, in this bu≈øines, but we mu≈øt ≈øtill Appeale to S. Peter, to be the fir≈øt founder of Harri≈øon ≈øupr. our Church in Britaine, where the≈øe Prote≈øtants and this man al≈øo haue told vs there were many Chri≈øtians ≈øoone after the A≈øcen≈øion of Chri≈øt; And yet by this Prote≈øtants coÃÑputation, this fir≈øt ≈øuppo≈øed coming of S. Simon Zelotes with S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia was 30. yeares after; his words be the≈øe: he came ouer into Britaine, about the 64. yeare after Chri≈øt, when the per≈øecution began vnder Nero. Harri≈øon ≈øupr.

2. Therefore we may not relye vpon this holy Apo≈øtle, to be our fir≈øt in≈øtructor, or to haue bene heare at all: Which other Prote≈øtaÃÑts perceauing ≈øpeake more doubtfully hereof. Among whom one a Bishop that would willingly exclude S. Peter, dareth onely to ≈øay: ≈øome thinke, Simon Zelotes to haue bene
one of Io≈øephs companions. So that now we haue not the former warrant, but a thinking of ≈øome, not one named for this matter. And by this man vnprobable Godwyn Conu. of Brit. p. 10. Pag. 11. or vnpo≈ø≈øible that we should re≈øt vpon S. Simon: for he faith froÃÑ Antiquities, that Io≈øeph was the cheife of the company of twelue holy men that came hither in the thirty and one yeare after the Pa≈øsion of our Sauiour. When by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, this kingdome had many Chri≈øtians aboue twenty yeares before. The next to the≈øe shall be their fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury Matthew Parker, who hauing ≈øpoakeÃÑ before of S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia that buried our Sauiour, and came hither in the 63. yeare of Chri≈øt, addeth the≈øe of S. Simon Matth. Parker. Antiquit. Brit. p. 3. Nicephor. l. 2. c. 40. Io. Capg. in Catal. ≈øanct. Angliae. Zelotes: alij Simonem Zelotem in Britanniam-veni≈ø≈øe, & Euangelium primum nuÃÑ cia≈ø≈øe referunt. Quorum verumque verum e≈ø≈øe pote≈øt. Nam Io≈øephi ≈øocij non nominantur, inter quos fui≈ø≈øe Simonem est veri≈øimile: Other Authors report that Simon Zelotes came into Britaine, and fir≈øt preached the gho≈øpell: Both which may be true, for the fellowes of Io≈øeph are not named, among which it is very likely Simon was. And he citeth for his Authours, Nicephorus, & Ioannes Capgrauius, as I haue placed them in the margin. Concerning Nicephorus other Prote≈øtants hereafter shall an≈øweare, that he neither doth, nor can bring S. Simon Zelotes the Apo≈øtle into this our Britaine at all. Yet if it could be ≈øo, not coming hither before the coming of S. Io≈øeph aboue twenty yeares, by the≈øe Prote≈øttaÃÑs before, that Britaine had receaued the faith, It cannot po≈ø≈øibly be true that he fir≈øt preached the faith in this Iland, but that mu≈øt needs by the≈øe meÃÑ be wholy left to S. Peter and his Di≈øciples. For his ≈øecond & other Authour Capgrauius, It is the forgery of this Prote≈øtant Archbishop, for no ≈øuch thing is to be found in him in all his booke, of which this man citeth no place at all, becau≈øe nu≈øquaÃÑ e≈øt. That, he one of the Apo≈øtles, the chiefe≈øt ≈øpirituall man and coÃÑmaunders in the Church of God that euer were in the world should come hither as a nouice and Inferiour vnder S. Io≈øeph the ≈øuperiour of all the Religious meÃÑ that came Antiq. Gla≈øcon. apud Lel. in A≈ø≈øert. Arthur. Capgrau. in S. Io≈øeph. Stowe & Howes hi≈øtor. Camden in Brit. Godwyn. Conuer≈ø. of Brit. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Engl. in Io≈øeph. Michael DraytoÃÑ Poly-Obion. Selden Illu≈øtr. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 5. Menolog. Graec. 6. Idus Maij. Baron. annot. in Martyrol. Rom. in Sanct. Simone Chanan. 28. die Octobr. Camden. in Britannia. Godwyn. Conu. of Britaine p. 2. with him, as all Antiquities & antiquaries, Prote≈øtaÃÑts and others are witne≈ø≈øes is as incredible an ab≈øurditie. And yet all this to no purpo≈øe, if we should be ≈øo ≈øimple to admit them for good congruitie: For by noe po≈ø≈øibilitie could he be the fir≈øt (as before) that preached heare. And if no Chri≈øtianitie had bene knowne heare, which the≈øe Prote≈øtaÃÑts haue already di≈øproued, vntill this time, yet he coming with S. Io≈øeph the Superiour of that holy coÃÑpany, rather S. Io≈øeph then any vnder him, should be ≈øaid to haue fir≈øt preached the Gho≈øpell, and not S. Simon or any other vnder him. An other Prote≈øtant hi≈øtoriaÃÑ citing that very place of Nicephorus, writeth thereof in this manner, Nicephorus writeth in his ≈øecoÃÑd booke, that one Simon Zelotes came likewi≈øe into Britaine, where by that his diminitiue additioÃÑ one, one SimoÃÑ Zelotes, he doth manife≈øtly declare his opinion to be, that this Simon could not be S. Simon the Apo≈øtle, but ≈øome other Simon, as Simon Lepro≈øus, or Nataniel al≈øo called Simon the Di≈øciples of S. Peter that came into the≈øe parts, as diuers French hi≈øtories are witnes. And Camden the greate Antiquary knowing it to be ab≈øurd, that S. SimoÃÑ Zelotes the Apo≈øtle should preach in Britaine, and ≈øo certaine that S. Peter the Apo≈øtle called al≈øo Simon, and mo≈øt zelous in Religion, preached & planted the faith in this Nation, Interpreteth that very place of Nicephorus to be vnder≈øtood of S. Peters preaching heare. An other, a Bishop with Prote≈øtants proueth from Nicephorus him≈øelfe that S. Simon Zelotes had not Britaine in his diui≈øion, but Egypt and Lybia, and he that had Britaine was alius, an other Apo≈øtle different from him, his words be the≈øe: whereas it is deliuered plainely by ≈øondry auncient writers, that Britaine fell in diui≈øion amongst the Apo≈øtles, amongst the re≈øt Nicephorus
hath the≈øe words: AegyptuÃÑ & LybiaÃÑ alius, alius iteÃÑ extremas Oceani Regiones & In≈øulas BritaÃÑnicas fortitus e≈øt. One Apo≈øtle had for his part Egypt & Lybia, al≈øo an other Apo≈øtle had for his lot the extreame RegioÃÑs of the OceaÃÑ, & the Brittish IlaÃÑds.

3. Therefore being euident both by Nicephorus, & the≈øe Prote≈øtants, that it was S. SimoÃÑ Zelotes the Apo≈øtle in their IudgmeÃÑts, which had Egipt & Lybia, allotted vnto him, & he that had the extreame Regions of the OceaÃÑ & the Brittish IlaÃÑds was alius, an other, not S. SimoÃÑ Zelotes thy caÃÑnot po≈ø≈øibly ≈øaye, that he preached heare, but S. SimoÃÑ Bariona Peter: for hauing graÃÑted before, that no other Apo≈øtle, except S. Peter, S. Paul, & S. SimoÃÑ Zelotes are remeÃÑbred in hi≈øtories to haue preached in Britaine, & thus now excluding both S. Paul for a long time, & S. Simon Zelotes for euer, they mu≈øt needs acknowledge, that it was S. Peter that plaÃÑted the faith of Chri≈øt in this NatioÃÑ, which ≈øome of theÃÑ haue before plainely coÃÑfe≈ø≈øed. And the words of Nicephorus fir≈øt obiected, if they were to be vnder≈øtood of S. SimoÃÑ Zelotes, yet they proue nothing for his preaching in this greate Britaine, or neare vnto it: his words be the≈øe: eandem
que doctrinam Nicephor. hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 2. c. 40. Stowe hi≈øt. in Agricola. etiam ad OccideÃÑtalem OceanuÃÑ, In≈øula≈ø
que BritaÃÑnicas perfert. Which a Prote≈øtaÃÑt thus traÃÑ≈ølateth: and the ≈øame doctrine he brought to the OccideÃÑtall OceaÃÑ, & the Iles called Britannie. Where he onely ≈øaith, which is true, that he preached as farre as vnto the we≈øt OceaÃÑ wheÃÑ he was in the we≈øt coÃÑfines of Africk, to which the we≈øt OceaÃÑ is adiaceÃÑt. But he neither ≈øaith, that he brought that doctrine ouer the OceaÃÑ, or preached it in any Brittish IlaÃÑd. Neither doth any hi≈øtory ≈øay, that he did preach either in IrelaÃÑd, Gern≈øey, Ieru≈øey, the Hebrides, Mona, or any other Brittish Ile, that lye betweene Africk & vs, & are more truely called In≈øulae Britannicae, the Brittish Ilands, theÃÑ this, not ≈øo named, but ab≈øolutely Britannia greate Britaine. TheÃÑ, not preaching in any of them, much le≈ø≈øe did he preach in this IlaÃÑd, & much le≈øe was he crucified heare, that kind of death neuer v≈øed by the Britans, yet Dorotheus the cheife≈øt Authour for this matter ≈øaith, he was martyred Doroth. in Synop≈ø. in Britannia, in ≈øome place called Britaine, or rather like to that name as our Prote≈øtants correct him, which two of them doe together in the≈øe words: Stowe. And Howes hi≈øt. in Agricola. Dorotheus, writeth thus: Simon Zelotes pa≈øsing through Mauritania and Africa, preached Chri≈øt, at length was crucified, ≈ølaine, and buried in Britaine, or rather Bithania. where it is euident, they deny his being heare, but rather in ≈øome place of like name. Which may ea≈øily be proued out of Dorotheus him≈øelfe, who directly teacheth, that S. Ari≈øtobulus one of the 72. Di≈øciples, & Di≈øciple of S. Peter, (as hereafter) was Bishop of Britaine ab≈øolutely, which he neither would, nor truely could haue ≈øaid, if ≈øuch an Apo≈øtle had preached, & bene martyred, & con≈øequeÃÑtly bene Bishop in this Britaine. For it will euideÃÑtly appeare in the Doroth. ≈øupr. in Ari≈øtobulo. due place hereafter, euen by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, that S. Ari≈øtobulus was a Bishop heare longe before the time they haue a≈ø≈øigned to S. SimoÃÑ Zelotes, & coÃÑtinued heare loÃÑge time after his death. And greate ingratitude it had bene both of the Brittish, and Saxon Chri≈øtians, If ≈øo renowned an Apo≈øtle of Chri≈øt, one of the twelue, had both preached, and bene martyred heare, and as a late writer without Author. of the Engl. martyrologe 28. Octobr. pag. 296. any Authoritie ≈øeemeth to thinke, ordeined Prei≈øts, and Deacons, erected Churches, and the like, if noe monument had bene kept thereof, no Church, no Chappell, no altar erected to his honor, & memory, wheÃÑ we fee it farre otherwi≈øe in all Nations, where any Apo≈øtle preached, and ≈øuffered martyrdome. And in this kingdome where S. Peter onely preached, & dyed not, we ≈øee the mo≈øt auÃÑcient Churches of this laÃÑd, except to the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary, were dedicated vnto him in our fir≈øt publike receauing of chri≈øtiaÃÑ ReligioÃÑ, as tho≈øe two in LondoÃÑ S. Peters Church at we≈øtmin≈øter, & in Cornhill in King Lucius time,
are witnes. So we euer kept vnuiolably, & with honor the memories of S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, S. Amphibalus, ≈øainct Alban, S. Aaron, Iulius and others. Martyrol. Rom. 28. die Octobr. Ado. Et V≈øuard. eodem die. Engl. Martyrologe 28. Octobr. Beda Martyrol. 28. Octob. all auncient CaleÃÑd. Breuia. Rom. in fe≈øto S. Simonis Chan. 28. die Octobr. Prote≈øtant CoÃÑm. booke die 28. Octobr. in the ≈øeru. of S. Simon and in Calendar. 28. Octobr. Menolog. Graec. 6. Id. Maij. Baron. annot. in Martyrol. Rom. 28. Octobr. Venantius Fortunat. l. 8. c. 4. Magdeburgen. Anton. part. 1. titul. 6. ca. 28. ¬ß. 3. Petr. de Natal. l. 4. c. 105. Guliel. Ei≈øengr. Centen. 1. part. 6. di≈øt. 6. Vincent. in ≈øpecul. Sabellic. En. 7. lib. 4. Magdeburg. 4. But all our hi≈øtorians of Antiquitie printed, & Manu≈øcripts, which I haue ≈øeene, many, both of our Brittans and Saxons agree with the whole Latine Church, with all Martyrologes, that be auncient, as that of the Romans, Ado, V≈øuardus, and others, that: Natalis Beatorum Apo≈øtolorum Simonis Chananaei, & Thadaei qui & Iudas dicitur: Quorum Simon in Aegypto Thadae√ºs in Me≈øopotamia Euangelium praedicauit, deinde in Pre≈øidem ≈øimul ingre≈øsi, cum innumeram gentis illius multitudinem Chri≈øti ≈øubdidi≈ø≈øent martyrium con≈øummarunt. The natiuitie (≈øo the Church nameth the happy Martyrdome and death of Saints) of the ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtles, Simon of Chananee, and Thadaeus who is called Iudas the 28. day of October: of the which Simon preached the ghospell in Egypt, Thadaeus in Me≈øopotamia, then entering together into Per≈øia, when they had made an innumerable multitude of that Nation ≈øubiect to Chri≈øt, they con≈øummated martyrdome. So hath S. Bede in his Martyrologe: ≈øo haue all auncient Calenders of Britans and Saxons. So hath the whole Latine Church in the fe≈øtiuitie of this holy Apo≈øtle, & to bind all English Chri≈øtians, as well Catholiks by the Rules before, as Prote≈øtants by the commaunding ≈øquares of their Religion, the Parlament, and their CoÃÑ munion Booke, they all celebrate with the Latine Church the fe≈øtiuitie of this glorious Apo≈øtle vpon the 28. of October, when he ≈øuffered martyrdome as before with S. Iudas in Per≈øia. When they which hold, he came into Britaine, keepe his day vpon the ≈øixt of the Ides of May, the tenth day of that moneth.

5. And this is the auncient opinion of the fathers, concerning this holy Apo≈øtle, that he with S. Iude was martyred in Per≈øia, among whom Venantius Fortunatus ≈øo renowned among our Prote≈øtants, for S. Pauls preaching heare, hath made it publike to the world, thus te≈øtifying that he was martyred in Per≈øia with S. Iudas, neuer bringing him neare vnto this Nation.

q.l: Hinc Simonem, ac Iudam lumen Per≈øida gemellum,
Laeta relaxato mittit ad a≈øtra ≈øinu.

div.p:
And to ioyne forraing Prote≈øtants with the≈øe of EnglaÃÑd, in this bu≈øines, The Mardeburgians ≈øay plainely, that if Nicephorus doth ≈øay, that S. Simon preached the gho≈øpell to the OccideÃÑtall Ocean, & Brittish Ilands, he doth it without any certaine te≈øtimony. Narrat, ≈øed ≈øine certo testimonio Nicephorus, EuangeliuÃÑ Simonem propaga≈ø≈øe per regiones ad Occidentalem OceanuÃÑ ≈øitas & In≈øulas Britannicas. Where they be ≈øo farre from allowing his coming to the≈øe Ilands, that they accompt his preaching in the Contryes neare the we≈øt Ocean vnprobable, and make him to be liuing in the Ea≈øt Countries, and preaching, & there ending his life, 50. yeares after this Iland had receaued the faith of Chri≈øt by the≈øe Prote≈øtants before. And Crato the Di≈øciple of the≈øe two Apo≈øtles S. Simon, and Iudas followed them throughout 12. Prouinces of Per≈øia, writing all they did and ≈øuffered there, by the ≈øpace of 13. yeares; the like hath Abdias. The like hath Antoninus, Petrus de Natalibus, Ei≈øengrenius and others. Their liues al≈øo in the ≈øame manner were writteÃÑ by Eutropius a Per≈øian ≈øonne of Adimundus Xerxes King of Babylon, both in the Chaldy and Greeke tonges. To the≈øe I add Vincentius, Sabellicus, the Magdeburgian Prote≈øtants of Germany in their Centuries, S. I≈øidor, or who≈øoeuer the auncient author of the booke of the life and death of the Apo≈øtles, who ≈øaith be≈øides, iacet in Bo≈øphoro, that he is buried in Bo≈øphorus, And died many yeares after his ≈øuppo≈øed death in Britaine. The like hath al≈øo Hartmannus Schedel, teaching, that he both preached, and ≈øuffered martyrdome in Per≈øia, al≈øo Dorotheus, that auncieÃÑt Greeke
father him≈øelfe, that is alledged, to ≈øay, that S. Simon the Apo≈øtle was crucified‚ñ™ killed, and buried in Britaine: in Britannia crucifixus, occi≈øus, ac ≈øepultus e≈øt, the greate≈øt authoritie for his being heare, is coÃÑtrary to him≈øelfe, if ≈øo he should meane of this our Britaine, for in the ≈øame place he maketh S. SimoÃÑ the Apo≈øtle to haue bene crucified in the Ea≈øt CouÃÑtry in, or neare Egypt. cruci alligatus, occi≈øus est in O≈øtracina ciuitate Aegypti: & maketh S. Simon the Apo≈øtle Bishop of Hieru≈øalem, & ≈øo neuer to come neare vnto Britaine. So ≈ømall is his Authoritie in the matter. The Authour of Fa≈øciculus temporum ≈øaith, he was martyred in Per≈øia Fa≈øciculus temp: an. 74. with S. Iude. Simon & Iudas martyri≈øati ≈øunt in regionibus Per≈øidis. The auncient Anonymus that writeth the liues of the Apo≈øtles published by Frediricus Nau≈øea, Bishop of Vienna, ≈øaith, that S. Simon & Iudas were ≈øent, by reuelation into Anonymus in vit. & pa≈ø≈øione SS. Apo≈øtolorum Apo≈øtolorum Simonis & Iude. Per≈øia, to confouÃÑd the wicked Sorcerers, Zaroes, and Arfaxard which had fled thither from S. Matthew the Apo≈øtle in Ethiopia, and the Prince of Per≈øia was then named Baradach, that they had many Di≈øciples there, of which they ordeyned Prei≈øts, DeacoÃÑs and other Clergy men, that in one yeare they baptized aboue fourty thou≈øands be≈øides children, and the King him≈øelfe, that they ordeined Abdias Bishop of Babilon, that came with them from iury. That Craton their Di≈øciple wrote their liues, which Iulius Africanus tran≈ølated into Latine, and after many miracles there wrought, they were there martyred togeather with S. Sennes by whome they were harboured. So that if we will beleeue either auncient, or later, Greeke or Latine, or the Per≈øians them≈øelues, Catholiks, or Prote≈øtants, or any thinge, that can be preteÃÑded for authoritie, worthie to be followed in this matter, S. Simon the Apo≈øtle was neither crucified, killed, buried or preached in or neare vnto this Nation.

6. Wherefore I cannot in any wi≈øe giue allowance vnto him, who not onely placeth him among the ≈øaints and Apo≈øtles of Britaine, but citeth diuers auncient writers (as he ≈øaith) for this his relation. In Per≈øia the Pa≈øsion of the gloroius Apo≈øtle S. Simon, ≈øurnamed Zelotes, who according to diuers auncient writers, among
The Authour of the English Marty rologe printed ann. 1608. 28. Octobr his greate mi≈øtaking authorities.
other his PeregrinatioÃÑs came into our IlaÃÑd of Britany, about the yeare of Chri≈øt fourty and ≈øixe, and there preached the Chri≈øtian faith, baptized, ordeined Prei≈øts, & DeacoÃÑs, erected Churches and the like, whereby we may worthely call him our Apo≈øtle, and with greater ≈øolemnitie celebrate his fea≈øt, by whom we receaued ≈øo ≈øingular graces & benefites. He afterward went into Per≈øia with S. Iude to preach the Chri≈øtiaÃÑ faith to the infidels of that Country, where at la≈øt he receaued the reward of his labours by martyrdome, Nicephor. l. 2. c. 40. Pol. Vir. l. 7. hi≈øt. We≈øt. ann. 636. & 652. Dor. in Synop≈øi. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 125. being nayled to a cro≈ø≈øe: though Dorotheus writeth, that he ≈øuffered and was buried in Britany. Hitherto this Authour, and he citeth for his warrant, as I haue placed theÃÑ in the Margin, Nicephorus, Polidor Virgil, Matthew We≈øtmin≈øter, & Dorotheus. Of all which not any one affirmeth the≈øe things. Matthew We≈øtmin≈øter & Poildor Vergil doe not ≈øo much as name S. Simon the Apo≈øtle, except Matthew We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øaith he was Bishop of Hieru≈øalem next after S. Iames. Dorotheus doth not ≈øay that S. Simon the Apo≈øtle was either crucified or at all in Per≈øia, neither doth Nicephorus, neither doth any of the≈øe or any other ≈øay that S. SimoÃÑ was heare about the yeare of Chri≈øt 46. neither caÃÑ that po≈ø≈øibly be true by any coÃÑputation, for by the vndeniable te≈øtimonies of many auncieÃÑt Fathers he was preseÃÑt with other of the Apo≈øtles at the death of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin in the ≈øame yeare or 45. & yet by Nicephorus, & all that ≈øeeme to thinke Matth. We≈øtm. an. 45. Dorotheus in Synop. Niceph. l. 2. c. 40. loc. cit. he was in Britaine, he preached both through Mauritania & all Afrike, therefore noe being for him in Britaine at that time, & Nicephorus maketh it more vnpo≈ø≈øible ≈øaying he trauailed through Egypt and Africk, theÃÑ through Mauritania and all Lybia preaching the gho≈øpell. And the ≈øame doctrine he brought to the Occid ‚Ä¢ ntall Ocean. Which all Co≈ømographers know not to be that part of the Otean,
which is next vnto vs, vpoÃÑ the co≈øte of Afrike, for Britaine froÃÑ thence is in the Boreale, & North Ocean, the Occidentall OceaÃÑ of Afrike is that which is next to the A≈øores, & Chanary Ilands & others exteÃÑding towards America, Which ≈øeemeth to haue bene that which deceaued Nicephorus, if he though Abrah. Ortel. in typo. Orbis & Africae de≈øcript. Ptolom. Bilibald Pirckeymher. & lij in Afric. Stephan. v. Brit. I≈øac. in Lymphr. S. SimoÃÑ came froÃÑ the we≈øt Ocean to the Brittish IlaÃÑds, taking perhaps all tho≈øe IlaÃÑds to be coÃÑprehended vnder that name. But more probable it is, that the Britannia, to which S. Simon went (if to any) or was put to death in, is the Britannia, in the Ea≈øt Country, neare vnto Per≈øia. For I≈øacius is witnes that of ould there were three Britaines, this which we inhabit, a ≈øecond about Thyle, now I≈øland, & a third in the Ea≈øte, which is mo≈øt like to be that which Dorotheus & Nicephorus meane in this matter. Or if we will ≈øay, that S. SimoÃÑ went froÃÑ the we≈øt coa≈øt & Ocean of Afrike vnto Per≈øia, if he pa≈ø≈øed by the MediterreÃÑ & Adriake ≈øea, which was his ea≈øie≈øt iorney going by Iury, as he did, he pa≈ø≈øed by Britannis, or Britannia an Iland in the Adriacke Sea, called by ≈øome Elaphu≈øa, Stephanus. v. Brettotia, Brettannis. or Elaphites, 12. myles from Malta, by Pliny. And that there was an other Britania, or BritaÃÑnis, in the ≈øame pa≈ø≈øadge betweene Afrike & Italy, is te≈øtified by our English Prote≈øtants in their Theater, who cite Polybius for Authour, (that Speed Theater. l. 5. c. 4. Polyb. Eglog. l. 10. 11. 42. Camden in Brit. Theater l. 5. c. 1. ¬ß. 11. Claudius Ptolomaeus in Geograph. Seba≈øt. Mun≈øter. in Co≈ømograph. Bilibald. Pirck-emher. in Ptolom. Abrah. Ortelius in Theatro Orbis. Rich. Hackluyt trauails of English. &c. I≈øidor. l. de vi ‚Ä¢ a & morte Sancto
‚Ä¢ um in S. Simone. Harris Hi≈øt. Ecc. of Britaine to. 1. M. S. HaÃÑnibal was inclo≈øed within the ≈øtreights of Britaine) which mu≈øt needs be about Italy, neare Afrike, & not out of his iorney by Sea to Iury, & Per≈øia, wheÃÑ if he had come by our Britaine, to goe thither, he should either haue returned the ≈øame way againe, or compa≈ø≈øed the greate≈øt part of the whole coÃÑtinent, & pa≈ø≈øed the frozen ≈øeas, by the North pole, which way no man is remeÃÑbred and knowne to haue gone at that time: & yet vncertaine, whether pa≈ø≈øable or no; & after his laÃÑding he had mo≈øt va≈øt, and Barbarous CouÃÑtries, to trauaile through, where no man writeth he euer was, before he could come to Per≈øia, as all Co≈ømographers, auncient, & late are witne≈ø≈øes: wheÃÑ pa≈ø≈øing by the other Britaine, or British IlaÃÑds, he had a short, & ready Iorney by ≈øea, & by laÃÑd to trauaile onely through Iury, or Syria to Per≈øia, & tho≈øe CouÃÑtries there, where the≈øe Prote≈øtaÃÑts & others tell vs, he preached, liued loÃÑg, & was put to death. This was his trauaile by laÃÑd, as we haue heard before froÃÑ ≈øuch as wrote the life of that holy Apo≈øtle. And, that was the part, which fell vnto him, as S. I≈øidore & others affirme, when the Apo≈øtles diuided the world among theÃÑ to preach the Gho≈øpell in.

div.head: THE XI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN DIVERS PROTESTANTS INclyne to thinke S. Peter preached heare in Britaine, before his coming to Rome: and what probabilitie that opinion hath.

div.p: 1. DIVERS English Prote≈øtant writers (whether for loue to S. Peter, or di≈ø≈øick to Rome) knowing what great warrant ther is, for ≈øainct Peters preaching heare, incline to affirme it to haue bene before he came to Rome. Amonge whome the THEATER WRITERS producing diuers te≈øtimonies Theater of great Britaine l. 9. c. 9. ¬ß. 5. for his being in Britaine, they add: If Peter were heare at all, It was before he went to Rome, and that the Ghospell was preached heare, before it was in Rome, if Peter were the first, as ≈øome hold, that preached there: both Diuers English Prote≈øtants incline to thinke, S. Peter preached in Britaine, before he came to Rome: and how probably. which may be more probable, if we con≈øider the huge multitudes of Chri≈øtians, fifteen thou≈øand, ≈øaith Baronius, which disper≈øed them≈øelues, into all parts of the worlde, Vpon the martyring of S. Stephen at Hieru≈øalem. Where we ≈øee that they make the coming of S. Peter into this our Nation, to haue beene ≈øo ≈øoone after the A≈øcen≈øion of Chri≈øt, that they ≈øeeme to ≈øuppo≈øe it to haue beene before his coming to Rome, and make it the more probable opinion (their owne phra≈øe) that it was ≈øoone after the Martyrdome of S. Stephen, which was to ≈øpeake in their owne words, pre≈øently vpon the death of Chri≈øt: which was diuers Theater ≈øupr. yeares before any Authoritie teacheth, he came to Rome. And their opinion before, that Britaine receaued the faith in the time of Tyberius will make theÃÑ of that minde, being before proued that S. Peter was the fir≈øt Apo≈øtle that preached heare. For which, they bring his owne te≈øtimony to S. Brithwald, and other te≈øtimonies. And that which is written before, of S. Man≈øuetus a Bishop of this Nation, ≈øent to Toul in Lorraine by S. Peter in the time of Caius Caligula, giueth ≈øome allowance to this opinion, if we will followe tho≈øe Hi≈øtorians, which write, he was ≈øent thither at that time in the yeare of Chri≈øt 40. making it not vnprobable, but he was ≈øent from S. Peter being in, or neare this Iland.

2. The like I may ≈øay of S. Ari≈øtobulus made Bishop, as William Ei≈øengrenius ≈øaith, in the yeare of Chri≈øt 39. who as commonly Prote≈øtants will tell vs hereafter, was our Bishop heare in Britaine: and this the rather becau≈øe we Guliel. Ei≈øengr. Centenar. 1. part. 1. di≈øt. 7. fo. 67. 66 & di≈øt. 8. Sophron. Patria. Hiero≈øol. l. delabor. S. Petr. & Paul. finde that about the ≈øame time, and in the ≈øame yeare, (if we may beleeue this Author) the ≈øame holy Apo≈øtle S. Peter placed S. Pancratius Bishop of Tauronienium, and ≈øainct Marcianus Bishop of Syrocufa in the Iland of Sicilia neare vnto Italie: and diuers others farre di≈øtant from Hieru≈øalem, Antioch, or any Ea≈øterne place of the aboade of that greate Apo≈øtle, as S. Clement with diuers others into the hither parts of Germany, as the antiquities of tho≈øe places are witne≈ø≈øe. And if we call to memory the vn≈øpakeable labours, and expedition v≈øed by this Apo≈øtle, in ≈øuch ≈øacred a bu≈øines before remembred, & how in that time he is ≈øaid to remaine at Antioch, he vi≈øited, as the Scripture is euidence, Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, A≈øia and Bithynia, the hither partes Petr. 1. v. 1. of A≈øia: from whence we shall not finde it a more difficult iorney for that renowned Apo≈øtle, to vouch ≈øafe to vi≈øite this Iland of Britaine, if we con≈øult with Co≈ømographers in the≈øe affaires, then to come from Antioch in Syria
the cheife place of his re≈øidency at that time, to vi≈øit all tho≈øe Contries related, in which he preached as the Scriptures a≈ø≈øure vs. But the≈øe be but coniectures, vpon which I may not found an Hi≈øtoriall Narration, e≈øpecially when we haue a whole world of witne≈ø≈øes to the contrary, that Rome was the fir≈øt place in the we≈øt, whether S. Peter came, and was cheifly directed vnto. And S. Peter came to Rome before he came into Britaine the cheife≈øt rea≈øon of the di≈øper≈øion of the Di≈øciples at the martyrdome of S. Stephan, is before an≈øwered how they preached onely to the Iewes. And the Scripture is manife≈øt that the Apo≈øtles were then at Hieru≈øalem (except the Apo≈øtles) and not di≈øper≈øed. And the hi≈øtory of the Acts of the Apo≈øtles keepeth Act. c. 8. v. 1. S. Peter preaching in the Ea≈øt, Ionge after this to the Iewes and Gentiles, vntill ≈øuch time in the dayes of Claudius Emperour, it plea≈øed Chri≈øt our ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour, as many and greate Authorities doe warrant vs, to ≈øend and direct this his cheife≈øt Apo≈øtle to make a great parte of his Re≈øidencie at Rome, the greate and commaunding Imperiall Citte, at that time in the world, that he might the better by that meanes, preach the Gho≈øpell both by him≈øelfe, S. Peters ≈øeating him≈øelfe at Rome, foretold by holy ≈øcripture, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ bbins, and Sibils, before Christ. and his Di≈øciples, to the≈øe We≈øterne Nations, and Contries of the world.

3. Of this mi≈ø≈øion of S. Peter to Rome E≈øay the Prophet though in more generall termes had longe before admonished, ≈øaying, (as I haue alledged before,) that God would ≈øend of his Apo≈øtles into Italy. Of this the auncient Rabbins before Chri≈øt were witne≈ø≈øes, as a Iewe him≈øelfe hath proued again≈øt the Iewes, that Rome should be the cheife place of the Lawe and Religion of the Me≈ø≈øias. Sybilla Erythraea longe time before preached this Hieronymus √† ≈øanct. fide l. contra Iudaeos. Sybill. Erithaer. in l. Na≈øalographi 1. Imperial. Scrip. Venetijs an. 1516 per Patriarch. Venet. approbat. & Pontif. Rom. to the Gentiles, when Prophe≈øying of Chri≈øt and his twelue Apo≈øtles, thus she foretolde: in vltima aetate humiliabitur Deus, & humiliabitur proles diuina. Iungetur humanitati deitas: iacebit in faeno agnus: puellari officio educabitur Deus & homo. Eliget ≈øibi ex pi≈øcatoribus, & deiectis numerum duodenarium, vnumque diabolum, non in gladio bellou√® Eneadem vrbem Rege≈øque ≈øubijciet, ≈øed in hamo pi≈øcantis, in deiectione & pauperie ≈øuperabit diuitias: ≈øuperbiam conculcabit morte propria: nocturno ≈øu≈øcitabit & commutabitur: viuet & regnabit & con≈øummabuntur haec omnia, fietque regeneratio. Vltimo bonos iudicabit & malos. Surget ≈øtella mirabilis: Danaos illuminabit: orbem illu≈øtrabit. In Eneadem latus pi≈øcatoris nomen agni v≈øque ad fines ≈øeculi virtute perducet: Inde in Eneade iuncta, vinctos √† diabolo liberabi ‚Ä¢ : In the la≈øte age God will be humbled, and the ≈øonne of God will be humbled: the lambe shall lye in Hay: God and man shall be brought vp by a virgin ≈øeruice: he shall chu≈øe vnto him out of fishers and meane per≈øons, a number of twelue, & one of them a deuill. He shall make ≈øubiect vnto him the citie of Aeneas, Rome, & Kings, not by ≈øworde & warre, but by the hooke of a fisher; in deiection & pouertie he shall ouercome Riches; he shall treade downe pryde with his owne death. He shall rai≈øe him≈øelfe in the night time, & shall be chaÃÑged: he shall liue and Reigne, and all the≈øe things shall be brought to pa≈ø≈øe, and there shall be a regeration; at the la≈øt he shall iudge the good and the euill. A meruaylous ≈øtarre shall ari≈øe, it shall illuminate the Greekes, & Illu≈øtrate the world. The ≈øide of the fisher shall by power bring the name of the lambe into the citie of Rome vnto the end of the world. From thence Rome ioyned vnto him, he shall deliuer the bounde from the deuill. Hitherto the words of that Sybilla in the time of Priamus writteÃÑ in the Chaldy tonge, and tran≈ølated into Greeke, and being founde in the Tre≈øury of Emmanuel, Eugenius King of Sicily tran≈ølated it into Latine, and was published by the Patriarke of Venice with great priuiledge, before the reuolt of Luther or deniall of the Popes iuri≈ødiction. Like is the te≈øtimony both of Catholiks and Prote≈øtants in this matter. And both the auncient Fathers, as S. Augu≈øtin, Lactantius,
with others and the Church of God it ≈øelfe longe ≈øince ioyning the Seba≈øtian. MuÃÑ≈øt. Co≈ømograph. l. 2 p. 208. Hertm. Shedel. Mag. Chron. aerate 3. f. 35. Aug. l. 18. de ciuit. Dei. Lact. offic. Defunct. in hymno. Aug. ≈øup. c. 21. & to. 6. concione ad Catechum. & in ep. ad Rom. & l. ciu. 18. cap. 45. Eu≈ø. praep. Euang. Magdeburg. ceÃÑt. 1. Clem. Rom. epi≈øt. 1. Con≈øtant. Mag. in decret. S. Sylu. apud Gennad. Patriarch. Con≈øtant. ≈øect. 3. pro Concilio Flor. Abb. Vr≈øperg. apud Ei≈øengr. ceÃÑt. 1. fol. 123. Marcell. epi≈øt. 1. ad Epi≈øc. Antioc. S. Leo ≈øerm. 1. de Natal. Apo≈øtol. Petr. & Pauli. S. Sim. Metaphr. in vit. Petr. prophe≈øies of the Sybils, with tho≈øe of the Prophet Dauid t ‚Ä¢ ≈øte Dauid in Sybilla, giue te≈øtimony vnto this.

4. S. Clement him≈øelfe both Di≈øciple and Succe≈ø≈øor to S. Peter, ≈øaith of him, that he was commaunded by Chri≈øt, as the more potent, amonge the Apostls to come to Rome and illuminate the we≈øt, the more darke part of the world. Qui ob≈øcurioreÃÑ mundi plagam occideÃÑtis velut omnium potentior, illuminare praeceptus e≈øt, quique & integr√® potuit implere praeceptum. And CoÃÑ≈øtantine the great, Emperour, our Renowned King, and Contryman thus witne≈ø≈øeth: That the ≈øee of Rome hath primacy and Principalitie in matters of Religion, becau≈øe our holy lawe maker, and Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt ≈øent S. Peter thither, and coÃÑmaunded him to hold his Chaire there, and there he was put to death: AequuÃÑ e≈øt enim, vt ibi diuina lex obtineat apicem & principatum, vbi ≈øanctus legi≈ølator Ie≈øus Chri≈øtus Saluator no≈øter, mi≈ø≈øo Beato Petro iu≈øsit Cathedram tenere, & vbi patibuluÃÑ pa≈ø≈øus e≈øt. Abbas Vr≈øpergen≈øis ≈øaith, that Chri≈øt coÃÑ maunded S. Peter to come to Rome. Aduentus Petri in Romam primi, fuit praeceptuÃÑ Chri≈øti iubentis. S. Marcellinus to the AntiochiaÃÑs ≈øaith: that his See was fir≈øt with them, but by the coÃÑmaundement of Chri≈øt, It was traÃÑ≈ølated to Rome. S. Leo ≈øaith, that S. Peter Prince of the Apo≈øtolike order, was ≈øent to Rome, the chife≈øt place of the Roman Empire: beati≈øsimus Petrus, Princeps Apo≈øtolici ordinis, ad arceÃÑ Romani de≈øtinatur Imperij. And to conclude this matter, S. Simeon Metaphra≈øtes is a witne≈ø≈øe, that S. Peter coming from his Ea≈øterne Trauailes to Hieru≈øalem, Chri≈øt appeared in a vi≈øion, and ≈øaid vnto him: Ari≈øe Peter, goe to the west, for it hath need to be lightned with thy torches, and I will be with thee: reuer≈øus e≈øt Hiero≈øolymam, vi≈øus e≈øt autem ei Dominus in vi≈øione dicens, ≈øurge Petre, vade ad occidentem, opus enim habet vt tuis illu≈øtretur facibus, & ego ero tecum. Which is ≈øufficiently in≈øinuated by our renowned Contrimen Florentius Wigornien≈øis, and Marianus Scotus as they are published by Prote≈øtants: The fir≈øt ≈øaith of S. Peter was ≈øent to Rome: Romam mittitur. The other ≈øaith, it was ≈øuperna vi≈øione ordinante: by the ordinance of an heauenly vi≈øion. And diuers Catholiks and Prote≈øtants ≈øay: omnem occidentalem plagam ≈øuo ≈øpecialiter Apo≈øtolatui de≈øtinatam. That all S. Peter directed by Chri≈øt to all the we≈øteren NatioÃÑs, as Britaine and others. the we≈øterne Nations were de≈øigned to S. Peters Apo≈øtleship.

5. Whereby it is manife≈øt, that S. Peter was not onely ≈øent by Chri≈øt, to the Imperiall Citie of Rome, and Italy, but vnto all the Occidentall Nations, whether vnder the Romane Empire then or noe; for the Empire and kingdome of Chri≈øt euen on earth, his holy Church, was not to be confined within Flor. Wigorn. an. 2. Claudij. Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. in Nerone. M. S. apud Lipp. 14. Sep. Franc. Burgoing. hi≈øtor. Eccl. l. 2. 3. 4. 5. Stow. hi≈øt. p. 34. edit. an. 1614. Mere des hi≈øt. aetat. 6. f. 22. c. 13. the limits of any terrene, or earthly Empire of what Nation ≈øoeuer: But the whole world was giuen to Chri≈øt for his Inheritance. And the then Emperiall Citie of Rome, though a commaunding place, to the va≈øte & mightie Pagan Empire, at that time, yet by the coming of Sainct Peter, his liuing, preaching, dying, and ≈øetling the highe≈øt powerable Apo≈øtolike See, and Chaire there, it was made not the heade of the worldly Empire, that was greate, but the heade of the whole world in the cheife≈øt affaires of men, without re≈øtriction, or limitation of either time, or place; As ≈øaith S. Leo that holy and learned Pope of this Roman citie. Vt ciuitas ≈øacerdotalis, & regia, per ≈øacram Beati Petri ≈øedem, caput orbis effecta, latius prae≈øideres religione diuina, quam dominatione terrena: Rome was made by the holy See of S. Peter, a prei≈øtly and Kingly Citie, heade of the world, and to rule further by diuine Religion, then by earthly Regiment. And therefore, as when S. Peter made Antioch the place of his greate≈øt Re≈øidency in the Ea≈øte, he preached to ≈øo many other Nations in that part of the world; ≈øo now being ≈øent to the greate
Imperiall Citie in the we≈øterne parts, he likewi≈øe v≈øed the ≈øame Pa≈øtorall care, labour, and diligence to conuert the we≈øterne Nations, euen tho≈øe, that be mo≈øt remote either from Hieru≈øalem, or Rome, ≈øuch as this kingdome is, for they properly and mo≈øt really are the we≈øterne Contries, and that Occidens: we≈øt, which is ob≈øcurior mundi Plaga: the more ob≈øcure or darke part of the world, for who≈øe lightning ≈øainct Peter was (as ≈øainct Clement before hath witne≈ø≈øed) ≈øent to the≈øe we≈øterne Regions. For how≈øoeuer we will expounde this ob≈øcure plaga of the world in the we≈øt, whether it be for temporall and bodily darkene≈ø≈øe, for the greate di≈øtance from the vi≈øible funne, or darkene≈ø≈øe of minde, growne by barbarous rudene≈ø≈øe, or how≈øoeuer; Rome and Italy are not ≈øo to be termed, neither Fraunce, Spaine, or any Contry betweene Rome, and vs, being all nearer the Southe and Ea≈øte, and accompted ciuill Nations before the preaching of Chri≈øt vnto them. And the Apparition and words of Chri≈øt, vade ad occidentem, goe to the we≈øt, for it hath need to be illuminated by thee, a≈ø≈øureth vs, it was the whole we≈øt part of the world, and not a portion of it onely, that was thus by our ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour commended, and committed to ≈øainct Peter, to be illuminated in the true faith by him. Neyther could the words of the Rabins or Sybils in this matter, be otherwi≈øe performed, in this greate fisher ≈øainct Peter, and his hooke, not onely to ≈øubiect the city of Rome, but Reges, the Kings of the Empire, and we≈øt vnto him; nor Rome be truely termed the cheife≈øt place, or permancy of the Me≈ø≈øias, to rule in all the world, except this his vicegerent, ≈øainct Peter, and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors there by the conuer≈øion of the≈øe nations, vnto Chri≈øt, had effected, and made it ≈øo: As we ≈øee accordingly, as they foretold, this fisher & his hooke haue made the name of Chri≈øt the lambe of God ≈øo glorious in that City, ouer all the world of Chri≈øtians, and v≈øque ad fines ≈øaeculi, and shall ≈øo continue to the end of the world, as that prophe≈øie, agreable with the holy Fathers, and ≈øcriptures them≈øelues, a≈ø≈øureth vs.

6. And if we may beleeue the Prote≈øtant writers, eyther of this, or other nations, they put vs out of all doubt, that ≈øainct Peter both by him≈øelfe, in his owne labours, in the≈øe we≈øterne parts, and Plaga, Quarter of the world, and by his holy and learned di≈øciples mo≈øt diligently performed this office, & charge impo≈øed vpon him. Our English Prote≈øtants are witne≈ø≈øes that the labours & trauailes of S. Peter in preaching in the≈øe CouÃÑtries were ≈øo longe, & painefull, that he did not accomplish them, vntill the foureteenth, the la≈øt yeare of Nero, Ba≈ø≈øus and Tu≈øcus being then Roman Con≈øuls (our Prote≈øtants words) The holy Stowe. and Ed. Howes hi≈øt. of the Romanesan. Dom. 70. in Iul. Agricola. Apo≈øtle S. Peter hauing accomplished his preaching, in the we≈øt parts, returned to Rome, where he preached againe, as he did before. Henricus Pantaleon, a german Prote≈øtant writeth: Cum Diuus Petrus Eccle≈øiam Chri≈øti Romae verbo Dei ≈øalutifero pa≈øceret, non contentus fuit vno in loco gentilium ≈øuper≈øtitiones tollere, & vineam Domini plantare, verumetiam ad alias partes, pios & eruditos viros ≈øuos di≈øcipulos Henricus Pantal. de viris Illu≈øtrib. Germ. parte 1. p. 200. ad an. 55. emi≈øit, qui homines in≈øtruerent: when S. Peter did feede the Church of Chri≈øt at Rome, with the hole≈øome word of God, he was not content, to roote out the ≈øuper≈øtitions of the Gentiles, and plant the vineyard of our Lord in one place, but he ≈øent Godly and learned meÃÑ, his Di≈øciples, to other parts to in≈øtruct the people. What the≈øe were in particular, which he thus ≈øent, and to what parts of the we≈øt he ≈øent them, I shall in ≈øome parte declare hereafter. For this pre≈øent I ≈øpeake in generall Henricus 8. Rex An ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ iae in a≈ø≈øert. 7. Sacram. art. 2. of the≈øe we≈øterne nations: of which al≈øo King Henry the eight in his booke again≈øt Luther writeth: Negare Lutherus non pote≈øt, quin omnis Eccle≈øia fidelium, ≈øacro ≈øanctam ≈øedem Romanam, velut matrem primatemque recogno≈øcat,
ac veneretur, quaecunque ≈øaltem neque locorum di≈øtantia, neque periculis interiacentibus prohibetur acce≈ø≈øu: Luther cannot denie, but euery Church of the faithfull doth acknowledge, and reuerence the holy See of Rome, as their mother and primate, how farre di≈øtant ≈øoeuer it be from it, and daungers betweene them. And Marcus Antonius de Dominis, euen at that time when he mo≈øt profe≈ø≈øed him≈øelfe a Prote≈øtant, Marc. Anton. de Dominis l. 4. ca. 10. de Repub. Chri≈øt. and defendor of our English Prote≈øtants, and mo≈øt earne≈øt again≈øt the ≈øee of Rome, yet thus confe≈ø≈øeth: E≈øt caput Roma, quatenus ab ea diffu≈øum est Euangelium in reliquas totius ocoidentis Eccle≈øias, & in multas Orientis, at que in barbaras etiam extra Romanum Imperium nationes: Rome is the head, becau≈øe from it the Ghospell was diffu≈øed to the re≈øt of the Churches of all the we≈øt, and to many of the east, and to barbarous Nations, euen out of the Romane Empire. Where we ≈øee plainely acknowledged, that all the Churches of this we≈øt part of the world, receaued the faith of Chri≈øt from ≈øainct Peter, and the See of Rome.

7. Wherefore our King Iames in open Parlament publikely pronounced of the Roman Church: It is our mother Church. An other calleth Kinge Iames Speach. in Parl. 1. Ormorod. pict. Pap. pag. 184. it, The eye of the we≈øt. From which this Nation among others mu≈øt needs fir≈øt receaue their ≈øight in Chri≈øt. Neither can any man without a preiudicate minde (con≈øidering what hath beene written before) be of other opinion. Yet we may add much more to that which is already written. As that Arnobius who liued with in the fir≈øt 300. yeares of Chri≈øt, ≈øpeaking of the conuer≈øion of the Gentiles, and ≈øainct Peters preachinge, ≈øaith of him, that Arnob. l. 2. adu. gentes. he preached in In≈øulis atque prouincijs omnibus quas ≈øol Oriens a ‚Ä¢ que Occidens lu≈øtrat: in all Ilands, and prouinces, which the ≈øonne ri≈øing and ≈øetting doth compa≈ø≈øc, all Iles and prouinces in the we≈øt part of the world.
