Michael Singelus ≈øaith of him: Michael Syngelus in Martyrio Dioni≈øij Areop. Regiam vrbem miraculis editis illu≈øtrauit, & occidu ‚Ä¢ m ob≈øcuritatem in splendorem clari≈øsimum commutauit: Peter did make the Kingly city renowned with the miracles he wrought, and chaunged the darkenes of the we≈øt into a mo≈øt bright ≈ølyninge; by which ob≈øcure we≈øt he mu≈øt needs, (to ≈øpeake truely) meane the≈øe furthe≈øt, and mo≈øt we≈øterne parts, as I haue vrged in the like ca≈øe before. Nicephorus ≈øaith of ≈øainct Peter: Petrus per orbem habitabilem vadens, Eccle≈øias vb√Øque con≈øtituit, Nicephor. lib. 2. hi≈øt. c. 35. & Romanam quos ≈øupradiximus Succe≈ø≈øoribus commi≈øit, Lino videlicet, Anacleto, & tertio Clementi: Peter trauayling throughout the inhabited worlds, appointed Churches euery where, and committed the Church of Rome to his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors which we haue named before. Linus, Anacletus (≈øo he calleth Cletus) and Clement the third. And againe: Orbem peragrauit: he trauayled throughout the world. The like haue many others, the number of them is too greate to be recited; all agreing, that after he came to Rome, he con≈øecrated there two Bishops ≈øainct Linus, and Cletus, to ≈øupply the ≈øpirituall needs, in that place, and he him≈øelfe trauayled often to preach in the≈øe we≈øtern Regions, as he did in the Ea≈øte before, when he had his Re≈øidency at Antioch, as the ≈øcripture it≈øelfe, with all, or mo≈øt Antiquities of that bu≈øines are witne≈ø≈øes. And this may ≈øuffice in generall for the labours of that holy Apo≈øtle, in the≈øe we≈øterne parts, ≈øo farre as they coÃÑcerne the Hi≈øtory of this Nation, which we haue in hand. What he performed in particular, in this kinde, and belongeth to the Eccle≈øia≈øticall affaires of Britaine, (≈øo much as the≈øe my Prote≈øtant directors will gi ‚Ä¢ e me leaue) shall immediately appeare.

div.head: THE XII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN IS SHEWED, TO BE THE MOST probable opinion, that S. Peter at his fir≈øt coming to Rome, was receaued there by Britans of this Nation: and who probably they were.

div.p:
1. THE holy and learned auncient Pope ≈øainct Leo, treating of the coming of ≈øainct Peter to Rome for the ≈øettling of his ≈øupreame Apo≈øtolicall power, and preeminency there, and reconciling this we≈øterne part of the world vnto Chri≈øt, writeth in this manner: CuÃÑ duodecim Apo≈øtoli accepta per spirituÃÑ ≈øanctuÃÑ omnium locutione linguarum, imbuendum Euangelio mundum, di≈øtributis ≈øibi terrarum S. Leo ≈øer. 1. de S S. Apo≈øt. Petro & Paulo. partibus ≈øu≈øcepi≈ø≈øent, beati≈øsimus Petrus Princeps Apo≈øtolici ordinis, ad arcem Romani de≈øtinatur Impery, vt lux veritatus, quae in omnium gentium reuelabatur ≈øalutem, officatius ≈øe ab ip≈øo capite per totum mundi corpus effunderet. Cuius autem nation is homines in hac tunc vrbe non e≈ø≈øent, aut quae v≈øquam gentes ignorarent, aut Roma didici≈ø≈øet? I am populos qui ex circumci≈øione crediderant, erudieras: iam Antiochenam Eccle≈øiam, vbi primum Chri≈øtiani nominis dignitas e≈øt orta, fundaueras: I am Galatiam, Cappadociam, A≈øiam, atque Bithyniam legibus Euangelicae praedicationis impleueras: nec vt dubius de prouentu operis, aut de ≈øpatio tuae ignarus aetatis, Trophaeum crucis Chri≈øti Romanis Acibus Inferebas: qu√≤ te diuinis praeordinationibus anteibant, & honor potestatis, & gloria pa≈øsionis: When the twelue Apostles hauing receaued by the holy Ghost, the guift of ≈øpeaking all languages, diuiding the parts of the earth amongst them, had vndertaken to endue the world with the gho≈øpell, most ble≈ø≈øed Peter, Prince of the Apo≈øtolike order, is seÃÑt to the chiefe≈øt place of the RomaÃÑ Empire, That the light of the Truth, which was reuealed for the ≈øaluatioÃÑ of all natioÃÑs, might more effectually diffu≈øe it ≈øelfe, from the heade thereof, to the whole body of the world. For what NatioÃÑ was there, that men thereof were not theÃÑ in this citie, or what Nations in any place could be ignorant of that, which Rome had learned? Now thou (S. Peter) had≈øt instructed the people of the circumci≈øion which had beleeued: Thou hadst already founded the Church of Antioch, where fir≈øt the dignitie of the Chri≈øtian name was ri≈øen: Thou had≈øt already replenished Pontus, Galatia, Cappado ‚Ä¢ ia, A≈øia, and Bithynia with the lawes of preashing the gho≈øpell: neither as doubtfull of the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of thy worke, or ignorant of the ≈øpace of thy age. Thou didst bringe the Trophie of the Cro≈ø≈øe of Christ, to the Roman Towers, whether by the preordination of God, both the honor of thy power, and glory of thy pa≈øsion went before thee. Where we ≈øee, by this mo≈øt learned Pope, (the generall con≈øent of the other holy Fathers, and Antiquitie, concurring with him, in this declaration,) that it was the mercifull preordinance of God, that ≈øeeing the whole world, and in that, the≈øe we≈øterne nations, al≈øo were to be in≈øtructed in the truth, and the number of the Apo≈øtles to performe ≈øo woÃÑderfull a worke, was ≈øo ≈ømall, That Rome theÃÑ being the of the head world, where people of all Nations liued e≈øpecially of the≈øe we≈øterne Regions, and more principally of this kingdome of Britaine, hauing many thereof then making their dwelling at Rome. The cheife≈øt Apo≈øtle should be directed, and ≈øent thither by Chri≈øt, to bring this happie worke
the more ea≈øily to pa≈ø≈øe, and ≈øettle there for euer, by the glory of his pa≈øsion, the honor of his greate≈øt Apo≈øtolicall power: qu√≤ te diuinis praeordinationibus anteibant & honor pote≈øtatis, & gloria pa≈øsionis.

2. In this happines common to all, then dwelling at Rome, this Iland hauing ≈øo many Britans, both as ho≈øtages, and otherwi≈øe re≈øiding there, as all our hi≈øtories of tho≈øe times a≈ø≈øure vs, was equall with the be≈øt: In one, which S. Peter fir≈øt entertained at Rome by Britans, his Cathedrall See, & Church fir≈øt in their how≈øe. I take to be the greate≈øt honor, and happines this kingdome euer had, or any other could haue, this our Britaine ≈øtript, and ouerwent them all. Which was, that our Britains then dwelling at Rome were the fir≈øt, except the Romans them≈øelues deceaue me, that receaued, entertained, and happily harboured that ble≈ø≈øed Gue≈øt S. Peter, there. The fir≈øt erection of ≈øainct Peters Chaire, and See, the coÃÑmaunder of the Chri≈øtian world, in ≈øpirituall things, was made in the how≈øe of one of our noble BritaÃÑs there. Where the fir≈øt Chri≈øtiaÃÑ Church of that greate and holy Apo≈øtolike Citie as the Chri≈øtian pouertie of that time would permit, was founded, where the gho≈øpell was preached, the mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Sacrifice of the ≈øacred body and blood of Chri≈øt was offered, for the lyuing and the deade, where the dayly and ordinary Synaxes, and holy A≈ø≈øemblies of Chri≈øtians then, for the≈øe, and other mo≈øt holy exerci≈øes, of Chri≈øtian Religion were kept, from whence many holy di≈øciples of that highe≈øt Apo≈øtle, were afterward ≈øent, and directed by him, both into this kingdome of Britaine, and other nations in this we≈øterne world, the happy and renowned Chri≈øtians of this Country that then dwelled there, in the be≈øt ≈øorte and ≈øence they could, cooperating and a≈ø≈øi≈øting in ≈øo heauenly labours. For whereas we are told for an vndoubted truth, by a Tradition of the Romans, that S. Peter Traditio Romanorum apud Baron. in Annotat. in Martyrolog. Roman. 19. die Maij in Pudent. Authour of the 3. conuer≈ø. with. others. was fir≈øt lodged at Rome, in the how≈øe of Pudens a Senator, and that the Chri≈øtians met there at their Synaxis, & had their Church there, which is now called the Church of S. Pudentiana: maiorum firmatum traditione prae≈øcriptum e≈øt, domum Pudentis Romae fui≈ø≈øe primum bospitium S. Petri, Principis Apo≈øtolorum, illicque primum Chri≈øtianos conueni≈ø≈øe ad Synaxim, coactam Eccle≈øiam, vetu≈øti≈øs imumque omnium Titulnm Pudentis nomine appellatum, qui & Pa≈øtoris nomine dictus reperitur, hodie vulg√≤ Eccle≈øia S. Pudentianae nuncupatur: The Romans mu≈øt giue me leaue to write, and more then probably to proue, that this how≈øe called by them the how≈øe of Pudens a Romane Senator, came not to him from his Roman Aunce≈øtors, but rather by his wife, Iure vxoris ≈øuae, a noble Chri≈øtian and lady of Beda Martyrol. 14. cal. Iunij. Seuerin. Binnius annotat in Tom. 1. Concil. in S. Pio. Baron. Tom 2. Annal. 159. Zepher. Bin. annot. in tom. 1. coÃÑ cil. in Pio. 1. Traditio Romanorum apud Patres tam Latin. quam Graecos. Matth. We≈øtm. ad An. 42. Florent. Wigor. hi≈øt. an. 28. & 60. Stowe. And Howes hi≈øt. Britaine, called by our hi≈øtories and ≈øainct Paul al≈øo Claudia, by others, Pri≈øcilla, or Sabinella.

3. And ≈øo at the coming of ≈øainct Peter to Rome, this holy place was the how≈øe, and habitation, of the Chri≈øtian Brittish parents, of that renowned Lady Claudia, which then liued as ho≈øtages at Rome, to the Emperour, for this lande, and kingdome of Britaine, and by that meanes it was their happines, and honor, to giue the fir≈øt entertainement to the ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtle ≈øainct Peter, at his fir≈øt coming thither; as that Roman tradition of that their how≈øe after by marriage with the holy Brittish Lady Claudia their daughter and heire with Pudens the Senator, and ≈øo long after this coming of ≈øainct Peter to Rome named the how≈øe of Pudens, the Senator, a≈ø≈øureth vs. Which I proue by an other vndoubted tradition of the Romans: That S. Peter was 15. yeares in Rome, before S. Paul came thither: Romani autem dicunt Petrum annis 15. in Roma fui≈ø≈øe, antequam Paulus ad Romam venit. So writeth our Florentius Wigornien≈øis with the common con≈øent of Antiquitie, and writers, both Catholiks, and Prote≈øtants. And the Roman Martyrologe it≈øelfe telleth vs, of this
Pudens the Senator, that he was baptized by the Apo≈øtles: Qui ab Apo≈øtolis Cori≈øto in bapti≈ømo ve≈øtitus Innocentem tunicam v≈øque ad vitae coronam immaculate cu≈øiodiuit. Martyrolog. Rom. antiq. die 19. Maij. And there calleth him plainely S. Pudens the Senator, Father of S. Pudentiana the virgin. S. Pudentis Senatoris patris ≈øupradictae virginis Pudentianae. So that being baptized by the Apo≈øtles, ≈øainct Peter, and ≈øainct Paul (for no others were then in Rome) ab Apostlis, this could not be, by true accompt, vntill, at the ≈øoone≈øt, fifteene yeares after ≈øainct Peter was fir≈øt receaued in that how≈øe. And if the Martyrologe could carry that interpretation, to vnder≈øtand by Apo≈øtolis, the Apo≈øtles, in the plurall number, one Apo≈øtle (no propper con≈øtructioÃÑ) yet by this frieÃÑdly & more then lawfull interpretation, he mu≈øt needs be baptized by S. Peter, & ≈øo al≈øo a mo≈øt vnprobable thing, that diuers Chri≈øtiaÃÑs then being, as before, in Rome, S. Peter could fir≈øt coÃÑmit him≈øelfe to a Pagan, or Catecumene, and he and the Chri≈øtians of Rome make ≈øuch an hou≈øe their cheife≈øt Church, & place of a≈ø≈øembly for diuine things. And to put all out of doubt, this S. Pudens as I shall demon≈øtrate hereafter in the proper place of him, and ≈øaint Claudia his wife, was either an infant, or not borne when S. Peter came to Rome; and was fir≈øt lodged and receaued in that how≈øe, which after many yeares by title of marriage with our Lady the Lady Claudia came to be his how≈øe, & not before, but it ≈øtill remayned in the hands of our Chri≈øtian Britanes the Parents of that Lady there in Rome. For more pregnant Martial Pocta. Epigram. proofe whereof, we are told by him that liued in the dayes of this Pudens, by the mo≈øt common con≈øent of writers, both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants, & was well acquainted with him, his ≈øtate and Countrie, that this PudeÃÑs was by birth, and Countrie, a Sabinite, farre di≈øtant from Rome, & his how≈øe at Sabinum, the cheife≈øt Towne there, and no mention of any how≈øe at all, which of their owne, eyther he or his parents had in Rome: when by all te≈øtimonies of writers, we are told, the parents of Lady Claudia being Britanes were dwelling in Rome, as ho≈øtages among others, for this Nation there, and without que≈øtion, had an how≈øe there, ≈øutable and an≈øwerable to their honorable degree, and that their daughter S. Claudia was borne there, & not in Britaine, for no Auihour that I reade, doth affirme she was borne in this Iland, but onely of Brittish parents lyuing in Rome. Claudia caerulcis cum ≈øit progmata Martial. l. 11. Epigr. 54. de Claud ‚Ä¢ a Ruff. Godw. Conuer≈ø. of Brit. p. 16. Theat. of greate Britainel. 6. Matt. Parker. antiq. Brit. p. 2. Io. Pit≈ø. l. de vir. Illu≈øtrib. p. 72. Authour of; conuer≈ø. part. 1. 2. Timoth. 4. Britannis. Claudia borne of Britans; But not in Britaine, onely she is called of the Poet Martial, peregrina, a straunger, as the children of ≈øtraungers v≈øually are termed both with vs, and other people. And the time of her birth, and age ≈øo conuince, as I shall declare hereafter; and may be plainely proued from S. Paul him≈øelfe a litle before his death.

4. And whereas we finde noe memory at all, of any naturall parents of S. Pudens dwelling in Rome, we haue ≈øufficient te≈øtimony, not onely of the permanent dwelling both of the Father, and Mother of S. Claudia there; before remembred, but that, by diuers probable Arguments they dwelled in that very how≈øe, where Pudens continued with them, after his marriage with their daughter, and were holy and renowned Chri≈øtians, although their natiue Countrie of Britaine hath hitherto bene almo≈øt wholy depriued of their honour, and ≈øo mu≈øt needs be by the Roman Tradition the fir≈øt entertainers God win conu. of Britaine p. 17. c. 3 ‚Ä¢ . Tim. 4. v. 21. of ≈øainct Peter in Rome: for as a Prote≈øtant Bishop in their common opinion writeth: Pudens and Claudia were two young per≈øons, but faithfull Chri≈øtians, at that time vnmarried, when Paul writ the ≈øecond epi≈øtle vnto Timothie, which was in the la≈øt yeare of Nero, a ‚Ä¢ all men ≈øuppo≈øe, that I haue reade except Baronius: and that they were married in the later end of Ve≈øpa≈øian, or about the beginning of Domitian.
Therefore Pudens being ≈øo young in the end of Nero his Empire, Although we graunt him then newly married, yet this was by all computations at the lea≈øt 24. yeares after the coming of ≈øainct Peter to Rome. And ≈øo it could not po≈ø≈øibly be Pudens, but the parents of Claudia, our Britans, that entertained fir≈øt S. Peter in their hou≈øe at Rome. Who for certaintie being Britans of noble order, & degree, & lyuing in Rome as Ho≈øtages by all IudgmeÃÑt they enioyed more freedome, and libertie in matters of Religion, then the Romans did at that time; The Emperours of Rome theÃÑ, nor long after, intermedling with the Britans, for matters of Religion, but leauing it voluntarie and free vnto them, as other Tributaries, to v≈øe the Religion of their Contries, or as they were be≈øt, and mo≈øt di≈øpo≈øed, priuately at the lea≈øt, euen in Rome it≈øelfe, without controlement. So by the great mercy, & prouidence of God, the ≈øubiection & temporall captiuitie, or re≈øtraint of diuers the≈øe our worthie Contrimen, proued to be the mo≈øt happy ≈øpirituall freedome in Chri≈øt, both of tho≈øe our Ho≈øtages there, & this whole kingdome, afterward conuerted to the true faith, from thence, by this originall, ≈øo renowned and glorious for euer to this Nation, to haue in Rome it ≈øelfe the fir≈øt Harbourers & Receauers of that mo≈øt Ble≈ø≈øed, & highe≈øt Apo≈øtle S. Peter. And thus I haue proued directly both again≈øt the Prote≈øtant Bishop of England denying it, the truth of that Roman Tradition, that ≈øainct Peter was fir≈øt with his holy Di≈øciples receiued in Rome in the hou≈øe which the Romans truely called the hou≈øe of Pudens, after he was God wyn ≈øupr. Conuer≈ø. of Brit. p. 17. c. 3. married to Lady Claudia of this Nation, confuting his idle obiection of the young age of Pudens: As al≈øo the Romans, therefore calling it the hou≈øe of Pudens, becau≈øe ≈øo it was, in ≈øuch ≈øence as I haue declared, and not truely inducing from thence, that therefore Pudens the Roman Senator fir≈øt entertained S. Peter there: for as I haue proued before, this Pudens being a Sabiline, and no Romane as of the citie of Rome by birth, was neither Senator, Chri≈øtian, Catechumen, or perhaps not borne at that time, and the hou≈øe was onely called his hou≈øe, becau≈øe longe after he was owner of it: as it was al≈øo after called Domus S. Nouati, Domus S. Timothaei, and S. Pudentianae; the hou≈øe Martyrol. Rom. die 20. Iunij. 26. Iulij. & Baron. Annot. ibid. Et in Sanct. Nouato, Tim. Pudent. & Praxede. Baron. in annot. 19. Maij. Authour of 3. Conuer≈ø. part. 1. p. 17. Rob. Barnes in vit. Pont. Rom. in Pio 1. Martyrol. Rom. 20. die Iunijin S. Nouato. of S. Nouatus, the hou≈øe of S. Timothie, the hou≈øe of S. Pudentiana, the ble≈ø≈øed children of S. Pudens and S. Claudia our Contry woman, who all ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed it, termed by their name for the time, as v≈øually hou≈øes & places be, by the owners name: vntill in the time of Pope Pius the fir≈øt, It was by the Donation of S. Pudentiana, ab≈øolutely conuerted to a Church, and euer ≈øince after her death, called the Church of S. Pudentiana, as the Romane Antiquities them≈øelues, and their continually kept tradition together with ≈øome English Prote≈øtants, and others te≈øtifie, Which before was called the hou≈øe of them, as they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed it in order, or the hou≈øe of them all ≈øometimes, as the old Roman Martyrologe calleth it, the hou≈øe of all tho≈øe foure children of S. Pudens, and Claudia, for ≈øpeaking of them all by name, S. Nouatus, Tymotheus, Pudentiana, and Praxedes, it addeth: horum domus in Eccle≈øiam commutata, Po≈øtoris Titulus appellatur: The hou≈øe of the≈øe being chaunged into a Church, is called the Title of Pastor.

5. And it is euident, that the Father of the Lady Claudia by all probabilitie, God win. Conu. of Brit. pag. 17. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. ¬ß. 6. owner of this hou≈øe, where all his children longe after liued, was yet liuing, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor thereof, both now, and when S. Peter was fir≈øt entertained there, for Martiall the Poet which liued in this time and wrote in the dayes of Domitian and Nerua long after maketh an honorable memorie of the Father of Lady Claudia, then lyuing calling him Socer of Pudens, the Father of his
wife, S. Claudia, our Contry woman by parents, for the word Socer, hath no other meaning, then a Father in lawe, Father to the wife who≈øe Father in Cooper. Rider. Thom. Thomas. Calepin. & alij v. Socer. Martial. l. epigr. ≈øaepe. Io. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. in Claudia Ruffin. Io. Pit≈ø. l. de Vir. Illu≈øtrib. in ead. Godwin. Conu. of Britaine. Et alij. lawe he is, or Father to the husband of that wife, to whom he is ≈øo termed Socer, Father in lawe, Cothen, Pentheros ≈øo in Hebrewe, Greeke, Latine, and all languages. Euident it is al≈øo, that Pudens had no other wife but Claudia, to haue any other Socer, or Father in lawe by, and she longe ouer lyued her husband Pudens. And that this Father in lawe was as noble for his faith, and Religion in Chri≈øt, as by di≈øcent, and birth, we may ea≈øely enforme our≈øelues, if from noe other grounds, yet from the mo≈øt holy and vertuous education of his daughter in that profe≈ø≈øion, whoe by the examples and documents of her pious parents the be≈øt Tutours of children their greate≈øt charge, was by their In≈øtruction come to that perfection in the lawe of Chri≈øt, that being yet but young in all opinioÃÑs, when S. Paul wrote his ≈øecoÃÑd Epi≈øtle to S. Timothie, a litle before his The Brittish parents of S. Claudia were Chri≈øtians. death, she de≈øerued the ≈øtile of one of the foure principall Chri≈øtiaÃÑs, in the iudgemeÃÑt of that great Apo≈øtle, as two greate Doctours, S. Chry≈øo≈øtome, & Theodoret expound that pa≈ø≈øage of his Epi≈øtle. Salutat te, inquit, Eubulus, & Pudens Chry≈øo≈øt. inep. 2. ad Tim. c. 4. & Linus, & Claudia, & fratres omnes, nominatim illos memorat, quos nouerat magis fide feruere: S. Paul ≈øaith: Eubulus ≈øaluteth thee, and Pudens, and Linus, & Claudia, and all the Brethren, he remembreth them by name, whom he knewe, to be more feruent in faith: and againe, Theodoret vpon that place, ≈øaith: Meliorum, & Theod. in ep. 2. ad Tim. cap. 4. in eund. loc. virtut is amantiorum nomina in ≈øerut: alios autem commu ni appellatione vocauit. S. Paul put in the names of them which were the be≈øt, and mo≈øt louing of vertue. By which we may ≈øufficiently ≈øee, the greate pietie not onely of S. Claudia, but her holy parents al≈øo, the then honours of this kingdome, that had cau≈øed her then vnder their charge, to be taught, and in≈øtructed, in ≈øo excellent a manner, in true Religion.

6. And if I may haue the like licence to write for the Religion of this Father in lawe to Pudens, which a Prote≈øtant Bishop taketh, to proue Pudens the ≈øonne in lawe a Chri≈øtian, I may doe it with much more rea≈øon, for thus he writeth: That the ≈øame Pudens was a Chri≈øtian, we haue a greate pre≈øumption, in the Epigram Godwin. Conu. of Britaine pa. 17. Theater of greate Brit. l. 6. ¬ß. 6. of Martial, where for his vertuous carriage, he calleth him, S. Maritus: but a greater in an other of the ≈øame Martial, wherein he yeeldeth him thanks, for per≈øuading him to amend his writings, that for ob≈øcenitie and la≈øiuiou≈øne≈ø≈øe, are indeed not to be endured by Chri≈øtian eares, and this it is.

q.l: Cogis me calamo, manuque no≈øtra
Emendare meos, Pudens, libellos.

div.p: That by this kinde of argument the Father of Claudia our Noble Contryman, Martial. l. 7. Epigram. 11. was in all degrees as good, or rather better Chri≈øtian then his ≈øonne in law Pudens was, is mo≈øt euident, for tho≈øe ver≈øes which Pudens did well like Martial. l. 7. Epigram. 57. ad Rufin. and allowe, yet by the te≈øtimony of Martiall him≈øelfe, might not be imparted to the Father in lawe of Pudens, but would ≈øeeme light vnto him, occupied in more ≈øerious things for thus he writeth vnto Pudens: S. Eubulus named with honour by S. Paul probably was the Father of S. Claudia, and a Britan.

q.l: Commendare meas in≈øtanti, Rufe, camaenas
Parce precor Socero, ≈øeria for≈øan amat.

div.p:
Where we ≈øee, that the grauitie of the Father in lawe to Pudens, was greater then his, therefore much more we may pre≈øume from hence, that he was a Chri≈øtian then the other, by that argument. And yet we haue a better Author, both for his Chri≈øtianitie, and name al≈øo: for the other three named by Martyrol. Rom. 20. Iunij in San. Nouato. Martia. in Epigram. S. Paul, to ≈øend ≈øalutations to S. Timothie from Rome at that time, for certaine except Eubulus, the fir≈øt, were mo≈øt continuing in one hou≈øe, Pudens and
Claudia were then married, as is euident in the auncient Romane Martyrologe, and others: And ≈øeeing by the Romans tradition, and other te≈øtimonies, the hou≈øe wherein they dwelled, was the cheife lodging if the Apo≈øtles S. Peter and Paul, and their Succe≈ø≈øors, vntill in the time of Pope Pius the fir≈øt, it was conuerted to be a Church, we mu≈øt needs accompt S. Linus the Bishop, the third which is here named, to be al≈øo of that familie for the mo≈øt part. Then how to ≈øingle forth onely S. Eubulus, which here is fir≈øt eyther for pietie, nobilitie, or that he was the cheife paterfamilias, owner and Ma≈øter of that hou≈øe, or all, and make him a ≈øtranger there, I cannot finde it by S. Paul, onely repeating them of one family, or any other warrant. For it is plaine here by the Apo≈øtle, that he was a cheife and principall Chri≈øtian in Rome, and fir≈øt named among the≈øe worthies, and before S. Linus, a Bishop then, & Pudens a Senatour, and ab≈øolutely there ≈øet downe, as their cheife≈øt receauer, friend, or patron, which cannot agree to any other, better then to the Father of S. Claudia, this father in lawe to her husband Pudens and fir≈øt entertainer of S. Peter the Apo≈øtle in Rome, by the Romans tradition. For neyther Dorotheus, the continuator of Florentius Wigornien≈øis, nor any other that write of the Di≈øciples there, place him among Clergie men, and S. Paul which giueth him that honour in that place, clearely proueth he was none of his Di≈øciples then in Rome, for he writeth in the ≈øame place. Lucas e≈øt mecum ≈øolus: onely 2. Tim. 4. ver≈ø. 11. Luke is with me. No Martyrologe ≈øpeaketh of him, neyther any Hi≈øtorian, or Interpreter of Scripture to my reading, ≈øetteth downe of what Nation he was, but leaue him for a ≈øtranger, as likewi≈øe many doe S. Claudia: Therefore except better authoritie can be brought again≈øt me ≈øeing he is by the Apo≈øtle him≈øelfe ≈øo dignified, and placed the fir≈øt in that family, and ≈øalutation, Eubulus greeteth thee, and Pudens, and Linus, and Claudia: There is no cau≈øe yet I finde, to 2. Tim. 4. deny him, to be the owner & Ma≈øter of that hou≈øe, that fir≈øt entertayned S. Peter in Rome, & he him≈øelfe the fir≈øt happy maÃÑ, that gaue that glorious Apo≈øtle entertaymeÃÑt there, that he was our mo≈øt renowned CoÃÑtrymaÃÑ of Britaine, & Father of Lady Claudia. For there is no other, who by any probable coniecture, was likely to performe this dutie in that hou≈øe. PudeÃÑs as before, was either then vnborne, or an Infant: of his owne parents father and mother, there is no meÃÑ tion in antiquities, that either they were Chri≈øtians, or that they dwelled at all in Rome, much le≈ø≈øe in that hou≈øe, being Inhabitants of Sabinum, and by CoÃÑtry Sabinites farre di≈øtant froÃÑ Rome; And ≈øo there is none left vnto vs, to be a Chri≈øtian, and entertaine that heauenly Me≈ø≈øenger, and Ghea≈øt, S. Peter in that time, and place, but the renowned Brittish parents of Lady Claudia, then dwelling in Rome, and there confined to a certaine hou≈øe, and place of permanency by commaund of Roman power, to whome with many other noble Britans they were ho≈øtages, and pledges for the fidelitie, and obedience of this kingdome, to the Roman Emperours at that time.

7. To ≈øtrengthen this opinion, we may add, that S. Paul ≈øendeth to S. Timothie, his Di≈øciple the ≈øalutations of Eubulus, before all others of which ≈øending the greetings of ≈øo few by name, It will be no ea≈øy ≈øearch, to finde out a better or more probable rea≈øon, then this, that S. Timothy ≈øo neare and beloued a ≈øcholler of S. Paul, lodged v≈øually in this hou≈øe, he al≈øo was there with his Ma≈øter, entertained by Eubulus the owner thereof, and by that title of his holy ho≈øpitality de≈øerued the fir≈øt place in that ≈øalutation: otherwi≈øe no man will doubt, but S. Linus Bishop by calling, ≈øo honorable in the Church of Chri≈øt, ought and should haue bene, named before him. And that this familiar
acquaintance, betweene S. Timothie, and the≈øe our holy Chri≈øtian Britans, receaued originall from their auncient entertainement of S. Timothie in their hou≈øe in Rome, manie yeares before this their ≈øalutation in S. Pauls Epi≈øtle, it is euident; for S. Paul being now lately, come to Rome when he wrote this epi≈øtle, and neyther he, nor ≈øainct Timothie there, after S. Pauls fir≈øt di≈ømi≈ø≈øion from pri≈øon there, ≈øo longe before, it is manife≈øt, that the≈øe though the lady in yong yeares, were auncient Chri≈øtians at that time. And we haue vncontroleable warrant, from S. Paul him≈øelfe, in his epi≈øtle to the Hebrewes, that S. Timothie was at Rome, when he was fir≈øt pri≈øoner there, in the beginning of Nero his Empire; for thus he writeth knowe you Hebr. c. 13. ver≈ø. 23. that our Brother Timothie is ≈øet at libertie. Thus S. Paul writeth from Rome in the time of his fir≈øt impri≈øonnement there. And ≈øo maketh the≈øe our Contry Chri≈øtians the acquaintance of S. Timothie then, to be more auncient in the ≈ø ‚Ä¢ hoole of Chri≈øt, then either S. Timothie or S. Paul his coming fir≈øt to Rome, wheÃÑ there were none to in≈øtructe eyther theÃÑ, or others, in Chri≈øtiaÃÑ ReligioÃÑ at Rome, but S. Peter, and his Di≈øciples: I add to this the charge, and warning which Martiall the Poet gaue before to Pudens, that his father in law should not ≈øee his Poems: commendare meas camaenas parce precor Socero: An euident te≈øtimony, Martial. ≈øup ‚Ä¢ . l. 7. Ep ‚Ä¢ gr. 67. that they then liued in one hou≈øe together, and ≈øo the Poems ≈øent to Pudens might ea≈øely come to his father in law his hands, and reading, except Pudens had bene ≈øo forewarned to keepe and conceale them from him. Whereof there had bene no daunger, or need of that admonition, if they had then liued in di≈øtinct places, and not in one hou≈øe. And thus much of the father, of lady Claudia.

8. Concerning her holy mother al≈øo, ≈øo good a Noor≈øe, and Tutrix to ≈øo happy a childe, we are not altogether left de≈øolate, without all hope, but we may probably finde her forth, for the honour of this kingdome, her Contry. And except the Roman Hi≈øtorians can finde vnto vs, a Chri≈øtian Father to S. S. P ‚Ä¢ i≈øc ‚Ä¢ lla foundr ‚Ä¢ ≈øse of the Church-yard of her name in Rome mother of S. Claudia, very probable. Pudens, and dwelling with his wife, in the ≈øame hou≈øe, as I haue found vnto them, a father to Claudia, and father in lawe to Pudens, an holy Chri≈øtian dwelling in that hou≈øe before Pudens his time, by Nation of this kingdome which by that is ≈øaid before, they caÃÑnot doe, ≈øeeing that noble Matrone which is acknowledged by the Roman writers, euen Baronius, to haue dwelled in that hou≈øe, & Grandmother to S. Claudia her children, mu≈øt needs be her Mother, her fathers wife, & mother in lawe to S. PudeÃÑs, I am bolde to a≈ø≈øigne that glorious & renowned Saint, S. Pri≈øcilla, foundre≈ø≈øe of that wonderfull and religious Churchyard, to be the ≈øame ble≈ø≈øed Brittish Chri≈øtian Lady. Ba ‚Ä¢ onius though ≈øtaggering ≈øometimes in his opinioÃÑ herein, ≈øaith plainely froÃÑ Antiquitie: fuit Romae nobili≈øsima Matrona Pri≈øcilla nomine, Auia Pudentianae, & Praxedis Baronius ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Annot. in Martyrolog. Rom. Iu ‚Ä¢ . 8. S. Pa≈øtor ≈øeu Hermes in act. S. Pudentianae. Baron. Annotat. in Martyrolog. Rom. die 16. Ian. Baron. Tom. 2. Annal. Ann. 159. & an. 166. virginum: de qua mentio habetur in Actis S. Pudentianae, √† Pa≈øtore con≈øcriptis. There was a mo≈øt noble Matrone in Rome, called Pri≈øcilla, GraÃÑdmother of the virgins PudeÃÑ tiana and Praxedes: of whoÃÑ there is mention in the Acts of Pudentiana, written by S. Pa≈øtour. The like he writeth in other places where as she is there called by him the mother of PudeÃÑs, Mater Pudent ‚Ä¢ s, he mu≈øt needs be vnder≈øtood, to ≈øpeake in their Phra≈øe, which ordinarily all Mothers in lawe, by the ab≈øolute name of Mothers, as the coÃÑmon cu≈øtome is. Sometimes in other places Baronius faith, S. Pri≈øcilla was wife to S. Pudens, and mother to S. Nouatus, Pudentiana, and Praxedes: ≈øo likewi≈øe doth Zepherinus Binius, when it is euident before, that S. Claudia our Brittish Lady was the onely wife, of S. Pudens, and Mother to tho≈øe Saints. Therefore to excu≈øe the one from errour, and the other from
contradiction, they mu≈øt holde, that both the Mother of S. Claudia, and she her≈øelfe al≈øo was ≈øometimes called Pri≈øcilla, as she was in Vmbria termed Sabinella, of her husbands hou≈øe at Sabinum there. And this may ≈øufficiently be gathered from tho≈øe Antiquities, Baronius citeth, in which one S. Pri≈øcilla is called Pri≈øcilla Seniour, the elder, or old Pri≈øcilla, to make which iu≈øtifiable, we mu≈øt haue al≈øo Pri≈øcilla Iunior, the youÃÑger or youÃÑg Pri≈øcilla, & this is v≈øuall for di≈øtinction ≈øake, where the mother and daughter, Father & ≈øonne be of one, and the ≈øame name, to call the Father and Mother by their name with the addition, old, or elder, and the ≈øonne and daughter, with the di≈øtinction, younge, or younger added vnto them. And there be other di≈øtinctions betweene the≈øe two: The elde≈øt (grandmother to tho≈øe holy children,) as the Roman Martyrologe with others te≈øtifieth, who died at Rome hauing employed Martyrol. Rom. die 16. Februarij. here≈øelfe, and her goods to the ≈øeruice of Martyrs: die 16. Pebruarij Romae Sanctae Pri≈øcillae, quae ≈øe ≈øuaque Martyrum ob≈øequio mancipauit. Where we ≈øee her fe≈øtiuitie kept vpon the 16. day of February, and that she dyed at Rome. Of the other, the younger, if by any called Pri≈øcilla, we finde no ≈øuch ob≈øeruation, nor that she died at Rome, but quite otherwi≈øe, that after her husband S. Pudens death, she liued ≈øo longe at his hou≈øe at Sabinum, in Vmbria, that she thereupon tooke her name Sabellina, and by all writers dyed there farre from Rome. Secondly S. Pa≈øtor who liued in the Apo≈øtles time, & familiarly in that our Brittish hou≈øe, as I shall shewe in due place, is witne≈ø≈øe, euen Baronius acknowledging it, That the elder S. Pri≈øcilla Grandmother to S. Nouatus, Tymotheus, Pudentiana, and Praxedes, which were S. Claudia her children, was foundre≈ø≈øe of that renowned Church-yard, in via Salaria, S. Pa≈øtor in actis S. Praxedis, & apud Baron. in Annot. Martyr. Rom. die 16. Ian. at Rome which boare her name, caemiterium Sanctae Pri≈øcillae via ≈øalaria, and was founded longe before S. Claudia was of yeares to be Authour thereof. Caemiterium via Salaria nomine ≈øanctae Pri≈øcillae, Pri≈øcillae ≈øeniori Pastor tribuit in act is S. Praxedis. And it mu≈øt needs be this, and noe other, which prepared that mo≈øt charitable Chri≈øtian co≈øtly worke; for we finde no other ≈øaints of that name, e≈øpecially in that time, but onely her, and S. Pri≈øcilla wife of S. Aquila, diuers times mentioned by S. Paul, being a Iewe, who could not be authour of that foundation at Rome. Fir≈øt becau≈øe probably it was founded before she came to Rome, being at Corinth, & there ≈øaluted by S. Paul in his 1. Cor. c. 16. fir≈øt epi≈øtle to the CorinthiaÃÑs, & was with her husband coadiutre≈ø≈øe to S. Paul, with her husbaÃÑd in tho≈øe parts before they came to Rome, as the ≈øame Apo≈øtle te≈øtifieth: Salutate Pri≈øcaÃÑ & AquilaÃÑ Adiutores meos in Chri≈øto Ie≈øu, qui pro anima Rom. 16. mea, ≈øuas ceruices ≈øuppo≈øuerunt. Neyther did she with her husband ≈øtay ≈øo longe at Rome, to effect ≈øuch a bu≈øines: for as S. Luke proueth, they came from Act. 18. Rome vpon the bannishment of the Iewes from thence by Claudius, which was ≈øoone after their coming thither. And they were at, or neare Ephe≈øus a litle before S. Pauls death, as he proueth writing his ≈øecond epi≈øtle then to S. Timothie. Saluta Pri≈øcillam & Aquilam. And the old Roman Martyrologe 2. Tim. 4. with others giue euidence, they ended their liues in A≈øia the le≈ø≈øe, vpon the 8. day of Iuly, when the other S. Pri≈øcilla, died (as before,) at Rome, farre from thence, the 16. of Ianuary.
‚Ä¢ ctaua Idus Iulij. In A≈øia minori Sanctorum Martyrol. Rom. 8. Iulij. Aquilae &, Pri≈øcillae vxoris eius, de quihus in Actibus Apo≈øtolorum ≈øcribitur.

9. And Baronius, who was an eye wetne≈ø≈øe of the chargeable worke of that foundation, found in his time, shall proue all the wealth both of this S. Pri≈øcilla, and her husband S. Aquila being but Tentma ‚Ä¢ ers; erant autem ≈øcenofactoriae Act. c. 18. artis, as the ≈øcripture te≈øtifieth, was not able to effect ≈øuch a worke.
Baronius which had ≈øeene and often vi≈øited it, compareth it to a citie, for Baron. Annal. Tom. 2. an. 130. lardgne≈ø≈øe and ≈øtreets vnder the earth, relating, that the whole citie of Rome was amazed to ≈øee it. Mirabile dictu: vidimus, ≈øaepiu≈øque lu≈øtrauimus Pri≈øcillae caemitcrium, haud pridem inuentuÃÑ, atque refo≈ø≈øum via ≈øalaria tertio ab vrbe lapide, quod nullo magis proprio vocabulo dixerimus prae cius amplitudine, multi≈øque atque diuer≈øis eiu≈ødem vijs, qu√†m ≈øubterraneam ciuitatem: quippe qu√≤d ip≈øius ingre≈ø≈øu primaria via caeteris amplior pateat, quae hinc inde vias diuer≈øas habeat, ea≈ødem frequentes, quae rur≈øum in diuer≈øos viculos diuidantur & Angiportus: rur≈øus vt in ciuitatibus, ≈øtatis locis, velutfora quaedam, ampliora ≈øint ≈øpatia, ad conuentus ≈øacros agendos, ead ‚Ä¢ mque Sanctorum Imaginibus exornata: nec de≈øint, licet nunc ob≈øtructa, ad lumen recipiendum de≈øuper exci≈øa foramina. Ob≈øtupuit vrbs, c√πm in ≈øuis ≈øuburbijs abditas ≈øe nouit habere ciuitates. So wonderfull and chargeable a worke, with ≈øuch ≈øtreets, turnings, Churches, altars for holy Ma≈ø≈øe, Images of Saints, and the other things of price, as they argue the ritch and noble degree of the ble≈ø≈øed foundre≈ø≈øe; ≈øo for a lady of Britaine a ≈øtraunger there, to be at ≈øo exce≈ø≈øiue chardg, and expences to prouide ≈øuch a Sanctuary for the honour of Chri≈øt, ≈øafety, releife, and coÃÑforte both temporall and ≈øpirituall of his Seruants in a forreine Countrie, mu≈øt be a perpetuall glory of this Nation. And to giue further te≈øtimonie: that this our renowned Country woman was foundre≈ø≈øe thereof, we finde expre≈ø≈øely, that diuers of her family and po≈øteritie namely S. Pudens her ≈øonne in lawe, her grandechildren, his daughters, S. Pudentiana, and S. Praxedes, as likely S. Nouatus, and Timotheus were honorably Martyrolog. Roman. 21. Iulij. Act. S. Praxedis in Breuiar. die 21. Iulij. & S. Pudentianae die 19. Maij. interred there. Cuius (S. Praxedis) corpus √† Pa≈øtore presbytero in patris & ≈øororis Pudcntianae ≈øepulchrum illatum e≈øt, quod erat in caemiterio Pri≈øcillae via Salaria. And yet be≈øides this memorable foundation, for the publike good of the Church of Chri≈øt, the≈øe Romans them≈øelues doe tell vs, and the lately continued buildings them≈øelues te≈øtifie, that there was an other ≈øuch ≈øecret Church yard, at her owne hou≈øe, to hide, protect, and bury holy Martyrs in. In ip≈øo Titulo Pa≈øtoris, vbi erant thermae Nouati, quae & Timothinae dictae, ip≈øae balnei inferiores Cae≈øar Baron. Annot. in Martyrol. Rom. die 16. Ianuarij. cellae in≈øtar porticuum ≈øibi concameratione coniuctae, quae v≈øque in hanc diem cernuntur poene integrae, caemiterij loco ad ≈øepeliendos ≈øublatos occulte martyres in≈øerui≈ø≈øe creduntur. And thus we haue found out now at the la≈øt the hou≈øe of our noble Chri≈øtian Britans at Rome, to haue bene the fir≈øt lodging of the great Apo≈øtle S. Peter there, his fir≈øt Church, and Seate, the Harbour of S. Paul, and many of their Di≈øciples, and Succe≈ø≈øors Popes of Rome after them, the fir≈øt Seminary, colledge, or mother of Chri≈øtian learning there, or in the we≈øterne world, the common and ordinary place of holy Chri≈øtian a≈ø≈øemblies, and exerci≈øes; from whence, as from the originall well and fountaine the water of life did take cour≈øe, and current, to diffu≈øe it ≈øelfe vnto all parts and Nations of the Occidentall world. We may make ≈øome e≈øtimate and apprehen≈øion of the wonderfull charitable helpe, and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, this mo≈øt happy hou≈øe of our noble Brittish Chri≈øtians, parents of S. Claudia yeelded to the holy worke of conuerting this, and all other we≈øterne Countries, if be≈øides their extraordinary loue to their owne Nation, we doe reflect vpon that the old Roman Martyrologe hath told vs before, of this Pri≈øcilla, Employing her≈øelfe and her ≈øub≈øtance to ≈øerue the Saints, and Seruants of Chri≈øt: ≈øe ≈øuaque Martyrol. Rom. dic 16. Ianuarij in S. Pri≈øcilla. martyrum ob≈øequio mancipauit: That she and her husband were two of the cheife≈øt of the nobilitie of Britaine kept ho≈øtages at Rome, for this kingdome, and yet after ≈øo many yeares ≈øpent, and their honorable reuenewes much exhau≈øted in the≈øe pious workes, in maintaining, and releeuing di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Chri≈øtians,
by rhem≈øelues, ≈øub≈øtance, and greate numbers of Attendants, and ≈øeruants, attending al≈øo to tho≈øe holy ends, they left ≈øo much to po≈øteritie, that in the Family of their grand child S. Pudentiana, in the ≈øame hou≈øe there Vita S. Pudent. in Breuiar. Rom. die 19. Maij. Bar. Tom. 2. Annal. in S. Praxede. were nonaginta ≈øex homines, 96. Chri≈øtian men, ordinarie Attendants, and S. Praxedes her Si≈øter liuing there, 19. holy Chri≈øtians were martyred in that hou≈øe at one time.

div.head: THE XIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: MAKING MANIFEST VNTO VS: HOW, and whome in particular, S. Peter the Apo≈øtle ≈øent from Rome into the≈øe parts of the world, next vnto vs: and ≈øo con≈øequently into this kingdome of Britaine al≈øo, ≈øo knowne and renowned then, among the Nations of the we≈øterne world.

div.p:
1. NOw let vs examine more particularly, who they were, whom S. Peter, (thus receaued in Rome by our Brittish Countrymen) ≈øent into the≈øe parts of the world, next adiacent vnto this Iland; That if we finde, the fir≈øt preachers of the faith of Chri≈øt, in all the≈øe Countries next vnto vs, were ≈øent by ≈øainct Peter ≈øo well acquainted with our Roman Britans, we may boldely conclude, that this kingdome alone was not left vnremembred, in tho≈øe holy Amba≈ø≈øages. Our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries from S. Innocentius twelue hundred yeares ≈øince, and other Antiquities, acknowledge it for ≈øo certaine, and vndoubted a truth. Quis ne≈øciat, cum ≈øit manife≈øtum, that no man can be ignorant of it, being manife≈øt: But S. Peter founded the fir≈øt Churches of Africke, Italy, Godwyn Conu. of Britaine p. 3. Innoc. 1. epi≈øt. ad Decent. di≈øt. 11. Simon Metaphr. 29. dic Iunij. Bar. Annal. an. 44. Fraunce, Spaine, Sicily, and the Ilands, that lye betwixt them, Sardinia or Corcica, Maiorca, Minorca. And for Sicily, and tho≈øe Ilands, we neede not expect S. Peters coming to Rome; for while he was in the Ea≈øt ≈øo farre of, he ≈øent S. Martianus and Paccatius thither, & landed there him≈øelfe in Sicily, the cheife≈øt Iland, when he came to Rome. Of Italy there is no que≈øtion, among writers, Prote≈øtants, or others, but it fell to the diui≈øion of ≈øainct Peter: for though Act. Apo≈øt. c. 12. 13. 14. 15. Sophron. tom. 7. Biblioth. Patr. Hartmann. Schedel Chronic. chronicor. f. 205. many bring ≈øainct Barnabas into Italy, yet it is euideÃÑt, by the holy Scriptures them≈øelues, that it mu≈øt needs be longe after ≈øainct Peters coming to Rome. And when ≈øainct Barnabas Brother to S. Ari≈øtobulus by ≈øome father in lawe to ≈øainct Peter preached in Italy, it was, as antiquaries ≈øay, by the direction of ≈øainct Peter. Barnabas√® 72. Di≈øcipulis fuit natione Cyprius, is in Italiam veniens, ex praecepto Petri omnem Longobardiam praedicando, & docendo circuiuit, & apud Mediolanum primus Cathedralem locum tenuit. Barnabas one of the 72. Di≈øciples, was by Nation a Cyprian, he coming into Italy, by the commaundement of Peter went about all Lombardy, preaching and teaching, and was the fir≈øt that held the Cathedrall place at Millane. The next Nation to this, in the way to this Iland of Britaine, is that of the Heluetians or Switcers, who≈øe Theater of great Britaine lib. 6. Pantal. de vir. Illu≈øtrib. Germ. Apo≈øtle, as our Prote≈øtants a≈ø≈øure vs was that our renowned Countriman S. Beatus ≈øent Apo≈øtle thither by his Ma≈øter ≈øainct Peters authoritie of which matter I am to ≈øpeake more hereafter. For the parts betweene Heluetia, and
vs, Seba≈øtian Mun≈øter, the Magdeburgian Prote≈øtants in the fir≈øt of their Seba≈øtian Mun≈øt. Co≈ømograp. l. 3. Magdebur. cent. 1. Henricus PaÃÑt. de vir. Illu≈øtrib. Germ. part. 1. pag. 100. Henricus de Erford hi≈øt. Germ. Catal. Epi≈øc. Tungr. Catal. Epi≈ø. Met. Catal. Epi≈øcop. Tullen. Guhel. Ei≈øengr. Centen. 1. Henric. de Erford. apud Mun≈øter. & Pant. ≈øup. beat. Rhenan. l. 2 rerum Germ. p. 88. Francis Burgoing. Eccl. hi≈øt. l. 2. c. 1. Theater of great. Brit. l. 6. Bal. l. de Scriptor. in Kentegern. Io. Capgrau. cat. in S. Kentegern. Guliel. Lomb. l. de leg. Regum. Britan. in Ewardo Confe≈ø≈øore. Richard. Kackluyt in Reg. Arthu. & Edga. Arnold. Mirman. in Theatro Conu. gent. Acta S. Ioan. in Breuiar. Rom. die 25. Iulij. Martyrol. Rom. 25. Maij. Bed. Mart. ib. V≈øuard. ib. & Ado. Breuiar. Eccle≈ø. Toletan. Greg. 7. Epi≈øt. ad AlphoÃÑ≈øum Reg. Vincent. in ≈øpec. hi≈øt. lib. 6. cap. 6. Francis Ma≈ø. l. 2. of Con≈øecrat. cap. 2. Loyes de Mayerne Turquet hi≈øtorie general d'E≈øpagne li. 4. p. 179. Beuter. ib. Vincent. ≈øupr. Centuryes, Henticus Pantaleon, Iodocus Willichius, Arnoldus Mermannius, Henry of Erford, and other hi≈øtorians of Germany both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants are witne≈ø≈øes with the auncient Catalogues of their Churches, that ≈øainct Peter about the yeare of Chri≈øt 55. or before, longe before S. Paul or any other Apo≈øtle came to Rome, or to any of the≈øe parts, ≈øent S. Maternus, Eucherius and Valerius, who conuerted Al≈øatia, Treuers, Argentine. Mentz, Colin and tho≈øe Contryes. Of his directing and ≈øending ≈øainct Clement, our renowned Countryman ≈øainct Man≈øuetus with others, into or neare the ≈øame parts, I haue related before. And to the parts of Germany nearer to DeÃÑmarke, the ≈øame glorious Apo≈øtle ≈øainct Peter ≈øent ≈øainct Aegi≈øtus one of the 72. Di≈øciples, and ≈øainct Marianus into the CouÃÑtryes of Germany next to Hol≈øt, and Denmarke who was Martyred there. Flanders and the lowe Countryes receaued the faith from this our Nation, by the preaching of ≈øuch as were ≈øent and authorized by the Church of Rome, as our Prote≈øtant Authours of the Theater of greate Britaine tell vs. For Denmarke, Norway, I≈øland and tho≈øe parts we haue proofe from our Prote≈øtants of England, the auncient lawes of ≈øainct Edward, and other Antiquities, that they receaued the faith of Chri≈øt from ≈øuch al≈øo of this Nation, as were licenced & warranted thereunto, from the Popes of Rome. The French and German writers, both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants te≈øtifie: Britannos, Normannos, Picardos, omnemque maris Oceani tractum in≈øtruxit formanitque ≈øide ≈øanctus Nica≈øius, √† ≈øancto Clemente Apo≈øtolus illuc delegatus, Imperante Nerone: ≈øainct Nica≈øius being ≈øent thither Apo≈øtle in the tyme of Nero by ≈øainct Clement, did in≈øtruct and forme in the faith the Britans, Normans, Picards, and all the coa≈øte of the Ocean Sea.

2. And to coÃÑpa≈ø≈øe all the next parts of the continent, and make ≈øure worke, that no preachers of the faith of Chri≈øt did or could come hither, but from S. Peter, and his Apo≈øtolike See of Rome; If we circuite France, and Spayne, and returne that way into Italy againe, we shall finde it ≈øo. For although we reade, that S. Iames the Apo≈øtle was in Spayne, yet it was before the Gentils were preached vnto, and profited not there in that kinde but left the labour and glory thereof to ≈øainct Peter. The publike Acts of ≈øainct Iames his life beare record: Hispaniam adij≈ø≈øe, & ibi aliquos ad fidem conuerti≈ø≈øe, Eccle≈øiarum illius prouincia traditio e≈øt: ex quorum numero ≈øeptem po≈øtea epi≈øcopi a beato Petro ordinati in Hi≈øpaniam primi directi ≈øunt: It is the tradition of the Churches of that prouince, that ≈øainct Iames the Apo≈øtle went into Spayne, and there conuerted ≈øome to the faith: of which number ≈øeuen were after made Bishops by ≈øainct Peter, and were the fir≈øt were ≈øent thither. The Romane Martyrologe, V≈øuardes ≈øainct Beda, Ado, Pope Gregory the ≈øeuenth in his epi≈øtle to kinge Alphon≈øus, or Adelphon≈øus, Vincentius and others haue the like, and name tho≈øe ≈øeuen Bishops ordeynad by S. Peter and by him ≈øent into Spayne to be the≈øe: Torquatus, Cre≈øiphontes, Secundus, Indaletius, Caecilius, He≈øichius, and Eupha≈øius. Amonge whome Pope Gregory writeth of the≈øe Bishops ≈øent into Spayne by ≈øainct Peter: De≈øtructa Idololatria, Chri≈øtianitatem fundauere, & Religionem plantuere, & ordinem & officium o≈øtendere: hauing de≈øtroyed Idolatrie, they fownded Chri≈øtianitie, and planted Religion, and shewed order and dutie. The generall Spannish hi≈øtorye of Spayne, Beuter and others write that ≈øainct Iames conuerted there onely 9. par≈øons, and ≈øpeaking of the time of Claudius longe before ≈øainct Paule came to Rome, affirme: Sainct Saturnine S. Peters di≈øciple, was ≈øent into Spayne, he which was the fir≈øt Bishop of Tholo≈øe: who preached
at Pampelone, and there conuerted in ≈øeuen dayes fourtie thou≈øand par≈øons. So that we ≈øee the kingdome of Spayne receaued the faith by ≈øainct Peter, his Di≈øciples, and direction.

3. Now let vs wynde nearer to Italy, and goe to Mar≈øeils, where we finde that renowned hi≈øtory of S. Lazarus, and Maximinus coming thither with ≈øainct Mary Magdalen, and her Si≈øter ≈øainct Martha. That the≈øe two holy Bishops were al≈øo directed by ≈øainct Peter, we cannot doubt, when we finde it proued by many Authours, that ≈øainct Maximinus was vnus ex Gulile. Ei≈øengr. centenar. 1. part. 5. 72. Di≈øcipulis Chri≈øti, cui √† diuo Petro Apo≈øtolorum Principe Maria Magdalena commendata fuerat: one of the 72. Di≈øciples of Chri≈øt, to whome Mary Magdalene was committed by ≈øainct Peter Prince of the Apo≈øtles. And as we reade in the acts of ≈øainct Martha, this Di≈øciple of ≈øainct Peter, ≈øainct Maximinus baptized Mai≈øtre Puiel hi≈øt. in vita S. Mariae Magdal. 22. Iulij. Volater. Petr. de Natal b. Antonin. Vuern. Bed. Hamular. & Fortunat. Epi≈øcopus Treuer. apud Ei≈øengr. Centen. 1. part. 1. di≈øt. 3. an. D. 46. all that family. And after their coming vnto Mar≈øeils, their dependance of ≈øainct Peter (then being come to Rome) was no le≈ø≈øe then before, for the French Antiquities tell vs, That after the A≈øcen≈øion of our Lord an. 14. the Iewes rai≈øed ≈øo horrible a per≈øecution again≈øt the Chri≈øtians, that the most part fled whether they could. S. Maximinus accoÃÑpanied with S. Lazarus taketh Mary Magdalen, Martha, Marcella her hand-mayde, and S. Cedoyne borne blynde whome our Lord made to ≈øee, and committed them≈øelues to the Sea, to auoyde the fury of the Iewes, they arriue at Mar≈øeils, after by the per≈øua≈øion of ≈øainct Mary Magdalen, the Prince of Mar≈øeils was Chri≈øtened, and went to Rome, and was there directed by ≈øainct Peter. And this Iorney of King or Duke StepheÃÑ of Fraunce to ≈øainct Peter at Rome to excu≈øe him≈øelfe of the Martyrdome of ≈øainct Valeria his wife, when he was a Pagan, is the common opinion of French Hi≈øtorians, treating of that time. Therefore we cannot Que≈øtion, but tho≈øe holy Bishops ≈øainct Maximinus, and Lazarus, who thus directed others, ≈øo greate a Iorney to Rome to be in≈øtructed, and receaue directions from S. Peter there, were in the ≈øame ca≈øe of dependancie from him them≈øelues.

4. Thus wee haue compa≈ø≈øed all the Sea coa≈øts of Italy, Spayne, Fraunce round about, and finde all places furnished with holy preachers from ≈øainct Peter and the See Apo≈øtolik of Rome. For the other Countryes of Germany, Denmarke, Norwey, and the re≈øt, I haue related how their conuer≈øion was longe after, from this Nation: And Origen writeth that tho≈øe Countries in his time had not yet heard the word of the Gho≈øpell: Circa Oceanum Daci, & Origen. tract. 28. in Matth. Sarmati, & Scythae nondum audierunt Euangelij verbum. Concerning the inward parts of Fraunce, being a Country neare≈øt vnto vs, we finde all the Bishops thereof, being many, to be the Di≈øciples of ≈øainct Peter, and ≈øent from him. And to begin with the cheife≈øt and Primate there, to whom the others were ≈øubordinate, Ei≈øengrenius from many Authors proueth that S. Guliel. Ei≈øengr. Centen. 1. part. 1. di≈øt. 3. f. 56. an. D. 54. He citeth. Bed. Martyrol. prid. cal. Ianuar. Petr. de Natal. l. 2. c. 25. Antonin. part. 1. tit. 6. c. 25. ¬ß. 3. Martin. in Chron. Vicel. in Hagialog. Vuern. Carthu≈øian. in Fa≈øic. tempor. Sauinianus or Sabinus one of the 72. Di≈øciples of Chri≈øt, was by ≈øainct Peter the Apo≈øtle Con≈øecrated Primate of all Fraunce, and Archbishop of Sens, in the 54. yeare of Chri≈øt, when Tybertus Claudius was Emperor, and to him ≈øucceeded in the yeare 74. ≈øainct Potentianus Martyr, al≈øo one of the 72. Di≈øciples and Scholler of ≈øainct Peter cheife of the Apo≈øtles and Companion of ≈øainct Sauinian; ≈øanctus Sauinianus ≈øiue Sabinus vnus ex 72. Chri≈øti Di≈øcipulis a ≈øancto Petro Apo≈øtolo Primas totius Galliae, & Senonen≈øis Archiepi≈øcopus con≈øecratus e≈øt anno Chri≈øti. 54. Tyberio Claudio Cae≈øare Augu≈øto ‚Ä¢ cui ≈øucce≈øsit anno d. 74. ≈øanctus Potentianus Martyr, & ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e ex 72. Petri Apo≈øtolorum Corypha di≈øcipulus, beati Sauiniani in Itinere comes & peregrinationis. Therefore If the two fir≈øt Primates of all Fraunce were the Di≈øciples of ≈øainct Peter, and by him placed in that Dignitie, ouer
all the Bishops of Fraunce, the re≈øt mu≈øt needs be at his Di≈øpotion, and ≈øub≈øtitution, and the fir≈øt of them being ≈øo placed in the yeare of Chri≈øt 54. in the Empire of Claudius when ≈øainct Paul was a ≈øtrunger in this part of the world, this prerogatiue, and honour mu≈øt needs be yeelded to ≈øainct Peter: who was the fir≈øt did ≈øend the fir≈øt preachers, and Bishops into Fraunce, in the time of Claudius, by all te≈øtimonies, longe before ≈øainct Paul came into any we≈øterne parte, or Nation; his fir≈øt coming thither being in the time of Nero, and yet as a Pri≈øoner, to Rome, and ≈øo continuing there two yeares, as both Scripture and Hi≈øtoryes giue ample Te≈øtimony. The Authorities for this ≈øending and mi≈ø≈øion by ≈øainct Peter; are too many to be alledged: Therefore I will onely ≈øet downe diuers of the≈øe fir≈øt Bishops, and the yeares wherein they were fir≈øt con≈øecrated, and directed thither, as they are gathered and collected out of many Authors by Ei≈øengrenius, and Democharez, that It may be euidently knowne, by the time it ≈øelfe, that onely ≈øainct Peter by his Di≈øciples founded the Church of Fraunce.

5. I haue ≈øpoaken of ≈øainct Maximinus, and ≈øainct Lazarus, the fir≈øt Bishop Guliel. Ei≈øengr. Centenar. 1. in S. Maximin. Lazaro & Iuliano. of Aquens, the ≈øecond of Ma≈ø≈øilia con≈øecrated and deputed to tho≈øe places by ≈øainct Peter, no other Apo≈øtle being in the≈øe parts to accomplish that holy worke, the≈øe being ordeined Bishops there, as the≈øe Authors tell vs, in the yeare of Chri≈øt 46. in which yeare al≈øo ≈øainct Simon Lepro≈øus whom our Sauiour cured of that infirmitie was con≈øecrated Bishop of Cenomanen≈øes: This Anton. Democ. l. 2. de Mi≈ø≈øacoÃÑ tra Caluin. Gul. Ei≈øengren. Cent. 1. part. 1. di≈øt. 3. al≈øo was called ≈øainct Iulianus. In the yeare following 47. ≈øainct Martial Di≈øciple and Godchila to ≈øainct Peter; D. Petri Apostolorum Principis, & in Bapti≈ømate filius, was with diuers others ≈øent by the ≈øame holy Apo≈øtle, and was father in Chri≈øt to ≈øo many Prouinces, and people in Fraunce, as the Annals thereof doe mention. In the ≈øame yeare ≈øainct Trophimus, out of who≈øe ≈øpirituall Magdeb. Centu. 1. in Trophim. mart. Rom. in S. Troph. Tom. 1. coÃÑ cil. Gul. Ei≈øengr. CenteÃÑ. 1. Matth. We≈øtm. Arnold. Mirm. in Theatr. conuer≈ø. gent. & alij. Gul. Ei≈øengr. centen. 1. in S. Aphrodi≈øio. fountaine, as Pope Zo≈øimus writeth all the Ryuers and brookes of Fraunce were filled, was ordeyned Bishop of Arles, which mu≈øt needs be by ≈øainct Peter, being twelue yeares at the lea≈øt, before that time, ≈øome thinke he was left there by ≈øainct Paul. In the yeare following being 48. ≈øainct Aphordi≈øius by birth an Egiptian, and Prefect of all Egpyt, at the time when our Sauiour being driuen into Egypt, the Idols of the temples there, fell doune, being the Di≈øciple of S. Peter, Prince of the Apo≈øtles at Antioch was con≈øecrated Bishop of the Church of Buturigum in Fraunce. ≈øanctus Aphrodi≈øius genere Aegyptius, totius Aegypti praefectus, eo tempore, quo puero Ie≈øu in Aegyptum fugato, & in templa Deorum illato, Idola omnia corruerunt, B. Petro Apostolorum Coryphaei apud Antiochiam Di≈øcipulus, Buturicen≈øis Eccle≈øiae con≈øecratus e≈øt Antistes anno Chri≈øti 48. ≈øedit annis VolaterraÃÑ. comment. l. 13. Petrus de Natalib. l. 3. c. 218. Gul. Ei≈øeng. Centenar. 1. part. 1. di≈øt. 3. Franc. Bellefore≈øt to. 1. Ei≈øengr. Centen. 1. fol. 56. ≈øex, moritur 11. cal ‚Ä¢ ndas Aprilis anno Saluatoris 54. he was Bishop there ≈øixe yeares, and dyed the eleuenth of the calends of April: and ≈øanctus Vr≈øinus √† beato Petro con≈øecratus: con≈øecrated by ≈øainct Peter, whom ≈øome call Nathaniel, ≈øucceeded hym, in his Bishoprick in the yeare of Christ 54. And the ≈øame yeare 48, (except Ei≈øengrenius and others cited by him, deceaue vs) Paulus Sergius was con≈øecrated Bishop of Narbon, eight or more yeares before ≈øainct Paul came to Rome, and ≈øo by no other Apo≈øtle but ≈øainct Peter. The next yeare after, the 49. of Chri≈øt, by the la≈øt accompt, ≈øainct Clement ≈øurnamed Flauius with Caele≈øtus & Faelix, and our contryman ≈øainct Man≈øuetus fir≈øt Bishop of Tullum were directed in Gallias, the parts of Fraunce by ≈øainct Peter. In the yeare 54. thes Authors te≈øtifie, That ≈øainct Amator, Potentianus, Sauinianus, Fronto, with others were ≈øent Bishops by ≈øainct Peter into Fraunce: all longe before ≈øainct Paules coming to Rome. And for a Religious memory, and due honour of ≈øainct
Peter, and the See of Rome in that re≈øpect, Tho≈øe Sees of Bishops which were fir≈øt founded by ≈øainct Peter, and his Succe≈ø≈øour ≈øainct Clement, of whom Annal. Gall. Booke of E≈øtat. in Fraunce. Edw. Grym≈øton. p. 97. I shall ≈øpeake hereafter in his proper place, are for the mo≈øt part the cheife≈øt Archbishops Sees there at this time. As the Archbishops of Reims, Sens, Lyon, Soi≈ø≈øons, Amiens, Noyon, Paris, Charters, Orleans, Angers, Mans, Beuuis, Burges, Bishops ≈øees founded in Fraunce by S. Peter in honor‚ñ™ thereof are for the mo≈øt part Archbishops Sees at this time. Tours, Chalon, Auxerre, Troys, Meaux, Angole≈øme, Baion, Narbon, Rouen, Burdeaux, Aix, Vienna, and others: all fir≈øt founded by ≈øainct Peter the Apo≈øtle, and his Succe≈ø≈øor ≈øainct Clement, as before ≈øainct Peter, and in ≈øainct Clement hereafter is, and shall be related.

6. And becau≈øe ≈øome Que≈øtion hath bene, by whom ≈øainct Trophimus ≈øo renowned in Fraunce, was fir≈øt ≈øent to Arles there, to pa≈ø≈øe ouer other te≈øtimonies, the epi≈øtle of the Bishops of that Prouince to ≈øainct Leo the greate, S. Trophimus ≈øent to Arles in FrauÃÑce by S. Peter. Pope of Rome, cleareth this for to be ≈øainct Peters doing. Omnibus Regionibus Gallicanis notum est, ≈øed non ≈øacro≈øanctae Eccle≈øiae Romanae habetur incognitum, quod prima inter Gallias Arelaten≈øis ciuitas mi≈ø≈øum √† beati≈øsimo Petro Apo≈øtolo Epi≈øtola coÃÑprouincialium Epi≈øcoporum Metropolis Arelaten. ad S. LeoneÃÑ Papam. inter epi≈øt. S. Leonis epi≈øt. 108. & in Tom. 1. concil. ≈øanctum Trophimum habere meruit ≈øacerdotem, & exinde alijs paulatim regionibus GalliaruÃÑ donum fidei & Religionis infu≈øum: It is knowne to all Countries of Fraunce, neyther is it vnknowne to the holy Romane Church, that Arles the cheife citie of Fraunce de≈øerued to haue for Prei≈øt, ≈øainct Trophimus ≈øent from ≈øainct Peter the Apo≈øtle, and from thence by little and little the gift of faith was infu≈øed to the other Regions of Fraunce. Where we ≈øee it proued by the publike letters and te≈øtimonie of all the Bishops of that Prouince: That it was a certaine and confe≈ø≈øed truth among all the Churches of Fraunce, and knowne al≈øo at Rome, that ≈øainct Trophimus who was ≈øo renowned in Fraunce was ≈øent thither by ≈øainct Peter; which yet doth not condemne their opinion, which ≈øay, ≈øainct Paul in his Iorney from Rome to Spayne left him by the way at Arles whether he was formerly ≈øent by ≈øainct Peter, and ≈øainct Paul finding him at Arles, went on his Iorney leauing ≈øainct Trophimus, where he found him. Which confirmeth that I haue deliuered before of this matter, and thus I haue compa≈ø≈øed and circuited all CouÃÑtries round about vs, & find that they all fir≈øt receaued the faith of Chri≈øt in the≈øe times by ≈øainct Peter the Apo≈øtle, and his di≈øciples, and no other meanes but this, was left, or to be fownde in hi≈øtories to bring the fir≈øt knowledge of ≈øaluation to this Kingdome. And hauing this farre entreated of ≈øainct Peters Di≈øciples, let vs now ≈øpeake of that mo≈øt glorious Apo≈øtle him≈øelfe & his & preacing heare.

div.head: THE XIIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN IS PROVED BY MANY ARGVments, Authorities, and Antiquaries both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants that ≈øainct Peter the Apo≈øtle par≈øonally preached, and founded Chri≈øtian Religion in this kingdome.

div.p: 1. NOW I am come, to giue that glory to this kingdome, whereof a Prote≈øtant thus ≈øpeaketh: we should accompt it Godwyn Conu. of Brit ‚Ä¢ ine. p. 6. a greate glory to our Nation to deriue the peti-degree of our ≈øpituall linadge, from ≈øo noble and excellent a father, as ≈øainct Peter. And diuers others of that profe≈ø≈øion will ≈øeeme to giue that Preeminencie vnto him. To ≈øatisfie therefore, the≈øe men, and giue that due honour to this kingdome: this is ≈øufficieÃÑtly proued before by tho≈øe that haue told vs he preached in all kingdomes and Ilands of the we≈øt; therefore this Cuontry, ≈øo greate, and ample a portion of the we≈øterne world, and the mo≈øt florishing Iland thereof, cannot be excluded from this prerogatiue. This moued our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King Lucius, and the S. Peter his per≈øonall preaching, and founding our Church in Britain proued by all human authoritie. cheife≈øt of the cleargie heare in that time, in the fir≈øt publik and generall conuer≈øion of this kingdome to dedicate the fir≈øt and principall Churches of this Land to this glorious Apo≈øtle, as our fir≈øt father and founder in Chri≈øt, as namely two in one cittie of London, the one of them the Metropolitane cheife See, diuers hundreds of yeares, ≈øcituated in Cornhill, and ≈øtill keeping the name of ≈øainct Peters Church: The other at we≈øtmin≈øter al≈øo to this day Stowe hi≈øt. in K. Lucius an. D. 179 Holinsh. ib. hi≈øt. of Engl. The Table of S. Peters Church there. Ihon Norden Specul. Britan. part. 1. p. 42. Camden in Brit. Belgae Sommer≈øetsh ‚Ä¢ re. Francis Ma≈øon Con≈øecrat. l. 2. c. cap. 2. pag. ‚Ä¢ 0. retayning the name, ≈øainct Peters Church, and diuers others in this kingdome, when except that of Gla≈øtenbury dedicated to our ble≈ø≈øed lady, ≈øainct Mary, we cannot finde the like of dedicating ≈øo auncient and many Churches to any other ≈øainct, ≈øainct Paul, ≈øainct Io≈øeph, or whom ≈øoeuer ≈øuppo≈øed to haue preached heare.

2. The next argument shall be from the te≈øtimonie of our holy King Inas and the Clergie of England then. Who in the place of the olde Church of Gla≈øtenbury, building a very magnificent new Church dedicated it to Chri≈øt, ≈øainct Peter, and ≈øainct Paul, and in the high forefront thereof engraued certaine ver≈øes in the honour of ≈øainct Peter and ≈øainct Paul, among which the≈øe three are founde.

q.l: Surgit in his templum quod placet ara Deo.
Anglia plaude lubens, mittit til ‚Ä¢ Roma ≈øalutem,
Fulgor Apo≈øtolicus Gla≈øconiam irradiat.

div.p:
The fir≈øt which our Prote≈øtants omitt to tran≈ølate is thus: in Th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe (to wit ≈øainct Peter and ≈øainct Paul‚ñ™ a Church and an Altar plea≈øing vnto God is rai≈øed, The other two are thus tran ‚Ä¢ lated by our Prote≈øtants: Be glad England, Rome ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ deth health to thee, and Apostolicall Brightnes doth lighten Glastenbury. And they ≈øay that this is ment either of doctrine, or protection. But the words mittit ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ bi Roma ≈øalutem: That Rome ≈ø ‚Ä¢ nt ≈øaluation vnto Britaine, and the Apo≈øtolicall
brightnes of ≈øainct Peter and Paule did illuminate Gla≈øtenbury, doe include onely doctrine and Saluation, and no mention there at all is had of protection, which is contrary, to prote≈øtant Religion: and in Catholik Religion, for ≈øo worthie a King, as ≈øainct Inas was to a≈øcribe the patronadge of Gla≈øten burie to ≈øainct Peter and ≈øainct Paul, if neither of them had giuen Influence to the fir≈øt ≈øettling of Religion there, and exclude ≈øainct Io≈øeph, who both liued and died in that place, is an harsh & vnworthie con≈øtruction: And to giue further te≈øtimonie, that the words of that In≈øcription are altogether to be vnder≈øtood of our fir≈øt conuer≈øion, and receauing the faith from ≈øainct Peter and Rome all tho≈øe ver≈øes excepting the words Anglia, and Gla≈øtonia, England, and Gla≈øtenbury, are taken word by word from Venantius Fortunatus, Bishop of Venant. Fortun. l. 3. c. 7. Poyctires in Fraunce, who te≈øtifieth in tho≈øe ver≈øes, (as I haue by others proued before) that Gallia, Fraunce, and the Allobroge people of Sanoye, and the Dolphinists were conuerted by S. Peter and his di≈øciples, and S. Paul al≈øo preached there, as I shall shew hereafter: And therefore among the re≈øt of the encomia≈øticall ver≈øes of tho≈øe two glorious Apo≈øtles, hath the≈øe:

q.l: Gallia plaude Lubens, mittit tibi Roma ≈øalutem:
Fulgor Apo≈øtolicus vi≈øitat Allobrogas.

div.p: Which King Inas applyed to Britanie, and Gla≈øtenbury, in the ≈øame maÃÑner onely changing Gallia into Anglia, and Allobrogas into Gla≈øtoniam, and to make a true ver≈øe, vi≈øitat into Irradiat in the maner before related:

q.l: Anglia plaude lubens, mittit tibi Roma ≈øalutem:
Fulgor Apo≈øtolicus Gla≈øtoniam irradiat.

div.p: Which he neither would, nor truly could haue done, except, as venantius Fortunatus truely found by vndeniable Authorities, that Fraunce and the people of Sauoy and Delphinate did fir≈øt receaue the doctrine of Saluation from Rome, S. Peter, and S. Paul; So King Inas had ≈øufficient warrant, to apply the very ≈øame, and in the ≈øame ≈øence, to Britaine or England and Gla≈øtenbury to haue receaued the fir≈øt light of faith from the ≈øame Rome, and holy Apo≈øtles S. Peter and S. Paul.

Thus we ≈øee by inuincible te≈øtimonies, and many Prote≈øtants them≈øelues, confe≈ø≈øing and approuing them, that this was a mo≈øt certainely true, and infallibly an vndoubted heauenly vi≈øion, That it was ≈øainct Peter glorified in heauen, that appeared and reuealed the≈øe things to our holy Bishop ≈øainct Brithwold.

14. And to demon≈øtrate ≈øainct Brithwold to be a true propo≈øer of the≈øe ≈øecrets, he had propo≈øed them to the world, and was dead before they began to take effect, and be fullfilled: The my≈øteries foretold were beyonde the compa≈ø≈øe of naturall knowledge, to fore≈øee, or prophe≈øie of. As that a bannished child, and perhaps then vnborne, should beconne ≈øo worthie, ≈øo holy, ≈øo victorious a King. That a Nation ≈øo generally, and long time ouerwhelmed with ≈øo greate calamities, should ≈øo ≈øtrangely, and beyond expectation in a time foretold, be redemed and ≈øet at liberty. That at a time appointed a bannished exile should become ≈øo miraculous, potent, and victorious a King, that he should reigne ≈øo many certainely appointed 24. yeares, that a married man e≈øpecially a king should liue and die a virgine. And the re≈øt before remembred, hauing no cau≈øes in nature to know them by, should thus miraculou≈øly, and infallibly, be foretolde ≈øo long before, there was no lea≈øte hope, expectation, or in morall Iudgmentany probabilitie or rather po≈ø≈øibilitie at all of many or mo≈øt of the≈øe extraordinary future euents: But rather a doubted Alred. Rieual. in vit. S. Edward. Guliel. Malme≈ø. ≈øup. Stow. hi≈øt. in K. Edward. Confe≈ø≈ø. Holinsh. l. 8. hi≈øt. of Engl. c. 7. Theater of great Britaine in K. Edward Conf. with others. Godwyn. Catal. in Winche≈øter 3. Brith wold. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of England. l. 8. cap. 1. Stowe hi≈øt. in K. Edward Confe≈ø≈ø. will. Malme≈øb. l. de ge≈øt. Reg. Anglorum c. 13. feare or certainety of the contrary. And yet all the≈øe things were published to the world, diuers yeares before they tooke effect, and in the life of ≈øainct Brithwold propo≈øer of them, who by the ≈øame reuelation was, dormire cum patribus, to be dead, before they began. Which is apparantly true euen by our Prote≈øtants them≈øelues, to giue them their choi≈øe whether ≈øainct Brithwold Bishop of winche≈øter or wilton it was, that had this vi≈øion. For the≈øe Prote≈øtants a≈ø≈øure vs, that ≈øainct Brithwold of winche≈øter was dead allmo≈øt 30. yeares before the returne of ≈øainct Edward from exile. And it is the common opinion the reuelation was made to him. And if it was Brithwold Bishop of wilton he was al≈øo dead by the≈øe mens accompts, 22. yeares at the lea≈øte before the≈øe things were accomplished. Therefore I mu≈øt infallibly conclude, that ≈øainct Peter or who≈øoeuer it was, which ≈øo prophetically and miraculou≈øly foretold ≈øo many things of this holy King, and this kingdome to be effected ≈øo long after, was not, and po≈ø≈øibly could not be an vntrue or doubtfull Relator of ≈øainct Peters fir≈øt preaching in this Nation, conteined, and as con≈øtantly auouched as the re≈øt of tho≈øe reuealed my≈øteries foretold in that vi≈øion. And the Inhabitants of Britaine are ≈øo much more bounde to glorifie God, and Honor this mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtle, as both his extraordinary fir≈øt labours in in≈øtructing this kingdome in the true Religion of Chri≈øt, and this his extraordinary care and Pa≈øtorall loue in ≈øo many wayes making it knowne vnto vs, to lett vs vnder≈øtand, how much we are bounde vnto him for ≈øuch ine≈øtimable benefices, de≈øerue it. Which we reade in our hi≈øtory ‚Ä¢ s both Catholik and Prote≈øtant to be confirmed by an other example of like nature, but of more auncient memory a thow≈øand yeares ≈øince, in the time of king Ethelbert,
our fir≈øt chri≈øtian king, of the Saxons Race. When ≈øainct Peter miraculou≈øly te≈øtified concerning the Church of We≈øtmin≈øter in London, in the≈øe M. S. antiq. in S. Edward. Confe≈ø. Guliel. Malme≈ø. l. 2. de ge≈øt. Pontif. c. de Epi≈øcopis Londin. Alred. Rieuall. in vit. S. Edward. Ioan. Capgrau. Catal. eodem. Franc. Ma≈øon Con≈øecr. of Bish. pag. 47. Nichol. Pap. 2. in epi≈øt. ad Edward. Reg. Angl. apud Capgrau. in S. Edward. M. S. antiq. in eod. & Alred. Rieuall. in vit. S. Edwardi. words as a Prote≈øtant writer tran≈ølateth them: E≈øt mihi locus: I haue quoth S. Peter a place in the we≈øt part of London, cho≈øen to my ≈øelf, and deare vnto me, which ≈øometimes I did dedicate with my owne hands; Quem locum quondam proprijs manibus con≈øecraui, renowne with my pre≈øence, and Illu≈øtrate with diuine miracles, the name where of is Thorneia, We≈øtmin≈øter. Which cannot litterally & truely be vnder≈øtood of any ≈øpirituall vi≈øion, wherin ≈øainct Peter in his onely glorified. ≈øoule should appeare, as in the time of King Ethelbert we reade he did, but of his per≈øonall pre≈øence there before his death, when and neuer after, nor vntill the day of Iudgment and the generall Re≈øurrection, ≈øainct Peter had, or at any time shall haue, proprias manus, his owne hands, or any parte of his body vnited to his ≈øoule, & yet he ≈øpeaketh plainely here, proprijs manibus con≈øecrauithe con≈øecrated that place with his owne hands, which is not true either in a ≈øpirituall vi≈øion, or where an a≈ø≈øumpted body is v≈øed, for an a≈ølumpted bodie, hand, foote, or any other member caÃÑnot be called the proper and owne body, Hande, foote or other member of any par≈øon. Therefore Pope Nicholas the ≈øecond ≈øpeaking of this matter, in his Epi≈øtle to ≈øainct Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor, ≈øaith, this place was con≈øecrated by S. Peter who≈øe vicar he was: primam autiquitus con≈øecrationem √† heato Petro accepit cuius licet Indigni Vicarij ≈øumus: Therefore except Pope Nicholas may be ≈øaid, to be Vicar to ≈øainct Peters Soule, and not to him, as he was Bishop of Rome in body and ≈øoule, we mo≈øt by him and this antiquarie referre this matter to ≈øainct Peters fir≈øt preaching in this land, when he liued, and not to any apparition in ≈øoule onely, as that was wherein he appeared at We≈øtmin≈øter in the time of King Ethelbert, and S. Mellitus Bishop of London: of which more hereafter. Now I will an≈øweare to ≈øome vaine and weake obiections of a few Prote≈øtant writers, and al≈øo shew by ≈øuch men, in what time, or times, once or oftner S. Peter preached per≈øonally in this Iland, ≈øo neare as probably may be concluded in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, as al≈øo what holy offices he performed heare in founding the Church of Chri≈øt in Britaine.

div.head: THE XV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN IS BOTH ANSWEARE MADE to Prote≈øtant obiections againct S. Peters preaching in Britaine, by the Prote≈øtants them≈øelues, and their owne Authors; and by the ≈øame confirmed, that S. Peter preached in this kingdome.

div.p:
A Prote≈øtant Bishop challengeth S. Symeon metaphrastes, for writing ≈øo confidently of S. Peters preaching heare; & hauing not Godwyn Conu. of Britaine p. 3. cap. 1. any thing to except again≈øt him, fir≈øt vpbraydeth him with his CouÃÑtries of Greece Graecus fuit, & haec natio e≈øt fuit
que ; ≈øemper ad mentiendum promptula: he was a Grecian, and that Nation is, and euer was a litle promt to lie. But by ≈øuch libertie we may condemne the greate≈øt lights of the Chuch of God, S. Athana≈øius, Chry≈øo≈øtome,
SS. Gregories, Naziancen, and Ni≈ø≈øen, the ≈øeeuen fir≈øt generall Councels kept in Greece, and cheifely of Greeke fathers, and ≈øo leaue nothing certaine in the Church of God. But how free from all ≈øu≈øpition of lying that holy Saint was in this poinct, I haue shewed to the shame of all ≈øuch accu≈øers before, demon≈øtratiuely prouing by all kind of Te≈øtimonyes, that his te≈øtimonye herein was true. And whereas this Prote≈øtant Bishop vrgeth again≈øt that holy Saint that Cae≈øar Baronius should write of him: in his e≈ø≈øe hallucinatuÃÑ con≈øtat: Baron. annal. Eccl. Chri≈øti. an. 44. pag. 371. it is euident he was deceaued in the≈øe things: It is mo≈øt euident, this Prote≈øtant Bishop was either deceaued in him≈øelf, or went about to deceaue others his readers in this point, for Cardinall Baronius is ≈øo farre from going about to take the lea≈øt exception again≈øt S. Simeon Metaphra≈øtes, for te≈øtifiing S. Peters preaching in Britaine, and the we≈øt Nations, that he followeth him, and others in that opinion, in the≈øe words: Cum non ≈øicut in Orientales orbis Baron. Annal. to. 1. an. Chri≈øti. 58. pag. 597. partes ≈øciamus caeteros Apo≈øtolos mi≈ø≈øos e≈ø≈øe in occidentem vno excepto Barnaba, qui ad breue tempus, Ligures docuit, vel Iacobo (Si tamen con≈øen≈øerimus ijs qui tradunt eum cito rediturum Hispaniam penetra≈ø≈øe) caeterorum autem neminem e≈ø≈øe mi≈ø≈øum liquido appareat. Petri igitur muneris erat, vt qui iam quamplures Orientis prouincias, praedicando Euangelium peragra≈ø≈øet, iam (quod reliquum e≈ø≈øe videbatur) lu≈øtraret orbem occidentalem, & v≈øque ad Britannos (quod tradunt Metaphra≈øtes & alij) Metaphr. die 29. Iunij. Chri≈øti fidem annuntians penetraret: when we know that the re≈øt of the Apo≈øtles were not ≈øent into the we≈øt, as into the Ea≈øterne parts of the world, except onely Barnabas who a short time taught the LigariaÃÑs, or Iames (if we shall con≈øent to them who deliuer, that quikly to returne from thence, he went into Spayne.) It manife≈øtly appeareth that none of the others were ≈øent into the we≈øt part of the world. Therefore it was the office of Peter, who hauing trauailed very many prouinces of the Ea≈øte, in preaching the gho≈øpell, now, which was left to doe, he should compa≈ø≈øe the westerne world, and as Metaphra≈øtes and others deliuer, penetrate to the Britans, preaching the faith of Chri≈øt. Where he maketh it a certaine knowne truth, and manife≈øtly apparent in Hi≈øtories, Sciamus, liquido appareat, that none of the twelue Apo≈øtles but onely S. Peter preached the word of Chri≈øt in Britaine; and among others citeth and followeth S. Metaphra≈øtes for that manife≈øt truth. And when he had alledged diuers, and approued Authors for Chri≈øts appearing to S. Peter, and ≈øending him into this we≈øt part of the world, he addeth: Metaphra≈øtes his con≈øentiens Metaph. 29. Iun. haec ≈øcribit: vi≈øus e≈øt ei Dominus in vi≈øione, dicens: Surge Petre, vade ad Occidentem, opus enim habet, vt tuis illu≈øtretur facibus: & ego ero tecum: Metaphra≈øtes con≈øenting vnto the≈øe, writeth thus: our Lord appeared to him (S. Peter) in a vi≈øion, Baron. Annal. to. 1. & in Indice v. Petrus. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. ≈øaying: o Peter ari≈øe and goe to the we≈øt, for it hath neede to be lighted with thy links, and I will be with thee. And he ≈øaith plainely, for his owne opinion: Petrus a Domino monitus in occidentem venit: Peter admonished by our Lord ≈øo to doe, came into the we≈øt: & as hereafter, ≈øetteth downe his time of coming hither into Britaine, in the tyme of Claudius the Emperor.

2. Therefore except we would be ≈øo willfull, that we should neither bel ‚Ä¢ eue ≈øo many worthie witne≈ø≈øes, nor Chri≈øt him≈øelf, we cannot be doubtfull Godwyn Conu. of Brit. c. 1. p. 6. & pag. 5. in the≈øe things. And it is more to be noted in this Prote≈øtant Bishop who in an other place calleth the ≈øame S. Simeon Metaphra≈øtes, an Authour without exception: and v≈øeth him as a principall witnes, in other matters of as greate importance. How gro≈ø≈øe and ignorant that exception of a Prote≈øtant Sutcliff. ≈øubuer≈ø. prope fuit. Doctor is, to the Reuelation made to S. Brithwold our Bishop about S. Peters preaching heare, becau≈øe, as he ≈øaith, the holy man to whome it was made, is not named, is allready manife≈øtly proued, his name being ≈øet downe together
with his learning, pietie, and worthines, by ≈øo many worthie Authours before remembred. And more childish is that, which an other by direction of the Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury, writeth ignorantly or malitiou≈øly affirming, that it was not this hi≈øtory and Reuelation, which Alredus Francis Ma≈øon Ordinat. of Bishops l. 2. cap. 2. pag. 47. 48. committed to writing, but an other about the Dedication of the Church of we≈øtmin≈øter, in the time of King Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor, to a Reclu≈øe, an holy man of that time. When both the matter, men to whome the≈øe things were reuealed, the times, places, and all circum≈øtances are quite different. And both the hi≈øtories and Reuelations for the mo≈øt part of them are ≈øet downe by S. Alredus, Willian of Malmesbury, the auncient Manu≈øcripts of S. Edwards life, Ihon Capgraue, and the Prote≈øtant Authours them≈øelues before alledged.

3. But our Prote≈øtants further obiect: Onuphrius denieth he (S. Peter) went Theater of great Britaine l. 6. c. 9. we≈øtward being expul≈øed by Claudius, but to Hieru≈øalem, and thence to Antioch, where he liued till the death of Claudius. To which I an≈øwere this is euidently fal≈øe, by their owne words, immediately before, which be the≈øe: I ≈øee not well how it can ≈øtand either with Eu≈øebius his accompt which keeps him (S. Peter) ≈øo longe at Rome, or Onuphrius: as before from him alledged. For if Eu≈øebius a≈ø≈øigning S. Peter to be ≈øo longe at Rome 24. or 25. yeares, did ≈øo fix him there, that he could not in that time vi≈øite this Iland, nearer to Rome then Antioch is: How dare the≈øe men in their next words thus auouch? that S. Peter went from Rome expul≈øed by Claudius to Hieru≈øalem, and from thence to Antioche, in Siria and ≈øtaied there vntill the death of Claudius. The≈øe two cannot po≈ø≈øibly agree, but I haue recon≈øiled the≈øe things before. And whereas the≈øe men would frame their building to keepe S. Peter out of Rome, by vertue of the Edict of Claudius bannishing the Iewes from thence, it is ouerthrowne before, for I haue proued that S. Peter was longe time in Rome in the life of Claudius, after that Edict. Secondly it is euident by all Antiquities, that S. Peter was gone from S. Sim. Metaphr. 29. Ian. S. Dama≈ø. orat. 2. de dormit. Deiparae. Dion. Areopag. epi≈øt. ad Timot. Nicephor. l. 2. c. 22. Mat. We≈øtm. an. 45. 49. Godwin. Conuer≈ø. Act. c. 18. v. 2. Rome to Hieru≈øalem, to be pre≈øent by reuelation with the other Apo≈øtles, at the Migration of our ble≈ø≈øed Lady Mary the virgine, and our Prote≈øtants do not deny it, longe time (4. yeares by Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter and others) before the Edict of Claudius, this being, as both the ≈øcriptures, and hi≈øtories agree, in, or about the 49. yeare of Chri≈øt; and the other in the 45. And how could the Edict of Claudius concerne S. Peters either expul≈øion, or keeping out of Rome? when both by the Scripture, Io≈øephus, Oro≈øius, Ado, & others, it onely concerned the tumultuous Iewes; Claudius Imperator Iudaeos tumultuantes √† Roma expulit: Claudius the Emperor expelled the Tumultious Iewes from Rome? for S.
