Peter was not within the compa≈ø≈øe of that Edict, being neither in Religion a Iew, but a chife Chri≈øtian then, fauoured rather then Act. 18. Io≈øeph. & Oro≈ø. l. 7. c. 6. Oro≈øij. Ado. chron. aetat. 6. in Claudio. FloreÃÑt. Wigorn. an. 50. or 72. &c. per≈øecuted by Claudius: much le≈ø≈øe was he accu≈øed of any tumult there. And though no good Chri≈øtian can thinke, that our cheife Pa≈øtor S. Peter did feare the Edict of Claudius, if it had concerned him, but was ready to die rather (as he did in the time of Nero) then to for≈øake the sheepe of Chri≈øt, ≈øo carefully coÃÑmitted vnto him: yet to make all ≈øure in this kind, that which the≈øe Prote≈øtants would make their ground, to keepe S. Peter from Rome & the≈øe parts, in that time, doth ouerthrowe theÃÑ in their owne deui≈øing: for it is as the Magdeburg. ceÃÑt. 1. l. 2. col. 26. Oro≈ø. l. 7. c. 6. Suein vit. Claudij. Magdeburgian Prote≈øtants acknowledge, froÃÑ their con≈øtructioÃÑ of the ≈øaying of Oro≈øius in his ≈øeuenth booke, and Suetonius in the life of Claudius: Claudium Iudaeos impul≈øore Chri≈øto a≈øsidu√® tumultiuantes Roma expuli≈ø≈øe: That Claudius did expell from Rome, the Iewes dayly making tumults, Christ (≈øo they reade)
being the mouer. Therefore ≈øeeing the Iewes were expelled for tumults they made, and we are a≈ø≈øured that the Chri≈øtians were in no wi≈øe Agents in the≈øe tumults, Claudius could not expell them vnder that pretence. And where they reade. Chri≈øto impul≈øore, Chri≈øt being the impeller, if we apply it to Chri≈øt our Sauiour, either it mu≈øt be vnder≈øtood that Chri≈øt moued to the tumults, which is bla≈øphemous, or that he moued Claudius to expell the Iewes, and ≈øo the Chri≈øtians were not expelled, for Chri≈øt neither did, would, or could moue to expell the Chri≈øtans his holy Seruants.

4. And Oro≈øius him≈øelf hauing with Gregorius Turonen≈øis, and others Oro≈øius l. 7. c. 6. Greg. Turon. l. 1. hi≈øt. cap. 25. a≈øcribed the conuer≈øion of the fir≈øt Chri≈øtians in Rome, in the beginning of the Reigne of Claudius vnto S. Peter, he addeth: Anno eiu≈ødem nono expul≈øos per Claudium vrbe Iudaeos Io≈øephus re≈øert. Sed me magis Suetonius mouet, qui ait hoc modo: Claudius Iudaeos Impul≈øore Chri≈øto a≈øsidu√® tumultuantes Roma expulit. Quod vtrum contra Chri≈øtum tumultuantes Iudaeos coerceri & comprimi iu≈ø≈øerit, an etiam Chri≈øtianos ≈øimul velut cognatae religionis homines voluerit expelli, nequaquam di≈øcernitur: Io≈øephus relateth, that Claudius expelled the Iewes out of the citie, in the ninth yeare of his Reigne. But Suetonius moueth me more, who ≈øaith in this manner: Claudius expelled forth of Rome the Iewes, dayly making tumults, Chri≈øt mouing. Which is not decerned whether he commanded the Iewes that made tumults against Christ to be corrected, and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, or would al≈øo haue the Chri≈øtians, men in Religion ≈øome what like the Iewes to be al≈øo expelled. This is all he ≈øaith, and which others ground vpon, and this later con≈øtruction as I haue proued before, mo≈øt needs giue place to the former, which keepeth the Chri≈øtians in fauour with Claudius, and free from Banishment; which is confirmed by Suidas and others: he writeth in Claudius in this manner: Cum ≈øub eo Iudaei ≈øeditionem contra Suidas in Claudio. Chri≈øtianos moui≈ø≈øent, Claudius Faelicem eis praefecit, co≈øque punire iu≈øsit. When vnder Claudius the Iewes did rai≈øe ≈øedition against the Chri≈øtians, Claudius oppointed Felix Gouernour ouer them, and cau≈øed him to punish them. Whereby it is manife≈øt, that Claudius was then rather a friend, then enemy to Chri≈øtians. And they which reade, Chri≈øto impul≈øore: Christ being the mouer, are mi≈øtaken, for it was Chre≈øto impul≈øore, Chre≈øtus being the mouer hereof. Which Chre≈øtus was a wicked Pagan then liuing in Rome, as many Pagans them≈øelues are witne≈ø≈øes. Zo≈øimus a Pagan together with Xiphilinus, Dio, Sextus Aurelius, victor and others witne≈ø≈øe, that „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Chre≈øtus was then a Con≈øul in great credit in Zo≈øim. Com. hi≈øt. Graec. l. 1. in Alexand. Seuer. Ioh. Xiphilin. in Epitom. Dionis in eodem. Sext. Aurel. Victor. hi≈øt. Aug. Oro≈ø. ≈øupr. Ado in Chronic. aetat. 6. Suetonius in Claudio. Sueton. in Nerone. Aelius Lamprid. in Alexand. Seu. Rome; and being by Latine tran≈ølators tran≈ølated Chri≈øtus after the maÃÑner of many Grecians pronouÃÑcing
‚Ä¢
or ita, as.
‚Ä¢ . in Latine, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ being the Greeke to Chri≈øtus, and written with
‚Ä¢ . iota, and not
‚Ä¢ , eta or ita, was the occa≈øion of this mi≈øtaking, to write, Chri≈øto Impul≈øore, for Chresto impul≈øore as Oro≈øius and Ado, and perhaps ≈øome others did, citing Suetonius for their Authour; which is euideÃÑt by Suetonius him≈øelf, who in the place cited from him, readeth Chre≈øto, and not Christo. His words be the≈øe: Iudaeos Impul≈øore Chre≈øto a≈øsidu√® tumultuantes Roma expulit. Claudius expelled the Iewes out of Rome becau≈øe they dayly made tumults, Chre≈øtus being the mouer thereof. And the ≈øame Suetonius calleth Chri≈øtians by their name Chri≈øtians, and not Chre≈øtians, ≈øo doth Flauius Vopi≈øcus in his epi≈øtle to Adrian the Emperor, call Chri≈øt our Sauiour, and Chri≈øtians beleuing in him Chri≈øtum, and Chri≈øtianos, Chri≈øt, and Chri≈øtians: ≈øo doth Aelius Lampridius and other Pagan Authours. And that Chre≈øtus which was Impul≈øor, a mouer in tho≈øe affaires, and occa≈øion of the Edict of Claudius, being a Pagan was ≈øo wicked a man that I may not de≈øcribe him, being ≈øo impious that Martial the Poet liuing in tho≈øe dayes, and ≈øtayned al≈øo with the tinctures
of greate ≈øinns, yet, ≈øpeaking of him and his behauiour, concludeth: pudet fari: Martial. Epigr. l. 7. Epigram. 54. & lib. 9. Epigr. 28 he is ashamed to speake it. Therefore to followe this ≈øo warranted opinion that S. Peter was no bannished man from Rome by that Edict of Claudius, but voluntarily, ex reuelatione, by reuelation, as the other Apo≈øtles di≈øper≈øed al≈øo did at that time, went to Hieru≈øalem, to celebrate the A≈ø≈øumption of the ble≈ø≈øed virgin, and to be pre≈øent at the Councell of the Apo≈øtles, we shall leaue time enough for S. Peter to returne againe to Rome, and vi≈øit al≈øo this kingdome, and the≈øe we≈øterne parts in the time of Claudius. For our Prote≈øtants agree, that Councell to haue bene kept about the fourteenth yeare of the A≈øcen≈øion of Chri≈øt, building vpon S. Paul, who ≈øaith: fourteene yeares Sutcliffe Subu. pag. 3. Godwyn Conuer≈ø. p. 5. c. 1. Gal. 2. v. 1. Prote≈øt Fa≈øti Reg. & Epi≈øcop. Angl. after I went vp againe to Hieru≈øaleÃÑ with Barnabas, and tooke Titus with mee. Which was the time of this Councell of the Apo≈øtles, & the la≈øt Act of note, at which the≈øe Prote≈øtants ≈øay S. Peter was pre≈øent at Hieru≈øalem, from which vnto the death of S. Peter they tell vs in their Chronologie of Kings & Bishops of this Nation, there were twenty yeares, time enough to haue preached heare in the time of Claudius, if he were not heare before his going from Rome to Hieru≈øalem.

5. If we should harken to their opinion, that would haue S. Peter bannished from Rome by that Edict of Claudius, and ≈øo to haue therevpon gone to Hieru≈øalem, ≈øeeing they tell vs before, he ≈øtaied not there longer then the 14. or 15. yeare after Chri≈øts A≈øcen≈øion, but by all men returned then againe into the we≈øt parts, where he had his Re≈øidency 24. yeares, if in the life of Claudius he did not returne to Rome, what Nation in the we≈øterne world shall we finde more probable to entertaine this exiled Apo≈øtle, then this Iland of Britaine? which harboured at that time ≈øo many other Chri≈øtians conuerted at Rome before by S. Peter, that our Prote≈øtants haue thus with a common con≈øent written of that time: It hath pa≈ø≈øed with allowance, among the Theater of great Britaine l. 6. c. 9. learned Senate of our Antiquaries, that when Claudius and Nero began to bannish and per≈øecute the Chri≈øtians in Rome, many Romans and Britains being conuerted to the faith, fled thence into the≈øe remote parts of the earth, where they might, and did more freely enioy the libertie of their profe≈øsions. Which di≈øciples of S. Peter ≈øo multiplied and encrea≈øed heare in that very time of Claudius, that a Prote≈øtant Bishop, and Antiquary writeth thus confidently of tho≈øe dayes: That there be manyfold testimonies of very credible Authours, who witne≈ø≈øe, that the Godwyn Cataloge of Bishops in Yorke. 1. faith of Chri≈øt was receaued in diuers particular places of this Iland, pre≈øently after the A≈øcen≈øion of Chri≈øt, or at lea≈øt while the Apo≈øtles yet liued. Therefore, if in the time of Claudius wheÃÑ no other Apo≈øtle had bene at Rome, or any of the≈øe parts of the world, and pre≈øently vpon the A≈øcen≈øion of Chri≈øt, ≈øo many both Romans and Britans which were Chri≈øtians, and mu≈øt needs be the di≈øciples of S. Peter, were in this Iland in diuers particular places, and this ≈øo vndoubted a thing by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, That it hath pa≈ø≈øed with allowance among the learned Senate of our Antiquaries: and is confirmed by manifolde te≈øtimonies of very credible Authours: It is a ≈øtrange, vnnaturall, and vndutifill minde, and will in them, that would and willingly doe admite ≈øo many of the di≈øciples of S. Peter, to haue bene receaued heare, and with more cruelty, then either Claudius or Nero could in any opinion performe, bannish the ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtle S. Peter their father and ours in Chri≈øt, both from Rome, and this kingdome al≈øo. Thus I haue fully ≈øatisfied the obiections of ≈øuch Prote≈øtants, as would exclude the greate Apo≈øtle S. Peter from this Nation, and depriue the Inhabitants of Britaine, of ≈øo greate an Honor to be the ≈øpirituall children of that
our mo≈øt worthie Protoparent in Chri≈øt. Now I will by the con≈øent of the≈øe men ≈øet downe ≈øo neare as Antiquities will giue me warrant, the time or times when he preached heare, and what he happily effected heare, in tho≈øe his greate labours and trauailes hither.

div.head: THE XVI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN IS SET DOWNE BOTH BY Prote≈øtants, and others, when S. Peter preached in Britaine: if not before his coming to Rome, yet afterward both in the dayes of Claudius, and Nero.

div.p:
1. I Haue before examined that Prote≈øtant opinioÃÑ, which becau≈øe it findeth S. Peter both to haue bene the fir≈øt that preached in Rome, and that he was heare in Britaine, would bring him hither before his fir≈øt coming to Rome: And therefore will now ≈øpeake little thereof. Our Theater Prote≈øtants froÃÑ thence would thus inferre. S. Peter was heare, before he euer went to Rome: both which may be Theater of great Britaine l. 6. c. 9. ¬ß. 5. more probable, if we con≈øider the huge multitudes of Chri≈øtians, fifteene thou≈øand, ≈øaith Baronius which di≈øper≈øed them≈øelues, in all parts of the world, vpon the martyring of S. Stephen at Hieru≈øalem, which was pre≈øently vpon the death of Chri≈øt. Their opinion which would bring S. Peter into Britaine, before he came fir≈øt to Rome, examined. Hitherto the≈øe Prote≈øtant Bishops and Antiquaries, making it the more probable opinion, as their owne words (which may be more probable) import, that S. Peter preached heare, before his fir≈øt coming to Rome, of which minde al≈øo all tho≈øe English Prote≈øtant Bishops, and writers mo≈øt needes be, which from the Authoritie of S. Gildas, as they would expound him, doe contend that Britaine receaued the faith of Chri≈øt in the dayes of Tyberius, or Caius Matth. Parker antiquit. Brit. p. 1. Georg. Abb. apud Ma≈øon coÃÑ ≈øecrat. l. 2. c. 3. p. 51. Ma≈øon ibid. Theater of Brit. p. 202. Caligula Emperors, and before the Empire of Claudius, in the beginning of who≈øe Reigne S. Peter came fir≈øt to Rome, for they all agree, that we fir≈øt receaued the faith from ≈øome one of the Apo≈øtles, and they haue concluded before, that no other Apo≈øtle, but S. Peter could be heare in tho≈øe dayes. Of this opinion is the fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury, and the pre≈øent, that is Director of the Authour of the bookes of the pretended con≈øecration of their Bishops, the Author of that Booke, the writers of their Theater, and others. And if tho≈øe words they cite were the true words of Gildas, they make not a little for that ≈øentence, being the≈øe: Tempore vt ≈øcimus ≈øummo Tyberij Cae≈øaris ≈øuos radios primum indulget, id e≈øt, ≈øua praecepta Chri≈øtus. Chri≈øt did Annot. Prote≈øt. Marginal. in prologum Gildae. afford his beames, to wit his precepts to the Ile of Britaine in the later time of Tiberius, as we know. But becau≈øe the Prote≈øtant publisher him≈øelf of Gildas, doth freely acknowledge that they were not v≈øually in the copies of Gildas, I dare not a≈øcribe ≈øo much vnto them. But if we will allow the computation of Arnoldus Mirmannius, following as it ≈øeemeth, the auncient Catalogue of the Bishops of Metz, who telleth that S. Peter ≈øent our CountrimaÃÑ S. Man≈øuetus into Arnold. Mirm. in Theatro Conu. gent. Catal. Epi≈øcop. Metens: tho≈øe parts, together with S. Clement, the fir≈øt Bishop there, in the yeare of Chri≈øt 40. in the time of Caius Caligula, two or three yeares before S. Peter came to Rome, it giueth not a ≈ømall allowance to this opinion, for tho≈øe Hi≈øtories doe not relate from what parts, Ea≈øt, or we≈øt, the≈øe men were ≈øent: but
the very Country of S. Man≈øuetus Natione Scotus, will rather incline vs to thinke S. Peter had bene then in this Iland, or neare vnto it at that time, or els we mu≈øt ≈øend this holy Saint of Britaine without authoritie a very loÃÑg Iorney to S. Peter in the Ea≈øt, and ≈øo farre back againe towards the≈øe Countries. Or if we should make ≈øo ample an acceptation of Galatia, where the Scripturs te≈øtifie 1. Petr. 1. S. Peter preached before the dayes of Claudius, as ≈øome Co≈ømographers and Antiquaries doe, we shall bring him ≈øo neare vnto vs in tho≈øe dayes, that con≈øidering the infinitie labors of that Apo≈øtle, and his loue to this kingdome, it will be noe vaine coniecture, to thinke he vi≈øited Britaine in tho≈øe dayes. Which is rather confirmed, if we reflect, and allowe of that which I haue ≈øet downe before, that his fir≈øt entertainment at Rome was among the Britans of this Nation, to whom he could not haue better direction, nor ≈øo good, from any other, as from this kingdome.

2. But to come to things certaine, & vndoubted in this Hi≈øtory of S. Peters S. Peter preached in Britaine, both in the time of Claudius and Nero Emperours. liuing and preaching in this Iland, it is an hi≈øtoricall veritie out of Que≈øtion, that he was heare both in the time of Claudius, and Nero al≈øo: his being heare in the dayes of Claudius, what time ≈øoeuer it was of his Empire, mu≈øt needes be long before S. Paul, S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, or any other, that is thought to haue preached heare, or came into the≈øe parts, as I haue proued already, as al≈øo that S. Peter was heare in that time. To which I add the te≈øtimony of Gildas our mo≈øt auncieÃÑt & renowned Hi≈øtorian: who in his booke De Excidio Britanniae; Gildas Epi≈øt. de Excid. Britan. of the de≈øtruction of Britaine, thus writeth: Ita vt non Britannia, ≈øed Romania cen≈øeretur: Et quicquid habere potui≈ø≈øe ‚Ä¢ aeris, argenti vel auri, Imagine Cae≈øaris notaretur. Interea glaciali frigore rigenti In≈øulae, & velut longiore terrarum ≈øece≈ø≈øu ≈øoli vi≈øibili non proximae verus ille non de firmamento ≈øolum temporali, ≈øed de ≈øumma etiam caelorum arce, tempora cuncta excedente vniuer≈øo orbi praefulgidum ≈øui coru≈øcum o≈øtendens, radios ≈øuos primum indulget, id est, ≈øua praecepta Chri≈øtus: So that this Iland might be rather deemed Romania, then Britannia and what ≈øoeuer Coyne it had eyther Bra≈ø≈øe, ≈øiluer or gold, it was stamped with the Image of the Roman Emperor. In the meane time, while the≈øe things were doeing, Chri≈øt who is the true Sunne, not onely from the temporall firmament, but from the high Tower of heauen, exceeding all times, showing his exceeding brightnes to the whole world doth fir≈øt afford his beames, to wit, his precepts to this Iland, ≈øtiffe with frozen cold, and by a long di≈øtance of land remoued from the vi≈øible ≈øunne. The≈øe be the true and vndoubted words of S. Gildas, in all examples both written and printed, which I haue ≈øeene: and the other words of propagating the lawe of Chri≈øt by the permi≈ø≈øion of Tyberius the Emperor again≈øt the will of the Senate, not ≈øo certaine to be the words of that holy, and auncient Father, but ≈øome later addition, and cannot be well applyed to this kingdome, where Tyberius had not ≈øuch command, and power as this Saint affirmeth, the Romans had in this kingdome, when Chri≈øt fir≈øt afforded his precepts, primuÃÑ Indulget Chri≈øtus, to this cold and termed frozen Iland. For it is certaine, by all Antiquities, that this great ≈øubiection of the Britans vnto the Emperors of Rome, did neuer fall out vntill the time of Claudius.

3. Therefore ≈øeeing this Nation did fir≈øt receaue the faith of Chri≈øt, Primum, at that time, it mu≈øt needes be in the time of Claudius, when fir≈øt and neuer before, this Iland was in that ≈øtate, he there de≈øcribeth: And this is that very time which ≈øo many Antiquaries, Catholiks, & Prote≈øtants, S. Simon Metaphra≈øtes, Surius, Lippomannus, Sir William Camden, Andrie Che≈øne, and others before named, agree vpon, that S. Peter preached in this kingdome.
To which S. Paul him≈øelfe, by our Prote≈øtaÃÑts con≈øtructioÃÑ, & interpretation, by his epi≈øtle writteÃÑ to the RomaÃÑs at that time, & among ≈øo many Chri≈øtians in Rome then, which he remeÃÑbreth; and neuer once ≈øaluting eyther S. Peter, S. Ari≈øtobulus, S. Clement, or any one that is ≈øuppo≈øed to haue bene in the≈øe parts with S. Peter, giueth no ≈ømall allowance: And yet in this epi≈øtle he taketh vpoÃÑ him certaine knowledge, that the faith of the Romans which was plaÃÑted by S. Peter; annuntiatur in vniuer≈øo muÃÑdo.
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
your faith is preached, or shewed in all the world; therefore al≈øo in Britaine, ≈øo greate a NatioÃÑ of this we≈øterne world, & the RomaÃÑ Empire, for as our Prote≈øtaÃÑts inferre froÃÑ Rom. 1. v. 8. that epi≈øtle; if S. Paul had not knowne S. Peter was not theÃÑ in Rome, he would haue ≈øaluted him, whom he ≈øo much honoured and loued. For as in the beginning of that epi≈øtle; he generally ≈øaluteth all: omnibus qui ≈øunt Romae dilectis Rom. 1. ≈øupr. Dei, vocatis Sanctis gratia vobis & pax √† Deo patre no≈øtra & Domino Ie≈øu Chri≈øto; To all that are at Rome beloued of God, called Saincts, grace be to you, and peace from God our father, and our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt: So in the later end of the ≈øame epi≈øtle, Rom. cap. 16. he ≈øaluteth by name Pri≈øca, Aquila, Epaenetus, Mary, Andronicus, Iulius, Ampliatus, Vrbanus, Stachis, Apelles, and many others there named. Neuer ≈øaluting S. Peter, or any which are thought to haue bene with him either in Britaine, Fraunce, or Germany, or any Nation on this ≈øide of Rome, or ≈øent thither about this time by S. Peter, of which I haue named many before, among which diuers were of the number of the 72. Di≈øciples and acquaintance of S. Paul, and among the acquaintance of this Apo≈øtle he doth not ≈øalute S. Ari≈øtobulus, nor S. Narci≈ø≈øus, though he ≈øaluteth their families then in Rome: ≈øalutate eos qui ≈øunt ex Aristobuli: ≈øalutate eos qui ≈øunt ex Narci≈øsi domo: ≈øalute theÃÑ that be of the houshold of Ari≈øtobulus: Salute them that be of the hou≈øehold of Narci≈ø≈øus. Therefore being ≈øo familiar with S. Ai≈øtobulus, and Narci≈ø≈øus, & kind vnto theÃÑ, that he ≈øaluteth their families, for his loue to theÃÑ, we mu≈øt needs, coÃÑclude that S. Paul well knew they were not then in Rome. And being ab≈øent at that time from their families, and thence, and the knowne Di≈øciples of S. Peter, as all at Rome then were, where should they, e≈øpecially S. Ari≈øtobulus our Bishop or Archbishop of Britaine, as I haue shewed before, be at that time, but with S. Peter their Ma≈øter heare, who then at the writing of this epi≈øtle of S. Paul to the Romans, was as I haue proued before by many te≈øtimonies, both of Prote≈øtants, and others, in this our Britaine. For this epi≈øtle of S. Paul was written after the a≈ø≈øembly of tbe Apo≈øtles at Hieru≈øalem, about the A≈ø≈øump≈øion of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, by all writers, and S. Paul him≈øelfe is Gal. 2. v. 1. 9. both witne≈ø≈øe, that he ≈øaw S. Peter there, and ≈øtayed ≈øome time with him, and that the Church of Rome was then ≈øo well founded, that their faith was famous, and renowned in all the world; therefore S. Peter the founder thereof being to be≈øtowe the re≈øt of his time by Chri≈øts direction vnto him, in conuerting this our Britaine, & other we≈øtern nations, we mu≈øt needes conclude from hence al≈øo, that S. Peter which was then come from the Ea≈øt againe into the≈øe parts, and was not at Rome, but had left S. Linus, and Cletus to ≈øupply Epi≈øcopall duties there, was heare in Britaine at that time, as ≈øo many before haue witne≈ø≈øed; And as the holy Apo≈øtles at their meetings imparted their iorneys they were to take, in preaching the gho≈øpell one to an other, as they did in their fir≈øt diui≈øion of the world, among them, for the better effecting their mo≈øt holy office and charge committed to them by Chri≈øt: So S. Peter, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ much beloued of S. Paul, and ≈øo greate a louer of him, that he calleth him hi ‚Ä¢ mo≈øt beloued, would not conceale his intended trauailes in the≈øe we≈øterne 1. Petr. 3. v. 5.
parts, vnto him, e≈øpecially ≈øeeing S. Paul was the onely Apo≈øtle, excepting S. Peter which was to vi≈øite the≈øe Occidentall Nations. And S. Paul ≈øaluting the family of Ari≈øtobulus in Rome, and omitting him doth ≈øufficiently in≈øinuate that S. Peter had acquainted him with this his we≈øterne voyage, and taking S. Ari≈øtobulus with him, or ≈øending him hither before him. For except identitie of name, or both Sophronius and Metaphra≈øtes deceaue vs, S. Ati≈øtobulus brother to S. Barnabas, was father in lawe to S. Peter, and ≈øo following Sophron. Hiero≈øolymit. l. de laborib. S. Petri & Pauli. Sim. Metaphr. die 29. Iunij. him, did likely at the coming of S. Peter to Rome, remoue his family thither, and left it there, and he him≈øelfe employed by S. Peter, and by him ordained Bishop of this our Britaine, as is before declared, mu≈øt needs be heare, or in his Iorney hither, at that time.

4. Whether S. Peter was heare in, or about the beginning, of the Empire of Probable, that S. Peter was in Britaine, or ≈øent Di≈øciples hither about the coming of Claudius hither. Claudius, and his inua≈øion of this Nation, in the fourth yeare of his Reigne as the common opinion of Antiquaries is, I dare not ab≈øolutely determine: though diuers together with Baronius encline to that opinion, and rea≈øons be not wanting to giue probabilitie vnto it. For if Pomponia Graecina, the wife of Aulus Plantius, the Emperours Lieutenant in Britaine, was conuerted heare to the faith of Chri≈øt, as our Prote≈øtants a≈ø≈øure vs, this being before the per≈øecution, Bar on. to. 1. an n. in S. Petr. Aut h. of 3. Conuer≈ø. which they ≈øay Claudius ray≈øed again≈øt Chri≈øtians in the 49. yeare of Chri≈øt, Aulus Plantius then being returned to Rome, together with his wife, and company to triumphe there, therefore she could not be conuerted heare by any which they ≈øay fled hither from Rome in the beginning of that per≈øecution, Matth. we≈øt. an. 49. and they can finde no other Chri≈øtians heare, except S. Peter, or ≈øome ≈øent by him, which they doe not expre≈ø≈øe, to performe that holy office. Secondly whereas it is manife≈øt before, that S. Peter after his coming to Rome, occiduam ob≈øcuritatem in splendorem clari≈øsimum commutauit, ob≈øcuriorem mundi Mich. Singel. in Martyrio Dion. Areopag. Clem. Rom. ep. 1. plagam Occidentis illuminare praeceptus e≈øt; chaunged the darkne≈ø≈øe of the we≈øt into mo≈øt bright ≈øplendor, and was commaunded to illuminate the we≈øt the more darke or ob≈øcure part of the world: It carryeth greate probabilitie, that he began this worke, before his coming from the Ea≈øt to Rome, the ≈øecond time, after the A≈ø≈øump≈øion of the ble≈ø≈øed virgin Mary, and had enterpri≈øed it heare in Britaine, before tho≈øe dayes: for we reade in our owne auncient hi≈øtorians e≈øpecially the Manu≈øcript Antiquitie of Canterbury that about the 49. yeare of Chri≈øt, Petrus iterum Romanam Cathedram ≈øu≈øcepit: Peter did take the Roman Hi≈øt. antiq. M. S. ex Eccl. CaÃÑtuar. ad circit. an. 49. Guliel. Ei≈øengr. Centen. 1. di≈øt. 3. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 46. Chaire againe; which mu≈øt needs be to make it true, after his returne to Rome out of ≈øome of the≈øe we≈øt parts. Thirdly we finde in the French Annals cited by Gulielmus Ei≈øengrenius, diuers Bishops con≈øecrated by S. Peter in this time, for our neighbouring Country of Fraunce, as namely S. Maximinus or Maximus at Aquens or Aix, and S. Lazarus at Mar≈øiles, in the yeare of Chri≈øt 46. S. Martial at Limoges, & S. Iulian at Mans the ≈øame yeare. S. Paulus Sergius at Narbon in the yeare 48. when S. Paul the Apo≈øtle was not come into Ei≈øengr. ≈øup. in S. Man≈øueto. & Epi≈øp. Gall. the≈øe parts, to place him there. And to make this more credible, if we follow that Authour with his Ant ‚Ä¢ quities, S. Clement at Metz, and our Countriman S. Man≈øuetus at Toul in Lorrayne, who in this opinion may be thought to be Arnold. M ‚Ä¢ rm. in Therat. CoÃÑu. gent. Guliel. Ei≈øengr. ≈øupr. Centen. 1. Franci≈øc. Bellef. Co≈ømograph. tom. 1. in Toul. left there by S. Peter in his fir≈øt returne from Britaine to Rome, being in his way from hence thither, and this the rather, becau≈øe many hi≈øtorians te≈øtifie, he was ordained Bishop there by S. Peter, and yet not any one remembreth any place from whence he was directed thither, but onely affirme, as he expoundeth them, that he was con≈øecrated Bishop of that place by S. Peter in the 49. yeare of Chri≈øt. And this more probable, becau≈øe after this 49. yeare
of Chri≈øt, the≈øe French hi≈øtorians which take paines to ≈øet downe exactly the very yeare wherein their fir≈øt Apo≈øtles and Bishops were ordained vnto them by S. Peter, which are many, do not ≈øet downe the yeare, wherein any one after this time was con≈øecrated vntill the 54. of the Natiuitie of Chri≈øt, by and before which time S. Peter was come from Hieru≈øalem, and the Ea≈øterne parts the ≈øecond time into the≈øe we≈øt ‚Ä¢ ne Nations of the world, when he both was, and ≈øtayed long time in this our Britaine.

5. And this giueth light vnto vs, that about this yeare of Chri≈øt 54. S. Peter came hither to ≈øtaie long time in Britaine, for in this yeare as the French Antiquaries Probable, that S. Peter came into Britaine the ≈øecoÃÑd time about the 54. yeare of Chri≈øt. write, S. Peter con≈øecrated many Bishops in Fraunce, his way from Rome to Britaine; in this yeare as they write, he ordained S. Sabinianus or Sabinus one of the 72. di≈øciples Primate of all Fraunce, Archbishop of Sens: Sanctus Sabinianus, ≈øine Sabinus vnus ex 72. Chri≈øti di≈øcipulis √† beato Petro Apo≈øtolo Primas totius Galliae, & Senonen≈øis Archiepi≈øcopus con≈øecratus anno Chri≈øti 54. in which Anton. Democharez lib. 2. de mi≈ø≈ø. contr. Caluin. c. 30. Ei≈øengr. centen. 1. fol. 56. cit. Bed. Martyr. prid. Cal. Ian. Petr. de Natal. l. 2. c. 25. Anton. part. 1. tit. 6. c. 25. ¬ß. 3. Mart. in chr. Vicel. in Hagiol. Vuerner. Carthu≈ø. in Fa≈øcul. temp. Ei≈øengr. Cent. 1. Franc. Bellefor. tom. 1. p. 202. l. 2. Vincent. in Specul. lib. 11. cap. 43. Bed. Anton. Volaterr. Petr. de Natal. apud. Ei≈øengren. ≈øupr. in S. Front. in Gall. S. Sim. Metaphr. ≈øupr. yeare al≈øo he con≈øecrated (as the≈øe Authours ≈øaye) many other Bishops in Fraunce, as S. Nathanael ≈øpoken of in the gho≈øpell, and by ≈øome named vr≈øinus, S. Amator, S. Potentianus, S. Fronto and others: among which, the rather to induce vs, to thinke, that S. Peter was then in Fraunce, this S. Fronto then con≈øecrated Bishop, by S. Peter, was a French man borne, as many Authorities proue vnto vs: and ≈øo mo≈øt likely to be con≈øecrated in his owne CouÃÑ try. And the Authoritie of S. Simeon Metaphra≈øtes, who of all others doth mo≈øt particularly ≈øet downe the Trauailes of S. Peter, will bring him into Britaine about this time, the ≈øecond time, (as it ≈øeemeth, of his being heare:) for bringing him to Rome as others doe, in the beginning of the Reigne of Claudius, he addeth of him: Cum non diu man≈øi≈ø≈øet apud Romanos, & ≈øancto bapti≈ømate multos regenera≈ø≈øet, & Eccle≈øiam con≈øtitui≈ø≈øet, & Linum Epi≈øcopum ordina≈ø≈øet: when he had ≈øtayed not long with the Romans, and baptized many, and founded the Church, and ordained Linus a Bishop, he went into Spaine, then into Egipt, and ≈øo to Hieru≈øalem by reuelation for the Tran≈ømigration of the mother of God, then returned into Egipt and through Africk returned to Rome, from whence he came to Millan and Photice, and ≈øo into Britaine. Which time being truely calculated, will teach vs, that he came hither in, or about the 54. yeare of Chri≈øt, when in the way hither he made ≈øo many Bishops in Fraunce, long before S. Paule came, although as a pri≈øoner fir≈øt to Rome, or any other Apo≈øtle thither or to any we≈øterne Nation. For as I haue proued before, S. Peter going vp to Hieru≈øalem by Reuelation, at the death of the ble≈ø≈øed virgin, did ≈øtaye but a short time there, and in the Ea≈øterne parts in that Iorney, but the chardge of the we≈øterne world being more peculiarly committed vnto him before, he returned vnto it to di≈øchardge this dutie heare; and allthough S. Simon Metaphra≈øtes bringeth him back againe by Rome, yet he ≈øpeaketh of no ≈øtay he made there at this time, but pre≈øently bringeth him into Britaine.

div.head: THE XVII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN IS PROVED, BY THE BEST ENglish Prote≈øtant writers, their Bishops, and others, that S. Peter founding the Church of Britaine, ordained in it, an Archbishop, Bishops, and Prei≈øts.

div.p: 1. THat we may without contradiction of any Catholik, or Prote≈øtant (except willfully erring in their owne proceedings) be a≈ø≈øured, that S. Peter performed heare all Pa≈øtorall duties, in fouÃÑ ding vnto our predece≈ø≈øors in this our Britaine, the true & vndoubted Church of Chri≈øt, and ≈øo left it to po≈øteritie, becau≈øe I ≈øtand a≈ø≈øured, my pen shall ≈øtill in all things carry with it an vndoubted A≈ø≈øent of Catholiks, ≈øeeing this matter of the true Church, founding thereof, profe≈ø≈øing the doctrine, which it teacheth to all her childreÃÑ, and they ought to followe, concerneth vs all, ≈øo much, that the Prote≈øtants of this Nation agree, there is no ≈øaluatioÃÑ to be had, or expected out of this holy ≈øocietie: I will ≈øet downe by their warrant, both what this Church is, and how it was fir≈øt in all things e≈ø≈øentiall, and by them needfull to ≈øaluation, founded heare by Saint Peter the Apo≈øtle.

2. Concerning the fir≈øt, the Canon or decree of the Prote≈øtant Religion in their Synodicall, and Parlament Articles, to which all Prote≈øtant Bishops and Mini≈øters of England haue ≈øworne, and ≈øub≈øcribed, is this: The vi≈øible Church Articl. of Religion. an. 1562. ar. 19. of Chri≈øt is a Congregation of faithfull men, in the which the puer word of God is preached, and the Sacraments be duely mini≈øtred, according to Chri≈øts ordinance, in all tho≈øe things that of nece≈øsitie, are requi≈øite to the ≈øame. Hitherto this publik Prote≈øtant Article of Religion. Therefore ≈øeeing it is allowed, and proued before by the≈øe men, that S. Peter fir≈øt founded the Church of Chri≈øt in this kingdome, to in≈øi≈øt ≈øtill in their owne allowances, I mu≈øt shew by them how he performed the≈øe things, which by the≈øe Prote≈øtants mu≈øt needs be in euery true Church, to wit true and lawfull Mini≈øters, to preach the word of God, and duely mini≈øter the Sacraments. So there be three things e≈ø≈øentiall, true Mini≈øters, the puer word of God preached, and Sacraments duely mini≈øtred, among which the two la≈øt depend vpon the fir≈øt, true and lawfull Mini≈øters. For where true and Orthodoxall Mini≈øters are, and accordingly preach the word, and Mini≈øter the Sacraments, there the puer word mu≈øt needs be preached, and Sacraments duely mini≈øtred. And contrariewi≈øe where ≈øuch Mini≈øters are not, there the≈øe things cannot be po≈ø≈øibly by ≈øuch performed. Which this Prote≈øtant Rule of ReligioÃÑ confirmeth in an other Article in the≈øe words: It is not lawfull for any man, to take vpon him the office of publick preaching, Articul. 23. or mini≈øtring of the Sacraments in the Congregation, before he be lawfully called, and ≈øent to execute the ≈øame. And tho≈øe we ought to Iudge lawfully called, and ≈øent, which be cho≈øen and called to this worke, by men, who haue publick authoritie giuen vnto them, in the Congregation, to call and ≈øend Mini≈øters into the Lords vyneyard. And in their Article intituled: of Con≈øecratioÃÑ of Bishops and Mini≈øters, they ≈øet downe the≈øe orders & degrees in ≈øuch men: Archbishops, Bishops, Preists, and Deacons:
and haue ≈øet forth a booke, both by the Regall Authoritie of King Edward the Sixt, Q. Elizabeth, and King Iames our pre≈øent Soueraigne, and their Parlaments, for the particular con≈øecration of all tho≈øe degrees; and in that ≈øo highly authorized Booke a≈ø≈øuer vs, that all the≈øe degrees and Orders haue euer bene in the Church of Chri≈øt from the dayes of him, and his Apo≈øtles. And all particular writers among the≈øe Prote≈øtants, as they are bound by ≈øub≈øcription to the≈øe Articles; ≈øo they plainely te≈øtifie in their writings, among whom the publick and approued Prote≈øtant comment vpon the≈øe Articles, Intituled, The Catholick doctrine of the Church of England. With greate priuiledge Rogers. in Artic. 36. ≈øetteth downe in this manner: It is ageeable to the word of God, and practi≈øe of the primatiue Church, that there should be Archbishops, Bishops and ≈øuch like differences, and inequalities of Eccle≈øiasticall Mini≈øters: and addeth: The proofe from the word of God: Albeit the termes, and Titles of Archbishops we finde not: yet the ≈øuperioritie which they haue, and authoritie which Bishops, and Archbishops doe exerci≈øe, in ordering, and con≈øecrating Bishops, and Eccle≈øia≈øticall Mini≈øters, is grownded vpon the word. And againe: from the Apostles dayes hitherto there neuer waÃÑted a Succe≈øsion of Bishops, neither in the Ea≈øte nor we≈øterne Churches. This is the generall, and common opinion of all the English Prote≈øtant Bishops, again≈øt their Puritans. Thus their Archbishops, whitgitf, Bancroft, their Bishops Bilson, Barlow, Bridges, Doctors, Fild, Hooker, Couell, Downame, Barlow Serm. before King Iames 21. Septembr. an. 1604. and others. Whereof one writeth: Epi≈øcopall function is an ordinance Apo≈øtolicall, Chri≈øt hath acted it for ≈øucceeding po≈øteritie, and ≈øo it is the≈øis Pneumatichi, a Canon or con≈øtitution of the whole Trinitie. Thus a Prote≈øtant Bishop before our King, with both his and the allowance of the Prote≈øtant Bishops, as the Puritans them≈øelues thus acknowledge. The callings of Prelates be of diuine ordinance, Offer of Conference. as Bishop Barlowe auoucheth in his la≈øt Sermon. The Bishop of Roche≈øter with the con≈øent, and by the direction no doubt of ≈øome of the cheife≈øt Prelates, hath now lately published his Sermon, preached in September, before the King at Hampton Court, the maine drift whereof, is to proue, that the office and calling of a Dioce≈øan Bishop, is a diuine and Apo≈øtolicall ordinance. The ≈øame, be≈øides ≈øo many their Bishops and doctors before, is remembred in their publick Apology, intituled of the Con≈øecration of the Bishops in the Church of England, masked vnder the name of Francis Ma≈øon. So that there can be no que≈øtion with any Prote≈øtant in England, both their Archbishops, Bishops, and Doctors of the English Prote≈øtant Church thus con≈øenting, but S. Peter, as the re≈øt of the Apo≈øtles, directed ≈øo by the lawe, and word of Chri≈øt, and their owne Tradition, Sutcliff. Subu. p. 3. Ihon Whitg. An≈øw. to the admonit. p. 65. ≈øect. 1. and def. of the An≈øw. pag. 318. Clem. l. CompeÃÑ diar. Chri≈øt. relig apud Pol. Virg. l. 4. de Inuent. c. 12. Whitg. ≈øupr. in Indic. & p. 372. 373. 427. 470. 471. Clem. Roepi≈øt. 1. to 1. Concil. did ordain, and con≈øecrate ≈øuch holy Rulers in tho≈øe Churches, which they founded: and ≈øo con≈øequently in this our Britaine, according to that I haue allready written of his preaching heare. Which diuers of the≈øe Prote≈øtant writers teache in plaine termes of him in particular: one of them writeth thus: Peter preached in no place, but he there ordeined Bishops, and teachers, and founded Churches. An other, an Archbishop with them, citing diuers authorities, for his A≈ø≈øertion, ≈øaith: I proue that the names of Metroprolitane and Archbishop be mo≈øt auncient: yea that they were in the Church, long before the gho≈øpell was publickly embraced by any Prince, or in any kingdome. Polidor Virgil lib. 4. de Inuentoribus rerum cap. 12. ≈øaith, that Clement in his booke intituled Compendiarium Chri≈øtianae Religionis, te≈øtifieth, that the Apo≈øtle Peter did in euery prouince appoint one Archbishop, whome all other Bishops of the ≈øame prouince should obey: he ≈øaith al≈øo, that the ≈øame Archbishop was called Primas, Patriarcha, & Metropolitanus. Which is al≈øo ≈øet downe at lardge from the mouth of S. Peter, by the ≈øame S. Clement,
his Di≈øciple and ≈øucce≈ø≈øor in his fir≈øt epi≈øtle. And ≈øo the≈øe Prote≈øtants iu≈øtifie both the precept and practice of S. Peter in this point: which they mu≈øt needs doe, except by their owne warrant before, they would make him a mo≈øt wicked tran≈øgre≈ø≈øor of the word of God, the Apo≈øtles Tradition, and his owne commandement.

3. Therefore with the licence of the≈øe men, we may boldly ≈øay, with S. Simon Metaphra≈øtes, of S. Peters holy labors of this kind in Britaine, verbo Metaph. 29. Iun. gratiae multos illuminauit, Eccle≈øias con≈øtituit, Epi≈øcopo≈øque, & Presbyteros, & Diaconos ordinauit: he illuminated many with the word of grace, con≈øtituted Churches, and ordained Bishops, and Prei≈øts, and Deacons. And this the rather becau≈øe not Arnold. Mirm. Theatr. conuer≈ø. gent. Sur. & Lippom. 29. Iun. Gul. Ei≈øengr. ceÃÑ tenar. 1. part. 7. di≈øt. 8. Baron. to. 1. Annal. Harris hi≈øt. to. 1. Theater of greate Brit. l. 6. Camden in Brit. Andre Che≈øne hi≈øt. of Eng. Scot. and Ireland lib. 3. onely Arnoldus Mirmannius, Surius, Lippomannus, Gulielmus Ei≈øengrenius, Baronius, M. Harris in his Manu≈øcript hi≈øtory and other Catholike writers haue thus deliuered: But our Prote≈øtant Theater writers ≈øpeaking of the≈øe matters proue the Relator of them lyued 800. yeares ≈øince, and for his Authoritie, produced them out of the Greeke Antiquities. And the cheife Prote≈øtant Antiquary of EnglaÃÑd affirmeth it to be ≈øo certaine, that it should not he doubted of; ≈øo doth Andrew Che≈øne in his French hi≈øtory of this Iland, and Ireland. And ≈øo mu≈øt all the Parlement Prote≈øtants of England, who allowe the booke of Articles, where it is decreed, that a true Church cannot be without ≈øuch cleargie Rulers. Therefore being graunted by them before, that S. Peter founded the Church of Chri≈øt in this kingdome, they con≈øequently haue graunted, he ordained Bishops, and others to exerci≈øe holy functions in that Church.

div.head: THE XVIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN ARE SET DOWNE BY WARrant of Prote≈øtants, and other Authorities the names in particular of the fir≈øt Archbishop, and diuers Bishops of, or in Britaine, in this time by S. Peters Ordination

div.p:
1. ANd to di≈øcend to ≈øome particulars in this kinde: our Prote≈øtants S. Ari≈øtobulus ordained Archbishop of Britaine by S. Peter, as our Prote≈øtants a≈ø≈øent. will giue me warrant, to ≈øet downe the very names of our fir≈øt Archbishop, and ≈øome Bishops, ordayned by that greate Apo≈øtle S. Peter: And concerning the Archbishop (except we should turne di≈øciplinary Puritans, & be ≈øingular again≈øt all English Prote≈øtants, Catholiks, and all Antiquities, and deny that S. Peter him≈øelf, S. Ihon the Euangeli≈øt, and others of the Apo≈øtles were Archbishops) we mo≈øt needs by the publike warrant of our English Prote≈øtants affirme, that S. Ari≈øtobulus was by S. Peter ordayned Archbishop of this our Britaine. For ≈øuppo≈øing (which is proued and graunted before) that he was made Bishop by S. Peter, in their common, publike, and allowed Commentary, vpon the Articles of their Religion, thus Thom. Rogers in Articul. Relig. in Artic. 36. they place him among the confe≈ø≈øed Archbishops of the Church of Chri≈øt, and proue him to be Archbishop of this our Britaine in the≈øe termes: In the Apo≈øtles dayes, how them≈øelues both were in dignitie aboue the Euangeli≈øts, and the
72. Di≈øciples, and for authoritie both in and ouer the Church, as twelue Patriarches Beza in act. Apo. 1. 2. ≈øaith Beza, and al≈øo e≈øtablished an Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hierarchie. Hence came it, that Bishop was of Hieru≈øalem Iames, of Antioch Peter, of the A≈øian Churches Ihon, of Alexandria Marke, of Ephe≈øus, yea and all A≈øia, Timothie: of all Crete Titus, of Philippos Epaphroditus, of Corinth and Achaia Apollos; of Athens Dioni≈øius, of Fraunce Cre≈øcens, of Britaine Ari≈øtobulus. Where we ≈øee it ≈øo manife≈øtly acknowledged by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, that S. Ari≈øtobulus was Archbishop of this our Britaine, that except we would deny that dignitie to the Apo≈øtles, and other knowne Archbishops there remembred, we may not deny it to S. Ari≈øtobulus for our Britaine. And ≈øo the≈øe Prote≈øtants in their words immediately going before doe name all the≈øe I haue recited, for telling vs how the Superioritie Rogers ≈øupr. and Authoritie which Archbishops doe exerci≈øe, in ordering and con≈øecrating of Bishops and Eccle≈øia≈øticall Ministers is grounded vpon the word of God: they immediately exemplify in tho≈øe men, and words as I haue related, making S. Ari≈øtobulus that cheife, or Archbishop of Britaine: from whome the con≈øecra ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n of Bishops, and cleargy men was deryued to po≈øteritie in this kingdome, as it was from S. Iames at Hieru≈øalem, from S. Peter at Antioch, S. Ihon in A≈øia, S. Marke at Alexandria, and the others remembred in tho≈øe kingdomes, and Prouinces, of which they are named Archbishops by Whitg. ag. Cattw. Bil≈øon true differ. Bridges l. of the Church. of Engl. Downam def. of the Serm. Gul. Camden. in Britan. in Belg. Andre Che≈øne hi≈øt. gen. p. 132. the≈øe Prote≈øtants, not onely in this, but many other places.

2. And S. Dorothaeus Bishop of Tyrus, euen as our be≈øt Prote≈øtant Antiquaries alledge, and expounde him, doth ≈øufficiently te≈øtifie. Thus they write: Dorothaeus Tyri Epi≈øcopus in ≈øua Apo≈øtolorum Sinop≈øi tradit Ari≈øtobulum, cuius meminit Paulus in Epistola ad Romanos, Britanniae Epi≈øcopum factum fui≈ø≈øe: Dorothaeus Bishop of Tyrus in his booke, intituled, Synop≈øis of the Apo≈øtles, doth deliuer, that Ari≈øtobulus, of whom S. Paul maketh mention in his Epi≈øtle to the Romans, was made Bishop of Britaine. Dorothaeus agreeth wholy with this Prote≈øtant, not in his booke of the Apo≈øtles, but of the 72. Di≈øciples, where he plainely ≈øaith: Ari≈øtobulus & ip≈øe ab Apostolo ad Romanos commemoratus, Epi≈øcopus Britanniae factus e≈øt‚ñ™ Ari≈øtobulus named by the Apostle, to the Romans, was made Doroth. in Syno. 72. Di≈øcip. in Ari≈øtobulo. Bishop of Britaine. Where by the words, Bishop of Britaine, and not in Britaine, or any particular place of Britaine, it is euident that he was made the cheife commanding Bishop, or Archbishop of Britaine, the whole kingdome of Britaine being ≈øubiected vnto him, in ≈øpirituall proceedings; and it is cleare in all ≈øuch Examples in Antiquitie, not one in≈øtance to be giuen to the contrary, as appeareth in the ≈øame auntient Father S. Dorothaeus in that place, and others entreating of the ≈øame ≈øubiect. And the words, The Bishop of Britaine, will allowe no other interpretation. And if there were no other motiue to induce vs to be of this opinion, but the con≈øent of writers, both Catholiks, and Prote≈øtants, that this holy Bishop of Britaine was one of the 72. Diciples of Chri≈øt, as both the ≈øame S. Dorothaeus, our contriman Floren ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ us Wigornien≈øis, Doroth. ≈øupr. in Titul. Florent. Wigorn. in Catal. 72. Di≈øcipul. Arnold. Mirm. in Theatr. Gul. Ei≈øeng. cent. 1. Magdeb. cent. 1. and later Authours agree, it would be a warrant ≈øufficient, in this cau≈øe, when we doe not finde in Antiquities, but probably all the 72. that ≈øuruiued were con≈øtituted Archbishops in their diui≈øions, in tho≈øe that concerne vs mo≈øt, which were ≈øettled in our neighbouring Nations, Fraunce, and Germany, I haue exemplified before. Alnoldus Mirmannius in his Theater of the Conuer≈øion of Nations, and the Authorities which he followeth, will make this a matter out of que≈øtion, for he deriueth the whole Hierarchicall order of the Church of Chri≈øt in this kingdome, from this holy man in Arnold. Mirm. in Theatr. conu. gent. in Britann. this manner: Britannia Straboni a Britone Regenun cuipata, primum Ari≈øtobulum
vnum certe ex cla≈ø≈øe 72. Di≈øcipulorum Apo≈øtolum est nacta. Deinde nacta e≈øt Britannia Fugatium, & Damianum, qui ordinem Hierarchicum Eccle≈øiae i≈øtic fundatae ab illo inchoatum con≈øtituerunt, ≈øanxeruntque more nimirum Apo≈øtolico: Britaine ≈øo named by Strabo, from King Brito, or Brutus, had fir≈øt for the Apostle of it Ari≈øtobulus, one doubtle≈ø≈øe of the order of the 72. Di≈øciples. After that, it had Fugatius Guliel. Ei≈øengren. centenar. 1. in S. Ari≈øtobulo. Actor. cap. 13. and Damianus, who con≈øtituted and confirmed after the Apo≈øtolik manner the Hierarchicall order of the Church there founded begun by him. Where he a≈øcribeth to S. Ari≈øtobulus this our holy Archbishop of this our Britaine named of Brutus, three Attributes, all commonly properties allmo≈øt quarto modo, belonging to S. Ari≈øtobulus Archbishop of Britayne, con≈øecrated by diuers Authours, an. dom. 39. and before S. Paule. Archbishops: to be our Apo≈øtle: to haue founded our Church: and begun our Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hierarchicall order. Which cannot belong to any other then an Archbishop, e≈øpecially in ≈øo greate a kingdome.

3. And if we will followe Ei≈øengrenius, and his Authours, he will tell vs, that this holy Saint and Archbishop of Britaine was made Bishop in the 39. yeare of Chri≈øt, within fiue or ≈øixe yeares of his A≈øcen≈øion, and before S. Paule the Apo≈øtle him≈øelf did receaue impo≈øition of hands, or S. Man≈øuetus Other Bishops, or ≈øome other Bishop then in Britayne be≈øides S. Ari≈øtobulus. by any accompt, or any other that is remembred in Antiquities, to haue bene a Bishop in, or of this Nation, except the mo≈øt glorious Apo≈øtle, our fir≈øt Father in Chri≈øt S. Peter, was made a Bishop. Therefore it doth euidently followe, that next vnto S. Peter, that renowned Saint, and Di≈øciple of Chri≈øt, S. Ari≈øtobulus was by S. Peters meanes the fir≈øt Archbishop of this kingdome, Who were the≈øe Bishops in particular, in or of Britayne. by this accompt. Which maketh it al≈øo an vndoubted truth, warranted both by holy Scriptures, Apo≈øtolike Tradition, and all cheife≈øt Authorities, as the≈øe Prote≈øtants haue proued vnto vs, that we al≈øo had ≈øome Bishops who≈øoeuer they were, ≈øubordinate to this cheife, ouer≈øeeing, commaunding and Arch-Bishop, S. Man≈øuetus Beatus his Anonymus companion and S. Augulus probably Bishops heare in Britayne. and by the ≈øame Authoritie of S. Peter: for all this is nece≈ø≈øarily induced, and depending of the name, nature, office and dignitie of an Archbishop, in≈øtituted and ordayned heare, by that greate≈øt Apo≈øtles power, and Authoritie. For it is an implicancy of contradiction, and in naturall euidence impo≈ø≈øible, that there should be an Archbishop aboue all other Bishops, where Engl. Martyrol. 7. Febr. in Augulus. Drek. in alm. an. 1620. 7. Febr. Io. King ≈øerm. at Pauls Cro≈ø≈øe 26. Mart. an. 1620. pag. 45. Martyrolog. Rom. 7. Febr. Bed. Martyrol. ib. v≈øuard hac die. Petr. de Natal. in Catal. l. 3. cap. 105. Ado & Vuandelbert. apud Baron. in annot. in Martyrol. 7. Feb ‚Ä¢ . Calendar. Eccle≈ø. Sarisb. Engl. Martyrol. 7. Febr. Rabanus hac die. there is no Bishop, for him to be the cheife≈øt, or vnder him. And that ≈øuch we had by S. Peters ordination, it is in plaine termes acknowledged before, both by Catholike, and Prote≈øtant Antiquaries, te≈øtifiing, and prouing that this highe≈øt Apo≈øtle when he in≈øtituted this mo≈øt ≈øacred ≈øubordination, did ordaine both Bishops, Prei≈øts, & Deacons in, and for this kingdome; Who the≈øe our Primatiue Bishops were in particular, or any of them, the Iniurie of time and ≈øo many Enemies of holy Religion, vnder who≈øe heauy burthens, and per≈øecutions this kingdome hath often groaned, doe make it a greater labour. Yet it is euident by that I haue already proued, that S. Man≈øuetus, S. Beatus, and his holy companion, though to vs now Anonimus, of which two, I shall ≈øpeake more hereafter, may be recompted in this number.

4. To which we may probably add S. Augulus, Bishop of Augu≈øta, London, in England, as both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants expound it, and among them one in a Sermon before King Iames ≈øpeaking to the Londiners ≈øaith: your citty hath bene aunciently ≈øtiled Augusta. For we reade both in the auntient Roman Martyrologe, that al≈øo of S. Bede, V≈øuardus, Ado, Vandelbertus, Petrus de Natalibus and others, that this S. Augulus was Bishop of Augu≈øta in Britannia, Augusta or London in Britaine, and was a martyr: Augu≈øtae in Britannia Natalis beati Auguli Epi≈øcopi, qui aetatis cur≈øum per Martyrium explens aeterna praemia ≈øu≈ø ‚Ä¢ ipere meruit. Baronius ≈øaith, he cannot tell when he ≈øuffered:
Quo tempore pa≈ø≈øus ≈øit, hactenus mihi ob≈øcurum. But if we compare the name of London at that time it was called Augu≈øta, with other circum≈øtances, and with the Catalogue of the Bishops of London, after the time of King Lucius, we shall very probably finde, that this worthy Saint our Bishop of London, is to be reckoned one of the fir≈øt Bishops, that were con≈øecrated in this kingdome, & long before our common Conuer≈øion, in the dayes of King Lucius, and ≈øo con≈øequently by S. Peter, or his Di≈øciple S. Ari≈øtobulus, no other then with eminent Authoritie being heare to con≈øecrate him Bishop, and ≈øettle him Bishop of Augu≈øta, London. For fir≈øt this citie was not called Augu≈øta in the Reigne of King Lucius, when this Nation was generally conuerted, but onely Londinum: London, nor neuer ≈øince that time, or by any before, but by the Romans at their fir≈øt ≈øetling heare in the time of Claudius, when as before is proued, S. Peter preached in this kingdome. Secondly the fir≈øt Bishop of London as all the re≈øt from King Lucius time to the coming of S. Augu≈øtine were Archbishops, and this onely in all Antiquities called onely Bishop of Augu≈øta in Britaine. Thirdly this was a Martyr, and ≈øo we doe not reade of any Iotz. in Catal. Epi≈ø. Brit. Io. Godcel. de Epi≈øc. LoÃÑd. Matth. Parker antiq. Brit. Godwin Catal. of Bishops. Stowe Hi≈øtor. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. Harris in Theat. to 1. Will. Harris de≈øcr. Archbishop of London, except on S. Vodinus Martyred in the times of King Vortigerne, and Hengi≈øt, in whome, both the times, names, callings, and other circum≈øtances are much different, making it vnpo≈ø≈øible that they were one and the ≈øame man. Fourthly no Antiquitie, or Antiquary, Catholike or Prote≈øtant ≈øetting downe the Catalogue of the Archbishops of London, as Iotzeline of Furnes, Ihon Godcilene, Matthew Parker, Godwine, Stowe, the Theater writers, or any other, once nameth this S. Augulus to be any of them that were ≈øince King Lucus time: But make S. Thean the fir≈øt, the la≈øt Theonus, that formerly was Bishop of Gloce≈øter, and in, or about the yeare of Chri≈øt 553. became Archbishop of London, and about the yeare 586. together with Thadiocus Archbishop of Yorke fled from the Pagan Saxons, into wales, and left their Sees vacant vntill the coming of S. Augu≈øtine. And betweene the≈øe there is not any one but S. Vodinus before a Martyr, or that hath any re≈øemblance in name, or other de≈øcription with S. Augulus. Their names be the≈øe: Thean. Eluanus. Cadar. Obinus. Conan. Palladius. Stephan. Iltut. Theodwin or Godwyn Catal. in London. & alij ≈øupr. Dedwin. Thedred. Hillary. Re≈øtitutus. Guitelnius or Guitelinus. Fa≈øtidius. Vodinus, Theonus.

5. A late writer in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory of Britaine, ≈øaith plainely that S. Harris in Theat. tom. 1. Nica≈øius the fir≈øt Bishop of Roan in Normandy of Fraunce, preached heare in this Britaine, in the≈øe times. And he ≈øeemeth to rely much vpon Arnoldus MirmaÃÑnius, who ≈øaith: Britones in≈øtruxit, formauitque fide S. Nica≈øius, imperante S. Nica≈øius Bishop in our Britaine by ≈øome writers. Nerone: Nica≈øius did in≈øtruct, and forme in the faith the Britans, in the time of Nero, being then delegated an Apo≈øtle thither, illuc Apostolus delegatus. And this he proueth to be vnder≈øtood of our Britans, becau≈øe the Britans of Armorica Arnold. Mirm. in Theatr. Conu. gent. in Fraunce, were not called Britans, vntill long after: which by all writers is a thing mo≈øt certaine, and out of Que≈øtion. Therefore except that Authour ≈øpake very vnproperly, to call them Britans, that were not vntill 300. yeares after, he mu≈øt needes meane, to ≈øpeake truely, the Britans of this Iland. And this S. Nica≈øius being ≈øent Apo≈øtle by Roman Authoritie, as he ≈øaith to the Britans, in the time of Nero, it mu≈øt needes be by S. Peter. And although the ≈øame Authour in the ≈øame place, ioyneth with the Britans, whome S. Nica≈øius thus in≈øtructed in the faith, the people of Normandy, Roan, Picardy, which be people in Fraunce, Britones, Normandos, Rothomagen≈øes, Picardos; this hindereth nothing, but he might preach both to them, and the Britans
heare al≈øo, as many others did; and that which followeth, omnemque maris Oceani tractum in≈øtruxit; he in≈øtructed in the faith all the Coa≈øte of the Ocean ≈øea, cannot well be iu≈øtified, except we bring him hither into our Britaine: for tho≈øe Countries he nameth in Fraunce, be farre from being omnis maris Oceani tractus, either all, or the half part of the Coa≈øte of the French Ocean.

6. To the≈øe I may probably add S. Martine lyuing in the Apo≈øtles time, and Probable, that S. Martin Di≈øciple of the Apo≈øtles was a Britan, or preached heare. ≈øo renowned in this kingdome, that in the time of King Lucius, to ≈øpeake in an old Authours words: con≈øtructa e≈øt extra Cantuariam Eccle≈øia Sancti Martini, a Church was builded vnto him without Canter bury. Which is the ≈øame, S. Bede and others write, was the old Church builded there, in the time of the Romans: who where departed hence before the dayes, eyther of S. Martine M. S. Abbreuiatio tempor. in Rege Lucio. Bed. hi≈øt. Anglic. in S. Augu≈øtino. l. 1. Stowe hi≈øtor. in Ethelbert. Theater of great Brit. Matth. Parker. antiq. Brit. Godwyn Conu. of Britaine p. 40. Ado in chronic. ad an. 101. Will. Lamb. perambulation of Kent. p. 13. the Pope, or S. Martine Bishop of Tours in Fraunce, by all accompts. And Ado and others te≈øtifie, this S. Martine was a Bishop in the time of Traiane, and armo. D. 101. Di≈øciple of the Apo≈øtles. Martinus Epi≈øcopus Di≈øcipulus Apo≈øtolorum Viennae re≈øedit. And M. Lambert the Prote≈øtant Antiquary doth a≈ø≈øure vs, that this Church by Canterbury dedicated to S. Martine, was both builded in the Romans time, and was, and continued a Bishops See, vntill the coming of the Normans hither, and ≈øo extraordinarily there were two Bishops Sees in one City, this being ≈øub≈øtitute to the Archbishop, which argueth how greate the honour was, that this nation gaue vnto him. And yet a Church ≈øo aunciently dedicated to him heare, would of it ≈øelfe by Brittish proceedings in ≈øuch affaires, induce vs to thinke, that eyther he was a Britan borne, or preached in this our Britayne, or both. For in peru≈øing our Antiquities of tho≈øe times, we shall hardly finde any Church dedicated in this kingdome to any Saint, except the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary, for her eminent priuiledge, but to ≈øuch as were Saints of this Nation, as S. Alban, Amphibalus, Aaron, Iulius; or preached heare as S. Peter the Apo≈øtle, S. Clement his Di≈øciple and ≈øucce≈ø≈øor, and ≈øuch like.

7. To make which more apparantly probable vnto vs, we haue two renowned and annuncient Authors, Methodius and S. Marianus, who ≈øpeaking Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. in Nerua Imp. col. 254. Method. apud cund. ≈øupr. of this holy Bishop S. Martine, and telling he liued and ≈øuffered Martyrdome in the time of Nerua the Emperour within the fir≈øt hundred yeare of Chri≈øt, ≈øay; That non ≈øolum propria prouincia, ≈øed & in extremis & vltimis indu≈øtrius & illu≈øtris non ≈øol√πm confe≈øsione, quin & martyrio exi≈øtens regna Tyrannorum vicit: He was not onely indu≈øtrious and renowned in his owne Prouince, but al≈øo in the vttermo≈øt and la≈øt Regions, not onely a confe≈ø≈øour, but a Martyr, conquered the kingdomes of Tyrants. Therefore to graunt vnto Ado, that he was ≈øometime Bishop of Vienna in Fraunce, ≈øeeing ≈øo greate authoritie doth warrant vs, that he preached in extremis, & vltimis, not onely in one prouince, but the very la≈øte and vttermo≈øt, in re≈øpect of that place, which mu≈øt needes comprehend this Iland of Britayne, we may not now exclude him from hence, where he hath bene honored with a Church dedicated to him as an holy Bishop, ≈øo many hundreds of yeares aboue 1400. ≈øince, in a Nation ≈øo peculiarly honoring the memories of the renowned Apo≈øtles, and Saints thereof, with ≈øuch te≈øtimonies of loue and duitie. And this the rather, becau≈øe we are told by forrain writers, that he was not onelie Apo≈øtolorum di≈øcipulus: a di≈øciple of the Apo≈øtles Arnold. Mitm. Theatr. Conu. gent. and ≈øent to the≈øe we≈øtern parts, whether as before, it is hard to finde any to haue bene ≈øent from any Apo≈øtle, but S. Peter. And this Church being aunciently a Bishops See, as the Kentish Prote≈øtant Antiquary hath told vs before, and yet without the City of Canterbury, it giueth more ≈øtrenght to this
opinion; for all Antiquities agree, that through out the whole kingdome in the time of King Lucius, all the Cathedrall and Epi≈øcopall Churches were in cyties. Which argueth this See to haue had a more auncient originall, then from that time: for further proofe whereof, the auncient Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory Hi≈øtor. Roffen. M. S. of Roche≈øter ≈øaith: Extra Ciuitatem in parte Orientali e≈øt Eccle≈øia Beati Martini, vbi Sedes Epi≈øcopalis erat: without the city of Canterbury one the Ea≈øt ≈øide is the Church of S. Martine, where there was a Bishops See. And Bishop Godwin was the la≈øt Bishop there in the time of Archbishop Lanfranke, who would not permit any ≈øucce≈ø≈øor therein, ≈øaying that two Bishops might not be in one city. Godwino vltimo illius Sedis Epi≈øcopo ≈øucce≈ø≈øorem Lanfrancus ≈øubrogare noluit: dicens, quod in vna ciuitate duo Epi≈øcopi minime e≈ø≈øe deberent. Standing vpon the Canons of the Church, as his rea≈øon argueth which further confirmeth, this cu≈øtome to haue bene long more auncient, then the Canons in that behalfe. And ≈øeeing Cathedrall Churches ordinarily take their denomination of the fir≈øt Saincts, that were Bishops there, except ≈øome other extraordinary merits of Saints, and deuotion vnto them giue them this priuiledge; this may be ≈øome warrant vnto vs, in this ca≈øe, to incline to thinke, this S. Martine eyther preached heare, or ≈øo well de≈øerued of this Nation, that we may not ea≈øily depriue him of this honour.

8. To this I may probably ioyne S. Nathanael, ≈øpoken of in the Gho≈øpel, Not vmprobable, but S. Nathaniel was, and preached in Britaine. and termed of our Sauiour, a true I≈øraelite: for as our French Hi≈øtorians tell vs, he was both con≈øecrated Bishop by S. Peter the Apo≈øtle, and was ≈øucce≈ø≈øour to S. Aphrodi≈øius in the See of Bituriges in Fraunce, about the time of S. Peters coming hither and at his direction at tho≈øe times, and by the Greeks in their Menologe called Symon. Therefore ≈øeeing ≈øome haue ≈øo contended before, Guliel. Ei≈øengr. centen. 1. f. 54. an. 54. Anton. part-1. tit. Anton. De. moch. l. 2. c. 24. Graeci in Menolog. Baron. in Annot. in Martyrol. 28. Octob. Sim. Chan. to bring one S. Symon into Britayne, and demon≈øtration is al≈øo made, that it could not be S. Symon Zelotes the Apo≈øtle, to leaue a place of due credit to their Authoritie, I may credibly a≈øcribe it to S. Nathanael, called S. Symon, and by ≈øome the brother of S. Philip the Apo≈øtle, and generally after the A≈øcen≈øion of Chri≈øt at the di≈øpo≈øitioÃÑ of S. Peter principally in the≈øe We≈øtern parts where although cheifely he bore the title of the Bishops of Biturigum: Burages in Berry in Fraunce, yet he trauailed in diuers other parts, as appeareth in Hi≈øtories, as others likewi≈øe did, who tooke their names of being Bishops of certayne places. Which is mo≈øt euident in S. Peter him≈øelfe, who although he neuer tooke name of Re≈øidency but at Anthioch and Rome; yet he trauay led and preached in ≈øo many Nations as I haue, and shall ≈øet downe hereafter.

9. And if we will follow the Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury, vpon who≈øe authoritie Antiq. Gla≈øt. M. S. in tabul. lignea perantiqua. Io. Capgrau. in Catalog. in S. Io≈øeph ab Aramathia. the Prote≈øtant Antiquaries of England haue builded much, in many things, we are told in them, that S. Io≈øephe ≈øonne of S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, that buryed Chri≈øt, & came hither & liued, & dyed heare, came hither with his Father, and that holy company, and al≈øo lyued and dyed a Bishop heare. That he was not a Bishop at his coming hither, it ≈øeemeth euident by many arguments: fir≈øt, becau≈øe no Hi≈øtory maketh mention of any Epi≈øcopall function S. Io≈øephe ≈øonne of S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia by diuers Antiquities, was a Bishop heare, and probably con≈øecrated heare by S. Peter or his Di≈øciples. performed then by him, or any of that happy ≈øociety; ≈øecondly, by all Antiquities, they liued and dyed in the Eremiticall ≈øtate of life. Which much differeth from Epi≈øcopall, which conuer≈øeth with, and ruleth others, and the Churches committed vnto his chardge. Thirdly in all Antiquities and Monuments of the≈øe holy men remembred eyther by Catholiks, or Prote≈øtants, S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia is called the cheife and principall: ex quibus Io≈øeph ab Aramathia primus erat.

q.l: Intrat Aualoniam duodena caterua vivorum. In≈øcriptio antiqua in aere in Caenob. Gla≈øton. Tabul. antiq. ib. Ioh. Capgr. in S. Io≈øeph ab Aramath. Godwin CoÃÑu. of Britaine p. 11. Theater of Brit. l. 6. Camd. in Gla≈øtenbury. Capgr. in S. Patricio.
Flos Aramathiae Io≈øeph e≈øt primus ‚Ä¢ orum.
Io≈øephes ex Io≈øeph genitus, patrem comitatur.

div.p: Where S. Io≈øeph that was no Bishop is euery were ≈øtiled their cheife, and Ruler: Therefore his ≈øonne Io≈øephe could be no Bishop at that time, for ≈øo a Bishop who≈øe office is to rule, and in all languadges by all interpretation is an Ouer≈øeer, Cheife commaunder and Ruler of others his ≈øubiects should haue bene inferiour, ≈øubiect, commaunded, and caled to, and by his inferiour and ≈øubiect. Therefore to iu≈øtifie the prediction of our Sauiour after his A≈øcen≈øion, that Io≈øephe, should be a Bishop, which the Antiquitie of Gla≈øtenbury ≈øetteth downe as a thing then done, ≈øaying of him: Io≈øephe quem Dominus Ie≈øus pri√πs in ciuitate Sarath in Epi≈øcopum con≈øecrauit: Io≈øephe whom our Lord Ie≈øus had con≈øecrated for a Bishop, before in the city Sarath: We mu≈øt needes ≈øay, that he was afterward according to the de≈øignment, and Prophe≈øie of Chri≈øt, con≈øecrated Antiquit. Gla≈øton. apud Cap. grau. in S. Io≈øeph ab Aramath. a Bishop in this kingdome, for Prophe≈øies that be true, are ≈øo certayne they shall come to pa≈ø≈øe, that often times they are expre≈ø≈øed as pre≈øently done and acted, as is v≈øuall in holy Scripturs and other wtiters, when they are not to be performed long after, becau≈øe they are as a≈ø≈øuredly to be after in due time, as if they were pre≈øently acted and fulfilled, as we mu≈øt needes interprete this. For the rea≈øons before demon≈øtrate, that S. Io≈øephe was not then con≈øecrated a Bishop by Chri≈øt. Neyther doth the Antiquitie ≈øo ≈øay, but in Epi≈øcopum con≈øecrauit, Christ con≈øecrated him to be a Bishop afterward. And we doe not reade that Chri≈øt after his A≈øcen≈øion did actually con≈øecrate any Bishop, hauing committed tho≈øe Functions to his Apo≈øtles. In ≈øo much that S. Paule him≈øelfe that was ≈øo extraordinarily and aboue all others that euer were called by Chri≈øt, cho≈øen and de≈øigned by him to be a Bishop, and Apo≈øtle, that he often and confidently, and as it were ≈øingularly ≈øpeaketh of him≈øelfe: Paule Ephe≈ø. 1. v. 1. Colo≈ø≈øen. 1. v. 1. Galat. 1 v. 1. an Apo≈øtle of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt by the will of God: Paulan Apo≈øtle, not of men, neyther by man, but by Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, and God the Father, who ray≈øed him from the dead: Yet when he ≈øpeketh of his Epi≈øcopall Con≈øecration, and the exerci≈øe of that holy Function, in the fir≈øt Chapter of his Epi≈øtle to the RomaÃÑs ≈øaying: Paula ≈øeruant Rom. 1. v. 1. Prote≈øt. CoÃÑcord. ibidem. of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, called to be an Apostle, ≈øeparated vnto the Gho≈øpell of God: He referreth this, as our Prote≈øtants in there CoÃÑcordance of Scripturs in that place expouÃÑd him, to his CoÃÑ≈øecration in the 13. Chapter of the Acts of the Apo≈øtles, by fa≈øting, prayer, and impo≈øition of hands. And before that time he neuer exerci≈øed Act. 13. v. 1. 2. 3. any Function meerly Epi≈øcopall. The like I may ≈øay of S. Barnabas by Act. 11. 12. 13. the ≈øame warrant, who though a Companion of S. Paul, and Preacher vnto the people, yet vntill he had at the ≈øame time with S. Paul externally receaued ordinary Con≈øecration he entermedled not with tho≈øe peculiar offices.

10. The like examples (to omit others) we haue of this Nation: We reade of S. Samp≈øon, Archbishop of Yorke, that S. Peter, S. Iames, and S. Ibon, Apo≈øtles Io. Capgrau. in Ca ‚Ä¢ alog. in S. Samplone Epi≈øcop. Et M. S. antiquit. ‚Ä¢ b ‚Ä¢ d. appeared vnto him before his Con≈øecration, and one of them being demaunded by him, who they were, he ≈øaid; Ego ≈øum Petrus Chri≈øti Di≈øcipulus, & hic Frater Domini Iacobus, & Euangeli≈øta Ioannes. Dominus Ie≈øus Chri≈øtus te ≈øibi in Prae≈øulem elegit, & t ‚Ä¢ con≈øecrare nos mi≈øit. Quem cum benedictione con≈øecra≈ø≈øent, abeius oculis elap≈øi ≈øunt: I am Peter the Di≈øciple of Chri≈øt, and this, Iames the Brother of our Lord, and Ihon the Euangeli≈øt. Our Lord Ie≈øus hath cho≈øen thee for a Bishop, and ≈øent vs to con≈øerate the. Whome when they had con≈øecrated with benediction, they di≈øappeared out of his ≈øight. Where nothing can be more playne then that this should be a true Con≈øecration, and thereby S. Samp≈øon and Vndoubted
con≈øecrated Bishop, if true con≈øecration could be ≈øo obtayned; for all things required vnto it, are here expre≈ø≈øed, that our Lord Ie≈øus had cho≈øen him, in Prae≈øulem; for a Bishop, as the other Antiquitie was of S. Io≈øeph in Epi≈øcopum: for a Bishop. Here is Chri≈øts warrant to con≈øecrate him, and the three greate≈øt Bishops and Apo≈øtles to performe it, and the words are plaine, that in that manner they effected it, quem cum benedictione con≈øecra≈ø≈øent: Yet it was adiudged both by heauen, and earth, God and man, that this was no Con≈øecration, nor S. Samp≈øon yet to be accompted a Bishop, but to expect the ordinary Con≈øecration by Bishops; for it followeth in the ≈øame Hi≈øtory: nec multo po≈øt Angelus Domini beato Dubritio apparens, Samp≈øonem ordinari Epi≈øcopum praecepit: not long after an Angel of God appearing to S. Dubritius (then Archbishop heare) commaunded that Samp≈øon should be con≈øecrated a Bishop. which he performed by the externall Rites of con≈øecrating Bishops, and this his externall Con≈øecration by that holy Archbishop, then the Popes Legate heare, was ≈øo miraculou≈øly confirmed, that as it followeth in the ≈øame Antiquitie: They which were pre≈øent at his Con≈øecration did ≈øee a Doue ≈øent from heauen immouably to ≈øtand ouer him: In cuius con≈øecratione qui aderant columbam caelit√πs emi≈ø≈øam immobiliter ≈øuper eam ≈øtare videbant.

11. And we haue heard from the≈øe Prote≈øtants, & others before, that S. Peter Godwin Catal. W ‚Ä¢ nche≈øter 31. in Brith ‚Ä¢ ald. Capgr. in S. Edward. Conf. M. S. Antiq. in eod. Alred. Rieuall. in Vit. S. Edwardi. Stowe hi≈øtor. in Edward. Confe≈øan. 1043. Holin≈ø. hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 8. cap. 1. did crowne King Edward the Confe≈ø≈øour, being an Exile in Normandy: Yet he was not King, or ≈øo accepted, vntill many yeares after, and then ordinarily crowned by the common Order of Coronation, belonging to our Kings at Winche≈øter, as our Prote≈øtant hi≈øtorians thus a≈ø≈øuer vs: Edward was crowned at winche≈øter by Ed≈øinus then Archbishop of Canterbury, on Ea≈øter day in the yeare of our Lord 1043. When the Propheticall Coronation of him by S. Peter was many yeares before. To the≈øe I may add the Dedication of the Church of our ble≈ø≈øed Lady at Gla≈øtenbury, builded by S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, and his holy company, which Chri≈øt him≈øelfe is written to haue dedicated: And that of We≈øtmin≈øter by an apparition of S. Peter the Apo≈øtle, onely with this difference, that the figuratiue Dedication of this la≈øt by S. Peter did declare, what he had there done before, as I haue partly shewed allready, and more hereafter; the other fore≈øignified, what should by ≈øome Bishop be effected after, no Bishop being of that company then to performe it, which I make an other Argument to shew that S. Io≈øeph was no Bishop at that time, but (if at all) con≈øecrated by S. Peter, or his Di≈øciples. And if we may giue ≈øo much credit to a late writer, that S. Ari≈øtobulus our fir≈øt Archbishop ≈øuffered Martyrdome at Gla≈øtenbury, the place of S. Io≈øeph and his ≈øonne, their onely or cheife≈øt aboade in this Nation. It will make it more vndoubted, that if S. Io≈øeph was Martyr. Angl. die 15. Martij in S. Ari≈øtobulo. a Bishop, he was con≈øecrated eyther immediately by S. Peter, or by this his renowned Di≈øciple our Archbishop then S. Ari≈øtobulus, who≈øe daughter S. Peter had marryed: Cepit vxorem Petrus filiam Ari≈øtobuli, fratris beati Barna
‚Ä¢ ae Apo≈øtoli, ex qua ≈øu≈øcepit filium & filiam, and ≈øent him hyther, as he ≈øent S. Sophronius Hiero≈øolym. Epi≈øc. Libell. de labor. S. Petri & Pauli. Simon Metaphra≈øt. die 29. Iun. HartmaÃÑ. Schedel in Chronic. Chron. f. 205 his Brother S. Barnabas to Millan in Italy, as Hartmanus Schedel, with diuers other Authours witne≈ø≈øeth.

div.head: THE XIX. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF DIVERS CHRISTIAN CHVRCHES, OR Oratories, ≈øuch as the state of things then allowed, erected, and founded in Britaine, in the time of S. Peters preaching heare.

div.p: 1. WE haue heard before, how among other holy labours of S. Peter in this kingdome, Eccle≈øias constituit: be con≈øtituted ≈øome Churches: how many in number, or which they, or any of them in particular were, it is not ≈øo ea≈øy to ≈øet downe from Antiquities, all being in a manner ≈øilent of tho≈øe proceedings; and we may not expect to finde any ≈øuch Churches in that time, to carry that glory, and honour with them, to continue to ≈øucceeding Generations, How poore the Chri≈øtiaÃÑ Churches were in th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe times. when the Church of Gla≈øtenbury builded by the Licence of King Aruiragus, and at the entreatie of the Roman Lieutenant, as Harding from others writeth, by the holy company of S. Io≈øeph, was made but of writhen wands, and ≈øo de≈øolate within one hindred and three yeares onely, after the fir≈øt building Harding Chroic. c. 47. f. 7 ‚Ä¢ . Antiq. Gla≈øcon. apud Capgrau. in S. Patricio. Et M. S. antiq. ib. Bed. Hi≈øt. Angl. Capgrau. in Catal. in S. Niniano. Bed. hi≈øt. Angl. l. 2. cap. 14. of it, that, caepit locus e≈ø≈øe ferarum latibulum, qui prius fuerat habitatio Sanctorum: The place which had bene an habitation of Saints, began to be a Dene of wylde bea≈øts. And diuers hundreds of yeares after this, the fir≈øt Church of ≈øtone, to remayne durable, that is remembred to haue bene in Britaine, was builded by S. Ninian, at witherne, as S. Bede and others write: and King Edwine of Northumberland, long after S. Augu≈øtins coming hither, was chri≈øtened at Yorke in the Church of S. Peter, the Apo≈øtle, which he had builded of wood: in Eccle≈øia S. Petri Apo≈øtoli, quam ip≈øe de ligno con≈øtruxit. And the dayes euen heare in Britayne were then ≈øuch for Chri≈øtians, that we mu≈øt rather ≈øeeke their places of abode, and poore Oratories among the De≈øarts, and ob≈øcure corners, in Cells, and Cotages, then in populous cities, and co≈øtly buildings: As our auncient Chri≈øtian Poet writing of ≈øuch times in Britayne, thus expre≈ø≈øeth.

lg.l: Sic vt erat celebris cultu numeroque Deorum, Nochamus apud Bal. & alios.
Cum Iouis Imperium ≈øtaret Britannia tellus:
Sic vbi terre≈øtres caelo de≈øcendit ad oras
Expectata ≈øalus patribus fuit inclyta Sanctis,
Qui Neptunicolum campos, & Cambrica rura,
Corineasque ca≈øas, loca de≈øolata colebant.

div.p: Which our Prote≈øtants haue thus tran≈ølated, for vs. T ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢ of g ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t B ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tainel. 5. c. 4.

lg.l: As were the Britans famous, for their zeale
To gentile Gods, whiles ≈øuch they did adore:
So when the heauens to earth did truth reueale,
Ble≈ø≈øed was that Land with truth, and learning ≈øtore,

Whence Brittish plaines and Cambreas de≈øart ground,
‚Ä¢ o. Bal. l. 1. d ‚Ä¢ vit. Pontif. Roman. Bap. Mantuan. l. 1. de Fa≈øt.
And Cornewals ‚Ä¢ rags, with glorious Saints abound.

div.p: To which purpo≈øe a Prote≈øtaÃÑt Bishop doth alledge an other Chri≈øtian Poet in this maner.

lg.l: Nam cum Cae≈øarei gens ≈øanguinolenta tyranni
Praedacentur oues Chri≈øti, nulla≈øque liceret
Christigenis habitare vrbes impune, ferarum
Con≈øortes facti, fines tenuere ≈øupremos
Orbis:

div.p: When the per≈øecution of Nero the Tirant grew ≈øo bloody, and de≈øtroyed the sheepe of Chri≈øt, and no Chri≈øtians might without punishement liue in cites. They became companions of wild bea≈øts, and inhabited the vttermo≈øt ends of the world. Therefore if out of the priuate hou≈øes of Chri≈øtians in tho≈øe times we would finde any places to beare the names of publike Churches, or Oratories for the Chri≈øtians then conuerted, though neuer ≈øo meane, and ob≈øcure, we mu≈øt ≈øeeke them out of frequent and inhabited places, in the De≈øerts and wilderne≈ø≈øes, whether the rage of per≈øecution did not ≈øo ea≈øily penetrate.

2. And to finde any ≈øuch, after ≈øo many huÃÑdreds of yeares, and changes of things in this kingdome, we mu≈øt be content with probable Arguments, and Probahle that S. Peters Church at we≈øtmin≈øter had ≈øome Originall at this time. te≈øtimonyes, as is v≈øuall in ≈øuch ca≈øes, & not expect demon≈øtrations, which caÃÑ not be giuen in ≈øuch affaires. AmoÃÑg ≈øuch De≈øerts of that time, diuers Prote≈øtaÃÑt and other Antiquaries will tell vs, the place of S. Peters Church at We≈øtmin≈øter was: Thus they write: Thorney now We≈øtmin≈øter was called Thorney-Iland, for that is was ouergrowne with Briers, and Thornes: which Thorney place was in the Ihon Norden in Specul. Britan. pag. 4. 2. Polidor. Virgil. Angl. hi≈øt. l. 2. pag 41. Holnish. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 10. pag. 25. Harris. de≈øcript. of Brit. cap. 2. pag. 140. Richard. Vit. Hi≈øt. l. 5. Io. Selden. Anaclet. cap. 6. Sulcardus apud Vit. Seld. Stowe hi≈øt. in K. Lucius. Holinsh. hi≈øt. ≈øupr. Harri≈øon. ≈øup. Ihon Norden Specul. Brit. part. 1. in Middel≈øex pag. 42. time of King Lucius clen≈øed about the yeare 186. which Lucius is ≈øaid to lay the fir≈øt foundation of the greate Temple of S. Peters. Which clen≈øing of that place by this religious King building a Church there, and dedicating it to S. Peter, giueth no ≈øwall argument vnto vs, to thinke it had a more auntient founding, with ≈øome Relation from the beginning, to that holy Apo≈øtle; otherwi≈øe there were many farre more fit and conuenient places in, or about the City of London to build ≈øo ≈øtately a Church, then a de≈øolate, briery, and thorney Iland. And the Church of S. Peter in Cornhill being dedicated to him, and the Cathedrall Church, by all Antiquities, we cannot be of any other minde, but S. Peter had ≈øome former title vnto that denomination. Which is rather ≈øtrengthned, in that the≈øe Prote≈øtants from Antiquities te≈øtifie, that Theonus Archbishop of London, in King Lucius time, who had his See at S. Peters in Cornhil, and helped to the building thereof, preached, read, and mini≈øtred the Sacraments there, to ≈øuch as made re≈øort vnto him in this IlaÃÑd Church. A Prote≈øtant Antiquary writeth. I haue heard, that there are, or haue bene Records in the ≈øame Abbey (of We≈øtmin≈øter) which declare it was a Church, before the Britans receaued the faith of Chri≈øt; He meaneth the time of King Lucius. Then, if he ≈øpeaketh properly, it proueth it was a Chri≈øtian Church before that time. For the word Church in English, Kyrke in the Scottish languadge of the Greeke Chiriache, the hou≈øe of God our Lord, cannot by Chri≈øtians be applyed or giuen to the Idols or pagan Gods of the Infidels, but onely to Chri≈øt, our true Lord and God. And this is confirmed by the knowne vi≈øion, and words of S. Peter the Apo≈øtle in that place, in the time of S. Ethelbert King of Kent, and S. Mellitus Bishop of London, which I haue alledged before from many allowed Antiquities, where S. Peter ≈øaid of this place and Church: By ≈øome a Chri≈øtian Church at Ald ‚Ä¢ lyhit. Quem locum proprijs manibus con≈øecraui: which place I con≈øecrated long agoe with my owne hands. Which mu≈øt needes, as I before haue proued, be vnder≈øtood of his par≈øonall pre≈øence, and con≈øecration of that Church, when he liued, and Harisin Theatr. l. 1. preached heare, for then onely and neuer ≈øince, he had proprias manus: his owne proper and naturall hands, to execute either that, or any function with.

3. A late writer in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory inclineth to thinke there was a Church founded by S. Peter the Apo≈øtle in the North parts of this Land, aunciently called Aldclihit, in the old languadge of that place Peters Clihit, as though S. Peter founded it, and it tooke the denomination from him, and citeth Henr. Hunting. hi≈øt. l. 1. Matth. Parker Antiq. Brit. p. 3. God wyn. conu. of Brit. c. 2. p. 10. S. Aug. in quad. Ep. apud Auth. ≈øupr. Henry of Huntington for his opinion, as is allready declared. The fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury, and an other al≈øo named ≈øuch a Bishop, will help vs to finde an other in the Ile of Gla≈øtenburye, more auncient then that which was builded there by S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, and his companions in the yeare of Chri≈øt 63. this being then fully and perfectly framed and finished before their coming thither, and ≈øo found by them ab≈øolutely perfected. And they cite for their Authour S. Augu≈øtine the Apo≈øtle of England, in a certaine Epi≈øtle written by him, wherein he ≈øaith, the≈øe holy men A Church at Gla≈øtenbury, before that builded by S. Io≈øeph of Arama ‚Ä¢ hia. found at their coming thither, a Church builded by no art of man, but prepared by God for mans ≈øaluation: Eccle≈øiam nulla hominum arte in≈øtructam, immo humanae ≈øaluti adeo paratam repererunt. Which is al≈øo recorded in the old Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury, written vpon parchiment fixed vpon broade bords, which cite for the ≈øame, hi≈øtoriam apud S.
