Edmundum, & Augu≈øtinum, the hi≈øtory at S. Antiq. Ga≈øton. M. S. ‚Ä¢ abulis fixae ex ‚Ä¢ i≈øt. apud S. Edmundum & S. Augu≈øtinum. Edmunds and S. Augustines. Which we mu≈øt needes referre to the time of S. Peters preaching heare, & among other miracles, to proue his doctrine by, God ≈øo miraculou≈øly prouided a Church, to preach the gho≈øpell, and Mini≈øter Sacraments in, and perhaps a motiue to the Pagan King, to graunt licence to S. Io≈øeph, to builde their poore Chappell at Gla≈øtenbury, and to endowe it with po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions. Neither can we thinke, this Church ≈øo priuiledged by that King, to haue bene finished without allowance of S. Peter, then pre≈øent in this kingdome, no Bishop being then heare, but by his Authoritie, or Con≈øecration, to dedicate and hallow it. And when our Prote≈øtant Theater writers with others haue told vs, that in diuers places of this kingdome euen in the Court of the Roman Lieurenant, and among them, his Lady and wife, Pomponia Graecia, there were many Chri≈øtians before S. Io≈øephs coming hither, which mu≈øt needes be the ≈øpirituall children of S. Peter, we may not make him ≈øo carele≈ø≈øe a Father, that ≈øtaÃÑding in no wor≈øe terms, with the then king of Britaine, and Roman Lieutenant, then by circun≈øtances before it appeared he did, but he prouided ≈øome Oratories, or poore Churches, either by tho≈øe Princes permi≈ø≈øion, or not contradiction, for them to exerci≈øe their ≈øacred Chri≈øtian Religion in, though the iniurie of ≈øo manie changes and alterations of gouernements, in this kingdome, with per≈øecutions, and Innouations in Religion, haue buried their memories in obliuion, and left the certaine knowledge and remembrance of ≈øo few vnto vs. And both Catholike T ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e Chri≈øtian old Churches in the Il ‚Ä¢ of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ wy ‚Ä¢ . and Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians tell vs, of two Miraculous auncient Chappels in the I≈øle, of Iewis; Boethius calleth it, Leui≈øa, the one dedicated to S. Peter the Apo≈øtle, the other to his Di≈øciple and Succe≈ø≈øor S. Clement; where if the fire or Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Scotland l. 4. c. 15 ‚Ä¢ ector Boetius de≈øcript. Scot. f. 14. light by mi≈øchance goth forth, it is, or was wont to be in Catholike times miraculou≈øly re≈øtored at the Altare: No man to my reading writeth, of their fir≈øt founding, but their names and dedication together with the Miracle giue no ≈ømall argument, they had ≈øome originall, in, or neare tho≈øe times, when S. Peter and S. Clement preached in this kingdome.

div.head: THE XX. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN FOR THE BETTER DECERNING of truely con≈øecrated Bishops, ≈øo many Eccle≈øia≈øticall matters depending therevpon, is shewed by the Antiquities how the≈øe Bishops were heare con≈øecrated in the Apo≈øtles time, and ≈øucceeding Ages.

div.p: 1. HAVING thus ≈øet downe ≈øome holy Bishops con≈øecrated by S. Peter, with Prei≈øts, and others ≈øubordinate vnto them, and places wherein they preached, practi≈øed, and profe≈ø≈øed the fir≈øt Apo≈øtolike Chri≈øtian doctrine, and Religion in this kingdome. Order and Methode in Hi≈øtorie call vpon mee, next to deliuer in particular, ≈øo fare as our penury of Antiquities will giue mee leaue, what Religion it was e≈øpecially in points now controuer≈øed, which that glorious Apo≈øtle by him≈øelfe and tho≈øe his worthie Di≈øciples taught the Chri≈øtians of this our Britaine, and profe≈ø≈øed in tho≈øe and other Churches, and places of Chri≈øtian A≈ø≈øemblies. But intending to re≈øerue that labour to the end of euery hundred of yeares, (or to ≈øome other booke a parte) to shewe the ReligioÃÑ of our Chri≈øtian BritaÃÑs in that age in ≈øuch, I will heare onely ≈øpeake of the Order & maÃÑner of coÃÑ≈øecrating Bishops heare in that happy time, both becau≈øe I haue made ≈øo late & lardge mention of ≈øuch holy Rulers, and our Prote≈øtants of England ≈øtill without exaÃÑple of any others, of the≈øe new Religions, retayne their names and offices, as they ≈øuppo≈øe, as euer to haue bene from the Apo≈øtles time mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary to rule, direct, and gouerne in the Church of Chri≈øt.

2. It is the common opinioÃÑ of their Antiquaries, that the Britans heare from their fir≈øt receauing of the faith of Chri≈øt, in the time of the Apo≈øtles, neuer altered, or chaunged it in any one e≈ø≈øentiall thing, at the lea≈øt vntill the coming of S. Augu≈øtine hither, in the later end of the ≈øixt hundred yeare of Chri≈øt. Then much more mu≈øt we affirme, by the≈øe men, that the e≈ø≈øentiall things in the con≈øecration of true and lawfull Bishops, vpon which all other depended were neuer chaunged, otherwi≈øe the chaunge and alteration in the≈øe vnchangeable and vnalterable affaires had bene contrary to the≈øe mens a≈ø≈øertions too greate and intollerable. Then we reade in a very old Manu≈øcript, Capgraue & to follow two Prote≈øtant Bishops with many others that Io. Bal. l. de Scrip. Cent. 1. in A≈øaph. Godwin Catal. of Bishops in cod. A≈øaph. Pits. l. de vir. Illu≈øtr. in eod. S. A≈øaph in vit. S. Kenteg. M. S. Antiq. in eodem. Io. Capgrau. in S. Kentegerno Epi≈øcop. & Confe≈ø≈ø. S. A≈øaph did write the life of S. Kentegern and dyed aboue a thow≈øand yeares ≈øince, that when S. Kentegern vas con≈øecrated Bishop allmo≈øt, by the≈øe Authours, 1200. yeares agoe: Mos in Britannia inoluerat, in con≈øecratione Pontificum tantummodo capita eorum Sacri Chri≈ømatis infu≈øione perungere, cum inuocatione Sancti Spiritus, & benedictione, & manus impo≈øitione. In≈øulani enim qua≈øi extra orbem po≈øiti emergentibus Paganorum infestationibus Canonum erant ignari: Eccle≈øia≈øtica ideo cen≈øura ip≈øis conde≈øcendens excu≈øationem illorum admittit in hac parte: A cu≈øtome was growne of long time in Britaine in the con≈øecration of Bishops, to annoint their heads with infu≈øion of holy Chri≈øme, with inuocation of the holy gho≈øt, and benediction, and impo≈øition of hands. For the Ilanders being as it were placed out of the world, by often Infe≈øtations of Pagans were ignorant of the Canons.
And therefore the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Cen≈øure conde≈øceÃÑding vnto them, admitteth their excu≈øe in this point. And immediately before this maÃÑner of coÃÑ≈øecrating Bishops is called Mos Britannorum & Scotorum: The custome or manner of the Britans and Scots in con≈øecrating Bishops, and the ≈øame is there p ‚Ä¢ oued of the Chri≈øtians in Ireland in tho≈øe times: For the ≈øame Antiquities te≈øtifie, that there was a Bishop ≈øent for out of Ireland to be pre≈øent and a Con≈øecratour of S. Kentegern after that manner, accito de Hibernia vno Epi≈øcopo more Britonum & Scotorum in Epi≈øcopum ip≈øum con≈øecrari fecerunt.

3. We are al≈øo taught by a Prote≈øtant Bishop, that S. A≈øaph who write the Io. Capgrau. M. S. & S. A≈øaph ≈øupr. in S. Kentegerno. life of S. Kentegern, and ≈øucceeded him in his Epi≈øcopall See in Wales and by his ≈øanctitie gaue that denomination vnto it, was con≈øecrated Bishop by holy vnction: vnctionem recepit: And there ≈øpeaketh as though it was the e≈ø≈øentiall ceremony of that holy Order, a≈øcribing there no other thing e≈ø≈øentiall vnto it, but authoritatem & vnctionem; authoritie, and inunction, ≈øo that Authoritie Ioh. Bal. lib. de Scriptor. cent. 1. in A≈øaph fol. 34. being the ≈øame with Iuri≈ødiction, he maketh the Sacrament onely or cheifely to con≈øi≈øt in Anointing with holy Chri≈øme. And though the≈øe te≈øtimonies that this Order or manner of con≈øecrating Bishops was a generall cu≈øtome with the Britans, Scots, and Irish people, when S. Kentegern was made Bishop, which was long before the death of S. Patrike the Popes Legate in the≈øe Countries, and before any notice taken of the Canons of holy Councels in this matter, doe ≈øufficiently proue this ordering of Bishops with holy Chri≈øme was e≈ø≈øentiall, and from the time of the Apo≈øtles; yet if we will followe the opinion of the Prote≈øtant Archbishop Whitgift, M. Foxe, M. Barnes and Ioh. Witg. An≈øwere to the Admonit. p. 65. ≈øect. 4. & p. 66. ≈øect. 1. Foxeto. 1. pag. 12. Rob. Barnes in vit. Pontif. in Anacleto. S. Anacletus Epi. ad Galliae. Epi≈øc. tom. 1. Concil. other English Prote≈øtaÃÑt writers, te≈øtifying S. Anacletus that was made Prei≈øt by S. Peter the Apo≈øtle, and after ≈øucceeded in the See of Rome, to be Authour of the Epi≈øtles extant in his name, it maketh this matter out of Que≈øtion: For an≈øwearing the petition of the Bishops of Fraunce de≈øirous to be in≈øtructed by him in this matter, thus he writeth: Vt a beato Petro Principe Apo≈øtolorum ≈øumus in≈øtructi, a quo & Presbyter ≈øum ordinatus, ≈øcribere vobis ≈øicut peti≈øtis, non denegabimus. Ordinationes Epi≈øcoporum, authoritate Apo≈øtolica, ab omnibus qui in eadeÃÑ fuerint Prouincia, Epi≈øcopis ≈øunt celebrandae. Qui ≈øimul conuenientes, ≈øcrutinium diligenter agant, ieiuniumque in omnibus celebrent precibus, & manus cum ≈øanct is Euangelys, quae praedicaturi ≈øunt, imponentes, Dominica die bora tertia orantes, ≈øacraque vnctione, exemplo Prophetarum, & Regum, capita eorum more Apo≈øtolorum, & Moy≈øis, vngentes, quia omnis ≈øanctificatio con≈øtat in Spiritu ≈øancto, cuius virtus inui≈øibilis Sancto Chri≈ømate e≈øt permixta, & hoc ritu ≈øolemnem celebrent ordinationem: As we were in≈øtructed by S. Peter, Prince of the Apo≈øtles, by whome al≈øo I was made Prei≈øt, we will not deny to write vnto you, as you haue reque≈øted. Ordinations of Bishops by Apo≈øtolike authoritie, are to be celebrated by all the Bishops that are in the ≈øame Prouince. Who a≈ø≈øembling together, let them diligently make ≈øcrutiny, and let them celebrate fa≈øting with all prayers, and impo≈øing their hands ‚Ä¢ ith the holy gho≈øpels which they are to preach, praying vpon our Lords daye at the third hower, and with holy vnctio by example of Prophets, and Kings, anointing their heads, according to the manner of the Apo≈øtles and Moy≈øes, becau≈øe all ≈øanctification con≈øi≈øteth in the holy gho≈øt, who≈øe inui≈øible vertue is mixed in holy Chri≈øme, and by this Rite let them celebrate ≈øolemne ordination. Where we learne of an eye witne≈ø≈øe, and Anditor and Di≈øciple of S. Peter, ≈øo authentically witne≈ø≈øing it, that the other Apo≈øtles and S. Peter did not onely v≈øe his holy anointing of tho≈øe Bishops they con≈øecrated, but in this externall ceremony the vertue and grace of that Sacrament was giuen.

4. To giue further confirmation to this Antiquitie, and inuincibly proue that this manner of con≈øecrating Bishops with holy vnction, mu≈øt needes de≈øcend from the Apo≈øtles, it was the generall cu≈øtome in all parts of the world, A≈øia, Afrike, and Europe, both in the Greeke and Latin Church, in the fir≈øt vn≈øpotted dayes of Chri≈øtianitie. For A≈øia, and the Greeke Church Marcus Marc. Anton. de Dom. l. 2. c. 2. p. 187. Antonius de Dominis when he was a writer for Prote≈øtants, and by their warrant in England writeth plainely: Areopagitae Dyoni≈øio tributum opu≈øculum vnctionem ponit expre≈øs√®: the worke a≈øcribed to Dioni≈øius the Areopagite doth expre≈øly put vnction in con≈øecrating a Bishop. And proueth directly out of S. Gregory Nazianz. orat. 20. de laudib. S. Ba≈øilij. & orat. 5. ad Pat. & Ba≈øil. Naziancen, that both S. Ba≈øile and he al≈øo were con≈øecrated Bishops with this holy Ceremonie: me Pontificem vngis. For Afrike he citeth diuers Councels. And for Europe and the Latin Church he alledgeth the Epi≈øtle of S. Anacletus before cited: addit vnctionem capitis Anacletus, quae e≈øt antiqui≈øsima. I rather cite the≈øe Prote≈øtants for the≈øe, then the auncient Catholike Authours them≈øelues, knowne to all learned men, that no Prote≈øtant may ≈øtand in doubt of the veritie of the Antiquities.

5. And to ≈øpeake a litle more of the Latin Church in which England is, S. Gregory ≈øaith playnely, that the annointing of Bishops is a Sacrament, and ≈øo cannot be omitted: Qui cum in culmine ponitur, Sacramenta ≈øu≈øcipit vnctionis. Gregor. in c. 4. 1. Reg. Quia vero ip≈øa vnctio Sacramentum e≈øt, is qui promouetur, bene foris vngitur, ≈øi intus virtute Sacramenti roboretur: he (a Bishop) that is placed in the top, receaueth the Sacrament of vnction. Becau≈øe that vnction is the Sacrament, he which is promoted, is well anointed out wardly, if inwardly he is ≈øtrenghtned by the vertue of the Sacrament. The learned Fathers S. I≈øidor, Amalarius, Fortunatus, at Treuers S. I≈øidor. lib. 2. de Eccle≈ø. offic. c. 25. Stephan. aduer≈ø. tractat. de Sacrament. Altar. S. Iuo ≈øerm. de reb. Eccl. de ≈øignific. Indumentorum Bed. l. 3. detabernaculo & va≈øis eius. Et apud Amalar. ≈øupr. Prote≈øt. Booke of Articles of Religion. art. 25. in Germany Stephanus Adnen≈øis a Bishop, and S. Iuo in Fraunce te≈øtify the ≈øame, that a Bishop is con≈øecrated cheifly with this holy ceremony of vnction. So doth S. Bede in England, ≈øaying: Indutus ≈øacris ve≈øtibus Pontifex, mox oleo vnctionis perfunditur, vt per gratiam Spiritus Sancti con≈øecratio perficiatur: The Bishop attyred with ≈øacred vestiments is pre≈øently perfu≈øed with oyle of vnction, that con≈øecration may be perfected by grace of the holy Gho≈øte. Where we ≈øee all, which the Religion of English Prote≈øtants in their publike Articles thereof, requireth to a Sacrament, an externall ≈øigne, in≈øtituted by Chri≈øt, giuing grace and internall grace performed in this holy vnction. And all the auncient Chri≈øtans of this kingdome, Britans, and Saxons before they were vnited in other things in the time of S. Theodor Archbishop of Canterbury euer agreed in this, as before is manife≈øt in the Britans their old cu≈øtome, and Saxons receauing the faith from S. Gregory, who held this holy vnction to be a Sacrament. And we reade in the life of S. Cedda our holy Bishop, who coming Io. Capgrau. in S. Cedda. to Canterbury to be con≈øecrated, S. Deu≈ødedi ‚Ä¢
being dead before his coming thither, and Wina being then the onelie Bishop a liue among the Saxons Bishop of the we≈øt Saxons Canonically ordered, he ioyned with two Brittish Bishops which differed from the Church of Rome, in the ob≈øeruation of Ea≈øter, and they three con≈øecrated S. Cedda Bishop: a≈ø≈øumptis in ≈øo
‚Ä¢ ietatem ordinationis duobus de Britonum gente Epi≈øcopis, qui Dominicum Pa≈øchae di ‚Ä¢ m ≈øec√πs morem Canonicum, √† quartadecima v≈øque ad vige≈øimam lunam celebrabant. Where we ≈øee, agreed by all parties though at difference in ≈øome other things, that this ≈øacred Rite of holy vnction, was the cheife e≈ø≈øentiall, and materiall ceremony in con≈øecrating Bishops, and they which obtayned it in their con≈øecration, though wanting other ceremonies of that holy Sacrament, were euer e≈øteemed, and honoured for true, and lawfull Bishops, and
otherwi≈øe of ≈øuch as want it, the ca≈øe of all Prote≈øtants at this time, which haue by this meanes depriued them≈øelues, of all true Bishops, Prei≈øts, and other Cleargie men depending vpon true Bishops: and ≈øo haue none but meere laye men in their profe≈ø≈øion, and con≈øequently no Church of Chri≈øt by their owne confe≈ø≈øions. But I shall more fully entreate the≈øe things hereafter; when I shall both demon≈øtrate that S. Peter, and all the Apo≈øtles where Ma≈ø≈øing ≈øacrificing Prei≈øts, and neyther did, nor could con≈øecrate any others then ≈øuch.

div.head: THE XXI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE COMING OF S. IOSEPH OF ARAmathia, who buryed Chri≈øt, into this our Britaine: And how it is made doubtfull, or denyed by many writers, but without either rea≈øon or Authoritie.

div.p: 1. ABOVT this time, when S. Peter and his holy Di≈øciples, were thus happily planting the faith of Chri≈øt, and founding his Church in Britaine, it is the common opinion, (which I will follow hereafter) that S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, (who as the Gho≈øpell te≈øtifieth, buryed our ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour) came hither, in, or about the 63. yeare of his Incarnation: and for the greate Honor of this kingdome, was with his Religious company the fir≈øt Founder of Mona≈øticall life in this Nation; But before we Diuers make the coming of S. Io≈øeph into Britaine doubtfull: others wholy deny it. can giue him quiet po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion heare by his pre≈øence, life, death, and buriall, to be made partakers of ≈øo greate happines, as they brought vnto vs: we finde, as in S. Peter before, many impediments, and hinderances of ≈øuch benefite to this kingdome; for ≈øome make his coming hither doubtfull, others affirme he was not heare at all. The writer of the auntient Roman Martyrologe ≈øeemeth to thinke, he died at Hieru≈øalem, for in his Fe≈øtiuitie, which he maketh the 17 day of March, ≈øo he affirmeth: Mart. 17. Hiero≈øolymis S. Io≈øeph ab Aramathia, Martyrol. Rom. 17. Martij. nobilis decurionis, Di≈øcipuli Domini, qui eius corpus de cruce depo≈øitum in monumento nouo ≈øepeliuit. Philippus Bergomen≈øis followeth the ≈øame opinion that he liued and dyed in Iury. And Cardinal Baronius though in his Annals Philipp. Berg. hi≈øt. l. 8. f. 104. in an. D. 34. Baron. Annal. tom. 1. an. 35. Baron. in annot. in Martyrolog. Rom. 17. Ma ‚Ä¢ t. Authour of the Booke 3. Conu. part. 1. c. 1. p. 24. n. 25. he citeth a Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory in the Vaticane, for his coming into, and dying in Britaine, yet in his Annotations vpon the Roman Martyrolog, he inclineth to that which I haue cited from thence, that he died in Hieru≈øalem. The Authour of the Three Conuer≈øioÃÑs of EnglaÃÑd, ≈øpeaking of S. Io≈øephs coming hither, ≈øaith: albeit I finde no verie certaine, ‚Ä¢ r auntient writer to affirme it, yet becau≈øe our later Hi≈øtoriographers for two hundred yeares or more doe hold it to haue come downe by Tradition, I doe not meane to dispute the matter heare.

2. Others there be who allthough they agree with the common opinion, and con≈øent to the receaued truth, that S. Io≈øeph came hither, liued, and died heare, together with diuers of his religeous companions, yet they a≈ø≈øigne ≈øuch a time, for this his coming into this land, that it cannot be reconciled to the true rea≈øons of Antiquities in this point, and ≈øo they weaken thereby the credit of the true Hi≈øtorye. Ihon Funccius a Prote≈øtant writer
≈øeemeth vtterly to deny his coming hither at all, ≈øo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gly ≈øay ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ g th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe thing ‚Ä¢
Io. Funct. lib. 6. Comm. in ≈øuam chronolog. ad an. 178. which the writers of Britaine deliuer of Io≈øeph of Aram ‚Ä¢ hia, who „Äà‚óä„Äâ the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ lp of Nicodem ‚Ä¢ s, buried the body of Chri≈øt, how with many others be ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to that „Äà‚óä„Äâ and there fir≈øt ≈øowed the Ghospell of Christ, and the re≈øt, I leaue them to the „Äà‚óä„Äâ to be beleeued: Quae de Io≈øepho de Aramathia, qui Chri≈øti „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Nicodemo, ≈øepalchro mandauerit, tradunt Britanniae Scriptores quomodo ad „Äà‚óä„Äâ cum multis alijs venerit, ac Euangelion Chri≈øti primus ibidem ≈øeminauerit, ac reliq ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Britonibus credenda relinquo. By which words if he meaneth that S. Io≈øeph was neuer heare at all, I shall plainely confute him with the re≈øt hereafter; but if he intendeth onely, that S. Io≈øeph was not the fir≈øt as his words be, Euangelion Christi primus ibidem ≈øeminauerit, that preached heare, it hindereth nothing at all, for I haue proued S. Peter, and his Di≈øciples to haue well de≈øerued that Preeminencie; which perhaps this Prote≈øtant was willing virtually to graunt, naming no others, when in the immediate next words he addeth: Quamuis non dubito, quin multis annis ante, Christi fides in Britannia fuerit culta, Funct. ≈øupr. quam Lucius Rex ad eam peruenerit: allthough I doe not doubt but the faith of Christ was reuerencedin Britaine many yeares before King Lucius receaued it. But allthough the≈øe Exceptions again≈øt S. Io≈øeph doe carry a greater countenance of authoritie and credit, then any were made again≈øt S. Peter, as I haue inuincibly freed this holy Apo≈øtle from the lea≈øt ≈øu≈øpition therein, ≈øo I will now This error confuted, with the occa≈øion thereof. deliuer S. Io≈øeph, and ≈øet him and his holy companions in the ≈øame ≈øtate of libertie.

3. And concerning the ≈øtronge≈øt obiections from the Roman Martyrologe, and Bergomen≈øis, they onely take notice of his fir≈øt Conuer≈øation in Chri≈øtianitie, as they found it in the Gho≈øpell, and ≈øo they goe no further then it doth, onely ≈øpeaking of him in Iury and Hieru≈øalem. Be≈øides, if we should expownd them, as Keepers of S. Io≈øeph out of Britaine, they are at variance with them≈øelues, for the Roman Martirologe keepeth his fe≈øtiuitie vpon the 17. day of March, and Philip of Bergon ≈øaith: cum ob eximias eius virtutes Sanctus habitus ≈øit, eius Fe≈øtum 13. calendas Augu≈øti celebratur: when for his excellent vertues he is accompted a Saint, his Fea≈øt is celebrated the 13. of the Calends of Augu≈øt, the twenteth day of Iuly. And whereas it is mo≈øt certaine S. Antiquit. Gla≈øton. & alij. Io≈øeph was pre≈øent at the Tran≈ømigration of the ble≈ø≈øed virgin Mary, and liued many yeares after, Bergomen≈øis ≈øetteth downe his death in the 34. of Chri≈øt, ≈øoone after his A≈øcen≈øion: And the writer of the Martyrologe taking no other notice of him, then from the Gho≈øpell ≈øetteth downe no time of his death, or other Act of his life at all, not hauing reade any Hi≈øtory entreating of him, after his coming from Iury, nor after the buryall of our Sauiour, and ≈øo no maruayle if he was ignorant of the ob≈øcure and Eremiticall life, and death of a Saint though otherwi≈øe ≈øo glorious, thus lyuing and dying in ≈øo remote an Iland, formerly accompted an other world. For to omit hundreds, or thow≈øands rather, of holy Saints of other Nations, which the Authour of that Martyrologe remembreth not, things memorable confu≈øed and concealed with vtter obliuion by the Per≈øecutions then, he ≈øpeaketh not one word of any one Saint of this kingdome in that fir≈øt age, and hundred yeares, though ≈øome of them are honored in holy Scripture by S. Paule as S. Eubulus, and Claudia, and others, renowned Bishops made publike mirrors and ≈øpectacles of the then Chri≈øtian world, as S. Man≈øuetus, Beatus he whome ≈øome call Achates and others. So many and credible auntient Antiquities of this Nation, which be≈øides the certaine Tradition of that veritie, I shall pre≈øently
bring for the true Hi≈øtory of S. Io≈øephs lyuing, and dying heare, will euidenrly declare, how litle or vnfortunate their ≈øerches had bene in our Antiquities, that could find no very certaine or auntient writer to affirme it: for I doe not doubt but I shall produce as many ≈øuch for this matter, as we haue for many mo≈øt certaine Relations, of ≈øo greate Antiquitie concerning this kingdome, and for ≈øuch acknowledged generally, both by Catholike and Prote≈øtant writers.

div.head: THE XXII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN IS PROVED BY ALL KINDE of te≈øtimonies, and authorities, that for certaine, S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, with diuers other holy A≈ø≈øociates, came into, preached, lyued, dyed, and was buryed in Britayne, at the place now called Glastenhury in Summer≈øet shire.

div.p: 1. THE mo≈øt credible, faithfull, and vndoubted human te≈øtimonies, which we can haue, or de≈øire in ≈øuch things of Antiquity, to try their truthe, were euer accompted tho≈øe which be giuen, and warranted by the publike Charters, and In≈øtruments of our Kings, to which commonly all ≈øubiects of vnder≈øtanding, and qualitie giue ≈øome a≈ø≈øent, or approbation, and in matters concerning Antiq. Gla≈øt. M. S. Et Capgrau. in S. Io≈øeph. Park. Antiq. Brit. p. 3. Godwin Conu. of Brit. p. 9. Stow hi≈øt. in Aruiragus. Camden in Belg. Io. Leland in a≈ø≈øer. Arthur. Bal. l. de Script. cent. in Io≈øeph ab Aram. Antiquit. Gla≈øt. M. S. tabulis affixae. vetu≈øt. Guliel. Malm. l. de antiq. Gla≈øtoniae M. S. Io. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 2. f. 81. in G ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ elu. Malmesburien. Ioh. Leland. l. de a≈ø≈øert. Arthur. f. 12. Stowe and Howes hi≈øtor. in Romans. Agric. Godwin Conu. of Brit. Theater of Brit. l. 6. the communitie, ≈øuch as freedome, priuiledge, and exemption in matters of a different Religion, and conuer≈øation, from other ≈øubiects are, mu≈øt needes take notice, and knowledge of them, the priuiledged & exempted par≈øons, or their cheife≈øt, and places, their names, nature, and condition. And yet the be≈øt and mo≈øt auncient Antiquities we haue of that, and which Catholiks receaue and allow for true in this point doe a≈ø≈øuer vs, that the Pagan which then lyued and reigned heare, did expre≈ø≈øely te≈øtifie and approue this Hi≈øtory of S. Io≈øeph by his publike In≈øtrumeÃÑt of Immunitie in ≈øuch manner, diuers of the≈øe Antiquities name that King, ≈øaying it was Aruiragus, and affirme the ≈øame of the two next ≈øucceeding Kings, Marius, and Coillus: others as the mo≈øt auncient Manu≈øcript Antiquitie written in greate leaues of parchment fixed vpon broade bords, and formerly belonging to the Mona≈øtery of Gla≈øtenbury, and William the Monke of Malmesbury, who as a Prote≈øtant Bishop writeth, was an old man in the yeare of Chri≈øt 1130. in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory de antiquitate Gla≈øtoniae: of the antiquitie of Gla≈øtenbury, (both which I haue ≈øeene) punctually ≈øet downe the ≈øame Hi≈øtory, but doe not expre≈ø≈øe the names of the Pagan King, and Kings which gaue this publike libertie and protection to S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, who≈øe name they plainely ≈øet downe, but onely ≈øay, it was the Pagan King which then reigned, and two other Pagan Kings after him.

2. The ≈øame irreprouable certainty of this verity was continually afterward warranted by other Kings, in the ≈øame Order by their publike Charters, and Te≈øtimonialls of the ≈øame truth: among whome King Henry the ≈øecond
in his letters Patents is witnes, that his Antece≈ø≈øours Kings heare, william and william, Henry, Edgar, Edmund, Elfred, Bringwalthius, Henthwine, Baldred, Inas, Arthure, Cynred Chri≈øtians, and Kennewalla a Pagan, had in the ≈øame manner by their publike Charters giuen te≈øtimony vnto it: all which (he there prote≈øteth) he had cau≈øed diligently to be ≈øought forthe, pre≈øented and read before him. Quorum priuilegia & Chartas feci diligenter inquiri, & coram me pre≈øentar ‚Ä¢ & legi: and that the venerable authoritie of the Auncients did proue the Church ≈øo priuiledged, was ≈øo builded by them, which were the very Di≈øciples them≈øelues of Chri≈øt our Lord: ab ip≈øis Di≈øcipulis Domini aedificatam fui≈ø≈øe, venerabilis habet antiquorum authoritas. Of which holy company all Antiquities bring Euidence, that S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia was the cheife, and principall. To which the name of the place called by the fir≈øt cheife≈øt builder, as is v≈øuall in ≈øuch things, beareth the name now euen in the Ruyns thereof, as it euer did when it florished mo≈øt, S. Io≈øephs Chappell. Becau≈øe principally builded by him, and not for that is was dedicated to him, for all Antiquities plainely acknowledge it was from the fir≈øt building dedicated to the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary. To this the holy body of S. Io≈øeph buryed there with the an auncieÃÑt In≈øcription in Bra≈ø≈øe vpon his Tombe, te≈øtifying that Saint Io≈øephs body was interred there, was a William HarisoÃÑ de≈øcript. of Brit. p. 23. witne≈ø≈øe without exception, ≈øo long, vntill the new Religion defaced it, with ≈øo many holy and memorable Antiquities. And as I haue bene credibly informed, it was after pre≈øented and giuen to Iudge wam≈ølowe, when he was Iudge of that circuite. The ≈øtiled holy mo≈øt miraculous tree, ≈øtill growing in the place of his, or ≈øome of his companions fir≈øt re≈øting there, doth euery Chri≈øtma≈ø≈øe time preach euen to this day the truth of this, and Chri≈øtian Religion, in ≈øo wonderfull and ≈øupernaturall manner, that no Iewe, Mahumetan, or Pagan can denye them. The Charter of King Henry the ≈øecond which te≈øtifieth that ≈øo many Kings had taken publike notice of this matter, is, or lately was extant, for Ihon Leland writing of this Hi≈øtory, ≈øaith: ip≈øa Henricianae donationis verba, ex Archetypo ≈øub≈øcribam. I will ≈øet downe the words of King Henry his graunt Ioh. Leland a≈ø≈øert. Arthurij fol. 12. out of his originall writing it ≈øelf. Therefore he had ≈øeene it. And Mai≈øter Stowe making relation, from this Charter of King Henry the ≈øecond, how all tho≈øe Kings before remembred, and many other Chri≈øtian Kings be≈øides, had publikly confirmed this truth, he addeth: all which ≈øo to be, the fore≈øaid King Henry Stowe hi≈øtory the Romans in Agricola. Theater of great Brit. lib. 6. cap. 9. Godwin Conu. of Brit. p. 10. Theater ≈øup. l. 6. Ihon Harding Chronicle fol. 60. c. 47. Act. SS. Damia. & Fugat. apud Capgr. in Catal. Leland. in A≈ø≈øer. Arthur. Theat. of Brit. l. 6. Epi≈øt. S. Patric. apud Capgr. ≈øup. & alios. Godwin Conu. of Brit. p. 10. Gaufrid. Abbas Burton. M. S. hi≈øt. de vit. S. Moduenae Virg. c. 2. 4. &c. Nenius apud Harding Chron. fol. 41. c. 48. Melkin. apud Capg. in S. Io≈øeph & in Antiq. Gla≈øton. Baleus l. de Scri. cent. 1. in Melkino. Matth. Parker in antiq. Brit. ≈øup. Godwin Conu. p. 10. Io. Anglic. Foxe to 1. Mon. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. c. 9. ¬ß. 2. Dauid Powel in Annot. in hi≈øt. Cambr. p. 12. 13. Godwin Conu. of Brit. p. 11. Ioh. Capgrau. in Catalog. in S. Patri. the Auncient in≈øcriptioÃÑ in Bra≈ø≈øe. Apud Capgrau. in S. Io≈øeph. M. S. Vatican. apud Baron. to. 1. Theat. of Brit. l. 6. Godw. Conu. of Brit. Philip. Pantal. Chron. ad an. 70. & 75. Andre Che≈øne hi≈øt. d'Angletere, E≈øco≈ø≈øe & Hiber. Matth. Parker. Antiq. Brit. Bal. cent. 1. in Io≈øeph Godwin Conu. Mont. Infra. Camden in Belg. Stowe & Howes Hi≈øt. Powell annot. in hi≈øt. Brit. Drayton in Poly. olb. Seld. Illu≈øtr. established by his Charter: which Charter my≈øelf haue ≈øeene and read.

3. The Prote≈øtant Theater writers write in like manner, and a Prote≈øtant Bishop writing in the yeare 1615. of this matter, plainely writeth: The Charters are extant of King Henry the ≈øecond. And the ≈øame Prote≈øtants late Theater telleth vs the like of the Charter of King Edward the third, to the ≈øame effect: one exemplified vnder the ≈øeale of King Edward the third is to be ≈øeene at this day: wherein Relation is made of all tho≈øe Charters and Te≈øtimonyes I haue before remembred. Ihon Harding writing of the coming of S. Io≈øeph hither, and the extraordinary fauour which King Aruiragus publikly shewed vnto him, and his A≈ø≈øociats, ≈øaith it was, at the entreaty of Ve≈øpa≈øian the Roman Lieutenant vnto Aruiragus, and his Queene. We haue further witne≈ø≈øes heare of the Acts of the Legats of Pope and Saint Eleutherius, in the ≈øecond hundred yeare alledged by S. Patricke, whether the fir≈øt ≈øent by S. Cele≈øtine Pope then of Rome as his Epi≈øtle te≈øtifieth, or the ≈øecond as a Prote≈øtant Bishop rather ≈øuppo≈øeth, I doe not heare contend, for this ≈øecond al≈øo was a glorious Saint as Gaufride Abbot of Burton in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory writeth, ‚Ä¢ ≈øent by Pope Leo into Ireland, the tenth in number from the fir≈øt S. Patrike.
we haue or had al≈øo Nenius in his Hi≈øtory in the Brittish tongue te≈øtifing the ≈øame, except Ihon Harding doth deceaue vs. We haue the Epi≈øtle of that S. Patrike; which lyued long and died at Gla≈øtenburye, where S. Io≈øeph al≈øo lyued and died, and was buryed, to the ≈øame purpo≈øe. We haue Melkinus who wrote aboue a thow≈øand yeares ≈øince, witne≈ø≈øing the ≈øame, and that he was buried vnder a marble ≈øtone at Gla≈øtenbury. In Aualonia Io≈øeph ab Aramathia dictus ≈øomnum ≈øub marmore caepit diuturnum. And except two Prote≈øtant Bishops, Parker and Godwyne, and as they ≈øay Ioannes Anglicus long ≈øince deceaue vs, S. Augu≈øtine our Apo≈øtle in an Epi≈øtle which he wrote to S. Gregory giueth like te≈øtimony. Ihon Foxe, the Theater writers, Dauid Powell, with ≈øume others alledge the ≈øame from Gildas in his booke of the victory of Aurelus Ambro≈øius. There is, as a Prote≈øtant Bishop writeth, and Ihon Capgraue citeth the ≈øame Hi≈øtory, an auncient In≈øcription in Bra≈ø≈øe formerly fixed vpon a piller in S. Io≈øephs Chappell at Gla≈øtenbury, and now, or lately in the cu≈øtody of M. Thomas Hewes E≈øquier in Wells, but three miles di≈øtant thence, expre≈ø≈øely prouing, that S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, with eleuen other holy men, he being the cheife≈øt, came hither in the thirtith yeare after the Pa≈øsioÃÑ of Chri≈øt: Anno po≈øt pa≈øsionem domini 30. duodecim ≈øancti, ex quibus Io≈øeph ab Aramathia primus erat, huc venerunt. And it is contained in the ≈øame Antiquit ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ that Saint Dauid in his time offered a Saphire of ine≈øtimable value vpon the Altar there: cuius altare inae≈øtimabili Sapphiro in≈øigniuit; And ≈øet a piller for a during marke, betweene the Chappell which S. Io≈øeph had builded, and other later additions vnto it, perpetually to knowe it by: with the perfect bredth, and length thereof.
4. We haue the auncient Poet to a≈ø≈øuer vs that S. Io≈øeph was the principall of the twelue holy men coming to Aualonia.

q.l: Intrat Aualoniam duodena caterua virorum,
Flos Aramathiae Io≈øeph e≈øt primus eorum.

div.p:
We haue forreyne te≈øtimonies hereof, both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants, the Manu≈øcript hi≈øtory in the Vaticane Library at Rome, cited by Baronius, our Theater writers, and others: Philip Pantaleon a German Prote≈øtant telling vs that Io≈øeph of Aramathia with his fellowes preached the Gho≈øpell in Britayne: Io≈øephus de Aramathia in Britannia cum ≈øocijs ≈øuis Euangelium praedicauit. So for France hath Andrew Che≈øne in his French Hi≈øtory of England, Scotland and Irelend with others, at home we haue a generall con≈øent of Hi≈øtorians, Catholiks, or Prote≈øtants, in this matter, namely among Prote≈øtants, their Prote≈øtant Bishops Parker their Archbishop, Bale, Godwine and Montague, of others Camden, Stowe, Howes, Powell, Selden, Drayton, and others. Among the≈øe, Doctour Montague Prote≈øtant Bishop of Welles with in three miles of the place where S. Io≈øeph dyed, and was buryed, and ≈øo taking the be≈øt knowledge thereof he could, to pre≈øent a Queene withall in his Panegiricall entertainement of the late Queene Anne producing foure par≈øons to repre≈øent S. Peter, S. Paul, S. Andrew Apo≈øtles and S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, bringeth forth the Repre≈øentor of S. Io≈øeph thus to ≈øpeake vnto her. I am the Herald of the≈øe Saincts Peter, Paul, and Andrew, ≈øent hyther by them full fifteene hundred and fortie yeares agoe, to bring the waters of life into this I≈øle of Britayne. In this I≈øle I made choi≈øe of an I≈øle, the I≈øland of Aualon, neare adioyning to this place, where after I had planted and watered, and God had giuen an happy encrea≈øe, I re≈øted from my labours, and my body lay buried in a graue of honour, hoping verely that ≈øince I had that honour, to intombe that ble≈ø≈øed body, no body would haue
done them≈øelues that dishonour, as to haue violated my ≈øepulchre. But God wot, ruinated it is, and with it the goodlye≈øt Mona≈øtery that euer eye in any I≈øland did behold. And after confirmeth his narration with the≈øe miraculous Arguments, pre≈øenting two boughes vnto her: Saint Peter open the gates with your keyes. Saint Paul defend with your ≈øword. Saint Andrew ble≈ø≈øe with your Cro≈ø≈øe. All of you pray the God of heauen to giue her Maiestie long life, happy health; glorious dayes, ble≈ø≈øed po≈øteritie, and all pro≈øperitie. As for mee that haue bene ≈øpoyled of all, I haue nothing left mee, but the≈øe boughes; the one a Branch of that Thorne, that in memory of my ble≈ø≈øed Mai≈øter euer buddeth one the day that he was borne. The other in memory of his Martyrs, which one the longe≈øt day begins to liue, one which they began to dye.

div.head: THE XXIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: EXAMINING WHO SENT S. IOSEPH HITHER, and euidently prouing that he was not ≈øent into Britayne by S. Philip the Apo≈øtle from our neighbouring Gallia or France: confuting all pretended arguments, and authorities to that purpo≈øe.

div.p:
1. BEING thus perfectly in≈øtructed in the truth of S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia and his A≈ø≈øociats being heare: It followeth next in Order, to be truely informed, from whome, whence, and when he came hither. The opinion of many Prote≈øtants is, that he was ≈øent hither out of this Gallia, or France next adiacent vnto vs by Saint Philip the Apo≈øtle, then preaching there. But as I haue not allowed this ≈øentence before, ≈øo I mu≈øt now vtterly di≈øable it to be receaued for true. Which cannot better be performed then by fir≈øt examining and improuing the rea≈øons one which it is grounded, and then ≈øet downe what is mo≈øt probable to be followed in this Que≈øtion. Some Prote≈øtants, as Foxe, Dauid Powell, Sir Francis Ha≈øtings, and the Theater writers would Foxe to. 1. Dauid Powell annot. in hi≈øt. Cambr. p. 12 13. FraÃÑ. Ha≈øtings &c. haue their Readers beleeue, that S. Gildas held this opinion that S. Io≈øeph was ≈øent to the Britans out of this next Gallia by S. Philip the Apo≈øtle. But when we come to finde this te≈øtimony in Gildas, we can finde no ≈øuch Gildas to proue it by: for the true Hi≈øtory of Gildas which is de Excidio & Conque≈øtu Britanniae, from which diuers of the≈øe men alledge it, hath no ≈øuch thing eyther Gildas pretended by ≈øome to ≈øay, that S. Io≈øeph was ≈øent out of France into Britaine by S. Philip the Apo≈øtle, hath no ≈øuch thing. in the printed booke published by the Prote≈øtants or Polidor Virgil, neyther in any Manu≈øcript copy which I can finde, or is cited for this matter. Ma≈øter Foxe writeth thus: Gildas in his History affirmeth plainely that Britany receaued the Gho≈øpell in the time of Tiberius the Emperour: and that Io≈øeph of Aramathia was ≈øent by Philip the Apo≈øtle from France to Britayne. Gild. lib. de victoria Aurel. Ambro≈øij. Ma≈øter Ha≈øtings followeth Foxe as his Ma≈øter word by worde, onely he citing Gildas doth not alledge that booke. And that Foxe Act. and Monum. to. 1. p. 96. which they cite from Gildas of Britayne receauing the faith in the time of Tiberius, ouerthroweth the credit of this allegation, for they cite both that and Saint Io≈øephs ≈øending hither out of France by S. Philip the Apo≈øtle from one and the ≈øame Gildas, and place, in him. And yet that Relation of
Britayne receauing the faith in the dayes of Tiberius, is in Gildas de Excidio Britanniae, and onely in that and no other auncient Authour, any Gildas or other for any thing I can finde in Antiquitie, or iu≈øtified or iu≈øtifiable by any later writer. For be≈øides the true acknowledged Gildas, of whome I haue ≈øpoken before, called the wi≈øe: cognomento ≈øapiens, we finde but two others mentioned in our Hi≈øtories, one of them liued at Rome and dyed as a Prote≈øtant Bishop te≈øtifieth in the yeare of Chri≈øts Incarnation 74. vitae compleuit cur≈øum anno ab incarnato Dei verbo 74. And for any thing we reade was no Chri≈øtian, neyther wrote any ≈øuch thing, and dying diuers hundreds of yeares before Ioh. Bel. l. de Script. cent. 1. in Gilda Cambrio f. 15. Aurelius Ambro≈øius was borne, could by no po≈ø≈øibilitie be Authour of the booke intituled, de victoria Aurelij Ambro≈øij: of the victory of Aurelius Ambro≈øius, from which this pretended te≈øtimony is alledged. The other Gildas commonly named Albanius could not be Authour of this pretended Antiquity of S. Philips ≈øending S. Io≈øeph to this Nation: for though I acknowledge, with the Brittish Hi≈øtory, Ponticus Virunnius, Bale, Pits, and others that this Gildas wrote a booke of that Title, and ≈øubiect, yet it could not be this which is here produced: for as both the Brittish Hi≈øtory and Virunnius witne≈ø≈øe, the names and Acts of the Roman Legats Damianus and Phugatianus with there A≈ø≈øociates Galfrid. Monu. hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 4. cap. vlt. Ponticus Virunn. Brit. hi≈øt. l. 4. in fine. were ≈øet downe by Gildas in that booke: eorum nomina & actus iÃÑn libro reperiuntur, quem Gildas de victoria Aurelij Ambro≈øij in≈øcrip≈øit. And yet the≈øe being ≈øo memorable things for our Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hi≈øtory, not any one of the≈øe Prote≈øtants which cite the pretended Gildas before, though all of them writing of purpo≈øe of ≈øuch matters, doth make the lea≈øt memory of them, which they would not haue ≈øo gro≈ø≈øely omitted, if they had ≈øeene the true Gildas which was written in that time.

2. Againe Doctour Powell a Prote≈øtant, Citer of this new found Gildas, Saith from thence, that Io≈øeph of Aramathia came into this Iland about the yeare of Chri≈øt 53. Which differeth ten yeares from the receaued Hi≈øtoryes of the time of his coming hither: and it is as much at variance with it≈øelfe, as it is cited by other Prote≈øtants, for Ihon Foxe ≈øayth: ≈øome other alleadge out of Gildas Foxe l. 1. de victoria Aurelij Ambro≈øij, that Io≈øeph of Aramathia was ≈øent by Philip the Apo≈øtle from France to Britayne about the yeare of our Lord 63. Where we ≈øee euident contradiction in the pretended Authour, and citers of him. And in an other place this Prote≈øtant quite di≈øcrediteth this citation, te≈øtifying that it was one and the ≈øame Gildas, which wrote of Britayne receauing the faith in the Foxe l. 2. p. 106. time of Tiberius, which was Gildas Sapiens, and that wrote of S. Io≈øeph ≈øent into Britayne out of France by S. Philip, which as before, he neuer mentioneth. An other Prote≈øtant more di≈øableth this citatioÃÑ making the difference of the time greater in this manner: George Maior writeth in a preface that immediately Stow hi≈øt. in Agricola. after Cri≈øts Re≈øurrection, vnder Claudius the Emperour the light of the Gho≈øpell was kindled in Britayne by Io≈øeph of Aramathia, that buryed the body of Chri≈øt. Polidor Virgil whome ≈øome Pote≈øtants, though vntruely, cite for S. Philips Bal. cent. 1. l. de Scriptor. f. 14. in Io≈øeph Arimath. Polydor. Virgil. l. 2. hi≈øt. Angl. p. 37. Polydor. Virgil. ≈øupr. l. 1. p. 16. ≈øending S. Io≈øeph hither, out of France hath no ≈øuch thing, but maketh the meanes of his coming hither doubtfull, whether by chaunce or of purpo≈øe; ≈øiue ca≈ø ‚Ä¢ , ≈øiue con≈øilio in Britanniam venit, and named the deui≈øer of this Gildas, the moste impudent knaue, that euer liued: Sane is nebulo long√® po≈øt homines natos impudenti≈øsimus. Wherevpon the be≈øt Prote≈øtant Antiquaries, Bale, Camden, Parker, Stowe, Godwine, and others quite for≈øake that pretended authority neuer vouch≈øafing to alledge it, and the citers of it, by the contradictions there, haue ≈øufficiently reproued it, diuers of them rather inclining to thinke, as I shall
entreate hereafter; that S. Philip the Apo≈øtle was neuer in this next France, to ≈øend S. Io≈øeph from thence into Britayne. And no man of any indifferent Iudgment will thinke, but if the true Gildas had written any ≈øuch thing, the mo≈øt diligent Collectours of the Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury; who gathered ≈øo many and of farre meanner credit, and Antiquitie, then the true Gildas was, would for the honour of that hou≈øe, in one place or other haue remembred it, which none of them, nor any other, old or new credible writer hath done.

3. Therefore ≈øeeing their hope from Gildas hath thus fayled theÃÑ, let vs con≈øider, what other Authoritie they finde to relye vpon. A Prote≈øtant Bishop writeth thus of S. Io≈øeph: Hunc Philippus Apostolus cum non paruo comitatu a Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. in Io≈øeph Aram. f. 14. Gallijs in Britanniam mi≈øit, no≈øtrae ≈øalutis anno 63. vt po≈øt Capgrauium & Scropum alio≈øque Scriptores Anglicos, te≈øtis e≈øt locuples Polydorus Virgilius Anglicae Hi≈øtoriae libro ≈øecundo: Philip the Apo≈øtle ≈øent Io≈øeph with no ≈ømall company, out of France into Britayne, in the yeare of Chri≈øt 63. as after Capgraue and Scroope and other English writers, Polydor Virgil is a ≈øufficient witnes in the ≈øecond booke of his English history. Where we ≈øee onely three particularly named. Capgraue the cheife≈øt, whome Scroope ≈øeemeth to followe and Polydor Virgil. This la≈øte as I Polyd. Vir. hi≈øt. l. 2. p. 37. 41. 89. haue cited before hath no ≈øuch thing in any place, where he ≈øpeaketh of S. Io≈øeph, neuer ≈øo much as naming S. Philip the Apo≈øtle in this matter. Capgraue reciteth ≈øuch an opinion in the life of S. Io≈øeph out of Freculphus, who, as hereafter, hath no ≈øuch thing at all, and in the life of S. Patrike written after that of S. Io≈øeph maketh the like narration of ≈øome, which thinke that S. Io. Capgrau. in Catal. in S. Io≈øeph & in S. Patricio. Io. Bal. de Script. cent. 5. f. 201. 202. in Io. Capgrau. Godwin. Conu. Philip ≈øent S. Io≈øeph hither, but he brandeth it, with this blemish: ≈øi Veritatem ≈øapiat, lectoris arbitrio relinquo. Which whether it ta≈øteth of truth, I leeue to the Iudgment of the Reader. Which is farre from approuing it for a true Hi≈øtory: AnÃÑd by our Prote≈øtant Bishops, who though they acknowledge Capgraue for a very learned Authour, make him credulous enough in ≈øuch things, it vtterly di≈øcrediteth that report: for when he had written all, which he thought credible of the matter, he then handled, he immediately addeth: Quae inferi√πs dige≈øta ≈øunt, ≈øi veritatem ≈øapiant, lectoris arbitrio relinquo. The things which followe I leaue to the Reader to Iudge of their ta≈øte of truth. And among the≈øe, the fir≈øt and cheife≈øt of all is this, of S. Philip the Apo≈øtle his coming into France, and from thence ≈øending S. Io≈øeph hither into Britayne. So that we euidently ≈øee, all authorities ‚Ä¢ itherto alledged by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, are rather again≈øt, then for, them in this bu≈øines.

4. Their la≈øte and principall whereupon they now relye herein, is a pretended te≈øtimony of Freculphus the auncient learned Bishop of Lexouium. The fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Arch bishop of Canterbury citing for his onely Authour Freculphus l. 2. cap. 4. ≈øaith: Philippus Apo≈øtolus qui in Galliam venit, & Euangelij Matth. Parker Antiq. Brit. p. 3. praedicatione plures ad fidem vertit, cum de Britannia modico freto ≈øeparata In≈øula accepi≈ø≈øet, a qua Druidum ≈øuperstitio manabat in Galliam, delegit ex ≈øuorum ≈øociorum numero duodecim; quibus Io≈øephum Aramathien≈øem, qui dominum Chri≈øtuÃÑ ≈øepulchro condidit, praefecit: Philip the Apo≈øtle which came into France, or Gallia, and by preaching the Gho≈øpell conuerted many to the faith, when he vnder≈øtood of Britaine, an Iland ≈øeperated from thence by a narrow ≈øea, from which the ≈øuper≈øtition of the Druids did flowe into France, he did chu≈øe twelue out of the number of his fellowes, among whome he ordained for Ruler, Io≈øeph of Aramathia that buried Chri≈øt. Another writeth in this maÃÑner: William of Malmesbury in his booke of the Antiquities Stowe Hi≈øtory Romans p. 37. of Glastenbury alledgeth Freculphus, to write in his ≈øecond booke, and fourth
Chapter as followeth: Philip the Apo≈øtle preaching the word of God in Gaule, now called France, cho≈øe out twelue amongst his Di≈øciples, whome he ≈øent into Britaine, to preach the word of life, and vpon euery one of them, he mo≈øt deuoutely ≈øtretched out his right hand, ouer the≈øe he appointed for cheife his deare freind Io≈øeph of Aramathia, that buried our Lord. An other Prote≈øtant Bishop plainely ≈øaith: the occa≈øion Godwin Conu. of Brit. p. 9. c. 2. Chronicil. c. 4. of Io≈øephs coming hither, Freculphus Bishop of Lexouia that florished an. 840. reporteth to be this. That when Philip the Apo≈øtle, or as ≈øome thinke rather the Euangeli≈øt, for their Actions are much confounded in Hi≈øtoryes, preaching Chri≈øt in France, had much to Doe with the Druydes, who had their beginning, and cheife Doctors in Britaine: and vnderstanding that this our Iland was ≈øeperated from France by a ≈ømall cut of a few howers ≈øaile, he thought good to ≈øend ouer hither 12. Preachers the cheife where of was Io≈øeph afore≈øaid. Thus perhaps other Prote≈øtants doe write, and might be cited in the ≈øame ≈øence, but the≈øe be too many, except their allegations were more free from falshood; for fir≈øt allthough William of Malmesbury in his Manu≈øcript of the Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury ≈øeemeth to alledge Freculphus, for S. Philips ≈øending S. Io≈øeph hither out of France, or Gallia; yet of the re≈øt, which the≈øe Prote≈øtants father vpon him, about the Druides and all other circum≈øtances ≈øet downe before, he writeth not one worde, neuer mentioning any ≈øuch thing at all, his words be the≈øe: Freculphus te≈øtatur libro 2. cap. 4. quod Philippus praedicans Euangelium in Gallia, duodecim Guliel. Malm. l. de antiq. Gla≈øt. M. S. ex ≈øuis Di≈øcipulis elegit, quos mi≈øit in Britanniam ad praedicandum verbum vitae, & ≈øuper ≈øingulos manum dexteram deuoti≈øsim√® extendit, hi autem praefecit amicum ≈øuum Io≈øeph ab Aramathia, qui dominum ≈øepeliuit. Venerunt his in Britanniam anno Dominicae Incarnationis 65. & A≈ø≈øumptionis beatae Mariae 15: Freculphus in his ≈øecoÃÑd booke and fourth Chapter doth witnes, that Philip preaching the Ghospell in Gaule, did chu≈øe twelue of his Di≈øciples, which he ≈øent into Britaine to preach the word of life, and vpon euery of them did most deuoutely ≈øtretch forth his right hand, and appointed his freind Io≈øeph of Aramathia to be cheife of theÃÑ. The≈øe came into Britaine, in the yeare of our Lords Incarnation 65. and of the A≈ø≈øumption of ble≈ø≈øed Mary the 15. where we finde no mention at all of tho≈øe pretended motiues concerning the Druids, and other circum≈øtances related before by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, and vntruely fathered vpon the≈øe Authours, but truely, though illegittimate, and Ba≈øtards, onely begotten and brought forth by the fal≈øe pens of the≈øe Prote≈øtant Relators. And the time of S. Io≈øephs coming hither to differ al≈øo ≈øo much by the≈øe alledged Authorities, from that which ≈øome of them cite from their concealed Gildas, as I haue before related. And the very ≈øub≈øtance of the narration it≈øelfe of S. Philips ≈øending S. Io≈øeph hither out of France grounded vpon the Authoritie of Freculphus, very ≈øu≈øpitious, that the true originall Manu≈øcript of Gulielmus Malmes burien≈øis (though ≈øome Tran≈øcripts which I haue ≈øeene doe) warranteth no ≈øuch thing. For this William Monke of Malmesbury him≈øelf in his ≈øecond booke, De ge≈øtis Ponfiticum Anglorum, which was written after his booke of the Antiquitie of Gla≈øtenbury, doth take plaine exception to the Hi≈øtory of S. Patrike his buriall there, whereon this narration is grounded, ≈øaying: Iacet ibi Patricius, ≈øi eredere dignum, Natione Britto ‚Ä¢ eati Germani Anti≈øiodoren≈øis Di≈øcipulus, quem a Papa Caele≈øtino ordinatum Epi≈øcopum Hybernien≈øibus mi≈øit Apo≈øtolum. So doe two English Prote≈øtant Bishops, God ‚Ä¢ in ≈øupr. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. in Patric. Gaufrid. Abb. B ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ton. in vit. S. Moduenae M. S. one cited before, thinking this was a ≈øecond Patrike, which the Abbot of Burton ≈øaith, Pope Leo ≈øent into Ireland, and was al≈øo a Saint. And the ≈øame William of Malmesbury doth in the ≈øame Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory of Gla≈øtenbury ≈øoone after the fir≈øt pretended citation from him, ≈øet downe
the Authoritie of Freculphus, onely to proue that S. Philip preached in Gallia, his words be the≈øe: Freculphus Hi≈øtoriae libro 2. cap. 4. te≈øtatur Philippum Gulielm. Malm. l. de Antiq. Gla≈øton. M. S. Paulo po≈øt initium. Apo≈øtolum Gullis verbum dei praedica≈ø≈øe: Freculphus in the ≈øeconde booke and fourth Chapter of his Hi≈øtory, doth witnes that Philip the Apo≈øtle did preach the word of God to the Gaules. Neuer writing one word, that Freculphus affirmed S. Philip to haue ≈øent S. Io≈øeph from thence into Britaine. Which Freculphus doth not teach in that, or any other place: his words in the place alledged be onely Freculphus Epi≈øcopus LexouieÃÑ. Chron. to. 2. l. 2. c. 4. p. 448. the≈øe: Philippus a Beth≈øaida, ciuitate hic Gallis praedicat Chri≈øtum; Barbara≈øque gentes, vicina≈øque tenebris, & tumenti Oceano coniunctas, ad ≈øcientiae lumen, fideique portum perducit. Deinde in Hierapoli phrygiae Prouinciae vrbe crucifixus, lapidatu≈øque obijt, rectoque ≈øepultus Cadauere ibidem requie≈øcit: Philip of the citye Beth≈øaida, preacheth Chri≈øt to the Gaules, and brought Brabarous Nations, and neare to Darkenes, and Ioyned to the ≈øwelling Ocean, to the light of knowledge, and the hauen of faith. And afterward crucified, and ≈øtoned, died in Hierapolis, a citic of the Prouince of Phrygia, and there re≈øteth his body being buried vpright. Which be the Author. l. d. vit. & mort. Sanct. inter opera S. I≈øid. in S. Philipp. Apo≈øtol. words al≈øo of the Authour of the booke, of the life and death of Saints: de vita & morte Sanctorum, among the works of S. I≈øidor. And Freculphus hath not any word of S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia at all, neither ≈øpeaketh more of S. Philip, but a little after ≈øetting downe breifely, as likewi≈øe the ≈øayed Authour of the life and death of Saints doth, where euery Apo≈øtle preached, he ≈øaith of S. Philip, Gallias accepit; he tooke the Countries Gallia. Which, as I will demon≈øtrate Freculph. ≈øupr. l. 2. p. 45 1. in the next Chapter, were not ment of this Gallia or France, next vnto vs, whether S. Philip the Apo≈øtle neuer came.

5. And to refute the gro≈ø≈øe error, and ignorance of them that cite S. I≈øidor or other Authour of the booke of the life and death of Saints, for S. Philips ≈øending S. Io≈øeph out of France into Britaine, be≈øides the negatiue te≈øtimonie Io. Bal. l. de Scritorib. cent. 1. in S. Io≈øeph. Aramat. Franc. Godwin Conu. of Britaine p. 11. of both tho≈øe Authours, which haue no ≈øuch thing at all, the Prote≈øtant Bishop Ihon Bale and others ≈øo much acknowledge, among whome Francis Godwin the Prote≈øtant Bishop mu≈øt needes be one, who bringeth the auncient Antiquitie of Gla≈øtenbury engraued in bra≈ø≈øe, which ≈øaith he had ≈øeene, and alledgeth it, word by word, for the coming of S. Io≈øeph and his companions hither, with the time, and other circum≈øtances, and yet hath not one word, that they were ≈øent hither by S. Philip out of France, or that he was at any time in this Gallia: The ≈øame I affirme of all FreÃÑch writers, both late & auncient, not any one among ≈øo many, which to my reading, and memory teacheth, that either S. Philip the Apo≈øtle ≈øent S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia into Britaine out of France, or that he him≈øelf euer preached there, or ≈øent any preachers thither; which will more manife≈øtly be proued in the next Chapter ‚Ä¢ ollowing: But the Gallia where S. Philip the Apo≈øtle is by ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øed to haue preached, is farre di≈øtant from this our neighbouring Gallia, or France. And ≈øo the ≈øimilitude or IdeÃÑtitie of one and the ≈øame name, for diuers Countries, gaue acca≈øion of Error vnto ≈øome few ≈øuch, as reading that S. Philip the Apo≈øtle was in a Country called Gallia, and S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia liued and died heare in Britaine, to make this fal≈øe, and Ignorant collection: That S. Io≈øeph was ≈øent hither by S. Philip out of this next Gallia, where he neuer Acta per Legat. Antiquit. Gla≈øt. Manu≈øcr. Tabul. Fix. was. And it is euident by our old Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury, that S. Philip neyther did, nor could ≈øend S. Io≈øeph or any hither from our next France, which had not that name vntill ≈øome hundreds of yeares after, when the Frankes of Sicambria came fir≈øt into ≈øome parts of that kingdome, thus it te≈øtifieth from the old Acts of the fir≈øt Chri≈øtians at Gla≈øteÃÑbury in S. Io≈øephs time:
In antiquis ≈øcriptis inuenerunt, qualiter ≈øanctis Apo≈øtolis per vniuer≈øum orbem di≈øper≈øis Sanctus Philippus Apo≈øtolus cum multitudine Di≈øcipulorum in Franciam veniens, duodecim ex ip≈øis in Britanniam mi≈øit ad praedicandum: S. Damianus and Phaganus ≈øent hyther by Pope Eleutherius did finde in an old writing, how when the Apo≈øtles were di≈øper≈øed into all the world, S. Philip the Apo≈øtle with a multitude of Di≈øciples coming into Francia, ≈øent twelue of them into Britayne to preach. This Manu≈øcript Antiquitie fir≈øt written in S. Io≈øephs time, and after founde in the dayes of King Lucius long before any Frankes gaue name vnto our next France, or came thither, giueth demon≈øtrance that S. Philip was among the Frankes of Sicambria, which many others al≈øo te≈øtifie, and if he ≈øent S. Io≈øeph hither out of Francia, it was that and no other Francia, from whence he ≈øent him. The Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury from the te≈øtimony of an auncient Monke of S. Denis in France, to one Godfridus a Monke of Gla≈øtenbury relateth that the Church of Gla≈øtenbury was con≈øecrated by the highe≈øt greate Bishop, meaning as it ≈øeemeth S. Peter the Apo≈øtle, the highe≈øt greate Bishop in that time, and that it was called the ≈øecond Rome, for the multitude of Epi≈øt. Godefrid. Monachi Gla≈øt. Antiquitates Gla≈øton. Manu≈ø. tab. Affix. Saints buried there, of the which S. Io≈øeph was the fir≈øt. Haec glorio≈øi≈øsimi Martyris Dioni≈øij Eccle≈øia, & illa (Gla≈øtonien≈øis) de qua te a≈ø≈øeris, eandem priuilegij dignitatem habent. I≈øta in Gallia, illa in Britannia vno eodem tempore exortae, √† ≈øummo & magno Pontifice con≈øecratae: Vno tamen gradu illa ≈øupereminet. Roma etenim ≈øecunda vocatur, & hoc propter multitudinem Sanctorum inibi requie≈øcentium, quorum primus fuit Io≈øeph ab Aramathia, ille nobilis Decurio qui & Dominum ≈øepeliuit, pro cuius ≈øepultura Dominus locum illum elegit, atque benedixit.

div.head: THE XXIV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: FVRTHER PROVING THAT S. PHILIP the Apo≈øtle was not in that Gallia France next to Britayne: neyther were S. Io≈øeph and his A≈ø≈øociates there, or came from thence into Britayne.

div.p:
1. BESIDES the recited Authorities of S. I≈øidor, or the Authour of the booke of the life and death of Saints among his workes and the learned Bishop Freculpbus, of which I haue ≈øpoken before, for their opinion that held S. Philip the Apo≈øtle preached Ordo officij Muzarabici in fe≈øto S. Iacobi Apo≈øtoli fratris S. Ioann ‚Ä¢ s Apo≈øtoli & Euangeli≈øtae in hymno. in the next France or Gallia, I finde the like mention, in the auncient Muzaraban publike Church office, receaued in the fourth Toletan Councell, at wbich S. I≈øidor Archbishop of Hi≈øpalis for all Spaine was Pre≈øident. In this Councell mention being made, where the Apo≈øtles preached, it is ≈øaid: Philippus Gallias: That S. Philip preached in the Countries called Galliae. Which although I doe not finde alledged by any Prote≈øtant to confirme this opinion of S. Philips being in this next France, yet becau≈øe I ≈øeeke the truth, and am vnwilling to conceale any thing that may either help, or hinder the finding fourth thereof, I heare produce it, and the rather becau≈øe it giueth more countenance to that booke, de vita & morte Sanctorum, to haue bene written by S. I≈øidor, Pre≈øident in that Councell, and taking (as it ≈øeemeth)
that Muzaraban Office, as warrant for his writing, that S. Philip the Apo≈øtle was in Gallia; as al≈øo Freculphus followed the ≈øteps of S. I≈øidor in the ≈øame A≈ø≈øertion; for better deciding whereof, becau≈øe the Muzaraban Office is ≈øo breife as I haue related in this matter, and I haue ≈øet downe the words of Freculphus before, I will and what S. I≈øidor, or other Authour of that booke, hath written of this bu≈øines, which is as followeth: Philippus √† Beth≈øaida ciuitate, I≈øidor. Hi≈øpal. Epi≈øcopus l. de vita & morte Sanctorum cap. 75. vnde & Petrus, Gallis praedicat Chri≈øtum, Barbara≈øque gentes vicina≈øque tenebris, & tumenti Oceano coniunctas ad ≈øcientiae lumen, fideique portum deducit. Deinde in Hierapoli Phrygiae Prouinciae Vrbe crucifixus lapidatu≈øque obijt: Philip of the citie Beth≈øaida, from whence al≈øo Peter was, preacheth Chri≈øt to the Gaules, and bringeth Barbarous Nations, and neare to darknes, and ioyned to the ≈øwelling Ocean, to the light of knowledge, and tbe heauen of faith, and after dyed, crucifixed, and ≈øtoned in Hierapolis, a citie of the Prouince of Phrygia. The very words of Freculphus before; ≈øo that it is euident the one of the≈øe receaued them from the other: and after the≈øe Hartmanus Schedel v≈øeth the ≈øame phra≈øe: Philippus Hartm. Sched. Chronic. chron. f. 202. p. 1. Gallias accepit: that S. Philip had the Countryes Galliae. Yet neither he, nor any of the others, make him the Apo≈øtle of this next Gallia, or France, neyther doe any of the Hi≈øtorians of France, or Antiquities thereof be≈øt to be credited in ≈øuch cau≈øes, make mention of S. Philip, or any other Apo≈øtle be≈øides S. Peter and S. Paule, to haue preached in that kingdome, neyther any others, but ≈øuch as were Di≈øciples vnto them, and not to S. Philip, or any other of the Apo≈øtles to haue taught the faith of Chri≈øt in that Nation.

2. Neyther doth any of our French Hi≈øtorians once alledge, or interpret M. Pniel. I Tigeon. M. Clem. Merch. M. I. le Frere de Leual in hi≈øt. Andre Che≈øne hi≈øt. general d'Angleterre, d'E≈øco≈ø≈øe, & d'Irland. pag. 152. Bed. Martyrol. cal. Maij. Martyr. Rom. 1. die Maij. V≈øuard. Martyrol. cod. die. Dorotheus in Synop≈øi in S. Phil. Magdeb. cent. 1. in S. Philip. Apo≈øt. Prot. comm. Booke in F. S. Philippi & Calend. 1. Maij. eyther S. I≈øidor, or Freculphus, to vnder≈øtand this next France, by any Gallia or place where they write, S. Philip preached. But expound them both, as they onely ment, he preached in Scythia and CouÃÑtries farre remote from this France. And ≈øo they expounde Freculphus him≈øelfe in the place alledged. Vincentius, Abdias, Nicephorus, Sabellicus, Eu≈øebius, Simeon Metaphra≈øtes, Clement of Alexandria, and Policrates are of that minde. So likewi≈øe teacheth S. Bede, the Roman Martyrologe, V≈øuardus, Dorotheus, the Magdeburgian Prote≈øtants, and the Prote≈øtants of England in their mo≈øt authori≈øed publike Church ≈øeruice booke, Calenders and others. And this is ≈øufficiently te≈øtified and expre≈ø≈øed in the words of S. I≈øidor, and Freculphus before, both of them plainely auouching, that the Gaules and people to whome S. Philip preached, were: Barbarae gentes, vicinae tenebris & tumenti Oceano coniunctae: Barbarous Nations, neare Inhabitants vnto Countries of darkenes, and conioyned to the ≈øwelling Ocean: which haue no re≈øemblance at all, to this our Gallia, but quite contrary, or different. For this Gallia is farre remote from either of the Poles Artike, or Antartike, and ≈øo by many degrees remoued from all Nations liuing in darknes. Neither is the ≈øea which is next to this Gallia, tumens Oceanus, that Ocean which is termed the ≈øwelling, but Oceanus Scythicus, the Ocean of Scythia, where S. Philip by all Antiquities preached. Neither was this Gallia at that time, or any other, euer e≈øteemed a Barbarous Nation by any credible writer, late or auncient, Chri≈øtian or Pagan, Catholike, Prote≈øtant, or other, but as a Prote≈øtant Co≈ømographer with others te≈øtifieth: Fuit Gallia ab antiquis temporibus, ≈øemper culta tam in vrbibus, Seba≈øtian. MuÃÑ≈øt. Co≈ømograph. l. 2 cap. 38. quam in oppidis, quam in agris, hortis, & pratis. Et vt strabo ≈øcribit, qui tempore Incarnationis Chri≈øti vixit, nullus tunc fuit angulus in Gallia incultus, praeter lacus & nemora quae culturam non admittunt: Gallia was euer from auncient times repleni ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d as well with cities, as with Townes, as with Feilds, Orchards, and Medowes, and
as Strabo writeth, who liued in the time of the Incarnation of Chri≈øt, there was no corner in Gallia vninhabited, except lakes and woods, which admit not habitation. And not onely Ioannes Annius out of Xenophon, S. Iu≈øtine and other auncients, Ioan. Annius Comm. in Bero≈ø. in orat. Iu≈øtin. p. 52. Bal. l. de Scriptor. cent. 1. in Samothe. Io. SeldeÃÑ Anaclet. l. 1. cap. 1. Nichol. Vigine ‚Ä¢ Biblioth. Hi≈øtorial. an. mundi 1900. 2200. &c. Io. Ioliuett ‚Ä¢ s in de≈øcript. Gall. apud Abr. Ortel. 1. 9. but our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries Bale, Selden, Nicholas Vignier, Ihon Ioliuet and other French Hi≈øtorians a≈ø≈øuer vs, that the≈øe Gaules had learning and letters before the Graecians, and that from this Gallia v≈øing the Greeke characters, they were brought into Greece. And that the Romans them≈øelues did v≈øe to ≈øend their youth, and children into Gallia e≈øpecially Ma≈ø≈øilia, to be in≈øtructed in learning, and ciuilitie. Therefore this cannot be any of tho≈øe Barbarous Countries, related by tho≈øe Authours where S. Philip preached. But by tho≈øe de≈øcriptions they might with more rea≈øon thinke S. Philip was in this our Britaine, by ≈øome taken for a part of Gallia, or an other continent, and much more likely in tho≈øe times to be a Barbarous Nation, as it was nearer the Regions of Darknes, by the Northpole, and the ≈øwelling Ocean: Yet no Authour affirmeth he was heare, and from hence hither (being a contradiction) he could not ≈øend S. Io≈øeph.

3. Moreouer if S. I≈øidor, and the others cited before, for S. Philip his preaching in Gallia, had thereby ment this Gallia, adiacent to Britaine, they could not bring him eyther by Land, or Sea, into tho≈øe Barbarous Nations, where they affirme, he long time liued, or Hierapolis in Phrigia, where he was put to death, but he mu≈øt needs haue pa≈ø≈øed through, and preached in diuers other great interiacent Nations betwene them, and yet they name not one, for S. I≈øidor him≈øelfe confineth this Gallia with the≈øe bounds: Iuga Alpium: the tops of the Alpes one the East ≈øide, with the Ocean Sea one the we≈øt, the Pyrenaean I≈øidor. l. 14. Origin. v. Gallia. MouÃÑtaynes one the South, & the Ryuer of Rhene and Germany. Where by S. I≈øidor his owne accompt and de≈øcription of this Gallia, there be aboue a thow≈øand miles betwene the Countries, where, he with all others, ≈øaith S. Philip liued, and died, and the neare≈øt part of this Gallia vnto any of them by all Co≈ømographers. In what Gallia, S. Philip the Apo≈øtle preached. Neyther shall we by this meanes exclude S. Philip from preaching to Gaules in Gallia or Gallatia, nor contradict the opinion of S. I≈øidor, and Freculphus, but shewe what Gallia it was, they truely did and mu≈øt needs vnder≈øtand, the very ≈øame Nation farre from this Gallia, where all writers agree he preached in the parts of Scythia, and this by S. I≈øidor his owne interpretation; for he plainely writeth of that Gallia or Gallatia where S. Philip by all Antiquities I≈øid. l. 14. Origin. did liue, was named of the auncient people of the Gaules, by whome it was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. Dicta √† pri≈ø ‚Ä¢ is Gallorum gentibus, √† quibus extitit occupata. Ioannes Zonaras maketh this matter cleare, diuiding the Gaules into the Gaules of Europe, Io. Zonaras Ann. to. 2. in Vitellio. and not of Europe, but A≈øia in expre≈ø≈øe termes. So doth Zo≈øimus, Diodorus Siculus, and others. Among whome the la≈øt writeth in this manner: Zo≈øim. l. 4. in Gratiano & Theodo≈øio. D ‚Ä¢ odor. Sicul. ‚Ä¢ er. antiq. l. 5. c 9. Omnis ea Regio Galatia, id e≈øt, Gallia, dicta e≈øt. Haec √† multis nationibus incolitur, Natio vt plurimum ad Arcton ≈øita. Regio frigida, vt quae hiemis tempore pro aqua niuibus oppleta exi≈øtat. Glacies quoque immen≈øa adeo regionem occupat, vt flumina congelata ≈øint peruia tran≈øeuntibus, non ≈øolum paucis, ≈øed exercitibus quoque cum curribus, atque impedimentis: all that Region is called Galatia, that is to ≈øay Gallia. It is inhabited of many Nations. A Country for the mo≈øt parte ≈øituated by the North a could Region, which in the time of winter for water is couered with ≈ønowe. And huge Ice doth ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the Region, that the Riuers being fro≈øen, are pa≈ø≈øable for trauaylers, and not onely for a few, but for whole Armies al≈øo, with their wagons and impediments. And a little after, he further addeth: Qui ad Scythiam v≈øque habitant dicuntur Galli: quas omnes gentes communi nomine Romani Gallos appellant.
Eorum qui ≈øubtus Arcton habitant quique Scythiae ≈øunt propinqui, vtpote caeteris agrestiores nonnullos aiunt humanis carnibus ve≈øci: They which dwell euen to Scythia, are named Gaules: all which Nations the Romans by a common name call Gaules. And ≈øome of them which dwell vnder the North Pole, and are neare to Scythia are ≈øaid to eate mans flesh. Titus Liuius al≈øo maketh mention of the Schytian Gaules, when he thus relateth the ≈øpeach of Manlius: non me praeterit milites, Tit. Liuius hi≈øt. l. 28. in orat. Manlij Con≈øulis. ad milites. omnium quae A≈øiam colunt gentium, Gallos fama belli prae≈øtare. O Souldiers I am not ignorant, that of all people, or Nations, which inhabite A≈øia, the Gaules excell in fame of warre. Thus renowned was the A≈øiaticall Gallia euen with the Romans, and their Hi≈øtorians at that time.

4. And Richardus Dinothus in his booke of Hi≈øtoricall common places, Rich. Dinothus loc. com. hi≈øt. l. 2. c. de Germanis. citing Diodorus Siculus, who hath te≈øtified as much before, proueth, that before the time of Caius Caligula, the Emperor, next vnto Tyberius, vnder whom Chri≈øt ≈øuffered his pa≈ø≈øion, the name of Germanie was not kowne; but all tho≈øe Countryes euen to Thracia, were called Gallia, or Gallatia all one in effect, the Romans commonly naming them Gallia, and the Greeks Gallatia. Hier. Gebuler. l. de libert. Germ. c. 12. Germanorum nomen paulo ante Caij Cae≈øaris tempora caepit innote≈øcere, cum antea omnes populi a Gallico Oceano ad Thraciam v≈øque Galatae vocarentur. Which Hieronimus Gebulerius al≈øo confirmeth, te≈øtifying, that the Romans them≈øelues aunciently called both the Germans, and tho≈øe which we now call Gaules, or French by the common name of Gaules, or Gallia. Non ne≈øcimus veteres Romanos Trog. Pomp. & Iu≈øt. hi≈øt. l. 24. & 25. communi Gallorum nomine cum Germanos, tum Gallos comprehendi≈ø≈øe. Which al≈øo Iu≈øtinus, Trogus Pompeius, with many others, ≈øpeeking of the conque≈øts of the Gaules, vnder the conduct of Brennus, commonly ≈øuppo≈øed to be a Britane, and brother to our King Beline, 400. yeares before the birth of Chri≈øt, doe plainely affirme: Gallorum ea tempe≈øtate tantae faecunditatis Iuuentus fuit vt A≈øiam omnem velut examine aliquo implerent, denique neque Reges Orientis ≈øine mercen ‚Ä¢ rio Gallorum exercitu vlla bella ge≈ø≈øerint, neque pul≈øi Reges, ad alios quam ad Gallos confugerint tantus terror Gallici nominis, ≈øiue armorum inuicta faelicitas erat, vt aliter neque maie≈øtatem ≈øuam tutam, neque ami≈ø≈øam ≈øe recuperare po≈ø≈øe, ≈øine Gallica virtute arbitrarentur: The youth of the Gaules at that time was ≈øo plentifull, that they filled as it were with a ≈øwarme all A≈øia, finally neither did the Kings of the East make warre without an army of Gaules, neither did Kings driuen froÃÑ their ≈øeats, fly vnto others for ≈øuccour, then to the Gaules. The Terrour of the Gaulish name was ≈øo greate, and their vnuincible felicitie in armes ≈øuch, that they thought they could not keepe their maie≈øty in ≈øafetie, nor recouer it, being lo≈øt, without the Gaulish pui≈ø≈øance. And our CouÃÑtry Hi≈øtorian Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter relating the ≈øame Matt. We≈øtm. hi≈øt. aetate 5. Stowe & Howes hi≈øt. in Belin. and BreÃÑnus. Galfrid. Monum. hi≈øtor. Briton. l. 3. Pont. Virun. hi≈øt. Brit. l. 3. H ‚Ä¢ er. Gebuin. l. de libert. Germ. cap. 12. Seba≈øt. Mun≈øter. Co≈øm. lib. 1. Hi≈øtory of Brennus Leader of the Gaules, being three hundred thow≈øands, affirmeth, ≈øua prole totam A≈øiam repleu ‚Ä¢ runt; they filled all A≈øia with their I≈ø≈øue. And ≈øo gaue the name of Gallia, or Gallatia vnto their po≈øteritie.

5. The like haue other English Hi≈øtorians, Stowe, Howes; and the Brittish Hi≈øtory with Ponticus Virunnius doe not differ, of which this la≈øt writeth: Exercitus eius adhuc Galatae nominantur: his army or the po≈øterity of it are called Galathians to this day. Which name Galathians is the ≈øame with Gaules, as al≈øo Galatia and Gallia are. Onely with this difference, that the Greekes more v≈øually called both the Gaules of A≈øia, & tho≈øe next to vs in Europe Galathians and Galathia, as their fir≈øt auncient denomination was; for as both Hieronymus Gebuinus, and Seba≈øtian Mun≈øter a Prote≈øtant with many others well proue, this next Gallia was fir≈øt called Galatia, a Galate Rege of their King of that name: and they were the Romans which altered it, taking a ≈øillable away
and naming it for breuitie Gallia: Romani autem dementes vnam ≈øyllabam pro Gallatia, Galliam appellarunt. And the old Greeke writer, as Dion Ca≈ø≈øius, Dion Epitom. p. 252. in Caio Calig. Dion in Cae≈øare Aug. p. 214. & p. 313. in Vitellio. Eutrop. l. 9. p. 122. Zo≈øimus l. 4. in Gratiano & Theodo≈ø. Theoret. in Epi≈øt. Pauli in Id. Cre≈øc. in Galatia. Godw. conu. of Britaine p. 2. Eutropius, Zo≈øimus, and S. Paul him≈øelf as both Theoderet, and a Prote≈øtant English Bishop with others expownde him, did call this our next Gallia, by the fir≈øt name Gallatia, and the≈øe Gaules, Galathians. So doth Ammianus Mercellinus with others, which a Prote≈øtant Bishop shall thus confirme: Ammianus Mercellinus ≈øaith: Gallos ≈øermone Graeco Galatas dici ≈øolere. That in the Greeke languadge the Gaules were v≈øed to be called Gallathians, and thereof we haue a plaine te≈øtomony in Theodoret, that writing of that place of the Apo≈øtle. Cre≈øceÃÑs into Galatia, &c. ≈øic Gallias appellauit, ≈øaith he. By which te≈øtimonyes it is made inuinciblye euident, that S. I≈øidor & Freculphus being Latine Authours followed the phra≈øe of ≈øpeach of the Romans, and Latins; and called the A≈øian Gallatia or Gallia, plainely Gallia, as the Latins v≈øually did, and that they onely ment, that S. Philip the Apo≈øtle preached in that A≈øiaticall Gallia, and not in this of Europe neare vnto vs, where, or neare vnto it, he neuer was.

6. And yet to giue the greate≈øt credit we may to them, that would haue In what ≈øence S. Philip the Apo≈øtle may be named the Apo≈øtle of the Frenchmen, de≈øcending from Sicambria where he preached. S. Philip to be named al≈øo the Apo≈øtle of the≈øe next Gaules, and FraÃÑkes, though he was neuer in that Nation, whereas it is the common opinion of French, and other Antiquaries, that they came from Sicambria, the Sicambers, or Frankes by the Maeotides paludes, betweene Scythia of Europe, and A≈øia, our Countriman Ingulphus Abbot of Crowland ≈øolueth this difficultie vnto vs, in this manner: Beatus Chri≈øti Apo≈øtolus Philippus, cum Scythis verbum dei praedica≈ø≈øet, & plurimos eorum ad fidem Chri≈øti conuerti≈ø≈øet, rediens in A≈øiam, per Sicambros viam fecit, ac illis Chri≈øti nomen primus annunciauit. De quibus exeuntes Ingulphus in Hi≈øt. Croland. Franci, vt plures eorum Hierochronographi te≈øtantur, beatum Philippum Apo≈øtolum ≈øuum specialem Protodoctorem, & Neopostolum adhuc tenent: Philip the ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtle of Chri≈øt, hauing preached the word of God to the Scythians, and conuerted very many of them to the faith of Chri≈øt, returning into A≈øia, pa≈ø≈øed by the Sicambers, and first preached the name of Chri≈øt vnto them. From which the Frankes or Frenchmen being de≈øcended, as many of their holy Chronographers doe witne≈ø≈øe, they accompt S. Philip the Apo≈øtle for their ≈øpeciall fir≈øt doctor and new Apo≈øtle. So we haue credibly fownde, how S. Philip the Apo≈øtle, might in a lardge manner of ≈øpeach, be called the Apo≈øtle of tho≈øe Frankes, or Frenchmen, which came from Sicambria; but not of the auncient Gaules of this Gallia which came not from thence. S. Philip the Apo≈øtle could not di ‚Ä¢ ectly ≈øend S. Io≈øeph hither from S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ aÃÑ bria or any other place.

7. Neither could S. Philip ≈øend S. Io≈øeph from Sicambria directly into this our Britaine, for the time when he preached in Sicambria was, by this authoritie, long before his death, and yet he was, as I haue allready proued, Martyred many yeares before S. Io≈øeph came into Britaine: yet doe I not deny but S. Io≈øeph might be ≈øome time, with S. Philip the Apo≈øtle, when he was among the Gaules of A≈øia and other Nations there, and that when he Hector. Boeth. hi≈øt. Scot lib. 4. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Scotl. Stow. Hi≈øt. in Marius. Galfrid. Monu. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 4. c. 17. Pont. Virun. Hi≈øt. Brit. lib. 4. Matth. We≈øtm. anno 75. came hither, he came, though long after S. Philips death, from parts not farre remote from thence. For we reade in our Scottish, and other Hi≈øtories, that about this time greate numbers of tho≈øe Countries arriued, and ≈øetled in our Ilands, and Northren parts, among whome Hector Boethius ≈øpeaking of this time of S. Io≈øephs landing heare, ≈øaith: ≈øub id tempus populus quidam Morauiae, vt no≈øtris Annalibus est prodituÃÑ, Romanis armis profligati, ≈øui≈øque pul≈øi ≈øedibus, di≈øpalatim ad Rheni O≈øtia deuenere. Vnd ‚Ä¢ conglobati nauibus vtcunque comparatis, nouas ≈øedes quaerendi gratia, per va≈øtos incognito≈øque maris tractus errauere, prohibiti tandem & Gallicis, & Britanicis Oris, ab ‚Ä¢ arum Incolis, in Fortheam ≈øunt delati:
About that time a certaine people of Morauia, as our Annales doe te≈øtifie, being driuen away by the Romans, and expelled from their Seats, came wandering to the mouth of Rhyne, where gathered together, and getting shipping, as well as they could, did roue through the va≈øte, and vnknowne pa≈ø≈øadges of the Sea, and being forbidden landing, either on the French, or Brittish Coa≈øtes by their Inhabitants, they came to Forth, by Pictland. Where we ≈øee the time when, place from whence this people came, and where they landed, and other circum≈øtances agree with the Iorney of S. Io≈øeph hither: the time as before con≈øenteth. Morauia from whence they came, is neare the parts where S. Philip preached. The place where they arryued agreeth with S. Io≈øeph Iorney, for by the Antiquities Antiquit. Gla≈øt. Io. Capgrau. in S. Io≈øeph & alij. of Gla≈øtenbury and others he mu≈øt needs land about the North of this Iland, from whence coming to Gla≈øteÃÑbury he came by the parts now called Northewales, and was impri≈øoned there, and the number which landed with him was ≈øo greate, that no Hi≈øtorye maketh memory of any ≈øuch to haue arriued heare, at, or neare that time, the Romans onely, which were not friends, but Enemyes to them, excepted.

8. And yet if we follow Ihon Harding, he will tell vs, that S. Io≈øeph and his Religeous company came hither with Ve≈øpa≈øian Lieutenant to the Roman S. Io≈øeph by Harding and others came into Britaine with Ve≈øpa≈øian the Roman Pre≈øident heare. Emperour, and he him≈øelfe al≈øo afterward Emperour, and that by the entreatie of Ve≈øpa≈øian to the then King, and Queene of Britaine, Aruiragus and Genui≈øsa, tho≈øe fauours & freedoms which by our Hi≈øtories he enioyed at Gla≈øtenbury, were be≈øtowed vpon him: for ≈øpeaking of Ve≈øpa≈øian he ≈øaith.

lg.l: With whom Io≈øeph full holy and full wi≈øe Ihon Harding Cronicle fol. 40. cap. 47.
Of Aramathie with his fellowes fourtene
Into this land then came and gaue contene.
For whome ≈øo then Ve≈øpa≈øian prayed the King,
The Queene al≈øo, to him to be good Lord, fol. 41.
And good Lady, which they graunted in all thing.
When Ve≈øpa≈øian to Rome returned home againe,
The King endued Io≈øeph in Meatrine.

div.p: Which Relation wanteth not probability, to make it good, for Ve≈øpa≈øian Eutrop. l. 7. Mart. Polon Supputat. an. D. 71. in Ve≈øpa≈øiano came hither out of Germany, by which S. Io≈øeph mu≈øt needs pa≈ø≈øe in his Iorney to Britaine from the A≈øiaticall Gallia, and the adioyning Countries, where S. Philip preached, and in his way were tho≈øe Di≈øciples of S. Peter, of whome I haue ≈øpoaken before, S. Egi≈øtus, Marianus, Maternus, Valerius, Eucharius, Clement, Man≈øuetus, and others. Neyther was Ve≈øpa≈øian an Enemie but a knowne friend, and louer of Chri≈øtians, as I shall shewe when I come to the time of his Empire: and the times of S. Io≈øephs and Ve≈øpa≈øians S. Io≈øeph probably was directed into Britaine by S. Peter the Apo≈øtle. coming hither may without difficultie be reconciled, e≈øpecially if we ≈øpeake of their aboad heare.

9. And if we will followe the be≈øt Antiquities we haue, or Prote≈øtants them≈øelues in this matter, we shall ea≈øily finde, that S. Io≈øeph rather came hither by direction of S. Peter, then any other Apo≈øtle: for fir≈øt they a≈ø≈øuer vs, that Antiquit. Gla≈øt. in Tabul. Antiq. Capgrau. in S. Io≈øeph and Patr. Godwin Conuer≈ø. pag. 36. cap. 3. Godw. ≈øupr. pag. 9. cap. 2. S.
