Io≈øeph was pre≈øent with the Apo≈øtles, at the time of the A≈ø≈øumption of the mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary; ≈øecondly, to ≈øpeake in a Prote≈øtant Bishops words, he receaued directions for his preaching and di≈øcipline, eyther in the Councell of the Apostles gathered at Hieru≈øalem, or el≈øe of S. Philip the Apo≈øtle in France. This ≈øecond is di≈øproued before, and this Prote≈øtant authour him≈øelfe doth di≈øabl ‚Ä¢ S. Philip the Apo≈øtle his being in France, then much more, that he directed
S. Io≈øeph there. And if S. Io≈øeph was then directed by ≈øome of the Apo≈øtles at Hieru≈øalem to come into Britaine, by whome should he take directions therein, rather then of S. Peter who alone among the Apo≈øtles was to preach at that time in Britaine, and the≈øe we≈øterne parts? Againe it is euident by the Scripture it≈øelfe, that S. Peter preached in Galatia, or the A≈øian Gallia, where S. Io≈øeph is ≈øaid to haue bene. Further, the≈øe Prote≈øtants tell vs, that S. Io≈øeph came hither in the beginning of the per≈øecution of Nero, and to auoide it; one of them a greate Antiquary writeth, in this manner: I will adde in few words, what I haue read of Io≈øephs arriuall heare. Fir≈øt of all therefore you shall Will. Harri≈øon de≈øcrip. of Brit. p. 23. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. Godw. Conu. note that he came ouer into Britaine about the 64. yeare after Christ when the per≈øecution began vnder Nero. Therefore ≈øeeing that per≈øecution, by all Antiquities, was in Rome, and the nearer places of the Empire vnto it, S. Io≈øeph was not altogether a ≈øtranger thereabouts, otherwi≈øe he could not come from any of them by rea≈øon of the per≈øecution there.

10. To conclude we reade in the mo≈øt approued Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury that one which came in the company of S. Io≈øeph was his kin≈øman, con≈øanguineus Io≈øeph, and a maÃÑ of ≈øuch note that the Hi≈øtory termeth him, Rex: a King, Antiquit. M. S. ‚Ä¢ la≈øton, intabul. antiq. ≈øome Prince or cheife Ruler among them: Rex Orcaniae, was named Petrus: Peter, which name was ≈øo new at that time, being fir≈øt giuen hy Chri≈øt him≈øelfe to S. Simon Bar-Iona, Peter the Apo≈øtle, and rare in the world, not found in Scripturs, but onely in him, and vnknowne al≈øo in hi≈øtories, being rather a name of ≈øignification, then v≈øuall denomination to import, what a Rocke, and foundation of the Church of Chri≈øt, S. Peter the Apo≈øtle was to be, we cannot but thinke, this Peter S. Io≈øephs Kin≈øman receaued that his name, with his bapti≈øme and Chri≈øtianitie of S. Peter the Apo≈øtle; and not altogether without iu≈øt merit of that name, for as Eccle≈øia≈øticall writers and holy Scripture make S. Peter, the cheife Piller ≈øpiritual in the Church of Chri≈øt; ≈øo this Peter S. Io≈øephs Kin≈øman, was as this Antiquitie affirmeth a temporall foundation, and Father euen to Kings and Princes in the≈øe parts, and in particular, it lineally deduceth from him King Loth that marryed the Si≈øter of King Arthur. Therefore if ≈øo cheife a man in S. Io≈øephs company was in all probable Iudgment, ≈øo nearely depending of S. Peter the Apo≈øtle, we may not rashly make the re≈øt ≈øuch ≈øtrangers vnto him, but that they had direction from him in their proceedings, as I haue euidently before proued, and shall make it more manife≈øt hereafter, that when they were come hither they depended of him, and his Di≈øciples in things ≈øpirituall: And ≈øuch ≈øubordination had the≈øe holy men to the See Apo≈øtolike of Rome, that when in the time of King Lucius their memory was allmo≈øt forgotten heare in Britaine, for any thing we finde in Hi≈øtories, it was renewed from Rome euen as our cheife≈øt Prote≈øtants them≈øelues acknowledge, among whome their fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop affirmeth, that S. Phaganus and Damianus were informed at Rome, before their coming hither of the dwelling of S. Io≈øeph and his companions Matth. Parker Antiq. Brit. p. 3. in Britaine de Io≈øephi ≈øociorumque in Britannia olim habitatione. And maketh this his rea≈øon, becau≈øe, Io≈øeph as al≈øo the other Apo≈øtles and Di≈øciples di≈øper≈øed throughout the whole world, v≈øed to certi≈øie by Me≈ø≈øengers, and letters, their fellowes at Rome, what they had done, and ≈øuffered in euery Region for Chri≈øt, and what profit they had. And that by this meanes the Legats of Pope Eleutherius did ≈øearch for tho≈øe places, which they had learned out of auncient writings at Rome, to haue bene fir≈øt inhabited by Chri≈øtians: neque √† veritate alienum e≈ø≈øe pote≈øt, Io≈øephum perinde ac alios Apo≈øtolos ac Di≈øcipulos per totum orbem ≈øpar≈øos, quid ≈øingulis
in Regionibus pro Chri≈øto effeci≈ø≈øent, quidue ≈øiue aduer≈øi, ≈øiue commodi ≈øen≈øi≈ø≈øent, per Nuncios ac liter as certiores feci≈ø≈øe Collegas ≈øuas, tam Romae quam Hiero≈øolimis, alij≈øque in locis: aut Eleutherij Legatos indagare volui≈ø≈øe ea loca quae √† Chri≈øtianis pri√πs culta Romae ex antiquis ≈øcriptis acceperunt. And immediately ≈øetting downe, how the≈øe Roman Legats after much ≈øerch and ≈øeeking, found out the place of S. Io≈øephs abiding, he addeth, how they knew by manife≈øt ≈øignes, and toke ‚Ä¢ s‚ñ™ that it was the habitation of Io≈øeph and his fellowes in Britaine, of which they were aduerti≈øed in Rome: Quibus alij≈øque manife≈øtis ≈øignis, atque indicijs, facile intellexerunt, eam ip≈øam fui≈ø≈øe Io≈øephi, ≈øociorumque in Britannia habitationem, de qua Romae acceperant. The like haue others: and the Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury which Antiquit. Gla≈øt. apud Capgrau. in S. Patric. in S. Io≈øeph. ≈øet downe this diligent ≈øearch in Britaine, mu≈øt needs haue relation, and reference to proceed from that notice which the Legats had receaued of the≈øe things at Rome, for they are ≈øo farre from te≈øtifying, that they learned this in Britaine, that they a≈ø≈øuer vs, the memory of them heare was ≈øo blotted out, and forgotten, that caepit idem locus e≈ø≈øe ferarum, qui pri√πs fuer at habitatio Sanctorum: The ≈øame place began to be a Denn of wilde bea≈øts, which formerly was the habitation of Saints. And ≈øo much the more vndoubted, that the be≈øt knowledge of Chri≈øtian affaires in Britaine in the≈øe times was at Rome, for it is a common opinion of our English Prote≈øtant Antiquaries, that euen at that time, when S. Io≈øeph came hither, many both Romans, and Britans that were Chri≈øtians, came from Rome into Britaine, to auoide the Per≈øecution of Nero, falling out at this time, of which the Theater Authours doe thus te≈øtifie: It hath pa≈ø≈øed Theat. of great. Brit. l. 6. cap. 9. with allowance, among the learned Senate of our Antiquaries, that when Claudius and Nero (which now reigned) began to bannish and per≈øecute the Christians in Rome, many Romans and Britans being conuerted to the faith, fled thence vnto the≈øe remote parts of the Earth, where they might, and did more freely enioy the libertie of their profe≈øsions. Therefore we cannot que≈øtion, but a more perfect memory of our Chri≈øtian proceedings, was kept at Rome, from whence ≈øo many of our primatiue Chri≈øtians came, then in any other forreyne place, and that the≈øe Chri≈øtian Romans, and Britans ≈øo reparing hither, being the Di≈øciples or ≈øpirituall children of S. Peter, that eyther S. Io≈øeph and his a≈ø≈øociates were of the ≈øame number, or ioyned with them in profe≈ø≈øion of Religion in this Nation.

div.head: THE XXV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THAT MANY OTHER CHRISTIANS CAME hither, e≈øpecially into the Northren parts, and Ilands with S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, be≈øides them which continued with him at Gla≈øtenbury: and many of them married with Britans continuing Christianitie heare in their children, and po≈øteritie, vntill the generall Conuer≈øion of Britaine, vnder the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian Kings, Lucius, and Donaldus.

div.p:
1. ALthough our v≈øuall Hi≈øtories of S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, cheifely ≈øpeake of the coming of him, and his Religeous companions, not aboue 14. by any accompt: yet we haue Antiquities te≈øtifiing, that greate numbers of other Chri≈øtians came with him hither, or to our Ilands adioyning at that time. Among the≈øe, a Brittish Eremite lyuing when Gla≈øtenbury Abbey was builded by King Inas, when the Antiquities thereof were diligently ≈øought, and examined, and he ≈øo conuer≈øant in them, that Io. Pit≈øeus l. de vir. Illu≈øtrib. aetat. 8. an. 720. in Eremit. Brit. Anonim. in l. Sanct. Graal. Ioh. Capgrau. in Catal. in S. Io≈øeph ab Aram. he wrote a booke of that ≈øubiect, doth plainely te≈øtifie in his Hi≈øtory hereof named, Sanctus Graal, the holy Graal, that there came hither in the company of Saint Io≈øeph, and his Religeous A≈ø≈øociats, which continued with him at Gla≈øtenbury in Eremiticall conuer≈øation, aboue 600. men, and women, that were Chri≈øtians, and had vowed cha≈øtity, or continency vntill they should happily arriue in this Land, Miraculou≈øly a≈ø≈øigned (as it ≈øeemeth) vnto them to continue in. Venerunt autem cum eis vt legitur in libro qui ≈øanctum Graal appellatur, ≈øexcenti & amplius tam viri, quam foeminae, qui omnes votum vouerunt quod ab vxoribus proprijs ab≈øtinerent, quou≈øque terram ≈øibi delegatam ingre≈øsi fui≈ø≈øent. And becau≈øe ≈øome take exception to this Authour, the mo≈øt warranted Pit≈ø. ≈øupr. and allowed Manu≈øcript Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury, written in old letters in parchment, vpon broade Tables aunciently belonging to the Mona≈øtery of Gla≈øtenbury affirme the ≈øame. And how diuers of them were noble par≈øonages, Antiq. Gla≈øt. in Tabul. Antiq. and ≈øuch as in tho≈øe times, and ≈ømall Ilands, were ≈øtiled Reges: Kings, and ≈øome of our Brittish Kings di≈øcended from them. Among the≈øe, was fir≈øt Helaius, Nephew to S. Io≈øeph, of whome this old Manu≈øcript Antiquitie thus relateth. Helaius Nepos Io≈øeph genuit Io≈øue, Io≈øue genuit Aminadab. Aminadab Diuers noble Chri≈øtians deliuered to haue bene in this Company and of whome our King in Britaine de≈øcended. genuit Ca≈øtellors. Ca≈øtellors genuit Manaclauiel, Manaclauiel genuit Lambrord, Lambrord genuit filium qui genuit Ygernam, de qua Rex Vterpendragon genuit nobilem & fama≈øum Regem Arthurum. Per quod pater quod Rex Arthurus de ≈øtirpe Io≈øeph de≈øcendit: Helaius Nephew of Io≈øeph begat Io≈øue, Io≈øue begat Aminadal, Aminadab begat Ca≈øtellors, Ca≈øtellors begat Manaclauiel, Manaclauiel begat LaÃÑbrord, LaÃÑbrord begat a ≈øonne which begat Ygerna, of whom vterpendr ‚Ä¢ gon begat the noble and renowned Arthur. By which it appeareth that King Arthur did di≈øcend of the
Race of Io≈øeph. And the≈øe Antiquities doe thus further relate vnto vs: Petrus con≈øanguineus Io≈øeph ab Aramathia Rex Orcaniae genuit Erlan, Erlan genuit Melianum, Melianus genuit Arguth, Arguth genuit Edor, Edor genuit Loth, Qui du xit in vxorem ≈øororem Regis Arthuri, de qua genuit quatuor filios ≈øcilicet walwanum, Agrauains, Gwerehes, Gaheries: Peter kin≈øman of Io≈øeph of Aramathia, King of Orcanie begat Erlan, Erlan begat Melianus, Melianus begat Arguth, Arguth begat Edor, Edor begat Loth, who tooke to wife, the Si≈øter of King Arthur, of whome he begat fower ≈øonnes to wit walwan, Agrauayns, Gwerehes, Gaheries. Antiquit. Gla≈øt. ≈øupr. Et Capgr. in S. Io≈øeph.

2. Againe the ≈øame Antiquities ≈øpeaking of S. Io≈øephs Impri≈øonment, pre≈øently after his coming into this Iland, which was in Venedocia, now Northwales, neare to the Ile of Man, was ≈øet at libertie by a noble man whome he had conuerted to the faith, named Mordraius whome the Antiquitie calleth a King, Rex Mordraius. A late writer thinketh this Mordraius to be the then Harris M. S. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 25. Hector. Boeth. Hi≈øt. Scot. in Crathlint. Bal. l. de Script. cen. tr. in Amphibalus. Theater of great Britaine l. 6. c. 9. ¬ß. 4. S. Io≈øephs Si≈øter. Married to a Britan. Nicholaus Vignier Bibliothee. Hi≈øt. an. 63. King, or Ruler of the Iland, Mona, and that the place where he was conuerted, named the city Saract, was Soder, in the Ile of Man, which was the fir≈øt Bishops See, we reade of in tho≈øe parts, in the time and per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian. And our Prote≈øtant writers of the Theater of greate Britaine tell vs of ≈øome others, of this company of S. Io≈øeph, that liued in the world, and were not of the Religeous number, that ≈øettled at Gla≈øteÃÑbury with S. Io≈øeph, and among them name a Si≈øter of S. Io≈øeph, called Eurgaine, who (to ≈øpeake in their words) afterwards marryed a Britan named Siarklos: and they cite Georg Owen Harry for the ≈øame opinion. And Nicholas Vignier a French writer in his Bibliotheke Hi≈øtoriall, in the yeare of Chri≈øt 63. plainely affirmeth: Io≈øeph of Aramathia arriued this yeare in great Britaine, auec vne trouppe: with a troupe or great number of his companions. To the≈øe I may add the te≈øtimonie of Tertullian before of the timely receauing of the faith of Chri≈øt, by our Northren Britans commonly confounded in Hi≈øtories with the Scottish Nation, by rea≈øon of their dwelling long together, and how Petrus Cluniacen≈øis writing to S. Bernard, as our Theater Prote≈øtants cite, and followe him Theater of great Brit. l. 6. c. 9. ¬ß. 9. therein, ≈øuppo≈øeth the Scottish men the more auncient Chri≈øtians, as not being in the like ≈øubiection to the Romans, as the other then were. Which cannot more probably In what re≈øpect the Scots may be termed the more auncient Chri≈øtiaÃÑs. be affirmed of any, then the≈øe that came, by tho≈øe Antiquities, with S. Io≈øeph, into tho≈øe outward Ilands, where the Scots then inhabited, and with whome they vnited them≈øelues, as al≈øo with our Northren Britans. Neither can we thinke, but among ≈øo many, euen hundreds (as before) which came hither at that time, ≈øome of them left a Po≈øteritie of children as is exemplified in two before, one the Nephew, the other kin≈øman of S. Io≈øeph; and we may take notice from the names them≈øelues of ≈øome of the≈øe, that be recited, as Io≈øue, Aminadab, and Loth, that they were Chri≈øtians, no others in the≈øe parts in tho≈øe times taking names from Scripture but they onely; and for Loth, one of them that is named, certaine it is by our Brittish and other Hi≈øtories that he was a Chri≈øtian, ≈øo of Ygerna and King Arthur which likewi≈øe by the≈øe Antiquities did di≈øcend from tho≈øe of the company of S. Io≈øeph. And allthough the≈øe three la≈øt were late in re≈øpect of that fir≈øt age of Chri≈øt, and liued when Britaine generally profe≈ø≈øed Chri≈øtian Religion, yet Helaius Nephew or Grand≈øonne to S. Io≈øeph placed for the fir≈øt of that Genealogiein this Land, at the time of S. Io≈øephs comig hither, and his ≈øonne Io≈øue, mu≈øt needs be liuing in the daies of S. Io≈øeph, and Aminadab the ≈øonne of Io≈øue being by his name a Chri≈øtian did probably liue vnto the dayes of Kings, Lucius, and Don ‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢ us‚ñ™ to be of tho≈øe which continued a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øtiantie heare,
vntill the generall Conuer≈øion of Britaine, at that time. So we may rea≈øonably affirme, of the po≈øteritie of Peter, kin≈øman to S. Io≈øeph in ≈øome part before remembred, out of tho≈øe Antiquities; and after the ≈øame proportion Iudge of the children of Eurgayne, S. Io≈øephs ≈øi≈øter, & her Brittish husband Siarklos, if they left any behind them in the world. For no man will once coniecture, that either ≈øonne, Si≈øter, Nephewe, kin≈øman or kindred of S. Io≈øeph would vndertake ≈øo long and tedious a Iorney with him from Iury into Britaine, to liue poore Exils heare, but for the loue of Chri≈øt, and his holy Religion ≈øo extreamely per≈øecuted by the Iewes in S. Io≈øeph, for his honorable burying of our Sauiour, and his friends and kindred, as we are taught in approued Hi≈øtories, that the mallice & hatred of the Iewes was not more enraged again≈øt any Di≈øciple of Chri≈øt, then towards S. Io≈øeph, and his frends. And as Gregorius Turonenfis and others te≈øtifie: maiorem in eum habentes ≈øaeuitiam, quam Antiquit. Gla≈øt. apud Capgr. in S. Io≈øeph. Drogo Epi≈øc. Ho≈øtien. Hi≈øt. de morte & Re≈øurrectione Saluatoris. Greg. Turon. l. 1. Hi≈øt. Franc. ¬ß. 21. p. 18. Vincent. in ≈øpec. Hi≈øt. l. 5. c. 56. 57. 58. Act. Pilati apud Capgrau. & Turon. ≈øupr. Nicodem. in EuaÃÑg. Eremita Anon. author l. 5. Graa. Manu≈øcr. antiq. Gla≈øton. Mona≈øterij tabulis affixum in membranis. in ip≈øum Dominum, vt cum ille a militibus, hic ab ip≈øis Sacerdotibus cu≈øtodiretur: The Iewes had more hatred again≈øt Io≈øeph, then again≈øt our Lord him≈øelf, for whereas Chri≈øt being buried, was kept and watched by ≈øouldiers, Io≈øeph being impri≈øoned in a clo≈øe place without any light, was garded and watched by the Prei≈øts them≈øelues. Yet he was Miraculou≈øly from thence and them deliuered, and pre≈øerued to honour this kingdome with the holy life, and death of him≈øelfe, and many his Religeous companions and friends.

3. The auncient Brittish Eremite of whom I haue ≈øpoken before, te≈øtifieth, that S. Io≈øeph his wife came in this company with her husband, and that it was appointed, and promi≈øed of God to them, and their po≈øteritie. Io≈øeph ab Aramathia qui Chri≈øtum ≈øepeliuit, cum vxore & filio Io≈øephe nomine in maiorem Britanniam ≈øibi & ≈øemini eius promi≈ø≈øam, venerunt. And the Collectours of the Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury, who as it ≈øeemeth by their o ‚Ä¢ ne te≈øtimony, were mo≈øt diligent, and carefull to deliuer nothing to po≈øteritie but what they found to be approued by auncient Hi≈øtoriographers, as the fir≈øt words of their Hi≈øtory deliuer, affirme the ≈øame. Quoniam dubia legentem fallunt, certa dubijs ablatis, atque ex antiquis Hi≈øtoriographorum dictis probata, de antiquitate Glastonien≈øis Eccle≈øiae quaedam in≈øeremus. It is al≈øo te≈øtified in this Antiquitie, recommended to containe ≈øo certaine, and vndoubted verities, that the Pagan King that had impri≈øoned S. Io≈øeph, & his companions in the Country now named Nothwales, Mordraius a Chri≈øtian ≈øet vp a Chri≈øtian King in his place, named Celidonius ≈øonne of Natianus, & his wife the daughter of Lalel or Label a noble Per≈øian was al≈øo a Chri≈øtian. And citeth the auncient Brittish Eremite for the Authour hereof. But this was rather to be e≈øteemed ≈øome noble Gouernour, or Ruler, called by the name Rex, King, or Ruler of ≈øome few people, in which ≈øence all Rulers though meane, may be truely termed Reges, Rulers, and not ≈øuch potent par≈øons, as the name is now allmo≈øt appropriated vnto: of which Ranke and Order, King Lucius was the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King, and Donaldus next to him.

div.head: THE XXVI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE COMING, AND SETTLING OF S. Io≈øeph and his company, where Glastenbury now is, then a wildernes, rather to profe≈ø≈øe the penitentiall contemplatiu ‚Ä¢ Eremiticall Religeous life, then employ their time in preaching.

div.p:
1. LET vs now pro≈øecute the Hi≈øtory of S. Io≈øeph, & his Religeous A≈ø≈øociats, that came to the place, where Gla≈øtenbury in Sommer≈øet shire now ≈øtandeth, where they liued, died, and were buried. The Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury tell vs, that the fir≈øt landing of S. Io≈øeph in this Iland was in, or neare vnto that part, we now call Northwales, Antiquit. Gla≈øt. apud Capgrau. in S. Io≈øeph. M. S. in tabulis latis. where he and his Companions preaching the faith of Chri≈øt, were not onely denyed all nece≈ø≈øarie things for their releife, and ≈øustenance, but their doctrine reiected, and them≈øelues committed to Pri≈øon by the King or Prince of that Prouince, a Pagan Infidell: perfidus Rex Northwalliae Io≈øeph ≈øeruum Dei in partihus ≈øuis praedicantem, cum ≈øocijs ≈øuis carceri mancipauit, inhumaniter nega ‚Ä¢ s eis victui nece≈ø≈øaria. Of which Impri≈øonment of S. Io≈øeph, although other Antiquaries are ≈øparing in relating it, yet they are ≈øo farre from denying it, that they rather shew vnto vs, how credible it is: for they generally teach, Guliel. Camd. in Brit. Godw. coÃÑu. of Brit. c. 2. p. 9. 22. Tacitus Ann. in Agric. Iul. Cae≈øar comment. l. 1. with Iulius Cae≈øar, Tacitus, and others how this Iland was at that time ≈øubiect to diuers petie kings, or Rulers. So that although Aruiragus which by marriage had entered into alliance, and amitie with Claudius the Emperour, a publike and profe≈ø≈øed enemy to the Druides, the greate≈øt Aduer≈øaries and hinderers of Chri≈øtian Religion: Yet ≈øuch Princes or Rulers as liued in Mona: Angle≈øey and the partsof wales, where S. Io≈øeph is ≈øaid to haue bene impri≈øoned, were friends and followers of the Druids, and profe≈ø≈øed Enemies Camd. in Brit. in O ‚Ä¢ douic. Hect. Boet. Hi≈øt. Scot. in Crathlint. to the Romans, and ≈øuch as they fauoured either in matters of Religion, or others. But S. Io≈øeph and his A≈ø≈øociats being freed of their impri≈øonment, by the greate mercy and prouidence of God vnto them, allthough with the contradiction and re≈øi≈øtance of their Per≈øecutors, as tho≈øe Antiquities make more particular Relation, and ≈øeeing how fruitle≈ø≈øe a bu≈øines it was like to be, to ≈øtay any longer among that then ≈øo ob≈øtinate and obdurate people, came into this part of this Iland Loegria now England, and diuiding them≈øelues into diuers Trad. of Gla≈øtoÃÑ. in Sommer≈ø. Shire. companies being in all 12. 13. or 14. (≈øuch is the diuer≈øitie of opinions) in number, three of them as the continued Tradition of the ≈øtill inhabitants of Gla≈øtenbury in Sommer≈øet shire te≈øtifieth, came tyred and wearie neare vnto the ≈øituation of that Towne, to an Hill allmo≈øt a mile di≈øtant from thence, called thereupon in our common English languadge, as the generall opinion there is, Weary-all hill, where the miraculous, and there named euen by Prote≈øtants at this day, holy thorne groweth of which more hereafter. And after their prayers made to be directed, where to make their ≈øtay and aboade, interpreted the will of God to be, they should ≈øet vp their re≈øt in the adioyning place
where the late renowned and now ruinated Mona≈øtery of Gla≈øtenbury ≈øtood, being at that time a ≈øolitary de≈øart, and wildernes compa≈ø≈øed about with fennish Lakes, and Marishes, and mo≈øt fit for the Contemplatiue Eremiticall Religeous life which they profe≈ø≈øed.

2. And it neither was, nor could be long after, when the re≈øt of that Religeous company a≈ø≈øembled, and ioyned them≈øelues againe together with the≈øe three. For all Antiquities agree in this, that in the fir≈øt yeare of their coming into Britaine, whereof they had ≈øpent part before their impri≈øonment, part in pri≈øon and part in trauaile after, to this place of their vnion and dwelling together, they builded their little Church or Oratory, and yet this not without the notice and allowance of the King obtayned in that behalfe. Thus te≈øtify all our Antiquaries, Catholiks, and Prote≈øtants with our Antiquities, Manu≈øcripts Io. Capgr. in Catal. M. S. Io≈øeph. Antiq. Gla≈øt. tabulis fixae. M. S. In≈øcriptio aeris in Cu≈øtod. T ‚Ä¢ . Hughes & apud Godwin conu. of Brit. p. 11. Capgr. in S. Patric. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. in Io≈øeph ab Aramath. Matt. Parker antiquit. Brit. p. 3. Guliel. Malm. l. de antiquit. Caenob. Gla≈øton. M. S. or printed: Eodem anno quo in Britanniam mi≈øsi ≈øunt: the very ≈øame yeare wherein they came into Britaine, being warned by diuine admonition ≈øo to doe, they builded a Church in the honour of the holy Mother of God, and perpetuall Virgin Mary, in the place shewed vnto them from heauen, per Archangelum Gabrielem in vi≈øione admoniti ≈øint Eccle≈øiam in honoreÃÑ ≈øanctae Dei Genitricis, & perpetuae Virginis Mariae, in loco eis caelitus demon≈øtra ‚Ä¢ o, con≈øtruere. At the building whereof, as the≈øe Antiquities tell vs, they were all pre≈øent, and there afterward euen vnto the times of their deaths continued together. By which, we ≈øee it made cleare vnto vs, that if S. Io≈øeph and his companions had bene the mo≈øt learned men that euer were, there is left litle or no time allmo≈øt at all for them to haue preached vnto the Britans of this kingdome; for the time of their trauaile before they were impri≈øoned, the ≈øpace of their impri≈øonment, trauaile after into the parts of their aboade, their ≈øuite to King Aruiragus for the place of their dwelling, his graunt and confirmation thereof, and their building their Church, being all finished and effected in the fir≈øt yeare of their coming hither, by ≈øo many Antiquities, eodem anno, leaueth litle ≈øpace or lea≈øure for S. Io≈øeph, and his a≈øsociates did but litle pr ‚Ä¢ uaile in preaching, or rather preached litle. any other bu≈øines. And therefore a Prote≈øtant Bishop and Antiquary might iu≈øtly write: It ≈øeemeth that Io≈øeph and his fellowes preuayled litle by their preaching, and therefore gaue them≈øelues at la≈øt vnto a Mona≈øticall and ≈øolitary life in the I≈øland of Aualon. Where he might well haue omitted the words (at la≈øt) Godw. Conu. of Brit. p. 16. c. 3. for if they thus imployed them≈øelues to Mona≈øticall and ≈øolitary Eremiticall life, as this Prote≈øtant Bishop and all acknowledge in the very fir≈øt yeare of their coming hither, it was at the fir≈øt and not at la≈øt, but with ≈øuch expedition, and celeritie, that it is rather to be maruailed, how in a ≈øtrang Nation among Pagan Infidels, they could quietly enioy that freedome, and libertie ≈øo ≈øoone: For to pa≈ø≈øe ouer other letts, and hinderances before remembred, no man of Iudgment will thinke, but that indulgence and priuiledge for their quietly and peacebly ≈øeruing of God, which King Aruiragus granted vnto them, came by long and earne≈øt ≈øuites, and ≈øupplications both of them≈øelues and others Interce≈ø≈øours for them in that behalfe, whereupon Ihon Harding writing vpon this immunitie allowed vnto S. Io≈øeph and his companions whome he affirmeth to haue bene fourteene, ≈øaith it was by the intreatie and interce≈ø≈øion of Ve≈øpa≈øian, who was afterward Emperour, vnto King Aruiragus, and his Queene, thus he writeth of him.

q.l: For whome ≈øo then va≈øpa≈øian prayed the King,
The Queene al≈øo, to him to be good Lorde,
And good lady, which they graunted in all thing.

div.p:
And then ≈øetteth downe the liberties, and priuiledges, giuen by King Aruiragus,
to S. Io≈øeph, and his Religeous companions as other Hi≈øtorians doe.

3. Neither was this Donation made vnto them, but after experience of their mode≈øtie of life, which could not be ≈øodainely knowne to the King, and then in re≈øpect of that, and their long Iorney as William of Malmesbury in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory of the Antiquitie of the Mona≈øtery of Gla≈øtenbury Guliel. Malm. M. S. de Antiq. Gla≈øt. Capgrau. in Io≈øepho ab Aramathia. with others writeth. The barbarous King did graunt vnto them to inhabite a certaine Iland named In≈øwitrin in the Borders of his Countrye compa≈ø≈øed about with woods, Bushes, and fennes: Rex Barbarus quia de longinquo venerant, vitaeque eorum exigebat mode≈øtas, quandam In≈øulam filuis, rubis, atque paludibus circundatam, ab Incolis In≈øwetrin nuncupatam, in lateribus ≈øuae Regionis ad habitandum conce≈øsit. The Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury which Capgraue and others followe ≈øay Capgrau. in S. Io≈øeph. ab Aramathia Matth. Parker Antiq. Brit. pag. 3. plainely, vi≈øa vitae eorum mode≈øtia. Thus before the King did grante them that fauour, he did ≈øee, and had experience of the mode≈øtie of their liues. Neither did the≈øe holy men pre≈øently after this their enfranchi≈øement by King Aruiragus, to liue peaceably in that Iland, build this Church which was finished in their fir≈øt yeare of Landing heare, but expected ≈øome time, and liuing as poore Eremits in that wildernes, as the Antiquities of that place, and other Antiq. Gla≈øton. in tabulis & apud Capgrau. in S. Io≈øeph Theat. of great Brit. l. 6. Io. Leland. in a≈ø≈øert. Arthur. Antiquaries thus proue vnto vs: praedicti ≈øancti in eodem De≈øerto coÃÑuer≈øantes po≈øt pu≈øillum temporis per Gabrielem ArchangeluÃÑ in vi≈øione admoniti ≈øunt, Eccle≈øiam in honorem ≈øanctae Dei Genetricis & perpetuae virginis Mariae con≈øtruere: The afor≈øaid holy men liuing in that De≈øart, after a litle time were admonished by Gabriel the Archangell in a vi≈øion to build a Church in honor of the holy mother of God, and perpetuall virgin Mary. And allthough there is no doubt but the≈øe holy men were as the≈øe Antiquities te≈øtifie, obedient to the heauenly admonition; diuinis admonitionibus obedientes, and made all ha≈øte they could to perfect that holy worke, yet in that their greate penurye and want of things, nece≈ø≈øary to bring to effect, though it was neuer ≈øo poore or meane a building, yet ≈øome time mu≈øt needs pa≈ø≈øe, before it was ended: And all the≈øe things were done, the Chappell perfected in the fir≈øt yeare of their coming hither: Capellam con≈øummauerunt eodem anno quo in Britanniam mi≈øsi ≈øunt. Where we ≈øee litle, or no time, or lea≈øure for them to preach, if they had come, or bene ≈øent hither for that purpo≈øe. Neither was this Oratory, being ≈øo litle, as Hi≈øtories mention, and the Guliel. Malm. M. S. de Antiq. Coenob. Gla≈øt. Antiq. Gla≈øt. apud Capgrau. ≈øupr. M. S. de Antiq. Gla≈øt. in Tab. M. S. Chronic. apud Haris The atrum l. 1. Io. Leland. in A≈ø≈øert. Arthurij. Matth. Parker Antiquitat. Brit. pag. 3. & 4. Godwin Conuer≈ø. of Britaine cap. 2. pag. 9. Antiquit. & Hi≈øtorici ≈øupr. lamentable ruynes of it ≈øtill extant witnes, a place conuenient to preach vnto multitudes, and greate numbers, but onely an≈øwereable to the ≈ømall company of the≈øe holy Eremits. Which is al≈øo manife≈øtly proued, by the poore building thereof, being framed onely of writhen wands, virgis torquatis, and was neuer amended in any re≈øpect vntill the coming of the holy Legats of Pope Eleutherius hither, aboue an hundred yeares after, but ≈øo rude and de≈øolate, after the death of the≈øe Saints which builded it, that it was onely an harbour for wilde bea≈øts, and not for men: caepit idem locus e≈ø≈øe ferarum latibulum, qui prius fuerat habitatio Sanctorum. Therefore if the≈øe Eremits had conuerted any to the faith of Chri≈øt in that place, either very ≈ømall was their number, and habilitie, or le≈ø≈øe their deuotion, that neither during the life of the≈øe holy men, they ≈øought more to enlardge or beutifie that building, nor after their death had more reuerence vnto it, but let it be an abyding for Bea≈øts, and not for men.

4. Neither will any man of Iudgment e≈øteeme that Chappell (builded in ≈øuch a De≈øart, by fenns, wods, bushes, almo≈øt inacce≈ø≈øible vnto, & inhabitable) a preaching place, to conuert wanton and libertine pagans, to the lawe of
Chri≈øt: yet this was the manner of life and proceeding of S. Io≈øeph and his company, as ≈øo manye Antiquities haue proued vnto vs, and the auncient Poet recordeth in this order.

q.l: Intrat Aualoniam duodena caterua virorum, M. S. in Tabul. de Antiq. Gla≈øt. Capgrau. in S. Io≈øeph. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. & Bal. ibid. Caradorus M. S. de vita S. Gildae. Godwin Conuer≈ø. of Brit. pag. 9. cap. 2.
Flos Aramathiae Io≈øeph e≈øt primus eorum;
Io≈øephes ex Io≈øeph genitus patrem comitatur.

div.p: Where we ≈øee they willingely and of ≈øet purpo≈øe, and by entreatyes and petitions ≈øeque≈øtred them≈øelues from the world, to liue a ≈øolitary Religeous life, mured and intreÃÑched about with woods, and waters, as walles and Rampiers, in a little rude wildernes, where no other people then did or would liue. Which a Prote≈øtant Bishop thus confirmeth: the place where they principally ≈øetled them≈øelues, was euen there where Gla≈øtenbury now ≈øtandeth neere Welles, which being at that time and long after an I≈øland all compa≈ø≈øed about with Lakes, and ≈øtanding water, was giueÃÑ vnto them by the King of tho≈øe parts. Where we ≈øee them≈øelues with their priuiledges and Immunities confined onely within a litle rude and vnpeopled willdernes. Where no others inhabited, whether none could, or morally would haue acce≈ø≈øe to be in≈øtructed in the faith by them, nor they ea≈øily might or by their libertie being onely par≈øonall, and locall for them≈øelues in that place, could goe forth from thence to preach vnto others abroade: or if that had bene permitted, being all Iewes or of Countries of a ≈øtrange S. Io≈øeph and his companions brought eremiticall Mona≈øticall life and profe≈øsion into Britaine. languadge, both to Britans and Romans then the onely or cheife dwellers, and Inhabitants heare, and wanting all Interpreters, nor hauing the Miraculous gifts of tongues (for any thing we reade in Antiquitie) I cannot ≈øee, how they did or po≈ø≈øebly could profit much by preaching in this kingdome, neither can it be rea≈øonably thought, that the≈øe men came hither of purpo≈øe to preach, but to giue a beginning and introduction to the praying, Penitentiall, and contemplatiue Religeous life, otherwi≈øe they would not haue ≈øeated them≈øelues, and make ≈øuch ≈øutes, to obtaine their ≈øetling in a place ≈øo inconuenient by all de≈øcriptions before, and in lateribus ≈øuae regionis; in the Guliel. Malm. M. S. de Antiq. Coenob. Gla≈øt. Antiq. Gla≈øt. apud Capgrau. in S. Io≈øeph. & al. Matth. Parker Antiquit. Brit. pag. 3. Io. Leland in a≈ø≈øert. Arthurij. Godwin Conuer≈ø. of Brit. pag. 10. out≈øide of King Aruiragus Country, as William of Malmesbury, diuers Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury, Capgraue and others write, and by the fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury and his Authours, in Regionis ≈øuae finibus: in the very end of his Dominion, a place vnfit to conuert the whole Country, or great parts thereof, which Apo≈øtolike men Conuerters of kingdomes, haue euer endeauoured, and aymed at, when they fir≈øt ≈øetled them≈øelues in any Countrye, to conuert it to Chri≈øt.

div.head: THE XXVII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THAT S. IOSEPH DID NOT ACTVALLY conuert to the Chri≈øtian Religion, eyther King Aruiragus, Coillus or Marius.

div.p: 1. MVCH le≈ø≈øe can I be of their opinion, that ≈øeeme to hold, that S. Io≈øeph conuerted King Aruiragus, Marius, or Coillus to the faith of Chri≈øt. A late writer ≈øpeaking of King Aruiragus ≈øaith: Quidam Hi≈øtorici te≈øtantur, ip≈øe omnium Regum Britannorum Io. Pit≈øeus Rel. hi≈øtor. to. 1. aetat. 1. in Aruirago. primus, fidem Chri≈øti cum Sacramentis Chri≈øtianis, Chri≈øtianus factus ≈øu≈øcepit: ≈øome Hi≈øtorians witne≈ø≈øe that of all Brittish Kings he was the fir≈øt that being made a Christian receaued the faith of Chri≈øt with the Chri≈øtian Sacraments: An other thus plainely writeth of S. Io≈øeph: He conuerted to the Chri≈øtian Author of the Engl. Martyrol. 27. Iulij. in S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia. faith, Marius, and Coillus, ≈øonne and Nephew to King Aruiragus. The fir≈øt doth not affirme, that either S. Io≈øeph did Conuert Aruiragus, or that he was at all conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, but onely ≈øaith ≈øome Hi≈øtorians doe affirme, that he was a Chri≈øtian: And Ihon Harding is Authour, that he both was a Chi≈øtian and conuerted by S. Io≈øeph, and plainely alledgeth Nennius King Aruiragus was not a Chri≈øtiaÃÑ conuerted by S. Io≈øeph or any other. Ihon. Harding. Chronic. c. 47. f. 41. Authoritie of this opinion, thus he writeth.

lg.l: Io≈øeph conuerted this King Aruiragus,
By his preaching to knowe the lawe diuine,
And baptized him as written hath Nenius,
The Chronicler, in Britain tonguefull fine,
And to Chri≈øts lawe made him incline.
And gaue him then a shilde of ≈øiluer white,
A croi≈øe endlong and ouerthwart full perfecte.

div.p: Thus writeth this Authour, but without warrant for any thing I can finde, for whereas he citeth Nennius to haue written thus in the Brittish languadge, it is euident by all Antiquities, that Nennius which wrote in that tongue was Io. Bal. l. de≈øcrip. Brit. cent. 1. in Nennio Helio Io. Pit≈øeus l. de Illu≈øtrib. Britan. Scriptorib. aetate 1. in Nennio. Selden Illu≈øtr. of Polialbion p. 128 long before the birth of Aruiragus, or S. Io≈øeph, and dead 50. yeares before the Natiuitie of Chri≈øt, and was Brother to King Ludd and Ca≈ø≈øibelam, and was named Nennius Helius: And ≈øo he could not write any ≈øuch thing. The other Nennius called Banchoren≈øis, as all Authours agree, wrote onely in Latine, and con≈øequently could not write ≈øo in the Brittish tongue, as that Authour thinketh: and our be≈øt Prote≈øtant Antiquaries affirme they finde no ≈øuch thing in any copie of Nennius. Codices ij, quos con≈øului≈ø≈øe me Nennij antiquos contigit, huiu≈øce rei parum ≈øunt memores, and for Catholiks, I haue ≈øeene diuers affirme the ≈øame. Neyther is King Aruiragus, or S. Io≈øeph named by him. Neyther doth any Antiquary of ≈øound Iudgment ≈øo teach, from any for Nennius, or otherwi≈øe.

2. And if we had no other Arguments, or euidence, then that I haue remembred before of the De≈øart and de≈øolate place, allmo≈øt vnacce≈ø≈øible vnto, as M. S. de vita S. Gyldae. per Caradoc. both printed and Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtories tell vs, propter munitiones Arundineti, & fluminis, & paludis; ≈øo compa≈ø≈øed, and inuironed with Reeds, Riuer, and fennes, which was allowed to S. Io≈øeph, and his Chri≈øtian company, and a poore
Oratory builded by them≈øelues of ≈øuch ba≈øe Alder wands, as that fenny wilderne≈ø≈øe afforded, giueth ≈øufficient te≈øtimony how farre this King was from being a Chri≈øtian, that had nothing but ≈øuch abiect, and outca≈øte things, to allowe to Chri≈øt, and his ≈øeruants. When for the maintenance of the Pagan Idolatrie, which he profe≈ø≈øed, both as the Brittish Hi≈øtory, Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, Galfrid. Monum. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 4. cap. 15. 16. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 44. 73. Pont. Virun. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 4. Ponticus Virunnius, and others as well Prote≈øtants as Catholiks are witne≈ø≈øes, he was Authour of ≈øtately and ≈øumptuous buildings, and ≈øo farre from diminishing any honour that was then giuen to the fal≈øe Pagan Gods of the Idolatrous Britons, that he added more vnto them, namely worshipped the wicked Emperour Claudius (who≈øe Ba≈øtard Daughter he had taken as wife) as God, dedicated a co≈øtely Temple vnto him ≈øoone after his death, yet after this his acquaintance with S. Io≈øeph: for as I finde in an olde Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtorie, and others doe not di≈ø≈øent, the Citie of Gloce≈øter then Cair M. S. Hi≈øtor. Antiq. an. 66. Glou, the Citie of Glaudius, was builded by King Aruiragus in the yeare of Chri≈øt 66. Which was after the donation of priuiledge by Aruiragus to S. Io≈øeph 2. ot 3. yeares. And it mu≈øt needs be longer before the Idolatrous Matth. We≈øtm. an. D. 73. Galfr. Monumeten. Hi≈øt. Reg. Briton. l. 4. cap. 16. Pontic. Virun. Britan. Hi≈øt. l. 4. King Aruiragus liued and died a Pagan. Temple erected by him to the honour of Claudius was founded, and finished.

3. And to demon≈øtrate that he both liued and died a Pagan, this King Aruiragus was, & by his owne Order, buried in that Pagan Temple in the yeare of Chri≈øt 73. Tenne yeares after S. Io≈øephs coming hither. Aruiragus vt dies ≈øuos expleuit, ≈øepultus e≈øt Claudioce≈øtriae in quodam Templo quod in honore Claudij dedicauerat, & con≈øtruxerat. And Ponticus Virunnius further addeth, that he did euery moneth offer Sacrifice in that Temple, after the Pagans manner, ≈øo much he loued him: ≈øingulis men≈øibus ≈øacrificabat, tantum eum amore pro≈øequebatur. And it is further euident, by many Antiquities, that Aruiragus did many publike Acts, be≈øides this, which Chri≈øtian Religion cannot permit; as that after he had bene long time married to Voada, Si≈øter of Cataracus, King of the Scots, and had diuers children by her, he di≈øinherited the children, put away and Compabellus Cornelius Hybern. & Verem. apud Hect. Boeth. l. 3. Hi≈øt. Galfr. Hi≈øt. l. 4. cap. 14. Pontic. Virun. l. 4. Matth. We≈øtm. Antiq. 44. Stowe Hi≈øt. in Aruiragus. Bal. l. Script. Brit. cent. 1. in Aruiragus Ioh. Pit≈øeus de V ‚Ä¢ r. illu≈øtr. aetat. ‚Ä¢ . in Arui ‚Ä¢ ago. Gu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ el. Malm. l. de Antiquit. Gla≈øton. M. S. Capgrau. in Catalog. M. S. Io≈øeph ab Aram. Antiquit. Gla≈øton. apud eundem. impri≈øoned the mother, & Marryed Genue≈ø≈øe, the ≈øuppo≈øed Ba≈øtard Daughter of Claudius, and kept her, the other yet liuing, and left the kingdome to Marius her ≈øonne: And was ≈øo farre from repenting this Barbarous Act, contrary to Chri≈øtian Religion, that being chalenged for that Impietie, he wrote a Booke in defence of this his wickednes; affirming therein, that it was lawfull for him to haue pluralitie of wiues, becau≈øe neither the Roman, nor Britan Pagan Lawes as he auouched, denied that to Princes, neuer ≈øpeaking of, or regarding the lawe of Chri≈øt, and in this ≈øtate he liued and died.

4. Moreouer all Antiquaries what≈øoeuer, of any credit, tell vs plainely that Aruiragus was no Chri≈øtian but ≈øtill per≈øi≈øted in his Pagan Religion. Fir≈øt William of Malmes bury ≈øaith: Rex qui tunc regnabat fuit Barbarus, & praedicationi eorum con≈øentire noluit, nec paternas Traditiones commutare volebat: The King which then reigned, was a Pagan, and would not con≈øent to their preaching, nor would he change his Auncestours Traditions. The Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury, Capgraue, and many other auncients write: Rex Barbarus cum ≈øua gente tam noua audiens, & incon≈øueta, nec paternas volens in meli√πs commutare Traditiones, praedicationi eorum renuebat: The Pagan King with his people, hearing ≈øuch new and vnaccuctomed things, as S. Io≈øeph and his fellowes taught, would not change his Aunce≈øtours Traditions for the better, but refu≈øed their preaching. The fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury with his Prote≈øtant followers, affirmeth: Qorum praedicatione Rex Aruiragus cum Proceribus ≈øuis ab inueterata Druidum
Religione abduci noluit: King Aruiragus with his Nobles would not by the preaching of Io≈øeph, and his companions, be drawne from the inueterate Religion of the Druids. Thus we ≈øee it manife≈øtly declared that King Aruiragus was in all his actions, life, and death, farre from being a Chri≈øtian in profe≈ø≈øion.

5. Now let vs examine, whether, as that late Authour ≈øaith, S. Io≈øeph conuerted Neyther King Marius, or Coillus was a Chri≈øtian. King Marius and Coillus to the Chri≈øtian faith: for this he bringeth no rea≈øon, or Argument at all, but onely in the Margent there citeth, as teaching that opinion, Ihon Capgraue, Polydor Virgill, Camden and Harp≈øfeld: but not any one of the≈øe ≈øo affirmeth but the contrary. Capgraue in the place by him cited, calleth them, duo Pagani Reges Marius & Coillus; Two Pagan Capgrau. in Vita S. Io≈øeph. CamdeÃÑ in Rom. in Aruirago. Polydor. Virg. l. 2. Hi≈øt. Angl. p. 41. Kings Marius, and Collius, ≈øo Camden maketh them longe after S. Io≈øephs time, and auoucheth King Lucius Sonne of Coillus to haue bene our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King. So doth Polydor Virgill, thus plainely te≈øtifiing of Lucius: Britannorum Regum primus Christianus factus est: he was the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian of the Brittish Kings. Harpsfeld ≈øaith, that neither Aruiragus, Marius, or Coillus the Kings which followed did embrace the ReligioÃÑ of Io≈øeph and his coÃÑpanions: Aruiragus caeteri
que Principes eum ≈øecuti et≈øi eorum ReligioneÃÑ non amplecterentur, mole≈øti eis non fueruÃÑt, immo Harpsf. Hi≈øt. Eccl. Angl. p. 3. virtutes eoruÃÑ admirati, beneficijs auxeruÃÑt. But onely were not troble≈øome vnto theÃÑ, & admiring their vertues be≈øtowed benefits vpoÃÑ them. Which no maÃÑ denieth: but this is farre froÃÑ ≈øaying S. Io≈øeph conuerted to the Chri≈øtiaÃÑ faith Marius, & Coillus Engl. Martyrol. in S. Io≈øeph. 27. Iulij. Sonne and Nephew to King Aruiragus; the words of that Authour from the≈øe writers, as he ≈øeemeth to pretend by his citing them. And if we should follow either the computation of Sir william Camden, the be≈øt Antiquary our Prote≈øtants euer had, or others of that Religion, we should make it vnpo≈ø≈øible, that any of the≈øe should be conuerted by S. Io≈øeph. For fir≈øt Sir Camden would haue them to haue liued long after the Age of S. Io≈øeph. And for the Bal. l. de Script. Britan. centur. 1. in Io≈øeph Aram. & in Aruirag. Catal. Reg. Brit. ante Hi≈øt. Brit. in Mario. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 72. Polydor. Virgil. l. 2. hi≈øt. p. 38. re≈øt they agree in this, that King Marius and yet a Pagan ouerliued S. Io≈øeph. To which computation Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, Polydor Virgill, and others doe not di≈ø≈øent. And concerning King Coillus, he was ab Infantia, euen from his Infancy, by all writers brought vp at Rome, and came not into Britaine while he came hither to reigne as King, many yeares by all accompts after S. Io≈øeph was dead. And ≈øo by no po≈ø≈øibilitie could he be conuerted to the Chri≈øtian faith in Britaine by S. Io≈øeph. What di≈øpotion or Inclination the≈øe had to the faith of Chri≈øt, I will intreate when I come to their dayes hereafter, in the meane time, William of Malmesbury in his Manu≈øcript of Gla≈øtenbury, all other Antiquities of that place, and Hi≈øtoryes as before generaly ≈øay, the≈øe three were Reges Pagani: Pagan Kings, which Harding him≈øelfe confe≈ø≈øeth of Marius, and Coillus, though friends to Chri≈øtian Religion, neither doth Guliel. Malm. M. S. de Antiq. Gla≈øton. Harding Chron. in Marius and Coillus. he affirme, that Aruiragus was a Chri≈øtian, but alledgeth Nennius (wherein he ≈øeemeth to haue bene deceaued) to be of that opinion. And the Authour which before would haue King Marius and Coillus to be conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt by S. Io≈øeph, doth in an other place with the con≈øent of Hi≈øtoryes name S. Lucius the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King of Britany. Therefore Marius and Coillus could not by his opinion, without contradiction, be Chri≈øtian Kings, Engl. Martyrol. die 3. Decembr. nor either of them a King Chri≈øtian before him, otherwi≈øe he had not bene the fir≈øt, but third or ≈øecond in that order, and degree.

6. And if King Marius had bene a Chri≈øtian, or inclined to that holy Religion, it carrieth no probability, that he learned it of S. Io≈øeph: for as Harding with others witne≈ø≈øeth, he was of a child brought vp at Rome with the Emperour Claudius, and his mothers kindred.

q.l: Who norished was at Rome in his Iuuente
With his mothers kinne the best of th'Empire Hard. Chronic. in Marius c. 49. fol. 41.
With Claudius al≈øo, that was his owne Grand≈øire.

div.p: And not returning into Britaine vntill the death of Aruiragus his father, to inherite the kingdome after him, for any thing we reade in Hi≈øtoryes; and by the common computation of Antiquities, King Aruiragus and S. Io≈øeph dying within three yeares together, it is not a thing to be ea≈øily beleeued, Matth. We≈øtm. an. 73. Bal. cent. 1. in Aruirag. & Io≈øeph Aram. that Marius did or could learne Chri≈øtianitie of S. Io≈øeph. Neither did, or could Chri≈øtian Religion allow Marius, a notorions knowne Ba≈øtard, to Inherite the kingdome of Britaine, as Heire to King Aruiragus, he hauing diuers legittimate children by his lawfull wi≈øe, Voada daughter of King Caratacus. Hector Boeth. Scotor. hi≈øt. l. 3. f. 41. Ex qua filium vnum & duas filias ≈øu≈øceperat. All which by Chri≈øtian Religion should haue inherited before them, and he, whether they had bene lyuing or dead, by that could not claime Title to inherite, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe the Crowne of Britaine as he did. And the Scottish Hi≈øtorians who had be≈øt rea≈øons Hector Boeth. from the Scottish antiqu. Scohi≈øt. l. 4. fol. 58. Stowe hi≈øt. Romans in Marius. to keepe the≈øe things in memory, doe tell vs, that he was ≈øo farre a Roman, as by all Antiquities, by his mother and education he truely was, they ≈øtile him Marius a Roman: Marius nobilis Romanus. And he was ≈øo farre from hauing any true Title to the Crowne by being the Ba≈øtard ≈øonne of Aruiragus, that he was declared king by the Emperors Authoritie, Cae≈øaris Authoritate Britonum Rex appellatus; and to take all controuer≈øie away, was forced to marry his owne Si≈øter by Father the elde≈øt dughter of Aruiragus and his lawfull wife Queen Voada: Harum natu maiorem, vt iam inde In≈øulae ≈øtatus pacatior foret Matrimonio ≈øibi copulauit. Which all meÃÑ knowe no Chri≈øtian could doe. And yet this was after the greate victory of Marius again≈øt the Scots, and Picts with their Captaine Roderike, which was as Matthew We≈øtmin≈øter Matth. We≈øtm. an. D. 75. Bal. ceÃÑt. 1. in Io≈øeph Ara. and others write, not aboue a yeare before the death of S. Io≈øeph, that chancing in the 75. and this in the 76. yeare of Chri≈øt. In which Battaile the two Daughters of Queene Voada, their Brother as it ≈øeemeth being dead, were taken Pri≈øoners, and the elde≈øt the next Heire of Britaine, after the matters pacified, which was not in any probabilitie before S. Io≈øephs death, was as I haue ≈øaid before, marryed to Marius her Ba≈øtard Brother. Which marriadge (if I may ≈øo terme it) was ≈øtill continued, & by them was begotten in it Coillus after King, and Father to our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King S. Lucius.

7. So that if we ≈øpeake properly, and ≈øtrictly of Chri≈øtians, and name them onely ≈øuch which actually, and really both in faith, and profe≈ø≈øion, doe hold, onely the Chri≈øtian Religion, and no other, it is euident that none of the≈øe three Kings of Britaine, Aruiragus, Marius, or Coillus was a Chri≈øtian, much le≈ø≈øe conuerted or bapti≈øed by S. Io≈øeph. But if we ≈øpeake of Chri≈øtiantie In what ≈øen≈øe the≈øe Kings may largely be termed Chri≈øtians. in a more ample and exteÃÑded ≈øen≈øe, as Tertullian and ≈øome other auncients haue done, of Tyberius, Caius, and ≈øome other Emperours, not actually Chri≈øtians, but ≈øo affected e≈øpecially in ≈øome points, and as he doth of Pilate, Tertullian. Apol. aduer≈øus gentes. Matth. c. 27. v. 24 which washed his hands, and ≈øaid he was innocent of the putting of Chri≈øt to death, Innocens ≈øum a ≈øanguine huius: I am Innocent of the blood of this iu≈øt par≈øon: that he was, in con≈øciens a Chri≈øtian, pro ≈øua con≈øcientia Chri≈øtianus, we may ≈øpeake the like of the≈øe Kings. And goe≈øo farre with Hardings Authour, as to ≈øay with him.

q.l: Io≈øeph conuerted this King Aruiragus
By his preaching to knowe the lawe diuine.

div.p:
For it is not vnprobable, but he was per≈øwaded, the Lawe and Religion
which S. Io≈øeph profe≈ø≈øed was true. But whereas Harding addeth.

q.l: And bapti≈øed him as written hath Nennius,
The Chronicler in Britaine tongue full fine.

div.p: Except we take bapti≈øing in a very lardge, and Poeticall amplifying con≈øtruction, and ≈øay Harding a Poet did thereby vnder≈øtand the true knowledge of Bapti≈øme, and not the receauing thereof, neither Nennius nor any approued Authour doth, or can proue any ≈øuch thing. By this al≈øo we are ≈øufficiently a≈ø≈øured, that neither S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, nor any of his company, though otherwi≈øe mo≈øt holy and renowned Saints, and excellently de≈øeruing of this NatioÃÑ, none of them conuerting either the King, Nobles, or people of Britaine, as ≈øo many worthie Authours, and Antiquities haue told vs, may be named the Apo≈øtle, which conuerted this kingdome to the faith of Chri≈øt, or fir≈øt founded Chri≈øtian Religion heare.

div.head: THE XXVIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: IN WHAT REVEREND SENSE S. IOSEPH of Aramathia is termed Apo≈øtle, by ≈øome holy Fathers, the renowned ≈øanctity of him, and his companions, together with ≈øome particular points of their holy Religion, now denyed by ≈øome, but euen from their time to this, Miraculou≈øly approued.

div.p:
1. BVT allthouh S. Io≈øeph was not in the common ≈øen≈øe, an Apo≈øtle properly vnto this Nation, yet we may not depriue him of his due honours; among which, one, as S. Hilary writeth, was to enioy the name of an Apo≈øtle, in an other, yet mo≈øt honorable con≈øtruction, and meaning, after the S. Io≈øeph how named an Apo≈øtle. ≈øame manner as he al≈øo calleth S. Io≈øeph husband to the ble≈ø≈øed virgin, an Apo≈øtle: becau≈øe as the Apo≈øtles did beare Chri≈øt about into the world, by their preaching, ≈øo the≈øe more really and per≈øonally carried him in their armes. The one in his Infancy into Egipt, this other to his ≈øacred ≈øepulchre. Io≈øeph enim Apo≈øtolorum habet ≈øpeciem, quibus Chri≈øtus circumferendus e≈øt creditus, Hilar. comment. in Matth. can. 33. & idcirco quanquam in duodecim Apo≈øtolorum numero non fuerit, Di≈øcipulus Domini nuncupatur. The other Apo≈øtles and bearers of Chri≈øt were diuers, but this Apo≈øtolike or Chri≈øt-bearing dignitie to take the ble≈ø≈øed body of our Sauiour from the holy Cro≈ø≈øe, ≈øo ≈øolemnely to carry it vnto, & bury it in the ≈øacred ≈øepulchre, was a peculiar honour and prerogatiue to this S. Io≈øeph, and regi≈øtred by all the foure Euangeli≈øts for this his mo≈øt heroicall Act of Chri≈øtian Matth. c. 27. v. 57 58. 59. 60. Marc. c. 15. v. 43. Luc. c. 23. v. 50. Ioa. c. 19. v. 38. 39. 4. charitie and magnamitie with greate≈øt honour: and not without iu≈øt de≈øert, ≈øeeing at that time, when all the properly named Apo≈øtles, as Chri≈øt had foretold them, were offended becau≈øe of him, (as our Prote≈øtants tan≈ølate) for≈øooke him and fled, this mo≈øt holy and valiant Apo≈øtle, Saint and Souldiar of Chri≈øt, went boldly vnto the Pre≈øident, that had condemned him, asked, obtained, Matth. c. 26. v. 31. 65. and buried his ≈øacred body, with ≈øo greate pompe, and honour, as the Euangeli≈øts haue remembred. For which his greate and ≈øingular faith, and beleife
in Chri≈øt, and loue of him, the malice of the Iewes was ≈øo vehemently incen≈øed again≈øt him, as the Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury, Vincentius, Drogo Epi≈øcopus Antiq. Gla≈øt. apud Capgr. in S. Io≈øeph. Drogo Ep. Ho≈øtien. hi≈øt. de morte & Re≈øurrect. Saluat. Greg. Turon. l. 1. hi≈øt. Franc. ¬ß. 22. p. 18. Vincent. ≈øpecul. hi≈øt. l. 5. c. 56. 57. 58. Euang. a≈øcript. Nicod. Acta Pilati apud Greg. Tur. ≈øupr. & al. Ho≈øtien≈øis, Gregorius Turonen≈øis, the Gho≈øpel a≈øcribed to Nicodemus, who a≈ø≈øi≈øted him in that holy action, the publike Acts of Pilate founde and examined by Theodo≈øius the Emperor, and other Authours, and Monuments beare te≈øtimonie, that they pre≈øently incloa≈øed him a clo≈øe Pri≈øoner in an obcure Cell, & watched him by the high Prei≈øts them≈øelues, hating him more, then they hated Chri≈øt him≈øelfe.

2. Yet he was miraculou≈øly deliuered from thence, to the greate amazement and confu≈øion of his Per≈øecutors: and hauing ≈øolemnized the A≈ø≈øumptioÃÑ of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary with the Apo≈øtles, renowncing all his worldly wealth, and terreene honour, his freinds, CouÃÑtry, Ritches, aduentured ≈øo long; tedious and dangerous a Iorney after S. Peter into this parte of the worlde, to liue and die in contemplation of the My≈øteries of his Ma≈øters Religion, in a corner of an Iland, where at that time litle or nothing at all was to be founde fit for the v≈øe of man, and thereby was the fir≈øt Founder of Eremiticall Religeous life in this Nation, and was by permi≈ø≈øion of King Aruiragus one of the builders and the principall among them, of the fir≈øt publikly allowed Church to the Ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary, and the fir≈øt ≈øetled knowne Altar for Prei≈øts to con≈øecrate and offer the ble≈ø≈øed body and blood of Chri≈øt, proprio ore Antiquit. Gla≈øt. apud Godwin Conu. p. 11. Capgrau. Cat. in S. Patricio f. 264. p. 1. col. 1. conficere, as the Antiquities of that holy place with other Monuments are ≈øufficient witnes. Their conuer≈øa≈øion was in that place, deuoutely to ≈øerue God, and the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary, wholly conuer≈øant in watchings, fa≈øtings, and prayers: duodecim ≈øancti praedicti in eodem loco Deo & beatae Virgini deuota exhibentes ob≈øequia, vigilijs, Ieiunijs, & orationibus vacantes. So much the≈øe holy men were honored for the≈øe ob≈øequies euen froÃÑ heauen it ≈øelfe, that no meaner, nor inferiour Angels, Prayer and dutie to the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary by S. Io≈øeph. nor any other but the ≈øame ArchaÃÑgel Gabriel which ≈øaluted the ble≈ø≈øed virgin with the happy tydings of Chri≈øts Incarnation, for which he was cho≈øen and ≈øent me≈ø≈øenger from God vnto her, was al≈øo ≈øent to them, to admonish and Antiq. Gla≈øt. apud Capgr. in S. Patric. l. 5. Io≈øeph Guliel. Malm. l. antiquit. Caenob. Gla≈øton. Leland. in A≈ø≈øert. Arthur. M. S. apud Harris Theatr. l. 1. c. 25. in≈øtruct them to build a Church in honour of this ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary Mother of God, and appointed them the place it ≈øelfe: Ibidem Deo ≈øeruientes, per Gabrielis Archangeli admonitionem, Eccle≈øiam in honore ≈øanctae Dei genetricis Mariae contruxerunt: Loco eius caelitus demonstrato. And as they were mo≈øt dutifull to Chri≈øt, and aboue all Saints, to his ble≈ø≈øed Mother, ≈øo neither of their helps and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance was wanting vnto them, for not onely Chri≈øt dayly and continually pre≈øerued and comforted them, in their difficulties, but the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin did extraordinarily a≈ø≈øi≈øt and ayde them in their nece≈ø≈øities. Eiu≈ødem Virginis Det genetricis auxilio in nece≈øsitatibus ≈øuis refocillabantur. And as Chri≈øt and his ble≈ø-Mother The ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary Protecteth S. Io≈øeph & his companions. gaue them the≈øe comforts, and con≈øolations from heauen for them≈øelues, and te≈øtimonye to others then of their ≈øanctitie, and holy Religion; So they giue continued witnes thereof to this day by yearely, and miraculous te≈øtimonie in the ≈øame place. For in the very place where S. Io≈øeph with two others of his holy company fir≈øt re≈øted their weary bodies, vpon an Hill with in a myle of Gla≈øtenbury, as the pre≈øerued Tradition of the Inhabitants there affirmeth, and therevpon in our languadge named weary-all Hill, there A wh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e Thorne at Gla≈øtenburie buddeth forth both leaues and flowers at Chri≈øtma≈ø≈øe. ≈øprunge vp, and ≈øtill groweth a miraculous Thorne Tree, of that kinde & ≈øpecies, in all naturall re≈øpects, which we terme a whyte Thorne, called v≈øually, euen by the Prote≈øtants which inhabite there, the holy Thorne, which euery yeare at Chri≈øtma≈ø≈øe in the colde≈øt yeares and weather, firo≈øt, ≈ønowe, or what ≈øoeuer, neuer fayling, buddeth forth both leaues, and flowers. The blomes
and branches where of are carryed as miraculous remembrances by the Marchants of Bri≈øtolle, not farre thence, into forrein Nations.

3. And not without greate warrant therefore doth a Prote≈øtant Antiquarie Selden Illu≈øtrat. vpon. Poly Olbion 3. Songe. p. 54. write: It goes for currant truth that a Hawthorne thereby, on Chri≈øtma≈ø≈øe daye allwayes blo≈ø≈øometh. You may ca≈øt this into the accomt of your greate≈øt wonders. And againe: worthely famous was the Abbay of Gla≈øtenbury from Io≈øeph of Aramathia, that noble Coun≈øeller, as S. Marke cals him, buried there. And a Prote≈øtant Poet thus.

l.hi: O three times happy Ile where is that place that might
Be with thy ≈øelf compard, for glory and delight,
While≈øt Gla≈øtenbury ≈øtood?
O who thy Ruynes ≈øee, whom wonder doth not fill,
With our greate Fathers pompe, deuotion and their skill?
Thow more then mortall power (this Iudgment rightly wayd)
Then pre≈øent to a≈øsi≈øt, at that foundation layd:
On whome for this ≈øad wa≈øte, should Iu≈øtice lay the cryme?
Is there a power in Fate, or doth it yeeld to time?
Or was their error ≈øuch, that thow could≈øt not protect
Tho≈øe buildings which thy hand did with their zeale erect?
To whom didst thow commit, that monument to keepe,
That ≈øuffereth with the dead their memory to ≈øleepe?
When not greate Arthurs Tombe, nor holy Io≈øephs graue
From ≈øacriledg had power their ≈øacred bones to ≈øaue:
He who that God in man to his Sepulchre brought,

lg.l: Or he which for the faith 12. famous battels foug ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ .

l.hi: What? Did ≈øo many Kings doe honour to that place,
For Auarice at la≈øt ≈øo vgly to deface?
For Reuerence to that ≈øtate which hath a≈ø≈øcribed bene,
Trees yet in wynter bloome, and beare their Sommers greene.

div.p: And noteth in his margyn thus: The wonderfull Tree at Gla≈øtenbury. And iu≈øtly may the≈øe men write in this manner, and further of this great wonderfull thing: for except my Iudgment with many be deceaued therein, it is one of the greate≈øt wonders, and continued miracles in the world, by my reading, if we con≈øider but a few of many circum≈øtances thereof. It groweth vpon an Hill in a Pa≈øture, bare, and naked of other Trees, for shade and shelter for cattaile feeding there, by rea≈øon whereof the Pa≈øture being greate and cattaile many, rounde about the Tree the grownde is as bare and beaten, as any highe way, flore, or coÃÑtinually trodden place; the Trunke of the Tree being as greate as the ordinary body of a man, is ≈øo cut and mangled rounde about in the barke by engrauing the letters of peoples names re≈øorting thither, to ≈øee that wonder, that a wonder in Nature it is, how the ≈øap and nutrument should be diffu≈øed from the roote, to the bowes and branches thereof, which al≈øo be ≈øo maimed and broken of by the coÃÑmers thither, to carry them away for shew, and maruaile, that a maruaile it is, how it can continue any vegetation or growing at all; And yet the armes and bowes are ≈øpred and dilated in a circular manner as farre, or farther then other Trees freed from ≈øuch impediments of like proportion, bearing the Hawes, fruites of that kinde, as fully and plentifully as others doe, of which I haue bene an eye witnes and ob≈øeruer.

4. And to make euident Te≈øtimony that the≈øe and ≈øuch effects are miracuous and haue no cau≈øe in Nature, but proceede from a ≈øupernaturall Agent, &
worker to witnes the holines of the≈øe Saints, and their Religion. This holy
A Prote≈øtant punished by God for endeuoring to cut downe the fore≈øaid Thorne. Part of the ≈øame Thorne florished as before though cut of from the bodie. A wallnut tree miraculou≈øly buddeth forth at Gla≈øtenburie on S. Barnabas daye: Cro≈ø≈øes and other Chri≈øtian picturs made by S. Io≈øeph and his company. Antiquit. Gla≈øt. M. S. tabulis ligneis affix. in meÃÑ branis. Holy Reliks brought hither, & reuerenced by S. Io≈øeph. M. S. antiq. de vit. S. Io≈øephi. Capgrau. in eodem. Melkin in S. Io≈øeph. Antiq. Gla≈øt. tabul. Fix. Antiquit. quondaÃÑ in Mona≈øter. S. Edmundi in Suffolc. & S. Augu≈øtini Cantuar. Theater of great Brit. Cat. of Rerelig. Hou≈øes Richard. Gibbonus Catalog. Religioa≈ø. aedium in Comit. Somer≈øetten. L. vlt. de Pagan. C. Theod. & l. Decernimus C. de Epi≈øc. & Cler. nouel. 117. c. 7. ex Iulian. & Con≈øt. 1. c. 1. Auth. coll. 5 tit. 17. Ord. Rom. de diuin. offic. c. deaedif. Eccl. pag. 107. Prudent. ‚Ä¢ ym. 5. de S. Vincent. & 12. de pa≈ø≈øionib. Apo≈øt. & al. apud Bar. To. 2. Annal. & die 26. Iulij. Thorne (as the Prote≈øtants them≈øelues there name it) had within the memory of diuers, there lyuing ≈øo te≈øtifing vnto me two Trunkes, or Bodyes, the other of a greater bigne≈ø≈øe, and a prophane Prote≈øtant endeuouring to cut downe the greate≈øt, and likely both, if God had not miraculou≈øly preuented his wicked de≈øignement, was extraordinarily punished by cutting his legge, and one of the chips which he hewed of, flying vp to his head put out one of his eyes, was enforced to de≈øi≈øt, yet hauing cut downe the greater Trunke onely, except a litle of the barke on the one ≈øide, this body of the tree ≈øo ≈øeperated from the roote, and lying vpon the grounde 30. yeares together, ≈øtill continued the miraculous florishing as the other did, and ≈øtill doth: and being after taken quite away, and ca≈øt into a ditch farre of from the place, it likewi≈øe florished and budded as it v≈øed before. And after that yeare it was quite ≈øtollen away, not knowne by whome or whether, as the old people there affirmed. There is al≈øo the remnant of a miraculous wallnut Tree neare S. Io≈øephs Chappell, the ≈øtocke remayning ≈øtill alyue with a few ≈ømall bowes, the re≈øt cut away, which neuer buddeth forth vntill the Fea≈øt of S. Barnabas the Apo≈øtle, commonly e≈øteemed the longe≈øt day, and then it ≈øodaynely florisheth as much as others of that kinde, of which I haue ≈øpoaken before from the Prote≈øtant Bishop of that place Doctor Montague. That which is left of this Tree keepeth the ≈øame miraculous cour≈øe euery yeare in florishing, and bringing forth of leaues, but no other frute, of nutts, the braunches being, when I ≈øawe it of late yeares, too ≈ømall, younge and tender to bring them forth or ≈øu≈øtaine their weight.

5. The≈øe holy men among other memoryes of their holy Chri≈øtian profe≈ø≈øion made, v≈øed, and left there, the Picture of the Crucifixe, and other holy Images to te≈øtifie to po≈øteritie they were Chri≈øtians by Religion, which there inhabited. Figuram no≈øtrae Redemptionis aliasque figuras manife≈øtas repererunt, quibus bene cognouerunt, quod Chri≈øtiani prius locum inhabitarunt. which remained there vntill the coming of tho≈øe Apo≈øtolike men, which Saint Eleutherius Pope ≈øent hither in King Lucius his time. There they kept with greate reuerence (which with like deuotion they brought ≈øo farre with them) two ≈ømall ≈øiluer ve≈ø≈øels filled with the blood and ≈øweate of our ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour. Duo va≈øcula alba & argentea cruore prophetae Ie≈øu perimpleta. There they left a Succe≈ø≈øion of the fir≈øt and mo≈øt holy Religeous men, continuing (except in one part of the ≈øecond Age) by ≈øome vntill S. Dun≈øtan his time, by all, many hundreds of yeares, after the Saxons coming hither, and were renowned in all NatioÃÑs in the time of the Romans, the Britans and diuers Ages of the Pagan Saxons, as al≈øo after they were Chri≈øtians, in and after S. Augu≈øtine his dayes: as I shall deliuer at large when I come to that Age. The≈øe two Religeous memories, the ve≈ø≈øels of ≈øweaty blood of Chri≈øt, and the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe found in that holy place, gaue inuincible te≈øtimony it was the Re≈øidency and habitation of ble≈ø≈øed S. Io≈øeph, and his holy company, none but good Chri≈øtians, reuerent pre≈øeruers of ≈øuch Relicks, and en≈øignes, and as appeareth by the auncient lawes and monuments heare cited, no Church founded by Chri≈øtians but with a Cro≈ø≈øe or Cro≈ø≈øes erected there, euen in tho≈øe fir≈øt happye times, as a Title and memory.

div.head: THE XXIX. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN IS SHEWED HOW OVR PROtestant Antiquaries and others of England vehemently contending to proue that S. Paule the Apo≈øtle preached heare in Britaine, doe proue no ≈øuch thing, by any Authorities, they alledge for his being heare.

div.p: 1. IT is a common opinion of our English Prote≈øtant Antiquaries, and others of that Religion, that S. Paule preached heare in Britaine, but the te≈øtimonies and Authorities vpon which Prote≈øtants Arguments and authorities for S. Paules preaching in Britaine examined. they ordinaly build, doe not in my Iugment proue any ≈øuch thing of him in particular, more then of the other Apo≈øtles. Their fir≈øt Archbishop of Canterbury thus pleadeth for S. Paul: Paulum ip≈øum gentium Doctorem, cum alijs gentibus tum nominatim Britannis Euangelium nuntia≈ø≈øe po≈øt priorem ≈øuam Romae incarcerationem, & Theodoretus & Sophronius Patriacha Matth. Parker. Antiq. Brit. p. 2. Lib. de curandis GraecoruÃÑ affect. Hiero≈øolymitanus affirmant: both Theodoret and Sophronius patriarke of Hieru≈øalem doe affirme that Paule him≈øelf, Doctor of the gentils did preach the Gho≈øpell to other Nations, and namely to the Britans, after his fir≈øt impri≈øonment at Rome. The Prote≈øtant Authours of their greate Theater of greate Theat. of greate Brit. l. 6. c. 9. Britaine, thus write of S. Paules being heare: who doubtle≈ø≈øe after his fir≈øt relea≈øement from Rome, confirmed the doctrine to the≈øe westerne parts of the world, and among them, as may appeare, to this Iland of Britaine, as both Sophronius Patriarke of Hieru≈øalem, and Theodoret an anncient Doctor of the Church doe affirme, and proue, ≈øaying that Fishers, Publicans, and the Tentmaker (meaning S. Paule) which brough the Euangelicall light vnto all Nations, reuealed the ≈øame vnto the Britans. Sir william Camden a principall Antiquarie ≈øpeaking of S. Peters preaching heare, ioyneth al≈øo S. Peter with him in the≈øe words: Petrus etiam Camden Brit. in Sommer≈øetshire ip≈øe huc penetrauit & diuini verbi lumen diffudit, vti etiam Paulus, teste Sophronio & Theodoreto po≈øt ≈øecundam Romae Incarcerationem: Al≈øo Peter him≈øelf came hither, and diffu≈øed the light of the diuine worde, as al≈øo Paule, as Sophronius and Theodoret te≈øtifie after his ≈øecond Impri≈øonment at Rome. Al≈øo Andre du Che≈øne in his Andre de Che≈øne hi≈øt. d'Anglet. E≈øco≈ø≈øe & Hiberne p. 152. Stowe hi≈øt. Romans. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Eng. Harri≈ø. de≈øcript. of Britaine. Author of 3. CoÃÑuer≈ø. part. 1. p. 21. 22. ¬ß. 22. Engl. Martyrol. die 25. Ianuar. French Hi≈øtorie of England, Scotland, and Ireland ≈øaith: S. Paule came hither apres ≈øe ≈øecond pri≈øon a Rome: after his ≈øecond Impri≈øonment at Rome. And citeth for this his opinion Theodoret, and Sophronius, as the alledged English Prote≈øtants haue done before, of which opinion and vpon the ≈øame Authoritie are other English Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians, as Stowe, Holinshed, and Harri≈øon.

2. To whome I add two late Catholiks, Authours of the Three Conuer≈øions, and the English Martyrologe both of them relying vpon the ≈øame Fathers Authoritie, and Arnoldus Miramannius, whome they al≈øo mi≈øtake as the others, contending to proue from him that S. Paule came hither in the fourth yeare of Nero the Emperor, which he affirmeth not, and who≈øoeuer ≈øo teacheth, or with our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries before, that S. Paule came
hither vpon his libertie from his fir≈øt Inpri≈øonment in Rome, quite ouer turneth his being heare at all, as I shall demon≈øtrate in the Chapter following, which perhaps the Gatherer of the English Martirologe ob≈øerued, and therefore Die Iunij. 29. contradicteth him≈øelfe; concerning this coming of S. Paul into Britaine in an other place, making it to fall out in the 67. yeare of Chri≈øt, which was Matth. We≈øt. an. gratiae 67. Godwin Conu. of Brit. p. 7. Godwin ≈øupr. p. 6. Hieron. in cap. 5. Amos. Godwin Conu. ≈øupr. p. 7. Theat. of great Brit. l. 6. c. 9. Engl. Mart. 25. Ianuar. by common accompt the la≈øt yeare of the Empire of Nero. And to carry Prote≈øtants con≈øent with me, a Bishop of their profe≈ø≈øion, ≈øpeaking of tho≈øe, which ≈øay S. Paule came hither in the fourth yeare of Nero, according to truth of Hi≈øtory, thus affirmeth: it cannot be, but he is mi≈øtaken, this Prote≈øtant citeth S. Hierome vpon the 5. Chapter of Amos the Prophet inclining to bring S. Paule hither, but the place being examined, proueth no ≈øuch thing, S. Hierome there onely ≈øpeaking, as diuers others of the holy and auncient Fathers doe, of the greate labours of S. Paule, but nothing at all of his coming either into, or neare our Britaine. Wherefore this Prote≈øtant Bishop leauing S. Hierome, as vnprofitable to his purpo≈øe, catcheth hold of Theodoret, as his fellowes did before, in this maÃÑner: But Theodoret ≈øome what more plainely to the ≈øame purpo≈øe, when S. Paul, ≈øaith he, vpon his Appeale being ≈øent to Rome by Fe≈øtus, was heard, and vpon his hearing acquitted, and ≈øet at libertie, he trauailed into Spaine, and making excur≈øion vnto other Nations, brought vnto them the light of heauenly doctrine. Againe Paule, ≈øaith he, extended his trauailes into Italy, and Spaine, profiting al≈øo the Ilands that lye in the Sea. And la≈øtly that we may not doubt, in the≈øe kind of ≈øpeaches (other Nations, and the I≈ølands that lye in the Sea) he had an ayme at our Britaine: in an other place he ≈øaith plainely and expre≈ø≈øely, (as I finde it cited In p≈øal. 116. l. 9. de curand. Graec. affect. by N. D.) that he preached in Britaine. The ≈øame ≈øeemeth, to be confirmed (if happely he v≈øed not, poetica licentia) by venantius a Chri≈øtian Poet, yet very auncient, that de≈øcribing the trauailes of S. Paule writeth of him thus.

lg.l: Tran≈øijt Oceanum, vel qua facit In≈øula portum,
Qua≈øque Britannus habet terras, qua≈øque vltima Thule.
He cro≈øt the Seas vnto the land, and vtmo≈øt Coa≈øts of Thule
Arryuing at the Ports and Iles, where Britans bare the Rule.

div.p: For ≈øo doe our Prote≈øtant Authours of the greate Theater alledge, and tran≈ølate that auncient Chri≈øtian Poet, yet with this clau≈øe of exception: if Theater of great Britaine l. 6. credit may be giuen to a Poet. And the ≈øame Prote≈øtant Bishop confidently thus writeth: Sophronius Patriarke of Hieru≈øalem in plaine termes deliuereth, that S. Paule was heare amongst vs. Godwin Conu. ≈øupr. pag. 7.

3. The≈øe be the cheife≈øt or onely grounds, where vpon our English Prote≈øtants with ≈øome other Antiquaries doe frame their ≈øo fixed opinion, of S. The≈øe Arguments di≈øabled to bring S. Paule into Britaine. Paules coming into Britaine, and preaching heare, farre too weake and feeble to beare and ≈øupport that their building, as will appeare by a breife examen of the≈øe their Authours. And fir≈øt concerning Venantius Fortunatus their owne Antiquaries before haue di≈øabled him in ≈øuch a bu≈øines, certainely to conclude Venantius Fortunatus doth not proue, that S. Paul preached in Britaine. that S. Paule was heare vpon any report of a Poet ≈øpeaking therein, as they thinke Poetically amplifingely or faignedly, if credit may be giuen to a Poet, ≈øay ≈øome, If happely he v≈øed not Poetica licentia; Poeticall exce≈ø≈øe, as an other writeth: Which is as much as if they had plainely ≈øaide, no certainty thereof can be concluded from that Authour. Which is a thing vndoubted, and without que≈øtion, if we examine, and con≈øider the di≈øcour≈øe and intention of that Poet, in that place, which being Poeticall, as the≈øe Prote≈øtants haue in≈øinuated, doth climbe vp to an high Hyperbole, that we might the better be a≈ø≈øured, that the trauails of S. Paule (whereof there is no doubt) were exceding
greate. For he telleth vs, after the manner of Poets, that S. Paul conuerted, or at the lea≈øt preached in all Nations, euen all Ilands of the world, which cannot po≈ø≈øibly be true. For de≈øides ≈øo many farre di≈øtant of, and va≈øt Nations, where others of the Apo≈øtles are knowne to haue preached, and S. Paul neuer to haue approched vnto them, there be innumerable Ilands in the knowne world, & to omit the other greate Ocean, Prote≈øtants & others a≈ø≈øure vs, there be eleuen thow≈øand and more which the Spaniards call Philippins, & and name their King Emperour of them, and yet this Poets words ≈øay, S. Paul was in, and trauailed through all Ilands, which had any landing Port in them.
div.q: Tran≈øijt Oceanum, vel qua facit In≈øula portum.
div.p: Where the words qua and In≈øula haue relatioÃÑ to all Ilands in all other places, Harri≈øon de≈øcription of Britany. p. 29. 30. and not to this our Britaine, or Brittish Ilands, which be remembred particularly in the next words.

And if we should onely in≈øi≈øt in the Brittish Ilands, there be ≈øo many, and tho≈øe that haue landing places, that S. Paule could out by any meanes vi≈øit them all, to iu≈øtifie the Poets words in a true literall ≈øen≈øe, and meaning: for our Co≈ømographall de≈øcriptions of Britaine ≈øet forth by Prote≈øtants, and others tell vs, be≈øides the greater Ilands, the Sorlings and Iles of Sully beyonde Cornewale are in number 147. The Hebrides 43. Orchades 31. or 28. further this a≈ø≈øertion, that S. Paule should trauaile and pa≈ø≈øe through all the land, and Ilands of Britaine, and Thule.

q.l: Qua≈øque Britannus habet terras, quae≈øque vltima Thule:
Tran≈øijt;

div.p: Cannot po≈ø≈øibly be verified of S. Paule, who could not by any accompt as I will proue hereafter, be in the≈øe parts aboue three moneths at the mo≈øt, in which short time all the lands of Britaine, and Thule, commonly taken to be I≈øland ≈øo farre di≈øtant hence, could not be pa≈ø≈øed ouer, nor in many yeares. Seba≈øtian Mon≈øter. in Co≈ømogr. & alij coÃÑmuniter mi≈ølandia. And it plainely appeareth by this Authour in the ≈øame place, that he ≈øpake this Poetically, and in amplifying manner of S. Paule; for there he ≈øaith of him, that he preached to all Nations, by all Sea and land, Europe, A≈øia, and Afrike that he preached in all places where the ≈øunne shyned, North, South, we≈øt, and Ea≈øte.

lg.l: Quid ≈øaccr ille ≈øimul Paulus tuba gentibus ampla,
Per mare, per terras Chri≈øti praeconia fundens.
Europam, & A≈øiam, Lybiam, ≈øale dogmata complens,
Et qua ≈øol radijs tendit, ≈øtylus ille cucurrit
Arctus, Meridies, hic plenus vesper, & ortus.

div.p: Which cannot literally be verified of S. Paule, or any man, that euer was; and then immediately followe the two before cited ver≈øes.
div.q: Tran≈øijt Oceanum: qua≈øque Britannus habet terras:
div.p: To te≈øtifie they were to be taken in the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe, Britaine being called by ≈øome an other wolde, and Thule, the vtmo≈øt end of the then commonly knowne globe of the earth; which is further proued by the next and immediate words hauing reference in con≈øtruction, with his ver≈øe of Britaine: for he maketh a di≈øtinction, and ≈øtay, at the and of the fir≈øt ver≈øe.
To te≈øtifie; he ment not Britaine, but all Ilands by the words.
div.q: Vel qua facit In≈øula port ‚Ä¢ m:
div.p: And then addeth as a narration of an other different thing.

q.l: Qua≈øque Britannus habet terras, atque vltima Thyle,
Buccina concrepuit Regiones vna per omnes.

div.p: That S. Paule ≈øounded forth the doctrine of Chri≈øt through all Regions which either the Britans or they of Thule did po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe. And then further reckoneth all other Nations conuerted by S. Peter, and S. Paule, and how they both preached in all the world.
div.q: Ambo triumphantes ≈øpargunt noua dona per orbem.
div.p: The like Hiperbolicall ≈øpeach he v≈øeth of S. Paule in an other place, ≈øaying, Venant. Fortun. Libell. ad Iu≈øtin. Iunior. Imperatorem & SophiaÃÑ Aug. the wheele of his tongue did runne about the Poles of the world, and to thow≈øands of Nations be preached.

q.l: Quod cecinit Paulus pa≈øsim tuba millibus vna,
Gentibus & ≈øtupidis fudit ab ore ≈øalem.
Cuius quadratum linguae rota circuit exem.

div.p: And plainely ≈øaith, that both S. Peter, and S. Paule preached through out Venant. Fortun. in vita S. Martin. the vniuer≈øall world.

q.hi: Dogmata quae Chri≈øti totum ≈øpar≈øere per orbem.
q.note: Theodoret cited by Prote≈øtants, doth not in any place affirme that S. Paul preached in Britaine.

div.p: And thus concerning venantius Fortunatus.

4. Now let vs come to Theodoret and Sophronius. The fir≈øt place which our Prote≈øtants alledge from Theodoret, for S. Pauls preaching heare, is in his 9. booke, de curandis Graecorum affectionibus, and thus vrged as al≈øo Sophronius by the≈øe men: Sophronius Patriarke of Hieru≈øalem, and Theodoret an auncient Doctor of the Church doe affirme, and approue ≈øaying, that Fishers, Publicans, and Theater of great Britaine l. 6. c. 9. Sophron. ≈øerm. of the Natiuitie of the Apo≈øtle. Theodoret. de Curand. Graec. affect. l. 9. the Tentmaker, (meaning S. Paule) which brought the Euangelicall light vnto all Nations, reuealed the ≈øame vnto the Britans. But if this were ≈øo te≈øtified by the≈øe Fathers, it no more proueth that S. Paule brought the EuaÃÑgelicall light hither, then all the other Apo≈øtles, which no man will affirme, for it is ≈øpoken equally of them all, meaning (as the words be plaine) that the whole company of the Apo≈øtles ioyned together, and ≈øome preaching in one Nation, ≈øome in others, both preached in Britaine, and the other Nations, as the words of Theodoret being the≈øe, which follow are manife≈øt: no≈øtri illi Pi≈øcatores ac Publicani Theodoret. l. 9. contra Graecos. Sutorque ille no≈øter cunctis Nationibus legem Euangelicam detulerunt. Neque ≈øolum Romanos, quique ≈øub Romano degunt Imperio, ≈øed Scythas quoque ac Sauromatas, Indos praeterea, Aethiopes, Per≈øas, Setas, Hircanos, Britannos, Timerios & Germanos, vtque ≈øemel dicatur, omne hominum genus, Natione≈øque omnes induxerunt Crucifixi leges accipere. Which by no po≈ø≈øibilitie can be verified, or vnder≈øtood to be ≈øpoken onely of S. Paule, but all the Apo≈øtles together, of which ≈øome one at the lea≈øt, as S. Peter before, did preach to the Britans, and cau≈øed them to receaue the Lawe of Chri≈øt crucified. And to manife≈øt this more fully, the ≈øame Author Theodoret ≈øpeaking in an other place of the trauailes and preaching of S.
