Paul in particular, neuer bringerh him nearer to Britaine, then Rome, or Spaine, thus he writeth of that holy Apo≈øtle: Beatus Paulus Theodoret. in p≈ø. 116. breuiter docet quot gentibus ≈øalutaria praeconia attulit, inquiens, ita vt ab Hieru≈øalem per circuitum v≈øque ad Illericum repleuerim Euangelium Chri≈øti: po≈øtea igitur in Italiam venit, & in Hi≈øpanias peruenit, & In≈øulis quae in mari iacent vtilitatem attulit. Romanis quidem ≈øcribens ait, spero enim cum in Hi≈øpanias profici≈øci caepero, quod praeteriens videam vos, & √† vobis deducar illuc. Et admirabili Tito ≈øcribens, inquit, huius rei gratia reliqui te Cretae, vt coÃÑ≈øtituas per Ciuitates Presbyteros, ≈øicut & ego di≈øpo≈øui tibi. Where we are fully told, and a≈ø≈øured, that Theodoret doth not write, that S. Paul came nearrer vnto Britaine then Rome, or Spaine, for he expoundeth him≈øelf, what Ilands he meaneth S. Paul brought Saluation vnto, when he exemplifieth in Crete, and the Ilands in the Adriake ≈øea,
where he ordained S. Titus Bishop, and it was Metropolitane to the others, Ptolomaeus Geogr. Mun≈øter. in Creta. Abraham Ortel. & alij. Ioannes Leuncl. de ordine Eccle≈øiarum Con≈øtantinopoli ≈øubiect. Prouincial. Roman. Hier. Catal. in Titus. Doroth. Synop≈ø. in eod. Theodoret. epi≈øt. Act. cap. 27. cap. 28. c. 13. c. 20. Godwin Conu. p. 7. Tree Conuer≈ø. part. 1. p. 21. Magdeburg. cent. 1. l. 2. cap. 10 col. 595. aunciently knowne by the name Ecatompolis, the Iland of an hundred Cities hauing ≈øo many in it, and the Metropolis of it, was Metropolis and Archiepi≈øcopall See to the adiacent Ilands, as we are a≈ø≈øured by Ioannes Leunclauius, Prouincialis Romanus antiquus, and others more auncient, as S. Hierome, and Dorothaeus, and Theodoret in his defen≈øory Epi≈øtle, where he te≈øtifieth, that being Bishop of Cyprus, he had 800. Churches vnder him, Octingentis Eccle≈øijs Pa≈øtor e≈ø≈øem. And the Scripture it≈øelfe telleth vs, of diuers Ilands in that Sea onely, where S. Paule was, as Cyprus, Crete it≈øelfe where he ordayned S. Titus, Bishop, Clauda, Melita, and others. And ab≈øurd it is which the ≈øame Prote≈øtant Bishop before cited from N. D. the Authour of the Three Conuer≈øions, that Theodoret ≈øaith plainely, and expre≈ø≈øely vpon the 116. P≈øalme, that S. Paule preached in Britaine, that Authour affirming no ≈øuch thing, but ≈øpeaking in the name of the Magdeburgian Prote≈øtants, who if they ≈øo teach, they are mi≈øtaken therein, as I haue proued before, Theodoret hauing no ≈øuch ≈øaying there, or in any other place, and there not ≈øo much as naming Britaine, or Britans: and the Magdeburgian Prote≈øtans ≈øeeme al≈øo to be of opinion, that S. Paul was neuer in Britaine, for dilating at lardge the Trauailes of that holy Apo≈øtle and teaching how a litle before his death he preached in Italy, Spaine, France, and other parts of the we≈øt: In Italia, Gallia, Hispania, & alijs Occidentis partibus docuit Euangelium, they name not Britaine, except coniecturally Sophronius teacheth not, that S. Paul preached in Britaine. they include it in that clau≈øe, and other parts of the we≈øt.

5. Now to come to their other Authour, Sophronius, Patriarke of Hieru≈øalem, who as ≈øome Prote≈øtants before, and ≈øome Catholiks al≈øo write, doth teach, in his Sermon of S. Peter and Paul, and as a Prote≈øtant Doctor affirmeth 3. CoÃÑuer≈ø. part. 1. Engl. Martyr. in S. Paul. Sutcliffe ≈øubuer≈ø. pag. 4. Sophron. l. aut Serm. de Petro & Paulo. in his Sermon of the Natiuitie of Chri≈øt, that S. Paule preached in Britaine, there is no ≈øuch thing or the like in any of tho≈øe Sermons. Onely I finde in his Sermon or Booke of S. Peter and Paule, how he writeth of S. Peter in this manner: illi mundi procuratio committitur, & traduntur caele≈øtium the ≈øaurorum claues. Super caetum Apostolorum con≈øtitutus e≈øt, vbique ≈øeminando verbum vitae: the chardge of the world is committed to S. Peter, and the keyes of the cele≈øtiall trea≈øures The charge of the world, committed to S. Peter. are deliuered vnto him, ≈øowing the worde of life euery where. Therefore the≈øe Authorities ≈øo magnified by Prote≈øtants for S. Pauls preaching heare, cannot warraÃÑt vs in that behalfe. Which ≈øome of their be≈øt Prote≈øtant Antiquaries haue both ob≈øerued, and plainely confe≈ø≈øed. One of them thus writeth, of the cheife≈øt Harri≈øon de≈øcrition of Britaine p. 22. 23. Authoritie: ≈øome repo≈øe greate a≈ø≈øurance vpon Theodoret, that Paul the Apo≈øtle should preach the word of ≈øaluation heare, after his deliuery out of Captiuitie: But ≈øith I cannot verefy the ≈øame, by the words of Theodoret, to be spoken more of Paul, then Peter, or the re≈øt, I will pa≈ø≈øe ouer this coniecture. And their greate fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop ≈øeeing the weaknes of the proofes for this opinion, doth Matth. Parker. Antiquit. BritaÃÑ nic. p. 2. 3. plainely ≈øay, that S. Paul was not heare in par≈øon at all: And is coÃÑtent to acknowledge it for an vncredible & vnpo≈ø≈øible thing al≈øo, that S. Paul was heare either par≈øonally by him him≈øelfe in pre≈øence, which he vtterly di≈øableth, or by ≈øending Prote≈øtants confe≈ø≈øe S. Paul was n ‚Ä¢ uer in Britaine. any others hither, except he conuerted Claudia Rufina, our Brittish Lady at Rome (the contrary whereof is euident) and she ≈øent the Chri≈øtian faith to her freinds in Britaine: hoc quod Pontificij incredibile, atque adeo impo≈øsibile ≈øtatuunt, cum vero cohaeret maxim√®. Quanquam enim ip≈øe ad hanc In≈øulam profectus S. Claudia a Brittish Lady, a Chri≈øtian before S. Paul his fir≈øt coming to Rome. non ≈øit, tameÃÑ Claudiae Rufinae nobili≈øsimae Britannae, & Graecis Latini≈øque literis in≈øtructae Chri≈øtianam Religionem ≈øua≈øi≈ø≈øe perspicuum e≈øt. Hanc itaque iam ad Christum conuer≈øam, non minus e≈øt veri≈øimile Chri≈øtiana dogmata ad Britannos
mi≈øi≈ø≈øe ≈øuos, quam ante acceptam fidem, Epigrammata Martialis. What a chimericall conceipted vntruth this is, will more appeare, when I come to this our Noble British Lady, a Chri≈øtian in Rome, long before S. Pauls fir≈øt coming thither. An other a Prote≈øtant Bishop among them, is witnes, that it is ≈øo farre from a common, and allowable opinion, that S. Paul was in Britaine that diuers auncient and worthie Authours exclude him from Spaine it≈øelfe, and all other We≈øterne Nations, except Italy, whither he was brought a Pri≈øoner to Rome. Innocentius the first, Bishop of Rome, ≈øaith plainely, that non of the Apo≈øtles Godwin Conu. of Brit. p. 6. except Peter taught either in Spaine, or in any other part of the we≈øt. And Thomas Aquinas grounding him≈øelfe vpon the Iudgment of Gela≈øius, deliuered by Gratian vtterly denieth the repaire of S. Paul into Spaine. So doth Dominicus Soto, yeelding for his opinion, that no auncient writer euer mentioned that voyadge. And the French Hi≈øtorians, Nicholas vignier, and Francis Burgoing, make it Nichol. Vignier Biblioth. hi≈øtorial. an. 61. FraÃÑcis Burgoing l. 2. c. 1. l. 3. c. 2. Rom. cap. 15. very doubtfull: the fir≈øt ≈øaith: it is not found by any certaine, and tru≈øti ‚Ä¢ Authours. The other ≈øaith: S. Paule did promi≈øe to goe into Spaine, but it is not certaine that he was there.

div.head: THE XXX. CHAPTER.

argument.p: HOW IT IS VERY PROBABLE, THAT S. Paule preached heare in Britayne allthough not vntill long after that S. Peter and his Di≈øciples had fir≈øt heare founded the Church of Chri≈øt.

div.p:
1. BVT although I may not be ≈øo confident as the≈øe our Prote≈øtants haue ben vpon ≈øo weake, and ≈ølender foundations, to builde an vndeniable and vnque≈øtionable certaintie of S. Paules being, & preaching heare in Britayne: Yet I doe not doubt but ≈øtanding vpon other grounds, then they haue done, I may both publish it for a morally warrantable hi≈øtoricall truth, that S. Paul preached heare, that we may honour him for one of our holy Apo≈øtles, ≈øette downe a prefixed time, though neare his death, of his coming hither, as al≈øo ≈øome few things, which in morall Iudgment he performed heare. And to S. Paul preached in Britaine. begin with his coming hither, we haue diuers both auncient and later Authorities to ≈øettle vs in that opinion. Fir≈øt Eu≈øebius him≈øelfe bringeth him into our Neighboring Countries, Italy, Spaine, and France to preach the Gho≈øpell: Dicitur peregre profectus in Hi≈øpaniam, & Italiam Chri≈øti Praeco verbum Eu≈øebius Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 2. di≈ø≈øemina≈ø≈øe. Therefore coming of purpo≈øe to the≈øe parts to preach, and to parts farre from Rome, peregre profectus Chri≈øti Praeco, and to ≈øowe the word round about, verbum di≈ø≈øemina≈ø≈øe, we may not exclude his labours out of this Nation. S. Hierome ≈øpeaketh more plainely, and vrgeth the te≈øtimonie of S. Paule him≈øelfe to intitle our Britaine ≈øo greate a part of the we≈øtern world to be partaker of the preaching of S. Paul, and ≈øpeaketh as though God had ordayned his libertie from Pri≈øon to that end. Sciendum Paulum ‚Ä¢ Nerone dimi≈ø≈øum, Hieron. in Catal. Scrip. in S. Paulo Apo≈øtolo. vt Euangelium Christi in Occidentis quoque partibus praedicaret, ≈øicut ip≈øe ≈øcribit in ≈øecunda Epistola ad Timotheum, eo tempore quo & pa≈ø≈øus e≈øt, de vinculis dictans
Epi≈øtolam. In prima mea ≈øatisfactione nemo mihi affuit, ≈øed omnes me dereliquerunt, non eis imputetur. Dominus autem mihi affuit, & confortauit me, vt per me praedicatio compleretur, vt audirent omnes gentes. Thus S. Hierome contendeth to proue by S. Pauls owne words, and te≈øtimonie, that he preached in the≈øe parts, and his words, vt per me praedicatio compleretur, vt audirent omnes gentes: that by mee the preaching might be fully knowne, and that all the Gentiles 2. Tim. 4. v. 17. might heare: as our Prote≈øtants tran≈ølate, doe proue no le≈ø≈øe. For it is euident by S. Paul him≈øelfe, and all others, that after his returne into the Ea≈øtern parts, he preached vnto tho≈øe he had in≈øtructed before, and not fulfilled all his preaching there, nor all the Gentils did or could heare him there, being di≈øper≈øed in ≈øo many Nations, al≈øo of the we≈øt, of which this Nation was ≈øo greate a portion, that where, omnes gentes: all the gentils were to heare S. Pauls preaching, in this part of the world, Britaine was not, nor, (to make good S. Pauls words) could be exempted, e≈øpecially ≈øeeing S. Hierome ≈øaith plainely, and S. Paule confirmeth it, that he was deliuered from his Pri≈øon to preach the Gho≈øpell to all gentils of the We≈øt. And S. I≈øidor beareth the ≈øame witnes, for shewing how S. Paule preached in the Ea≈øte, and then after in Italy, and Spaine, he addeth of the other we≈øtern Nations, ac nomen Chri≈øti multarum I≈øid. Hi≈øp. l. de vita & morte Sanctorum c. 71. manife≈øtauit gentium populis, quibus ante non fuerat declaratum: and he made the name of Chri≈øt manife≈øt to people of many Nations, to which it was not before declared. And ≈øaith he was cho≈øen a Mai≈øter, and preacher in all places, and his Apo≈øtleship was giuen for the vncircumci≈øed gentils. Paulus in omnibus Magi≈øter Cap. 83. ≈øupr. & Praedicator eligitur. Paulo Apo≈øtolatus praeputij in gentibus datus e≈øt. S. Epiphanius ≈øeemeth to be of the ≈øame opinion. And our renowned Countriman Epiph. haere≈ø. 52. Bed. in Martyr. prid. cal. Iul. to. 3. S. Bede ≈øpeaking of S. Paule, ≈øaith, that be≈øides his greate labours in the Ea≈øte, he al≈øo preached in the parts of the we≈øt: Euangelium chri≈øti in Occidentis quoque partibus praedicauit. Where the words, the parts of the we≈øt, ≈øpoken without re≈øtriction, or limitation to any particular place, parte, Prouince, or kingdome, will not ≈øuffer ≈øo greate a part, as greate Britaine to be excluded from his preaching,

2. For which opinion we may al≈øo cite the auncient Roman Martyrologe, Martyrol. Rom. Ado, & V≈øuard ‚Ä¢ in Martyrol. die 29. Iunij. Petr. Cluniacen. l. 2. ep. 1. Trithem. in S. Maximo. Cat. Epi≈øc. Mogune. Ant. Demochar. cont. Calu. Gul. Ei≈øengr. cent. 1. Philip. Bergom. hi≈øtor. l. 8. an. 90. Genebrard. in Chron. an. 63. Franc. Burgoing hi≈øt. l. 3. c. 2. Magdeb. cent. 1. l. 2. c. 10. col. 595. Theater of great. Brit. l. 6. Godw. Conu. Ado Vien≈øis, V≈øuardus, Petrus Cluniacen≈øis, Trithemius, the Cathalogue of the Bishops of Ments, Philippus Bergomen≈øis, Antonius Democharez, Gulielmus Ei≈øengrenius, Genebrard and others, te≈øtifying S. Paules preaching in the we≈øt Countries, neare vnto Britaine: ≈øo doe diuers forrein Prote≈øtants, and of this Nation al≈øo: Francis Burgoing, the Mageburgians with others, writing plainely, that, in Italia, Gallia, & Hi≈øpania, & alijs occidentis partibus docuit Euangelium: he preached the Gho≈øpell in Italy, Gaule and Spayne, and other west parts which he had concluded with him≈øelfe: citing for this proofe, Philip. 1. v. 25. 26. Epi≈øt. ad Phillem. v. 22. and Rom. 15. By which relation we cannot without iniury both to S. Paul, and this kingdome, depriue Britaine of his preaching. And therefore diuers both auncient and late writers doe expre≈ø≈øely, and particularly affirme, that Sainct Paule preached in this Nation. Among which for auncients I may alledge Venantius Fortunatus before; for allthough as I haue proued, his narration of S. Pauls preaching cannot without ≈øome Poeticall ≈øtrain, or fiction be verified, yet being a Chri≈øtian, a Prei≈øt of Italy, and Bishop of Poicters in France where he was mo≈øt likely to be truely informed of S. Pauls labours, he might not without too much liberty, and amplification in his kinde extend them, as he doth, vnto Thule and the vttermo≈øt parts of the knowne world, except he had found good warrant to
write as he did, that he preached in all the Dominions of the Britans, the way and pa≈ø≈øadge thither.
div.q: Qua≈øque Britannus habet terras, qua≈øque vltima Thule.
div.p: And Arnoldus Mirmannius plainely writeth of him: Ad Occidentis & Arnold. Mirm. in Theatro coÃÑu. gent. Europae Climata importare Euangelium ≈øtudens, Hi≈øpaniam primum, hinc Galliam, inde Britanniam pridem a Claudio triumphatam, Orchades, caetera≈øque Oceani Regiones, ≈øeu In≈øulas extremas qua≈øque petens, per Germaniam in Italiam contendit. De≈øiring to carry the Gho≈øpell vnto the Climats of the we≈øt, and Europe, going first into Spaine, then to France, from thence to Britaine, where Claudius had triumphed a while before, the Orchads and other Regions or Iles of the Ocean by Germany went into Italy. Where we ≈øee, a con≈øtant affirmation of his preaching heare, with ≈øuch circum≈øtances, and particulars, that without greate Authoritie for ≈øo con≈øtant a Relation, it had bene greate rashnes to haue made it. To the≈øe we may adde Bellarmine, who ≈øpeaking of Chri≈øts ≈øending his Apo≈øtles to preach, ≈øaith: he ≈øent ≈øome into the furthe≈øt part of Britaine to de≈øtroy by them the Idols of the world, and erect the Standard of the Cro≈ø≈øe to chaunge lawes, and cu≈øtomes, and Bellarm. l. meditat. Anglice tran≈ølat. pag. 207. to ouerthrowe the Tyranny of the Deuill. Where ≈øpeaking in the plurall number of Apo≈øtles ≈øent hither, he mu≈øt needs by one of them vnder≈øtand S. Paul. For it is euident before, euen by Prote≈øtants allowance, that excepting him none of them but S. Peter preached in this kingdome of greate Britaine. And in this opinion are diuers Catholike writers of this Nation, expre≈ø≈øely writing that S. Paule par≈øonally preached heare.

3. M. Harris in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory thus te≈øtifieth of him: he came into Harris Theat. l. 1 c. 15. Engl. Martyrol. die 29. Iunij. this laÃÑd of Britany, and heare preached the Ghospell. The Publisher of the English Martyrologe ≈øaith of him: It is recorded by diuers auncient writers, that he came par≈øonally into our Iland of greate Britaine, and there preached the Chri≈øtian faith. And againe in another place: according to diuers auncient writers, S. Paul par≈øonally came into Britany, and there preached the faith of Christ. The author of the Ianuarij 25. The Author of the 3. Conu. of Brit. p. 22. Gulielm. Camd. in Britannia. in Sommer≈øetshire. Matth. Parker. Antiquit. Brit. p. 2. booke intituled The 3. Conuer≈øions is of the ≈øame iudgment. So be many others, and ≈øome Prote≈øtants as their cheife Antiquarie Camden; who affirmeth, that both S. Peter and S. Paul preached heare: Petrus ip≈øe huc penetrauit, & diuini verbi lumen diffudit vti etiam Paulus: Therefore it is a farre fetched fiction, of the fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury to ≈øay, that tho≈øe which be of the Popes Religion doe make it a thing incredible, and vnpo≈ø≈øible, that S. Paul either par≈øonally by him≈øelfe, or by any his Di≈øciples preached heare: pontificij incredibile atque adeo impo≈øsibile ≈øtatuunt. For Catholiks are ≈øo farre from making either of the≈øe either incredible, or vnpo≈ø≈øible, that we willingly allowe them, both for probable. Onely I haue proued, and by Prote≈øtants warrant that it is a thing both incredible, and vnpo≈ø≈øible that either S. Paul or any other of the Apo≈øtles, but S. Peter and his Di≈øciples should be the fir≈øt and principall Founders of the Church of Chri≈øt in this Kingdome. But they be Prote≈øtant and not Catholike writers, which by their weake grownds, and feeble Authorities haue ≈øo much as in them lieth, made S. Pauls preaching in Britaine to be neither credible, nor probable, both which I haue thus di≈øproued, and proued it be both po≈ø≈øible, credible, and probable that he was, and preached in this kingdome.

div.head: THE XXXI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: CONCERNING THE TIME OF S. PAVLS coming into, and preaching in Britaine. That it could not be vntill the later end of the Empire of Nero, a litle before the Martyrdome of S. Paule, and was heare, but a very short time.

div.p:
1. CONCERNING the time of S. Pauls ≈øuppo≈øed coming hither, being but a circum≈øtance of a doubtfull obiect, and matter it ≈øelfe, it mu≈øt needs be more doubtfull and vncertaine‚ñ™ the Authours of the English Martirologe, and the Three Conuer≈øions of Britaine, a≈ø≈øcribe his coming to the fourth yeare of Nero Engl. Martyrol. die 25. Ianuar. The fir≈øt ≈øaith: According to diuers auncient writers, in the fourth yeare of Nero the Emperor his Reigne, the Iewe ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ eing by his Edict banished Rome, he (S. Paul The error of them which thinke S. Paul came into Britaine in the 4. yeare of Nero, confuted.
par≈øonally came into Britaine, and there preached the faith of Chri≈øt: The other writeth in this order: Arnoldus Mirmannius in his Theater of the Conuer≈øion of all Nations affirmeth, S. Paul to haue pa≈øt to Britaine, in the 4. yeare of Nero. Anno Domini 59. and there to haue preached. Diuers Prote≈øtants ≈øeeme to incline to the ≈øame opinion, and for the ≈øame re≈øpects: But as I haue proued before this could not be, and the fir≈øt Authour contradicteth him≈øelfe, both in the time, and his Authour of 3. Conu. of Brit. p. 22. Engl. Martyr. Iune 29. Authours: for in an other place v≈øing the ≈øame Authorities of Theodoret, Sophronius, Venantius Fortunatus, & MirmaÃÑnius, as in the former, not any one of them ≈øpeaking any ≈øuch thing, he ≈øaith: It is recorded by diuers auncient writers that about the yeare of Chri≈øt, three≈øcore and ≈øeuen S. Paule came par≈øonally into our Iland of greate Britaine, and there preached the Christian faith. And the Authour of the booke of the Three Conuer≈øions is as much deceaued, if he thinketh Arnoldus Mirmannius did teach, that S. Paul came hither in the fourth yeare Theater of great Brit. l. 6. Godwin Conuer≈ø. p. 7. of Nero, as our Theater Prote≈øtant writers doe cite him, for Mirinannius ≈øpeaketh of no yeare at all, of S. Paule his coming hither: But making S. Paule to begin his trauailes after his Impri≈øonment by Nero in the fourth yeare of his reigne, caryeth him pre≈øently into Syria, Pamphilia, Licaonia, Phaenice, My≈øia, Phrigia, Galatia, Bithinia Achaia, Macedonia, the re≈øt of Greece and A≈øia, and after Arnold. Mirm. Theatro conu. gent. all this affirmeth, he came into the we≈øt, Spaine, France, and Britaine: Quarto Neronis anno postremum iter ingre≈ø≈øus, peragrauit tertium aut quartum Syriam, Pamphiliam, Lycaoniam, Phaenicen, My≈øiam, Phrygiam, Galatiam, Bythiniam, Achaiam, Mac ‚Ä¢ doniam, reliquamque Graeciam, pariter & A≈øiam, Illericum v≈øque Chri≈øtianae Religionis prorogans pomaeria. Demum ad Occidentis & Europae Climata importare Euangelium ≈øtudens Hi≈øpaniam primum, hinc Galliam, inde Britanniam petens. Where he maketh his coming into the≈øe parts, one of his la≈øt labours, and his la≈øt of all, except his returne to Rome, to ≈øuffer Martyrdome, in the later time of Nero. And he is no le≈ø≈øe deceaued, which ≈øaith: About the later end of Guiderius Reigne, or not longe after Claudius returne to Rome, it ≈øeemeth both by te≈øtimonie of auncient writers, and by the cour≈øe of S. Pauls peregination that he came into this land of Britaine, and heare preached the Gho≈øpell. For it is euident Harris hi≈øt. M. S. l. 1. c. 15.
by diuers places of holy Scripture, that it was both loÃÑge after the returne Rom. 15. Act. ca. 26. c. 27. & 28. c. 25. Matth. We≈øtm. ad an. 44. & alij. Stowe & Howes hi≈øt. in Claudius. Cat. Prot. ReguÃÑ Brit. of Claudius the Emperor vnto Rome, being about the 44. or 45. yeare of Chri≈øt, and after his death al≈øo, 8. or 9. yeares after this, and after Nero had reigned ≈øome time before S. Paule came to Rome it≈øelfe, or any part of Europe or the We≈øt. And this Author naming in generall auncient writers for his a≈ø≈øertioÃÑ mi≈øtaketh them in this thing, for none doth, or can, whether auncient or late writer contrary to Antiquitie, and the holy Scripture, ≈øo affirme. The cheife te≈øtimonye he bringeth is from Theodoret, affirming that S. Cor. 8. v. 19. he is before ≈øaid to haue come into the≈øe parts, and la≈øtely becau≈øe S. Paul at his returne from hence te≈øtifieth that S. Luke was the onely Di≈øciple, or companion co ‚Ä¢ tinued ≈øtill with him: onely Luke is with me. The like I affirme of 2. Tim. 4. v. 11. Demas, who as he writeth, for≈øooke him after that time, and the ≈øame I ≈øuppo≈øe of S. Cre≈øcens, which after this went, from him into Galatia, and Titus vnto Dalmatia, and Tyticus whome he ≈øent to Ephe≈øus. 2. Tim. 10. 12.

div.head: THE XXXII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF OVR HOLY CHRISTIAN BRITANS IN Rome at this time, and cheifely of Lady Claudia, and her holy family.

div.p: 1. HAVING thus attended S. Paul in his holy trauailes, and probably brought him, in tho≈øe his long Iorneys, into this kingdome, and from hence to Rome to the place, and neare the time of his triumphant Martyrdome, before I performe that dutie to S. Peter, I will ≈øay ≈øome what of our Brittish Chri≈øtians, then at Rome: And the rather becau≈øe S. Paul in his ≈øecond Epi≈øtle to S. Tymothie written from his Pri≈øon in Rome at this time, making an honorable memory of ≈øome of them, putteth me in minde to make mention of them in this, as their fitte≈øt place. I haue ≈øpoken before of our noble Britans, the Chri≈øtian parents of S. Claudia, and of her the holy childe of tho≈øe Religeous Chri≈øtians: Now Iam to entreate of her, as an happy naturall Mother of diuers holy Chri≈øtian children, which she brought into this world, and as a ≈øupernaturall Mother vnto many of this her Nation, being in her degree and order an happy occa≈øion and meanes of their birth in Chri≈øt. But a late English Catholike writer litle to the honour of this NatioÃÑ hath que≈øtioned, whether our noble Countriwoman Author of 3. Conuer≈ø. of Brit. part. 2. p. 17. Claudia was the ≈øame, whome S. Paul recounteth among the renowned Chri≈øtians at Rome, or no; and ≈øeemeth to deny it, rather leauing this Brittish Lady by his opinion, in Paganish Infidelitie, then to be a Chri≈øtian: and a Prote≈øtant Bishop writeth not ≈øo clearely of that matter, as he might haue done, leauing it almo≈øt doubtfull to his Readers, by ≈øaying, he will Godwin Conu. of Britaine p. 16. c. 2. not ≈øtand, to di≈øpute it; whether that Brittish Lady Claudia ≈øo honorably remembred by Martial the Poet, lyuing in that time, was the ≈øame Claudia which S. All obiections to di≈øproue Claudia honored by S. Paul for a renowned Chri≈øtian, not to be our Brittish Lady Claudia are di≈øproued. Paul hath ≈øo renowned: which words take away ≈øome credit from the true opinion making her a Chri≈øtian and to be one and the ≈øame woman. For our Prote≈øtants them≈øelues which receaue her into the number of holy Chri≈øtians, deriue their greate≈øt Authoritie for their affirming thereof, from S. Pauls words, recounting S. Claudia among the holy Chri≈øtians at Rome.

2. Allthough I haue ≈øofficiently cleared the truth in this matter before, to the eternall honor of that mo≈øt noble Ladye, and this her Country of Britaine; yet for ≈øatisfaction of all, I will now fully an≈øweare all obiections. It Martial. Epigr. de morte PudeÃÑ tis. Bal. l. de Scrip. Brit. cent. 1. in Claudia Rufina. Doroth. in Synop. in Pudens. Martyr. Rom. die 19. Maij. V≈øvard. eod. die. Bed. Martyrol. in S. Praxede. ‚Ä¢ . Conu. part. 1. p. 17. 2. Timoth. 4. may be obiected by the≈øe men that Pudens ≈øpoaken of by Martiall the Poet, husband to our brittish Claudia died in Cappadocia, diuers hundreds of miles from Rome, When the Eccle≈øia≈øticall monuments which ≈øpeake of S. Pudens the Chri≈øtian ≈øpoaken of by S. Paul, ≈øay he died at Rome. And S. Bede with others ≈øaith, S. Praxedes his daughter was buryed at Rome, by her Father Pudens, as likewi≈øe her Si≈øter S. Pudentiana was. Other obiections there be of the difference of the ≈øuppo≈øed time, and age hinde ‚Ä¢ ing the Chri≈øtian Claudia to be ≈øo be wtifull in the dayes of Martial as he commendeth our brittish Claudia. This Poet writing in the time of Ve≈øpa≈øian, and Titus, and dying in the dayes of Traian, whereas S. Pauls Chri≈øtian Claudia was a woman, and of note in Rome in the la≈øt yeare of Nero. Be≈øides our Brittish Lady Claudia both as Martiall, and our English Prote≈øtants are witne≈ø≈øes had onely three children, or at the lea≈øte they name but three, S. Nouatus, S. Praxedes and S. Pudentiana. Whereas the old Roman Martyrologe propo≈øeth vnto vs 4. Chri≈øtian children of the Chri≈øtian Parents S. Pudens and S. Claudia & name tho≈øe three remembred Nouatus, Praxedes, Pudentiana, and S. Timotheus a Prei≈øt, Romae depo≈øitio S. Nouati filij S. Pudentis Senatoris, & fratris S. Tymothei Martyrol. Rom. die 20. Iunij in S. Nouato. presbyteri, & ≈øanctarum Chri≈øti virginum Pudentianae & Praxedis, qui ab Apo≈øto≈øtolis eruditi ≈øunt in fide. Againe S. Bede and others write, that the wife of Pudens the Chri≈øtian mother to S. Pudentiana, was called Sabinella, Cuius mater erat Sabinella. But the≈øe are ea≈øily an≈øweared: And fir≈øt for S. Pudens, finding but one of that name in this time, for his dying, or being rather in Cappadocia, and yet buried at Rome, we may either ≈øay that he returned to Rome before his death, in≈øinuated by Martial. Martial. l. 6. Epigram. 58. Io. Pit≈øeus lib. de Illu≈øtrib. Britan. Script. aetate 2. p. 72. in Claudia Rufina. Martyr. Bed. 14. cal. Iunij. Rom. Martyrol. die 19. Maij.
div.q: Sospite me ≈øo≈øpes Latias reueheris ad vrbes.
div.p:
Or with other writers, that his body by the Chri≈øtians was brought from Cappadocia to Rome if the report of his death in Cappadocia is true: Pudens in Cappadocia dicitur a ‚Ä¢ imam effla≈ø≈øe, „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢ orpus Chri≈øtiani Romamtran≈øtulerunt, & in caemiterio Pri≈øcillae via Salaria ≈øepult ‚Ä¢ re honoratae tradiderunt, vbi po≈øtea Pudentiana & Praxedes ≈øepultae fuerunt. And S. Bede ≈øaith, he was buried at Rome.

3. The obiection of the bewtie of our Brittish Claudia ≈øo recommended by Martial, was neither worthie of propo≈øing, or de≈øeruing an≈øweare, being but a bla≈øt of a vayne moÃÑuth, vented by the pen of a Poet, forward enough, as ≈øuch men be to giue too greate a flattering florish to womens bewtyes: yet as our Prote≈øtaÃÑt Antiquaries not vnprobably calculate, she could not be aboue 40. yeares of age at the mo≈øt, when this Poet ≈øo commended her in that re≈øpect, Godwin Conu. of Brit. p. 17. 18. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. c. 9. and when his Epigram thereof was published; although as he well ≈øaith, that Epigram happily might be written, ≈øome yeares ≈øooner, when her bewtte was more fresh, and againe: except the ≈øaid Epigram, as often it falleth out in tho≈øe ca≈øes, was made longe before it was published, or ≈øome time after their marriage. Which is mo≈øt probable, the Poet taking notice onely of three children she then had, S. Tunotie not then yet borne. And it is no meruaile, if S. Timothie her ≈øonne an holy Prei≈øt, liuing in ob≈øcurity in that time, and much in this kindome of Britaine (as hereafter I shall shew‚ñ™ was vnknowne to a Pagan Poet e≈øpecially ≈øeeing for ≈øuch re≈øpects there is litle memory of him in Eccle≈øia≈øticall monuments.

4. How it came to pa≈ø≈øe that S. Claudia was al≈øo called Sabinella, the ≈øame Poet will ≈øufficiently informe vs, when he telleth vs expre≈ø≈øely, that her Lady Claudia of Britaine the ≈øame holy Chri≈øtian Claudia, whome S. Paul remembreth. husband S. Pudens had an hou≈øe at Sabinum in Italy where she al≈øo liued, & after the auncient manner had her name Sabinella from thence. Which two denominations of Claudia and Sabinella onely agreeing to our Brittish Claudia and by no po≈ø≈øibilitie to any el≈øe, I conclude it for a certaintie both by rea≈øons, and Authorities, that our Brittish Lady Claudia mentioned Martyrol. Rom. 20. die Martij. Graeci in Menol. eod. die. Mart. Rom. 28. Maij & Menol. Graecorum eod. die. by Martiall, was the ≈øame renowned Chri≈øtian Claudia which S. Paul ≈øpeaketh of with ≈øo honorable memory. The name, time, place and all circum≈øtances agree, and pleade it is ≈øo. For of that name, in that time & place, I finde no other ≈øuch in Hi≈øtories, nor longe time after in any other place, and then of two: one at Ami≈øis in Paphligonia, the other at Ancyra in Galatia a Matrone and Martyr longe after this time, and farre di≈øtant from Rome & Italy where our S. Claudia liued, and died. Againe among the Roman writers much is ≈øpoken of her husband S. Pudens, and their holy children, bredd vp, and borne among≈øt them, and allmo≈øt a ≈øilence of the ble≈ø≈øed Mother S. Claudia, but that Martial. lib. 4. Epigram. 10. Godw. Conu. of Brit. p. 17. Parker Antiq. Brit. pag. 2. Camd. in Brit. Stowe hi≈øt. Bal. cent. 1. Pitz. aetat. 2. in Claudia Rufina. Harri≈øon de≈øcri. of Brit. Harris hi≈øt. l. 1. Theater of great. l. 6. c. 9. Andre du Che≈øne hi≈øtoire generale d'Angleterre &c. p. 152. Mart. l. 11. Epigram. 30. Io. Herald. epi≈øt. dedicat. ant hi≈øt. Mari ‚Ä¢ ni Scoti. it plea≈øed God by S. Pauls pen to remember her, which argueth she was a ≈øtranger to the Romans, who≈øe Annals would not haue left any woman of their Nation, though of meaner merit, and glory, then she was, in ≈øo greate darknes of obliuion. Further when we finde ≈øuch a penurye of the names, Pudens, and Claudia, in the Roman, and other Hi≈øtories, that there is allmo≈øt no mention of them; And yet we ≈øee them both remembred, and ioyned together in one line, and to be in one Citie of Rome, and by all probable Iudgment in one hou≈øe, and as husband and wife, by the holy Apo≈øtles writing of them, as he is commonly interpreted: And a Pagan writer al≈øo of that time, who well knew both Pudens and Claudia and their children, plainely affirmeth with many later Authours, that this Claudia lyuing in Rome in the ≈øame hou≈øe with Pudens, and his vndoubted wife, was borne of Brittish Parents, which cannot be verified of any other Claudia: we mu≈øt needs therefore be of opinion that this our Brittish Claudia was as bewtifull in ≈øpirituall fayrenes, and Religion, for S. Pauls te≈øtimony thereof, as in corporall bewty, by th ‚Ä¢ Poets writing.

5. Wherevpon it is the con≈øtant receaued, and not to be que≈øtioned opinion, among writers, Catholiks and Prote≈øtants, Chri≈øtians, and Pagans, English, French and others, that the holy Chri≈øtian Claudia ≈øo dignified by S. Paul, was the ≈øame Brittish Lady Claudia, whome Martial ≈øo commendeth, borne of Brittish Parents.

q.l: Claudia caeruleis cum ≈øit Rufina Britannis
Edita:

div.p:
Elle e≈øtoit Bretonne de Nation: she was a Britan by Nation. And by the happie occa≈øion of this ≈øo renowned, and noble Chri≈øtian of this Nation continually then re≈øiding at Rome, and ≈øo perfectly in≈øtructed in the faith of Chri≈øt, and acquainted with the holy Apo≈øtles, many ≈øpirituall ble≈ø≈øings were in that time be≈øtowed vpon many our Britans both at Rome, and heare in Britaine; of this both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants agree, allthough there is diffence in the order and manner thereof. The fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Arch-Bishop thus writeth of this holy Brittish Lady: hanc iam ad Chri≈øtum conuer≈øam, non minus est veri≈øimile Chri≈øtiana dogmata ad Britannos mi≈øi≈ø≈øe ≈øuos, quam ante Matth. Parker. Antiquit. Brit. p. 3. acceptam fidem Epigrammata Martialis. Nec veri≈øimile ≈øolum, ≈øed verum iudicandum e≈øt, in tam nobili familia, fui≈ø≈øe cum Claudia gentiles ≈øuos Britannos, qui vna
baptizati fuerunt, √† quibus Euangelij Ignicula per totam gentem Britannam di≈øper≈øa, viritim ad multos peruenerunt. After Claudia was conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, it is as likely that she ≈øent Chri≈øtian doctrine to her Countrimen the Britans, as before she receaued the faith, she ≈øent the Epigrams of Martial. Neyther is it onely likely, but to be adiudged true, that in ≈øo noble a familie, there were with Claudia diuers BritaÃÑs of her Country, which were baptized with her from whome the ≈øparkes of the Gho≈øpell being di≈øper≈øed through all the Brittish Nation, came from one to an other to many. The Prote≈øtant Bishops with other their Antiquaries in their greate Theater of greate Britaine thus write of her: This Claudia with S. Pauls ≈øpirituall Theat. of great Brit. l. 6. c. 9. Manna is ≈øaid to ≈øend the choy≈øe≈øt and cha≈øte≈øt of the Po≈øies of Martiall (who≈øe ver≈øes generally are no le≈ø≈øons befitting Ladies) for new yeares guifts vnto her friends in Britaine, both for to feede their ≈øoules with the bread of life, and to in≈øtruct their mindes with le≈ø≈øons be≈øt fitting vnto ciuill behauiour. Which thing moued the Poet him≈øelfe with no ≈ømall ≈øelfe glory, in his ver≈øe thus to write.

And they note in their Margine the≈øe wordes: Claudia ≈øenas both S. Pauls, and Martials writings into Britaine; Which is allowed by other Prote≈øtants al≈øo: among whome one a cheife Antiquarie thus boldly ≈øpeaketh: of this Lady Harri≈øon de≈øcription of Britaine in Claudia. Io. Bal. l. de ≈øcript. Brit. cent. 1. in Claudia Rufina. Martial ≈øpeaketh reioycing, that his Po≈øies were reade al≈øo in Britaine, and onely by her meanes, who v≈øed to cull out the fine≈øt and hone≈øt of his Epigrams, and ≈øend them to her friends for tokens, ≈øaying after this manner.

Britaine is ≈øaid to ≈øing our ver≈øes. Like is the te≈øtimonie of other Prote≈øtants; to whome, in that they affirme much ≈øpirituall good to haue growne to this Nation of Britaine, by the beleeuing Britans, and others which liued in, or re≈øorted vnto the hou≈øe of S. Claudia in Rome, I willingly con≈øent vnto them, and haue allready proued no le≈ø≈øe, and will ≈øpeake more of the ≈øame hereafter.

6. But where the≈øe men ≈øo con≈øtantly auouch this holy Lady was a tran≈ølater Lady Claudia neither ≈øent S. Pauls Epi≈øtles, nor Martial his Poems into Britaine. of S. Pauls Epi≈øtles, and ≈øent them hither, for the In≈øtruction of others, and al≈øo ≈øent into this Nation the Epigrams of Martial, prouing the fir≈øt onely by ≈øome likelyhood, becau≈øe they a≈ø≈øuer them≈øelues, by the ver≈øe of Martial recited, that Britaine was reported to ≈øinge his ver≈øes; as the la≈øt is vntrue, and not affirmed by Martiall, or any other except the≈øe Prote≈øtants, and a foule forgery to blemish the bewty, of that holy Lady; ≈øo the other hauing no warrant, or Authoritie, but their fal≈øely imagined congruence from that, mu≈øt needs be as vnprobable. And fir≈øt, where the≈øe men ≈øay that the Poet ≈øayth his ver≈øes were ≈øung in Britaine by the meanes of this holy and vertuous Lady; Martial hath no ≈øuch thing, but rather the contrary, for except she a woman of ≈øo greate cha≈øtitie, mode≈øtie, and pietie, by all te≈øtimonies, could ≈øo farre forgete her shamefa≈øte ≈øexe, and temperate carriadge, and exceede the boldnes of men euen her owne Father, and Husband, she was ≈øo farre from being an approuer, and recommender of Martiall his Poems vnto others in Britaine, that by the Poets owne te≈øtimonie, she vtterly condemned them for their vntollerable wantones, and ≈øcurrilitie; for ≈øo did both her Father, Father in lawe to Pudens her Husband, and her owne Husband al≈øo, as the ≈øame Poet him≈øelfe hath before plainely confe≈ø≈øed: ≈øaying of the Husband of Claudia, to whome he pre≈øented diuers Poems, that he compelled him to correct and amend his books.

q.l: Cogis me calamo, manuque no≈øtra
Emendare meos, Pudens, libellos. Martial. l. 7. Epigram. 11. ad Pudentem.

div.p: And S. Claudia her Father was much more auerted from the Poems of Martiall, then Pudens his ≈øonne in Lawe was, by that Poets owne confe≈ø≈øion, for euen tho≈øe Poems which he ≈øent to Pudens would haue ≈øo much bene di≈øliked by Claudia her Father, that he entreated S. Pudens not to communicate them vnto him, becau≈øe he knew well he condemned their leuitie.

q.l: Commendare meas Instanti, Rufe, camaenas
Parce precor ≈øocero, ≈øeria for≈øan amat. Martial. l. 7. Epigram. 57. ad Rufin.

div.p: And a ≈øimple ≈øugge≈øtion it is to write, she culled out the fine≈øt and hone≈øte≈øt of his Epigrams, and ≈øent them hither; for this she could not doe, without reading al≈øo the fowle≈øt, and dishone≈øte≈øt, which we may not thinke that ≈øo mode≈øt, and holy a Saint would doe, which is of the≈øe Prote≈øtants ≈øufficiently before acknowledged, when they expre≈ø≈øely ≈øay, Martials ver≈øes generally are no le≈ø≈øons be fitting Ladyes. Therefore if generally they were ≈øo vnbe≈øeeming, Theater of great Brit. ≈øupr. l. 6. we may not make ≈øo holy & renowned a Lady either a generall or particular Approuer of ≈øuch ≈øtuffe, to ≈øend it ≈øo loÃÑg a Iorney to her beloued FrieÃÑds in this her Natiue CouÃÑtry of Britaine, for toakeÃÑs, much les for Newyeares gifts, neither was that name, nor ceremony knowne in Britaine, loÃÑg after that time‚ñ™

7. And the fir≈øt Prote≈øtant English Archbishop which before ob≈øerued that ab≈øurditie, and yet willing to in≈øi≈øt in the ≈øame erroneous ≈øteps of his brethren in this point, and therefore hath written that it is likely Claudia ≈øent the≈øe ≈øtrange Poems hither from Rome before she was a Chri≈øtian; veri≈øimile e≈øt Claudiam ante acceptam fidem Epigrammata Martialis ad Britannos mi≈øi≈ø≈øe ≈øuos, ≈øpeaketh farre more ab≈øurdly, for it is euident by all Accompts, both of Chri≈øtians and Pagans, Catholiks and Prote≈øtants, that Claudia was a Chri≈øtian, and renowned by Saint Pauls pen, in the time of Nero, 26. yeares before Martial wrote, or came to Rome: Therefore it was greate ignorance, or willfulnes in that Prote≈øtant Archbishop, to write, it was veri≈øimile a very likely thing, that Claudia ≈øent that Poets Epigrams into Britan before she was a Chri≈øtian, she being a renowned Chri≈øtian ≈øo long before he was a Poet. Godwin Conu. of Britaine p. 17. 18. But Martial had other meanes to vent his Poems hither, he was acquainted with Quintus Ouidius, and his company that came hither, he and wrote an Epigram vnto him cited before, ≈øuch was al≈øo one Stella as he writeth. Martial. l. 10. Epigram. 40. ad Quintum Ouidium. Lib. 12. Epigram. 3. ad librum ≈øuuÃÑ.
div.q: Ille dabit populo, Patribu≈øque, Equitique legendum.
div.p: And it was his glory, thus by idle headed par≈øons, to ≈øend his bables about, both to Rome, and from thence to other parts, as appeareth in the beginning of the ≈øame Epigram.

q.l: Ad populos mitti qui nuper ab vrbe ≈øolebas,
Ibis tu Romam nunc peregrine liber.

div.p: And he plainely declareth, euen in his fir≈øt Epigram to his Reader this was his humour to make him ≈øelfe knowne in the world for ≈øuch Poeticall, and vaine ≈øcriblings:

q.l: Hic e≈øt quem legis, ille, quem requiris.
Toto notus in Orbe Martialis,
Argutis Epigrammaton libellis.

div.p:
And to make ≈øpeedy vtterance of ≈øuch wares to all par≈øons & places, the very Martial. l. 1. Epigram. 1. ad Lectorem. Lib. 1. Epigr. 2. next Epigram (which is al≈øo to the Reader) is to tell where his bookes were to be bought: and be≈øides he ≈øent them vp and downe to particular par≈øons as their Titles te≈øtifie. And allthough we had diuers holy Chri≈øtians then in Rome of this Nation, which reiected Martial his Poems, as S. Claudia, and
her Father did; yet there were al≈øo at that time many Pagan Britans, and ≈øome of them al≈øo Poets, as Gildas Cambrius, a mo≈øt noble Britan Poet, as Ponticus Pontic. Virun. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 1. Girald. Ferrar. hi≈øt. Poet. Dialog. 5. Io. Bal. Script. Brit. cent. 1. in Gilda Cambrio. Virunnius calleth him, Gildas Poeta Britannicus nobili≈ø≈øimus, and others, by who≈øe meanes, be≈øides ≈øuch as I haue related before, it is not vnlikely, but Martials ver≈øes, a≈øwell as others came into this Countrie, and he might take notice there of, and therevpon write: it was reported that his ver≈øes were ≈øunge in Britaine.

8. And hereby it appeareth how weake a propp they haue to ≈øupport S. Claudia did not tran≈ølate or ≈øend S. Pauls Epi≈øtles into Britaine. them therein, that would probably and by compari≈øon conclude that S. Claudia did ≈øend S. Pauls Epi≈øtles into Britaine, becau≈øe she ≈øent Martials Poems hither: for fir≈øt there is ≈øo greate difference and repugnancy betweene the holy writings of S. Paul, and the idle Epigrams of that Poet, if we chu≈øe their be≈øt; that rather the contrary is to be gathered, that who≈øoeuer did affect the libels of Martial, could not be a louer of S. Pauls doctrine, ≈øo oppo≈øite vnto ≈øuch vanities: and ≈øo she knowne to be ≈øo renowned a Chri≈øtian when Martial wrote, and ≈øo highely commended by S. Paul, could be no recommender of Martials vanities, vnto this, or any other parts, or par≈øons. And it is euident before, she allowed them not. And allthough I willingely allowe, what a Prote≈øtant Bishop writeth of her, placing her among our Brittish writers, and affirming, that she was renowned all through out Italy, and other Nations, for her ≈øtyle in the Latine, & Greeke tongue: Claudia Rufina Britannici generis nobili≈ø≈øima Io. Bal. l. de Scrip. Brit. cent. 1. in Claudia Rufina. mulier, nominis claritatem ex ingenti vtriu≈øque linguae Latinae & Graecae notitia, per Italiam, & alias commeruit mundi Regiones: yet this is no warrant for others to ≈øay, that therefore she tran≈ølated S. Pauls Epi≈øtles, and ≈øent them into Britaine. For euery one that hath knowledge in Latine, and Greeke, allthough in a more excellent manner, then a Lady, a ≈øtranger to them both, and young in yeares, as by the≈øe men she was, is not a fit Tran≈ølator of holy Scripturs, and we doe not finde that honor then giuen to any of her ≈øexe, nor did that, or ≈øuch office belong to her or any ≈øuch; her Father before confe≈ø≈øed to be a learned Chri≈øtian, was a fitter man to performe ≈øuch things to this his Nation, if any ≈øuch was done at that time. But amoÃÑg all the Epi≈øtles which S. Paul wrote, we doe not finde any one of them written, or ≈øent by him, to any par≈øon, or place, but ≈øuch as had receaued the faith of Chri≈øt before, neither S. Pauls Epi≈øtles, nor any part of Scripture will make an Infidell a good Chri≈øtian without a Preacher or Interpreter. And I ≈øuppo≈øe he would be thought a ≈øtrange Poet ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing Martiall in that kind, in the iudgment of Antiquaries, who should ≈øay, he had euer ≈øeene, or credibly heard of any part of Scripture then tran≈ølated, much more by any woman into the Welch or Brittish languadge.

9. And no le≈ø≈øe paradoxe it is, which a Prote≈øtant Bishop and Antiquarie Godwin Conu. of Brit. p. 18. c. ‚Ä¢ . propo≈øeth to the world, concerning S. Pudens, husband to this our holy Country woman S. Claudia, laboring to per≈øwade his Readers, that he came into S. Pudens Hu≈øt. ad to S. Claudia did „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ B ‚Ä¢ itain ‚Ä¢ , n ‚Ä¢ r nea ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢

Fir≈øt he maketh this his Marginall Note of that which followeth: Britaine a Refuge for Christians. And then addeth of this time: it was not counted vnlawfull for tho≈øe to be Chri≈øtians, that dwelt beyonde Italy, and France, as in Britaine or neare the PirenaeaÃÑ Mountains, and ≈øo to the we≈øterne Ocean. Whereby vndoubtedly it came to pa≈ø≈øe, that many profe≈ø≈øing Chri≈øt, not daring to abyde neare vnto the hart of the Empire, as in Italy, France, or ≈øome other of the neere≈øt Prouinces, made choy≈øe of our Britaine, and ≈øome other remote places, where to leade their liu ‚Ä¢ s in ≈øuch ≈øorte, as they might enioy libertie
of con≈øcience. In the number of the≈øe, I may well ≈øuppo≈øe Aulus Rufus Pudens before mentioned to be one, who after the time of his marriadge, trauailed to the≈øe Northren parts of the world, as it is plaine, by the≈øe ver≈øes following.

By meanes of the≈øe kinde of men adding their helps vnto the ≈øucce≈ø≈øours of Io≈øeph, Io. Pit≈ø. l. de Illu≈øtr. Brit. Script. aetate 2. in Claudia Rufina. Io. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. in eadem. Maij. Et Tom. 1. & 2. Annal. 3. conu. part. 1. p. 17. and his Di≈øciples, I ≈øuppo≈øe it came to pa≈ø≈øe, that Lucius a King of this Countrie, was drawne to a liking of Chri≈øtian Religion. Where we plainely ≈øee this Prote≈øtant Bishop and Antiquarie would make this PudeÃÑs to haue preached heare in Britaine, and to haue bene one of them, which gaue continuance to the faith formerly preached heare, euen to the time of King Lucius; when it is euident not onely by all other Hi≈øtories which tell vs he liued and died in Cappadocia, but by their Prote≈øtant Archbishop, and Antiquary, and this Prote≈øtant Bishop him≈øelfe, and his owne Authour, Martial liuing in that time and acquainted both with the man, and his Iorney, that he was a corporall and bodily ≈øouldiar, and warryer for the Romans. Eques Romanus, Tribunus militum, which the la≈øte ver≈øe cited from Martial plainely proueth, and neuer came neare vnto this kingdome, the neare≈øt when he was in Italy, for Parrha≈øia where Martiall ≈øaith he was, and this Prote≈øtant Bishop ab≈øurdlie citeth again≈øt him≈øelfe, is Archadia, and all Archadia called often by that name, farther hence then Rome is, and what Scythia ≈øoeuer A≈øiatica, or Europaea S. Pudens was in, or neare vnto, ≈øuer we are, that Britaine is farre remote from any part of any Scythia, and as I haue shewed before, his body was brought from Cappadocia to Rome, and there interred: And by ≈øome auncient Authorities, that probably he was returned aliue from the warrs of Cappadocia vnto Rome, died and was buried there. Romae Sancti Pudentis Senatoris, Patris S. Pudentianae Virginis, qui ab Apo≈øtolis Chri≈øto in bapti≈ømo ve≈øtitus innocentem tunicam v≈øque ad vitae coronam immaculate cu≈øtodiuit. Which te≈øtimonie al≈øo confirmeth their opinion, which write, that this Brittish hou≈øe was according to the Roman Tradition, primum Principis Apo≈øtolorum Romae ho≈øpitium, illicque primum Chri≈øtianos conueni≈ø≈øe ad Synaxim, coactam Eccle≈øiam: The fir≈øt lodging of S. Peter at Rome, being there fifteene yeares before S. Paule, and the fir≈øt Church of Chri≈øtians in Rome where they a≈ø≈øembled to ≈øerue God, from the fir≈øt preaching of Chri≈øt there by S. Peter; for although S. Paul maketh that ≈øpeciall memory of S. Pudens, and Claudia, yet here we are told by vndeniable Authoritie, S. Claudia her hou≈øe in Rome what profit it brought to Chri≈øtian R ‚Ä¢ ligion. be≈øides the Roman Tradition, that they were al≈øo S. Peters di≈øciples, ≈øignified in the worde Apo≈øtolis Apo≈øtles in the plurall number, when no Apo≈øtles but S. Peter and S. Paule came thither in tho≈øe times. And ≈øo this hou≈øe of our holy Chri≈øtian Britans being the then principall Church for S. Peter, S. Paul, the Popes which ≈øucceeded, among whome S. Linus is reckoned by 2. Tim. 4. S. Paul, together with the owners of that holy hou≈øe, as commonly re≈øident S. Claudia her knowne learning, and other vertues. therein, we may ea≈øely gather how greate ≈øpirituall good flowed to this Nation, from that onely fountaine, and well of life, in this we≈øterne world, where the Chri≈øtian Parents of S. Claudia before her, she and her Husband Iacob. Bergom. l. de Poeti≈ø≈øis. Harris Theater. l. 1. c. 21. S. Pudens after, and after them their holy children gaue the greate≈øt entertaynement, and releife to the holy Apo≈øtles, their Di≈øciples, and Succe≈ø≈øours, and
others the ≈øeruants of Chri≈øt in tho≈øe dangerous dayes of Per≈øecution. Of this our renowned Country woman it is written by ≈øtrangers: Claudia Rufina mulier Britannica, vtraque lingua erudita: Claudia Rufina a Briton borne was learned and skillfull in both tongues, both Greeke and Latine. Which our English Prote≈øtant Antiquaries, and others confirme, affirming the ≈øame of her. Haec Io. Bal. l. de Scriptor. cent. 1. Io. Pit≈ø. l. de Illu≈øt. Brit. Script. aetat. 2. in Claudia Ruffina. magno praedita ingenio mulier, tam Latin√® quam Grec√®, and regi≈øter her among the learned writers of this Nation, deliuering vnto vs the names of diuers bookes penned by her.

10. What her worthines was, I haue ≈øomewhat related from S. Chry≈øo≈øtome, and Theodoret before. And be≈øides the te≈øtimonie of S. Paule, making her one of the foure mo≈øt renowned in Rome, & the onelie Worthie both of Britaine, and the≈øe we≈øtern Nations, except S. Eubulus was her Father and our Countriman, which is remembred in holy Scripturs. What a meanes and help she was to propagate the faith of Chri≈øt both to her Countrymen, and others at Rome, Italy, e≈øpecially in Vmbria where she liued after her going from Rome, and in this our Britaine, we may be a≈ø≈øured both by that is ≈øaid before, that her hou≈øe was the cheife≈øt and v≈øuall a≈ø≈øembling place in that time, for ≈øuch Religeous de≈øignements, as al≈øo by the receaued and approued Hi≈øtories of her holy children, as namely S. Pudentiana and S. Praxedes, which she had brought vp in ≈øo greate ≈øanctitie, both by her in≈øtructions, and example, that together with their two Brethren S. Nouatus and S. Timotheus they are honoured in the Catalogue of holy Saints. Of one we reade, that in Acta S. Praxedis in Breuiar. Rom. 21. Iulij. Martyr. Rom. eod. die. Sic Bed. V≈øuard. Ado. Sur. & Lipp. eod. die. the Per≈øecution vnder Marcus Antonius the Emperour, her Parents being now deade: Chri≈øtianos facultatibus, opera, con≈øolatione & omni charitatis officio pro≈øequebatur, nam alios domi occultabat: alios ad fidei con≈øtantiam hortabatur: aliorum corpora ≈øepeliebat: ijs qui in carcere inclu≈øi erant, qui in erga≈øtulis nulla re deerat: The per≈øecuted Chri≈øtians she a≈øsi≈øted with her welth, labour, confort, and all offices of charitie: for ≈øome she did hide in her hou≈øe; others she exhorted to con≈øtancy of faith: she buryed the bodies of others: To tho≈øe that were in pri≈øon, and durance, she was wanting in no kinde of releife. Of her Si≈øter S. Pudentiana, we reade, that Act. S. PudeÃÑtianae in Breu. Rom. die 19. Maij. Mart. Rom. eod. die. Ado Treuer. ad 12. Calend. Iulij. Momb ‚Ä¢ it. tom. 2. Beda & V≈øuard. 19. die Maij. Sur. & Lipp. eod. die. she was of admirable ≈øanctitie in Chri≈øtian Religion. She had in her family notwith≈øtanding the Per≈øecution 96. Chri≈øtian men: nonaginta ≈øex homines. And whereas the Emperour Antonius had made a Decree, that Chri≈øtians should not publikly offer their Sacrifice, the holy Pope S. Pius with the ChristiaÃÑs v≈øed to ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe in her hou≈øe: Quod autem ab Antonino Imperatore ≈øancitum erat, ne Chri≈øtiani public√® ≈øacrificia facerent, Pius Pontifex in aedibus Pudentianae cum Chri≈øtianis ≈øacra celebrabat: And she gently entertayned them, and ministred all nece≈ø≈øaries vnto them: Quibus illa benign√® acceptis, quae ad vitam nece≈ø≈øaria e≈ø≈øent ≈øuppeditabat. Therefore if this ≈øanctitie of the≈øe childen was deriued vnto them from their holy Parents and after their deaths, when their Ritches and Reuenewes were diuidie into ≈øo S. Claudia her ‚Ä¢ ou≈øe as a Chri≈øtiaÃÑ ≈øchoole and Seminarie to teach the Chri≈øtian faith in Britaine and the we≈øterne NatioÃÑs. many portions, one onely daughter dwelling in that their hou≈øe at Rome, was able to keepe ≈øuch ho≈øpitalitie that be≈øides 96. Chri≈øtian men which she kept in her family, she receaued the Pope, and all Chri≈øtians re≈øorting to her, and ≈øupplyed both their ≈øpirituall nece≈ø≈øities in making her hou≈øe their ≈øetled Church to celebrate Ma≈ø≈øe, and other diuine exerci≈øes, and mini≈øtred al≈øo temporall things vnto them, as their needs required: how much the rather mu≈øt we conclude the≈øe things of their holy Parents, more enabled to performe ≈øuch bounties, then any their children were. And this much more in the time of the parens of S. Claudia, being by exemption as ≈øtrangers, not ≈øo lyable to the Roman Pagan lawes, and penalties of them, and ≈øo Chri≈øtian A≈ø≈øemblies
were more frequent, and freely kept there, then in any Roman hou≈øe, the Apo≈øtles and their Di≈øciples there more ≈øecurely entertayned, Religion exerci≈øed, Prei≈øts, & Cleargie men con≈øecrated and directed into diuers Countries, and among ≈øo many, ≈øo greate multitudes of Chri≈øtian Britans liuing in that hou≈øe, and v≈øually re≈øorting thither, and there in≈øtructed, we may not thinke but diuers Britans then and there, receaued holy prei≈øtly Orders, and con≈øecration: And with others were ≈øent into this kingdome, ≈øome of which number I shall remember hereafter, when I haue fir≈øt brought S. Peter againe from Britaine to Rome, becau≈øe they principally depended one him, and by him, or his Suece≈ø≈øours receaued Con≈øecration, Iuri≈ødiction, Directions and In≈øtructions, for the Conuer≈øion of this, and other we≈øtern Countries. After a long and happy life ≈øpent in ≈øuch ≈øanctitie she ended her dayes at Sabinum in Vmbria, whether she retired her≈øelfe, to her Husband S. Pudens his noble hou≈øe, and Municipium there, after his death.

div.head: THE XXXIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF S. PETER HIS RETVRNE FROM BRItaine to Rome, and ≈øetling the Apo≈øtolike Papall power there. His greate care of Britaine: and our Chri≈øtian Britans dutifull loue, and honor to him. The cheife Scate of the Me≈øsias Prophe≈øied to be at Rome.

Peter, & ≈øo from him to remaine in his Succe≈ø≈øors, in that prime Apo≈øtolike See, and the time of his death now drawing neare, hauing allmo≈øt ended his preaching in the≈øe parts of the world, to giue that further honor to this kingdome of Britaine, an Angel appeared vnto him, telling him, the time of his leauing this world was at hand, and that he mu≈øt returne to Rome, where after he S. Peter admonished in Britaine from heauen of his death at haÃÑd to be in Rome. had ≈øuffered death vpon the Cro≈ø≈øe, he should receaue his reward of Iu≈øtice: Angelicam aspexit vi≈øionem, quae dicebat; Petre in≈øtat tempus tuae re≈øolutionis, & aportet te ire Romam: in qua cum mortem per crucem ≈øu≈øtinueris, recipies mercedem iu≈øtitiae.
