And this cannot be well con≈øtrued to be that admonition of his death which S. Peter wrote off in his Epi≈øtle, being both ob≈øcure, and in all probable Iudgment after the writing of that his Epi≈øtle, and immediatly before his apprehen≈øion, and death, as appeareth by tho≈øe Authours, affirming S. Peter was pre≈øently taken and martyred: conu ‚Ä¢ r≈øus in vrbem redijt, captu≈øque √† per≈øecutoribus cruci adiudicatus. Therefore ≈øeeing be≈øides this ≈øo ob≈øcure admonition giuen to S. Peter by Chri≈øt of his death, we finde no other, but that mo≈øt cleare and manife≈øt foretelling thereof to S. Peter, by an holy Angel in Britaine, we mu≈øt needs conclude that the holy Apo≈øtle in that pa≈ø≈øadge of his Epi≈øtle, how he should shortly leaue the Tabernacle and dwelling place of his ≈øoule, his mortall body, as our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt had shewed vnto him, did this Nation that honour, to remember in his holy writings, that fore≈øight and admonition of his end approaching made vnto him by the heauenly vi≈øion and In≈øtruction thereof, which he had in Britaine. And ≈øignifiing in the fir≈øt words of this his la≈øte Epi≈øtle that he wrote it to all beleeuing Chri≈øtians at that time, ≈øaying: Simon Peter a Seruant and an Apo≈øtle 2. Petr. 1. v. 1. 2. of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, to them that haue obtayned like pretious faith with vs, grace and peace S. Peters care and loue to Britaine to his death, and after in heauen by his owne promi≈øe. be multiplied. We mu≈øt needs acknowledge, that coming then immediately from the Chri≈øtians in this Nation, whome he had ≈øo lately conuerted, he mo≈øt fatherly remembred them with others in tho≈øe words, and the whole Epi≈øtle following, e≈øpecially where he writeth: I thinke it meete, as long as I am in this Tabernacle, to ≈øtirre you vp, by putting you in remembrance. Knowing that Ver≈ø. 13. 14. 15. shortly I mu≈øt pute of this my Tabernacle; euen as our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt hath shewed mee. Moreouer, I will endeuour that you may be able after my decea≈øe, to haue the≈øe things allwayes in remembrance. In which wordes this our kingdome of Britaine doth mo≈øt iu≈øtly claime, that S. Peter remembred it, and rather then any other, citing there the admonition, which he receaued by the holy Angell heare, and there prote≈øteth his greate care he had of this CouÃÑtry, that it might not onely during his life but after his death remaine con≈øtant in the profe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øtian Religion. And by Oecumenius and diuers others, both the Greeke and Latine Text giuing way to that expo≈øition, S. Peter did there promi≈øe Oecumenius in verba illa: Dado operam &c. 2. Petr. 1. v. 15. to remember this Nation, not onely during his life, but after when he should be in Heauen, as I haue shewed by diuers examples from auncient and credible Authours before, & shall remember more hereafter. And in the next ver≈øe he proueth, that he principally heare remembred Britaine, and tho≈øe Nations, to which he had par≈øonally preached, for he ≈øaith: We haue not followed 2. Petr. 1. v. 16. cunningly deui≈øed fables, when we made knowne vnto you the power and coming ‚Ä¢ f our Lord Ie≈øus Christ, but were eye witne≈ø≈øes of his Maiestie. Where he plaine
‚Ä¢ y ≈øpeaketh, of ≈øuch people, and Nations, to whome he had made knowne
the power of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, by his preaching, ≈øuch as Britaine was.

3. And when being to leaue this world and his cheif Pa≈øtorall chardge, which might not die with him, to his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor, we mu≈øt further acknowledge, how mindefull he was of this kingdome, with others in that de≈øignement, whether he con≈øtituted S. Linus, or S. Clement, to be his next Succe≈ø≈øor; for the fir≈øt as I haue shewed before, was familiarly knowne to our Chri≈øtian Britans, and lyued mo≈øt with them in Rome, and the other. S. Clement was not onely in the ≈øame e≈øtate, but was par≈øonally heare with S. Peter in this Nation. Neyther were our Chri≈øtian Britans then vnmindfull or vngratefull for ≈øo many fauours of S. Peter vnto this Country, but euer continued mo≈øt dutifull, and faithfull vnto him without any di≈øcontinuance of tho≈øe ob≈øequies vnto him; for as I haue probably shewed they were the fir≈øt that entertayned him in Rome, and after: ≈øo I cannot without preiudice, and iniury The greate honor, & loue of our fir≈øt Christian Britans to S. Peter: and how probably diuers of them, honorably buried him. vnto this kingdome thinke, but they were cheifely Chri≈øtian Britans that performed the la≈øt and funerall duties to that holy Apo≈øtle, among whom likely was S. Marcellus Di≈øciple of S. Peter, by birth a noble Britan, of whom I will ≈øpeake more hereafter, for we reade in many, that one of S. Peters Di≈øciples ≈øo named did honorably bury that glorious Apo≈øtle martyred by the cruell Tirant Nero. Marcellus quidam Di≈øcipulus S. Petri accepit Corpus Apo≈øtoli, Bed. Hom. de S. Petro & Paulo Tom. 7. oper. Guliel. Ei≈øengr. centur. 2. part. 6. D ‚Ä¢ ≈øt. 1. S. Anton. Vinc. Petr. de Nat. apud Magdebur. cent. 1. l. 2. c. 12. 650. 2. Tim. 4. & lauit illud tali vnguento, quod nunquam po≈ø≈øet putre≈øcere, & postea mi≈øit illud in monumento. Yet I finde that there was an other Marcellus in this time a Roman borne, Marci vrbis Romae Praefecti filius, that ≈øometime followed Simon Magus, and was conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt by S. Peter, and wrote among other works the Acts of S. Peter, and S. Paul. But this man being thought to be martyred by Nero, cannot ≈øo well be adiudged to haue bene the buryer of S. Peter, ≈øeeing S. Peters Martyrdome was one of Nero his la≈øt Actions. And we may not doubt, but our Britans that fir≈øt receaued S. Peter in their hou≈øe at Rome, and were euer afterward mo≈øt faithfull and true vnto him both at libertie and in pri≈øon, as we are taught by their loue to S. Paul in like ca≈øe te≈øtified by him≈øelfe, and brought vp their children in ≈øuch ≈øorte that among other Acts of Chri≈øtian pietie, we finde as in S. Praxedes, that they Vita S. Praxed. in Breuiar. die. 21. Col. Iulij. buried the bodies of the holy martyrs; Imperatore Chri≈øtianos per≈øequente, eos facultatibus, opera, con≈øolatione, & omni charitatis officio pro≈øequebatur. Nam alios domi occultabat: alios ad fidei con≈øtantiam hortabatur: aliorum corpora ≈øepeliebat: ijs qui in carcere inclu≈øi erant, qui in erga≈øtulis exercebantur, nulla re deerat: Therefore much more we may iudge, that the holy parents their Chri≈øtian Brittish family and friends, who from the fir≈øt coming of S. Peter to Rome had mini≈øtred in ≈øuch duties vnto him, were not wanting to performe this la≈øt and Antiquit. Gla≈øt. Capgr. Cat. in S. Io≈øeph. Hard. in chron. Stow hi≈øt. Cornelius Tacit. in Vita Agricolae. farewell ob≈øequie to that greate≈øt Apo≈øtle: both in re≈øpect, their greate loue and effection to S. Peter, be ≈øufficient Te≈øtimonialls thereof, and aboue all others they might more freely performe it, then many others. For the Romans did not intermeddle then with the Britans in matters of Religion, but left ≈øuch affaires to their owne Gouernment, and Brittish Gouernours, as we ≈øee in their Kings then Aruiragus, Marius, Coillus, and Lucius, all friends and fauourers That neither S. PudeÃÑs, S. Claudia, any of their family, or any Britan was then punishable by the Romans for Religion. of Chri≈øtians, before Lucius was conuerted to the faith, openly to profe≈ø≈øe it, and none of them ioyned with the Pagan Romans in their Religion. which we cannot affirme ≈øo freely of France, where Claudius had forbidden the v≈øe of their old Religion, which in Britaine neyther he nor any other Emperour had done, but the Chri≈øtian Britans did both at home, and els where
vnder the Romans quietly enioy the free v≈øe of the Religion of Chri≈øt, vntill the Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian.

4. If any man obiect, that S. Pudens husband to S. Claudia was a Roman, and ≈øo ≈øubiect to their Lawes in Religion. I an≈øweare fir≈øt, that it is euident before, that the Father of S. Claudia, a Chri≈øtian and cheife commander in that family, was yet lyuing, and long time after. Secondly I an≈øweare, that S. Pudens him≈øelfe was but a Municeps, and no Romane, partaker thereby of the Roman priuiledges, and immunities, but not ≈øubiect to their penalties; e≈øpecially in things concerning Religion, as is te≈øtified by Aulus Gellius, and others their owne writers. Municipes ≈øunt ciues Romani ex municipijs ≈øuis ≈øuo Aul. Gellius Noct. attic. l. 16. c. 13. Io. Selden Analect. p. 39. Cicero l. 2. de legibus. Iure & legibus ≈øuis vtentes, muneris tantum cum Populo Romano honorarij participes, a quo munere cape≈ø≈øendo appellati videntur, nullis alijs nece≈ø≈øitatibus, neque vlla populi Romani lege a≈øtricti. Marcus Tullius Cicero hath the like euen in matters of Religion, and diuers others. Therefore a Prote≈øtant Antiquarie boldly concludeth, that by the Roman Lawes, the Municipes ≈øuch as S. Pudens was, might be of what Religion they would, without controlement. Tanta municipiorum videtur fui≈ø≈øe libertas, vt maiorum ac auitis ≈øibique proprijs ≈øacris vti minime prohiberentur. Selden ≈øupr.

div.head: THE XXXIV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: ENTREATING OF THE TIME OF POPE Linus, Vespa≈øian Emperor, and Marius King of Britaine: and of our Chri≈øtians in tho≈øe dayes, both at Rome, in Britaine, and other places.

div.p: 1. THE cheife Gouernour of the Church of Chri≈øt S. Peter, hauing now happily by holy Martyrdome ended his labours in this world, and obtained his Crowne, and reward, in heaueÃÑ; as an other ≈øucceeded him, in that high Pa≈øtorall chardge After the death of Nero, others enioy the Empire a very shorte time. in ≈øpirituall things: ≈øo al≈øo at, or ≈øoone after that time, the ≈øupreame Gouernors in temporall affaires, both in the Roman Empire, and this kingdome of Britaine were changed. Nero the Emperor the ≈øame yeare he Eu≈øeb. in Chron. Matt. We≈øtm. in Galba. Otho. & Vitell. Marrian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. Martin. Polon. in Supput. Flor. Wigorn. & al ‚Ä¢ j. Martyred the holy Apo≈øtles, murthered him≈øelfe, and Galba was Emperor though a short time of ≈øixe monethes or litle more, and Otho who ≈øtewe Galba, was an Emperor allthough of a le≈ø≈øe continuance, for being in the fourth battaile he fought with Vitellius, conquered by him, hauing had victory in the three former, impatient of dishonor killed him≈øelfe, bearing the name of Emperor but three monethes. And Vitellius which triumphed ouer him, enioyed as short an Imperiall life, onely eight monethes long, as his death, for his cruell wickednes was dishonorable, ≈øtabbed to death, ca≈øt into the Riuer of Tyber, and wanting buriall. Cum Vitellius multa crudeliter, ac nequiter Romae ageret, minuti≈øsimorum ictuum punctionibus e≈øt excarnificatus, & ad Ve≈øpa≈øian Emperour. vltimum in Tyberim mer≈øus, communi caruit Sepultura. After the≈øe Ve≈øpa≈øian was Marius King in Britaine, no Per≈øecutor of Chri≈øtiaÃÑs, but a freind, and Benefactor to theÃÑ. inue≈øted in the Empire enioying it allmo≈øt eleuen yeares.

2. In Britaine Marius commonly e≈øteemed the ≈øonne of Aruiragus, and Genui≈ø≈øa, the reputed daughter of Claudius, was King: and both the≈øe ≈øo
farre from being enemies and Per≈øecutors of Chri≈øtians, that King Marius is by diuers, as I haue shewed before, reported to be a Chri≈øtian, and by all opinions both a friend, and Benefactor vnto them, confirming vnto the Chri≈øtian Eremites of Aualon, S. Io≈øeph and his A≈ø≈øociates tho≈øe Donations, liberties, and Immunities which his Father King Aruiragus had formerly granted Iohn Harding Cronicle c. 47. vnto them. And the Emperor Ve≈øpa≈øian whas ≈øo friendly and fauourable to holy Chri≈øtians, that when he was in Britaine, before he was Emperour, as Ve≈øpa≈øian Emperour al≈øo a freind to Chri≈øtians, and thought to haue beleeued in Chri≈øt. Harding from more auncient Authours hath te≈øtified, he procured tho≈øe Immunities, and Exemptions for S. Io≈øeph, and his company, which King Aruiragus endowed them with. And I doe not doubt, but he was ≈øo farre a Chri≈øtian in iudgment, that I may recompt him in the number of tho≈øe fir≈øt Emperours of whome Tertullian thus writeth: The Emperours them≈øelues would haue Tertullian. Apol. contr. gent. c. 21. beleeued in Christ, if the Emperours had not bene nece≈ø≈øarie to the world, or men that where Chri≈øtians might haue bene Emperours: Sed & Cae≈øares credidi≈ø≈øent ≈øuper Chri≈øto: ≈øi aut Cae≈øares non e≈ø≈øent ≈øaeculo nece≈ø≈øarij: aut ≈øi & Chri≈øtiani potui≈ø≈øent e≈ø≈øe Cae≈øares. For we finde in auÃÑcient Hi≈øtories, Manu≈øcripts and others written diuers Manu≈øc. French hi≈øt. pr. Or que nous ≈øommes. hundred yeares ≈øince, that this Ve≈øpa≈øian being Miraculou≈øely cured of a naturally irrecouerable de≈øea≈øe, by the power of Chri≈øt, did plainely acknowledge him to be the ≈øonne of God, fuist le filz de Dieu, And promi≈øed therevpon to reuendge his death vpon the Iewes. Which he performed, when he ≈øacked Hieru≈øalem, and ≈øo ≈ølaued that people. For executing which Iu≈øtice of God, and de≈øolation of the Iewish Nation, this kingdome of Britaine, though ≈øo farre di≈øtant thence, was pre≈øent there, as both Haebrew & English writers euen Prote≈øtant Mini≈øters are witne≈ø≈øes, with 20000. ≈øouldiers. I 20000. Britans ≈øerued under Ve≈øpa≈øian, at the ≈øacking of Hieru≈øalem by Ve≈øpa≈øiaÃÑ and Titus.
reade (≈øaith a learned Prote≈øtant Antiquarie and Mini≈øter) in Io≈øeph Bengorion a very authenticall Haebrew Authour, a Te≈øtimony of the pa≈ø≈øing of twentie thow≈øand Britans valiant ≈øouldiers to the ≈øeige and fearefull ≈øacking of Hieru≈øalem vnder the conduct of Ve≈øpa≈øian and Titus the Roman Emperour. Therefore ≈øo many thow≈øands going ≈øo greate a Iorney, to fight vnder ≈øo Chri≈øtanly a minded Generall, and for the Quarrell of Chri≈øt, we cannot thinke but many of the≈øe were Io≈øeph Bengor. apud Rich. Hakluit praef. l. Nauigat. Angl. al≈øo in iudgment, Act, or both, Chri≈øtians.

3. And ≈øo we may worthely regi≈øter Britaine for one of the fir≈øt beleeuing Nations, though ≈øo farre di≈øtant from the place of the life, death, and fir≈øt preaching Credible that many of the≈øe Britans were Chsi≈øtians. of Chri≈øt, and boldly ≈øay, it was the fir≈øt, cheife≈øt, principall, or onely kingdome that ≈øent ≈øo greate forces, and ≈øo farre of, through ≈øo many difficulties, to execute the iu≈øt Reuendge of God vpon his Enemyes. And the Chri≈øtian either publike profe≈ø≈øion, or knowne di≈øpo≈øition of many Brittish Souldiars there mixed with the Romans vnder Ve≈øpa≈øian, mu≈øt needs be a Motiue to iu≈øtifie his words for true, to force Io≈øephus to tho≈øe forcible complaints to the Iewes at that time, that they could not expect any help froÃÑ God, for as Oratio Io≈øephi ad Iudaeos Ege≈øippus l. 5. excid. Hiero≈øolymitani cap. 15. they had for≈øaken him, ≈øo he al≈øo had for≈øaken them. And he that was wont to defend them, was gone to the Romans their Enemyes, who then worshiped the true God, whome the Iewes had offended, and the true God was with the Romans: an prae≈øidium ≈øperatur diuinum, atque auxilium de penetralibus? Sed qui nos defendebat, ad hostem migrauit: quoniam quem nos colebamus, Romani venerantur, nos offendimus. Quis autem ignorat cum illis e≈ø≈øe deum? So that whether ≈øoeuer we goe where BritaÃÑs Io≈øephus & Ege≈øipp. ≈øupr. were in that time, either in Iury about Hieru≈øaleÃÑ, where the faith of Chri≈øt was fir≈øt preached, or Rome in Italy where the cheife Vicar of Chri≈øt was ≈øeated, The cheife Rulers in Britaine friends to Chri≈øtians in this time. or in Britaine, then termed by Io≈øephus and Ege≈øippus an other world: Quid attexam Britannias, interfu≈øo Mari a toto orbe diui≈øas, & a Romanis in orbem
terrarum redactas. We finde there were many Chri≈øtians among them. And their cheife Rulers euen in temporall affaires, not vnchri≈øtinaly minded, as Vespa≈øian in Iury, King Marius in Britaine, at Rome Coillus, his ≈øonne afterward King heare brought vp at Rome euen from his Infancy, hic ab Infantia Romae nutritus, a greate friend to Chri≈øtians, both there, and in Britaine, when Matth. We≈øtm. an. 78. Galfrid. Monum. li. 4. ca. 18. PoÃÑtic. Virun. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 4. Stow Hi≈øt. in Coillus. he came to Rule.

4. And to come to the ≈øpirituall cheife Gouernour of the Church of Chri≈øt in the See at Rome in this time (to defere the Que≈øtion whether S. Linus, or S. Clement immediately ≈øucceeded to S. Peter vntill I come to S. Clements place, by common computation) and heare to followe that opinion, which the Church of Chri≈øt ≈øeemeth to preferre, that S. Linus was S. Peters next ≈øucce≈ø≈øour, in the Papall Gouernment, Linus Pontifex primus post Petrum Breuiar. Rom. die 23. Septemb. in S. Lino. gubernauit Eccle≈øiam: How carefull and mindefull this Pope was of the ≈øpirituall good of this Nation, and the meanes he had to effect it, may be gathered by his acquaintance, and familiarity, which he had with our Britans, then remayning Pope Linus his care of Britaine. at Rome, by whom, and with whom, he was mo≈øt releiued, and re≈øident, as is before related. And to in≈øtance in ≈øome particulars; it ≈øeemeth that both S. Beatus, and his other holy Brittish companion of whome I haue H ‚Ä¢ con≈øecrateth diuers Brittish Prei≈øts of this Nation. ≈øpoken before, were con≈øecrated Prei≈øts and ≈øent into the≈øe parts by this Pope S. Linus: To which opinion both our English and German Prote≈øtants with other Authours induce me. Our English Prote≈øtant Antiquaries write in this manner: As Beatus Rhenanus, in his Hi≈øtorie of Germanie, Pantaleon, and others Theater of great Britaine l. 6. ¬ß. 9. doe reporte, one Suetonius a Noble mans ≈øonne in Britaine conuerted to the faith, by the fir≈øt Planters of the Gho≈øpell in this Iland, and after his bapti≈øme called Beatus, was ≈øent by the Brethren, from hence vnto Rome, to be better in≈øtructed, and further directed by Saint Peter. By which, and that I haue proued before, that S. Peter was put to death ≈øoone after his returne to Rome from hence, it may well be concluded, that S. Beatus and con≈øequently al≈øo his companion in the ≈øame ca≈øe were con≈øecrated by S. Linus, and not by S. Peter: for Pantaleon proueth, that the≈øe men were long at Rome to be in≈øtructed both in faith, and learning, requi≈øite for ≈øuch Eccle≈øia≈øticall par≈øons, before they were con≈øecrated Prei≈øts, and directed into the≈øe Countries, and this rather by S. Peters ≈øucce≈øfor, then by him≈øelfe then Martyred and in heauen; S. Beatus Heluetiorum Apo≈øtolus. Henric. Pantal. de viris Illu≈øtrib. Germ. parte 1. p. 114. Stumpff. l. 7. Bibliotheca Patrum minor. Chronic. chronicor. tom. 2. Beatus ille nobilibus parentibus natus ex Britania RomaÃÑ profectus e≈øt, vt a S. Petro, in vera fide rectius in≈øtitucretur. Cum autem in humanioribus literis optime profeci≈ø≈øet, atque Suetonius diceretur, Chri≈øtianis dignus vi≈øus e≈øt, qui doctrinaÃÑ veram perciperet, atque eandem vbique di≈ø≈øeminaret. Which could not be well effected in ≈øo short a time, as is shewed before S. Peter liued after his returne from Britaine to Rome. Therefore I mu≈øt needs a≈ø≈øcribe it, to the time and ordinance of S. Linus. Which I may ≈øafely affirme in both opinions concerning S. Linus, a≈øwell of them which deny him to haue bene Pope, and affirme that what he did in Papall affaires, he did it by S. Peters direction, and appointment: ex praecepto beatt Petri Apo≈øtoli: as al≈øo of ≈øuch, as ≈øay, he was true Pope, and immediate ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to S. Peter, in which la≈øt opinion there can Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. Mart. Polon. Supput. in S. Lino. Leo 2. epi≈øt. decret. Florent. Wigorn. in Siluan. & Otho. be no pretence of difficultie at all; And in the former opinion, allthough we may not without iu≈øt rea≈øon ≈øay, that, Exp ‚Ä¢ aecepto Petri, S. Linus proceedings by commandment of S. Peter are to be vnder≈øtood of things he did in the life of S. Peter, and time of his ab≈øence from Rome, for if S. Linus was not Pope after, but S. Clement, it should rather be ≈øaid that S. Linus did ex praecepto S. Clementis, as S. Clement then liuing commanded and directed, then by the
commandement of S. Peter, who being dead neither could command as Pope, nor be e≈øteemed Pope: yet we may lawfully ≈øuppo≈øe, that S. Peter who had bene in Britaine, and had ≈øuch care thereof, And ≈øeeing in his life time S. Beatus, and his Brittish companions, went ≈øo long a Iorney, as from hence to Rome to be in≈øtructed in the faith, and de≈øirous to be con≈øecrated Prei≈øts, to preach in their Countrie, would giue chardge, and direction to S. Linus, his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to performe tho≈øe duties for the ≈øpirituall good, and honor of this Nation.

5. And ≈øo we may probably vpon ≈øufficient warrant ≈øuppo≈øe, the≈øe holy Brittish Prei≈øts, and Saints were directed into the≈øe parts, both by S. Peter, and S. Linus Authoritie, and Order. By this holy Pope al≈øo were ≈øuch Britans, as were Chri≈øtians in Rome at that time in≈øtructed, the mo≈øt principall place of S. Linus Re≈øidence being then in the hou≈øe of S. Claudia our Brittish Lady, and ≈øo ordinary and v≈øuall that S. Paul before ≈øeemeth to number, and accompt him one of that family, Eubulus greeteth thee, and Pudens, and Linus and Claudia; that hou≈øe being as is allready shewed, the mo≈øt knowne and frequeÃÑt place of Chri≈øtiaÃÑs in Rome eyther to in≈øtruct, or be in≈øtructed in ReligioÃÑ, mini≈øter or receaue the holy Sacraments thereof. And allthough King Coillus of Britaine, did not openly profe≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe a Chri≈øtian at that time, for feare of the Roman Emperour, and Senate; yet being brought vp at Rome, and in this time, and ≈øo farre a Chri≈øtian in iudgment, and affection, that he confirmed to the Eremits of Gla≈øtenbury, tho≈øe immunities and priuiledges, which Antiquit. Gla≈øt. in tabula antiq. Io. Capgr. Cat. in S. Io≈øepho Ara. Gulielm. Malm. l. de antiq. coenobij Gla≈øt. M. S. his Grandfather, and Father, Kings, Aruiragus, and Marius had graunted before vnto them, we mu≈øt needs affirme, that he learned this his ≈øo greate allowance, and loue to Chri≈øtians, and their Religion at Rome from S. Linus and his Di≈øciples, in who≈øe time of Papacy he liued, and had his education and In≈øtruction there by all Antiquities. And to giue vs a≈ø≈øurance that this S. Linus had a Pa≈øtorall care, as part of his greate chardge, and cuer, as nece≈ø≈øitie required, and the times would permite, to ≈øend Bishops, and preachers into the≈øe parts where Britaine is, we are told by diuers French Hi≈øtorians, and from their primatiue Antiquities: that euen in the fir≈øt yeare of his dignitie, he ≈øent Saint Cler, to the Realme of Britanny Armorike, who brought with him the Mere des hi≈øtoires & chroniques de France lib. 1. fol. 87. Alani Bouchard. Annales de Bretaigne l. 1. f. 19. Nayle, wherewith the right Arme of S. Peter was crucefied, and S. Cler there ≈øetled his Epi≈øcopall See in the city of Nantes in the yeare of grace 72.

div.head: THE XXXV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE STATE OF CHRISTIAN RELIGION in Britaine in the time of Pope Cletus, King Marius, or Coillus: and how we had heare in Britaine a continued Succe≈øsion both of Prei≈øts and Bishops all this fir≈øt hundred of yeares.

div.p: 1. S. Linus being martyred, S. Cletus ≈øucceeded him in the Apo≈øtolike Roman See, and was Pope aboue 11. yeares: And for temporall Rulers Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter and diuers after him doe te≈øtifie, that King Marius died in the 78. yeare of Chri≈øt, & left Coillus his ≈øonne his Succe≈ø≈øour in this kingdome, Anno gratiae 78. Marius Britannorum Matth. We≈øtm. an. 78. Catalog. Regum Britann. in Mario. Stowe Hi≈øt. in Marius. Harding Cronicle in King Marius. c. 50. fol. 42. Rex, ab hoc ≈øeculo tran≈øiens, Coillum filium habuit ≈øucce≈ø≈øorem. By whom he reigned but a short time, not aboue ≈øixe yeares. Others affirme he reigned a farre longer time, the Prote≈øtant Publishers of the Brittish Hi≈øtorie a≈øcribe 52. yeares for his Reigne, Polidor Virgil giueth him 48. yeares, Stowe ≈øaith he reigned 53. yeares, Harding auoucheth that he dyed,

lg.l: When he had Reigned ≈øixtie yeares and three.
His Tribute payed full well to Rome Citie.
Of Chri≈øts faith ≈øome what he was enformed,
But much more he needed to haue bene reformed.

div.p: But how≈øoeuer the que≈øtion about the time of his Regiment, long or short, be re≈øolued; certaine it is, that he was a friend to Chri≈øtians, and if he reigned long, longer was their peace by his permi≈ø≈øion, and if his Regiment was shorter yet the quiet of Chri≈øtian Religion was not thereby abbreuiated, for Coillus his Sonne being al≈øo very fauourably affected to Chri≈øtians, and leauing the Kingdome to his Sonne Lucius, vnder whome the whole Nation was conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, we cannot finde any King of Britaine in tho≈øe dayes, which was an enemy to Chri≈øtianitie; ≈øo that if any outrage or crueltie was committed again≈øt any of that profe≈ø≈øion, it was rather by the malice of Marian. Scot. lib. 2. aetat. 6. in Tit. Martin Polon. Supput. col. 36. in Tit. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 81. Florent. Wig. in Tit. the Druids, and ≈øome ≈øuch, and not by regall commaunde, and Authoritie, which rather ≈øtood for the defence, then offence of Chri≈øtians all that time.

2. And ≈øo long as Titus Sonne of Ve≈øpa≈øian was Emperour of Rome, which was but two yeares, and not many moneths, ther was no Per≈øecution of Chri≈øtians there not putting any of them to death, and ≈øo mercifull he was to all, that he pardoned the very conuicted, that had con≈øpired again≈øt him, and v≈øed them as familiarly as he did before. vir omni genere virtutum mirabilis, adeo vt amor & deliciae humani generis diceretur. Hic in Imperio tantae bonitatis Domitian a v ‚Ä¢ ry wicked and per≈øecuting Emperour. fuit, vt nullius omnino ≈øanguinem fuderit, ≈øed conuictos aduer≈øum ≈øe coniurationis dimitteret, atque in eadem familiaritate, qua antea habuerat, retineret. But after Eu≈øeb. Hi≈øt. & in Chron. Marian. Martin. Matth. We≈øt. Flor. ≈øupr. the death of Titus, his younger Brother Domitian taking the Empire vpon him, differed ≈øo much from his Brother, and Ve≈øpa≈øian his Father before him, that he fell into ≈øo greate pride, and impietie, that he cau≈øed and commaunded
him≈øelfe to be called, and worshiped as God, and was the ≈øecond after Nero, who ≈øetting forth his cruel Edicts to that end, per≈øecuted Chri≈øtians and the Church of Chri≈øt. Which crueltie of his, allthough it did not extend to our Chri≈øtian Britans as Rome, ≈øtill by the Roman Lawes enioying there their priuiledges, and immunities from compul≈øion to ≈øquare them≈øelues in matters of Religion to the Emperiall lawes, and Edicts, yet being of force again≈øt all that had not ≈øuch municipall prerogatiues, many of the≈øe bannished and per≈øecuted Many Chri≈øtians in this Per≈øecution of Domitian fled into Britaine. Chri≈øtians, as in the Per≈øecution of Nero before, as our Prote≈øtant and other Antiquaries tell vs, fled into this our Britaine, whether that Per≈øecution did not, nor could extend it ≈øelfe, for refuge, and ≈øuccour, at the lea≈øt vntill his wicked Edicts 15. yeares and ≈øome moneths after the beginning of his Empire immediately vpon his death for their crueltie were reuoked by Nerua, his Succe≈ø≈øour, who by his fir≈øt Edict recalled all which Domitian had bannished. Nerua primo edicto ≈øuo cunctos exules, quos Domitianus relegauit, reuocari praecepit. Whereupon a Prote≈øtant Bishop and Antiquarie ≈øpeaking of this time of Domitian Matth. We≈øtm. an. Dom. 97. Godwin Conu. of Brit. p. 18. Tripart. hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 7. calleth Britaine, a refuge for Chri≈øtians. And addeth both from Ca≈ø≈øiodorus, and his owne iudgment: It was not counted vnlawfull for the≈øe to be Chri≈øtians, that dwelt beyond Italy, and France, as in Britaine or neere the Pireney Mountaynes, and ≈øo to the we≈øterne Ocean. Whereby vndoubtedly it came to pa≈ø≈øe, that many profe≈øsing Chri≈øt, not daring to abide neere vnto the heart of the Empire, as in Italy, France, or ≈øome other of the neere≈øt Prouinces, made choyce of our Britaine, where to leade their liues in ≈øuch ≈øort, as they might enioye libertie of con≈øcience.

3. By which meanes it ≈øeemeth, that the number of our Apo≈øtolike men, though their names be buried in obliuion, by iniquitie of time, was againe S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, & diuers of his coÃÑpany died about this time, as al≈øo others our primatiue Chri≈øtians. renewed, and encrea≈øed, diuers of the former now ha≈øtning to their death, and ≈øome of them, credibly decea≈øed allready. Among which we may with good warrant number S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia and others of his holy companions, which though they were ≈øubiect vnto him, as their Abbot and cheife: yet for yeares and age litle, or not at all inferiour vnto him, in probable iudgment. And S. Io≈øeph was ≈øo venerable for yeares before this time, that the holy Euangeli≈øts, as our Prote≈øtants tran≈ølate them, tell vs he was at the death of Chri≈øt one and thirtie yeares, of age. And he was, as the Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury, with many other Authorities witne≈ø≈øe, before his coming Matth. cap. 27. Marc. cap. 15. Luc. cap. 23. Ioa. cap. 19. into Britaine, an honorable Counceller, in high e≈øteeme with the Iewes, and ≈øo honoured by Pilate, the Pre≈øident of Iury, that he boldly had acce≈ø≈øe vnto him, asked, and obtayned of him the body of Chri≈øt, which he buryed in his one Tombe, thinking thereby, that he had not long to liue; and ≈øo old he was at his coming hither, that as many before haue thought his ≈øonne Io≈øeph was con≈øecrated a Bishop at the lea≈øt a≈ø≈øigned to that dignitie. Therefore the auncient writers, and Antiquities of this Hi≈øtorie ≈øay, that within few yeares M. S. antiq. de Vit. S. Io≈øeph ab Aramathia. Io. Capgrau. in eod. Antiquit. Gla≈øt. & alij. of their ≈øetling them≈øelues at Gla≈øtenbury, they gaue place to nature and ended their liues one earth, and S. Io≈øeph, as probably the re≈øt, was buryed by the holy Chappell which they had founded to the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary: effluentibus paucis annorum curriculis ≈øancti memorati carnis erga≈øtulo ≈øunt educti: inter quos & Io≈øeph ≈øepultus e≈øt, & po≈øitus in linea bifurcata iuxta Oratorium praedictum. And about this time our renowned Archbishop S. Ari≈øtobulus died heare (a late writer ≈øaith) by Martyrdome, & at Gla≈øtenbury, ≈øetting downe the time about the yeare of Christ three ≈øcore and ten; which how true it is, I dare Author of the Engl. Martyrol. 15. day of March. not affirme, becau≈øe I finde none of his Authours which he citeth, who are Arnoldus Mirmannius, Dorotheus in Synop≈øi & Baronius, to deliuer any ≈øuch
thing, but if we should leaue him to a naturall death, we cannot coniecture, S. Ari≈øtobulus his death in Britaine by Martyrdome. that he liued long after this time, for if he was the Father of S. Peters wife, he mu≈øt needs be very old in the≈øe dayes; ≈øo likewi≈øe if he was a Roman, and Arnold. Merm. in Theatro coÃÑu. gent. in Britainnia. Martyrol. Rom. 15. die Martij. Catal. Regum. Britannor. 1. Fa≈øti Regum & Epi≈øcoporuÃÑ Angl. in Domitiano. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 94. Prote≈øt. Marginal. Ann. in eund. ibid. the ≈øame S. Paul mentioneth to haue had his familie in Rome, before his coming thither. Arnoldus Mermannius ≈øaith he died in Britaine in the time of Domitian Emperour and S. Clement Pope in the yeare of Chri≈øt 99. anno & quod excurrit 99. Clemente Pontifice Maximo Domitiano Imperatore. The old Roman Martyrologe is plaine that he ended his life by Martyrdome, qui cur≈øu praedicationis peracto, martyrium con≈øummauit. By whome he was martyred, eyther by the Druids, or any Lieutenant of the Romans in the time of Domitian his Per≈øecution, or ≈øoone after Iulius Agricola being heare about that time, and conquering this Britaine to the Romans in the dayes of the per≈øecuting Emperour Domitian, BritaÃÑnia tunc primuÃÑ penitus ≈øubiugata ductu Agricolae au≈øpitijs Domitiani, I dare not conclude; neither preci≈øely of the time, or place. But thus we ≈øee that the cheife Di≈øciple of S. Peter liued heare among the Chri≈øtian Britans vntill the dayes of S. Clement, and after ≈øuch time as he ≈øent many other Bishops into the≈øe we≈øterne parts, which as Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter Britaine was not without Prei≈øts, and Bishops after S. Ari≈øtobulus death but ≈øtill enioyed diuers. and his Prote≈øtant publishers, was in the yeare of Chri≈øt 94. Doctores mittuntur ver≈øus Occidentem. Which was 5. yeares before the Martyrdome of our Archbishop S. Ari≈øtobulus.

4. And yet after his death, we had diuers other Bishops in, or of this Nation, as namely S. Beatus that liued vntill the yeare 110. as al≈øo his companion, Marian. Scotus aetat. 6. in Nerua. Catal. Epi≈øcop. Treuer. Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 98. Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. in Domitian. Martin. Pol. ≈øupput. in cod. Florentius. Wigor. in chron. Eu≈øeb. in Chron. & hi≈øt. Hi≈øt. Tripartit. Stow hi≈øt. in Domitian. Catal. Reg. Brit. who≈øe certaine name is not remembred, ≈øo did S. Man≈øuetus long ouerliue this Age, as I shall shew in the ≈øecond Century, or hundred of yeares, and S. Peter at his time of his going from hence a litle before his death, and con≈øecrating at his departure diuers Bishops with Prei≈øts, we may not probably thinke that they all were dead, though their particular memories doe not remaine, for both S. Man≈øuetus and S. Ari≈øtobulus were longe time Bishops before them, and yet the one liued vntill now, and the other a farre longer time: And they which fled, or came hither in the Per≈øecutions of Nero, and Domitian, (which la≈øt reigned and raged again≈øt Chri≈øtians, vntill the 98. yeare of Chri≈øt, commonly ≈øuppo≈øed the time of his death) could not be all dead, but many liuing, at, and long after this time, euen heare in Britaine: for Traian ≈øucceeding him next, except Nerua, who was Emperour but one yeare, & 4. moneths, kept the Empire all mo≈øt twenty yeare he, and many of them continued a Per≈øecutor, at the lea≈øt vntill he was (about the yeare of Chri≈øt 107. in the next age) moued by the letters of Plinius, to mitigate his Some Religious men liued at Glastenbury, all this fir≈øt Age to the end, and longer. Per≈øecution. And allthough, as I haue in≈øinuated before, S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia & his holy coÃÑpanie did not liue long at Aualon, yet it is a thing not to be doubted in Hi≈øtorie, but either ≈øome of them, or ≈øome that ≈øucceeded them in that holy place, and his conuer≈øatioÃÑ of life, liued there all this, & ≈øome time of the beginning of the next Age. For it is te≈øtified by all Antiquities of that holy Catal. Reg. Brit. Galfrid. Monu. Hi≈øt. Brit. Virun. hi≈øt. Matt. We≈øt. Stowe hi≈øt. in Claudio. Man≈øion of their, that King Coillus confirmed tho≈øe priuiledges thereof which his Grandfather, and Father Aruiragus and Marius had formerly granted vnto it: And many hold, it was the next Age before Coillus was King. The Cataloge of the Brittish Kings ≈øaith, he began his Reigne in the yeare 125. And certaine it is, that this his confirmation could not be vntill towards the later end of this Age at the ≈øoone≈øt, for Claudius the Emperour concluded not the Marriadge betweene his Grandfather Aruiragus, and Genui≈ø≈øa or Geui≈ø≈øa his Grandmother, vntill the 44. or 45. yeare of Chri≈øt. This was
none of his fir≈øt Acts heare, her ≈øending for from Rome hither, according to her e≈øtate required time, we mu≈øt allowe a mans Age to Marius his Father, before Coillus was borne or begotten, and to make Coillus his Charter of confirmation validate, requireth ≈øo many yeares in him, that the end of this fir≈øt Age mu≈øt needs approach before it was effected, and tho≈øe holy Eremits to whome it was made, did but a short time enioy that priuiledge, if none of them ≈øuruiued to ≈øee the ≈øecond Age. Which is confirmed by tho≈øe Hi≈øtories Antiquit. Gla≈øt M. San Tabulis. M. S. de Vit. S. Io≈øeph. Capgrau. Catal. ineod. Melkin. in S. Io≈øeph. Gulielm. Malme≈øb. l. de antiq. Caenobij Gla≈øton. M. S. which a≈ø≈øuer vs, that when S. Damianus and Fugatianus came thither, towards the later end of the ≈øecond hundred of yeares, they found both their hou≈øe or Oratorie ≈øtill ≈øtanding, and diuers Chri≈øtian Images of the Cro≈ø≈øe, & others, which could not haue ≈øo long continued, con≈øidering the weake and meane building of that poore Chappell, the matter of tho≈øe picturs, and the inhabitants thereabouts Pagans, more apte to de≈øtroy, then maintaine ≈øuch Chri≈øtian memories, if the Chri≈øtian Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors thereof had all bene dead, and left it de≈øolate long before.

5. I haue made former mention, how among all CouÃÑtries betweene this and Rome, this kingdome was in all times the mo≈øt ≈øafe and quiet harbour and refuge for Chri≈øtians in the≈øe times: And yet we finde in German, and French Hi≈øtories, that towards the later end of this fir≈øt hundred yeares, in the dayes, and by the holy labours, of S. Valerius and others ≈øent thither by S. Peter the Apo≈øtle, there were ≈øo many conuerted to the Chri≈øtian faith, that in number they exceeded the Pagans in many or mo≈øt parts of France and Germany, e≈øpecially tho≈øe that be neare vnto Britaine, and from whence to v≈øe the phra≈øe of ≈øtrangers it is but a short cutt into this kingdome. Vnde breui≈øsimus in Britanniam, nunc Angliam, e≈øt traiectus, vti Tacitus & Iulius Cae≈øar Tacit. & Iul. Cae≈øar apud Anold. Merman. Theat. conuer≈ø. gent. Petr. Mer≈ø≈øaeus Catal. Archiep. Treuer. in S. Valer. & Materno. meminere. Such was the encrea≈øe of Chri≈øtians there: Iam tunc pene per Galliam & Germaniam Chri≈øtiani Paganos & numero ≈øuper ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ent & Religione. This was in the time of S. Valerius, which died in the yeare 93. and, being before the Diui≈øion of Prouinces was fully made into Archiepi≈øcopall Sees, ruled diuers cheife Churches, and farre di≈øtant, as Collen, Tungers, and Treuers, as al≈øo his Succe≈ø≈øour S. Maternus did, and both of them were probably heare in Britaine, and conuerted many heare: for Marianus ioyneth the≈øe with other S. Valerius and S. Maternus Di≈øciples o≈ø S. Peter were by probabilitie in Britaine ≈øometime. holy Preachers and Bishops of tho≈øe dayes which preached not onely in their owne Prouinces, but in the≈øe vttermo≈øt, and extreme parts. Qui non ≈øolum propria Prouincia ≈øed in extremis & vltimis indu≈øtrij & illu≈øtres existentes regna Tyrannorum vicerunt. And this greate encrea≈øe and multiplication of Chri≈øtians, continued all this age in the≈øe Countries, as the≈øe forreyne Antiquaries tell vs, and vntill the death of S. Maternus, which was in the yeare of Chri≈øt Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. in Nerua. 133. as they witnes: all which time and longer our renowned Bishop and Countriman ≈øtill liued, and often vi≈øited this his natiue Country preaching heare. And yet before the end of this age, we had a new ≈øupply of Apo≈øtolike men ≈øent hither, from the See of Rome and Authoritie thereof, as I shall further declare in the next Chapter.

div.head: THE XXXVI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE STATE OF ECCLESIASTICALL affaires in Britaine in the Papacy of S. Clement, Empire of Traian and Reigne of King Coillus, vnto the end of this first hundred of yeares of Chri≈øt.

div.p: 1. S. Cletus hauing happily ended his life by Martyrdome, S. Clement tooke vpon him the gouernement of the Apo≈øtolike Roman See, and the tyrannicall time of Domitian being now by his death expired, and his Acts for their crueltie generally recalled by Nerua, though Emperour Marian. Scotus l. 2. aetat. 6. Method. apud. eund. col. 255. Martin. Pol. Supput. in Clem. & Traiano. Matth. We≈øt. an. 102. 98. 117. 124. & alij. litle aboue one yeare, Traian ≈øucceeded him, holding the Empire vntill, or about the yeare of Chri≈øt 117. being for diuers yeares a Per≈øecutor of Chri≈øtians, e≈øpecially about Rome, the Ea≈øterne, and other parts, remote from this Nation, where King Coillus agreat friend, and fauouror of Chri≈øtians reigned.

2. Before I proceede further in S. Clements dayes: my promi≈øe before, and vrgent rea≈øons to be remeÃÑbred hereafter, doe call vpon mee, to cleare the doubt, whether S. Clement was ordained by S. Peter his Succe≈ø≈øor immediate or noe. S. Clement him≈øelfe thus writeth in the≈øe words: S. Peter him≈øelfe Clemens Rom. Epi≈øt. 1. for his greate charitie, towards all men, when he perceaued his death at hand, in the A≈ø≈øembly of our Brethren, the whole Church hearing him, taking mee by the hand, vttered the≈øe words: heare mee, my brethren and fellowe Seruants, becau≈øe, as I am taught of him, my Lord and Mai≈øter Ie≈øus Chri≈øt that ≈øent mee, that the day of my death is at hand, I ordayne this Clement your Bishop, to whome onely I commit the Chaire of my preaching, and doctrine. To him I deliuer the power of binding, and loo≈øing, deliuered to mee by our Lord, that of all things what≈øoeuer he shall decree on earth, the ≈øame be decreed in heauen. For he shall binde that which ought to be bounde and shall loo≈øe that, which ought to be loo≈øed, as he which perfectly knoweth the Rule of the Church: Ip≈øe Petrus pro immen≈øa charitate, quam erga omnes homines gerebat, in ip≈øis diebus, quibus vitae finem ≈øihi imminere prae≈øen≈øit, in conuentu fratrum po≈øitus apprehen≈øa manu mea, in auribus totius Eccle≈øiae, haec protulit verba: audite me fratres, & con≈øerui mei, quoniam vt doctus ≈øum ab eo, qui mi≈øit me, Domino, & magi≈øtro meo Ie≈øu Chri≈øto, dies mortis meae in≈øtat, Clementem hunc Epi≈øcopum vobis ordino, cui ≈øoli meae praedicationis, & doctrinae Cathedram trado. Ip≈øi trado √† Domino mihi traditam potestatem, ligandi & ≈øoluendi, vt de omnibus quibu≈øcunque decreuerit in terris, hoc decretum ≈øit & in caelis. Ligabit enim quod oportet ligari, & ≈øoluet quod expedit ≈øolui, tanquam qui ad liquidum Eccle≈øiae regulam nouerit. This Act ≈øo concerning, and ≈øo publikly effected, and concerning the whole Church, regi≈øtred by ≈øo worthie a pre≈øent witne≈ø≈øe and partie in that bu≈øines leaueth no place of exception vnto it, e≈øpecially when we ≈øee allmo≈øt all, that followed,
coÃÑfirming it. S. Anacletus the next ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to S. ClemeÃÑt, whom our greate≈øt Anaclet. epi≈øt. 1. & 3. to. 1. Concil. Matt. Parker. Antiq. Brit. p. 24. Io. Pri≈ø. defen≈ø. hi≈øt. Brit. p. 73. Rob. Barnes l. de vit. Pontif. in Anacleto, & AlexaÃÑ dro. Alexand. Pap. 1. epi≈øt. 1. S. Leo 2. apud Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. col. 238. Florent. Wigor. an. 50. & 75. Bed. Martyr. 9. cal. 7. Therefore ≈øeeing he plainely writeth, that ≈øome of the≈øe Cities euen in Britaine, had receaued ≈øuch Primats from S. Peter or him≈øelfe, and we finde it witne≈ø≈øed by many, that one S. Taurinus ≈øent by S. Clement, was Archbishop or Primate of Yorke, which is one of the Sees remembred for ≈øuch, both by S. Peter, S. Clement, and S. Anacletus, we may not vtterly deny, that he was our fir≈øt Primate in that Citie. And if he was the ≈øame which was Bishop of Eureux in France ≈øent by S. Clement, as diuers hold, being v≈øuall in that time, as Methodius, Marianus and others teach, for one Bishop S. TaurinÍù∞ thought by ≈øome the fir≈øt Archbishop of yorke, and ≈øente by S. Clement. to preach in diuers places, and Countryes, he liued long, much propagated the faith of Chri≈øt, & was renowned for Miracles he wrought, as the auncient Roman Martirologe with others giue euidence: Euangelij praedicatione Chri≈øtianam fidem propagauit, ac multis pro ea ≈øu≈øceptis laboribus miraculorum gloria conspicuus, obdormiuit in Domino. But whereas ≈øome ≈øay, and Harris ≈øupr. l. 1. Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae. 115. Hector Boeth. Scotor. hi≈øt. l. 5. for 76. 77. 78. alledge S. Antoninus for Authour, that this S. Taurinus did rai≈øe from death, a daughter of Lucius King of Britaine: filiam Lucij Legis Britanniae a morte ≈øu≈øcitauit: I cannot be of that opinion; for fir≈øt Lucius our Chri≈øtian King was not borne vntill the yeare of Chri≈øt 115. and we doe not reade of any daughter or child he had. And though Lucius Antenous the Roman Prefect, did as ≈øome write, pre≈øcribe lawes heare, and in that re≈øpect might S. Antoninus mi≈øtaken by ≈øome for writing S. Tauri
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rai≈øed from „Äà‚óä„Äâ a daughter „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¢ ius King in „Äà‚óä„Äâ . be called King, and liued in Yorke in the time of Adrian the Emperour, and ≈øo both his name, Title, the place, and time might well agree, that S. Taurinus might there rai≈øe his daughter to life, if he had any which died there, being ≈øo Miraculous a man, miraculorum gloria con≈øpicuus. Yet this could not
be that Miracle, which S. Antoninus ≈øpeaketh of; for in that very place, which is cited for the rai≈øing of the daughter of King Lucius of Britaine, he hath no ≈øuch thing, not once naming any Britaine, much le≈ø≈øe any King of Britaine, but plainely ≈øaith, that the Father of that daughter, which S. Taurinus rai≈øed from death to life, was, Lucius ciuis Ebroicen≈øis; Lucius a Citizen Francis Godwin Cat. of Bishops Yorke 1. of Eureux, which is in France and farre from our Eboracum, Yorke in Britaine. Where; as a Prote≈øtant Bishop writeth: It is reported that Con≈øtantius Chlorus the Emperour appointed Taurinus Bishop of Eureux to be Archbishop of Yorke: This confirmeth the opinion, that one and the ≈øame S. Taurinus ≈øent into the≈øe parts by S. Clement, was Bishop of Eureux in France, and Archbishop of Yorke in Britaine. But the ≈øuppo≈øed time of his remouall Matt. We≈øtm. in Con≈øtant. Flor. Wigor. in Chro. Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. Martin. Polon. in Suppu. Io. Xephil. Epitom. Dion. l. 55. in Cae≈øar. Aug. Camden in Middle≈øex. English. Martyr. 7. Febr. Martyrol. Rom. die 7. Febr. Bed. eodem die. & V≈øuard & Ado. Vuandelb. & Petr. in Catal. l. 3. c. 105. Baron. Annot. in Martyr. Rom. 7. die Febr. Auth. of English. Mart. 7. Febru. mu≈øt needs be mi≈øtaken; for I haue proued before, that S. Taurinus was ≈øent with diuers others by S. Clement in, or about the yeare of Chri≈øt 94. when there were by all accompts, 160. yeares at the lea≈øt betweene that, and the fir≈øt coming of Con≈øtantius Chlorus into, Britaine. For our other cheife Metropolitan See, which we call now London, being from the beginning of Chri≈øtiantie heare, as Camden and others witnes, called Augu≈øta, we reade in approued Authours, the auncient Roman Martyrologe, S. Bede, V≈øuardus, Ado and others ≈øaying, he was Bishop of Augu≈øta, London, in Britaine, and ended his life with Martyrdome. Augustae in Britannia Beati Auguli Epi≈øcopi, qui aetatis cur≈øum per Martyrium explens, aeterna praemia ≈øu≈øcipere meruit. Baronius doth plainely confe≈ø≈øe he knoweth not in what time he died. Quo tempore pa≈ø≈øus ≈øit, hactenus mihi ob≈øcurum. An other late writer is bold to ≈øay: Augulus Bishop and Martyr in the Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian the Emperour for preaching the Chri≈øtian faith in our Iland of greate Britaine, was put to death, by the enemys of truth, about the yeare of Chri≈øt, three hundred and fiue, a litle after the death of S. AlbaÃÑ. But I caÃÑnot be of his min ‚Ä¢ e therein, he neither alledging any one authour that ≈øo affirmeth, nor rea≈øon which ≈øo induceth. But many rea≈øons there be to the contrary: & ≈øuppo≈øing with the common opinion that London was called Augu≈øta, becau≈øe, as Dio and Xephilinus write, Legio Augu≈øtalis nominata hibernabat in≈øuperiore Britannia, The Roman Legion ≈øo termed wintered in the vpper Britaine, neare London as is thought, it was loÃÑg before S. Augulus probably fir≈øt Archbishop of London, about this time. Diocle≈øians time when it was thus called, in the daies of Cae≈øar Augu≈øtus, or ≈øoone after, & in the time we haue now in hand. SecoÃÑdly the Catalogue of all the Archbishops of London, froÃÑ the generall conuer≈øion of this kingdome, long after Diocle≈øian his per≈øecutioÃÑ, is, & hath bene carefully, & diligeÃÑtly gathered Dio Ca≈ø≈øius l. 55. Xephil. Epitom. in Aug. Cae≈øare. Marcellinus l. 28. Andre Che≈øne Hi≈øt d' Angleterre l. 1. Iocelin. de Epi≈øc. Brit. & Io. Gotcelin de ei≈ødem Stowe hi≈øt. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. Harr. Theatr. l. 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. Godwin Catal. of Bish. in London. Harris Thea ‚Ä¢ r. ≈øupr. l. 4. c. 7. by many, & no ≈øuch name as Augulus, or like vnto it, found among theÃÑ, being accompted the≈øe: Thean, Eluanus, Cador, Obinus, Conan, Palladius, Stephan, Iltut, Theadwin, or Dedwin, Thedred, Hillary, Restitutus, which was at the Councell of Arles in France about the yeare of Chri≈øt 326. after Diocle≈øian his death. And after him ≈øucceeded Guitelinus, Fa≈øtidius; Vodimus, Theonus. And no mention of S. Augulus, or any ≈øuch to be found.

8. Further M. Harris in his Manu≈øcript Theater, taking vpon him more particularly then others, to ≈øet downe the times of tho≈øe Archbishops of London froÃÑ King Lucius time, expre≈ø≈øely ≈øaith: About this time an. Do. 308. liued Stephanus the ≈øeuenth Archbishop of London next after Paladius, certaine yeares, and died in London. Wherefore making Stephanus the ≈øeuenth, as others doe, and ≈øaying he was Archbishop there in the yeare 308. which is within 3. yeares of the imagined time, when S. Augulus was Archbishop, & Martyred there and Paladius, which name hath no proportion with that of Augulus, was his
immediate Predece≈ø≈øor, either Paladius or Stephanus by this accompt, was Archbishop at the ≈øurmi≈øed time of S. Augulus Martyrdome, and ≈øo no place found for him in London after King Lucius his conuer≈øion. And all our Hi≈øtories are witnes, how diligent the Chri≈øtians of Britaine were, immediately vpon the cea≈øing of Diocle≈øian his Per≈øecution, to renewe the memories and honor of their late principall Martyrs, in honoring their Reliks, and dedicating Churches vnto them: And yet no mention at all of him, though their G≈øldas l. de excid. & conq. Brit. Bed. Hi≈øt. l. 1. Galfrid. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. Virun. Hi≈øt. Britan. Matth. We≈øtm. an. gra. 313. Godwin Catol. inwinche≈øter. 1. Archbishop and mo≈øt noble Martyr if he had liued and ≈øuffered in that time. No Church ≈øpoken of dedicated to him, not his name once remembred in tho≈øe Antiquities; yet ≈øo worthie an Archbishop, Primate, Saint and Martyr he was, that as I haue before mentioned, he hath the be≈øt and mo≈øt renowned writers of ≈øuch things to be Regi≈øters of his Triumphe by holy Martyrdome, and mo≈øt of them in forreine Countries, the memory of our fir≈øt Apo≈øtolike men allmo≈øt by iniquitie of ≈øea≈øons heare forgotten in our owne writers, but as we are enforced to begg and borrow them from ≈øtrangers not ≈øo punctually and circum≈øtantially allways writing of the affaires of Britaine, then with many reputed an other world or continent, as we could de≈øire. Therefore to giue S. Augulus his due place, and de≈øerued memory, I cannot tell what time to a≈ø≈øigne him more agreeable to his life, and death, then this whereof I now entreate: for I haue shewed before how S. Peter left vs a Metropolitan S. Ari≈øtobulus, who liued vntill the≈øe dayes of S. Clement, and allmo≈øt the end of this Age in the 24. yeare of the next CeÃÑtury 124. Lucius our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King tooke the Regiment of Britaine in hand, when there was no Perfecution but all fauour for Chri≈øtians heare, the auncient Authours Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 124. & alij. which write of his death ≈øpeake, as though he had liued long before he was Martyred, almo≈øt a cour≈øe of life, ≈øo ≈øay S. Bede and the Roman Martirologe, Statis cur≈øumper MartyriuÃÑ explens: V≈øuardus hath the like; cur≈øum temporis Bed. Martyrol. 7. Id. Februar. Rom. Martyrol. die 7. Februar. V≈øuard. eod. die. per Martyrium explens. So te≈øtifie others; By which I haue ≈øufficient warrant, to thinke this glorious Saint our Metropolitan was one of them which S. Clement according to his owne promi≈øe before, the chardge S. Peter gaue vnto him, and ≈øo many haue allready te≈øtified, ≈øent hither into this kingdome. S. Augulus probably ≈øent Archbishop into Britaine by S. Clement Pope.

9. And what I haue ≈øaid of S. Augulus, if I should incline to thinke the ≈øame of our two other glorious Martyrs of greate Britaine S. Socrates and S. Stephen, which S. Bede, the Roman Martyrologe and V≈øuardus with others doe proue were martyred heare, I haue all, or allmo≈øt all the ≈øame rea≈øons and Bed. Martyrol. 15. Cal. Octobr. Mart. Rom. die 17. Septemb. V≈øuatd. & Ado Mart. Anglic. Secundum v≈øum Sarum. cod. die Engl. Marty. 17. Sept. authorities to a≈ø≈øi≈øt mee, which I v≈øed for S. Augulus, and therefore need not repcate them againe, and no argument or Authour, but that late writer without all warrant for the≈øe, as for S. Augulus to impugne mee, and him I haue fully an≈øweared. Onely one thing he writeth to their honour, which I willingly allowe: There are diuers Churches yet remayning in Wales, that in auncient times haue bene dedicated in their honour: among whom al≈øo their memory is yet famous vntill this day, e≈øpecially in Monmouthshire, and the Southern parts adioyning. But that they were martyred vnder Diocletian he bringeth no Authoritie. The Authours which he citeth for them, being tho≈øe I alledged before, are ≈øilent S. So ‚Ä¢ ates and S. Stephen probably ma ‚Ä¢ tyred in Britaine about this time. of any ≈øuch thing, onely they ≈øay, that vpon that day, not ≈øpeaking of any time, they were martyred in Britaine. Neyther can I finde any grounde with him or el≈øwhere, for that he ≈øaith of them: They were conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt in our Primatiue Church by the preaching of S. Amphiball Prei≈øt, and Martyr? For Britaine, and the Britans were conuerted long before. And though
many Chri≈øtians in Britaine were put to death in the time, or Per≈øecution commonly a≈øcribed to Diocle≈øian, as a thow≈øand at one place called Lichfeild, which argueth the inhabitants heare then were Chri≈øtians, and more needed grace of per≈øeuerance, then preaching e≈øpecially towards the Countryes now called Wales: yet I doe not finde any particularly named in auncient Authours but S. Alban, Heraclius Amphibalus, Aaron and Iulius: except we should allow of that, which Regino writeth of S. Lucia Virgin, and Martyr in Britaine: Lucia Virgo in Britannia. Which is di≈øcredited by him≈øelfe, for he ≈øaith she Regino in Chronic. an. D. 242. was putt to death in Britaine in the yeare of Chri≈øt 242. Which probably was before Diocle≈øian was borne. Yet will I not denie but Regino PrunieÃÑ≈øis, mi≈øtaking the time for the number of yeares, may otherwi≈øe write a truth, that S. Lucia Virgin & Martyr in Britaine by Regino Prunien≈øis. Lucia a Virgin was martyred in Britaine, and in the dayes of Diocle≈øian, and if halfe ≈øo much Authoritie had, or could be brought for S. Augulus, Socrates, or Stephen, I should not ≈øo ea≈øilie haue di≈øabled it. Onely one thing I will adde, concerning the place of S. Augulus Martyrdome.

10. That a late French writer in his Hi≈øtorie of this our Britaine ≈øeemeth to Andre du Che≈øne Taurauge en l'Hi≈øtorie general d'Angleterre, E≈øco≈ø≈øe, & d'Irland. thinke that Caerlegion was in the time of Iulius Agricola, and by him named Augu≈øta, which if it were ≈øo, it onely varieth the particular place of his Martyrdome, nothing detracting from the glorie of him, or this Nation, or contradicting that I haue ≈øaid of the time of his death, for no memory is in Hi≈øtories of any ≈øuch there in the time of Diocle≈øian, nor any Archbishops name of that place pre≈øerued long after Diocle≈øian his death, Tremonius & S. Dubritius the fir≈øt that be named in Hi≈øtories, which rather confirmeth the honor of the place of his Martyrdome to LondoÃÑ, e≈øpecially ≈øeeing this Authour bringeth neither rea≈øon nor Authoritie to infring it; & if we take the denominatioÃÑ Augu≈øta to haue bene giuen heare in re≈øpect of the Nobility of the place, it mu≈øt needs be≈øt agree to our mo≈øt auncient and noble Citie, as Camden and others yeeld that rea≈øon ea dignitate floruit Londinum, vt Augu≈øta dici caeperit, many forreine Cities very famous were called Augu≈øta in that re≈øpect: as Vacienorum, Augu≈øta praetoria: Camden in middle ≈øex pag. 217. Mon≈øter in Co≈ømogra. Cooper. in Augu≈øta. Abraham Ortelius in Indice Antiq. Region. In≈øul. Vrb. Oppid. &c. Augu≈øta Taurinorum: Augu≈øta Trica≈øtinorum: Augu≈øta Veromanduorum: Augu≈øta Valeria: Augu≈øta Emerita: Augu≈øta Bracchara: Augu≈øta Acilia: Augusta Tiberij: Augusta Vindeliciorum: Augu≈øta Cae≈øarea: Augu≈øta Ve≈øtonum: Augu≈øta Treuirorum and other famous Cities among Co≈ømographers, which haue taken that name for their Noblenes, and not from the Roman Legion, called Augu≈øta, lying in ≈øo many places: And of all places, Caer-legion could not be ≈øo named from that relation, no euidence giuen, that any ≈øo named Legion continued there. And the generll name Caer-legion, the Citie of the Legion conuinceth, it had not the name from any Legion in particular, much le≈ø≈øe Augu≈øta, for then it should haue bene named Caer-augu≈øta, and not Caer-legion, as we ≈øee all the others are before named Augu≈øta, ab≈øolutely without reference to any Legion either in generall, or particular. And the Cities before named Augu≈øta, are called, as we ≈øee, of the Countryes, where they be, or were, and not from any Roman Legion.

11. I haue mentioned before, that the Emperour Traian was a Per≈øecutor of Chri≈øtians, and among many others, the renowned Pope S. Clement was barbarou≈øly fir≈øt exiled, and after cruelly put to death. But this Per≈øecution as it much aduanced the honor of our Brittish Chri≈øtians, ≈øo it gaue occa≈øion, to encrea≈øe their number. Our noble Chri≈øtian Brittish hou≈øe at Rome, as in this time and before it was the mo≈øt frequented receptacle of Chri≈øtians, releeuing them in all their wants, while they liued, ≈øo now in this ≈øtorme of
Per≈øecution, be≈øides the famous Sepulchrary, and burying place, which it had mo≈øt charitably before prouided, in via Salaria, bearing the name of S. Pri≈øcilla, our Brittish Foundre≈ø≈øe thereof, there was an other very co≈øtely burying place, Loco caemiterij, at their owne dwelling hou≈øe, as the Baron. Annot. in Martyrol. Rom. die 16. Ianuarij. Romans haue before confe≈ø≈øed: where they ≈øecretly buryed the bodyes of the holy Martyrs ≈øuffering in the≈øe Per≈øecutions: ad ≈øepeliendos ≈øublatos occult√® Martyres. And as I haue shewed before, this Chri≈øtian Brittish hou≈øe hauing ≈øo greate re≈øorte of Chri≈øtians vnto it, that at one time there were in it baptized, nonaginta ≈øex homines, 96. men be≈øides women, and children, as that phra≈øe is v≈øually taken in Hi≈øtories, and was as the coÃÑmon ≈øchoole, Seminary, cheife Church, and place to mini≈øter Sacraments, and con≈øecrate holy par≈øons: we mu≈øt needs conclude from hence, that this kingdome of Britaine was before all other Nations, to take e≈øpeciall fruite and benefite thereby, to haue diuers of tho≈øe holy Prei≈øts there con≈øecrated, to be ≈øent hither vnto it. This the lawe of the Gho≈øpell allowed, the chardge of S. Peter exacted, and S. Clement as duely performed: the lawe of nature pleading for Britaine to our Chri≈øtian Brittish hou≈øe, and ≈øchoole in Rome, that ≈øo it ought to be. And yet an other lawe, and of no ≈ømall power, with tho≈øe, that de≈øired to ≈øerue Chri≈øt with quiet, and ≈øecuritie, the lawe of nece≈ø≈øitie, drewe many Chri≈øtians from Rome, and tho≈øe parts of the Empire, where the Per≈øecution then raiged, as diuers both Catholike and Prote≈øtant Authours haue before proued, to come vnto, and liue in this Nation, both in re≈øpect of the King, a friend to Chri≈øtians, and the Immunities of the place, and Countrie. And this may ≈øuffice for the Hi≈øtory of this fir≈øt Age of Chri≈øtianitie in this kingdome of greate Britaine. For them that are de≈øirous to knowe, and enforme them≈øelues more fully in euery particular point of true Chri≈øtian Catholike Religion, lately and now ≈øtill heare, as in diuers other places que≈øtioned, what was publikly preached, profe≈ø≈øed, and receaued for ≈øuch, by the holy Apo≈øtles, Apo≈øtolike men and Primatiue Chri≈øtians of this fir≈øt Age, when by all, the holy and vndoubted true Religion, to be a Rule and direction to all Po≈øteritie in ≈øucceeding times for euer, was published and accepted: I haue ≈øet it downe at lardge in my late Booke intituled: The Iudgment of the Apostles betweene Catholiks and Prote≈øtants in matters of Religion. Wherein they shall finde the true and holy ≈øentence of them, and other Apo≈øtolike men liuing in this Age, in euery Que≈øtion, to be for the pre≈øent Catholiks, and again≈øt their Aduer≈øaries, the fir≈øt to profe≈ø≈øe vndoubted truth, the others knowne and confuted Error, in euery Article. Which would ≈øeeme too long to be ≈øet downe in an Hi≈øtorie, & thererefore I cau≈øed it to be printed a parte in the yeare of our Lord 1632.

div.p: THE ECCLESIASTICALL HISTORIE OF GREAT BRITAINE.
THE SECOND AGE.

div.head: THE ECCLESIASTICALL HISTORIE OF GREAT BRITAINE.
THE SECOND AGE.
THE I. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN IS RELATED BY ALL TESTImonies of Prote≈øtants, and others, how in the Papacie of S. Anacletus, this kingdome was diuided into Prouinces for Chri≈øtian Primats and Bishops; and that the≈øe Bishops and holy Prei≈øts were Ma≈øsing ≈øacrificing Prei≈øts, and con≈øecrated by ≈øuch forme and manner of Con≈øecration, as the pre≈øent Roman Church now v≈øeth, as likewi≈øe all our Primatiue Brittish Bishops and Prei≈øts were: and diuers ≈øuch ≈øent into the≈øe parts by this holy Pope, as S. Peter, and Clement had giuen chardge before.

div.p:
1. BEING now to begin the ≈øecond hundred of yeares from the Birth of Chri≈øt, we mu≈øt make our beginning with tho≈øe Rulers, with which we coÃÑcluded the fir≈øt to witt S. Clement Pope, Traiane Emperour, and Coillus King of Britaine. The≈øe two la≈øt reigned diuers yeares, in this Age; but S. Clement being putt to death by Traiane, euen in the beginning of this Eu≈øebius in Chronic. an. 3. Traiani. Hieron. Catal. in S. Clement. Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 102. Dama≈øus in Pontif. in S. Clem. Baron. Annal. an. D. 100 Centurie, as Eu≈øebius, S. Hierome with others te≈øtifie, and likely bannished from the See Apo≈øtolike, into the Iland Cher≈øone≈øus (where working ≈øtrange miracles, and conuerting many thereby, he ≈øuffered glorious martyrdome) in the later end of the former Age, I mu≈øt come to his next Succe≈ø≈øour, in that highe≈øt chardge, and dignitie S. Anacletus, who enioyed it, as S. Dama≈øus and others witnes, nine yeares, three moneths, and tene dayes: ≈øedit annos nouem,
men≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tres, dies decem. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øaith: 9. yeares, and ten moneths: ≈øedit in Cathedra Romama annis 9. men≈øibus decem. He as him≈øelfe, and Dama≈øus in PoÃÑ tif. in Anacleto Vit. cius in Breuiar. 13. Iulij. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 102. Martin. Polon. ≈øupput. in Anaclet. Anaclet. Epi≈øt. 1. Epi≈øt. 3. Florent. Wigor. in chronic. an. 93. vel 71. Marianus Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. in Domitiano. Magdeburg. in Indice cent. 2. tit. Anacletus. Magdeb. cent. 2. ca. 7. col. 146. Matth. Park. Ant. Brit. p. 24. Bil≈ø. Barl. Bridg. Couell. Hooker. Down. l. in Text. citat. Ioa. Pri≈ø. defen≈ø. Hi≈øt. Britan. pag. 73. 74. Rob. Bar. l. de vit. Pontif. Rom. in Anaclet. Ormerod. pict. of Pop. p. 78. Gir. Kentegerne it is ≈øo termed, and te≈øtified.

6. Therefore we haue ≈øufficient warrant to thinke that both Britans and Scots from their fir≈øt receauing the faith of Chri≈øt, ob≈øerued this holy Rite, and manner in con≈øecrating Bishops. And without the≈øe by the te≈øtimony of S. Anacletus, warranted therein by S. Peter, as he hath told vs, the grace and
power of the holy Gho≈øt was not giuen in that Sacrament. And ≈øo where it is wanting, as in our Prote≈øtants of England and all other Heretikes, there can be no true and lawfull Bishops, no Prei≈øts made by ≈øuch as be not ≈øo con≈øecrated, no Sacraments duely mini≈øtred, no word of God truely and orderly preached, euen by the Articles of the English Prote≈øtant Religion, di≈øabling in Articles of Engl. Prote≈øt. Religion Articul. 19. 23. 36. ≈øuch things euery one but lawfully, and rightely con≈øecrated, & called Cleargie men, ≈øaying it is no true Church, where the≈øe things are wanting. And that S. Anacletus did ≈øend ≈øuch Bishops, euen Metropolitans, and Sacrificing Ma≈ø≈øing Prei≈øts, Con≈øecrators and Offerers. Sacri corporis Domini tractatores (as he nameth Prei≈øts,) of the ≈øacred body of our Lord, into diuers Countryes, euen Anaclet. Epi≈øt. 2. the≈øe parts it is euident, where he writeth that S. Peter, S. Clement, and he him≈øelfe ≈øent ≈øuch from the See Apo≈øtolike. Illi qui in Metropoli √† beato Petro Anaclet. Epi≈øt. 3. Apo≈øtolo ordinante Domino, & √† praedece≈ø≈øore no≈øtro Sancto Clemente, ≈øeu √† nobis S. Anacletus ≈øent diuers Archbishops, Bishops and Prei≈øts, con≈øecrated as before, in the≈øe parts. con≈øtituti ≈øunt, non omnes Primates vel Patriarchae e≈ø≈øe po≈øsunt: ≈øed illae vrbes quae pri≈øcis temporibus Primatum tenuere, PatriarcharuÃÑ aut Primatum nomine fruantur. And to make it manife≈øt, that he, a≈øwell as S. Peter, and S. Clement, did ≈øend Metropolitans al≈øo, as well as Patriarckes, and gaue direction where ≈øuch should be re≈øident, he addeth: aliae autem primae ciuitates, quas vobis con≈øcriptas in quodam Tomo mittimus, a ≈øanctis Apostolis, & a beato Clemente, ≈øiue √† nobis, Primates Praedicatores acceperunt. Among which were heare our Metropolitan Cities in Britaine. Therefore we thus learne of S. Anacletus, that either our Metropolitans which S. Peter, & S. ClemeÃÑt ≈øent hither, or ordained heare, were now liuing, or el≈øe their places, ≈øome at the lea≈øt, were ≈øupplied by his Mi≈ø≈øion of others to ≈øucceede them, for ≈øo he witne≈ø≈øeth. And we finde in ≈øome our neighboring Countryes, which haue better pre≈øerued their Antiquities then Britaine hath done, that he performed this in particular to them. Diuers French Hi≈øtorians among which Richard de Wa≈ø≈øeburg Archdeacon AntiquiteÃÑs de la Gaule Belgique per Rich. de Wa≈ø≈øeburg. f. 28. 29. Bouchard Annal. de Bretaigne. Antiquit. Eccle≈øiae Verdunen. in S. Sanctino. of the Church of Verdune in Lorraine, where our worthie Countriman S. Manfuetus was Bishop or Archbishop at Tullum yet and long after liuing (and therefore I fir≈øt name this place as hauing correpondeÃÑce with our Country) is witnes out of the ≈øame Church, that in this time S. Sanctin which before had bene Bishop of Meux, and S. Antonine preached there S. Sanctin was by Pope S. Anacletus con≈øtituted Bishop of that place, and liued and died there in the yeare of Chri≈øt 118. And S. Saluin his next Succe≈ø≈øor but one, the third Bishop there, was heare in Britaine, as I shall shew heareafter, in King Lucius time. Which is not vnprobable al≈øo of S. Sanctin, there ≈øo neare vs, ≈øo many yeares, and ≈øo neare to S. Man≈øuetus of this our kingdome, vi≈øiting it, as I haue before mentioned.

div.head: THE II. CHAPTER.

argument.p: HOW IN THE PAPACIE OF S. EVARISTVS, and Empire of Traiane, the ≈øame holy Pope ≈øent a Legate to our King in Britaine, to exhort him to Christian Religion, and the benefite thereof, Traian commaunding that Chri≈øtians should not be per≈øecuted.

div.p:
1. S. Anacletus hauing gloriou≈øly ended his dayes by Martyrdome, Martin Pol. in Euari≈øt. Dama≈øus in eodem. vit. S. Euari≈øti in Breuiar. Rom. 26. die Oct. Matth. We≈øt. an. gratiae 111. Martin. Pol. in Euari≈øto. an. 112. Plin. l. 10. Epi≈øt. 97. Epi≈øt. Traiani ad Plin. apud euÃÑ deÃÑl. 10. Epi≈øt. 98. Tertullian. Apol. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 107. Martin. Pol. in Traiano. Mar. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. in Traian. Martin. Polon. ≈øupr. in, or about the 111. yeare of Chri≈øt, Traiane ≈øtill continuing his Empire, and Coillus King in Britaine, S. Euari≈øtus borne of a Iewe by Father, called Iudas, in the Citie of Bethlem, ≈øucceeded him, in the Papall dignitie, and continued therein 9. yeares, and 3. Moneths. Some ≈øay 10. moneths and 2. dayes, Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter giueth him 10. yeares: Martinus ≈øaith, 13. yeares. 7. moneths 3. dayes. In his dayes the Church of Chri≈øt enioyed more quiet, then it had done in his Predece≈ø≈øours time. For Traiane the per≈øecuting Emperour being moued with many, and forcible motiues, did not onely mitigate the Per≈øecution, ≈øo much as he could, but vtterly forbad any at all to be v≈øed. Fir≈øt vpon the letters of Plinius the ≈øecond his Lieutenant or Prefect in Bithinia, of the greate number of Chri≈øtians there, their feruour and zeale in their Religion, their Innocency and pietie of life, and Inoffen≈øiuenes to the Roman Empyre, and lawes in other re≈øpects, he ≈øo farre mitigated the former rigour of Per≈øecution, that he commanded no enquiry should be made to call them into que≈øtion. And ≈øome be of opinion, that although much Per≈øecution was v≈øed in his time, yet it was by the in≈øtigation of his Sub≈øtituts more then his de≈øire. Traianus non per≈øe, ≈øed per ≈øuos Con≈øiliarios, tertiam Chri≈øtianis iu≈øsit inferri Per≈øecutionem. And this is further Traiane the Emperour a fauourer of Christians in Britaine, and all places. confirmed by Suidas an auncient Greeke writer, who doth in≈øinuate ≈øo much, and plainely witne≈ø≈øeth, that vpon the letters of information from Tiberianus Prefect in Pale≈øtina, how the number of Chri≈øtians was ≈øo greate and their de≈øire of Martyrdome ≈øo much, that he was not able to putt all to death, which voluntary offered them ≈øelues to dye for that cau≈øe. Whereupon Traiane Suidas in vitis Cae≈øarum in Traiano. the Emperour ≈øent expre≈ø≈øe commandement to all his Prefects, in all places that they should not per≈øecute Chri≈øtians any longer. Traianus Christianis aliquid induciarum conce≈øsit. Nam qui illis temporibus √† Romanis Magi≈øtratus redimebant ad demerendos Imperatores, varijs Chri≈øtianos ≈øupplicijs afficiebant: adeo vt Tiberianus qui primae Pale≈øtinorum genti praeerat, ad eum retulerit ≈øe non parem e≈ø≈øe Chri≈øtianis occidendis, qui vltr√≤ ≈øupplicia appeterent. Vnde Traianus omnibus Praefectis mandauit ne ≈øupplicijs eos afficerent. Whereupon we haue warrant ≈øufficient to hold, that this Mandate of the Emperour which was ≈øo generall, that it was to all his Prefects, omnibus Praefectis, was ≈øent al≈øo in to Britaine, and Nennius Hi≈øt. M. S. in Mults exemplan. ant. ≈øo farre extended it≈øelfe; which is with aduantage confirmed by our auncient Brittish Hi≈øtorian Nennius, in many Manu≈øcript Exemplars, where he doth
a≈ø≈øure vs, that the RomaÃÑ E ‚Ä¢ perour (which was when S. Euari≈øtus was Pope) was onely Traiane, who did not onely forbid Per≈øecution in Britaine, but ≈øent a ≈øolemne Amba≈ø≈øadge hither, mi≈ø≈øa Legatione ab Imperatore Romanorum, that they which would might be baptized and profe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øtian Religion.

2. And that S. Euari≈øtus then Pope making religeous v≈øe of this lenitie of the Emperour, and his fauour to Chri≈øtians, did write and ≈øend to our King heare Coillus at that time, and Nobles of Britaine to receaue the Chri≈øtian Gildas & NeÃÑnius writt, how longe before K. Lucius, S. Euari≈øtus Pope ≈øent a Legat to the King of Britaine, to per≈øuade him to the Chri≈øtian faith. faith, and ≈øo there came a double Amba≈ø≈øadge from Rome hither then about that bu≈øines, one from the Pope exhorting, and an other from the Emperour permitting it. Mi≈ø≈øa Legatione ab Imperatore Romanorum, & Papa Romano Euari≈øto. Gildas al≈øo (as our Prote≈øtants terme that Authour) in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory in two di≈øtincts Libraries in Cambridge giueth the ≈øame te≈øtimonie of S. Euari≈øtus Pope his ≈øending hither at this time, and differeth from Nennius onely in this, that whereas Nennius hath told vs, that the Amba≈ø≈øadge was ≈øent hither by the Roman Emperour and the Pope of Rome Euari≈øtus, Gildas ≈øaith it was ≈øent from the Roman Emperours, and Euari≈øtus Pope of Rome, Mi≈ø≈øa Legatione ab Imperatoribus Romanorum, & √† Papa Romano Euari≈øto. Which more confirmeth this matter, for how≈øoeuer we will take the≈øe Gildas hi≈øt. in Bibliotheca public. Cantabrigiae. & in Colleg ‚Ä¢ o S. Benedicti. Emperours of the Romans, eyther for the cheife Emperours, as commonly they are vnder≈øtood, or the cheife Rulers vnder them, in the Roman Empyre, as he ≈øeemeth ≈øome time to accept that worde, and the word Imperator properly ≈øignifying a Ruler, will beare it in ≈øome ≈øence, it cannot haue a proper and literall reference (≈øuch as the≈øe worthie Authours would v≈øe) to the time of King Lucius, though there was ≈øuch a ≈øending after in his dayes, by like men, and meanes, which is made plaine by their ioyning of S. Euari≈øtus with them, who dyed in the time of King Coillus Father to King Lucius, by all accomps, and by common computation before King Lucius was borne, and by their rekening which giue the ≈øoone≈øt life to King Lucius, which is Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, ≈øaying he was borne in the yeare of Grace 115. WheÃÑ Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 115. he was a childe, ≈øixe yeares old at the mo≈øt, his Father liuing and reigning King, when neyther Emperour nor Pope would write or ≈øend to him about ≈øuch bu≈øines, and the words of Suidas are plaine before the Emperours commande in the≈øe affaires was to his Prefects omnibus Praefectis mandauit, ≈øuch as his Father King Coillus, and Iulius Agricola were then in Britaine. And allthough in the ≈øame places where Gildas & Nennius ≈øpeake of the≈øe Me≈ø≈øadges from the Pope Euari≈øtus and Emperour, they write al≈øo of King Lucius and his Nobles conuer≈øion, this can be no Argument that they ≈øent to King Lucius, but his Father Coillus; for allthough they mention both tho≈øe things neare together, after their breife manner of writing, they mu≈øt make them two di≈øtinct matters and neuer ≈øay that the me≈ø≈øadge was ≈øent to King Lucius, neither could they ≈øo haue done, if the time and other circum≈øtances would haue giuen allowance thereunto: for they which write of King Lucius, his Nobles, and Countrie's Conuer≈øion, doe write al≈øo how he wrote for, and entreated it by ≈øuppliant letters to Pope Eleutherius. Secondly both the≈øe being learned Britans, and the be≈øt writers they had, and knowing a≈øwell as any the time of their Conuer≈øion in King Lucius and Pope Eleutherius time could not be ≈øo mi≈øtaken in ≈øuch a cau≈øe to mi≈øcalculate ≈øo many yeares, for the Copie of Gildas ≈øaith: 164. annis po≈øt aduentum Chri≈øti Lucius Britannicus Rex cum vniuer≈øis Britanniae Regulis Bapti≈ømuÃÑ ≈øu≈øcepit that King Gildas ≈øupr. Lucius was baptized with all his Nobles of Britaine 164. yeares after the coming of
Chri≈øt: and Nennius ≈øaith it was three yeares afte ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ Po≈øt centum & ≈øexaginta ≈øeptem annos post Aduentum Chri≈øti, Lucius Britanulcus Rex cum omnibus Regulis Nennius ≈øupr. totius Britannicae Gentis bapti≈ømum ≈øu≈øcepit. So that whether we will take the accompt of S. Gildas or Nennius, for King Lucius his time of coÃÑuer≈øion, though others make a greater difference by 20. yeares and more; we ≈øee, that King Lucius was conuerted 44. yeares after the death of S. Euari≈øtus, and 54. from his fir≈øt entrance into the Papacie: 7. Popes, S. Alexander, Sixtus, Tele≈øphorus, Higinius, Pius, Anicetus and Soter being betwene him and S. Eleutherius, in who≈øe time, by all accompts, King Lucius was conuerted, of which two ≈øuch renowned writers could not be ignorant, much le≈ø≈øe may we iudge without greate iniury and dishonour to them, and bold rashnes in our ≈øelues, that they would, or could erre, or be mi≈øtaken in ≈øo high a degree, the one of them Nennins the meane≈øt ≈øtiled by our Catalogi≈øts of ≈øuch men, both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants: the mo≈øt excellent Doctour of the Britans; Principall or Arch-Abbot Io. Lelandus in Nennio. lo. Pit≈øaeus de vir Illu≈øtrib. aetat. 7. in Nennio. BaÃÑchoren≈øi. Balaeus centur. 1. Script. Brit. in eod. of the mo≈øt renowned Mona≈øtery of Bangor, renowned both for wi≈øedome, and Religion: Britannorum eximius Doctor, egregius Britannorum Doctor, famo≈øi≈øsimi Mona≈øterij Banchoren≈øis Archiabbas, Banchoren≈øis Collegij Pontifex, ≈øapientia clarus, & Religione con≈øpicuus. The other S. Gildas the mo≈øt renowned writer of the Britans, of whome Hi≈øtories remember, by all Antiquities, wherein he is ≈øtiled for his excellent, and ≈øingular wi≈øedome ≈øingularly, Gildas ≈øapiens: Gildas the wi≈øe; and ≈øo doth this Manu≈øcript begin: Incipiunt ge≈øta Britonum √† Gilda Sapiente compo≈øita. Here begin the Acts of the Britans, compo≈øed by Gildas Initium Gildae in Bibliotheca public. Cantabrigiae. Volum. 247. tract. 3. Surnamed the wi≈øe. And if the firme grounde of ≈øuch ≈øo auncient and worthie Authours could neede Supporters, there is an other Manu≈øcript in the Library of S. Ben ets Colledge in Cambridge, ≈øo auÃÑcient and credible that it is bound vp in the ≈øame Volume with Nennius, the auncient Hi≈øtory of Landaffe and ≈øuch others, and by the Prote≈øtant Publisher of the Titles of the Manu≈øcripts of Cambridge, and Oxford ≈øtiled Gildae Sapientis Hi≈øtoria; the Hi≈øtorie of Gildas Thom. Iames in libris Manu≈øcr. Cantabrig. in Bibl. Collegij S. Bened. Volum. 373. tract. 7. Surnamed the wi≈øe, but by an auncient note in that Copie a≈øcribed to an other auncient writer Qua≈øtus, or much like, which is more likely, for euen in this place there is ≈øome difference though not materiall, betwene that Copie of Gildas in the publike Librarie where is written: 164. annis po≈øt Aduentum Christi: and this in S. Benets Colledge there readeth: po≈øt centum ≈øexaginta quatuor annos post Aduentum Chri≈øti: And this ≈øo commended and authori≈øed Manu≈øcript hath the ≈øame words with Gildas, and Nennius in this point: mi≈ø≈øa Legatione √† Papa Romano Euari≈øto: That S. Euari≈øtus Pope wrote to the King of Britaine, to receaue the faith of Chri≈øt. And for the difference betwene S. Gildas and Nennius about the Emperour, or Emperours of the Romans writing, is of the ≈øame minde with Gildas: mi≈ø≈øa Legatione ab Imperatorihus Romanorum, & √† Papa Romano Euari≈øto. That they were the Emperours of the Romans in the plurall number, which thus ≈øent to the then King of Britaine.

3. And this confirmeth not onely the exhortation of Pope Euari≈øtus to our King then to receaue the Chri≈øtian faith, but that be≈øides the command of Traiane the Emperour, again≈øt all Per≈øecution of Chri≈øtians, ≈øufficiently proued by Suidas, and Nennius, ≈øent to his Prefects and Lieutenants heare, as in other places, but that the≈øe Roman Lieutenants them≈øelues did ≈øignifie ≈øo much to King Coillus, that it was Edicted, and commanded of Traiane the Emperour, that Chri≈øtians should not be per≈øecuted in Britaine. For in that ≈øence, which I ≈øomewhat in≈øinuated before, doth S. Gildas vnder≈øtand, Imperatores
Romanorum, in the ≈øame worke, where ≈øpeaking of the Tribute which was payed to the Emperour of Rome, ≈øayeth, it cea≈øed to be payed in that Gildas ≈øupr. in Claudio. manner, and was payed to the Britaine Emperours: in tempore Clundij quieuit dari cen≈øus Romanis √† Britannia; ≈øed Britannicis Imperatoribus traditur. Which ≈øo named Emperours of the Romans that were in Britain, mu≈øt needs be their Prefects or Lieutenants heare, receauing that Tribute to the v≈øe of the greate Emperour and Senate of Rome.
