And by this clemency of Traiane towards Chri≈øtians, with prohibition to per≈øecute them, not onely our King which was euer before a fauourer of them, did now receaue new ≈øpirit, to doe all friendely offices he could to the Chri≈øtian Britans ≈øubiect vnto him; but the Roman Prefects, which then were commorant in this kingdome, did eyther willingly or forcebly by the Emperours Mandate, permit all Romans and others which were, or de≈øired to be Chri≈øtiaÃÑs, quietly and without any trouble, or mole≈øtation to enioy their Religion; which both for the pre≈øent and after times gaue greate a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to the happy encrea≈øe of Chri≈øtians in this kingdome, for the conuerted Romans, and their Apo≈øtles, by long conuer≈øation, now made acquainted with the languadge, and manners of the Britans, were become not onely for ≈øuch as were learned among them, to be fitti≈øt men among ≈øtrangers to preach vnto them, but the very vnlearned them≈øelues mo≈øt de≈øirous all they could to promote and further ≈øo holy a worke, became ready and skilfull Interpreters to ≈øuch Apo≈øtolike men, as the See of Rome ≈øent of forreyne Countries into this Nation, to conuert it to Chri≈øt.

div.head: THE III. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE STATE OF BRITAINE IN ECCLE ≈øia≈øticall Affaires in the time of S. Alexander Pope, Adrianus Emperour, and Coillus, or Lucius his ≈øonne King heare. Their affections to Chri≈øtian Religion, and of diuers Apostolike Dio in Traiano. Eutropius lib 8. Spartian, in Adrian. Matth. We≈øtm. ann. 117. 118. 119. Marian. aetat. 6. in Traiano & Adriano Martin. Polon. Supput. in ei≈ød. Martyrol. Rom. 28. die Octob. Bed. V≈øuard. & Ado eod. die. Vit. Alexand. 1. 3. die Maij in Breuiar. Rom. Dam. in Pontif. in Alex. 1. Method. apud Marian. in Adrian. Imp. Matt. We≈øtm. an. 120. 115. 124. men ≈øent from the See of Rome preaching heare.

div.p:
1. TRAIANE the Emperour being now dead, about the 117. 118. or 119. yeare of Chri≈øt, the accompts being ≈øomewhat and ≈øo much different therein, Adrianus ≈øucceeded him in the Empire, wherein he ruled 21. yeares, or there abouts, and S. Euari≈øtus being Martyred in the beginning of the Reigne of Adrian, S. Euari≈øtus Papa & Martyr Eccle≈øiam Dei ≈øub Adriano Imperatore ≈øuo ≈øanguine purpurauit, S. Alexander the fir≈øt of that name, was his next Succe≈ø≈øor, and ruled the See Apo≈øtolike, 10. yeares, 5. Moneths 20. dayes, by the mo≈øt receaued opinion. The liues of Popes a≈ø≈øcribed to S. Dama≈øus, ≈øay ≈øo many yeares, 7. monethes, 2. dayes: annos Decem, men≈øes 7. dies 2. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter alloweth to his Papacy, but 8. yeares, 5. Moneths, and 2. dayes. Sedit annis 8. men≈øibus 5. & diebus 2. in the beginning of who≈øe Regiment, and vntill the fourth yeare of Pope Alexander and the ≈øixt of Adrian the Emperour, in the yeare of Chri≈øt 124. Coillus was King in Britain, then leauing the Crowne to his youÃÑg ≈øonne Lucius not aboue ten yeares
old, as the ≈øame MoÃÑke of We≈øtmin≈øter, with others reckoÃÑ. But by others Coillus liued, and continued King long after. Which ≈øeemeth more probable, euen Rem. Higed. l. 4. c. 16. Catal. Reg. Britannor. ante Hi≈øt. Brit. an. 125. 165. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 115. by that which Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter him≈øelfe with the common opinion alloweth, that Coillus was an old man before he begat Lucius, Natus e≈øt Coillo Regi Britonum, vnicus filius, quem vocauit Lucium, qui factus e≈øt Patri gaudium, & exultatio, qua≈øi in ≈øenectute, & qua≈øi ab haerede de≈øtitutus, generat eum. Which could not probably be in this yeare of Chri≈øt 115. when he ≈øaith Lucius was borne. For by that computation I haue made before of the marriadge of his Grandfather, and Grandmother, after the coming of the Emperour Claudius hither, at this time when Lucius is ≈øuppo≈øed to be begotten, Coillus could not be much aboue fourtie yeares of Age, and ≈øo not then an old man, nor to be ≈øaide to doe any thing in his old Age, much le≈ø ‚Ä¢ e allmo≈øt out of hope of a child an heire for Age: in ≈øenectute & qua≈øi ab haerede destitutus.

2. This Emperour Adrian is he which in the beginning of his Empire, about the yeare of Chri≈øt 123. came into Britaine, and among other Reformations, and Proui≈øions he made heare (as Spartianus and others after him te≈øtifie) cau≈øed the French, which we call, the Picts wall to be made, to ≈øeperate Spartianus in Adriano. Stowe Hi≈øt. Holinsh. Hi≈øtor. of Engl. Theater of great But. l. 6. and deuide that part of Britain which was vnder the Romans, from the Northren Inhabitants, not ≈øubiect to them. Hadrianus Britanniam petens, multa correxit, murumque per Octoginta millia pa≈øsiuum primus duxit, qui Barbaros Romano≈øque diuideret. In his fir≈øt yeares he was a Per≈øecutor of Chri≈øtians, among whome S. Euari≈øtus the la≈øt Pope was by his Authoritie put to death, and he cau≈øed to take away the memory of Chri≈øt, the Statues of Deuills to be erected in the place of our Lords Pa≈ø≈øion, and by Seuerus Sulpitius and others, is termed the fourth Per≈øecutor. In loco Dominicae Pa≈øsionis daemonuÃÑ Simulachro con≈øtituit. Seuer. Sulpitius ≈øacrae Hi≈øt. l. 2. Yet ≈øoone he corrected his error therein, forbidding Chri≈øtiaÃÑs to be punished for their Religion. Quarta ≈øub Hadriano Per≈øecutio numeratur. Quam tamen po≈øtea exerceri prohibuit. Iniu≈øtum e≈ø≈øe pronuntians, vt qui≈øquam ≈øine crimine reus con≈øtitueretur. And wrote ≈øo expre≈ø≈øely, commanding, to Minutius Fundanus Eu≈øeb. Hi≈øt. l. 4. c. 3. & in chron. An. 9. Adriani. Hier. de Script. Eccle≈ø. in Quadr. & Ari≈øtid. Hier. Epi≈øt. 84. Eu≈øeb. l. 4. c. 8. 9. Iu≈øt. in Apol. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 135. Aelius Lamprid. in Alexandro Seuero. his Procon≈øull in A≈øia, moued there perhaps by the Apologie, & Oration of S. Quadratus vnto him for Chri≈øtians, and the letters of Sereius Granianus his Legate in behalfe of Chri≈øtians, declaring their Innocencie. And S. Ari≈øtides pre≈øented the like Apologie vnto him. And he was ≈øo much moued by the≈øe meÃÑ, that one of our owne Hi≈øtoriaÃÑs writeth, that he was thereby in≈øtructed, and informed in the Chri≈øtian Religion. Inperator Hadrianus per Quadratum Apo≈øtolorum Di≈øcipulum, & Aristidem Athenien≈øem virum fide & ≈øapientia plenum, ac per Serenum Legatum, libris de Chri≈øtiana Religione compo≈øitis in≈øtructus e≈øt & eruditus. And Aelius Lampridius confirmeth a≈ømuch or more, when he ≈øaith that this Emperour Adrian did intend to receaue Chri≈øt for God, and cau≈øed Temples in all Cities to be erected without PagaÃÑ Idols, which remained ≈øo in Lampridius time, and were called Adrians Churches, which he inteÃÑded to the honor of Chri≈øt, but was kept backe froÃÑ performing it, by feare or flattery of the Idolaters, told by their Oracles, that if he proceeded ≈øo, all would become Chri≈øtians, and their Temples should be left de≈øolate and forelorne. Chri≈øto templum facere voluit Alexander, eumque inter Deos recipere. Quod & Adrianus cogita≈ø≈øe fertur, qui templa in omnibus ciuitatibus ≈øine ≈øimulachris in≈ø≈øerat fieri: quae bodie idcirco quia non habent Numina, dicuntur Adriani. Quae ille ad hoc para≈ø≈øe dicebatur: ≈øed prohibitus e≈øt ab ijs qui con≈øuleÃÑtes ≈øacra, repererunt omnes Christianos, ≈øi id optato eueni≈ø≈øet, & templa reliqua de≈øerenda. And the≈øe were motiues to very many in the≈øe dayes, to embrace Chri≈øtian Religion, both at
Rome, where the minde and iudgment of the Emperour him≈øelfe, a good Prince was ≈øo knowne to be conuinced, by the con≈øtancie and Innocency of the Chri≈øtians and their vnan≈øwerable Apologies for the onely truth of their Religion, and euident errors and fal≈øehood of the Pagans ≈øuper≈øtitious Rites, now made manife≈øt in all places.

3. So that to extend my pen no further then to the bounds I haue appointed vnto it. Fir≈øt for Rome where we had many Britans Chri≈øtians and other then re≈øident, we are told by the be≈øt allowed Relation of tho≈øe things, that the holy Pope S. Alexander did then conuert to the faith a greate part of the Roman Nobilitie. Alexander Romanus, Hadriano Imperatore regens Eccle≈øiam, magnam partem Romanae Nobilitatis ad Chri≈øtum conuertit. Among whome was Hermes the cheife Prefect or Ruler of Rome: Hermes Praefectus vrbis qui per euÃÑ
Vita S. Alexand. Papae 1. in Breu. Rom. 3. die Maij. (Alexandrum) crediderat. The encrea≈øe of Chri≈øtians in the Papacie of this holy man, was ≈øo greate, that notwith≈øtanding the fauour and loue of the Emperour. vnto Chri≈øtians, the Pagan Flamins and others were ≈øo malitious Martin. Polon. in Alexandro 1. again≈øt him, that they procured him to be put to cruell death, euen in the time of the ≈øame Emperour, The≈øe proceedings e≈øpecially of the fauour of the Emperour to the Chri≈øtians, their pietie, con≈øtancie, and encrea≈øe were ≈øo much diuulged in the world, that among others they moued, or more incited our King of Britaine, which then was Coillus or Lucius to ≈øend to Pope Alexander, as we are informed by forreine Hi≈øtories, and procure of him to haue the Chri≈øtian faith preached heare in Britaine, by ≈øuch as he should thinke The King of Britaine Sedeth to Pope Alexander to haue Chri≈øtian Preachers ≈øent hither. fitte≈øt for that de≈øignement. Albertus Krantzius a worthie Hi≈øtorian, and one which hath giuen light to diuers of our Antiquities, relateth this matter, thinking it was King Lucius which now began ≈øo timely to shew his loue, and liking of Chri≈øtian Religion. Religionem Chri≈øti Lucius quondam Britanniae Rex ab Alexandro primo eius nominis ≈øummo Pontifice, impetrauit in In≈øula praedicari. Albert. KraÃÑtzius Metropol. l. 1. c. 6. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 115. Baron. Annal. to. 2. an. D. 132. Zepherin. Binnius in Vit. Alexandr. to. 1. Concil. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 124. 132. Io. Bal. l. de Scri. Brit. Cent. 3. pag. 143. in Matth. Florigero. Prot. Publ. of Matth. We≈øt. in Praefat. Which may well ≈øtand with the common opinion of King Lucius his owne conuer≈øion, in the time of Pope Eleutherius, e≈øpecially if we will folow Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, and his followers, which haue told vs before, that King Lucius was borne in the 115. yeare of Chri≈øt; for by that accompt he was 18. yeares of Age at the Martyrdome of S. Alexander by the common opinion in the 132. yeare of Chri≈øt, and King Coillus had then bene dead 7. or 8. yeares, by Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, whome our Prote≈øtaÃÑt Antiquaries ≈øtile a man excellently learned in all kind of learning, and in the right Supputation of yeares, ≈øingular. Vir ≈øuo ≈øeculo in omni genere bonarum literarum plane eruditus, & quantum ad Hi≈øtoriam, in recta annorum ≈øupputatione ≈øingularis. So we haue King Lucius old enough, by this mans te≈øtimony, ≈øo ≈øingular in Hi≈øtoricall Accompts, to write to Pope Alexander of this matter, before his death, and iu≈øtifie the very words of the recited Antiquitie. Or if we will followe the other opinion, which I haue written to be more probable, that King Coillus liued longer, this hindereth nothing, but either Lucius in the life of his Father might reque≈øt this of Pope Alexander, and King Coillus thought by diuers before to haue bene actually a Chri≈øtian, to haue giuen allowance vnto it, or he him≈øelfe being ≈øo per≈øuaded in iudgment, did ≈øo write to that holy Pope, more moued vnto it by the example of the Emperour, and ≈øo many Nobles of Rome, whome he ment to followe, at the lea≈øt in performing that fauour to ≈øo many Britans now allready Chri≈øtians, and more de≈øiring ≈øo to be: which his proceedings were honorable in him, though he him≈øelfe intended not to be a Chri≈øtian, and offen≈øiue to none in Authoritie,
whome he needed to feare: And yet afterward ≈øeeing S. Alexander ≈øo cruelly King Coillus ≈øuppo≈øed by ≈øome to be a Chri≈øtian. put to death for that Religion, did deferre to procure that happines to him≈øelfe, which he did to others. But Harding ≈øuppo≈øeth him to haue bene a Chri≈øtian, and therevpon ≈øaith: Lucius was the ≈øecond Chri≈øtian King of Britaine. Harding Chron. 50. 51. in Coillus. and Lucius. And it will appeare hereafter, that about this time there were diuers Chri≈øtian Preachers ≈øent into Britaine, & within few yeares after the death of Pope Alexander, if not in his life, they conuerted many heare to the faith of Chri≈øt, among whome I may probably number S. Timothie, Marcellus or Marcellinus and S. Saluine. Of who me I shall ≈øpeake more in the certaine time of S. Timothie an Apo≈øtolike Prei≈øt ≈øonne to S. Claudia a noble Britaine, probably ≈øent into Britaine by Pope Alexander. King Lucius his Reigne.

4. Heare onely I ≈øay of S. Timothie a Britiane of this Nation, by his holy Mother S. Claudia Sabinella, who as diuers write preached in this kingdome, ≈øent hither by the Roman See Apo≈øtolike, mu≈øt needs be ≈øent hither about this time. For as the auncient Roman Martyrologe with others te≈øtifie, he was at Rome and martyred there in the time of Antoninus. Romae Sanctorum Martyrum Marci & Timothei, qui ≈øub Antonino Imperatore Martyrio coronati ≈øunt. Petrus Mer≈ø≈øaeus Catal. Archiep. Treuer. in S. Marcello 20. Magdeburgen. Cent. 1. l. 2. Martyrolog. Rom. die 24. Martij. Which Antoninus began his Empire in, or about the yeare of Chri≈øt 138. within 6. yeares of the Martyrdome of S. Alexander Pope. Therefore to allowe him but competent and ordinary time for his coming hither from Rome, where he was borne and liued, his aboade heare, returne to Rome againe, and being there before his Martyrdome, I cannot finde any fitter time, or par≈øon, when and by whom he was ≈øent hither, then Pope Alexander, ≈øollicited by our King of Britaine to ≈øend ≈øuch to preach heare, and no S. Marcellus a Britan and Bishop preached heare in his time. man more fitt then he by his Mother a Britane, and ≈øo not vnskilfull in the Britans tongue, and their affaires.

5. S. Marcellus al≈øo was a noble Britan of this Nation, and had preached heare, and among others per≈øuaded King Lucius to embrace the faith of Chri≈øt, & departed ≈øo ≈øoone hence at that time, that he was the third Bishop of Ca≈øpar Bruch Cat. Epi≈øc. Tungren. Petr. Mer≈ø≈øaeus Catal. Archiep. Treuer. Anton. Democh. l. 2. contra Calu. Guliel. Ei≈øengr. centen. 2. Tungers, the fir≈øt being S. Maternus S. Peters Di≈øciple and by him ≈øent with others thither into tho≈øe parts; the ≈øecond, Auitus & our ble≈ø≈øed Countryman the next, continuing that See 29. yeares, and was after Archbishop of Treuers, where he was martyred, and S. Metropolos ≈øucceeded him, as the Annals of Treuers witne≈ø≈øe, in the ≈øecond yeare of Marcus Aurelius Antoninus, long before the commonly ≈øuppo≈øed time of King Lucius Conuer≈øion. By which accompt he mu≈øt needs be a Prei≈øt or Bishop heare in this time, I haue now in hand. Annal. Eccle≈ø. Verdun. Rich. de Wa≈ø≈øeburg. l. r. f. 32. antiq. de la Gaule Belgique.

6. So I ≈øay of S. Saluine the third Bishop of Verdune in Lorayne, termed by the Annals of that Church, long before King Lucius his death, to haue bene his old acquaintance, which mu≈øt needs be heare in Britaine, long time before, and giueth ≈øome argument, he was al≈øo borne in this kingdome. And no man will doubt, but King Coillus, which in his younger time, and S. Saluin probably Bishop heare in this time, and a Britan. when Chri≈øtian Religion was more per≈øecuted by the Roman Emperours, their Augu≈øtals, Procon≈øulars, Lieutenants, and other Prefects in Prouinces, then now it was, and eyther vpon his owne pietie to that holy profe≈ø≈øion, or at the ≈øuite and petition of Chri≈øtians heare, or their friends had, as all the Antiq. Gla≈øt. in Tab. ligneis Guliel. Malm. l. de antiq. Caenob. Gla≈øton‚ñ™ Io. Capgr. in Catal. in S. Io≈øeph ab Aramathia. Etalij. Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury, William of Malmesbury, with others witnes, confirmed to the Chri≈øtian Eremits there, tho≈øe priuiledges which his Acce≈øtours King Aruiragus and Marius had granted before, would now in more ea≈øie times be per≈øuaded to write to Pope Alexander, then the mo≈øt renowned man in the Chri≈øtian world, and hauing cheife care and chardge of
≈øuch things, to acquaintaine him, how willing he was to giue way to ≈øuch proceedings, and de≈øire his highe≈øt Pa≈øtorall help, and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance therein. Who, hauing bene ≈øo diligent, as before, in ≈øuch holy works, that he had conuerted a greate part of the Roman Nobilitie, would mo≈øt willingly giue his be≈øt furtherance vnto this ≈øo laudable, and honorable bu≈øines. For the Martyr. Rom. Bed. Ado. & V≈øuard. 24. Martij 20. Iunij. 21. Iulij. better and more ea≈øie, and honorable effecting whereof, all the paynes and chardges the happy children of our glorious Countrywoman S. Claudia would vndertake herein, were accompted nothing vnto them, hoping to ≈øee their Mothers Country conuerted to Chri≈øt. The elde≈øt ≈øonne S. Nouatus ≈øtill continued in Rome with his noble Patrimonie and Religeous offices a≈ø≈øi≈øting tho≈øe which were imployed in this bu≈øines, ≈øolliciting the holy Popes to pro≈øecute with all endeauour, ≈øo worthie a worke. S. Timothie one of our Apo≈øtolike men, his Brother came, and par≈øonally preached heare, and gayned the honour to be the Conuerter of King Lucius, and one of the Apo≈øtles of this Nation. Their holy Si≈øters, S. Pudentiana, and Praxedes, made their hou≈øes, and Patrymonie, Seminaries and In≈øtruments to harbour and entertaine Clergie men, to be directed hither, among other Acts of eternall memory, and left to the honour of this their Mothers Country, that among the few auncient Tituli titles, or Churches (all is one) in Rome, by which the Cardinals haue their honour, & ≈øtile two of the mo≈øt auncient, S. Pudentiana and S. Praxedes Onuphrius Panuin. Veronen. l. de Epi≈øc. tit. & Diaconijs Cardinalium. Baron. in annot. Martyr. Rom. die 19. Maij in S. Pudente. Act. Nouat. Pudent. & Praxedis. came by donation of our holy Britans. And of all in Rome Baronius him≈øelfe confe≈ø≈øing it, that of S. Pudentiana to be the mo≈øt old, & auncient. Vetu≈øti≈øsimumque omnium Titulum Pudentis nomine appellatum, qui item & Pa≈øtoris nomine dictus reperitur, hodie vulgo Eccle≈øia S. Pudentianae nuncupatur. But of ≈øuch things I shall ≈øpeake more hereafter, when I come to tho≈øe ble≈ø≈øed Si≈øters, who to encrea≈øe their glory in heauen by their ≈øufferings for Chri≈øt, and Charitie in Harboring, releeuing, and burying his, both liuing, and martyred Seruants, and Saints in earth, liued longer time then their happie Brothers did; Of ≈øome fruites & effects among others who≈øe memory is perished, I will entreate hereafter in the next Pope, in who≈øe time, and not, or not much before, it ≈øeemeth the≈øe Apo≈øtolike men de≈øigned by S. Alexander Pope for Britaine, entered their chardge there, their happie Sender ha≈øtening to his glorious end by Martyrdome.

7. Onely in this place becau≈øe they were appointed by S. Alexander, the What Religion concerning matters now que≈øtioned the≈øe Apo≈øtolike men did teach in Britaine by Prote≈øtants Confe≈øsioÃÑ. better and more ≈øurely to be informed with our Prote≈øtants con≈øent, what Religion in matters now que≈øtioned they receaued of that holy Pope and brought hither, I will call the≈øe Prote≈øtants them≈øelues to be witne≈ø≈øes and Relatours thereof. They haue with publike allowance, and Authoritie of their cheife men, in ≈øuch matters both of England and their Flemmish Confederats in Religion, the one penning and approuing, the others approuing and publishing it to the world, giuen vs their be≈øt a≈ø≈øurance, fir≈øt that he was a man renowned for preaching the Gho≈øpell, and working miracles, and ≈øuffering mo≈øt greuious punishments for the holy doctrine he taught; he was Robert. Barn. in Vit. Pont. Rom. in Alexandro 1. Io. Bal. in Rom. Pont. Act. l. 1. in eod. Alex. Ioan. Martin. Lydius Mini≈øt. p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ uileg. Illu≈øtr. DD. Ord ‚Ä¢ num general. putt to death by Martyrdome, ≈øtudio Euangelizandi & Miraculis celebris, interfectus Martyr obijt. Supplicia graui≈øsima ad mortem v≈øque pa≈ø≈øus e≈øt. This ableth him for a glorious Saint, and ≈øo di≈øableth him to deceaue vs in his doctrine, which the≈øe men confe≈ø≈øe was this: He added in the Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe all th ‚Ä¢ t is from the words: Pridie quam pateretur: The day before Chri≈øt ≈øuffered; vnto the≈øe words: Hoc e≈øt corpus meum: This is my body. Where the Con≈øecrationis. In this Sacrifice of the Eucharist, he cau≈øed wine to be mingled with water. For the Sacrifice
of the Euchari≈øt, he commanded to take vnleuened bread. He commanded water with ≈øalt mixed with it, to be hallowed and kept both in the Church, and in hou≈øes to driue away Deuils. And in the end of Ma≈ø≈øe the people to be ≈øprinkled with holy water. He excommunicated tho≈øe which re≈øisted the Popes Legats, he decreed that one ≈øacrificing Prei≈øt should ≈øay but one Ma≈ø≈øe in one day. Speaking of the Euchari≈øt, he ≈øaith that ≈øins are blotted out by Sacrifice: Therefore he instituted, that the Pa≈øsion should be recited in Ma≈ø≈øe. He added the rea≈øon of ≈øuch effect of this Sacrifice, ≈øaying: Becau≈øe in Sacrifices, nothing or none is greater then the bodie and blood of Chri≈øt: In Mi≈ø≈øa, pridie quam pateretur, v≈øque ad haec verba, hoc est Corpus meum, addidit, ad memoriam Pa≈øsionis Chri≈øti inculcandam. In Eucharistiae Sacrificio aquam vino admi≈øceri voluit. Ad Euchari≈øtiae oblationem azinium panem, non fermentatum ≈øumendum e≈ø≈øe praecepit. Aquam admixto ≈øale precibus benedicendam, eamque in Templo, & domi, ad Sathanam propellendum, & ad peccata tollenda, ≈øeruari iu≈øsit. Aqua con≈øecrata populum finitis ≈øacris a≈øpergendum e≈ø≈øe iu≈øsit, vt (inquit, ≈øanctificarentur, & purificeÃÑtur. Legatis Apo≈øtolicis ob≈øi≈øtentes Decreto excommunicauit: Vno die vnam tantum Mi≈ø≈øam √† ≈øingulis ≈øacrificis fieri debere, Decreto ≈øanciuit. Peccata Sacrificio, de Euchari≈øtia loquens, deleri ait: Ideo Pa≈øsionem in Mi≈ø≈øa recitandam in≈øtituit. Rationem effectus huius Sacrificij, hoc e≈øt, quod peccata expiet, adiecit, dicens: Quia Corpore & Sanguine Christi in Sacrificijs nihil maius e≈øt: He al≈øo forbad that any Cleargie man should be called to a Lay Tribunall, Clericum ad Plebenum Tribunal pertrahere prohibuit.

div.head: THE IV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE ECCLESIASTICALL ESTATE OF Britaine in the Popedome of S. Sixtus, the re≈øt of the Empire of Adrianus, and beginning of Antoninus Pius. How many learned Britains were conuerted, and conuerted others, to the faith of Chri≈øt in this time.

div.p:
1. NEXT after Pope Alexander, ≈øucceeded S. Sixtus, the fir≈øt of that name in the Papali dignitie. Which he enioyed, by the Dama≈ø. Pontif. in Sixto. 1. Martin. Polon. Supput. in Sixto 1. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 128. Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. in Adriano. an 131. Onup. Pano. l. de PoÃÑtif. part. 1. in Sixto. 1. liues of Popes a≈ø≈øcribed to S. Dama≈øus, 10. yeares three moneths, and 21. dayes. Sedit annos decem, men≈øes tres, dies 21. the ≈øame, word by word writeth Martinus. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter detracteth one onely day from that accompt: ≈øedit in Cathedra Romana annis decem, Men≈øibus 3. diebus 20. Marianus a≈ø≈øigneth him twelue yeares: Sixto 12. annis Romanae Eccle≈øiae gubernaculis functo. Onuphrius alloweth him but 9. yeares, 9. moneths, and 30. dayes, ≈øedit annos 9. men≈øes nouem, dies 30. By Baronius, and others which begin his Papacie in the yeare 132. and giue him the shorte≈øt Regiment, he continued onely vntill the yeare 142. by Marianus beginning his Papall Gouerment a yeare ≈øooner, then the others, and allowing it the continuance of twelue yeares, he entered the 143. yeare of Chri≈øt, ≈øo Marianus from Methodius accompteth. Vntill the ninth yeare of this Pope, Hadrianus continued Emperour, after whom, then ≈øucceeded Antoninus Surnamed
Pius, the Godly, who by Baronius reckning was Emperour 22. yeares, Martyrol. Rom. 6. die Aprilis Baron. Tom. 2. Annal. An. D. 163. Marian. Scot. aet. 6. l. 2. in Antonino Pio. Flor. Wigorn. Chron. an. 12 ‚Ä¢ . & 145. ≈øeuen moneths, and 26. dayes. Annis viginti duobus, men≈øibus Septem, & diebus viginti ≈øex, Which differeth not much from Oro≈øius and Marianus, which ≈øay: viginti, & non plenis tribus annis. And both Marianus and Wigornien≈øis ≈øay, Eu≈øebius and S. Bede gaue 3. moneths more then 23. yeares: becau≈øe it was the cu≈øtome of Hi≈øtoriaÃÑs, to depute vnto the Emperour that yeare, wherein he died: & therefore we may ≈øay, (≈øay they) that Antoninus Pius did not reigne full 23. yeares, becau≈øe he liued not vntill the end of the yeare. Men≈øibus item tribus ≈øecundum Eu≈øebium & Bedam, hoc e≈øt v≈øque ad Calendas Nouembris, in anno 134. po≈øt pa≈øsionem Domini. Quia autem mos erat Hi≈øtoricorum, vt Imperatori deputuretur Annus in quo moreretur, velregno deficeret: Ideo dici potest, quod non plenis viginti tribus annis Antoninus Pius regnauit, quum ‚Ä¢ on v≈øque in finem anni vixit.

2. In the Time of this Pope reigned heare King in Britaine, either Coillus or Lucius his ≈øonne, according to the diuer≈øitie of opinions before remembred. But ≈øeeing all Antiquities, and Antiquaries confe≈ø≈øe, ≈øo many greate, and renowned things, and of ≈øuch labour, and difficultie to be performed, were effected for receauing generally Chri≈øtian Religion, and abandoning the Pagan Super≈øtitions in this kingdome in the reigne of King Lucius, we Harding Chron. c. 50. f. 42. p. 2. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 124. mu≈øt not keepe the Crowne of Britaine from King Lucius long after the death of Pope Sixtus. Harding, who ≈øaith his Father Coillus reigned but 13. yeares, will make him King all this Popes time, which Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter doth confirme, with 4. yeares addition at the lea≈øt, to the time of his Reigne in the dayes of Pope AlexaÃÑder before: And yet he maketh the yeares of his whole Age but 87. froÃÑ which, if we deduct the whole terme betweene the yeare 124. when the Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øaith Lucius begaÃÑ his Reigne, vntill the yeare 142. or 143. when it is before agreed S. Sixtus was Martyred, to proue by all accompts King Lucius regined in ≈øome part of the Papacie of S. Sixtus, we make the time of his Reigne, being very younge at the death of his Father, old when he was borne as is before declared, but 59. yeares, and his Age not greate. And Ihon Harding ≈øaith, Lucius King of Britaine reigned Harding Croni. c. 51. f. 43. Author of the English Martyrol. die 2. Decembr. 54. yeares. And they which write he died in the yeare 84. make him reigne but 53. yeares, if they allowe him King in Pope Sixtus time, and yet leaue him dead before Pope Eleutherius, which we may not doe. That this holy Pope was for learning & ≈øanctity of life & well gouerning the Church of God renowned the≈øe Prote≈øtants tell vs in the≈øe Termes: He was a man powerable in worde, and worke, adorned the Church it≈øelfe with certaine holy Acts, allwayes carefull for the flock of Chri≈øt. Sixtus Romanus, in Sermone & opere vir potens, Io. Bal. l. 1. de Act. Rom. Pontif. in Sixto. Io. Mart. Lyd. ≈øupr. Eccle≈øiam ip≈øam pijs quibu≈ødam factis ornauit, pro Dei grege ≈øollicitus ≈øemper. And what holy deeds, and doctrine they were, with which this ≈øo worthie a man did thus adorne the Church of God, and prouided for his flocke, thus they declare vnto vs: Sixtus Romanus Natione, ≈øacra va≈øe, ne qui praeter ≈øacros Ministros Robert. Barns. in Vit. Pontif. Rom. in Sixto 1. Ioan. Martin. Lyd. & Ordin. general. ≈øupr. attingerent, praecepit. Quod corporale appellant, ex lineo panno fieri iu≈øsit. Epi≈øcopum ad Pontificem Romanum accer≈øitum, domum redeuntem, ni≈øi Eccle≈øiae a Pontifice datas literas reddiderit, non e≈ø≈øe recipiendum ab Eccle≈øia ≈øanxit. Vt Sanctus, in Communione Euchari≈øtiae ter caneretur, ordinanit. Mi≈ø≈øam non ni≈øi in Altari celebrandam e≈ø≈øe con≈øtituit. Ab Epi≈øcopo ad Romanum Pontificem appellandi ius dedit Eccle≈øia≈øticis Mini≈øtris: Sixtus √† Roman by Nation, commanded that none but con≈øecrated Mini≈øters should handle the holy ve≈ø≈øels. He ordained that, which we call the Corporall should be made of linnen cloth. He decreed that a Bishop being ≈øent
for to the Pope of Rome and going home, should not be receaued of the Church, except be brought letters vnto it from the Pope, he ordayned, that Sanctus, should be ≈øonge thri≈øe in the Communion of the Euchari≈øt; he con≈øtituted that Ma≈ø≈øe should The Emperor Antoninus Pius his loue to Chri≈øtians and their ReligioÃÑ. not be celebrated but on an Altar. He gaue power to Eccle≈øiasticall men to appeale from the Bishop to the Pope of Rome.

3. Antoninus Pius the Emperour of this time, was ≈øo frieÃÑdly to Chri≈øtians, that as both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants witnes, he wrote into all places, for Melit. Sarden. Apologia. Melit. apud Eu≈øeb. l. 4. c. 26. 25. Magdeburg. ceÃÑt. 2. c. 3. col. 9. Anton. Pius Ep. ad Populos A≈øiae pro Chri≈øtian. apud Eu≈øeb. l. 4. c. 13. & Nicep. l. 3. c. 28. Iu≈øtin. in fine orat. ad Anton. them to be free from Per≈øecution. Te≈øtatur Melito, referente Eu≈øeb ‚Ä¢ o, Antoninum Pium generaliter ad omnes ciuitates pro Chri≈øtianis ≈øcrip≈øi≈ø≈øe. And in his Epi≈øtle to the people of A≈øia, recited at lardge by Eu≈øebius, Nicephorus, and other writers, he plainely affirmeth, that the Chri≈øtians had bene vniu≈øtly per≈øecuted, for worshipping the one true God: mortem ob ≈øingularis & veri Dei cultum oppetere. And addeth further, that their Per≈øecutors did not ob≈øerue the worship of God, and therefore did enuie the Chri≈øtians which worshipped him, and pro≈øecuted them to death. And that diuers Rulers of Prouinces had writen to his Father before again≈øt Chri≈øtians, to whome he wrote againe, that they should not troble ≈øuch men, except they could be proued to doe any thing again≈øt the Roman Empire. And many hauing writen to him al≈øo of ≈øuch men, to whome he an≈øweared according to his Fathers ≈øentence, whome he ment to followe: If any man hauing an Action again≈øt a Chri≈øtian, accu≈øeth him onely as ≈øuch a man, the Chri≈øtian accu≈øed shall be ab≈øolued, allthough it is manife≈øt he be ≈øuch an one: and his Accu≈øer shall be punished in Iudgment. And that Chri≈øtians were farre moore dutifull and faithfull to God then their Per≈øecutors were: Longe illi ≈øunt quam vos erga Deum liberiores atque fidentiores. Vos cultum Dei non tenetis. Quocirca & illum colentibus aemulatione inuidetis, & ad mortem v≈øque per≈øequimini. De rebus eiu≈ømodi & alij quidam prouinciarum Rectores diuini≈øsimo patri meo ≈øcrip≈øerunt. Quibus ille re≈øcrip≈øit, nihil molestiae faciendum e≈ø≈øe talibus viris, ni≈øi quid aduer≈øus Imporium Romanum moliti e≈ø≈øe deprehenderentur. Quin & ad me multi de eis literas deder ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t, quibus de patris mei, quem imitandum mihi e≈ø≈øe duxi, ≈øententia re≈øpondi: Si quis actionem aduer≈øus quempiam eiu≈ømodi habens, deferat illum duntaxat, vt huiu≈ømodi hominem: Delatus quidem √† crimine ab≈øoluatur; etiam≈øi talis e≈ø≈øe appareat: Ip≈øe autem Delator Iudicio paenas pendat. And allthough diuers yeares of this Emperour his Reigne had pa≈ø≈øed before he e≈øtablished ≈øuch publike Order for the quiet of Chri≈øtians, and much Per≈øecution was in the beginning of his time, yet it cannot be thought to haue had warrant, and Originall from him. And it was allmo≈øt in the beginning of his Empire, the third yeare thereof, as ≈øome write, that S. Iu≈øtine wrote, Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 141. an. Anton. Pij 3. and deliuered vnto him, his Apologie for Chri≈øtians, and made him friendly vnto them: Anno gratiae 141. Iu≈øtinus Philo≈øophus librum de Chri≈øtiana Religione compo≈øitum Antonino tradidit, eumque benignum erga Chri≈øtianos fecit. And he was ≈øurnamed Pius: Godly, by ≈øome iudgments, for his pietie towards Chri≈øtians, a≈øwell as for other re≈øpects: Antoninus Pius gener Adriani erat, erga Mart. Polon. in Antonino Pio. Chri≈øtianos Pius. And he him≈øelfe before is witnes, that he propo≈øed his adopting or Father in lawe Adrian ≈øo friendly to Chri≈øtians to be imitated by him herein. Quem imitandum mihi e≈ø≈øe duxi. And he therefore being ≈øo fully Antoninus Pius Epi≈øt. ≈øupr. per≈øuaded that Chri≈øtians did worship God truely, and better then any Pagans their Per≈øecutours, the≈øe mu≈øt needs be motiues to our King of Britaine Motiues to the King of Britaine to be a Chri≈øtian. euer a fauourer of Chri≈øtians, now much more to defend and maintayne that Religion, when in ≈øo doing he might al≈øo maintayne his honour with God, with the Emperour, and thereby obtayne re≈øt and quietnes to his con≈øcience on earth, and eternall peace and happines to his ≈øoule in heauen.

4. And both for the continuance and encrea≈øe of Chri≈øtians heare in Britaine, all this time from Pope Alexander, of whom the King of Britaine procured Godwin Conu. of Brit. pag. 18. Caius l. 1. ant. q. Cantab. Will. Harri≈ø. de≈øcr. of Brit. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of England. Preachers to be ≈øent hither, we are a≈ø≈øured not onely by Catholiks but diuers Prote≈øtant writers. And ≈øure if there had not bene Chri≈øtians heare to exhort our King to Chri≈øtian Religion, and by him to be fauoured therein, he could neyther haue bene per≈øuaded by them to Chri≈øtianitie, or bene a friend to them for their quiet and libertie in profe≈ø≈øing thereof. And yet be≈øides the Court and Re≈øidence of our King, we ≈øee euen by that litle light of Many Britans receaued the faith of Christ in this time. our Antiquities, that in ≈øondry and farre ≈øeparate places, there were many which both preached the faith to others, and which at ≈øuch mens preaching embraced it. Among others we reade: in peruetustis Annalibus Burtonen≈øibus ≈øic lego. Anno Domini 141. hic baptizati ≈øunt nouem ex Doctoribus & ≈øcholaribus Io. Caius l. 1. ant. CaÃÑtab. Accad. p. 95. Cantabrigiae: I reade in the very old Annals of Burton thus: in the yeare of our Lord an hundred fortie one heare were baptized nine of the Doctours or Teachers and Schollers of Cambridge. What great di≈øtance and ≈øeparation of ≈øpace Many Schollers of Cambridge now conuerted, and conuerting others. there is betweene Burton in Stafford-shire, where the≈øe Annals were written, and kept which te≈øtifie ≈øo many Schollers of Cambridge the cheife Towne of that Shire, were baptized there at Burton, hic baptizati ≈øunt, and the Vniuer≈øitie of Cambridge, is not vnknowne to English Readers. And yet we are ≈øure if they came ≈øo farre to be baptized, they had bene catechized, and in≈øtructed in the faith of Chri≈øt, there before, and ≈øo the faith of Chri≈øt had then bene taught at Cambridge, and not by vnlearned Preachers to conuince ≈øo many learned men, to be ≈øo deuoute to trauaile ≈øo farre, to receaue holy Bapti≈øme. Neyther can any man imagin, but the Brittish inhabitaÃÑts betweene the≈øe two ≈øo di≈øtant places, were al≈øo preached vnto, by tho≈øe holy men which preached in them both, and pa≈ø≈øed from the one to the other. Many others there be Stowe Hi≈øtor. Theater of great Brit l. 6. Willam. Harris de≈øcript. of Britaine. Harris Theatr. l. 2. Annal ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Burton. in Co ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚ñ™ S. Benedict. in Bibliot. ib. vol. 38. tract. 2. Catholiks and Prote≈øtants, which Iu≈øtifie this Antiquitie, and the Antiquitie it≈øelfe is yet extant in the Colledge of S. Benet in Cambridge: where the very ≈øame words be, without any difference at all: Anno 141. hic baptizati ≈øunt nouem ex Doctoribus & Scholaribus Cantabrigiae. And there written that the Booke belonged to the Abbey of Burton. Qui fuit de Communitate Burtoniae.

5. The Prote≈øtant Authours of the Theater of greate Britaine with others, doe ≈øufficiently approue, what I haue written, eyther of the continuance of the faith of Chri≈øt in Britaine in this time in generall, as al≈øo of this Antiquity in particular, although they adde ≈øome exceptions, which rather are their owne mi≈øtakings, then worthie the name ef exceptions. Fir≈øt they truely te≈øtifie in this manner: As we haue ≈øearched the first foundation of our faith, ≈øo neyther Theater of great Brit. l. 6. c. 9. want we te≈øtimonies concerning the continuance of the ≈øame in this Lande, vnto following Po≈øterities: allthough the iniurie of time and warre haue con≈øumed many Records. For the Britans that were dayly ≈øtrengthned in their receaued faith, by the doctrine of many learned and Godly men, left not their fir≈øt loue, with the Church of Apoc. 2. 4. Zachar. 8. 23. Radulph. Niger. Eu≈øeb. l. 4. c. 9. &c. 13. & l. 5. c. 5. Bal. Vit. l. 1. Ephe≈øus, but rather tooke hold of the skirts: As the Prophet ≈øpeaketh, vntill the Tortures of Martyrdome cutt them of by death: and tho≈øe Fathers euen from the Di≈øciples them≈øelues held a Succe≈øsion in doctrine (not withstanding ≈øome repugnance was made by the Pagans) and preached the Gho≈øpell with good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, euen till the ≈øame at lenght went forth with a bolder countenance, by the fauourable Edicts of The English Prote≈øtant Theater writers much ouer ≈øeeme in diuers things in this time. Adrian, Antoninus Pius, and Marcus Aurelius Emperours of Rome, as Eu≈øebius hath noted, and in Britaine was e≈øtablished by the Authoritie of Lucius their King. Of the Teachers of tho≈øe times, Bal ‚Ä¢ froÃÑ ≈øome other hath the≈øe ver≈øes. Sic vt erat celelebris &c. Which thus they English.

lg.l: As were the Britans famous for their zeale,
To Gentile Gods, whiles ≈øuch they did adore:
So, when the heauens to earth did truth reueale,
Ble≈ø≈øed was that Land, with truth, and learnings ≈øtore.
Whence Brittish Plaines and Cambreas de≈øart ground,
And Cornwals Craggs with glorious Saints abounde.

div.p: But this Authoritie proueth not what they affirmed, for the auncient Authour ≈øpeaketh not of learned Teachers of that time, nor learning ≈øtore, as the≈øe men tran≈ølate him, or that they dwelt in the playne grounds of Britaine: But onely of Eremits, liuing in the out Ilands, in De≈øarts, in walls, and Coates in Cornwayle, which were men farre vnfite to preach in Townes and A≈ø≈øemblies.

q.l: Britannica tellus patribus fuit inclita Sanctis:
Qui Neptunicol√ªm Campos & Cambrica rura,
Corniea≈øque Ca≈øas loca de≈øolata colebant.

div.p: where he confineth them to De≈øarts, and de≈øolate places: where no people were to be preached vnto: and rather hath reference to the after per≈øecuting times of Diocle≈øian when Chri≈øtians heare as in other places were forced to tho≈øe cour≈øes. Yet thus we ≈øee the con≈øent of Prote≈øtants is, that in this time we now ≈øpeake of, and from the beginning of Chri≈øtianity heare, Britaine neuer wanted Preachers of the true faith, this they plainely affirme, though they haue failed vs to proue how, and by whome it was preached, which I haue performed for them and others.

6. Such like is that which they ≈øpeake of this time: It is reported al≈øo, that Theater of great Brit. l. 6. ≈øup. Patricke the Irish Apo≈øtle, and canonized Saint long before the Reigne of King Lucius, preached the Gho≈øpell in many places of Wales: as al≈øo that Ninianus Bernicius of the Race of the Brittish Princes, conuerted the Picts to the Religion of Chri≈øt. I maruaile much that a whole learned Senate, as they terme them≈øelues, of Prote≈øtant Antiquaries would goe about to blinde their Readers eyes, with ≈øuch palpable, foggy, and filthie mi≈øts of Lies, ≈øeeing no Authour, no Antiquitie, Manu≈øcript or other ≈øo reporteth of S. Patrike, the Irish Apo≈øtle, and of S. Ninian, Apo≈øtle of the Picts, both of them being ≈øent hither by the Popes of Rome by all Antiquaries and Antiquities aboue 250. yeares after the≈øe dayes, whereof we now entreate. Concerning the Antiquitie of the Annals which affirme ≈øo many Schollers of Cambridge, as before, to haue bene baptized in this time, thus they write: That there were Chri≈øtians in Britaine at the≈øe times Theater of great Brit. l. 6. c. 9. ¬ß. 9. Holinshed de≈øcr. of Brit. c. 9. I make no question, though ≈øome exceptions may be taken again≈øt the Monke of Burton, the Reporter thereof, who ≈øaith, in the 141. yeare and Raigne of Hadrian, nine Mai≈øters of Grantce≈øter were baptized them≈øelues, and preached to others the Gho≈øpell in Britaine, how≈øoeuer he faileth in the Emperours name, which yeare was the ≈øecond of Antoninus Pius, his Succe≈ø≈øour, and a≈øcribeth to the≈øe men Schoole Degrees, alltogether vnknowne for nine hundred yeares after, yet the≈øe doe not hinder the truth of the thing, though that Monke was none of the be≈øt Hi≈øtorians. Thus they allowe the te≈øtimonie, and yet would di≈øgrace the Authour and witnes, although he ≈øeemeth to be the onely auncient Antiquarie, which is now left vnto vs, that hath pre≈øerued this ≈øo memorable a matter. But the≈øe men that had not ≈øeene the≈øe Annals, might haue ≈øpared to haue branded the Authour, to be none of the be≈øt Hi≈øtorians, for tho≈øe exceptions which they take to this Relation, are their owne deui≈øes, and not his a≈ø≈øertions, he neuer a≈øcribeth Schoole Degrees to tho≈øe Cambridge men, but ≈øaith, as I haue recited, that nine of the
Doctours or Teachers, and Schollers of Cambridge were baptized in that yeare. Neyther doth that Prote≈øtant, from which they cite this Antiquitie, mi≈øtaking Hollinshed for William Harri≈øon Authour of that De≈øcriptioÃÑ of Britaine, giue them Schoole Degrees, but onely calleth them nine Mai≈øters of GraÃÑtce≈øter, taking the name Mai≈øters for Teachers or Profe≈ø≈øours of Arts there learned, and the Latine word Doctores hath that ≈øignification, ≈øo euery Mai≈øter or Teacher is a Doctour in Latine; Chri≈øt is ≈øo called in Scripturs the Doctour of Iu≈øtice; ≈øo is S. Paul the Doctour of the Gentils, becau≈øe principally he taught them; ≈øo S. Ambro≈øe, Augu≈øtine, Hierome, Gregory, Ba≈øile, Chry≈øo≈øtome, the two Greeke Gregories Naziancen and Ni≈ø≈øen are commonly called Doctours of the Latine and Greeke Church; So of the two Amba≈ø≈øadours King Lucius ≈øent to Rome, Eluan and Medwine, the Pope by all Antiquaries Catholiks and Prote≈øtants made the one S. Eluan a Bishop, and the other S. Medwine a Doctour, Meduuinum in Doctorem, allowing and authorizing him to teach and preach. And in this ≈øence doe the≈øe men them≈øelues before take the word Doctours or Mai≈øters for Preachers of the Gho≈øpell. And their ≈øuppo≈øed mi≈øtaking of the Emperour his name then, Hadrian for Antoninus Pius is as vnworthie an exception, for diuers learned Hi≈øtorians write, that Hadrian was aliue in that yeare 141. of Chri≈øt, & after, S. Marianus ≈øo plainely affirmeth: Adrianus regnauit v≈øque ad Calendas Augu≈øti in anno 111. po≈øt Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. in Adriano Florent. Wigot. in Chronic. an. 145. 146. Pa≈øsionem. Our learned Countryman and Antiquarie Florentius Wigornien≈øis continueth his Empire vntill the yeare of Chri≈øt 145. foure yeares longer, ≈øuch is the accompt of others. And they which will haue him dead before this yeare make it no longer di≈øtance then betweene the fir≈øt day of Augu≈øt in the yeare 140. and the fir≈øt day of Ianuary 141. 5. Moneths. And their owne Prote≈øtant Authour William Harri≈øon mi≈øtaken by them doth both Iu≈øtifie that Antiquitie, and neuer contradicting that opinion, ≈øeemeth to be of the fame minde that Hadrian was then Emperour. Thus he writeth: I finde in Will. Harri≈øon De≈øcription of Brit. p. 23. the Chronicles of Burton vnder the yeare of grace 141. And time of Adrian the Emperour that nine Schollers of Grantha, or Granta (now Cambridge) were baptized in Britaine, and became Preachers of the Gho≈øpell there, but whether Taurinus Bishop ouer the Congregation of Yorke (who as Vincentius ≈øaith) was executed about this time, were one of them or not, as yet I doe not certainely finde. Lib. 10. c. 17.

7. By which it is euident that this Prote≈øtant Antiquarie with others did certainely finde, as I haue proued, that nine Schollers of Cambridge were King Lucius as other Kings of Britaine taught the Christian faith by Cambridge men. at this time conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, and baptized: and by the≈øe men became Preachers of the Gho≈øpell. Which is further confirmed by the publike Charter of Priuiledges and Immunities of King Arthur to that renowned auncient Towne, Schoole or Vniuer≈øitie of Cambridge: Where among other memorable things he declareth, that his Chri≈øtian Predece≈ø≈øours Kings of Diploma. Arthuri Regis Dat. an. D. 531. die 7. April. in Ciuitate London. apud Caium l. 1. de Antiquit. Cantab. Accadem. & in Arce. Londin. inter. Antiquit. Conce≈ø≈ø. vt idem ≈øupr. p. 72. Britaine had bene in≈øtructed there, in learning and Religion: Vbi hactenus splendorem ≈øcientiae, & lumen doctrinae, gratia fauente Conditoris, m ‚Ä¢ i Praedece≈ø≈øores acceperunt: And in particular ≈øpeaking there of King Lucius, what Immunities he granted to that Vniuer≈øitie te≈øtifieth further, that this our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King did receaue the faith of Chri≈øt by the preaching of the learned Chri≈øtian Schollers of Cambridge: Sicut glorio≈øus Rex Britanniae Lucius decreuit, Chri≈øtianitatem amplectens praedicatione Doctorum Cantabrigiae. This Charter was dated at London in the yeare of Chri≈øt 531. the ≈øeuenth day of Aprill. Dat. Anno ab Incarnatione Domini 531. ≈øeptimo die Aprilis, in Ciuitate London. The Charter of King Cadwalladar to Almericus Rector of the Schollers of Cambridge, Almerico
Rectori Scholarum Cantabrigiae, giueth not vnlike te≈øtimonie, when it witne≈ø≈øeth Charta Regis Cadwalladri: Rect. Schol: Cantabrig. in Antiq Cantabr. & Io. Caium l. 1. de Antiq. Cant. Accadem. p. 92. 93. 94. that his Praedece≈ø≈øours Kings of Britaine, Lucius, A≈øclepiodorus, Con≈øtantine Vhother-Pendragon, Arthur, and his Father Ceadwall Kings of Britaine did honour and reuerence the Inhabitants of the Citie of Cambridge for their learning, and ≈øanctitie, and becau≈øe the cheife≈øt Philo≈øophers and louers of wi≈øedome in all Europe, had gone from that Citie. Quemadmodum Antece≈ø≈øores mei Rectoribus eiu≈ødem Ciuitatis conce≈ø≈øerunt, & ≈øtatuendo confirmauerunt, videlicet Lucius, A≈øclepiodorus, Con≈øtantinus, Wther-PendragoÃÑ, Arthurus, & Pater meus Ceadwallus, Britanniae Patris alti≈øsimi gratia Reges, qui Ciuitatis Cantabrigiae habibatores, cau≈øa doctrinae & Cambridge renowned for learning longe before this time. ≈øanctitatis vitae honorantes, in reuerentia habuerunt & amore, cum ex illa Ciuitate praecipue praece≈ø≈øerunt Philo≈øophantes & ≈øcientiae amatores totius Europae. And before declareth how Cambridge the mo≈øt renowned Mother of learning, was builded and founded by Cantaber a Spaniard many hundred yeares before Chri≈øt, and walled about by Grantinus. Sintque Doctores & Scholares illius celeberrimae matris Philo≈øophiae Ciuitatis Cantabrigiae √† Cantabro aedificatae, necnon √† Grantino Comite hono rabiliter muratae, ab omni calumnia, inquietatione & ≈øcandalo liberi. Which diuers Oxford men and Antiquaries though no friends to the glory of Cambridge yeeld vnto, both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants.

8. Therefore if Cambridge was ≈øo renowned for learning and Chri≈øtian Io. Ro≈ø≈ø. Hi≈øtor. Wil ‚Ä¢ iam Harri≈ø. de≈øcript. of Brit. c. 3. p. 148. Nich. Cantilupus. Hi≈øt. Cantab. Io. Bal. in Praefat. l. de Script. Brit. Harding CroÃÑcle c. 25. f. 22. Merlin. apud eund. ib. Io. Ro≈ø≈ø. Hi≈øt. in StaÃÑford. Stow hi≈øt. in Bladud. Io. Caius Hi≈øt. Cantabr. Accad. p. 20. Will. Harri≈øon De≈øcript. of Brit. c. 3. pag. 148. Hector Boeth. Hi≈øt. Scot. Plutatchus Dial. Holinsh. de≈øcrip. of Irland. p. 48. Velleius Patercul. Hi≈øt. Rom. l. 1. Pontic. Virun. l. 1. Hi≈øt. Brit. Io. Bal. ≈øupr. in Praef. Sanctirie and Religion in the time of King Lucius, we may boldly affirme, that nine, and many times nine Schollers there were Chri≈øtians in this time, and the≈øe nine were not the fir≈øt that were conuerted there. And as I haue ≈øpoaken of Cambridge, ≈øo we may more then probably hold of our other Schooles, or Vniuer≈øities in this our Britaine then, namely Stamford founded by King Bladud and furnished with Philo≈øophers of Athens by him, and ≈øo continued a place of learning vntill the coming of S. Augu≈øtine hither, when it was by the Pope of Rome interdicted for Here≈øies. Glamorgan before the fir≈øt Arriuall of Iulius Cae≈øar heare. Eridon or Criclade, and perhaps others. For be≈øides our owne Writers te≈øtifying the≈øe things, Plutarch and other Groecians are witne≈ø≈øes, that the learned GroeciaÃÑs had much re≈øort into the≈øe parts, euen this our Britaine before the birth of Chri≈øt. And Velleius Paterculus is witnes, that the learned Groecians di≈øper≈øed them≈øelues into many Countries, and Cities to encrea≈øe learning. Corpora gentis illius ≈øeparata ≈øunt in alias Ciuitates. And Vitrunnius a Roman Writer plainely with the truth confe≈ø≈øeth, that our Britaine before Chri≈øts time euer loued learning, and had their renowned men both for Greeke and Latine learning, vnicum e≈øt in tot & tantis turbinibus verum ≈øemper litteras amauit, & vtraque lingua ≈øaep√® plurima floruerunt magni vates, ≈øicut Plenidius Oronius. And all Hi≈øtories forreine and dome≈øticall, Chri≈øtian and Pagan, Catholike and Prote≈øtant are full, what a learned Sect, that of the Druids was, how they florished in France, and of the learning of that Nation, contending with Greece it≈øelfe for prioritie and preeminencie therein, and yet, that the principall and cheife≈øt of that profe≈ø≈øion, were heare in Britaine, therefore ≈øeeing they were with all mankinde borne in ignorance, not learned but to learne, and God did not, doth not, will not miraculou≈øly Many Learned meÃÑ of Britaine in other Schools be≈øides Cambridge now conuerted. infu≈øe knowledge to ≈øuch men his Enemies, we mu≈øt needs allowe them Accademies, Shooles, learning, and teaching places to be fir≈øt in≈øtructed, and then in≈øtruct others in ≈øo many Arts and ≈øciences, for who≈øe knowledge they are ≈øo much by all Antiquaries commended.

9. Then to denie tho≈øe which I haue recompted to haue bene their Schooles and teaching places te≈øtified for ≈øuch by ≈øo greate Authoritie, and
≈øeeke or feigne others without any allowance to ≈øupply that v≈øe, and office, would argue vs of greate willfulnes in ≈øimplicitie, or errour. And for performing ≈øuch a bu≈øines as the generall Conuer≈øion of this Kingdome, ≈øo lardge, and ample, to furnish and enioy ≈øo many Places and Dignities of Archbishops, Bishops, and other Cleargie with learned and worthie men, will shortly and now at hand require vs to finde, we mu≈øt needs ≈øay, that verie many both in Cambridge, as al≈øo in all Schools in Britaine were conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, catechi≈øed long before they were baptized, and baptized no short time and enabled to in≈øtruct, and teach others, before they were thought worthie of holy Orders, Prei≈øtly and Epi≈øcopall calling, and dignitie, to which by the lawe of the Gho≈øpell of Chri≈øt, Neophits, new Conuertits, and young Schollers were not to be admitted; & not without vrgent cau≈øe, when ≈øuch men could not po≈ø≈øibly performe ≈øuch duties, and difficulties, as in ≈øuch time and circum≈øtances are expected, and of nece≈ø≈øitie mu≈øt be done by Clergie men. And by this Conuer≈øion of ≈øo many learned men of Cambridge, then the principall Schoole, and place of learning at one time and place, and proportionably of other ≈øuch places and learned per≈øons therein, being founded and dedicated for the In≈øtruction of others, from the highe≈øt the King him≈øelfe, to the lowe≈øt, and meane≈øt ≈øubiect, we may ea≈øely learne, what a greate meanes, motiue, and di≈øpo≈øition it was to King Lucius, his Nobles, and all others to con≈øider, and diligently di≈øcour≈øe, and di≈øpute with them≈øelues and others, how vnworthie that profe≈ø≈øion of their Pagan Religion was, which ≈øo many cheife men for Iudgment in ≈øuch things, and ordayned to be their Doctours and Teachers had now not without ≈øome temporall lo≈ø≈øes, and Indignities vtterly and publikely renownced, and for≈øaken; and how holy and honorable that Chri≈øtian Religion was, which with many labours and difficulties they had embraced. Which ≈øeemeth to haue bene a ≈øingular help, and furtherance to ≈øo ea≈øie, timely, and generall a Conuer≈øion of this kingdome to Chri≈øt, litle or no impediment now remayning, but temporall di≈øgrace, and lo≈ø≈øes in departing from their ≈øo long receaued and pro≈øe≈ø≈øed Rites, and Ceremonies, which had bene lately qualified, euen by the commanding letters, and Edicts, of ≈øome Emperours them≈øelues, in ≈øuch re≈øpects.

div.head: THE V. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE GREATE ENCREASE OF CHRI≈øtians in Britaine in the Papacie of S. Telesphorus and S. Higinius, and how King Lucius him≈øelfe did now either actually receaue and priuately profe≈ø≈øe the Christian Religion, or made promi≈øe thereof.

div.p: 1. ANTONINVS Pius ≈øtill po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing the Empire, and King Lucius the Crowne of Britaine as diuers holde, S. Sixtus gloriou≈øly ending his life by Martyrdome in the beginning of this Emperours time: ≈øub Antonino Pio, vt ≈øibi Chri≈øtum Lucri faceret, libenter mortem ≈øustinuit temporalem: S. Tele≈øphorus Martyrol. Rom. 6. die Aprilis. Dama≈ø. Pontif. in Tele≈øphoro. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 139. Martin. Polon. in Tele≈øphor. Onuphr. in cod. Rob. Barns in Vit. Pontif. Rom. in Tele≈øphoro. Io. Bal. l. 1. de Act. Rom. Pontif. in Tele≈øphoro. Rob. Barns in Vit. Tele≈øphori. ≈øucceeded him in the Apo≈øtolike Roman See. Which he continued aboue 11. yeares, in all opinions. Onely one English Prote≈øtant much forgetting him≈øelfe, or mi≈øtakeÃÑ by his Printer giueth him but 2. yeares. 3. monethes, & 22. dayes. This Pope was, as our English Prote≈øtants informe vs, eruditione ac pietate vir in≈øignis, tam ore quam ≈øanguine fidelis Ie≈øu Chri≈øti Te≈øtis fuit. A man renowned for learning and pietie, a faithfull witnes of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt as well with word, as bloud. His doctrine they deliuer vnto vs in this manner: Septem ≈øeptimanas ante Pa≈øcha Ieiunium ob≈øeruanduÃÑ √† Clericis in≈øtituit. Tres Mi≈ø≈øas celebrandas in die Natalitio Christi ≈øanciuit, alijs diebus ante horam diei tertiam Mi≈ø≈øam celebrari prohibuit. Gloria in excel≈øis Deo &c. in Mi≈ø≈øa canendum praecepit: he In≈øtituted ≈øeuen weeks fa≈øt (Lent) before Ea≈øter to be ob≈øerued of Cleargie men. He decreed that Prei≈øts should celebrate three Ma≈ø≈øes on the day of the Natiuitie of Chri≈øt: vpon other dayes he forbad Ma≈ø≈øe to be celebrated before the third hower of the day. He commanded that Gloria in excel≈øis Deo: glorie to God one high: (the ≈øong of the Angels at the birth of Chri≈øt) should be ≈øong at Ma≈ø≈øe. The pietie of Pope Tele≈øphorus, and his Religion by Prote≈øtant witne≈ø≈øes in matters now controuer≈øed by them.

2. And heare I will ioyne S. Higinius immediate Succe≈ø≈øor to S. Tele≈øphorus, both in re≈øpect he continued but a short time in that highe≈øt ≈øpirituall dignitie, litle aboue 4. yeares, but he was exalted to a more permanent, eternall, and farre greater honor in heauen by Martyrdome. For his holy life and conuer≈øation thus our Prote≈øtants recommend him: officia boni Pa≈øtoris, & Eccle≈øia≈øtici Operatoris in Me≈ø≈øe Domini per≈øecit: ac morte non incruenta, ≈øub mundi Tirannis Bal. lib. 1. de Vit. Rom. Pontif. in Higinio. Rob. Barns & alij Prote≈øtant. ≈øupr. in Vit. PoÃÑt. Rom. in Higinio. vitae finem accepit: he performed the offices of a good Pa≈øtor, and Eccle≈øia≈øticall workeman in the harue≈øt of our Lord, for which he ended his life by shedding his blood vnder the Tirants of the world. That which they breifely ≈øet downe for his Religion and practi≈øe therein, is this: he commanded to dedicate Churches with ≈øolemne Ceremonie, and Sacrifice. That Churches should neither be diminished, nor encrea≈øed without the con≈øent of the Metropolitane. He forbad the timber, Tiles, The Religion of Pope Higinius by English Prote≈øtaÃÑts te≈øtimony in Articles n ‚Ä¢ w que≈øtioned by them. and other matter of Churches, to be conuerted to prophane v≈øes. He appointed that in Bapti≈øme a Godfather, or Godmother should be had. And that the Metropolitane should not conuict or condemne any man without the con≈øent of the Bishops of his Prouince: and if he did otherwi≈øe he pronounced the ≈øentence to be voide: Templa dedicare
cum ≈øolemni ceremonia & Sacrificio iu≈øsit. Item Templa nec minuenda, nec augenda e≈ø≈øe, ≈øine Metropolitani con≈øen≈øu. Trabes, tegulas, aliamue templorum materiam in prophanos v≈øus vertere vetuit. Vnum vt vocant, Compatrem, vel virum, vel faeminam in Bapti≈ømo adhiberi voluit. Ne Metropolitanis aliquem vel reum ageret, vel damnaret, ≈øine ≈øuae Prouinciae Epi≈øcoporum ≈øuffragio: quod ≈øi fecerit ≈øecus latam ≈øententiam irritam pronuntiauit. Clerum in ordinem redegit, & gradus di≈øtribuit: he brought the Clergie into order, and di≈øtributed degrees. Thus we are acquainted by the≈øe Prote≈øtants, what the life and doctrine was of the≈øe Popes: and cannot doubt but they which were ≈øo holy men by the≈øe witne≈ø≈øes, and taught and profe≈ø≈øed the true Religion and ≈øuffered Martyrdome for profe≈ø≈øing and teaching thereof, were farre from profe≈ø≈øing or teaching error, otherwi≈øe they could not haue bene good Pa≈øtors and worke men in the harue≈øt of our Lord, and faithfull witne≈ø≈øes of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, but the contrary.

3. What was the encrea≈øe of Chri≈øts Church and Seruants heare in Britaine The great encrea≈øe of Chri≈øtians, in Britaine in the time of the≈øe Popes. in their time, we may ea≈øily coniecture by that which hath bene ≈øayde before of ≈øo many learned men conuerted heare to the faith in the very later end of their immediate Predece≈ø≈øor, which in all Iudgments mu≈øt needs be much more verified of the dayes of the≈øe Popes: for the cheife learned men and of their principall Schoole for learning, being thus conuerted to Chri≈øt, & as we haue bene told before, became Preachers of the Ghospell heare in Britaine, Will. Harri≈ø. ≈øup. in De≈øcri. of Brit. we cannot but a≈ø≈øuer our ≈øelues of greate and plentifull fruite of their labours, being manife≈øt by the generall Conuer≈øion of the whole Kingdome, all Degrees, and E≈øtates, now at hand, a greate di≈øpo≈øion thereof was made, and diuers of the Druyds, Nobles, and others were now conuerted, or els the generall Conuer≈øion of all with ≈øo greate a change in all per≈øons, and places heare, as our Hi≈øtories mention, and will hereafter appeare, could not haue ≈øo ≈øoone en≈øued: And this was made ≈øo euident then, that one of the≈øe holy Pope Higinius carefull of the generall CoÃÑuer≈øion of Britaine, and manner thereof. Popes Higinius or Eugenius as ≈øome call him, began to take order how to ≈øettle and perfect our generall Conuer≈øion at hand. Which Ihon Harding in his auncient Chronicle doth manife≈øtly declare, though not citing his Authours, when recounting how the Archflaming Seats, were turned to Archbishopriks, and tho≈øe of Flamins 28. in number, into ≈øo many Bishopriks, he pre≈øently thus addeth: all the≈øe workes Eugeny confirmed. Then if Pope Eugenius or Harding. Chron. f. 43. c. 51. Higinius confirmed and allowed the≈øe affaires, and proceedings, we mu≈øt needs yeeld, they were in a greate forwardnes in this his time. No man can rea≈øonably ≈øay, that the name Eugeny is mi≈øtaken for Eleutherius, for there is no proportion betweene tho≈øe two names, for any Authour, Scribe, or Printer to commit ≈øo greate an error, e≈øpecially no man correcting it, as an e≈øcape in writing, and to a≈ø≈øure vs heareof, the ≈øame Authour maketh mention in Hard. ≈øupr. the ≈øame Page both of Eleutherius, calling him by our English phra≈øe Eleuthery, and Higinius by the ≈øame manner of our languadge naming him, as before Eugeny which confirmed the≈øe things. And it is no maruaile, or any ≈øingular thing, but v≈øuall and the ordinary common cour≈øe for Popes to giue ≈øuch order before hand, how things shall be ≈øetled, when there is ≈øuch hope of happy proceedings, and Apo≈øtolike men taking the chardge in hand, as heare it was at this time, if God shall ≈øo cooperate with their labours, and to proceede otherwi≈øe, is to worke without warrant and Authoritie. So S. Paul writeth to S. Titus, that he had left him in Crete to con≈øtitute Bishops or Prei≈øts in euery Citie; yet it would be greate and vnwarranted boldnes to ≈øay, that S. Titus profited there ≈øo much in his time, to make and ordaine ≈øo many Prei≈øts or Epi≈øt. Pauli ad Tit. cap. 1.
Bishops there, for we are told by Homer, & Strabo liuing about S. Pauls time, and others that there were an hundred Cities in Crete, and there vpon it was „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ the Ile of an hundred Cities in Homers time: Poeta aetate ≈øua Cretam Strabo Geograp. l. 10. p. 338. Homet. Odyff. 3.
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ; id e≈øt centum vrbibus in≈øtructam e≈ø≈øe inquit. So when S. Peter ≈øent any Apo≈øtolike man, or men, into any Nation, he gaue him direction and warrant where to con≈øtitute Bishops, ≈øo did the other Apo≈øtles, ≈øo did the Popes of Rome in this la≈øt Age in the Conuer≈øion of America, & other Countryes; and for this our Britaine, I haue proued before that S. Anacletus euen by the order of the Apo≈øtles gaue direction, and made a litle booke ≈øetting downe therein, where Pirmats and others were to be re≈øident, and this, when there was le≈ø≈øe hope of our Britans Conuer≈øion, then now, and no ≈øuch ≈øucce≈ø≈øe therein.

4. Thus it was al≈øo in the time of S. Augu≈øtine when he was ≈øent hither by S. Gregory to the Saxons. He ≈øent him his Archiepi≈øpopall Pall to be Archbishop of London, yet he ≈øeated him≈øelfe after by warrant at Canterbury, and gaue him power to ≈øend an Archbishop to Yorke, if that Country should receaue Greg. Epi≈øt. ad Augu≈øt. Bed. Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. Gent. Angl. l. 1. c. 29. the Chri≈øtian faith, and he would ≈øend him an Archiepispopall Pall, and that See should haue Bishops vnder it, and be a Metropolitan See: Ad Eboracum vero ciuitatem te volumus Epi≈øcopum mittere quem ip≈øe iudicaueris ordinare: ita du ntaxat, vt ≈øi eadem ciuitas cum finitimis locis verbum Dei receperit ip≈øe quoque duodecim Epi≈øcopos ordinet, & Metropolitani honore perfruatur. Quia ei quoque, ≈øi vita comes fuerit, Pallium tribuere, Domino fauente, di≈øponimus. And yet it is certaine, that S. Augu≈øtine in his time neuer ≈øent Archbishop to Yorke, neither did he make aboue two Bishops in his owne Prouince, S. Mellitus at London, and S. Iu≈øtus at Roche≈øter. Neither did S. Gregory liue to ≈øend a Pall to any Archbishop of Y√≤rke, or ≈øee any there. Neither euer had that See ≈øince the Saxons time twelue, or halfe twelue Bishops vnder it. Neither did S. Augu≈øtine who receaued this warrant for all the Saxons, preuaild ≈øo farre, nor all that came with him, or after him from Rome to conuert halfe the English Nation, but farre the greater part of them was conuerted by holy Bishops, Prei≈øts, & Religious men, which were of our auncient Hierarchiall Brittish ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, and order heare. And allthough I doe not finde it expre≈ø≈øely affirmed in any Antiquarie but Harding that S. Higinius now Pope did ≈øo particularly, giue a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and direction in this bu≈øines of our Britains Conuer≈øion, yet many very auncient and renowned Writers giue ≈øuch te≈øtimonie herein, that we mu≈øt needs graunt that to be mo≈øt true, which Harding affirmeth, and that after coming Scribes and Copiers of their Hi≈øtories haue done the Authours wronge by their negligence or ignorance in writing one man for another, Eleutherius for Higinius. For among others S. Bede, as he is extant, ≈øaith that King Lucius of Britaine did write to the Pope of Rome in the yeare Bed. Eccl. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 4. of the Incarnation of our Lord 156. anno ab Incarnatione Domini cente≈øimo quinquage≈øima ≈øexto, that by his order or command he might be a Chri≈øtian. Ob≈øecrans vt per eius mandatum Chri≈øtianus efficeretur. The Manu≈øcript Antiquities of the Church of Landaffe, more auncient in probable Iudgment then S. Bede, Antiq. M. S. Eccle≈ø. Landaffen. Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 5. c. 1. Hi≈øt. Brut. Stowe Hi≈øt. in Lucius. Caius Anti. CaÃÑtabr. l. 1. p. 107. M. S. ant. and written by a Brittan, which should not be ignorant in that the greate≈øt bu≈øines of his Country, giueth the ≈øame te≈øtimonie of the ≈øame yeare, anno ab Incarnatione Domini 156. The auncient Authour of the Brittish Hi≈øtorie, al≈øo a Brittan, maketh King Lucius a Chri≈øtian in, and before this yeare 156. in direct termes. So te≈øtifieth the old Hi≈øtorie called Brutus, auncient Records belonging to the Guildehall in London, the Antiquities of S. Edwards Lawe ‚Ä¢
‚ñ™
Goceline in the life of S. Augu≈øtine, ≈øo writeth Nauclerus, and diuers auncient Manu≈øcript Antiquities which I haue ≈øeene. Therefore to ≈øaue ≈øo many auncient, and worthie Authours, and their Scribes from a double error both of the time, and name of the Pope, to whome King Lucius did now write, we mu≈øt needs lay this ≈øingle taxe vpon ≈øuch, as haue Tran≈øcribed their Hi≈øtories, that they did mi≈øtake the name of the Pope, writing Eleutherius for Higinius. And this they were more ea≈øily drawne vnto, becau≈øe they found, that Pope Eleutherius was a greate Agent in the generall Conuer≈øion of this Nation, which was long after this time, and their Scribes are more excu≈øable in this point. And this by their leaue we mu≈øt ≈øay, or els both wander from the proued truth of this Hi≈øtorie, and lay a double imputation of mi≈øtaking vpon the≈øe Authours or their Tran≈øcribers. For it is euident by all Antiquities that S. Eleutherius was not Pope many yeares after this time, which they mu≈øt contradict, if they will maintaine their mi≈øtaking. And where they ≈øay, that King Lucius wrote to the Pope of Rome in this yeare, they mu≈øt recall that, and ≈øay he wrote then to no Pope, for Eleutherius was not Pope vntill long after. King Lucius either actually conuerted, or con≈øented to be a Chri≈øtian in the time of Pope Higinius.

5. Therefore to giue euery one his due, I may not depriue S. Higinius Pope of this honour, nor this Nation of the true Title of ≈øo greate a benefite and ble≈ø≈øing by him, and yet when I come to his time, place, and happy proceedings with this kingdome in ≈øuch affaires, I shall render vnto him his mo≈øt worthely de≈øerued glory. For it is manife≈øt in holy Hi≈øtories that what≈øoeuer was written to the Pope of Rome in the yeare of Chri≈øt 156. mu≈øt needs be written to S. Higinius, who then two yeares before, and two yeares after, vntill the 11. day of Ianuary 158. when he was martyred was Pope of Rome, Eu≈øeb. l. 4. c. 10. & in chronic. Martyrol. Rom. 11. Ianua, Ado, & alij eod. die Baron. Tom. 2. Annal. Seuer. Binnius To. 1. Conc. in Higin. Dama≈ø. Pontif. in Pio. Aniceto & Sotere. Baron. Seuer. Binnius. Rob. Barn. Ioa. Bal. in ei≈ødem Marian. Scot. Mart: Pol. & alij. Ethel verdus chron. l. 1. an. 156. and no other, true or pretended. And betweene him and S. Eleutherius were three Popes, S. Pius, S. Anicetus and S. Soter, Which held the Papacie aboue twenty yeares, S. Eleutherius fir≈øt po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing that Apo≈øtolike dignitie in the yeare 179. which was 24. yeares after the time an. 156. when King Lucius by ≈øo many Authours wrote to the Pope to be a Chri≈øtian. And this is more confirmed by the Te≈øtimony of our Countryman Ethelwerdus, who te≈øtifieth that the Pope of Rome which was in the yeare of Chri≈øt 156. which was S. Higinius ≈øent letters to King Lucius, and a Legate to him al≈øo, to the ≈øame purpo≈øe exhorting him to be a Chri≈øtian, to which he con≈øented, and after performed accordingly. In ≈øexto quinquage≈øimo anno beati≈øsimus Chri≈øti famulus per Nuntium & literas Lucium adijt In≈øulae Regem, admonens eum de fide, & bapti≈ømo Catholico, qui tum Britanniae Regni pote≈øtatem pollebat: qui etiam conce≈øsit verifimili ratione Christianum ≈øe e≈ø≈øe futurum, quod & perfecit. Which confirmeth that which Harding hath before deliuered, that Pope Higinius did confirme the ≈øpirituall labours and proceedings in Britaine in this time; for heare is proued that the Pope then, which could be no other, but this holy Saint, did both write his letters, and ≈øend his Legate hither to ≈øuch intent, & per≈øuade the King to Chri≈øtian Religion. And we are a≈ø≈øured that in this time both King Lucius ≈øent to the Pope of Rome, to haue Apo≈øtolike men ≈øent hither to preach the faith of Chri≈øt to his ≈øubiects heare, and the Pope both by letters and Legate ≈øollicited King Lucius to receaue the Catholike faith and Bapti≈øme, and he ≈øo did: quod & perfecit; but whether he was actually bapti≈øed at this time, or onely promi≈øed it now, and performed it after, I am not heare to determine: onely I adde that the very Authours them≈øelues Matth. We≈øtm. anno gratiae 185. 186. 596. as namely Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter that teach the generall Conuer≈øion to
haue bene long after this, yet confe≈ø≈øe the Britans receaued the faith at this time: in parte Britonum fides Chri≈øti anno Dominicae Incarnationis 158. habita, nunquaminter eos defecit.

div.head: THE VI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN IS INTREATED WHAT LEARned and Apo≈øtolike men they were which preached in this time in Britaine, and conuerted King Lucius, and very many of his people. Such were S. Timothie, S. Marcellus, Man≈øuetus, Theanus with others.

div.p: 1. HITHERTO we haue heard of the happy proceedings heare in plaÃÑting the faith of Chri≈øt, & the letters & Legate of the Pope, and per≈øua≈øion of the holy Chri≈øtian Clergie heare, which had taken ≈øo good effect, that the King him≈øelfe was eyther in act, or by promi≈øe, and de≈øire a Chri≈øtian; it would make much to the honour of the In≈øtruments of ≈øo holy a worke, if we could finde out the name, but of any one of them, which then per≈øuaded, and conuerted this fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King of the world, in publike profe≈ø≈øion, and manner, to be a Chri≈øtian. The auncient Charter which the Antiquities of Cambridge a≈øcribe to King Arthur, doth giue this honour, or a great part thereof to the learned King Lucius per≈øuaded to be a Chri≈øtian by Brittish Christians of Cambridge. Schollers of Cambridge, which being conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, and diuers of them now become Clergie men, and Preachers, moued King Lucius by their preaching to be a Chri≈øtian: glorio≈øus Rex BritaÃÑniae Lucius Chri≈øtianitateÃÑ amplectens praedicatione DoctoruÃÑ Cantabrigiae. Which is more confirmed by the Chart. Regis Arth. 7. April. an. 531. Bull. Honotij 1. Academ CaÃÑtab. conce≈ø≈ø. 20. die Febr. an. D. 624. Caius Antiquit. Accadem. Cantabr. li. 1. p. 75. 76. 77. Chart. Reg. Arthuri. ≈øupr. apud Caium ≈øupr. p. 69. 70. auncieÃÑt Bull of Pope Honorius the fir≈øt of that name, to coÃÑfirme the Priuiledges of Cambridge Vniuer≈øitie, a thou≈øand yeares ≈øince, & other te≈øtimonies there are, which ≈øay that both King Lucius did conferre and confirme by his publike Charter greate Priuiledges and Immunities to that Schoole, and Pope Eleutherius likewi≈øe, which he did not for any thing we finde in Hi≈øtories, to any other Schoole or Vniuer≈øitie in the world, nor any of his holy Succe≈ø≈øours many yeares after. The cheife≈øt motiue of the≈øe exemptions and Prerogatiues to that place we cannot interprete in any better ≈øence, then that King Lucius had receaued much ≈øpirituall benefite from thence, which he requited with temporall honour, and dignitie; and the holy Pope Eleutherius be≈øtowed that ≈øingular grace, and fauour to that Schoole, for the holy labours, and frutefull effects it had wrought in the Church of Chri≈øt, by their Conuer≈øion and Preaching, mouing King Lucius, and ≈øo many men of ≈øundry degrees in Britaine, to for≈øake ≈øuper≈øtitious Idolatrie: And embrace the Chri≈øtian faith and Religion. Will. Harri≈øon de≈øcript. of Brit. ≈øupr.

2. A Prote≈øtant Antiquary before ≈øeemeth to leaue it as probable, that one of the≈øe Cambridge men was Archbishop of Yorke, and by ≈øome called Taurinus; an other ≈øuppo≈øeth Eluanus and Meduuinus which were employed by King Lucius was not conuerted by S. Taurinus. King Lucius in this holy bu≈øines, and by diuers writers were In≈øtruments both
of his Conuer≈øion and Bapti≈øme, were Schollers of Cambridge. Fui≈ø≈øe Eluanum & Meduuinum Cantabrig ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n≈øis ≈øtudij Alumnos conijcio. But the opinion of Io. Caius Antiq. Cantabr. Acad. l. 1. p. 99. S. Taurinus to haue bene Archbishop of Yorke in Britaine, is before founde too feeble a grounde to build vpon. And certaine it is by approued witne≈ø≈øes, King Lucius not conuerted by Eluanus or Meduninus. that Eluanus and Meduuinus were but Catechumens in Chri≈øtian Religion, when they were ≈øent by King Lucius to Rome, and they were there perfectly in≈øtructed in the faith and continued there ≈øo long, that being become learned in Chri≈øtian Religion, after they had bene baptized, and taken inferiour Orders, not ≈øodainely performed, Eluanus was con≈øecrated a Bishop, and the other Meduuinus made Prei≈øt, were ≈øent backe againe to preach in Britaine. Con≈øilio Senioris Romae placuit, ‚Ä¢ o≈ødem Legatos baptizari, & Catholica fide ≈øu≈øcepta ordinari Eluanum in Epi≈øcopum, Meduninum autem in Doctorem. Antiquit. Eccle≈ø. Landaffe ‚Ä¢ . Thus haue the auncient Antiquities of the Church of Landaffe, and others. Therefore I doe not ≈øee, how it is probable, that the≈øe men being but Catechumens should preach that faith to King Lucius before their going to Rome, they them≈øelues hauing not yet embraced it: And, much le≈ø≈øe dare I ≈øo boldly affirme, as a Prote≈øtant Bishop and Antiquarie doth, perhaps more for his hate to Rome then loue of truth, and by good warrant, that Eluanus and Meduuinus had often inculcated the faith of Chri≈øt to King Lucius. Qui eandem ip≈øi fidem ≈øaepius inculca≈ø≈øent. But to excu≈øe this man, he holdeth before, that they Bal. l. de Scriptor. Brita. centur. 1. in Eluan. & Meduuino. were both baptized by Apo≈øtolike meÃÑ heare in Britaine, were & become Prei≈øts to preach and Mini≈øter the Sacraments, and were recompted among the mo≈øt renowned heare for tho≈øe offices, before they were ≈øent to Rome. Eluanus & Meduuinus Britannorum Doctores & in Britannia nati imbibitis primum Ethnicorum litteris, ≈øcientiam habebant cum eloquentia non infaeliciter coniunctam. Per Apostolicos viros tandem in Chri≈øto renati, adeo Scripturis ≈øacris operam dederunt, vt in dispen≈øandis Dei Mini≈øterijs, inter primos haberentur. Per eos igitur, vt per illos, qui candem ip≈øi fidem ≈øaepius inculca≈ø≈øent, litteris ≈øuis Rex Lucius, ad Eleutherium Pontificem egit, vt apud Romanos Chri≈øtianorum ad≈øcriberetur numero. If he had proued this by any allowed Authoritie, we might haue harkned vnto him, but citing none for any thing here affirmed, but Ihon Capgraue, Ioanne Capgrauio te≈øte, for King Lucius ≈øending Eluanus and Meduuinus to Rome, which no man denieth, I dare not ≈øecond him in the re≈øt, which he findeth no warrant to affirme. Yet doe I not denie hauing proued ≈øo much before, that as this man teacheth, there were Apostolici viri, diuers Apo≈øtolike men, then in Britaine per≈øwading King Lucius and his ≈øubiects to the Religion of Chri≈øt. Such I ≈øeeke in particular, and not Catechumens; and yet more then probable it is that neyther Eluanus nor Meduuinus was eyther Chri≈øtian or Catechumen at this time, nor diuers yeares after, or els we mu≈øt make them to haue ≈øtayed at Rome aboue twenty yeares fot their better In≈øtruction, Bapti≈øme and Con≈øecration: For I haue proued before, that there was ≈øo long time, euen from the death of this pre≈øent Pope Higinius of who≈øe dayes we now entreate, and the beginning of the Papacie of S. Eleutherius, to whom as Pope Eluanus and Meduuinus were ≈øent by King Lucius. So that finding no warrant, to allow them Prei≈øts, or Preachers as yet, I mu≈øt re≈øerue them to King Lucius conuerted to the faith with many of his Subiects, Nobles and others by S. Timothie and Marcellus, BritaÃÑs. their true time and place, where I shall giue them their worthely due and de≈øerued honour.

3. But we finde ≈øome Apo≈øtolike men in this very time, to haue preached the faith in Britaine to King Lucius him≈øelfe, as well as to his ≈øubiects, and the≈øe to haue bene of this Nation, though by warrant and Authoritie from
the Apo≈øtolike See of Rome. Among the≈øe, two are cheifely commended vnto vs, in this bu≈øines S. Timothie, and S. Marcellus, or Marcellinus. And to begyn with S. Timothie, we finde, that he preuay led ≈øo farre with King Lucius, that by his learning our King was induced to the Religion of Chri≈øt. S. Lucius Britanniae Rex S. Timothei eruditione ad Religionem Chri≈øti inductus e≈øt. Petrus M ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ us in Catal. Archiepi≈øc. Treuer. in S. Marcello alias Marcellino. Henric. Pantal. de vir. Illu≈øtrib. Germ. part. 1. p. 116. Io. Naucler. vol. 2. general. pag. 565. Io. Caius l. 1. Antiq. Cant. Academ. Legenda S. Timothei. Petrus de Natalib. l. 1. c. 24. Harris. Theat. l. 1. And to make this an opinion both of Catholiks and Prote≈øtants, Henricus Pantaleon writeth, that King Lucius of Britaine was the Di≈øciple of S. Timothie. S. Lucius ex Regio Britannorum ≈øanguine Timothei Di≈øcipulus: And citeth the Magdeburgian Prote≈øtants, Stumphius, and the Annalls of Curre in Germany. And Nauclerus with others writeth plainely, that one S. Timothie came into Britaine, and Lucius King of Britaine, and his kingdome of Britaine did receaue the faith of Chri≈øt from him: Lucium Britanniae Regem, cum tota Britannia √† Timotheo Apo≈øtolo qui in Britanniam venerat fidem recepi≈ø≈øe. Where we ≈øee this matter con≈øtantly affirmed both by Catholike and Prote≈øtant Antiquaries. that King Lucius did receaue the faith from one S. Timothie, and he was ≈øo renowned, that he is ≈øtiled an Apo≈øtle, at the lea≈øt to King Lucius and the Brittish Nation. And that we might the better come to notice, what S. Timothie this was, that ≈øo de≈øerued of this kingdome, they doe allmo≈øt Indiuiduate him, when they agree, it was one S. Timothie Di≈øciple to S. Paule the Apo≈øtle. Of this name, which can in any probable ≈øence be termed S. Paules Di≈øciples, we finde but two remembred in Hi≈øtories, S. Timothie Bishop of Ephe≈øus, to whom S. Paule wrote two Epi≈øtles part of holy Scripture, and S. Timothie ≈øonne of our noble Countrywoman S. Claudia honoured in holy Scripture S. Pius Papa 1. Epi≈øt. ad Iu≈øtum Viennen≈ø. Epi ‚Ä¢ c. Tom. 1. Biblioth. Sanct. by S. Paules penne, who as S. Pius Pope of Rome writeth was ab Apo≈øtolis educatus, brought vp by S. Peter and Paule, and ≈øo might iu≈øtly be termed Di≈øciple to eyther of them, and very probably tooke his name from the other S. Timothie, familiarly acquainted in his parents hou≈øe as appeareth in the ≈øame Epi≈øtle; where it is al≈øo manife≈øt, that this youÃÑg S. Timothie and his holy Parents were of the mo≈øt faithfull Di≈øciples which S. Paule then had, as they were al≈øo to S. Peter, and his next following Succe≈ø≈øours: for when allmo≈øt all had for≈øaken him in his impri≈øonment before his death, the≈øe remayned con≈øtant and mini≈øtring vnto him. And allthough S. Timothie was then 2. Tim. 4. very young, yet now being come to be of auncient yeares, was an holy Prei≈øt, had performed the exhortation of Chri≈øt to perfection, to giue all to the poore and followe him, for he had giuen ouer his Patrimony, leauing his hou≈øe at Rome called of his name Timothinae, Timothies hou≈øe, and preached the Gho≈øpell. And being by his Mother a Brittan, remembred by the example and writing of S. Paul to haue an e≈øpeciall care of this his Cou ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y, and to manife≈øt his true loue to it, to winne it to Chri≈øt, as he had before performed the ≈øame, to the Natiues thereof which were at Rome. So that if the≈øe Hi≈øtorians which te≈øtifie King Lucius was conuerted, or per≈øuaded to the faith of Chri≈øt by S. Timothie, and ≈øaid no more, that he was S.
