Pauls Di≈øciple, or giuen any other note or di≈øtinction to knowe what Timothie it was, which vndertoocke ≈øo greate labours, and had ≈øo happie ≈øucce≈ø≈øe in this kingdome, we mu≈øt needs, (expre≈ø≈øing it with great Ioy) conclude, it was S. Timothie Sonne of our renowned Brittish Lady Claudia, which shewed ≈øo greate loue and atcheiued ≈øo worthie things in his and our Country Britaine. And to leaue it without que≈øtion, it could be no other.

4. The other S. Timothie Bishop of Ephe≈øus was martyred, and buryed there in the time of Domitian, and many yeares by all accompts before King
Lucius was borne. And S. One≈øimus mentioned by S. Paul was his Succe≈ø≈øour, Vi ‚Ä¢ . S. Timothei Ephe≈ø. in Breu. die 24. Ianuar. Martyrol. Rom. eod‚ñ™ die Bed. Ado. & Lipp. Ignat. Epi≈øt. ad Ephe≈ø. & Epi≈øt. ad Antioch. Nicep. l. 3. c. H. Magdeb. cent. 2. Breuiar. Rom. die 22. Augu≈øt. Martyrol. Rom. 23. Aug. Bed. V≈øuard. & alij Martyrol. Rom. 3. Maij. & Menol. Martyrol. Rom. Bed. V≈øuard. 21. Maij. Petr. Catal. l. 5. c. 28. Martyr. Ro. Bed. & V≈øuard. 23. Aug. Greg. Tur. l. de glor. Mart. c. 54. Martyrol. Rom. & alij 19. Decembr. Martyrol. Rom. & Menol. 10. Iunij. 2. Tim. 4. S. Pius Pap. 1. Ep. ad Iu≈øtum VieÃÑn. Epi≈øt. ≈øup. & apud Baron. To. 2. Annal. an. 166. and Bishop there in S. Ignatius dayes, as he him≈øelfe witne≈ø≈øeth, both which were al≈øo martyred 50. yeares before this time I now entreate of, by all witne≈ø≈øes, Catholiks, and Prote≈øtants. There haue bene diuers other holy Saints of that name, but none of that time, and Epi≈øcopall or Prei≈øtly Function, to whome we can po≈ø≈øibly a≈øcribe this honour. S. Timothie of Antioch preached at Rome, but long after this, in the time of Pope Melchiades, martyred there. There was an other martyred in Macedonia, but no Prei≈øt, nor about this time. An other martyred at Thebais, but a married man Hu≈øband to S. Maura martyred with him in the time of the Arrians. An other of that name was martyred in Mauritania, with Polius and Eutichius Deacons, he him≈øelfe al≈øo onely a Deacon. An other in Rhemes in France with S. Apollinaris, but not noted to haue bene any Clergie man. An other a Deacon onely in Mauritania. An other with Tecla and Agapius, but no Prei≈øt, and in the time of Diocletian now vnborne, as al≈øo S. Timotheus Bishop of Pru≈øiadis, in the time of Iulian the Apo≈øtata in Bithinia. I can finde no more of that name, for holy Saints, neyther any eyther probabilitie, or po≈ø≈øibilitie, that any of them conuerted, or euer per≈øwaded King Lucius to be a Chri≈øtian.

5. Therefore I leaue it as due to our glorious Countryman S. Tymothie, ≈øonne of S. Claudia, and brother to S. Nouatus, S. Pudentiana and S. Praxedes: ≈øufficiently in≈øinuated by S. Paul him≈øelfe when he ≈øo honorably enrolled his Parents for ≈øuch his mo≈øt beloued in holy Scripturs, when that holy Pope which ordinarily liued in his hou≈øe, dedicated it for a Church, was pre≈øent in Rome to ≈øee his happy death by Martyrdome, and next ≈øucceeded S. Higinius, of who≈øe Papacie we now write, doth expre≈ø≈øely witnes, that he was brought vp, by two mo≈øt glorious Apo≈øtles S. Peter and S. Paul, and was, their Di≈øciple. Sanctus Timotheus, qui ab Apo≈øtolis educatis, Presbiter v≈øque ad nos peruenit. Greate honor it was for the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King of Britaine, the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian kingdome of the world, to be in≈øtructed in the faith by ≈øo noble and renowned Apo≈øtle of his owne Nation, with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and concurrance of the Pope him≈øelfe S. Pius as he te≈øtifieth, when he ≈øaith concerning S. Timothie and S. Marke that was Martyred with him, that he di≈øpen≈øed the word of faith with them: cum quibus ≈øimul verbum fidei partiti ≈øumus. What were the Impediments in temporall re≈øpects, which hindered King Lucius from publike Profe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øtian Religion, wherein he was thus in≈øtructed, vntill, or neare the Papacie of S. Eleutherius, I shall declare hereafter, and ≈øpeake more of S. Tymotheus our Countriman and Apo≈øtle, as al≈øo of S. Nouatus his ble≈ø≈øed brother, and the holy virgins his Si≈øters S. Pudentiana, and S. Praxedes. Onely I ≈øay now of him, that he was a mo≈øt worthie man to be Legate to the Pope of Rome, of whome Ethelwerdus hath told vs before which in the yeare of grace 156. ≈øent a Legate hither with letters to King Lucius exhorting him to the Chri≈øtian Religion: Beati≈øsimus Chri≈øti famulus per Nuntium & literas Lucium adijt In≈øulae Regem, ammonens eum de fide & Bapti≈ømo Catholico; which he ≈øo honorably performed. Yet in giuing this ≈øo greate de≈øerued honor to S. Tymothie, I doe not exclude others froÃÑ their due prai≈øe & glory for their labours in this bu≈øines, but as I haue proued before, ≈øo heare I acknowledg againe in our Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians words: Euen from the dayes of Io≈øeph of Arimathia, and his fellowes, or what other godly men fir≈øt taught the Holinshed Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 19. Britans the Gho≈øpell of our Sauiour, there remayned among the ≈øame Britans ≈øome
Chri≈øtians, which cea≈øed not to teache, and preache the worde of God mo≈øt ≈øincerely vnto them: But yet no King amongst them openly profe≈ø≈øed that Religion, till Lucius. S. Marcellus a Brittan conuerted King Lucius.

6. Among the≈øe was S. Marcellus, or Marcellinus, afterward Bishop of Tungers; and then Archbishop of Treuers, where he ended his dayes with Martyrdome for the truth of Chri≈øt about the yeare 180. as diuers write, and Petr. Mer≈ø≈øaeus Catal. Epi≈øcop. Tungren. & Archiep. Treuer. in S. Marcell. Engl. Martyr. 4. Sept. Anton. Democh. l. 2. Mi≈ø≈øae contra Caluin. Guliel. Ei≈øengr. cent. 2. Part. 4. yet was Bishop of Tungers 29. yeares, before he was tran≈ølated to Treuers, where he was Archbishop ≈øome time. Therefore ≈øeeing we reade that he preached heare in Britaine his Country, and to King Lucius a≈øwell before his going into tho≈øe forreine parts, as after, he mu≈øt needs haue preached heare, in, or before the 150. yeare, and ≈øo might well be one of tho≈øe Cambridge Doctors before remembred. The Annals of the Arcbishops of Treuers ≈øay of this man, that Lucius King of Britaine, now England, was Baptized by his preaching: huius praedicatione Rex Angliae, id e≈øt Lucius, Baptizatus e≈øt. The Hi≈øtorie of Tungers ≈øpeaketh more plainely, that this S. Marcellus did by his preaching conuert Lucius Prince of Britaine with all his Nation to Chri≈øt. S. Catal. Archiep. Treu. in S. Marcello al. Marcel. lino. Marcellus Lucium Britanniae Principem cum tota gente, ≈øua praedicatione ad Christum conuertit. And the ≈øame Catalogue of Treuers ≈øaith, that King Lucius was made a Chri≈øtian, and Baptized by this our renowned Countryman S. Marcellus. S. Lucius Britanniae Rex factus Chri≈øtianus, atque ab hoc Marcello Petr. Mer≈ø≈øaeus Catal. Epi≈øcop. Tungren. in S. Marcello. Treuirorum Doctore Baptizatus. And to giue vs notice, that S. Marcellus mu≈øt needs performe the≈øe holy offices heare, at, or about this time, the ≈øame Annals of Treuers in his next and immediate Succe≈ø≈øor S. Metropolus, ≈øaying that he was Archbishop there in the ≈øecond yeare of Marcus Aurelius Antoninus: Catal. Treuer. Arch. ≈øupr. Metropolus caepit tempore M. Aurelij Antonini anno ≈øecundo: Marcus Aurelius Antoninus beginning his Empire by accompts, betweene the yeares of Chri≈øt 158. and 163. though S. Metropolus did pre≈øently ≈øucceede to S. Marcellus Matth. We≈øtm. an. 159. Marian. Scot. an. 163. Bar. Tom. 2. Annal. an. eod. in the Archbishops See of Treuers, & S. Marcellus left that greate chardge to come hither, to returne thither againe, and be Martyred before the ≈øecond yeare of Marcus Aurelius, King Lucius mu≈øt needs be a Baptized Chri≈øtian before the 165. yeare of Chri≈øt, long before Pope Eleutherius Papacy. And if we followe the Annals of Tungers, telling vs that when he was Bishop there, King Lucius a Chri≈øtiaÃÑ Baptized by S. Marcellus a Britaine longe before the Papacy of S. Eleutherius a≈ø≈øi≈øting S. Timothie long before he came to Treuers, he performed this holy office in Britaine, we are enforced to ≈øay, that he ≈øtayed heare very short time, which will not ≈øerue to conuert a King and Country: Lucium cum tota gente conuertit. And pre≈øently po≈øted bake with as greate celeritie to Treuers, and without ≈øtay or ceremony was admitted Archbishop, and as pre≈øently, was Martyred, very vnprobable things; or els we mo≈øt ≈øay he preached heare at the ≈øame time, S. Tymotheus did, and a≈ø≈øi≈øted in the conuer≈øion of King Lucius, which the Annals Catal. Archiep. Treuer. ≈øupr. of Treuers them≈øelues ≈øufficiently proue, when they ≈øay, that S. Marcellus after his rerturne from the Conuer≈øion of King Lucius, Sancte & prudenti≈ø≈øime praefuit; he ruled the Archiepi≈øcopall See there, holily, and mo≈øt prudently. Catal. Archiepi≈ø. T ‚Ä¢ euer. in S. MaÃÑ ≈øueto. Which to be truely, and ≈øo certainely affirmed, of the gouerment of ≈øo greate and lardge a Prouince as Treuers then was, and ≈øtill is, requireth no short experience, and ≈øpace of time.

7. I may reckon in this number, our fir≈øt Prei≈øt and Bishop I finde of this Nation S. Man≈øuetus, con≈øecrated by S. Peter the Apo≈øtle fir≈øt Bishop of Tullum in Lorraine and after Archbishop of Treuers, before S. Marcellus, often coming into Britaine, as I haue proued before, liuing very long euen to S. Eleutherius time, as many then did, and among others, S. Maternus his Predece≈ø≈øor
Di≈øciple al≈øo of S. Peter gouerned the Sees of Treuers, Cullen, and Catal. Archiep. Treuer. in S. Materno. Tungers vntill the yeare 133. and ≈øo may not be depriued of all the glory of the Conuer≈øion of King Lucius and his people. The like I may probably affirme, of S. Thean, after Archbishop of London, S. Samp≈øon, or Theodo≈øius, or S. Man≈øuetus, Thean, Samp≈øon and others probably preached here in this time. both, Archbishops after at Yorke, and others. For if S. Eluan, one of King Lucius his Amba≈ø≈øadors to Rome about the Conuer≈øion of Britaine, and there con≈øecrated Bishop by the Pope did giue place to Sainct Thean to be Archbishop of London before him, and he was his Succe≈ø≈øor, we mu≈øt needs conceaue that S. Thean had bene long time Bishop before, as many others heare were, otherwi≈øe Sainct Eluan in ≈øo greate honor for his Amba≈ø≈øadge and con≈øecration at Rome, and that prai≈øe is giuen him in Hi≈øtories, for his vertue and learning, would before the death of S. Thean in the Vacancy of 3. Archbishopricks and 28. Bishops Sees then in Britaine haue had a greate honor before that time: and his Companion S. Meduuinus ≈øo prime and excellent a man should haue returned a Bishop from Rome, and not onely a Doctor, but that there were many worthie and learned Bishops heare then in Britaine de≈øeruing, or actually hauing that Prerogatiue before him. And were or could ≈øo many Archflamens & Flamens be conuerted in the generall Conuer≈øion, and embraced Chri≈øtian Religion, if none of them had re≈øigned their places before? Or who can imagine, that King Lucius entered into ≈øuch a Di≈øpute of Learning without con≈øultation with his learned Flamens, and Archflamens, which then ruled not onely in ≈øpirituall but temporall affaires? Or how could he, and his temporall Nobles be conuerted, except the others were fir≈øt conuicted to be in error? How can it with credibilitie be conceaued, that ≈øo many of tho≈øe cheife Gentile Prei≈øts should willingly relinquish their profe≈ø≈øions, and mo≈øt of them be made and con≈øecrated Chri≈øtian Prei≈øts and Bishops by the common opinion, except many of them had profe≈ø≈øed Chri≈øtianitie before? New Conuerties might not by the lawe of Chri≈øt be admitted to that charge and dignitie in his Church.

8. And of this opinion are, or ought to be, our Cambridge Antiquaries, in expre≈ø≈øe termes te≈øtifiing, that King Lucius ≈øent Eluanus and Meduuinus Io. Caius hi≈øtor. Cantabrig. p. 22. to Rome about his Conuer≈øion in the yeare of Chri≈øt 156. and it was in the yeare 178. before they returned hither againe to exerci≈øe their Prei≈øtly function, which they had receaued at Rome, id egit anno Domini 156. & regni ≈øui 18. King Lucius ≈øent the≈øe Amba≈ø≈øadors to Rome in the 156. yeare of Chri≈øt and 18. of his Reigne. Regem Baptizarunt anno Domini 178. and either they or Damianus and Fugatianus Baptized the King, and his Subiects in the yeare of our Lord 178. which was 22. yeares after the fir≈øt ≈øending of Eluanus, and Meduuinus to Rome, by the≈øe men. The olde Manu≈øcript of the life of S. Helen our contry Manu≈øcr. Antiq. de Vita S. Helenae. Capgrau. in Catal. in eadem. woman, and holy Empre≈ø≈øe, with Capgraue and others follwing it, te≈øtifie the ≈øame, when they ≈øay, that King Lucius ≈øoone after his Fathers death being but young in yeares, in inuenili aetate, did ≈øend Epistles to the Pope of Rome humbly entreating to be made a Chri≈øtian by his direction. Lucius ex Patre Coillo optimae indolis puer in Inuenili aetate ≈øenilem animo canitiem moribus praeferebat. Qui cum defuncto Patre Regni diademate in≈øignitus fui≈ø≈øet, exitum ≈øuum praeferri volens principio, √† Spiritu Sancto edoctus Epi≈øtolas Papae humiliter direxit, petens vt ab eo fidem Christianam recipere mereretur. The like hath the Authour of the Brittish Hi≈øtorie, Galfrid. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 4. c. 19. Pontic. Virun. l. 4. Brit. Hi≈øt. and Virunnius, who ≈øeemeth to alledge Gildas in the ≈øame ≈øence, when he ≈øaith he writeth, many things in many places of King Lucius: de quo Gildas multa tradit multis in locis. And allthough it is now in the Copies of the≈øe Authours,
or mo≈øt of them, that this me≈ø≈øadge was ≈øent to Eleutherius, it cannot be but that name is in them mi≈øtaken, Eleutherius being neither Pope, nor probably Prei≈øt when by the≈øe Authours, the≈øe men and me≈ø≈øadge was ≈øent to Rome by King Lucius a young man and newly crowned: for Matthew of Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 124. Manu≈øcrip. Antiquit. in the Church of S. Peter in Cornhill in London Matth. We≈øtm. ≈øupr. & an. 201. We≈øtmin≈øter, the Antiquitie in S. Peters Church in Cornhill in London, with others witne≈ø≈øe, that Lucius was crowned King in the yeare of Chri≈øt 124. The yeare of our Lord God (≈øaith the Antiquitie of S. Peters Church) 124. Lucius was crowned King, and the yeares of his Reigne were 77. yeares. To which the Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter iu≈øtly agreeth, crowning him King in the yeare 124. Anno gratiae 124. Lucius Regni diademate in≈øignitus e≈øt; And recording his death in the yeare 201. Anno gratiae 201. Inclitus Britannorum Rex Lucius ab hac vita migrauit ad Chri≈øtum. This Monke is ≈øtiled by our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries, to be mo≈øt exqui≈øite in the true Supputation of yeares: Matthaeus Florigerus quantum Io. Bal. l. de ≈øcript. Britan. centur. 3. in Matth. Floriger. ad Hi≈øtoriam, in recta annorum ≈øupputatione ≈øingularis. And of all writers of ≈øuch matters, we may lawfully Iudge, that the auncient Authour, or Authours of the Manu≈øcript pre≈øerued in that Church dedicated to S. Peter, to te≈øtifie to all Po≈øteritie, how that Church was founded by King Lucius, and was the fir≈øt Archiepi≈øcopall See or Church in Britaine, as is contained in that Antiquitie, was mo≈øt diligent, and indu≈øtrious in ≈øearching out the truth of ≈øuch things, ≈øo publikly to be receaued. Such likely were the rea≈øons which moued the Cambridge Antiquarie, to affirme ≈øo re≈øolutely as he hath done, that King Lucius ≈øent Eluanus and Meduuinus to Rome about his, and this Countryes Conuer≈øion, ≈øo long before the dayes of the Papacie of Eleutherius, and they returned hither againe in his time, to help to effect that holy worke. And I hope ≈øuch an Vniuer≈øitie as Cambridge would ≈øtill be accompted, and in Catholike times hath bene, would not without greate warrant from their owne, or ≈øome other Antiquities, which they remember not in particular, ≈øuffer it to be published, and printed as the generall ≈øaying and te≈øtimony of their whole Vniuer≈øitie; That King Lucius when the que≈øtion of Religion was in hand, came purpo≈øely to Cambridge about it, and there being re≈øolued by the holy learned Chri≈øtians, which were ≈øtudents in Cambridge, that the Religion which they profe≈ø≈øed was true, he ≈øent Eluanus & Meduuinus to the Pope of Rome in the 156. yeare of Chri≈øt, and the 18. of his owne Reigne, for the receauing of Chri≈øtian Religion in Britaine: Cantabrigiam Lucius, pius & moderatus Princeps clementi≈øsimus
que
Hi≈øt. Cantabrig. Accadem. Auth. Ioanne Caio. ex aedibus Io. Daij. An. Dom. 1574. pag. 22. Britannorum Rex venit. Cui cum ex Sanctorum virorum, qui Chri≈øtum profe≈øsi ≈øunt, & Cantebrigiae ≈øtudebant, praedicatione per≈øua≈øum e≈øt, non fui≈ø≈øe vana quae de Deo, deque Trinitate diuulgata ≈øunt, fidei Chri≈øtianae cupidus, √† Pontifice Romano, vt ad Chri≈øti fidem reciperetur per Legatos Eluanum & Meduuinum petijt: id egit Anno Domini 156. & regni ≈øui 18.

div.head: THE VII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: DECLARING MANY HVMANE LETS and Impediments, hindering King Lucius, and his Noble Britans ≈øome yeares from publikely profe≈øsing Christian Religion, which ≈øecretly they embraced: and the occa≈øions of diuers mi≈øtakings eyther of Hi≈øtorians, or their Scribes, in the Date, Times, and Titles of letters written about the Conuer≈øion of Britaine to the faith of Chri≈øt.

div.p: 1. WHEN the E≈øtate of Eccle≈øia≈øticall affaires in Britaine had taken ≈øo happy proceedings, and effect, that both our King heare and many principall men were thus conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, from their former errours, and ≈øuper≈øtitions, and ≈øo greate hope, and forwardnes there was, to haue that faith publikely profe≈ø≈øed, which they Diuers humane feares and Impediments now chancing, and hindering King Lucius from open profe≈øsion of Chri≈øtian Religion in Britaine. priuately embraced, and acknowledged for the onely truth: many wordly temptations and oppo≈øitions did pre≈øently ari≈øe, to hinder the≈øe new and vntrayned Souldiers of Chri≈øt, to make ≈øo bold and open Profe≈ø≈øion of their holy Religion, as many holy Martyrs at that time, and they them≈øelues not long after did, and the glory of that required. For as we may probably with many Antiquities affirme, that the fauourable Edicts of diuers Emperours, and among them Antonius ≈øurnamed Pius yet reigning had ≈øome what encouraged them in temporall re≈øpects, actually to be baptized in that Religion, The Martyrdome of the holy Popes S. Tele≈øphorus, and S. Higinius. which their internall vnder≈øtanding, and Iudgment was by many inuincible motiues, and Arguments conuinced before to be onely true: So now by like contrary wordly euents, and lets, they were for ≈øome time more ≈ølowe and Antoninus Pius Emperour incen≈øed again≈øt the Britans. dull to profe≈ø≈øe it openly. They did perfectly vnder≈øtand that notwith≈øtanding the pretended and expected fauour of the pre≈øent Emperour, eyther by his commande or permi≈ø≈øion, two holy Popes (to omit many others in other places) S. Tele≈øphorus, and S. Higinius, procures of their Conuer≈øion, cruelly Polydor. Virgil. Vrb. Anglic. Hi≈øt. l. 2. pag. 42. Iulius. Capitol. in Antonin. Nichol. Vignier Biblioth. Hi≈øtor. and An. 143. were putte to death for that Religion, euen in Rome it≈øelfe vnder the Emperours ≈øight, within the ≈øpace of foure yeares or litle more by all accompts. And becau≈øe pre≈øent and home daungers doe mo≈øt terrifie, they did ≈øee, and ta≈øted, that the pre≈øent Emperour Antoninus was at this time incen≈øed again≈øt the Britans, and had allready ≈øent Lollius Vrbicus with forces hither, and he had fought ≈øome Battailes again≈øt the Britans: As both our owne, and the Roman Hi≈øtorians te≈øtifie. Pius Antoninus id temporis Imperator, Lollium Vrbicum The ≈øuper≈øtitious education and di≈øpo≈øition of Marcus Aur ‚Ä¢ lius Antoninus adopted Succe≈ø≈øour in the Empire. Legatum in Britanniam mi≈øit, qui factis aliquot praelijs, In≈øulanos in officio manere coegit.

2. And to maintayne, and fo≈øter the≈øe conceiued and ingendered humane feares, and Impre≈ø≈øions to liue and continue longer then Antoninus Pius was like to liue, now being old and long time Emperour, when he came fir≈øt to
the Empyre by the Adoption of Hadrian, he was commanded or directed by him that Marcus Aurelius Antoninus, whom from his Infancy he had trayned vp in the Gentils ≈øuper≈øtitions, should ≈øucceed him in the Empire. Iul. Capitolin. in Marco Aurelio Antonino. When he was but 8. yeares old he was putt by Adrian into the Colledge of the Salij mo≈øt ≈øuper≈øtitious Prei≈øts of Mars, and was made a Prei≈øt, a cheife Marcus Aurelius Antoninus his Per≈øecutioÃÑ again≈øt Chri≈øtians. Prelate, or Ruler, a South≈øayer, and Ma≈øter among them: octauo ≈øuae aetatis anno ab Adriano in Saliorum Collegium relatus e≈øt, & in Saliata functus Sacerdotio, & Prae≈øul & vates, & Magister, & nonnullos inaugurauit, & exaugurauit, nemine praeeunte, quod ip≈øe carmina didici≈ø≈øet. So that there could be litle hope, but this man; ≈øo ≈øuper≈øtitiou≈øly brought vp, and ≈øuch a maker, and vnmaker of their Sacrificers, and Enchaunter, would ≈øtill continue in the ≈øame, and profe≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe an enemy to all Impugners of ≈øuch proceedings, ≈øuch as all Chr≈øtians were, which he performed when he came to be Emperour, ray≈øing a generall Per≈øecution again≈øt Chri≈øtians; which to omitt, but as it concerned this kingdome, and Chri≈øtians thereof, the holy hou≈øe of our glorious Countrywoman S. Praxedes in Rome, which vntill then both in the time of S. Nouatus her brother, her holy parents S. Pudens, and S. Claudia Sabinella or Pri≈øcilla, and likely as before vnder her parents al≈øo Chri≈øtian Britans, had bene a ≈øafe refuge, and as a Sanctuarie for per≈øecuted Chri≈øtians, was now cruelly ran≈øaked, and 22. holy Chri≈øtian Martyrs together with the ≈øacred Act. S. Praxed. per S. Pa≈øtor. Martyr. Rom. die 26. Maij. Bed. V≈øuard. & Ado, eodem die. Petr. Catal. l. 5. c. 58. Baron. Tom. 2. Annal. an. 164. Prei≈øt S. Simitrius mo≈øt barbarou≈øly without any triall, que≈øtion, or Iudgment pre≈øently putt to death, of which ble≈ø≈øed company, we may not but thinke diuers of this kingdome to haue bene. And S. Timothie him≈øelfe returning from hence to Rome vpon the death of his brother, and Si≈øter, S. Nouatus, and S. Pudentiana was martyred there, and before the 62. yeare of Chri≈øt, if we will allowe of Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter his computation, who ≈øaith that S. Iu≈øtus Bishop of Vienna after long exile was martyred that yeare: Anno gratiae 162. in Gallijs plurimi pro Christo ≈øanguinem glorios√® fuderunt. Inter quos Iu≈øtus Viennen≈øis Epi≈øcopus, longo tempore exilio maceratus, Martyr efficitur. For S. Pius Pope of Rome in his Epi≈øtle to this S. Iu≈øtus, writeth of the Martyrdome Pius 1. Papa Ep. ad Iu≈øtuÃÑ Vienn. Epi≈øc. To. 1. Bibl. Sanct. & Baron. To. 2. Annal. an. 166. of our S. Timothie. And by no accompt he liued not aboue 4. yeares longer, but was Martyred in this time. So by ≈øome accompts our glorious Countryman S. Marcellus, ≈øo diligent a procurer of the Conuer≈øion of King Lucius, as I haue declared, was martyred in this Per≈øecution. And to heape vp the mea≈øure of fears for Chri≈øtian Britans, this Emperour did not onely thus per≈øecute vs abroade, but ≈øent Calphurnius Agricola hither into Britaine, with armed Troopes to keepe the Britans in ≈øubiection, as Roman Pagan Iul. Capitolin. in Marco Aurelio Antonin. Polyd. Virgil. Anglic. Hi≈øt. l. 2. p. 42. Writers terme it, but Britans may ≈øay, in a kinde of flauery.

3. The≈øe and ≈øuch were the worldly Temptations which allured King Lucius, and many noble Britans, to be more timerous, and lingering to profe≈ø≈øe the Chri≈øtian faith with ≈øuch con≈øtancy openly, as inwardly they firmely beleeued, and honored, vntill the Emperour him≈øelfe conuicted by the written Marcus Aurel. Anton. Emperour miraculou≈øly conuerted to beleeue in Chri≈øt, o ‚Ä¢ at the lea≈øt, to be a Protector of Chri≈øtians. Apologies, and Miracles wrought by Chri≈øtians, was enforced to yeeld the honour to Chri≈øt, and ab≈øtayne from Per≈øecution, and many of his noble Pagans embraced Chri≈øtian Religion. Imperator victoriam ≈øuam Chri≈øto gaudenter attribuit. And this I take to be the cheife≈øt occa≈øion of the mi≈øtakings in ≈øome Hi≈øtorians, or their Scribes, ≈øetting downe ≈øo many and ≈øeuerall times when King Lucius receaued the faith of Chri≈øt, or profe≈ø≈øed it. Many ≈øaying Tertull. Apol. c. 6 Eu≈øeb. Eccl. hi≈øt. l. 5. cap. 5. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 174. it was in the yeare of Chri≈øt 156. according as I haue before related. Others in the yeare 164. others 165. as William of Malmesbury with others. Henry
of Hartford in the yeare 169: And others in other and later times. All which be true, if we ≈øpeake of the Religion of Chri≈øt which he held, and beleeued from the very fir≈øt of the≈øe a≈ø≈øigned times, but for his, and his Nobles publike profe≈ø≈øion thereof, and the kingdome generall receauing it, with building of Churches, placing Chri≈øtian Bishops and Prei≈øts in them, and abandoning the ≈øuper≈øtitious Rites of the Pagan Gentils, we mu≈øt expect a later date, in the time of Pope Eleutherius. And the honour this holy Pope had, long before he was Pope, and the often occa≈øion of King Lucius, and others heare Occa≈øions of ≈øo ofteÃÑ mi≈øtaking the name Pope Eleutherius in letters written to and from Rome by Hi≈øtorians, or their Scribes. writing and ≈øending to Rome about this holy worke, might occa≈øion ≈øome errour in the Titles of letters to Pope Eleutherius, when he was not yet Pope, but in high e≈øtimation with the Popes there, as a principall learned and holy Prei≈øt of the Church of Rome, as appeareth in the fir≈øt Epi≈øtle of S. Pius Pope to S. Iu≈øtus Bishop of Vienna: wherein he onely ≈øendeth him ≈øalutations from S. Soter after Pope and S. Eleutherius as the cheife≈øt Prei≈øts then in Rome, and ≈øo he recommendeth them: ≈øalutant te Soter & Eleutherius, digni Pius 1. Epi≈øt. 1. ad Iu≈øtum Vienn. Epi≈øc. Tom. 1. Biblioth. Sanct. presbyteri. Which Epi≈øtle was written, and this honour giuen to Eleutherius by that holy Pope, allmo≈øt twenty yeares before Eleutherius was Pope. And yet he mu≈øt needs be a renowned man long before that time, and ≈øo no maruaile if diuers letters were written to him from Britaine, and from him hither before his Papacie: e≈øpecially if we reflect, to con≈øider how probable a thing it is, that he was mo≈øt re≈øident with our Chri≈øtian Britans there and the Popes of that time committed vnto him, to haue a peculiar care of this Country, which his greate credit and familiaritie with Pope Pius conuer≈øing ≈øo much Eu≈øeb. Hi≈øt. & Chronic. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 157. with our Britans there, and with ≈øuch principall men as were ≈øent into the≈øe parts, ≈øuch as S. Iu≈øtus of Vienna, then was, will induce to thinke: Iu≈øtus Viennen≈øium Epi≈øcopus & Lugdunen≈øium Photinus, in Eccle≈øia Chri≈øti clari habentur. And our owne Annals doe ≈øufficiently witnes, that the fame and renowne of S. Eleutherius was greate heare in Britaine before he was cho≈øen Pope: ab Ethelwerd. Chronic. ortu ≈øolis v≈øque ad occa≈øum exiuit ≈øancta opinio eius. And that this his glory was ≈øo greate in Britaine before he was Pope, tho≈øe our both auncient and later Hi≈øtorians prooue, which ≈øay that King Lucius wrote vnto him the fir≈øt yeare of h ‚Ä¢ s Con≈øecration, to take Order for the generall Conuer≈øion of this kingdome: Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. in Eleutherio Papa. Harris in Theatro. to. 2. So doth the mo≈øt authenticall and approued Relation of this Hi≈øtory te≈øtifie, that it was in the very beginning of his Papacie that King Lucius ≈øent tho≈øe letters and ≈øolemne Amba≈ø≈øadge vnto him about this Bu≈øines: Huic initio Pontificatus ≈øupplices litterae venerunt √† Lucio Britannorum Rege, vt ≈øe, ac ≈øuos Vita S. Eleutherij in Breu. Rom. 26. die Maij. in Chri≈øtianorum numerum reciperet. Which plainely proueth, this fame and honour of S. Eleutherius ≈øo well knowne in Britaine, did not now begin heare, with his Papacie; but was of farre more auncient continuance, and Antiquitie. For the very beginning of any Ruler, or Gouernour, cannot giue him ≈øo ≈øingular a commendation ≈øo ≈øoone, e≈øpecially where his Regiment is ≈øo greate, and ample, that in ≈øo short a time he can hardly take notice of the ≈øtate of tho≈øe things which belong vnto his chardge, much le≈ø≈øe take ≈øo good Order for them all, that his fame and honour should be for that doing, reported in all the world. And King Lucius ≈øending vnto him in the fir≈øt yeare of his Papacie, and the very beginning thereof initio Pontificatus, could not po≈ø≈øibly haue notice of his ≈øo renowned carriadge therein, con≈øult with all his Nobles, Flamens, and Archflamens ≈øo di≈øper≈øed in this ≈øo large a kingdome, and haue their generall con≈øent, for a generall Conuer≈øion, and ≈øend notice of this, by ≈øolemne Amba≈ø≈øadours ≈øo long a Iorney, to be there in the beginning of his
Papacy, but that this greate honour, and fame of S. Eleutherius was renowned heare long before, and this publike and generall a≈ø≈øent to for≈øake Idolatrie and embrace Chri≈øtian Religion had bene formerly concluded, & agreed vpon in Britaine; and very probably, as our Cambridge Antiquaries haue told vs before, not onely S. Timothie was ≈øent, or returned to Rome about this bu≈øines, but Eluanus and Meduuinus al≈øo, as they write, being but Catechumens to be in≈øtructed and con≈øecrated there, towards the performing ≈øo great a worke in this kingdome.

4. Neyther can we with equalitie of Iudgment thinke that among ≈øo many Britans now conuerted, or ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed heare, the≈øe two onely went now from hence thither to ≈øuch end, and purpo≈øe, but allthough the≈øe be the onely men remembred in Hi≈øtories to haue bene therein imployed, as more worthie, or els de≈øigned and ≈øent by King Lucius: yet there went many others about this time from Britaine thither, the better to enable them≈øelues for a generall Conuer≈øion of this their Country: and there continued to able them≈øelues with learning and Religion, to be made fitt In≈øtruments and workemen in ≈øo holy labours, and were therein a≈ø≈øi≈øted both by the Popes of the≈øe times, (much conuer≈øant with our Chri≈øtian Britans, and in their hou≈øes at Rome) and others the mo≈øt renowned in the Roman Clergie at that time: Among whome S. Eleutherius, after Pope, and happie Conuerter of this Nation, was a cheife man. And in their opinion (which hold the Title, Cardinall, was giuen to that holy Prei≈øt which was the cheife, and mo≈øt eminent commanding Onuphrius Panuin. l. de Epi≈øcop. Titul. & Diacon. Cardinal. Dama≈øus. Et alij in Cleto, Euari≈øt. & Higinio. S. Pa≈øtor Epi≈øt. ad S. TimotheuÃÑ. Timoth. Epi≈øt. ad Pa≈øtorem. To. 1. Biblioth. SaÃÑct. & Tom. 1. Ann. Baron. Pius Ep. ad S. Iu≈øtum Viennen. Prei≈øt in euery Church, or Titulus in Rome, according to the In≈øtitution and ordinance of the holy Popes S. Cletus, S. Euari≈øtus, and S. Higinius, in who≈øe time we now are) I cannot but probably thinke, that S. Eleutherius ≈øo high in credit, and renowne, both with S. Higinius, and Pope Pius, and his brother S. Pa≈øtor, (to who≈øe di≈øpo≈øing and di≈øtribution the fir≈øt Titles or Churches in Rome, (founded by our Chri≈øtian Britans, and ≈øtill called by their names, S. Pudentiana, and S. Praxedes, and to this daye giuing the names of honour to the Roman Cardinals ≈øo ≈øtiled) was left,) was an eminent, Cardinall, and cheife Prei≈øt pre≈øently after this time, in one of tho≈øe our Brittish Churches or Tituli in Rome: which among other bondes, tied him ≈øo firmely in loue to this Nation, and this Nation to him, that he is ≈øo often honoured in Titles of letters, and otherwi≈øe by our Antiquaries aboue other Popes. Some add an other te≈øtimonie, which if it be true, it greately maketh, for the e≈øpeciall honour, wherewith our Hi≈øtorians adorne him, thinking that S. Eleutherius came par≈øonally into Britaine, and preached heare. And this is that opinion which M. Foxe the Prote≈øtant writer, thus remembreth: Timotheus in his ≈øtorie thinketh that Eleutherius came him≈øelfe: Which wanteth
‚Ä¢ oxe Act. and Mon. l. 1. p. 56. not probable Arguments, by that is ≈øaid before, if they ≈øpeake of his preaching heare before he was Pope, ≈øent hither with S. Timothie our Countryman, or ≈øome others ≈øent by any of tho≈øe Popes before him.

div.head: THE VIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OE THE HOLY POPE S. PIVS, AND OVR renowned Chri≈øtian Britans by their Mother S. Claudia, S. Pudentia, S. Nouatus, S. Timotheus and S. Praxedes with their holy families and friends in Rome.

div.p:
1. S. Higinius hauing now gloriou≈øly ended his cour≈øe by Martyrdome, S. Pius the fir≈øt of that name ≈øucceeded him in the See Apo≈øtolike, by the more receaued opinion in the yeare of Chri≈øt 158. the 15. day of Ianuary, and the 19. yeare of the Empire of Antoninus Pius, and gouerned that holy Vita S. Pij Papae 11. Iulij in B ‚Ä¢ eu. Ro. Baron. To. 2. Annal. in Pio. Seuerin. Binn. Tom. 1. Concil. in S. Pio. See vntill the 11. day of Iuly in the 167. yeare of Chri≈øt, and 5. of Marcus Aurelius Antoninus Emperour, in who≈øe Per≈øecution he then ≈øuffered Martyrdome. All which time, and long after King Lucius ≈øtill reigned in Britaine. Concerning this Pope, we are told by our Prote≈øtant Cen≈øurers of their liues and doctrine, that as he was then called Pius, godly, ≈øo he was in act and deed: he wrought many works of true pietie in the feild of Christs The pietie and Religion of Pope Pius, by Prote≈øtaÃÑts Iudgment. Church and obtained the glory of Martyrdome by effu≈øion of his blood vnder Antoninus Verus: Pius Aquilien≈øis ≈øub Antonino Vero, multa verae pietatis opera, in agro Chri≈øtianae Eccle≈øiae fece≈ø≈øe perhibetur: Martyrij gloriam in ≈øui ≈øanguinis effu≈øione adeptus. Touching the ≈øeede of doctrine which this ≈øo holy a workeman did Io. Bal. l. 1. d ‚Ä¢ act. Rom. PontificiuÃÑ in Pio Aquile ‚Ä¢ en. Rob. Barns l. de Vit. Pontif. Ro. in Pio 1. ≈øowe in the feild of the Chri≈øtian Church, they thus informe vs: Pa≈øcha die Dominica e≈ø≈øe celebrandum, per reuelationem Hermeti facta ≈øtatuit. Sacerdotibus negligentius Mi≈ø≈øae ≈øacra facientibus, paenas ≈øtatuit, vt ≈øi quis per imprudentiam, de ≈øanguine Chri≈øti, effunderet in terram, paenitentiam ageret dies 40. ≈øi ≈øuper altare, dies 3. ≈øi ≈øuper linteum ≈øub≈øtratum calici, 4. dies: ≈øi ≈øuper aliud linteum, dies 9. ≈øanguinem Christi effu≈øum lambere, vel ≈øi id fieri non po≈øsit, aut radere, aut cluere: & ra≈øum, aut lotum, vel comburi, vel in ≈øacrarium repo≈øitum ≈øeruari: Thermas Nouati templo dedicauit. Sacrilegij reos fecit, qui fundos, aliaue bona religioni dicata, in prophanos v≈øus conferunt. Virgines ante annum 25. non e≈ø≈øe con≈øecrandas praecepit. Quae ad Religionem ≈øpectant, √† ≈øuae Diaece≈øeos Synodis audienda e≈ø≈øe ≈øtatuit: ≈øalua tamen Pontificia authoritate: he decreed that Ea≈øter day should be kept vpon the Sonday, according as it ‚Ä¢ as reuealed to Hermes. He ordained punishments for Prei≈øts which should negligently offer the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, as if any should by improuidence ≈øpill any of the blood of Chri≈øt vpon the ground, he should doe penance 40. dayes; if vpon the Altar, 3. dayes: if vpoÃÑ the linnen cloath which is ≈øpredd vnder the chalice 4. dayes: if vppon the other linnen cloath 9. dayes. That they should licke vp the blood of Chri≈øt that was ≈øpilt, or if that could not be done, either pare it, or washe it: and ≈øo pared or washed to be burnt, or layed in the Sacrary, and pre≈øerued. He dedicated the Bath of Nouatus for a Church. He made them guiltie of Sacriledge, which conuerted lands or other goods that were dedicated to Religion, to prophaine v≈øes. He commanded that virgins should not be con≈øecrated before they were 25. yeares olde. He decreed that matters which belonged to Religion, should be heard by the Synods of their
Dioce≈ø≈øe, euer re≈øeruing the Popes Authoritie. This is our Prote≈øtants Relation of this holy Popes pietie, and doctrine, concerning the whole Church of Chri≈øt. In which Narration there is one Act, and practi≈øe of his, more peculiar to this kingdome; which is his conuerting and dedicating the hou≈øe of S. Nouatus, which the≈øe men terme Thermas Nouati, Nouatus his Bathes ≈øome time belonging to him, and adioyning neare his hou≈øe, to be a Church. Of which, and this holy man, Sonne of our Noble Countrywoman S. Claudia, his Brother S. Timothie of whome I haue ≈øpoken before and their holy Si≈øters S. Pudentiana and S. Praxedes, their due time and place now call vpon mee, to make ≈øome more memory of them, which ≈øo honorably de≈øerued of this Nation, and the whole Church of Chri≈øt, in their dayes.

2. And becau≈øe we are better a≈ø≈øured, which of them died, then liued, fir≈øt; I will begin with S. Pudentiana, who as S. Pa≈øtor or Hermes which well knew them all, and is ≈øuppo≈øed to haue written their Acts, in his Epi≈øtle to S. S. Pa≈øtor Epi≈øt. ad S. Timotheum fratrem S. Noua
‚Ä¢ i. Tom. 1. Biblioth. Sanct. & Tom. 2. Annal. Baron. Timothie, as it ≈øeemeth by the Tenor thereof in Britaine ≈øent to him from Rome by Eu≈øebius a Subdeacon of the Roman Church was the fir≈øt of them, which happily changed this tran≈øitory for immortall life. This holy Virgin by her holy Mother S. Claudia of our Brittish Nation borne in that her happy hou≈øe in Rome, which by the Roman Tradition, gaue the fir≈øt lodging and entertaynement in that Citie to the glorious Apo≈øtle S. Peter, The R ‚Ä¢ ligious honor of the hou≈øe of ‚Ä¢ ur Brittish Lady Saint Claudia in Rome. The lodging and place of entr ‚Ä¢ tainment of S. Peter, S. Paul, Popes, and other Saints. was baptized and in≈øtructed in the faith by him, and probably ≈øome time by S. Paule often making his aboade, and re≈øidence in her parents hou≈øe. As her holy Mother had before both in the pre≈øence and long ab≈øence of her Hu≈øband S. Pudens in Cappadocia and other remote places made her hou≈øe, domus ampli≈øsima, a mo≈øt ample and honourable hou≈øe, as the Roman Hi≈øtorians terme it, the prime and cheife Harbour and lodging of Chri≈øtians then, and there, primum ac praecipuum hospitium Chri≈øtianorum. So that it being, in Monte Viminali the auncient Poet of that time taketh notice, that it was the ordinary place of Entertayning the Pilgrims which came to Rome in tho≈øe dayes: dictumque petunt a vimine collem vi≈øcera magnarum domuuÃÑ: And founded that euer Baron. Tom. 2. Annal. an. 159. & Tom. 1. & not. ad Martyrol. Iuuenal. Satyra 3. memorable monumeÃÑt reuerently to intoombe and bury the ≈øacred bodies and Reliks of holy Martyrs and other holy Chri≈øtians: So this her ble≈ø≈øed daughter following the example of ≈øo worthie a Mother per≈øi≈øted in the like works of pietie. And allthough that honorable Liuing and reuenewe of her noble S. Pud ‚Ä¢ ntiana her daughter in≈øi≈øteth i ‚Ä¢ h ‚Ä¢ r Par ‚Ä¢ nts ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ m ‚Ä¢ le of Pietie. parents was now diuided to the Children into foure parts, and the farre greate≈øt by the Roman Imperiall Lawes vnto their ≈øonnes, her brothers S. Nouatus and Tymotheus, yet wonderfull was that charitie she extended to all. Chri≈øtians both Britans, and others, both for ≈øpirituall and temporall releife, in this time. She cau≈øed an Altar to be erected in her hou≈øe, for the holy Popes to whom the greate≈øt re≈øort and concour≈øe of people was to offer the holy Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and the holy communicants there to receaue the mo≈øt venerable Sacrament of Chri≈øts ble≈ø≈øed body: And kept tho≈øe Apo≈øtolike Popes, as S. Pius & others there, with temporall maintenance to theÃÑ and tho≈øe which re≈øorted to them, or continually remayned there with theÃÑ, to tho≈øe Religious purpo≈øes and intents. Pius Pontifex in aedibus Pu ‚Ä¢ entianae cum Chri≈øtianis ≈øacra Vit. S. Pudentianae ‚Ä¢ n Br ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . Ro. die 19. M ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . Adom Martyr. die 18. M ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . Surius eod. die & al. celebrabat. There she and her family with the≈øe holy Popes and others ≈øerued God in all exerci≈øes of pietie day and night: in omni exercitatione pietatis ita ex ‚Ä¢ reuit‚ñ™ vt nocte dicque ince≈ø≈øanter hymnis & orationibus cum familia ≈øua Domino in≈øeruiret, Beat ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ imo Pio Vrbi ‚Ä¢ Epi≈øcopo cum ea in laudibus Dei participante. And to te≈øtifie her long time ≈øpent in this Religeous conuer≈øation, in entertayning
the Popes, Prei≈øts, and other Chri≈øtians mini≈øtring vnto them, in all nece≈ø≈øaries, the worthie writers of her life doe witne≈ø≈øe, that she kept this Order euen from the death of her Father S. Pudens, when she was fir≈øt at her owne di≈øpo≈øition, euen to her dying day: po≈øt obitum ≈øancti Patris, probably Matth. We≈øtm. an. 98. Martial. in Epigram. Godwyn. Conuer≈ø. of Brit. c. 3. the ≈øpace of 60. yeares or more: for her Father by common opinion died in the time of Domitian ≈ølayne in his Pallace in Rome in or about the yeare of Chri≈øt 98. And for the greater increa≈øing the number of Chri≈øts people, she cau≈øed a Font to be made in this her hou≈øe, for the baptizing of new Chri≈øtians, and the more to per≈øuade all people to Chri≈øtian Religion, it ≈øeemeth she redeemed many ≈ølaues and Bondmen from the Pagans, and cau≈øing them to be catechized and baptized in her owne hou≈øe, made them free. For we reade in her life in Ado, Surius, and others, that at one time S. Pius the Pope baptized 96. ≈øuch par≈øons in the Bapti≈øtery or Font belonging to her hou≈øe, which she had made. Ad nonaginta ≈øex numero manumi≈ø≈øos Beatus Pius aquis Ado. & Sur. ≈øupr. & die 21. Iulij in S. Praxede. Lipelous aut Cornelius Gra≈øius die 21. Iul. in S. Praxede. ≈øalutaribus abluit. In this manner she ≈øpent all her ample Noble Wealth and ≈øub≈øtance, and after very many afflictions for her holy Religion, and pietie, after she had reuerently buryed many Martyrs, and ≈øpent all her Riches vpon the poore ≈øeruants of Chri≈øt, and his honour, she changed earthly life & things for heauenly, and was buried neare her holy Father S. Pudens, in the funerall place mentioned before, founded by her renowned Mother. Po≈øt Innumeros Agones, po≈øt multorum Martyrum venerabiliter exhibitas ≈øepulturas, po≈øt omnes facultates ≈øuas in vi≈øceribus pauperum inclu≈øas, Chri≈øtoque fideliter commendatas, tandem de terris ad Christum migranit, quarto decimo Calendas Augu≈øti, & iuxta Patrem, ≈øanctum Pudentem ≈øepulta. About the yeare of Chri≈øt 160. Baronius Baron. Tom. 2. Annal. an. 162. ≈øeemeth to hold it was in the next yeare 161. And by all accompts it mu≈øt needs be in a little before, or after this time, for all writers of her life affirme, she died in the dayes of the Papacie of S. Pius, and Empire of Antoninus Pius, who by all recknings of his Imperiall Gouernment died a litle before, or ≈øoone after this yeare.

3. Very ≈øoone after the death of S. Pudentiana died al≈øo her brother S. Nouatus, S. Pa≈øtor Epi≈øt. ad S. Timoth. ≈øupr. as among other te≈øtimonies, we reade in that Epi≈øtle which S. Pa≈øtor or Hermes ≈øent to their Brother S. Timothie then farre out of Rome, and probably by the circum≈øtances of time and others, heare in Britaine, where he S. Nouatus Prei≈øt a Brittan by his Brittish Mother S. Claudia. thus writeth that S. Praxedes being afflicted much for the death of S. Pudentiana, Pope Pius, many Noble Chri≈øtians and her Brother S. Nouatus came to comfort her, and within a moneth and 28. dayes after his returne from her S. Nouatus fell ≈øicke, and about 13. dayes after died of that ≈øicknes. Po≈øt men≈øem & dies viginti octo aegritudine detentus e≈øt Nouatus, po≈øtquam abce≈ø≈øerat √† conspectu Virginis Praxedis. And tertio decimo die tran≈øiuit ad Dominum. It ≈øeemeth by S. Pa≈øtor in this his Epi≈øtle to S. Timothie of his happy death and di≈øpo≈øing his temporall Riches, that he was a Prei≈øt, a Sacrificing Ma≈ø≈øing Prei≈øt, as it is euident before S. Pius then Pope was, for S. Pa≈øtor there plainely te≈øtifieth, that both Pope Pius, and Nouatus did often remember S. Timothie at the Altar of our Lord. Idemque (Nouatus) vos frequenter cum Beati≈øsimo Pio Epi≈øcopo ad altare Domini commemorabat. The cheife cau≈øe of this ≈øo often their remembring S. Timothie our Brittish Prei≈øt, preaching heare in Britaine is often remembred in the Ma≈ø≈øes of S. Pius Pope, and S. Nouatus. S. Timothie in the holy Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, e≈øpecially by S. Pius the Pope, I cannot a≈øcribe, but to the greate care that holy Pope had of the greate chardge he with his Predece≈ø≈øour had committed to S. Timothie, about his preaching and labours in Britaine, ≈øo much concerning the Apo≈øtolike See, and Church of Chri≈øt, that an holy Pope and Pa≈øtor could not but often remember
and commend it, in his be≈øt office of Sacrifice to God. And S. Nouatus ≈øo holy a man, as all Antiquities of him giue euidence, ≈øo louing a Brother and carefull of his Countries Conuer≈øion, and good of the Chri≈øtians then di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, that he left all his worldly wealth to be di≈øpo≈øed by this his Brother S. Timothie, diligently labouring in the Harue≈øt of Chri≈øt in Britaine, and S. Praxedes his Si≈øter, the cheife≈øt Nur≈øe and Releeuer of Gods ≈øeruaÃÑts in Rome, to be imployed to ≈øuch holy ends, and v≈øes, could not be vnmindefull in his prayers and Sacrifice of ≈øuch a Brother, and his Countries mo≈øt important bu≈øines which he had in hand. This holy Saint was, as al≈øo his Father, Mother, Brother, and Si≈øters in≈øtructed in the faith by the holy Apo≈øtles S. Peter and S. Paule, Romae Depo≈øitio Sancti Nouati, filij Beati Pudentis Senatoris, & fratris Martyrol. Rom. 20. die Iunij. Bed. V≈øuard. & Ado eod. die. ≈øancti Timothei Presbyteri, & Sanctarum Chri≈øti Virginum Pudentianae, & Praxedis, qui ab Apo≈øtolis eruditi ≈øunt in fide. That he was a Prei≈øt, the Martyrologe is ≈øilent, but that which I haue before cited from his renowned acquaintance and friend S. Pa≈øtor giueth vs ≈øufficient warrant to be of that opinion. How The hou≈øe of S. Nouatus an other Harbour for the Popes and Saints in Rome. he in herited his parents vertues in exerci≈øing all works of pietie, harbouring and releyuing the per≈øecuted and di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Seruants of God, that his hou≈øe which had bene the fir≈øt lodging of S. Peter, and harbour to diuers his Succe≈ø≈øours and a Receptacle & fo≈øterer of all Chri≈øtiaÃÑs re≈øorting thither both for ≈øpirituall and temporall comforts, was ≈øo continued all his time. Se ≈øuaque Act. S. Nouati. &c. in Antiq. cod. Baron. tom. 2. Annal. an. 159. Chri≈øtianorum ob≈øequio mancipa≈ø≈øe coÃÑ≈øtat. And his mo≈øt Noble hou≈øe was open to all Chri≈øtians. Nobili≈øsima Chri≈øtianis patens, apud quam & Thermae Nouati. This was a di≈øtinct hou≈øe and place from that where his holy Si≈øters formerly liued as both the two auncient Cardinals Titles in Rome S. Pudentiana and S. Praxedes ≈øtill continued from that time, as I haue shewed before, and the vi≈øitation which ≈øaint Nouatus going from his owne hou≈øe to his Si≈øter ≈øaint Praxedes after ≈øaint Pudentiana her death regi≈øtred by ≈øaint Pa≈øtor then pre≈øent in an other di≈øtinct hou≈øe where she then continued in Harbouring and releyuing the Saints of Chri≈øt aboundantly te≈øtifie. S. Pa≈øtor to the greate honour of ≈øaint Nouatus and Praxedes al≈øo thus relateth it.

4. That ≈øaint Nouatus accompanyed with S. Pius the Pope and many Noble Chri≈øtians went to ≈øaint Praxedes her hou≈øe to comfort her about her Si≈øters death: Multi nobiles Chri≈øtiani ad eam veniebant, & con≈øolabantur eam vna cum Epi≈øcopo Pio, ventique ad eam Germanus vester Nouatus. And ≈øaint Pius together with ≈øaint Praxedes and ≈øaint Pa≈øtor, went from ≈øaint Praxedes her hou≈øe to the hou≈øe of ≈øaint Nouatus when and where he was ≈øick, and ≈øtaied with him there 8. dayes. eamus ad eum fuimus in domo eius diebus ac noctibus octo. And vntill after the death of ≈øaint Nouatus who gaue all his ≈øub≈øtance to ≈øaint Timothie and ≈øaint Praxedes, she had no Intere≈øt in that hou≈øe. How charitable and munificent ≈øaint Nouatus was to the poore Chri≈øtians, may ≈øome what appeare by ≈øaint Pa≈øtor his Relation of him, when he went to comfort his Si≈øter, where he ≈øaith of him to ≈øaint Timothie, Germanus vester Nouatus, qui e≈øt frater no≈øter in Domino, multos Chri≈øtianos pauperes donis ≈øuis re≈øecit, & mini≈øtrauit omnibus de facultatibus ≈øuis: Your naturall Brother Nouatus who is our Brother in our Lord did releeue many poore Chri≈øtians with his guifts, S. Nouatus dying leaueth all to S. Timothie and S. Praxedes, to be employed for releife of Chri≈øtians. and mini≈øtred to them all out of his ≈øub≈øtance. And as in his life he had euer an e≈øpeciall care of the ≈øpirituall good of this kingdome, his Country, ≈øo at his death he was not vnmindefull of it, but gaue all be had to his Brother ≈øaint Timothie then labouring and preaching heare, and to his Si≈øter ≈øaint Praxedes as mindefull of it though she was at Rome. Hoc placuit ei, vt vobis
vna cum beata Praxede omnem ≈øub≈øtantiam ≈øuam relinqueret. And made as it were Superui≈øours of this his la≈øt Will and Te≈øtament to ≈øee it performed, the holy Pope ≈øaint Pius and his renowned Brother ≈øaint Pa≈øtor, as appeareth by that Epi≈øtle, the two mo≈øt powerable and honourable then in the Church of Chri≈øt, and mo≈øt louing of this Nation of Britaine, and ≈øpirituall good thereof, as allready appeareth, and will be more manife≈øt in the next Chapter following.

div.head: THE IX. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OE S. TIMOTHIE STIL PREACING IN Britaine, his di≈øpo≈øing his temporall goods in Rome for entertaining and releeuing per≈øecuted Prei≈øts and Chri≈øtians, his hou≈øe there being dedicated a cheife Church, mo≈øt Christians re≈øorting to it. And other Apo≈øtolike men ≈øent from Rome into Britaine in this time.

div.p:
1. I Haue ≈øpoaken before of the preaching and Apo≈øtolike holy labors of S. Timothie Brother to S. Nouatus in this their Country of Britaine. And it (more then probably) appeareth euen by the Epi≈øtle of S. Pa≈øtor to S. Timothie, pre≈øently vpon S. Nouatus his death, that he theÃÑ both ≈øtill continued heare wholly imploying his Trauailes for the Conuer≈øion of his Country Britaine, and S. Pius yet continuing Pope continued al≈øo the auncient fatherly care of his Predece≈ø≈øors to vs, ≈øent hither at this time, a new Mi≈ø≈øion and ≈øupply of Clergie meÃÑ to encrea≈øe the number of them, which with ≈øo greate ≈øpirituall fruite trauailed in the worke of our Conuer≈øion. The fir≈øt, of S. Timothie being S. Timothie our Apo≈øtolike Britan preaching in Britaine at the death of S. Nouatus his Brother in Rome. ≈øtill in Britaine at this time, ≈øuppo≈øing what is proued before of his preaching heare a litle before, and no memory made in Hi≈øtories of his departing hence, or preaching in any other place but Italy and Britaine before this time, we mu≈øt needs yeeld ≈øo much to the te≈øtimonie of S. Pa≈øtor, that it conuinceth his ≈øtill continuance in this place ≈øo remote from Rome, that he did not, nor could take notice of things there done, and nearely concerning S. Timothie, but by letters and Me≈ø≈øengers to be ≈øent vnto him, a long Iorney. For in this Epi≈øtle of S. Pa≈øtor to S. Timothie, he doth aduerti≈øe him, of the death of his Si≈øter S. Pudentiana, which was before S. Pius, S. Nouatus, and the Chri≈øtian Nobilitie of Rome came to her Si≈øter S. Praxedes to comfort her in her ≈øorrowes for ≈øo greate a lo≈ø≈øe, and yet maketh it allmo≈øt two moneths after, po≈øt men≈øem & dies viginti octo, before S. Nouatus fell ≈øike, who died not vntill aboue twenty dayes after this, diebus ac noctibus octo, and tertio decimo die, all this together with that S. Nouatus had left S. Timothie and S. Praxedes his Heirs, he writeth to S. Timothie for Newes and late accidents whereof he had no Intelligence before: This requiring ≈øo greate a di≈øtance from Rome where the≈øe things were pre≈øently knowne and acted to make them concealed from S. Timothie, whome they ≈øo concerned vntill they were now after diuers
moneths writen vnto him by a man of ≈øuch worthines and Authoritie, as S. Pa≈øtor was, doth giue mee allowance to be of opinion, that S. Timothie was all this while heare in Britaine.

2. The ≈øecond, of a new mi≈ø≈øion of Cleargie men to be ≈øent hither at this time by Pope Pius hath ≈øufficient warrant in the later end of the ≈øame Epi≈øtle from S. Pa≈øtor at Rome to S. Timothie in Britaine, where the ≈øame Epi≈øtle is ≈øaid to be ≈øent by Eu≈øebius a Subdeacon of the Roman Church. Mi≈ø≈øa per Eu≈øebium S. Pius ≈øent with Eu≈øebius a DeacoÃÑ of Rome, and other Apo≈øtolike man into Britaine at this time. SubdiaconuÃÑ ≈øanctae Romanae Eccle≈øiae. Wherefore when I finde in ≈øo worthy an eye witnes that a Subdeacon of the holy Roman Church, who≈øe office is to be ≈øubordinate and attendant vpon ≈øacred Prei≈øts and Bishops in their holy Sacrifice, and function, and hath no power committed vnto him of him≈øelfe in ≈øuch affaires, was ≈øent into Britaine ≈øo farre di≈øtant, and then for the mo≈øt part, a Pagan Nation, and thus to be ≈øent from that Apo≈øtolike See which euer ≈øent holy Prei≈øts and Bishops into all the≈øe parts of the worlde, I may not make my ≈øelfe ≈øo ignorant in Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hi≈øtories, ≈øilent of ≈øuch examples, and vnskillfull in Diuinitie, which vtterly di≈øableth ≈øuch men to intermedle in reconciling people to Chri≈øt, and mini≈øter his Sacraments, to haue the lea≈øt conceipt this Subdeacon Eu≈øebius was ≈øent hither alone, but ≈øome reuereÃÑd Prei≈øts and Bishops, or Bishop at the lea≈øt, on whome he with others was to attend, were ≈øent hither by Pope Pius at that time, to exerci≈øe tho≈øe powerable ≈øpirituall offices which Britaine needed, and he could not performe. Their names in particular I doe not finde, no more then of others ≈øent in later times by S. Eleutherius, & S. Gregory, who≈øe ≈øixt part is not to be found in any of our Hi≈øtories, Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 4. c. 20. Pontic. Virun. l. 4. hi≈øt. in fine. Matth. We≈øtm. an 186. except the auncient true Gildas relating the names of tho≈øe S. Eleutherius ≈øent, as the Brittish Hi≈øtory, Virunnius, and Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter te≈øtifie, can be produced. Yet I haue ≈øet downe the name of one, their Subdeacon Eu≈øebius, which probably is as much as any doth for S. Eleutherius, or S. Gregorie their Mi≈ø≈øions, if we con≈øider how farre for number the≈øe by common opinion did exceeded this Mi≈ø≈øion of S. Pius. And allthough iniquitie of times hath buried both the names, & labours of mo≈øt of the≈øe Apo≈øtolike men in obliuion, for their particulars, yet we cannot but con≈øider it was a great comfort to the Chri≈øtians heare, and motiue to others to embrace the faith, when they did ≈øo certainely vnder≈øtand by ≈øuch approued warraÃÑt, that many Noble men in Rome were become Chri≈øtians, and boldly profe≈ø≈øed that Religion. And among other matters concerning Britaine cettified to S. Timothy by S. Pa≈øtor, this was an other, that S. Pius Pope, S. Pa≈øtor and S. Praxedes being pre≈øent in the ≈øikenes of S. Nouatus, he bequeathed all his Ritches and ≈øub≈øtance to his Brother S. Timothie and Si≈øter S. Praxedes: his diebus cum ibi e≈ø≈øemus, hoc placuit ei, vt vobis vna cum beata Praxede omnem ≈øub≈øtantiam ≈øuam relinqueret. And S. Pa≈øtor by the con≈øent of Pope Pius and S. Praxedes wrote hither into Britaine vnto him to know what order he would giue in this affaire: de quo facto nos literas huius textus ad vos direximus vna cum beato Pio Epi≈øcopo Sedis Apo≈øtolicae, & virgine Praxede, vt, quid tibi placuerit de ≈øub≈øtantia Germani tui Nouati, facias nos certiores, vt tua ordinatio in omnibus cu≈øtodiatur. That they might certainely know from him, what order he would ≈øet downe for the di≈øpo≈øing of ≈øo greate wealth; for they vndoubtedly a≈ø≈øured them≈øelues, that he who had for≈øaken his holy Brother and Si≈øters, his Fathers Country and friends, and his owne temporall E≈øtate there, for the ardent loue & de≈øire he had to preach the Gho≈øpell in this kingdome his Mothers Country, and to wine his Countrimen and friends heare to Chri≈øt, would not giue
ouer ≈øo holy a worke to take ≈øo long a Iorney to di≈øpo≈øe of temporall things, which he had ≈øo contemned before, in re≈øpect of Religeous and heauenly bu≈øines.

3. And thus it proued true, for S. Timothie writing againe to S. Pa≈øtor, his brother in holy Prei≈øthood, and his mo≈øt holy Si≈øter S. Praxedes: Timotheus confratri presbitero Pa≈øtori, & ≈øancti≈øsimae Sorori Praxedi in Domino ≈øalutem: S. Timothie committerh the di≈øpo≈øing of his temporall Ritches in Rome to S. Pius Pope, S. Praxedes his Si≈øter, and S. Pa≈øtor to Eccle≈øia≈øticall v≈øes. de≈øiring to be remembred at the memory of the holy Apo≈øtles, and to S. Pius Pope, and all Saints there, referreth the di≈øpo≈øition of all that temporall ≈øub≈øtance to S. Pa≈øtor and Praxedes, giuing them full power and Authoritie to di≈øpo≈øe thereof. Oramus ≈øanctimonium vestrum, vt nos commendare dignemini memoriae ≈øanctorum Apo≈øtolorum, & ≈øancto Pio Epi≈øcopo, ≈øanctae Sedis Apo≈øtolicae Prae≈øuli, & omnibus ≈øanctis. Agno≈øcat Sanctitas ve≈øtra, quia quod germano ≈øuo Nouato placuit, & nobis famulis vestris placet: vt in arbitrio ≈øanctae virginis ≈øit, quod mihi dereliquit, & quod vobis, & ≈øanctae virgini placuerit, ex eo faciendi plenam per omnia habeatis pote≈øtatem. This power and Epi≈øtle being receaued by S. Pa≈øtor at Rome from S. Timothie in Britaine, he deliuered the Epi≈øtle to Pope Pius to reade, who gaue thanks to God to ≈øee ≈øo greate pietie in our holy Countriman: accepta hac Epi≈øtola gaudio repleti ≈øumus, & tradidimus eam legendam His hou≈øe that was S. Nouatus hou≈øe dedicated a Church by Pope S. Pius. ≈øancto Pio Epi≈øcopo. Tunc beatus Pius Epi≈øcopus gratias egit Deo omnipotenti. And ≈øainct Praxedes ≈øo ≈øoone as she had receaued this warrant from ≈øainct Timothie, entreated ≈øainct Pius the Pope to dedicate that hou≈øe of Nouatus, for a Church, becau≈øe the building was greate, and ≈øpatious, which ≈øaint Pius performed dedicating a Church there at Nouatus Bathes, and con≈øtituted it a Roman Title, con≈øecrating a Bapti≈øterie, or Font there, the fourth of the Ids of May, Eodem tempore virgo Domini Praxedes, accepta Pote≈øtate, rogauit beatum Pium Epi≈øcopum vt in Thermis Nouati, quae iam in v≈øu non erant, Eccle≈øiam dedicaret, quia in eis aedificium magnum & ≈øpatio≈øum videbatur e≈ø≈øe: quod & placuit Pio Epi≈øcopo, & dedicauit Eccle≈øiam in Thermis Nouati, in vrbe, in loco qui appellatur vicus Lateriorum, vbi & con≈øtituit Titulum Romanum, in q√∫o & Bapti≈øterium, con≈øecrauit quarto Idus Maias. This Title or Church decayed with oldnes was decently reedified and renewed by Henry Cardinall Caietan, Prei≈øt, and Baron. Annal. Eccle≈øia≈øt. Tom. 2. an. 162. Ado Treueren. Martyr. 12. Cal. Aug. Sur. die ‚Ä¢ 1. Iulij in S. Praxede. Cardinall of that auncient Title, when Cae≈øar Baronius wrote his Hi≈øtorie of this Age, anno, quo haec ≈øcribimus. Ado Archbishop of Treuers, and others write, that this Church or Title was dedicated in her parents time, in titulo quem Pater earum Pudens dedicauit: Which may be well ≈øaid, in re≈øpect of the continuall re≈øidence and continuance of the holy Apo≈øtles, or their Di≈øciples and other Apo≈øtolike ≈øacred Prei≈øts and Chri≈øtians there continually ≈øeruing God. And after this ≈øolemne dedication by ≈øaint Pius, our holy Country woman The honour of this our BritaÃÑs Church in Rome, S. Praxedes, Martyrs and other holy Saincts there. ≈øaint Praxedes continued there in greate holines both in time of quiet and Per≈øecution entettayning all Chri≈øtians, and releeuing ≈øuch of them as were needy there. In ≈øo much that ≈øoone after this time Antoninus Pius being departed out of this life and Marcus Aurelius Antoninus ≈øucceeding him in the Empire, and per≈øecuting Chri≈øtians, and our ble≈ø≈øed Countrywoman notwith≈øtanding the terror of Per≈øecution continuing S. Pa≈øtor in Act. S. Praxed. Ado. Treu. 12. cal. Augu≈øt. Sur. & alij 21. Iulij. Bed. V≈øuard. & Rom. Martyrol. die 26. Maij. Petr. Cat. l. 5. c. 58. her auncient Religeous charitie in harbouring and maintayning the per≈øecuted Chri≈øtians, the Emperour being informed of ≈øuch meetings and a≈ø≈øemblies to be v≈øed, and continued in the hou≈øe of ≈øaint Praxedes, ≈øent his per≈øecuting In≈øtruments thither, who apprehended many, among whome he commanded ≈øaint Simitrius an holy Prei≈øt, and 22. others without any examination or Proce≈ø≈øe of lawe barbarou≈øly to be put to death
in the ≈øame Church. Vulgatum e≈øt Antonino Imperatori, quod conuentus fieret, in domo Praxedis: qui mi≈øit & tenuit multos, inter quos Simitrium Presbyterum cum alijs viginti duobus, quos ≈øine interrogatione, gladio puniri praecepit in eodem Titulo. Who≈øe bodies ≈øaint Praxedes carefully gathered together and reuerently in the night time buryed them in her holy Mothers funerall place. And she her≈øelfe ≈øoone after, within 34. dayes of this greate Martyrdome, departed this life to receaue her eternall happines and reward in heauen, and was buryed there al≈øo, neare her holy Father by ≈øaint Pa≈øtor the reuerend Prei≈øt and Martyr, who al≈øo wrote her life. In which place ≈øaith he the prayers of Saints doe florish at this day. Vbi florent hodie orationes Sanctorum.

4. Neyther did this holy Brittish Receptacle and Nur≈øery of ≈øacred Prei≈øts and Chri≈øtians, departe froÃÑ this ≈øo long continued Religion, deuotion, & charitie v≈øed there by the death of ≈øaint Praxedes, nor she, ≈øaint Pius and ≈øaint Pa≈øtor vpon that warrant or Re≈øignation of ≈øaint Timothie, ≈øpoken of before, ≈øo This Church bore the name of S. Timothie, and euen by the Romans coÃÑ fe≈øsion was from S. Peters fir≈øt coming to Rome the greate≈øt receptacle of Chri≈øtians there. transferre the dominion and Rule thereof from him though erecting a Title or Church there, but they ≈øtill re≈øerued a commande thereof to him, and it bore his name Balneum Timotheum, Thermae Timothinae, Timothies Bath, after ≈øaint Praxedes death, and ≈øaint Timothies al≈øo, keeping long the name of the la≈øt Brittish owner thereof. Baronius freely confe≈ø≈øeth after this time that this Brittish hou≈øe was then, and had bene the common and v≈øuall lodging place of Chri≈øtians in Rome from the fir≈øt coming of ≈øaint Peter thither, patebat Pudentis Senatoris domus, vt alias meminimus, ab initio Petri Romam aduentus hospitio Baron. Annal. Eccl. Tom. 2. an. 165. Chri≈øtianorum: And he very often times reiterats the like. And to make this good, we haue many worthie Writers, ≈øome in the life of S. Iu≈øtine the renowned Chri≈øtian Philo≈øopher and Martyr, who as the Authours te≈øtifie, did offer his ≈øecond Booke for the Defence of Chri≈øtian Religion to Marcus Martyrol. Rom. die 13. Aprilis. Bed. V≈øuard. Ado. Antoninus Verus, and Lucius Aurelius CoÃÑmodus the per≈øecuting Emperours, and defended it publikely in di≈øputation, after this time: ≈øecundum librum pro Religionis no≈øtrae defen≈øione praefatis Imperatoribus Marco Antonino Vero, & Lucio Aurelio Commodo porrexi≈ø≈øet. This renowned man being openly, together with the holy Chri≈øtians Cariton, Caritina, Euelpi≈øtius, Hierax, Pean, and Valerian, Menol. Graecor. cal. Iunij. Metaphra≈øtes die 1. Iunij. Sur. & Lipol. eod. die. or Liberian, conuented and examined by Ru≈øticus, Praefect of the Citie of Rome, vnder the named Emperours, in what place the Chri≈øtians there v≈øed to a≈ø≈øemble, and his ≈øchollers came together to heare him: Iu≈øtine an≈øweared, that he euer continued at Timothies Bath, neare the hou≈øe of one named Martius, and hauing bene now twice in Rome, knew no other place, and there he preached to all, that re≈øorted to him, Respondit Iu≈øtinus: Ego prope domum Martij cuiu≈ødam, ad balneum cognomento Timothinum, hactenus man≈øi Veni autem in vrbem Romam ≈øecundo, neque alium quempiam locum, ni≈øi quem dixi, cogno≈øco. Ac ≈øi quis ad me venire voluit, communicaui cum illo veritatis doctrinam. By which it is euident, that this our Chri≈øtian British hou≈øe in Rome after the death of S. Praxedes, and S. Timothie his warrant to di≈øpo≈øe of it, was employed to ≈øuch holy v≈øes as formely it was and that it now continued notwith≈øtanding the greate trobles and Per≈øecution again≈øt it, the mo≈øt famous and renowned place in Rome, for entertayning & maitaining afflicted Chri≈øtians, there preaching, mini≈øtring Sacraments, and other holy exerci≈øes. And that it ≈øtill continued at our Countriman S. Timothie his di≈øpo≈øition, as the ≈øtill bearing his name as owner or cheife commander thereof, Balneum cognomento Timothinum proueth, which it could not truely beare vntill after the
death of S. Nouatus, the immediate and onely Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor of it, from his parents before. And it ≈øeemeth that allthough S. Timothie had left it in the power of S. Pius, Praxedes and Pa≈øtor to di≈øpo≈øe of it, they ≈øtill re≈øerued the Right and Intere≈øt thereof to S. Timothie, and though at the Con≈øecration of it, for a Church it was termed Titulus Pa≈øtoris, the Title or Church where S. Pa≈øtor was ordinary and cheife Prei≈øt, yet S. Pa≈øtor dying pre≈øently after S. Praxedes, as Baronius writeth, and by S. Pius Epi≈øtle to S. Iu≈øtus Bishop of Vienna, Baron. Tom. 2. Annal. ann. 164. Martyrol. Rom. die 26. Iulij. Pius Pap. Epi≈øt. ad Iu≈øtum Epi≈øcop. Viennen. where he ≈øaith of S. Pa≈øtor, that S. Pa≈øtor hauing this Title or Church conferred on him, decea≈øed, presbiter Pa≈øtor titulum condidit, & dign√® in Domino obijt. And ≈øo pre≈øerued the hereditarie Right together with the Title and Church thereto S. Timothie the true heire and owner thereof, from his Aunce≈øtors, by lawfull and lineall di≈øcent.

div.head: THE X. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE LAST HOLY LABOVRS OF S. TImothie in Britaine, his honour with S. Denys the Areopagite, his returne from hence to Rome, and Martyrdome there, and Martyrdome of S. Pius Pope in the ≈øame place.

div.p:
1. I Left ≈øaint Timothie diligently labouring in Chri≈øts Harue≈øt in Britaine, and now I mu≈øt attend to doe him honour at his glorious death, and Martyrdome at Rome: but before we bring him hither, to take his heauenly rewarde for his ≈øufferings and trauailes there, we mu≈øt for the greater glory of him, S. Timothie his effectuall la≈øt labours in Britaine for the Conuer≈øion thereof. and our Nation by him, make ≈øome e≈øteeme how farre he profited, and preuailed in that imployment. We haue heard before, that by the paynes and preaching of him, and our Countryman ≈øaint Marcellus, both our King Lucius became a Chri≈øtian, and a great part of Britaine began to profe≈ø≈øe the faith of Chri≈øt: S. Lucius Britanniae Rex S. Timothei eruditione ad Religionem Chri≈øti inductus e≈øt. Britannia magnam ex parte fidem Chri≈øti profiteri caepit: And the per≈øeuering of ≈øaint Timothie ≈øo ≈øeriou≈øly and with ≈øuch intentiue feruour, that no thing could ≈øeparate him from that mo≈øt Heroicall Enterpri≈øe, not the death of his deare≈øt Si≈øter and Brother S. Pudentiana and Nouatus, nor ≈øo ample and Noble a Patrimonie now fallen vnto him, a≈ø≈øureth vs, if we had no other te≈øtimonie to adheare vnto, that he was now Father of many ≈øpirituall children, had many ≈øuch Brothers and Si≈øters, and by labouring long heare among the ≈øtones and Rocks of Britaine, had founde out and procured to this kingdome greater and more enduring Mines of Trea≈øure, then all ≈øaint Pudens and Claudia his parents, or ≈øaint Nouatus his Brother their wordly Riches could yeeld vnto him. I can hardly be drawne to other opinion, finding no rea≈øon to warrant mee, but his inflamed loue to the ≈øpirituall good, and happines of Britaine bounde and fixed him heare, with the chaines thereof vntill with vnexpre≈ø≈øible Ioy he did ≈øee and reape that fruite of his holy works (my Authours before haue told vs of) that by his meanes King Lucius
was induced to Chri≈øtian Religion, and a greate parte of Britaine profe≈ø≈øed it. And this was the occa≈øion of his returne from hence and going to Rome, hoping by that Iorney to be the happy Me≈ø≈øenger and In≈øtrument of relating His returne to Rome, and occa≈øioÃÑ thereof. and procuring that, which was re≈øerued for the honour of ≈øaint Eluanus, Meduuinus, Damianus, Fugatianus and their A≈ø≈øociats after, to ≈øee, and effect, the generall and publickly warranted, both by Pope and Prince, Conuer≈øion of this Britaine, now hindered for a time by a ≈øodden and new ray≈øed ≈øtorme of Per≈øecution vnder new Emperours. For allthough at the time of ≈øaint Timothie his beginning his Iorney from Britaine to Rome the Church of Chri≈øt was at ≈øome ea≈øe, and quiet, Antoninus Pius that friend to Chri≈øtians, yet continuing his Empire, or if Marcus Aurelius Antoninus the per≈øecuting Emperour had begun his Empire, yet he had not begun his Per≈øecution at that time, or the knowledge thereof had not yet trauailed ≈øo farre as Britaine, to giue warning and notice to King Lucius, of any ≈øuch thinge, eyther acted or intended. But when he, and his new Chri≈øtian people heare had for certaintie learned what barbarous and cruell Per≈øecutions were now in hand, as all Antiquities of that time doe witnes, and to be ≈øilent in others, that our Noble Brittish Chri≈øtian hou≈øe in Rome, which had continued ≈øo long quiet, and bene ≈øuch a Seminary of Religion for this kingdome, was now ≈øo cruelly afflicted, 23. renowned Martyrs tyrannically and without all tryall putt to death in the place and hou≈øe it≈øelfe, as I haue related, and ≈øaint Iu≈øtine and his ≈øacred company after that, carryed al≈øo from thence to durance and Martyrdome, and ≈øaint Timothie our Apo≈øtle Countryman and owner of that holy hou≈øe together with ≈øaint Marke his happy companion in Martyrdome, and likely in his Trauailes in Britaine, were taken from that place to Martyrdome, and Pope Pius al≈øo which much conuer≈øed there, and should haue bene a cheife meanes in directing and a≈ø≈øi≈øting our generall Conuer≈øion, if it had then taken effect putt to death by the≈øe Emperours for that cau≈øe.

2. The≈øe and ≈øuch cruelties euen again≈øt the Chri≈øtians of this kingdome by the≈øe per≈øecuting Emperours being now knowne in Britaine, there was no hope left of our generall Conuer≈øion to be compa≈ø≈øed at this time, ≈øo many principall Agents therein violently putt to death, and the Emperours, without who≈øe permi≈ø≈øion or conniuencie it could not probably be brought to pa≈ø≈øe, ≈øo enraged and cruell again≈øt vs, for ≈øuch things. Yet cannot this ≈øtay and adiourning of this greate≈øt publike good of this Nation be imputed to pu≈øillanimitie of minde, or want of Heroicall Chri≈øtian fortitude, and magnanimitie in our Chri≈øtian King, and diuers of his people and Nobles among them, who, as before, had receaued the Chri≈øtian faith, and priuately profe≈ø≈øed it, but to the Iniquitie of the violent and ouer≈øwaying times and Pagan Emperours with their Lieutenants, Imperiales, or Proimperatours, Procon≈øuls, Propretours hindering that holy worke. For allthough the ≈øtate of Britaine was not ≈øo ≈øeruile to the Romans as the condition of many kingdomes was but we euer had our owne Kings both by inheritance and di≈øcent of our former auncient Brittish regall Race, and with the de≈øired allowance and agreement of the Roman Emperours after the marriadge of King Aruiragus with Genui≈ø≈øa daughter of Claudius, and the greate≈øt dutie they could demande, was their Tribute: yet becau≈øe in a publike and authoritatiue change of Religion in a whole kingdome, there mu≈øt al≈øo be a change of ≈øuch lawes, and cu≈øtomes, as were contradicting and repugnant vnto the Religion to be receaued, this could not be done in ≈øuch per≈øecuting dayes without greate ielou≈øie
in the Per≈øecutours Emperours, of an vtter reuolt from them in all re≈øpects. And therefore our old Manu≈øcripts both of Nennius, and S. Gildas al≈øo, as they are commonly reputed, doe tell vs, that when our generall and publike Conuer≈øion was, there was al≈øo an Imperiall allowance, permi≈ø≈øion, or tolleration for it, from the Roman Emperours or their Lieutenants heare. Mi≈ø≈øa Nennius in M. S. Hi≈øt. Gildas in Hi≈øt. M. S. in publica Biblioth. Cantabr. & in Colleg. S. Benedicti. legatio ne ab Imperatore Romanorum: ≈øaith Nennius. Mi≈ø≈øa legatione ab Imperatoribus Romanorum: writeth Gildas in two Seuerall Manu≈øcripts, one in the publike Library of Cambridge, the other in ≈øaint Benets Colledge there. The rea≈øons hereof I shall deliuer in due place hereafter.

3. That which is wanting yet, and to be added to the honour of our Apo≈øtle and Countryman ≈øaint Timothie, is his glorious Martyrdome, ≈øo honoured of ≈øaint Pius the Pope then, and ≈øoone after al≈øo martyred, that writing to the renowned Bishop of Vienna not long vnmartyred, and exhorting him to con≈øtancy and per≈øeuerance in afflictions and Per≈øecution in Chri≈øt, propo≈øeth onely vnto him for the mo≈øt worthie examples this ≈øaint Timothie, and his holy companion at Martyrdome, and probably of his labours in Britaine ≈øaint Marke, ≈øaying they were Prei≈øts, brought vp by the Apo≈øtles, continuing vntill this time, with whome he had imparted the word of faith, men called of God and now liuing in euerla≈øting Ioyes in heauen. S. Timothie and Marke haue ended their cour≈øe by a good Combatt. O Brother remember thow imitate≈øt them S. Pius Epi≈øt. ad Iu≈øtum Vienn. Epi≈øcop. Tom. 1. Biblioth. Sanct. & apud Baron. Tom. 2. Annal. an. 166. in following them, and be not bound with the bands of the world: presbyteri illi, qui ab Apo≈øtolis educati v≈øque ad nos peruenerunt; cum quibus ≈øimul verbum fidei partiti ≈øumus, √† Domino vocati, in cubilibus aeternis clau≈øi tenentur. Sanctus Timotheus & Marcus per bonum certamen tran≈øierunt. Vide frater, vt illos imiteris ≈øequendo, ne vinculis mundi illigeris. This is that greate honour of Britaine, and Gods Church, whome ≈øaint Dioni≈øius the Areopagite, that wonderfull Diuine and His honor with S. Denis the Areopagite. glory of ≈øaint Paules Schollers honored ≈øo much, as euery Reader may ≈øee in his diuine Bookes, de diuinis nominibus & Eccle≈øia≈øtica Hierarchia, of diuine names & the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hierarchie, calling him mo≈øt holy, ≈øancti≈øsime, and the like, and dedicated them to him as the auncient Title, Compresbytero Timotheo Dioni≈øius Presbyter, Denys Prei≈øt to his fellow Prei≈øt, Timothie; and in his Baron. Tom. 2. Annal. an. 109. booke de diuinis nominibus citi ‚Ä¢ g an Epi≈øtle of ≈øaint Ignatius, written after the other ≈øaint Timothie Bishop of Ephe≈øus his death, doe witnes, Baronius and others ≈øo acknowledging: How before his death he di≈øpo≈øed his wordly Pius Pap. Epi≈øt. ad S. Iu≈øt. tom. 1. Bibliot. Sanct. & Baron. an. 166. wealth to the glory of Gods Church, and recommended the care of his Country Britaine to the mo≈øt glorious lights then of Chri≈øts Church ≈øaint Pius Pope and his worthie friends and familiars ≈øaint Soter and ≈øaint Eleutherus or Eleutherius after Popes, we may gather by his former loue and labours for this Nation. The Martyrdome of S. Timothy and S. Pius Pope. And ≈øo after ≈øo many yeares of mo≈øt holy life & trauailes for the Church of Chri≈øt, after his releeuing and maintenance of ≈øo many Saints, lodged, Manu ‚Ä¢ cr. Antiq. in Mona≈øt. S. Cirian. Martyrol. Rom. die 24. Martij. & Tabul. Ant. apud Baron. Tom. 2. ann. 162. Pius Pap. 1. Epi≈øt. ad S. Iu≈øtum. ≈øupr. 1. Epi≈øt. 2. ad eund. fedd, clothed, and fo≈øtered both with temporall and ≈øpirituall ≈øu≈øtenance, his chardges and proui≈øion in his holy hou≈øe, many of them al≈øo martyred there, he was al≈øo martyred with his worthie A≈ø≈øociate and fellow Prei≈øt ≈øaint Marke at Rome the 24. day of March an. 165. And ≈øaint Pius the Pope of Rome was martyred al≈øo ≈øoone after vnder the ≈øame per≈øecuting Emperours, his death at hand being reuealed vnto him as he writeth in an other Epi≈øtle to ≈øaint Iu≈øtus of Vienna in France, and Bishop there. Reuelatum mihi e≈ø≈øe ≈øcias, collega beati≈øsime, citius me finem huius vitae e≈ø≈øe facturum.

div.head: THE XI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE HOLY POPES NEXT SVCCEEDING S. Pius, and their Religion. The fauorable Edict of Marcus Aurelius Emperour for defence and protection of Chri≈øtians, and the Chri≈øtian Lieutenants Trebellius and Pertinax, with the forbidding the Druids Religion, occa≈øions of the publike receauing and profe≈øsion of Chri≈øtianitie in Britayne by King Lucius and his ≈øubiects.

div.p:
1. S. Pius hauing thus gloriou≈øly ended his holy life and Papacie, ≈øaint Anicetus by the more common opinion after many Auncients, Iraeneus, Tertullian, Hege≈øippus, Eu≈øebius, Epiphanius, with others teacheth that ≈øaint Anicetus ≈øucceeded him in this hihe≈øt chardge. Yet there be very auncient Hieron. l. de Scr. in Hege≈øippo. Optat. Mileu. l. contra. Parmen. Augu≈øt. Epi≈øt. 161. Rober Barnes l. de Vit. Pontif. Ro. in Aniceto. and worthie Authours as ≈øaint Hierome, Optatus, ≈øaint Augu≈øtine, with others which hold that ≈øaint Anicetus was Pope betweene ≈øaint Higinius and ≈øaint Pius. And an English Prote≈øtant writer though he followeth the fir≈øt and more common opinion for the Order of his Succe≈ø≈øion, next after ≈øaint Pius, yet ≈øaying of him that he was Pope in Antoninus Pius his Empire, ≈øub Antonino Pio vixit, he mu≈øt fall to the ≈øecond opinion by that I haue ≈øpoken before of the time of Antoninus Pius his Empire, and contradict him≈øelfe, as al≈øo he is ≈øingular when he ≈øaith of ≈øaint Anicetus, that he was Pope but two yeares, foure moneths, & three dayes, Annos 2. men≈øes 4. dies 3. others commonly tripling that time in his Papacie. Therefore to auoide all the lea≈øt inconuenience and exception, I will ioyne al≈øo in this place ≈øaint Soter in all opinions vndoubtedlie Pope immediately before ≈øaint Eleutherus or Eleutherius, and next to ≈øaint Anicetus by the more receaued, Dama≈øus Pont. in Sotere. Martin. Polon. Suppu. in Soter. and to ≈øaint Pius by the other, opinion. The ≈øpace of his Papacie is not agreed vpon, the liues of Popes a≈øcribed to Dama≈øus, a≈øcribeth to him nine yeares, ≈øeuen moneths, and 21. dayes. Martinus alloweth him ≈øo many yeares and dayes but detracteth foure moneths: Sedit annis nouem, men≈øibus tribus, Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 175. diebus viginti vno. The verie ≈øame hath Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter: Sedit in Cathedra Romana, annis 9. men≈øibus 3. & diebus 21. Baronius, and Binnius doe not afford him halfe ≈øo much time, ≈øaying he was not Pope fully and compleately foure yeares, but wanted twelue dayes of that terme: defunctus habetur Baron. Tom. 2. Annal. ann. 179. Seuerin. Binnius Tom. 1. Concil. in Sotere. Soter die 22. men≈øis Aprilis, cum ≈øedi≈ø≈øet annos quatuor, minus diebus duodecim. And a≈ø≈øigne the yeare of his death 199. from the Natiuitie of Chri≈øt, and 17. of the Empire of Marcus Aurelius, ≈øpoken of before, continuing Emperour vntill the third yeare of the next Pope ≈øaint Eleutherius: All which time and longer Lucius was ≈øtill King in Britaine. The≈øe two Popes as our Prote≈øtant
writers of their liues, are witne≈ø≈øes, were holy men and Martyrs. Saint Anicetus painefully gouerned the Roman Church in the holy mini≈øtery of the word, and in greate con≈øtancie in the Chri≈øtian faith, shedd his blood for Gods truth. Anicetus Romanae Eccle≈øiae in verbi ministerio ≈øacro laborios√® praefuit, & in magna Christianae fidei con≈øtantia pro Dei veritate ≈øanguinem po≈øtrem√≤ fudit. Io. Bal. l. 1. de Act. Pontif. Rom. in Aniceto.
