The like they te≈øtifie of ≈øaint Soter: In armis Spiritualibus Chri≈øto fideliter militauit: hoc vnum agens praecipu√®, vt animas per Bapti≈ømum Chri≈øto dicatas doctrina, & exemplo, illi ≈øuo ≈øpon≈øo ≈øaluandas adduceret: mortemque ≈øui corporis pro Christi ip≈øius testimonio pertulit. Thus we are ≈øecured that both their example and conuer≈øation of life, as al≈øo their doctrine and Religion, which they taught and profe≈ø≈øed, was holy.

2. What this was, ≈øome what in particular the≈øe men thus deliuer vnto vs. Robert. Barns l. de Vit. Pontif. Rom. in Anicet. Anicetus, decreed that if an Archbishop were accu≈øed by a Bishop, it should be done eyther before the Primate or Pope of Rome. He appointed that Archbishops should not be called Primats, but Metropolitans, except this prerogatiue of name was granted The Doctrine and Religion of S. Auicetus and Soter. to any by the Pope of Rome. He commanded that the crowne of Prei≈øts heads should be shaued round: Anicetus Archiepi≈øcopum √† ≈øuo Epi≈øcopo, aut coram Primate, aut Romano Pontifice accu≈øandum e≈ø≈øe ≈øtatuit. Archiepi≈øcopos non Primates, ≈øed Metropolitanos appellandos e≈ø≈øe dixit, ni≈øi i≈øta praerogatiua Nomenclaturae ei √† Romano Pontifice concederetur. Capitis verticem ≈øpherulae instar radendum ≈øacerdotibus praecepit. Soter appointed again≈øt that errour of the Gno≈øtiks, that a Robert. Barns. ≈øupr. in Sotere. Nunne should not handle the Pall, nor put incen≈øe into the Cen≈øor: and ordained that a Prei≈øt Should not ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe except two at the lea≈øt were pre≈øent: Ne Monacha Pallam contrectaret, neue Thus in Acerram poneret, ≈øtatuit. N ‚Ä¢ ≈øacerdos celebraret, ni≈øi vt minimum duo ade≈ø≈øent ordinauit. In the≈øe times the per≈øecuting Emperours ≈øtill reigning, and Per≈øecution raging, not onely in the Ea≈øterne parts, but in Italy, France, and Countryes in the continent neare vnto vs. This our Iland as an other world, was allmo≈øt quite free thereof both now before, and Gildas l. de Excid. & conq. Brit. c. 7. after vntill the generall Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian, as ≈øaint Gildas and others after him doe witnes: v≈øque ad per≈øecutionem Diocletiani Tyranni nouennem, both in re≈øpect of the ≈øcituation, remote di≈øtance and ≈øeparation from the cheife Brittish Kings euer fauourers & friends of Chri≈øtians, drewe many per≈øecuted Chri≈øtians hither. commanding place of the Empire, and that it euer had Kings not ≈øo depending of the per≈øecuting Emperours, and ≈øo farre from the name and nature of Per≈øecutours, that they euer were friends, and fauourers of Chri≈øtians, and now the King and many both of his Nobilitie and other ≈øubiects had receaued Chri≈øtian Religion. This, as our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries and others haue told vs of like former times, drewe many worthie and learned Chri≈øtians among others hither, where for them≈øelues they might more quietly enioy the libertie of their con≈øcience and Religion, and for others de≈øirous to be in≈øtructed in the truth thereof, and not kept back with ≈øuch terrours of Per≈øecution as in other Countryes, they might with more confidence and boldnes, and with greate hope of fruite, and increa≈øe, preach and teach it vnto them. And ≈øo this Per≈øecution in other Nations, not ≈øayling ouer it≈øelfe but ≈øending Apo≈øtolike men vnto vs eyther to conuert, or by their holy doctrine, conuer≈øation, and miracles which they wrought, at the lea≈øt ≈øo to di≈øpo≈øe the minds and wills of many men in all degrees, that it made our generall Conuer≈øion now at hand, more ea≈øie to be ≈øo ≈øpeedely and vniuer≈øally performed.

3. That ≈øuch was the ≈øtate of Britaine for ≈øpirituall affaires in this Idolatry and ≈øuper≈øtition, daily diminishing and decaying, and Chri≈øtiaÃÑ Religion in all places and per≈øons encrea≈øing, and multiplying both Authoritie, and the
knowne certaine effect it ≈øelfe, the ≈øure≈øt te≈øtimonie in ≈øuch ca≈øes shall witnes heareafter. And this was the condition thereof, vntill about the beginning of the Papacie of S. Soter, or the end of the fir≈øt yeare thereof about the yeare of our Redemption 175. when as it appeareth by the Edict of Marcus Aurelius Emperour before the ≈øtrange deliuery of him and his Army by the Chri≈øtians Literae Marci Aurelij Anton. ad Senatum. in fine operum S. Iu≈øtini. Baron. To. 2. Annal. an. 176. Mat. We≈øt. an. gratiae 174. Tertull. Apol. c. 5. Eu≈øeb. l. 5. c. 5. Oro≈ø. l. 7. c. 15. Florent. Wigor. Chronic. an. 161. vel 184. miraculous prayers, he ≈øuffered many Chri≈øtians to liue in quiet, and had a great number of them about him, inuenique magnam eorum multitudinem. And ≈øeeing him≈øelfe and his Army in di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, ≈øent for them and entreated them to pray for his deliuery: eos qui apud nos Chri≈øtiani dicuntur, accer≈øiui, ac rogaui. Which he would not haue done, being a wi≈øe and learned Emperour, but that either by the Apologie of Athenagoras, the vertues and Miracles of many Chri≈øtians, or ≈øome other inuincible ArgumeÃÑt, his Iudgment was then wholly or allmo≈øt conuicted that their Religion was holy and they al≈øo, and thereby likely to be powerable with God to procure his ≈øafety, which his owne prayers & Sacrifices to his Pagan Gods were not able to doe, Deos Patrios votis ≈øu≈øceptis rogaui, ≈øed cum ab eis negligerer, As he him≈øelfe publikly proprofe≈ø≈øed, and therefore preferring the prayers of the Chri≈øtians, appealed vnto them. But after God by the prayers of the Chri≈øtians which he procured them to make, had ≈øo Miraculou≈øly deliuered him and his Army con≈øi≈øting but of foure Legions, not 27. thou≈øand men, enuironed allmo≈øt with a thow≈øand thow≈øands of Enemies, as the common reading is, ho≈øtium Nongentorum & ≈øeptuaginta ≈øeptem millia, and his people di≈øtre≈ø≈øed with thri≈øt and hunger, not hauing drunke in fiue dayes, by ≈øending a mo≈øt cooling and comforting Raine in the Campe of the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Emperour, and Haile like fier, and lightnings among his Enemyes confounding and di≈øcomfiting them, he pre≈øently ≈øent out his Imperiall letters and Edict, chardging the Senate of Rome, to confirme them with their Decree, wherein wholly a≈ø≈øcribing this deliuery of his Army and him≈øelfe, and confu≈øion of his Enemyes to the God of the Chri≈øtians, & their prayers vnto him, wherein he gaue free libertie for any man to be a Chri≈øtian: concedamus talibus, vt ≈øint Chri≈øtiani: and no man should be mole≈øted for being a Chri≈øtian: cen≈øeo neminem, quod Chri≈øtianus ≈øit, e≈ø≈øe in crimen & in Iudicium vocandum; And he that should accu≈øe a Chri≈øtian for his Religion should be burned aliue, and he that shall profe≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe to be a Chri≈øtian, shall be freed from all danger intended again≈øt him for that cau≈øe; And no gouernor of any Prouince shall punish any ≈øuch for his Religion, or depriue him of libertie. Volo eum qui Chri≈øtianum accu≈øauit, viuum exuri: Illum vero qui Chri≈øtianum ≈øe e≈ø≈øe profe≈ø≈øus fuerit, periculo omni, quod ob eam rem ei intendebatur, liberatum. Is cui Prouincia commi≈ø≈øa est, nequaquam ad paenitentiam adigat, aut libertatem ei adimat. And he willed the≈øe things to be confirmed by the Senats Decree, and this his Edict to be propo≈øed in the open Marcet place, to be read; And that the Prefect of the Citie then Vetra≈øius Pollio should cau≈øe it to be ≈øent to all Prouinces, and no man should be forbidden to write it out. Haec autem Senatus con≈øulto etiam ≈øanciri volo, atque hoc meum Edictum in Foro diui Traiani proponi, vt legi po≈øsit. Curae autem erit Vetra≈øio Pollioni, Praefecto vrbi, vt ad omnes Prouincias haec con≈øtitutio mittatur: neque qui≈øquam qui eam ex≈øcribere, vel ip≈øe vti voluerit, prohibeatur. This was ≈øent to the whole Senate and people of Rome, Senatui populoque Romano, and by the Emperours publike chardge, and command, as into other Prouinces, ≈øo likewi≈øe ≈øent it into Britaine for the priuiledge of all Chri≈øtiaÃÑs heare, by the Emperours publike Officer in ≈øuch affaires the Ruler of the City of Rome, ad omnes Prouincias
haec con≈øtitutio mittatur. Any man that would, might freely be a Chri≈øtian, and no man vnder paine of cruell death to be burnt aliue, might call any into que≈øtion for that cau≈øe. And to giue greater te≈øtimony of the≈øe things in Britaine, and ≈øee this Imperiall Edict for the freedome of Chri≈øtians heare take place and effect, where as our English Antiquaries & others tell vs, that Trebellius and Pertinax the Roman Lieutenants heare about this time were Chri≈øtians, our Countriman Florentius Wigornien≈øis plainely affirmeth, that Florent. Wigor. chron. an. 159. 181 Pertinax was a cheife commander in the Emperours Army, when this Miraculous Victory was by the Chri≈øtians prayers, and this Edict writen and decreed by the Emperour for their freedome and libertie, and probably was then conuerted to the Chri≈øtian faith by this Miracle. Pertinaci, & exercitui qui cum eo in Quadorum Regione pugnabat, ≈øiti oppre≈øsis, pluuia diuinitus mi≈ø≈øa e≈øt, cum √® contrario Germanos & Sarmatas fulmi na per≈øequerentur, & plurimos eorum interficerent. And the Emperour him≈øelfe who in his publike cited Edict, doth ≈øay of Chri≈øtians, that in equitie he mu≈øt thinke them now to be defended by God, whome before he accompted for wicked men, and alienated from God, mu≈øt needs be a Chri≈øtian in con≈øcience and Iudgment. Equum e≈øt, vt, quos impios e≈ø≈øe, & √† Deo alienos opinabamur, eos exi≈øtimemus Deo munitos e≈ø≈øe. And he mo≈øt needs at lea≈øt internally beleeue in that true God, whome he ≈øaid the Chri≈øtians did beare in their con≈øcience, Deum in con≈øcientia ge≈øtant. And in no wi≈øe a learned Emperour or other would or could in Iudgment, rea≈øon, equitie, and con≈øcience make a lawe to condemne men to ≈øo cruell death as burning aliue, which he inflicted vpon the accu≈øers of Chri≈øtians, except he knew or probably thought their accu≈øation was vniu≈øt, and the cau≈øe of the accu≈øed Chri≈øtians lawfull, iu≈øt, and holy.

4. Wherevpon it came to pa≈ø≈øe that very many, both pre≈øent at this Miracle and the Emperours change vpon it, or hearing it by ≈øo vndoubted Relation as the Emperours publike and ≈øeuere Edict for the quiet of Chri≈øtians, began then to loue and embrace their Religion, ≈øo plea≈øing and powerable with God, and honored by men of greate≈øt commande and iudgment. And Marci Aurelij Edict. ≈øupr. this Imperiall Edict and Relation of the≈øe things by publike Authoritie, and warrant, both of the Emperour and the Con≈øuls of Rome, was with all expedition ≈øent, proclaimed and diuulged heare in Britaine, as in other Prouinces, to King Lucius and the Lieutenants for the Emperour heare, as his precept was. And this I take to be that Amba≈ø≈øadge or Me≈ø≈øadge which S. Gildas and Nennius before haue ≈øpoken of, ≈øent from the Roman Emperour, or Emperours, as the diuers readings haue, mi≈ø≈øa Legatione ab Imperatore Romanorum, or, ab Imperatoribus Romanorum, to exhort or warrant king Lucius to profe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øtian Religion. For how≈øoeuer we will vnder≈øtand the≈øe words Emperour or Emperours of the Romans, whether for the cheife Emperour, or his Sub≈øtituts ≈øo ≈øometime named by S. Gildas, ≈øo it was coÃÑcerning the high Emperour, his Edict publikly proclaimed and diuulged in all Prouinces, was come to King Lucius ‚Ä¢ is knowledge, ≈øo that he mu≈øt needs take notice thereof by that meanes. And if we will take the phra≈øe of ≈øpeach, Imperatores RomanoruÃÑ the Emperous of the Romans, as S. Gildas before in Claudius ≈øeemeth to v≈øe it, Gild. Hi≈øtor. in Claudio. when he ≈øaith: in Tempore Claudij quieuit dari cen≈øus Romanis √† Britannia: ≈øed Britannicis Imperatoribus traditur. Tribute cea≈øed to be giuen to the Romans from Britaine in the time of Claudius: but it is deliuered to the Brittish Emperours, which the Roman true Emperours ≈øeeme to haue deputed, as the Roman Con≈øuls had their Procon≈øules, and Pretors, Propretors, and Kings
now haue their Proreges, Viceroyes in remote Kingdomes ≈øubiect to them, ≈øupplying their place and power. And in this ≈øence al≈øo King Lucius had both Martyrol. Ant. apud Baton. To. 1. Annal. an. 183. Holinshed. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 19. ‚Ä¢ o≈øcelin. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. Ang. in Lucio. Matth. Parker. Antiq. Brit. p. 4. Galfri. Monum. l. 4. c. 19. Virun. l. 4. Harris Theatr. l. 2. cap. 18. Hect. Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øtor. l. 5. f. 85. Io. Go≈øcelin. ≈øupr. c. de Rel. Lucij. Matth. Parker. Antiquit. Brit. p. 4. notice and warrant giuen vnto him of the≈øe proceedings by the Emperours or Lieutenants of the RomaÃÑs in Britaine, as all Antiquaries giue te≈øtimonie herein, our Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians thus write of this matter: King Lucius perceaued not onely ≈øome of the Roman Lieutenants in Britaine, as Trebellius and Pertinax, with others to haue ≈øubmitted them≈øelues to the Chri≈øtian profe≈øsion, but al≈øo the Emperour him≈øelfe to begin to be fauourable to them that profe≈ø≈øed it. An other ≈øaith of King Lucius; comperit ex Legatis Cae≈øaris Praepotentes at
que Illu≈øtres quo≈ødam ex Romanis Trebellium nempe ac Pertinacem, alio≈øque noÃÑnullos Chri≈øtianae Religioni acce≈ø≈øi≈ø≈øe: immo etiam ip≈øum Imperatorem aequum factum: King Lucius was a≈ø≈øured by the Legats of the Emperour, that very potent and renowned meÃÑ of the Romans, as Trebellius and Pertinax and others had embraced the Christian Religion; and the Emperour him≈øelfe was become indifferent herein. The like haue Catholike writers of this bu≈øines. And ≈øome Prote≈øtants haue published that the Roman Emperours had forbidden all v≈øe, and profe≈ø≈øion of the Druyds Religion in their Prouinces: Edicto cautum Romanorum fuit, ne v≈øus aut exi≈øtimatio in Prouincijs ≈øuis Religioni Druidum vlla adhiberetur. An other writeth that the Emperour Marcus Aurelius Antoninus, who had ≈øet out the fauourable Edict for Chri≈øtians, had ≈øet out an other vtterly to abandon the Druids Religion, which had reigned ≈øo longe with honor in Britaine, where the cheife≈øt profe≈ø≈øors and Mai≈øters thereof remained, & that King Lucius was at this time greate in fauour, and familiaritie with this Emperour. Erat eodem tempore Lucius & Romanorum fautor, & Marco Antonio vero Cae≈øari ≈øumma bene volentia, ac familiaritate coniunctus cuius Authoritate & Decreto, cum profliganda e≈ø≈øet tantae Authoritatis Religio (Druydum) quae omnium memoriam ≈øuperabat. Thus write the≈øe Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians, but neither bringing Authoritie, or rea≈øon that the Roman Emperours had made any ≈øuch Edict, particularly again≈øt the practi≈øe of the Druyds Religion in Britaine. I dare not follow them therein. For there was greate difference betweene the gouerment of Britaine, Prouincia Regia, gouerned by our owne King onely Tributary to the Romans, and other Countries, as France Gallia where the Druyds al≈øo ruled, immediately ≈øubiect to the Romans, Iure belli, by Title of CoÃÑque≈øt, which they neuer had ouer Britaine, and ≈øo by their owne conditions of peace could not claime any ≈øuch Prerogatiue heare to binde the Britans, but onely their Romans and Ciues, heare, to what Religion they plea≈øed to pre≈øcribe.

5. And therefore their owne writers as Suetonius Tranquillus and our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries al≈øo, knowing how offen≈øiue the Druids which ruled both in matters of warre and peace, and their Religion, were vnto the Roman C. Suetonius Tranquillus in Claud. Plinius l. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . cap. 1. Io. Selden Analect. c. 5. p. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . ‚Ä¢ 8. Au
‚Ä¢ elius V ‚Ä¢ ctor Hi≈øt. abbreuiat. part. 2. an. ab vrbe condit. 794. cap. 4. Opimer. Chronograph. in Tyberio. Theater of great B ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t. l. 6. Conque≈øts and proceedings, and how de≈øirous tho≈øe Emperours therefore were to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe them, doe tell vs, that before they were ≈øuch Conquerours in tho≈øe parts where the Druids ruled, Augu≈øtus did forbid all Citizens of Rome, and tho≈øe would enioy the Immunities of being ≈øuch, to profe≈ø≈øe the Druids Religion: Druidarum Religio tantum ciuibus ≈øub Augu≈øto Interdicta. And after they had made them≈øelues Mai≈øters of Gallia, Claudius did quite abolish it from thence what he could. And Aurelius Victor writing after this time, and of ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing the Druids by the Roman Emperours, extendeth this ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion no further then Gallia, now France: compre≈ø≈øae per Galliam Druidarum famo≈øae ≈øuper≈øtitiones. Which Suetonius had written of Claudius before. Druidarum Religionem apud Gallos dirae immanitatis, & tantum ciuibus ≈øub Augu≈øto
interdictam, penitus aboleuit. So doth Aurelius Victor and Opimerus of Tyberius, shewing one rea≈øon among others, becau≈øe when they tooke any of the Romans Pri≈øoners they killed, and offered them in Sacrifice to their Idols: cum Gallias po≈øsideret ea immanitas, vt Druides illorum homines immolarent, Tyberij Cornelius Tacitus H ‚Ä¢ ≈øt. l. 14. in Vit. Iulij Agricolae. Ponticus Virun. l. 4. Pol ‚Ä¢ dor. Virgil. Angl. Hi≈øtor. lib. 1. pag. 11. Stowe Hi≈øtor. in Suetonius Paulin. Holinsh. Hi≈øtor. of Engl. l. 4. c. 9. Hect. Boeth. Scotor. Hi≈øt. l. 3. fol. 55. & 23. Iul. Cae≈øar. CommeÃÑt. l. 6. Robert. Caenal. Tom. 1. Gallic. Hi≈øt. Perioch. 3. Diodorus Siculus rerum ant. l. 5. Io. Xiphi ‚Ä¢ in. in Epitom. Dionis. in Nerone. Iulius Cae≈øar Commentar. l. 6. Boeth. Theat. of Brit. ≈øupr. Matth. Parker. Antiquit. Brit. p. 4. Cae≈øaris principatus ≈øu≈øtulit Druidas. Of which their ≈øacrificing of Romans in Britaine, both the Roman and our owne Hi≈øtorians are witne≈ø≈øes; iu≈øtely calling them cruell ≈øuper≈øtitions: In quibus In≈øulani cruore captiuo adolere aras, & hominum fibris con≈øulere Deos fas habebant. And, Sacerdotes infando ritu humanis mactatis ho≈øtijs, Deos con≈øulebant. And the Druids were euer pre≈øent at the≈øe cur≈øed, cruell and mo≈øt Inhuman Sacrifices: horum erat publicis ≈øacrificijs intere≈ø≈øe. For example our Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians, with others, thus write of Bunduica, directed by the Druids, when she had ≈øtayne 80000. Romans: she exerci≈øed all kinde of crueltie one ≈øuch men as she tooke. As for the Noble women that she gate, she hanged them vp, and cut of their pappes, & ≈øewed them to their mouthes: be≈øides this, she ≈øtretching their bodies out at leÃÑgth, thru≈øt sharpe ≈øtakes cleane through them: all which things were done in despight, when they ≈øacrificed, and feasted in their Temples. And what≈øoeuer cruelties, outrages, reuolts, tumults, or ≈øeditions, as the Romans termed or interpreted not concurring with them by the Britans, the Druids hauing power with ≈øeuere≈øt punishments to Order and direct all things, all the≈øe were by the Romans a≈øcribed, and imputed vnto them.

6. Therefore of all people in Britaine the≈øe Druids were, and mu≈øt needs be mo≈øt odious to the Romans; and their Religion which allowed and practi≈øed ≈øuch Barbarous, cruell, and execrable deui≈øes, & was ≈øo hatefull vnto them, that as our Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians write this Emperour by his Imperiall Authoritie, and decree had forbidden the Druids Religion in Britaine: Marci Antonij Veri authoritate & decreto profliganda e≈ø≈øet Religio quae omnium memoriam ≈øuperabat. In which opinion there was now no eua≈øion to be founde out, but the Druids ≈øuper≈øtition mu≈øt pre≈øently be abandoned in Britaine. And not to build too much vpon the≈øe mens words, mo≈øt euideÃÑt it is, that although the Roman Emperours had not published any Edict, for the abolishing the Religion of the Druids in Britaine, nor without the allowance and approbation of the King of Britaine, could by the agreed conditions betweene them, ≈øo farre intermedle to make any generall lawe to binde all the Druids, or any other kinde of people in this kingdome: Yet now both our King Lucius con≈øenting, and ≈øeeking it, and the Roman Emperours ≈øo long de≈øiring it, and farre preferring Chri≈øtian Religion before that which they profe≈ø≈øed, the way is laid wide open, and ready prepared for a common for≈øaking of the Druids ≈øuper≈øtition, and embracing the ≈øacred Religion of Chri≈øt in this Nation. For allthough we yeeld to them which hold King Lucius did not Rule in all Britaine on this ≈øide the wall or Trench of Adrian, yet mo≈øt certaine in Hi≈øtories it is, that he and the Roman Emperours together po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed it all. And the≈øe Emperours and their Lieut ‚Ä¢ nants had publikely, as before, giuen warrant for any man to be a Chri≈øtian in all their Territories, and Anton. Sabelicus Eunead. 7. libr. 2. Hector Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. l. 3. f. 55 Ho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nsh. H ‚Ä¢ ≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. cap. 9. Theater of great Britaine l. 6. they de≈øired nothing more, then the Druids vtter de≈øtruction, and extirpation, and P. Suetonius not long before Lieutenant heare for the Romans had begun it when in the I≈øle of Angle≈øey, which was the re≈øident place of the mo≈øt learned and commanding Druids both for Britaine and Gallia he had v ‚Ä¢
terly de≈øtroyed them, their execrable places of Sacrifice, and ≈øca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ely left there any memory of them. By which proceedings the cheife≈øt difficulties of the
Conuer≈øion of Britaine e≈øpecially in temporall re≈øpects were now ouercome. And for ≈øpirituall further helps be≈øides ≈øo many holy and Apo≈øtolike men preaching heare then among the Britans, of whome I haue made memorie before, we finde that many among the Romans heare at that time were Chri≈øtians, and ≈øo had their ≈øpirituall guides to direct them; and which al≈øo gaue In≈øtructions to King Lucius and his Britans. Lucius Britanniae Rex de Chri≈øtianorum Hector Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. l. 5. f. 55 pietate & miraculis √† Romanis in Britannia ≈øub Trebellio & Pertinace merentibus permulta audiuit. And we are further a≈ø≈øured by forreyne Hi≈øtories, that in the time of this Pope S. Sote ‚Ä¢ and Emperour about the yeare of Chri≈øt 174. Anno & quod excurrit 174. Pontifice Maximo Sotere: diuers Bishops were Arnold. Merm. Theatro conu. gent. & alij apud eund. ib. ≈øent into the≈øe parts, which the≈øe Antiquaries bring on their Iorney hitherwards as farre as Callice, Morinis, naming diuers of them, as S. Fu≈øcianus, Victoricus, Piato and their companions: Anti≈øtitibus S. Fu≈øciano, Victorico, Piatone, alij≈øque ≈øocijs. And to put vs in minde of their coming hither, they tell vs, they had there the shorte≈øt pa≈ø≈øadge into Britaine, & they bring auncient witne≈ø≈øes thereof. Vnde breui≈øsimus in Britanniam, nunc Angliam, e≈øt Traiectus, vti Tacitus, & Iulius Cae≈øar meminere.

div.head: THE XII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: HOW THE RELIGION OF THE DRVIDES in Britaine made ≈øome hinderance for the generall receauing of the lawe of Chri≈øt; But conuicted to be abominable Idolatrie, and Super≈øtition, the Profe≈ø≈øors of it generally embraced the faith of Chri≈øt, detesting their former Infidelities and Impieties.

div.p:
1. WHEN matters were thus farre proceeded for the generall receauing of Chri≈øtian Religion in Britaine, the King and his Nobles ≈øeeking it, the Roman Emperours and Lieutenants giuing con≈øent there vnto, and many holy Apo≈øtolike Bishops and Prei≈øts now heare both among the Britans, and Romans which vrged it, and offered them≈øelues dayly to maintaine and proue that to be the onely true and lawfull ≈øeruing of God, and way to eternall happines, and ≈øaluation after this life: And that profe≈ø≈øion of the Druids which the Britans heare before this time, as al≈øo the Inhabitants of Gallia, and a greate part of Germany, had many hundreds of yeares followed, and practi≈øed, was impious, fal≈øe, Idolatrous, damnable and diabolicall, many of the cheife Doctors and teachers thereof were much troubled and perplexed hereat, and in teÃÑporall re≈øpects not without cau≈øe. For if a for≈øaking of their Rites and Ceremonies should generally and with publike warrant, and regall Authoritie, en≈øue, their temporall honours, dignities, reuenewes, Immunities and priuiledges graunted vnto them onely in regard of their teaching, and maintaining that their Profe≈ø≈øion, would not onely be taken from them, but in all Iudgment be conferred and be≈øtowed, (as they after were) vpon the Chri≈øtian Bishops and Cleargie to
≈øucceed, profe≈ø≈øed enemyes of their callings. Heare vpon to giue a quiet and peaceable Introduction to the holy Lawe of Chri≈øt, which alone yeeldeth all true peace, and quietnes to the ≈øoules of men in earth and heauen, and not to bring it in with the onely temporall ≈øwaye or power of the King of Britaine and Roman Emperours, as the cu≈øtome of Mahumetans and ≈øome others is, which haue no thing but ≈øword, penall Edicts, and Per≈øecution, to vent and ≈øupporte their ba≈øtardly Religions withall, diuers conflicts and di≈øputations were had in this kingdome betweene our Chri≈øtian Apo≈øtolike men, and the be≈øt learned of the Druids Lawe. The≈øe vrged many rea≈øons and popular, for their manner and cu≈øtome of worship, yet pre≈øerued in Hi≈øtories. They had to pleade for them≈øelues, that not onely Britaine and Brittish IlaÃÑds many in number, but France, and greate parts of Germany ioyned with them in Religion: And in their worshiping for Gods, Iupiter, Apollo, Mars, Mercury, Audate, Berecynthia and ≈øome others, mo≈øt of the gentiles con≈øpired with them. Their Religion and them≈øelues by that name had continued, and florished in the world from the time of Druius that greate King and high Prei≈øt, Druius Germanorum Pontifex. Who reduced the gentils Religion into Henric. Pantal. l. de Vir. Illu≈øtrib. Germ. part. 1. p. 40. 41. Selden Analect. Anglobr. l. 1. c. 1. c. 4. Bero≈øus. Nichol. Vignier. Biblioth. Hi≈øt. An. mundi 2200. Hi≈øt. aggregatiue des Annales fol. 3. Bernard. Giunti Cron. in Driius. Ioa. Fri≈øius Biblioth. Philo≈ø. Anno mundi 2070. Ante Chri≈øtum 1892. Io. Bal. l. de Scriptor. centur. 1. in Samothe. Camd. Brit. p. 12. Plini. l. 12. cap. 1. Lud. Caelius. l. 7. c. 1. Tacit. lib. de morib. & popul. German. Andr. Altham. in ≈øchol. in Cornel. Tacit. ≈øupr. I ‚Ä¢ l. Cae≈øar lib. 6. Belli Gallic. Hector. Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. l. 2. f. 22. 23. this order, founded them a Colledge & gaue them their denomination about the yeare of the worlds Creation 2900. Druius ille apud Germanorum Celtas, vir magnae Authoritatis gentilitiam Religionom in ordinem redegit, at
que Druidarum Collegium Religionis ergo in≈øtituit, a quo etiam Druides apud Gallos & Germanos dicti. And the Towne in Normandy, called Dreux, was al≈øo ≈øo named from him, as their Hi≈øtories ≈øay, and the Ryuer Druentia running therby. What was the certaine time of their beginning is not ≈øo certaine. Pantaleon before ≈øaith, it was in the yeare of the world 2900. Ioannes Fri≈øius ≈øaith, in the yeare thereof 2070. and 1892. yeares before Chri≈øt. Bernado Giunti will haue it in the 420. yeare after the flood of Noe. Nicholas Vignier a≈ø≈øcribeth the Reigne of King Dryus or Driuus to the yeare of the world 2200. Therefore I cannot be of the≈øe late writers minde, which ≈øay, they were called Druides of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ an Oke in Greeke, becau≈øe they were ≈øome times vnder Okes in the woods. For ≈øo we might call all old Idolaters Druids, for the Scripturs witne≈ø≈øe, they ≈øacrificed in Groues and Woods, ≈øo doth Pliny, Lud. Caelius and others Lucos, & nemora con≈øecrant. And the Greeke writers, as Eutropius, Dio, Herodian, Zo≈øimus and the re≈øt are ≈øilent of this Sect, as the Latins al≈øo, but when they ≈øpeake of Britaine, France and ≈øome parts of Germany where onely, and no where els this Religion reigned. And Iulius Cae≈øar is plaine, there were no Druids in Germany, but they differed much from the Gaules in Religion. Germani multum √† Gallorum con≈øuetudine differunt. Nam neque Druides habent, qui rebus diuinis prae≈øunt. And the Scottish Hi≈øtorians ≈øay, the auncient name of the≈øe men in the languadge heare, was Durcerglijs, and they were Romans which ≈øpake not Greeke which gaue them fir≈øt the name Druides of Druius, to make the ≈øtrange name to take Latyne declen≈øion: hos Romani Scriptores Druides vt peregrinum vocabulum inflexionem caperet Latinam, appellant. And heare were no Greeks in the≈øe parts to giue them a Greeke name, neither did their Sect come neare a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ art of Greece, at any time, and how≈øoeuer we will pronounce the Greeke word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ an Oke, drys or drus, we should by deriuing them from thence, call then Dri≈ø≈øets, or Dru≈ø≈øets, as of Cus, and Hus, we call Cu≈øsits, and Hu≈øsits, and not Druidae, or Druids: But for their Antiquitie they might truely make it of ≈øo greate continuance.

2. Neyther was their honour and glory in Britaine, and where els they
liued, of a lower degree. Ve≈øtitus corum valde pretiou≈øus, atque ornatus in≈øignis. Henricus PaÃÑtal. l. de Vir. Illu≈øtr: Germ. part. 1. p. 40. 41. Nam collo torques, manibus annuli, lacertis Armillae addebantur. Vestes erant tinctae, & auro pictae: Their apparell was very precious, and attire ≈øingular. For they wore chaynes of gold about their necks; Rings one their hands, and bracelets one their Armes. Their garments were dyed, and embrodered with gold. And their habitations and dwelling places were no le≈ø≈øe ≈øtately, the cheife≈øts of them ≈øeated Antiquit. Eccle≈ø. Landau. Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. c. 4. Gildas l. de excid. & coÃÑq. Brit. Galfr. monum. Hi≈øt. l. 4. c. 19. Pont. Virun. libr. 4. Dicetus Hi≈øt. M. S. ann. 178. Matt. We≈øt. Hi≈øt. an. 185. 186. Martin. Polon. Supput. in Eleutherio. Robert. Barnesin Vit. Pontif. Rom. in Eleuther. Matth. Parker Antiq. Brit. Godwin. Conuer≈ø. of Britaine. Stow. Hi≈øt. in King Lucius. an. 179. Polid. Virgil. Hi≈øt. l. 2. Hector. Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. l. 2. f. 23 Theater of great Brit. l. 6. Selden Analect. Mich. Dract. Polyolb. Io. Hard. Chron. c. 51. Ammianus Marcellin. l. 15. in CoÃÑ ≈øtantio. Iulius Ce≈øar Belli Gallici. l. 6. Lucan. l. 1. in the cheife Cities of Britaine, and their Man≈øions conuerted afterward to be Archbishops, and Bishops Pallaces, ≈øometimes they re≈øorted to woods as all auncient Witches, Magicians, and Idolaters did, to exerci≈øe their Sorceries, and offer their Sacrifices, e≈øpecially to ≈øuch Oakes, as bore Mi≈ø≈øeltoe, naturallie medicinable for diuers infirmities, and therefore to the rude people they a≈øcribed a certaine Diuinitie to ≈øuch Trees. Their hou≈øes, as them≈øelues al≈øo had exemptions from all ≈øeruices, exactions, and trobles. They were cheife Iudges in all matters both ≈øpirituall and Temporall, hauing all men obedient to their Order, ≈øentence and determination vnder the greate≈øt penaltie of abandoning, and exilement from the Societie of men, and ≈øuch like, and death it≈øelfe at their plea≈øures, de≈øigning whome they li≈øted to be cruelly ≈øacrificed to their Deuils, and Idols, whome they termed Gods. The cheife≈øt of them had for a ≈øingular ≈øigne of honour fier borne before him. Ante quem ignis dignitatis, honorisque in≈øigne deferretur. Ammianus Marcellinus ≈øpeaking of the≈øe men, giueth this prai≈øe vnto them, that they were of great wits, and liued in companies or Colledges, according as Pythagoras ordayned, they were lifted vp with que≈øtions of hiddeÃÑ and high things, and de≈øpi≈øing human matters, pronounced that mens ≈øoules were Immortall. Druidae ingenijs cel≈øiores, vt authoritas Pitagorae decreuit, ≈øodalitijs a≈øtricti con≈øortijs quae≈øtionibus occultarum rerum altarumque erecti ≈øunt: & de≈øpectantes humana, pronuntiarunt animas immortales. Which opinion of theirs of the ≈øoules immortalitie Iulius Cae≈øar with diuers others al≈øo confirmeth, but in a lewde ≈øence of Tran≈ømigration of going from one body to an other. Hoc volunt per≈øuadere, non interire animas, ≈øed ab alijs post mortem tran≈øire ad alios. And if any man was dangerou≈øly ≈øike, in warre or perill, & would offer Sacrifice, or vowe to offer it, they v≈øed the Druids as Mini≈øters to offer it. Qui ≈øunt affecti grauioribus morbis, qui
que in praelijs periculisque ver≈øantur, aut pro victimis homines immolant, aut ≈øe immolaturos vouent, admini≈øtrisque ad ea ≈øacrificia Druidibus vtuntur. Diodorus Siculus who liued in the ≈øame time with Iulius Cae≈øar giueth his rea≈øon, that the Druids were thus v≈øed for Prei≈øts in all the Sacrifices of the Gaules and Britans, much to their honour in their opinion which were ruled by the Druids: becau≈øe they hold that Sacrifices should be offered by them, which be acquainted with the diuine Nature, and are skillfull of the languadge of the Gods: and they thinke that by the≈øe mens interce≈ø≈øion good things should be Diodor. Sicul. l. 5. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ um antiq. asked of the Gods, by who≈øe coun≈øaile they enioy peace and warre. E≈øt apud cos moris, nullum ab≈øque Philo≈øopho Sacrificium facere. Exi≈øtimant enim per diuinae naturae con≈øcios ≈øacra fieri oportere, tanquam linguae Deorum peritos. Atque horum interce≈øsione bona a dijs cen≈øent petenda, quorum con≈øilio, & pace, & bello fruuntur. Our Prote≈øtant Authours of the Theater of greate Britaine make Cae≈øar and auncient writers to write in this manner: The Druids office was imployed about holy things: for they had the managing of publike and priuate Sacrifices, and to interpret Theater of great Brit. l. 6. and di≈øcu≈ø≈øe matters of Religion. Vnto them doe re≈øort great numbers of youÃÑg men to learne at their hands, and they he had in greate reuerence, for they determine allmo≈øt, all controuer≈øies and matters in variance, as well publike, as priuate. And
if there happen any thing to be done ami≈ø≈øe, if there be any murther committed, if there ari≈øe any controuer≈øie concerning inheritance or bounds of lands, they take the matter into their power, and award eyther recompence or penalties in the ca≈øe. And if there be any, be he priuate par≈øon, or be it corporation, that will not ≈øtand to their Iudgment, they interdict him, which punishment amongst them is held mo≈øt greuious. They that are ≈øo excommunicated, are accompted in the number of the wicked, and vngratious. All men shune them, all men e≈øchue their company, and communication. This is one of the cheife≈øt things that they labour mo≈øt to beate into mens minds, that the ≈øoules dye not, but doe after death pa≈ø≈øe from one to an other. And hereby they thinke men should be mo≈øt ≈øtirred vnto vertue, when the feare of death, is nothing regarded. Al≈øo they di≈øpute many other things: as of the ≈øtarrs, and of their mouings: of the bignes of the world, and the earth: of the nature of things, of the strength and power of the Gods Immortall: and doe therein in≈øtruct the youth. Thus we haue heard what tho≈øe Druids and their followers, which had not before ≈øubmitted them≈øelues to Chri≈øt, did or could plead for the maintenance of their pretended Religion, and honour and glory which they principally enioyed by profe≈ø≈øion thereof.

3. Now lett vs a litle examine their cau≈øe by their owne Authours and their owne proceedings, for to write at lardge of their mo≈øt gro≈ø≈øe and inhuman ab≈øurdities would require a volume from mee, as the like hath done of other writers again≈øt ≈øuch Pagan Gentils their ≈øuper≈øtitions. Whereas all creaturs cry out vnto vs, e≈øpecially the more Noble as the Cele≈øtiall bodies (in ≈øearching who≈øe natures and effects the≈øe men were mo≈øt conuer≈øant,) that there is an eternall and omnipotent maker and cau≈øer which created all things, who being without begining or ending was made or cau≈øed by no other: caeli enarrant gloriam Dei, & opera manuum eius annuntiat firmamentum. And diuine worship is onely due vnto him, for his allmightie excellencie, and the benefites, which man a rea≈øonable creature receaued, and further expecteth, and needeth to receaue from him, which we commonly call Religion, a Religeinge, Religation, or dutifull binding of man enformed with a rea≈øonable intellectuall, and immortall ≈øoule, ordayned as it were the Lieutenant and Viceroy of God to gouerne this inferiour world, & by his better eternall part, a≈ø≈øured that better and eternall things are ordayned for him, if he doth not depriue him≈øelfe of them, but ≈øeeke, finde out and performe the will and commandement of ≈øo infinite good and bountifull a Creatour, Pre≈øeruer and Maitayner of all things, e≈øpecially for the v≈øe and end of man ≈øo dignified and exalted among his creaturs. Which the≈øe Druids and their Di≈øciples were ≈øo farre from effecting, that they gaue him noe honour at all, neuer remembring him among tho≈øe they worshiped, but doing the greate≈øt dishonour they could vnto him, in giuing that glory and maie≈øtie, which is onely proper and due to him, to his rebellious creaturs and profe≈ø≈øed enemies, damned and infernall ≈øoules hundreds of thow≈øands before them, and diuers of the≈øe by probable Hi≈øtoricall accompts of later time, and Creation, then the Authour of their owne Sect, Druius was. And if we will followe Iulius Cae≈øar, who of all writers writeth mo≈øt of their pretended ReligioÃÑ, liuing in the time of their cheife≈øt ≈øway, and be≈øt knew what they profe≈ø≈øed, he writeth of the Germans, that they differed much from the French, and their Druids in Religion: Hauing no Sacrifices, and onely accompting them for Gods, whome they ≈øee, and by whome they are manife≈øtly knowne to be helped, as the Sunne, Moone, and ≈øuch vi≈øible things, and heard not of any other God. Germani
multum √† Gallorum con≈øuetudine differunt. Neque Sacrificijs ≈øtudent, Deorum numero Iulius Cae≈øar l. 6. Belli Gallici. Andreas Althanur. BreÃÑzius in ≈øcholijs in Cornel. Tacit. l. de ≈øit. Mor. Germ. Henric. Pantal. l. de Vir. Illu≈øtrib. part. 1. p. 40. 41. eos ≈øolos ducunt quos cernunt: & quorum apert√® opibus in ‚Ä¢ antur. Solem, Vulcanum, & Lunam: reliquos ne fama quidem acceperunt. Yet the German writers are ≈øo confident, that the Druids ruled there in Religion, that they shew vs to this day in Germany, as farre as Bauaria two e≈øpeciall places; where they were wonted to a≈ø≈øemble vnder greate Okes, to exerci≈øe their ≈øuper≈øtitions, and in dete≈øtation thereof, two Mona≈øteries called Oberaltaich and Nideraltaich, were founded there, to blot out their memory. In Banaria quoque inferiore, ≈øub quereu magno ≈øuperiore & inferiore ≈øuam ≈øuperstitionem exercebant, quae loca postea in Mona≈øteria conuer≈øa, etiamnum Oberaltaich, & Nideraltaich appellantur. Therefore the≈øe could not be Profe≈ø≈øours & Teachers of the true God, his worship and Religion, which for diuers people and Countries, and for them≈øelues al≈øo had ≈øuch varietie and change of Gods, and Religion, in diuers times and places, and yet all of them profe≈ø≈øing mo≈øt gro≈ø≈øe and ≈øtupid ignorance, or willfull Idolatrie, the greate≈øt Irreligion to God that can bee.

4. And as they thus proued them≈øelues to be Athe≈øts leauing no po≈ø≈øible true God to be worshipped, ≈øo by their errour of Tran≈ømigration of ≈øoules from one body to an other, they fall into one of the≈øe ab≈øurdities, that one ≈øoule might and should in the end informe many, euen hundreds of bodyes, or els cea≈øe at the la≈øt to informe, cea≈øe to be, and made mortall. And as Chimericall a fictioÃÑ it was of theÃÑ to ≈øay, as Lucan expoundeth them, that when a ≈øoule left a body in this world, it went into an other world, and there informed an other body.

lg.l: Vobis Authoribus, vmbrae
Non tacitas Erebi ≈øedes, Diti≈øque profundi Luc. l. 1.
Pallida regna petunt; Regit idem Spiritus artus
Orbe alio longe,

div.p: For ≈øo they mu≈øt needs make more worlds, where generation and corruption is, be≈øides this terre≈øtriall and ≈øublunary, were we inhabit. And therefore iu≈øtly doth the ≈øame Authour call their profe≈ø≈øion Barbarous rites, a fal≈øe manner of worship, and ≈øingular again≈øt all the world be≈øides.

lg.l: Et vos barbari ‚Ä¢ os ritus moremque ≈øini≈øtrum
Sacrorum, Druidae po≈øitis repeti≈øtis ab armis.
Solis no≈øce Deos, & caeli ≈øidera vobis,
Aut ≈øolis ne≈øcire datum.

div.p: And thus in their Religion we finde neyther true God to be worshipped, nor true man to worship him. And their practi≈øe both tooke away all things, that are required to true worship, and Religion, and they exerci≈øed in place of them quite contrary and vnlawfull things. Which we shall euidently perceaue if we examine them by the Decaloge or Ten commandements giuen by God in the Lawe of Moy≈øes, commonly thought both by Diuinitie and Philo≈øophie to be the Lawe of Nature except that of the Sabboth day to be ob≈øerued.

5. The fir≈øt of, one onely God, we haue heard how they tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed it; ≈øo likewi≈øe of not making any Idoll to adore or worship, hauing the Idols and fal≈øe Gods before remembred. S. Gildas is an able witnes that the mon≈øtrous Idols of Britaine in this time were not inferiour in number to tho≈øe of Egipt, commonly e≈øteemed the mo≈øt Idolatrous Nation of the world, and ≈øome of them with deformed lineaments remayned to be ≈øeene in his time. And this blinde people of Britaine gaue diuine honour euen to Mountaynes, Hills and Gildas l. de Excid. Brit. Riuers. And yet be≈øides the≈øe, had errours and Idolatries common with other Nations. Non omittens pri≈øcos commune≈øque cum omnibus gentibus errores, quibus
ante aduentum Christi in carne omne humanum genus obligabatur ob≈øtrictum, nec enumerans patriae portenta ip≈øa diabolica pene numero Egiptiaca vincentia, quorum nonnulla lineamentis adhuc deformibus intra vel extra de≈øerta maenia ≈øolito more rigantia, toruis vultibus intuemur: neque nominatim inclamitans montes ip≈øos, aut colles, aut fluuios olim exitiales: nunc ver√≤ humanis v≈øibus vtiles; quibus diuinus honor √† caeco tunc populo cumulabatur. The ≈øame haue others both Catholike and Theater of great Brit. l. 6. Prote≈øtant Antiquaries after him. And the Sacrifices which they offered to the≈øe abominable Idols, were the mo≈øt dete≈øtable, and for ≈øuch not vnworthily ranked both by their owne Pagan, and Chri≈øtian writers, among the mo≈øt cruell and Barbarous ≈øauages of the world. Pro victimis homines immolant admini≈øtri≈øque ad ea Sacrificia Druidibus vtuntur. Publiceque eiu≈ødem generis Cae≈øar l. 6. Belli Gallici. Cicero Oratione pro M. Fonteio. habent in≈øtituta Sacrificia. They offer men for Sacrifices, and the Druids be the mini≈øters in ≈øuch Sacrifices. And ≈øuch Sacrifices be in≈øtituted by publike Authoritie among them. Thus hath Cae≈øar and others. Cicero ≈øpeaking of the≈øe Druids ≈øaith: His quicquam ≈øanctum, ac Religio≈øum videri pote≈øt, qui etiam≈øi quando aliquo metu adducti Deos placandos e≈ø≈øe arbitrantur, humanis ho≈øtijs eorum aras, ac templa funestant? vt ne Religionem quidem colere po≈øsint, ni≈øi eam ip≈øam ≈øcelere violarint. Quis enim ignorat, eos v≈øque ad hunc diem retinere illam immanem, ac Barbaram con≈øuetudineÃÑ hominum immolandorum? QuamobreÃÑ quali fide, quali pietate existimatis eos e≈ø≈øe, qui etiaÃÑ Deos immortales arbitrentur hominuÃÑ ≈øcelere & ≈øanguine facile po≈ø≈øe placari? Can any thing be accompted holy and Religious with the≈øe men, who when they are a fraid of any thing and would haue their Gods pacified, doe prophaine their. Altars and Temples with ≈øacrificed men? So that they cannot exerci≈øe their Religion, except they fir≈øt violate it with wickednes. For who is ignoraÃÑt, that euen to this day, they retayne that ≈øauage and Barbarous cu≈øtome of ≈øacrificing men? Therefore can you thinke tho≈øe men to haue any Religion, or piety, who thinke their immortall Gods (≈øo he a Pagan nameth their Pagan Gods and Idols) may be ea≈øily appea≈øed with the wickednes, and blood of men? The like hath Dio Ca≈ø≈øius, Ammianus Mercellinus, and others among the Gentils, all crying out again≈øt Dio Ca≈ø≈ø. in Epitom. apud Xephelin. in Nerone. Ammian. Mercell. in eod. Iul. Cae≈øar. lib. 6. Belli Gallici. Io. Selden Analect. p. 27. Plinius natural Hi≈øt. l. 3. Io. Seld. Analect. Anglob. p. 35. Theater of great Britaine l. 6. the≈øe mo≈øt Barbarous proceedings, and yet termed with them Religion. And to fill vp the mea≈øure of this their mo≈øt inhuman Irreligion, as Iulius Cae≈øar with others te≈øtifieth, the≈øe men had Idols of an Huge greatenes who≈øe members being made of wands, they filledfull of men aliue, and ≈øo ≈øetting them on fire burned them: immani magnitudine ≈øimulachra habent, quorum contexta viminibus membra viuis hominibus complent, quibus ≈øuccen≈øis circumuenti flamma exanimantur homines. And Pliny with others is witnes, that they were ≈øo farre, from doing any homage or dutie to God, that they be≈øtowed all ≈øuch vpon the Deuills his Enemyes, and were ≈øo farre and ≈øo long time in his dayes had bene practi≈øed in Magike and Inuocation, and worshiping deuills, that he ≈øuppo≈øeth the Per≈øians ≈øo farre di≈øtant, and giuen ouer then to that mo≈øt horrible dishonoring of God, had learned and receaued it from hence, where the cheife Mai≈øters and practi≈øers thereof remained.

6. And concerning the other commaundements of the ≈øecond Table, of honoring Parents, not committing murther, adultery, theft, or wronge vnto men, which are warranted by the Lawe of Nature, the≈øe men were as farre from performing theÃÑ, as tho≈øe of the fir≈øt Table about diuine worshipe, but this ≈øo termed Religion gaue either coÃÑmandemeÃÑt or publike allowance to breake them all Iulius Cae≈øar writeth, that the men kept women as wyues common vnto them, and brothers the women or wyues of their brothers, and Iul. Cae≈øar Bell. Gallici l. 6. parents tho≈øe of their children. Vxores habent deni duodenique inter ≈øe communes,
& maxime fratres cum fratribus, & parentes cum liberis. The like hath Io. Zonaras in Seuero. Zonaras; and how in ≈øome parts of this Country the people went naked. Nudi degunt, mulieribus promi≈øcu√® vtuntur. And this was accompted a vertue & honour among them, as their Queene Bunduica did publikly profe≈ø≈øe, in her prayer to her Godde≈ø≈øe Andra≈øte, or Anda≈øte: Qui cum caetera omnia, tum liberos, BuÃÑduica Regina in orat. ad Ada≈øten apud Io. Xephilin. in Epitom. Dionis. in Nerone. & in Seuero. Dio. & Xephil. ≈øupr. Io. Zonaras in Seuero. Theater of great Britaine lib. 6. S. Io. Chry≈øo≈øtom. Serm. de Penteco≈øt. Hier. aduer≈ø. Iouinian. & vxores communes inter ≈øe putant: The Britans did e≈øteeme children; wyues, as all other things to be common among them. And both Xephilinus, Dio, and Zonaras ≈øay, it was as lawfull for them to ≈øteale, libenti≈øsim√® latrocinantur: If theft may be, where all things are allowed to be common. What they e≈øteemed of murther, and corporall violence may be collected by that is ≈øayde, when the Innocents were at commaund to be ≈øacrificed to their deuills. And to v≈øe S. Chry≈øo≈øtoms and S. Hieroms ≈øpeach as our Theater Prote≈øtants tran≈ølate them: S. Ihon Chri≈øo≈øtome ≈øaith, the Britans fedd vpon human flesh, making no difference betwixt the blood of man, and bea≈øt. Of which barbari≈øme S. Hierome al≈øo complained, that ≈øome of tho≈øe Nations (he expre≈ø≈øely nameth the Scots) v≈øed to eate the Buttoks of Boyes, and Paps of virgins, which in their fea≈øts were ≈øerued for the daintiest dishes. And this mo≈øt ≈øauadge and barbarous behauiour of this kingdome, vnder the Religion and Reignement of the Druides, was by their gouerment now become ≈øo notorious in the world, and odious, that, as S. Gildas noteth Pophyrie that greate Pagan Philo≈øopher and maintainer of their ≈øuper≈øtitions, and ≈øo enraged again≈øt the Church of Chri≈øt, that he calleth him the madd dogge, Porphirius rabidus orientalis aduer≈øus Eccle≈øiam Porphir. apud Gildam l. de excid. Britanniae prope Initium. canis, liuing in the Ea≈øt nameth this Country, the mother of Tyrants. Britannia fertilis Prouincia Tyrannorum.

7. The≈øe and ≈øuch other mo≈øt gro≈ø≈øe and hellish ≈øuper≈øtitions, errors, and exercrable wikednes in practi≈øing their pretended Religion, being ≈øo inuincibly proued, that neither denyall, nor excu≈øe would be made, and ≈øeeing how all the world had allready, or now was to for≈øake them, the Roman Emperours and their Lieutenants in France had bannished them, they ≈øought their de≈øtruction heare in Britaine, and the King him≈øelfe with his Nobilitie condemned them, and very many of their be≈øt learned men both in this and other Countryes had abandoned their Rites, and v≈øadges, and now embraced and actually profe≈ø≈øed Chri≈øtian Religion, thus ≈øpurred forward, and thereby more ≈øeriou≈øly, and deliberately reflecting vpon tho≈øe conuicting, and vnan≈øweareable motiues therevnto, which I haue remembred in the fir≈øt Age, and more properly belonging to the Druides of Britaine, then any people of this or other Nation. They al≈øo with their followers and Di≈øciples gaue a common con≈øent to relinquish their ≈øo condemned ≈øuper≈øtitions, and receaue the lawe of Chri≈øt, and this in ≈øo generall or vniuer≈øall manner, that within short time after, few or none were to be found, which profe≈ø≈øed their ≈øo condemned Idolatryes, and Impieties. And among their owne ≈øuper≈øtitions, they had ≈øome better ob≈øeruations and directions deliuered and propo≈øed by a better ≈øpirit, to bring them more readily into the way of truth, among which was that their auncient Tradition, which I haue ≈øpoken of before of picturing & reuerencing a Child in a Virgins Armes, which wheÃÑ the My≈øteries of Chri≈øt were preached & proued vnto them more ea≈øely brought them publikly and plainely to profe≈ø≈øe and followe that, which figuratiuely, & prophetically in ob≈øcure manner and ≈øignes they had acknowledged long before Chri≈øts Natiuitie.

div.head: THE XIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF POPE S. ELEVTHERIVS, AND HOW IN his Papacie, and by his Papall order and power Britaine had the honour to be the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian kingdome in the worlde, and elde≈øt daughter of the mother Church of Chri≈øt, King Lucius by his Emba≈ø≈øadors and petition to the Pope of Rome ≈øo obtaining.

div.p: 1. ABOVT this time when matters were thus acting, or acted in Britaine, S. Soter the holy Pope of Rome was Martyred, not by the commandement, but rather again≈øt the commande and Edict of Marcus Aurelius the Emperour, hauing giuen ≈øo ≈øeuere and ≈øtrict order and chardge that no Chri≈øtian should be mole≈øted or que≈øtioned for his Religion, by ≈øome malitious and fal≈øe accu≈øing Aduer≈øaries. And S. Eleutherius, Dama≈øus Pontif. in Eleuth. Martin. Polon. in Eleuth. Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 185. Florent. Wigorn. Chron. an. 162. al. 184. Lampridius in Commodo. Mar. Max. & Senat. apud eund. ib. Herodianus l. 1. Dio in Commodo. or Eleutherus ≈øucceeded him in the See Apo≈øtolike, and by the common opinion ruled the ≈øame, 15. yeares, or more. Marcus Aurelius Antoninus was yet Emperour, and after him his ≈øonne Commodus, who though he was a mo≈øt wiked man, exceeding all that went before him in impiety, as Marius Maximus, Lampridius, and in them the whole Senate of Rome with others are witne≈ø≈øes, yet as a ≈øcourge of God, to the Per≈øecutors of Chri≈øtiaÃÑs, he oppre≈ø≈øed them, and was fauorable vnto Chri≈øtians, neuer mole≈øting them; whether it was at the mediation of Marcia a woman, whome he exceedingly affected, and was as Dio ≈øaith, mo≈øt friendly to Chri≈øtians, Chri≈øtianorum ≈øtudio≈øi≈øsima, or otherwi≈øe, I doe not examine, he remained Emperour all Pope Eleutherius his time. And Lucius was ≈øtill King in Britaine, and ≈øo by generall con≈øent of Antiquaries continued all the time of Pope Eleutherius, who as all our English Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians, with others doe willingly and freely acknowledge, was an holy Bishop and ≈øtudious to haue the word of God published, a good Mai≈øter of the hou≈øehold of Chri≈øt, and ≈øo adhering to the Doctrine of the Apo≈øtles that he confirmed the Britans therein. Pius Epi≈øcopus, Matth. Parker. Ant. Brit. p. 4. Io. Bal. lib. 1. de Act. Pontif. Rom. in Eleutherio. diuino verbo propagando ≈øtudens. Bonus paterfamilias de the≈øauro ≈øuo noua cum veteribus proferens effecit, vt confirmatis & con≈øolidatis Britannis in ≈øu≈øcepta prius ab Apo≈øtolis Doctrina, totum illud regnum in eius fidei verba iuraret. Thus write two Prote≈øtant Bishops, the one their fir≈øt Archbishop to whome the re≈øt ≈øub≈øcribe in this opinion of S. Eleutherius.

2. What was his Religion in particular concerning matters now que≈øtioned by them, they are not ≈øo willing to vtter in expre≈ø≈øe terms, becau≈øe they are enforced by all Antiquitie to yeeld that the Religion which he profe≈ø≈øed was the ≈øame which was then by publike Authoritie generally preached and embraced in Britaine. But he e≈øtablished among other things, the Florent. Wigor. Chron. an. 181. true Ob≈øeruation, of Ea≈øter, die Dominico a 14. v≈øque ad 21. celebraretur. Acknowledging,
as before, that he confirmed the Britans in the Doctrine of the Apo≈øtles. And further te≈øtifying from Antiquities that his mother Authia comitted Magdeb. cent. 2. col. 133. cap. de Scholis. N ‚Ä¢ ceph. l. 3. c. 29. Pius 1. Epi≈øt. 1. ad S. Iu≈øtum. Vienn. him to Anicetus Pope before S. Pius, by many Authorities, to be in≈øtructed in Diuinitie: Authia Eleutherium filium ≈øuum Aniceto tradidit erudiendum, qui ≈øacras literas ab eo doctus, ≈øacro Cleri numero in≈øeritur: and ≈øo familiar, and accoÃÑpted renowned with Pope Pius, that famous Ma≈ø≈øing Pope, as is allready declared, they mu≈øt needs grant he was as farre a profe≈ø≈øor of that pre≈øent Roman Religion, which they name Papi≈øtrie or Poperye, as they haue confe≈ø≈øed of tho≈øe holy Popes his predece≈ø≈øors in the See Apo≈øtolike, and Tutors in Religion. And for ≈øome cheife≈øt particulars, they giue vs their particular warrant, that it was ≈øo. For the Popes ≈øpirituall Supreamacie they write that he claymed, and parti≈øed it, as the definition or In≈øtitution of the Apo≈øtles, and their ≈øucce≈ø≈øors to his time: Romanae ≈øedis Primatum arrogat, cum ait ab Apo≈øtolis eorumque Magdeburgen≈øes cent. 2. c. de primatu. col. 141. 142. Robert. Barns l. de Vit. Rom. Pont. in Eleutherio. ≈øucce≈ø≈øoribus multorum con≈øen≈øu Epi≈øcoporum definitum e≈ø≈øe: and prouided that in Bishops ca≈øes, and accu≈øations, nothing should be determined, but by the Pope of Rome. Accu≈øationem contra Epi≈øcopos intentatam, Epi≈øcopos audire permi≈øit: ≈øed vt nihil, ni≈øi apud Pontificem definiretur, cauet. But this will more plainely appeare in the planting of Chri≈øtian Catholike Religion heare, in the en≈øuing Hi≈øtory thereof. And this shall ≈øtand in place of a Sea Marke to bring mee into the true way of my British Hi≈øtoricall Narration againe.

3. For when matters of Religion had ≈øo farre and pro≈øperou≈øly proceeded in Britaine, as I haue related in the former Chapter, and now nothing remained to be concluded of in tho≈øe affaires, but how the true faith and Religion of Chri≈øt might be planted heare, by the mo≈øt publike, powerable, warrantable, and vncontroleable Authoritie in ≈øuch proceedings, it was generally agreed vpon according to tho≈øe grounds and approued Rules which our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries haue propo≈øed and pre≈øcribed vnto vs before, that ≈øo greate important and generall a bu≈øines of conuerting a whole, and ≈øo Lardge a kingdome neither lawfully might, or could be e≈øtablish in all things thereto required and nece≈ø≈øarie, without the help, power and highe≈øt warranting prerogatiue of the Roman See Apo≈øtolike. And therefore the finall determination of our King, his Nobles, and mo≈øt Religious and wi≈øe≈øt Adui≈øers in this Noble worke, was, to petition to the Pope of Rome by letters and Amba≈ø≈øadors from hence, that he would accordingly as his high Pa≈øtorall charge and office called vpon him in ≈øuch affaires, to take this greate Action in hand, and effect it by ≈øuch men and meanes as should be thought mo≈øt fit, and approued vnto him. Whether this Re≈øolution and Amba≈ø≈øadge of King Lucius was made and directed fir≈øt at this time in the Papacie of S. Eleutherius, or toward the later end of Pope Soter, I dare not to determine, becau≈øe we reade in the be≈øt and mo≈øt allowed Relation of this Amba≈ø≈øadge, that it was now acted in the very beginning of the Popedome of Eleutherius, and then both King Lucius letters and Amba≈ø≈øadors were come to Pope Eleutherius at Rome, with this ≈øuite. Huic (Eleutherio) initio Pontificatus ≈øupplices literae venerunt √† Act. Eleutherij Papae in Breuiar. Rom. die 26. Maij. Anton. Sabellicus l. 5. Ennead. 7. Platina in Eleutherio. Lucio Britannorum Rege, vt ≈øe ac ≈øuos in Chri≈øtianorum numerum reciperet. Which giueth Argument, that if ≈øuch letters and Amba≈ø≈øadors were not ≈øent in the life of Pope Soter, and hindered of execution by his vnexpected Martyrdome, yet at the lea≈øt the Re≈øolution heareof was made in his time, otherwi≈øe tho≈øe Amba≈ø≈øadors and letters could not haue bene tran≈øported ≈øo farre, and ≈øo ≈øoone, if we should expect re≈øolution to his dayes as to be there in the beginning of his Papacie. The largnes of this kingdome, the diuer≈øitie and
manifold number of par≈øons, euen of cheife accompt, both in ≈øpirituall and ciuill re≈øpect commorant in di≈øtinct and much ≈øeperated places, who≈øe con≈øent was requi≈øite, and many of them, thir Iudgments not pre≈øently conuicted Stow Hi≈øt. in Lucius. Matt. Park. Ant. Brit. p. 4. Io. Go≈øceln. Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. Io. Balaeus l. de Script. cent. 1. in Lucio Pio. Act. S. Soteris in Breu. Rom. 22. April. Baron. Tom. 2. an. 179. in Sotere & Eleuther. Seuer. Bin. notat. in to. 1. Concil. in Vita Soteris & Eleut. Anton. Sabellic. l. 5. Ennead. 7. Go≈øcelin. & Bal. ≈øupr. for ≈øuch a me≈ø≈øadge, and other difficulties drawe me deeper into this opinion that this Amba≈ø≈øadge was attempted, or concluded, in Pope Soters time. For as our learned Prote≈øtant Antiquaries write: haec contigerunt anno √† Chri≈øti aduentu in carne 179. vt veriores Annales commemorant: according to the true≈øt accompt in Hi≈øtories this Amba≈ø≈øadge was in the 179. yeare of Chri≈øt, in which yeare by the common accompt, S. Soter was put to death, on the 22. day of Aprill, and the See Apo≈øtolike was voide before S. Eleutherius his Election 10. dayes. So the remnant of this yeare from the ≈øecond day of May is farre too short a time to a≈ø≈øigne for the managing of ≈øo many and important affaires, e≈øpecially if we add the ≈øending hither againe, from Rome by Pope Eleutherius, Damianus and Fugatianus, which was al≈øo done in this yeare, as the≈øe men affirme: and much more if Eluanus and Meduuinus, which were but Catechumens and not Baptized when they were ≈øent from hence to Rome were ≈øo perfectly in≈øtructed, examined, and ordinarily as the cour≈øe of the Roman Church was at that time proceeded in taking Eccle≈øia≈øticall Orders, Eluanus returning a Bishop, and Meduuinus a cheife Preacher and Prei≈øt, the≈øe things requiring a longer time then is allotted before to be done in the Papacie of Eleutherius, if they returned hither this yeare with S. Fugatius, and Damianus, as our Antiquaries incline to deliuer, I mu≈øt needs al≈øo incline to hold this Amba≈ø≈øadge was begun in S. Soter his time, and by his death hindered Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. in Lucio. Matth. Parker. Antiq. Brit. p. 5. Stowe Hi≈øt. in Lucius. Io. Go≈øc. Hi≈øt. Eccl. from execution vntill this beginning of S. Eleutherius Ruling in the Church of Chri≈øt.

4. But how ≈øoeuer this Amba≈ø≈øadge may be que≈øtioned, when it was taken in hand, in the time of Pope Soter, or not before the entrance of S. Eleutherius into that chardge, it is a confe≈ø≈øed truth, and out of Controuer≈øie, among all Hi≈øtorians, Catholiks, or Prote≈øtants, both that this Amba≈ø≈øadge about the publike Conuer≈øion of Britaine was from King Lucius, King in Britaine to the Pope of Rome, as al≈øo that at this time all Countries betweene this kingdome and Rome, as France, Lorrayne, Germany, and Italy had many renowned learned Bishops, and Prei≈øts, neyther was Britaine de≈øtitute of ≈øuch as I haue proued before. And this was well knowne to King Lucius as our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries thus a≈ø≈øuer vs hereof: Cumque cognoui≈ø≈øet Lucius, Matth. Parker. Antiq. Brit. p. 4. quamplures nobiles Romanos fidem Chri≈øti √† Romano Pontifice accepi≈ø≈øe, eorumque exemplo Chri≈øtianum nomen in ≈øingulas Prouincias ≈øpar≈øum & di≈ø≈øeminatum, ≈øtatuit All Nations in the we≈øt part of the world as well as Britaine by all antiquaries receaued the Chri≈øtian faith from Rome. in eadem fide, ≈øub Eleutherio tunc Romano Pontifice inaugurari: When King Lucius knew that very many noble Romans had receaued the faith of Christ from the Pope of Rome, and by their example the Chri≈øtian name was di≈øper≈øed and ≈øowen into all Prouinces, he appointed to be inaugured in the ≈øame faith by Eleutberius then Pope of Rome. Where we ≈øee it iu≈øtified by the fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop that euer was, whome the re≈øt of our English Prote≈øtants doe willingly followe, that not onely the Nobles of the Romans had receaued the faith of Chri≈øt from the Pope of Rome, but all Prouinces had followed their example therein: Whereby it is euident both that there were many learned Bishops and Clergie men betweene this and Rome, of whome King Lucius with farre le≈ø≈øe labour and difficulties might haue receaued the faith of Chri≈øt, then from the Pope of Rome, had not the Preeminency of that Apo≈øtolike See in ≈øuch, ca≈øes called vpon him to appeale thither, for the generall and Iuridicall ≈øetling of him≈øelfe
and kingdome in the Chri≈øtian faith. And by this narration it≈øelfe, without further Authoritie in this place, it is manife≈øt, that if King Lucius had not v≈øed the Roman Popes power, and direction herein, he had bene ≈øingular, hauing no example to warrant him, but the example of all Prouinces ≈øingulas Prouincias in this part of the world, receauing the faith from the Pope of Rome to condemne him, euen in the Iudgment of Prote≈øtants them≈øelues, if he had otherwi≈øe proceeded in this bu≈øines.

5. Therefore I can but maruayle what a Prote≈øtant Bishop meaneth, fir≈øt to extoll with greate prai≈øe our King Lucius for this Action: and after a≈ømuch condemne him in the ≈øame re≈øpect. He commendeth him in this manner: great cau≈øe haue we with all thankfullnes to celebrate the memory of this excellent Godwin conu. of Brit. p. 35. Prince, by whome God did not onely ble≈ø≈øe this Land with the knowledge of his truth, but in ≈øuch ≈øort did it, as thereby he hath purcha≈øed vnto the ≈øame the Title of Primogenita Eccle≈øiae, the mo≈øt auncient, and first begotten of all the Churches in the world, for that as Sabellicus hath well noted allthough Chri≈øt was preached el≈øwhere priuately Britaine the fir≈øt Kingdome in the world which publikely, and generally receaued the ≈øaith of Chri≈øt. in many other Nations, long before, yet, omnium Prouinciarum prima publicitus Chri≈øti nomen recepit. Of all Nations it was the fir≈øt that with publike approbation of Prince and State receaued the Profe≈øsion of Chri≈øtian Religion. Thus farre he commendeth King Lucius for the carriadge of this bu≈øines, afterward in≈øinuating fir≈øt to his Readers, that there were Chri≈øtian Prei≈øts and Preachers heare in Britaine, when King Lucius ≈øent to Pope Eleutherius about the generall Conuer≈øion of this kingdome, and (to v≈øe his words) there is no doubt to be made, that at their haÃÑds (if he were not) he might haue bene bapti≈øed, that were the In≈øtrumeÃÑts of his Conuer≈øion: And then he immediately thus addeth to dishonour this Noble King, for this his mo≈øt honorable Amba≈ø≈øadge: But what shall I ≈øay? humanituÃÑs aliquid pa≈ø≈øus e≈øt: he thought happily it would be ≈øome litle glory vnto him, and a countenance al≈øo to the action, to fetch them that might ≈øeeme to be the Authours of this de≈øigne from Rome, the Seate of the Empire, the Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe of the world, yea and al≈øo happily the vpholders of his Crowne, and Authoritie regall. Thus farre this Prote≈øtant Bishop and Antiquarie: all which I haue an≈øweared before, and now breifely repeate; if King Lucius was or might haue bene bapti≈øed by any heare, (all they as I haue proued before of S. Timothie, Marcellus, Man≈øuetus, and others ≈øent hither, or conuerted being coÃÑ≈øecrated Prei≈øts, or Bishops heare, by Authoritie from the Apo≈øtolike Roman See,) he mu≈øt needs al≈øo be bapti≈øed by power from thence, if he had not ≈øent this ≈øolemne Amba≈ø≈øadge thither. So likewi≈øe if he ≈øtayed the returne of his Amba≈ø≈øadours, Eluan and Medwin, if the Pope had ≈øent no others hither, ≈øeeing by all Antiquities, the≈øe were but Cathecumens, and not bapti≈øed, when they were ≈øent to Rome, but there perfectly in≈øtructed, bapti≈øed, and coÃÑ≈øecrated, the one a Prie≈øt, the other a Prei≈øt and Bishop, if the≈øe or eyther of them bapti≈øed him, and his people, (if they alone had bene able to performe ≈øo generall and greate a worke,) it had bene done by the power of the Pope of Rome, who con≈øecrated them, and by Authoritie ≈øent them hither, to that end.

6. So if King Lucius had appealed in this bu≈øines to the Bishops of France or any Country betweene Rome and vs, and if they had harkened vnto him herein without con≈øulting with the Pope of Rome, yet all they being con≈øecrated, and directed thither by his Authoritie, as we haue ≈øeene before, King Lucius and his ≈øubiects re≈øolued to be Chri≈øtians, mu≈øt become ≈øuch by the labour, power and warrant of the Pope of Rome. And by that which is ≈øaide before, by the warrant of our Prote≈øtants, of the both claymed and practi≈øed
≈øupreame ≈øpirituall power of all Popes from S. Peter, to this time of S. Eleutherius, and of him al≈øo, it is euident that this kingdome nor any other could be in ≈øuch ≈øolemne and publike manner conuerted, and all Eccle≈øia≈øticall matters with change of Temporall lawes be e≈øtablished, without the warrant and approbation of the Apo≈øtolike See of Rome, and Church thereof: in which re≈øpect and noe other Sabellicus and others which truely call this our Britaine, the elde≈øt daughter of the Church; primogemita Eccle≈øiae, ≈øo terme it in re≈øpect of the Church of Rome, our holy Mother, which brought forth this Country generally, and publikly to Chri≈øt before any other in the world, by ≈øending holy Preachers and Apo≈øtolike men hither, which ≈øo brought it to pa≈ø≈øe to the greate honour of this Nation. Eleutherius Graecia oriundus, ≈øed Neapoli Anton. Sabellicus l. 5. Ennead. 7 in Italia ortus ≈øucce≈øsit Soteri. Cum hoc nuper dignitatem adepto Lucius Britanniae Rex per litteras egit: vt ≈øe & ≈øuos vellet Chri≈øtianorum numero addicere. Mi≈øsi ≈øunt eo Fugatius & Damianus viri pietate in≈øigni, hi Regem cum tota domo populoque vniuer≈øo Bapti≈ømi Sacramento in≈øignauerunt: ≈øublatoque malorum daemonum cultu, vera in gente pietas con≈øtituta e≈øt. Sic Britannia omnium Prouinciarum prima publicitus Chri≈øti nomen recepit. Where it is euident, that Sabellicus this Prote≈øtant Bishops Authour giueth this dignitie to Britaine, to be the elde≈øt and fir≈øt borne daughter of the Church, becau≈øe the Roman Church, fir≈øt, and before all other Nations, did bringe it wholy forth to Chri≈øt, wholy conuerting it: in which ≈øence the King of France accompteth and ≈øtileth him≈øelfe, primogenitus Annal. Galliae. in Claudio. Eccle≈øiae, the fir≈øt begotten child of the Church among Kings, becau≈øe Stephen a King in France rather a Duke, was in their opinion in the time of Claudius the Emperour conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, by Apo≈øtolike men ≈øent from the See of Rome. And our King Iames whome our Prote≈øtants would haue to be the fourth ≈øuch ≈øupreame heade of their Church in England after King Henry the eight, the youÃÑge child King Edward the ≈øixt, and Elizabeth a woman and Queene, plainely and publikly in open parlament hath thus confe≈ø≈øed: I acknowledge the Roman Church to be our Mother Church. Therefore except Mother and Daughter be not correlatiues, and vn≈øeperable, Britaine King Iames ≈øpeach in his 1. Parlament. was the Daughter, & hauing no elder Si≈øter, Daughter of that Church, was the fir≈øt borne Daughter of the Church, by this prerogatiue, primogenita Eccle≈øiae.

7. And the Arguments which this Prote≈øtant Bishop would haue to accu≈øe or condemne King Lucius of vaine glory, for ≈øending to Rome to e≈øtablish Godwin Conu. of Brit. ≈øupr. p. 35. the Conuer≈øion of Britaine, becau≈øe Rome was then, the Seate of the Empire, Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe of the world, and happily vpholder of his crowne and regall Authoritie doe aduance the honour of King Lucius his zeale in Religion, and Dutie to the Roman Church. For if the Conuer≈øion of Britaine in ≈øo vinuer≈øall & e≈øtablished order, could haue bene compa≈ø≈øed without allowance of the Pope of Rome, it had bene more ≈øecure for him, to haue ab≈øtayned from that Amba≈ø≈øadge, ≈øent vnto the Pope liuing in ≈øtate of Per≈øecution for his Chri≈øtian Religion, and cheife office therein by the temporall and Imperiall Rome, temporall Seate of per≈øecuting Emperours, their times of conniuency onely excepted, temporall Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe of the world & temporall Vpholder, or friend to the Regall crowne of Britaine, ≈øo farre as it did nothing which ta≈øted of alienation from the Roman Pagan Imperours will, and dignitie, with which King Lucius his profe≈ø≈øing a Religion per≈øecuted by them, and ≈øuing for e≈øtablishing and confirmation thereof by the Authoritie of the Pope of Rome, which aboue all other things was mo≈øt di≈øta≈øtfull to the Roman Empire, and
had for that cau≈øe put all the Popes hitherto to death, did mo≈øt tw harte, and di≈øagree. And therefore among diuers others Ihon Funccius the Prote≈øtant Antiquary doth thus freely acknowledge: That at this time there were many mo≈øt renowned Bishops in France who≈øe help and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance for the Conuer≈øion of Britaine King Lucius might farre more ea≈øily haue v≈øed then to haue ≈øent ≈øo farre as Rome for Preachers to be ≈øent hither, and order to be giuen from thence for effecting that worke, but that the dignitie and prerogatiue of the Pope of Rome called vpon him to appeale to him, for ordering and ≈øettling the≈øe affaires, and giueth this Act and example of King Lucius the mo≈øt potent King of the Britains as he ≈øtileth him, for a ≈øure and certaine ≈øigne and Argument of the Popes of Rome true honour at that time, when they were ≈øo dishonored by the Emperours and worldly proceedings: Quo in honore Io. Funccius l. 6. commentarior. in Chronolog. ad An. 178. Romani Pontifices eo tempore fuerint, ex hoc ≈øatis apparet, quod poteÃÑti≈øsimus Britanniarum Rex, Lucius, qui ea tempe≈øtate Chri≈øti fidem primitus ex continenti vltra Germanicum Oceanum in Britannicam In≈øulam public√® vocauit, non ab alio quodam Epi≈øcopo Doctores veritatis petijt, quam √† Romano, cum tamen eodem tempore multi per Gallias clari≈øsimi haberentur Epi≈øcopi. And in this, all Antiquaries doe or ought to agree.

div.head: THE XIV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN IS RELATED, HOW KING Lucius did not onely ≈øue vnto the Pope of Rome by his Emba≈ø≈øadges, for the generall ≈øetling of Christian Religion in Britaine, but for ciuill and temporall lawes al≈øo to be allowed by him to rule heare in Temporall affaires.

div.p:
1. OVR auncient Hi≈øtorian Ethelwerdus, warranted as ≈øome thinke by S. Gildas, and Nennius before cited, writeth that Pope Eleutherius ≈øent letters, and a Legate to King Lucius of Britaine, admonishing and calling vpon him, to make profe≈ø≈øion of the holy Chri≈øtian faith, and Catholike Bapti≈øme: Eleutherius beati≈øsimus Chri≈øti famulus per Nuntium & literas Lucium adijt In≈øulae Ethelwerdus in Chronico in Eleutherio. Gildas & Nennius in M. S. Hi≈øtorijs ≈øupr. Regem, ammonens eum de fide, & Bapti≈ømo Catholico, qui tum Britanniae Regni pote≈øtate pollebat. To which Legacie and letters King Lucius did very ≈øoone after ≈øend as plea≈øing and contenting an an≈øweare, both by Amba≈ø≈øadors and letters to Pope Eleutherius, as the letters and Legacie of the Pope about ≈øo greate and holy bu≈øines, which he had ≈øo much and long de≈øired, were wellcome and gratefull vnto him, for allthough he mo≈øt affected the accomplishing of this ble≈ø≈øed worke before this incitation giuen him by this renowned Pope according to this auncient Authour of our Nation, who al≈øo ≈øay the fame of this Pope was greate in all the worlde, ab ortu≈øolis v≈øque ad occa≈øum exijt ≈øancta opinio eius: yet now receauing new couradge, warrant, and direction, without any further delay, or procra≈øtination, as this Authour writeth, yeeldeth to the coun≈øayle and exhortation of Pope Eleuthererius: Qui
conce≈øsit veri≈øimili ratione Christianum ≈øe e≈ø≈øe futurum. And by the adui≈øe and con≈øent of his Nobles, and others of this kingdome whome it mo≈øt concerned, ≈øent two Amba≈ø≈øadors with ≈øuppliant and humble letters to this holy Pa≈øtor of the Flocke of Chri≈øt, to giue him thanks for that fatherly care, he had of his ≈øpirituall children ≈øo farre off, & to ≈øignifie his mo≈øt willing a≈ø≈øent to godly Admonition, and entreate his further and ≈øpeedy care and proui≈øion for the effecting thereof.

2. The mo≈øt Authori≈øed Hi≈øtorie of S. Eleutherius, and the≈øe letters warranted vnto vs by the Church of Chri≈øt in the Fea≈øt of this holy Pope, deliuereth Act. Eleutherij in Breuiar. Rom. in fe≈øto eius. 26. die Maij. the manner and tenure of them in this order: Huic Initio Pontificatus ≈øupplices literae venerant, √† Lucio Britannorum Rege, vt ≈øe ac ≈øuos in Chri≈øtianorum numerum reciperer. In the beginning of the Popedome of S. Eleutherius, humble letters came vnto him from Lucius King of the Britans to receaue him, and Dama≈ø. Pontif. in To. 1. Concil. in Eleutherio. his people into the number of Chri≈øtians. The old Pontificall a≈ø≈øcribed to S. Dama≈øus ≈øaith of this Pope and this bu≈øines: hic accepit Epi≈øtolam √† Lucio Britannico Rege, vt Chri≈øtianus efficeretur per eius mandatum. Pope Eleutherius receaued an Epi≈øtle from Lucius a Brittish King, that by his commandement he might be made a Chri≈øtian. The auncient Eccle≈øia≈øticall Annals or Martyrologes doe thus expre≈ø≈øe it: Lucius Legationem mi≈øit ad Eleutherum Romanum PoÃÑ tificem, Antiq. Tabulae Eccle≈ø. apud Baron. To. 2. Ann. an. 183. per Eluanum & Meduinum Britannos: rogans per eos Eleutherum, vt per ≈øe ≈øuo≈øque mini≈øtros ad Chri≈øtianam Religionem ≈øu≈øcipiendam, aditum patefaceret: King Lucius ≈øent an amba≈ø≈øadge to Eleutherius Pope of Rome by two Britans Eluan and Medwine; entreating Eleutherius by them, that by him≈øelfe and ≈øuch as he should plea≈øe to employ therein, he would make proui≈øion that his kingdome might receaue Chri≈øtian Religion. I haue cited Sabellicus before, that King Lucius wrote to Anton. Sabellic. l. 3. Ennead. 7. Pope Eleutherius to this purpo≈øe in the beginning of his Papacie: Cum Eleutherio nuper dignitatem adepto Lucius Britanniae Rex per literas egit: vt ≈øe & ≈øuos vellet Chri≈øtianorum numero addicere. Martinus Polonus ≈øaith: Pope Eleutherius receaued an Epi≈øtle from Lucius a Britan King, that by his commandement he might be made a Chri≈øtian. Hic accepit Epi≈øtolam a Lucio Rege Britanno, vt Martin Polon. Supput. in Eleut. Hartm. Schedel. Chronic. chronicorum f. 114. p. 2. Ponticus Virun. Brit. Hi≈øt. l. 4. Magdeb. Cent. 2. c. 2. col. 8. Chri≈øtianus per eius mandatum fieret. Hartmannus Schedel writeth, that Eleutherius receaued an Epi≈øtle from Lucius a Britan King to receaue him and his ≈øubiects into the number of Chri≈øtians. Eleutherius Papa a Lucio Rege Britanno Epistolam accepit, vt ≈øe, ac ≈øuos in Chri≈øtianorum numerum ≈øu≈øciperet. The like hath Verunnius, and other forreine Catholike Hi≈øtorians, as al≈øo their Prote≈øtants writing of Brittish affaires; among which the Magdeburgians witne≈ø≈øe: That Lucius King of Britaine did ≈øend Eluan and Meduuin very Learned Britans, to Eleutherius Pope of Rome, entreating him to ≈øend ≈øome Doctors from thence, that might renewe Chri≈øtian Religion, and abolish Ethnici≈øme in his kingdome. Ad Eleutherium Romanae Eccle≈øiae Epi≈øcopum, Eluanum & Meduinum Britannos doctrina prae≈øtantes, mittit, ac rogat, vt inde Doctores quo≈ødam accipiat, qui Chri≈øtianam Religionem in ≈øuo Regno abolito toto Ethnici≈ømo in≈øtaurent. And if we come home into Britaine, our mo≈øt auncient & approued Hi≈øtoriaÃÑs both Britans, and Saxons make the ≈øame Relation vnto vs; S. Gildas and Nennius haue before told vs, how the Pope of Rome wrote to King Lucius to haue Chri≈øtian Religion planted heare, & he con≈øented therto. The old Manu≈øcript Manu≈øcr. Peruetu≈øtum de primo ≈øtatu Landauen. Eccle≈øiae. Brittish Antiquitie of the fir≈øt State of the Church of LaÃÑdaffe thus recordeth it: Lucius Britannorum Rex ad Eleutherium Apo≈øtolicae Sedis Papam Legatos ≈øuos ≈øcilicet Eluanum & Meduinum mi≈øit, implorans vt iuxta eius Ammonitionem Chri≈øtianus fieret. Lucius King of the Britans ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øadors, Eluan and
Medwne to Eleutherius Pope of the Apo≈øtolike See, be≈øeeching him, that Galfrid. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 4. c. 19. Antiquit. Gla≈øt. Tabulis affixae. & Capgr. in S. Patric. according to his admoniton, he might be made a Chri≈øtian. The Authour of the old Brittish Hi≈øtory ≈øaith: Lucius Epi≈øtolas ≈øuas Eleutherio Papae direxit, petens vt ab eo Chri≈øtiani≈ømum reciperet: King Lucius directed his Epi≈øtles to Pope Eleutherius, de≈øiring to receaue Chri≈øtianitie from him. The old Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury citing other Brittish Authours, doe tell vs, that very cridible Antiquities deliuer, that Lucius King of the Britans did ≈øend to Pope Eleutherius to pray him, that he would illuminate the darknes of Britaine with the light of Chri≈øtian preaching: Tradunt bonae credulitatis Annales, quod Lucius Rex Britannorum ad Eleutherium Papam mi≈øerit oratum, vt Britanniae tenebras luce Chri≈øtianae Praedicationis illu≈øtraret. S. Bede ≈øaith: King Lucius did entreate Pope Eleutherius Bed. l. 1. Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. c. 4. Theat. of Brit. l. 6. Radulphus de Diceto Hi≈øt. in Eleutherio. an. 188 Abbreuiat. teÃÑp. inter an. 170. & 180. by his letters, that by his commandement, he might be made a Chri≈øtian: ob≈øecrans vt per eius mandatum Chri≈øtianus efficeretur. Dicetus in his auncient Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory writeth: King Lucius of Britaine obtained of Pope Eleutherius by his Epi≈øtle written vnto him, to be made a Chri≈øtian. Ad Eleutherium Papam Lucius Rex Britanniae mi≈ø≈øa Epi≈øtola ≈øe fieri Chri≈øtianum impetrat. The old Authour of the Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory termed, Abbreuiatio Temporum, (if it was not the ≈øame Radulphus de Diceto) hath the ≈øame words, though not preci≈øely at the ≈øame yeare (wherein the copie of Dicetus in the Kings Library, as our Theater Prote≈øtants cite him) but as I haue alledged him. Marianus Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. an. 177. Florent. Wigor. Chron. an. 162. & 184. Sigebert. GeÃÑbl. Chronogr. in Regno Britan. Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 185. ≈øaith the very ≈øame al≈øo: Lucius Britanniae Rex ab Eleutherio Papa per Epi≈øtolam Christianum ≈øe fieri impetrat. Florentius wigornien≈øis writeth in the ≈øame words. Sigibertus ≈øaith, King Lucius reque≈øt was the cau≈øe that the Britans receaued the My≈øteries of Chri≈øtian Religion by the Legats of Pope Eleutherius: Britanni in≈øtantia Lucij Britanniarum Regis per Legatos Eleutherij Papae My≈øteria Chri≈øtianitatis perceperuÃÑt. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter giueth the like te≈øtimony to this petition of King Lucius to Pope Eleutherius: Lucius Britannorum Rex ad Papam Eleutherium Epi≈øtolas direxit, petens ab eo, vt Chri≈øtianus efficeretur. Henry Archdeacon of Huntington ≈øaith: When Eleutherius was Pope of Rome, Lucius King of the Britains ≈øent an Epi≈øtle vnto him, be≈øeeching him that by his commandement Henricus Huntingt. Hi≈øt. l. 1. in Marco Antonino Vero & Aurelio Lucio CoÃÑ modo. Harding Cronicle in King Lucius c. 51. f. 43. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. de Vita S. Dubtitij. Io.
