Capgrauius Catal. in eod. he might be made √† Chri≈øtian: Cum Eleutherius Pontificatui Romanae Eccle≈øiae praee≈ø≈øet, mi≈øit ad eum Lucius Britanniarum Rex Epi≈øtolam, ob≈øecrans vt per eius maÃÑdatum Chri≈øtianus efficeretur. Harding ≈øaith this was done, at the ≈øupplication of Lucius. The old Manu≈øcript of the life of S. Dubritius, which Capgraue and others followe, witne≈ø≈øeth, that King Lucius ≈øent two Amba≈ø≈øadors Eluan and Medwine to Pope Eleutherius that he might be made a Chri≈øtian according to his direction: Lucius Britannorum Rex ad Eleutherium Papam Legatos mi≈øit, ≈øtilicet Eluanum & Meduinum, vt iuxta eius ammonitionem Chri≈øtianus fieret. And in the life of S. Helen the Empre≈ø≈øe our Country woman: Lucius Epi≈øtolas Eleutherio Papae humiliter direxit, petens vt ab eo fidem Chri≈øtianam recicipere mereretur, King Lucius did humbly direct Epi≈øtles to Pope Eleutherius, de≈øiring that he might be thought worthie to receaue the Chri≈øtian faith from him. The like hath Ado: Lucius Britannorum Rex mi≈ø≈øa ad Eleutherium Romae Epi≈øcopum Epi≈øtol√†, vt Chri≈øtianus efficeretur, petijt. Many others (and they auncient Catholike writers of greate credet) there be, both of this and other M. S. in Vita S. Helenae. Et Capgrau. in ead. Nations, which thus confidently for mo≈øt certaine deliuer this Hi≈øtory vnto vs, which for auoiding tediou≈ønes I omit, as I might haue ouerpa≈ø≈øed many of the≈øe: but to shew to my Readers, that the mi≈øtakings of ≈øome Scribes before remembred, and reconciled, about times and Titles doe nothing hinder Ado in Chron. inter an. 163. & 181. the vndoubted, and vnque≈øtionable truth of the Relation hereof. That the
generall Conuer≈øion of this kingdome to Chri≈øt was happily brought to pa≈ø≈øe in the time of Pope Eleutherius, by his direction, warrant and Papall Authoritie.

3. For confirmation whereof by all manner of Antiquaries, euen our Prote≈øtants mo≈øt aduer≈øe to the prerogatiues of the holy Apo≈øtolike Roman See, they generally con≈øent vnto it in this Order. Matthias Flaccus, Illiricus, Ioannes Vuigandus, Matthaeus Index, and Ba≈øilius Faber the Magdeburgian Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians haue thus of this matter: Lucius ad Eleutherium Romanae Eccle≈øiae Centur. 2. cap. 2. col. 8. Epi≈øcopum, Eluanum & Meduuinum Britannos doctrina prae≈øtantes mittit, & rogat, vt inde Doctores quo≈ødam accipiat, qui Christianam Religionem in ≈øuo Regno, abolito toto Ethnichi≈ømo in≈øtaurent. King Lucius of Britaine ≈øent two excellently learned Britans, Eluanus, and Meduuinus, to Eleutherius Bishop of the Church of Rome, and de≈øired him, that he might receaue ≈øome Doctours from thence, that might e≈øtablish Chri≈øtian Religion in his kingdome, and abolish Heathen ≈øuper≈øtition out of it. And they alledge Gildas Albanius, that this King was addicted to Chri≈øtian Religion euen from the beginnig of his Reigne: Non erat omnino iniquus Lucius Chri≈øtianorum Religioni, ≈øtatim initio ≈øui Imperijmouebatur enim nonnihil miraculis illu≈øtribus quae √† Christianis in te≈øtimonium & ornamentum ≈øuae doctrinae pa≈øsim edebantur: vt Gildas Albanius in libro de victoria Aurelij Ambro≈øij refert. A Prote≈øtant Bishop of England, whome the≈øe Magdeburgians cite and follow, writeth in like manner: cum Io. Bal. l. de Scriptor. Brit. cent. 1. in Lucio & Eluano, & Meduuino. audi≈ø≈øet per ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e≈øaris Legatos Trebellium & Pertinacem Romanorum illu≈øtres aliquot, quie≈øcente Per≈øecutione, Chri≈øtianam Religionem admi≈øi≈ø≈øe, ≈øtatim per eruditos Britannos, Eluanum & Meduuinum, ad Eleutherium Romanorum Ponti≈øicem mi≈øit ac ≈øcrip≈øit pro ≈øu≈øcipiendo Bapti≈ømo Epistolam. When King Lucius vnder≈øtood by the Emperours Amba≈ø≈øadours, Trebellius and Pertinax, that Per≈øecution again≈øt Chri≈øtians was cea≈øed, and ≈øome of the renowned of the Romans had embraced Chri≈øtian Religion, he pre≈øently ≈øent and wrote an Epi≈øtle to Eleutherius Pope of Rome by learned BritaÃÑs Eluanus & Meduuinus, to haue Bapti≈øme receaued heare. And he ≈øufficiently in≈øinuateth there as the Magdeburgians before haue done, that he would haue done this ≈øooner but for feare of the Roman Emperours, by who≈øe permi≈ø≈øion and Authoritie, as this man Bal. ≈øupr. ≈øaith, he was King in Britaine, making him litle better then a King by courte≈øie onely: Lucius Pius, Coilli Regis filius vnicus, Romanorum fautor, Cae≈øaris Marci Matth. Parker. Antiq. Brit. p. 4. Antonini Veri & beneuolentia & authoritate, Britannis po≈øt patrem imperabat. The fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury ≈øetting downe the ≈øame motiue, and how by the Romans example the Chri≈øtian faith was now receaued in all Prouinces, addeth for King Lucius: Ad Eleutherium Romanum Pontificem illu≈øtres & facundos viros Eluanum Aualonium, & Meduinum Belgam, cum literis & mandatis legauit: In quibus petijt, vt ad ≈øe iam doctrina Chri≈øtiana imbutum Nuncios ac Legatos, √† quibus Bapti≈ømate lauaretur, mitteret: King Lucius ≈øent renowned Iewell again≈øt Harding. 119. Godwin conu. of Britan. Catal. of Bishop. Theater of great Britaine l. 6. Selden Analect. Rob. Barn. l. de vit. Pontif. Rom. in Eleutherio. Stow Hi≈øt. in Lucius. men Eluan of Aualonia, and Medwin a Belgian to Eleutherius Pope of Rome with letters, and commandements, in which he reque≈øted, that he would ≈øend Me≈ø≈øengers and Legats to bapti≈øe him allready in≈øtructed in Chri≈øtian doctrine. His Prote≈øtant Succe≈ø≈øours Whitegift again≈øt the Puretans and George Abbot directour of Francis Ma≈øon in their Booke of Con≈øecration, as they followed him in place, ≈øo in this opinion: So their Prote≈øtant Bishops Iewell, and Godwine: So teacheth the whole company of Prote≈øtant Antiquaries in their Theater of Britaine: So their particular Hi≈øtorians and writers Barnes, Selden, Stowe with others: Lucius Britanniae Rex Chri≈øtiano coetui cum ≈øuis ≈øubditis adiungi petijt,
‚Ä¢ er litteras. An other ≈øaith: King Lucius ≈øent his two Amba≈ø≈øadours Eluanus and Meduuinus, two learned meÃÑ in the Scripturs, with his louing letters to Eleutherius Bishop of Rome, de≈øiring him to ≈øend ≈øome deuoute and learned men, by who≈øe InstructioÃÑ both he and his people might be taught the faith and Religion of Chri≈øt. And the≈øe Prote≈øtants doe not ≈øtay their pens heare, in giuing this ≈øupreame prerogatiue King Lucius did not onely ≈øend to the Pope, to obtaine the ≈øetling of Religion heare, but to e≈øtablish the temporall ≈øtate and Lawes of this kingdome, as our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries with others acknowledge. and preemineÃÑcie to the See of Rome, for the ordering & ≈øetling of ≈øpirituall affayres, but goe further enforming vs, that this holy King of Britaine Lucius, ≈øo renowned in all Antiquities, did appeale to the ≈øame Pope of Rome to haue the temporall and Ciuile Lawes of this Nation to be framed, and enacted, and ≈øo ≈øetled by his Authoritie. And diuers of them are ≈øo earne≈øt herein that they ≈øay King Lucius ≈øent at this time, and by the≈øe Amba≈ø≈øadours for obtayning thereof. Their fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop is playne in this opinion, for hauing, as before, ≈øett downe the Amba≈ø≈øadge our King ≈øent to Pope Eleutherius, de≈øiring to haue In≈øtructours ≈øent hither to ≈øetle Chri≈øtian Religion; he immediately addeth with a connectiue phra≈øe of ≈øpeach, entreating that tho≈øe Legats this Pope should ≈øend hither for e≈øtablishing Religion, should al≈øo Matth. Parker. Antiq. Brit. p. 4. bring with them the Roman Lawes by which he might de≈øcribe and e≈øtablish the ≈øtate of Religion, and common wealth in his kingdome. Quique vn√† deferrent Romanas leges, quibus Religionis & Reipublicae ≈øtatum in Regno ≈øuo de≈øcriberet, atque ≈øtabiliret. This mans opinion together with diuers others of the Prote≈øtant profe≈ø≈øion concerning this matter, is related by a Prot ‚Ä¢ ≈øtant Bishop and Antiquarie, in this manner: Lucius ≈øome time after his Conuer≈ø ‚Ä¢ on (but whether Godwin Conu. of Brit. p. 29. 30. before or after his Bapti≈øme appeareth not) made reque≈øt vnto Eleutherius to ≈øend him ≈øome kind ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ b≈øtract of the Roman Lawes, whereby he might establish a ≈øetled Order of Gouernment in his Dominions.

4. Now whereas the Druids were the Iudges of all matters both in Cae≈øar com. l. 6. ≈øpirituall and temporall gouernment: fer√® de omnibus controuer≈øijs publicis priuatisque con≈øtituunt, & ≈øi quod e≈øt admi≈ø≈øum facinus, ≈øi caedes facta, ≈øi de haereditate, de finibus controuer≈øia e≈øt, ijdem decernunt praemia, poena≈øque con≈øtituunt. The abolishing of the≈øe Druids made an alteration, in politick matters a≈øwell as Eccle≈øia≈øticall, or concerning Religion, ≈øo that the cau≈øe of reformation in both kindes being one and the ≈øelfe ≈øame, I ≈øee no rea≈øon why we should not thinke, that the remedie of both was likewi≈øe ≈øought at once. And true it is, that the Authour of the booke called Antiquitates Britannicae (Matthew Parker their Prote≈øtant fir≈øt Archbishop la≈øt cited) affirmeth, how that Eluan and Medwin made the fore≈øaid motion for the Roman Lawes, at their being with Eleutherius before the Bapti≈øme of Lucius, and then receaued an≈øweare: So doth Foxe. Iewell contra Hard. p. 119. M. Foxe, and the Reuerend Father of happy memory Bishop Iewell (thus one brother commendeth an other) ≈øeemeth to be of the ≈øame opinion. Yet becau≈øe the Authours of our greate Chronicle, Holinshead, and the re≈øt deliuer that this motion was made after the Bapti≈øme of Lucius, but al≈øo ≈øetting downe preci≈øely the particular time, doe ≈øay it was in the third yeare of his Conuer≈øion, I will not take vpon mee to pronounce eyther the one way, or other, but leaue it vnto the Readers Iudgment and di≈øcretion to determine of, hitherto this Prote≈øtant Bishop for him≈øelfe and his adherents in Religion concerning this matter. This motion and reque≈øt of King Lucius to the Pope about the temporall ‚Ä¢ awes, was after his fir≈øt Amba≈ø≈øag ‚Ä¢ and receauing Chri≈øtian ReligioÃÑ.

5. But bccau≈øe he leaueth the determination hereof to his Readers Iudgment & di≈øcretion, I being one of his Readers will take vpoÃÑ me thus to determine again≈øt him, his Brethren the Prote≈øtant Bishops, and the re≈øt by their owne te≈øtimonie & citation, for all the≈øe which he named as him≈øelfe al≈øo cite at lardge the letter of Pope Eleutherius to King Lucius about this bu≈øines, and
it is all the light of this relation, which is left vnto vs in Hi≈øtories: And therein Pope Eleutherius telleth vs plainely that this motion, and an≈øweare vnto it, were after the publike Conuer≈øion of this Country, and after it had receaued al≈øo the holy Scripturs: ≈øu≈øcepi≈øtis nuper mi≈øeratione diuina in Regno Britanniae legem & fidem Chri≈øti: habetis penes vos in Regno vtramque paginam. And ≈øeeing they were the Apo≈øtolike men, which were ≈øent hither by Pope Eleutherius to conuert the kingdome to Chri≈øt, Which were principally to be employed, for collecting and ≈øetling ≈øuch lawes, as appeareth by the ≈øame Epi≈øtle, they had worke enough of an higher nature, and greater nece≈ø≈øitie, the ≈øpirituall Conuer≈øion of ≈øo greate a Country, to attend vnto, before any lea≈øure was left vnto them, to take the other of le≈ø≈øer con≈øequence in hand. And vntill they could both be in due manner effected, no man of ordinary Iudgment, much le≈ø≈øe of happy memory may thinke, but tho≈øe conuerted Britans which had committed their ≈øoules vnto the Cen≈øure and direction of tho≈øe their ≈øpirituall guides, and relied vpon them for their eternall being and ble≈ø≈øednes, would and did mo≈øt willingly referre them≈øelues for ciuill debats, vntill a ≈øetled Order could be publikely prouided, to decide and end ≈øuch doubts, and difficulties. And they well knew, this was the Coun≈øaile and direction, if not commandement of S. Paule to Chri≈øtians in like ca≈øe.

6. And diuers of the≈øe men differ, and erre a≈ømuch in deliuering their opinion of the≈øe two Amba≈ø≈øadours of King Lucius, of what Country, Prouince Matth. Parker. Antiq. Brit. ≈øupr. p. 4. Godwin. Conu. of Brit. p. 21. or place they were. Their fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop before hath ≈øaid, that Eluanus was Aualonius, and Meduuinus was Belga. An other Prote≈øtant Bishop doth thus interprete him and others in this matter: The Authour of the Booke called Antiquitates Britannicae, and Bale out of Leland report, how that Medwin was by birth a Dutchman, but as for Eluan he was a Brittain brought vp in the Colledge or Mona≈øtery of Auallon amongst the Di≈øciples and Succe≈ø≈øours of Io≈øeph of Arimathia. The Prote≈øtant Authours of the greate Theater of great Britaine Theater of great Brit. l. 6. ≈øpeaking of the place giuen to S. Io≈øeph of Arimathia Aualon, or Gla≈øtenbury ≈øay: from hence were tho≈øe two diuine Doctours ≈øent to Eleutherius What, and from whence the Amba≈ø≈øadors of King Lucius, to the Pope, were. by King Lucius, as by their Epithets doth appeare: one of them called Eluanus Aualonius, or of Gla≈øtenbury: and the other Meduuinus of Belga, that is welles, neare vnto this place; And they note in their Margin: Two Diuins ≈øent by Lucius to Rome from Glastenbury. And thus: welles called Belga. But is is greate ignorance fir≈øt, and dishonour to this Nation, to ≈øay any of the≈øe was a Dutchman. all Antiquaries, Catholiks, and Prote≈øtants teaching they were both Britans. And the word Belga there, hath reference to tho≈øe people in Britaine which were called Belgae, and inhabited the Prouinces now named Somer≈øetshire, Camdenus in Belga. wilshire, and part of Hampshire, as Cambden according to true Antiquitie relateth vnto them: Ad Belgas no≈øtras qui long√® lat√©que habitarunt per Regionem Sommer≈øetten≈øem, Wiltonien≈øem, Hantonien≈øisque agri partem interiorem, accedamus. And for welles, which they ≈øay was then called Belga, is as farre wide from truth, the people of tho≈øe places being onely named Belgae, and no e≈øpeciall Towne or place to giue denomination to all tho≈øe Countries, and the Towne of welles as the ≈øame Prote≈øtant Bishop is witnes, was a Villadge long after that time, named Tiddington builded or named by the Saxons as that name declareth: thus he being an inhabitant there ≈øome time writeth: welles, that ≈øometimes Godwin. Catal. of Bishops in dathe and Welles. heretofore was called Tiddington, is not a Towne of any verie greate Antiquity. And there proueth, how King Inas in the yeare 704. and King Kenulphus 60. yeares after, fir≈øt made it of any name, and tooke the denomination welles of
weluue or wielea a little Ryuer or Brooke there, as appeareth often in the Charter Chart. Regis Kenulphi Mona≈øterio de Weluuean. D. 766. ‚Ä¢ pud Godwin. ≈øupr. p. 358. 359. Godwin. Bathe and Welles p. 38. num. 49. of King Kenulphus bearing date an. Dom. Incarn. 766. Indictione 12. to a Mona≈øtery or Colledge there, being a Towne of no memory at this time, as ≈øayeth this Prote≈øtaÃÑt Bishop & Antiquary, mo≈øt likely to learne & tell the truth therein, becau≈øe, to v≈øe his words, Thomas Godwyn his deere and mo≈øt Reuerend Father was made Protestant Bishop there Sept. 13. 1584. So the people Belgae could not take their name of this place, nor eyther of the≈øe Amba≈ø≈øadours of King Lucius or any other be called Belga, by that imaginary Title. Neyther was, or could eyther of them, or any other at that time be truely ≈øaid to be an Auellonian, for I haue proued before, and shall more plainely ≈øett forth hereafter, that there was no Mona≈øtery, or Re≈øidence of any Chri≈øtians there at that time, but S. Io≈øephs Chappell was de≈øolate, ferarum Latibulum.

7. Neyther doth any Antiquitie to my reading and memory ≈øay, that the≈øe Me≈ø≈øengers or Amba≈ø≈øadours were of ≈øuch places, as the≈øe men haue ≈øtiled them by, but it is onely a new Prote≈øtant Chimericall Inuention of their owne, and if there had bene any remnant of the Chri≈øtian po≈øteritie and Succe≈ø≈øion from S. Io≈øeph left about Gla≈øtenbury, King Lucius would not haue cho≈øen a Catechumen from them, to ≈øend about ≈øuch important bu≈øines: neyther could this imagined Gla≈øtenbury man haue bene ignorant of the Chappell of S. Io≈øeph when it was ≈øo diligently ≈øought for, and founde out by S. Damianus, and Fugatianus, as the Antiquities of that place, and ≈øome of the≈øe Prote≈øtants Antiquitates Gla≈øt. apud Capg ‚Ä¢ au. in S. Io≈øeph & Patricio. Leland. in Arthur. Antiq. Gla≈øt. tabulis ‚Ä¢ igneis affixae in membr. Guliel. Malm. Hi≈øt. Manu≈øcr. de Antiq. caeno
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ j G ‚Ä¢ a≈øt. Io. P ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øaeus l. de vir ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Illu≈øtr. aetat. 2. in Eluano. & Meduuino. them≈øelues are witne≈ø≈øes, if he had in≈øtruction and education there. So I cannot con≈øent vnto the≈øe Prote≈øtants in this point: Neyther ioyne in opinion with that late Catholike writer, who citing no Authoritie, affirmeth of Eluanus that he was brought vp in the Schoole of S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, and learned the My≈øteries of the Chri≈øtian faith from the Di≈øciples of the Apo≈øtles: Eluanus Aualonius, natione Britannus, in Schola S. Io≈øephi Arimathen≈øis educatus, ab ip≈øis Apostolorum Di≈øcipulis fidei Chri≈øtianae my≈øteria didicit Iunior. And of Meduuinus he ≈øaith: He was a Belgian of that part of Britaine which is about welles, and was aunciently called Belgia. For to an≈øwere fir≈øt to the later, allthough the Country about welles, was part of tho≈øe Prouinces which the Belgae inhabited, being part of Sommer≈øetshire, which with wiltshire, and Hampshire, or a greate part thereof was inhabited by the Belgae, and ≈øo all the≈øe together were, or might be named Belgia: Yet this doth no more proue, if he were a Belgian, that he was borne neare vnto welles, then to any Towne or Village els, either in Sommer≈øetshire, wiltshire, or the parts of Hampshire within that denomination, all of them being as truely and properly parts of Belgia, as welles, or any part of that Country neare vnto it. Yet this Authour no more proueth, that Eluanus was a Belgian, then the Prote≈øtants before, again≈øt whome I haue shewed he could not be a Belgian. His other a≈ø≈øertion of Eluanus being brought vp in the Schoole of S. Io≈øeph is too manife≈øt a mi≈øtaking, for I haue proued in the fir≈øt Age, that S. Io≈øeph, and all of that company, or Schoole, as this Authour termeth it, were dead within the fir≈øt huÃÑdred yeares of Chri≈øt, long before Eluanus was borne. Neyther is it credible with mee, that any of the immediate Di≈øciples (for he ≈øpeaketh in the plurall number ab ip≈øis Apo≈øtolorum Di≈øcipulis) of the Apo≈øtles, were liuing heare in Britaine in the Papacie of Eleutherius when this man was but a Catechumen, by them that hold he was fir≈øt ≈øent to Rome from King Lucius after Eleutherius was now Pope: or by tho≈øe which (as before) a≈ø≈øigne his going to Rome twenty yeares ≈øooner, for betweene this and the death of the Apo≈øtles S. Peter and S.
Paule, are 87. yeares at the lea≈øt, and who≈øoeuer were, or could be accompted their Di≈øciples in proper ≈øen≈øe, were ≈øo old at the Apo≈øtles death, that if now liuing, and heare in Britaine, they were an hundred yeares of age. Of which age in this Country I dare not take vpon mee to finde Di≈øciples of the Apo≈øtles. Onely I graunt, (as I haue done before) that by the greate prouidence of God, one of this Nation and S. Peters Di≈øciple S. Man≈øuetus, was probably then liuing, but he was but one, and liued mo≈øt at Tullum or Treuers, where he was Bishop farre from Gla≈øtenbury or any part of Britaine.

8. And if there had bene any probable Authoritie that the≈øe men had bene borne in that part, I would haue thought my phra≈øe harsh in Hi≈øtory, if I had termed the one of them an Aualonian, and the other a Belgian, for the Ile of Aualon, is hard by welles, Gla≈øtenbury it≈øelfe but three English miles from welles, and part of Belgia, a≈øwell as welles and ≈øo euery Aualonian was a Belgian, and a Belgian borne about welles, in ea circa welliam parte, was not vnproperly an Aualonian, the Ile of Aualon there circuiting about it; & no Chri≈øtian was probably in that part of the Country but in Aualonia, the onely Re≈øidency of S. Io≈øeph and his holy company, and onely alloted and enfranchi≈øed for Chri≈øtians by the donation and priuiledge of our Kings then Aruiragus, Marius, and Coillus. And Eluanus brought vp and in≈øtructed where S. Io≈øeph liued, as this Authour & our Prote≈øtants before haue written, if it were ≈øo, could not po≈ø≈øibly be ignorant of that very place where he liued, and was in≈øtructed in the Chri≈øtian faith, neyther ≈øo neare a neighbour and companion vnto him as Meduuinus was, by the≈øe writers, could be without all knowledge thereof, yet by all the Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury before, neythe ‚Ä¢ of them knew this Man≈øion of S. Io≈øeph, the mo≈øt memorable and reuerenced place of this kingdome then with Chri≈øtians. Therefore we mu≈øt trauaile further then any part of Belgia to finde (but with probabilitie) where the≈øe Amba≈ø≈øadours, were borne and in≈øtructed in the Chri≈øtian faith in Britaine before they were ≈øent to Rome. Cambridge hath pleaded for them before with more congruitie and le≈ø≈øe inconuenience, then any part of the Belgae inhabitants can doe, ≈øo perhaps might Stamford, Burton where the Cambridge Schollers are thought to haue bene bapti≈øed, ≈øo might diuers Schooles of the Druids where were many learned men ≈øuch as Eluanus and Meduuinus are de≈øcribed vnto vs, ≈øo farre remote froÃÑ the Belgae and Gla≈øtenbury, and lately in≈øtructed in the faith of Chri≈øt, that they might pleade Ignorance without ≈øinne or shame of S. Io≈øeph his Chappell, and Eremiticall habitation. I may likewi≈øe ≈øo ≈øay of the Court it≈øelfe of King L ‚Ä¢ cius, where ≈øo many learned Chri≈øtians, and Catechumens were now, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ whence the≈øe were ≈øent, as the cu≈øtome and v≈øadge of Kings is to ≈øend „Äà‚óä„Äâ Amba≈ø≈øadours ≈øuch as be in grace in Court with them. In all which places many learned men then liued, but no ≈øuch, no Schoole or place of learning, at this time for any thing I finde in Antiquities, was about, or neare to welles, or Aualon, then it being a De≈øart. From whence in particular they were, I dare ‚Ä¢ ot yet for want of ≈øufficient warrant, certainely determine.

div.head: THE XV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THE MISSION OF THE HOLY LEGATS S. Damianus, Fugatianus Bishops, and diuers others from S. Eleutherius Pope of Rome, at the reque≈øt of S. Lucius King heare in Britaine, by Authoritie to plant, and ≈øetle heare the true Chri≈øtian Religion.

div.p: 1. THe≈øe renowned Brittish Amba≈ø≈øadours of King Lucius, being now arriued at Rome, with letters, Commi≈ø≈øion, and In≈øtructions, for their proceeding, in ≈øo greate and important bu≈øines, pre≈øented them≈øelues with their Kings humble and earne≈øt petition to the holy Pope Eleutherius: Whether they came now immediately from Britaine, as mo≈øt ≈øeeme to affirme, or had bene for ≈øome, and no short time before in Rome, and in ≈øtudies there and In≈øtruction in Chri≈øtian Religion to enable them for ≈øuch Eccle≈øia≈øticall Degrees and functions, as they were now shortly to receaue, as our Cambridge Antiquaries and others a≈ø≈øi≈øted with no contemptible rea≈øons haue allready deliuered, and now receaued the≈øe letters and Commi≈ø≈øion from King Lucius about our generall Conuer≈øion I referre my Readers to that I haue written before of this matter. But how≈øoeuer that is to be re≈øolued, it is generally agreed vpon among Antiquaries, that vpon the deliuery of this Amba≈ø≈øadge, the holy Pope Eleutherius appointed for his Legats S. Damianus and Fugatianus, with power and In≈øtructions to come hither, to effect that happy bu≈øines. And ≈øome ≈øay that among others de≈øigned for worthie labourers in this renowned worke, the≈øe Amba≈ø≈øadours of King Lucius were pre≈øently employed about it. The old Brittish Manu≈øcript Antiquitie of the auncient Church of Landaffe thus relateth it: Eleutherius gratias agens Deo ≈øuo, quod illa gens, quae √† primo Antiquit. Eccle≈ø. Landau. Manu≈øcript. Peruetu≈øt. Regionis inhabitatore Bruto gentilis fuerat, tam ardenter ad fidem Chri≈øti festinabat, con≈øilio ≈øenioris vrbis Romae placuit eo≈ødem Legatos baptizari, & Catholica fide ≈øu≈øcepta, ordinari Eluanum in Epi≈øcopum, Meduuinum autem in Doctorem: Et propter eloquentiam, & ≈øcientiam quam habebant in ≈øacris Scripturis, Praedicatores ad Lucium in Britanniam reuer≈øi ≈øunt: Pope Eleutheri ‚Ä¢ s giuing thanks to God, that the Nation which from Brutus the fir≈øt Inhabiter of the Country had bene euer Pagan did ≈øo feruently ha≈øten to the faith of Christ, it was agreed vpon by the Coun≈øaile of the elder Rome, that the ≈øame Amba≈ø≈øadours should be baptized, and hauing receaued the Catholike faith, Eluan should be con≈øecrated a Bishop, and Medwin made a Doctour or Teacher: And in re≈øpect of the eloquence and knowledge which they had in holy Scripturs they returned Preachers vnto King Lucius in Britaine. The old Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory of the life of S. Dubricius and Capgraue following it, Manu≈øcrip. Antiq. de Vit. S. Dubr ‚Ä¢ cij. Capgrau. Catal. in S. Dubricio. haue the verie ≈øame words of that Antiquitie, ≈øo farre as it concerneth this narration.

2. I finde few others that be auncient, which write of the con≈øecrating any of the≈øe Amba≈ø≈øadors of King Lucius to be a Bishop, but ≈øpeake generally
of the Roman Legats, Damianus and Fugatianus pre≈øentl ‚Ä¢ ≈øent hither from Pope Eleutherius with others to be In≈øtruments in performing this greate de≈øignment. S. Gildas, Nennius, S. Bede, Marianus, Florentius wigornien≈øis, Ethelwerdus, Matthew We≈øtmin≈øter, WilliaÃÑ Malmesburie, HeÃÑry of HuntingtoÃÑ, Radulphus de Diceto, Martinus, Harding, Ado, Platina, with others writing of this Amba≈ø≈øadge of King Lucius, and S. Eleutherius ≈øending his Legats hither about the effecting our Kings reque≈øt, are ≈øilent of this con≈øecrating, and ≈øending Eluanus & Meduuinus hither againe at this time, or after in ≈øuch manner, as the others write. And the Roman Antiquities of this matter, which Baronius termeth the aunciente≈øt of King Lucius Acts, vetu≈øtiora de Lucio monumenta, Monum. Vet. apud Baron. To. 2. Annal. an. 183. though they ≈øay King Lucius ≈øent the≈øe two Amba≈ø≈øadors Eluanus and Meduuinus to Pope Eleutherius, about the CoÃÑuer≈øion of Britaine, yet they onely te≈øtifie, that King Lucius his ≈øuite was to haue it effected by Pope Eleutherius, and ≈øuch as he should thinke fitte≈øt to vndertake that labour, & how he therevpon ≈øent Fugatius, and Donatianus, otherwi≈øe called Damianus, to effect it as they did, neuer naming further Eluanus or Meduuinus Agent herein. Lucius Legationem mi≈øit per Eluanum & MeduuinuÃÑ Britannos: rogans per eos Eleutherum, vt per ≈øe, ≈øuosque mini≈øtros ad Chri≈øtianam Religionem ≈øu≈øcipiendam, aditum patefaceret: quod & obtinuit. Nam Idem pontifex Fugatium & Donatianum, aliter Damianum, in Britanniam mi≈øit. And diuers of our Prote≈øtants which relate Magdeb. cent. 2. col. 8. Io. Funccius l. 6. commeÃÑ tar. in Chronol. ad An. 178. Ioan. Bal. li. de Scritp. Brit. ceÃÑt. 1. in Lucio, Eluano, & Meduuino. Idem l. de vitis Pontif. Rom. in Eleuth. Rob. Barns l. de Pontif. Rom. in Eleutherio. Godwin Conu. of Britaine p. 21. this Hi≈øtorie, make no memory therein of Pope Eleutherius his con≈øecrating, and ≈øending Eluanus and Meduuinus hither: ≈øuch be the Magdeburgian writers, Funccius, Barns, and their Bishop Bale, allthough in his booke of writers dedicated to King Edward the ≈øixt, he expre≈ø≈øely handleth this matter, both in King Lucius, Eluanus, and Meduuinus, and there ≈øpeaketh of the≈øe men ≈øent to Eleutherius at Rome, yet he is ≈øilent of their con≈øecration there, ≈øeeming to thinke they were con≈øecratd in Britaine before their going to Rome: per Apo≈øtolicos viros in Chri≈øto renati, in dispen≈øandis Dei mini≈øterijs inter primos haberentur. And in his Booke of the liues of Popes writen after, he ≈øpeaketh not of them at all, when he handleth this matter in Pope Eleutherius. And an other 4. Prote≈øtant Bishop and Antiquary though he holdeth with them that ≈øay Pope Eleutherius made Eluanus a Bishop, and ≈øent both him, and Meduuinus hither, yet he addeth: by mo≈øt it is affirmed, how that Eleutherius ≈øent with the≈øe two before named S. EluaÃÑ, and Medwin, two other, to order the ≈øtate of the Church, who had the honour of performing that office. The one of them is called by ≈øome Damianus, by others Duuanus, and by others againe Deruianus, Dimianus, Diuianus, and Donatianus. the other is ≈øometimes termed Faganus, and ≈øometimes Fugatius. And the other la≈øt cited Prote≈øtant Bishop confirmeth Bal. ≈øup. in Lucio. Eluan. & Meduuino. Matth. Parker. Antiq. Brit. p. 5. Stowe Hi≈øt. & Howes An. 179. in Lucius. Io. Go≈øcelin. Hi≈øt. Manu≈øcr. de Archiep. CaÃÑt. in Lucio. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of England l. 4. c. 19. this, telling vs, all things were ordered by tho≈øe two Legats of Pope Eleutherius.

3. This is ≈øufficiently yeelded vnto, by their fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury, and by mo≈øt, as the other hath before acknowledgde. And Go≈øcelin in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory of the Archbishops of Canterbury, relating this Hi≈øtory of King Lucius ≈øending Eluanus and Meduuinus, is ≈øilent of any con≈øecration or mi≈ø≈øion they receaued at Rome, but a≈ø≈øcribeth the ordering of all Eccle≈øia≈øticall matters heare to the Legats of Pope Eleutherius: Fugatius vna cum Damiano ‚Ä¢ uc remi≈ø≈øus Chri≈øtianam Religionem in Regno in≈øtaurant, & & tota Ethnici≈ømo abolito ≈øolid√® con≈øtituunt. Holinshed in his Hi≈øtory of England is al≈øo ≈øilent in this con≈øecration of our Amba≈ø≈øadors, onely ≈øaying of them: King Lucius ≈øent vnto Eleutherius Bishop of Rome two learned men of the
Brittish Nation ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ an and Medwine requiring him to ≈øend ≈øome ≈øuch Mini≈øters as might in≈øtruct him and his people in the true faith more plentifully, and to Baptize them according to the Rules of Chri≈øtian Religion. Heareupon were ≈øent from the ≈øaid Eleutherius two godly learned men, the one named Fugatius, and the other Damianus. How they performed this chardge committed vnto them by Pope Eleutherius in the opinion of this Prote≈øtaÃÑt, he shall with others te≈øtifie, when I come to entreate of their proceedings heare. Our Prote≈øtant Authours of the Theater of greate Britaine relying much vpon the Authoritie of the Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory of Radulphus de Diceto, ≈øometime Deane of S. Pauls Church Theater of great Brit. l. 6. in London, in the Kings library as they cite him, mu≈øt be of the ≈øame minde, that the chardge of this greate bu≈øines was committed by Pope Eleutherius to his Legats, Faganus, and Damianus, for he writeth ≈øo, and that all things heare Radulph. de Diceto in Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. inter ann. 170. & 180. Io. Leland in a≈ø≈øert. Arthurij. Pri≈øeus defen≈ø. Hi≈øt. Brit. p. 73. 74. Selden Analect. c. 6. Whitg. defen≈ø. of the An≈øwere p. 323. Foxe To. 1. f. 146. Ma≈øon l. 2. c. 3. p. 52. 55. Godwin Catal. of Bishops of Yorke. ‚Ä¢ n Panlinus. 1. Winche≈øter 1. were ≈øetled by their Legatine Authoritie. Leland in his Defence of King Authour, and Sir Ihon Pri≈øe of the Brittish Hi≈øtory, affirmeth the like, citing diuers others for warrant. M. Selden relateth this matter as the others haue done before, that King Lucius craued the direction & a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Pope Eleutherius herein, Pontificem Romanum, qui tunc fuit, Eleutherium vt cum ≈øuis Chri≈øtiano nomine ob≈øignaretur, mandatis literis con≈øuluit. And he ≈øent Fugatius and Damianus very learned, and holy men to conuert this Country, Fugatium & Damianum imprimis doctos, in≈øigni≈øque pietatis viros mi≈øit. So write their two Archbishops white gift, and Abbots, M. Foxe, & Francis Ma≈øon. And that Prote≈øtaÃÑt Bishop him≈øelfe who before would not haue this ≈øo vndoubted a truth, as the≈øe his fellowes in Religion haue made it, when afterwards he came to ≈øounder Iudgment, and better reflected vpon this Hi≈øtory and grounds thereof, maketh it a veritie vndeniable in this manner: It cannot be denyed but Eleutherius Bishop of Rome at the reque≈øt of Lucius then King of Britaine, ≈øent Damianus, Faganus and other learned Preachers to ≈øowe the ≈øeed of the Ghospell heare. And in other places proueth from Antiquities, that the≈øe Legats of Pope Eleutherius exerci≈øed Apo≈øtolike Legatine Power by Commi≈ø≈øion from that holy Pope in this kingdome.

4. And of this their Power & Commi≈ø≈øion from Pope Eleutherius we are a≈ø≈øured by all Antiquities of this matter. I will epitomate ≈øome of them to shew how euident and cleare a truth it is, and (though they be not fir≈øt in prioritie of time) begin with tho≈øe which haue written of the con≈øecration, and mi≈ø≈øion of Eluan and Medwin hither, from the See Apo≈øtolike of Rome, which I doe not deny, but onely di≈øallowe that they were the cheife≈øt in this bu≈øines: which the≈øe very Authours al≈øo te≈øtifie. For the Antiquities of Landaffe ≈øay, that King Lucius made his petition to Pope Eleutherius to haue his Country conuerted by his direction, and obtayned it. Implorans, vt iuxta eius ammonitionem Antiq. Eccl. Landauen. Chri≈øtianus fieret, quod ab eo impetrauit. And it followeth in the ≈øame Antiquitie, that Eccle≈øia≈øticall matters were ≈øetled heare according to the order or commandement of Pope Eleutherius: ≈øecundum iu≈ø≈øum beati Eleutherij Papae, Eccle≈øia≈øticum ordinem constituit. The Antiquitie of the life of S. Dubricius, Manu≈øcr. de Vit. S. Dubricij. & Io. Capgrau. in cod. and Capgraue, al≈øo the other Authours haue the ≈øame fir≈øt words, which containe the ≈øecond: vt iuxta eius ammonitionem Chri≈øtianus fieret. And in the life of S. Helen after, he maketh it mo≈øt manife≈øt, that as the truth is, he held with all Antiquitie, that King Lucius did both humbly entreate Pope Eleutherius, to giue order & direction for the ≈øetling of Chri≈øtian Religion heare in Britaine, and he ≈øent hither his Legats, Damianus, and Fugatius with direction and power to performe it, and they accordingly effected it in all re≈øpects.
Lucius Epi≈øtolas Eleutherio Papae humiliter direxit petens, vt ab eo fidem Chri≈øtianaÃÑ
Io. Capgrauius in Catalogo. in S. Helena Regina. recipere mereretur. Beatus ergo Pontifex ille compert√¢ eius maxim√¢ deuotione duos religio≈øi≈øsimos viros Fugacium videlicet & Damianum ad illum mi≈øit.

5. How the≈øe Apo≈øtolike men did order and actually ≈øetle all Eccle≈øia≈øticall bu≈øine≈ø≈øes heare, I shall deliuer from this, as other Authours in due place. Now I ≈øpeake onely of their Power and Commi≈ø≈øion granted vnto them by Pope Eleutherius. The old Roman Monuments cited by Baronius, and the Monum. Antiq. apud Baron. To. 2. Annal. an. 183. Dama≈øus in Eleutherio. Martyrol. Rom. 26. die Maij. receaued Acts of Eleutherius, which the Church approueth, and readeth on his Fe≈øtiuitie ≈øay, he ≈øent Fugatius and Damianus to conuert Britaine. Quamobrem Fagatium & Damianum mi≈øit in Britanniam, per quos Rex & reliqui fidem ≈øu≈øciperent. The worke a≈ø≈øcribed to S. Dama≈øus ≈øayeth, the Kings reque≈øt was, to haue it done by the Popes coÃÑmandement, per eius mandatum. The old Roman Martyrologe ≈øaith ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ is bu≈øines was effected by Damianus, and Fugatius whome Pope Eleutherius ≈øent into Britaine to that end: Sanctos Damianum & Fugatium in Britanniam mi≈øit, qui Lucium Regem vna cum vxore ac toto fere populo baptizarunt. V≈øuardus, Ado, and others confirme it, Ponticus Virunnius affirmeth Ponticus Virun. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 4. the Pope ≈øent the≈øe hither, and they ordered all things heare for Religion: Pontifex Faganum & Doeuanum ad Lucium mi≈øit. Martinus Polonus ≈øo affirmeth: Papa mi≈øit duos religio≈øos viros, videlicet Faganum & Damianum. And if Abbot Fecknam auouching it publikly in open Parlament in the fir≈øt yeare of Queene Elizabeth, and there offering to make it good again≈øt them that then brought in Prote≈øtant Religion, may be admitted for a credible Authour, Abbot Fecknam in his oration in Parlament an. 1. Elizab. S. Gildas did write as much or more: for the≈øe be the words of that worthie Prelate: The Religion, and the ≈øelfe ≈øame manner of ≈øeruing God, of the which ye are at this pre≈øent in po≈ø≈øe≈øsion, did begin heare in this Realine, 1400. yeares pa≈øt, and that in King Lucius his dayes by the first Christian King of this Realme, humble letters ≈øent to the holy Father Pope Eleutherius, who ≈øent into this R√®alme two holy men, the one called Damianus, and the other Fugatius. And they as Amba≈ø≈øadors ≈øent froÃÑ the See Apo≈øtolike of Rome, did bring into this Realme, ≈øo many yeares pa≈øt, the very ≈øame Religion, whereof we are now in po≈ø≈øe≈øsioÃÑ, and that in the Latine tongue, as the auncient Hi≈øtoriographer D. Gildas witne≈ø≈øeth in the Prologue and beginning of his booke of the Britaine Hi≈øtories. And the Magdeburgian Prote≈øtants, Balaeus, and others of that Religion, be≈øides our Catholike writers, the Authour Magdeb. cent. 2. c. 2. col. 8. Io. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Lucio. Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. l. 4. c. 20. Virun. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 4. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 186. of the Brittish old Hi≈øtory, Virunnius, and Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter cite S. Gildas for a witnes in the≈øe things. And tho≈øe Manu≈øcript Copies of S. Gildas, as our Prote≈øtants tell vs, which are yet extant in their cu≈øtodies both in the Library of S. BeÃÑnets Colledge, and the Vniuer≈øitie at Cambridge doe te≈øtifie, that all matters heare in Religion were ordered by the Legats of the Pope of Rome, mi≈ø≈øa legatione a Papa Romano. And we haue farre more auncient Brittish te≈øtimonies hereof, then S. Gildas time, euen the Acts them≈øelues of tho≈øe holy Legats written in their time, as both auncient Catholike writers & Prote≈øtants Charta S. Patricij apud Leland. a≈ø≈øert. Arthurij. Capgrau. Catal. in S. Patric. Ant. Gla≈øt. Manu≈øcr. Tabulis affixae in membranis. Io. Bal. l. de Scriptorib. Brit. cent. 1. in Eluano & Meduuino. are witne≈ø≈øes, ≈øo the Epi≈øtle a≈ø≈øcribed by Prote≈øtants and others to S. Patrick, ≈øo other Brittish Monuments, as the old Manu≈øcripts of Gla≈øtenbury with others affirme: Venerunt Eleutherio mittente Praedicatores Britanniam duo viri ≈øancti≈øsimi Phaganus, & Deruianus pro vt charta ≈øancti Patricij, ge≈øtaque Britannorum testantur hi verbum vitae euangelizantes, Regem cum ≈øuo populo Sacro Fonte abluerunt. And a Prote≈øtant Bishop in his booke of Brittish writers, as he acknowledgeth all Chri≈øtian affaires then to haue bene ordered by the≈øe two Legates, Fugatius and Damianus: omnia ordinatione quadam per Fugatium & Damianum in rem Chri≈øtianam permutata: ≈øo Eluanus and Meduuinus did write
in Parchement a Booke of the Acts of the≈øe Legats, whereby the notice of the≈øe things came to Po≈øteritie. Vt apud Po≈øteros clariora perdurarent, membranis hi dederunt Acta per Legatos li. 1. Inde ad nos, & non alio medio peruenerunt.

6. And to make all ≈øure that all things heare were effected by the Popes Authoritie, and by power of their Commi≈ø≈øion from him; he addeth immediately, that this Conuer≈øion of Britaine by the Popes Authoritie, was a Patterne and Pre≈øident to other ≈øucceeding Popes, to diuide other Prouinces into Parishes and Dioce≈øes. Ex hoc & ≈øimilibus fundamentis, caepere po≈øtea Romanorum Pontifices occa≈øionem Prouincias diuidendi in Paraecias, & Diocae≈øes. And S. Patrike Epi≈øt. S. Patricij Antiq. Gla≈øt. apud Capgrau. in S. Patricio. (as our Prote≈øtants with others allow that Antiquitie) te≈øtifieth that he found this Legatine power of S. Faganus and Damianus, with effects thereof in other writings of the Britans betweene their time and his. I ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ riptis recentioribus inueni, quod ≈øanctus Phaganus & Deruuianus ab Eleuthe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ o Papa qui eos mi≈øerat decem annos Indulgentiae impetrarunt. Nennius writeth, as the extant Copies of Nennius Hi≈øt. Manu≈øcr. Bed. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 1. c. 4. & in Martyrol. 8. cal. Iunij. Ethelwerd chronic. in Eleuther. Marian. Scot. l. 2. ‚Ä¢ tat. 6. an. 177. Florent. Wigor. in Chronic. ann. 162. vel 184. Martin. Pol. ≈øupput. an. 188. in Eleut. S. Gildas before, that Chri≈øtian Religion was ≈øetled heare by the Legats of the Pope of Rome. Mi≈ø≈øa Legatione a Papa Romano. S. Bede in diuers places affirmeth that Chri≈øtianitie was planted heare by Pope Eleutherius commande or Authoritie, and this was King Lucius ≈øuite: vt per eius mandatum Chri≈øtianus fieret, & effectum piae po≈øtulationis con≈øecutus est. Ethelwerdus ≈øaith, it was done by the Legats and letters of Pope Eleutherius to King Lucius: Eleutherius beati≈øsimus Chri≈øti famulus per Nuncium & literas Lucium adijt In≈øulae Regem. Marianus ≈øaith, King Lucius obtained it of Pope Eleutherius. Lucius Britanniae Rex ab Eleutherio Papa per Epi≈øtolam Chri≈øtianum ≈øe fieri impetrat. Florentius Wigornien≈øis hath the ≈øame words. Martinus relateth it by Fuganus and Damianus hauing Mi≈ø≈øion or Commi≈ø≈øion from Pope Eleutherius. Papa mi≈øit duos religio≈øos viros, videlicet Fuganum & Damianum, qui Regem & populum Baptizarent. Radulphus de Diceto in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtorie reporteth, King Lucius petitioninge to Pope Eleutherius about this bu≈øines, the Pope ≈øent Faganus and Diuuanus hither, and they affected it Ad Eleutherium Lucius Rex Radulphus de Diceto in Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. abbreu. Chronic. inter an. 170. & 180. Henricus Huntingt. Hi≈øt. l. 1. in Marco Antonino Vero. Manu≈øcrip. Hi≈øt. de Rome≈øey. Princ. In≈øula i≈ø ‚Ä¢ a q ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nunc Anglia. Gulielm. Malm. l. de Antiquit. cae ‚Ä¢ obij Gla≈øton. Caxton H ‚Ä¢ ≈øt. part. 4. in King Lucius. Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. l. 4. c. 19. 20. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 185 186 Hu ‚Ä¢
ting. Chronic. c. 31. f. 4 ‚Ä¢ . Britanniae mi≈ø≈øa Epi≈øtola ≈øe ≈øieri Chri≈øtianum impetrat: Eleuther ergo mi≈øit Faganum & Diuuanum qui Regem Lucium baptizauerunt. Henrie of Huntington his phra≈øe is, that it was done by Pope Eleutherius commandement. Per Eleutherij Papae mandatum. The old Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory of Rome≈øey ≈øaith: King Lucius did humbly entreate Pope Eleutherius by an Epi≈øtle, that he would ≈øend him faithfull Doctors to Bapti≈øe him and his Nation, and he obtained his ≈øuite. Rex Britannorum Lucius ≈øanctum Eleutherium tunc temporis Papam per Epi≈øtolam ≈øuppliciter expetiuit, & gratanter obtinuit quatenus fideles Doctores destinaret, qui ≈øe ac gentem ≈øuam in Chri≈øto regenerarent. William of Malmesbury in his Manu≈øcript Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury relateth, that the≈øe Legats Phaganus and Deruianus came into Britaine to preach the Gho≈øpell, & haue preached & Baptized through all the Iland. Phaganus & Deruianus venerunt in Britanniam ad praedicandum EuangeliuÃÑ, Baptizantes & praedicantes, & vniuer≈øam In≈øulam peragrantes. The old English Chronicle published by Caxton a≈ø≈øcribeth the whole managing of the≈øe affaires to the Legats of Pope Eleutherius. The Brittish Hi≈øtory al≈øo, the Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter and Harding are mo≈øt manife≈øt for the≈øe Legats and Commi≈ø≈øioners of Pope Eleutherius to haue directed all the≈øe affaires by that Popes Authoritie.

7. Thus we haue proued by Authorities the high Apo≈øtolike Legatine Power which the holy Pope Eleutherius communicated to the≈øe his learned and renowned Legats, and Commi≈ø≈øioners Faganus and Damianus for the
Conuer≈øion of this kingdome; this Power being thus granted, and ≈øo many Epi≈øcopall Acts in con≈øecrating Bishops, Prei≈øts, and other Clergie men, and The≈øe Legats of Pope Eleutherius were Bishops. others proper to that highe≈øt function being to be exerci≈øed heare, as in all other Nations, in ≈øuch a ≈øtate and condition, and which none but Bishops could performe, and the≈øe worthie Founders of our Church performed heare by all Antiquities, we mu≈øt needs conclude they were con≈øecrated Bishops by ≈øuch Apo≈øtolike Catholike manner, as I haue before related. Therefore I can but maruayle how the pre≈øent Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury Directour of M. Francis Ma≈øon, and his ≈øcribe were no better directed then to Franc. Ma≈øon Pref. to his Books of Con≈øecr. & l. 2. c. 3. p. 55. 56. write: from Rome there came two Fugatius and Damianus, but we cannot learne that eyther of them was a Bishop. Which is too weake a ≈øaying of an Archbishop, or any writer directed by ≈øuch a man. For ≈øo many Epi≈øcopall Acts, which by all writers they effected were le≈ø≈øons plaine enough to learne that they were endowed with Epi≈øcopall Order and power to doe ≈øuch things, and ≈øo mu≈øt needs be Bishops. And if we mu≈øt ≈øeeke them Mai≈øters expre≈ø≈øely to call them ≈øo, the old Brittish Hi≈øtory calleth them expre≈ø≈øely Anti≈øtites, Bishops, Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 4. c. 20. Pont. Virun. Hi≈øt. l. 4. in fine. Matth. We≈øtm. Anno gratiae 186 Godwin Cat. of Bishops in Wince≈øter. pag. 207. edit. an. 1615. ≈øo doth Virunnius: And Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter naming them the ble≈ø≈øed Bishops Faganus and Deruuianus: b ‚Ä¢ ati Anti≈øtites Faganus & Deruuianus. And to omitt others, that Prote≈øtant Bishop which before was mo≈øt backward in the≈øe things, produceth an old Manu≈øcript te≈øtifying they were Bishops, and exerci≈øed the holy offices of that Function. The Cathedrall Church of Winche≈øter (≈øaith he) as the ≈øame Authour of an old Manu≈øcript ≈øaith, wash allowed and dedicated vnto the honour of our Sauiour October 29. 189. by Faganus and Damianus Bishops. And diuers forrayne Hi≈øtorians, e≈øpecially of France witne≈ø≈øe that the cheife ≈øuite of King Lucius, was for ≈øuch, hauing otherwi≈øe of his owne Nation many Prei≈øts and Preachers of the Chri≈øtian Religion. Mere des Hi≈øtoires & Chroniques de France l. 1. pag. 91. an. 182. Alan Bouchard in Annales de Bretaigne l. 1. fol. 19. p. 2. Many Chri≈øtians (≈øay the≈øe Authours, being bapti≈øed and preaching the faith in Britaine, King Lucius ≈øendeth to Pope Eleutherius, vn Amba≈ø≈øadeur, an Amba≈ø≈øadour to make ≈øuit to him to ≈øend Prelats of his Church to in≈øtruct and baptize him, And a≈ø≈øure vs the cheife of the≈øe were Damianus and Faganus, exerci≈øing Epi≈øcopall Function heare. And ≈øo according to their high calling and dignitie, and as the holy Popes before, euen from S. Peter had practi≈øed, and ordayned, the≈øe holy Bishops before had their ≈øacred Prei≈øts, Deacons, and other Many other Bishops employed by the Popes authoritie in this holy works. Clergie men to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them. And the ca≈øe and condition of ≈øo lardge Dominions, as Britaine comprehended, to be conuerted, required, diuers other both Prei≈øts and Bishops were ≈øent by Pope Eleutherius with them to be workemen in this happy harue≈øt. And their names were diligently pre≈øerued and left to Po≈øteritie in our Primatiue Church, and among others, our renowned Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Brit. lib. 2. c. 20. Ponticus Virun. l. 4. Hi≈øtor. Brit. Matt. We≈øt. an. gratiae 186. Mere des Hi≈øtoires & Alan Bouchard ≈øupr. Hi≈øtorian S. Gildas, as the old Authour of the Brittish Hi≈øtorie, Ponticus Virunnius, Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter and the≈øe la≈øt recited French Antiquaries with others te≈øtifie, did committ them to writing. Which being performed by him, they therefore omitt to make repetition of. Eorum nomina & actus in libro reperiuntur, quem Gildas de victoria Aurelij Ambro≈øij in≈øcrip≈øit. Quod autem tam lucido Tractatu parauerat; nullatenus opus ≈øuit vt inferiori ≈øtylo renouaretur. And this our mo≈øt noble and auncient Hi≈øtorian, as the≈øe Authours te≈øtifie, did al≈øo Regi≈øter the names and Acts of them, which came hither with The ≈øecond Mi≈ø≈øion of Pope Eleutherius into Britaine. them, at their ≈øecond comming hither from Pope Eleutherius, when by Apo≈øtolike power he confirmed that which the≈øe his holy Legats had done in Britaine. I haue made mention of many of them before, in the ≈øixt Chapter Supr. Cent. 2. p. 6. of this Age, and needles to repeate them heare. Onely I wish now to be remembred,
that ≈øo many Bishops as were ≈øent hither with the≈øe his Legats and mo≈øt of this Nation, as Man≈øuetus Bishop of Tullum, Marcel ‚Ä¢ us or Marcellinus Bishop of Tungers, S. Saluin Bishop of Verdune, S. Eluanus newly con≈øecrated Bishop by Pope Eleutherius, all proued before to haue bene now Bishops, and imployed in this holy worke, be≈øides the Legats of S. Eleutherius hauing their Prei≈øts and Clergie men with them, as the Apo≈øtolike In≈øtitutions ordered, amounted to no ≈ømall number. To which if we make addition of them, which either actually then al≈øo were Bishops, though not ≈øo euidently knowne, or mo≈øt certainely ≈øoone after, as S. Thean fir≈øt Archbishop of London, S. Samp≈øon, and Theodo≈øius of Yorke which came in al≈øo with the≈øe Roman Legats, we shall (notwith≈øtanding the lo≈ø≈øe of the help of S. Gildas, of which our Prote≈øtants by their ill handling Antiquities may be ≈øu≈øpected to haue depriued vs) finde no improportionable number of mo≈øt fitt and worthie Eccle≈øia≈øticall labourers to vndertake and performe ≈øo memorable and greate a worke.

div.head: THE XVI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: HOW THESE HOLY ROMAN LEGATS by Power and Commi≈øsion from the Pope, and Apostolike See of Rome, conuerted and confirmed vnto, and in the faith of Chri≈øt, all manner of par≈øons in all places of Briaine, whether the Nobilitie, Flamens, Archflamens, or of what Order or degree ≈øoeuer.

div.p:
1. WHEN the≈øe holy Legats had thus receaued Con≈øecration, In≈øtruction and Commi≈ø≈øion for this greate chardge and bu≈øines remitted vnto them, they now tooke their long and tedious Iorney into Britaine, where, being a≈ø≈øociated with ≈øuch worthie men to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them in ≈øo honorable and greate a bu≈øines, as I haue related, they arriued within short time; and fir≈øt with all conuenient ≈øpeede both to ≈øatisfie the de≈øire of King Lucius, and orderly to performe the chardge, and tru≈øt which the holy Pope Eleutherius had recommended vnto them, they pre≈øented them≈øelues vnto our King, and his Nobles, long time expecting and attending their de≈øired comming. And ≈øo ≈øoone as they had deliuered the greetings Of the preaching of tho≈ø ‚Ä¢ holy Legats & A≈øsi≈øtants heare in Britaine, & many conuerted by them. of the See Apo≈øtolike, and acquainted them with their Legatine Power, and Commi≈ø≈øion, for the Conuer≈øion of this kingdome to Chri≈øt, and e≈øtablishing all things thereto belonging, they happily began this worke, and putt the≈øe things in Execution. It is allmo≈øt the generall a≈ø≈øent and Harmonie of our Antiquaries, that they conuerted the King, Queene, Peeres, and Nobilitie of Britaine: Yet I dare not affirme whether they may be ≈øaid actually and fir≈øt Gildas Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. Nennius Hi≈øt. Manu≈øcrip. Ant. Eccle≈ø. Landauen. & alij po≈øteriores. to haue conuerted and bapti≈øed King Lucius, or this was before performed by our remembred Chri≈øtian Brittish Prei≈øts, and Bishops, and the≈øe onely confirmed him in the faith he had receaued, which may be, and in Hi≈øtories is
called a Conuer≈øion, and Bapti≈øme, becau≈øe the Sacrament of Confirmation is the perfection and complement thereof, as in our owne Hi≈øtories, King Cadwallader is ≈øaid to be conuerted and bapti≈øed by Pope Sergius at Rome, when the Brittish Hi≈øtorie onely ≈øaith he receaued Confirmation of him. Caduualladrus Galfrid. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 12. c. 18. abiectis mundialibus propter Deum, Regnumque perpetuum, venit Romam, & √† Sergio Papa confirmatus. Of this Que≈øtion I haue ≈øufficiently before related, what Antiquitie hath deliuered vnto vs, thereof. And therefore pa≈ø≈øe it ouer now without further repetition, ≈øuppo≈øing it eyther acted before, or ≈øo much de≈øired to haue bene pre≈øently effected by them, and ≈øo proceed to their other labours, and effects of them.

2. Some Prote≈øtant writers would gladly diminish the glory of the≈øe Legats, in per≈øuading their Readers, that they ignorant of the Brittish tongue preached not to the Britans, but committed that office to our Brittish Prei≈øts, and Preachers, and ≈øo in this kinde they litle or nothing preuayled, or profited this Nation. A Prote≈øtant Bishop thus writeth of them: The men that were ≈øent from Rome were vtterly ignorant of the Brittish languadge, and ≈øo could not po≈ø≈øibly Godwin Conu. of Brit. p. 36. preach any thing them≈øelues, but were faine to committ that office alltogether vnto others, to witt e≈øpecially to Eluan and Medwin. And what is all this to the See of Rome? Surely hitherto we ≈øee litle cau≈øe to acknowledge our ≈øelues any thing at all obliged thereunto. Thus farre hath Pa≈ø≈øion and malice carried this people, not onely again≈øt the pre≈øent Roman Church, which they accu≈øe of errour: But when in their owne Iudgments and Confe≈ø≈øions, it was mo≈øt pure and vn≈øpotted, and Commandre≈ø≈øe of all, and to which if we neuer had bene beholding, we neuer had bene true Chri≈øtians, neuer the legitimate children of Chri≈øt, and his holy ≈øpou≈øe. And to bewray the≈øe mens follies in their owne words: if the≈øe Legats of the See Apo≈øtolike had bene ≈øo ignorant of the Brittish languadge, that they could not thereby haue preached to the vulgare people ordinarily vnder≈øtanding no other, were we not beholding vnto Pope Eleutherius for ≈øending them, as our King de≈øired? Then we were not beholding to that holy King, to ≈øend ≈øo far with an humble and earne≈øt petition for the generall good of this Nation, that it being obtayned, we receaued no benefite thereby. Were we not obliged to tho≈øe Legats, that trauailed ≈øo long a Iorney to vnite vs to Chri≈øt and his holy Church? Was it worthie no thankes, but contumely and de≈øpite, if they by their Power committed the office of preaching vnto vs, vnto others which knew our languadge by this mans confe≈ø≈øion, and ≈øo conuerted vs? Did not dutie oblige vs, to the See of Rome in this mans Iudgment, when he him≈øelfe thus confe≈ø≈øeth before. By mo≈øt it is affirmed, how that Eleutherius ≈øent Damianus and Fugatius to Order the ≈øtate of Godwin ≈øupr. p. 21. Pag. 20. the Church, who had the honour of performing that office? Doth that make no obligation, which he plainely with S. Bede and others thus confe≈ø≈øeth? Eleutherius a holy man ≈øitting Bishop of the RomaÃÑ Church: Lucius a King of the Britans writ vnto him his letters, praying that by his appointment, and direction, he might be made a Chri≈øtian. And pre≈øently he obtayned the effect of his godly de≈øire. Or how will this man per≈øuade vs, that the≈øe Legats did not vnder≈øtand our languadge, and ≈øo preached not them≈øelues being ≈øtrangers, but committed that office e≈øpecially to Eluan and Medwin. And Pope Eleutherius appointed Meduinus S. Eluanus and M ‚Ä¢ dwinus with other Brittish Prei≈øts & learned Cl ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gymen a≈ø ‚Ä¢ i≈øt them. a Doctour or teacher: and ≈øaith with his fellowes in Religion Parker, Bale, and Leland as he glo≈ø≈øeth them: That Medwin was by birth a Dutchman, and thereby as vnfit a Preacher to Britans as the Italian Legats were.

3. But we are a≈ø≈øured by better Authoritie and Antiquitie then this man
can shew vs to the contrary, that both our King, his Nobles and all the cheife≈øt heare of the Britans at that time vnder≈øtood the Latine Roman tongue. Our Antiquaries of Cambridge and others proue vnto vs, that there was an Imperiall Con≈øtitution decreed and receaued heare in the≈øe times, that euery man that would or should beare office mu≈øt learne the Latine tongue. In≈øtitutum fuit, vt qui Magi≈øtratum gerere vellet, Latinam linguam di≈øceret. And long Io. Caius in Hi≈øt. Cantabrig. p. 19. before this time the Latine tongue was ≈øo v≈øuall in this Nation, as the≈øe Prote≈øtants tell vs, that the Romans Latine ≈øonges were ≈øent hither, and ≈øunge heare euen to the vulgar audience: And of this Martiall the Poet ≈øpeaketh: when he ≈øaith his ≈øonges and Poems were ≈øunge in Britaine.

q.note: Matth. Parker Antiq. Britan. in Claudia. Io. Bal. lib. de Scriptor. cent. 1. in Claud. Martial. in Epigr. Theater of great Brit. l. 6.

div.p:
Therefore the≈øe Latine ≈øonges being ≈øent from Rome to our Brittans heare, as the≈øe Prote≈øtants write to be ≈øunge & heard, both the ≈øingers and heares of them mu≈øt needs be ≈øaid to haue vnder≈øtood that languadge of the Romans in which they were penned by the Poet. So we need not ≈øeeke any further for Auditours to vnder≈øtand the preaching of the≈øe Roman Legats, though in the Latine tongue, when we haue founde allready the King him≈øelfe, all his Nobles and officers in Authoritie, and hauing command, all Schollars in our Vniuer≈øities, or Schooles, be≈øides others by probable Iudgment without number, which vnder≈øtood them preaching, per≈øuading, rea≈øoning, di≈øputing, in≈øtructing or catechizing in that ≈øpeach. And we may with ≈øtrong rea≈øon from hence informe and a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelues, that this ≈øo v≈øuall and allmo≈øt common knowledge heare of the Latine tongue, the naturall languadge in Rome from whence ≈øo many Apo≈øtolike Preachers were ≈øent into the≈øe parts, was a greate help and furtherance, to that ≈øo ≈øpeedy Conuer≈øion of this kingdome, which otherwi≈øe to haue bene effected as it is deliuered in our Hi≈øtories, may iu≈øtly be termed miraculous. And allthough both the King and very many of his Nobles learned Druids, and others were eyther actually conuerted, or conuicted in Iudgment of the vndoubted truth of Chri≈øtian Religion and fal≈øehood of their Pagan ≈øuper≈øtitions before the comming of the≈øe Legats hither, or King Lucius ≈øent for them to Rome, as I haue shewed before: Yet no ≈ømall number and of the learned among them ≈øtill continuing in their old errours, and the Chri≈øtian Clergie then in Britaine neyther being ≈øo greate or learned in that fir≈øt Age, and Infancie of our Church, that it was able to conuert ≈øo many millions which ≈øtill profe≈ø≈øed Pagani≈øme in this kingdome, if our Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hierarchie could or might haue bene ordered, and ≈øetled without the Popes allowance, and Authoritie, which allmo≈øt euery Chapter in this Hi≈øtorie di≈øproueth, yet we mu≈øt needs acknowledge our ≈øelues obliged, and very much in dutie obliged, to the Apo≈øtolike See of Rome, for ≈øending vnto vs ≈øo learned, reuerend, and holy Pa≈øtors as all Hi≈øtories confe≈ø≈øe them to haue bene, to deliuer vs ≈øo happily from that mo≈øt damnable infernall darknes, wherewith we were blinded, and without ≈øuch ≈øpirituall Phi≈øitians help, and cure, de≈øperately and irrecouerably ouerwhelmed, infected, and di≈øea≈øed at that time. Therefore the≈øe Renowned, and in all re≈øpects mo≈øt honorable Legats, knowing well what chardge, Power, and tru≈øt was committed vnto them, by the Popes Authoritie and our Kings entreatie, and perfectly informed heare of the ≈øtate, and nece≈ø≈øitie of this kingdome in ≈øpirituall affaires, pre≈øently di≈øpo≈øed them≈øelues, and the whole Chri≈øtian Clergie heare vnder them for the mo≈øt ≈øpeedy and perfect recouery, and expelling the venime from ≈øo many allmo≈øt deadly poy≈øoned ≈øoules in Britaine. And the
theife≈øt places in Britaine, where this infection principally did reigne, and was fo≈øtered, and from them di≈øper≈øed into all the other parts and members of the bodie of this kingdome, next vnto the Court of the King now conuerted, being our auncient Schooles or Vniuer≈øities, and cheife Re≈øidences of the principall Pagan Idolatrous Prei≈øts, Flamens, and Archflamens in the mo≈øt auncient and commanding Cities of this Nation, they di≈øpo≈øed and diuided them≈øelues & our Cleargie to ≈øtop the≈øe ≈øprings, and fountains of that foule ouerflowing ≈øtreame.

4. How they preuayled in our old Brittish Vinner≈øities or Schooles in confouÃÑ ding the Pagan Philo≈øophers and conuerting them, their followers and Di≈øciples to the Chri≈øtian faith, we may take ≈øome notice by that which the Antiquaries of Cambridge propo≈øe vnto vs, performed by them in their Vniuer≈øitie, where they ≈øay, they after long di≈øpute with their Philo≈øophers, they Io. Caius Hi≈øt. Cantabr. p. 35. conuerted them all to Chri≈øt, and bapti≈øed both them and three thou≈øand others there in one day. Cantabrigiam venerunt, vt fertur, vbi po≈øtquam multum
The Schollers of Cambridge now generally conuerted, and 3000. other Britans there Baptized in one day.
vari√®que cum Philo≈øophis di≈øputatum est, baptizarunt vno die, & Philo≈øophos omnes, & tria hominum millia. And though they doe not deliuer the names of their Authours for this Relation, yet they doe ≈øufficiently expre≈ø≈øe, that they found this narration of the di≈øputing with the≈øe Cambridge Philo≈øophers, and the Bapti≈øing both of them and ≈øo many thou≈øands at one time, there te≈øtified by diuers Antiquities, for they ≈øay expre≈ø≈øely that ≈øome a≈ø≈øcribe it to EluaÃÑ and Medwine after their returne froÃÑ Rome and Bapti≈øme of King Lucius, and by others to the Legats of Pope Eleutherius: ≈øecundum quo≈ødam qui i≈øta ad Faganum & Damianum, ≈øeu Fugatium & Deruuianum Eleutherij Nuncios referunt. And record it done in the ≈øame yeare they came into Britaine: Which they hold to haue bene the 178. of Chri≈øt, id actum fuit anno Domini 178. And allthough the≈øe men ≈øtand as much as Antiquities doe warrant them, for the honour and prioritie of their Vniuer≈øitie, yet in this place they doe not auouch this Hi≈øtorie, as any ≈øingular grace or prerogatiue aboue other Schooles in Britaine at that time, but doe ≈øufficiently in≈øinuate, that the≈øe holy Legats and their A≈ø≈øociats did the like in all other ≈øuch auncient Schooles and places, and in mo≈øt of them before they came to Cambridge; per In≈øulam diuulgare verbum So in other Schooles and places of learning heare. Dei, ≈øementem Dei iacere. And after this, they came to Cambridge, Tandem Cantabrigiam venerunt. By which and like te≈øtimonies of many others, we may ≈øuppo≈øe they had ≈øo done at Stamford, Cricklade or Greeke-lade, and e≈øpecially by the≈øe men in Glamorgan-shire where they ≈øay learning florished, a≈øwell as at Cambridge before the coming of Iulius Cae≈øar hither: Ex quibus Caius ≈øupr. p. 20. ≈øcire licet, claram fui≈ø≈øe ≈øcientiarum profe≈øsionem in Britannia, ante Cae≈øaris aduentum in Britanniam, praecipu√® vero Cantabrigiae, & Glamorgantiae. And the Schoole of Clamorgan being ≈øo neare to Caerlegion vpon vske in that Country, S. Eleutherius Pope granteth Priuiledges and immunities to the Schoole of Cambridge. where one of the three greate Idolatrous Temples of Britaine, and Seate of their Archflamen of tho≈øe We≈øterne Prouinces was, and thereby a Nur≈øery of Pagani≈øme for that ≈øo ≈øuper≈øtitious place, it teacheth vs of it≈øelfe without further te≈øtimonie, that a prime and principall care of the holy Legats, and our Chri≈øtian Clergie then was, vtterly to roote vp, or alter the nature of the Bulla Honorij 1. Papae dat. Romae An. D. 624. die 20. Februar. apud Caium l. 1. de Antiq. Cantabrigiae p. 75. 76. 77. infecting ≈øeedes and plants of that offen≈øiue Seminarie. Of this, we haue ≈øome more particular te≈øtimonie out of the Bull of Pope Honorius dated the. 20. day of February in the yeare of Chri≈øts Incarnation 624. granted for the priuiledge of the Schoole or Vniuer≈øitie (for ≈øo he termeth it) of Cambridge, which thus beginneth: Honorius Epi≈øcopus Seruus Seruorum Dei, dilectis filijs
Doctoribus & ≈øcholaribus in Vniuer≈øitate Cantabrigiae ≈øedentibus, ≈øalutem & Apostolicam benedictionem. Wherein is expre≈ø≈øely ≈øaid, that S. Eleutherius granted Immunities, and Priuiledges to that Vniuer≈øitie, then become Chri≈øtian: All Flamens and Arch≈øtamens of the PagaÃÑstogether with their Cities c ‚Ä¢ nuerted. An Argument that he extended the like fauours, and Immunities to our other ≈øcholes or Vniuer≈øities then in the ≈øame condition with Cambridge, but that they longe ≈øince decayed and ouerthrowne, could keepe no memory of ≈øuch things, as Cambridge, clayming a neuer Interrupted coÃÑtinuance, hath done. Galfr. Monum. l. 4. Hi≈øt. Brit. p. 19. Pont. Virun. l. 4. Hi≈øt. Mart. Pol. Supput. in Eleut. Radulp. de Dicet. Hi≈øt. Manu≈øcr. inter an. 170. & 180. Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 185. Vita S. Helenae apud Capgra. in Catalog. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. in Lucio & Eluan. & Medu. Barns l. de Vit. Pont. in Eleuth. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. Godw. CoÃÑu. of Britaine Selden Analect. Stowe & Howes Hi≈øt. in Lucius Harri≈ø. de≈øcript. of Brit. Martyrol. Rom. 26. die Maij in S. Eleutherio. Act. S. Eleutherij in Breu. Rom. die 26. Maij. This will be more and inuincibly euident by that which is affirmed with the allmo≈øt generall a≈ø≈øent of all Antiquities, te≈øtifying they par≈øonally vi≈øited, preached vnto, and conuerted all, not onely the Metropolitan, but the other Cities of this kingdome: and be≈øides them the whole Nation, in ≈øuch manner that ≈øcarcely a Pagan was left to be found therein. Of our Cities, their Rulers, and Inhabitants thus conuerted by them, we haue the con≈øtant agreement both of Catholike and Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians.

5. The Brittish Hi≈øtorie Ponticus Virunnius and Martinus ≈øay, of the≈øe, that they deliuered theÃÑ from Idolatrie, & coÃÑuerted them to Chri≈øt. Hos Idololatriae eripuerunt. Radulphus de Diceto in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtorie proueth as much, that they coÃÑuerted all the Cities in Britaine, a≈øwell their FlameÃÑs, and ArchflameÃÑs, by whome they were directed in their Idolatrous worship, as others: ≈øo doe the other Authours before, ≈øpeaking more particularly of their Flamens, or Archflamens conuerted by them, then any others. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter writeth in like manner how they vi≈øited, and conuerted all the Cities of Britaine. So hath the old Writer of the life of S. Helen and other Catholike Authours. Which is ≈øeconded and confirmed by mo≈øt of our Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians, Bale, Barns, the Theater writers, Godwyn, Selden, with others con≈øenting, that all the≈øe Cities of Britaine with their Flamens or Archflamens which then ruled in them, were now conuerted by the≈øe holy Legats, and that Apo≈øtolike Mi≈ø≈øion from the Pope of Rome S. Eleutherius.

6. And the principall Stats and Members of this kingdome King Lucius, his Nobles, Vniuer≈øities, Philo≈øophers, Flamens, and cheife Prei≈øts, and Teachers of the Pagan ≈øubiects, and their cheife places of commorancie and commande being thus conuerted, the conque≈øt ouer the vulgare ≈øorte was ea≈øie and ≈øoone effected. The old Roman Martyrologe ≈øaith, that Fugatius and Damianus ≈øent by S. Eleutherius Baptized King Lucius, his wife, and allmo≈øt all his people. Qui Lucium Regem vna cum vxore, ac toto fere populo baptizarunt. The auncient and approued Acts of S. Eleutherius ≈øay, that King Lucius and The Brittans here were now generally conuer ‚Ä¢ ed, in all places. all his ≈øubiects receaued the faith of Chri≈øt by the≈øe Legats: per Quos Rex & reliqui fidem ≈øu≈øciperent. The Authour of the Brittish Hi≈øtorie te≈øtifieth, that ≈øo ≈øoone as the people of Britaine knew their King was a Chri≈øtian, they gathered them≈øelues together to be catechized, and receaue Bapti≈øme. Nec mora, Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 4. c. 19. concurrentes vndique Nationum populi, Regis exemplum in≈øequuntur, eodem lauacro mundati, caelestique regno restituuntur. And ≈øaith, that the≈øe holy Legats did blot out Pagani≈øme, allmo≈øt through out all the Iland, then much more where Ponticus Virun. Hi≈øt. Brit. lib. 4. prope finem. Guliel. Malme≈ø. l. de Antiq. Caenobij Gla≈øton. Antiquitates Gla≈øt. Manu≈øcr. tabulis affixae. King Lucius ruled Beati Doctores per totam fere In≈øulam Pagani≈ømum deleui≈ø≈øent. Ponticus Virunnius affirmeth as much, or more, that they baptized all the people of Britaine. Baptizarunt omnes gentes Britanniae. William of Malmesbury in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory of Gla≈øteÃÑbury teacheth, that they trauailed all ouer the Iland, preaching and baptizing. Phaganus & Deruianus venerunt in Britanniam ad praedicandum Euangelium, qui baptizantes & praedicantes & vniuer≈øam In≈øulam peragrantes. The old Manu≈øcript Antiquities of Gla≈øteÃÑbury
written in Parchment, and fixed to broade Bords doe witnes, that the≈øe Legats baptized King Lucius, and his people preaching and baptizing through out Britaine, and cite other more auncient Hi≈øtories for it. Phaganus atque Deruianus prout charta ≈øancti Patricij ge≈øtaque Britannorum testantur, verbum vitae Euangelizantes, Regem cum ≈øuo populo ≈øacro fonte abluerunt, huic praedicando & baptizando Britanniae partes peragrantes. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter is witnes, that after King Lucius was baptized, his ≈øubiects followed his example Matth. We≈øtm. in ≈øuch order that in a short time there was not heare any Infidell to be found. Quod cum factum fui≈ø≈øet, concurrerunt ad Bapti≈ømum Nationes diuer≈øae, exemplum Regis ≈øequentes, ita vt in breui nullus inueniretur Infidelis. Hartmannus Schedel reporteth, Hartni. Scedel. Chron. Chronic. f. 115. p. 2. Epi≈øt. S. Patricij apud Capgrau. in vita eius. Leland. a≈ø≈øert. Arthurij. & Antiq. Gla≈øt. Scriptor vitae S. Helenae apud Capgrau. in Catalog. as others before, that the≈øe Legats baptized the King and his people: Regem ip≈øum ac populum. The Hi≈øtoricall Relation of S. Patrike, commonly called his Epi≈øtle, witne≈ø≈øeth, that they conuerted both the King & people, trauailing quite through Britaine. Phaganus & Deruianus Regem cum ≈øuo populo ad fidem conuerterunt, peragrantes Britanniam. The old Authour that wrote S. Helen her life recordeth how vpon the Bapti≈øme of King Lucius, all the people of the whole Nation pre≈øently flocked together to be in≈øtructed in the faith of Chri≈øt and were baptized. Nec mora concurrentes vndique totius Nationis populi Regis exemplum in≈øequuntur, eodemque ≈øalutari lauachro mun dati caele≈øti Regno re≈øtituuntur. Harding thus ≈øetteth it downe in his olde ver≈øes:

lg.l: Eleuthery the fir≈øt at ≈øupplication Harding Chron. c. 51. f. 43.
Of Lucius, ≈øent him two holy menne
That called wer Faggan and Duuyen
That baptized him, and all his Realme throughoute
With hertes glad and laboure deuoute.

div.p: Sigebertus ≈øaieth generally of the Britans without re≈øtriction, that they Sigebert. Chron. in Regno BritaÃÑ norum. receaued Chri≈øtianitie by the Legats of Pope Eleutherius, ≈øent at the reque≈øt of their King Lucius. Britanni in≈øtantia Lucij Britanniarum Regis per Legatos Eleutherij Papae My≈øteria Chri≈øtianitatis perceperunt. Walterus Rollwink in his Fa≈øciculus, writeth that Fuganus and Damianus the Legats of Pope Eleutherius baptized both King Lucius and his people, who vpon the ≈øolemne Bapti≈øme of their King ≈øubmitted them≈øelues to Chri≈øtian Religion. Eleutherius Walter. Rollw. in Fa≈øcicul. teÃÑp. an. 184. mi≈øit Legatos Lucio Regi Britonum, qui eum cum populo ≈øuo baptizarunt. Solemniter Rege Lucio baptizato ≈øubiectus populus eius exemplo fidei colla ≈øubmi≈øit pacific√®.

div.head: THE XVII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: HOW IN BRITAINE THESE HOLY LEGATS placed Archbishops and Bishops in our Cyties, Archbishops in the places of Archflamens, and Bishops for Flamens. And how by all writers, ≈øuch dignities were among the auncient Pagans, both in Britaine and other Nations.

div.p:
1. WHEN the Eccle≈øia≈øticall affaires of Britaine had thus pro≈øperou≈øly proceeded, that the King, and all his Nobilitie were become Chri≈øtians, as Gildas, Nennius, the Antiquities of Landaffe and others after them te≈øtifie. Rex cum vniuer≈øis Britanniae Regulis Bapti≈ømum ≈øu≈øceperunt. And as an other Copie of Gildas agreeing with Nennius readeth: Lucius Britannicus Rex cum vniuer≈øis Regulis totius Britanniae Bapti≈ømum ≈øu≈øceperunt. And in the Antiquities of Landaffe: Lucius & totius Britanniae Primates Bapti≈ømum ≈øu≈øceperunt. And all Scholes, Cities, Druids, Teachers and Schollers of Idolatrie were thus conuerted to Chri≈øt, as all our Antiquaries Catholiks and Prote≈øtants haue deliuered, ≈øo that all both Rulers and ≈øubiects both temporall, and ≈øuch as were then called ≈øpirituall, had now embraced that Religion and worship of God, which as it was diametrically, as it were, repugnant to the ≈øuper≈øtions of the Gentils in Britaine, about their Idols, & termed Gods, ≈øo it vtterly condemned many of their barbarous and prophaine cu≈øtoms and ob≈øeruations in meerely ciuill and human affaires, and proceedings, as I haue in very many things (intollerable to be practized, or permitted) giuen In≈øtance before. Therefore as the ≈øtate of Religion and reue
‚Ä¢ ence to God was now changed, and onely heare wanted an externall Authoritatiue ≈øetling of an Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hierarchie of Bishops, Prei≈øts, & Cleargie men to gouerne in Religion, and places or Churches for profe≈ø≈øing and publike practi≈øe of the ≈øame, which were now to be prouided by the≈øe holy Legats; ≈øo King Lucius as the Vicar of Chri≈øt in this kingdome in temporall things, as S. Eleutherius ≈øtileth him in his Epi≈øtle about this bu≈øines, wrote vnto that holy Pope for his direction al≈øo in this greate affaire of changing his temporall Lawes, to make all ≈øure that nothing should be receaued and e≈øtablished heare, either concerning the dutie and office of man to God, or man to man, one towards an other, but what should haue direction or allowance Godwin Conu. of Brit. p. 26. The Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hierarchie of Archbishops, Bishops, Prei≈øts, and other Clergy men now ≈øetled heare by the Popes authoritie. from the See Apo≈øtolike of Rome. Of this ≈øecond I will ≈øpeake, when I haue in ≈øome manner finished or deliuered the fir≈øt, the ≈øetling or founding our Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hierarchie and gouernement in ≈øuch affaires.

2. That the≈øe Roman Legats did pre≈øently vppon our Conuer≈øion, appoint the Sees of Bishops and Archbishops, according to the place and number of the Flamens, and Archflamens of the Pagans, is ≈øo generally receaued for an vndeniable truth in Antiquities, as a Prote≈øtant Bishop ≈øingularly excepting one
other of his profe≈ø≈øion, heare naming him, that he perceiueth not any that haue gaine≈øaid it, before Mai≈øter Doctor Sutcliffe: But contrariwi≈øe diuers both auncient and learned are to be found, that haue partly broached it, and partly applauded the ≈øame. And yet this bold faced man, again≈øt all learned Antiquitie, in his owne confe≈ø≈øion, plea≈øeth to call it: a deui≈øe ≈øo childish and ridiculous, as he cannot but wonder, that any man of Learning and Iudgment should approue it. And bringeth no more rea≈øon then he doth Authoritie for this his ≈øingularitie. Onely he ≈øaith that Fene≈øtella which directly teacheth this dignitie of Archflamens among the Gentils, is not the auncient Fene≈øtella which was in the time of Tiberius the Emperour: but a man of later time then that, which Fene≈øtella printed & published by the Prote≈øtaÃÑts of Ba≈øile. may not be ≈øo shuffled ouer vpon the bare word of one Prote≈øtant of England again≈øt all his Brethren in Ba≈øile, where by their Authoritie the booke was printed and published, for a true auncient Fene≈øtella. And it is a ≈øtrange conceite of his to be vttered to vewe, to thinke to Father this opinion fir≈øt vpon Gratian, as thus he doth: The defendor of this conceit is Gratian, whome I doubt not we may accompt the fir≈øt Authour of the ≈øame. For I haue proued in the fir≈øt chapter of this Age at lardge both by Catholiks and Prote≈øtants, that diuers lyuing and writing in the time of the Apo≈øtles were of this opinion, and proued it by the practi≈øe of the Apo≈øtles them≈øelues, which appointed Primats for tho≈øe cheife Cities of Prouinces, where in the time of the Gentils, their Archflamens were re≈øident, and Ruled, and gaue order this v≈øadge should be ob≈øerued by Po≈øteritie. And this Prote≈øtant Bishop contradicteth him≈øelfe in this matter, for fir≈øt making Gratian Authour heareof, pre≈øently he thus addeth of him: True it is, that hauing fir≈øt deliuered it as his owne opinion, in one Godwin ≈øupr. p. 27. place: afterwards he citeth, for the ≈øame Clement a Pope: wherein, either he abu≈øeth vs in citing that which neuer was written: or him≈øelfe is abu≈øed by ≈øome couÃÑterfeit Clement. Therefore whether this Clement be counterfeit or no, this Prote≈øtant mu≈øt needs be a counterfeit, for if this ClemeÃÑt were a counterfeit he was couÃÑ terfeited long before Gratians time, being cited by him as auncient, and ≈øo the auncient counterfeiter of Clement mu≈øt needs broach this opinion before Gratian. But except the auncient Popes Anacletus, Anicetus, Stephen the fir≈øt, Lucius, S. Leo the ≈øecond, S. Marianus Scotus and Florentius Wigornien≈øis Cap. 1. ≈øupr. our learned Countrimen all before Gratian were deceaued are counterfeitors, this was the true Clement Di≈øciple of S. Peter, and ≈øo they cite and approue him, euen in this matter, & they confirme that not onely S. Clement, but S. Peter the Apo≈øtle thus both practized, and ordained: and how in the time of the Pagans there were Archflamens, and they were cheife ouer the other Flamens, as Patriarks and Primats be ouer Bishops in the Lawe of Chri≈øt.

3. And if this man had trauailed no further into Antiquities, then tho≈øe of this Nation, he might haue found both Archflamens in the Pagans time, heare in Britaine, and that the Legats of Pope Eleutherius did con≈øtitute and ordai ‚Ä¢ e Archbishops in their places, and this affirmed by Authoritie more Abbas Spanheymen≈ø. l. de Script. in Sigeberto Gembl. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 2. in Henric. HuÃÑtingt. Henric. Huntin. Hi≈øtor. lib. 1. & in Prologo Hi≈øt. auncient then Gratian was. For both Sigebertus GeÃÑblacen≈øis, Henricus Huntingtonien≈øis, and others which wrote before Gratian, doe take often and expre≈ø≈øe notice of our Brittish Hi≈øtorie, in which we reade of this matter in the≈øe words: fuerunt tunc in Britannia octo & viginti Flamines, nec non & tres Archiflamines, quorum potestati caeteri Iudices morum atque phanatici ≈øubmittebantur. Hos etiam ex praecepto Apostolici Idololatriae eripuerunt & vhi erant Flamines, Epi≈øcopos, vbi erant Archiflamines Archiepi≈øcopos po≈øuerunt. Sedes autem Archiflaminum
in tribus nobilioribus ciuitatibus fuerant, Londonijs videlicet atque Eboraci, & in vrbe Legionum: quam ≈øuper O≈øcam fluuium in Glamorgantia veteres muri & aedificia ≈øitam fui≈ø≈øe te≈øtantur: There were then (in the time of King Three Archbishops placed heare for the
‚Ä¢ . ArchflameÃÑs, in London, Yorke, and Caerlegion. Lucius) 28. Flamens, and 3. Archflamens, to who≈øe power other Iudges were ≈øubiect. The≈øe by the commande of the Pope his Legats deliuered from Idolatrie, and where there were Flamens they placed Bishops, and where there were Archflamens they placed Archbishops. The Seates of the Archflamens were in the three mo≈øt Noble Cyties, London, Yorke, and the Cytie of Legions which the old walles and buldings doe witne≈ø≈øe to haue bene vpon the Ryuer Oske in Glamorgantia. Hitherto this old Brittish Hi≈øtorie, which is older then Gratian by ≈øo many yeares, as were betweene the end and writing thereof at the death of Gadwallader the la≈øt King of the Btitans where it endeth, about the yeare of Chri≈øts Natiuitie 689. or 690. by Sigebertus and others computation when the Brittish Authour thereof compo≈øed it, and the writing of Gratian aboue 400. yeares after. And Sigebertus who endeth his Chronicle in the yeare 1112. and then dyed, as his Continuator there noteth: Sigebertus Gemblacen≈øis Monachus De≈øcriptor praecedentium Continuat ‚Ä¢ r Sigebertiin Chron. an. 1112. Sigebertus GeÃÑ blacen≈ø. initio Chronici c. de Regno Britannorum. in hoc libro temporum obijt, cui nos illa quae ≈øequuntur fideli narratione ≈øubiecimus, is a ≈øufficient witnes euen in the beginning of his Hi≈øtory that this Brittish Hi≈øtory then was an old Hi≈øtory: narrat antiqua Britannorum Hi≈øtoria, and v≈øually and cheifely citeth and followeth it for the Brittish affaires.
