And Henry of Huntington, who by Baleus and others dyed before Gratian had written, was well acquainted with this Hi≈øtorye, and wrote a Booke of the Kings of the Britans yet extant in the publike Library of Cambridge, and ≈øo conformable to the Brittish Hi≈øtory, that our Prote≈øtants which published his workes, thereby excu≈øe them≈øelues for not publishing that his worke, becau≈øe there is nothing in it, but what is written by S. Bede and Geffery of Monmouth more at lardge: quia nihil noui affert quod non in Beda & Monemuthen≈øi plenius Prote≈øtantium Annotatio inter librum 7. & 8. Hi≈øtor. Henrici Huntingtonien≈øis. Ponticus Virun. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 6. in fine. Ciacon. „Äà‚óä„Äâ . Ro≈ø≈øus. Bo≈øtoÃÑ apud Godwin. in A≈ø≈øaph. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 2. in Galfrid. Ar. Notatio in Manu≈øc. exempl. Cantab. Io. Bal. l. de Scrip. Brit. cent. 2. in Waltero Caleno. reperiatur. And Geffery Archdeacon of Monmouth when he tran≈ølated this Booke out of the Brittish into the Latine tongue, and after Bishop of A≈ø≈øaph, and Cardinall of the Church of Rome, as Virunnius, Ciaconius, Leland, Ro≈ø≈øeus, Bo≈øtonus, the Prote≈øtant Bishop Bale, and others ≈øay, was an excellent Hi≈øtorian, Hi≈øtoricus egregius, and as the note vpon the olde Manu≈øcript Copie thereof in Cambridge witne≈ø≈øeth, tran≈ølated it mo≈øt truely, ≈øimplici≈øsime transtulit. And this Booke was brought out of litle Britaine by Walter Calenus Archdeacon of Oxford a Britaine by birth, a man mo≈øt famous for learning, as our Authours ≈øay, and the Booke was, then he dying in the yeare of Chri≈øt 1120. anno Incarnati filij Dei 1120. a mo≈øt old Booke, vetu≈øti≈øsimum Britannici ≈øermonis Codicem: written aboue 400. yeares before‚ñ™ per quadringentos & eo amplius annos. From which date vnto his time the ≈øame Archdeacon of Oxoford continued the Brittish Hi≈øtory cloquently, non incleganti ≈øermone protraxit Britannorum Annales.

4. So we euidently perceaue that we can hardly finde either more auncient or credible Authoritie for any Hi≈øtoricall truth in our Brittish Antiquities, then for this. For the Authour both was a Britan, and wrote in that Languadge, and the la≈øt pa≈ø≈øadges thereof written allmo≈øt a thow≈øand yeares ≈øince. The Agents and In≈øtruments of the tran≈ølation thereof both Britans and the be≈øt learned, and greate≈øt Hi≈øtorians of that time, & this Bookew pre≈øerued by the Britans of Armorica, or litle Britaine in France, driuen thither by the Infidell Saxons, with their Antiquities and other Ritches mo≈øt pretious vnto them. And ≈øo the former parts of this Booke wherein the Hi≈øtorie
of the≈øe Archflamens is contained, carrieth ≈øufficient Argument of a farre more auncient date. Which the Authour him≈øelfe both in the Copie which is printed, and that which Virunnius did epitomate‚ñ™ and was neuer printed, as the note vpon it te≈øtifieth, doth witne≈ø≈øe: for he expre≈ø≈øely citeth Gildas for this Hi≈øtorie. And Ponticus Virunnius ≈øeemeth to make Gild ‚Ä¢ s Authour of that part of this Booke. For thus he writeth:
‚Ä¢ orum no ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ na & A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ us in libro reperiuntur, quem alter Gildas de victoria Aurelij Ambro≈øij in≈øcrip≈øit: The names Ponticus Virunnius Brit. Hi≈øt. l. 4. in fine. and ge≈øts of them which came with Damianus, and Faganus are found in the Booke which the other Gildas did Intitle, of the victorie of Aurelius Ambro≈øe. Where the di≈øtinction, alter Gildas, the other Gildas, hauing ≈øpoken of no other before, but onely the Authour whome he did epitomate mu≈øt needs make one Gildas Authour of that Brittish Hi≈øtorie, and ≈øo both the one and other Gildas to approue this narration of Archflamens in Britaine. Which he further confirmeth in the later end of his Bookes citing, for Authours of all which he had ≈øaid, both the Tran≈ølation of Geffery of Monmouth, whome he nameth an excellent Hi≈øtorian, and Cardinall, and Gildas the renouned Poet writing more then he did epitomate, which were things mo≈øt concerning the Romans, he being an Italian. Haec autem & multa alia de≈øcribit idem Gaufridus Monumeten≈øis, Hi≈øtoricus egregius, & Cardinalis: „Äà‚óä„Äâ & Gildas Poeta in≈øignis. Sed ego Ponticus Virunnius excepi, quae ad rem Romanam attinerent plurimum. And he ≈øpeaketh of many things which Galfridus Tran≈ølation hath not, which he mu≈øt needs by his owne confe≈ø≈øion haue from Gildas. And for this Hi≈øtory of our Brittish Archflamens; comprehend ‚Ä¢ d in the ge≈øts of the Brit. Hi≈øt. l. 4. c. 20. Roman Legats, the Tran≈ølation of Galfridus citeth Gildas, as Virunnius did, onely omitting the di≈øtinction, alter, the other, of that name: and mentioneth that Gildas did write more plainely or copiou≈øly of this m ‚Ä¢ tter then he doth: eorum nomina & actus in libro reperiuntur, quem Gild ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ de victoria Aurelij Ambro≈øij in≈øcrip≈øit. Quod autemtam lucido Tractatu parauer ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , nullatenus opusfuit, vt inferiori ≈øtylo renouaretur.

5. To this changing of Archflamens, three in number in Britaine to ≈øo many Archbishops, naming their places as before, and that Gildas in his Booke of the victory of Aurelius Ambro≈øe, wrote of this matter of King Lucius ≈øo conuerted then, is coÃÑ≈øented vnto by many forreine writers, as in France the Authour of the Hi≈øtorie Intituled, Mere des Hi≈øtories & Chroniques de France, Alan Bouchard, Mere des Hi≈øtoires l. 1. p. 91. Alan Bauchard Annales de Bretaigne l. 1. f. 19. p. 2. Ponticus Virun. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 4. and others; And to manife≈øt that the≈øe Authours which cite and follow Gildas in this Relation, as they haue witne≈ø≈øed before, doe ≈øpeake as plainely of this matter as the Brittish Hi≈øtorie, Virunnius deliuereth it, in the≈øe the ≈øame words: fuerant enim in Britannia octo & viginti Flamines, necnon & tres Archiflamines, quorum pote≈øtati caeteri Iudices morum, atque phanatici ≈øubmittebantur. Hos etiam ex praecepto Apostolico Idololatriae eripuerunt: & vbi erant Flamines, Epi≈øcopos: vbi autem Archiflamines, Archiepi≈øcopos po≈øuerunt, mira ≈øanctitate & incredibili deuotione. Sedis autem Archiflaminum in tribus nobilioribus ciuitatibus fuerant, Londonijs videlicet atque Eboraci, & in vrbe Legionum, quam ≈øuper O≈øcam fluuium in Glamorgantia veteres muri & aedificia ≈øitam fui≈ø≈øe te≈øtantur. And to leaue it without exception, that Gildas, or what≈øoeuer other old Brittish Authour he followed herein, went further in this matter of Archflamens, theÃÑ Galfridus his Tran≈ølation doth, he there addeth froÃÑ this old Brittish Antiquitie, that the Religion of the Archflamens, was the mo≈øt auncient Religion. Archiflaminum quae fuit antiqui≈øsima Religio. And Giraldus Cambren≈øis a mo≈øt Noble Co≈ømographer, Co≈ømographus nobili≈øsimus, as a Prote≈øtant Bishop

But I shall ≈øpeake hereafter of the Antiquitie of this ≈øtate from the Pagans them≈øelues, heare I was onely to Iu≈øtifie that ≈øuch men were heare in Britaine in King Lucius time, and their Re≈øidences changed into the Sees of Chri≈øtian Archbishops, which I haue performed, by the be≈øt and mo≈øt receaued Antiquities we haue left vnto vs. Which is confirmed by tho≈øe that haue written after namely among, ≈øtrangers writing of Brittish affaires, Martinus Polonus, Philippus Bergomen≈øis, Platina, Hartmannus Schedel Martin. Archflamens, which opinion will appeare the more probable, when I shall hereafter shew from our mo≈øt auncient and approued Authours, that this our Britaine as it contayned onely Loegria and Cambria, now England and Wales, neither King Lucius nor the Romans then Lords of more, had but 28. Cities in all to feate the≈øe 3. Archflamens and the other Flamens in, and 3. Archbishops and Bishops after them.

For English Hi≈øtorians whether Catholiks or Prote≈øtants I may pa≈ø≈øe The greate nuÃÑber of Bishops placed ‚Ä¢ ea ‚Ä¢ e. them ouer in this bu≈øines, ≈øeeing this Prote≈øtant Bishop hath before acknowledged that he and one other onely haue oppo≈øed therein. Therefore very vnadui≈øedly hath this Prote≈øtant Bishop before ≈øpoken, as he hath done of this Godwin ≈øupr. p. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . thing, and with no le≈ø≈øe boldnes further thus addeth: no man I dare affirme, is able to shew out of any auncient writer or other autheÃÑticall Monument, that euer there was any ≈øuch office amongst the Gentils as Archflamen or Protoflamen. Looke who li≈øt in that volume of auncient Incriptions published of late, by Gruterus, Scaliger and others: he may there finde oftentimes mentioned Flamen, for a man, and Flaminica for a woman Prei≈øt: but of Archflamen, Protoflamen or any other like, altum Silentium, there is no mention. For I haue proued by auncient, and the mo≈øt auncient writers we haue, that there was ≈øuch an office among the Gentils euen heare in Britaine. And if there were no memory of ≈øuch in auncient In≈øcriptions, as there is not of many, which mo≈øt confe≈ø≈øedly were, this is not able to di≈øcredit the truth hereof. And his Authour Gruterus is ≈øo farre from di≈øcrediting this, that the Gentils had Archflamens, as well as Flamens, that vpon the fir≈øt Epi≈øtle of S. Clement where Archiflamines be iu≈øtified both by his owne and S. Peters te≈øtimony, and that they were to be changed among Chri≈øtians into Primats or Patriarkes, he plainely writeth, it is the true Epi≈øtle of S. Clement: Lambert. Grut. Verenad. in Argumento 1. Epi≈øt. Clement. omnino ≈øtatuo, hanc Clementis veram e≈ø≈øe Epi≈øtolam: And vpon the very word Archiflamines, as in his opinion Rufinus liuing in S. Hierome his time tran≈ølateth S. Clement, he noteth in the Margin, that others called them the cheife Flamens Prei≈øts, or cheife Flamens. Archiflamines. Alias primi Sacerdotes

7. Be≈øides the≈øe, it is manife≈øt al≈øo by Aulus Gellius, Cicero and others Aulus Gellius l. 15. c. 27. that there were euen among the Romans, Pontifices, Rex Sacrorum & Flamines, the high Prei≈øts or Archflamens, King of holy things and Flamens. And how both the Flamins, and Rex were ≈øubiect to the Pontifex is, be≈øides that is ≈øaid before, expre≈ø≈øely affirmed by Titus Liuius, where he teacheth that the Rex which was aboue the Flamins, was ≈øubiect to the Pontifex; Regis ≈øacrificuli ≈øacerdotium Pontifici ≈øubiectum. Licinius the Pontifex. Flaminem Dialem inuitum inaugurari coegit P. Licinius Pontifex Maximus. Which is confirmed Valer. Maxim. l. 6. c. 9. Lucius Florus Epitom. l. 19. Titus Liu. l. 7. decad 4. This is confirmed out of the Imperiall and Ciuill Lawe, where it is written of the time long before Chri≈øt, where the cheife Power of interpreting all their Lawes, Tribunitian of the twelue Tables or other beloÃÑged to the Colledge of the Pontifices or Archflamens: omnium harum & interpretandi ≈øcientia & actiones, apud Collegium Pontificum erant: ex quibus con≈øtituebatur, quis quoquo Tom. 1. pandect. lib. 1. And to ≈øpeake expre≈ø≈øely of our Brittish Flamens and Druids: Iulius Cae≈øar as our Theater Prote≈øtants tran≈ølate him, witne≈ø≈øeth, that in euery gouernment or Prouince: ouer all the≈øe Druids there is one Primate which hath cheife Authoritie ouer them. Magdeburgen: centur. 2. pag. 15. Beat. Rhenan. Re ‚Ä¢ . Germanic. l. 3. pag. 123. 124. quo mortuo alius, qui dignitate pollebat, eligebatur. The Magdeburgians ≈øay there were diuers orders of ≈øuch among the Gentils, ≈øome Pontifices Maximi, others Flamens and the inferior Prei≈øts, Alij Pontifices Maximi appellantur: alij Flamines. Beatus Rhenanus deliuereth how the primatiue Chri≈øtians did place Archbishops and Metropolitans according to the Prouinces of the Pagan Romans, and particularly reciteth many, ≈øaying they had Archbishops, and Metropolitans for their old Primacy in the Pagans times, propter ciuitatum veterem primatum, and this is that, ≈øaith he, which Pope Lucius ≈øaith: Cities and places in which Primats ought to gouerne were appointed long before Chri≈øt. negotijs appellabant. And there acknowledgeth that both this S. Lucius which was Pope in the yeare 155. and S. Clement Succe≈ø≈øor to S. Peter directed, that the≈øe Metropolitans should be placed where ArchflameÃÑs were in the time of the Pagans. The fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury, his Succe≈ø≈øor there Whitegift, Foxe, Ihon Pri≈øe, Barnes, and other principall Prote≈øtants of England acknowledg as much, and proue it from S. Anacletus Matth. Parker Ant. Brit. Whitgift again≈øt Cartw. Pri≈ø. def. hi≈øt. Britan. Rob. Barnes in Vit. Pontif. in Anacl. Otto Frigen≈ø. Chron. l. 3. c. 2. and others, that it was an Apo≈øtolicall ordination, that ≈øuch should ≈øucceed in place of the Pagan Archflamens. Therefore, ≈øeeing there is ≈øo generall a con≈øent herein of all writers, I will coÃÑclude with that auncieÃÑt Noble and learned Bishop Otto FrigeÃÑ≈øis that wrote before GratiaÃÑ, or the TraÃÑ≈ø≈øator of the Brittish Hi≈øtorie, & ≈øpeaketh as plainely as either Fene≈øtella did, or any man can doe, and with the generall opinion of Chri≈øtians in his time: vbi ≈øub principibus gentium Flamines erant, ibi po≈øtmodum a nostris locati ≈øunt Epi≈øcopi. Vbi illi Archiflamines, nos Archiepi≈øcopos: vbi illi Protoflamines, nos Primates ≈øeu Patriarchas habere caepimus, omnes quidem vnius ordinis, ≈øed pro differentia ciuitatum diuer≈øae dignitatis: where vnder the Primas of the gentils there were Flamins, there by Chri≈øtians, Bishops were placed. Where they had Archflamens we began to haue Archbishops. Where they had Protoflamens, there we had Primats or Patriarks, all of one order, but of different dignitie for the diuer≈øitie of the Cities.

div.head: THE XVIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: IN WHAT PLACES OF BRITAINE THESE cheife≈øt commanding Archflamens were, to witt at London, Yorke and Caerlegion, and how the≈øe Roman Legats placed for them Archbishops, with their ≈øeuerall commands, and Iuri≈ødictions, ≈øome of them by the Apo≈øtolike power extending, and commanding ouer Prouinces and Countryes not temporally ≈øubiect to King Lucius of Britaine, or the Romans, but rather enemyes vnto them in cyuill affayres.

Chronicl. f. 16. c. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . fir≈øt, Thalie≈ø≈øinus aboue 1000. yeares ≈øince, William of Malmesbury, Henry of Huntington, Gualterus Calenus, Sigebertus with many others before Galfridus Monumeten≈øis wrote, and him≈øelfe Virunnius, and innumerable after both of this and other Nations, and publike Parlaments, as that in the time of King Edward the fir≈øt at Lincolne, where after mo≈øt diligent ≈øearch of Antiquities, and due examination, as this greate≈øt matter of the right of a kingdome required, ≈øent his Apologeticall letters to the Pope of Rome, ≈øealed with an hundred ≈øeales, and witne≈ø≈øes. Rex Angliae ex deliberato apud Lincolniam conuocato Con≈øilio, pro iure ≈øuo declarando literam huius tenoris re≈øcrip≈øit centum ≈øigillis ≈øignatam. Wherein is declared, and iu≈øtified that in the time of Hely, and Samuel the Prophet, Brutus the Troian landed heare, and by his owne name, called the Country Britannia, before named Albion‚ñ™ de nomine ≈øuo Britanniam, ≈øocio≈øque ≈øuos Britones appellauit. And hauing three ≈øonnes, Locrinus, Albanact, and Camber, did at his death diuide the IlaÃÑd into three parts, or Prouinces, Loegria, now England to Locrinus his elde≈øt ≈øonne: Albania, Scotland to Albanact the ≈øecond: and Cambria Wales to Camber the younge≈øt. Locrino primoginito dedit illam partem quae quondam Loegria, nunc vero Anglia nominatur. Albanacto filio natu ≈øecundo dedit Albaniam, quae nunc Scotia vocitatur, Cambro vero tertio filio dedit Cambriam, quae modo wallia nominatur, re≈øeruata Locrino Regia dignitate. This might ≈øuffice for this bu≈øines, for being te≈øtified with ≈øo many dome≈øticall and forreine, priuate and publike witne≈ø≈øes, that this Tripartited diui≈øion was heare from the beginning and fir≈øt name of Britaine, we mu≈øt needs for euery ≈øeuerall part and Prouince, a≈ø≈øigne a ≈øeuerall gouernment, and order therein, as their Rulers and Gouernours were diuers and di≈øtinct.

2. But our Antiquities carry vs further, and informe not onely that London, Yorke, and Caerlegion were the ≈øeuerall cheife Cities in this diui≈øion, but the Kings which founded them, for ≈øuch, ordayned them likewi≈øe to be the Seats and Re≈øidences of three ≈øeuerall Archiflamens, or Protoflamens. For the glory and Noblenes of London therevpon named Augu≈øta, I haue ≈øpokeÃÑ before, and as it is the common opinion in Antiquities, that it is the mo≈øt auncient Citie of this Iland, builded by Brutus, as not onely the Brittish Hi≈øtorie, Galfridus, Virunnius, and our English Antiquaries after them, but Gildas, Sigebertus, and others ≈øufficiently witnes, and except M. Stowe is deceaued in his Authours Aethicus an old Pagan Philo≈øopher te≈øtifieth no le≈ø≈øe, affirming that Brutus named this kingdome Brutannia. And Ihon Harding in his plaine ver≈øe with others recordeth, how he there from the very beginning in≈øtituted an Archflamens Seate.

An Archflaume his S ‚Ä¢ e Cathedrall certayne

By Troian Lawe.

div.p: This is commonly written to haue bene 1100. yeares before Chri≈øt. And it is a coÃÑmon receaved opinion among our Antiquaries, that EbraÃÑcus ≈øonne to Mempricius about 100. yeares after, builded the Citie of Yorke, calling it after his name, Kairbranke, as both Brittans and Saxons, Catholiks and Prote≈øtants con≈øent. Whereas Harding, and Stowe with others affirme he ≈øeated an Archflamen. Harding ≈øaith.

Of Diane, where an Archflamen he ≈øett
To rule Temples as that time was his dett.

div.p: In the tweÃÑtith yeare of his Reigne (writeth Stowe) he builded Kayrbranke, ≈øince by the Saxons called Euorwike, now corruptly Yorke, wherein he builded a Temple to Diana, and ≈øett there an Archflamen, and was there buryed when he had reigned 60. yeares. Thus auncient the≈øe our Hi≈øtorians make Archflamens in Britaine, and I haue related their very words: not that I thinke the name and worde Archflamen, but onely their office and calling among the Gentils to be ≈øo auncient, as the time a≈ø≈øigned to our Brutus, but of youÃÑger continuance and age by diuers hundreds of yeares, the word Flamen not knowne vntill the time of Numa Pompilius, and taken from a kinde of attyre worne vppon their heads on Fe≈øtiuall dayes, yet the office of Flamen, Ranulp. Higed. l. 1. c. 24. and Pontifex, and Archflamen and ≈øummus Pontifex was allwayes the ≈øame among the Pagans.

3. The In≈øtitution of the third Archflamen at Caerlegion vppon vske was of later time, as al≈øo the Foundation of that Citie fir≈øt builded by Belinus, as the Brittish Hi≈øtorie, Galfridus, Virunnius, Matthew We≈øtm. Ranulph. Higeden, Caxton, Harding, Stowe, Hollinshed, and to write in his words, mo≈øt parte of Holinshed Hi≈øt. Engl. l ‚Ä¢ b. 3. cap. 4. Galfr. Mon. l. 3. H ‚Ä¢ ≈øt. c. 10. V ‚Ä¢ run. l. 3. Matth. We≈øt. aetat. 5. Ranulp ‚Ä¢ . Higeden l. 1. c. 48 all our writers, haue deliuered. Galfridus calleth this Citie Kaero≈øe. Virunnius nameth it Caeru≈øc, the Monke of We≈øtm. Kaeru≈øc. Higeden termeth it Caerhuth. And ≈øuch nake it kept vntill the comming of the Romans hither, when of their Legions wintring there, it was named Caerlegion, as al≈øo Che≈øter was as the ≈øame Ranulphus which liued and wrote his Hi≈øtorie there with others, witne≈ø≈øeth. And this Caeru≈øc was the Metropolis of tho≈øe parts. And as diuers of the Authours te≈øtifie Belinus ≈øeated an Archflamen there as he al≈øo confirmed the Archflamens of London and Yorke. Thus among Harding Cron. f. 29. c. 33. others Harding relateth.

lg.l: Three Archflamens he made through all Britaine
As Archbishops now in our Lawes bene:
There Temples all to gouerne and domaine
At Troynouant one Logres to ouer≈øene
Her fals Gods to ≈øerue and to queme.
At Ebranke an other for Albany,
And at Caerleon for Cambre one ≈øoueranly.

div.p:
So hath Stowe with others. And their generall agreement is, that the≈øe Stowe Hi≈øt. in Bel ‚Ä¢ n. were the cheife, mo≈øt renowned and Metropolitan Cities in Britaine. which being ≈øo amply proued, and ≈øo many con≈øenting that there were Archflamens in them all ≈øo long before the coÃÑming of Chri≈øt, le≈ø≈øe Authoritie then we haue for this matter, might ≈øerue vs to coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe, that ≈øeeing at the abolishing of the≈øe Pagan Rulers, and Rites they ought to be and were changed into ≈øo many Archbishops or Metropolitans in Chri≈øtian Religion. And this is ≈øo euident a truth in Hi≈øtories, that the Prote≈øtant Bishop him≈øelfe, which before with one onely oppo≈øed again≈øt Archflamens freely confe≈ø≈øeth, that at this time Archbishops were placed in tho≈øe three Cities in Britaine, and in them onely, where ≈øo many haue te≈øtified, and shall te≈øtifie further hereafter, the≈øe Archflamens were re≈øident. Thus he writeth: At what time Chri≈øtian Godwin Cat. of Bishops in London 1. p. 181. edit. an. 1615. R ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gion „Äà‚óä„Äâ fir≈øt publi ‚Ä¢ ly receaued in this I≈øland, there were established in the ≈øame 28. Sees or Cathear ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ i Churches, whereof three were Archbishopricks, Yorke who≈øe Prouince was Scotland, and the North of England: Caerlegion, now called
Carlcon vpon v≈øk, to which the Churches of Wales where ≈øubiect: and lastly London, that had Iuri≈ødiction ouer the re≈øt of England.

4. Therefore this, which is the cheife≈øt matter in this bu≈øines, being thus granted by all, and the other ≈øo ≈øufficiently proued, I will onely add to the former, for the more euidency hereof, the te≈øtimonie of ≈øome few others, ≈øuch as eyther were before the time of Geffery of MoÃÑmouth the Tran≈ølatour of the Brittish Hi≈øtory, or tooke their notice from other Authours then that Hi≈øtory. Ranulphus Higeden in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory citeh Alfridus Beuerlacen≈øis, who by a Prote≈øtant Bishop wrote an excellent Hi≈øtory from the beginning of the Britans and coming of Brute hither to his owne time in the Reigne of King William the Ba≈øtard, allmo≈øt 100. yeares before Geffery of Monmouth could write. Ab origine Britannorum ad ≈øuam aetatem v≈øque contexuit Historiam Io. Bal. l. de Scrip. cent. 2. in Alfrid. Beue ‚Ä¢ lacen. Alf ‚Ä¢ idus Beuerl. apud Ranulph. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ geden. l. 1. c. 52 de Epi≈øcop ‚Ä¢ t ‚Ä¢ b. in l ‚Ä¢ bro Manu≈øc. perpulchram: And writeth, as Ranulphus citeth him, that in the time of Lucius the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King of the Britans, there were in Britaine three Archbishops Sees: To witt, at London, Yorke and Caer-hur≈øc the Citie of Legions in Glamorgan shire, to whom there were ≈øubiect 28. Bishops then called Flamens, that is to the Metropolitan of London were ≈øubiect Cornewall, and all Loegria to the Riuer Humber. To him of Yorke all Northumberland from Humber, with all Albania. To the Citie of Legions was ≈øubiect all Cambria then adorned with ≈øeuen Bishops, now with fower Suffragans. Sedes Archiepi≈øcoporum in Britannia tres fuerunt tempore Lucij Regis Britannorum primi Chri≈øtiani, videlicet apud London, apud Eboracum, apud Caer-hur≈øc vrbem Legionum in Glamorgancia. Quibus tunc ≈øubiecti fuerunt 28. Epi≈øcopi Flamines tunc vocati. Videlicet Londonien≈øi Metropolitano Cornubia & tota Loegria v≈øque ad flumen Humbrum. Eboracen≈øi ver√≤ tota terra Northimbrina ab arcu Humbri fluminis cum tota Albania. Vrbi Legionum ≈øubiacuit tota Cambria 7. tunc Epi≈øcopis, nunc ver√≤ 4. Suffraganeis in≈øignita: Quam flumen Sabrinae tunc ≈øecernebat √† Loegria. I haue peru≈øed an old French Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtorie, who≈øe manner of writing and Characters may well giue it a greater Age then any copy of Galfridus Tran≈ølation, though it be continued vntill within 400. yeares perhaps by ≈øome other, but whether ≈øo or otherwi≈øe, this differeth in very many things euen in this Hi≈øtorie from that Tran≈ølation of the Brittish Hi≈øtory, whether we will follow that which our Prote≈øtants haue published, or that which Ponticus Virunnius did epitimate, and ≈øo he cannot ground what he deliuereth vppon Galfridus. Fir≈øt they differ in the number of the Flamens, Galfride and Ponticus number 28. in Britaine be≈øides the Archflamens, this Hi≈øtory ≈øaith, there were but 27. they ≈øay that King Lucius was buried at Gloce≈øter, dying by Galfridus in the yeare 156. and by Virunnius an. 159. the French Hi≈øtory deliuereth he died in the yeare 196. So long after, and though he died at Gloce≈øter, yet he was buried at Caerlegion: Galfride calleth this Citie Kaer-o≈øe, and Virunnius Caer-u≈øc: whereas the French Authour nameth it, the Citie of Legions which i ‚Ä¢ vppon the Ryuer of V≈øks, not as others terme it, And he nameth Yorke Euerwicks, as the Saxons did, and not as Geffry, Ponticus and the Britans did of Ebranke. Therefore this auncient Authour whether before or after Galfridus, cannot be ≈øaide to take his directions from that Tran≈ølation, Manu≈øc. French H ‚Ä¢ ≈øt. very old pr. or que nous ≈øommes. c. 9. an. 18 ‚Ä¢ . with which he cro≈ø≈øeth ≈øo often both in the≈øe and other matters: Yet for this bu≈øines we haue now in hand, he deliuereth it in the≈øe words: At that time there were in Britaine now called England 27. Flamins, and three Archflamins according to the manner of their Pagani≈øm ‚Ä¢ , but the aforenamed Doctours ‚ñ™Fagan and Damian, cast them out, and where were Flamyns, they made Bishops, and where
there were Archflamyns, they made Archbishops. The Sees to the≈øe three Archflamins
To what Archbishop what Bishops and Prouinces were ≈øubiect. The Orchades Iles and Scotland ≈øubiect to the Archbishop of York ‚Ä¢ . M. S. Fran√ßoi≈øe ≈øupr. an. 180. Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 5. c. 1. being in the three mo≈øt Noble Cities of Britaine, which were London Euerwicks, and the Citie of Legions vppon the Ryuer vsks, in the Country of Glamorgan in Wales, not farre from Seuerne, which is in a place delitious, and pa≈øsing in Ritches all other Cities. To the≈øe three were ≈øubiect 27. Bishops. To the Archbishop of Euerwicks were ≈øubiect Deira, and Northumberland, Scotland and Albania diuided by Diece≈øes beyond Humber which parteth them from Loegres which now is called England. To the Archbishop of London were ≈øubiect Loegres, and Cornwayle. And he ≈øetteth downe with the truth and common opinion, that the≈øe things were acted about the yeare of Chri≈øt 180. both in Pope Eleutherius and King Lucius time, which the published Tran≈ølation of Galfridus mu≈øt needs mi≈øtake, affirming King Lucius died in the yeare 156. when Eleutherius was not Pope while long after. So this Authour mu≈øt needs follow others and not Galfridus in this narration. And the Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory named Abbreuiatio Chronicorum, in that copy which I follow beginning at Adam and ending in the yeare of Chri≈øt 1063. argueth the Authour farre more auncient then Geffry of Monmouth, and placing this Hi≈øtory of planting Religion heare by Faganus and Diuuanus Pope Eleutherius Legats betweene the yeare 170. and 180. writeth more truely of this matter then our published Galfridus Tran≈ølation, and could not imitate that herein: Yet this Authour plainely te≈øtifieth, that the≈øe two Legats finding heare in Britaine three Archflamens be≈øides 28. Flamens, one of them at London, a ≈øecond at Yorke, and the third at Caerlegion con≈øtituted Archbishops in their places, conformably limiting their Circuits and Iuri≈ødictions. Erant tunc in Britannia 28. Flamines, & tres Archiflamines, & vbi erant Flamines, Epi≈øcopos: vbi autem Archiflamines, Archiepi≈øcopos po≈øuerunt. Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. Abbreuiatio Chronicorum inter ann. 170. & an. 180. Io. Bal. l. de Scrip. Brit. cent. 2. in Radulph. de Rizeto. Londonen≈øi Archiepi≈øcopo ≈øubiacuit Loegria, & Cornubia. Eboracen≈øi Deira & Albania: Vrbi autem Legionum Cambria.

5. Vnto the≈øe I may ioyne Dicetus Deane of London, or as a Prote≈øtant Bishop calleth him Radulphus de Rizeto, who though he wrote a litle after Galfridus, dying about the yeare of Chri≈øt 1200. yet he did not follow Galfridus Tran≈ølation, but a≈ø≈øigneth this labour of the Popes Legats in placing Bishops and Archbishops for Flamens and Archflamens to the yeare of Chri≈øt 178. aboue twenty yeares after King Lucius death by Geffery his Tran≈ølation. Theater of great Britaine l. 6. Dicetus Deane of London, a Manu≈øcript in the Kings Library ad an. 178. Yet by our Prote≈øtant writers of the Theater of greate Britaine in his Manu≈øcript in the Kings Library at the yeare remembred 178. this matter is thus regi≈øtrid. There were in Britaine eight and twenty Flamyns, and three Archflamins, in ≈øtead of which ≈øo many Bishops and Archbishops were appointed: vnder the Archbishop of London were the Prouinces of Loegria and Cornubia: vnder Yorke Deira, and Albania: vnder vrbs Legionum Cambria. And Harding differing aboue thirtie yeares in his computation from the Bishop of A≈øaph his Tran≈ølation, and ≈øo in no manner to be thought his follower in this matter, yet thus he agreeth herein. Harding Chron. f. 4 ‚Ä¢ . c. 51.

lg.l: Of 3. Archflamens they made Archbishopricks

l.hi: One at London, Troynouant that hight
For all Logres with Lawes full autentikes
To rule the Church, and Chri≈øtentee in right.
An other at Carlion a Towne of might
For all Cambre, at Ebranke the third
From Trent North, for Albany is kvde.

div.p:
I haue cited Martinus Polonus, Bergomen≈øis, Ptolomeus Lucen≈øis, Platina,
Hartmannus Schedel and diuers French Hi≈øtorians before, all of them ≈øo farre differing from the Brittish Hi≈øtorie in their calculation, and other circum≈øtances, that they caÃÑnot be called followers thereof: yet they all agree, that the Flamens and Archflamens heare were now changed into Bishops and Archbishops, & the three ArchflameÃÑs as al≈øo the Archbishops which were ordayned in their places were at London, Yorke, and Caerlegion in Wales. So al≈øo te≈øtifie our English Cronicles, as the old English Chronicle published by Caxton, Caxton Hi≈øtorie in King Lucius. Old Manu≈øcript. Engl. Chronicle in K. Lucius. Ho
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h. hi≈øt. of Eng ‚Ä¢ . lib. 4. cap. 19. Stow. & Howes Hi≈øt. an. 179. in Lucius. Theater of great Britaine l. 6. Barnes in vit. Pontif. Rom. in Eleuther. Stowe ≈øupr. Godwin Conuer≈ø. of Brit. p. 26. Io. Selden Analect. c. 6. Pomp. Laet. de Sacerd. Rom. c. 7. Fene≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ l. de Sacerd. Rom. c. 5. and thereby commonly called Caxtons Chronicle: likewi≈øe doth an other more auncient English Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory. So te≈øtifie our Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians, Raphael Holinshed, Howes and Stowe, the Prote≈øtant Theater writers, Barnes, Whitgift, Bridges, Barlowe and others again≈øt the Puritans, and to conclude with two Prote≈øtants Stowe, and Godwine, the fir≈øt ≈øaith it is the common opinion of the writers of that time: The other as before granteth it is the Iudgment of diuers both auncient and learned, and ≈øo generall, that he, a greate Searcher into Antiquities perceaueth not any that haue gayne≈øaid it before Doctour Sutcleffe. And he is wholly reiected therein by ≈øuch Prore≈øtant Antiquaries, as haue written ≈øince, among whome M. Ihon Selden following the generall opinion of changing Flamens and Archflamens in Britaine to Bishops and Archbishops, and placing the Archflamens and Archbishops in London, Yorke and Caerlegion, and citing both Pomponius Laetus, and Fene≈øtella, addeth: Quemadmodum autem Epi≈øcopis apud nos Archiepi≈øcopi, ≈øic Flaminibus Archiflamines praeponebantur. As among vs Chri≈øtians, Archbishops are aboue Bishops, ≈øo in the Pagans Lawe were Archflamens aboue Flamens. And he proueth with the re≈øt before, that although neither King Lucius, nor the Roman Emperours had any command in Scotland, yet the≈øe Legats ≈øubmitted that Country to the Archbishop of Yorke his Iuri≈ødiction; diui≈øis Parochijs ≈øubiacuit Metropolitano Eboracen≈øi Deira & Albania, quas magnum flumen Humbri √† Loegria fecerunt. And citing Polyder, and Camden, he addeth that in Polid. Virgil. l. 13 H ‚Ä¢ ≈øt. Camden. ‚Ä¢ n Brig. auncient time the Archbishop of Yorke was Primate of Scotland, and this was ree≈øtablished in a Prouinciall Councell heare by Hugo the Popes Legate in the time of King Henry the ≈øecond. Eboracen≈øis autem Archiepi≈øcopus in omnes Scotiae Prae≈øules ac Anti≈øtites iure Primatus olim fungebantur. Quod & re≈øancitum erat ≈øub Henrico ≈øecuÃÑdo, & Hugone Legato PoÃÑtificio. His fir≈øt Authour ≈øaith Polyd. Virgil. Angl. Hi≈øt. l. 13. in Henric. 2. pag. 234. it was vrged in this Councell by Roger then Archbishop of Yorke, that the Right of that See to haue Power ouer the Scottish Bishops might be re≈øtored vnto it, for the Popes of Rome had euen from the beginning ordayned the Bishop of Yorke to be Primate of all Scotland, and the Orchades and the re≈øt of the Ilands. Which Lawe ≈øo made, the Bishops of tho≈øe places had kept many yeares. Agitatum e≈øt vt Rogerio Archiepi≈øcopo Eboracen≈øi qui id temporis eam tenebat ≈øedem, ius in Epi≈øcopos Scotiae re≈øtitueretur: Quandoquidem Romani Pontific ‚Ä¢ s George Buc. kni ‚Ä¢ ht di≈øcour≈øe of the 3. Vmuer≈øitie. c. 6. of S. Pete ‚Ä¢ s in Cornehill. i am inde ab initio ≈øanxerant ip≈øum Eboracen≈øem Anti≈øtitem totius quoque Scotiae atque Orchadum, caeterarumque In≈øularum Primatem. Quam ≈øan√® datam legem eorum locorum Epi≈øcopi per multos deinde annos ≈øeruarunt. The auncient Armes of S. Peters Church one Cornhill, as our Prote≈øtaÃÑt Antiquaries deliuer theÃÑ, will keepe in memory from whom Religion heare receaued Foundatian. Thus

Peter in Chornill, by right of prioritie and precedencie, which belongeth to Antiquitie, should haue the fir≈øt place, for it is held by our be≈øt Antiquaries to be the mo≈øt aunci ‚Ä¢ nt Chri≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n Church of London, being founded about the yeare of Chri≈øt 160. and it is recorded, to be the mo≈øt auncient See both of the Ar ‚Ä¢ hbishops, and al≈øo Bishops of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ndon. Lucius King founded the fir≈øt Metropolitan See of Lond ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ at We≈øtmin≈øter, out of the Ruines of a Temple there, formerly erected to „Äà‚óä„Äâ

div.head: THE XVIV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE EPISCOPALL SEES AND CITIES, of the Inferiour Bishops ≈øubordinate to the Archbishops, which, where, and how many they were, ordayned by the≈øe Roman Legats, and continued Bishops Sees in the Romans and Britans time.

div.p:
1. HAVING thus ≈øeated, and di≈øpo≈øed of our holy Primatiue, Arche, Cheife, Higher and commanding Bishops in their ≈øeuerall Sees and Iuri≈ødictions, Method and Order by relatiue and mutuall connexion betweene ≈øuch, Where other Bishops were now placed in Britaine in this time, with our auncient Cyties, their Sees. and Ordinary, Lower, Suffragan and Inferiour Bishops, calleth vppon mee to ≈øetle the≈øe al≈øo, ≈øo well as a de≈øolation of our Antiquities will permitt in their Cities, Dioce≈øes, and Gouernments. We haue had two Rules from Antiquitie deliuered vnto vs before, to help vs in this labour; One, that they were placed, as the cu≈øtome was from the beginning, in our Brittish Cities; The other, that they were ordayned where the Pagan Flamens were before. Gildas writeth that Britaine had eight and twenty Cities be≈øides ≈øtrong Ca≈øtles, but nameth them not. Bis denis, bisque quaternis ciuitatibus in≈øtructa. So do many others, Gildas libro de conq. & exidio Brit. in initio. Nennius in proaem. hi≈øt. Manu≈øcript. among whom Nennius or Nenius is one, and he deliuereth both the number, and names of our Brittish Cities in this Order. Haec ≈øunt nomina omnium ciuitatum quae ≈øunt in tota Britannia, quarum numerus e≈øt 28. The≈øe are the names of all the Cities which be in all Britaine, being 28. in number: Cair Gnoricon. Cair Guerthigirn. Cair Municip. Cair Megnod. Cair Eboranc. Cair Caratanc. Cair Mauchguid. Cair Caint. Cair Peris. Cair Legion. Cair Regent. Cair Guerit. Cair Lerion. Cair Pen≈øanelcoit. Cair Celermon. Cair Gunting. Cair Luordijs. Cair Colan. Cair Custemt. Cair Granth. Cair Lunden. Cair Guoirangon. Cair Danu. Cair Legion. Cair Britto. Cair Droithan. Cair Vrnach. Cair Luitcoit. Thus they are recompted by Nennius in one Copy. In an other more auncient, they are related thus. Cair Guntgme. Cair miuncip. Cair Ligalid. Meguard, or, Meguid. Colun. Ebranc. Cu≈øtemt. Carntanc. Granth. Manuguid. Lunden. Guorchigirn. Gumigon. Peris. Claun. Legion. Guricon. Segemt. Cair Legion. Guar V≈øic. Guent. Brithon. Lerion. Draithon. Cair Pen≈øa Vell Coit. Vrnach. Celennon. Cair Luit Coit. Thus they are ≈øeuerally written in tho≈øe two ≈øeuerall Manu≈øcript Copies, of Nennius, as I could with my be≈øt diligence ob≈øerue. Onely with this further difference, that the note of their number to be 28. in all, is in the fir≈øt and later Manu≈øcript written in the end, after the Cities recited, in the la ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
and olde≈øt, it is ≈øett downe before the names of the Cities. And although at the fir≈øt vewe the≈øe Relations will ≈øeeme to vary much, yet an indifferent Reader though but meanely exerci≈øed in reading auncient Manu≈øcripts, and ob≈øeruing how often and ordinarily vnlearned, or improuident Scribes doe mi≈øtake, alter, add, or detract letters in tran≈øcribing old writings, he will reconcile them with litle or no materiall difference.

2. And Henry ArchdeacoÃÑ of Huntington, who as Geffry of MoÃÑmouth writeth, Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. l. 12. c. 20. Henricus Hunting. hi≈øtoriar. l. 1. ¬ß. Hucu≈øque. L. 1. Fere in Initio. had written his Hi≈øtory before he tran≈ølated the Brittish Hi≈øtorie, & had not ≈øeene it, as he relateth the coÃÑming of Brutus hither, as he found it in other Authours, which had written it before, in alijs Authoribus reperi, ≈øaith, this our Britaine which he called ≈øo after his owne name, ex nomine ≈øuo Britanniam vocauit, be≈øides innumerable walled & ≈øtronge Ca≈øtels, had aunciently in the Britans and Romans time 28. mo≈øt Noble Cities: erat ciuitatibus quondam 28. nobili≈øsimis in≈øignita, praeter Ca≈øtella innumera, quae & ip≈øa muris, turribus, portis ac ≈øeris erant in≈øtructa firmi≈øsimis. Ciuitatum autem nomina haec erant Britannic√®: And the≈øe 28. Cities names in Brittish ≈øpeach were the≈øe: Kair Ebrancid e≈øt Eboracum, Yorke. Kair chent 1. Cantuaria, Canterbury. Kair Gorangon 1. Wigornia, worce≈øter. Kair Lundene 1. Lundonia, London. Kair Legion or Lirion. 1. Le ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øtria, Leice≈øter. Kair Collon, 1. Colecea≈øtria, Colche≈øter. Kair Glou. 1. Gloueceastria, Gloce≈øter. Cair Cei, 1. Cicea≈øtria. Kair-Bri≈øton. Kair-Ceri, 1. Cicerceastria. Kair Guent, 1. wincea≈øtria, winche≈øter. Kair Grant, 1. Grantecea≈øtria quae modo dicitur Cantebrigia alias Grantebrigia, Cambridge. Kair Lion quam vocamus Carleuil, Carlile. Kair Dauri. 1. Doreceastria, Dorchester. Kair, Dorm. 1. Dormeceastria, quae ≈øita in Huntedonen≈øi Prouincia ≈øuper Flumen quod vocatur Nen penitus destructa e≈øt. Dormanche≈øter (not Godmanche≈øter or Gormanche≈øter) in Huntington shire vpon the Riuer Nen, vtterly de≈øtroied. It was betweene Wansford and Stilton, about twelue myles North from Huntington in the Roade way to Yorke. Kair Loitchoit 1. Lincolnia Lincoln. Kair Merdin, quae nunc quoque ≈øic vocatur. Still ≈øo called. Kair Guorcon. Kair Cucerat. Kair Guortigern. Kair vraac. Kair Celemion. Kair Meguaid. Kair Licelid. Kair Peris 1. Porce≈øtre. Kair Kegion al. Lerion in qua fuit Archiepi≈ø ‚Ä¢ opatus tempore Britonum: nunc autem vix maenia eius comparent, Vbi v≈øca ‚Ä¢ adit in Sabrinam, in which there was an Archbishops See in the time of the Britons, now ≈øcarly appeare the walls thereof where the Ryuer V≈øc falleth into Seuerne. Kair Draiton. Kair Mercipit. Kair Segent quae fuit ≈øuper Tame≈øin non long√® a Reding & vocatur Silce≈øtre. Haec erant nomina Ciuitatum tempore Romanorum & Britannorum. Kair Segent which was vpon the Riuer of Thems not farre from Reding and is called Silce≈øtre. The≈øe were the names of the Cyties in the time of the Romans and Britans. Thus this Archdeacon of Huntington:

3. And the Monke of Che≈øter Ranulphus Higeden citing Alfridus, thus writeth in the ≈øame manner. Regio Britanniae quondam erat ciuitatibus nobili≈øsimis Ra ‚Ä¢ ulph. Higid. Polychronic. l. 1. c. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . M. S. 28. in≈øignita. The Country of Britaine was in old times adorned with 28. Cyties be≈øides an innumerable number of Ca≈øtles defen≈øed with mo≈øt ≈øtronge walls, Towers Gates and Locks. The names of the Cyties were the≈øe: Caerlud, that is London. Caer Ebranc, Yorke. Caerkent, Canterbury. Caergorangon, worce≈øter. Caerlirion, Leyce≈øter. Caer Clau, Glorce≈øter. Caer Golden, Colche≈øter. Caerrei, Chiche≈øter. Which the Saxons aunciently called Ci≈ø≈øance≈øter. Caerceri, Cirence≈øter. Caerwent, Winche≈øter. Caergrant, Cambridge. Caerliel, Lugubalia, Carlile. Caerperis, Porche≈øter. Caerdrom, Dorche≈øter. Caerludcoit, Lincoln. Caermerthin, that is to ≈øay the Citie of Merlin. Caer≈øegen, Silce≈øter which is ≈øeated vpon Thames nor farre from Reding. Caerthleon, or Caerlegion, that is the Ci ‚Ä¢ ie of Legions, which fir≈øt was called
Legecester, but now it is named Che≈øter. Caer Badon, Bathe, which ≈øometime was called the Citie of Achamannus. Caer Paladur, Septoma now Sha≈øtesbury. There are al≈øo others names of Cities found in Chronicles. Thus this Manu≈øcript Authour ≈øpeaking of Caerlegion vpon V≈øc where the Achiepi≈øcopall See was in the l. 1. cap. 48. next Chapter. Diuers of the≈øe Cities had their Foundation, or at the lea≈øt tooke their denomition long after this time of the generall ordaining Bishops in our Cities, as Caer Golden, Colche≈øter tacking the name from King Coel Father to the holy Empre≈ø≈øe S. Helena, mother to Con≈øtantine the Emperour: Cair Guortigern, of King Vortigern, and Caer Merthin of Merlin: ≈øo we may not number the≈øe among our fir≈øt Epi≈øcopall Cities. Diuers al≈øo of the others were ≈øo vnknowne in the time of Henry of Huntington, that he a very learned and auncient writer dareth not to take vpon him to deliuer what or where they were, as he and Ranulphus Higeden after him, doth of the other remembred Cities, Which we may take to be the rea≈øon that this later writer did not mention them at all. But yet if we looke into our Hi≈øtories we shall finde more auncient Cities, as Ranulphus ≈øaith, and among them diuers which were then Epi≈øcopall Sees. Ihon Rous affirmeth, that Oxford fir≈øt Io. Rous apud Stowe Hi≈øt. Brit. in Ebranke Galfrid. Monum. Hi≈øt. l. 4. c. 16. Annales Duren: apud Leland. in comment. Antiq. Britan. v. Doris. Leland. ≈øupra. verb. Couae. & verb. Manditi Ca≈øtrum. called Caier Mennip, at building thereof, after Belli≈øitum, Caier Bo≈ø≈øa Rhidohen and la≈øtly Oxford was founded by King Ebranke, as Yorke was. Galftidus calleth it Caerpen huelgoit, Leland from the Antiquities of Douer writeth, that it was a Citie before the time of King Aruiragus that builded the Ca≈øtle adioynÃÑing, and nameth it a mo≈øt renowned Citie, and that King Lucius builded a Church in that Ca≈øtle, referunt & ijdem Annales Lucium Regem Britannorum. And the ≈øame Authour from Antiquities is witnes, that there was an other auncient City of the Britans called by them Cairbro by the Ile of Wight. He writeth al≈øo, that there was aunciently a Bishops See at S. Maus in Cornewayle, by Famouthe, and that S. Manditus was Bishop there, giuing that name to the place, now a fisher Towne. It is al≈øo euident in our Hi≈øtories that be≈øides the Citie Venta that is Wincester called among other names Venta Belgarum, the Inhabitants in tho≈øe parts being called Belgae, there were diuers other auncient Cities of that name among the Britans: as Venta Silurum, by Camd. in Brit. in Belg. Io. Leland ≈øupr. in Venta, & Verolamium. Ptolom. Co≈ømograph. de≈øcript. Britan. Hect. Boeth. in elucidatione Regionum, Oppid. ante Hi≈øtoriam. ≈øome in South wales neare Chep≈øtow, quite de≈øtroyed: Venta Simenorum: Venta Icenorum: and Verolamium where S. Albons ≈øtandeth was famous euen with the Pagan writer Cornelius Tacitus, and Ptolomaeus. So was Barwicke, which Ptolomy nameth Tue≈øis, of the Ryuer thereby pa≈ø≈øing, & diuiding England and Scotland. Hector Boethius ≈øaith, that Corinimum which now we call Shrewsbury was in auncient time a mo≈øt famous Towne, oppidum olim celebrati≈øsimum. And at the comming of S. Augu≈øtine hither be≈øides their Archbishop, there were ≈øeuen other Bishops of ≈øeuerall Sees, and Cities in that Iuri≈ødiction; of which ≈øcarcely any one in probable Iudgment is before recited.

4. Therefore to trauaile no further in this enquiry, we haue found more then a ≈øufficient number of old Brittish Cities, to ≈øetle 3. Archbishops, and 28. Bishops in, and yet not carry any of them into Scotland, but onely where King Lucius and the Romans ruled. Now I will endeuour particularly to The Epi≈øcopall Sees and Cities in particular in that Age. finde out the ≈øeuerall Cities and Sees of all, many, or mo≈øt of them. A late writer in a Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtorie neuer yet printed, thus recounteth them: Winche≈øter, Gloce≈øter, Cilice≈øter, Worcester, Cheche≈øter, Bangor, Hereford, Cardiffe, Landaffe, Morgan, Alclud, Canterbury, Godmanche≈øter in Huntington Ha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ is Manu≈øc. Tom. 2. in Lucius. shiere, where S. Machutus was Bishop, about the yeare of our Lord 550. for
the re≈øt except the three Archbishop Sees London, Yorke and Caerlegion he confe≈ø≈øeth ignorance, where they were. A Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorian William Harri≈øon in his De≈øcription of England hath v≈øed ≈øome more diligence in this bu≈øines. And thus proceedeth herein: in old time we reade that there were eight William Harri≈øon de≈øcription of England. c. 13. of Cities and Townes. and twenty Flamins and Archflamins in the South part of this I≈øle, and ≈øo many greate Cyties, vnder their Iuri≈ødiction. Then to shew where they were, and where Archbishops and Bishops ≈øucceeded them, he addeth: If any man be de≈øirous to knowe the names of tho≈øe auncient Cyties, that ≈øtood in the time of the Romans, he shall haue them heare at hand, in ≈øuch wi≈øe as I haue gathered them out of our writers, ob≈øeruing euen their manner of writing of them ≈øo neare as to mee is po≈ø≈øible, without alteration of any corruption crept vp into the ≈øame. Then he ≈øetteth downe the names of the≈øe auncient Cyties in this order: Lundon, Yorke, Canterbury, Colche≈øter, Lincoln, warwicke, aunciently called Cair Guttelin, Cair Line or Cair Leon, Cair Gwair, Cair vmber, Cair Gwaerton, Che≈øter or Cair Legion vpon Vsk, Carleill, S. Albons aunciently named Cair Maricipit, Cair Municip verolamium, Verlamce≈øter, and Cair watteling of the ≈øtreet whereon it ≈øtood, Winche≈øter, Ci≈øceter, Silcester, Bath, Sha≈øtesbury, worce≈øter, Chiche≈øter, Bristow, Roche≈øter, Portche≈øter, Cair Marden, Gloce≈øter, Leirce≈øter, Cambridge, formerly ≈øtiled Grantabric, Cair Graunt. After the≈øe 23. he addeth, Cair vrnach, peraduenture Burgh ca≈øtle, Cair Cucurat, Cair Draiton, now a ≈ølender villidge, Cair Celemon, Cair Megnaid, pleading Ignorance of the fiue la≈øt places, as likewi≈øe Cair Dorman, of which I haue ≈øpoken before, and Alcluid, of which more hereafter: But ≈øeeing both Britans and Saxons, Catholiks and Prote≈øtants before haue agreed vpon the≈øe Cities, and the diui≈øion of this Iland into Loegria, Albania, and Cambria wales; and that in England or Loegria alone there were ≈øo many Cities in the Britans time, as are remembred, onely two of them Cair Leon vpon v≈øc and Cair Merthen to be found in wales, except we will place Cair Guorchigirn there, we may not depriue the Archbishop there of his Suffragan Bishops nor that auncient Countrye of the old Cities, but ≈øay, the≈øe fiue not to be found in any part of Loegria by any Authour, were Cities of wales, how≈øoeuer their names vpon many accidents be changed ≈øince Nennius time, and diuers of them were Epi≈øcopall Sees: allthough Cair Draiton bewraieth it≈øelfe to be no older then the Saxons Languadge heare, and ≈øo could not be a Bishops See in the Reigne of King Lucius. For mo≈øt of the re≈øt, the onely Argument of this Prote≈øtant Authour finding them called by diuers old Brittish names, if we had no other, giueth them probable title to that Honour.

5. But I shall help him with more, both rea≈øons and Authoritie herein. Harding c. 25. 26. 27. Harding Cron. c. 23. 24. Stowe and Howes Hi≈øt. in Bladud Leir. Harris Hi≈øt. Galfr. l. 2. Virun. l 2. Annal. Wintomen. Manu≈øcr. Godwin Catal. of Bishops Winche≈øter 1. For the auncient Cities of Canterbury, winche≈øter, Sha≈øtesbury, Leirce≈øter, Bathe, Carlile and Alcliud, We haue both Brittish and Saxon, Catholike and Prote≈øtant Antiquaries affirming they were the auncient Re≈øidences of Flamens, and ≈øo mu≈øt, by that is ≈øaid before, needs be Bishops Sees in this time. And to exemplifie in ≈øome of them, the old Manu≈øcript Antiquitie of Winche≈øter ≈øaith, King Lucius builded there a Cathedrall Church: Lucius Rex fundauit Eccle≈øiam Wintonien≈øem: dedicating it to our Sauiour: which a Prote≈øtant Bishop thus al≈øo writeth from the ≈øame or like Antiquitie: The Cathedrall Church of Winchester, according to a report that I finde in an old Manu≈øcript, was fir≈øt build and erected by King Lucius. Seeing then a Cathedrall Church and a Bishop are knit together, we mu≈øt needs acknowledg there was then a Bishop there. And to ≈øpeake in this mans and his Authours words: This Church was hallowed and dedicated October 29. 189. by Faganus and Damianus Bishops. And he proueth
from the ≈øame Antiquitie, that in the yeare 309. one Con≈øtans was Bishop there. And in S. Dubricius time by the Brittish Hi≈øtory Diuuanius was Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 9. c. 15 & l. 8. c. 17. Harding. Chron. c. 76. f. 67. the Bishop of that place, Epi≈øcopatus Guintoniae Di ‚Ä¢ uanio decernitur. And concerning the Bishoprike of Alcliud, it was then giuen to one named Eledanius, Pontificalis Infula Alclud Eledanio decernit ‚Ä¢ r. Elednore by Harding was Bishop there. Which proueth it was a Bishiprock froÃÑ the beginning, no change Harding. Chro. c. 24. f. 21. Abbreuiatio Chron. inter an. 170. & 180. in Lucio. of Sees, being before this time. For Canterbury it was fir≈øt a Flamens ≈øeate; And the old Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory Abbreuiatio Chronicorum, ≈øaith in this time and ≈øetling Bishops in King Lucius Reigne, that the old Church of S. Martin, which liued in the Apo≈øtles time, was builded: Tunc con≈øtructa est extra Cantuariam Eccle≈øia ≈øancti Martini and to notifie that he ment thereby a Cathedral and Epi≈øcopall Church, he addeth this when he ≈øpeaketh of changing Hi≈øtoria RoffeÃÑn. Manu≈øcr. Lambert PeraÃÑb. of Kent. p. 113. Flamens into Bishops. And all Hi≈øtories te≈øtifie, that the holy Bishop Lethardus, which came hither with Queene Bertha, before S. Augu≈øtins time v≈øed it as his Epi≈øcopall See. And Canterbury be≈øides the Archbishop had an other Bishop in that Church of S. Martin diuers hundreds of yeares: and Harding. Chro. c. 23. Harding. ≈øup. c. 30. f. 24. Stowe Hi≈øt. Britan. in Morg. and Cunedag. Lel. com. Brit. antiq. v. Manditi Ca≈øtr. Cap. in Catal. in S. Kebio, Meloro, Vr≈øula. Gul. Malm. l. 1. de Regib. c. 6. & l. 3. in Gul. 1. Contin. Flor. Wigorn. in Prae≈øul. Cridiat. Godwin Catal. in Exeter 1. Ann. Eccl. Meneuen. apud eund. ≈øupra, in S. Dauids. Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 5. c. 1. Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 201. Hi≈øt. Manu≈øcr. apud Harris Hi≈øt. Tom. 2. c. 21. M. Lambert the P ‚Ä¢ ote≈øtant Antiquarie of Kent ≈øaith from Antiquities: S. Martins Church built by the Romans in Canterbury was a Bishops See, vntill the Normans came in and ≈øo two in one Citie, this ≈øub≈øtitute to the Archbishop. Likewi≈øe we may ≈øo ≈øay of Sha≈øtesbury, Bathe, Leice≈øter, and Carleil, by the ≈øame rea≈øon all of the≈øe as before, hauing Flamens, and being old auncient Brittish Cities: the fir≈øt named Cair Paladour, & Septonia: The ≈øecond Cair Badon, Aquae Solis, and Thermae, by Ptolomaeus. Leirce≈øter before by Henry of Huntington Cair Legion or Cair Lirion, Leice≈øtria. Carlile Cair Lueill, Cair Leill, Lugubalia, Cair Doill: Which proue they were auncient Cities both to the Britans and Romans, as Harding ≈øaith:

q.l: In Britaine tongue plainely
Cair is to ≈øay a Citie in their language,
As yett in Wales is their common v≈øage.

div.p:
As in the time of the Pagans there was a Flamen in Cornwaile: So in exordio Chri≈øtianae fidei, in the beginning of Chri≈øtianitie heare, as Capgraue and others before him write there was a Bishop, and a Synode of Bishops there. Diuers of their names be pre≈øerued Kebius, Manditus, Columbanus, Iwanus, Dotharius with others in Succe≈ø≈øion: and the See ≈øome time at S. Manus, S. Petroks, Crediton, or S. Germans vppon diuers changes remembred by Antiquaries. And a Prote≈øtant Bishop hath produced an old Manu≈øcript belonging to S. Dauids, that in the≈øe times of the Britans, there was a Bishops See and Bishop at Exceter in Deuonshire. And that an other of the≈øe our fir≈øt Primatiue Bishops was ≈øeated at Gloce≈øter, Cair Glowy, or Glou we haue diuers Authorities: for mo≈øt of our Antiquities that entreate of the death of King Lucius, ≈øay he was buried there in the Epi≈øcopall and Cathedrall Church. In vrbe Claudioce≈øtriae ab hac vita migrauit; & in Eccle≈øia primae Sedis honorific√® ≈øepultus e≈øt. And M Harris in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtorie ≈øaith, he had an old written Chronicle which ≈øpake of this Church. The Table of King Lucius hanging in S. Peters Church in Cornhill in London is witnes, this Church ≈øtood where the Order of S. Francis was placed in Gloce≈øter. And no Authour ≈øpeaking either of change of Sees, or new founding any there after in the Britans time, our Hi≈øtories are witne≈ø≈øes, that one Theonus Bishop of Gloce≈øter, was made Archbishop of London in the Britans time. So was Eldad long before Bishop of Glocester in the Reigne of Aurelius Ambro≈øius. That Caer Segent, Segen
or Silce≈øter now onely there being a Farme hou≈øe was a Bishops See in tho≈øe Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae. 489. Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 8. c. 7. Manu≈øcript. Gallic. antiq. an. 477. c. 47. Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 9. c. 15. Manu≈øcr. antiq. apud Stowe Hi≈øt. Britans and Sax. in Arthur. Galfr. Monum. l. 9. c. 1. Hi≈øt. Brit. & l. 6. c. 5. Harding Chron. c. 76. f. 67. dayes, be≈øides the name, and place for a Flamen we are a≈ø≈øured from the Brittish Hi≈øtory, that in the time of S. Dubritius Archbishop, and King Arthur when diuers old Bishops Sees were voide, this was one among the re≈øt, and that Bishoprick was giuen to one named Mauganius: Epi≈øcopatus ver√≤ Silce≈øtriae Mauganio decernitur. This Citie was ≈øo renowned in the Britans time, that as an old Manu≈øcript witne≈ø≈øeth, Con≈øtantius ≈øonne of Con≈øtantine was honorably buried there, and Con≈øtantine and Arthur there crowned with ≈øuch Pompe and ≈øolemnitie as our Hi≈øtories declare. This place is 6. miles or there abouts from Reading in Barkshire, the remnants of the wall, with 4. places where the 4. gates were, were two myles in compa≈ø≈øe: much Roman Money there was found in digging.

6. Ihon Harding ≈øaith, that Chiche≈øter was a Bishops See in the time of King Arthur, and S. Dubritius and that Mangauero was Bishop there in tho≈øe dayes. And among the≈øe, I would take Dunwich, to haue al≈øo bene an Epi≈øcopall See about that Age: the place in Suffolke no other Towne a≈ø≈øigned for a Bishops See in that part of England, giueth way vnto it; our English Antiquaries confe≈ø≈øe it was an auncient Citie, and in probable coniecture, that which our old Nennius expre≈ø≈øeth among the mo≈øt renowned Brittish Cities, by the name of Caer Daun or Dunn, after by the Saxons Danmocke or Dunwick, no o ‚Ä¢ her auncient knowne Citie more an≈øweareable to that Brittish Appellation. And to giue more life to this opinion, when the Saxons became Chri≈øtians and had Bishops, it was the care of the Popes and ≈øpirituall Rulers then to place both Arcbishops and Bishops where ≈øuch had bene in the Britans time. The two Archbishops Sees of London and Yorke which were voide, were by S. Gregory appointed for ≈øuch againe; and by this Title diuers decayed Cities, as I shall more expre≈ø≈øe hereafter, had al≈øo Bishops, being Epi≈øcopall Sees when the Britans and Romans heare ruled. And ≈øo S. Faelix by Stowe ≈øup. liber. Elu. Records. Dun. this Title was fir≈øt Bishop among the Ea≈øt Angles, and of that Citie, ≈øo renowned, that it hath had as a Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorian writeth from the Tradition and Records of that Citie, two and fyftie diuine hou≈øes, and very many of them Parish Churches. Heare I haue rather ≈øought to ≈øetle a Bishop, then at Colche≈øter as one doth, where be≈øides the old name, Caer, common to very Will. Harri≈øon de≈øcr. of Brit. c. 13 Nenn. Hi≈øtor. Henr. Hunt. Hi≈øt. l. 1. many that neuer were Epi≈øcopall Cities, be≈øides what I haue ≈øaid before, I finde no motiue at all, to ≈øay it was at any time, much le≈ø≈øe then a Bishops See: it is in a corner of that Country, an vnwalled thing vntill S. Helen her time, much to late to make it a Bishops Citie in King Lucius dayes, I can neither finde a Flamen there before, nor any Bishop ≈øince, either when the Britans, Romans, Saxons, or any others ruled heare. And yet to giue all to Colche≈øter which the aduauncers thereof require, that it was the Towne called Camulodunum, as al≈øo Colonia, of the Colonie planted by the Romans, which is more then I dare to doe to giue two ≈øo ≈øeuerall and di≈øtinct names to one ≈øingular place by one people at one time; yet allowing it ≈øo, and a Municipium enioying the Romans priuiledges: yet all this doth not ≈øufficiently able it, for being a Bishops See; for we doe not finde that the Romans were then ≈øuch friends to Chri≈øtian Religion in tho≈øe times, as with publike allowance to place ≈øuch ≈øpirituall Rulers in their priuiledged Townes, as were contrary to the priuiledges, & Immunities of them; ≈øo that of all Cities heare, tho≈øe which were Municipia to the Romans, as Verolamium, S. Albons, & others were, they were the furthe≈øt from hauing Chri≈øtian Bishops in them. And we ≈øee by experience
in Verolamium their Municipium, that within one hundred yeares after this in the time of Diocle≈øian his Per≈øecution, when S. Alban a cheife man there was martyred for the Chri≈øtian faith, the Citie of Verolamium was by all Hi≈øtories ≈øo ignorant thereof, as if there neuer had bene any Chri≈øtian there before, much le≈ø≈øe a Bishop, which should haue very ill intended to his greate office, to ≈øuffer him≈øelfe, and his cheife chardge to haue ≈øo pre≈øently apo≈øtated from Chri≈øt.

7. But I mu≈øt rather hold, that the re≈øt of the Bishops Sees were where we finde Chri≈øtians profe≈ø≈øing con≈øtantly euen to death their holy faith, in that mo≈øt tempe≈øtuous time of per≈øecution, & where we finde any Bishop to haue bene then, or where the fir≈øt Bishops were ≈øeated when the Saxons were conuerted, then where not any of the≈øe but a manife≈øt priuation or de≈øtitution of the≈øe is found. And we haue the old English Hi≈øtorie and others for witnes, Old English hi≈øt. part. 4. in K. Lucius. that many Bishopriks of the time of King Lucius were ≈øtill in this Land in tho≈øe dayes. So we may probably add to the≈øe Bishopricks, by the≈øe Titles, the Citie of Lichfeild not vnprobably that which Nennius nameth Caerligalid, Io. Ro≈ø≈ø. & Warwicen. l. de Epi≈øcop. Wigorn. Theater of great Brit. lib. 6. Stowe Hi≈øt. Romans in Coill. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 26. ≈øo con≈øtant in Chri≈øtian Religion in the Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian, that at one time it brought forth a thou≈øand Martyrs, and thereuppoÃÑ tooke in the Saxon tongue the name Lichfeild, a feild of blood, and in the Conuer≈øion of the Saxons was at the fir≈øt a Bishops See by the old Scottish or Brittish Bishops. The like I ≈øay of Dorchester now a Villadge neare Oxford, but aunciently a Citie Caer Dor, as before Dorce≈øtria, and Ciuitas Dorche≈øtriae, and in the Primatiue Church of the SaxoÃÑs a Bishops or the rather onely Bishops See of the kingdom of the Mercians, or Middle English diuers hundreds of yeares vntill time of King William the fir≈øt, when Remigius Bishop thereof remoued his See to Lincoln. That there was a Bishops See in Huntington shire eyther at the decayed Citie Caer dorm, before named, or at Godmanche≈øter, we haue diuers te≈øtimonies both of late and auncient time: a late writer ≈øpeaking of the Bishops ordayned by the≈øe Legats of Pope Eleutherius ab≈øolutely affirmeth: They founded a Bishopricke in the Citie of Gumica≈øtrum now called Godmanche≈øter in Huntinghton shire, where S. Machutus was ≈øometime Bishop about the yeare of Harris Theatr. Brit. Tom. 2. in Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. Vit. S. Machuti. Theater of great Brit. in de≈øcr. of Hunting. shire. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. Harding Chron. f. 26. 27. c. 30. our Lord. 550. So hath the old written life of S. Machutus, as our Theater writers te≈øtifie, and diuers others, and among the≈øe an old Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory. Among the≈øe I may number be≈øides the Archflamens, and Arcbishops See in London, an other inferiour place of a Flamen, and Bishop after, fir≈øt founded as Harding with others witne≈ø≈øeth by Dunwallo, S. Paules Church the Bishops See now is ≈øeated there. He made ≈øixe Temples, ≈øay Authours, in Logres, Cambre, and Albanie, and as many Flamens to rule them of ≈øtates as Bishops now doen.

lg.l: A Temple al≈øo in Troynouant ≈øothely
Of peace and concorde he made verely
In which when there fell any di≈øcorde
Emong his Lords, there were they made accorde.

div.p:
And thus noteth: This Temple was S. Paules Church in London. How the Pagans dedicated it to Apollo, and there ≈øacrificed to him, I haue ≈øaid before. And this neuer being either the Arcflamens or Arcbbishops See, and yet pre≈øently vpon the Conuer≈øioÃÑ of the SaxoÃÑs made a Bishops ≈øeate giueth ≈øtrength to this opinion: and we finde in our Hi≈øtories more Arcbishops of London in the time of the Britans, then of Yorke and Caerlegion both Ioyned together, yet was the Citie of London more ≈øubiect to tumults and alterations then eyther
of the≈øe was, ≈øome ArgumeÃÑt that to make ≈øo greate a number both Archbishops and Bishops there be accompted together.

8. But though we leaue London onely to an Archbishops See, we shall otherwi≈øe make vp our common reckoning of 28. Bishops in that time. A Prote≈øtant Bishop writeth that Chiche≈øter was a Bishops See in the Britans time, and had a Bishop at the comming of S. Augu≈øtine hither, and citeth Roger Houeden for his Authour, which I doe not finde in him, but that Che≈øter Godwin Catal. in S. Dauids. 1. Roger. HouedeÃÑ Part. 2. Annal. in Rege. was then a Bishops See, he affirmeth in the life of King Ihon, the place I take it which this Prote≈øtant meaneth, Where he al≈øo plainely affirmeth the ≈øame of Worche≈øter. The old Citie of Lincolne al≈øo to haue bene then a Bishops See, we haue the conueniencie of place, Antiquitie of the Citie both with the Britans, and Romans: Cair Lud Coit, Cair Loichoit, Lindum, Lindocollinum, and that in the Conuer≈øion of the Saxons, next vnto Yorke it was made the fir≈øt Bishops See in tho≈øe parts.

9. Now if we ≈øtay heare, before we proceed further, we haue probably found all the fir≈øt Bishops Sees that were vnder the Iuri≈ødiction of London, both in Loegria and Cornewayle, be≈øides ≈øome others: For Harding holding Hardin. Chron. f. 29. c. 23. Sigebert. Gemb. Chron. ann. 445. Matth. Parker. Antiq. Brit. p. 9. there were 13. Flamens vnder the Archflamen of London, and others that there were 14. we haue Antiquities to direct vs, that there were but 7. Bishops vnder Yorke, and no more vnder Caerlegion, ≈øo allowing 28. with the common opinion, 14. of the≈øe mu≈øt needs be vnder the Iuri≈ødiction of the Archbishop of London: to witt the Bishop of Cornwayle, of Exceter, Bathe, Gloce≈øter, Worche≈øter, Silce≈øter, Sha≈øtesbury, Winche≈øter, Canterbury, Dunwich, or ≈øome other Bishops Sees vnder the Archbishop of London in King Lucius, or the Brittans time. place among the Ea≈øte Angles afterward, Godmanchester, Leyche≈øter & Leichfeild. The other 4. Carleyle, Che≈øter, Lincoln, or Leichfeild if we ≈øubiect Lincoln to London‚ñ™ and Alchlud were vnder Yorke, this Citie of Alchlud was very auncient, and renowned in the North parts, and by Harding and others, ≈øtood at Harding ≈øupr. f. 20. c. 21. Bed. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 12. Galfrid. Monum. Hi≈øtor. Brit. l. 9. c. 5. 6. the We≈øt end of the Picts wall, and by our Brittish Hi≈øtory and S. Bede, not farre from thence, and as is euident before, was both vnder the Spirituall Iuri≈ødiction of Yorke, and the temporall Gouernment al≈øo of our Kings in this part of Britaine, di≈øtinct from Scotland long after this time. And to ≈øpeake as our Brittish Hi≈øtory doth, it was not in Scotland, Albania, but neare or towards it. Con≈øtituit Ebrancus vrbem Alclud ver≈øus Albaniam. And if it had Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 2. c. 7. bene in that part, which now is called Scotland, yet when this Citie was builded, Bishops Sees vnder Yorke. and when it was al≈øo made a Bishops See, the Scots, had nothing to doe there abouts, except as Theeues and Pirats then liuing in the out Ilands as both S. Gildas, S. Bede and others are ample witne≈ø≈øes. duabus gentibus tran≈ømarinis Gild. l. de excid. Brit. Bed. Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 1. ≈øaith S. Gildas of the Scots and Picts, the like hath S. Bede, long after this time of tho≈øe people. Therefore they were Britans for the mo≈øt part, though not ≈øo ≈øubiect eyther to King Lucius or the Romans which there inhabited: of which Tertullian al≈øo is an Ample witne≈ø≈øe, ≈øo te≈øtifying: Britannorum loca Romanis in acce≈ø≈øa: as our Prote≈øtant Theather writers tranflate him, and truely: Tertullian (≈øay they: who liued within 200. yeares of Chri≈øts Natiuitie, affirmed the Britans had receaued the word of life, the power whereof hath peirced into tho≈øe parts Theate ‚Ä¢ of great Brit. l. 6. Tertul. contra Iudaeos c. 7. whether the Romans could not come. This Te≈øtimonie of Tertullian is more auncient then the Scots receauing the faith in the third Age in the Time of Pope Victor. And by this we may be bold to ≈øeeke and ≈øetle a Bishops See euen in tho≈øe parts, which were after termed Scotland, hauing allowance from Antiquitie ≈øo to doe. For our Hi≈øtories tell vs, that there was a Flamen ≈øetled at Perche now S. Ihons in Scotland by our Brittish Kings, diuers huÃÑdreds of yeares
before any Scot ≈øett footing there: Condage made a Flamyne, a Temple al≈øo Harding Chron. f. 24. c. 30. Stowe Hi≈øtor. Britan. in Morgan and Cunedagius. in honour of Mars, at Perche, that now is S. Ihons Towne in Albany, that now is Scotland Region. When Cunedagius was King of Britaine, ≈øaith an other, about 800. yeares before Chri≈øt, he builded a Temple of Mars at Perche that now is S. Ihons Towne in Scotland, and placed there a Flamen. Therefore by the common con≈øent of Antiquitie before remembred, we mu≈øt needs place a Bishop there vnder the Archbishop of Yorke.

10. And yet I grante what Hector Boethius writeth from the Scottish Antiquities, Hector Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. l. 6. f. 102. that S. Amphibalus our holy Brittish Bishop and Martyr in Diocle≈øian his time, was the fir≈øt Bishop the Scots had mentioned in their Annals: fuit id Templum omnium primum, Chri≈øtiano ritu, vbi Pontifex ≈øacerque Magi≈øtratus ≈øedem haberet Primariam inter Scotos, cuius no≈øtri meminere Scriptores, dedicatum; for this was in the out Iland where the Scots then liued, not yet Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed in Britaine, where this Bishop of Perche or S. Ihons Towne was ≈øeated. And allthough, that further part of Britaine, where the Scots now Inhabite was not ≈øo fully conuerted at this time, as that vnder King Lucius, and the Romans was: yet being ≈øubiected by Pope Eleutherius to the Archbishop of Yorke, it mu≈øt needs haue one Bishop at the lea≈øt, to maintaine the name and calling of a Bishop Suffragan, or inferiour Bishop ≈øubordinate to the Archbishop, or higher Bishop, otherwi≈øe we shall not ≈øay ea≈øily, properly, and congruou≈øly, that ≈øo greate a Country was vnder the Iuri≈ødiction of a See, ≈øo remote, and in an other kingdome, and Kings Dominion. The other two Bishopricks ≈øubordinate to Yorke, I cannot more probably ≈øuppo≈øe to haue bene in other Capgrau. Catal. in S. Niniano. places, then tho≈øe, or neare vnto them, where I finde the fir≈øt Bishops in tho≈øe parts, which be witerna, were S. Ninian was Bishop, being Apo≈øtle of the Picts, and Lindisfarne or holy Iland, where S. Aidan and diuers others were Beda Eccl. Hi≈øt. l. 3. c. 5. Bishops in the Primatiue Church of the Saxons comming out of Scotland, where a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of Bishops had long continued, and like be≈øt knewn and ≈øought to honour tho≈øe places where their Brittish predece≈ø≈øors Bishops had Bishops Sees vnder the Archbishop of Cambria. bene before them.

11. Concerning the Bishops of Cambria, wales which were vnder their Archbishop of Caerlegion, vpon vske, many haue written, affirming there were ≈øeuen at the coming of S. Augu≈øtine, and diuers, though ≈øome what diuer≈øly, haue ≈øet downe the names of their Sees, mo≈øt of them ≈øeeming to haue bene ≈øuch from the beginning. Roger Houeden thus recompteth them: Landauen≈øem, & de S. Paterno in Kardican, Bangoren≈øem, & de S. A≈øaf, Ce≈øtren≈øem, Roger. HouedeÃÑ Annal. part. Po≈øterior. in Ioan. Rege. Manu≈øcr. antiq. apud Godwine Catal. in S. Dauids. 1. & Hereforden≈øem, & Wigornen≈øem: Landaff, S. Patern in Cardiganshire, Bangor, S. A≈øaph, Chester, Hereford, and Worce≈øter, but granteth the≈øe three la≈øt e≈øpecially Che≈øter and Worce≈øter did not belong to Wales. A Prote≈øtant Bishop from an old Antiquitie thus relateth them: Exeter, Bathe, Hereford, Landaffe, Bangor, S. A≈øaph, and Furnes in Ireland. Of Exeter and Bathe I haue ≈øpoken before, being ≈øubiect to London. But likely it is, this old Authour remembred them heare, becau≈øe in the de≈øolation of Bishops and Religion heare vnder the Saxons, the≈øe two neare vnto Wales kept their Bishops longer, as al≈øo Worce≈øter and Chester did by the ≈øame rea≈øon, and thereby are remembred by Houeden. For Furnes in Ireland as it neuer did by old right belong to Wales, ≈øo it now as litle belongeth to our purpo≈øe to ≈øpeake further of it. The fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury ≈øpeaking of this fir≈øt In≈øtitution of Bishops heare in King Lucius time, and how Loegria had 14. vnder the Archbishop; Yorke 7. and Cambria ≈øo many: ≈øetteth downe their
names from that time in this order: Diocae≈øes Cambriae hae Fucrunt, Hereforden≈øis, Tauen≈øis, Paternen≈øis, Banchoren≈øis, Eluine≈øis, Wiccen≈øis, ac Morganen≈øis. The Dioce≈øes of Cambria be≈øides the Archbishoprick were the≈øe: Hereford, Taffe, Lanpatern in Cardiganshire, Bangor, Elwy, Wicce, and Morgan. Harpesfeild, Dauid Dauid Pouel annot. in l. 2. c. 1. Giraldi Cambren. Cambr. Itinerar. Harpesfeld. ≈øaecul. 7. Matth. We≈øtm. 712. Bed. l. 4 c. 23. Hi≈øt. Eccl. Angl. Godwin Catal. in Worce≈øter 1. Powell a Welch Prote≈øtant Antiquarie and others doe al≈øo ≈øo recite them. Tauen≈øis was that we call Landaffe: Eluien≈øis named of the Ryuer Elwy, the ≈øame with A≈øaph; Wiccien≈øis as S. Bede calleth it, Prouincia Victiorum, in the kingdome of Mertia, in which Worce≈øtershire, or part of it was. So we ≈øee that Hereford, Landaffe, Bangor, S. Patern, Glamorgan, S. A≈øaph, and Wiccia did aunciently, and in the time of the Britans belong to the Archbishop of Cambria, and mo≈øt of them euen from the beginning. For Hereford I haue credibly heard reported, that there is or lately was an old Antiquitie there, te≈øtifying the Church thereof to haue bene builded in King Lucius his time. For Landaffe the Prote≈øtant Bishop thereof thus writeth: The Cathedrall Church of Fran. Godwin Prot. Bishop of Landaffe Catal. of Bish. in Land. 1. Landaffe is reported to haue bene fir≈øt built in the time of Lucius, about the yeare of Chri≈øt 180. The holy Bishops of Patern and Bangor, S. Patern of the fir≈øt changing, and giuing name to the place for his Sanctitie, and S. Daniel of the other, are renowned among our auncient Brittish Saints and Bishops. And as our Antiquaries witne≈ø≈øe, Bangor was a Flamens ≈øeate, diuers hundreds of yeares Harding Cron. f. 24. c. 30. Stowe Hi≈øt. in Cunedagius. Harding Chron. p. 24. c. 29. Stowe Hi≈øtor. ≈øupr. Io. Caius Hi≈øt. Cantabr. accad. p. 20. before Chri≈øt, and much honored by King Lucius, as more hereafter. Of the glory and Antiquitie of Glamorgan, taking the name of a King ≈øo called Morgan, there ≈ølayne aboue 2000. yeares ≈øince, and a Schoole among the PagaÃÑs of no le≈ø≈øe continuance, as diuers writers teach, there can be litle que≈øtion in this ca≈øe. For the other two, though perhaps there is not ≈øo greate te≈øtimony for their Antiquitie in this kinde; yet the≈øe being ioyned with the re≈øt in the ≈øame degree in generall by ≈øo many Authours, we cannot be of other minde, but Bishops were al≈øo there, or not farre from them of the like continuance, otherwi≈øe we shall hardly iu≈øtifie the common agreed vpon opinion of ≈øeuen Bishops placed in that Prouince in King Lucius time, but wander vp and downe among meere coniecturs. For allthough we reade in the life of S. Kentegern Predece≈ø≈øor to S. A≈øaph, that in the time of S. Dauid Archbishop in Wales, and by his con≈øent, he built a Mona≈øtary in this place of Elgn for 960. Monkes, and there remayned Bishop, yet this doth not improue, but rather confirme, there was Bishops See there or not farre from thence before. For it is recorded in the ≈øame Authour, ≈øuppo≈øed to be S. A≈øaph his ≈øcholler, and Succe≈ø≈øor, that this Bishoprick being voide, the King and Cleargie of Wales de≈øired him for their Bishop there: Rex & Clerus Regionis Cambren≈øis cum caeteris Chri≈øtianis ip≈øum in Pa≈øtorem & Epi≈øcopum eligerent. To which, S. Dauid their Archbishop his greate friend con≈øented. So his erecting that Colledge, did honour and beutifie and not alter or di≈øgrace that Bishoprick, and it is euident before, that with this Bishops See there were but 7. be≈øids the Archbishoprike: ≈øo many there were long before as the Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury and others proue, ≈øo many at the beginning as I haue shewed before, therefore no addition of number by the foundation of S. Kentegern.

div.head: THE XX. CHAPTER.

argument.p: HOW S. ELEVTHERIVS POPE DID NOT onely by his Papall Authoritie establish and ≈øetle Religion, and Eccle≈øiasticall things heare, but directed what temporall Lawes were to be v≈øed, appointed the bounds and limits of this kingdome, ≈øending an hallowed Crowne to our King: and ≈øuch Lawes and Order continued heare inmany Ages after

div.p: 1. WHEN the≈øe things had ≈øo farre and pro≈øperou≈øly proceeded in Britaine, King Lucius intending a perfect Reformation in this kingdome, and knowing that Religion being thus happily changed, there mu≈øt al≈øo be a change or greate alteration in the old Pagan Lawes, and, as it ≈øeemeth, ob≈øeruing, that in the Municipall Townes and Places of Britaine, which in ≈øome ≈øort had receaued the Roman Lawes, and among the Romans which conuer≈øed heare, there was much more ciuill behauiour and conuer≈øation, then in many Britans, wrote vnto Pope Eleutherius among other things to haue the Roman Lawes ≈øent hither vnto him, to be receaued heare. The≈øe letters of King Lucius are not extant, neyther the an≈øweare of Pope Eleutherius vnto him, and his Nobilitie, but in ≈øuch a lame, halting, and deformed manner, as it hath plea≈øed our Prote≈øtants, hauing po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of that old Antiquitie, to publish it to the world, without head, foote, or perfect body, wanting both beginning, end, and midle in many things, in ≈øuch order as they thought it would any wi≈øe helpe, and lea≈øt hinder Matth. Parker Ant. Britan. p. 5. Bridges in K. Lucius. Godwin Conu. of Brit. p. 30. 31. 32. Willam Lamb. in Legib. S. Eduardi. Foxe To. 1. Act. and Mon. Theater of great. Brit. lib. 6. lewell again≈øt. Hard. f. 119. Godw. ≈øup. p. 30. Roger. Houeden Annal. part. Po≈øterior. in Henr. 2. Leg. S. Eduardi. cap. 1. apud Gul. Lamb. & Stowe Hi≈øt. an. 179. in King Lucius. and blemish their new Religion, when it came to vewe. And according to the diuer≈øitie of their owne humors, they haue as diuer≈øly put it in print, ≈øome more, ≈øome le≈ø≈øe, ≈øome one way, ≈øome an other, as hath be≈øt fitted their phanta≈øies, as you may reade in there fir≈øt Archbishop of Canterbury, their Bishops, Iewell, Bridges, & Godwin, M. Lambert, the Antiquarie Foxe, the Theater writers and others, differing herein one from an other: of which one of them a Prote≈øtant Bishop as mannerly as he might, thus complayneth: The Epi≈øtle is as heare en≈øueth: allthough I mu≈øt acknowledge, that I finde greate varietye in the diuer≈øitie of Copies, ≈øome containing much more, then others. And yet he him≈øelfe doth there further alter, chopp, and change it, both in his relation, and tran≈ølation of it, as euery Reader may there ea≈øily ob≈øerue, if he vnder≈øtandeth but a litle, the Latine tongue.

2. The Copies which beare mo≈øt credit be tho≈øe, which Stowe publisheth in English, and M. William Lambert in Latine, the fir≈øt out of a Booke of Con≈øtitutions belonging to the Guildhall of London; the ≈øecond as extant among, and part of King Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor his Lawes, ≈øo called not becau≈øe he made them, as Houeden and others proue, but being the old Lawes,
of this kingdome, and euacuated where the Danes had ruled, he reuiued them, and were mo≈øt Authentically proued, in the ti ‚Ä¢ e of King William the fir≈øt, by the ≈øolemne Oathes of Twelue Iurors out of euery County in EnglaÃÑd, and ≈øo not likely to deceaue vs in this point. The fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Authour, thus writeth of them: I onely finde the ≈øame entered in a Booke Intituled, Con≈øtitutions, pertaining to the Guildhall of London, mi≈ødated in the Latine as the English following sheweth. The yeare after Christs birth 169. Pope Eleutherius did write to Lucius King of Britaine for the amendement of the Kings and the Nobilitie of L. Con≈øt. Lond. Britaine as followeth. You required that we should ≈øend you the Roman and Imperiall Lawes, that you might v≈øe them in your kingdome of Britaine: But tho≈øe Lawes we may di≈øproue, and not the Lawes of God. You haue receaued lately through Gods goodnes in your kingdome both Te≈øtaments, out of them by Gods grace, and the adui≈øe of your Realme take a Lawe, and thereby patiently gouerne the kingdome. You are the Vicar of God in your kingdome, according to the kingly Prophet. The earth is the P≈øalm. 45. Lords, and his fullnes is the whole worlde, and all that dwell therein: And againe, Thow ha≈øt loued Righteou≈ønes, and hated Iniquitie, wherefore God, euen thy God, hath annointed thee with the oyle of gladnes aboue thy fellowes. They are the Kings children Chri≈øtian Nations, and people of your kingdome that liue and con≈øist vnder your protection, peace and kingdome according to the Scripture, as an Hen gathereth her Chikens vnder her wings, the people and Nations of the kingdome of Britaine is yours, ≈øuch as are diuided you should gather them together to the Lawe of Chri≈øt, his holy Church, to peace and coneorde: and cherishe, maintaine, protect, gouern, and defend them, from the iniurious, malitious, and their enemyes. Woe be to that kingdome, the King whereof is a childe, and the Princes eate early in the morning. I doe not call a King a child, for his youth or Minoritie, but for his folly, Iniquitie, & madnes according to the kingely Prophet. The blood thirsty and deceatefull men shall not outlyue P≈øal. 55. halfe their dayes. By eating, We shall vnder≈øtand gluttonie: by glouttonie luxurie: by luxury, all filthie wickednes and Mi≈øcheife, according to King Salomon: wi≈øedome will not enter into a spitefull ≈øoule, nor inhabite in a body ≈øubiect to ≈øinne. A King hath Sapien. 2. his name of gouerning, and not of his kingdome, ≈øo longe you shall be a King as you rule well, otherwi≈øe you shall not be ≈øo named, and loo≈øe that name, which God forbid. God grant that you may ≈øo rule your Realme of Britaine, that you may reigne with him euerla≈øtingly, who≈øe Vicar you are in the ≈øayed kingdome. To whome with the Father &c.
