Thus this Epi≈øtle is related by this Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorian out of the Booke of Con≈øtitutions of London. M. Lambert ≈øetteth it downe among S. Edward his Lawes in this order.

body.head: EPISTOLA DOMINI ELEVtherij Papae Lucio Regi Britanniae.
body.p:
ANno 169. √† Pa≈øsione Chri≈øti, Dominus Eleutherius Papa Lucio Regi Britanniae Al. 156. ≈øcrip≈øit ad petitionem Regis & Procerum Regni Britanniae. Peti≈øtis The Epi≈øtle, and Order of S. Eleutherius Pope concerning Britaine. √† nobis Leges Romanas, & Cae≈øaris vobis tran≈ømitti, quibus in Regno Britanniae vti volui≈øtis. Leges Romanas & Cae≈øaris ≈øemper reprobare po≈ø≈øumus, Legem Dei nequaquam. Su≈øcepi≈øtis enim nuper mi≈øeratione Diuina in Regno Britanniae, Legem & fidem Chri≈øti, habetis penes vos in Regno vtramque Pagmam, ex illis Dei gratia per Con≈øilium Regni ve≈øtri ≈øume Legem, & per illam Dei patientia ve≈øtrum
Reges Britanniae Regnum. Vicarius ver√≤ Dei estis in Regno iuxtae Prophetam Regem: Domini e≈øt terra, & plenitudo eius, Orbis terrarum, & Vniuer≈øi qui inhabitant in eo: Et rur≈øum inxtae Prophetam Regem, dilexi≈øti iu≈øtitiam, & odi≈øti miquitatem, proptere√† vnxit te Deus tuus oleo latitiae, prae con≈øortibus t ‚Ä¢ is: & rur≈øum inxta Prophetam Regem, Deus Indicium tuum &c. non enim Indicium neque in≈øtitiam Cae≈øaris. Filij enim Regis gentes Chri≈øtianae, & populi Regni ≈øunt, qui ≈øub ve≈øtra protectione, & pace, & Regno degant, & con≈øi≈øtant iuxta Enangelium, quemadmodum galina congregat pullos ≈øub alis &c. gentes ver√≤ Regni Britaenniae, & populi ve≈øtri ≈øunt, & quos diui≈øos debetis in vnum ad concordiam, & pacem, & ad fidem, & ad legem Chri≈øti, & ad ≈øanctam Ecele≈øiam congregare, reuocare, fouere, manutenere, protegere, regere & ab iniurio≈øis, & malitio≈øis & ab inimicis ≈øemper defendere. Vae Regno cuius Rex puer e≈øt, & cuius Principes man√® comedunt. No voco Regem puerum propter paruam & nimiam aetatem iuxta Prophetam Regem: viri ≈øanguinum & dolo≈øi non dimidiabunt dies ≈øuos &c. per come ≈øtionem intelligimus gulam, per gulam luxuriam, per luxuriam omnia turpta, & mala inxta Salomonem Regem, in maleuolam animam non introibit ≈øapientia, nec habitabit in corpore ≈øubdito peccatis. Rex dicitur √† regendo, non √† Regno: Rex eris dum bene regis, quod ni≈øi feceris, nomen Regis non in te con≈øtabit, & nomen Regis perdes, quod ab≈øit. Det vobis Omnipotens Deus Regnum Britanniae ≈øic regere, vt po≈øsitis cum eo regnare in aeternum, cuius Vicarius e≈øtis in Regno praedicto, qui cum patre & Filio &c.

body.head: THE EPISTLE OF LORD ELEVtherius Pope to Lucius King of BriÃÑtaine.
body.p:
IN the yeare 169. from the Pa≈øsion of Chri≈øt, Lord El ‚Ä¢ utherius Pope wrote to Lucius King of Britaine, at the reque≈øt of the King and Nobles of Britaine. You reque≈øted of vs to haue the Lawes of the Romans, and Cae≈øar, to be ≈øent ouer vnto you, which you would haue v≈øed in the Kingdome of Britaine. We may allwayes reproue the Roman and Imperiall, but the Lawe of God we may not reproue. For you haue lately by the diuine mercy receaued in the kingdome of Britaine, the Lawe and faith of Chri≈øt, you haue among you in the kingdome both the Partes thereof, out of them by the grace of God, with the Coun≈øaile of your kingdome take a Lawe, and by that, with the help of God, you shall Gouerne your kingdome of Britaine: You are verily the vicegerent of God in your kingdome according to the Prophet a King. The earth is our Lords and the fullnes thereof, and the globe of the earth, and all that dwell therein. And againe by the Prophet a King, Thou ha≈øt loued Iu≈øtice, and hated Iniquitie, therefore thy God hath annointed thee with oile of gladnes, aboue thy fellowes. And againe by the Prophet a King, √¥ God giue thy Iudgment to the King, and thy Iu≈øtice to the Kings ≈øonne. Not the Iudgment and Iu≈øtice of Cae≈øar. And the ≈øonnes of the King (there) are Chri≈øtian Nations and people of the kingdome which may liue and be vnder your protection, and peace, and kingdome, according to the Gho≈øpell: euen as an hen gathereth her chickens vnder her wings &c. for the Nations and people of the kingdome of Britaine be yours, whom now diuided, you ought to gather together, to concord, and peace, and to the faith, and to the Lawe of Chri≈øt, and to his holy Church recall them, norish them, maintaine, Gouerne and defend them allwayes from iniurious and malitious par≈øons, and from their enemyes. Woe to the kingdome who≈øe King is a Child, and who≈øe Princes eate early in the morning. I call not a King
a Child for his little or greater age, but for foolishnes, and Iniquitie, and Madnes, according to the Prophet a King: men of blood, and crafty shall not liue halfe their dayes. By eating we vnder≈øtand glutonie, by glutonie luxurie, by luxurie all filthie things, and euill, according to Salomon a king. Wi≈øedome will not enter into a malitious ≈øoule, nor dwell in a body ≈øubiect to ≈øinnes. A King is named of ruling not of a kingdome: You shall be a King ≈øo long as you Gouerne well: but if you doe otherwi≈øe, the name of a King shall not remayne with you, and you shall loo≈øe the name of a King, which God forbid. God allmightie grante, you may ≈øo gouerne the kingdome of Britaine, that you may Reigne with him for euer, who≈øe vicegerent you are in the afore≈øaide kingdome, who with the Father and ≈øonne &c.

div.p:
3. Hitherto this part of S. Eleutherius Epi≈øtle, which the Publisher in the yeare 1568. thought to haue ben ‚Ä¢ written aboue fiue hundred yeares before, and feemeth to ≈øay it was among the old Lawes, pri≈øcis legibus, he then published, in the Library of Matthew Parker the fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury: Plan√® ≈øu≈øcipio atque profiteor magna fide & Religione ex vetu≈øti≈øsimis (vt quae ante quingentos annos, vti coniectura autumo, Saxonicis depicta ≈øunt literis) exemplaribus fui≈ø≈øe de≈øumptas, quorum pleraque in Reuerend. in Chi≈øto Patris D. Matthaei Cantuarien≈øis Archiepi≈øcopi Bibliotheca, alia aliorum in Librarijs vi≈øenda ≈øuper≈øunt. And this Prote≈øtant Archbishop wtiteth, this Epi≈øtle is commonly accompted among the Lawes of S. Edward: Haec Epistola communiter Matth. Parker. Antiq. Brit. p. 5. in Margin. Gulielm. Lamb. in Legib. S. Edwardi. Matth. Parker. ≈øupr. p. 5. in Text. habetur inter leges diui Edwardi: And the Prote≈øtant Lawyer which published them, maketh it a part of tho≈øe Lawes. And yet this Prote≈øtant Archbishop, ≈øaying he will ≈øett downe the whole Epi≈øtle renowned, and rare: Cuius Epi≈øtolae quia tam rara & augu≈øta e≈øt, totam ≈øeriem in≈øeramus; And yet he reciteth litle more then halfe of that is before related. But yet the≈øe men will not ≈øuffer vs to doubt of the credit thereof: For be≈øides that they haue confe≈ø≈øed, it was both in the old Booke of Con≈øtitutions, and commonly among S. Edwards Lawes, and as part of them: an other ≈øaith, it was in an old Manu≈øcript of auncient Kings: Ex vetusto Codice Regum Antiquorum. The Cambridge Antiquarie Foxe Act. and Mon. p. 107. Io. Caius Antiq. Cantabr. l. 1. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. c. 19. found it in the old Hi≈øtorie called Brutus. Our Prote≈øtant writers of the Theater, doe ≈øeeme to write, that the Autographon and Antiquitie it≈øelfe is in the cu≈øtody of Syr Robert Cotton Baronet of Conington in Huntingtonshire: but I heare by others he onely hath an old Copy thereof. Yet a Prote≈øtant Bishop thus confidently affirmeth. we haue ≈øeene the Bishop of Romes owne letter to King Lucius, that is reputed to be the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King of Britaine. Ihon Bridges def. of the gouernm. in the Church of Engl. l. 16. p. 1355. Guliel. Lambr. l. de Pri≈øcis Angl. Legib. fol. 1. ante praf. f. 126. 131. Matth. Parker antiq. Brit. ≈øupr. p. 5. in Marg. If he ≈øaith truely, that he had ≈øeene it, it need not walke inui≈øible in the≈øe times, wherein he liueth, or lately liued. And of ≈øo greate creditt this Antiquitie is with our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries, as the Publisher a Prote≈øtant profe≈ø≈øed, Lawyer and Antiquarie confe≈ø≈øeth, it was receaued as part of our Lawe in England, both by our Saxon and Norman kings, as namely king William the fir≈øt, who confirmed that and other auncient Lawes of this kingdome. And their Archbishop before hath aknowledged no le≈ø≈øe. And the Lawes them≈øelues of S. Edward doe as expre≈ø≈øely ≈øo proue this part of Pope Eleutherius Epi≈øtle to be a portion of them, as any part, parcell or ≈øentence contayned in any of tho≈øe Lawes, making it the ≈øtronge≈øt and mo≈øt warranting Authoritie for the 17. Act or Article of them, which as the Title sheweth is of this greate≈øt point, and mo≈øt materiall in a Temporall Gouernment and Kingdome: Of the Dutie of the King, and of the Right and Appertinences of the Crowne of the Kingdome of Britaine: De Regis of ficio, & de Iure & Appendicijs coronae Regni Leges S. Edwardi Confe≈ø≈øoris c. 17. Britanniae. All which ≈øo materiall and concerning, being very long is wholly
and onely warranted by the Authoritie of Pope Eleutherius, and Pope Ihon after him in the time of Pipinus and Carolus his ≈øonne in France, pre≈øcribing the Dutie of a King to them in France, as S. Eleutherius had before done to King Lucius in Britaine: as the very beginning of that Lawe doth plainely witne≈ø≈øe in the≈øe words: Rex autem quia Vicarius ≈øummi Regis est, ad hoc est con≈øtitutus, vt Regnum terrenum, & populum Domini, & ≈øuper omnia ≈øanctam veneretur Eccle≈øiam cius, & regat & ab iniurio≈øis defendat, & maleficos ab ea euellat, & de≈øtruat, & penit√πs di≈øperdat. Quod ni≈øi fecerit, nec nomen Regis in co constabit, verum te≈øtante Papa Ioanne nomen Regis perdet.

4. And becau≈øe it is euident before that this Epi≈øtle of Pope Eleutherius did contayne more things then be deliuered in that parcell thereof, which is remembred, as the very beginning without any name of eyther the ≈øender or to whome it was ≈øent, greeting, or ≈øuch preambles, as Popes Epi≈øtles to Princes in all Antiquitie haue, doe proue, and we finde further in this very Authenticall Lawe it≈øelfe, and part thereof, that this holy Pope at, or about this time, did ≈øend to King Lucius an hallowed Crowne, with the Title of King of Britaine, and pre≈øcribed the very limits and precints of his kingdome, how farre it did, and was to extend, we cannot be of other Iudgment. But the≈øe things al≈øo were, either included in that Decretall Epi≈øtle of Pope Eleutherius, or ≈øome other about that time, which the words of the Lawe rather incline vnto, te≈øtifying, the Decree of the≈øe later remembred things bore date two yeares before the other: The very words of the Lawe be the≈øe: Debet ver√≤ de Iure Rex omnes terras & honores, omnes dignitates, & Iura, & libertates coronae Regni huius in integrum cum omni integritate, & ≈øine diminutione ob≈øeruare, & defendere, di≈øper≈øa, & dilapidata, & ami≈ø≈øa Regni Iura in pri≈øtinum ≈øtatum, & debitum viribus omnibus reuocare. Vniuer≈øa ver√≤ terra & tota, & In≈øulae omnes v≈øque Norwegiam, & v≈øque Daciam pertinent ad coronam Regni eius, & ≈øunt de Appendicijs & dignitatibus Regis, & vna e≈øt Monarchia, & vnum est Regnum, & vocabatur quondam Regnum Britanniae, modo autem vocatur Regnum Anglorum. Tales enim metas & fines vt praedictae ≈øunt, con≈øtituit & impo≈øuit Coronae Regni Dominus Eleutherius Papa ≈øententia ≈øua, anno cente≈øimo ≈øexage≈øimo ≈øeptimo po≈øt Pa≈øsionem Chri≈øti, qui primo de≈øtinauit coronam benedictam Britanniae, & Chri≈øtianitatem Deo in≈øpirante Lucio Regi Britonum. Debet enim Rex omnia rit√® facere in regno, & per iudicium Procerum regni. Debet enim Ius & iu≈øtitia magis regnare in regno quam voluntas praua: Lex e≈øt ≈øemper quod ius facit, voluntas autem, violentia & vis non e≈øt ius. Debet ver√≤ Rex Deum timere, ≈øuper omnia & diligere, & mandata eius per totum regnum ≈øuum ≈øeruare. Debet enim ≈øanctam Eccle≈øiam regni ≈øui cum omni integritate, & libertate iuxta con≈øtitutiones patrum, & praedece≈ø≈øorum ≈øeruare, fouere, manutenere, regere, & contra inimicos defendere, ita vt Deus prae caeteris honoretur, & prae oculis ≈øemper habeatur. Debet etiam bonas leges & con≈øu ‚Ä¢ tudines approbatas erigere, prauas autem delere, & omnes √† regno de ponere. Debet ‚Ä¢ udicium rectum in regno facere, & iu≈øtitiam per con≈øilium Procerum regni ≈øui tenere. I≈øta ver√≤ debet omnia Rex in propria per≈øona, inspectis & tactis Sacro≈øanctis Euangelijs, & ≈øuper ≈øacras & ≈øanctas reliquias coram regno & ≈øacerdotio & clero iurare, antequam ab Archiepi≈øcopis & Epi≈øcopis regni coronaretur. Tres enim Rex habere debet ≈øeruos, ≈øcilicet luxuriam, auaritiam, & cupiditatem, quos ≈øi habuerit ≈øeruos, bene, & illu≈øtr√® regnabit. Regno omnia debet praemeditari, & hoc Regis e≈øt. Quia mal√® cuncta mini≈øtrant impetus iuxta Euangelium, omne regnum in ≈øe diui≈øum de≈øolabitur: Truly a King ought of right to ob≈øerue and defend all the Lands and honours, all the dignities and rights, and liberties of the Crowne of this kingdome
wholly with all integritie, and without diminution, and with all his power recall to the auncient ≈øtate, and due all the rights of the kingdome, which were di≈øper≈øed, dilapidated, and lo≈øt. And all and the whole Land, and all the Ilands vnto Norwey, and vnto Denmarke doe belong to the Crowne of his kingdome, and they are of the Appendences, and dignities of the King, and it is one Monarchie, and one kingdome, and aunciently was called the kingdome of Britaine, but now is ‚Ä¢ alled the kingdome of the English men. For our Lord Eleutherius Pope who fir≈øt by in≈øpiration of God, did ≈øend an hallowed crowne to Britaine, and Christianitie to Lucius King of the Britons did ordayne and impo≈øe to the Crowne of the kingdome, ≈øuch boundes, and limits, as are ≈øpoken before by his Decree in the yeare one hundred ≈øixtie ≈øeuen after the Pa≈øsion of Chri≈øt. A King al≈øo ought to doe all things in the kingdome truely, and by the Iudgment of the Peeres of the kingdome. For Right, and iu≈øtice ought to Reigne more in a kingdome, then wicked will. That is Lawe which allwayes doth right, but will, violence and force is not right. A King ought to feare God, and loue him aboue all things, and keepe his Commandements throughout the kingdome. He ought al≈øo to pre≈øerue, fo≈øter, maintaine, gouerne, and defend again≈øt Enemies, the holy Church of his kingdome, with all integritie, and libertie, according to the Con≈øtitutions of the Fathers, and Predece≈ø≈øours, ≈øo that God may before all things be honoured, and euer had before his eyes. He ought al≈øo to erect good Lawes, and customes allowed, and blott them out which be wicked, and bannish them all from the kingdome. He ought to doe right iudgment in the kingdome, and keepe Iu≈øtice, by the Coun≈øaile of the Nobles of his kingdome. All the≈øe things a King mu≈øt ≈øweare in his owne par≈øon, looking vpon and touching the holy Gho≈øpels, and vpon holy and ≈øacred Reliks, before the Realme, and Prei≈øthood, and Clergie, before he be crowned by the Archbishops and Bishops of the kingdome. For a King must haue three things ≈ølaues vnto him, to wit, luxury, a ‚Ä¢ arice, and concupi≈øcence, which if he maketh ≈ø ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ es, he shall reigne well, and renownedly, he mu≈øt premeditate all things for the kingdome, and this is the office of a King. Becau≈øe violences doe mini≈øter all things ill, according to the Gho≈øpell, euery kindome diuided in it≈øelfe will be de≈øolate.

5. Hitherto this our holy and auncient Lawe, of the office and dutie of our Kings, v≈øed and practized euen from the beginning of Chri≈øtianitie, publikly receaued heare, both in the Britans and Saxons gouernment, founded, warranted and grounded vppon the Authoritie and direction of the holy Pope S. Eleutherius, as appeareth by that part of his Epi≈øtle which I fir≈øt recited, immediately without any one ≈øentence, worde, or ≈øillable interpo≈øed betweene them, annexed and ioyned to this Lawe, as the originall cau≈øe, motiue, allowance, and confirmation thereof. Whereby we may cleartly ≈øee, the greate power, prerogatiue, and Iuri≈ødiction the Popes of Rome euen from the beginning, and fir≈øt founding Chri≈øtian Religion heare, claimed, had, and exerci≈øed, in this kingdome, and from the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King we enioyed, a Saint and ble≈ø≈øed man, all our Kings Britans, Saxons, or what≈øoeuer Chri≈øtians to the≈øe dayes, did with this whole kingdome allowe to the Apo≈øtolike See of Rome, as much as it claimeth now at our hands, and as any good and learned Catholiks doe yeeld vnto it. From that holy and eminent See we had by the≈øe greate≈øt Te≈øtimonies Chri≈øtian Religion planted and Iuridically ≈øetled heare. Our Epi≈øcopall and Archiepi≈øcopall Sees a≈ø≈øigned, our fir≈øt Bishops and Archbishops to enioy them appointed, and con≈øecrated. Direction giuen euen in temporall and ciuill affaires, what Lawes we should take, our King Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor but of a part of this kingdome declared to be King of all Britaine, and ≈øo many adiacent Ilands enioyed by his enemyes, and an hallowed Crowne
≈øent him to weare, as Monarch and King of them all. A Prote≈øtant Lawyer, Bracton l. 1. de acquir. rer. Dom. c. 8. Io. Selden Analect. p. 46. and Antiquarie ≈øaith, that from this Popes donation our Kings had the Title, viracius Dei, vicar or vicegerent of God, and citeth Bracton for his Authour, who rather denyeth, then affirmeth it: onely he ≈øaith again≈øt the ≈øence of Prote≈øtants, that it is euident, a King ought to be vnder the Lawe, being but Gods vicegerent: Quod ≈øub lege Rex e≈ø≈øe debeat cum ‚Ä¢ it Dei vicarius. And Roger Houeden who reciteth this verie Lawe verbatim, hath not that Title, Vicarius, no ‚Ä¢ the wo ‚Ä¢ de, Regert, to Rule, which our Prote≈øtants apply to the Church, the Title is Regis Officium, the Kings dutie, and is this: Rex atque Vicarius eius ad hoc Roger. HouedeÃÑ Annal. part. po≈øter. in Henric. ‚Ä¢ . c. de legib. Angl. e≈øt con≈øtitutus, vt regnum terrenum, populum Dei, & ≈øuper omnia, ≈øanctam Eccle≈øiam reuereatur, & ab Iniuriatoribus defendat, & maleficos ab ea euellat, & destruat & penitus disperdat. where, aboue all things he mu≈øt reuerence the holy Church, and be ruled by it, and not Rule it. And this, all our Chri≈øtian Kings to King Edward the ≈øixt a child did publikly profe≈ø≈øe before their Coronation, as the old Order thereof is witnes. And the≈øe Titles to be Vicarius Cbri≈øti in his Pontificale Roman. in Benedictione & Coronatione Regis. holy Church, is as fully before giuen to Pope Eleutherius by King Lucius, and his Chri≈øtians, and Regere to rule it vnder Chri≈øt, made by them the Popes peculiar, as they were euer after to the≈øe Times.

6. And to ≈øpeake more particularly of the ciuill and temporall Lawes, which King Lucius reque≈øted Pope Eleutherius to giue direction in, and he accordingly e≈øtablished in this kingdome, this holy King now a Chri≈øtian, did not, and could not by his Religion demand the Roman Pagan Lawes, without alteration or correction, of S. Eleutherius, but according to ≈øuch moderation, change, or alteration he should v≈øe in them, to ≈øpeake in a Prote≈øtant Bishops words: Lucius made reque≈øt vnto Eleutherius to ≈øend him ≈øome Kinde of Ab≈øtract of the Roman Lawes, whereby he might e≈øtablish a ≈øetled order of Gouernment‚ñ™
Godwin Conu. of Britaine p. 29. in his Dominions. And when Pope Eleutherius directed him, to take his Lawe, conformable to the Lawe of God, by the adui≈øe of his kingdome, ex illis Dei gratia, per con≈øilium Regni ve≈øtri ≈øume Legem, he ment as an other Prote≈øtant Bridges defence l. 16. p. 1355. Bishop expoundeth him, that this should be done principally by the Adui≈øe of the clergie of his DominioÃÑ, the Bishops and Prei≈øts which he had ordained heare, be≈øt Learned and conuer≈øant in the holy Scripturs, and Lawe of God. That the Lawes which they receaued and e≈øtablished heare were the old Britan Lawes, a≈øcribed for their greate≈øt part to Mulmutius Dunwallo, corrected and Galf. Mon. l. 2. c. 17. Brittsh. Hi≈øt. l. 3. c. 5. Pontic. Virun. l. 23. Hi≈øt. Stowe Hi≈øt. in Mulmut. Dunwall. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. Matth. We≈øtm. aetat. 5. c. 2. Galfr. Mon. l. 2. Hi≈øt. c. vlt. Pontic. Vir. l. 2. Hi≈øt. in fine. Stowe Hi≈øt. in Mulm. Dunwallo. Holinsh Hi≈øt. of Engl. 3. c. 1. Forte≈øcue l. de laudib. legum Angl. c. 13. made conformable to holy Chri≈øtian Religion, we haue all Kinde of Antiquities Brittish, Saxon, French, Italians, Catholiks, and Prote≈øtants for witne≈ø≈øes. The≈øe Lawes were tran≈ølated out of Brittish into Latine long before this time, by the auncient Gildas that liued about the time of the birth of Chri≈øt, as many both auncient and late writers agree, and continued heare vntill late time, and in diuers re≈øpects at this pre≈øent. So the Authour of the Brittish Hi≈øtory, Virunnius, and Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter write of their times: Dunwallo Mulmutius Leges Mulmutinas ≈øtatuit, quae v≈øque ‚Ä¢ odie inter Anglos celebrantur. Thus he wrote within the≈øe 300. yeares, that Mulmutius Lawes were tho≈øe which were then v≈øed in England. Galfridus and Ponticus write the ≈øame, Quae v≈ø
que ad hoc teÃÑpus celebraÃÑtur inter Anglos. The like haue our Prote≈øtants Stowe, Hollinshed, and others. And the be≈øt witne≈ø≈øe we can v≈øe in ≈øuch a ca≈øe of Lawes, Iudge Forte≈øcue mo≈øt Learned in them, and Antiquities concerning ≈øuch affaires, he ≈øpeaking in commendation of Lawes, and our auncient Lawes in particular, fir≈øt writeth, how from the time of Brutus this kindome was Ruled by Lawes: ≈øic (per leges) Regnum Angliae, quod ex Bruto
comitiua Troianorum, quam ex Italiae & Graecorum finibus produxit, in Dominium politicum, & Regale prorupit: By Lawes the kingdome of England from the company of Troians which Brutus brought from the Co≈øts of Italy, and the Grecians came to be a Politicall and Regall Dominion. And after, thus proueth a continuance of the≈øe Lawes by all people which heare inhabited: Regnum Angliae primo per Britannos inhabitatum e≈øt, deinde per Romanos regulatum, Forte≈øcue ≈øupr. cap. 17. iterumque per Britannos, ac deinde per Saxones po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øum, & tunc per Danos, Iterum per Saxones, ≈øed finaliter per Normannos, & in omnibus Nationum harum, & Regum earum temporibus, Regnum illud, ei≈ødem, quibus iam regitur, con≈øuetudinibus continu√® regulatum est, quae ≈øi optimae non extiti≈ø≈øent, aliqui Regum illorum, Iu≈øtitia, ratione, vel affectione concitati, eas muta≈ø≈øent aut omnino deleui≈ø≈øent, & maxim√® Romani qui legibus ≈øuis qua≈øi totum orbis reliquum iudicabant: The kingdome of England was fir≈øt inhabited by the Britans, after that ruled by the Romans, and againe by the Britans, and after po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the Saxons, and then by the Danes, againe by the Saxons, but finally by the Normans, and in all the times of the≈øe Nations and their Kings, that kingdome was ruled continually by the ≈øame Cu≈øtomes, by which it is now gouerned, which if they had not bene the best could be made, ≈øome of tho≈øe Kings incited by Iu≈øtice, rea≈øon, or affection would haue changed them, or vtterly blotted them forth, and e≈øpecially the Romans, who Iudged as it were all the re≈øt of the worlde by their Lawes. Ranulphus Higeden in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory ≈øaith: ≈øancciuit primum Leges Dunwallo Mulmutius, cuius Leges Mulmutnae dicebantur v≈øque ad tempora Willielmi Conque≈øtoris ≈øatis celebres. Inter quae ≈øtatuit Ranulph. Higeden in Manu≈øcr. Polychr. l. 1. c. 50. de legib. vt Ciuitates & Templa Deorum, viaeque ad villas ducentes, ac Aratrum colonum immunitate confugij gauderent. Deinde Marcia Regina Britonum vxor Guithelmi Regis, √† qua Prouincia Merciorum putatur denominata legem edidit, di≈øcretione & Iu≈øtitia plenam, quae lex Martia vocabatur. Has duas leges Gildas Hi≈øtoricus tran≈øtulit de Britannico in Latinum, &. Rex Aluredus postmoduÃÑ de Latino is Saxonicum, quae Marchenelaga dicebatur: Dunwallo Mulmutius did fir≈øt ordaine Lawes, which from him were called Mulmutius his Lawes and renowned vntill the time of william, the Conqueror. Among which he decreed, that Cyties and the Temples of their Gods, and the wayes that ledd to Townes, and the Plough of husbandimen should haue freedome. Afterward Martia Queene of the Britans wife of King Gwitheline of whome the Prouince of the Martians is thought to be ≈øo named, made a Lawe full of di≈øcretioÃÑ and Iu≈øtice which was called Martia Lawe. The≈øe two Lawes Gildas the Hi≈øtorian did Tran≈ølate out of Brittish language into Latine, and King Alfred did tran≈ølate them out of Latine into the Saxon tongue, which was called Marchenlage.

6. The like haue the Brittish Hi≈øtory, Virunnius, Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter with others, and diuers Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians: among whome one for Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 3. c. 1. the re≈øt thus writeth: Mulmutius made many good Lawes, which were longe after v≈øed, called Mulmutius Lawes, turned out of the Brittish speach into the Latine by Gildas Pri≈øcus, and longe time after tran≈ølated out of Latine into English by Alfred King of England, and mingled in his statuts. And this is ≈øufficiently proued by the Lawes them≈øelues, of King Aluredus: wherein after he had ≈øet downe the Iudiciall Lawes of the old Te≈øtament applyed for the gouernment of this kingdome, as Pope Eleutherius had giuen directioÃÑ to King Lucius, he maketh this mention thereof: haec ea ≈øunt Iura quae rerum omnium praepotens Deus ip≈øe Moy≈øi cu≈øtodienda propo≈øuit: The≈øe be tho≈øe Lawes, which the Allmightie Leges Regis Aluredi in praefatioÃÑe, apud Gul. Lambert l. de pri≈øcis legib. God of all things him≈øelfe did propo≈øe to Moy≈øes to be kept. Then he cometh to the New Te≈øtament, and Lawes which after the preaching of the Gho≈øpell, the A≈ø≈øemblyes of Bishops and renowned wi≈øe men decreed heare in
Britaine, then England: In Anglia Epi≈øcoporum aliorumque; clari≈øsimorum ≈øapientum Conuentus agebantur, atque hi diuina edocti mi≈øeratione cuique iam primum peccanti paenam imperabant. And addeth, that he hath gathered them all together, Rex Aluredus ≈øupra in praef. and approueth a greate part of tho≈øe auncient Lawes, to be ≈øtill ob≈øerued, and ioyneth vnto them ≈øome others which he enacted: Has Ego Aluredus Rex ≈øanctionesin vnum collegi, atque ea≈ødem literis mandaui, quarum bon ‚Ä¢ m c ‚Ä¢ rt√® partem Maiores no≈øtri Religio≈øe coluerunt, multa etiam mihi digna videntur, quae a nobis hac etiam aetate pari Religione ob≈øeruentur, nonnulla tamen, quae nobis minus commoda videbantur ex con≈øulto ≈øapientum partim antiquanda, partim innouanda curaui. And it is manife≈øt by the Lawes of King Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor, as they were ≈øolemnely proued and propo≈øed to King William the fir≈øt, by ≈øome named the Conqueror, both as they are recorded by our auncient Hi≈øtorian Roger Houeden, and M. Lambret the Prote≈øtant Lawyer, and Antiquarie, that he was ≈øo carefull to knowe, and make ≈øemblance al≈øo of e≈øtablishing the≈øe auncient Lawes reuiued, and maintained by S. Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor, that Leg. S. Edwardi c. 1. apud Roger. Houed. part. 2. Annal. in Henr. 2. & Guliel. Lambert. in Legib. S. Edwardi. fir≈øt he appointed a Iury of twelue ≈øworne men in euery Shire taking their Oathes before the King, that to their power, they would truely and ≈øincerly ≈øet downe the Decrees of their Lawes and Cu≈øtomes, without any omi≈ø≈øion, addition, or mutation, electi de ≈øingulis totius Patriae Comitatibus viri duodecim, Iureiurando coram Rege primum confirmauerunt, vt quod po≈ø≈øent, recto tramite incedentes, Legum ≈øuarum & con≈øuetudinum ≈øancita patefacereÃÑt: nihil praeter mittentes, nihil addentes, nil praeuaricando mutantes. And this ≈øo ≈øolemnely examined, pre≈øented, and performed, ‚Ä¢ e did confirme in all things the≈øe auncient Lawes termed S. Edwards Lawes for the rea≈øon before, to be kept and continued as well as tho≈øe which were added by him≈øelfe, as appeareth in his owne ≈øtill extant Lawes: hoc quoque praecipio, vt omnes habeant & teneant Legem ≈øancti Leges Regis Gulielm. 1. apud. Gul. Lamb. in eod. Edwardi in omnibus rebus, adauctis his quae con≈øtituimus ad vtilitatem Anglorum. And ≈øo it is euidently true that many of tho≈øe auncient Lawes of Mulmutius and King Lucius by Pope Eleutherius direction, did continue in the time of Iudge Forte≈øcue, as al≈øo at this pre≈øent, but where they haue bene taken away by our Prote≈øtant Princes, to giue way to their new Religion.

div.head: THE XXI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF MANY ARCHIEPISCOPALL, EPISCOpall and other Churches, and Mona≈øteries both of men and women founded, and ritchly endowed and priuiledged in this time.

div.p:
1. KING Lucius being thus enformed and ≈øecured in con≈øcience by the≈øe letters, and declaration of the holy Pope and Pa≈øtor of Chri≈øts Church Eleutherius, that the whole kingdome of Britaine with the Ilands, belonged to his temporall chardge and Gouernment, and that ≈øo much as he could he was to wine his ≈øubiects to the faith and Lawe of Chri≈øt, and his holy Church, and prouide for the peace and quiet of the ≈øame and the members thereof, he did fir≈øt in receauing and admitting the≈øe new corrected Lawes by the adui≈øe of his Clergie and Nobles of his kingdome ≈øee them ≈øo qualified, that they were for the defence and propagation of Chri≈øtian Religion, and further founded many Godly, co≈øtly, and memorable Monuments, as Churches, Vniuer≈øities or Schools, Mona≈øteries and other ≈øuch comforts‚ñ™
‚Ä¢ elps, and furtherances of Sainct Lucius King of greate Britaine, the fir≈øt King „Äà‚óä„Äâ of Chri≈øts Church. that holy end: So that as he was the fir≈øt King which publikly with his kingdome profe≈ø≈øed Chri≈øt, ≈øo he wonne the honour, to be the fir≈øt Nur≈øing Father among Kings, of his holy Church, as the Prophet had foretold: erunt Reges nutric ‚Ä¢ tui: Kings shall be thy Nur≈øing Fathers. He was fir≈øt among Kings properly termed, Vicarius Dei, the Viceg ‚Ä¢ rent of God, being the fir≈øt King, which ≈øo religeou≈øly performed his will. And that Title which the Pope gaue to King Henry 8. when he was better then he proued after, defen≈øor fidei, defendo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of the faith, was among Kings the fir≈øt due and Right of King Lucius, for his ≈øo Heroicall Religeous fortitude and magnanimitie in defending the faith and Church of Chri≈øt. And as the Brittish Hi≈øtorie, Virunnius, Matthew of The Popes Legats change the Pagan Temples into Chri≈øtian Churches. We≈øtmin≈øter and others write, of the holy Legats, that be≈øides their changing Flamens, Archflamens into Bishops and Archbishops, the Temples of the Gentils, which were founded in honour of many Gods, they dedicated the ≈øame to the one true God, and to his Saints, and replenished the ≈øame with diuers companies Churches dedicated to Saints. of con≈øecrated par≈øons: Templ ‚Ä¢ quae in ho ‚Ä¢ orem pluri ‚Ä¢ orum Deorum fundata fuerant, vni Deo eiu≈øque Sanctis dedicauer ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t, diuer≈øi≈øque ordinatorum caetibus repleuerunt. Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 4. c. 19. PoÃÑ tic. Vir. l. 4. Mat. We≈øtm. an. 185. Manu≈øcr. Gallic. Antiq. an. 180. Matth. We≈øtm. Hi≈øt. an. 187. So the ≈øame Authou ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ write of King Lucius: Glorio≈øus Britonum Rex Lucius, cum intra Regnum ≈ø ‚Ä¢ um verae fidei cultum magnificatum e≈ø≈øe vidi≈ø≈øet, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øsiones & territoria Eccle≈øijs & ‚Ä¢ iris Eccle≈øia≈øticis abundanter conferens, chartis & munimentis omnia communiuit. Eccle≈øias vero cum ≈øuis caemiterijs, ita constituit e≈ø≈øe liberas, vt quicunque malefactor ad illa confugeret, illae≈øus ab omnibus remaneret: The glorious King of the Britans Lucius when he ≈øawe that the worship of the true faith was aduanced within his kingdome, be≈øtowing aboundantly po≈ø≈øe≈øsions and The Churches are furnished with other Eccle≈øia≈øticall Clergy men be≈øides Bishops, & Prei≈øts. territories vpon Churches, and Eccle≈øia≈øticall men, he confirmed all things with charters and priuiledges. And appointed that Churches and Churchyards should be ≈øo free, that what≈øoeuer malefactour should fly vnto them, should remaine without hurt from all. The Brittish Hi≈øtorie thus relateth it: Interea glorio≈øus ille Rex Lucius,
cum intra Regnum ≈øuum cultum vere fidei magnificatum e≈ø≈øe vidi≈ø≈øet, maximo gaudio Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 5. c. 1. fluctuans, Po≈ø≈øe≈øsiones & Territoria quae prius Templa IdoloruÃÑ po≈øsidebant, in meliorem v≈øum vertens, Eccle≈øijs fidelium permanere conce≈øsit. Et quia maiorem honorem Churches founded and endowed by King Lucius, And what ReligioÃÑ they profe≈ø≈øed. ip≈øis impendere debuerat, augmentauit illas amplioribus agris & man≈øis, omnique libertate ≈øublimauit: In the meane time when that renowned King Lucius did ≈øee true Religion exalted within his kingdome, most greatly reioicing thereat, conuerting the Po≈ø≈øe≈øsions and Territories which formerlie the TeÃÑples of Idols did po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe to a better v≈øe, granted that they should remayne to the Churches of the faithfull and becau≈øe he ought to be≈øtowe more honour one them, he augmented them with more ample lands and Man≈øions. Which how greate and ample they were, we may make ≈øome e≈øtimate, if we reflect vpon the greate Ritches of the Idoll Temples heare before this Conuer≈øion, all which with an ample addition were now left to the Chri≈øtian Cleargie, and Churches.

2. I will onely exemplify in one ≈øolemnitie of tho≈øe Gentils and in one place of this kingdome London, at one time, & thus related in the old Brittish Hi≈øtorie, which our Prote≈øtants haue published, litauerunt ibi quadraginta millia Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 4. c. 8. vaccarum, & centum millia ouium: diuer≈øorumque generum volatilia, quae leuiter ≈øub numero non cadebant. Praeterea triginta millia Sylue≈øtrium ferarum cuiu≈øcunque generis collectarum: They ≈øacrificed there, at Trinouantum LoÃÑdon, forty thou≈øand kyne, & a hundred thou≈øand sheepe, and foules of all ≈øortes, which could hardly be numbred and thirtie thousaÃÑd wilde bea≈øts, of euery kinde which they had gathered together. And PoÃÑ ticus Virunnius hath the very ≈øame words in all things; except in the fir≈øt Ponticus Virun. Hi≈øt. l. 4. number, which he much abateth, vndecim millia vaccarum. This for thankes to their pretended Gods for the repul≈øe the Britans had then giuen to Iulius Cae≈øar. Of the Ritches, reuenewes, ≈øtate and Pompe of the Pagan cheife Druids, Flamens and Archflamens I haue ≈øpoken ≈øomewhat before: therefore all this welth and ≈øub≈øtance, and with ≈øo ample addition now conuerted by King Lucius to the v≈øe of the Chri≈øtian Clergie, as we mu≈øt needs yeeld him the remembred Titles, ≈øo he employing them, and ≈øo lardge immunities to Manu≈øcr. Gallic. antiq. ann. 180. Antiq. Gla≈øcon. Manu≈øcr. Capgr. in S. Io≈øeph & S. Patricio. ≈øuch a Clergie, as builded, and dedicated Churches, and prayed vnto Saints, and for the deade, ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe, and gaue ≈øuch Supreamacie to Pope Eleutherius, we may not ≈øay, he was of the Prote≈øtant Profe≈ø≈øion, which hath taken all from that holy Religion, and left nothing but Per≈øecution and Oppre≈ø≈øion vnto it.

3. How in this time all the cheife Temples in all the Cities of Britaine together with their Reuencwes were turned into the Sees of Archbishops, and Bishops, is before related, and in diuers of tho≈øe Cities new Cathedrall Churches founded, and erected, as I haue exemplified before in Winche≈øter, Landaffe, S. Martins Church in Canterburie, and S. Peters in Cornhill in London, Manu≈øcript. in S. Peters Church in Cornhill in London. for which the auncient Manu≈øcript there ≈øtill or lately hanging with diuers other Antiquities thus pleadeth: Lucius the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King of this Land then called Britaine, founded the fir≈øt Church in London, that is to ≈øay, S. Peters S. Peter ‚Ä¢ Church in Cornhill in LoÃÑ don a Metropolitan See. Church vpon Cornhill, and he founded there an Archbishops See, and made that Church the Metropolitan and cheife Church of this kingdome, and ≈øo endured the ≈øpace of 400. yeares, and more vnto the comming of S. Augu≈øtine the Apo≈øtle of England, the which was ≈øent to this Land by S. Gregory the Doctour: then was the Arbishops See and Pall remoued from the fore≈øaid Church of S. Peter vpon Cornhill vnto Dereberman that now is called Canterbury, and there it remayneth to this day. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. cap. 19. Hollinshed writeth that there were in his time Tables hanging in the Reue≈øtry of S. Paules Church in London, which affirme the ≈øame. An other Prote≈øtant
citing the fir≈øt cited Table in S. Peters Church vpon Cornhill, and inclining to that opinion, and addeth: Iocelyn of Furnes in his booke of Brittish Stowe Hi≈øtor. Romans in K. Lucius. Bishops ≈øaith, Thean was the fir≈øt Archbishop of London, in the time of Lucius, who builded the ≈øaid Church of S. Peter in a place called Cornhill in London, by the ayde of Cyran cheife Butlar to King Lucius. Godwin a Prote≈øtant Godwin Catal. of Bish. in London 1. Polid. Virgil. Angl. Hi≈øtor. l. 2. p. 41. Richard. Vitus in Hi≈øt. l. 5. Holins. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. cap. 19. Will. Harri≈øon de≈øcr. of Brit. p. 24. c. 9. Sulcar. apud Vit. ≈øupr. Selden Annal. c. 6. Bishop hath allmo≈øt the ≈øame words, though not citing any Authour in particular. Others both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants affirme, that the Church of S. Peter at we≈øtmin≈øter by London was then founded, and v≈øed for the Cathedrall Church, as ≈øome write: There be that affirme; ≈øaith a Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorian, how this Lucius should build the Church of S. Peter at We≈øtmin≈øter. They add further that Thomas (likely Theonus mi≈øtaken) Archbishop of London preached, read, and mini≈øtred the Sacraments there to ≈øuch as made re≈øort vnto him. And of this opinion that this Church was then made or reedified (for that I haue written before) is Sulcardus a learned Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter, mo≈øt likely to write the truth of that Church liuing in the time of S. Edward the Confe≈ø≈øour, and that it was the Cathedrall Church to London. Both which may be true, if we make the old Church, of We≈øtmin≈øter the Cathedrall Church vntill the other was builded, not finished in the fir≈øt Arbishops How it is probable that both S. Peters Church & We≈øtminster, and in Cornhill were Archiepi≈øcopall Churches in this time. time, but by his Succe≈ø≈øour Eluanus who builded the Library, & likely ≈øome part of S. Peters Church vpon Cornhill. William Harri≈øon a Prote≈øtant Antiquarie, borne as he ≈øaith in London, and ≈øo chalendging knowledge of the Antiquities there, proueth this by ≈øondry rea≈øons, and citeth William of Malmesbury for the ≈øame opinion. And Polidor Virgil with many others ≈øaith, the Cathedrall Church in London was then Templum & ornatu, & opere magnificum, a Church magnificent both for ornament and worke. Which Stowe ≈øupr. froÃÑ others. Will. Harri≈øon ≈øupr. c. ‚Ä¢ . Gildas l. de Excid. & conq. Brit. we doe not finde of S. Peters Church vpon Cornhill.

4. And the ≈øame Authour witne≈ø≈øeth, that the like magnificent Churches were then founded at Yorke and Car-legion, Londini, Eboraci, & in vrbe Legionum templa & ornatu & opere magnifica condita ≈øunt. And much like vnto this we mu≈øt ≈øpeake of all Churches in Cities that were Epi≈øcopall, and Cathedrall, whether they were new founded, or of Temples of Flamens conuerted to be ≈øuch, as al≈øo of all other Pagan Temples which then were, changed into Chri≈øtian Churches. For allthough all tho≈øe temples were not de≈øtroyed and vtterly ruinated, but newly dedicated to Chri≈øt and his Saints, as our Antiquaries haue proued before: yet the ≈øuper≈øtitious and Idolatrous Altars, where vpon their prophane and adhominable ≈øacrifices were offered in them, to their fal≈øe Gods, were vtterly ouerthrowne, and left de≈øolate, and as S. Gildas the mo≈øt auncient Brittish Hi≈øtorian with others te≈øtifie, Chri≈øtian Altars which were the place of Chri≈øtian Sacrifice of the holy Ma≈ø≈øe, wherein Chri≈øts holy body and blood were offered, and therefore termed by him the Polidor. Virgil. l. 2. Hi≈øt. p. 41. ≈øeate of the heauenly ≈øacrifice, ≈øedes caele≈øtis ≈øacrificij, and the Altars whereon their fir≈øt Primatiue Prei≈øts offered that mo≈øt diuine Sacrifice, which we commonly call Ma≈ø≈øe: Sacerdotes inter altaria Sacrificantes, and in re≈øpect thereof Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. lib. 11. cap. 4. Gildas ≈øupr. Stowe Hi≈øt. an. 542. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 5. c. 15. Mat. We≈øt. an. 543. the cheife≈øt of the immunities before remembred were granted to tho≈øe ≈øacred Altars, in all Churches in this kingdome of Britaine from King Lucius time. And the ordinary Churches which were vnder the Iuri≈ødiction of ≈øo many Bishops in ≈øo lardge a kingdome could not be few, e≈øpecially if we con≈øider the multitude of Gods the Britans worshipped, when they were Pagans, and the greate number of Temples dedicated vnto them, which were changed into Chri≈øtian Churches. Leland writeth, that King Lucius built a
new Church in the Ca≈øtle of Douer, and citeth the Annals thereof, for warrant. Io. Leland. a≈ø≈øert. Arthurij c. 7. Annal. Duren. ibid. Will. Lambard. peramb. of Kent. p. 158. Iacob. Genuen. Epi≈ø. in Vita S. Aug. Cantuar. Archiep. Capgr. Catal. in eodem. Tradunt Annales Doren≈øis Caenobij Lucium Regem Britannorum Chri≈øtianum Eccle≈øiam Seruatori ≈øuo in Duren≈øi Ca≈øtro con≈øecra≈ø≈øe. William Lambard the Antiquarie of that Country al≈øo ≈øaith, King Lucius builded a Church within Douer Ca≈øtle. Iacobus GenueÃÑ≈øis Bishop of Genua, Capgraue and others writeth of an old Church at Compton in warwicke shire, carrying argument of foundation in that time. The Authour ≈øaith it was a Parish Church and had ≈øuch a Prei≈øt for the Pa≈øtor thereof receauing Tithes hundred of yeares before S. Augu≈øtine time, which if it were ≈øo, we may make coniecture of an vn≈øearchable number in the ≈øame condition. Which our Antiquities ≈øufficiently confirme before, teaching that the Temples of all the Gods of the Gentils which were in all parts of Britaine, were changed into Chri≈øtian Churches. And Anacletus apud Rob. Barnes in Vit. Pont. in eod. our Prote≈øtants tell vs, it was the old Decree of Pope Anacletus, which the≈øe Legats of the Pope would not tran≈øgre≈ø≈øe, that as Bishops were to be in cheife Cities, ≈øo they should appoint Prei≈øts in Ca≈øtles, Townes, and Villages, binding them to Re≈øidencie there: Ne Epi≈øcoporum dignitati derogaretur, in egregijs tantum vrbibus Epi≈øcopos con≈øtituendos cen≈øuit. Presbiteros ver√≤ ab Epi≈øcopis in Ca≈øtellis, Pagis, ac Villis con≈øtituendos e≈ø≈øe ea lege, vt inibi vitae ≈øuae ≈øpacium tran≈øigerent. Which to haue bene ob≈øerued in this Conuer≈øion, the multitude of Bed. Hi≈øt. Galfr. Mat. We≈øtm. & alij in Diocle≈ø. Churches de≈øtroied heare by Diocle≈øian within an hundred yeares after ≈øufficiently declareth.

5. And we finde in Antiquitie that in this very time of King Lucius be≈øides the Cathedrall Churches in the greate Cities, there were others al≈øo builded in them, as namely Gloce≈øter, Worchester, Caerlegion, and others for we reade, of diuers kindes of Churches in them all, both Cathedrall, and others. King Lucius was buried at Gloce≈øter in the Church of the cheife Order; in Eccle≈øia primae ≈øedis. The ≈øame di≈øtinction is giuen for Winche≈øter, which nece≈ø≈øarily Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. l. 5. c. 1. Mat. We≈øtm. an. 201. Galfr. l. 8. c. 17. l. 9 c. 12. Bed. & Mat. ≈øupr. inferreth other Churches, or a Church in eyther of them of inferious Order. For the word, fir≈øt proueth a ≈øecond: for the Inferiour Churches be≈øides the Cathedrall in Caerlegion they are remembred in Hi≈øtories. So of other Cities, not inferiour vnto the≈øe, Gloce≈øter being then but a new and no greate Citie. We may finde others, as at Abington in Oxfordshire, Ambsbury in Wilshire, Cambridge, Stamford, and other places to be remembred hereafter where to haue bene Chri≈øtian Churches in that time, there is ≈øtill ≈øufficient Argument, and Euidence left vnto vs. And the Pagan Temples being throughout, the whole kingdome, and now with their Reuenewes encrea≈øed by King Lucius, and changed into Churches dedicated to Chri≈øt, and his Saints, as before is proued, euidently conuinceth, the≈øe to haue bene more honorable, and as generally in all places, and ≈øo not to be numbred, as the others were and all this alteration made by King Lucius with the direction and Order of the Roman Legats, S. Phaganus and S. Damianus. And this is that which our old Manu≈øcript Annals of Landaffe with other Antiquities te≈øtifie; that our Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hierarchie was ≈øetled, Bishops ordayned, and the Rule of well liuing taught in Britaine, according to the commande and direction of Pope Eleutherius: ≈øecundum Antiquitates Manu≈øcr. Eccle≈ø. Landauen. Iu≈ø≈øum be ati Eleutherij Papae Eccle≈øia≈øticum ordinem con≈øtituit, Epi≈øcopos ordinauit, & ben√® viuendi normam docuit. And to prouide a≈øwell for the continuall maintenance and repayre of the hou≈øe of God, at the fir≈øt founding and building thereof, tho≈øe auncient Schooles, Colledges or Vniuer≈øities of this kingdome, which all now had receaued the faith and Religion of Chri≈øt, and ≈øo were to be as Seminaries and Mothers of Chri≈øtian Diuinitie, and holy learning, for
pre≈øeruation, and Vpholding of Gods Church, King Lucius endowed with greate Priuiledges and Immunities, that they might more quietly, and diligently employ them≈øelues, to their ≈øo profitable and holy ≈øtudies.

6. This his Charter of priuiledge to the Vniuer≈øitie of Cambridge, the Antiquaries thereof proue by diuers auncient Te≈øtimonies, the Bull of Pope Honorius Bulla Honorij Papae ann. 624. Charta Regis Cadwalladri An. 685. Charta Regis Arthuri an. 531. die 7. Apr. apud Caium l. 1. de Antiq. accad. Cantabrig. 1000. yeares ≈øince, the Charter of King Cadwalladrus, and King Arthur long before: wherein is contayned that he granted to the Vniuer≈øitie of Cambridge, as King Lucius with other Kings had done before, to be free from all publike Vectigals and Burthens that they might more quietly and freely attend their ≈øtudies: con≈øilio & a≈ø≈øen≈øu omnium & ≈øingulorum Pontificum & Principum i≈øtius Regni, & Licentia ≈øedis Apo≈øtolicae, ≈øtatuo prae≈øenti ≈øcripto & firmiter decerno, vt Ciuitas Scholarium praedicta, vbi hacten√πs ≈øplendorem ≈øcientiae & lumeÃÑ doctrinae, gratia fauente Conditoris mei Praedece≈ø≈øores acceperunt, √† publicis vectigalibus & operibus onero≈øis ab≈øoluantur, vt quietudine Doctores inibi & Scholares valeant doctrinae ≈øtudio inhaerere, ≈øicut glorio≈øus Rex Britanniae decreuit. The like I may Ioan. Harding Chron. c. 25. f. 22. Io. Ro≈ø≈øe Hi≈øtor. Manu≈øcript. Io. Caius Apol. accad. Cant. & de Antiq. l. 1. William Harri≈øon De≈øcr. of Britaine c. ‚Ä¢ . Tit. of Vniuer≈øities pag. 146. Stowe Hi≈øt. in Bladud. Bal. praefat. in lib. de Script. Twyn. l. de Ant. Oxon. Harri≈øon ≈øupr. Harris Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. Grafton Chron. Bal. l. de Script. Brit. cent. 1. in Congello, Bannachorren. Galft. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 11. c. 12. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 603. Io. Bal. Praef. in l. de Scri. Brit. Galfi. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 9. c. 12. Galft. Mon. Hi≈øt. lib. 4. c. 19. Matt. We≈øt. an. 185. King Lucius founded diuers Mona≈øteries both of men and women. affirme of Stamford, which from the time of King Bladud, vntill it was interdicted by S. Gregory Pope, for Pelagian Here≈øie, continued an Vniuer≈øitie: So of Glamorgan, clayming but a litle later Originall, Greekelade and Lichelade of ≈øuch Antiquitie, Belli≈øitum now Oxford as it pleadeth, Theodford where, as a Prote≈øtant Antiquarie boldly writeth, there were 600. ≈øtudents in auncient times, and others not ≈øo well remembred. To all which, now conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, and trayning vp ≈øpirituall ≈øouldiers for the defence, Profe≈ø≈øion, and maintenance thereof, we haue ≈øufficient grounds before, to affirme King Lucius gaue the like priuiledges, as vnto Cambridge, one and the ≈øame rea≈øon being for all. And yet be≈øides the≈øe which he found founded before, he him≈øelfe was Founder of others, namely Bangor in Wales, which long continued in that ≈øtate, vntill it was after changed into ≈øo greate a Mona≈øtery, of aboue 2000. Monkes, as our Hi≈øtories te≈øtifie. A Prote≈øtant Bishop would haue an other Vniuer≈øitie, for ≈øo he calleth it, by the name of Accademia Legionen≈øis the Vniuer≈øitie of Caerlegion, which he would haue to be We≈øtche≈øter, others rather take it for Caerlegion in Glamorganshire, to haue bene founded in this time of King Lucius and to haue ended in the time and manner that Stamford did. The Brittish Hi≈øtorie calleth it Gymna≈øium Philo≈øophorum a Schoole of Philo≈øophers, and ≈øeateth it in Caerlegion vpon Vske in Glamorganshire, making it a fourth di≈øtinct place from the Metropolitan Church, and the Seuerall Churches of S. Iulius, wherein were ≈øacred Nonnes, and S. Aaron of Canons Regular.

7. And whereas the Authour of the Brittish Hi≈øtorie, the Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter, and others haue told vs, that the≈øe holy Legats with the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of King Lucius did not onely change the Pagan Temples vnto Chri≈øtian Churches dedicating them to the onely true God, and his Saints, vno Deo eiu≈ødem Sanctis dedicauerunt, but, diuer≈øi≈øque Ordinatorum Caetibus repleuerunt: did replenish them with diuers companyes of par≈øons ordered or liuing in order, that we should not be ignorant, what they ment by this phra≈øe of ≈øpeach, the one of them mo≈øt auncient expoundeth him≈øelfe after, in the like ca≈øe that he ment thereby, how they placed Religeous men and women, Monkes, and Nunnes in diuers of tho≈øe Churches: Eccle≈øias v≈øque ad≈øolum de≈øtructas renouat, atque Religio≈øis Caetibus viroruÃÑ ac mulierum exornat, Speaking this of King Galfr. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 9. c. 8. Arthur, after he builded againe the Churches which the Pagan Saxons had de≈øtroyed. And the very practi≈øe of the≈øe holy Legats and King Lucius doth
proue no le≈ø≈øe, for we finde diuers Religeous hou≈øes of both ≈øexes, who≈øe Gulielm. Malm. Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. de Antiq. Caenobij Gla≈øton. foundation mu≈øt needs be referred to this time. Fir≈øt of the mo≈øt auncient Mona≈øtery of Gla≈øte ‚Ä¢ bury (of which more hereafter) diuers Antiquities beare witne≈ø≈øe that it being decayed, and in a manner forgotten, it was reuiued by the≈øe Legats and king Lucius A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and Religeous men placed there. A Prote≈øtant Bishop produceth an old Manu≈øcript which re≈øtifieth of an other then founded at Winche≈øter: onely his error is (which the Antiquitie doth not ≈øay) that it was the Cathedrall Church, confounding them as one, Godwin Catal. of Bish. in Wince≈øter 1. Galfrid. Mon. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 8. c. 17. l. 10. c. 4. Mat. We≈øt. an. gratiae 498. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. Eccl. Winton. whereas both the Brittish Hi≈øtorie and Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter make them two ≈øeuerall Churches: otherwi≈øe he thus truely writeth, a Church in Winche≈øter according to a Report that I finde in an old Manu≈øcript, was fir≈øt built and erected by King Lucius, who abolishing Pagani≈øine embraced Chri≈øt about the yeare of our Lord 180. and placing Monkes in the ≈øame, allotted for their maintenance lardge Reuene ‚Ä¢ es, which hearetofore had belonged for the most part vnto the Fl ‚Ä¢
mins, and other Heathen Prei≈øts. And this Mona≈øtarie ≈øo continued, vntill the Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian, when it was de≈øtroyed, and the Monks Martyred or di≈øper≈øed, yet vpon the cea≈øing of the Per≈øecution it was pre≈øently within one yeare and thirtie dayes new builded, and the Church hallowed and dedicated vnto the honour and memorie of S. Amphibalus, that had ≈øuffered death for Chri≈øt in the late Per≈øecution by Con≈øtans Bishop of Winche≈øter, in the yeare 309. the 15. day of March at the reque≈øt of Deodatus Abbot. The fir≈øt Dedication of that Church in King Lucius time by the two Legats Faganus and Damianus Bishops, was by that old Antiquitie October 29. 189. The Antiquities of Winche≈øter make it more auÃÑcient, & it thus continued a famous Mona≈øtary vntill the yeare 519. at which time Cerdick the fir≈øt King of the we≈øt Saxons, being a Pagan conuerted the Church into the Temple of Dagon; and either ≈ølewe or cha≈øed away all the Monkes. This was that holy Sanctuary, whether to the Altar of this Church one of the ≈øonnes of Mordred did fly for ≈øuccour again≈øt Con≈øtantine the YouÃÑger, who there cruelly ≈ølewe him before the Altar. Con≈øtantinus filios Mordredi caepit, & alterum Iuuenem Guintoniae in Eccle≈øiam Sancti Amphibali fugientem, ante altare trucidauit, in the yeare 543. Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. lib. 11. cap. 4. We≈øtm. an. 543. Stowe Hi≈øtor. in Con≈øt. Iunior. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. Pit≈ø. in Amphibal. Iuniore. Man. Script. callic. & Angl. antid. Galfr. Mon. l. 8. c. 16. & 24. Hi≈øt. Gallic. Manu≈øcr. ant. Princ. or que nous. cap. 47. An. 477. Galfrid. Mon. Hi≈øt. l. 8. c. 9. Annales Abingdon. apud Harpesfeld. decicimo ≈øaeculo pag. 203. Others ≈øay it continued within 17. yeares of Augu≈øtins comming hither: others continue Chri≈øtians there farre longer time.

8. And the like I may ≈øay of the Mona≈øterie in London, where the other ≈øonne of Mordred was cruelly put to death, by the ≈øame King Con≈øtantine before the Altar. alterum vero Londonijs in quorundam Fratrum Caenobio ab≈øconditum, atque tandem iuxta altare inuentum, crudeli more affecit. Th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe Sanctuaries and priuiledges of the≈øe Churches and ≈øacrifing Altars thus violated were of tho≈øe Immunities before remembred, which King Lucius endowed ≈øuch ≈øacred places with. There was al≈øo an other Mona≈øtery at Anisbury where both Aurelius Ambro≈øius prope Caenobium Ambrij, and by him Vther Pendragon was buryed by the Bishops and Abbots of the Prouince: ≈øo, many Abbies then. Conuenerant Pontifices & Abbates, atque totus Clerus eiu≈ødem Prouinciae, & tanti Regis funus procurauerunt. This Mona≈øtery was builded there long before, and then had 300. Monkes in it, as diuers auncient Hi≈øtorians doe warrant vs. Be≈øides the≈øe, we reade al≈øo in the old Annals of Abington neare Oxford of the greate Antiquitie thereof, that Con≈øtantine the greate was brought vp in, or by that hou≈øe, that it had in tho≈øe primatiue times of Chri≈øtianity heare, about 600. Monkes, belonging vnto it, whereof aboue 500. liued vpon their labour in the woods, and De≈øarts adioyning, and came to the
Mona≈øtery vpon fe≈øtiuall Euens, and dayes, and 60. others which euer continued in the Mona≈øtery in ≈øeruing God. De Antiquitate illius caenobij & celebritate illius ante Anglorum Aduentum, multa refert, & quod Monachi ≈øupra quingentos illi fuerant‚ñ™ a≈ø≈øcripti, qui per ≈øiluas & loca de≈øerta, quae in vicinia fuere, manuum labore victitabant, ad caenobium ≈øingulis Sabbatis & Dominicis conuenientes, praeter ≈øexaginta, qui a≈øsidu√® in ip≈øo caenobio ver≈øanbantur, & quod Con≈øtantinus ille Magnus Abingdoniae educatus fuerat. Wherefore ≈øeeing we finde litle S. A≈øaphus in Manu≈øcr. Vita S. Kentegerni. Capgr. Catal. in eod. Godw. Cat. in S. A≈øaph. 1. founding, but rather de≈øolation of ≈øuch holy Monuments betweene the death of King Lucius, and the YouÃÑge of greate Con≈øtantine, when this Mona≈øtery by the auncient Records thereof was in ≈øuch renowne, I mu≈øt needs a≈ø≈øigne the fir≈øt beginning of it to King Lucius dayes. And when we finde in good Authours ≈øuch greate numbers of Monkes belonging to one onely Mona≈øtary of Elgue in Wales where S. Kentegern liued in S. Dauids time, that they then amonted to allmo≈øt 1000. and this ≈øo euident that our Prote≈øtants them≈øelues confe≈ø≈øe it, we mu≈øt needs giue a very auncient being to that order there, or not farre of. A Prote≈øtant Bishop thus relateth it: Kentegernus Godwin ≈øupr. Bishop of Gla≈øcow in Scotland being dryuen out of his owne Country, found meanes to erect a Mona≈øtery for him≈øelfe and his company betweene the Riuers of Elwyd, and Elwy, where in proce≈ø≈øe of time, hauing builded a Church and ≈øome other edifices fit for his entertaynemeÃÑt: there flocked vnto him ≈øuch multitudes of people, as the nuÃÑ ber of his Monkes amonted vnto no le≈ø≈øe then 960. whereof it is ≈øaid, he appointed 300. that were vnlearned to tilladge, and husbandry abroade, other 300. he emploied in ≈øondry Kindes of labous, within the Mona≈øtery at home, and the re≈øt being diuided into companyes attended the ≈øeruice of God in the Church in ≈øuch ≈øort, as day and night perpetually ≈øeruice was there continued, ≈øome while by ≈øome, and otherwhile by others according to an order by him established and ≈øet downe. An other Io. Bal. l. de Scri. cent. 1. in Kentegerno. Bed. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. l. 2. c. 2. Galfr. l. 11. c. 12. Godw. CoÃÑ uer≈ø. of Brit. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. in Dionotho. Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 11. c. 13. Prote≈øtant Bishop ≈øaith, the number of the≈øe learned Monkes in the Mona≈øtery were 365: in Elguen≈øi Collegio trecentos & ≈øexaginta quinque literatos viros ≈øemper ad id paratos habebat. All both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants agree, that notwith≈øtanding the greate Per≈øecution of the Pagan Saxons, there were in one Mona≈øtery of Bangor aboue 2000. Monkes, when S. Augu≈øtine came hither, and as the Brittish Hi≈øtorie with others reporteth, there were then in tho≈øe parts an innumerable company of Monkes and Eremites. Innumerabiles Monachi & Eremitae. Therefore we may rather wonder to our owne shame, and confu≈øion of the Enemyes of Mona≈øticall life, that among ≈øo many Per≈øecutions and trobles as fell among the Britans, from the Reigne of King Lucius to tho≈øe dayes, the number of Religeous men should in that ≈øpace growe to ≈øo greate a reckoning, then make the lea≈øt doubt that diuers Mona≈øteries were founded heare by that our fir≈øt holy Chri≈øtian King: which an old Hi≈øtoria Gallica antiq. Manu≈øcr. c. 28. French Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory plainely affirmeth, when it witne≈ø≈øeth, that the Mona≈øteries of Britaine were de≈øtroyed in the Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian, as other Churches were.

6. The like I affirme of Nunneryes and Mona≈øteries of Religeous women, a≈øwell as of men: which we may finde in the fir≈øt comming of the Pagan Saxons hither, of which a Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorian from Antiquitie thus writeth: all the Churches in Kent were polluted with blood. The Nunnes with other Stowe Hi≈øt. Brit. and Saxons in Vortiger. Religeous par≈øons, were by force put froÃÑ their hou≈øes, and goods. And this was not peculiar onely in this Country, but generall in all Britaine, ≈øacred Nunnes being in all parts thereof, as for breuitie, for the Archbishop-See of London, the≈øe in in Kent: for Yorke we reade that in the City it ≈øelfe when the Pagan Saxons
had de≈øtroyed the Churches, and Religeous hou≈øes, there both of men and women, King Arthur did repaire them, and placed diuers Conuents both of men and women in the repayred Mona≈øteries. Eccle≈øias v≈øque ad ≈øolum de≈øtructas Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 9. c. 8. renouat: atque Religio≈øis caetibus virorum ac mulierum exornat. And for Caerlegion, the ≈øame and other Authours tell vs, there was aunciently a Nunnery in the very Citie, Templum Deo ≈øacratarum Virginum: And a Queene Lib. 9. c. 13. Mat. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 541. Io. Go≈øcelin. Hi≈øt. Manu≈øcript. Matth. Parker Antiq. Brit. pag. 8. of Britaine there receaued the habit of Religion among the Nun nes. Inter Moniales habitum Religionis ≈øu≈øcepit. As both auncient Catholike Hi≈øtorians and new Prote≈øtant writers doe witne≈ø≈øe, among which be Ihon Go≈øceline in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtorie, and Matthew Parker the fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterburye, both which al≈øo for Prote≈øtants expre≈ø≈øely acknowledge that there were Religeous par≈øons and Mona≈øteries heare in Britainte in all Ages from the very fir≈øt Conuer≈øion. The fir≈øt ≈øaith, presbyterorum, Monachorum, Abbatum, Prae≈øulum, Epi≈øcoporum ≈øedium nomina permulta quouis ≈øaeculo extiterunt, ab eo tempore quo primo ≈øit orta: from the fir≈øt beginning of Chri≈øtianitie in Britaine there were in cuery Age very many names of the Seates of Prei≈øts, Monks, Abbots, Prelates, Bishops. And proueth from Antiquitie, that within the fir≈øt 400. yeares of Chri≈øt, there were 11000. vowed virgins in Britaine at one time: puellae ver√® virgines & Deo con≈øecratae. The Prote≈øtant Arcbishop ≈øaith. Tot tantaque presbyterorum, Monachorum, Epi≈øcoporum, Eccle≈øiarum, Caenobiorum, ≈øediumque vetu≈øta nomina quae quouis ≈øaeculo extiterunt. Very many old names of Prei≈øts, Monks, Bishops, Churches, Mona≈øteries, and Sees haue bene in euery Age. Of ≈øuch Religeous and Regular par≈øons and places, e≈øpecially at Gla≈øtenbury now renewed, or reuiued, I shall more and in particular hereafter entreate.

div.head: THE XXII. CHAPTER

argument.p: HOW AFTER THESE ROMAN LEGATS had fully ≈øetled the affaires, and estate of our Church heare, they went againe to Rome to procure the Pope there to ratifie and confirme what they had done, which he did, and they returned hither againe with that his Confirmation, and many other Preachers then ≈øent hither from Rome.

div.p:
1. WHEN the≈øe holy laboures thus happily proceeded in, & all things required to the foundation, and building the hou≈øe of God, in Britaine, taken ≈øo good effect, Archbishops, and Bishops, with their Sees, con≈øecrated, and a≈ø≈øigned, Churches builded, and endowed, Schooles, and Vniuer≈øities erected, and confirmed, Mona≈øteries and Nunneries founded and finished, and all the≈øe holy proceedings pre≈øcribed, taught, directed and heare ≈øetled by the≈øe Roman Legats, and Legatine
power, and mo≈øt willingly and Religiou≈øly receaued and embraced by our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King and Saint, and holy Chri≈øtian Britans his Subiects, our late Noueli≈øts, Enemyes and Per≈øecutors of this our old Chri≈øtian, Catholike, Apo≈øtolike, Apo≈øtles, Roman, and fir≈øt holy Chri≈øtian Kings Religion, would haue thought and taught, if they had then lyued, that the Popes Authoritie by his Legats, at our Kings ≈øuite and de≈øire had taught, allowed, commanded and confirmed too much, and would haue bene farre from ≈øeeking, ≈øueing for, and reque≈øting any further actuall and expre≈ø≈øe confirmation, or ratification of the Pope him≈øelfe; But tho≈øe our holy Apo≈øtles and ≈øo glorious and renowned King were of a quite contrary minde to ≈øuch men, for our King who had ≈øent ≈øuch huÃÑble petitions to Pope Eleutherius by his Emba≈ø≈øadors & Emba≈ø≈øadges before, to be in≈øtructed in the faith, his kingdome, Country, Nobles, all his people & beloued Subiects to be coÃÑuerted to Chri≈øt, to be directed by him in his ciuill Lawes, had receaued an hallowed Crowne, and warraÃÑt and Limits of his kingdome from him, was as carefull and ≈øollicitous to haue all things now effected, to be approued and confirmed by the ≈øame highe≈øt ≈øpirituall Papall Power, and Authoritie, which as he well knew by the Te≈øtimonies of diuers Popes holy Saints, and Martyrs before, as our Prote≈øtants haue acknowledged, was in≈øtituted and ordained by Chri≈øt him≈øelfe, as a Rule and direction to all other members of his Catholike Church. And therefore when it could otherwi≈øe be no Polecy or plea≈øure to our holy King to ≈øpare from hence ≈øo long a time the Legats he had ≈øo much de≈øired, no ea≈øe to them now old, and weryed in Labors, to trauaile to Rome, and returne hither againe, nor expedient for a new conuerted kingdome to want the Apo≈øtles and conuerters thereof ≈øo ≈øoone, before it was perfectly ≈øetled in the Religion it had receaued by them, but very dangerous to them all, in re≈øpect of the Roman ≈øtate, ≈øo Ieleous and violent an enemy to diuers things, now thus to be confirmed, again≈øt their challendg and claime at that time, for the kingdome either to haue incited or allowed, that Iorney and confirmation, or the Legats to haue vndertaken it, with ≈øo much trouble, hazard, and perill, had it bene either a needle≈ø≈øe, or meere voluntarie, and no nece≈ø≈øarie bu≈øines, was in ≈øo many and worthie par≈øons the greate≈øt madnes could de deui≈øed.

2. And yet our Antiquities a≈ø≈øuer vs, our Eccle≈øia≈øticall ≈øtate and affaires were thus confirmed, and all things accompted as vncertaine, vntill ≈øuch confirmation was procured and obtayned. The old Brittish Hi≈øtorie, Virunnius, Matthew of Westmin≈øter with many others both Manu≈øcripts, and printed Antiquaries Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 4. c. 20. vlt. Pont. Vir. l. 4. in fine. Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 186. Ma≈ønu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. antiq. in Luci. tell vs: Beati Antistites Faganus & Deruuianus Romam reuer≈øi; quae fecerant, impetrauerunt √† Papa beati≈øsimo confirmari: The ble≈ø≈øed Bishops Faganus and Deruuianus returning againe to Rome obtayned to haue the things which they had done to be confirmed, by the mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Pope. Where we ≈øee that the Pope by petition and proofe made vnto him of the orderly, and Religeous proceedings of his Legats in Britaine confirmed what they had done heare. What that was in founding the Church of Chri≈øt in this kingdome, I haue mentioned before; all which was now confirmed by the Pope him≈øelfe. And if a generall confirmation will not confirme and conforme vs in this truth, let vs re≈øorte for the mo≈øt que≈øtionable things to tho≈øe particulars, which cheife Prote≈øtants with others haue deliuered and warranted before out of our generally binding, and receaued auncient Lawes, and Pope Eleutherius owne writings in which we often finde Lucius to be adiudged King of Britaine, and the kingdome
of Britaine to be his kingdome. And yet many Hi≈øtorians, Italians, Epi≈øt. Pape Eleutherij ≈øupr. & leg. S. Edwardi apud Plur. Authores. Baron. Tom. 2. Annal. in Eleut. Hect. Boet. Scot. Hi≈øt. l. 5. f. 83. Godwin CoÃÑ uer≈ø. of Brit. p. 22. Scots, English, Catholiks and Prote≈øtants haue doubted thereof. Baronius would haue him, if any at all, but a pety King. Hector Boethius alloweth him but a King by courte≈øie: Lucius Britonibus Cae≈øaris beneuolentia & authoritate imperitabat. A Prote≈øtant Bishop thus di≈øputeth it: It is made a doubt, and not without good cau≈øe, whether euer there could be any ≈øuch King, as Lucius or no. In this very ≈øea≈øon that is appointed by our writers to the Reigne of Lucius, the Romans po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Britaine quietly, as may appeare by all the Roman writers, to wit, during the times of M. Antoninus and Commodus: and long after this Britaine was wholly ≈øubdued vnto the Romans, and brought vnder the forme of a Prouince, to wit in the time of Domitian, as W. Malmesbury hath deliuered, and amongst later writers two men of greate iudgment, Baronius and Mai≈øter Camden: which is partly confirmed by Tacitus, deliuering that a great part of it was reduced into the forme of a Prouince, as a fore≈øaid, in the time of Claudius. The≈øe things being ≈øo, how should a King haue any Gouernment heare? Thus this Prote≈øtant Bishop and Antiquarie. What force is in his allegations I haue ≈øufficiently ≈øaid for the honour of this kingdome in other places. But in this ca≈øe and que≈øtion, if we allowe him all for truth: both he and we thereby are nece≈ø≈øitated to allowe ≈øo much the greater prerogatiue and power to Pope Eleutherius, the Pope of Rome to haue Authoritie in ca≈øes doubtfull, or where a kingdome or true Heire is by violence oppre≈ø≈øed to declare a true lawfull and vndoubted King, as this Pope in this Act did by our King Lucius and this kingdome, which with all others this Prote≈øtant Bishop him≈øelfe acknowledgeth: per con≈øilium Regni ve≈øtri ≈øume legem: & per illam Dei patienti√¢ ve≈øtrum Reges Britanniae Regnum: Vicarius Dei Epi≈øt. Eleutherij apud Godw. ≈øup. p. 30. 31. Matth. Parker Antiq. Brit. p. 5. Foxe to. 1. Act. Guliel. Lamb. in Legib. S. Edwardi. Stow Hi≈øt. in Eleuth. Leges S. Edwardi cap. 17. apud Gul. Lamb. l. de Legib. Pri≈øcis f. 130. estis in Regno. Gentes Regni Britanniae, & populi ve≈øtri ≈øunt. Where notwith≈øtanding any clayme or Title the Romans at that time did, or could make to Britaine, or any part thereof, King Lucius is by Pope Eleutherius openly pronounced, and declared to be King of Britaine, and all the people and Nations of Britaine to be his people, and ≈øubiects. And for further confirmation and proofe heareof he did expre≈ø≈øely declare, as our publike Lawes ≈øtill witne≈ø≈øe, that all this kingdome or Ile of Britaine was his kingdome, as al≈øo all the Ilands vnto Norway, and Denmarke belonged to the Crowne of this his kingdome. Vniuer≈øa terra & tota, & In≈øulae omnes v≈øque Norwegiam & v≈øque Daciam petinent ad coronam regni eius. And to ≈øecure King Lucius herein, he ≈øent him, as King of the Britans, an hallowed Crowne, to weare as King of all the≈øe remembred Dominions. Tales metas & fines con≈øtituit & impo≈øuit coronae regni Dominus Eleutherius Papa ≈øententia ≈øua, qui destinauit coronam benedictam Britanniae & Chri≈øtianitatem Deo in≈øpirante Lucio Regi Britonum. How this holy Pope did giue direction, and in≈øtruction to this King, about his Lawes I haue ≈øaid before, as al≈øo of the former more at lardge. So likewi≈øe of the ≈øetling three Archbishops in the three named places, with Bishops vnder them, which was long before S. Eleutherius time, decreed by other Popes, and from the Apo≈øtles, and ≈øo needed litle confirmation, being by Apo≈øtolike Order long before in≈øtituted.

3. Yet this being a cheife and principall thing, in ≈øetling our Church affaires, by the holy Legats, it was by the ≈øame euidence as carefully and principally confirmed by this holy Pope, and ≈øo was ob≈øerued throughout this kingdome, vpon this In≈øtitution and Confirmation many hundreds of yeares by all Antiquities. The exception which ≈øome may make by finding Britaine diuided into fiue Prouinces, I haue fully an≈øweared before, and our cheife
Prote≈øtants namely Doctour George Abbots Archbishop of Canterbury, and ≈øuch others as directed and a≈ø≈øi≈øted Mai≈øter Francis Ma≈øon in the Booke intituled, Cro≈ø≈øes and Chri≈øtian Images then certaine tokens of Chri≈øtians. Of the Con≈øecration of the Bishops of the Church of England, & he their Scribe will thus ≈øecondemee therein: The Romans before this time of King Lucius his receauing the faith, had diuided Britaine into three Prouinces, one of theÃÑ was called Maxima Cae≈øarien≈øis, the Metropolis whereof was Yorke. An other Britannia prima, the Metropolis whereof was London: the third Britannia ≈øecunda, the Metropolis whereof was CaerlegioÃÑ. And prouing be≈øides ≈øo many Authorities before cited, by A≈ø≈øerius Meneuen≈øis, Schoolme≈øter to King Alfred, Ptolomaeus LuceÃÑ≈øis, William Reade, & Ihon LelaÃÑd, that the Archbishops of this IlaÃÑd were onely ≈øeated in tho≈øe three MetropolitaÃÑ Cities, LondoÃÑ, Yorke, & Caerlogion, according to that diui≈øioÃÑ of Prouinces heare; & to cleare the obiectioÃÑ thus they had further in this bu≈øines: Although Britaine was after the Nicen Councell diuided into fiue Prouinces, Valentia and Flauia Cae≈øarieÃÑ≈øis being added to the former, yet there were no new Archbishops erected. The rea≈øon whereof was, becau≈øe tho≈øe two new Prouinces were taken out of the former: and con≈øequently could not haue Bishopriks without the diminishing of the Authoritie of the former, in who≈øe Iuri≈ødiction originally they were, which was not ≈øufferable, becau≈øe it was again≈øt the Canon of the Nicen Councell, decreeing that in Antioch, and in other Prouinces, the dignitie, prerogatiues, and Authorities of Churches should be mainetained, Hitherto the≈øe Prote≈øtant writers.

4. And to leaue it without que≈øtion, that this placing both of Archbishops, and Bishops al≈øo, at this time in Britaine, was both warranted and confirmed by this highe≈øt ≈øpirituall Papall Power and Prerogatiue in Pope Eleutherius, among ≈øo many hundreds of Archbishops, and Bishops as haue bene in Britaine, as it conprehendeth England, Wales, and Scotland, no Hi≈øtorie mentioneth, no Antiquarie can proue, that from this time of King Lucius, vntill the Reuolt of King Henry 8. from the Church of Rome, any one Archbishoprik or Bishoprik was eyther founded, tran≈ølated, vnited, diminished, or any wi≈øe changed, but it was eyther fir≈øt done, or afterward confirmed or made fru≈øtrate by this greate Apo≈øtolike and Papall Power of the Roman See. I neede not the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Catholike Antiquities herein, our Prote≈øtant Bishops and Antiquaries which haue written of this ≈øubiect, of Bishops and their Sees, Gul. Malme≈øb. l. de Ant. Caenob. Gla≈øton. doe leaue and cleare it for an euident truth. And becau≈øe ≈øuch an including propo≈øition without confe≈ø≈øion in particular would co≈øt my Readers ≈øome labour to examine it, let them take for pregnant witne≈ø≈øes hereof the two greate Flatterers of King Henry 8, Matthew Parker the fir≈øt Prote≈øtant Archbishop of Canterbury, a man of all Religions with that King, his ≈øonne King Edward The Popes Legats con inue diuers at Gla≈øtenbury, & renew and ≈øetle re ‚Ä¢ igious meÃÑ there, in place of the first of S. Io≈øeph his company. and Queene Elizabeth, and Polidor Virgill a time Plea≈øer, and Seruant thereof. The fir≈øt, ≈øpeaking of King Henry 8. his Lawes again≈øt the Popes Authoritie, and the time of the Saxons, ≈øaith, that by them then made, the Popes Power which had euer vntill then continued in England, and was thought vn≈øuperable was ouerthrowne: his legibus potentia Papalis quae nongentis amplius annis in Anglia durauit, & in≈øuperabilis vi≈øa e≈øt, concidit. The other writeth, then a liuing witnes, that the ≈øupreamacie, taken from the Pope and giuen to the King, was a thing neuer heard of in any time before. Habetur Concilium Londini, in quo Eccle≈øia Anglicana formam potestatis nullis ante temporibus vi≈øum induit: Henricus enim Rex Caput ip≈øius Eccle≈øiae con≈øtituitur. By which al≈øo, as in a gla≈ø≈øe, by a truely repre≈øenting ≈øpecies, we may behold, that it neyther was, nor could be any other then the Pope of Rome, onely clayming and exerci≈øing ≈øuch ≈øpirituall Power heare in tho≈øe times, which did or could giue a
full and finall confirmation to tho≈øe Vniuer≈øities, or Schooles, and Religeous hou≈øes of Britaine, with the Rule and Order they followed and profe≈ø≈øed in the≈øe daies.

5. Yet we are not alltogether de≈øtitute of In≈øtances in particular of ≈øuch Honorius Papa 1. in Bulla Vniuer≈øitati Canta-Cantabr. coÃÑce≈ø≈ø. ann. 624. 20. die Februarij apud Io. Caium l. 1. de antiq. Cantabr. Academ. p. 75. 76 77. confirmation. For Schooles or Vniuer≈øities, the Antiquaries of Cambridge produce the auncient Bull of Pope Honorius the fir≈øt, 1000. yeares ≈øince coÃÑfirming that Vniuer≈øitie, and priuiledges thereof, and in the ≈øame affirming, that his Predece≈ø≈øours, Pope Eleutherius, in who≈øe time we are, Fabianus, Leo, Simplicius, Foelix, and Bonifacius gaue the like confirmation and exemption vnto it: Praedece≈ø≈øorum no≈øtrorum Romanae Eccle≈øiae Pontificum Eleutherij, Fabiani, Leonis, Simplicij, Faelicis, & Bonifacij ve≈øtigijs debit√® inhaerentes, authoritate omnipotentis Dei di≈øtricti√πs inhibemus ≈øub paena excommunicationis, ne quis Archiepi≈øcopus aut eorum officiales &c. Where it is ≈øaid, that the≈øe Popes gaue the≈øe priuiledges again≈øt all parsoÃÑs, by the Authoritie of God. For the Schoole of GlamorgaÃÑ we haue the like te≈øtimonie, that the Pope gaue the cheife charge thereof to S. Iltutus renowned both for his learning and piety, as al≈øo his mo≈øt worthie Schollers and their greate number, in which were both Gaules and Britans, in whome S. Samp≈øon, S. Paulinus, S. Dauid, S. Gildas. Magi≈øtralis Charta MerchiaÃÑ ni Regis. l. Sanct. Wall. Caius ≈øup. p. 147. Capgr. Catal. in S. Il ‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢ o Abbate & Confe≈ø≈øore. Io. Bal. l. de Script. Britan. cent. 1. in Elchuto Morgan. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. Mona ≈øterij S. Aug. Cantuariae. tibi cura conce≈ø≈øa est √† Ponti≈øice, as King Merchiannus te≈øtifieth in his Charter of priuiledge vnto him, and that his Schoole or Vniuer≈øitie. For our Mona≈øteries and Religeous hou≈øes then, that they were confirmed and priuiledged by this holy Pope, I shall more fully shew, when I come to the≈øe Legats returne, and vi≈øiting Gla≈øtenbury, bringing with them a confirmation, Immunities, and Indulgences from S. Eleutherius, to that mo≈øt auncient and Religious Mona≈øtery, with an approbation of the holy Rule, and Order which there and in all Britaine after many hundreds of yeares was kept and followed. In the meane time he that will but behold (if he may) the old Manu≈øcript of S. Augu≈øtins in Canterbury, shall there ≈øee aboue 100. particular Bulls of Popes confirming the liberties and Immunities of that hou≈øe. He may reade in the fir≈øt Prote≈øtantically made Archbishop there, that as I haue proued, and shall proue of our Britans, how all their Archbishops had their ordination Power and Authoritie from the Popes of Rome, ≈øo amoÃÑg the Saxons Matth. Parker. Antiq. Brit. vntill he fir≈øt brake that Rule & right, all their Archbishops then, were there inue≈øted and ≈øetled by the Popes Authoritie, and ≈øwore obedience vnto him, this Prote≈øtant new Archbishop ≈øetting downe their Oath, at lardge.

div.head: THE XXIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE ARCHBISHOPS OF LONDON, Yorke and Caerlegion in this time in particular: and many other inferiour Bishops, and the Roman Church Di≈øcipline heare al≈øo ≈øetled by Papall Authoritie.

div.p: 1. THvs was the ≈øtate of Chri≈øtian Catholike affaires in Britaine in all matters, Callings & Degrees ratified and confirmed by this holy Pope, euen as our Prote≈øtants them≈øelues doe glo≈ø≈øe our Hi≈øtories, fides Chri≈øti in Britannia confirmatur, and this bu≈øines Prot. Annotati: in Matth. We≈øt. an. 186. performed with ≈øuch diligence, and expedition, that the Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter, accompted one of our mo≈øt exact Calculators of times, doth recompt the Iorney of the holy Legats from Britaine to Rome, their obtayning the Confirmation, receauing further direction, procuring many other holy workemen to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them, in founding and framing the Church of Chri≈øt in this kingdome, the whole time of their ≈øtay at Rome, Matth. We≈øtm. An. gratiae. 186. returning hither againe, with a greate number of diuine labourers, and effecting diuers things heare after their returne, all to haue bene happily performed within the ≈øpace of one yeare, ≈øuch was the fatherly care and ≈øollicitude of that holy Pope and his ≈øacred Legats our ≈øpirituall Parents towards their children the conuerted Britans, as S. Paules was in like ca≈øe, whome in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus they had begotten: Anno gratiae 186. Beati Anti≈øtites Faganus & Diruuianus Romam reuer≈øi; quae fecerant, impetrauerunt √† Papa beati≈øsimo confirmari. Quibus peractis redierunt in Britanniam praefati Doctores, cum alijs quamplurimis, quorum doctrina gens Britonum, in fide Chri≈øti, in breui fundata reful≈øit. Istorum autem nomina & actus in libro reperiuntur, quem Gildas Hi≈øtoricus de victoria Aurelij Ambro≈øij con≈øcrip≈øit. In the yeare of grace 186. the ble≈ø≈øed Bishops Faganus, and Deruuianus returning to Rome did obtaine of the mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Pope to haue all things which they had done, confirmed. Which things being finished the fore≈øaid Doctours with very many others came againe into Britaine, by who≈øe doctrine the Nation of the Britans being founded in a short ≈øpace, became renowned. The names and Acts of the≈øe men are founde in the Booke, which Gildas the Hi≈øtorian did write of the vistory of Aurelius Ambro≈øius. All this is ≈øet downe as acted in that one yeare by Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter.

2. The like Relation is made hereof in the Brittish Hi≈øtory, Ponticus Virunnius, diuers Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtories, and others, all agreeing in the≈øe things Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. ‚Ä¢ 4. cap. 20. Ponticas Virun. Hi≈øt. l. 4. done together, allthough they doe not ≈øo punctually proceede by the yeares, as the other doth.
