The greate≈øt difference is this, that whereas the Hi≈øtorian of We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øayth, the faith of the Britans was thus made renowned, reful≈øit: the others ≈øay, corroborata fuit: it was corroborated or confirmed by receauing this Confirmation from the Pope, by his Legats & ≈øo many their a≈ø≈øi≈øtants giuing te≈øtimony thereof. Which breedeth no variance in the matter, but more plainely declareth the meanes by which the kingdome of Britaine was thus renowned for Chri≈øtian Religion, being the fir≈øt kingdome in the
world that had then publikly profe≈ø≈øed the faith of Chri≈øt, publikly by petitions ≈øought it, and as publikly required and obtayned Confirmation of the ≈øame, and their proceedings therein from the high Vicar of Chri≈øt, yet not freed from Per≈øecution. What a comfort this was to our King, and Britaine, to receaue ≈øuch a Confirmation from the See of Rome, by ≈øo Noble and renowned meanes, ≈øuch holy learned and Noble Legats, with ≈øuch ≈øolemnitie, quampluribus alijs comitati; at ≈øuch a time when the ≈øword of Per≈øecution was ≈øtill vnsheathed, and dropping with holy blood of Mattyrs, the very circum≈øtances Io. Bal. l. de Scri. cent. 1. in Gilda Albani. Magdeb. cent. 2. c. 2. Col. 8. Fox. Act. and Mon. l. 2. p. 106. Iames lib. de Manu≈øcr. in Bibliot. public. & Colleg. S. Benedict. Abbot FecknaÃÑ orat. in Parlam. 2. Elizabeth. them≈øelues and refulgent glory, refulcit, it wonne to this Nation, in all the world, will giue vs ≈øome light thereof. But much more would the ≈øplendor of it appeare, if the Monuments wherein the names and Acts of ≈øo many worthie men, penned by ≈øuch a Secretary as S. Gildas was, might come to vewe. Many Prote≈øtaÃÑts would make the world beleeue, they haue both ≈øeene and haue that mo≈øt auncient and de≈øired Monument in their cu≈øtodies. If it be not ≈øo, they are to blame to write it: if ≈øo, both blame and shame to conceale it. I can now ≈øay no more, then Abbot Feckman did publikly deliuer in ≈øolemne Oration in the fir≈øt Parlament of Q. Elizabeth, when Catholike Religion was condemned, in the≈øe termes of that matter: Pope Eleutherius ≈øent into this Realme Damianus and Fugatius, and they as Amba≈ø≈øadours ≈øent from the See Apo≈øtolike of Rome, did bring into this Realme ≈øo many yeares pa≈øt, the very ≈øame Religion whereof we are now in po≈ø≈øe≈øsion, and that in the Latin tongue, as the auncient Hi≈øtoriographer diuus Gildas witne≈ø≈øeth in the Prologue and beginning of his Booke of the Britaine Hi≈øtories. The≈øe be his words, which a man of his worth should not, and would not haue vttered in ≈øuch a time and place, if the Booke and ≈øuch things therein had not beene then extant to haue iu≈øtified his ≈øo ab≈øolute, confident and ≈øo coÃÑcerning ≈øpeach in that A≈ø≈øembly, which by their proceedings ouerthrew Catholike Religion in that Parlament, and was not vnwilling to contradict any thing they could which cro≈ø≈øed with their Intention.

3. I haue made as diligent enquiry as I could, and the≈øe times would permit mee, to be enformed whether any ≈øuch worke of Gildas is to be ≈øeene, and cannot finde that any true or pretended Hi≈øtorie of his, or any other doth now mention the Names and Acts of any ≈øuch men. Therefore I mu≈øt re≈øt contented, and otherwi≈øe take, and giue the be≈øt light I can in the≈øe matters. Fir≈øt we are a≈ø≈øured before, that at this time of the≈øe Legats Returne, or thereabouts‚ñ™ King Lucius was confirmed, and declared King of all Britaine, and the Ilands adiacent, and an hallowed Crowne was brought vnto him from Pope Eleutherius, mo≈øt probably by them, the mo≈øt honorable par≈øons mentioned as Amba≈ø≈øadors betweene tho≈øe two renowned Potentats, Pope and King, in the affaires which pa≈ø≈øed betweene them, and by this meanes our holy King Lucius was in con≈øcience abled, and ≈øecured to giue, or confirme any guift, graunt, or donation‚ñ™ he formely had be≈øtowed, or afterward was to conferre, or confirme for the good of Chri≈øts Church in Britaine, or effect and doe what≈øoeuer, belonging to ≈øtate and office of a Chri≈øtian King. They brought with them al≈øo a Confirmation, of the three Metropolitan or Archiepi≈øcopall Sees before remembred, as al≈øo ≈øuch Papall Approbation of the con≈øecrated Our fir≈øt Archbishop or Archbishops of London with their See. Archbishops, as had bene before their going againe to Rome, or now were here to be ≈øetled, and confirmed in tho≈øe Sees, with all ≈øuch Rites, and Ceremonyes, as belonged to that highe≈øt calling in the Church of Britaine. By vertue and power whereof they placed and confirmed in the See of
London S. Thean, one Prote≈øtant writer calleth him Thomas, he builded the Iocelinus l. de Epi≈øc. Brit. Go≈øcelin. Hi≈øt. Eccl. c. de Epi≈øcopis Londin. Harris M. S. Hi≈øt. to. 2. Will. Harri≈ø. de≈øcrip. of Britaine Stowe Hi≈øtor. in King Lucius. Hollinsh. hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 19. Godwin Catal. of Bish. London. 1. Godwin Catal. ≈øupr. in Yorke 1. Catal. Epi≈øcop. Hiero≈øol. Nicephor. Continuator Flor. Wigor. Eu≈øebius Hi≈øt. Eccl. Harris Hi≈øt. l. 2. Will. HarrisoÃÑ de≈øcript. of Brit. c. 9. Church dedicated to S. Peter in Cornehill in London, by the ayde of Cyran cheife Butler to King Lucius, this ≈øome what draweth mee to their opinion before remembred, which rather make his Cathedrall See at We≈øtmin≈øter, at the lea≈øt vntill the other was builded: and I haue ≈øufficiently in≈øinuated before from Antiquities, that all the Metropolitane Churches were either changed from Archflamens Temples, or newly builded, at the chardges of our King, and no ≈øubiect named. Concerning Yorke a Prote≈øtant Bishop writeth: The fir≈øt Archbishop that euer Yorke had, our Hi≈øtories ≈øay, was one named Samp≈øon, appointed by the fore≈øaide King Lucius. The veritie whereof I cannot but ≈øu≈øpect in regard of the name. For I finde not that the names of the old Hebrewes, or Chri≈øtian Saints were yet in v≈øe. Which rea≈øon of his, is not true, for euen in Hieru≈øalem it≈øelfe, where S. Iames was made fir≈øt Bishop, he had his next Succe≈ø≈øors Simeon, Iu≈øtus, Zachaeus, Tobias, Beniamin, Ioannes, Matthias. And in Britaine it≈øelfe I haue proued before, that we had S. Ari≈øtobulus, and S. Timotheus, and as ≈øome write, one Aaron, in this time which came with the holy Legats hither, and ≈øoone after S. Aaron our holy Martyr vnder Diocle≈øian. S. Stephen was shortly after Archbishop of London, and by ≈øome the fir≈øt of all was named Thomas. And as vntrue it is, that either our Hi≈øtoryes doe ≈øay, there were onely foure Archbishops of Yorke, in the Britans time, Samp≈øon, Taurinus Bishop of Eureux, Pyrannus and Tadiacus, or that Samp≈øon was the fir≈øt Archbishop there; for the fir≈øt of the number, many reckoÃÑ dyuers others, and more, and this Samp≈øon could not po≈ø≈øible be the fir≈øt, by his owne accompt, The fir≈øt Archbishops and Bishops of Yorke. placing Taurinus there in the time of Con≈øtantius Chlorus, 200. yeares before S. Samp≈øon was Bishop there. And by the accompt of the Brittish Hi≈øtory and others S. Samp≈øon which fledd hence into litle Britaine, was the ≈øeuenth Archbishop of Yorke: Pa≈øtor Eboracen≈øis ≈øeptimus in Armorico regno frequentabitur. So readeth Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter and diuers others. Matth. We≈øtm. An. 490. Sigeb. Gemblacen. Chronico. 445. Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. l. 7. c. 3. Mat. We≈øtm. an. 464. Radulph. Niger. apud Harris Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. l. 2. c. 20. Will. Harrid ‚Ä¢ ≈øcr. of Britaine cap. 9. Wherefore I mu≈øt rather harken to Radulphus Niger, as M. Harris in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory writeth, to him≈øelfe, ad William Harri≈øon a Prote≈øtant Antiquary, and others, who tell vs that S. Theodo≈øius was made the fir≈øt Archbishop of Yorke in this time of King Lucius: So they coÃÑfidently affirme. And if this Prote≈øtant Bishop could proue that S. Taurinus Bishop of Eureux, was Archbishop of Yorke in Can≈øtantius Chlorus time, we shall finde 10. Archbishops there from this time, 7. to S. Samp≈øon, whome he nameth the fir≈øt but was long after, and be≈øide S. Taurinus, Pyrannus and Thadeoceus, but S. Taurinus of Eureux was not lyuing aboue an hundred yeares before Con≈øtantius Chlorus time.

4. Mai≈øter Harrys ≈øaith Eadnochus a Martyr was the third Archbishop there, and S. Teruanus, the fourth. The ≈øecond, fift and ≈øixt he nameth not. Trith. l. de Scri. in Sedul. Manu≈ø. Hi≈øt. Vit. S. Niniani. Capgr. in eod. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. in Niniano. Hector Boet. Hi≈øt. Scotor. l. 7. f. 119. & 133. Trithemius calleth Hildebertus, Mai≈øter to Sedulius, an Archbishop: ≈øo doe others. Among the≈øe we may number. Ninian, ≈øent by the Pope into tho≈øe parts, and exerci≈øing Archiepi≈øcopall Power both among the Britans, Scots, and Picts, which none but the Archbishop of Yorke could doe, and the Country of Pictland neuer was an Archiepi≈øcopall Prouince. So I ≈øay of S. Teruanus whome as our Scottish Hi≈øtorians write, S. Palladius the Popes Legate made Archbishop, neither Pictland, nor Scotland many hundred yeares after hauing any Archbishop, but the Archbishop of Yorke. And likely it is, this is the ≈øame S. Teruanus whome Mai≈øter Harris onely numbreth among the Archbishops of Yorke, not yeelding his rea≈øon or any Authour. If there
was any Taurinus or Samp≈øon be≈øides him, that was the ≈øeuenth and went into Armoca, they may be added to this number, but I dare nor take vpon mee to ≈øet them in order as they ≈øucceeded. How the Pope ≈øubiected all the Country now called Scotland to the Iuri≈ødiction of this See, I haue ≈øaid before, and now he confirmed the ≈øame, making that Metropolitan the ≈øpirituall Superior of that Country, in which then there were many Chri≈øtians, and by the te≈øtimony of Tertullian and others before this time, that the Chri≈øtian Religion was preached and planted there, from Rome, whether the temporall power of the Romans could not come, did truely confirme that Tertullian. Apol. S. Le ‚Ä¢ . Serm. 1. de Natali Apo≈øt. Petri & Pauli. ≈øaying of S. Leo ≈øpeaking to Rome: per ≈øacram beati Petri ≈øedem caput orbis effecta, lati√πs prae≈øideres Religione diuina, quam Dominatione terrena: Thow being made the head of the worlde by the See of S. Peter, rule≈øt further by Diuine Religion, then terreane DominioÃÑ. The≈øe ≈øtreights we haue pa≈ø≈øed, in ≈øeeking to finde Archbishops of Caerlegion. the fir≈øt Archbishops of London, and Yorke in King Lucius time, and now comming to Caerlegion, we fall vpon greater difficulties in this trauaile. A Prote≈øtant Bishop and Antiquarie would make this way vnpa≈ø≈øable when he ≈øaith: we mu≈øt accompt S. Dubritius the fir≈øt Bishop. Not that I deny any other to haue ≈øate Godwin Catal. of Bish. in Landaffe 1. and S. Dauids 1. there before him, but becau≈øe he is the fir≈øt who≈øe name is remembred. And it is probable he had no Predece≈ø≈øors, becau≈øe the memory of his Succe≈ø≈øors is ≈øo carefully pre≈øerued. But as this mans Authoritie is ≈øo weeke to be re≈øted vpon, that it hath often before deceaued them which builded vpon it, ≈øo his rea≈øon heare alledged is of as feeble ≈øtreÃÑgth. For the memory of the Succe≈ø≈øors haue bene ≈øo carele≈ø≈øely pre≈øerued by his owne confe≈ø≈øion after, that he hauing cited two different Catalogues of their names onely, aboue twenty in number concludeth in the≈øe termes again≈øt him≈øelfe before: of the≈øe forenamed Bishops vntill Harpesfeild hi≈øt. in fine 7. ≈øaeculi. Io. Bal. l. de Scri. Brit. cent. 1. in Samuele Beulano. Io. Lelan. apud Pit≈ø. l. de Vir. Illu≈øtr. in Elbodo. Harris Hi≈øt. Ecc. Manu≈øcr. lib. 2. c. 20. Samp≈øon, there remayneth litle or no memoriall, but their names onely. And in the names them≈øelues there is difference in tho≈øe Memorials of them. And both of them omitt their mo≈øt renowned Archbishop Elbodus, who ioyned with S. Augu≈øtine, and his company, and wrote again≈øt his owne Britans, and Scots for their vntrue ob≈øeruatioÃÑ of Ea≈øter. Some thinke he was created Archbishop by Augu≈øtine, M. Harris inclineth to be of opinion, that S. Fugatianus one of Pope Eleutherius his Legats was the fir≈øt Archbishop of Caerlegion, and S. Damianus the other Archbishop of London, yet with the common opinion he had placed S. Thean there before both, which may ≈øtand with truth in due con≈øtruction, if S. Damianus re≈øigned it to S. Thean, who as he ≈øaith, was Archbishop there 18. yeares. And ≈øeeing we finde no finall departure of the≈øe two holy Legats from hence, but rather a continuall aboade heare after their returne from Rome, as though they were wholly de≈øigned for the ≈øpirituall good of this kingdome, if we ioyne hearewith what eminent men and Bishops they were, we may not deny them any cheife place of honour heare, according to their worth and de≈øeruings heare.

5. The old writer of Sainct Gudwalus life, Surius, Haraeus, and others ≈øay Anonym. in Vita S. Gudwali. Surius & Haraeus in eod. 6. Iunij. he was Archiepi≈øcopus Britannus an Archbishop of Britaine, & by his life, and aboade, of no other place but our old Caerlegion. And if we should followe theire opinions which hold, that Caerlegion was Augusta, where our renowned Archbishop S. Augulus (of whome I haue ≈øpoken before) was Martyred, we mu≈øt al≈øo make him Archbishop there. And the old Brittish Hi≈øtorie with diuers others te≈øtifieth, that Tremonus was Arcbishop there, Tremonus vrbis Legionum Archiepi≈øcopus, long before S. Dubricius. And it was foretold Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Briton. l. 8. c. 10. before S. Dubricius probably was borne, or Tremonus was Archbishop of
Caerlegion, that this Archbishops See should be tran≈ølated from thence to S. Dauids, and there the Archbishops Pall of Caerlegion should be worne. Meneuia Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 464. Galfr. Monum. l. 7. c. 9. pallio vrbis Legionum induetur. Which was after verified in the time of S. Dauid, as al≈øo the Prophe≈øy of the Tran≈ølation of London to Canterbury by S. Augu≈øtine, and the ≈øeuenth Archbishop of Yorke going into Armorica performed in S. Samp≈øon, all foretold at one time together long before. Therefore as in London, and Yorke, there were Archbishops, ≈øo in this Citie Caerlegion, Girald. Cambr. Catal. Archiep. Men. Antiquit. MeneueÃÑ. in ‚Ä¢ atal. Godwin Catal. in S. Dauids and Landaff. Capgr. in S. Dubrit. & S. Dauid. al≈øo there were ≈øuch and wearing the Pall Archiepi≈øcopall, iu≈øtifiing the vndeniable changed and performance of that prediction. After this time all Hi≈øtoryes agree of S. Dubritius, S. Dauid, Eliud, Theeliaus Kinocus immediately ≈øucceeding each other, and Elbodus in S. Augu≈øtins time. Of the≈øe three new Archiepi≈øcopall Churches, a late Prote≈øtant Antiquarie vpon diligent ≈øearch, as he would haue his Readers enforme them≈øelues, thus writeth more ab≈øolutely then others: in which three Cities of London, Yorke, and Caerlegion, vpon vske, there had bene beforetime three Archflamins erected vnto Apollo, Mars, and Minerua, but now raced to the ground, and three other Churches builded in their ≈øteeds by Lucius, to the intent that the Countryes round about might haue indifferent acce≈ø≈øe vnto tho≈øe places, and therewithall vnder≈øtand for certaintie, whether to re≈øorte for re≈øolution.

6. Neither are we vtterly left de≈øtitute of the names of the holy Bishops then placed, in the inferior Sees; for we haue ≈øufficient Te≈øtimony, of Thomas Many Bishops of other Sees not Archiepi≈øcopall. Rudburne, a Monke of Winche≈øter, Moratus an old Brittish writer and others, that Denotus was then made Bishop of Winche≈øter. And all the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of Tho. Rudburne Chron. Maiore. Morat. l. 1. c. 9. Nichol. Harpe≈øfeld. hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. p. 6. cap. 3. the Pagan FlameÃÑ there, were coÃÑferred vpon him, & his Cleargie, which were ≈øo ample, that euen about that Citie, all the Lands within 12. miles of it, on all ≈øides were belonging vnto it, containing in number 32. Villadges. Be≈øides him we had diuers others, as S. Damianus, one of the holy Legats, S. Eluanus our CountrymaÃÑ of Britaine ≈øent Bishop hither by Pope Eleutherius, Medwinus a Brittan, S. Aaron ≈øent al≈øo with the Legats, and Eu≈øebius ≈øent hither to S. Timothy, all now probably Bishops, be≈øides diuers of the old Archflamens, Flamens, and other learned Druyds long ≈øince conuerted, for vertue and Radulph. Niger. Harri≈øon de≈øcr. of Brit. c. 9. Harris Hi≈øt. l. 2. c. 20. learning and number ≈øufficient to ≈øupply tho≈øe Epi≈øcopall Sees, and dignities. Be≈øides among the ≈øo many, quamplurimis, which came hither with S. Damianus and Fugatianus the ≈øecond time, no man can que≈øtion, but diuers of them were not onely renowned, and men in all re≈øpects worthie of Epi≈øcopall order, and dignitie, but de facto were there ≈øo promoted, and ≈øupplied ≈øome of tho≈øe vacancyes. The re≈øt for the mo≈øt part for want of the Brittish languadge to preach to the people heare, not ≈øo fit to be Pa≈øtors in Churches, were placed in Mona≈øteryes, and inferior Orders, Deacons, Subdeacons, Acoluthi≈øts, Exorzi≈øts and the re≈øt, then generally v≈øed in the Church of Chri≈øt, e≈øpecially at Rome by who≈øe exemple the frame of our Brittish Church was framed by the Popes direction, his Legats execution, and his owne after Papall Confirmation.

7. And ≈øo Britaine neither had then, nor could haue any other Religion, Britaine receau ‚Ä¢ th Church di≈øcipline from Rome at this time. or Church Di≈øcipline, Lawes, and order, but as the Church of Rome then practized. Which ≈øome of our Prote≈øtants haue remembred, and confirme it, both with King Lucius reque≈øt and ≈øuite, and Pope Eleutherius graunt, and allowance. One of them expre≈ø≈øeth it in the≈øe Termes: The faith of Chri≈øt being Will. Harri≈øon de≈øcription of Brit. c. 9. thus plaÃÑted in this Iland in the 177. after Chri≈øt, and Faganus & Dinaw with the re≈øt ≈øent ouer from Rome 178. it came to pa≈ø≈øe in the third yeare of the Ghospell receaued,
that Lucius did ≈øend againe to Eleutherius, requiring that he might haue ≈øome breife Epitome of the order of Di≈øcipline then v≈øed in the Church. For he well con≈øidered that as it auayleth litle to plant a co≈øtly vyneiard, except it afterward be cherished, kept in good order, and ≈øuch things as a ‚Ä¢ noye, dayly remoued from the ≈øame: ≈øo after Bapti≈øme, and entrance into Religion, it profiteth litle to beare the name of Chri≈øtians, except we doe walke in the spirit, and haue ≈øuch thinges as offend apparently, corrected by ≈øenere Di≈øcipline. For otherwi≈øe it will come to pa≈ø≈øe, that the weedes of vice, and vicious lyuing, will ≈øo quickly abound in vs, that they will in the end choke vp the good ≈øeed ≈øowne in our minds, and either enforce vs to returne vnto our former wickednes, with deeper ≈øecuritie then before, or els to become meere Athei≈øts, which is a greate deale wor≈øe; for this cau≈øe therefore did Lucius ≈øend to Rome the ≈øecond time, for a Copie of ≈øuch politick orders as were then v≈øed there, in their Regiment of the Church. Thus farre this Prote≈øtant Antiquarie; And then he bringeth the holy Pope S. Eleutherius, ≈øo to vnder≈øtand King Lucius petition to be both for the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Lawes of the Church of Rome, to Rule heare in ≈øpirituall affaires, and the Lawes of the Emperous for temporall gouernment, and ≈øaith, he findeth it ≈øo in ≈øondry verie auncient Copies, of Pope Eleutherius An≈øweare to King Lucius, thus beginning by his Tran≈ølation: you require of vs the Roman ordinances, and thereto the Statuts of the Emperours to be ≈øent ouer vnto you, and which you de≈øire to practi≈øe, & put in vre within your Realme and kingdome. Then ≈øeeing the Decrees of the Popes of Rome for Church Di≈øcipline, were generally generall for the whole Church, as many of them cited before by Prote≈øtants allowance, doe te≈øtifie, and this our Britaine was vtterly ignorant in ≈øuch things, but as it had receaued them from Rome; Our Apo≈øtles, Preachers, and Conuerters came from thence, and diuers of them ≈øtill remained heare in cheife ≈øpirituall cammande, and many other Chri≈øtian Romans were mixed with our Britans heare, and our Brittans ab≈øolutely and wholly directed by the Pope of Rome, and his Legats in ≈øuch bu≈øines, this con≈øidered, no man of Iudgment will apprehend how any other but the Roman Papall Church Di≈øcipline was then receaued or admitted it this kingdome.

div.head: THE XXIV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE COMMING OF THESE HOLY LEgats to Glastenbury, their holy labours, deeds and long aboade there, their renewing there the old Religeous Order of S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, and his brethren, greate priuiledges and Indulgences by them procured to that holy place, the glory, honour and renowne thereof, in the whole Chri≈øtian world.

div.p: 1. I Haue made mention before, of diuers Mona≈øteries, and Religeous hou≈øes in Britaine in this time; now to take ≈øome notice, in what honour and Reuerence ≈øuch holy places, the par≈øons re≈øident in them, and the Mona≈øticall Religeous life which they there liued and profe≈ø≈øed, were, we cannot better come eyther to the certaine knowledge, or not to be denied opinion thereof, then to take direction herein from the≈øe our Apo≈øtles, Founders, and Fathers in Chri≈øt, by that litle memory which is left in our Hi≈øtories, of the Religeous paines, and labour they tooke in finding, and founding them: the greate zeale, and deuotion they exerci≈øed there, the Immunities, Indulgences, and priuiledges they procured vnto them from holy Popes, and Princes: what ≈øpirituall comfort and plea≈øure they had in them≈øelues, and what example of pietie they left to po≈øteritie by their heauenly Conuer≈øation in them, and what Pa≈øtorall care and Prouidence they had to make this perpetuall, had not the Impietie of late times and par≈øons like wolues, as it was aunciently prophe≈øied, de≈øtroyed that, which the pietie of our fir≈øt Aunce≈øtours in Religion had ≈øo long and firmely founded.

q.l: Has aedes ≈øacras pietas con≈øtruxit Auorum, Antiq. Mona≈øt. Croy ‚Ä¢ andiae.
Quas Succe≈ø≈øores va≈øtabunt more luporum.

div.p: I will principally, and cheifly for all, exemplifie in the holy hou≈øe of Gla≈øtenbury, the fir≈øt Mother of that contemplatiue holy profe≈ø≈øion, both in this and other Nations, from which we may drawe a proportion to others, the ≈øacred children thereof. How diligently the≈øe holy Legats ≈øought to finde out this Religeous place, I haue ≈øome what in≈øinuated before, for they had heard of the greate Renowne and Sanctitie of S. Io≈øeph and his companions fir≈øt in habiting there, and the Venerable Sanctitie of the place, e≈øpecially the miraculou≈øly ≈øacred Church, there builded by heauenly admonition in honour of the mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary, Mother of God, for the memory of it was allmo≈øt quite forgotten, the fir≈øt Religeous men inhabitants there being all dead before this time, and the holy Church ≈øo de≈øolate, that it began to be a Denn of wild bea≈øts to lodge in, which was before an habitation of Saints. Sancti memorati in eadem Eremo ≈øic degentes affluentibus multis annorum curriculis carnis Antiq. Gla≈øt. tabulis fixae. Gul. Malme≈ø. l. de Antiq. Caenob. cla≈øt. Io. Capgrau. in S. Io≈øeph & S. Patricio. erg astulo ≈øunt educti, idemque locus caepit e≈ø≈øe ferarum latibulum, qui pri√πs fuerat habitatio Sanctorum. This is the te≈øtimonie and relation of the old Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury, William of Malmesbury in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtorie, of the Antiquitie of that Mona≈øtery, Capgraue and others.

2. But it was the will of God, and the will of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin to haue her ≈øacred Oratory come to the knowledge of their faithfull Seruants: donec placuit beatae Virgini ≈øuum Oratorium redire ad memoriam fidelium. Which was in this manner, the≈øe holy Legats trauailing throughout Britaine, teaching, preaching, and baptizing, and receauing from the Brittish people Information, where abouts this ≈øacred Habitacle was, as Mo≈øes they entered into this De≈øart to finde it, and at the la≈øt finding the old Church builded by the hands of Christs Di≈øciples, and a Cro≈ø≈øe the ≈øigne of our Redemption, and other Chri≈øtian figures or Images, they were a≈ø≈øured thereby, that this was the place where tho≈øe Di≈øciples of Chri≈øt inhabited: Praedicando & baptizando, Britanniae partes peragrantes in In≈øulam. Aualloniae, more Moy≈øis Legi≈ølatoris interiora De≈øerti penetrantes, ≈øunt ingre≈øsi: Vbi antiquam Deo duce Britanniae repererunt Eccle≈øiam, manibus Di≈øcipulorum Chri≈øt con≈øtructam, & humanae ≈øaluti √† Deo paratam. Figuram no≈øtrae redemptionis, alia≈øque figuras manife≈øtas repererunt, quibus cognouerunt, quod Chri≈øtiani pri√πs locum inhabitauerant. This ≈øo diligent ≈øearching and ≈øeeking for this holy place, by S. Phaganus and Damianus, and their a≈ø≈øured knowledge by the remembred Can. 6. ≈øignes and badges there left and remayning, that they had founde it, ≈øeemeth by that which followeth in this Narration, to haue bene before their returne to Rome to procure the confirmation of their proceedings heare. After this they founde the Antiquitie of the comming of S. Io≈øeph and his Brethren thither, as al≈øo the Acts, and liues of them there, how religeou≈øly they liued, and how three Pagan Kings mini≈øtred nece≈ø≈øaries by a certaine portion of Land for their ≈øu≈øtenation, the miraculous building and con≈øecrating that holy place, as I haue shewed in the fir≈øt Age: wherevpon filled with vn≈øpeacable ioy, they continued there long time, nyne yeares in pray≈øing God: oratorio illo ≈øic reperto, ineffabili ≈øunt referti gaudio, ibidem in Dei laudibus moram protrahentes diuturnam, per nouem videlicet annos. And in memory of the fir≈øt twelue in the time of S. Io≈øeph, they did chu≈øe 12. of their owne company, to dwell there, in that Iland, King Lucius con≈øenting thereto. Which remayned there as Anchorits in diuers places, or Groaues (locis vel lucis) in the very ≈øame, wherein the fir≈øt twelue had formerly dwelled. But they came together very often euery day, crebr√≤ conuenerunt quotidi√®, readeth William of Malme≈øbury, Matth. Parker in Antiq. Britan. Io. Go≈øcelin. Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. de Epi≈øcop. Godwin. Catal. of Bishops that they might more deuoutely performe their diuine offices. And as the three Pagan Kings had long before granted the ≈øaid Iland with the Appertinances to the fir≈øt 12. Di≈øciples of Chri≈øt, ≈øo the ≈øaid Phaganus and Deruianus did obtayne of King Lucius to haue it confirmed for euer to the≈øe their 12. companions, and others their Succe≈ø≈øours after them. And ≈øo they continued by Succe≈ø≈øion, yet allwayes in the ≈øame number of 12. Locum ip≈øum prae caeteris dilexerunt. Qui etiam in memoriam primorum 12. ex ≈øuis ≈øocijs 12. elegerunt, & in praefata In≈øula Rege Lucio con≈øentiente habitare fecerunt. Qui po≈øtea in diuer≈øis locis ≈øicut Anachoritae man≈øerunt ibidem, in ei≈ødem videlicet locis in quibus primi duodecim primit√πs habitauerant. In vetu≈øtam tamen Eccle≈øiam, ad diuina ob≈øequia Matth. Parker. ≈øupr. 68. in Thoma Cranmero p. 329. edit. ann. 1605. deuoti√πs complenda crebr√≤ conuenerunt. Et ≈øicut tres Reges Pagani dictam In≈øulam cum adiacentijs ≈øuis, duodecim primis Chri≈øti Di≈øcipulis dudum conce≈ø≈øerant, it a praedicti Phaganus & Deruianus i≈øtis duodecim ≈øocijs & alijs in po≈øterum ≈øecuturis ab eodem Rege Lucio eandem confirmari impetrabant, ≈øic autem multi alijs ≈øuccedentes ≈øemper tamen in numero duodenario per multa annorum curricula in commemorata In≈øula perman≈øerunt. Polid. Virgil. Angl. Hi≈øt. l. 27. in Henric. 8. p. 689.

3. Cap graue and his Authours ≈øay that the≈øe holy Legats cau≈øed lodgings to be builded there for the≈øe Religeous men: ex ≈øuis ≈øocijs duodecim elegerunt,
& in In≈øula illa L ‚Ä¢ cio fauente aed ‚Ä¢ ficia con≈øtruere, & v≈øque ad finem vitae per≈øeuerare fecerunt. And the words both of the before cited Antiquitre, and William of Malmesbury, that they inhabited, and dwelled there, inhabitare f ‚Ä¢ cerunt, perman≈øerant, proueth as much, for euery dwelling or habitation inferreth ≈øome hou≈øe, Cell, or Lodging to dwell and inhabite in. Which is further confirmed out of the lame Antiquities, where it is proued that the≈øe Religeous men there placed by the Roman Legats, did build an other new Chappell, or Church of ≈øtone neare the old Churh, and dedicated it to Chri≈øt, and his Apo≈øtles S. Peter and S. Paule. Huic Eccle≈øiae ≈øic repertae, aliud addider ‚Ä¢ nt ≈øancti Neophitae opere lapideo oratorium, quod Chri≈øto ≈øancti≈øque Apo≈øtolis Petro & Paulo dedicauerunt. And it is proued by the auncient ge≈øts, and Acts of the≈øe Apo≈øtolike men, S. Phaganus and Damianus, writen in their time in a Volume, or Booke, that by admonition, and direction from heauen they builded an other Chappell, or Oratory in honour of S. Michael the Archangel, that he might there haue honour one earth of men, who at the command of God should bring men to eternall honours in heauen. In cuius fine voluminis inuenimus Scripturam quae dicebat quod praedicti ≈øancti, Phaganus & Deruianus per reuelationem They build a new Oratory neare, in honor of Saint Michael, to be there honored, and protect ≈øuch as honored him. Domini no≈øtri Ie≈øu Chri≈øti idem oratorium ibi aedificauerant in honorem ≈øancti Michaelis Archangeli, quaten√πs ibi ab hominibus haberet honorem, qui homines in perpetuos honores, iubente Deo e≈øt introducturus. Where we ≈øee the greate reuerence was v≈øed to that holy place, euen in our fir≈øt Chri≈øtianitie. Three Chappels there founded with ≈øacrificing Altars in them for the celebration of Ma≈ø≈øe, as tho≈øe Antiquities with others ≈øufficiently mention, one of them dedicated to the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mother of God; the ≈øecond to S. Peter and S. Paule Apo≈øtles; the third in honour of S. Michael the Archangell, all which to haue bene confirmed by the holy Pope S. Eleutherius, it plainely proued by the greate priuiledges he granted to the≈øe ≈øacred places, and par≈øons vpon the Information of his Legats heare, ten yeares of Indulgence to the Pilgrims which should with deuotion vi≈øit the old Chappell of our Lady: Sancti Phaganus & Deruianus perqui≈øierant Indulgences grauÃÑ ted to the Church of Gla≈øtenbury by Pope Elentherius, ≈øo to S. Michaels Chappell. ab Eleutherio Papa qut eos mi≈øerat, deceni annos Indulgentiae. And to all Bishops that should to the honour of S. Michael the Archangell vi≈øit with deuotion the place ≈øacred to him, thirtie yeares of Indulgence. Venerandi Phaganus & Deruianus moram ibi fecerant per nouem annos, & quod ibi etiam perqui≈øierant triginta annorum Indulgentiam omnibus Epi≈øcopis ip≈øum locum, ob honorem beati Michaelis pia voluntate vi≈øitantibus. This Religeous hou≈øe was ≈øo renowned in, or ≈øoone after this time, that Pilgrims came to vi≈øit it from all parts, and ≈øo much honoured it, both in their life and death, that before the time of Melchinus, who others call Meuinus, who as Capgraue writeth, liued before Merlinus, qui fuit ante Merlinum, who liued in the yeare of Chri≈øts Incarnation Capgrau. Cat. in S. Io≈øeph. Io. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. in Ambro≈ø. Merlino. 480. Thou≈øands of Saints were buried there: In≈øula Aualonia auida funeris. Millia dormientium accepit: And ≈øo greate a number and of ≈øo holy Saints were buried there in the holy Church-yard, Sanctum caemiterium, as it is ≈øtiled in Antiquities, that euen in our primatiue Church Age, as we finde in the old Monuments of that reuerend place, a Chappell was there founded to S. Michael, S. Io≈øeph, and the Saints in generall, who≈øe bodies were there interted. De Capella Sanctorum Michaelis & Io≈øeph & Sanctorum in caemiterio requie≈øcentium, Thus the Title of that Relation in the old Manu≈øcript of that Abbey. And then it followeth: Scientes Sancti Patres no≈øtri dignitatem & ≈øanctitatem Prayer to Saints, and for the deade there v≈øed. huius ≈øancti caemiterij, quandam Capellam in eius me ‚Ä¢ io con≈øtruxerunt, quam in honorem ≈øancti Michaelis & Sanctorum inibi requie ≈øcentium dedicari fecerunt, ≈øub
cuius altare o≈ø≈øa mortuorum & ≈øanctorum Reliquias licet incognitas magna multitudine Altares and h ‚Ä¢ ly Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe there v≈øed and frequented. cumulauerunt, & mi≈ø≈øam de caemiteri ‚Ä¢ in ea qu√≤tidi√® celebrari con≈øtituerunt: Our holy Fathers knowing the dignitie, and ≈øanctitie of this holy Church yard did build a Chappell in the midle thereof, which they cau≈øed to be dedicated to the honour of S. Michael, and the Saints which re≈øted there, vnder the Altar whereof, they heaped the bones of the deade, and the Reliks though vnknowne of the Saints in greate multitude, and appointed that an e≈øpeciall Ma≈ø≈øe of the Churchyard should dayly be celebrated in it.

4. And to te≈øtifie to po≈øteritie the Religion and deuotion that holy time had to their Saints, and ≈øacred Reliks, there is a greate long Chapter in the Manu≈øcript Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury, there ≈øtiled and intituled: De Dignitate & Sanctitate vetu≈øtae Eccle≈øiae Beate Mariae Glastoniae, ac eiu≈ødeÃÑ ≈øancti Caemiterij: of the dignitie, and ≈øanctitie of the old Church of ble≈ø≈øed Mary at Gla≈øtenbury, and the holy Churchyard of the ≈øame. Where it is thus among other notable things regi≈øtred: In that Church, and Churchyard, and the Chappell in that Churchyard, are re≈øerued the holy bodies of many Saints: The conpa≈ø≈øe about that Church: The pauement, the Altars vnder, aboue and within, are ≈øo heaped with holy Reliks thronged together, that in all that Churchyard 16. foote deepe from the topp, there is no place, that is without the bodies of Saints: In ea autem, & in caemiterio, & in eiu≈ødem caemiterij capella multorum Sanctorum corporales ≈øeruantur exuuiae adeo √† beatorum reliquijs illius fani ambitus, adeo pauimentum lapide con≈øtratum, adeo altaria, ≈øub, ≈øupra, & infra, Reliquijs conferti≈øsimis aggeruntur, nec in toto illo caemiterio √† profunditate 16. pedum v≈øque ad eius ≈øuperficiem √† Sanctorum cineribus habetur locus vacuus: Our holy Aunce≈øtours had that place in ≈øo greate reuerence, that they dur≈øt not ≈øpeake in it, or ≈øpitt vpon the earth, except vpon greate nece≈østie, and then with greate ≈øorrowe of hart. They dur≈øt not bury any enemy of this Church, nor enormeous ≈øinner ≈øo much as they could learne in that holy Churchyarde, for the horrible voices which were often heard of them, vntill they were digged vp, and ca≈øt out of the Churchyard. And many of the Monkes for reuerence to this holy place, by the iu≈øt Iudgment of God lo≈øt their buriall there. No man brought hawke or dogge thither, which e≈øcaped vnpunished. That place was aunciently reuerenced with ≈øo greate deuotion, that Kings, Queens, Archbishops, Bishops, Dukes, Knights, and Nobles of both Sexes, of what≈øoeuer Order, of what≈øoeuer dignitie they were, did thinke them≈øelues happy, which had endowed that place with any po≈ø≈øe≈øsions, or might be buried there, or in other place with any part of this holy earth. And it was in ≈øuch reuerence, that they which were in health, and dwelled in other Nations beyond the ≈øeas, that diuers of them did often ≈øend for litle parcels of this holy earth, and keepe it mo≈øt deuoutely for their burials. And often ≈øay to our English Pilgrims in tho≈øe parts, that if they knew the worthines and holines of this holy Churchyard, they would not ≈øeeke ≈øo many Pilgrimadges beyond the ≈øeas. There be three cau≈øes e≈øpecially, why that holy earth is with ≈øo greate greedines de≈øired for the buriall of Chri≈øtians. The fir≈øt cau≈øe is, in re≈øpect our Lord with his pre≈øence did dedicate it for the buriall of his ≈øeruants. The ≈øecond becau≈øe it is thought that greate remi≈øsion of ≈øins, is granted by our Lord by the prayers and merits of the Saints buried there, to ≈øuch as be buried in that place, or other with any parte of this holy earth. The third cau≈øe is, for the Ma≈ø≈øes and other prayers which are daily ≈øaid for them. For the≈øe thr ‚Ä¢ e rea≈øons many euen to this day come from diuers parts of the world, and humbly aske peeces of this holy earth in litle ve≈ø≈øels and keepe them most deuoutely for their burials, ≈øome in pur≈øes, ≈øome in gloues, ≈øome otherwi≈øe, as we reade certaine Saracens to haue done in memory of S. Io≈øeph and his companions, who≈øe bodies, as they and others te≈øtifie, doe re≈øt in our Lord in
that grounde: Inta ‚Ä¢ ta reuerentia hab ‚Ä¢ erun ‚Ä¢ ≈øancti patres ‚Ä¢ o≈øtri praedictum loc ‚Ä¢ m, quod non audebantin eo loq ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ; vel flegmain terram ≈øanctam proijcere, ni≈øi i ‚Ä¢ magna nece≈øsitate, vel cum magna cordis compunctione. Nec audeban ‚Ä¢ alique ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ huius Eccle≈øiae inimic ‚Ä¢ m, vel aliquem enormem peccatorem, ≈øecundum quod ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ elligere poterant, in praedicto ≈øacro caemiterio ≈øepelire, propter voces horribiles, quae ≈øaepe ab e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ audiebantur, donec effoderentur, atque de cae ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ iterio proijcerentur. Multi etiam ex Monachis propter reuerentiam huic ≈øacro loco factam iu≈øto Dei Iudicio ≈øepul ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ram inibi perdiderunt. Nullus Auem venatoriam aduexit, vel quadru pedem i ‚Ä¢ d ‚Ä¢ xit, qui ≈øui vel rei po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øae indemnis adierit. Locus ille ab Antiquis tanta colebatur deuotione, vt Reges, Reginae, Archiepi≈øcopi, Epi≈øcopi, Duces, milites, & vtri ‚Ä¢ ≈øque ≈øexus Nobiles, cuiu≈øcumque ordinis, cuiu≈øcumque e≈ø≈øent cel≈øitudinis ≈øe beat ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ fore arbitrabantur, qui locum illum aliquibus po≈ø≈øe≈øsionibus auxi≈ø≈øent, vel qui ibidem, vel alibi cum aliqua portione huius ≈øanctae terrae ≈øepeliri potui≈ø≈øent. Et inter valentes in partibus tran≈ømarinis tanta reuerentia habetur locus ille, quod quidam eorum pro particulis huius ≈øanctae terrae ≈øaepe mittunt. Et pro eorum ≈øepulturis deuoti≈øsim√® custodiunt, & ≈øaepe dicunt Anglicis in partibus illis peregrinantibus, quod ≈øi dignitatem & ≈øanctitatem i≈øtius ≈øancti caemiterij ≈øcirent, non tantas tran≈ømarinas Peregrinationes quaererent. Tres enim ≈øunt cau≈øae notabiliter, quare terra illa ≈øancta ad Chri≈øtianorum ≈øepulturam tanta auiditate de≈øideratur. Prima cau≈øa e≈øt, quia Dominus eam ad ≈øeruorum ≈øuorum ≈øepulturam prae≈øentialiter dedicauit. Secunda, quia omnibus hic vel alibi cum aliqua portione huius ≈øanctae terrae ≈øepultis, per Sanctorum inibi requie≈øcentium preces, & merita, creditur magna peccatorum remi≈øsio √† Domino conce≈ø≈øa. Tertia propter Mi≈ø≈øas, & alias Orationes, quae quotidi√® pro eis dicuntur: propter istas tres cau≈øas multi de diuer≈øis mundi partibus v≈øque ad hodiernum diem veniunt, & particulas huius ≈øanctae terrae in va≈øculis ≈øuis humiliter petunt, & pro eorum ≈øepulturis deuoti≈øsim√® cu≈øtodiunt. Quidam in Bur≈øis, quidam in chirothecis, quidam in ampullis ≈øtanneis & plumbeis, ≈øicut legitur de quibu≈ødam Saracenis feci≈ø≈øe in memoriam ≈øancti Io≈øeph, & ≈øociorum eius, quo ‚Ä¢ um corpora illis ac alijs multis te≈øtantibus in eadem terra in Domino requie≈øcunt. Hitherto the very words of this auncient Manu≈øcript, giuing diuers ≈øure in≈øtances and examples, in particular of tho≈øe things I haue from thence thus generally deliuered. And shewing how in all Per≈øecutions of the infidell Romans, Saxons, and Danes, this holy place was ≈øtill pre≈øerued without mole≈øtation, as it had bene fir≈øt endowed and honoured by the Pagan Brittish Kings.

5. The≈øe Antiquities, as al≈øo William of Malmesbury in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtorie of the Antiquitie, and dignitie of this place, are ample witne≈ø≈øes, that from this time of King Lucius to S. Patricks Age, there were euer without interruption or di≈øcontinuance the whole number of the fir≈øt In≈øtitution of Religeous men there, multi alijs ≈øuccedentes in numero duodenario per Tbe old Eremits or Monks at Gla≈øtenbury thus ≈øetled ther ‚Ä¢ , continued many hundreds of yeares without change or alteration. multa annorum curricula v≈øque ad Aduentum Sancti Patricij in commemorata In≈øula perman≈øerunt. So we ≈øee the ouerraging Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian did not di≈øper≈øe or hurt them. And in the generall ≈øpoile of the Pagan Saxons, in this kingdome, when an other abomination of de≈øolation was heare in Britaine, this holy hou≈øe ≈øtill enioyed both Monkes, and an Abbot called Morgret, and was ≈øo fare from de≈øtruction or ruine thereby, that it then receaued more libertie and a new endowment, the King of Domnonia giuing Gulielm. Malm. l. de Antiq. Gla≈øt. vnto it the land called In≈øwitrin in the 601. yeare of Chri≈øts Incarnation, Anno Dominicae Incarnationis 601. Rex Domnoniae terram quae appellatur In≈øwitrin ad Eccle≈øiam vetu≈øtam conce≈øsit ad petitionem Morgret eiu≈ødem loci Abbatis. And it appeareth by this Authour, that he had ≈øeene the originall Charter
it≈øelfe thereof: for be≈øides his ≈øetting downe the very names of the Abbots, to whome it was granted, and the Bishop Manuto, who wrote the Charter, and ≈øigned it with others, Ego Manuto Epi≈øcopus hanc Chartam ≈øcrip≈øi: he addeth of the King that granted it, that the ≈øcedule was ≈øo old, whereon his name was writen, that it could not be knowne: Quis i≈øte Rex fuit ≈øcedulae vetu≈øtas negat ≈øcire. In the Danish Inua≈øion and Per≈øecution, ≈øome of tho≈øe Infidels did attempt to ≈øpoyle it, but being Miraculou≈øly ≈øtricken blinde, and therevpon penitent for their wickednes, and receauing their ≈øight by the meanes of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary, they cau≈øed a pretious Cro≈ø≈øe of curious work of gold, ≈øiluer, and pretious ≈øtones to be made, and offered it in the old Church in memory thereof: multi eorum audientes ≈øanctitatem huius loci, ne matrem mi≈øericordiae, & alios, quorum inibi corpora pau≈øant ad Iracundiam prouocarent, rece≈ø≈øerunt. Sed tamen intrauerunt nonnulli, nec impun√®. Nam Virgo faecunda arma Iustitiae concutiens, omnes caecitate mulctauit, quos postea paenitentes, & quod iniqu√® ge≈ø≈øerant dete≈øtantes mi≈øericorditer illuminauit. Denique facta collatione Crucem eleganti ≈øatis opere, ex auro, & argento, & pretio≈øis lapidibus fabricauerunt, & Eccle≈øiae veteri ad huiu≈øce miraculi monumenta obtulerunt. And this holy place was made as a common Sanctuary to Religeous per≈øons, in ≈øuch ≈øtormes and tempe≈øts to pre≈øerue them≈øelues, the holy Relicks of Saints, and ≈øuch ≈øacred things there, from Pagan Per≈øecution.

div.head: THE XXV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE GREATE HONOVR, AND REnowne of our old Brittish Apo≈øtolike Order of Religion, from the comming of S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, in the yeare of Chri≈øts Natiuitie 63. (without any di≈øcontinuance, or Interruption by ≈øome, and very short time after his death by all) many hundreds of yeares in greate perfection without any change or alteration, (to be named a Mutation of Mona≈øticall Rule) being the Mother or Nur≈øe of Mona≈øticall holy life to many Nations, and Religious Orders in them: by which al≈øo many Countryes to Chri≈øt were conuerted.

div.p:
1. IF after ≈øo long a Circuite of time and inuolued with ≈øo many difficulties to hinder vs from certaine knowledge of ≈øuch The most holy and auncient Apo≈øtolike Order of Gla≈øtenbury there ≈øetled by S. Io≈øeph. of Arimathia. Cha≈øtitie, obedience, pouertie. things, we are de≈øirous to make ≈øome e≈øtimate, what was the Rule of this holy Order, it ≈øomewhat appeareth by that is ≈øaid, and is re≈øembled in our Hi≈øtories, and diuers ob≈øeruances thereof kept in ≈øuch ≈øtrict Orders, as afterward borrowed them from hence. The three Vowes, or ≈øtates of perfection, of cha≈øtitie, pouertie, and obedience nece≈ø≈øary in all ≈øuch conditions of life, were diligently and exactly performed in this Order. CoÃÑcerning obedience, at and before the fir≈øt comming of S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia, with the re≈øt hither, S. Io≈øeph was ordained their Superior by the Apo≈øtle which directed them hither: his praefecit amicum ≈øuum Io≈øeph ab Aramathia, qui Dominum ≈øepeliuit. Flos Aramathiae Io≈øeph est primus eorum. So writeth William of Malmesbury, the Antiquities of Gla≈øtenburye,
Capgraue and others who keepe a ≈øucce≈ø≈øiue continuance of mo≈øt of their Guliel. Malme≈ø. l. de Antiq. Caen. Gla≈øt. Io. Capgr. Catal. in S. Io≈øeph. ab Aramat. Antiq. Gla≈øton. Abbots after, both in the Britans and Saxons time, who Ruled them, and to whome they were obedient, Iure Abbatis rexit. The pouertie which the≈øe men with the contempt of Riches profe≈ø≈øed, is ≈øufficiently declared, in for≈øaking all they had of their owne, and liuing by their labour and ≈øuch things, as at the fir≈øt were giuen vnto them by Infidels in a ≈øtrange Country. And after King Lucius was conuerted, they had nothing, but the Almes of Chri≈øtians, and their owne paines and Indu≈øtrie to ≈øu≈øtaine them, and yet the≈øe not at their owne, but Abbots di≈øpo≈øition. The holy place wherein they liued being left ≈øo long, and ≈øtrangely de≈øolate without man, woman, or childe, after the death of S. Io≈øeph and his companions, the ≈øub≈øtitution of Monkes in the ≈øame number of 12. by S. Damianus, and Phaganus, and the continued ≈øucce≈ø≈øion in that number, their names regi≈øtred, their ≈øo often a≈ø≈øembling, and meeting euery day in the holy Church: The greate cha≈øtitie is remembred of them, which be mo≈øt mentioned by Hi≈øtorians, no marryed or vncha≈øte woman euer inhabiting there, by any Antiquitie, giueth a warrant boldly to ≈øay, they liued in perpetuall ≈øacred cha≈øtitie.

2. If we will follow the more common opinion of Antiquaries, that the Miraculous man S. Patricke the Apo≈øtle of Ireland, was Abbot there, and giue allowance to the old Manu≈øcript Epi≈øtle, a≈ø≈øcribed vnto him, we mu≈øt Their holyne≈ø≈øe, and au≈øteritie of life. ≈øay, their au≈øteritie of life and deuotion were wonderfull: For he ≈øaith of the twelue which were there in his time, and who≈øe names for their honour he ≈øetteth downe, that he was not worthie to vntye the buckles of their shewes, non dignus eram ≈øoluere corrigias calceamentorum eorum. And yet we reade of him in approued Authours, that he was one of the mo≈øt holy, vertuous, and Miraculous men, that euer liued: omni namque Die P≈øalterium cum canticis & himnis & ducentis orationibus cantauit, & offerebat corpus Chri≈øti, docebat Di≈øcipulos, turbis praedecabat, & in omni hora ≈øigno crucis Chri≈øti centies ≈øignabat ≈øe. In prima vero noctis parte centum P≈øalmos canebat, & ducentis vicibus genua curuabat, & a pullorum cantu in aquis stabat donec adimpleret orationes ≈øuas, post haec dormiebat ≈øuper lapidem nudum, alterumque ≈øub capite eius po≈øuit, & tunicam pelliceam habebat circa lumbos ≈øuos in aqua tinctam: he did euery day ≈øinge the P≈øalter, with canticles and himnes, and two hundred prayers, he offered the ≈øacrifice of Chri≈øts body, taught his Di≈øciples, preached to the people, and in euery hower ≈øigned him≈øelfe an hundred times with the ≈øigne of the cro≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt. In the fir≈øt part of the night, he ≈øunge an hundred p≈øalmes, and bowed his knees two hundred times, and from the crowing of the cocke he ≈øtood in the water vntill he had ended his prayers, after this he ≈ølept vppon a bare ≈øtone, and layed an other vnder his heade, and he had about his loines a leather coate dipped in water. And if we should que≈øtion S. Patrike his long liuing, being and dying Abbot at Gla≈øtenbury, and ≈øo leauing ≈øuch au≈øteritie to the Monks as he exerci≈øed in him≈øelfe, yet we may not haue any doubt but he being Nephew to S. Martine that greate Apo≈øtolike man, taught by him, and he him≈øelfe being the Apo≈øtle of Ireland, where the Religeous men were of the ≈øame Order they were in Britaine, but this ≈øtrict manner of life was common to all Monkes in the≈øe parts in his, and from this time, we haue in hands, no memory of change being found in Hi≈øtories.

And we reade that S. Brendon found in an Iland of America a Mona≈øtery wherein were 24. very holy Monkes, Di≈øciples of S. Patrike, and S. Albeus which had liued there 80. yeares with breade, rootes, and water, and had no Manu≈øcr. Antiq. & Capgr. in S. Brendan. other foode to entertaine their worthie gue≈øt S. Brendan and his holy company
withall, a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ yet their bread Miraculou≈øly prouided for them. Parata men≈øa, appo≈øiti≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ panibus miri candoris, & quibu≈ødam radicibus incredibilis ≈øaporis comedebant: ≈øedebant mixti fratres cum hospitibus per ordinem & inter duos fratres ≈øemp√©r panis integer ponebatur. Ex fonte facite charitatem cum Iucunditate & timore Domini. And we finde, that in an other Mona≈øtery in the≈øe parts where there were many Monkes, Plures monachi, there was no other foode, or ≈øu≈øtenance for them, but appels, nutts, rootes, and herbes. Nihil aliud cibi mon≈øtrabatur, ni≈øi poma, & nuces, atque radices, & herbae. And to come to the holy roote it≈øelfe of this ≈øacred Profe≈ø≈øion at Gla≈øtenbury, which had ≈øo ≈øoone, ≈øo farre extended and ≈øpreed the branches thereof, with ≈øuch ≈øeueritie and ≈øanctitie of life, what other thing can we hope to finde in ≈øuch a De≈øart, and wildernes, as then it was: in the woodly wildernes corne did not growe, the Bishops, or Archbishops them≈øelues did not then, nor many hundreds of yeares after eate flesh.

4. The fir≈øt Archbishop of Caerlegion, or S. Dauids, which did eate flesh was as both Catholike and Prote≈øtant Antiquaries write called Morgeneu, the 33. in number after S. Dauid, allmo≈øt 1000. yeares after Chri≈øts Natiuitie. A Prote≈øtant Bishop thus relateth the Hi≈øtorie. Morgeneu this man (≈øaith Giraldus of all the Bishops of S. Dauids, pre≈øumed fir≈øt to eate flesh, which none of them Godwin Catal. in S. Dauids in Morgeneu. had euer done before him. For punishment of which hainous offence, he ≈øuppo≈øeth it fell out, that afterwards he was murthered of Pirats: reporting withall, how that after his death he appeared to a Bishop of Ireland, v≈øing the≈øe words: Quia carnes comedi, caro factus ≈øum: for eating of flesh, I am no ‚Ä¢ become nothing but flesh. The Art and skill of fishing was allmo≈øt vtterly vnknowne in the≈øe partes of Britaine, Bed. l. 5. Hi≈øtor. Gent. Angl. Capgrau. Catal. in S. W ‚Ä¢ lf ‚Ä¢ id. Godwin Catal. of Bish. Chiche≈øter in Wilfride. Antiquit. Gla≈øt. Manu≈ø. & Capgr. Catal. in S. Patricio. vntil when in the ≈øeuenth hundredth yeare it was taught there by S. Wilfride. The≈øe holy men planted fruite trees there, in greate number to bring them meate, wherevpon that De≈øart was called Aualonia, or the Iland Aualonia, the I≈øle of fruites, becau≈øe in the old Brittish toÃÑgue Aualla ≈øignifieth fruites, In≈øula Aualoniae, id est In≈øula pomorum vocabatur, Aualla Britannice, poma Latine. And the InhabitaÃÑts of tho≈øe parts to this day doe call greate Nutts, growing in that Country by the name of Aualons. Therefore our Antiquaries knowing how ≈øtrict and penitentiall life they ≈øedd, and in carnall cen≈øure exceeding ordinary humane habilitie, without heauenly help and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, doe deliuer Their foodefruites Herbes and bread. vnto vs, that S. Io≈øeph and his companions, the fir≈øt Religious Inhabitants of this place, before Orchard or gardeine was planted there for fruites, rootes or herbs, to feede vpon, offerring and performing there their deuoute duties to God, and the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, in watchings, fa≈øtings, and prayers, were reliued Antiq. Gla≈øton. Manu≈øcr. Tabulis affix. Capgr. Catalog. in S. Io≈øeph ab Aramat. S. Patric. Epi≈øt. & alij. in all their nece≈ø≈øities, by the help of the ≈øame ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mother of God. Duodecim ≈øancti praedicti in eodem loco Deo & beatae virgini deuota exhibentes ob≈øequia, vigilijs, Ieiunijs & orationibus vacantes, eiu≈ødem virginis Dei Genetricis auxilio in nece≈øsitatibus ≈øuis refocillabantur.

5. And this ≈øo ≈øtrict Mona≈øticall conuer≈øation though likely in ≈øome places, and times afterward ≈øome what mitigated from the fir≈øt rigour, was the generall ob≈øeruation of our old Brittish, Scottish, and Irish Monkes, all of them The Monks there drunke then no wyne or ≈øuch drinke, but water. drinking onely water or milke, and neuer any wine, Ale, or ≈øuch manner of drinke, for we reade in approued, and Auncient Hi≈øtorians, that when King Ceolnulfus left his terreane kingdome to be a Monke in the Mona≈øtery of Lindisfarne about the yeare of Chri≈øt 764. the Monkes there according to the old Tradition and cu≈øtome did drinke nothing but water or milke, and then they had di≈øpen≈øation at this Kings procuring to drinke wine or Ale, hoc
Rege iam Monacho facto efficiente, data e≈øt LindiffarneÃÑ≈øis Eccle≈øi ‚Ä¢ Monachis licentia Roger HouedeÃÑ Annal. par. Pr ‚Ä¢ o. an. 764. & an. 882. bibendi vinum vel cerui≈øiam: ante enim non ni≈øi lac vel „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øolebant, ≈øecundum antiquam traditionem Sancti Aidani primi eiu≈ødem Eccle≈øiae Anti≈øtitis, & Monachorum, qui cum illo de Scotia venientes, ibidem donante Rege O≈øwaldo man≈øionem acceperant, & cum magna di≈øtrictione Deo ≈øeruire gaudebant. Where we ≈øee this to haue bene the old receaued v≈øe and cu≈øtome of tho≈øe Brittish and Scottish Monkes.

6. What their Ma≈ø≈øe and other publike Church ≈øeruice was, I finde in an Their auncient Church ≈øeruice, that a≈ø≈øcribed to S. Marke the EuaÃÑ geli≈øt, or of Saint Peter. old Brittish Manu≈øcript Antiquitie written allmo≈øt 1000. yeares ≈øince and Intituled the fir≈øt In≈øtitution and varietie of the Church ≈øeruice: prima In≈øtitutio & varietas Eccle≈øia≈øtici ≈øeruitij, that they were the ≈øame which S. Marke the Euangeli≈øt by S. Peter his approbation, compo≈øed and practized. Cur≈øum qui dicitur prae≈øenti tempore Scotorum Beatus Marcus decantauit. This is recorded for the office Eccle≈øia≈øticall of Scotland in tho≈øe times by this old Manu≈øcript, but for thee re≈øt of this Iland, now England and wales it rather deliuereth, that the Roman v≈øe deriued from S. Peter and S. ‚Ä¢ lement his Succe≈ø≈øour, which it calleth cur≈øum Romanum, was practized heare, and ≈øetteth downe how it was continued and deriued to the Britans from S. Peter, and S. Clement: Yet with ≈øome alteration & addition of Antiphones, Respon≈øories and Alleluias, but the≈øe taken out of holy Scripturs, or the workes of the old holy Fathers ≈øucceeding the Apo≈øtles, and not out of the Inuention of tho≈øe, though wi≈øe men, which made ≈øuch alteration or addition; Inde per diuer≈øorum prudentium virorum con≈øilium, non de proprijs ≈øed de ≈øerie ≈øcripturarum noui & veteris te≈øtamenti, diuer≈øorum prudentium virorum Paginis, ≈øed de ≈øacris ≈øcripturis receperunt Antiphonas, & Re≈øpon≈øoria, ≈øeu ≈øonos & alleluias compo≈øuerunt. That they continually Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. Brit. antiqui≈ø≈ø. without intermi≈ø≈øion day & night per≈øeuered in praying and ≈øeruing God, one company therein ≈øucceeding an other, e≈øpecially where their number Gulielm. Malm. l. de Antiq. Caen. Gla≈øton. Antiq. Gla≈øton. Tabulis fixae. was greate. I haue declared before by the example of the Mona≈øteries of Abington, and S. Kentegerne: ≈øo I may ≈øay of the Mona≈øterie of S. Vuandilocus and S. Gomogillus, wherein there were about 3000. Monkes: Beatus Vuandilocus & beatus Gomigillus habuerunt in eorum Mona≈øterio Monachos circiter tria millia. So of the Mona≈øtery of S. Brendan, that of Bangor, and Capgr. Catal. in S. Brendano. Io. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. in BreÃÑdan. Capgr. ≈øupr. Bal. centur. 5. in Io. Capgr. Girald. Cambr. Itinerar. CaÃÑbr. l. 2. c. 6. Capgr. in S. Brendan. Hector Boeth. Scot. h ‚Ä¢ ≈øt. others. And in the lea≈øt of them all there was litle le≈ø≈øe deuotion v≈øed. For in this fir≈øt of Gla≈øtenbury, when there were but twelue Religious men there, we haue heard before, that they ofteÃÑ times in the day came alltogether, to tho old Church to performe diuine office: in vetu≈øtam Eccle≈øiam ad diuina ob≈øequia deuotius complenda crebro conuenerunt quotidie. Many comitted this holy Rule (though with ≈øome difference) to writing, to be ob≈øerued and kept of holy Monkes; among whome were S. Brendan directed by an Angel as both old and late, Catholike and Prote≈øtant Antiquaries deliuer, S. Dauid, S. Kentigern, & S. ColuÃÑbanus, which Rule of S. ColuÃÑban, Pope Honorius coÃÑfirmed. And this Rule with the Regulars profe≈ø≈øing it, continued heare in greate ≈øanctitie in the time of Giraldus CaÃÑbren≈øis, in the time of Capgrauius, v≈øque hodie The Apostolike Order and Mona≈øtery of Gla≈øteÃÑbury the most auncient. manet, who lyued in the yeare of Chri≈øt 1464. and after in Hector Boethius his time in the dayes of Luther, as they plainely proue & witne≈ø≈øe, eueÃÑto the≈øe new Here≈øies. Whereby appeareth, it was the mo≈øt auncient, holy and generall S. A≈øaphus in Vit. S. Kentegerni. Ca ‚Ä¢ gr. in eod. Io. Bal. l. de Scriptor. cent. 1. in Kentegern. Order of Religion, or euer was in the world. And from which very many Religious orders e≈øpecially in the we≈øt part of the world, haue proceeded as childreÃÑ of ≈øo ble≈ø≈øed a mother, not onely in Italy, Germany, FraÃÑce & others in that Continent, but as both Catholike and Prote≈øtant Antiquaries haue deliuered,
in all Regions neare to Britaine, Orchades, Norway, Denmarke, I≈øeland, Script. Vitae S. BreÃÑda. & capg. in eod. LaÃÑb. in Leg. S. Edwardi. Hackluit booke of Engl. trauail. in Arthur. and the Ilands of America it≈øelfe, the New found world, as it is termed by ≈øome, but knowne vnto, preached and inhabited in by the≈øe ou ‚Ä¢ Monkes 1100. or 1200. yeares ≈øince. No order of Religion in the world hath or had ≈øo many glorious Saints.

7. Many Infidell Nations were by the≈øe conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, and among others, both by our owne and forreyne Hi≈øtories, they the holy Bishops, and Clergie of Britaine, haue wonne and iu≈øtly de≈øerued the honour, to be the ble≈ø≈øed In≈øtruments, of conuerting the farre greater parte of the Saxons in this kingdome, before, at, and after S. Augu≈øtine and his holy A≈ø≈øociats preaching heare. And not onely of the Saxons and Germans heare, but in the Higher, and Lower Germany, and other peoples there, tho≈øe which were of England, Monks and Preachers in tho≈øe parts, being trayned vp in Mona≈øticall Order, in our Mona≈øteries in our North England of our old Order, before any other, but our old Brittish Rules was ≈øetled heare. Neyther shall I ea≈øily be per≈øuaded by any thing I finde in Antiquitie, that S. Augu≈øtine Greg. in Dialog. Epi≈øt. ad Reg. Ethelbert. Re≈øp. ad Interrogat. S. Augu≈øt. Honor. Pap. Epi≈øtol. ad Honor. CaÃÑtuar. Bed. Hi≈øt. lib. 2. Capgr. in S. Honorio Cantuar. with his A≈ø≈øociats was of any other, but the old Apo≈øtolike Order and Rule that was v≈øed in S. Gregories Mona≈øtery, as S. Gregory him≈øelfe, Pope Honorius his Succe≈ø≈øour, S. Bede, Capgraue and other renowned Authours doe plainely affirme, and witne≈ø≈øe which ea≈øily ioyned and vnited the Profe≈ø≈øours of it, with all other Apo≈øtolike Rules of S. Martine, S. Augu≈øtine, of Gla≈øtenbury, Bangor, S. Columba, S. Brendan, S. Kentegern and others renowned heare in Britaine, which allthough they haue not bene well knowne, to remote and forreyne writers, among whome, Britaine was ≈øo vnkowne, to ≈øome, that they were ignorant, whether it was an other world, or no, yet we the Inhabitants indigenae thereof, which may not pleade ignorance, nor be excu≈øed, in being ill affected, to ≈øo worthie Aunce≈øtours and Parents in Chri≈øt, may not ignorantly, or wittingely defraude them of their mo≈øt worthilie due, and de≈øerued glory, or giue it from them to others.

8. No Regular Abbot in the Schoole of Chri≈øt was more auncient, then our Founder S. Io≈øeph of Aramathia ≈øo renowned by holy witne≈ø≈øe of God All Apo≈øtolike men and Orders that came after into Britaine ioyned with that of Gla≈øtenbury. him≈øelfe in ≈øacred Scripturs, none more louing of Chri≈øt or for≈øaking more for him, then he that ≈øeeing Chri≈øt for≈øaken, as it were of all, for≈øooke him not, but boldly begged his ble≈ø≈øed bodie, shrowded, and honorably buried it in his owne Sepulchre, ≈øuffered ≈øo much of the wicked Iewes, as Hi≈øtores recompt for that cau≈øe, and for≈øaking for Chri≈øt loue, the loue of him≈øelfe, his Country, Ritches, Lands, reuenewes, and friends, becau≈øe he would be a ≈øtranger to the world and wordly things, ≈øo to liue and die, came ≈øo farre a Iorney as from Arimathia and Hieru≈øalem, to liue and die ≈øo ≈øtrict a contemplatiue and heauenly life, in the De≈øart Ile of Aualon in our Britaine heare, and founde for this Nation the fir≈øt Mona≈øtery, and be thereof the fir≈øt Abbot in the world: ≈øuch as their Abbots, ≈øuch were the Religeous vnder him as I haue remembred. And they continued there ≈øo long, as many hold, there was no interruption betweene them, and the≈øe in King Lucius time, if there was, it mu≈øt needs be very short. All agree that Chri≈øt immediately him≈øelfe, S. Peter, or S. Philip Apo≈øtles ≈øent them as Apo≈øtles hither, and certaine it is before, S. Peter heare approued them. And when the≈øe our Legats S. Damanus and Faganus were ≈øent Bishops hither, from S. Eleutherius Pope, the Antiquities of Winche≈øter, S. Gildas, as he was publikly cited in Parlament by Abbot Fecknam of We≈øtmin≈øter, and others holde, were Monkes, and
yet as before, and as the Antiquaries and Antiquities of G ‚Ä¢ a≈øtenb ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y prone, Annales Win
‚Ä¢ on. Gildas apud Abbot. Feckn. o ‚Ä¢ at. in 1. Parliament. Elizabeth. Antiquit. Gla≈øt. Guliel. Malm. l. de Antiq. Caeno. Gla≈øt. Capgr. in S. Patricio & S. Io≈øeph. Aram. Manu≈øcr. Ant. de prima In≈øtit. Eccl. officij. Vit. S. Lupi. Sur. & Haraeus in eod. Con≈øtant. in Vit. S. Germani Anti≈øiodoren. Antiq. Gla≈øton. Guliel. Malm. ≈øupr. Capgr. in S. Patricio. Manu≈øcript. Antiq. & Capgrau. in S. Brendano. Manu≈øcr. Brit. ≈øupr. Capgr. in S. Dubritio & S. Dauid. Antiq. Eccl. Landau. Caius l. 1. Antiq. Cantabr. S. A≈øaph. in Vit. S. Kentigerni. Capgr. in eod. they there ≈øubmitted them≈øelues, and diuers of their ≈øacred company to this. Apo≈øtolike fir≈øt Rule and Order of S. Io≈øeph, lyuing in the ≈øame manner as he and his A≈ø≈øociats did. They them≈øelues ≈øtayed there. 9. yeares, whether they died there or not, the Antiquities doe not determine, but clearely te≈øtifie they left there a Succe≈ø≈øion of their holy companie, huing and dying there in that Apo≈øtolike holy Order, and S. Eleutherius Pope granted diuers Indulgences to that holy place. Our next Apo≈øtolike men ≈øent hither from the Roman See, and Pope Cele≈øtine, both S. German and S. Lupus, by an old Brittish Antiquitie, and other Authours, were, before they were Bishops, Monkes of the old Mona≈øtery, and Order of Lirinum, which both by them, and others ioyned in one with our old Brittish Order heare: and all agree that without all que≈øtion S. Lupus was a Monke of that Order, Rule and place, and S. German liued euen being a Bishop and Legate a life as ≈øtrict, and in as great au≈øteritie, as any Regular then did, v≈øed, gaue, and left that example heare. S. Patrike the next Apo≈øtolike Legate of the≈øe parts was Abbot of this our ≈øacred Brittish Apo≈øtolike Order and Rule in our Mona≈øtery of Gla≈øtenbury. And then the Monks of Britaine, Ireland, and Scotland with other agreed in the ≈øame Order, and Rule: and of the ≈øame Order, he ≈øent Monks into America, and the Ilands thereof. S. Gomogillus and S. Vuandilocus had in their Mona≈øtary, monachos circiter tria millia, about 3000. Monks of the ≈øame Order; and be≈øides others the Mona≈øtery of Bangor had few le≈ø≈øe of the ≈øame Rule. After S. German and his A≈ø≈øociates departure hence, S. Dubritius and S. Dauid were the Popes Legates, or greate≈øt commaunders heare, by the highe≈øt ≈øpirituall Power. S. Dubritius was a famous Mai≈øter to ≈øuch Schollers, and S. Dauid liuing long in the next Age, founded many Mona≈øteries of this Order, and left his Rule after his death, which I haue ≈øett downe in due place. S. Kentegern was renowned in his time, fot this Regular life, and had in his Mona≈øterie continuall learned Prei≈øts, and Preachers all mo≈øt 400. Apo≈øtolike men, be≈øides others, whome he ≈øent to preach in all the≈øe we≈øterne parts, and liuing vnto the time of S. Gregory Pope, who approued, confirmed and much commended his holy Order, ≈øtate and cour≈øe of life, as S. A≈øaph his renowned Scholler, and Succe≈ø≈øour in his Epi≈øcopall See and dignitie, and Capgraue in his life are ample witne≈ø≈øes. At, before, and after S. Augu≈øtines Ionas in Vit. S. ColuÃÑbani. Capgrau. in eod. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. in Columbano. Ionas in Vit. S. coÃÑming hither, S. Columban a Monke of Bangor of this Order, with his holy companions was renowned in France, Burgundy and Italy, and there founded many Mona≈øteries both of Monks and Nunnes of this our old Order, and Rule, and Pope Honorius confirmed it, euer in tho≈øe places.

9. The Lirinum Monks of that learned Order vnited them≈øelues with him in his Rule, and among others, S. Attila, who ≈øucceeded him, Abbot in his Mona≈øtery of Luxouium, was one. The Di≈øciples and Schollers of S. Augu≈øtine, in Vit. S. Attalae & S. Eu≈øtachij. Script. Vit. S. Liuini Archiepi≈øc. Surius. Haraeus & al. in eod. 12. die Nouemb. Antiq. Gla≈øton. Tabulis fixae. Gul. Malm. l. de Antiq. Caenob. Gla≈øton. ≈øent into England by S. Gregory Pope ioyned in this holy Order, and Rule, ≈øuch was S. Liuinus made Prei≈øt by S. Augu≈øtine, and after a Bishop, and by ≈øome an Archbishop, who liued with S. Foillanus, Helius and Kilianus, were holy Monks of this our old Order, S. Liuinus being Di≈øciple to S. Benignus the renowned Abbot of Gla≈øtenbury, Di≈øciple to S. Patrike, as the name, place, and time agreeing proue. S. Paulinus the fir≈øt Archbishop of Yorke in the Saxons, time a principall man in the Roman Mi≈ø≈øion with S. Augu≈øtine liued in our Mona≈øtery of Gla≈øtenbury, with our Monks there, diuers monthes, and made new buildings or reparations there for them, and
their holy Order. Thus the Antiquities there te≈øtifie at lardge. S. Brithwald a Antiq. Gla≈øton. Bed. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. Catal. Archiep. Cant. Godwin in Brithwaldo. Monke of Gla≈øtenbury of our old Order was cho≈øen to be Abbot among the Monks that came from Rome, in their Mona≈øtery at Reculuer in Kent, and after Archbishop of Canterbury. S. Benedict Bishop one of the fir≈øt and mo≈øt renowned Abbots in Canterbury, the fir≈øt Englishman Abbot there after tho≈øe of S. Augu≈øtins Mi≈ø≈øion, and was fir≈øt in≈øtructed by Monks of our old Capgr. in S. Benedic. Bi≈øc. Bed. Hi≈øtor. Florent. Wigorn. Chron. Matth. We≈øtm. Chronic. Antiq. Gla≈øton. Gul. Ma ‚Ä¢ mesb. l. Antiq. Caenob. Gla≈øton. Brittish Order in Northumberland, went thence to Lirinum Mona≈øtery that ioyned then with S. Columbanus, and our old Order, was there two yeares, and there profe≈ø≈øed long before S. Benedicts Rule came thither, went to Rome whence S. Augu≈øtine and his Monks came, and there liued with the Roman Monks, was after Abbot of S. Augu≈øtins in Canterbury, Monke and Abbot among our Monks in Northumberland of our old Order, no Mona≈øtery then and there hauing receaued S. Benedict his Rule. And aboue 40. yeares after his death, S. Ticca Abbot and Succe≈ø≈øour in his Mona≈øtery with his Monks, Ticca venerabilis Abbas cum ≈øuis Monachis, carrying with him in time of Per≈øecution the bodies of S. Benedict, and all the Abbots of that Abbey, went to Gla≈øtenbury of our old Order then, and hundreds of yeares after, and was Abbot there many yeares: Cum ≈øuis Monachis Gla≈øtoniam v≈øque peruenit eandeÃÑque Eccle≈øiam ≈øub nomine Abbatis plurimos annos rexit. It is euident by all Hi≈øtorians, that the Monks of S. Benedict Bi≈øcop, in our North England, tho≈øe of Gla≈øtenbury, & other Mona≈øteries heare much differed in many and much materiall things, from the Monks of any late or new Order then in Italy or other place, or Nation: As in Church ≈øeruice and ob≈øeruations, habit, dyet, Abbots, Monks, and many things di≈øtinguishing ≈øuch Rules not to be mentioned heare, belonging rather to an other place, and time, if need be thereof.

div.head: THE XXVI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THAT DIVERS OF THE BRITANS WHICH liued in that part of Britaine, then called Albania now Scotland, were conuerted by the ≈øame meanes, and manner by the≈øe Roman Legats, as the other Britans of Loegria and Cambria were at that time.

div.p:
1. BY this appeareth, that as the≈øe Legats Commi≈ø≈øion was not confined within the temporall limits, and bonds of King Lucius, and the Romans heare in Britaine, commonly by our Antiquities and Hi≈øtories then, no further extending it≈øelfe, The≈øe Legats and Apo≈øtolike Mi≈øsoÃÑ of Pope Eleutherius preached in the whole kingdome of Britaine. then to Seuerus wall, diuiding and ≈øeparating Albania, now commonly called Scotland, from the other parts of Britaine, now England: So they, or ≈øome of their A≈ø≈øociats, and holy company preached in the whole kingdome, or Ile of great Britaine, and the cheife Ilands thereof: for if Pope Eleutherius (as before is proued) ≈øubiected that part of Britaine, now Scotland, beyond the wall, out of the temporall Iuri≈ødiction of King Lucius, at who≈øe reque≈øt and petition he ≈øent Preachers hither, vnto Yorke a Metropolitan See in his kingdome, and Dominion, he though highe≈øt iudge, and Ruler in the
Church of Chri≈øt, and ouer ≈øuch as beleeued in him: yet ouer ≈øuch as had not receaued the faith and Religion of Chri≈øt, he would v≈øe no ≈øuch commande, or Power, to ≈øubiect them either to the Archbishop of Yorke, London, Cacrlegion, or any other out of the temporall Dominion where they liued, nor within the ≈øame, if any ≈øuch had bene there, except they had bene Chri≈øtians. So the ≈øame holy learned Pope, in his allowing all the Ilands betweene Britaine and Norwey with Denmarke, v≈øque Noruegiam & Daciam to belong to the Crowne of King Lucius in Britaine, the ciuill Lawe, and Ius gentium, adiudging Ilands, e≈øpecially le≈ø≈øer Ilands to be parts of, and belonging vnto the next Continent, Norwey being a greate kingdome, and in the mayne continent, as a greate parte of Denmarke likewi≈øe was, and is, Britaine being proued to the Romans before, to be an Iland, ≈øeparate from the greate Continent, though the greate≈øt knowne Iland, it will bring many be≈øides Prote≈øtants to defend this Donation of Pope Eleutherius, and thereby the old right and Title of Britaine, to the Ilands neare Norwey and Denmarke, to be of opinion, that diuers there, were then conuerted to Chri≈øt, and Pope Eleutherius laboured what he could for their Conuer≈øion. Otherwi≈øe the Pope though ≈øupreame Pa≈øtor and Ruler of the Church of Chri≈øt, did not, nor would claime ≈øuch Power ouer Infidels neuer conuerted to the true faith, or sheepe of the folde of Chri≈øt, of which and not of Infidels he is cheife≈øt Sheephard vnder Chri≈øt, one earth.

2. The old Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury, one of our be≈øt Records in ≈øuch things, a≈ø≈øure vs, that the≈øe our holy Legats, and Apo≈øtles did heare preach Chri≈øt, and baptized the Inhabitants, throughout the whole Iland of Britaine, and not onely in King Lucius, and the Romans Dominion heare, Phaganus & Deruianus venerunt in Britanniam ad praedicandum Euangelium, qui Antiq. Gla≈øt. Guliel. Malm. l. de Antiq. Caeno. Gla≈øt. Capgrau. in S. Patricio. bapti≈øantes & praedicantes, & vniuer≈øam In≈øulam peragrantes. Which Tertullian, a learned witne≈ø≈øe, and writer in this time, within the fir≈øt 200. yeares of Chri≈øt, and writing in Afrike, ≈øo farre from taking ≈øpeedy and certaine notice, or Intelligence of the affaires of this ≈øo remote kingdome, proueth when he ≈øaith, Britannorum Romanis inacce≈ø≈øa loca, the places of the Brittans, whether Tertull. l. cont. Iudaeos c. 7. the Romans could not come, had before his writing, receaued the faith of Chri≈øt, which mu≈øt needs be performed at this time, before Pope Victor his ≈øending Preachers vnto the Scots, at the reque≈øt of their King, and fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King of the Scots, Donaldus. And his Mi≈ø≈øion was vnto the Scots, but this Conuer≈øion of the Britans in the places vnacce≈ø≈øable to the Romans, or to which the Romans had not made acce≈ø≈øe, mu≈øt needs be of the Britans, as they are ≈øo expre≈ø≈øely named, by that auncient writer of that time, and the≈øe Britans were the ≈øame, which then inhabited in the Country, now and long ≈øince called Scotland, of the Scots afterward entering, and inhabiting there; for all other places in Britaine had before ≈øuffered and knowne the Romans Acce≈ø≈øe, and Inua≈øion into them.

3. No other part of Britaine is found in Hi≈øtories, into which they had not made acce≈ø≈øe, and there obtained Rule, or thence receaued Tribute. And in this our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries doe agree, When thus they write: It is certaine by Chemnitius, citing Sabellicus, that the Britans were with the fir≈øt Conuerts: and Prote≈øt. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. ¬ß. 9. Chemnit. in Exam. Concil. Tridentin. ex Sabellico. Tertullian who liued within 200. yeares of Chri≈øts Natiuitie, sheweth no le≈ø≈øe: when the more to prouoke the Iewes again≈øt whome he wrote, calleth to witne≈ø≈øe the fruitefull encrea≈øe of the Ghospell of Saluation, through many Countryes, and Nations, and among them, nameth the Britans to haue receaued the word of life, the power
whereof, ≈øaith he, hath pirced into tho≈øe parts whether the Roma ‚Ä¢ s could not come. Where they alledge Tertullian in the ≈øame ≈øence for the Conuer≈øion of the Britans, euen in the places whether the Romans could not come vnto them, yet they doe not plainely cite Tertullian as he wrote, and I haue cited him before, that the places heare conuerted, to which the RomaÃÑs could not come, The Britans the mo≈øt auncient Chri≈øtians in this part of the world, or whole world, for a kingdome. to haue bene places of the Britans, Britannorum Romanis inacce≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ loca, and of no other people or Nation. Therefore I cannot allowe, what they without controlle immediately thus write in that place: whence Petrus Cluniacen≈øis ≈øuppo≈øeth the Scottish men, the more auncient Chri≈øtians, as not being in the like ≈øubiection to the Romans, as other then were. Which collection of Petrus Cluniacen≈øis, if the≈øe men, or any other should allowe, and not reproue, they should thereby proue them≈øelues much ignorant in the Antiquities, honour and priuiledges of our Britaine, in this re≈øpect, contrary to all Hi≈øtorians, and the≈øe men contrary to them≈øelues, often in this their Theater teaching, Britaine and the Britans to haue bene the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian kingdome and Nation in the worlde: No Scots or others, e≈øpecially in the≈øe parts of the knowne world the comming neare vnto them in that ≈øtate or degree of glorie.

4. And it is euident by our olde≈øt British Hi≈øtorian S. Gildas, and others Gildas l. de excid. & conque≈øt. Britanniae. after him, that the Scots were not ≈øeated, or dwelling in the greate Iland of Britaine, not in the mo≈øt remote and Northren parts thereof vntill the departure of Maximus hence with the cheife≈øt power of the Britans heare, when and not before they inuaded the North parts vnto the wall of diui≈øion: omnem Aquilonarem, extremamque terrae partem, pro Indigenis murotenus cape≈ø≈øunt. The Britans Indigenae were the generall Inhabitants and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors there before. And the picts did not vntill then inhabite any extreame parte of greate Britaine, Picti in extrema parte In≈øulae tunc primum, & deinceps requ√Æeuerunt, and yet by all were heare planted before the Scots. But they liued vntill then: the Gild. Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Brittan. Matt. We≈øt. Chron. Harding. Chron. Scots in Ireland, and the our-Ilands: as the Picts al≈øo in tho≈øe le≈ø≈øer Ilands did. And the Britans dwelling beyonde the wall, were as free from ≈øubiection to the Romans, as any Scots now were, or rather more, when we finde that in Claudius the Roman Emperour his time, he with his Romans brought the Orchades, and after, Angle≈øy to their ≈øubiection. And the Scottish Hi≈øtorians, Veremund. Hi≈øt. Hector Boeth. Scotor. Hi≈øtor. Georg. Buchan. in Donald. Raph. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Scotland. auncient and late, Catholiks and Prote≈øtants freely and plainely confe≈ø≈øe, that they receaued not the faith of Chri≈øt, vntill the time of Pope victor, and their King Donaldus, the generall conuer≈øion of the Brittans being prefected before vnder S. Eleutherius, and S. Lucius King of Britaine. So they as generally confe≈ø≈øe, and acknowledge they had no Bishop, or Epi≈øcopall See, among them vntill in Diocle≈øian his Per≈øecution, S. Amphibalus was their fir≈øt Bishop, S. Amphibolus a Britan, the fir≈øt Bishop of the Scots in the time of Diocle≈øian his Per≈øecution. and his See the fir≈øt among them in the Ile of Man, they then hauing no Epi≈øcopall See or Citie within the Brittish continent at that time to place him, or any other in.

5. And allthough ≈øome Scottish writers labour to proue, that they were ≈øeated in the continent of greate Britaine ≈øooner, then the time I haue limited vnto them, and were by Maximus vtterly bannished hence, euen with their Bishops and Monks; this ≈øo ea≈øy and ≈øodaine bannishment of them all generally, which they confe≈ø≈øe, to haue bene done by an Edict or Proclamation of Maximus, proueth they were rather in ≈øome few companies entered, a litle before, then ≈øeated heare: and after their bannishment hence, that part where they then were and now are, was left onely to the old Inhabitants thereof, the Brittans, and ≈øome Picts, there continuing ≈øtill by Maximus his
permi≈ø≈øion. This their owne Hi≈øtorians generally acknowledge: and further, that S. Palladius ≈øent vnto the Scots, in the fifth Age by Pope Caele≈øtinus, was the fir≈øt Bishop they had ≈øent vnto them by ≈øuch power: which doth litle agree with their conceipt of theire Bishops heare in the time of Maximus, except they will yeeld, that as their temporall people were heare then vniu≈øt Intruders vpon the Brittans, Soe their pretended Bishops were without due ≈øpirituall and Papall allowance, and ≈øo were from hence bannished and exiled. But we are fully a≈ø≈øured before, that this part of Britaine beyonde The Britans then inha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ting where it is now called Scotland, had a Bishop, or Bishops in this time, and where. the wall, had euen in this time of Pope Eleutherius and King Lucius Epi≈øcopall Sees, and Bishops, at the lea≈øt one Bishops See, and Bishop, with Prei≈øts and Clergie men: for all our Antiquaries haue a≈ø≈øured & deliuered for an vndoubted truth vnto vs before, that in this time all the Temples of the Flamens in Britaine, without any LimitatioÃÑ, more in Loegria, & Cambria, then in Albania, were changed into Epi≈øcopall Sees, and Bishops with Prei≈øts and other Clergie men placed in them. Soe we are a≈ø≈øured by all Kinde of Hi≈øtories, auncient, late, Catholike and Prote≈øtant: That in Albania now Scotland, Edenburgh was an auncient Flamens Citie, and Re≈øidence, and ≈øo now conuerted to be a Bishops See. And by Foundation being of the ≈øame Antiquitie with Ranulp. Higede. Polichron. l. 1. Hector. Boeth. declarat. Scotiae. Regionum. ante Hi≈øt. Scotor. Guliel. Malm. l. 3. de Pontif. Ranulp. Higed. Polychron. l. 1. c. 48. Stow Hi≈øt. Britans. Yorke, both of them builded by one and the ≈øame Brittish King Ebrancus. And the old Flamens Citie Alcluid, or Alclutht was al≈øo, founded by the ≈øame King of Britaine. There is que≈øtion where this Citie for certaine was, but all agree, neare that wall of Diui≈øion, and ≈øo the priuiledges and power thereof, mo≈øt probably extended on both ≈øides of that Diui≈øion: The Citie Caerliel or Lugubalia was a place of this Prerogatiue, builded by Leil the ≈øeuenth in number of the Brittish Kings, and out of doubt had power, and prerogatiue in both ≈øides of the wall, both in Loegria and Albania, hauing as our Antiquaries deliuer, and experience yet proueth, in it part of that famous wall of ≈øeperation: habet haec vrbs aliquam partem illius Muri famo≈øi qui tran≈øcindit Northumbriam.
