Ranulphus Higeden and others placeth an old Citie vrbs Beble, vrbs regia, a Regall Citie vpon the Ryuer Twyde, ≈øuper ripam Twidi, which diuideth England and Scotland, and if it was a Flamens, and Bishops See, as the auncient glory of it per≈øuadeth to thinke, the Iuri≈ødiction of it mu≈øt needs extend into Albania.

6. Be≈øides we finde both in Prote≈øtant, and other Antiquaries, to ≈øpeake in their words, that 800. yeares before the comming of Chri≈øt, Cunedagius King of all Britaine builded a Temple of Mars at Perche, that is now S. Ihons Towne in Scotland, and placed there a Flamine. Therefore we may not ≈øingularly deny vnto this olde Citie, and Flamens Seate, which Antiquaries generally grant vnto all ≈øuch in this time, to haue bene changed into a Bishops See. And Seuerus who cau≈øed the wall of ≈øeperation to be made or finished, and defended, comming hither after the death of King Lucius, when this change of Temples into Epi≈øcopall Sees was generally made and confirmed, this Temporall ≈øeperation could not in any re≈øpect hinder the exten≈øion, and practi≈øe of ≈øpirituall power, and Iuri≈ødiction, at that ≈øetling and e≈øtablishing it heare generally in Britaine. And the Scottish Hi≈øtorians them≈øelues, when they come to make Relation of their Conuer≈øion in the time of Pope Victor, after S. Eleutherius time, and after the Brittans, and Britaine had generally receaued the faith of Chri≈øt, and all Eccle≈øia≈øticall matters heare e≈øtablished, they neither ≈øay, that any one Bishop was ≈øent vnto them by Pope Victor, but rather the Countrarye, when it is hard to finde in Antiquities how any
greate, and temporally independing people, or Nation, ≈øuch as the Scots then clay me to haue bene, except they were ≈øubiected to other Bishops, to rule and gouerne them in ≈øpirituall affaires, which is properly belonging to that highe ≈øpirituall dignitie, were conuerted without a Bishop, or Bishops.

7. And when S. Victor Pope ≈øent Preachers vnto them, they doe ≈øay, that he ≈øent them vnto them in, and throughout Albania, as if they, and not the Brittans had then po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and inhabited there: but they ≈øay, the Scots were then taught and in≈øtructed by Prei≈øts, which Pope Victor ≈øent to Veremund. & Hect. Boeth. l. 5. Scot. Hi≈øt. preach the Gho≈øpell of Chri≈øt vnto the vttermo≈øt part of Albion, Sacerdotibus praeceptoribus, quos Victor Pontifex Maximus ad Christi dogma propalandum, in extremam mi≈øerat Albionem; which furthe≈øt part of Albion is 300. miles di≈øtant, from that part of Albania, which ioyned with Loegria, England. Therefore we ≈øee clearely, that the Scots onely then liued in the furthe≈øt and mo≈øt remote parte of Albion, or ≈øome Ilands thereof, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed not our greate Albania, the Brittans Country, and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: and in ≈øuch ≈øen≈øe they may call their ≈ømall place, or places of aboude Scotia, Scots land, which could Io≈øephus orat. ad Iudaeos apud Ege≈øipp. l. 5. c. 15. yet be very ≈ømall when Io≈øephus in the Age before, had te≈øtified that it had no land at all: Scotia terris nihil debet: of which, and their place of habitation at land, I shall ≈øpeake more when I come to their Conuer≈øion in the time, and by the meanes and help of Pope Victor, in the beginning of the next Age; And for this pre≈øent, and my purpo≈øe now concerning the Conuer≈øion of the Brittans in Albania, this which I haue ≈øaide, ≈øufficeth to let vs be a≈ø≈øured, it was effected in the ≈øame time, and manner, as the other of our other Brittans in Loegria and Cambria, and by the ≈øame meanes, Mi≈ø≈øion, and Apo≈øtolike men, ≈øent and directed hither, and heare their ≈øacred Actions, and labours were confirmed by the highe≈øt Papall power of holy Pope Eleutherius.

div.head: THE XXVII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF DIVERS BOOKES OR WRITINGS OF S. Phaganus, Damianus, Eluanus, Meduuinus, and others: Charters and Immunities of Pope Eleutherius, and King Lucius: the Scripturs heare receaued in the old Latine Tran≈ølation, and the ≈øame Canon of them, which Catholiks now ob≈øerue, and followe.

div.p:
WHEN our holy Eccle≈øia≈øticall ≈øtate was thus ≈øetled in Britaine, that the memory and ob≈øeruation thereof might be more firmely fixed and impre≈ø≈øed in the vnder≈øtandings, and wills of men to haue duely in minde, and performe tho≈øe duties which particularly belonged vnto them in this Kinde, the≈øe holy Legats, as both Catholike and Prote≈øtant Antiquaries deliuer, committed the≈øe their Acts to writing, by which meanes they came, and not onely by Tradition, to the knowledge of Po≈øteritie; and the Popes of Rome (to write in a Prote≈øtant Bishops phra≈øe) tooke the≈øe their proceedings heare in Britaine, of all kingdomes their fir≈øt begotten
child in Chri≈øt, as a Patterne, to diuide other Prouinces in to Parishes and Dioce≈ø≈øes, Io. Bal. l. de Script. Brit. cent. 1. in Eluan. as they had done heare. Quum in fine e≈ø≈øent omnia ordinatione quadam per Fugatium & Damianum in rem Chri≈øtianam permutata, vt & apud Po≈øteros clariora perdurarent, membranis Eluanus & Meduinus dederunt Acta per Legatos l 1. 1. Inde ad nos, & non alio medio peruenerunt. Ex hoc & ≈øimilibus fundamentis, caepere po≈øtea Romanorum Pontifices occa≈øionem Prouincias diuidendi in Paraecias & Dioece≈øes. A late Catholike Collector of holy Writers of this Nation, ≈øaith, that Eluanus did write one Booke of the Originall of the Brittish Church: Eluanus Io. Pit≈øeus l. de Illu≈øtr. Britan. Script. aetate 2. in Eluan. & Meduino. Antiq. Gla≈øt. Manu≈øcript. S. Patri. Epi≈øtol. Capgrau. in S. Patricio. Leland. in Arthur. a≈ø≈øert. ≈øcrip≈øi≈ø≈øe perhibetur, de origine Eccle≈øiae Britannicae librum vnum. And that Meduinus wrote a Booke of the Acts of Fugatius, and Damianus in Britaine. Meduinus Po≈øteris tradidit Fugatij & Damiani ge≈øta in Britannia, librum vnum. The old Manu≈øcript Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury make mention of three Bookes founde there, all which, or parts of euery of them, were writen in this time. The fir≈øt is called, Scripta Sanctorum Phagani & Deruiani. The writings of the Saints Phaganus and Deruianus. The ≈øecond, had among other things, how the≈øe holy Legats procured 10. yeares Indulgence to that holy place. The third was, Volumen, a Volume, wherein were writen the Acts of the Apo≈øtles, and the Acts, and ge≈øts of S. Phaganus, and Deruianus. Volumen vnum in quo ≈øcripti erant actus Apo≈øtolorum pariter cum Actibus & ge≈øtis Sanctorum Phagani & Deruiani.

2. I haue mentioned before, how King Lucius wrote diuers Epi≈øtles to the Pope, or Popes of Rome in his time, about the ≈øetling of Chri≈øtian Religion in this kingdome. And as S. Eleutherius Pope of Rome directed him by the Coun≈øaile and adui≈øe of his Clergie, and Nobles, he cau≈øed a collection, and correction of Lawes temporall, to be compiled, and published, to gouerne The Chri≈øtian munifi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nce and bouÃÑ tic of King Lucius in this time. his Chri≈øtian kingdome by, which continued long after in writing, among many both Brittish and other Kings of this Nation, allthough with ≈øome change or addition, as the times and other circum≈øtances required in ≈øuch ca≈øes. This holy King al≈øo granted, made, and ≈øigned many writings, Charters, and Donations for the defence, maintenance, and pre≈øeruation of Religion, and the cheife Teachers, and Profe≈ø≈øours thereof, as to the Vniuer≈øitie of Cambridge, the Schoole of Bangor, Mona≈øtery of Shaftesbury, and ≈øuch others, and to euery Archiepi≈øcopall and Epi≈øcopall See in Britaine, both for the a≈ø≈øuring the old Reuenewes, and Priuiledges of the Archflamens, and Flamens, as others new and more ample, which he conferred vnto them, and ≈øuch as should ≈øitt and ≈øucceede in them for euer. Pope Eleutherius granted many priuiledges, immunities, and Indulgences heare.

3. In this time al≈øo the Rule of the holy Religeous men, I haue ≈øpoken of before, was written, and ob≈øerued by them. And be≈øides the generall confirmation of Pope Eleutherius, which I haue formerly ≈øpoken of, for the ratifying and approuing the proceedings of his Legats, he granted very many other particular Ratifications, and Immunities to certaine Par≈øons, and Places heare: ≈øuch was his Bull of Confirmation, which the Cambridge Antiquaries contend he granted to that Vniuer≈øitie: ≈øuch his grant of 10. yeares of Indulgence at the reque≈øt of his Legats to the pilgrims, that deuoutely vi≈øited the old Church of Gla≈øtenbury: as likewi≈øe, that of 30. yeares pardon to all Bishops, that should with deuotion come one Pilgrimadge to the Chappell of S. Michaell The old Decrees of the primatiue Popes receaued heare in this time. there, as the Antiquities of that place giue te≈øtimony.

4. The Order of the holy Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and other publike ≈øeruice of the Church deliuered, and e≈øtablished heare at that time, was the Roman Order, which the holy Legats our Apo≈øtles brought from Rome, who al≈øo
published heare the Decrees of the holy Popes from S. Peter to their time, many of which, ≈øo farre as our Prote≈øtant writers would giue mee leaue, and allowance vnto, I haue remembred before. This time and Age al≈øo is the Eleuther. Epi≈øt. ad Regem LuciuÃÑ. Leg. S. Edw. Lambert. de leg. Antiq. Godwin. Conuer≈ø. of Brit. fir≈øt, wherein eyther the Scripturs of the Old, or New Te≈øtament, were by any auncient Authour receaued, and published in Britaine. For S. Eleutherius Pope in his Epi≈øtle to King Lucius maketh it, but a nuper, late thing to haue the holy Scripturs in this kingdome. By which al≈øo, as by the knowne ignorance of the Britans in tho≈øe dayes, eyther in Greeke, or Hebrew language, it is euident they were receaued heare in the Latine tongue, vnder≈øtood The holy Scriptures receaued heare then, in the Latine toÃÑgue, with the ≈øame Canon of Bookes which the Roman Church now v≈øeth. by all the learned of this kingdome of Britaine. Likewi≈øe we learne by the ≈øame part of Pope Eleutherius his Epi≈øtle to King Lucius, that the Primitiue Church both at Rome, and Britaine then receaued that Canon of holy Scripturs, and tho≈øe Bookes to be Canonicall, which the pre≈øent Roman Church embraceth for ≈øuch, and not that maymed, and mangled new Canon which our English Prote≈øtants with ≈øome others of their Schoole, would onely haue receaued for that peece of his Epi≈øtle, which is left vnto vs, being very short, and very few citations of Scripturs v≈øed in it, onely one out of the New Te≈øtament, and not aboue 4. or 5. out of the Old: yet among the≈øe ≈øo few, he citeth for Canonicall Scripture ≈øuch as the≈øe men di≈øallow for ≈øuch, namely the≈øe words by their Prote≈øtants Tran≈ølation: according to King Salomon: wi≈øedome will not enter into a spitefull ≈øoule nor inhabite in a bodie ≈øubiect to ≈øinne. This is found onely in the ≈øecond Chapter of the Booke of Wi≈øedome: which with Sap. 2. diuers others the ≈øixt Article of our Parlament Prote≈øtant Religion di≈øalloweth to be holy. And S. Gildas the mo≈øt auncient Writer left vnto vs, citeth Articul. 6. of Prot. Relig. Gild. l. de excid. & conq. Britan. as parts of holy Scripturs, receaued by our Primatiue Chri≈øtian Brittans, diuers Bookes of holy Scripturs, which the new Religion doth not admite. The old Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury, which more plainely, and fully ≈øet downe the Apo≈øtolike Labours, and Trauailes of the≈øe holy Legats, then any other Monument we haue, and of many glorious Saints both of the Di≈øciples of S. Io≈øeph and the Apo≈øtles, and of the≈øe Legats buried at Gla≈øtenbury, and the long liuing of S. Damianus and Faganus there 9. yeares, and their greate deuotion to that holy place, and how theire Di≈øciples there liuing Religious Eremits by Succe≈ø≈øion 267. yeares vntill S. Patrike his comming thither, died and were buryed there, but whether the Legats them≈øelues there were interred, or returned thence, they doe not deliuer, but leaue it doubtfull: hij vero duo ≈øancti regionem i≈øtam in principio ad fidem Chri≈øtianam conuerterunt, ≈øed vtrum ibi requie≈øcunt, vel ind√® redierunt, non inuenimus ≈øcriptum. Ibi multi ex Di≈øcipulis Sanctorum Phagani & Deruiani requie≈øcunt, qui per ducentos ≈øexaginta & ≈øeptem annos quidem alij po≈øt alios v≈øque Aduentum ≈øancti Patricij in praefata In≈øula ≈øicut Anachoritae habitauerunt. And ≈øo I end this ≈øecond Age.

div.trailer: The end of this Second Age.

div.p: THE ECCLESIASTICALL HISTORIE OF GREAT BRITAINE.
THE THIRD AGE.

div.head: THE ECCLESIASTICALL HISTORIE OF GREAT BRITAINE.
THE THIRD AGE.
THE I. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN IS DELIVERED, THAT S. VICTOR being now Pope, Seuerus Emperour, and S. Lucius yet King of Britaine, but shortly dying, S. Victor was Supreame in gouernment of the whole Church of Christ, in A≈øia, Afrike and Europe, and particularly in Britaine, which ≈øo acknowledged, and receaued from him the true ob≈øeruation of Ea≈øter, as it had done with other Catholike cu≈øtomes, from S. Eleutherius before.

div.p:
AS I clo≈øed vp the ≈øecond Age with the Renowned Pope S. Victor, Seuerus Emperour of Rome, and that our mo≈øt Illu≈øtrious & relucent Lucius King of Britaine: So I mu≈øt open my way, and pa≈ø≈øadge to the Third and next Centurye, by the continuance Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. An. 194. Baron. Tom. 2. An. 194. Seuer. Binius Tom. 1. Concil. in Vict. Iacob. Gordon. An. 194. Matth. We≈øtm. An. 198. Florent. Wigornien. An. 199. of the ≈øame Rulers in the worlde. S. Victor began his Papacie in, or about the yeare of Chri≈øt 194. as Marianus and diuers others write. But our Monks and Contrimen Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, and Florentius Wigornien≈øis giue him a later entrance to the See Apo≈øtolike. The former ≈øaith, it was in the yeare of Grace 198. Anno gratiae 198. Victor Romanae Sedis Pontifex effectus. The other ≈øaith, that Pope Eleutherius liued vntill the yeare after this 199, when Victor was cho≈øen. Martinus Polonus maketh him not Pope before the beginning of this Age, in the yeare of Chri≈øt 203. And therefore finding no memorable thing of this Pope belonging to the
Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hi≈øtory of Britaine vntill this time, I doe heare fir≈øt remember him.

2. This holy Pope in his Epi≈øtle to Theop ‚Ä¢ ilus Patriarke of Alexandria, Victor. Epi≈øt. ad Theoph. Alexand. Tom. 1. Concil. Dama≈øus in Victor. Papa. Florent. Wigor. in Chronic. An. 200. Marian. Scot. aetate 6. An. 192. ≈øtileth him≈øelfe Archbishop of the Roman, and Vniuer≈øall Church: Victor Romanae ac vniuer≈øalis Eccle≈øiae Archiepi≈øcopus. This Epi≈øtle with this ≈øtile of Archbishop of the Vniuer≈øall Church, as our auncient and learned Hi≈øtorian Florentius Wigornien≈øis witne≈ø≈øeth, was written in the yeare of Chri≈øt 200, the 13. of the Calends of Augu≈øt: Victor Romanae ac vniuer≈øalis Eccle≈øiae Archiepi≈øcopus Theophilo, & Fratribus Alexandrae Chri≈øto famulantibus, ≈øalutem in Domino: haec Epi≈øtola data est 13. Calendas Augusti. Our learned and renowned Countryman al≈øo S. Marianus hath the ≈øame words, concerning this Supreame Spirituall ≈øtile, & power of Pope Victor ouer the Vniuer≈øall Church, onely differing in the yeare from Florentius: Victor Romae ac vniuer≈øalis Eccle≈øiae Archiepi≈øcopus. To this dignitie of Supreamacy both claymed, & exerci≈øed Matthias Flacius Illyric. Io. WigaÃÑ dus, Mat. Iudex. & Ba≈øil. Faber. cent. 2. c. 8. col. 155. & cent. 3. col. 168. Barn. in Vit. Pontif. Rom. in Victore. Io. Bal. l. 1. de Act. Pontif. Roman. in eod. Robert. Barnes ≈øupr. Dama≈øus, ≈øeu Ana≈øta≈øius in Victore. Rob. Barn. l. de Vit. Rom. Pont. in Pio 1. Florent. Wigor. in Chron. Ann. 202. Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. An. 194. Robert. Barnes ≈øupr. in Victore. S. Victor. Epi≈øt. 1. Decret. ad Theophilum Alexandriae Epi≈øcopum apud Sur. & Seuerin. Bin. to. 1. Conc. Magdeb. cent. 2. Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. an. 194. Mart. PoloÃÑ Supput. in Vict. Florent. Wigor. An. 200. Robert. Barnes l. de Vit. Pont. in Victore. by this holy Pope S. Victor, both forreine and English Prote≈øtants giue full allowance, when they plainely confe≈ø≈øe that he excommunicated the Churches of A≈øia, for their ob≈øtinate error in the Pa≈øchall ob≈øeruation. Victor mi≈øsis literis, fratres omnes A≈øiaticos, & Eccle≈øias vicinas √† ≈øe excommunicatione Eccle≈øiae exclu≈øos & reiectos palam denuntiat. The ≈øame Title and preeminent power he both claymed, and executed by the≈øe men, when as they te≈øtifie, he excommunicated Theodorus for affirming Chri≈øt was onely man: Victor Theodorum dicentem Christum purum hominem ≈øine Deo e≈ø≈øe, Eccle≈øia eiecit. And Interdicted all them, which vpon an Iniury done, would not be reconciled to him that had hurt them. Sacris Interdixit illis, qui ob illatam Iniuriam reconciliari nollent ei, qui lae≈øit. And yet as both the Prote≈øtants, and all Catholiks acknowledge, he did not make any new ordinance in this, but as S. Pius had done before: Pius Pa≈øcha die Dominica e≈ø≈øe celebranda in≈øtituit. And his Immediate Predece≈ø≈øor Eleutherius our Apo≈øtle had done the ≈øame: Victor Papa d ‚Ä¢ tis lat√® libellis con≈øtituit vt Pa≈øcha Die Dominico, ≈øicut & Praece≈ø≈øor eius Eleutherius, √† 14. luna primi Men≈øis v≈øque in 21. celebraretur. And the fir≈øt generall Councell of Nice, a our Prote≈øtants confe≈ø≈øe, did approue this Decree of S. Victor. In Niceno Concilio Victoris Decretum approbatum e≈øt. Et cautum est, vt Pa≈øcha die Dominico celebraretur, and was heare receaued in our Britaine. And this is manife≈øt, in that Decretall Epi≈øtle of Pope Victor, receaued by Prote≈øtants before, where he plainely ≈øaith, that his Predece≈ø≈øors had commanded before him, that which he did for keeping Ea≈øter. Celebritatem ≈øancti Pa≈øchae Die Dominico agi debere, & Praedece≈ø≈øores no≈øtri iam ≈øtatuerunt, & nos illud vobis eadem Die celebrari ≈øolemniter mandamus, quia non decet, vt membra √† capite di≈øcrepent, nec contraria gerant. Where we ≈øee, he calleth him≈øelfe the head of the Patriarke, and Clergie of Alexandria, and them his members. And giuing other Rules in that Epi≈øtle both about ≈øolemne Bapti≈øme in the time of Ea≈øter, and not ≈øoleÃÑne in time of nece≈ø≈øitie, and not intermedling in Bishops cau≈øes, without the allowance of the See Apo≈øtolike of Rome, prouing it was ≈øo from the Apo≈øtles time, & confirming his Decree both by the words of Chri≈øt to S. Peter, and the fir≈øt Epi≈øtle of S. Clement, which ≈øome haue que≈øtioned, he vtterly forbiddeth any man to alter or gaine≈øay the≈øe Decrees. Haec vero ≈øtatuta nulla debent improbitate conuelli, nulla nouitate mutari: quia alia e≈øt ratio cau≈øarum ≈øaecularium, alia diuinarum. Ea vos iudicare, ad Apo≈øtolicam delatum e≈øt ≈øedem, quae praeter no≈øtram vobis d ‚Ä¢ finire non licet Authoritatem, id e≈øt Epi≈øcoporum cau≈øas. Vnde ita con≈øtitutum liquet a tempore Apostolorum, & deinceps placuit, vt accu≈øatus
vel iudicatus a Comprouincialibus in aliqua cau≈øa Epi≈øc√≥pus, licenter appellet, & adeat Apo≈øtolicae Sedis Pontificem, qui aut per ≈øe, out per Vicarios ≈øuos eius retractari negotium procuret. Et dum, iterato Iudicio, Pontifex cau≈øam ≈øuam agit, nullus alius in eius loco ponatur, aut ordinetur Epi≈øcopus: Quoniam quanquam a Comprouincialibus Epi≈øcopis accu≈øati ca ‚Ä¢ ≈øam Pontificis ≈øcrutari liceat, non tamen definiri, inco ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ lto Romano Pontifice permi≈ø≈øum e≈øt, cum B. Petro Apo≈øtolo non ab alio, quam ab ip≈øo Matt ‚Ä¢ . 16. dictum ≈øit Domino: Quaecunque ligaueris ≈øuper terram, erunt ligata & in caelo: & quaecumque ≈øolueris ≈øuper terram, erunt ≈øoluta & in caelo. Et alibi in In≈øtitutis legitur Epi≈øt. 1. ClemeÃÑt. Apo≈øtolicis. Si quis putauerit ≈øe a proprio Metropolitano grauari, apud Patriarcham vel Primatem Diaece≈øeos, aut penes vniuer≈øalis Apo≈øtolicae Eccle≈øiae iudicetur ≈øedem. Nihil aliud est fratres, talis prae≈øumptio, ni≈øi Apo≈øtolorum ≈øuorumque ≈øucce≈ø≈øorum terminos trangredi, eoruÃÑque Decreta violare. Culpantur enim vt ≈øcriptum e≈øt, fratres, qui aliter circa Epi≈øcopos iudicare prae≈øumunt, quam Apo≈øtolicae Sedis Papae fieri placuerit. Et quis e≈øt qui iudicat eum, quem Dominus ≈øibi, & huic ≈øanctae Sedi re≈øeruari voluit iudicandum? And as this holy and learned Pope, and Saint, claymed and exerci≈øed that highe≈øt ≈øpirituall power and Iuri≈ødiction ouer the Churches of Europe, where he liued, and A≈øia, he tooke al≈øo vpon him the ≈øame ≈øupereminent ≈øuperioritie ouer the Clergie and Churches of Afrike, the other part of the world, commanding them to peace, and concorde and vnitie in Religion, and either actually excommunicating, or threatning excommunication Victor Epi≈øt. ad Vniuer≈øos Epi≈øcopos Africae. Tom. 1. con. & apud Magdebur. cent. 2. vnto tho≈øe, that should di≈øobey him in tho≈øe commands: perlatum e≈øt ad Sedem Apo≈øtolicam, aliquos ve≈øtrum, nocere fratres velle, & vt cadant, decertare. Similiter in Sacramentis di≈øcrepare, & ob id contentiones & aemulationes inter vos fieri, a quibus di≈ø≈øen≈øionibus vos auertere, & in his concordare, & opem ferre vici≈øsim, mandamus nam ≈øi hoc agere cit√≤ neglexeritis, & vici≈øsim reconciliari non ≈øtudueritis, ab Apo≈øtolicae Sedis & totius Eccle≈øiae communione vos pelli non dubitetis. where he expre≈ø≈øely declareth his Authoritie, as Pope of Rome, to excommunicate the Bishops and Churches of Afrike, as he had done to tho≈øe of A≈øia, both from the Apo≈øtolike, Roman, and Catholike Church of the whole worlde.

3. Now for his Power ouer the Churches of Europe, wherein his Apo≈øtolike Roman See, was by all Antiquaries, Catholiks and Prote≈øtants euer the onely cheife Apo≈øtolike Metropolitan Church, it cannot be que≈øtioned, when we shall finde, how euen by Amba≈ø≈øadge and entreaty, he ≈øent Apo≈øtolike men into the furthe≈øt parts of this Iland to conuert it to Chri≈øt. And Holinsh. Hi≈øtor. of Scotland p. 68. in K. Donaldus. our Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians confe≈ø≈øe, of this holy Pope, that being glad to encrea≈øe the faith of Chri≈øt through all parts of the world, ≈øent into Scotland ≈øuch well di≈øpo≈øed par≈øons, as he thought mo≈øt fitt for that purpo≈øe. The Scottish Hi≈øtorians ≈øay, he ≈øent his Preachers to the vttermo≈øt parts of this We≈øterne and Europian parts Veremundus apud Hector Boeth. & idem. l. 5. Scotor. Hi≈øt. prope finem. of the world, and the Barbarous Inhabitans learned Diuinitie of tho≈øe Apo≈øtolike Preachers which he ≈øent. Incaepere & no≈øtri tum primum, ≈øacras colere litteras, ≈øacerdotibus praeceptoribus, quos Victor Pontifex Maximus, ad Chri≈øt dogma propalandam in extremam mi≈øerat Albionem. This will ≈øufficiently declare, that the Primatiue Chri≈øtian Britans, and Scots which were conuerted to Chri≈øtian Religion, by the≈øe two renowned Popes, and Saints, S. Eleutherius and S. Victor, which ≈øo clearely and earne≈øtly declared, and commanded the true Apo≈øtolicall ob≈øeruation of Ea≈øter, and had receaued al≈øo the fir≈øt generall Councell of Nice, where the ≈øame was defined, and published to the whole Chri≈øtian world, did not receaue their erroneous Pa≈øchall ob≈øeruance from their fir≈øt Mai≈øters, and In≈øtructers in Religion, but by long later accidents,
and ignorant Mi≈øinformations. Of Seuerus the Emperour, whether he was di≈øcended of our Britans Race, or other, I shall more particular entreate, when I shall bring him to continue long time, and to die in Britaine. Onely Method. apud Mar Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. & Marian. ib. an. 203. in Se√ªero Martin. Polon. Supputat. col. 51. florent. Wigorn. Chronic. an. 189. vel 211. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 195. Manu≈øcript. of S. Peters Church in Cornhill Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 201. heare I ≈øay that by common coÃÑ≈øent he was a greate Per≈øecutour of Chri≈øtians, as both our owne writers, and others te≈øtifie, and therevpon ≈øtiled the fift per≈øecuting Emperour after Nero. Po≈øt Neronem, Seuerus quintam Per≈øecutionem in Chri≈øtianos exicita ‚Ä¢ it, plurimique Sanctorum per diuer≈øas Prouincias Martyrio coronantur. Concerning our mo≈øt Noble Protochri≈øtian King Lucius, as we are come to Ioye of his Immortall glory, and honour in heauen, by his happy Tran≈ølation from a tran≈øitory terre≈øtriall, to an eternall cele≈øtiall and neuer cea≈øing kingdome, ≈øo we mu≈øt bewayle the vn≈øpeakeable want, and lo≈ø≈øe, which this kingdome long time by many mi≈øeries, and afflictions ≈øuffered by the death of ≈øo holy, iu≈øt, and prudent a Prince, and Ruler hapning by the mo≈øt diligent Calculatours of time we haue, in the beginning and fir≈øt yeare of this Age. Anno gratiae 201. Inclitus Britannorum Rex Lucius in bonis actibus a≈ø≈øumptus ab hac vita migrauit ad Chri≈øtum.

div.head: THE II. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE TIME, AND PLACE OF KING LVCIVS his death; That he did not die, or was martyred in Germanie. Neither had he any Si≈øter called Emerita martyred there. It was an other Prince of Britaine after this time. This our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King Lucius died at Glouce≈øter in Britaine.

div.p:
1. BEING come to celebrate the day of the death of our glorious King Lucius, for the Ioy that he enioyed thereby, and bewayle The time of King Lucius death. it, for the vn≈øpeakeable lo≈ø≈øe this Nation receaued thereby, we are to fall into the like difficulties, both of the time, and place Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 201. Manu≈øcript. Antiq. Eccle≈ø. S. Petri in Cornhill Londin. Matth. Paris in Hi≈øt. maiori apud Io. Caium l. 1. Ant. Cantab. Acad. pag. 109. Martin. Polon. Supputat. an. 188. in Eleutherio. thereof, which we pa≈ø≈øed for the beginning of his Reigne and Conuer≈øion to Chri≈øt, before handled and di≈ø≈øolued: yet for the time of his death, the auncient Manu≈øcript of S. Peters Church in Cornehill in London, and Matthew the Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter haue giuen vs particular intelligence, that it was in the fir≈øt yeare of this third hundred of yeares. Matthew Paris writeth the ≈øame. And Martinus Polonus, that te≈øtifieth King Lucius wrote to Pope Eleutherius concerning his Conuer≈øion in the yeare 188. mu≈øt needs giue euidence to that opinion, for certaine it is by all Antiquities, that King Lucius liued many yeares after that, to ≈øee his kingdome conuerted to Chri≈øt. And our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries with the be≈øt Authours (as they ≈øay) which confe≈ø≈øe this fir≈øt writing of King Lucius to Pope Eleutherius was not before the 178. yeare of Chri≈øt: Haec contigerunt anno √† Chri≈øti aduentu in carnem 178. vt potiores commemorant Annales. For William of Malmesbury Io. Bal. l. de ≈øcript. Britan. cent. 1. in Lucio Pio. Caius ≈øupr. pag. 111. in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory of Gla≈øtenbury, and other old Antiquities thereof, doe proue, that after S. Damianus and Faganus had conuerted this kingdome, by the Papall Commi≈ø≈øion of S. Eleutherius, they did continue 9.
yeares at the lea≈øt at Gla≈øtenbury, King Lucius ≈øtill liuing, and reigning heare. Guliel. Malm. l. de Ant. Coen. Gla≈øton. Antiq. Manu≈øcrip. tab. fixae Gla≈øt. Polid. Virgil. Hi≈øt. in Lucio. Lilius Hi≈øt. & alij Hollinshed Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 19. Stowe Hi≈øt. an. 179. in Lucius. Io. Bal. l. de Scriptor. Britan. centur. 1. in Lucio Pio. Author of the Engl. Martyrol. 3. day of December. Martyrol. Rom. die 3. Decemb. & alij. Polidor, Lilly, Hollinshed, Stowe, and other Prote≈øtants leane to this opinion.

2. About the day of his death there is better Agreement, for both tho≈øe which ≈øay he died in Britaine, both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants, as al≈øo they which deny it, affirming he died in Germany, agree, that this was vpon the third day of December: Lucius Pius Claudioce≈øtriae tertia die Decembris vitae ≈øuae finem accepit. So writeth a Prote≈øtant Bishop of England, with others. And the Roman Martyrologe with others, which otherwi≈øe write of the place of his death con≈øent: Tertio Nonas Decembris Lucij Britannorum Regis, qui primus ex ijs Regibus Chri≈øti fidem ≈øu≈øcepit, tempore Eleutherij Papae.

3. The place and manner of his death is more que≈øtioned: diuers forreyne writers contend, that he for≈øooke his kingdome, and being made a Prei≈øt, and afterward Bishop, preached to the Rhetians in Germany, was Bishop there of Curre, and died by Martyrdome. The Roman Martyrologe inclineth to this opinion, making his death to haue bene Curiae in Germania: At Curre in Germanie, ≈øaying plainely as I haue cited before, that this Lucius which died there, was the fir≈øt of the Kings of the Britans which receaued the faith of Chri≈øt in the time of Pope Eleutherius. This is the greate≈øt Authoritie I finde for this opinion, yet this Authour doth not take vpon him to ≈øay, that he was eyther Bishop, or Martyr, which he would not, neyther by his Order and rule of writing, which might not omit ≈øuch things, could haue omitted, if he had knowne or probably thought eyther of them to haue bene true. And whereas this Authour confidently ≈øaith of King Lucius, that he was primus ex ijs King Lucius did not preach in Germanie, neyther was he martyred or died there. Regibus qui Chri≈øti fidem ≈øu≈øcepit, the fir≈øt of the Brittish Kings which receaued the faith of Chri≈øt, it doth formerly appeare, that diuers Authours euen of this Nation which might better learne the truth hereof then a ≈øtranger, could haue written otherwi≈øe both of Aruiragus, Marius, and Coillus Brittish Kings. And I haue giuen ≈øufficient warrant before, that for the faith and Religion of King Lucius in particular, it was Chri≈øtian, before the Papacy of S. Eleutherius, and the generall Conuer≈øion of the kingdome of Britaine, and not of King Lucius, was wrought in the time of Pope Eleutherius: And yet this Authour ab≈øolutely affirmeth that King Lucius him≈øelfe did receaue the faith of Chri≈øt in the time of Pope Eleutherius: fidem Chri≈øti ≈øu≈øcepit tempore Eleutherij Papae. Neither doth he in that, or any other place make any memory of S. Author of the Engl. Martyrol. ex Ei≈øengren. cent. 2. d. 1. & Breuia. Curien≈øi 4. Decemb. Ca≈øpar Bruch. Catal. Epi≈øcop. Curien. Io. Stumpff. in Rhetia. Magdeburg. cent. Guliel. Ei≈øengr. centenar. 2. Io. Naucler. gener. 6. volum. 8. Petr. de Natal. l. 1. cap. 24. Emerita, ≈øuppo≈øed by ≈øome others, to be Si≈øter to our King Lucius, and departing forth of Britaine with him, to haue bene martyred in Germany, in, or neare Curre in Rhetia, to which in ≈øome Iudgments the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Office of that Church ≈øeemeth to giue allowance, at the lea≈øt for one Lucius regio stemate apud Britannos ortus, borne of the Brittish Kingly Race, and his Si≈øter S. Emerita; but this proueth rather, that it was not S. Lucius our King, but an other of the Kingly Line, which I shall proue hereafter, to haue bene a Sonne of Con≈øtantius, and S. Helena Empre≈ø≈øe, that honour of Britaine, an elder brother to Con≈øtantine the Greate Emperour, who became an holy Clergie man, and preached in tho≈øe parts of Germany. Which together with the likenes, or Identitie of name, Regall Race, and nearnes in blood, gaue occa≈øion to ≈øome to thinke, it was the renowned fir≈øt Brittish Chri≈øtian King of that name which vndertooke that cour≈øe of life and ≈øo ended it there.

4. That our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King Lucius could not be Bishop there, is euident before, when I haue kept him ≈øo long in Britaine, that for Age he was
di≈øabled, for ≈øuch a Iorney. Further they which hold he was Bishop of Churr ‚Ä¢ in Germany, and Martyred there, ≈øay this Martyrdome of his there, was about the yeare of Chri≈øt 182. when I haue proued him liuing, and King ≈øtill in Britaine 9. yeares after. Be≈øides they ≈øay, that S. Emerita his Si≈øter went with him, and was Martyred there al≈øo. But it is euident by our Hi≈øtories, that our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King Lucius had neyther Brother, Si≈øter, nor childe, but he was vnicus patris, and begotten of King Coillus in his old Age, hauing no other childe, Anno gratiae 115. natus e≈øt Coillo, Regi Britonum, vnicus filius, Matth. We≈øtm. an. 115. Pontic. Virun. Hi≈øt. Brit. lib. 4. quem vocauit Lucium, qui factus e≈øt patri gaudium & exultatio, quia in ≈øenectute, & qua≈øi ab haerede de≈øtitutus, genuerat eum. Whereby is euident, that this King Lucius had neyther Brother, nor Si≈øter named Emerita or any other. And with what probabilitie can it be affirmed that a King ≈øo holy, and louing of his Countries good, and quiet, hauing no Chri≈øtiaÃÑ heire to ≈øucceede him, would, or in con≈øcience could for≈øake his natiue Country, and ≈øubiects in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, that were in iu≈øtice belonging to his cheife≈øt chardge, which no other could execute, to preach vnto forreyners, which many of his ≈øubiects and others could, and at his reque≈øt would mo≈øt willingly haue performed. We reade in Hi≈øtories that many de≈øcended of Regall Race, haue in ≈øuch ca≈øes bene taken forth of their Mona≈øteries, and Religeous Conuer≈øation, to gouerne kingdomes, de≈øtitute of heires, but that a King ≈øo vertuous, wi≈øe, louing, and beloued of his Country hauing no ≈øuch heire to ≈øucceede him, but by ≈øuch cour≈øe to expo≈øe and leaue his kingdome to ≈øo many certaine mi≈øeries, & calamities, as fell vpon Britaine by the death of King Lucius, and probably were fore≈øeene of all wi≈øe men, did, might, would, or could take ≈øuch a cour≈øe, Antiquities haue no example, iu≈øtice denieth it, charitie cannot allowe it. Further I shall proue hereafter that S. Emerita called the Si≈øter of S. Lucius, was the Si≈øter of Lucius Sonne of Con≈øtantius, and Helena, and ≈øo neyther daughter of King Coillus, nor Si≈øter to our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King Lucius, and ≈øo he could not be that Lucius which preached in Germany. Aegid. Schudus in de≈øcript. Rhethiae cap. 15.

5. And where they ≈øay, he was Bishop of Curia, Aegidius Schudus a German Writer proueth, that Curia was not then builded, no ≈øuch Citie in that Country, nor long after, and therefore with Ca≈øpar Bruchius in his Catalogue of the Bishops of that Citie, and others as well German and other Writers maketh Ca≈øpar Bruchius in Catal. Epi≈øc. Curien. in Init. the fir≈øt Bishop of that place aboue two hundreds of yeares after the time of our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King Lucius. Bruchius ≈øaith it was not a Bishops See, vntill about the 440. yeare of Chri≈øt: Epi≈øcopatus Churen≈øis vel Curien≈øis in Rhetis vnus ex vetu≈øti≈øsimis Germaniae Epi≈øcopatihus, caepit circa annum Christianae Redemptionis 440. and maketh A≈øimo the fir≈øt and Puricius or Pruricius the ≈øecond Bishop thereof. Thus the≈øe German Writers them≈øelues, and others of them eyther doubt of, or deny that Hi≈øtory. Iohannes Nauclerus much vrged Ioannes Naucl. in Chron. gener. 6. pag. 565. for this Relation, maketh it onely a report, fertur: and ouerthroweth the Hi≈øtory of the Church of Curre, ≈øo much ≈øtood vpon for this matter, in confe≈ø≈øing that by this Hi≈øtory that Lucius, which is ≈øaid to haue preached in Rhetia, was conuerted by S. Timothie the Apo≈øtle S. Paules Scholler, dead long time before our S. Lucius was borne. Seba≈øtian Mun≈øter ≈øaith plainely, that Seba≈øt. Mon≈øter. Co≈ømogr. l. 3. cap. 344. whereas there is a vulgar reporte, √† vulgo per≈øua≈øum habetur (he maketh no more of any Lucius preaching there) that one Lucius peeached in that place, if it were ≈øo, it could not po≈ø≈øibly be our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King Lucius, for he neuer went out of Britaine, but very godly liued and died heare. Britanniae ille Rex qui circiter Annum Domini 190. floruit patriam nequaquam exiens, pi√® apud
≈øuos obdormiuit. Ca≈øpar Bruchius al≈øo doth plainely reiect all that Hi≈øtorie, as Ca≈øpar Bruchius in Catal. Epi≈øc. Curien. prop√® Initium. Manu≈øcr. Gallic. Antiq. An. 296. it is applyed by ≈øome to our King Lucius, and among other rea≈øons addeth that the greate difference of yeares will not permit it to be true, Numerus Annorum non conuenit. An old French Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtorie ioyneth in the ≈øame, and leaueth him liuing, dying, and buried in Britaine. And if we come home to our owne Hi≈øtorians, and Antiquities mo≈øt likely to make the mo≈øt true and King Lucius died and was buried in Gloce≈øter in the Cathedrall Church there. certaine Relation of this their ≈øo renowned King, they ≈øet downe the yeare, the day, and particular place of his death, and the very Church, one of his owne foundation, where his body was enterred. The day and yeare they haue remembred before, the 201. yeare of Chri≈øt, the third day of December. Matth. We≈øtm. ann. 201. Antiq. Eccl. S. Petri in Cornhill Lond. Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 5. c. 1. Ponticus Virun. Brit. Hi≈øt. l. 5. in initio. Matth. We≈øtm. 201. in Chron. Compilatio M. S. de ge≈øt. Brit. & Anglo. in Lucio. Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. Gallicar. Princip. Or que nous ≈øommes. In Lucius. Caxton. Hi≈øtor. part. 4. in K. Lucius. Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. Antiq. in Lucio. Antiquit. Eccl. S. Petri in Cornhill Londini. Harding Cronic. c. 51. f. 44. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. c. 9. ¬ß. 18. Aegidius Schudus de Pri≈øca Rhetia: Hermanus Schedelius c. 3. Stowe & Howes Hi≈øt. Titul. the Romans in Marcus Aurelius Antonius. HarrisoÃÑ De≈øcriptioÃÑ of Britaine. c. 9. S. Lucius body after tran≈ølated to other places, or ≈øome part thereof. For the place our old Brittish Hi≈øtory ≈øaith, he died at Gloce≈øter and was with honour buried there in the Cathedrall Church. In vrbe Claudioce≈øtriae ab hac vita migrauit, & in Eccle≈øia primae Sedis honorific√® ≈øepultus est. So likewi≈øe writeth Ponticus Virunnius; vitam finiuit in vrbe Claudioce≈øtriae ≈øepultus. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øetting downe the time, as before, ≈øaith al≈øo he died at Gloce≈øter, and was honorably buried there in the Cathedrall Church. Inclitus Britannorum Rex Lucius in bonis actibus a≈ø≈øumptus, Claudioce≈øtriae ab hac vita migrauit ad Christum, in Eccle≈øsa primae Sedis honortfic√® ≈øepultus. The ≈øame hath an ould Manu≈øcript called Compilatio de Ge≈øsis Britonum & Anglorum, where, in Lucio is ≈øayed, in vrbe Glouce≈øtriae obijt, & in Eccle≈øia primae Sedis honorific√® ≈øepultus e≈øt. The old Authour of the French Manu≈øcript, which beginneth, or que nous ≈øumes: ≈øaith: at the last he died at Glouce≈øtre, and was interred in the Church of the Cheife See, Del primer See. Our old English Chronicle ≈øaith: he reigned with much honour, and after died, and lieth at Gloce≈øter, ≈øo hath an old Latine Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory: mortuus e≈øt Lucius & ≈øepultus in Claudioce≈øtria. The old Manu≈øcript of S. Peters Church in Cornhill at London auoucheth from diuers Antiquities that he was buried at Glouce≈øter where the Church of S. Francis was after builded, being at the time of his death the Cathedrall and Epi≈øcopall Church of that Citie, as I haue remembred. Ihon Harding al≈øo witne≈ø≈øeth of this Kings death and bury all at Gloce≈øter.
div.q: At Cairglowe buried after his dignitie.
div.p:
6. And not to exclude the te≈øtimony of our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries in this Relation, in their Theater of great Britaine, written and coÃÑpo≈øed by diuers of their be≈øt Hi≈øtorians, and published with their common applau≈øe, and Approbation, they make this Hi≈øtory of King Lucius his death in Britaine a matter without que≈øtion, true, and thus ≈øcoffingly condemne tho≈øe writers Which would carry him to end his dayes in Germanye. That this Lucius should be the Apo≈øtle to the Bauarians, or that his Si≈øter Emerita was crowned with the Flames of Martyrdome fifteene yeares after his death, I leaue to the credit of Aegedius Schudus and Hermannus Scedelius the Reporters. Others of them plainely ≈øay: Lucius was buried at Gloce≈øter. Yet this generall con≈øent of Antiquitie for his fir≈øt buriall at Gloce≈øter doth nothing hinder, but as the kuowne deuotion both of the Britans and Saxons after them towards holy Reliks did often and with greate reuerence and ≈øolemnitie remoue the bodyes of holy Saints, or parts of them for their greater honour. So it might or did after fall out with the whole body of this renowned King, or ≈øome part thereof. And the Tradition of Winche≈øter is, that the whole body of King Lucius, or a greate part thereof, being once remoued before, was the ≈øecond time Tran≈ølated thither, & there lieth in the bodie of the greate Church vnder a marble ≈øtone eleuated about two foote froÃÑ the pauement, the ≈øame ≈øtone being now broken in two places, hauing vpon
‚Ä¢ t, and tho≈øe holy Reliks a Cro≈ø≈øe of 7. greate bra≈ø≈øe buttons, whereof 5. are ≈øet downe in length, and the other two making the perfect figure and forme of the Cro≈ø≈øe, one on each ≈øide of the others making the length. And this reuerent Tran≈ølation of King Lucius body to diuers places in Britaine is ≈øufficiently in≈øinuated, by the old Authour of the French Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory, I Manu≈øcr. Gallic. ≈øup. c. 9. haue cited before, who allthough he confidently affirmeth, that King Lucius died at Gloce≈øter, deuia a Glouce≈øtre: yet he addeth, that he was afterward buried in the cheife See in the Citie of Caerlegion: & En Legli≈øe del Primer See, ce≈øt a≈ø≈øauoir en la cittie de Legions e≈øtoit enterres, and this he ≈øaith, was in the 196. yeare of Chri≈øts Incarnation, l'an de l'Incartion 196. 4. or 5. yeares ≈øooner then others before haue ≈øet downe his death, except the forenamed Manu≈øcript Compilation which hath the ≈øame Computation of his death ≈øaying, ≈øepultus Compilatio M. S. de ge≈øt. Brit. & Angl. in Lucio. e≈øt Anno Incarnationis Dominicae 196. herede carens.

div.head: THE III. CHAPTER.

argument.p: HOW NOTWITHSTANDING THE DEATH of King Lucius without Heire to ≈øucceede in the gouerment of the kingdome, the Brittans per≈øeuered constantly in the Christian faith: and the Scots by Preachers ≈øent from Sainct Victor Pope of Rome at the entreatie of their King Donalde receaued the faith, and as the Brittans continued in it vntill the Prote≈øtants time, euen by their owne confe≈øsions.

div.p: 1. AND both to a≈ø≈øure vs further of the vndoubted truth of tho≈øe Hi≈øtories, which te≈øtifie, the death and buriall of King Lucius to haue bene in Britaine, and not in any forreine The greate lo≈ø≈øe Britaine had of King Lucius his death. Region, as al≈øo to giue vs better notice and triall what honour, peace and quiet ≈øpirituall and temporall with other happines this kingdome enioyed by King Lucius ble≈ø≈øed life, and lo≈øte them by the lo≈ø≈øe of him: it is the con≈øtant agreement of Antiquities, Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 5. c. 1. Virun. l. 5. Hi≈øtor. Matth. We≈øtm. An. 201. Holinshed Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 19. Compilatio M. S. de ge≈øt. Brit. & Angl. in Lucio. that Britaine now made by his death de≈øtitute not onely of ≈øo worthie a King, but al≈øo of any certaine Heire, or Succe≈ø≈øor of that Regall Race, fell to inte≈øtine di≈øcord, and variance, by which it was mi≈øerably afflicted, long time vpon that occa≈øion. Caruerat ille ≈øobole, oritur ≈øeditio inter Britones de ≈øucce≈ø≈øuro in Regnum: & Romana pote≈øtas infirmata e≈øt. A Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorian thus writeth in generall of this matter: King Lucius dyed without i≈ø≈øue, by rea≈øon whereof, after his decea≈øe, the Brittans fell at variance, which continued about the space of fiftene yeares as Fabian thinketh, howbe it the old English Cronicle affirmeth that the contention betwixt them remained fifty yeares, though Harding affirmeth but foure yeares. Which his words of Hardings opinion that this variance among the Brittans continued but 4. yeares, are to be ameÃÑded, for Harding ≈øetteth downe Matth. We≈øtm. An. 205. Florent. Wigor. in Chro. Marianus Scotus & Martin. Polon. in Seuero. Harding. Chronic. c. 51. f. 44. the di≈ø≈øentions of the Brittans, as other Hi≈øtorians doe, and maketh them of as long continuance, onely he ≈øaith, that Seuerus the Emperour came hither, foure yeares after the death of King Lucius, to ≈øeeke to appea≈øe things, ≈øo doth Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, Florentius and others as farre as Harding doth, his words be the≈øe of King Lucius death.

l.hi: For cau≈øe he had non heire to keepe the land,
Through all Britaine the Barons gan di≈øcord
Vnto the time that Romans tooke on hand
To cho≈øe a Prince by their ≈øtedfa≈øt accord:

lg.l: But 4. yere were gone or then they could accorde,

l.hi: In which then Seuer the Senatour
Hether came to be their Gouernour.

div.p: Where Harding doth limit the foure yeares, onely to the Romans, to take notice and deliberate of the≈øe things, and conclude to ≈øend Seuerus hither, ≈øaying.
div.q: But foure yeares were gone or then they could accorde,
div.p: Meaning the Romans about this matter, for it is euident both by Harding and all other Antiquaries, that Seuerus did not accord the Britans, but the variance continued heare during his whole life, and he was ≈ølaine at Yorke, in the ≈øame contention, as both Harding and all others te≈øtifie. Harding ≈øaith:

lg.l: But King Fulgen of Pightes and Scots againe Harding Chron. c. 53. ≈ø. 45.
With hoo≈øt full great, ≈øeiged Ebranke citee
Which Seuer re≈øcowed, and was ≈ølaine
And Fulgen al≈øo for beten there did die.

div.p: And he continueth the Brittans warrs, and tumults heare long time after Seuerus his death, and his ≈øonnes after him, as other Antiquaries likewi≈øe Chri≈øtians in Britaine quiet for Religion, vntill the Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian. doe, finding litle quiet heare, vntill the later end of Con≈øtantius, Father of Con≈øtantiue the Greate, Emperour. Which will more appeare hereafter, ≈øo farre as it carrieth any connexion with our Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hi≈øtory.

2. And yet notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch a worlde of vnquietnes heare, and many mo≈øt or allmo≈øt all our Kings in the meane time being Pagans, the Chri≈øtians heare were quiet for Religion by Antiquities. The auncient Manu≈øcript of Winche≈øter, ≈øaith, that from the fir≈øt planting of the faith in Britaine, in the Antiquitat. Manu≈øcr. Eccle≈øiae Wintonien. time of King Lucius to the fir≈øt yeare of Diocle≈øian, an hundred yeares together, Chri≈øtiaÃÑ ReligioÃÑ was quiet in peace, & the Religious men all that while liued quietly in their Mona≈øteries. Durauit Chri≈øtianitas in Britannia a tempore Bed. Eccl. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 4. F ‚Ä¢ orent. Wigor. Chron. An. 162. 184. Henr. Hunting. Hi≈øt. l. 1. in Marcus Anton. Verus. Peruetu≈ø. Antiq. Manu≈øcr. de primo ≈øtatu. Landau. Eccle≈ø. Matth. Parker. l. de Antiq. Britan. Go≈øcelin. Hi≈øt. Io. Bal. cent. 1. de Script. Brit. Godwin Conuer≈ø. of Brit. Theater of great Brit. & alij. Gildas l. de Excid. & Conque≈øt. Brit. c. 7. vide licet a primo Anno Lucij Regis primi Britannorum Cri≈øtiani, v≈øque ad primum Annum Diocle≈øiani Principis quieta in pace, centum annis & tamdiu Monachi Deo ≈øeruientes praedictum vetus Caenobium (Wintonien≈øe) quiete inhabitabant. S. Bede ab≈øolutely affirmeth of the Brittans, that from the planting of the faith of Chri≈øt, among them in the dayes of King Lucius, they kept it vnuiolate, and whole in quiet peace vntill the times of Diocle≈øian, Su≈øceptam fidem Britanni v≈øque in tempora Diocle≈øiani Principis inuiolatam integramque quieta in pace ≈øcruabant. Florentius Wigornien≈øis hath the verie ≈øame words: ≈øo hath Henry of Huntington. The old Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory of the fir≈øt ≈øtate of the Church of Landaffe iu≈øtifieth, that the Brittans kept this their fir≈øt faith ≈øincere without any ≈øtayne of error vntill the Pelagian Heri≈øie. Quam Chri≈øtianae Religionis fidem ≈øine aliqua praui dogmatis macula ≈øinceram con≈øeruauerunt v≈øqueduÃÑ Pelagiana Haere≈øis orta e≈øt. This is al≈øo the generall opinio of our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries. Yet we mu≈øt not make this ≈øo vniuer≈øall a truth, to thinke that all which receaued the Chri≈øtian faith in tho≈øe dayes of King Lucius, did Religiou≈øly ob≈øerue the ≈øame, and that all the Brittans without exception were Chri≈øtians: for we reade in S. Gildas, who≈øe Authoritie we may not ea≈øily reiect: praecepta Chri≈øti licet ab Incolis tepid√® ≈øu≈øcepta ≈øunt, apud quo ≈ødam tamen integr√®, & alios
minus v≈øque ad Per≈øecutionem Diocle≈øiani Tyrani nouennem, perman≈øere: Allthough the Precepts of Chri≈øt which the Britans receaued in the time of King Lucius, were coldly entertained of the Inhabitants heare, yet among ≈øome they remayned whole, and with others not in ≈øuch integritie, vntill the Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian the Tirant.

3. We shall finde hereafter many continuing heare in Britaine in Pagani≈øime, both of the Princes, and people, before Diocle≈øian his Per≈øecution began, in this or any other Nation. Yet it will be remembred for euer to the eternall honour of tho≈øe our Primatiue Chri≈øtian Brittans, that notwith≈øtanding the vniuer≈øall Inundation of licentious Pagani≈øme, which had reigned heare before, the hazard of the di≈øfriendship of the Idolatrous Roman Emperours and Senate then ≈øwaying allmo≈øt the knowne world, and diuers Per≈øecutions of Chri≈øtians raging in that time, and ciuill di≈ø≈øentions now further by the death of King Lucius falling out among our Brittans, yet in all the≈øe tempe≈øts of calamities, and afflictions they ≈øtill without any interruption, or corruption continued in their holy Chri≈øtian Religion, not onely ≈øecretly, but with externall glory, and ≈øplendor of Bishops, Prei≈øts, Religious men, and women, Churches, Altars, and their Ornaments, as I haue before remembred. And at this pre≈øent, when in morall and wordly v≈øuall proceedings, nothing could haue bene more feared, then a relap≈øe to Idolatry, by the death of ≈øo worthie, and holy a gouernour as King Lucius, a new zeale and deuotion was kindled in the harts of the Northren Brittanes, and Scots in imitating the example of The Scots with their King Donaldus receaue the faith of Chri≈øt froÃÑ S. Victor Pope. him, and his happy Subiects in this kinde. For at, or pre≈øently after his death, King Donald then reigning ouer the Scots receauing from Pope Victor, as King Lucius before had done from Pope Eleutherius, holy Preachers, and In≈øtructors, receaued and publikly with his wife, Nobles and Hector Boeth. Scotor. Hi≈øt. l. 6. f. 89. other ≈øubiects, profe≈ø≈øed the faith of Chri≈øt. Talem dederat Regi Donaldo animum pacis Princeps & Authour Chri≈øtus Dominus, quod verae pietati aspernato malorum Daemonum cultu, ≈øe≈øe Paulo ante addixerat. Nam Seuero imperante Romanis apud Victorem Pontificem Maximum, qui quintu≈ødecimus po≈øt Petrum Eccle≈øiae praefuit, per Legatos obtinuit, vt viri Doctrina & Religione in≈øignes in Scotiam ab eo mi≈øsi, ≈øe cum liberis & coniuge Christi nomen profitentes, bapti≈ømate in≈øignirent. Regis exemplum Scotica Nobilitas ≈øequuta, auer≈øata impietatem, Christi Religionem complexa, Sacro fonte e≈øt abluta. Fuit annus ille quo Scoti adlumen verae pietatis, Dei optimi maximi benignitate vocati ≈øunt & recepti, ab eo qui primus fuit humanae ≈øalutis tertius, ≈øupra ducente≈øimum: Christ our Lord Prince and Authour of peace gaue ≈øuch a minde to King Donald, that contemninge the worship of wicked Deuills, he addicted him≈øelfe to true pietie. For when Seuerus was Emperour of the Romans, by his Amba≈ø≈øadors he obtained of Pope Victor, the fifteenth after S. Peter, Which ruled the Church, that men renowned for Learning and Religion to be ≈øent from him into Scotland, that might baptize him with his children, and wife profe≈øsing Chri≈øt. The Scottish Nobilitie following the example of their King for≈øaking impietie, and embra≈øing the Religion of Chri≈øt, was baptized. This yeare wherin the Scots by the mercy of God allmightie were called, and receaued to the light of true pietie, was the third aboue two hundred from the first of mans Saluation. Thus farre this Scottish Georg. Buchan. Rer. Scoticar l. 4. c. & Rege 27. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Scotl. in K. Donald. Hi≈øtorian from the Antiquities of that Nation, to which their Prote≈øtant Writers doe al≈øo in ≈øub≈øtance con≈øent, as al≈øo the Prote≈øtant Antiquaries of England. Among which one writeth in this manner: King Donald in the dayes of the Emperour Seuerus, ≈øent a Me≈ø≈øenger with letters vnto Pope Victor, being the 15. in number, as they ≈øay, after S. Peter, declaring vnto him, that he was fully minded
to receaue the Chri≈øtian Religion, and vtterly to for≈øake the ≈øuperstitious ≈øeruice of the Heathnish Gods, and therefore in≈øtantly required him to ≈øend ≈øome godly learned men, to in≈øtruct him in the right beleife. The Pope hearing this, and being glad to encrea≈øe the faith of Chri≈øt through all parts of the world, ≈øent with all ≈øpeed into Scotland, ≈øuch well di≈øpo≈øed par≈øons, as he thought mo≈øt meete for that purpo≈øe, who at their arriuall there, did their endeuour in ≈øuch diligent ≈øort, that not onely the King, but al≈øo through his exaÃÑple, a greate number of the Nobilitie were bapti≈øed, and clerely for≈øooke their former errors and Idolatrie. This was in the yeare after the birth of Will. Harri≈øon de≈øcript. of Brit. cap. of Relig. Edw. Grym≈øton Booke of E≈øtat. in Scotland pag. 20. Christ our Sauiour 203. The like haue other English Prote≈øtants of this matter, of whome one ≈øaith: Scotland receaued the faith in the time of Pope Victor the fir≈øt in the yeare 203. and Idolatrie did quite cea≈øe vnder King Crakinte, who died in the yeare 313. Cele≈øtine the fir≈øt ≈øent Palladius thither to roote out the PelagiaÃÑ Here≈øie, which began to encrea≈øe there vnder Eugenius the ≈øecond, who died in the yeare 460. ≈øince this time the Realme continued longe in profe≈øsion of the Romish Church vntill the≈øe later dayes, the Reigne of King Iames who now liueth.

4. Thus we ≈øee how ignorantly, or rather impudently ≈øome Prote≈øtants haue written, in affirming that becau≈øe ≈øome of the Britans and Scots of this Iland at the comming of S. Augu≈øtine hither were fallen into old and exploded error of ≈øome Churches of Greece, that therefore without any warrant or Writer ≈øo affirming, they receaued their fir≈øt faith from the Churches of A≈øia, when it is euident by all Antiquities, and the≈øe Prote≈øtants them≈øelues, that the Britans did receaue Chri≈øtian Religion from the Pope of Rome S. Eleutherius, and the Scots from Pope S. Victor, the two greate≈øt Promulgers, and Defenders of the true Pa≈øchall ob≈øeruation, and greate≈øt Enemies to the other erroneous cu≈øtome, and abu≈øe that euer were. And being ≈øo plainely All Britaine, both Britans, Scots, and others, Chri≈øtians, euer ≈øubiect to the Pope in Spirituall bu≈øines vntill Caluins time. confe≈ø≈øed by the≈øe Prote≈øtants before, that the Scots which agreed in Religion with the old Chri≈øtian Britans of this kingdome, as all Prote≈øtants and others agree, did continue in the Profe≈ø≈øion of the Romish Church from their fir≈øt Conuer≈øion, vntill the crowning of King Iames the ≈øixt a Child in his Cradell, what a childish new vp≈øtart Profe≈ø≈øion of Prote≈øtants mu≈øt that needs be, by their owne confe≈ø≈øion, which beginning with not contradiction of a yet ≈øpeachle≈ø≈øe Infant, to build one ≈øuch a grounde hath reiected the Authoritie of all Popes, Councels, Churches, holy learned Fathers, Saints, holy Kings and Chri≈øtian Rulers in ≈øo many hundreds of yeares? Or how can any man, Scot, or other apprehend, that except King Donald his Nobles and Coun≈øailers therein, had bene a≈ø≈øured that the cheife di≈øpo≈øition of ≈øpirituall affaires belonged to the See of Rome, and Pope thereof, that he a Chri≈øtian in Iudgment at the lea≈øt before, as ≈øo auncient and approued Antiquities proue, and in peace, and amitie with King Lucius of Britaine, where ≈øo many renowned Bishops, and Clergie men then liued, and to whome by the Te≈øtimonie and Decree of Pope Eleutherius before remembred, all Scots ‚Ä¢ nd Picts about this kingdome of Britaine were Feudatories and Subiects, and that in France and all other Nations betweene our Scots, and Rome, there were many holy and learned Chri≈øtian Bishops and Clergie men, that he in prudence would, or could haue ≈øent ≈øo ≈øolemne Amba≈ø≈øadge, and ≈øupplication to effect this ≈øuite to the Pope of Rome, who≈øe Emperour then, or pre≈øently after, and before this holy worke was wholly effected, was the greate≈øt enemy in the world to the Scottish Nation, with all force, malice, and Power he could, inuadinge it? Therefore we mu≈øt needs conclude, euen by Prote≈øtant warrant, and allowance, that this whole kingdome of Britaine from the
fir≈øt Conuer≈øion thereof to Chri≈øt, did euer and continually vntill the≈øe dayes of Ihon Caluine, that Father of the English Prote≈øtant Religion, in all dutie and obedience per≈øeuere in the vnitie, and doctrine of the Popes and Church of Rome, by whome it was fir≈øt conuerted to Chri≈øtianitie.

div.head: THE IV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THAT ALLTHOVGH THE BEING OF THE Scots in Britaine in the time of S. Victor is vncertaine, and not proued, but rather otherwi≈øe, yet the Inhabitants of the part now called Scotland, Britans or who≈øoeuer, were conuerted in King Lucius and this time. The Bishops of the conuerted Scots were euer true Bishops, and they euer obedient to the See of Rome.

div.p:
1. BVT before we enter into any further particulars of the Conuer≈øion of the Scottish Nation by S. Victor Pope, and his Apo≈øtolike Di≈øciples imployed therein, which is very ≈øparingly remembred in any Antiquities left vnto vs; to deliuer our ≈øelues ≈øo farre as we can from Ambiguities, and vncertainties, it is requi≈øite to ≈øay ≈øome what, at lea≈øt in generall of what parte, place, When the Scots now ≈øuppo≈øed to be conuerted to the faith came first into Britaine, and where they now liued. Country, or Iland, in, or about this great Iland of Albion, or Britaine, the≈øe Scots were, which are recorded to be conuerted at this time. For what≈øoeuer the Scots pleade that this hapned to their Nation long after their entrance into this greate Iland, which they contend to haue bene in the yeare of the worlds Creation 4617. Annum quo Albionem Scoti ingre≈øsi fe runtur ab orbe condito tradunt ≈øupra quater mille≈øimum & ≈øexcente≈øimum decimum ≈øeptimum. This Hect. Boeth. de≈øcript. Scot. Reg. fol. 4. Nicephor l. 1. Hi≈øt. cap. 10. Alphon≈øus Rex. Eu≈øeb. in Chron. I≈øid. l. 5. Origin. Cyprianus lib. Exhort. Martyr. Hieron. in Epi≈øt. ad Tit. Augu≈øt. lib. 12. ciuit. cap. 10. Martyrolog. Rom. Marian. aetate 6. an. 1. Math. We≈øt. an. 1. Prote≈øt. Angl. marginal. Annotat. in illum locum. Hol ‚Ä¢ insh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 3. cap. 18. Iacob. Gordonus in Apparatu cap. 2. ≈øeemeth to be a ≈øtrange calculation, and not firme enough to be builded vpon: for how could the Scots liuing in darke ignorance of God, and heauenly things and knowing nothing of the Creation of the world, or ≈øuch things, but by all writers, a very vnlearned, rude, and barbarous people, exiled, bannished and wandering men, po≈ø≈øibly haue any ≈øuch certaine Tradition of their arriuall in Albion, in ≈øuch a yeare of the worlds Creation, of which they were long time after vtterly ignorant? And Hector Boethius the Scottish Hi≈øtorian, which with other writers ≈øetteth downe this Conuer≈øion in the 203. of Chri≈øt, and yet maketh that to be in 5399. yeare of the worlds Creation, differeth from all other Computations, eyther of Nicephorus, recompting the birth of Chri≈øt in the 5500. yeare of the world, K. Alphon≈øus in the 6984. Eu≈øeb. 5199. S. I≈øid. 5220. S. Cyp. to his time 6000. and S. Hier. & S. Aug. in their dayes 6000. long after S. Cyp. By the Roman Martyrologe 5199. betweene the Creation & Chri≈øt. By Marianus 4163. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter maketh an other accompt, ≈øome English Prote≈øtant Antiquaries, make the di≈øtance betwene the Creation 3066. others 3807. Others of them reckon otherwi≈øe. And by ≈øome writers it cometh to about 4000. yeares. Such and ≈øo manifold variances being among learned Chri≈øtians in this accompt, we may not ea≈øely admitt for certaine, what any man will therein propo≈øe from a Scottish PagaÃÑ ≈øurmi≈øed Tradition. E≈øpecially when we haue many Antiquities, both Brittish, English,
and forreyne, Chri≈øtian and heathen, to incline vs to thinke, that the Scots were not long after this time, ≈øo ≈øeated in any number in this greate Iland with ≈øuch Power, or commande, that they could giue the denomination of Scotland, to any greate part thereof, or a≈ø≈øume the name of a King vnto them, called Scotorum Rex, the King of the Scots, but they ≈øtill remayned in the out litle Ilands, Hebrides, Mon ‚Ä¢ ; Orchads, Iona, and others. We finde in an Oration of Io≈øephus the Iew to his Countrymen in the time of Titus, ≈øpeaking Io≈øephus orat. ad Iudaeos, apud Ege≈øippum l. 5. cap. 15. Fa≈øcicul. Temp. Anno D. 74. Humf. Lhoid in Breuiar. Britan. of the Roman Emperours Power at that time: Tremit hos Scotia quae terris nihil debet, that our Scots then liued not in any greate part of Land, but at Sea and in litle Ilands neare vnto Britaine. Walterus Rollewink Authour of Fa≈øciculus Temporum writeth, that the Brittish Scots did begin heare, but in the yeare of Chri≈øt 74. Scotagens oritur ex Pictis & Hiberis in Albania prop√® Angliam circa Annum Domini 74. Which is manife≈øt al≈øo by Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, and others writing, that the Picts coming hither about that time, and finding none but Britans heare, de≈øired to match with them in marriadge, which the Britans refu≈øing, the Picts went to the Sots of Ireland in the yeare of Chri≈øt 76. and had wiues from thence. And the Scots thus came fir≈øt into Britaine. Picti vxores non habentes, filias & cognatas Britonum petierunt ab eis. Matth We≈øtm. Anno gratiae 76. 77. Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. cap. 1. At illi vt pa≈øsi fuerunt repul≈øam, transfretauerunt in HiberniaÃÑ, & exilla Patria mulieres reducentes, pueros‚ñ™ ≈øu≈øceperant ex Pictis & Hibernen≈øibus Scoti originem habuerunt, qua≈øi ex diuer≈øis Nationibus compacti. Scot etenim illud dicitur quod ex diuer≈øis rebus in vnum aceruum congregatur. Our English Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians Hollinsh Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 15. Stowe and Howes Hi≈øt. Romans in Marius. Humfry Lhoyd in Breui. Brit. cap. in de≈øcript. Scotiae. thus relate this matter: King Marius hauing conquered the Picts, that came into Britaine, granted licence to them, that remained, that they might inhabite in the North part of Scotland, called Catne≈ø≈øe, being as then a Country in manner de≈øolate wirhout habitation: whereupon they withdrew thither, and ≈øetled them≈øelues in tho≈øe parts. And becau≈øe the Britans di≈ødained to grant vnto them their daughters in marriadge, they ≈øent vnto the Scots into Ireland, requiring to haue wiues of their Nation. The Scots agreed to their reque≈øt, with this condition, that where there wanted lawfull I≈ø≈øue of the Kings Linage to ≈øucceede in the kindome of the Picts, then should they name one of the womans ≈øide to be their King. Thus the Picts next after the Romans, were the fir≈øt of any ≈øtrangers, that came into this land to inhabite, as mo≈øt writers affirme, allthough the Scottish Chronicles auouch the Picts to be Inhabiters heare, before the Incarnation of Chri≈øt. But the Victory which Marius obtained again≈øt their King Roderike, chanced in the yeare after the Incarnation 87. neither was there any Writer of name, that made mention either of Scots, or Picts, before Ve≈øpa≈øianus his time, about the yeare of the Incarnation 72. Henry of Huntington Henric. hunting. Hi≈øt. l. 1. following (as he ≈øaith) Auncient Authours, haec ≈øunt quae √† ≈øcriptis veterum traduntur, ≈øetting downe the comming of the Picts into Britaine, and their marrying with the Irish, ≈øetteth downe the comming of the Scots out of Ireland hither long after that time: procedente tempore venerunt & Scotti ab Hibernia Harding Cron. fol. 42. cap. 50. in Britanniam. Harding citing Mewinus the old Brittish Writer for Authour, affirmeth, that the fir≈øt Scots that came to Britaine, came in the 75. yeare of Chri≈øt. Giraldus Cambren≈øis maketh the fir≈øt inhabiting of the Scots in Britaine to haue bene in the time of greate Nell, Nelli magni, King of Ireland, who was Father to King Laegirius, in who≈øe dayes S. Patrike preached Girald. Cambr. Topograph. Hibern. cap. 16. in that Country, which was not by any accompt before the yeare of Chri≈øt 418. praedicto Nello Hiberniae Monarchiam obtinente, ≈øex filios Muredi Regis Vltoniae in cla≈ø≈øe non modica Boreales Britanniae partes occupa≈ø≈øe. Vnde & gens ab ijs propagat ‚Ä¢ , & ≈øpeci≈øicato vocabulo Scotica vocata, v≈øque in hodiernum diem Angulum
illum inhabitant, Where he confidently deliuereth, that the name of Scots, and Scotland in Britaine began heare at this time.

2. And allthough the Scottish Hi≈øtories contend, that the Scots in Britaine had gathered a greate Armie of men and women, as their v≈øe and neede was, again≈øt Maximus, which they had gathered ou ‚Ä¢ of Ireland, the out Ilands, and ≈øuch Scots as were then come into Britaine, y ‚Ä¢ t being ouerthrowne in battaile, they were ≈øo farre vnable after to make re≈øi≈øtance, euen by their owne Chroniclers, that to v≈øe their owne words, A Proclamation comming forth from Maximus that all ≈øuch as were naturall Scottish men should by a certaine day auoide out of tho≈øe Countryes that they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed in Britaine, vpon paine of loo≈øing life, and goods, and to deliuer vp their hou≈øes, and lands vnto ≈øuch Brittans, and Picts, as were appointed by the Romans for to enioy the ≈øame. The Scots perceauing them≈øelues not Boeth. Scotor. Hi≈øt. l. 7. Hollinshed Hi≈øt. of Scotland in Eugen. an. 352. Georg. Buchan. Rerum Scot. lib. 4. in Reg. 39. able to make any re≈øi≈øtance, obayed this commandement, ≈øome of them pa≈øsing ouer into Ireland, ≈øome into the Westerne Iles, and ≈øome of them got ouer al≈øo into Norway and Denmarke, and many got entertainemen amongst the Roman ≈øouldiers, and went ouer with them into France. And ≈øo there was neither man, woman nor child of the Scottish Race left in Britaine, their Prei≈øts al≈øo and Religious men were banished and fled into the Ile of Iona. This was in the yeare of Chri≈øt 352. Boethius ≈øaith, this was about the 379. yeare of Chri≈øt, and the Hect. Boeth. in Catal. Scotor. Reg. in Eugen. 1. & Fergu≈øio 2. & l. 6. Hi≈øtor. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Scotland in Fethelmacus. Scots had no King after this vntill the 422. yeare of Chri≈øts Incarnation. Scoti inde quatuor & quadraginta annis ≈øine Rege ad Annum virginei partus quadringente≈øimum vige≈øimum ≈øecundum fuere. And they confe≈ø≈øe, that Eugenius which was thus ouerthrowne by Maximus, was but an Ilander of Mona. Eugenius √® Mona In≈øula, and from thence made King of the Scots. Paulus Oro≈øius ≈øcholler to S. Augu≈øtine the Doctor, liuing long after this time, confineth the Scots to Ireland, and the Iles Meuainae in his dayes: Hibernia proprior Britanniae a Scotorum gentibus colitur. Huic etiam Meuania In≈øula proxima e≈øt, & ip≈øa ≈øpatio non parua, ≈øolo commoda, aeque a Scotorum gentibus habitatur. S. Bede al≈øo, both by Paulus Oro≈øius Hi≈øt. Brittans, Saxons and Scots iudgments, the ≈øure≈øt Authour we can haue in this matter, ≈øetting downe the comming of the Picts into the≈øe parts, fir≈øt to the Scots in Ireland, and then landing in Britaine in the time of Marius, as I haue before related, longe after the Natiuitie of Chri≈øt, proueth that the Scots came hither longe after that time. Procedente autem tempore Britannia po≈øt Britones & Pictos tertiam Scotorum Nationem in Pictorum parte recepit. And againe: Hibernia propri√® patria Scotorum e≈øt ab hac egre≈øsi vt diximus, tertiam in Britannia Beda Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. lib. 1. cap. 1. Britonibus & Pictis gentem addiderun ‚Ä¢ . And the Scottish Antiquaries which would make ≈øo longe, and auncient a Catalogue of their Kings, doe not at any time call them, or any of them in tho≈øe times Kings of Scotia, or Scotland, Hector Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. l. 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. 6. Georg. Buchan. Rer. Scoticar. l. 1. 2. 3. 4. &c. but Kings of the Scots, Scotorum Reges.

3. And to returne to Eccle≈øia≈øticall matters againe. This is confirmed by this pre≈øent Hi≈øtory of the Conuer≈øion of the King of Scots Donaldus by Pope Victor, and his Apo≈øtolike Preachers, among whome we doe not finde any one Bishop to haue bene ≈øent, nor any Bishoprike erected in any place, where probably this King Donald, or any King of the Scots ruled, longe time after this. The Scottish Antiquaries them≈øelues that ≈øtand ≈øo ≈øtiffely for the Antiquitie of their Nation, doe freely acknowledge that the fir≈øt Epi≈øcopall See, that euer was, where their Kings ruled, was erected in the time of Diocle≈øian his Per≈øecution, and this in the Iland of Mona, and giuen to S. Amphibalus a Brittish Bishop by King Crathlint, King of the Scots at that time. Fuit id templum Hect. Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. lib. 6. fol. 102. omnium primum Chri≈øtiano ritu, vbi Pontifex ≈øacerque Magi≈øtratus ≈øedem haberet
primariam inter Scotos, cuius nostri meminere Scriptores, dedicatum. Nunc S. Palladius ≈øent by S. Caele≈øtine Pope, the fir≈øt Bishop of Scots ≈øent from Rome. vocant Sodoren≈øe Fanum. And they both confe≈ø≈øe, that S. Palladius whome S. Caele≈øtine Pope ≈øent to the Scots aboue 200. yeares after this, was the fir≈øt Bishop which any Pope made & ≈øent thither, & the fir≈øt that con≈øecrared other Bishops among the Scots. Erat Palladius primus omnium qui Sacrum inter Scotos Hector Boethius Scot. Hi≈øt. l. 7. f. 133. Georg. Buchan. Rer. Scotic. l. 5. in Rege 42. Hector Boeth. ≈øupr. l. 6. Holins. Hi≈øt. of Scotland p. 88. Manu≈øc. Antiq. & Io. Capgrau. in Vita S. Niniani. Hector Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. l. 7. f. 119. Io. Bal. l. de Scriptorib. Brit. cent. 1. in Niniano Beruicio. egere Magi≈øtratum, a ≈øummo Pontifice Epi≈øcopus creatus. And: creditur idem Palladius primus, Epi≈øcopos in Scotia crea≈ø≈øe. And they ≈øet downe the Bishops, and places, which, and where he created them: Seruanus in the Iles of the Orchades, and Toruanus for the Picts. Palladius Seruanum Epi≈øcopum ad Orchadas In≈øulas creauit: Et Teruanum Pictorum Archiepi≈øcopum con≈øtituit. The≈øe were the fir≈øt Bishops which the Scottish Antiquities remember to haue bene either among them or the Picts, except S. Ninian, ≈øent a litle before from the See of Rome, to conuert the Pictish Nation. The old Manu≈øcript, and Capgraue in S. NiniaÃÑ his life ≈øay, that he there ordained Prei≈øts, con≈øecrated Bishops, & diuided the CouÃÑtry into Parishes. Ordinauit Presbyteros, Epi≈øcopus coÃÑ≈øecrauit, & totam terram per certas Parochias diui≈øit. He being a Noble Britan by birth preached both to the Scots, Picts, and Britans that were in tho≈øe parts, and dyed an old man about the yeare of Chri≈øt 432. about which time S. Palladius came hither. Ninianus Epi≈øcopus ≈øanctitate & Miraculis clari≈øsimus, Scotorum, Pictorum, Britouumque Doctor ad ≈øenium v≈øque, obijt faelicitatis no≈øtrae Anno 432.

4. It is an euident fal≈øehood which a Puritane Scottish Hi≈øtorian ≈øpeaking of this time of Paladius his preaching to the Scots affirmeth, that vntill then the Churches were gouerned by Monkes without Bishops. Ad id v≈øque tempus Georg. Buchan. Rer. Scoticar. l. 5. Rege 42. Eccle≈øsiae ab≈øque Epi≈øcopis per Monachos regebantur. For I haue shewed before, how from the beginning of Chri≈øtianitie the Churches of Chri≈øt in all places were gouerned by Bishops, and ≈øuch euer ruled heare in Britaine al≈øo, thirtie or more in number heare in Britaine, and how the Northren inhabitants of Britaine that were Chri≈øtians, whether Britans, Picts, or Scots, were ≈øubiect to the Archbishop of Yorke and the Bishops which were vnder him. And allthough at the fir≈øt Conuer≈øion of the Scots of this our Britaine, whether continuing in the out Ilands, or in ≈øome ≈ømall numbers within the maine kingdome, not being Owners or Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øioners of any Cities, & places, which were, or by the practi≈øe of the primatiue Church, might be allowed for Fpi≈øpall Sees, they could not haue Bishops of their owne at that time, yet I haue in≈øtanced before that ≈øo ≈øoone as they came to enioy ≈øuch places as might be allowed for Bishops Re≈øidences, they al≈øo enioyed Bishops, with all other Holinshed Hi≈øt. of Scotland in K. Eugenius. Io. Bal. l. de Scri. Brit. cent. 1. in Brigida Lagin. Capgr. in S. Brig. Hector. Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. l. 9. f. 187. Holinsh. hi≈øt. of Scotl. in Malcolme 3. Hector Boeth. Scotor. Hi≈øt. l. 7. f. 133. Henric. Huntington. Hi≈øt. l. 3. Chri≈øtian Nations, ≈øo they had S. Amphibalus in Mona Bishop of Soder there, S. Ninian and other Bishops con≈øecrated by him. And a Prote≈øtant Antiquarie in his Hi≈øtorie of Scotland writeth, that the Scots had Bishops in the time of Maximus, and were banished then with the other Scots. And we finde many Auncient Bishops, as Machillas, Bruno, and others Succe≈ø≈øours to S. Amphibalus in Soder. And the Scottish Hi≈øtorians confe≈ø≈øe, that the Hebrides Ilands, Galloway and the adioyning Countryes were ≈øubiect to that Bishops See, till the time of King Malcome the third, about the yeare of Chri≈øt 1057. Hebrides, Gallouidiam, ac illis vicinus Regiones Sodoren≈øi Epi≈øcopo, cui in Mona Sedes erat Sacra, v≈øque ad Malcolmi tertij Regis tempora in rebus parui≈ø≈øe diuinis. And the ≈øame Scottish Antiquaries with others proue, that allthough their Bishops were commonly cho≈øen at the fir≈øt out of their Culdeis, holy Prei≈øts, or Monkes, yet they were con≈øecrated and made Bishops, as others were. Ex monachis & Culdeis Pontifices a≈ø≈øumerentur. And to be a≈ø≈øured, that the≈øe
Scottish Bishops were truely and ritely con≈øecrated, it was an old cu≈øtome of the Scots in the time of S. Wiro allmo≈øt a thow≈øand yeares ≈øince that when Manu≈øcr. Ant. in Vita S. Wironis Epi≈øc. Capgr. Catal. in eod. the Scots had any Bishop to be Con≈øecrated, they ≈øent him to Rome to be ≈øacred there: moris erat apud Incolas Pastorem √† ≈øe electum Romam manibus Apo≈øtolicis ordinandum dirigere, ordinatumque ≈øedem & plebem reui≈øere. And that holy The Bishops of ScotlaÃÑd euer truely con≈øecrated, as the Roman v≈øe was. Bishop, together with Plechelmus, which went with him, was ≈øo Con≈øecrated by the Pope according to that cu≈øtome, a cu≈øtome ≈øo long ≈øince with that Nation, that it ≈øeemeth to haue bene there kept, and ob≈øerued from the time of the fir≈øt Bishop there S. Ninian con≈øecrated, and ≈øent thither by the Pope of Rome. For S. Bede ≈øaith, that this S. Plechelmus which was thus Con≈øecrated at Rome with S. Wyro by the Pope, was Bishop of Candida Ca≈øa (S. Ninian his See, both builded and founded by him) Plechelmus in ea quae Candida Bed. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 5. c. 24. Capgrau. in S. Ninian. Manu≈øcript. & Capgr. ≈øupr. in S. Wyrone Epi≈øcopo. ca≈øa vocatur Epi≈øcopi Prae≈øulatum tenet. Which ≈øtandeth in that Ile, or Penin≈øula, where this cu≈øtome was to ≈øend their elect Bishops to Rome to be CoÃÑ≈øecrated by the Pope. Moris erat apud Incolas eiu≈ødem In≈øulae Pa≈øtorem a ≈øe electum Romam manibus Apo≈øtolicis ordinandum dirigere. Which is euident by the words immediately following: ordinatumque ≈øedem & plebem reui≈øere. That the per≈øon thus elect and ≈øent to Rome to be CoÃÑ≈øecrated Bishop by the Pope, should after his Con≈øecration returne to his See and people of his Dioce≈ø≈øe, which mu≈øt needs be this Scottish Iland where Candida Ca≈øa was; whether S. Pecthelmus or Plechelmus returned, after his Con≈øecration at Rome, and there held his Epi≈øcopall See, as S. Bede witne≈ø≈øeth, ≈øo this cu≈øtome mu≈øt needs be in that Scottish Iland. And except our Scottish Hi≈øtories before deceaue vs, when they call Teruanus Archbishop, who was Bishop heare by S. Palladius, Pope Cele≈øtine his Legate, his ordination, all the Scots ob≈øerued or were bound to this cu≈øtome. So that of all people in the world we may not call The Chri≈øtiaÃÑ Scots truely obedient to the See of Rome. the validitie of the Scottish Bishops Con≈øecration into any que≈øtion or enter into the lea≈øt ≈øu≈øpition of any willfull reuolte of that people from the Church of Rome. Of Ignorance as in the Pa≈øchall ob≈øeruation, by di≈øtance of place, and troble≈øomene≈ø≈øe of times they may be accu≈øed, of any willfull error or di≈øobedience they cannot be condemned.

5. Allthough I haue bene thus ≈øparing vpon the remembred rea≈øons, to affirme, that the Scottish Nation either in this greate Iland, or any the out Ilands thereof had before this time of S. Victor his ≈øending Preachers to conuert them receaued the faith of Chri≈øt: yet I may be bold, vpon better warrant to deliuer, that generally for the mo≈øt parte, the Inhabitants of that parte, now called Scotland, whether Britans, Picts, or Scots, did then or ≈øoone after receaue the Chri≈øtian faith: for the Britans of that Country we haue heard before, that they were conuerted in the time of King Lucius by the Legats, Manu≈øcr. Antiq. de primo ≈øtatu Landau. Eccle≈ø. Antiq. Gla≈øton. tabul. ligneis Fixae. Guliel. Malm. l. de Ant q. Caenobij Gla≈øton. Tertull. l. contr. Iudae√≤s c. 7. Magdeburg. centr. 2. cap. 2. Theat. of greate Brit. l. 6. and Apo≈øtolike Preachers ≈øent by Pope Eleutherius. To pa≈ø≈øe ouer printed Authorities in all mens hands, the old Manu≈øcript of Landaffe ≈øaith, that both King Lucius and the Nobles of Britaine, the name to the whole Iland then, were baptized, Lucius & totius Britanniae Primates Bapti≈ømum ≈øu≈øceperunt. The Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury from old Annals of credit, Tradunt bonae credulitatis Annales, doe deliuer that the Legats of Pope Eleutherius did preach and baptize through all parts of Britaine, huic praedicando & baptizando Britanniae partes peragrantes. William of Malmesbury in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtorie of the Antiquitie of that place, plainely teacheth, that they baptized, preached, and trauailed throughout the whole Iland. Baptizantes, & praedicantes & vniuer≈øam In≈øulam peragantes. And Tertullian ≈øpeaketh directly of the Britans, when
he ≈øaith, Britannorum Romanis inacce≈ø≈øa loca. That the Britans in tho≈øe places whether the Romans could neuer come, had receaued the faith of Chri≈øt, which mu≈øt needs be vnder≈øtood of the Britans which were then in Albania, now Scotland. And I haue proued before, that in the time of King Lucius Pope Eleutherius and his Legats heare did make all the Chri≈øtians of that Northren part what≈øoeuer they were, Britans, Picts or Scots, Bishops, Prei≈øts, others of the Cleargie or Laitie ≈øubiect to the Archbishop of Yorke. And the Scottish Antiquaries who pleade ≈øo much for their honour, ≈øay, that Pope Victor his Prei≈øts which he ≈øent hither did not onely preach the faith of Chri≈øt vnto the vttermo≈øt parte of this Iland of Britaine or Albion: but in≈øtructed the people in Learning & Diuinitie. Incaepere & no≈øtri tum primum, ≈øacras Hector Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. l. 5. f. 89. 90. colere literas, Sacerdotibus praeceptoribus, quos Victor Pont. Max. ad Chri≈øti dogma propalandum in extremam mi≈øerat Albionem. And by the≈øe Apo≈øtolike men thus ≈øent from Rome by Pope Victor, many of the Picts al≈øo which inhabited in the North of Britaine, were coÃÑuerted at this time, or before in the CoÃÑuer≈øion in the time of King Lucius: for allthough S. Ninian which came hither about the end of the fourth hundred of yeares of Chri≈øt, is commonly reputed the fir≈øt Bishop, e≈øpecially Con≈øecrated at Rome, and expre≈ø≈øely by the Pope ≈øent to that Nation, yet many of them were long time before conuerted to Chri≈øtian Religion and finding no other generall conuer≈øions heare, in our primatiue Church but vnder Pope Eleutherius and Victor, we mu≈øt a≈ø≈øcribe the≈øe Picts Chri≈øtianitie to them or their Di≈øciples.

6. Chri≈øtian Religion was ≈øo propagated among the≈øe Picts, in the later end of this Age, that the very women of that Nation were able in di≈øpute to confownd the be≈øt Learned Pagans. Among them there was one mo≈øt renowned Hector Boeth. Scotor. Hi≈øt. l. 6. f. 104. 105. Ann. Scotici ibidem. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Ireland. Marcus Antonius de Dominis l. 2. de Repub.
