Chri≈øt. c. 8. p. 277. 278. not onely by our Irish, Scottish, Brittish, or English Antiquaries, whether Catholiks or Prote≈øtants, but by the auncient Greeke writers, among whome Theodoret with others witne≈ø≈øeth, that a Chri≈øtian Pictish woman ≈øo with rea≈øons, and Miracles conuinced a King and Queene with many others in Ireland, in the time of greate Con≈øtantine Emperour, that a Bishop was ≈øent to that Nation, to perfect that she had ≈øo happily begun. And we finde that longe before the comming of S. Ninian, both the King namely Heirgu≈øtus and people of the Picts generally were conuerted Chri≈øtians, and at the comming of S. Regulus thither with the holy Reliks of S. Andrewe the Apo≈øtle, entertained and reuerenced them with greate zeale, and deuotion, and built a Church in honour of S. Andrewe, endowing it with greate Hector Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. l. 6. f. 108. 109. Hollin≈ø. Hi≈øt. of. Scotland in Augu≈øia ‚Ä¢ us An. D. 369. Will. Harri≈ø. de≈øcrip. of Brit. c. 9. Will. Harri≈øon ≈øupr. c. 9. po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, and pretiou≈øly adorning it with all things belonging to Chri≈øtian Religion, all this was longe time before S. NiniaÃÑ came hither, that the King & people of the Picts were thus zealous in Chri≈øtian Religion; which could not probably proceede from any later or other Originall theÃÑ this ≈øending of preachers hither by Pope Victor, which a Prote≈øtant Antiquarie confe≈ø≈øeth plainely by this his calculation of time: while≈øt the≈øe things were thus in hand, the Mates, Picts and Caledoniens receaued the faith. This Conuer≈øion of the North parts fell out in the ≈øixt yeare before the warres that Seuerus had in tho≈øe quarters, and 170. after the death of our Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt: Which was the 203. of his Incarnation, the very yeare before a≈ø≈øigned by all Hi≈øtories of Pope Victor his ≈øending Preachers into tho≈øe parts. Which is further confirmed by the firme a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and ioyning of the Picts and Scots then with the Chri≈øtian Britans again≈øt the Romans, te≈øtified by all Antiquities. Which we cannot better impute to any other motiue, then their new vnion in Chri≈øtian Religion, being
enemies and at variance before. Arnoldus Mermannius in his Treati≈øe Of the Conuer≈øion of Nations to Chri≈øt, confirmeth the ≈øame, for ≈øpeaking of the Britans Conuer≈øion in the time of King Lucius and Eleutherius, ≈øaith, that the Scots, Picts, Irish, and other Ilanders of this Climate did at, or about that time receaue the Chri≈øtian faith, though they then had no Bishop. Scoti, Picti, Hiberni caeterique eius climatis In≈øulares, videnter eodem tempore fidem accepi≈ø≈øe, ≈øed Epi≈øcopum Arnold. Merm. Theatro conu. Gent. p. 123. non ita, ≈øi venerabili Bedae credendum e≈øt. And this, with that is ≈øaide before, is ≈øufficient for the Conuer≈øion of the Scots about Britaine, where≈øoeuer they were ≈øeated.

7. But to allowe them eyther habitation then in this greate Iland, or to haue had that time any Bishops, I dare not for the rea≈øons and Authorities I haue alledged before: And yet might write more plainely, and not ≈øingularly of this matter, if I should ≈øpeake onely in the words of Prote≈øtant Antiquaries, among whome two principall men haue with greate applau≈øe with many men of their Religion, thus published to the world. Neyther was there Humfry Lhoyd Breuiar. Brit. Thom. Twyne f. 35. 36. any Writer of name, that made mention eyther of Scots or Readshanks before Ve≈øpa≈øians time, about the yeare of our Lords Incarnation three≈øcore and twelue, at what time Maurigus, or Maus, or Aruiragus reigned in Britaine. For our Chronicles doe reporte of a Nation which liued by Piracie and Rouing one the Sea, comming forth of Sueuia, or Norway, hauing one Rhythercus to their Captaine and landed in Albania, wa≈øting all the Countrie with robbing and ≈øpoyling ≈øo farre as Caerleil, where he was di≈øcomfited and ≈ølayne by Meurigus, and a greate many of his men al≈øo, and tho≈øe which e≈øcaped fledd to their ships, and ≈øo conueyed them≈øelues into the Orchades, and the Iles of Scotland, where they quietly abode a greate while. The≈øe after they had taken hart of grace, and were growen to ≈øome power, out of the≈øe Ilands in their litle leathern boates, ≈øuch as our fishermen doe v≈øe now a dayes, a long Scotland were wont to robbe and ≈øpoyle shephards and husbandmen. Vntill that about the yeare of our Lord 290. when the Romans and Britans were both at ciuile warres, for the purple Robe which Carau≈øius woare, and after him Allectus, they entered generally into Cathene≈øia, and Caledonia, and driuing thence the Brittish Shephards, and Heard≈ømen Fol. 37. and calling vnto them the Gatheli out of Ireland, which are now called the Scots, were ≈øo bold as to prouoke the Britans in open warre. Dion a man which had bene Con≈øul, and familiar with Seuerus the Emperour, and vnto him dearely beloued, Fol. 40. whil≈øt he declareth his expedition into Britaine at lardge, not once ≈øpeaketh of the Scots, or Readshankes, being very well knowne to all men, that he conueyed all his force and Power into Albania or Scotland. For quoth Dion, the Meati, and Caledonij Dion. Ca≈ø≈øius in Seuero. two diuers kinds of Britans, reuolted from the Romans, and Seuerus calling together his ≈øouldiers, commanded them to inuade their Country, and kill all that euer they mett. If the Scots had bene in Britaine at that time, the Reporter hereof being a friend, neyther after him Herodian, who in ≈øufficient long di≈øcour≈øe hath ≈øett forth that voiage, would haue defrauded an Emperour ≈øo ambitious and thir≈øty of honour, as Seuerus was, of his due pray≈øe. Wherefore it is as euident as Noone dayes, that at this time, which was about two hundred and two yeares after the Incarnation of our Lord, the Scots had no ≈øeate in Britaine. Ouer and be≈øides all this, neyther Eutropius, neyther Spartianus, neither Capitolinus, neyther Lampridius, neyther Vopi≈øcus nor Aurelius Victor, who haue all written the expeditions and warres of the Roman Emperours in Britaine, haue in any place made mention of the Scottish or Readshanks name. And they conclude in this manner: it appeareth manife≈øtly that at this time, that is to witt in the yeare of our Saluation 410. The Scots po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed no certaine Fol. 47. place in Britaine, but many times v≈øed to make Irruptions out of Ireland, and by litle
and litle ≈øubdued the North parts of the Iland, and at lenght hauing driuen thence the Inhabitants, e≈øtablished their kingdome there vnder ValeÃÑtinian the youÃÑger in the yeare of God Incarnate 444. when as now the Romans had left off the chardge and Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 3. cap. 10. Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 5. c. 3. Hard. Cron. c. 54. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 292. care of Britaine. An other Prote≈øtant Antiquarie ≈øaith confidently: ≈øure it is that no speciall mention of the Scots is made, till about 300. yeares after the birth of our Sauiour, And the old Brittish Hi≈øtory inclineth to hold, that Carau≈øius gaue the Picts their fir≈øt place in Albania to inhabite, and they matching with the Britans which dwelled there, continued to after Ages. Victoria ce≈øsit Carau≈øio. Qui vt triumphum habuit, dedit Pictis locum man≈øionis in Albania, vbi cum Britonibus mixti per ≈øequens aeuum man≈øerunt. And Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter with ≈øome others maketh it the yeare of Chri≈øt 202. before Carau≈øius entered into this bu≈øines.

8. And the Scottish Hi≈øtorians them≈øelues doe acknowledge that 48. of their fir≈øt Kings, as they call tho≈øe their Leaders, were buried in a litle Out-IlaÃÑd called Iona or Columkill: And al≈øo 4. petty Irish and 8. ≈øuch Noruegian Princes; and to this day there is euidence thereof. Eminent inter caeteros Tumuli Georg. Buchan. Rerum. Scotic. l. 1. William Harri≈øon de≈øcript. of Brit. p. 40. in Iona. tres, in Occidente cuiu≈øque parte lapis in≈øcriptus, quorum Tumuli ≈øint, indicat. Qui medius e≈øt, Titulum habet, Tumulus Regum Scotiae, ferunt enim quadraginta octo Reges Scotorum ibi fui≈ø≈øe humatos, an Argument ≈øufficient, what litle intere≈øt they had in Britaine, when their ≈øo called Kings had no place of buriall heare. Neither can the Scots ≈øay, they v≈øed that Iland for buriall vpon deuotion, for the holines thereof by the Monkes there, and not nece≈ø≈øitie, for by their owne confe≈ø≈øion, their re≈øpect to that Iland grewe but from the time of Fergu≈øius the ≈øecond, who fir≈øt founded the Mona≈øtery, and funerall place for the Scottish Kings there, as the≈øe men confe≈ø≈øe, Fergu≈øius Abbatiam condidit, vbi Scotorum Regum deinceps voluit e≈ø≈øe ≈øepulchrum; who, as they write, was the 40. King, and Malcolme Cammoir after their 86. King changed that place of buriall, and Hector Boeth. in Catal. Reg. Scot. & Hi≈øt. Scot. l. 7. & 8. Georg. Buchan. Rer. Scot. l. 4. 6. it was time, for in the next King Donaldus his Brother his time, the Scots lo≈øt that, and all tho≈øe Hebrides Ilands, the Danes and Noruegians driuing them from thence. Betweene which two Scottish Kings, we cannot finde 48. to be buryed there, or where els. Yet the≈øe Scottish Antiquaries agree, that very many of their Kings in that time were not buried there in that funerall Ile, but in other places: neyther deny, but diuers which were buried there, were very wicked, and Impious men, farre from being ≈øuch as had any deuotion to that holy place, or any thinge that was Religeous. Therefore we mu≈øt needs acknowledge, that this was not onely a buriall place of deuotion, but ≈øome nece≈ø≈øitie was intermixed with it. Therefore no meruayle if the≈øe Scots had no Bishops in Britaine, when they had neither Sees nor Cities for eyther Bishops, or them≈øelues in this kingdome.

div.head: THE V. CHAPTER.

argument.p: HOW THE EMPEROVR SEVERVS, WHICH came into Britaine and ruled heare King, after Lucius, was of the Regall Race of the Britans and true Heyre to the Crowne heare, and ≈øo of others reigning heare after him.

div.p: 1. WHEN Eccle≈øia≈øticall affaires had thus proceeded with the Scots, and the Britans continued in variance and contention about a Succe≈ø≈øour to King Lucius in the kingdome, Seuerus Emperour came hither, ≈øome ≈øay, to quiet the debates, others affirme, it was to winne honour to him≈øelfe, being accompted very greedy and ambitious thereof, & to reduce the kingdome wholly to the Romans ≈øubiection, not willing that any Britan heare borne should Reigne, and therefore as ≈øome write they made a Decree and Lawe among them again≈øt ≈øuch gouernment. Eo fer√® temporis, po≈øt Lucium Regem Britonum extinctum, Romani gnari Britannos Reges Hector Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. lib. 5. f. 86. multarum in populo ≈øeditionum, & rebellionum in ≈øe fui≈ø≈øe Authores, vt res Romana in Britannia foret quietior publico vetuere Decreto, ne qui≈øpiam Britannici ≈øanguinis deinceps regia in≈øigniretur dignitate. If there was any ≈øuch Decree of the Romans, it could neyther be vpon this ≈øurmi≈øed motiue, that the Brittish Kings had bene occa≈øion of many Rebellions, and Seditions again≈øt the Romans, for it is euident that in the time of the three la≈øt Kings Marius, Coillus, and Lucius, peace was duely kept with the Romans, and their Tribute payed vnto them, and the≈øe kings di≈øcended of Genui≈ø≈øa a Roman Lady of the Emperours kindred, a≈øwell as from King Aruiragus the Britan, did participate both of the Brittish and Roman blood. And the≈øe were the onely Kings were heare after the compo≈øition betweene the Romans and Britans in the time of Claudius, and Aruiragus, when Aruiragus marrying the daughter of the Emperour ioyning the Brittish and Roman Regall and Imperiall Lines together thereby ended all debates betweene them.

2. Neither did any ≈øuch Decree probably pa≈ø≈øe the RomaÃÑ Senate, that none borne of Brittish blood should afterward be King in Britaine, if we will be guided either by rea≈øon, or Authoritie herein. For how could the Romans theÃÑ neither hauing ≈øuch power, or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øioÃÑ, take vpoÃÑ theÃÑ ≈øuch a definitiue ≈øentence? This had bene the next way to haue made a generall defection from them heare of all Britans. And I haue proued before, that the Britans except in ≈øome Municipall places, were gouerned by their owne, and not the Romans Lawes. And for Authoritie, we waÃÑt not tho≈øe that write how both our Will. Harri≈øon de≈øcr. of Brit. c. 22. Harding Chron. c. 52. f. 44 & alij apud Harri≈øon ≈øupr. Raphael Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 21. next Kings heare that came from Rome after this imagined Decree, Seuerus, and Ba≈ø≈øianus his ≈øonne and ≈øucce≈ø≈øor heare, were, Britannici ≈øanguinis, borne of Brittish blood, and yet both of them our Kings in Britaine, and Emperours al≈øo, and by ≈øome Antiquaries the next Heires to the Crowne of Britaine: Harding in his Chronicle thus te≈øtifieth from Antiquitie of Seuerus:

lg.l: Di≈øcended downe right Heire to Androgeus,
The elde≈øt ≈øonne of Lud that with the Emperour
Out of Britaine went with Iulius,
Which Senator afor≈øaid Seuerus
To Britaine came, and was introni≈øate
And with a crowne of gold was coronate.

div.p: Therefore if Seuerus the Emperour was di≈øcended downe right Heire to Androgeus, the elde≈øt ≈øonne of King (Lud the wordes of the≈øe Authours ≈øo ab≈øolutely and con≈øequently not without good warrant affirming it) he mu≈øt needs both be di≈øcended of the Regall Brittish Race, & be al≈øo the vndoubted next true Heire to the Crowne of this kingdome at that time: all other Lines which might by any probabilitie make claime before him, being now extinct. And this of it≈øelfe (be≈øides that I shall add hereafter) is more then any Authour of like credit to him I haue alleadged doth bringe to proue that Seuerus was not di≈øcended by lineall and lawfull birth from our Brittish Regall Race, but ≈øome other, in which I finde a ≈øilence in Antiquitie, onely diuers write, (and nothing hindering his Regall Brittish Genealogie) that he was Florent. Wigor. Chron. an. 181. & 203. Matt. We≈øt. an. 192. Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. Martin. Polon. An. 213. Henr. Hunting. l. 1. Hi≈øt. in Seuero. borne at Leptis in the Prouince of Tripolis in Afrike, and was the onely African that euer was Emperour: yet none of them denieth thereby his di≈øcent from Brittish Parentadge, but ≈øome of them yeld to that which confirmeth it, and his Aunce≈øters being ≈øtrangers ≈øo long out of Britane, as from Iulius Cae≈øar his time, no wonder if he was borne in that place of Afrike. For I haue shewed before that in the time of Ve≈øpa≈øian, we had many thow≈øands of Britans went into tho≈øe parts, and without que≈øtion diuers of them married, and continued there in their Po≈øteritie: ≈øo did diuers Britans at other times, euen with wiues and children, goe to Rome, and from thence were di≈øpo≈øed into diuers parts neuer returning hither.

3. Baronnius with others confe≈ø≈øing that Seuerus was di≈øcended of mo≈øt Baron. Tom. 2. Annal. An. D. 195. Manu≈øcr. Gallic. ant. c. 109. Matt. We≈øtm. an. 206. Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 5. c. 2. Rich. Vit. Hi≈øt. l. 4. Io. Selden Analect. c. 7. Galfr. Mon. ≈øup. l. 5. c. 3. Prot. Cata. Reg. Brit. in Seuero. Magdeburg. cent. 3. c. 16. Flor. Wigor. 198. 220. Matth. We≈øtm. An. 205. 206. noble Parents, con≈øtat Seuerum fui≈ø≈øe Maiorum claritudine nobili≈øsimum: & yet not able to de≈øcribe his Aunce≈øtrie, doth ≈øufficiently proue him a ≈øtranger to tho≈øe Countryes, and their Hi≈øtorians. And to make further Manife≈øtation herein, allthough he was borne in Afrike about Tripolis, ≈øo farre from Britaine, yet he had Marryed a Brittish Lady, as diuers of the ≈øame Authours and others te≈øtifie, and had by her Ba≈ø≈øianus his ≈øonne, after King of Britaine, and Emperour al≈øo. Some ≈øay her name was Martia, and the fir≈øt wife of Seuerus, and Si≈øter of Fulgentius the Britan that warred again≈øt, and ≈ølew, Seuerus at Yorke, Fulgenius Matris Ba≈øsiani frater, as the Brittish Hi≈øtory reporteth. And this Brittish Lady could not be Married to Seuerus after his comming into Britaine, but longe before, where he then liued in the Ea≈øt parts of the world. For in Britaine he liued but a short time, by our Prote≈øtants calculation in their Catalogue of the Kings of Britaine, 4. yeares. The Magdeburgian Prote≈øtants haue the like accompt, following Eu≈øebius. Florentius Wigornien≈øis maketh his aboade heare but three yeares. The Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øcarcely alloweth him 2. yeares continuance heare. The like haue others, all agreeing he was old and feeble at his comming hither. Yet Ba≈ø≈øianus his ≈øonne by our Dio in Caracalla. Brittish Lady was ≈øo old at his death, that he ≈øucceeded him both in this kingdome and the Empire, who being Emperour but 6. or 7. yeares was, as Dio and others write, at his death goeing on his 29. yeare of Age, aetatis annum agens vndetrigi≈øimum: Allmo≈øt 20. yeares olde, when his Father fir≈øt landed in Britaine.

4. Therefore it is ≈øo farre from being a di≈øproofe of Seuerus his di≈øcent from the Regall Race of our BritaÃÑs, becau≈øe he was borne in Afrike, that liued ≈øo remote from hence, & with ≈øo many difficulties ioyning him≈øelfe in Marriadge with a Lady of Briraine, & of ≈øo Noble a Family that her brother claimed to be King heare, is a pregnaÃÑt ArgumeÃÑt that he al≈øo was of our Brittish kingly Race, and ≈øo di≈øcended as our Antiquarie hath before de≈øcribed. And in this re≈øpect being the fitte≈øt & mo≈øt likely maÃÑ, by his true Title to the Crowne of Britaine, with the vnion of the Roman & Brittish forces to appea≈øe the Tumults heare, Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. l. 5. c. 2. Harding Chron. in Seuer. c. 52. & alij. & by this his vndoubted Right to the Crowne of Britaine, he was ≈øo coÃÑfident to effect this de≈øigne, that he brought but two Legions of Roman Souldiers to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him. For the more willing enterpri≈øe whereof, Britaine the Natiue Country of his Empre≈ø≈øe she ≈øtill liuing, and Ba≈ø≈øianus their ≈øonn's vndeniable Title to be King heare after his Father, called vpoÃÑ him to take this expeditioÃÑ in his owne par≈øon, otherwi≈øe mo≈øt vnfitt for ≈øuch a Iorney and attempt, for as diuers write he was not onely olde, but ≈øo lame and trobled with the Goute, that for the mo≈øt part he was carried in his bed-couche. Senex iam & morbo articulari Hector Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. l. 5. f. 87. laborans, lectica plurimum vehebatur. Thus it appeareth how probable it is, that Seuerus was not onely di≈øcended of the Line of our Brittish Kings, but was immediate true Heire to the Crowne of Britaine, for being granted, that he was right Heire to Androgeus the elde≈øt ≈øonne of King Lud, there could be Galfrid. Mon. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 3. c. 20. l. 4. c. 1. 2. 3. 4. 5. 6. 7. 8. 9. Matth. We≈øtm. aetat. 5. ca. 25. 26. 27. 28. Hard. Chron. c. 41. 42. 43. 44. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 3. c. 10. Stowe and Howes Hi≈øt. in Lud. Ca≈ø≈øibelan. Theomantius. Balaeus l. de Scri. Brit. centur. 1. in Fulgenio. none to claime it before him. For it is the generall con≈øent of our Hi≈øtorians, Brittish or Saxons, Catholiks or Prote≈øtants, that King Lud left two ≈øonnes behinde him younge at his death, the forenamed Androgeus being the elde≈øt & vndoubted Heire of Britaine, and Theomantius, or Tenancius the ≈øecoÃÑd: & two Brothers, Ca≈ø≈øibelan which next ruled in re≈øpect of the Minoritie of his nephewes, (Androgeus the elde≈øt going a way with Iulius Cae≈øar) and Nennius: after Ca≈ø≈øibelaÃÑ (by the departing hence of the elde≈øt brother Androgeus) Theomantius ruled. After whome Aruiragus, Marius, Coillus, and Lucius by who≈øe death without I≈ø≈øue or Heire in Britaine, the immediate true Right of this kingdome belonged to Seuerus. And after Seuerus his death Ba≈ø≈øianus his onely ≈øonne by the Brittish Empre≈ø≈øe his wife, Si≈øter to Fulgenius of the Regall blood of Britaine, Fulgenius vir ≈øanguine Regio clarus, and ≈øo neare Titler to the Crowne, that he with greate a≈ø≈øi≈øtance aduaunced his claime vnto it, being both by Father and Mother (his Father & Vncle taken away by death) the next immediate Heire was both King of Britaine and Emperour by all Antiquities. And by this we finde how vntrue, or to no purpo≈øe the ≈øuppo≈øed Decree of the Roman Senate was to di≈øable tho≈øe to gouerne heare, which di≈øcended of Brittish Parents.

div.head: THE VI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE STATE OF CHRISTIANS ESPECIALLY, in Britaine in the time of Seuerus, vnder whome allthough in ≈øome parts there was greate per≈øecution of Chri≈øtians, yet not heare in Britaine, but the Chri≈øtians were heare in quiet without affliction.

div.p: 1. NOW to ≈øpeake ≈øomewhat of Seuerus his Alienation or affection, from, or to Chri≈øtian Religion, it is the common opinion, and our owne Antiquaries be of the ≈øame, that in diuers places of the Empire, he was an enemy ≈øo farre vnto it, that many terme him the fift Per≈øecutor among the Emperours after Nero, and many Chri≈øtians in diuers Prouinces were Martyred in his Empire. Po≈øt Neronem Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. an‚ñ™ 283. Matth. We≈øtm. An. 195. Flor ‚Ä¢ nt. Wigor. in Cron. An. 189. & 211. Iudas Scr ‚Ä¢ ptor. Eccle. teÃÑpore Seueri apud Eu≈øeb. l. 6. c. 6. & Baron. To. 3. Annal. An-204. Spartianus in Seuero. Eu≈øeb. in Chron. & l. 6. c. 2. Hier. l. de Scrip. Eccl. in Origene c. 54. Magd. coÃÑt. 3 Dio. Hi≈øt. Rom. l. 51. Acta S. Phil. Martyris apud Baron. To. 2. An. 204. & nota ‚Ä¢ . in Martyr. 13. Sept. Martyr. Rom. 13. Septemb. B ‚Ä¢ d. V ‚Ä¢ nard. & Ado. eod. die. Act. S. Philipp. ≈øupr. & Cornel. Tacitus l. 17. Seuerus quintam Per≈øecutionem in Chri≈øtianos excitauit, plurimique Sanctorum per diuer≈øas Prouincias Martyrio coronantur. And it is ≈øo certaine by all forreine Antiquities, that there was ≈øuch Per≈øecution in his time, that it was allmo≈øt a common opinion that the comming of Antichri≈øt was at hand, as an Eccle≈øia≈øticall Writer of that time hath left to Po≈øteritie: propterea quod per≈øecutionis tumultus contra nos excitatus multorum mentes, tam grauiter perturbaret, Antichri≈øti aduentum, omnium ore atque ≈øermone iactatum, iam tum appropinquare arbitratus e≈øt. Yet we doe not finde any expre≈ø≈øe Edict or Prohibition of him vntill about the tenth yeare of his Empire. When as Spartianus writeth in his Iorney from Syria to Alexandria, he made many Lawes, forbidding vnder greate penaltie, any man to be either a Iew or Chri≈øtian. In Itinere Palae≈øtinis plurima Iura fundauit. Iudaeos fieri ≈øub graui paena vetuit: Idem etiam de Chri≈øtianis ≈øanxit. And as Dio and others witne≈ø≈øe, he con≈øented euen by his Imperiall letters, both to the depriuing of S. Philip of the Augu≈øtall Prefectship of Egipt, being become a profe≈ø≈øed Chri≈øtian, and giuing Authoritie to Terentius his Succe≈ø≈øor ≈øecretly to martyr him. But for Seuerus excu≈øe, we finde the greate≈øt, and allmo≈øt onely Per≈øecution of this time, to haue bene either in, or about Iury, occa≈øioned by the tumults of the Iewes, or in Afrike wher Seuerus was borne, and principally in Egipt then full of Chri≈øtians, the Prefect him≈øelfe S. Philip a profe≈ø≈øed Chri≈øtian, and ≈øo potent, as the letters of Seuerus vnto him ≈øay, he liued more like an ab≈øolute King, then Prefect, that Prefecture of Egipt being of ≈øo greate Authoritie, and dignitie: te tanquam Regem potius quam praefectum elegit Egipti Prae≈øidem: and Cornelius Tacitus affirmeth as much of the Prerogatiue of that Pre≈øidentship: Aegiptum a diuo Augu≈øto Equites Romani obtinent loco Regum.

2. Therefore Africk being the Country of Seuerus birth, and ≈øo formidable an ‚Ä¢ nemie in former times to the Romans, as all Hi≈øtories report, and now ≈øo abounding with Chri≈øtians, ≈ølanderou≈øly accu≈øed by their Pagan Enemies to be Enemies to the Roman Empire, Seuerus may ≈øeeme by ≈øuch acclamations again≈øt his owne inclination to haue giuen way to Per≈øecution.
And the rather becau≈øe the Gno≈øtick Heretikes giuen then ouer ≈øo farre to all filthines, that as Irenaeus, Nicephorus, and others write, they did publikly profe≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo practi≈øe, that all which would come to perfection in their Sect, which they onely allowed, mu≈øt commite all filthines: omnem eos oportere perpetrare Nicephor. l. 4. c. 2. Hi≈øt. Eccl. Iraen. apud eund. & aduer≈ø. Haere≈ø. l. 1. c. 24. turpitudinem, & infandis omnibus faeditatibus ≈øatisfacere. The≈øe Heretiks being accompted Chri≈øtians with Pagans, might ≈øooner prouoke the Emperour by ≈øuch mens informations, again≈øt the mo≈øt holy Profe≈ø≈øours of Chri≈øtian Religion: Which were ≈øo free from being ≈øuch as they were fal≈øely reputed with tho≈øe their Enemies to be, that as Athenagoras in his defen≈øiue Oration for theÃÑ, in the name of the Chri≈øtians de≈øired no mercie or fauour but to be vtterly rooted out, if tho≈øe impious ≈ølaunders could be proued true again≈øt them. Si vera ista ≈øunt, nulli parcite generi, animaduertite in eiu≈ømodi facinora, Athenagor. orat. pro Chri≈øtianis. Niceph. l. 5. Hi≈øt. c. 26. Tertull. l. ad Scapul. c. 4. vn√† cum coniugibus & liberis radicitus nos extirpate, & occidite. Nicephorus ≈øaith Chri≈øtianitie florished in his time. Cum Seuerus ≈øucce≈øsit ≈øatis bono loco res no≈øtrae fuere. Vniuer≈øae multitudines & domus totae ad fidem accedebant. And Tertullian then liuing ≈øaith: Ip≈øe etiam Seuerus Pater Antonini Christianorum memor fuit, nam & Proculum Christianum qui Toparcion cognominabatur, qui eum per oleum aliquando curauerat, requi≈øiuit, & in Palatio ≈øuo habuit v≈øque ad mortem The Emperor Seuerus a louer of Chri≈øtians, and in Britaine no Per≈øecutor of them but protected ≈øuch. eius, quem Antoninus optim√® nouerat lacte Chri≈øtiano educatus. Sed & clari≈øsimas faeminas & clari≈øsimos viros Seuerus ≈øciens huius Sectae e≈ø≈øe, non modo non lae≈øit, verum & te≈øtimonio exornauit, & populo furenti in os palam re≈øtitit: Seuerus al≈øo him≈øelfe Father of Antoninus was kinde to Chri≈øtians, for he ≈øought for Proculus √† Chri≈øtian, who had ≈øome time before cured him with oile, and kept him in his Palace with him ≈øo long as he liued. He was exceedingly well knowne to Antoninus, that was nur≈øed by a Chri≈øtian woman. And Seuerus knowing both mo≈øt renowned women, as al≈øo most honorable men to be of this Profe≈øsion, was ≈øo farre from doeing them any hurt, that he commended them, and openly re≈øisted euen to their face the raging people. Therefore if Seuerus the Emperour was of his owne di≈øpo≈øition ≈øo great a louer of Chri≈øtians in generall, if he honoured Proculus in his Palace ≈øo long as he liued, gaue allowance that his Sonne and Heire Antoninus Ba≈ø≈øianus Tertull. ≈øupr. Dio in Seuero. & Antonino Caracull. Baron. To. 2. Annal. An. 195 King of Britaine, and Emperour after his Father, should both be nur≈øed by a Chri≈øtian woman, and be ≈øo familiar with ≈øuch knowne profe≈ø≈øed Chri≈øtians, as Proculus was, and was the Ouer≈øeer of Euodus the Tutor or Bringer vp of Ba≈ø≈øianus his Sonne, as may be gathered both by Tertullian, Dio, and The Empre≈ø≈øe Lady Martia wife to Seuerus a Britan, and in profe≈ø≈øion, or affection a Chri≈øtian. others, and both Seuerus him≈øelfe ≈øo greate an honourer both of mo≈øt renowned Chri≈øtian men and women, and his Lady and Empre≈ø≈øe Martia of Britaine, ≈øo farre affected and di≈øpo≈øed to Chri≈øtian Religion, that if she did not profe≈ø≈øe it in Act, yet in affection and de≈øire ≈øo honoured it, that she would not permit her Sonne and Heire to be nur≈øed by any, but a Chri≈øtian woman, and the Ouer≈øeer of ≈øo greate a chardge to be a Chri≈øtian, ≈øo famous and renowned for his faith, as Proculus was knowne of all men to be. The≈øe con≈øidered I dare not boldly ≈øay, that Seuerus did in any time or place of his owne inclination wittingly and willingly without great incitation condi≈øcend to ≈øuch Per≈øecutions, as are remembred in Hi≈øtories to haue bene in his Empire.

3. And after his comming into Britaine, we doe not finde the lea≈øt ≈øu≈øpition in our Antiquities, that he did of him≈øelfe, or ≈øuffer any other to per≈øecute any for Chri≈øtian Religion: But rather both of him≈øelfe, and at the In≈øtance of his Brittish Empre≈ø≈øe, at the lea≈øt a Chri≈øtian in affection, and both powerable with him and their Sonne Ba≈ø≈øianus his Heire and Succe≈ø≈øour, and
for that loue and tru≈øt he founde in the Brittish Chri≈øtians of all that part of Britaine, South to the wall and Trench which Adrian and he made ioyning with him, again≈øt his Enemies to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe him of the Crowne of Britaine, he was a greatefull friend to them, and their holy Profe≈ø≈øion. And all our Hi≈øtories are cleare, that Religion was heare in quiet without mole≈øtation or affliction, vntill the Empire of Diocle≈øian, that greate Per≈øecutor. Yet we cannot deny, but all places in Britaine being now full of warlike mi≈øeries, and the Chri≈øtians heare both in Albania, Loegria, and Cambria mixed and ioyned both with Roman, and Scythian Infidels, many of them fell both to wickednes, and Pagani≈øme al≈øo. Which occa≈øioned holy Gildas to write, that Chri≈øtianitie was receaued but coldly of the Inhabitants of Britaine, and with ≈øome continued perfect, but not ≈øo with others, before Diocle≈øian his Per≈øecution. Praecepta Christi ab Incolis tepid√® apud quo≈ødam tameÃÑ integr√® & alios minus, v≈øque Gild. l. de excid. & conqu. Brit. c. 7. ad Per≈øecutionem Diocletioni Tiranni. And not onely in the time of Diocle≈øian his Per≈øecutioÃÑ, following in this Age we finde euen whole Cities & Townes, as Verolamium and others vtterly de≈øtitute of Chri≈øtians, but long before, and about this time we are a≈ø≈øured, that there were very many Britans, and not of meane e≈øtate, but ≈øuch as were publikly employed about the affaires of S. Mello a Britan, Archbishop of Roan in NormaÃÑdy the kingdome, and ≈øent from hence to Rome about it, that eyther were fallen from Chri≈øtianitie, or neuer for≈øooke their Pagan Religion. For we reade both in auncient Manu≈øcripts, and other Authours, in the life of S. Mello a Britan and after Archbishop of Roan in Normandy, ≈øent thither by S. Stephen Pope, not onely that he and his Brittish Companions, which were then ≈øent to Rome to paye the Tribute of Britaine there, were Pagans, and ≈øacrificed in the Temple of Mars, but it was then the cu≈øtome of the Britans comming thither about that office, ≈øo to doe, which to be a cu≈øtome could not be Manu≈øcr. antiq. in Vita S. Mellonis Epi≈øc. & Confe≈ø≈øoris. Io. Capgrau. Catalog. in eod. younger then the≈øe dayes, time short enough betweene this and that time to make a cu≈øtome. Tempore Valeriani Imperatoris Mello quidam de maiori Britannia oriundus Romam venit, vt Patriae ≈øuae TributuÃÑ ≈øolueret, & Imperatori ≈øeruiret. Ibique ≈øicut mos erat cum ≈øocijs ≈øuis ad templum Martis ductus e≈øt, vt ≈øacrificaret. And it ≈øeemeth this cu≈øtome had bene from the fir≈øt ≈øubmi≈øsion of the Britans to the Romans, for both Prote≈øtants and others affirme, that in Octauius Augu≈øtus time: Amba≈ø≈øadours came from Britaine to Rome, ≈øwearing Fealtie in the Stowe & Howes Hi≈øt. in Octauius Augu≈øtus. Temple of Mars, offering gifts in the Capitall to the Gods of the Romans. And we haue Te≈øtimonie in our Hi≈øtories, that after King Lucius death, and this very time, which we haue now in hand, it was the v≈øe and cu≈øtome of our Britans heare, when any of their Nobilitie or Gentry, were to obtayne the dignitie of Knighthood, to ≈øend them to Rome, to receaue that honour there, and after ≈øuch Pagan Rites and ceremonies, that Chri≈øtians could not in con≈øcience, ≈øo accept thereof. And yet ≈øuch multitudes euen in this time flocked thither from hence ≈øo to be created, that in this time when S. Amphibalus was conuerted Iacob. Genuen. Epi≈øc. in Catal. Sanctor. in S. Amphabel and Alban. to the faith by Pope S. Zepherine, as Iacobus Genuen≈øis a learned Bishop writeth, 15. hundred were ≈øo created. Of all which we finde no memory that any more were Chri≈øtians, then S. Amphibalus, and S. Alban, and yet both the≈øe conuerted after they had thus profe≈ø≈øed Pagani≈øme, S. Amphibalus by Pope Zepherine, who after made him Prei≈øt at Rome, and S. Alban S. Alban de≈øceÃÑded of the Romans. long after his returne from Rome, by the ≈øame holy Saint Amphibalus ≈øent hither by Pope Zepherine, in Britaine. And yet as the old Brittish Writer of Author Britan. Antiq. in Vita S. Albani. Capgr. in eod. S. Alban his life, Capgraue and others witne≈ø≈øe, S. Alban was rather di≈øcended of Noble Roman, then Brittish Parentage: Albanus ex illu≈øtri Romanorum
Pro≈øapia originem ducens, probably both of Roman and Brittish Aunce≈øtours.

4. And it ≈øeemeth the condition of many of others was not vnlike, and thereby a greate allurement for them to continue in the Romans Religion of who≈øe blood they were di≈øcended, in who≈øe municipall and priuiledged Townes many of them liued, and from whome they hoped and expected to receaue terreane honours and Aduancements. The Britans generally or, for the mo≈øt part profe≈ø≈øing the holy Chri≈øtian Religion, preferring heauenly before earthly honours. Yet it is euident by this is ≈øaide, that in this short tract of time, after the death of King Lucius many of the Britans by the continuall trobles of that time and conuer≈øation with Pagans, were either fallen from Chri≈øtianitie, or, as holy Gildas ≈øaith, profe≈ø≈øed it but coldly, tepid√® in re≈øpect of that zeale and feruour which was v≈øed in the dayes of Saint Lucius. And yet Seuerus of him≈øelfe was not ≈øo much giuen to wicked life, but renowned Martin. Polon. Supput. in Seuero. not onely for warlike affaires, but for learning and ≈øtudyes. Praeter bellicam gloriam ciuilibus studijs & ≈øcientia Philo≈øophiae clarus fuit. And ≈øo greate an enemy to IncontineÃÑcy, that he puished Adultery by Lawe with death, with ≈øuch ≈øeueritie, that Dio writeth that wheÃÑ he was Con≈øul he fouÃÑde by Records, Dio in Seuero. Herodianus in Seuero. Herodianus l. 3. that 3000. had bene put to death for that offence. Ego cum Con≈øul e≈ø≈øem, inueni ≈øcriptum in Tabulis tria millia Maechorum morte fui≈ø≈øe mulctata. And was after his death made a God among the Pagans. And Herodianus ≈øaith, he died rather of greefe for his childrens wickednes, then of ≈øicknes. Maerore magis quam morbo con≈øumptus, vita functus e≈øt. Which greefe for the ≈øinns of his ≈øonnes, as al≈øo Galfr. Mon. l. 5. c. 2. F. or. Wigorn. An. 195. 217. Mat. We≈øtm. an. 205. Harding. Cron. c. 53. f. 44. Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. l. 5. c. 2. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 206. Hard. ≈øup. Pont. Virunn. l. 5. Dio Hi≈øt. l. 55. of his owne in permitting the Chri≈øtians in many places to be greuiou≈øly per≈øecuted, I would not deny: but that he died of any ≈øuch greefe, is vntrue, being mo≈øt certaine, that he after ≈øo many Conque≈øts in other Countryes, when he came to fight again≈øt his Country Chri≈øtians, he was enforced dishonorably to make a Wall and Trench of aboue 130. miles in lenght to keepe his Enemyes back from inuading him, and ≈ølaine in battaile by Fulgenius (others call him Fulgentius) brother, by ≈øome before, to his fir≈øt lawfull true wife the Empre≈ø≈øe Martia a Briton, Interfectus e≈øt Seuerus Imperator. In acri certamine interficitur Seuerus. And by the Roman Writers them≈øelues, he was at this time when he was ≈øo ≈ølaine at Yorke 65. yeares old. And allthough he left 32. Legions as Dio writeth, to defend that his temporall Empire, which had ≈øo per≈øecuted the Church of Chri≈øt, yet that temporall Empire with all tho≈øe propes began to ≈øtagger, and notwith≈øtanding ≈øo greate Per≈øecution the kingdome of Chri≈øt, as Tertullian then liuing witne≈ø≈øeth, was adored and ruled in all places. Cum Romani tot Legionibus ≈øuum Imperium muniant, nec trans i≈øtas gentes Tertullian. aduer≈ø. Iudaeos c. 7. porrigere vires regni ≈øui po≈øsint: Chri≈øti autem Regnum, & nomen vbique porrigitur, vbique creditur, ab omnibus gentibus ≈øupranominatis colitur, vbique regnat, vbi
que adoratur. And particularly heare in Britaine, as he hath ≈øaid before, Chri≈øtianitie reigned whether the Pagan Romans could not, nor dur≈øt come, but walled and trenched in them≈øelues for feare.

5. He left behinde him two ≈øonnes, Ba≈ø≈øianus his elde≈øt by his lawfull wife of Britaine, before remembred, and Geta by Iulia his ≈øecond wife a Roman, if she may be termed a wife, his fir≈øt & lawfull ≈øtill liuing. He reigned as Baronius contendeth 17. yeares 8. moneths and 3. dayes. But our Hi≈øtorians make Baron. An. D. 195. 213. Flor. Wigorn. Chron. An. 180. 202. his Empire ≈øomewhat longer. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter maketh him Emperour compleate 18. yeares: Romanum con≈øecutus Imperium, imperauit annis 18. Florentius Wigornien≈øis citing Ca≈ø≈øiodorus, and the Roman Hi≈øtorie ≈øaith,
he was Emperour 18. yeares, and 3. Moneths, Seuerus regnauit annis 18. te≈øte Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. in Seuero Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 5. c. 2. Pontic. Virun. Hi≈øt. l. 5. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 206. Ioan. Harding. Chron. c. 53. Bal. l. de Script. Brit. cent. 1. in Fulgenio Audaci. Ca≈øsiodoro men≈øibus etiam tribus ≈øecundum Hi≈øtoriam Romanam. Marianus Scotus ≈øaith, he held the Empire 19. yeares, Cum 19. annis Seuerus tenui≈ø≈øet Imperium, dece≈øsit. And whereas it is generally agreed vpon, both by our Brittish and Saxon Hi≈øtorians, and Antiquaries, whether Catholiks or Prote≈øtants, that Fulgenius after his former di≈øcumfiture by Seuerus, went ouer into Scythia, interpreted to be that Country which now is called Denmarke, and brought with him a greate Armie of the people of that Nation, which our Antiquities call Picts, before he fought with Seuerus, and they both there were ≈ølaine, or died at Yorke: Fulgenius cum diutius re≈øistere nequiui≈ø≈øet, transfretauit in Scythiam, vt Pictorum auxilio dignitati re≈øtitueretur. Cumque ibi omnem InuentuteÃÑ Patriae collegi≈ø≈øet, reuer≈øus e≈øt cum maximo nauigio in Britanniam, atque Eboracum ob≈øedit: the≈øe were none of the Chri≈øtian Picts, or Scots which liued in our Ilands, who had ioyned with Fulgenius before, and many of them were ≈ølaine, as the ≈øame Authours te≈øtifie: con ‚Ä¢ ucebat in auxilium ≈øibi quo ≈øcumque In≈øulanos populos inueniebat: but they were Pagan Picts, of whome many remaining heare after the death of the≈øe two Generals, they had a place giuen vnto them to Inhabite in the Country Albania. Carau≈øius vt triumphum habuit, dedit Pictis locum man≈øionis in Albania, vbi cum Britonibus mixti per ≈øequens aeuum Galfr. Mon. ≈øupr. c. 3. Fabian. Hi≈øt. Polychron. Wil. Harri≈øon de≈øcri. of Brit. c. 22. Hollinsh. Hi≈øtor. of Engl. l. 4. c. 23. Bed. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. l. 1. Capgr. in S. Niniano. Hect. Boeth. Scotor. Hi≈øt. l. 7. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. in Ninia. Bernicio. man≈øerunt. Thus write our Brittish Hi≈øtorians, and our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries agree, when they ≈øay, that, Carau≈øius gaue vnto the Scots, Picts and Scithians the Country of Cathne≈ø≈øe in Scotland, which they afterward inhabited. And the≈øe were tho≈øe Pagan Picts, and people which S. Ninian and others ≈øent from Rome, did longe after conuert to the faith of Chri≈øt, as S. Bede and others te≈øtifie, for the Ilanders which were Picts, and Scots, were conuerted in Pope Victor his time as I haue declared before, which is an other Argument again≈øt the Scottish writers, which would haue them≈øelues ≈øeated in the Country now called Scotland ≈øo long a duration of yeares, as they haue claymed before.

div.head: THE VII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: HOW IN THE TIME OF BASSIANVS SONNE of Seuerus being Emperour he was both in Britaine, whence he was di≈øcended, and other places: he was a friend to Chri≈øtians, and Per≈øecutour of their Per≈øecutours. How S. Zepherine the Pope then ≈øent diuers Apo≈øtolike men into Britaine.

div.p:
1. AS ≈øoone after the death of the Emperour Seuerus, the TeÃÑporall ≈øtate of our Britans being freed from many ≈øurges, & waues of calamities did finde a calme; So the Church of Chri≈øt e≈øpecially in this kingdome, eÃÑtered thereby into an harbour of ≈øome ea≈øe, and quietnes from ≈øuch enormities & afflictioÃÑs, as v≈øually growe and happen in ≈øuch times. For the Quarrell for this kingdome being principally betweene Seuerus, and Fulgenius their Complices and Confederats,
allthough Seuerus was actually ≈ølayne in that bloody conflict at Yorke, yet Fulgenius followed pre≈øently after, being by all Writers mortally wounded in the ≈øame Battayle. Fulgenius laethaliter vnlneratus est. And for Po≈øteritie the Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. l. 5. c. 2. Pontic. Virun. l. 5. Matt. We≈øtm. An. 206. Harding. Chron. c. 53. condition of Seuerus was farre berter then that of Fulgenius, for whether the Britons or Romans should preuayle in choo≈øing a King, or Emperour, Seuerus leauing two Sonnes, one of the Brittish, the other of the Roman blood, left proui≈øion for both euents: When the ca≈øe of Fulgenius was not ≈øuch, he him≈øelfe not noted to haue had any true Title to the Crowne of Britaine, but cho≈øen King or Captayne of them, which would not admitt the Romans Gouernment, duce Fulgenio, and Fulgenius Dux populi profligati: And King Fulgenius Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. l. 5. c. 2. Pontic. Virun. l. 5. Matt. We≈øtm. ≈øupr. Hard. ≈øupr. elected to be King rather of Loue, and nece≈ø≈øitie, then by any Title he had ≈øo to be. And if he had any Right by di≈øcent to the Crowne of Britaine, ≈øeeing we reade of no child, or Brother, he left behinde him, that Title which he claymed, mu≈øt needs di≈øcend to the elde≈øt Sonne of Seuerus, which was Ba≈ø≈øianus, Sonne al≈øo to the Si≈øter o ‚Ä¢ Fulgenius, as ≈øome before haue written, now hauing by the death of his Father Seuerus, and vnkle Fulgenius, both their Titles with the allowance of the Empre≈ø≈øe Martia his Mother, lawfully inue≈øted in him.

2. Therefore to decide, and end all Controuer≈øies in this bu≈øines, the Britans with common a≈ø≈øent did chu≈øe and accept Ba≈ø≈øianus, both for their King, (being the next and vndoubted Heire, whether we shall ≈øtaÃÑd eyther vpon his Fathers or vnkles Title) and al≈øo for Emperour, as the Elde≈øt Sonne and Heire of Seuerus vndoubted Emperour, and for his leauing Sonnes behinde (as the cheife≈øt cau≈øe) made a God among the Romans; So writeth Herodian with others: Mos e≈øt Romanis con≈øecrare Imperatores, qui ≈øuper≈øtitibus filijs vel ≈øucce≈ø≈øoribus Herodian. l. 4. moriuntur. And an English Prote≈øtant Antiquarie though not citing Authoritie, deliuereth the ≈øame in the≈øe words: The Romans accu≈øtome to con≈øecrate Stowe Hi≈øt. Romans in Seuerus. with Immortalitie ≈øuch Emperours as at their death leaue eyther children, or Succe≈ø≈øours in the Empire behinde them. And tho≈øe which are endued with that honour they canonize among≈øt the Gods. Therefore to v≈øe the ≈øpeach of an other Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorian from Antiquitie, Seuerus by birth a Roman, but in blood a Harri≈øon de≈øcr. of Britaine c. 22. Manu≈øcr. Gallic. Antiq. cap. 109. Galfr. Mon. l. 5. c. 2. Pontic. Virun. l. 5. Matth. We≈øt. an. 206. Harding Chron. in Seuerus & Ba≈ø≈øianus. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Eng. l. 4. cap. 22. Harri≈ø. de≈øcript. of Brit. c. 22. Tertull. ad Scapul. c. 4. Spartian. in Caracall. Briton, and the lineall Heire of the body of Androgeus Sonne of Lud, and Nephew to Ca≈øsibelan, was Emperour and King of Britaine. Geta borne of a Roman woman Iulia, was cho≈øen Emperour by diuers Romans, but ≈øoone after ≈ølayne by his halfe Brother Ba≈ø≈øianus the Briton. This Ba≈ø≈øianus reigned alone both Emperour and King of Britaine vntill his death. Be≈øides his hereditarie Title to this kingdome, it ≈øeemeth, that the Chri≈øtian Britans heare, were not a litle moued to chu≈øe, and receaue him for their King, for the hope they had, that he would eyther become a Chri≈øtian, or at lea≈øt a friend and no Enemy to that Profe≈ø≈øion, of which in his youth and tender yeares he had giuen no vulgar Argument: for be≈øides many other hopefull graces, and gifts he was then endued with, and brought vp by a Chri≈øtian Nur≈øe, and Chri≈øtian children, when he did ≈øee any Chri≈øtian Martyrs brought to wild bea≈øts to be killed and deuoured, he would weepe or turne his face away, as Spartianus is an ample witnes, Si quando feris obiectos damnatos vidit, fleuit, aut ocolos auertit. And being but ≈øeuen yeares old, hearing that one of his Chri≈øtian Playfellowes was greeuou≈øly beaten for that his Religion, as the common interpretation is, he could not long after enduer the Procurers of his beating, by the ≈øame Authour: Septennis puer, cum collu≈øorem ≈øuum puerum ob Iudaicam religionem grauius verberatum audi≈ø≈øet, neque patrem ≈øuum, neque patrem pueri vel Authores Spartian. ≈øupr.
verberum diu re≈øpexit. Where the Pagan Authour by the Iewes Religion, as often ≈øuch men doe, vnder≈øtandeth Chri≈øtian Religion, which both his Nur≈øe and this Playfellow of Ba≈ø≈øianus her Sonne did profe≈ø≈øe. And in this hope of the Britans now Chri≈øtians, that ‚Ä¢ a≈ø≈øianus would rather be a friend then Per≈øecutour of ≈øuch, they were not deceaued: for allthough contrary to his fir≈øt education, when he was with Chri≈øtians, being ≈øeparated from them he fell to ≈øuch and ≈øo many kindes of Impietie, as Hi≈øtories doe recompt, and putt an innumerable company of the Pagan Roman Nobles to death, and many of them, which had bene greate≈øt Enemies to Chri≈øtians, yet he died innocent from Chri≈øtian blood and Per≈øecution, and by his ≈øeueare punishmeÃÑt towards their aduer≈øaries, iu≈øtly to be interpreted a Reuenger of their wrongs, and former calamities. The common opinion is, that he reigned betweene 6. and 7. yeares. Allthough I finde in an old French Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtorie, entreating Manu≈øcr. Gallic. Antiq. c. 109. much of the affaires of this kingdome, written aboue 400. yeares ≈øince, that he was King of Britaine 29. yeares: Ba≈øsian tenoit le Roilme de Bretaine 29. ans.

3. All Ba≈ø≈øianus his time, and diuers yeares before, in the Empire of Seuerus, S. Zepherine was Pope of Rome, who as our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries acknowledge, being giuen wholly to the ≈øeruice of God, more then earthly things, ended his life with holy Martyrdome. Zepherinus rei diuinae magis, quam Ioh. Bal. l. 1. de Act. Rom. Pont. in Zephermo. Robert. Barns in Vit. Pont. Rom. in eod. Matth. Parker. Antiq. Brit. c. 17. humanae intentus Martyrio coronatus e≈øt. The≈øe Prote≈øtaÃÑts al≈øo, doe relate many worthy Actes of this holy Pope, amoÃÑg≈øt which, the≈øe they ≈øett downe at large in their publike Writings. He Decreed (≈øaye they) that Prei≈øts should not con≈øecrate the blood of Chri≈øt in a Chalice of wood. That all which were of yeares of di≈øcretion, should communicate at Ea≈øter at the lea≈øt euery yeare. That Prei≈øts should be pre≈øent when the Bishop ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe. That a Bishop accu≈øed should not without the Authoritie of the Pope of Rome, be condeÃÑned in Iudgment, eyther by Primate, Patriarke, or Metropolitane. Sanguinis Chri≈øti coÃÑ≈øecrationeÃÑ no in calice ligneo fieri debere ≈øtatuit. Omnes iaÃÑ Puberes vt ≈øemel in Anno ad Pa≈øchatis Ferias Euchari≈øtiam ≈øumerent, edixit. CuÃÑ Epi≈øcopus celebraret Mi≈ø≈øae ≈øacra, iu≈øsit omnes Presbyteros ade≈ø≈øe. Sine Romani Pontificis authoritate accu≈øatuÃÑ Epi≈øcopuÃÑ, nec a Primate, nec √† Patriarcha, nec √† Metropolitano in iudicio coÃÑdemnanduÃÑ e≈ø≈øe. This holy Pope as I haue cited before, from Iacobus Genuen≈øis (others con≈øenting thereto) conuerted our renowned Countryman S. Amphibalus which Iacob. Genuen. Epi≈øc. in Catal. Sanct. in S. Amphibalo. Author of the Engl. Martyrol. die 25. Iunij. Io. Lidg ‚Ä¢ te Monac. Bu ‚Ä¢ ien≈ø. in ‚Ä¢ ius Vita. Gerar. Li ‚Ä¢ gh. in ‚Ä¢ udim. In≈øignium. wonne by his preaching, life, and death after, ≈øo many thow≈øands of this Nation to Chri≈øt. Of whome a late Writer citing diuers Antiquities thus writeth: S. Amphibale being a Noble young man of Britany, and going to Rome with Ba≈øsianus Sonne to Seuerus Viceroy of the Britans, was there by Pope Zepherinus in≈øtructed ≈øecretly in the Chri≈øtian ≈øaith, baptized, made Preist, and ≈øent back into Britaine, there to preach vnto others. Neyther may we with prudence iudge, that ≈øo greate a concour≈øe of our Brittish Nobilitie, being then at Rome, and S. Amphibalus thus conuerted (a greate Noble man termed in Antiquities, the Sonne of a Prince, and ≈øo not without attendance) that he alone was thus conuerted, and employed by that holy Pope at this time. And not vnprobable but ≈øome of tho≈øe holy Apo≈øtolike men which are yet remembred in Hi≈øtories to haue a≈ø≈øi≈øted S. Amphibalus afterward in preaching Chri≈øt in Veremu ‚Ä¢ d. apud H ‚Ä¢ c ‚Ä¢ or. Boeth Sco ‚Ä¢ or. Hi≈øt. l. 6. f. 102. Hol ‚Ä¢ insh. Hi≈øt. of Scotl. in Chrathlint. the≈øe parts, receaued their Ordination, and In≈øtruction for the ≈øame at Rome, now or about this time, ≈øuch as were Modocus, Pri≈øcus, Calanus, Ferranus, Ambianus, and Carnocus, there is no repugnancie in time, for the≈øe were old men when the Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian raged heare, and S. Alban was martyred
in the yeare of Chri≈øt 282. pa≈ø≈øus e≈øt glorio≈øus Martyr Albanus anno Domini Manu≈øcr. Antiq. Vit. S. Albani. Capgr. Catal. in eod. Bar. Annal. An. 221. Robert. Barnes in Vit. Pont. Rom. in Zeph. Io. Bal. l. 1. Act. Pont. Rom. in eod. Dio in Caracal. Spartian. in Caracalla. Dio in Macrino. Manu≈øcr. Gallic. Antiq. c. 14. CoÃÑpilatio M. S. de ge≈øt. Brit. & Ang. in Carau≈øio. ducente≈øimo octoge≈øimo ≈øecundo: And S. Zepherine continued Pope as both Catholike and Prote≈øtant Antiquaries agree, vntill the yeare of Chri≈øts Natiuitie 220. when as a Prote≈øtant Bishop writeth, he was crowned with Martyrdome: anno Domini 220. martyrio coronatus e≈øt. About this time al≈øo, or a litle before, Ba≈ø≈øianus Emperour & King of Britaine was murthered betweene Ede≈ø≈øa, and Carras by Mardianus a Centurion, he marrying with the Si≈øter of the holy Chri≈øtian Lady Mammea, left their Sonne Heliogabalus behind him, who ≈øoone after was Emperour. An old French Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory ≈øaith, that Ba≈ø≈øianus was ≈ølayne by Carau≈øius, who after reigned 38. yeares. The ≈øame hath the Manu≈øcript Compilation in the≈øe words, & tandem fauentibus Britonibus (Carau≈øius) dimicauit cum Ba≈øsiano, & interfecit eam, & ≈øic gubernaculum regni in ≈øe ≈øu≈øcepit.

div.head: THE VIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: HOW VERY MANY KINGS WITH VARIABLE proceedings Ruled heare in Britaine before Con≈øtantius Father to the Greate Con≈øtantine by S. Helen our Brittish Lady: yet the Chri≈øtians heare were quiet from Per≈øecution, in all or most of their time.

div.p:
1. AFTER the death of S. Zepherine Pope, Calixtus the fir≈øt of Lamprid. in Diadame. & Iul. Capitolin. in Macrino. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 214. Flor. Wigorn. Chron. an. 226. Marian. aetat. 6. in Macrin. Mart. Polon. in Macrino. Henr. Hunt. Hi≈øt. l. 1. Dio in Macrino. Eu≈øebius l. 6. c. 15. Henr. HuÃÑt. Hi≈øt. l. 1. Matth. We≈øt. An. 215. Martin. Polon. & alij Marian. aetat. 6. in Heliogabalo. Florent. Wigor. Chron. an. 229. 207. that name ≈øucceded in the See Apo≈øtolike of Rome. And Ba≈ø≈øianus being, as before, murthered, Macrinus a Mauritanian, or Mori≈øcan by Nation, with his ≈øonne Diadumenus, or by ≈øome Diadumenianus, obtained the Empire; but they were both ≈ølayne by their owne ≈øouldiers, rebelling again≈øt them, when they had bene Emperours but one yeare, and two moneths. After whome Marcus Aurelius Antoninus Heliogabalus, or Elagabalus ≈øonne of Ba≈ø≈øianus Caracalla, before ≈øpoken of, was cho≈øen Emperour by the Armie, his Mother was named Soemiades, or Semiamira, the daughter of Me≈øa Si≈øter to Iulia the Empre≈ø≈øe the ≈øecond wife of Seuerus, and this Soemiades or Semiamides was Si≈øter to that mo≈øt renowned Chri≈øtian Lady Mamea Mother to Alexander the Emperour. Henry of Huntington and Florigerus a≈ø≈øcribe 4. compleate yeares to the Empire of Heliogabalus: adeptus imperium, tenuit 4. annis. Martinus alloweth him not fully ≈øo longe a Regiment. Yet Marianus ≈øaith with Roman writers, that he was Emperour 4. yeares and 8. Moneths. Marcus Aurelius Heliogabalus Antonini Caracallae filius regnauit annis quatuor, meÃÑ≈øibus 8. iuxta Hi≈øtoriam Romanam. Florentius Wigornien≈øis hath the ≈øame words, both for that continuance of his Empire, and Authoritie of the Roman Hi≈øtory affirming it, that he was true and immediate next King of Britaine, not onely during the time of his Empire, but in that ≈øpace al≈øo when Macrinus and his ≈øonne Diadumenus were Emperours, euen from the death of Antoninus Ba≈ø≈øianus Caracalla his Father, the vndoubted King of Britaine, both by his Fathers and Mothers Title. For allthough Martinus ≈øaith, that Seuerinus ≈øonne
of Ba≈ø≈øianus was Emperour with his Father: Antonius Caracalla imperauit annis Martin. Polon. Supput. An. 212. in Anton. Caracalla. in Macrino & Marc. Anton. & alij. Septem, & Seuerinus filius eius: yet ≈øeeing this Authour who ≈øo writeth con≈øenteth with all others, that Macrinus immediately ≈øucceeded to Ba≈ø≈øianus Caracalla, and Heliogabalus to Macrinus, he mu≈øt needs, to iu≈øtifie that his te≈øtimonie of Seuerinus being Emperour with Ba≈ø≈øianus his Father, ≈øay, that this Seuerinus died with his Father, or before, or was the ≈øame ≈øonne of Ba≈ø≈øianus which others doe call Heliogabalus, Marcus Antoninus and other names, which Heliogabalus is ≈øtiled by in Hi≈øtories.

2. While the≈øe things were acted with the Romans, the ≈øtate of Britaine was al≈øo vnquiet, and allthough Heliogabalus, and his brother Seuerinus al≈øo (if Ba≈ø≈øianus had any ≈øuch ≈øonne) was next true King of Britaine, yet neither of them enioyed it. For by all writers, one named Carau≈øius was King of Britaine not onely next after Ba≈ø≈øianus, but by diuers Authours ≈øome time al≈øo while he liued, giuing an ouerthrowe either to Ba≈ø≈øianus the Emperour, or Matth. We≈øtm. an. 286. rather ≈øome Lieutenant or generall of his of the ≈øame or like name heare in Britaine, and ≈øo made him≈øelfe King of Britaine. After whome by our Brittish Hi≈øtorie and Ponticus Virunnius, A≈øclepiodotus Duke of Cornwayle was made King, depo≈øing Alectus ≈øent hither again≈øt Carau≈øius, with three Legions, Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. lib. 5. cap. 4. Pont. Virun. l. 5. Matth. We≈øtm. An. 292. 293. 294 Harding. Cron. c. 56. 57. Galfrid. Mon. l. 5. Pontic. Virun. l. 5. Hard. Chron. cap. 59. Matth. We≈øtm. 302. Catal. Reg. Brit. & alij. Matth. We≈øtm. Ann. 286. Will. Harri≈ø. De≈øcript. of Brit. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 23. and as Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter and Harding write, was King three yeares vntill A≈øclepiodotus depo≈øed him. Next to A≈øclepiodotus was King Coel Father to the mo≈øt renowned Empre≈ø≈øe S. Helena married to CoÃÑ≈øtantius Emperour, and Mother to Greate Con≈øtantine their ≈øonne, our mo≈øt glorious King, and Emperour, after which time our Hi≈øtory will not be ≈øo ob≈øcure and confu≈øed as now it is. For as in the Succe≈ø≈øion of the≈øe I haue remembred, there is que≈øtion, ≈øo concerning the time of their gouernement, and their conuer≈øation al≈øo whether it was Chri≈øtian, or otherwi≈øe, it is not free from difficultie. Antiquaries agree, that Carau≈øius was next King to Ba≈ø≈øianus. Therefore when Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, and ≈øome others would not haue Carau≈øius to be King vntill about the 286. yeare of Chri≈øt, it mu≈øt needs be an error, either in them, their Scribes, or Printers: for it is euident before, and all the Roman Writers proue, that Ba≈ø≈øianus was dead many yeares, and diuers Emperours had ≈øucceeded longe before this time, and Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter him≈øelfe ≈øaith, that Ba≈ø≈øianus making warre again≈øt the Parthians was circumuented & ≈ølaine of his Enemyes betweene Ede≈ø≈øa and Carras in the yeare of Chri≈øt 213. Anno gratiae 213. Ba≈øsianus Imperator contra Parthos bellum mouens, Matth. We≈øtm. An. 213. Otto. Fri≈øing. Chron. l. 3. c. 29. Floren. Wigorn. an. 204. & 226. Marian. aetat. 6. an. 218. in Caracallo. inter Ede≈ø≈øam & Carras ab ho≈øtibus circumuentes occi≈øus e≈øt. which was aboue 70. yeares before he bringeth Carau≈øius to attempt any thing for the Crowne of Britaine. Florentius WigornieÃÑ≈øis followeth the like accompt, and ≈øetteth downe the very place of his death there to be O≈ødroena. And Marianus affirmeth the ≈øame, with the Roman Hi≈øtories, ≈øaying it was in the yeare of Chri≈øt 218. And both our old Brittish Hi≈øtory, and Ponticus Virunnius who giue the greate≈øt light in this matter, ≈øay plainely that Carau≈øius liued in Ba≈ø≈øianus time. Ba≈øsianus regno potitur. Eo tempore fuit in Britannia Inuenis quidam Galfrid. Mon. Hi≈øt. Reg. l. 5. c. 3. Pont. Virun. l. 5. nomine Carau≈øius. And add further that Carau≈øius ioyning with the Picts, which Fulgenius had got together again≈øt Seuerus, Father to Ba≈ø≈øianus, fought with his Army, and ouerthrowing it, was made King of Britaine. Prodiderant Ba≈ø≈øianum Picti quos dux Fulgenius matris ≈øuae frater in Britanniam conduxerant. Nam dum ei auxiliari debui≈ø≈øent, promi≈øsis & donarijs Carau≈øij corrupti, in ip≈øo praelio diuerterunt ≈øe a Ba≈øsiano, & in commilitones eius irruerunt. Vnde ≈øtupefacti caeteri, Galfr. & Pontic. ≈øupr. cum ignorarent, qui ≈øocij, qui ho≈øtis, ocius dilabuntur: & Victoria ce≈øsit Carau≈øio.
Qui vt triumphum habuit, regnique gubernaculum ≈øu≈øcepit, dedit Pictis locum man≈øionis in Albania, vbi cum Britonibus mixti per ≈øequens aeum man≈øerunt. And the≈øe Picts and Scots mu≈øt needs be tho≈øe of which the Scottish Hi≈øtorians write, when they ≈øay Ba≈ø≈øianus made peace with them, and the Britans which followed Fulgenius, and ≈øo went from hence to Rome. Icto cum Scotis & Pictis Hector Boeth. Scotor. Hi≈øt. l. 6. fol. 88. 89. Galfr. & Virun. ≈øup. faedere, dataque pace Fulgentio, & ijs qui cum eo coniurauerant Britonibus Romam cum patris vrn√¢ contendit. And whereas the Brittish Hi≈øtory and Virunnius ≈øay, that Carau≈øius did kill Ba≈ø≈øianus, dimicat cum Ba≈øsiano, & eum interemit: This was not Ba≈ø≈øianus our King and Emperour ≈øonne of Seuerus and Martia, but one Quintus Ba≈øsianus a Legate of the Romans. Perierunt eo tumultuario Hect. Boet. Hi≈øt. Scot. l. 6. fol. 100. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Scotl. in Chrathlint. praelio Quintus Ba≈øsianus Legatus, Hircius Cae≈øaris Procurator in Britannia, & cum illis praeter Romanorum militum ingentem numerum, gregariorum magna multitudo. Now being the common receaued opinion both of Roman and other Writers that Seuerus died in the yeare of Chri≈øt 213. the Authour of the Catalogue of our Brittish Kings thus ≈øetteth downe their Succe≈ø≈øions & RegimeÃÑts with their continuance. Ba≈ø≈øianus Caracalla 6. yeares. Carau≈øius 7. yeares. Alectus 6. Catal. Reg. Brit. ante Hi≈øt. Galfr. Monum. yeares. A≈øclepiodotus 30. yeares. Coelus 27. yeares. After whome Con≈øtantius his ≈øonne in Lawe by marrying his daughter S. Helen ≈øucceeded in the Crowne. By which accompt we haue betweene the death of Seuerus and Con≈øtantius his reigning heare 76. yeares and from Carau≈øius his death, and the beginning of Con≈øtantius Reigne 65. yeares. Harding maketh the di≈øtances Ioan. Harding. Chron. c. 53. 54. 55. 56. 57. 59. shorter, a≈ø≈øcribing to Ba≈ø≈øianus 7. yeares, to Carau≈øius 4. Alectus 3. A≈øclepiodotus 10. and Coile 11. yeares: Yet by this accompt al≈øo Carau≈øius was dead many yeares before that time, wherein Hector Boethius and ≈øome others make him to haue fir≈øt aduaunced any title to the crowne of Britaine.

3. Yet we may make ≈øome part of Attonement betwene the≈øe opinions, if we shall ≈øay with the Brittish and other Hi≈øtories, that Carau≈øius was but a younge man in the time of Ba≈ø≈øianus, or Heliogabalus, the true Kings of Britaine: eo tempore erat quidam Iuuenis in Britannia nomine Carau≈øius. And he went to Rome to procure his Commi≈ø≈øion there of the Senate to be Admirall, to keepe the Brittish ≈øeas: Romam profectus petiuit liceÃÑtiam a Senatu vt Maritimam Matth. We≈øtm. an. 286. Stowe Hi≈øt. Titul. the Romans an. 285. Britaniae ab incur≈øione Barbaric√¢ nauigio tueretur. Quae petijt impetrauit, & cum chartis ≈øigillatis Britanniam petiuit. And after he was thus admitted Admirall, longe time, and diuers yeares, mu≈øt needs be ≈øpent before he could come to that power by ≈øea and Land, with Britans, Picts and Scots, to be King of Britaine, allthough he was as diuers hold of the kingly Race, ex Regio ≈øtemmate, Hector Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. lib. 6. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Scotl. in Crathlint. and Vncle to that renowned Chri≈øtian King of the Scots, Crathlintus, though ≈øome ≈øtile him to haue bene of ba≈øe Linadge, ex infima gente procreatus, vnprobable in a maÃÑ obtaining ≈øuch honour of the Roman Senate, & renowne amoÃÑg Princes, Kings, and Emperours, and diuers of them Chri≈øtians. But to goe no further out of my way into a matter of temporall Hi≈øtorie, whether Ba≈ø≈øianus, or his ≈øonne Heliogabalus, both Emperours and Britans by Parentage, or Carau≈øius was in Britaine at this time, we are by this which is ≈øaide, a≈ø≈øured, that the Chri≈øtians heare were in quiet and peace: for if Ba≈ø≈øian us ≈øtill continued Hector Boeth. & alij ≈øup. Harding cap. 53. King, he had made peace with all Chri≈øtians heare, whether Britans, Picts, or Scots, before his departure hence to Rome, as I haue before remembred. And allthough Heliogabalus was otherwi≈øe a man of ≈øuch wicked conuer≈øation, that I had rather to referre any man de≈øirous to knowe the manner both of his owne and Fathers life to forreine Writers, then fill my pen with
the dishonour of their Race in them, yet no Hi≈øtorie maketh mention that he was any Per≈øecutour of Chri≈øtians. If Carau≈øius was King, it is not vnprobable, but he was a Chri≈øtian, aduanced, cho≈øen, and honored with that kingely dignitie by the Chri≈øtians, confederate with, and a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Chri≈øtian Scots and Picts their Kings or Rulers, and again≈øt the Pagan Romans a profe≈ø≈øed Patrone and Propugnor of the Rights and priuiledges, and Reuenger of the wrongs and Iniuries of the Chri≈øtians heare, contending by all meanes he could euen with the aduenture of his life, loo≈øing it in that Quarrell, to re≈øtore the Chri≈øtians of this kingdome to that quiet and honorable e≈øtate to be free from thraldome of forrein Pagans, which they happily enioyed in the gouernment of King Lucius, and the Roman Senate began now to infringe, and violate. This was the pretended end and ≈øcope of his de≈øignes, allthough by ≈øome Writers, not with a litle de≈øire of his owne greatnes and exaltation, no ≈øtrange di≈øea≈øe among greate Princes in any Age‚ñ™

4. Neyther doe we findeÃÑ that Alectus ≈øent hither with three Legions again≈øt Carau≈øius, allthough he ≈ølew him in Battayle and ouerthrew his armie making him≈øelfe King, and ≈øo continuing three yeares, in≈øulam tenuit per triennium, Compilatio M. S. de ge≈øt. Brit. & Angl. in Al ‚Ä¢ ect. Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 5. c. 4. Pont. Vir. l. 5. Ma ‚Ä¢ th. We≈øt. an. 292. Compilatio M. S. Supur. did per≈øecute the Chri≈øtian Britans vnder pretext of Religion, but for following Carau≈øius, and not yeelding ≈øubiection to the Romans, as they required. Alectus maximaÃÑ intulit Britonibus cladem, quia relict√¢ Republic√¢, ≈øocietati Carau≈øij adhae≈øerant. Where we ≈øee the rea≈øon of that affliction of the Britans by the Romans, becau≈øe, quia, they had for≈øaken the common wealth and Gouernment thereof, and followed Carau≈øius an V≈øurper, as the Romans e≈øteemed him. And other Hi≈øtorians maKe it plaine that onely the followers of Carau≈øius and no others were thus pro≈øecuted by Alectus. interficitur Carau≈øius, & in eius ≈øequaces ≈øaeuitum e≈øt. And Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter al≈øo ≈øaith, that Alectus did afflict onely tho≈øe Britans who for≈øaking their Country, had committed them≈øelues to the command of Carau≈øius. Alectus Carau≈øium interfecit. Pont. Virun. l. 5. Deinde cladem maximam Britonibus intulit, qui Republica relicta, Carau≈øij ≈øe coÃÑmi≈øerant Iu≈øsioni. Which Harding more plainely coÃÑfe≈ø≈øeth wheÃÑ he ≈øaith Matth. We≈øtm. an. 292. Harding Cron. cap. 56. of Alectus: Alecto then crowned and made King of all Britaine reigning fully yeares three; and well he ruled in all manner werking. And if Alectus or his Pagan Souldiers, and Vnderrulers, did vniu≈øtly per≈øecute any Britans for Religion, neyther he, nor they did e≈øcape the Iu≈øt vengance of God executed vpon them by the Chri≈øtian Britans in the like kinde, for when Alectus and his Infidell con≈øorts were at London gathered together to make ≈øolemne Sacrifice to their Idols, they were by the Chri≈øtians driuen from their Sacrifice, Alectus Pontic. Vir. l. 5. Galfr. Mon. l. 5. c. 4. Mat. We≈øt. an‚ñ™ 294. Harding Chron. cap. 56. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 23. Stowe & Howes Hi≈øt. Romans in A≈øclepiodotus shamefully putt to flight, and ≈ølayne, his army ≈øcatered, and though by Leuius Gallus his Colleage in ≈øome part renewed againe, yet both their Generall, Gallus and all his Romans were ≈ølayne by the Chri≈øtian Britons in one day. Factoque agmine den≈øo, inua≈øerunt Romanos, & vna die omnes interfecerunt. And their Leader Gallus coÃÑtemptuou≈øly throwne into a brooke taking name thereof, as our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries with Antiquitie thus deliuer. A≈øclepiodotus recouered Britaine, and ≈ølew the Romans Captaine named Liuius Gallus, neare vnto a brooke there at that time running, into which brooke he threw him, by rea≈øon whereof it is called in Brittish Nant Gallon, ≈øince in Saxon tongue Gallus or Wallus Harding. ≈øupr. c. 56. Galfr. Monll. 5. c. 5. Virun. lib. 5. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 294. brooke, and to this day the streete, where ≈øome times the brook raÃÑre, is called Walbroks. And proueth the Hi≈øtory of this Brooke both by publike Records, and Inqui≈øitions.

5. A≈øclepiodotus vpon this Victory was crowned King of Britaine, by
Parlament ≈øaith Harding, and by common con≈øent of the people, as both the Brittish Hi≈øtory, Virunnius, and Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter write, being Duke of Cornwall before, Triumphatis Romanis caepit A≈øclepiodotus regni diadema, & capiti ≈øuo, populo annuente, impo≈øuit. All the≈øe la≈øt Writers, except Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, ≈øay, Diocle≈øian his Per≈øecution began heare in his time, of which I shall ≈øpeake hereafter. And it ≈øeemeth, that diuers Hi≈øtorians not ob≈øeruing, that Con≈øtantius was heare twice, marrying S. Helen the fir≈øt time, and the ≈øecond time receauing her againe, when Maximian the per≈øecuting Emperour had forced him to putt her away, doe there vpon vary much about the yeares of our Kings in tho≈øe times. An old Manu≈øcript Chronologie doth ≈øay Ba≈ø≈øianus reigned 27. yeares, Carau≈øius whome yt calleth CareÃÑ cius 39. yeares, Alectus 15. yeares, A≈øclepiodotus 10. yeares, Coel 4. yeares. And after him his Sonne-in-Lawe and daughter, Con≈øtantius and Helen 11. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 295. Catal. Reg. Brit. ≈øupr. Hollinshed Hi≈øt. of Engl. c. 23. in A≈øclepiod. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. Engl. ≈øupr. yeares. The Prote≈øtant Cataloge of our Kings hath told vs, that A≈øclepiodotus reigned 30. yeares. The ≈øame hath Hollinshed calling it the common accompt of our Chroniclers. And by the ≈øame Authours and diuers others, King Coel, in the later end of who≈øe reigne the Romans by Con≈øtantius came in againe, was King 27. yeares. Thus he writeth of this matter, Coelus Earle of Colche≈øter, began his Dominion ouer the Britans, in the yeare of our Lord 262. Thus Coelus or Coell ruled the Land for a certaine time, ≈øo as the Britans were well content with his Gouernment, and liued the longer in re≈øte from Inua≈øion of the Romans, becau≈øe they were occupied in other places: but finally they finding time for their purpo≈øe, appointed one Con≈øtantius to pa≈ø≈øe ouer into this Ile with an armie, the which Constantius putt Coelus in ≈øuch dread, that immediately vpon his arriuall, Coelus ≈øent vnto him an Amba≈ø≈øadge, and concluded a peace with him, couenanting to paye the accu≈øtomed Tribute, and gaue to Con≈øtantius his daughter in marriadge, called Helen, a noble Ladie, and learned. Shortly after King Coell died, when he had reigned as ≈øome write Cap. 27. ≈øupr. Fabian. Matth. We≈øtm. Galfrid. Monum. Pont. Virun. Harding. ≈øupr. Manu≈øcrip. Antiq. pr. RegnuÃÑ Brit. Compilatio M. S. de ge≈øt. Bri. & Angl. Lib. M. S. qui vocatur Scala mundi. Sozomenus Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. l. 2. c. vlt. Eu≈øeb. l. 4. de Vita Con≈øtantin. Socrates Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. vlt. Eutropiusl. 10. Hier. in Chron. Ruffin. l. 1. c. 11. Bal. ceÃÑt. 1. in Flauio Con≈øtantin. Stow. Hi≈øtor. in CoÃÑ≈øtant. Holins. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 29. Bal. Cent. 1. in Helena Flauia. 27. yeares. And then he ≈øetteth downe, as all other Antiquaries doe, Con≈øtantius Father of Con≈øtantine the greate, our next King. And this he calleth the common opinion of our Writers. Which I finde not onely in our printed Hi≈øtorians, but in diuers Manu≈øcripts, not wanting Antiquitie for their warrant, though among them there is difference about the yeares of the reignes of tho≈øe Kings, all con≈øenting they reigned, and ≈øucceeded one to an other heare, as hath bene related.

6. And we mu≈øt eyther ≈øay, Coelreigned long, was twice King, or not King when Con≈øtantius marryed S. Helen his daughter, but after toward his death, or els contradict all Antiquaries, Greeks, or Latines, Chri≈øtians or Pagans, Catholiks or Prote≈øtants in the Hi≈øtorie of the Age and Empire of the mo≈øt renowned, noted and honorably remembred Emperour that euer was in the world Con≈øtantine the Greate. For they all agree, that he dying about the yeare of Chri≈øt 340. was then 65. yeares old, hauing bene Emperour aboue 30. yeares, and as Sozomen with others proue, was at the lea≈øt when he began to reigne 34. yeares of Age: Con≈øtantinus circiter quintum & ≈øexaginta aetatis ≈øuae annum moritur. Ex quorum annorum numero triginta & vnum regnauit: The like hath Eu≈øebius: duos & triginta annos extra paucos men≈øes & dies cum Imperio fuit: eundemque annorum numerum vita duplicabat. Socrates ≈øaith: vixit Imperator Con≈øtantinus annos ≈øexaginta quinque: triginta vnum regnauit. Eutropius ≈øaith, his Age was 66. and his Reigne 31. yeares. S. Hierome and Ruffinus for the Latins, agree with them. Our Prote≈øtants ≈øay he died in the 66. yeare of his Age, and the 32. of his Reigne. √® vita dece≈øsit ≈øenex aetatis
≈øuae anno 66. & Imperij 32. √† Chri≈øti Incarnatione 339. the 339. yeare of Chri≈øt. And by all in the yeare 340. at the furthe≈øt. The like Argument I may v≈øe, by the life and death of his ble≈ø≈øed Mother S. Helena in all Iudgments dying before her Sonne, being about 80. yeares old then, and but a young Virgin when she was marryed to Con≈øtantius his Father. One of our cheife≈øt Prote≈øtant Antiquaries, and not ≈øo plainely receauing the former Order in our Kings, doth confirme it further, ≈øaying, Helena liued 79. yeares and then departed Holinsh. ≈øupr. l. 4. c. 29. this life about the 21. yeare of her Sonnes reigne. Her Sonne the Emperour Con≈øtantine liued till about the yeare of Chri≈øt 340. after he had ruled the Empire 32. yeares and odd moneths. Therefore both he and all others mu≈øt needs allowe the Reigns and Succe≈ø≈øions of our Brittih Kings before remembred, and in a manner free this kingdome from the Romans in their times, as al≈øo make it euident, that the Roman Emperours neither did, nor could rai≈øe any Per≈øecution again≈øt our Chri≈øtians in Britaine, except in the time when Con≈øtantius fir≈øt came hither in the dayes of the Emperour Aurelianus, about the 3. yeare of his owne Empire, and yeare of Chri≈øt 273. and marryed Helen Daughter of Coel, then, or after King, or both, which no Antiquitie affirmeth, but all deny it, or the short Reigne of Alectus, vntill the comming of Maximian the Tyrant hither in the time of A≈øclepiodotus, as the common opinion is.

div.head: THE IX. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE POPES OF ROME IN THIS TIME, how by all writers, euen the Prote≈øtants them≈øelues, they were holy men, and both they and other learned holy Fathers in this time, were of the ≈øame faith and Religion, which the pre≈øent Roman Church and Catholiks now profe≈ø≈øe, and Prote≈øtants deny and per≈øecute.

div.p:
1. AFter the Martyrdome of S. Calixtus, S. Vrbanus the fir≈øt of The Religion of the Popes then the ≈øame that is now, by their aduer≈øaries. that name was Pope of Rome. This man, as Prote≈øtant Antiquaries, English and others write, liued in the time of that licentious Emperour Heliogabalus, and by the ≈øanctitie of his life, and ≈øingular learning did bring many in all places to Io. Bal. l. 1. de Act. Rom. Pontif. in Vrban. Pap. 16. Rob. Barnes in Vit. Pont. Rom. in V ‚Ä¢ bano. 1. Magdeb. cent. 3. c. 10. c. 277. true Religion: for which he was often bannished, but ≈øecretly recalled by the faithfull Chri≈øtians, and at he la≈øt receaued the Cro ‚Ä¢ ne of Martyrdome in the yeare of our Lord 233. Vrbanus Romanus ≈øub libidino≈øa be≈øti√† Heliogabalo Cae≈øare vixit, vitaeque ≈øanctitate & doctrin√† ≈øingulari multos vn ‚Ä¢ iquaque mortales ad Euangelium traxit. Hic ≈øaepenumer√≤ pro fide Chri≈øtiana ab vrbe pro≈øcribebatur; ≈øed √† fidelibus iterum claÃÑ reuocatus, Martyrij coronam anno Domini 233. tandem accepit. His Decretall Epi≈øtle is extant, written to all Bishops
S. Vrbanus Pope Martyred in the yeare of our Lord 233. of the common life, and offering of the faithfull. He plainely maketh mention of ≈øuch a common life as was vnder the Apo≈øtles, & defeÃÑdeth by his Decrees the goods ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the Church, that no man should inuade them by force or fraude. And he ≈øpeaketh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the vo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e of them which promi≈øe to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe nothing proper to them≈øelues, he instituted
that Confirmation should be mini≈øtred after Bapti≈øme. He ≈øaith that by Impo≈øition of the Bishops hands therein, the holy Gho≈øt is receaued: Extat vna eius Epi≈øtola Decretalis ≈øcripta ad omnes Epi≈øcopos, de communi vita & oblatione fidelium. Plan√® enim eiu≈ømodi vitae communis meminit, qualis ≈øub Apo≈øtolis fuit. Munit deinde Edictis bona Eccle≈øiae, ne quis ea vi aut fraude inuadat: & aliqua dicit de voto promittentium, ≈øe nihil rerum propriarum po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øuros. In≈øtituit in fine Confirmationem post Bapti≈ømum: dicit, per manus Impo≈øitionem Epi≈øcoporum accipi Spiritum ≈øanctum.

2. Next vnto S. Vrbanus ≈øucceeded Pope Pontianus, who as the≈øe Prote≈øtants Io. Bal. lib. 1. de Rom. Pont. Act. in Pontiano. tell vs, was Chri≈øti mini≈øter, ac di≈øpen≈øator My≈øteriorum Dei: exilium & ≈øupplicia pro Euangelio, proque Eccle≈øia pa≈ø≈øus e≈øt, post multas calamitates & grauia tormenta, Anno Domini 239. pro Chri≈øti fide, martyrij paena ≈øubijt. The Mini≈øter
S. Pontianus Pope ≈øuffered Martyrdum an. D. 239. of Chri≈øt and di≈øpen≈øer of the my≈øteries of God, ≈øuffered exilements, and punishments for the Ghospell, and the Church, and after many calamities and greuious Torments ≈øuffered the payne of Martyrdome for the faith of Chri≈øt, in the yeare of our Lord 239. He taught that God would haue Prei≈øts ≈øo familiar with him, that he Magdeburgen. centur. 3. col. 278 in Pontian. would accept of other mens Sacrifices by theÃÑ, and by them forgiue their ≈øinns, and reconcile them to him. And that Prei≈øts doe make with their owne mouth, the body of our Lord, and giue it to the people: Sacerdotum dignitati multa tribuit. Eos, inquit, Deus familiares in tantum ≈øibi e≈ø≈øe voluit, vt etiam aliorum ho≈øtias per eos acceptaret atque eorum peccata donaret, ≈øibique reconciliaret. Ip≈øi quoque proprio ore Corpus Domini conficiunt, & populis tradunt.

3. After S. Pontianus ≈øucceeded S. Anterus, who as our Protertants ≈øaye, attributed S. Antherus Pope and Martyr ≈øucceeded S. Pontinus. ≈øuch ≈øupreame Priuiledge to his holy See, that he ordained that Bishops might not goe from one Bishopricke to an other, without the Authoritie of the Pope of Rome. Epi≈øcopos ab vno Epi≈øcopatu ad aliam transferre, ≈øi id Eccle≈øiae nece≈øsitas vel vtilitas exigat licere: ≈øed ne id ≈øine ≈øummi Pontificis authoritate Robert. Barnes l. de Vit. Pont. Rom. in Antero. Io. Bal. l. 1. de Act. Pontif. Rom. in eod. fiat, cauit: and beatified the Church with his blood in Martyrdome in the yeare of our Lord 243. decorauit hic Antherm anno Domini 243. Eccle≈øiam ≈øuo ≈øanguine, quam antea pauerat verbo: which he had before fedd with the word of God.

4. S. Fabian as the≈øe men ≈øay was Miraculou≈øly cho≈øen Pope, the forme of a Doue ≈øitting vpon his heade, when he was ≈øought for to be Pope. Cum ad S. Fabianus miraeulou≈øly cho≈øen Pope. PoÃÑtificatum de≈øignatus quaereretur Columba ≈øuper eius caput ≈øedere vi≈øa e≈øt. He buil ded a Church-yard for the honour of Martyrs. He decreed that euery yeare vpon Maunday Thur≈øday, new Chri≈øme should be con≈øecrated, and the old Barnes & Bal. ≈øup. in Fabiano. Magdeb. Cent. 3 c. 10. col. 279. 280 &c. 5. col. 144. burnt. That Prei≈øts should not be accu≈øed or punished in the teÃÑporall, but Eccle≈øia≈øticall Court. He forbad marriadge within the fir≈øt degree of coÃÑ≈øanguinitie. That euery Chri≈øtian should communicate at the lea≈øt thri≈øe euery yeare. He decreede about ≈øatisfaction, the Rite of penance, & Excommunication, of the Age of ≈øuch as were to be made Prei≈øts, or admitted to holy Orders, of oblations or Ma≈ø≈øes euery day. Caemiterium pro Martyrum dignitate extruxit. Singulis annis in caena Domini Chri≈øma vt renouaretur, vetere combu≈øto, ≈øtatuit. Sacerdotes cau≈øam dicere, & mulctari in Sacro, non prophano foro debere edixit. Ne vxorem quis ducat intra quintum con≈øanguinitatis gradum, ≈øtatuit. Qui≈øque Chri≈øtianus vt ≈øingulis annis ter Euchari≈øtiam ≈øumeret, praecepit. Quaedam de ≈øatisfactionibus, de ritu paenitentiae, & de excommunicatione ≈øtatuit, de aetate presbyterorum ordinatorum, de oblationibus per ≈øingulos dies. They add further how he coÃÑdemned the Here≈øies S. Fabianus condemned the Here≈øies of the Nouatians and Helchites. of the Nouatians, and Helchites. And that he both baptized Philip the Emperour, and after put him to publike penance, among the ordinarie penitents. Whereas the≈øe men ≈øay, that S. Fabian appointed that euery yeare vpoÃÑ Maunday-Thur≈øday
new Chri≈øme should be hallowed, and the old burnt, no man may thereby phanta≈øie, that he was the fir≈øt Authour either of con≈øecrating, or yearely renewing of Chri≈øme, for in the very place from whence the≈øe Prote≈øtants deriue this Con≈øtitution, which is the ≈øecoÃÑd Decretall Epi≈øtle of this holy Pope, he playnely ≈øaith, that vpon that day when Chri≈øt ≈øupped with his Di≈øciples, and washed their feete, Chri≈øt him≈øelfe taught this con≈øecrating of Chri≈øme, and that the Popes of Rome thus receaued it from the Apo≈øtles. And for the yearely renewing of it vpon that day, he ≈øaith al≈øo, that it di≈øcended from the Apo≈øtles by all his Predece≈ø≈øors Popes of Rome, and ≈øo from the Apo≈øtles both the Church of Rome, Antioch, Hieru≈øalem, and Ephe≈øus, where the Apo≈øtles liued, did euer ob≈øerue. Art. 36. Prot. publ. glo≈ø≈øe ther. Prot. Booke of Con≈øecration in Pref. allowed glo≈ø≈øe, and authorized Booke of Con≈øecration) it is iu≈øtified to be vnque≈øtionably true, and mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary. And this allready proued by all Authoritie: as al≈øo the doctrine of exemption of Bishops, and Clergie men, from being conuented before Lay Iudges and Tribunals. The ≈øame is euident before of the Popes of Rome Spirituall Supreamacie. And diuers of the≈øe te≈øtimonies of S. Cyprian therein, are in his ≈øeuerall Epi≈øtles to Pope Cornelius. That place where he calleth the Roman Church the Roote and Mother of the Catholike Church is in his 45. Epi≈øtle, which is to Cornelius Pope, where he plainely ≈øaith, he exhorted all to follow that Church: Vt Eccle≈øiae Catholicae radicem & matricem agno≈øcerent, ac tenerent. Likewi≈øe his te≈øtimony that Rome is the Chaire of S. Peter, the principall Church from which Prei≈øtly vnitie is ri≈øen, is in his 55. Epi≈øtle, which is to the ≈øame Pope Cornelius.
