In which he affirmeth further that it is the Church of Rome, who≈øe faith the Apo≈øtle commended, and to which fal≈øe doctrine cannot haue acce≈ø≈øe: Eos e≈ø≈øe Romanos, quorum fides, Apo≈øtolo praedicante, laudata e≈øt, ad quos perfidia habere non po≈øsit acce≈ø≈øum. And there plainely ≈øaith, that Here≈øies and Sci≈ømes haue onely had originall, becau≈øe men would not obay Gods Prei≈øt, nor allow onely one Cheife Prei≈øt, and Iudge the Vicar of Chri≈øt in his Church. And calleth the Iudgment of this Prei≈øt, Chri≈øt Vicar, the Pope of Rome, the Iudgment of God, not to be di≈øobayed of any, and from ≈øuch di≈øobedience Sci≈ømes and Hee≈øies
doe ≈øpring. Neque aliund√® haere≈øes obortae ≈øunt, aut nata ≈øci≈ømata, quam inde quod Sacerdoti Dei non obtemperatur, nec vnus in Eccle≈øi√¢ ad tempus Sacerdos, & ad tempus Iudex vice Chri≈øti cogitatur. Cui ≈øi ≈øecundum mini≈øteria diuina obtemperaret Fraternitas vniuer≈øa, nemo aduer≈øum Sacerdotum Collegium quicquam moueret: Nemo po≈øt diuinum Iudicium, po≈øt populi ≈øuffragium, po≈øt Coepi≈øcoporum con≈øen≈øum, Iudicem ≈øe iam non Epi≈øcopi, ≈øed Dei faceret: nemo di≈øsidio vnitatis, Chri≈øti Eccle≈øiam ≈øcinderet: nemo ≈øibi placens, ac tumens ≈øeor≈øim foris Haere≈øim nouam conderet: ni≈øi ita e≈øt aliquis Sacriligae temeritatis ac perditae mentis, vt putet ≈øine Dei Iudicio fieri ≈øacerdotem.

12. Now that the≈øe holy Popes ≈øtoode vpon the ≈øame ≈øupreame priuiledge for the Church of Rome being the common doctrine and practi≈øe of them all, as Prote≈øtants confe≈ø≈øe, we neede not to ≈øtand vpon the≈øe in particular: yet the≈øe Prote≈øtants doe a≈ø≈øure vs fir≈øt, that Pope Cornelius maintayned Appeales to Rome: Cornelius Epi≈øtol√¢ 2. facit mentionem Appellationis ad Apo≈øtolicam Magdeb. cent. 3. c. 7. col. 181. Rob. Barnes l. de Vit. Pontif. Rom. in Cornelio. Sedem. And made a generall Decree to free Prei≈øts from ≈øwearing, except in matter of faith. And condeÃÑned the AfricaÃÑ Bishops Decree about RebaptizatioÃÑ. Pope Lucius, as they confe≈ø≈øe, maketh the Church of Rome the Mother of Churches, and affirmed that the Popes of Rome neuer erred, and contended that they cannot erre, prouing it by that place, where Chri≈øt ≈øaid to S. Peter, I haue asked for thee, that thy faith may not fayle. Lucius Romanam Eccle≈øiam Matrem Magdeb. Cent. 3. col. 183. c. 7. Eccle≈øiarum facit: & Apostolicos Pontifices nunquam erra≈ø≈øe a≈ø≈øerit, & ne quidem errare po≈ø≈øe contendit, ex eo loco quod Christus Petro dixerit: rogaui pro te, ne fides tua deficeret. And Pope Stephen made a generall Decree as the≈øe men affirme, for the whole Church, about receauing penitent Heretikes, how they were to be receaued. Stephani Papae Romani ≈øententia & re≈øcriptum hoc Magdeb. cent. 3. c. 8. col. 190. Robert. Barnes l. de Vit. Pont. Rom. in Stephano. Io. Bal. l. 1. Act. Rom. Pontif. in Stephano. fuit. Si √† quacumque haere≈øi ad Eccle≈øiam veniant, nihil innouetur ni≈øi quod traditum est, vt manus illis imponatur in paenitentiam. And generally for all Prei≈øts in all places, that they should not v≈øe at Ma≈ø≈øe, any other then ≈øacred ve≈øtments, Ne Sacerdos ali√¢ ve≈øte quam ≈øacr√¢, in ≈øacris vteretur, ≈øtatuit: By this holy Pope, which our Prote≈øtants confe≈ø≈øe was an holy Saint, and Martyr, and receaued a Crowne of Iu≈øtice thereby after he had conuerted many Gentils to Chri≈øt. Cum multos Gentilium ad Chri≈øti fidem conuerti≈ø≈øet, capite mulctatus, fit victima S. Sixtus Pope and Martyr. Deo, accept √† Iu≈øtitiae coron√¢.

13. The like they te≈øtifie of all his Succe≈ø≈øours in this Age. S. Sixtus the Ambr. l. 1. O≈øhc. c. 41. Prudent. in Hymno de S. Laurent. Magd. cent. 3. cap. 10. in Sixto. cap. 12. in Laurent. col. 297 298. next was Chri≈øti di≈øcipulus, & √® terreno coele≈øtis aeconomus factus, Chri≈øtiani gregis decus, atque imitandum exemplar, and preached the true word of God, ≈øalutare Dei verbum populo proponens. And yet this doctrine of this holy Pope, by all Antiquities, and the≈øe Prote≈øtants them≈øelues, was ≈øacrificing prei≈øthood, Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, Deacons a≈ø≈øi≈øting at the Altar, Chri≈øt really pre≈øent there, and offered in Sacrifice, with Lights vpon the Altar. Hic primus √® ≈øeptem viris, qui ≈øtant ad Aram proximi. Hunc e≈ø≈øe ve≈øtris orgijs moremque & artem proditum e≈øt, hanc Di≈øciplinam foederis libent vt auro Anti≈øtites. Argenteis ≈øcyphis ferunt fumare ≈øacrum ≈øanguinem, auroque nocturnis ≈øacris ad≈øtare fixos cereos. And this was ≈øo common and publikly receaued and knowne, that the Pagans them≈øelues were not ignorant of it. S. Dioni≈øius Pope and Martyr. Bal. l. 1. de Act. Rom. Pontif. in Diony≈ø. Robert. Barnes in Vit. Pont. in eodem.

14. Of S. Diony≈øius the next Pope, the≈øe Prote≈øtants ≈øay, he was famous for preaching the true faith, and dilating of Chri≈øts Church, and conuerted many, and among others the daughter and wife of the Emperour Decius, Cyrilla and Triphonia, and dyed an holy Martyr: Yet they al≈øo acknowledge, he was a Monke and Eremite before he was Pope. He
diuided Parishes and Dioce≈øes, a≈ø≈øigning their limits, and made other generall Lawes for the whole Church, concerning Heretikes and others to be accu≈øed, and conuented.

15. S. Faelix which was his next Succe≈ø≈øor was al≈øo, as the≈øe men confe≈ø≈øe, S. Foelix Pope and Martyr. an ab≈øolute vertuous man, and renowned, for he preached the word of God and died a glorious Martyr. Yet they al≈øo ≈øay, he was a Ma≈ø≈øing Pope, and Bal. l. 1. de Act. Pontif. ≈øupr. in Foelice. Rob. Barnes in eod. tooke order, that none but con≈øecrated Prei≈øts should ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe, he ordained that Ma≈ø≈øes should yearely be ≈øaide in honour of Martyrs on their Anniuer≈øary dayes, and no where but in ≈øacred places.

16. They ≈øay of Eutichianus, the next Pope, that he was, vir Deo dediti≈øsimus, √† doctrin√¢ & virtutihus Eccle≈øiae commendatus, diuini verbi praedicatione ≈øalutem S. Eutichianus Pope and Martyr. multis attulit populis: A man mo≈øt deuoted to God, renowned for learning, Bal. l. 1. Act. Ro. Pontif. in Eucichiano. Barn. in eod. and vertue, and by preaching the word of God, brought ≈øaluation to many people, and died a Martyr. Yet as they acknowledge, he tooke order for ≈øacred Ve≈øturs of Cleargy men, ≈øo honored he Martyrs, that with his owne hands he buried 300. and made generall Lawes for the whole Church.

17. Of S. Caius the next, and by common opinion the la≈øt of this Age, they S. Caius Pope and Martyr. ≈øay he was kin≈øman of Diocle≈øian the per≈øecuting Emperour, yet a mo≈øt worthie Ruler of the hou≈øe of God, in the Roman Church, and died a Martyr: Bal. & Barnes ≈øupr. in Caio. praepo≈øitus domus Dei in Eccle≈øi√† Roman√¢ probati≈øsimus. And yet he exempted Clergy men from lay Iudges, and as S. Euari≈øtus had done before, gaue order, that none should be a Bishop which had not before bene O≈øtiarius, Lector, Exorci≈øta, Acolythus &c.

18. If our Prote≈øtants will haue S. Marcellinus to haue bene Pope in the S. Marcellinus Pope and Martyr. end of this Age, ≈øeeing they bring him to the greate Councell of Sinue≈ø≈øa of 300. Bishops, be≈øides many other greate Clergie men: They haue this greate Barnes ≈øupr. in Marcello. Magdeburg. cent. 4. c. 9. To. 1. Conc. in Marcellino & Conc. Sinue≈ø≈øano in 3. exaÃÑplar. antiq. generall Councell the fir≈øt that euer was in the worlde, in all Copies plainely pronouncing: no man euer Iudged the Pope of Rome. The fir≈øt See is indged by none, Nemo vnquam iudicauit Pontificem: Prima Sedes non iudicatur √† quoquam. Now I will returne againe to the time of Pope Stephen, where I left.

div.head: THE X. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF S. MELLO, OR MELLON A BRITAN, SENT Archbishop by Pope Stephen from Rome to Rhoan in Normandy. Of S. Mellorus a Noble Brittish Martyr, and a Prouinciall Councell of Brittish Bishops heare in Cornewalle in this time.

div.p:
1. THE Hi≈øtorie of out renowned Britan S. Mello, or Mellon, by mo≈øt Authours, fell our in the time of S. Stephens being Pope. And it should ≈øeeme by out Hi≈øtories (which ≈øpeake of many, and long defections of the Britans in the≈øe dayes, and their withdrawing their Tribute, and obedience from them, except when Quintus Ba≈ø≈øianus, Alectus or ≈øuch men were ≈øent hither with power from the Romans to keepe Britaine in their ≈øubiection) that S. Mello S. Mello went to Rome. his going from hence to Rome with others of this kingdome, to pay the Brittans Tribute there, was in the time of that Ba≈ø≈øianus, or ≈øome ≈øuch Roman: our Antiquities being ≈øparing to giue vs warrant to ≈øay, that the Britans did ≈øo carefully pay their Tribute, vnder their other Rulers which loued not the Romans, but laboured to free them≈øelues, and this Kingdome rather from that ≈øubiection. And this the rather, becau≈øe as I haue proued before, it is probable the other Britan Rulers heare were Chri≈øtians, and ≈øo would not ea≈øely imploy Pagans in ≈øuch a bu≈øines, and ≈øeruice. For it is the con≈øtant agreement of the Writers of this Relation, that this Mello with his A≈ø≈øociats was at his S. Mello was fir≈øt, a Pagan. going to Rome, and being there al≈øo at the fir≈øt, a Pagan, & at the performing of his temporall dutie there, did after the manner of the then Infidell Romans Manu≈øcr. antiq. in Vita S. Mellonis. Capgtau. in codem. Anual. Eccl. Rothomagen. Diony≈ø. Alexandrin. & Eu≈øeb. l. Eccl. Hi≈øt. cap. 9. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 25 ‚Ä¢ . Trebellius. Aurelius Victor. Eutropius & alij in Galeriano. Eu≈øeb. in Vita Con≈øtantini l. 4. CoÃÑ ≈øtan. orat. ad SaÃÑ ctorum caetum c. 24. Florent. Wigor. an. 250. 272. Eu≈øeb. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 7. c. 12. ≈øacrifice in the Temple of Mars, being a ≈øouldiar by profe≈ø≈øion, and this was in the time of Valerian the Emperour, Tempore Valeriani Imperatoris Mello quidaÃÑ de Maiori Britannia oriundus Romam venit, vt patriae ≈øuae Tributum ≈øolueret, & Imperatori ≈øeruiret, ibique ≈øicut mos erat, cum ≈øocijs ≈øuis ad Templum Martis ductus e≈øt vt ≈øacrificaret. And by the Hi≈øtory of this renowned man, it ≈øeemeth, to haue bene in the beginning of this Emperours reigne, about the yeare of Chri≈øt 256. when by the te≈øtimony of Diony≈øius and Eu≈øebius, he was more friendly to Chri≈øtiaÃÑs, then any of his Predece≈ø≈øors, euen tho≈øe that were Chri≈øtians, as the two Philips, the Father and ≈øonne, and all his Court was full of Chri≈øtians, and as a Church of God, Valerianus prae Antece≈ø≈øoribus ≈øuis ≈øic comparatus fuit initio, vt erga homines Dei placidus e≈ø≈øet, & animo amico praeditus. Neque enim qui≈øquam Imperatorum ante eum tam clementer ac placid√® erga eos affectus fuit, ne illi quidem qui palam facti Chri≈øtiani dicebantur, ≈øic initio ille familiari≈øsim√® & amanti≈øsim√®, idque palam no≈øtros complectebatur, & tota illius aula referta erat pijs, & Eccle≈øia Dei facta. For (Valerian after ≈øeduced by the Magicians) became a mo≈øt greuious Per≈øecutor of Chri≈øtians, vntill being takeÃÑ Pri≈øoner by the Per≈øians, was detained there Pri≈øoner, vntill his death, made a Foote≈øtoole for their King when he tooke his hor≈øe, who cau≈øed this cruell Emperour to haue his skin to be pulled of, and his body powdred with ≈øalt
By which mi≈øerable life and death of Valerianus being Father to Gallienus, who was al≈øo a per≈øecuting Emperour, the ≈øonne recalled all Edicts again≈øt Chri≈øtians, and gaue them free v≈øe and exerci≈øe of their Religion: publicis Edictis Per≈øecutionem contra nos motam remi≈øit, & vt doctrinae no≈øtrae Prae≈øides cuncta liber√® pro Con≈øuetudine ≈øua obirent. So there was not ≈øuch freedome after in the time of Galerianus, for S. Mello or others to be pre≈øent at the Sermons either of S. Stephen, then Pope, or any Chri≈øtian Preacher, as the life of S. Mello witne≈ø≈øeth he was an hearer of Pope Stephen, and by him conuerted. Neither can it well appeare, how this Brittish Saint being a Souldiar, and a Pagan at his comming to Rome in the time of Valerian, not 8. yeares enioying the Fmpire, and both conuerted to Chri≈øt, and baptized by S. Stephen, and by him promoted to Pree≈øthood, by all Eccle≈øia≈øticall Orders, and degrees, Quem Stephanus Papa≈øibi adhaerentem per omnes Eccle≈øiae gradus v≈øque ad Sacerdotium promouit, and after made him Bishop, could come to ≈øuch perfection in the Papacy of S. Stephen, who ≈øuffered Martyrdome about the 257. yeare of Chri≈øt, by common conputation, longe before the death of Valerian, except he had bene conuerted in the beginning of his Empire.

2. This Mello, Mellon, or Mellanius coÃÑming to Rome with others of this kingdome, to pay the Tribute thereof to the Romans, as I haue ≈øayed before, and to ≈øerue the Emperor, and re≈øorting to the A≈ø≈øemblyes and meetings of S. Mello conuerted by S. StepheÃÑ Pope. the Chri≈øtians not yet forbidden in the beginning of Valerianus his Empire, hearing S. StepheÃÑ Pope preaching, was coÃÑuerted by him to the faith of Chri≈øt, and baptized, & being thus in≈øtructed, he ≈øold all that he had, eu & the Armour which he wore in the warrs, and di≈øtributing the money which he receaued Sainct Mellomade Prie≈øt. and Bishop. Act. & Vit. S. Steph. Pap. apud Baron. Tom. 2. Annal. Ann. 259. Dama≈øus in PoÃÑt. in Stephano 1. Baron. Tom. 2. Annal. An. 260. Martyr. Rom. 22 die Octobris. V≈øuard. Martyr. 22. die Octobris. S. Mello miraculou≈øly ≈øent to be Archbishop of Rohan in Normandie. to the poore, following his Conuerter S. Stephen, and giuing him≈øelfe wholly to Chri≈øtian deuotion, and ≈øtudy of Diuinty profited therin ≈øo much, not being ignorant in human Learning, which he had obtained in Britaine, (euer renowned for ≈øtudies, and Learned men) was by S. Stephen, by all inferior Orders (which I haue before remeÃÑbred) promoted to holy Prei≈øthood & after Miraculou≈øly cho≈øen of God therevnto was by the ≈øame holy Pope CoÃÑ ≈øecrated Bishop, and both extraordinarily by God, and ordinarily by Pope Stephen ≈øent to gouerne the Church of Rhoan in Neu≈øtria, now called Normandy in France, after he had ≈øuffered many mi≈øeries, and afflictions for his holy faith with S. Stephen, and others of his Cleargie impo≈øed vpon them by Valerianus, as may plainely be gathered out of the Acts and life of S. Stephen. And whereas S. Dama≈øus, or who≈øoeuer the auÃÑcient Writer of the liues of the Popes, commonly a≈ø≈øcribed to him, doth te≈øtifie, that S. Stephen did Con≈øecrate three Bishops onely, ≈øpeaking of no more, Epi≈øcopos per diuer≈øa loca tres. Baronius doth, and well conclude, that our holy Britan S. Melanius was one of them and renowned for ≈øanctitie, Ex ijs vnus fuit Melanius Epi≈øcopus Rhotomagen≈øis, ≈øanctitate celebris: Citing for that, the old Roman Martyrologe Manu≈øcr. antiq. de Vita S. Mellonis. Iacob. Genuen≈øis in Catal. de eodem. Capg. in S. Mellone. Petrus de Natalibus l. 9. cap. 93. Tabulae Epi≈øcoporum Rhotomagen. Vincent. l. 11. c. 74. which ≈øaith of this holy Bishop, that he was Con≈øecrated by Pope Stephen, and by him ≈øent to preach the faith about Rhoan, where he was Bishop in France. Rhotomagi S. Melanij Epi≈øcopi qui a ≈øancto Stephano Papa ordinatus, illuc ad praedicandum Euangelium mi≈ø≈øus e≈øt. V≈øuardus al≈øo hath the ≈øame, vpon the ≈øame 22. day of October.

3. The manner of his Miraculous Mi≈ø≈øion and ≈øending to be Archbishop of Rhoan in Normandy, is thus regi≈øtred in the old Manu≈øcript of his life, the auncient Learned Bishop Iacobus Genuen≈øis, Capgraue, Petrus de Natalibus and others: Cumque Ieiunijs & vigilijs in≈øtaret quadam Die Mi≈ø≈øam co celebrante
viderunt ip≈øe & Papa Angelum Dei ≈øtantem ad dexteram altaris. Qui peracta mi≈ø≈øa dedit ei virgam Pa≈øtoralem, quam manu tenebat dicens, accipe virgam, ≈øub qu√¢ reges populum Rhotomagen≈øis Ciuitatis in ≈øinibus Neu≈øtriae. Tibi enim illic praeparatus e≈øt a Deo locus: & licet labor incognitae vitae ≈øit tibi onero≈øus, nequaquam tamen tibi timendum, quoniam ≈øub vmbr√† alarum ≈øuarum proteget te Dominus Ie≈øus Chri≈øtus. Tunc accept√¢ benedictione a Papa Iter arripuit: As he continued in fa≈øtings, and watchings when he ≈øaid Ma≈ø≈øe, on a certaine day both he and the Pope did ≈øee an Angell of God, ≈øtanding at the right hand of the Altar. Who when Ma≈ø≈øe was ended, gaue vnto him a Pa≈øtor all ≈øtaffe which he held in his hand, ≈øaying, take the rodd with which thow shall Rule the people of the Citie of Rhoan in the borders of Neu≈øtria. For there a place is prepared for thee by God: and allthough the Labour of the vnknowne life be burden≈øome vnto thee, yet be not a fraide, becau≈øe our Lord Ie≈øus Christ will defend thee vnder the shadowe of his wings. So receauing benediction from the Pope, he tooke his Iorney. In which comming to Anti≈øiodorum he Miraculou≈øely cured S. Mello cured alame man, he died and was buried at Rhoan. a man there mo≈øt greuou≈øly wounded. Comming to Rhoan he there faithfully performed his ≈øacred office, renowned for vertue, and Miracles, he ended his life there, about the yeare of our Lord 280. his body is there ≈øtill kept with greate reuerence in the Cathedrall Church of that Citie neare to the body of S. Nica≈øius fir≈øt Bishop there, ≈øent by S. Clement Pope Succe≈ø≈øor to S. Peter, Tab. Eccl. Rhotomagon. apud Anton. Democharez contra Caluin. Io. Molan. in addition. ad V≈øuardum 22. Octobr. Martyr. Rom. die 11. Octobris. Bed. Martyrol. Prid. Idus Nouembr. and this the ≈øecond, as the Annals of that Church giue te≈øtimony. Molanus ≈øaith, he was Archbishop of Rhoan and was there mo≈øt honorably buried. In Gallijs ciuitate Rothomagi notalis Sancti Meloni, qui eiu≈ødem vrbis primus Eccle≈øiaÃÑ Archiepi≈øcop us rexit, ibidemque ≈øepultus glorio≈øi≈øsim√® quieuit. But the Roman old Martyrologe ≈øaith plainly, that S. Nica≈øius was Bishop there: Nica≈øij Epi≈øcopi Rhotomagen≈øis. S. Bede in his Martyrologe ≈øetteth downe the Fe≈øtiuitie of this holy Saint on the 12. day of Nouember, pridie Idus Nouembris Sancti Melani Rodouicae ciuitatis Epi≈øcopi. All others, place it vpon the 22. of October. What ≈øpirituall benefite the rare example of this holy Brittish Bishop by his ≈øtrange conuer≈øion in neglecting the ≈øeruice of the Emperour, and honour thereof, to be the poore ≈øeruant of Chri≈øt in per≈øecution, his Miraculous calling, and Mi≈ø≈øion in Epi≈øcopall dignitie, his life renowned for vertue, and Miracles, multis virtutibus & Miraculis clarus: and ≈øo long continuing ≈øo glorious and Archbishop ≈øo neare to this our Nation his Country, we may in prudence apprehend, though Iniquitie of times hath depriued vs of their memory ≈øo farre, that for this his short Hi≈øtory we are forced to appeale to forreine Antiquities.

4. And yet we haue ≈øufficient warrant left vnto vs by our owne Hi≈øtories, not onely in generall, a≈ø≈øuring vs that our Britans continued their fir≈øt faith quietly and inuiolably vntill Diocle≈øians bloody Per≈øecution, but particular te≈øtimonie, that euen in this time, by arguments, we had ≈øuch a florishing Church heare in Britaine, that we had not onely Bishops and Prei≈øts in greate numbers, but (which few other Nations can ≈øo ≈øoone for them≈øelues giue in≈øtance in) both publike Councells of Bishops and diuers Religious hou≈øes, both of men and women. We reade in the old Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtorie of the life of S. Melorus liuing in the beginning of the Britans Chri≈øtianitie, cum in exordio Manu≈øcr. Antiq. de Vita S. Melor. Io. Capgr. Catal. in eod. Harris. Hi≈øt. of Brit. to. 3. Christianae fidei conuer≈øa e≈øt Britanniae gentilitas, that there was a Councell of Brittish Bishops kept in Cornewayle, but a corner of this kingdome, In Cornubia Concilium Epi≈øcoporum congregatuÃÑ. And this holy Saint was there brought vp, and in≈øtructed in a Mona≈øtery nutritus in quodam Mona≈øterio Cornubiae: A Councell of Bishops in Cornwaile in this time. where the di≈øtinctiue word quodam, one certaine Mona≈øtery of Cornewayle,
doth ≈øufficiently notifie, that be≈øides all others in other parts of Britaine there were then more Mona≈øteryes in that Prouince of Cornewayle. Which is further proued by that which followeth in the ≈øame Authours, what an e≈øpeciall care the Abbot of that place had of this Noble glorious Saint yet a child: Abbas illius loci: ≈øufficiently prouing there were then other Abbots of other Abbayes in that Country. There, al≈øo mention is made of the Church, Nunnery, Altar, and Abbe≈ø≈øe of Anbesbury, whether the Reliks of that holy Saint were brought, after they had bene honorably buryed by the Bishops and Prei≈øts: ≈øepulto ab Epi≈øcopis & Clericis capite cum Sacro corpore. That the≈øe Bishops, Prei≈øts, Mona≈øteryes, and Religious men and women of Britaine were in this time, I am vrged to thinke, becau≈øe the≈øe Hi≈øtorians haue told vs before that the≈øe things were in the beginning of Chri≈øtianitie heare, and add, that then many beleeued, and following the Apo≈øtles Precepts, were famous for Miracles, and that S. Melorus was one of that number Multi Domino credentes, & Apo≈øtolica praecepta ≈øequentes varijs virtutum Miraculis ful≈øerunt de quorum numero beatum Melorum fidenter credimus extiti≈ø≈øe. Which is further confirmed in the ≈øame Antiquities, te≈øtifying that after many yeares the Reliks of this holy Saint were with greate reuerence tran≈ølated to the Church of Am≈øbury, and there in their shryne layed vpon the Altar. Po≈øt multorum annorum curricula Praedicatores Alienigenae ≈øcrinium cum Reliquijs ≈øancti Melori circumquaque deferentes peragratis terrarum tractibus iniunctum ≈øibi officium exercentes Ambrisburiam tandem deuenerunt, & ≈øuper altare Reliquias ≈øanctas po≈øuerunt. The remouing of the≈øe Reliks to the Church and Nunnery of Amsbury mu≈øt needs be before the preuayling of the Pagan Saxons, and Hengi≈øt his murthering our Noble Britans, and taking King Vortiger Pri≈øoner hard by that place, at Stonehendge by Treachery. For at that time, both that and all other Religious hou≈øes, and Churches, tho≈øe Pagans could enter to, were de≈øtroyed. Yet the Hi≈øtoryes haue told vs before, that many yeares were pa≈ø≈øed ouer, betweene the buriall and remouing the≈øe holy Reliks thither. Neither dare I affirme, that this Hi≈øtory is more auncient then this time. For excepting the Religious hou≈øe of Gla≈øtenbury, all others had their Foundation after the CoÃÑ uer≈øion of King Lucius, who dyed in the beginning of this Age. And probably we may coniecture, this Tran≈ølation of the≈øe ≈øacred Reliks was in the time of S. Germanus and Lupus the Legats of Pope Cele≈øtine, being and preaching heare, for they were praedicatores Alienigenae: Strange Preachers, and the mo≈øt renowned ≈øtrange Preachers we can thinke the≈øe to be, much deuoted to the reuereÃÑce of our holy Brittish Reliks by all Hi≈øtoryes making ≈øolemne Pilgrimadges vnto theÃÑ. And if we affirme, the≈øe holy Reliks were fir≈øt interred in the≈øe dayes, the circuite of many yeares, post multorum annorum curricula, after which they were remoued by ≈øtrange Preachers, will well agree with the comming of tho≈øe ≈øtrangers, the Popes Legats hither about the yeare of Chri≈øt 432. which was before the Nunnery of Amsbury was de≈øtroyed.

5. The Hi≈øtorie of this holy Saint is thus ≈øett downe by the auncient writers S. Meliorus his Martyrdome. thereof: Melorus or Meliorus was the onely Sonne and Heire of Melianus Duke of Cornwayle. Who in the ≈øeuenth yeare of his Gouernment, calling an A≈ø≈øembly of the Nobles, to con≈øult about the affayres of his Country, was in the ≈øame a≈ø≈øembly murthered by his owne Brother, named Rinoldus, his Sonne Melorus being but 7. yeares old at that time. This Rinoldus hauing thus killed the Father, & knowing his Sonne to be the onely true Heire, and fearing if he should liue to maÃÑs e≈øtate he might take the Dukedome from
him, being his iu≈øt inheritance, ≈øought to murther him al≈øo: and bringing him into Cornewayle where there was a Councell of Bishops and others gathered together, who≈øe con≈øent he laboured to haue for the putting of Melorus to death, to make him≈øelfe ≈øecure in his ≈øo wickedly procured dignitie: But when the holy Bishops a≈ø≈øembled, dete≈øted ≈øo barbarous impietie, and cruelty, and would in no wi≈øe a≈ø≈øent vnto it: This wicked v≈øurping Vncle, to make this child loath≈øome, and ≈øo vncapable or vnfitt for Gouernment, cau≈øed his right hand, and left foote to be cutt of. After which he had an hand of ≈øiluer, and a foote of bra≈ø≈øe, and was brought vp in a Mona≈øtery in Cornewayle vntill he was 14. yeares old, daily profiting and encrea≈øing in vertue, and holy learning a≈øwell, as in yeares. And this his ≈øiluer hand did miraculou≈øly bend too and froe, and ≈øtretch out it≈øelfe to doe the office of a naturall hand, as if it naturally con≈øi≈øted of bones, ≈øinewes, veines, blood, and flesh, Mirumque in modum manus illa argentea qua≈øi reflexus carneos habere, & manum extendere & recludere caepit qua≈øi natiuam o≈øsibus, neruis, venis, ≈øanguine atque pelle. Wherevpon the wicked Tirant his Vncle, taking him from the Abbot, and Religeous men, committed him to one, named Cerialtanus to be brought vp, bribing him with promi≈øes of many po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions and rewards to putt Melorus to death, which he mo≈øt wickedly and barbarou≈øly effected, cutting of his head. Which done the Sonne of Cerialtanus with the con≈øent of his Father, bearing the head of the holy Martyr vpon the wall of the Ca≈øtle, fell downe from the wall, broke his neck, and died. Cerialtanus then tooke vp the head of the Saint, and brought it to the Tirant his Vncle. Who with ioy receauing it, badd the wicked Murtherer goe to the topp of an hill adioyning, and what≈øoeuer he could there ≈øee he would giue him to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe, Cerialtanus going to the hill thinking to ≈øee round about, ≈øodenly was ≈øtruken blinde, one both his eyes, and pre≈øently died. And the wicked Vncle touching the ≈øacred head brought vnto him, within three dayes after ended his wretched life with a mi≈øerable death. The Bishops and Clergie buried his holy body, and head, with great honour together. Where they which faithfully prayed vnto him, did obtayne their de≈øire. Sepulto ab Epi≈øcopis & Clericis capite cum ≈øacro Bishops, Prei≈øts & others pray to S. Meliorus Martyred. corpore. Corpus ≈øanctum cum honore ≈øepelierunt: vbi opem eius cum fide implorantes, optatum remedium gaudentes con≈øequi ≈øolebant.

div.head: THE XI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: CONTAYNING AN ABREVIATE OF SOME ROman Emperours, and inuincibly prouing that the most holy Queene and Empre≈ø≈øe S. Helen, was a Britan of Regall Race, the onely true and lawfull wife of Con≈øtantius Emperour: and Con≈øtantine the Greate their true lawfull Sonne and Heire, borne in Britaine.

div.p:
1. I Haue ≈øpoken before, how the Roman Emperours after the death of Heliogabalus, vntill Con≈øtantius marryed, fir≈øt, or after receaued againe Helen daughter of Coel had litle command in this kingdome, and ≈øo not ≈øo nece≈ø≈øarie to be much remembred, in the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hi≈øtorie thereof, none of them, except the two Philips, the Father and Sonne, dignified in Hi≈øtories, with name of Chri≈øtianitie; therefore it will ≈øuffice, to ≈øett downe breefely their names, and continuance of their Empiers, which our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries doe thus propo≈øe vnto vs: After Seuerus, Ba≈øsianus Surnamed Antonius Carracalla ≈øucceeded Hows & Stowe Hi≈øt. Titul. the Romans. in Seuerus. in the Empire, he was murthered by Martialis, when he had gouerned ≈øixe yeares. Macrinus one yeare. Antonius Heliogabalus three yeares. Alexander Seuerus 13. yeares. Iulius Maximus 3. yeares. M. Antonius Gordianus one yeare. Iulius Philippus (they omitt Philip the ≈øecond his Sonne) the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian Emperour, 5. An Epitomie of the Roman Emperours. yeares. Decius 2. yeares. Trebonianus, Gallus, and Vibius Ho≈øtilianus two yeares. Iu lius Aemilianus foure moneths. Licinius Valerianus ≈øixe. Lacinius Gallicinus fifteene. At this time there arou≈øe in diuers Countries thirtie V≈øurpers which are called the thirtie Tirants, of the which Lollianus Po≈øthumus, Victorianus Tetricius, as it is ≈øuppo≈øed, kept Britaine from Gallicinus. Flauius Claudius two, Aurelianus fiue. Tacitus ≈øixe moneths. Florianus three moneths. This yeare 276. Aurelian the Dane was cho≈øen Emperour, he hated Chri≈øtians, and in the fourth yeare of his Reigne, he ≈øtirrid vp the ninth Per≈øecution, vpon the Church of God, he reigned fiue yeares, and ≈øixe dayes. And after, Tacitus ≈øucceeded him in the Empire, being a very fitt and worthie Gouernour, and after, Tacitus Probus Equirius Sonne to Delinacius a Clowne, and Gardiner by profe≈øsion, this Probus Equirius was a most valiant man at armes, and as good a Iu≈øticiar, as any that had the publike Gouernment, he began his Reigne in the yeare of Chri≈øt 282. and reigned ≈øixe yeares, and foure moneths. Aurelius Probus fiue yeares. In which time Bone≈øus a Britan borne, v≈øurped the Empire, with Proculus at Cullen, and would haue exempted from the Romans, Britaine, Spayne and part of France, but being vanquished by Probus, he ≈øtrangled him≈øelfe. This Probus, after he had reigned fiue yeares, was ≈ølayne of the ≈øouldiers. Carus was created Augu≈øtus, he made Carinus and Numerianus his Sonnes, Cae≈øars. To Carinus he a≈øsigned Britaine, Gaule, Illiricum, Italy, and Spaine, but Carinus was ≈ølaine by lightning, and the other two within three yeares ≈øpace lo≈øt their liues. Diocle≈øian was then cho≈øen Emperour, who adioyned Maximianus vnto him in like Gouernment. The two Emperours elected two Cae≈øars, Valerius Maximus, and Con≈øtantius
Chlorus, to which Constantius they committed the recouery of Britaine. Hitherto the≈øe Prote≈øtants Epitome of the Roman Emperours, from Antiquitie. And ≈øo being come to this Con≈øtantius, by whome Britaine, and the Romans were vnited againe in ≈øo happy an vnion, that thereby this our Noble Nation a≈ø≈øi≈øted more then any kingdome before had done, or after did for the vnion of the world with Chri≈øt, I mu≈øt heare more enlardge my ≈øtile, for our Countries honour.

2. Some there be, whether to detract ≈øo great a glory from this Nation, or to giue it to an other, or of Ignorance in Hi≈øtories, doe both ≈øay, that one Theodora was the fir≈øt lawfull wife of Con≈øtantius, and the ble≈ø≈øed S. Helen Mother of that happy Emperour the Greate Con≈øtantine, was not onely a ≈øtranger to this Nation, but of meane e≈øtate, and which is vnworthie to be Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. col. 304. in Con≈øtantio. Flor. Wigorn. Chron. an. 321. & 299. written, not the wife, but Concubine of Con≈øtantius. Which name and attribute, Concubina, this mo≈øt Noble Empre≈ø≈øe and Saint Helen is ≈øtiled by, not onely among diuers forreyne Writers, but of this Nation al≈øo, as Marianus Scotus, and Florentius Wigornien≈øis, as they be published by our Prote≈øtants, many of which doe not to the dishonour of that mo≈øt holy Lady and this her S. Helen borne of noble Parents in Britaine. Country ab≈øtayne from the ≈øame phra≈øe of ≈øpeach. This errour being ouerthrowen, ouerthroweth the others that she was a ≈øtranger, and ba≈øely borne. For excepting tho≈øe that wander in that Tract, all agree she was the ≈øole Capgrau. Catalog. Praefat. in Vit. S. Helenae. Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetate 6. in Auteliano. Baron. Tom. 2. Annal. an. 306. Iacob. Gordon. An. 273. in Aureliano. Harris. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. Brit. Tom. 4. c. 2. Zo≈øim. l. 2. Suid. in Con≈øtant. Matt. We≈øtm. ann. 273. Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. in Aureliano. Martin. Polon. Caxton f. 38. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. Capgr. in S. Helena Niceph. lib. 7. Cap. 18. Andre Che≈øne l. 4. Hi≈øt. daughter and Heire of the Noble Brittish King Coel, farre from being eyther an Alien, or of ba≈øe Parentage and di≈øcent, and the more ea≈øely to ouerthrowe them, it fir≈øt fighteth with, and ≈øo ouerthroweth it≈øelfe. Some which incline to this errour, ≈øay, that she did ≈øecretly fly out of her Country, and went to Rome, and there was ≈øo familiar with Con≈øtantius the Emperour. Multi eam clam patriam fugi≈ø≈øe affirmant ac raptam, apud Romam ab Imperatore: But it is euideÃÑt by all Hi≈øtories, that Con≈øtantius at his fir≈øt acquaintaince with Helena, was not Emperour, nor long after, neither was he at Rome, but in Britaine in this time, ≈øent hither, by Aurelianus the Emperour in the yeare of Chri≈øt 273. and as both Zo≈øimus and Suidas ≈øay, liued mo≈øt part heare: In Britannia plerumque viuebat. And being ≈øent hither by Aurelianus Emperour, as ≈øo many agree, to haue long imployment, and great cau≈øe of ≈øtay heare, he mu≈øt needs come hither about that time, for by all Antiquities, Aurelianus died ≈øoone after, and was Emperour but a short time. So that neither Con≈øtantius nor Queene Helen could be either at Rome, or in any place, but in Britaine at this time.

3. Nicephorus and ≈øome later after him, would haue her to be borne in Bithinia, at Drepanum, and the daughter of an Inkeeper there, with whome Con≈øtantius pa≈ø≈øing that way to the Per≈øians fell in loue. But this is made vnpo≈ø≈øible, by that is ≈øaid before of the being both of Con≈øtantius and Helena in Britaine, ≈øo remote from any part of Bithinia at that time. And neither of them comming to, or neare Drepanum, or any part of Bithinia, at, or after this S. Helen was not burne in Bythinia. time, but when she an holy widowe, many yeares after Con≈øtantius his death, pa≈ø≈øed by Greece in her Pilgrimadge to Hieru≈øalem, as is euident in all Marian. l. 2. aetat. 6. in Con≈øtan ‚Ä¢ io. Flor. Wigorn. C ‚Ä¢ ron. Regino An. 243. Martin. Polon. in Supputat. An. 30 ‚Ä¢ . Otto Frigen. l. 3. c. 45. Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. c. 8. kinde of Antiquaries, and will mo≈øt manife≈øtly appeare when I shall entreate thereof. Others there be which doe terme this renowned Empre≈ø≈øe by the name of Concubina as Marianus, and Florentius Wigornien≈øis as our Prote≈øtants haue published them, and Regino without ≈øpeaking any thing of her parentage, or Country, and Martinus Polonus, who confe≈ø≈øeth she was daughter to the King of Britaine, Constantius filiam Regis Britanniae, nomine
Helenam accepit in concubinam, de qu√¢ genuit Con≈øta ‚Ä¢ in ‚Ä¢ m Magnum: But it is euident that either Martinus, or his Prote≈øtant Publisher hath with gro≈ø≈øe Ignorance abu≈øed the Readers, for he ≈øaith, as I haue cited, that Con≈øtantine (not Con≈øtantius) begott Con≈øtantine the greate in the yeare of Chri≈øt 307. when by common opinion Con≈øtantius was dead before. And not content Martin. Polon. ≈øupr. An. 309. col. 66. with this, they bring in Con≈øtantine the Greate, to be Emperour in the yeare 309. when by their accompt he could not be two yeares old. The other three, if their Prote≈øtant Publishers haue not abu≈øed them, ≈øpeake in the phra≈øe of the Pagan Romans, who in tho≈øe times, called all wiues of their Lieutenants taken from ≈øtrangers, though neuer ≈øo lawfully ioyned in true Mariadge, by Papinian. l. Praefectur. ff. de ritu nuptiarum. that rude terme of Concubine, as their old Pagan Decree is ≈øtill witne≈ø≈øe again≈øt them. When I shall make it as cleare as the Sunne, that S. Helena was from the beginning the onely true lawfull wife to Con≈øtantius. This I haue S. Helen the true lawfull wife, to Con≈øtantius and no Concubine. written heare, to an≈øweare the≈øe friuolous Cauills again≈øt that ble≈ø≈øed woman, and with Ihon Capgraue call their allegations no better then dreames, talia ≈øomnijs ≈øimilia. And to ≈øpeacke ≈øtill in his words: That opinion doth not onely blemish the fame of ≈øo holy a woman, but maketh that mo≈øt Noble Con≈øtantine to be a Ba≈øtard, begott out of Marriadge, and ≈øo di≈øableth him to haue bene the Heire of Io. Capgr. in Catal. in praefat. in Vit. S. Helenae. Con≈øtantius, eyther King or Emperour, when all men know he came to the Imperiall dignitie by right of inheritance: Talis opinio non tam ip≈øius tam ≈øanctae faeminae denigraret famam, quam ip≈øum quoque nobili≈øsimum Constantinum, ≈øpurium ac extra ≈øpon≈øalia genitum, comprobaret, cum tamen ip≈øum iure haereditario culmen a≈øcendi≈ø≈øe Imperatorium, neminem lateat. And thus taxeth the Authours of Ignorance. Ip≈øis for≈øan qui ista ≈øcrip≈øerunt, talia placuerunt, quia potiora & veriora inuenire mi nim√® potuerunt. Diuers forreyne Hi≈øtorians as Baronius, Spondanus, and others write, as plainely in this matter; And may with greate warrant. For as Ca≈ø≈øiodorus is an able witne≈ø≈øe, it was but a Pagan report, dicitur, and rai≈øed fir≈øt by Zo≈øimus that mo≈øt malitious Ethnick, and Rayler again≈øt Con≈øtantine, for profe≈ø≈øing and aduancing of Chri≈øtian Religion, and renouncing Idolatry, De≈øertorem Deorum. And this is euident by the be≈øt learned Authours M. Aurelius Ca≈ø≈øiodorus in Chronic. Zo≈øimus Comes in Con≈øtantino. l. 2. them≈øelues, which in any ≈øence called S. Helen by that name: for they doe plainely confe≈ø≈øe, as namely Marianus, that S. Helen was the true wife of Con≈øtantius, and he forced by Maximian the Emperour to putt her away, and take Theodora his wiues daughter: Con≈øtantius vxorem quam habuerat repudiare, compul≈øus e≈øt. And further ≈øaith Con≈øtantine was true Sonne and Heire Whence it came fir≈øt that S. Helen was called Concubine. of Con≈øtantius, and by that Title ≈øucceded him in the kingdome, and Empire. Merito Religio≈øus Pater Religio≈øiorem filium Con≈øtantinum videlicet regni ben√® parti reliquit haeredem. Which could not be truely ≈øaid, if Helen had not bene his lawfull wife, neither could Con≈øtantius by this learned, and holy Authour, Marian. an. 292. c. 301. Marian. l. 2. aetat. 6. Ann. 305. col. 303. be named Religio≈øus Pater, a Religeous father, if he had not begott his Sonne in lawfull in true marriage. And S. Bede confe≈ø≈øeth from Eutropius, that Con≈øtantine ≈øucceeded his Father in the kingdome in Britaine. Scribit autem Eutropius, quod Con≈øtantinus in Britanni√¢ creatus Imperator, Patri in Regnum ≈øucce≈ø≈øerit. And ≈øo by him al≈øo mu≈øt needs be his lawfull Sonne. Florentius Wigornien≈øis writeth in the ≈øame manner, and confe≈ø≈øeth, S. Helen to haue bene heare in Britaine, long after her Sonne Con≈øtantine was Emperour. Yet the≈øe be the cheife≈øt Authours that in any ≈øence haue termed S. Helen by that Bed. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 8. name.

4. It is euident by all Hi≈øtoryes, not onely of Chri≈øtians, that S. Helen was Flor. Wigorn. Chron. An. 328. & 306. a mo≈øt cha≈øte and holy woman, and that Con≈øtantius al≈øo liued in coniugall
cha≈øtitie marrying when he was but vouÃÑge but al≈øo eueÃÑ by the Pagan Writers Gallic. Orat. Panagyr. ad Con≈øtantinum apud Baron. Tom. 2. An. 306. Henric. Spondan. ibid. & al. Harris Hi≈øt. Eccl. Tom. 3. Nichol. Vignier Biblioth. Hi≈øtor. ad An. 306. theÃÑ≈øelues, as witne≈ø≈øeth Gallicanus the Orator, that liued in his time, in his publike Oration to his ≈øonne Con≈øtantine, and others: ab ip≈øo fine p ‚Ä¢ eritiae Matrimonium ini≈ø≈øe. Therefore S. Helen being the fir≈øt woman was thus wedded vnto him in Marriadge, she mu≈øt needs be his true lawfull wife by their owne te≈øtimonies. And the ≈øame Authour witne≈ø≈øeth before Con≈øtantine at the publike Solemnitie of his Marriadge with Fau≈øta, in mo≈øt playne and expre≈ø≈øe words, that Con≈øtantine was borne in Britaine: ≈øan√™ ip≈øum Con≈øtantinum in Britanni√¢ fui≈ø≈øe ortum, di≈øer tis verbis coram ampli≈øsimo Conuentu te≈øtatus e≈øt celebris ille Gallic anus Orator in Panegyrico dicto in publicis nuptiarum eiu≈ødem Con≈øtantini cum Fau≈øta ≈øolemnitatibus. So te≈øtifie diuers Writers, euen of the Roman Pompon. Laetus in Compend. Hi≈øt. Rom. in Con≈øtant. Maximo. Hi≈øtorye: among who me one plainely ≈øaith, that Con≈øtantine was the Lawfull ≈øonne of Con≈øtantius and Helena, and borne in Britaine, and that his Father Con≈øtantius was compelled by Herculius the Emperour to be deuorced from Helen his true wife to take Theodora daughter-in-Lawe of that Emperour: Con≈øtantinus natus e≈øt in Britannijs, Patre Con≈øtantio, matre Helena, quam vir coactus fuit repudiare, vt Theodoram priuignam Herculij duceret. Eutropius plainely ≈øaith that Con≈øtantine was the ≈øonne of Con≈øtantius in true Matrimony. Eutrop. l. 10. Hi≈øt. Rom. Con≈øtantinus ex Matrimonio eius filius in Britanni√¢ creatus e≈øt Imperator. Con≈øtantinus Mana≈ø≈øes ≈øaith, S. Helen was the wife of Con≈øtantius, and a Con≈øtant. Mana≈ø≈ø. l. Annal. mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed woman, Habebat iam tum Constans Helenam vxorem faeminam beati≈øsimam. Hunibaldus aboue 1000. yeares ≈øince, relateth the Hi≈øtory of the compo≈øition betweene Con≈øtantius, and our Brittish King Coel, as our owne Writers Doe: Con≈øtantium vt Coelus audiuit littori appli cui≈ø≈øe, Nuntios mi≈øit, pacem HunibaldÍù∞ apud Trithem. l. de Orig. Francor. petijt, Romanis Tributum promi≈øit, taÃÑtum vt regnum habeat. A≈ø≈øen≈øit Con≈øtantius. His compactatis, Coelus intra 40. dies moritur, cuius mox filiam nomine Helenam, cui pulchritudine, ≈øcienti√¢ liberalium artium, periti√¢ in≈øtrumentorum mu≈øicalium, puella ≈øimulis non fuit in Britanni√¢, Con≈øtantius duxit vxorem, de qu√¢ genuit filium nomine Con≈øtantinum, qui patri po≈øtea ≈øucce≈øsit in Regno, non ≈øolum BritonuÃÑ, ≈øed etiam contra Maxentium praeualuit ad Imperium Romanum. Againe both Victor, Eu≈øebius, Eutropius, and other auncient Authours are witne≈ø≈øes, that when Diocle≈øian made Con≈øtantius, and Galerius, Cae≈øars, he compelled them to put away both their lawfull wyues, and Con≈øtantius to put away S. Helen, Eu≈øeb. Chronic. An. 294. Eutro-l. 9. Hi≈øt. Rom. Victor in Diocl. & Con≈øtantio. Iornand. lib. de Regn. ≈øucc. Seucrus Sulpitius l. 2. Hi≈øt. ≈øacrae in Diocle≈øiano & Maximiano. Theoph. Ceram. in Chronogr. Egbert. Abbas Ser. 3. de increm. & manif. Catholicae fidei. Berengo≈øus Abbas l. de Inuentione. & laude S. Crucis c. 1. and take Theodora Maximion Herculeus his daughter-in-Lawe, & Galerius to take Valeria his owne daughter, Ambo vxores quas habuerunt repudiare compul≈øi ≈øunt. Which accompt of theirs, that S. Helen was thus put away in the yeare 294. inuincibly proueth, how according to Eu≈øebius and many others before ≈øetting downe the Age of Con≈øtantine to haue bene aboue 60. yeares, that S. Helen had then bene 20. yeares the wife of Con≈øtantius. Seuerus Sulpitius doth not onely call S. Helen the true wife of Con≈øtantius, but ≈øaith, she was Empre≈ø≈øe both in her husbands, and ≈øonnes time, Helena mater Con≈øtantini, quae Augu≈øta cum filio coÃÑregnabat. Which proueth her, daughter and Heire to Coel, our Brittish King, by which Title onely she reigned with Con≈øtantine. Theophanes Cepameus an olde Greeke Writer ≈øayth, they were Arrian Heretiks & Pagans which denyed Con≈øtantine to be legitmate, and that they lyed therin. Ariani & Pagani calumniantur vti spurium MagnuÃÑ Con≈øtantinum: quin & ip≈øi mentiuntur. Egbertus ≈øaith, she was Queene, and Mother of Con≈øtantine. Berengo≈øus an eye witne≈ø≈øe of the mo≈øt things, writing, of her, ≈øaith, fir≈øt she was a Queene, Helena Regina, and ≈øo the lawfull wife of Con≈øtantius, for the Concubine of the greate≈øt King or Emperour that euer was,
is not thereby a Queene, in ≈øuch ≈øence as the≈øe Authours name her, Queene to Rule and gouerne, Augu≈øta cum filio conregnabat. Nor can the lawfull true wiues of Kings be termed Queens by ≈øuch worthie Authours, except they were Queens by Title of Inheritance, or ≈øuch like, as our Antiquaries write of Queene Helen, that she was daughter and Heire to her Father King S. Helen her ≈øumptuous Pallace. Coel. Which this worthie Authour doth al≈øo, though a ≈øtranger to vs, confirme, when he proueth she was of a mo≈øt Noble Parentage, and by experimentall Idem Berengo≈øus l. 3. c. 2. ≈øup. Arguments, becau≈øe he had ≈øeene the old buildings of her ≈øtately Pallace, continuing in his time, the pauement whereof was Marble, and Tooch≈øtone, the mo≈øt Regall Pallace in all tho≈øe parts, the walles were guilded with gold. Her chamber was ≈øo ≈øumptuous, that the like was not in the world, and to free her from all ≈ølaunders, the chamber of her heart, and ≈øoule was farre more pure, and in all things she was obedient to the will of God, and yet externally plea≈øing her husband Con≈øtantius, although more plea≈øing to God, then to her husband, Nobilitatem eius apud Treuiros aedificiorum ≈øuorum adhuc antiqua testatur gentilitas: vbi pauimentum domus illius varijs Marmoribus & Pario quondam lapide ≈øtratum, ben√® declarat, quantum ibi prae aliis videretur habere Primatum. Praeterea vero ip≈øa planities parietum fuluo auro velut Hiacinthino textu depicta bene testabatur in≈øignia nobilitatis eius inuictae: In≈øuper etiam Praediorum eius copiae Eccle≈øijs Dei olim collatae bene declarant, quam nobili≈øsima generis polleret Antiquitate, ≈øed & cubile ip≈øius aureis ≈øetis in≈øtructum & in≈øignitum, nobilitatem quodaÃÑmodo in ea, qua≈øi Romanorum te≈øtabatur Quiritum, maxim√® cum ab ortu ≈øolis v≈øque ad vltimam Thyle cubili huic ≈øimile non po≈ø≈øet inueniri. Quia cubiculum cordis ≈øui cubicularius ille nulla vnquam inquinauit pollutione, de quo ≈øcriptum e≈øt: in Cubili ≈øuo a≈øtitit omni viae non bonae. Quoniam intrin≈øecus tantis ac talibus decorata fuit virtutibus, idcirco per omnia in omnibus diuinis placebat obtutibus, quia vero specie ≈øu√¢ & pulchritudine forin≈øecus erat ornata, ideo viro ≈øuo Con≈øtantio amabilis videbatur & grata, quoniam internae pietatis & aeternae pulchritudinis ita instructa e≈øt norma vt & Deo placeret in anim√¢, & Con≈øtantio in form√¢, ≈øecundum enim opinionem vulgi & veritatem rei, officio≈øa erat in ob≈øequio viri, ≈øed officio≈øior ad ob≈øequium Dei: quoniam amor Constantij & Dei ita in corde illius duplici ratione fuit di≈øtinctus, vt & Constantio exterius, & Deo ≈øubderetur interius.

5. Thus we ≈øee how farre this mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed, and Noble Queene and Empre≈ø≈øe, was in all times from being ba≈øe, either by birth or conuer≈øation, ≈øuch ≈øanctity of life could neuer agree with that fowle name by which ≈øome haue ≈øo wrongefully termed her; ≈øuch Parentage, Pallaces, and Reuenewes, able to entertaine the greate≈øt Princes, according to their ≈øtate, and dignitie, mu≈øt denominate their Noble Owners with better termes, and attributes, then Ho≈øte≈ø≈øe, Inkeeper, Stabularia, Except we will expound them in ≈øo lardge a ≈øence, that we shall ≈øo ≈øtile Abraham and Loth that lodged the Angels, tho≈øe that entertained Chri≈øt, all Receauers of Kings, Princes, and Emperours, and all harbourers, and exerci≈øers of Ho≈øpitalitie, for ≈øo both S. Helen and King Coel entertained Con≈øtantius, the one an Husband, the other a ≈øonne in Lawe, as Princes v≈øe. It ≈øeemeth this Palace and lands in, and about Treuers to haue di≈øcended to S. Helen by her Mother, or ≈øome Ance≈øtor of that Country, for both Beringo≈øus ≈øaith, S. Helen was brought vp at Treuers, Helena Treuiro-Indigena ciuitatis. And Ottho Fri≈øingen≈øis ≈øaith, she was by ≈øome of her Ance≈øtors Berengo≈ø. ≈øupr. l. 2. c. 1. Ottho Fri≈øingen. Chron. l. 4. c. 45. come from thence, Helena ex Pago Treuirorum oriunda. And Treuers being at that time, the mo≈øt renowned place of tho≈øe Countries for Nobilitie, Learning, and Chri≈øtian Relegion, and she the onely child of her Father
King Coel, and to ≈øucceed him in the kingdome of Britaine, he ≈øent her thither to haue the mo≈øt Noble education: and there it was probably, where she fir≈øt came to be acquainted with Con≈øtantius then liuing in tho≈øe parts: And this made the Attonement betweene Con≈øtantius for the Romans, and king Coel to be ≈øo ≈øoone, and peaceably effected, without any effu≈øion of blood, as our Antiquities te≈øtifie, whereof it will be a difficult thing to giue any other rea≈øon, in any morall iudgment.

6. This Marriadge betweene Con≈øtantius and S. Helena daughter of King Coel is proued by many other forraine Hi≈øtorians: ≈øo hath the auncient Bishop Iacob. Genuen. in S. Helena. Trithem. l. de Orig. Francorum. Io. Naucler. Chron. generat. 6. p. 565. Hi≈øt. Manu≈øcr. Gallic. Antiq. c. 29. Iacobus Genuen≈øis and Trithemius. So plainely writeth Nauclerus. Con≈øtantius Cae≈øar in Britanniam mi≈ø≈øus, In≈øulam Romanis pacauit, eamque po≈øt interitum Coelis, duct√¢ illius fili√¢ Helen√¢ vxore, ≈øolus admini≈øtrauit. A very old FreÃÑch Manu≈øcript hath thus: Con≈øtans came into Britaine, and after the death of King Coelreigned ouer Britaine, and tooke Helen daughter of Coel to wife. This Helen was a woman of greate vertue, and pa≈øsing in Beuty all the Maydes of the Prouince of Britaine, and there was not found any other ≈øo learned in In≈øtruments of Mu≈øike and the 7. liberall Arts. For her Father Coel had no other child, which might gouerne the Realme after him, and therefore procured, that she was ≈øo learned, that she might Reigne after him. Bouchet ≈øaith: Cohel Duke of Cohelce≈øter ≈ølew A≈øclepiodotus in Bouchet Annals de Aquitaine l. 1. c. 5. Nicholas Giles Annal. de France f. 8. p. 2. Zonaras Annal. Tom. 2. in Diocletiano & Con≈øtante. Zonar. ≈øup. in Con≈øtantino Magno. Battaile, and was made King of Britaine. Con≈øtantius married his daughter Helena, and had Con≈øtantine by her. An other French Hi≈øtorian ≈øaith: Helena Mother of Constantine the Greate was daughter of Coel King of the Britans. And whereas ≈øome would haue Zonaras to be a mouer of this que≈øtion, it is mo≈øt cleare that Zonaras plainely ≈øaith, S. Helen was the fir≈øt and true wife of Con≈øtantius, Con≈øtantine his elde≈øt Sonne, and ≈øo declared his lawfull Heire & Succe≈ø≈øour. Filio natu maiore, Magno videlicet Con≈øtantino, ex priore coniuge, Imperij Succe≈ø≈øore declarato. And ≈øaith futher, that Con≈øtantine was the Sonne of Con≈øtantius by ble≈ø≈øed Helena, Eum ex beat√¢ Helen√¢ procreauit Pater. Which could not be truely ≈øaid, if she had not bene his lawfull wife, for otherwi≈øe she had rather de≈øerued the name of cur≈øed, theÃÑ ble≈ø≈øed Helen. And he confirmeth this truth, not onely by terre≈øtriall but heauenly te≈øtimonie, shewing, that when Con≈øtantius Zonar. ≈øupr. in Con≈øtante. was ≈øick an Angel appeared vnto him, commanding him to leaue the Empire to Con≈øtantine, Fertur Con≈øtanti aegrotanti Angelus a≈øtiti≈ø≈øe, qui iuberet vt Con≈øtantino relinqueret Imperium. Which is al≈øo te≈øtified in this manner by Pompon. Laet. Rom. Hi≈øt. compend. in Con≈øtaÃÑ tino Magno. Pomponius Laetus: Eum Pater Cae≈øarem fecerat, caele≈øti nuntio admonitus, quum aegrotaret vt primum Con≈øtantinum ≈øucce≈ø≈øorem faceret, qui e≈ø≈øet ab tyrannis Romanum Imperium liberaturus, & militibus Dei opem laturus: Constantius the Father had made Con≈øtantine his Sonne Cae≈øar, being thereto admonished by an heauenly me≈ø≈øadge, when he was ≈øicke, who was to deliuer the Roman Empire from Tyrants, and help the ≈øouldiars of Chri≈øt. And although Baronius and his Epitomer Spondanus citing this Angelicall vi≈øion, and admonition from Zonaras, and ≈øeeme to thinke that Eu≈øebius did not remember it: mirum haec praeterij≈ø≈øe Eu≈øebium: Baron. Tom. 2. An. 306. Spondanus ibid. Yet if the Tran≈ølator and Notator of Eu≈øebius deceaueth vs not, euen by his te≈øtimony, Con≈øtantine was made Emperour by the Coun≈øaile of God: diuino con≈øilio Con≈øtantinus Imperium con≈øecutus e≈øt. And Eu≈øebius him≈øelfe expre≈ø≈øely Iacob. Grynaeus in c. 18. l. 1. Eu≈øeb. l. 1. de Vit. CoÃÑ≈øt. ≈øupr. ≈øaith: God the Authour of all things, and Gouernour of the whole world, did by his owne will choo≈øe Con≈øtantine Prince, and Emperour: Con≈øtantinum Principem & Imperatorem Deus omnium Author, & totius mundi gubernator, ≈øuo ≈øolum arbitrio delegit. Therefore we may not call that holy marriadge into que≈øtion, which ≈øo many human te≈øtimonies, and God him≈øelfe hath thus approued to be
lawfull. And ≈øo it is confirmed by other forreyne Authours. The old In≈øcription of the Church of S. Gereon at Cullen founded by her, proueth her to Petr. Mer≈ø≈øaeus in Catal. Archiepi≈øc. Colonien. be a Queene, and ≈øo an example to Kings.

q.l: Regibus exemplum ≈øacroque Chri≈ømate plena.
Condidit hoc templum Sancti Gereonis, Helena.

div.p:
And by the ≈øame Authour, she is called Empre≈ø≈øe al≈øo: pia Helend Augu≈øta. Petr. Mer≈ø≈ø. Catal. Archiep. Treuer. Anton. Sabelic. Ennead. lib. 8. Ennead. 7. Walter. Rollew. Fa≈øcul. temp. Ann. 234. Io. Bapti≈ø. Egnat. in Con≈øtantino Magno. Gon≈øtant. Mana≈ø≈ø. in Annal. & apud Camden. in Rom. in Britannia in Con≈øtant. Baron. & Spond. An. Chri≈øti 306. And her Pallace mentioned. Sabellicus al≈øo maketh her the true wife of Con≈øtantius. The like hath Walterus Rollewinke ≈øaying: Queene Helen was Mother of Con≈øtantine, and then an holy woman. Helena Regina Mater Constantini ≈øanctae & admirandae deuotionis & ciuilitatis. Ioannes Bapti≈øta Egnatius ≈øaith, that Con≈øtantine was borne of Helena, wife of Con≈øtantius. Rerum Constantinus potitur ex Helena Con≈øtantij vxore ≈øu≈øceptus. And Con≈øtantinus Mana≈ø≈øes, as our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries confe≈ø≈øe, long before Nicephorus time, proueth S. Helen to haue bene the true wife of Con≈øtantius, and ≈øeparated from him for a time onely for feare of the Emperour: The ≈øame haue Baronius, Spondanus and other late forreyne Writers, expre≈ø≈øely calling the other a≈ø≈øertion figmentum a forgery, and vnworthie of confutation. Teaching it is euident, that she was a Brittish Lady, eandem fui≈ø≈øe Britanniam constat. And they relye vpon our Britan and English Antiquaries, as mo≈øt fitt Relators of ≈øo memorable a matter of their owne Queene and Country, directly te≈øtifying, she was the daughter and Heire of King Coel, the vndoubted and true lawfull wife of Con≈øtantius, and named Stabularia, Inholdre≈ø≈øe by the friends of Theodora the Concubine of Con≈øtantius, putt to him again≈øt his will. When she was ≈øo honorable by birth, that her Father King Coel receaued Con≈øtantius in all Regall manner. So farre she was from being an Inholdre≈ø≈øe, or daughter of ≈øuch a man. Eandem ≈øtabulariam fui≈ø≈øe √† nonnullis a≈ø≈øertum S. Ambro≈øius tradit. Sed eo plan√® nomine vulgo dicta, quod hospitis apud quem diuertit Con≈øtantius Ambro≈ø. orat. in funere Theodo≈ø. in Britanni√¢ filia fui≈ø≈øet. At qualis ho≈øpitis, qui Ducem totius exercitus domi exciperet? Quamobrem qui antiquas res Britannicas ≈øunt pro≈øecuti, quod compertum habuerunt ex antiquis Annalibus, Helenam tradunt fui≈ø≈øe filiam vnius ex Britanniae Regulis Coel nomine: apud quem hospitatus Con≈øtantius, quam pulcherimam nouit eius filiam accepit in coniugem. How they haue freed her from the imputation of the name of Concubine, by ≈øome Writers layed vpon her by mi≈øapplying a Roman Pagan Edict they haue witne≈ø≈øed before, and thus further cleare it: Inde mana≈ø≈øe videtur illa opinio, quod Helena fuerit Con≈øtantij Concubina, L. Praefectus D. de Ritib. nupt. L. eos qui. D. eo. quia non creditae ≈øunt nuptiae quas Ciuis Romanus cum peregrin√¢ contraxi≈ø≈øet: atque amplius, quod Romanorum legibus cautum e≈ø≈øet, vt ≈øi aliquis Praefectus vxorem duceret in e√† Prouinci√¢, in qua officium gerebat, Matrimonium non e≈ø≈øet, quod ratio Potentatus eiu≈ømodi nuptias prohiberet. Verum cum ij≈ødom legibus iu≈øtae efficerentur nuptiae ≈øi po≈øt depo≈øitum officium in eadem voluntate per≈øeueraret: con≈øtat Helenam ver√® fui≈ø≈øe Con≈øtantij coniugem, ac Matrimonium ratum, quod ille ≈øic eam duxit, vt cum √† prouinci√† di≈øce≈øsit, ac Magi≈øtratuÃÑ depo≈øui≈ø≈øet nunquaÃÑ illam dimi≈øerit v≈øque ad nuptias Theodorae. That opinion, that Helen was the Concubine of Con≈øtantius ≈øeemeth to haue proceeded from thence, that it was not e≈øteemed with ≈øome Pagans, Marriadge which a Citizen of Rome had contracted with a ≈øtranger: and the rather becau≈øe it was prouided by the Lawes of the Romans, that if any Prefect should marry a wife in that Prouince, where he bore office it should not be Matrimony, becau≈øe the rea≈øon of Principalitie did forbid ≈øuch Marriadges. But when by the very ≈øame Lawes the Marriadges were made lawfull, if after the Office giueÃÑ ouer or ended, the Husban ‚Ä¢ per≈øeuered in the ≈øame will: It is euident, that HeleÃÑ was the true wife of Con≈øtaÃÑtius, and
the marriadge betweene them lawfull: Becau≈øe Con≈øtantius ≈øo marryed her, that when he went out of that Prouince, and left his Office, he neuer di≈ømi≈ø≈øed Helen, vntill he was compelled by the Emperour to take Theodora. Thus the≈øe Roman Writers haue cleared this our glori ‚Ä¢ us Brittish Queene, and Empre≈ø≈øe from that imputation, which ≈øome by pretext of ≈øuch Pagan Edict of the Romans, haue layed vpon her vniu≈øtly.

7. To which I adde, that both that Lawe, and the rea≈øon thereof, was froÃÑ the beginning voide in the ca≈øe of Con≈øtantius, & Helena. And they were truely Husband, and wife, not onely by the Lawe of God, but by the Heathen Romans them≈øelues. Fir≈øt, becau≈øe when Con≈øtantius marryed S. Helen, he was not admitted Prefect heare, but after. Secondly, S. Helen a Britan enioying by old compo≈øitions betweene the Romans and Britans the Roman Priuiledges, was not by their Lawe a ≈øtranger. Thirdly, if she had ≈øo bene, yet being al≈øo next Heire to the Crowne of Britaine, and this marriadge betweene her and Con≈øtantius agreed vpon, and publikly confirmed by both Romans and Britans, and their Lawes, no exception could be made again≈øt them by any Lawe. Fourthly, Con≈øtantius claiming the kingdome of Britaine by his wiues Title, she neither was, nor could be a ≈øubiect to him in that re≈øpect, and ≈øo the pretended rea≈øon of that Pagan Edict, ratio Potentatus, Soueraintie had no place in this ca≈øe. Fiftly, this rea≈øon did di≈øable all Roman Kings, Emperours, and Prefects to marry, for by marriadge their wiues were as others vnder their Principalitie, and ≈øo the Lawe in it≈øelfe voide by the grounde thereof. Sixtly, this Lawe onely concerned Pagans, but both Con≈øtantius and Helena were now Chri≈øtians (as hereafter) in con≈øcience, and Iudgment: And ≈øo mu≈øt needs interprett that Pagan Con≈øtitution, to be both again≈øt the Lawe of God, & Nations and farre from hindering the vndoubted lawfulnes of their true and mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øarie, de≈øired, and allowed marriadge, both by the King, Nobles, and Lawiers of Britaine, and the Emperour and Senate of Rome, who≈øe grant and con≈øent was a full euacuation, or Di≈øpen≈øation of that their Lawe, in their owne proceedings, to preuent and appea≈øe the greate contentions, and bloody wars betweene the Romans and Britans, at that time by no other means to be qualified but by this marriadge and vnion.

8. If from forreyne Antiquities we will come home to the Hi≈øtorians of this Nation, mo≈øt likely to knowe and write the truth of this their mo≈øt honorable Country woman, they will putt vs out of doubt, that she was the daughter of our King Coel, and the true wife of Con≈øtantius, King Coel and he ≈øo couenanting, that Coel should continue the kingdome during his life, and Con≈øtantius marrying his daughter and Heire Helen, should with her ≈øucceed him therein. Con≈øtantius duxit filiam Coel, cui nomen erat Helena. Pulchritudo eius Prouinciales puellas ≈øuperabat, nec v≈øpiam reperie batur altera, quae in Mu≈øic Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 5. c. 6. Pontic. Virun. l. 5. Hi≈øt. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 302. Old. Eng. Hi≈øt. part. 3. f. 34. Henr. Hunting. Hi≈øt. l. 1. Necham. apud Camden. in E≈ø≈øex in Colce≈øter. Io. Capgr. Catal. in S. Helena. Annal. Manu≈øcript. antiq. plurim. is in≈øtrumentis, ≈øiue in Liberalibus Artibus doctior ill√† cen≈øeretur. Caruerat Pater alter√¢ ≈øobole, quae Regni ≈øolio potiretur. Vnde eam ita docere laborauerat, vt Regnum po≈øt Patris obitum facili√πs tractare quiret. So writeth the old Authour of our Brittish Hi≈øtory, Ponticus Virunnius, Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, our old English Hi≈øtorie, Henry of Huntingt on writing before Galfridus tran≈ølated the Brittish Hi≈øtorie, Necham, Capgraue, with very many old Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtories which I haue ≈øeene. And they all agree, she was the daughter and Heire of King Coel of Britaine, that she was ≈øolemnely marryed to Con≈øtantius, vpon publikly agreed Articles, and Ho≈øtages giuen one eyther ≈øide, datis ob≈øidebus, betweene the Romans and Britans. That she was by her
Husband, an Empre≈ø≈øe by her Father a Queene: Helena ≈øancti≈øsima faemina ex marito Imperatrix, ex patre Regina, Coelis Regis Britanniae vnica fuit filia. And in auntient In≈øciptions ≈øo generally ≈øtiled, In antiquis In≈øcriptionibus pij≈øsima, & venerabilis Augu≈øta pa≈øsim nominatur. This is the old tradition of the Towne of Colche≈øter, bearing to this day for the Armes thereof, in memory Camden & Necham. ≈øupr. & Manu≈øcr. antiq. pr. Britannia quae. nunc Anglia. Henric. Hunting. Archidiac. l. 1. Hi≈øt. Andre de Che≈øne Hi≈øt. l. 4. Michael Drayton Polyolbion Songe 9. Seld. Illu≈øtrat. p. 144. Io. Selden Analect. c. 7. p. 50. 51. of her, and her finding the holy Cro≈ø≈øe, a Gro≈ø≈øe knotty, betweene 4. Crownes. Ciues Helenam Con≈øtantini magni matreÃÑ ≈øuam alumnam e≈ø≈øe a≈ø≈øerunt ex Coelo Rege natam, & in memoriam Crucis ab illa repertae, crucem nodo ≈øam inter quatuor Coronas interpo≈øitam publico in Clipeo gerunt. And she both made the old wall of Colche≈øter, and London, and paued the greate way in Merioneth-shire, called in that languadge of the Britans Sarn Helen, the highe way of Helen, to this day.

9. This is the common opinion of our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries Bale, Go≈øceline, Leland, the Theather Writers, Hackluit, Hollinshed, Harri≈øon, Camden, Selden and others, too many to be recompted; therefore I will onely cite the two la≈øt, as of cheife name and late≈øt time among them: The one ≈øpeaking of the Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian heare, ≈øaith, that this kingdome brought forth a Prince Con≈øtantine the Greate of Brittish blood, the greate≈øt honour of this Iland borne in true Marriadge betweene Con≈øtantius Chlorus and Helen daughter of King Caelus, and citeth a Panegyri≈øt liuing and writing in that time, for an vndoubted warrant hereof. Terra i≈øta no≈øtra Principem cui nihil prius erat quam Chri≈øtianam fouere Religionem, Britannico ≈øanguine natum (≈øummum In≈øulae duces, tunc t ‚Ä¢ mporis nutriuit, atque in Imperium euexit, Con≈øtantinum nempe illum quem ex Helena Coeli Reguli qui A≈øclepiodotum regno ≈øpoliauerat, filia primis nuptijs ducta Con≈øtantius Chlorus Cae≈øar duÃÑ Britannijs agebat, ≈øu≈øceperat. De re illa Chri≈øtiana maxim√® meruit, & de Britannica, de quo Britannia patria. O fortunata & nunc omnibus beatior, inquit Anonymus Panagyre≈øtis, terris Britannia, quae Con≈øtantinum Cae≈øarem prima vidisti. And in an other Booke, and place Panegyric. Con≈øtantino dictus. Io. Selden Illu≈øtr. vpon PolyolbioÃÑ p. 129. 130. ≈øpeaking of this renowned woman, he ≈øaith: She was wife to Constantius, or Con≈øtans Chlorus the Emperour, and Mother to Con≈øtantine the Greate, daughter to Coile King of Britaine, where Con≈øtantine was by her brought forth. Do not obiect Nicephorus Calli≈øtus, that erroneou≈øly affirmes him borne in Drepanum of Bithynia, or Iu lius Firmius, that ≈øayes at Tar≈øus, vpon which te≈øtimonie not vncorrupted a Lip≈ø. de Roman. Magnitud. l. 4. c. 11. NimiuÃÑ lap≈øus. greate Critique (he meaneth Lip≈øius) hath violently offered to depriue vs. both of him, and his Mother, affirming her a Bithynian: nor take aduantage of Cedrenus, that will haue Dacia her birth ≈øoyle: But ouer Hi≈øtories, and with them, the Latine Eccle≈øia≈øtique relation in pa≈ø≈øadges of her inuention of the Cro≈ø≈øe, and ≈øuch like, allowed al≈øo by Cardinall Baronius, make her thus a Brittish woman. And for greate Con≈øtantius birth in this land, you shall haue Authoritie, again≈øt which I wonder how Lip≈øius dur≈øt oppo≈øe his conceipt. In an old Panegyri≈øt ≈øpeaking to Con≈øtantine, liberauit ille he meanes his Father, BritaÃÑnias ≈øeruitute, tu etiaÃÑ nobiles illic oriuÃÑdo feci≈øti, He freed Britaine of bondage, thow enoble≈øt it with thy birth. And an other, √¥ fortunata & nunc omnibus beatior terris Britannia, quae Con≈øtantinum Cae≈øarem vidi≈øti. O happy Britaine that first of all ≈øawe≈øt Con≈øtantine. Of this Helen her Religion, finding the Cro≈ø≈øe, good deeds in walling London, and Colche≈øter, which in honour of her they ≈øay, beares a Cro≈ø≈øe betweene foure Crownes, and for the Inuention, she is yet celebrated in holy Roode-day in May, and of this Constantine her Sonne, a mightie and Religous Emperour, that in this ayre receaued his fir≈øt light and life, our Britons vaunt not vniu≈øtly, as in that ≈øpoken to King Arthur. Rob. Cloe≈øtren.

lg.l: Now it worth iended that Sibile the ≈øage biuore
That there ≈ø≈øold of Britaine thre men be ybore
That ≈ø≈øold winne the aumpire of Rome, of tweye yed it is
As of Bely and Con≈øtantine, and thow art the thredde ywis

div.p:
Which very words were publikly iu≈øtified al≈øo by Hoelus King of litle Britaine, Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 9. ca. 17. Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. Bri. l. 9. c. 16. Old. Engl. Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. c. 52. CaxtoÃÑ Hi≈øt. part. 5. f. 50. Harding. Chron. c. 80. f. 74. Camden Romans in Britaine pag. 74. edit. ann. 1610. and it is regi≈øtred both in our olde Brittish and Saxon Hi≈øtories, both Manu≈øcripts and others, that Con≈øtantine ≈øonne of S. Helen was Ance≈øtor to King Arthur, and others of this kingdome. Which mu≈øt needs be by his Mother S. Helen a Britan, and of the Regall Race of this kingdome, for by Con≈øtantius his Father a ≈øtranger heare, Con≈øtantine could not be Ance≈øtor to our Kings of Britaine. The other cheife≈øt Prote≈øtant Antiquary writeth in this manner euen in his la≈øt Edition. Con≈øtantius what time he ≈øerued in Britaine vnder Aurelian, tooke to wife the daughter of Caelus, or Caelius a Brittish Prince, on whome he begatt that Noble Constantine the Greate in Britaine. For ≈øo together with that greate Hi≈øtoriographer Baronius, the common opinion of all other Writers with one con≈øent beareth witne≈ø≈øe: vnle≈ø≈øe it be one or two Greeke Authours of late time, and tho≈øe di≈ø≈øenting one from the other, and a right learned man grounding vpon a corrupt place of Iulius Firmicus. This is that Helen which in antike In≈øcription is called venerabilis & pij≈ø≈øima Augu≈øta, and for Chri≈øtian pietie for cleaÃÑ≈øing Hieru≈øaleÃÑ of Idols, for building a goodly Church in the place where our Lord ≈øuffered, and for finding the ≈øauing Cro≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt is ≈øo highly commended of Eccle≈øia≈øticall writers. And yet both Iewes and Gentils termed her, by way of ignominy and reproach Stabularia: becau≈øe she a mo≈øt godly Prince≈ø≈øe ≈øought out the Cribbe or Manger, wherin Chri≈øt was borne, and in the place where stood that Ho≈øtelry, founded a Church. Heareupon S. Ambro≈øe: they ≈øay that this Lady was first an Inholder or Hoste≈ø≈øe &c. Capgraue Manu≈øcr. antiq. in Vit. S. Helenae Capgr. in ead. Annal. Aquitan. apud Bouchet l. 1. cap. 5. and the old Manu≈øcript of S. Helens life affirme the like, ≈øaying, the Iewes in hatred of her, in doing ≈øo many holy Chri≈øtian deeds derogatory to their profe≈ø≈øion, and building ≈øo glorious a Church ouer the holy Cribbe where Chri≈øt was borne, rai≈øed that ≈ølaunder. Impij≈øsimi Iudaei cum tanta bona ab Imperatrice in eo rum opprobrium facta cernerent, ip≈øam inter ≈øe ex inuidi√† stabulariam vocauerunt eo quod ≈øupra ≈øtabulum & tam vilem locum eis admodum exo≈øum tam nobilem Eccle≈øiam aedificauit. The Annalls of Aquitane where her children lyued, and ≈øay she di≈øcend from our King S. Lucius, shall be cited in the next Chapter. The error of them which deferre her marriadge vntill Con≈øtantius comming hither after A≈øclepiodotus death, is palbable. For by that accompt, as of Matthew We≈øtmin≈øter, Con≈øtantine was but an Infant 5. yeares olde, when after Con≈øtantius his Fathers death he was both King of Britaine, and Emperour. For he ≈øetteth downe their marriadge in the yeare of Chri≈øt 302. and in the yeare 307. ≈øaith he was declared Emperour. Anno gratiae 307. Con≈øtantinus Matth. We≈øtm. an. 302. 307. Harding Chron. ca. 62. Con≈øtantij & Helenae filius, in Britannia ex Rege Imperator creatus. And others by that mi≈øtaking make him litle older; But they are to be vnder≈øtood, of the reconciliation of Con≈øtantius to S. Helen, after the death of Theodora, & not his fir≈øt taking her to wife, being allmo≈øt 30. yeares before in the time of Aurelianus Emperour, for after he had married S. Helen in Britaine at that time, and had ruled this kingdome no short ≈øpace, he went againe from hence to Rome, and returned hither the ≈øecond time, as is manife≈øt before, when be dyed heare. Which many more Authours both Manu≈øcripts and Manu≈øcr. antiq. in Vit. S. Helenae Io. Capgr. Catal. in eadem. others confirme, in this manner: Cum illam (S. Helenam) in Thori ≈øocietatem accepi≈ø≈øet Constantius, generauit ex ea filium quem appellauit Con≈øtantinum. Ip≈øe vero Con≈øtantius cum regno Britanniae aliquandiu potiretur, Romam reuer≈øus. And then they bring him hither the ≈øecond time, and lyuing heare diuers yeares.
and dying at Yorke, as others haue done before. Britanniam rediens, po≈øt annos Manu≈øc. & Cap. ≈øupr. Pomponius Laetus compend. Rom. Hi≈øt. in Con≈øtantio Chloro. vndecim apud Eboracum morti ≈øubiacuit, & regnum filio Con≈øtantino reliquit, Leauing the kingdome to his elde≈øt ≈øonne Con≈øtantine. And this is euident by the time of Con≈øtantine his Age, and Reigne before remembred, out of the mo≈øt auncient Hi≈øtories of this matter, and ≈øuch as no man willing to retaine the name of an Antiquary may deny. I add to this, that Con≈øtantine at his Fathers death, was a marryed man, then marryed vnto Fau≈øta, daughter of Maximianus Herculius the Tyrant, and by him made Augu≈øtus, and yet Panegyric. 1. in nuptijs Con≈øtantini & Fau≈øtae. Baron. Annal. an. 307. was marryed to an other wife before, as the Authours of that time are witne≈ø≈øes, and had Pri≈øcus his elde≈øt ≈øonne by this former wife named Mineruina. Of which all Hi≈øtories both Chri≈øtian and Pagan are plentifull.

div.head: THE XII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE OTHER THREE CHILDREN, OF CON≈øtantius and S. Helen; and particulary of two of them S. Lucius and S. Emerita, renowned and glorious Martyrs for holy Chri≈øtian Religion, among forreine Pagans, S. Lucius an holy Bishop preaching it to them in Germany.

div.p:
1. HAVING thus euidently cleared the Hi≈øtorie for the birth, and Education, of the≈øe two greate Glories of the world, the Mother, and ≈øonne, in Britaine: I ame to ≈øpeake ≈øome thing of other children this happy Empre≈ø≈øe S. HeleÃÑ had in this Nation by her husband CoÃÑ≈øtantius, for allthought the greatnes of that greate Emperour CoÃÑ ≈øtantine doth in the Hi≈øtories of that time drawe all mens pens, and eyes to de≈øcribe and beholde his ≈øplendor and renowne, and in ≈øome ≈øort eclip≈øe the honour of diuers others, renowned in tho≈øe dayes, yet we finde in auncient memorable Antiquities, that S. Helen had other children be≈øides Con≈øtantine, whereof ≈øome were in their lyues renowned in S. Lucius ≈øonne to S. Helen. this world, and now greate Saints in heauen, by for≈øaking terreane, and temporall dignities, to purcha≈øe ≈øpirituall and eternall. We finde she had foure children heare in Britaine by her husband Con≈øtantius, three ≈øonnes, whereof Annal. Eccl. Cathedralis Lucion. in Aquitania. Ion. Bouchet de Poictiers Annales Aquitan. l. 1. c. 5. will. Harri≈øon de≈øcription of Brit. c. 9. p. 25. col. 2. Con≈øtantine after ≈øurnamed the Greate, was the younge≈øt, S. Lucius the ≈øecond, the name of the elde≈øt ≈ølayne, or dying when he was but Younge is not ≈øo readily pre≈øerued in Antiquities, and one daughter S. Emerita. This S. Lucius is he, that was Apo≈øtle to diuers peoples, and places in Germany, mi≈øtaken by ≈øome, through I dentitie of name, and Nation, Regall di≈øcent, and nearenes in time, for King Lucius our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King, Grandfather to this Prince Lucius, as the Annals of Aquitayne, where he long time liued a mo≈øt penitentiall and holy life in a Mona≈øtery, which he there founded called after his name, hath te≈øtified before, and he al≈øo tooke his name Lucius from him: de ≈øon Bi≈øageal Roy d' Angleterre. And this Lineal di≈øcent of Queene Helen from King Lucius, proximitie in blood to him, and thereby true Titler to
the crowne of Britaine may ≈øeeme to haue bene a ≈øtronge motiue for the Romans ≈øo ea≈øely and de≈øirou≈øly to con≈øent vnto, and procure the vniting Mariadge betweene her and Con≈øtantius. The Hi≈øtorie of this S. Lucius, S. Helen her ≈øonne is thus recorded in tho≈øe Antiquities, as the Antiquarie of Aquitane relateth it from thence. I fynde by the foundation of the Church of Lucon, Bouchet. l. 1. c. 5. ≈øupr. Annal. Eccl. Cathed. Luc. & al. or Lucius in Poycters, contayned in an Hymne, beginning, gaude LucionuÃÑ, the ≈øaid Lucius killed his elder brother, ≈øon frere ai≈øn√© and for that cau≈øe, was bannished the Country and to liue in perpetuall Religion, √† tenir ReligioÃÑ perpetuell and embarked on the ≈øea in a ship with greate riches, and Relicks, with many Prei≈øts, and deuoute par≈øons: Who all landed at Lucon which is vpon the ≈øea, and there Lucius founded a faire Abbey, and Church to the honour of our Lady, which he called by his name. Where he lyued with his Prei≈øts Religiou≈øly. And it was after erected into √† Bishops See. An English Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorian thus relateth the occa≈øion of Will. Harrri≈øon de≈øcription of Britaine p. 25. c. 9 Prince Lucius his for≈øaking Britaine his natiue Country: It hapned that Lucius by meanes of a quarell growne betweene him & his elder brother, either by a fray, or by ≈øome other meanes, did kill his ≈øaid brother, whereupon his Father exiled him out of Britaine, and appointed him from thenceforth to remayne in Aqnitayne in France. He became a Bishop in the Church of Chri≈øt. He erected a place of prayer, wherein to ≈øerue the liuing God, and is ≈øtill called euen to this our time, after Lucion, or Lucius the fir≈øt Founder thereof, and the originall beginner of any ≈øuch hou≈øe in tho≈øe parts. In this al≈øo he and diuers others of his friends continued their times in greate contemplation, and prayer, and from hence were Tran≈ølated, as occa≈øion ≈øerued vnto ≈øondry Eccle≈øia≈øticall promotions in the time of Constantine his brother. So that euen by this short Narration it is now ea≈øie to ≈øee that Lucius the King, and Lucius the ≈øonne of Chlorus, were di≈øtinct par≈øons. He had expre≈ø≈øely ≈øaid before in his merginall notation: Chlorus had three ≈øonnes and a daughter by Helena. And thus more at Lardge in his Relation hereof: Constantius Chlorus being at the fir≈øt matched with Helena, and before she was put from him by the Royall power of Diocle≈øian, he had by her three ≈øonnes, be≈øides one daughter called Emerita, of which the name of the fir≈øt is perished, the ≈øecond was called Lucius, and the third Con≈øtantine, S. Lu ‚Ä¢ ius conuerted the Curien≈øes and there was Martyred. that after was Emperour. And he after addeth: Hereunto Hermannus Schedelius addeth al≈øo, how he went into Rhetia with Emerita his Si≈øter, and neare vnto the Citie Augusta, conuerted the Curien≈øes vnto the faith of Chri≈øt, and there likewi≈øe (being put to death in Ca≈øtro Martis) lieth buried in the ≈øame Towne, where his Fea≈øt is holden vpon the third day of December, as may readily be confirmed, whereas the bones of our Lucius were to be ≈øeene at Gloce≈øter. That Schedelius erreth not herin al≈øo, the auncient monuments of the ≈øaid Abbay, whereof he was the originall beginner, as I ≈øaid, doe yeeld ≈øufficient te≈øtimony, be≈øide an Hime made in his commendation, intituled, gaude LucionuÃÑ &c. The ≈øaid Schedelius furthermore ≈øetteth downe, that his ≈øi≈øter was martyred in Trineca≈øtle, neare vnto the place, where the ≈øaid Lucion S. Emerita S. Lucius his Si≈øter Martyred. dwelled, whereby it appeareth in like ≈øorte, that she was not ≈øi≈øter to Lucius King of Britaine. Hitherto this Prote≈øtant Antiquarie. But whereas he would make Hartmannus Schedel a witne≈ø≈øe, that this was S. Lucius ≈øonne of Con≈øtantius, and S. Helena, he is deceaued therein, for that Authour ≈øaith expre≈ø≈øly, it was S. Lucius our King, that was coÃÑuerted by Pope Eleutherius meanes. Lucius Anglorum Rex Coilli Regis filius: but ≈øuppo≈øing as it hath bene allready Hartman. Schedel. Ch ‚Ä¢ onic. Chronic. f. 115. p. 2. proued, that it was S. Lucius ≈øonne of Con≈øtantius and S. Helena, he, goeth further, and ≈øaith, he conuerted all Bauaria, and Rhetia, betweene the Alpes, Totam Bauariam & Rhetiam inter Alpes Chri≈øto acqui≈øiuit.

2. But there be many german Authours, which this Prote≈øtant might
haue better cited for this purpo≈øe, as Ga≈øpar Bruchius Seba≈øtian, Mun≈øter, with others, who with diuers other Writers they alledge, a≈ø≈øcribe as much to S. Lucius, that preached to the Rhetians, as Schedel doth, and more; and yet plainely proue, this could not be S. Lucius our King of Britaine, who as Mun≈øter truely ≈øaith, neuer went out of Britaine but liued, dyed, and was buried heare. Britanniae ille Rex, qui circiter annum Domini 190. floruit, patriam nequaquam exiens, pi√® apud ≈øuos obdormiuit. And to demon≈øtrate it could be no other Seba≈øtian. MuÃÑ≈øt. Co≈ømogr. l. 3. c. 344. p. 735. S. Lucius a Britan, but this ≈øonne of Con≈øtantius, and S. Helena, he bringeth from the German Antiquities, that the Lucius which preached there, continued his preaching vntill the mo≈øt bloody Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian. Ad v≈øque Diocle≈øionam illam cruenti≈øsimam per≈øecutionem. Which this onely S. Lucius did, and could doe, the other King Lucius being dead before Diocle≈øian was borne by all Antiquities. And to cleare it further, he writeth that diuers affirme, he was of the kingely Race of the Britans, & borne among them, neuer mentioning that he was a King, Lucium hunc aliqui regio ≈øtemmate apud Britannos Cap. 214. ortum & natum e≈ø≈øe affirmant. Ga≈øpar Bruchius al≈øo hath the very ≈øame words, for the opinion of diuers writers: That S. Lucius which preached to the Ga≈øpar. Bruch. l. de Epi≈øcop ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ b. Ge ‚Ä¢ maniae Catal. Epi≈øcopor. Curien. Eccle≈øiae. Germans was borne of the Regall Race among the Britans, and to propagate the faith of Chri≈øt, came out of Britaine into Germany, and preached first at Salisburge, then at Ausburge, from whence he was cast out by the Infidels there, and then went with his ≈øi≈øter S. Emerita to the Cytie of Chur, where preaching againe both he and his Si≈øter Emerita were Martyred by the Pagans, S. Lucius at Chur in the ca≈øtle of Mars, and S. Emerita at Trine-ca≈øtle. And that there is without the walls of Chur a very old Mona≈øtery, called S. Lucius, which was begun by him, and was his Oratory: Lucium hunc aliqui regio ≈øtemmate apud Britannos ortum, & natum e≈ø≈øe affirmant, veni≈ø≈øe autem illum amore propagandae doctrinae, de filio Dei Ie≈øu Chri≈øto, ex Britannia in Germaniam: vt Christum Germanis etiam adhuc Idololatris concionaretur, & eos ad Chri≈øtum conuerteret. Id aiunt illum primum feci≈ø≈øe Salisburgi, po≈øtea Augu≈øtae Vindelicorum: vbi cum eijceretur ab Infidelibus, dicitur Churam cum ≈øorore S. Emerita ce≈øsi≈ø≈øe: vbi cum itidem Idololatricas opiniones reprehenderet, & aliquamdiu concionaretur Chri≈øtum liberatorem, ab Infidelibus tum Rhetis cae≈øi & Martyrio coronati ≈øunt S. Lucius & S. Emerita. S. Lucius Churae in Martis Ca≈øtro, S. Emerta apud Trimontium. E≈øt Churae extra vrbis muros Caenobium S. Lucij preuetu≈øtum, in vitifero colle ≈øitum, quod ab eo caeptum, & Oratorij loco conditum aiunt. And he vtterly di≈øliketh their opinion, which hold that this was our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King S. Lucius. And that onely Tradition that the S. Lucius which was the Apo≈øtle of that people was Martyred, Curae in Martis Ca≈øtro, at Chur in the Ca≈øtle of Seba≈øt. Mun≈øter. Co≈ømogr. l. 3. ca. 214. de Epi≈øcopatu Curien≈øi. Aegyd. Schud. in de≈øcript. Rhaetiae Alpinae c. 15. & alij.
