Mars, doe make it vnpo≈ø≈øible, to be our King Lucius, ≈øo doth their Tradition, that this S. Lucius which fir≈øt preached vnto them, was their fir≈øt Bishop of Chur, for both Seba≈øtian Mun≈øter, Egidius Schudus, and others doe demon≈øtrate, that the Citie of Chur was not builded vntill after King Lucius time: ≈øo he could neither be Bishop of, nor Martyred in that Citie, then not extant.

3. And how would, or in con≈øcience could ≈øo wi≈øe and Religious a King as Lucius, hauing no child, or Heire fitt, or able to gouerne Britaine, or which the Romans would allowe, for≈øake his owne kingdome, to leaue it in ≈øuch certaine di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, and troble both temporall, and ≈øpirituall, as after his death en≈øued and could not but be morally fore≈øeene in his prudence, with the Apo≈øtacy of ≈øo many Britans his ≈øubiects, to aduenture vpon vncertaine ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, to preach in forraine Countries? or what Antiquitie doth proue, that he was
either Bishop, Prei≈øt, or Cleargie man? all our Hi≈øtorians ≈øett downe the time, and place of his death, and buryall in Britaine, making him onely a glorious King, Lay par≈øon, and Confe≈ø≈øour, no Cleargie man, nor Martyr. And tho≈øe forreine Writers which inclyne to hold he went out of Britaine into Germany, either for the mo≈øt part mi≈øtake their Authours, or grounde vpon heare-≈øayes and vn≈øound reports. Nicholas Viginier v≈øeth S. Bede for witne≈ø≈øe, which Nich. Vign. Biblioth. H ‚Ä¢ ≈øt. pag. 765. Naucler. Chron. Genera. 6. p. 565. Petr. Mer≈ø≈øaeus in Epi≈øc. Treuer. & in Epi≈øcop. TuÃÑgar. in S. Marcelio. Henric. Patal. de Vir. Illu≈øt. Germ. part. 1. p. 110. Magdeb. cent. 2. c. 2. col. 9. hath no ≈øuch thing. And he him≈øelfe beleeueth it not, rather teaching the contrary. Nauclerus ≈øaith, fertur, it is onely reported, and ≈øetteth downe King Lucius death as our Hi≈øtorians doe. Petrus Mer≈ø≈øaeus writeth doubtfully, ≈øome times ≈øaying, S. Lucius of Britaine that preached in Germany was a King, otherwhiles onely a Prince, as Con≈øtantius and S. Helens ≈øonne was. Henry Pantaleon, the Annals of Chur as he citeth them, and Stumphius onely ≈øay, that S. Lucius the Apo≈øtle of Chur, was borne of the Regall Race among the Britans, ex Regio Britannorum ≈øanguine prognatus, which is true of the ≈øecond S. Lucius. The Magdeburgian Prote≈øtants terme it a very fable to thinke that King Lucius left his Country, and kingdome to preach in Germany: fabulam omnino re≈øipiunt, quod Lucius Rex Imperio ≈øuo sponte abdicato, factus ≈øit Concionator: qui in Gallijs & in Germania, nempe Augu≈øtae & in Sueuia, pa≈øsim praedicarit Chri≈øtum: ac denique Curien≈øis Eccle≈øiae Doctor effectus, Martyrio occubuerit. And they ≈øay it is one of the fables, with which the Deuill defiled the Church of Chri≈øt, His fabulis Diabolus conspurcauit Eccle≈øiam Chri≈øti: when and where King Lucius dyed, & was honorably interred in Britaine in the Cathedrall Church of Gloce≈øter, I haue ≈øet downe in his time before.

4. And a very greate mi≈øtaking it is of Auentine, Feuardentius, Ga≈øpar Bruchius, and Seba≈øtian Mun≈øter, if they incline to thinke, that this Apo≈øtle Auentin. apud Magdeb. cent. 1. l. 2. c. 10. Feuardentius Annot. in Irenaeum. l. 1. Har. c. 3. Ga≈øpar. Bruch. Cata og. Epi≈øc. Curien. & Augu≈øtano. Martyrol. Rom. die 3. Decembr. Annal. Eccle≈øiae ChurieÃÑ. Breu. Eccl. ChurieÃÑ. die 3. & 4. Decembr. in fe≈øto S. Lucij, & Emeritae. Martyrol. Rom. die 6. Maij. Bed. V≈øuard. & Ado eod. die Seba≈øtia. Mun≈øter. l. 3. cap. 217. Act. Apo≈øt. c. 13. Naucler. gener. 6. Volum. 2. pag. 565. Bishop and Martyr of Chur, and the Rhetians, named Lucius, was Lucius Cyrenen≈øis S. Paules Kin≈øman, and mentioned in the Acts of the Apo≈øtles: For be≈øides all tho≈øe Authours, named before, the old Roman Martyrologe, the Annals of Chur, and their publike Church office, one the Fea≈øts of S. Lucius, and his Si≈øter S. Emerita with others doe fully a≈ø≈øure vs, that S. Lucius the Apo≈øtle there was borne in Britaine, of the Regall Race there, brother to S. Emerita, a Martyr, and Martyred at Chur. Of which not any one agreeth with S. Lucius CyreneÃÑ≈øis, for he was borne at Cyrena in Lybia, poore by birth, ≈øonne of S. Simon Cyrenaeus, that bore the Cro≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt, Bishop of Cyrena, where he was borne, no Martyr, and died the 6 day of May, on which his Fea≈øt is kept, when they of Chur celebrate their Apo≈øtles ≈øolemnitie, vpon the third day of DeceÃÑber. And it is proued before, Seba≈øtian MuÃÑ≈øter him≈øelf vrging it, that the Citie of Chur was not builded vntill loÃÑg time after the death of S. Lucius CireneÃÑ≈øis. No other S. Lucius (though many of that name) is remeÃÑbred in any Martyrologe, or other MonumeÃÑt to haue preached & ≈øuffered Martyrdome, in, or neare that place, or this time, nor any other a Britan borne, or of ≈øuch Noble Parentadge, but this our renowned S. Lucius ≈øonne of Con≈øtantius, and S. Helen, therefore of nece≈ø≈øitie we mu≈øt yeeld, as his due this honour onely to him: And glorifie God, that ≈øo greate a Prince of this Nation, elde≈øt Sonne to an Emperour, our King, and Empre≈ø≈øe our Queene, and by iu≈øt di≈øcent Heire both to the kingdome of Britaine, and the Roman Empire, abandoning all that and ≈øuch terreane honours, preferred the poore Religeous life, founded Mona≈øteries, and conuer≈øed in them with greate deuotion, ≈øuffered ≈øo many mi≈øeries and di≈øgraces, for preaching Chri≈øt, ≈øtoned and ca≈øt into a pitt at Ausburge by the Infidels, liuing ≈øome time in a Cliffe by Chur ingreate
au≈øteritie, ≈øtill called Lucius Cliffe: cliuo illi ad tempora no≈øtra nomen Aegid. Schudus Clarouen. in de≈øcript. Rhaetiae Alpinae cap. 15. man≈øit, Sancti Lucij Cliuus.

5. Allthough his memory hath bene allmo≈øt omitted in Antiquities on earth, yet he hath enioyed his de≈øerued honour in heauen, and the very foundations of his Mona≈øteries the one at S. Lucius in Aquitaine, the other S. Lucius in Rhaetia, and the hard ≈øtones of his S. Lucius Cliffe doe call vpon vs to honour, and not bury in obliuion ≈øo noble and worthie a Saint of our Nation, the fir≈øt among the Kings and Princes of Britaine, that for loue of the heauenly kingdome left his Title to ≈øo great a Temporall Throne, and ≈øcepter, to beare the Cro≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt, and preache his Lawe to his Enemies. Which wonderfull zeale, and deuotion in this mo≈øt holy Saint, being of the ≈øame name, Country, and kindred with King Lucius, and vndoubted Heire to the ≈øame kingdome, he enioyed, and liued to ≈øee it conuerted vnto Chri≈øt, and thereby renowned in all the world, and this S. Lucius for the mo≈øt part muring vp him≈øelfe in Cloi≈øters and Clifts, and concealing his Regall Right, and di≈øcent, gaue occa≈øion to ≈øome to a≈ø≈øcribe that to S. Lucius King in Act, which belonged to S. Lucius King and Emperour by Hereditarie Right and Title. Wherevpon I boldly ≈øay, for the glory of Britaine our Lucius the fir≈øt, was the fir≈øt King in the world, which for him≈øelfe and his ≈øubiects publickly receaued the Lawe of Chri≈øt: Our S. Lucius the ≈øecond, was the fir≈øt owner or Heire of a kingdome and Empire in the world, which for≈øooke them to preach, and purcha≈øe the heauenly kingdome and Empire, and S. Emerita his Si≈øter the fir≈øt daughter of ≈øo greate Parents, which publickly profe≈ø≈øed and practi≈øed ≈øuch holy conuer≈øation. And allthough we doe not finde in Hi≈øtories, ≈øo exact Eutrop. l. 10. Eu≈øeb. l. 1. Vit. Con≈øtaÃÑt. c. 14. Victor in Con≈øtantino. Zonaras in Diocle≈øiano. Pomponius LaetÍù∞ Roman. Hi≈øt. comp. in Con≈øtantino Max. Io. Bapti≈øta Egnat. in CoÃÑ ≈øtantino Magno. Anton. Sabellic. Ennead. li. 8. Ennead. 7. Niceph. l. 7. c. 49 50. Nich. Har. pesfeld. Hi≈øt. Eccl. in 6. primis ≈øcaecul. c. 12. p. 19. accompt, and memory of the cheife≈øt procurers and pro≈øecutours of the Martyrdome of the≈øe two glorious Brittish Saints, Brother and Si≈øter, S. Lucius, and S. Emerita, nor the certaine time of their death; yet if we call to minde, that which is common in Writers of tho≈øe dayes, that Maximianus Herculeus their mortall Enemy, was then Emperour in the We≈øt, and rai≈øed mo≈øt greuous Per≈øecutions there, and hauing forced Con≈øtantius before to putt his true lawfull wife their holy Mother S. Helen away, to take Theodora his daughter in Lawe, and what hate he bore to the children of S. Helen, ≈øeeking to depriue them of their Regall and Imperiall Right, and Title, as well appeareth in his plotts and proceedings again≈øt Con≈øtantine, ≈øtill liuing, and happily e≈øcaping them, iniuriou≈øly to aduance his owne title≈ø≈øe and vnworthie creaturs, it will be voide of pre≈øumption to thinke, that he countriued the death of the≈øe holy Saints about that time, when he ≈øought to murther their Brother Con≈øtantine, a litle before the death of Con≈øtantiustheir Father, knowne to be ≈øickly, and vnlikely long to liue, and ≈øo they receaued a double Crowne of Martyrdome, one for the kingdome of heauen which they diligently preached, an other for their Title to a kingdome and Empire one earth of which they were thus vniu≈øtly depriued. And we finde that among other Churches, which the Emperour Con≈øtantine the Greate, their Brother founded in honour of Saints, he founded one to S. Lucius, not vnprobable to this his renowned Brother then Martyred. A late Authour ≈øetteth downe S. Emerita Si≈øter of S. Lucius to haue bene dead before the Empire of Con≈øtantine the Greate, citing ≈øome, though not naming them, that she was burnt to death for the faith of Chri≈øt, Ante haec tempora quidam Emeritam Lucij ≈øororem, pro Chri≈øti fide exu≈øtam tradunt. But that which he alledgeth others without name to thinke she was not putt to death for Religion but in the time of Tumults
heare after King Lucius death: alijid ad≈øci≈ømata & factiones poti√πs, quae hoc regnum totos, po≈øt Lucium quindecim annos mi≈øer√® di≈øtrahebant, quam ad vllam Christianae fidei cau≈øam referunt. Be≈øides that wanteth Authoritie is confuted before.

div.head: THE XIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THAT S. HELEN WAS ALL HER LIFE AN holy and vertuous Christian, neuer infected with Iudai≈øme, or any error in Religion. And that Con≈øtantius her Husband long liued and dyed a Chri≈øtian, and protected both Britaine and other Countries vnder him from Per≈øecution.

div.p: 1. BY this we doe not onely ≈øee the greate and wonderfull Sanctitie of the≈øe mo≈øt holy children of Con≈øtantius & Helena, with a new confirmation of their true & lawfull marriadge, but the extraordinary greate loue, and affection of the≈øe greate PareÃÑts them≈øelues towards Chri≈øtian Religion. For the≈øe ble≈ø≈øed children receauing their Education, as birth and being, from them, and by them both allowed and furthered in ≈øo ≈øacred, and holy cour≈øe of life, in their young yeares, if we had no other Arguments but this, and that S. Helen was Grandaughter to S. Lucius our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King for his mo≈øt ≈øingular pietie, a ≈øpectacle to all after Princes, and Con≈øtantius her Husband euen again≈øt the liking of many of the Roman Nobilitie, and by diuers before, again≈øt their Lawes ≈øo farre enamoured with the rare vertues of that vnmatchable Lady, that aboue all others, he cho≈øe her to wife, to liue with her in ≈øo remote and ≈øtrange Country, e≈øpecially profe≈ø≈øing Chri≈øtianitie, which the Romans then per≈øecuted, we mu≈øt needs at the lea≈øt conclude from hence, that this our King and Queene were very farre from being Per≈øecutours of that Religion, if they were left to their owne Iudgments, and di≈øpo≈øition and not incited or inforced by others again≈øt their con≈øciences and propen≈øions.

2. Of Queene Helen there can be no que≈øtion, for being borne in a Chri≈øtian kingdome, di≈øcended from ≈øuch Parents, her ≈øelfe Mother of ≈øuch children, and by all Antiquities brought vp in Britaine in extraordinary learning and knowledge, where after the Druides and their Rites extinct by King Lucius, and their maintenance and reuenewes be≈øtowed vpon Eccle≈øia≈øticall learned Chri≈øtians, and our Vniuer≈øities and Schooles replenished with ≈øuch, we shall hardly with good congruence thinke otherwi≈øe but Queene Helen was in that her prime and florishing Age; rather an holy profe≈ø≈øed actuall Chri≈øtian, then in minde and affection onely. If any man will hold and affirme, that for the ≈øumptuous Pallace Queene Helen had in Treuers in Germany, Annal. Treuer. Sigeb. Chron. & alij. her loue to that Citie, and in re≈øpect of learning then there florishing, as in the Metropolis of tho≈øe parts, she had part of her education and in≈øtruction in ≈øo greate learning there, this will rather confirme that she was then actually an holy Chri≈øtian. For this Noble Citie receauing the faith of Chri≈øt
by S. Maternus and his A≈ø≈øociats, Di≈øciples of S. Peter the Apo≈øtle, ≈øent thither by him, had euer ≈øince faithfully continued therein ≈øo generally, and con≈øtantly, that about the yeare of Cri≈øt 288. when that bloody Tyrant Maximianus Herculius Galerius which forced Con≈øtantius to putt away his true wife S. Helen, to take the prophane Strumpett Theodora his daughter or daughter in Lawe, by his Prefect Rixiouarus per≈øecuted the Chri≈øtians in tho≈øe parts, all the Inhabitans of Treuers were founde to be Chri≈øtians, and Pamachius Gouernour of the Citie being al≈øo a Chri≈øtian with 11. Senatours thereof, ≈øo encouraged them in their holy faith, that all the Citizens, men, women, and children, not one excepted, were putt to death for that glorious cau≈øe. Haec vrbs √† D. Materno ac eius ≈øocijs lege Chri≈øtian√¢ imbuta e≈øt, inde tempore Maximiani Tyranni qui fuit anno Domini 288. agente truculenti≈øsimo Rixiouaro Petrus Mer≈ø≈øaeus Catal. Archiep. Treu. in encom. eiu≈ødem. Franci≈ø. Irenicus ib. Ro. Martyrol. die 5. & 6. Octobr. Sigebert. in Chron. An. 1071. Tabul. Eccle≈ø. Treuer. Petr. Mer≈ø≈øaeus in Annal. Archie. Treuer. in ValeÃÑ tino. Praefecto, tota ob Catholicam fidem interempta est. Tum vrbis Gubernator ac Princeps fuit in clitus Pamachius, Senator Pius, qui ob Cri≈øti Religionem cum vndecim Senatoribus ac tot√¢ Ciuitate interfectus e≈øt. Hij enim optimi viri ciuitatem illam ad Chri≈øti Religionem ita animauerant, vt pro e√¢ con≈øtanter occumbere non dubitarent: hic nulli aetati, nulli ≈øexui parcitum, ≈øed omnes ad vnum interempti. The Roman Martyrologe and Sigebertus call that Chri≈øtian Gouernour of Treuers and Martyr, Palmatius, and not Pamachius, nor Palmachius. And this opinion is more ≈øtrengthned by the greate Religeous loue of S. Helen to that Citie after this de≈øolation there, procuring S. Agritius Patriarke of Antioche, a man of admirable holines, and learning, to come forth of the Ea≈øt to be Archbishop there, with allowance of S. Silue≈øter then Pope of Rome, enritching him, and that Citie with mo≈øt pretious Reliks, the Seamele≈ø≈øe Coate of our Sauiour, one of the Nayles wherewith he was fixed to the Cro≈ø≈øe, the Knife he v≈øed at his la≈øt Supper, a greate parcell of the holy Cro≈ø≈øe, the body of S. Annal. Archiep. Treuer. in S. Agritio. 27. Matthias the Apo≈øtle, and others, cau≈øing her Pallace to be conuerted and dedicated a Church in honour of S. Peter. The old Chri≈øtian Writers and In≈øcriptions which before call her euen from the time of her Marriadge with Con≈øtantius, and before, ≈øancta, pij≈øsima, holy, mo≈øt Godly, and the like, will not be iu≈øtified in a Chri≈øtians mouth, penne, or pencell, except ≈øuch e≈øteemed her then a Chri≈øtian, for no other can by Chri≈øtians be ≈øtiled and honoured with tho≈øe Titles.

Neyther may we with prudence conceaue, that King Coel at her Marriadge with Con≈øtantius, hauing po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of, or Title vnto Britaine, a Chri≈øtian kingdome, nor the Religeous Chri≈øtian Archbishops, Prelates, and Nobles thereof, then at freedome in Religion, would haue condi≈øcended to ≈øuch a match, if neither Con≈øtantius nor she had bene a Chri≈øtian: that had not bene the way to procure to them≈øelues peace, and freedome which they ≈øought, but hazard of new trobles, Tumults and Per≈øecutioÃÑ, which they thereby hoped to auoide. Experience gaue a good Argument hereof to the Chri≈øtians of this Nation, for ≈øo long as this holy Lady and Queene was permitted to continue with her Husband, the State of Chri≈øtianitie was quiet heare, and the per≈øecuting Emperours Diocle≈øian and Maximian could compa≈ø≈øe nothing again≈øt it in this kingdome, but when they had forced Con≈øtantius to for≈øake her, and take a Pagan in her place, she her≈øelfe was per≈øecuted, her Chri≈øtian children bannished, and that generall affliction, and de≈øolation of Religion en≈øued in this Nation, that no ≈øemblance of the like is left in Hi≈øtories to Po≈øteritie. The Chri≈øtian Antiquities of Aquitaine will giue new ≈øtrength to this, in the≈øe their owne words: Becau≈øe Con≈øtantius was enforced
to take Theodora daughter of Herculius, he putt Queene Helen away, who patiently Antiq. Aquitan. apud Bouchet in Annal. c. 5. bore the Iniury, and liued in merueilous holines, ≈øeparated from all worldly curio≈øities, and Royall honours by the ≈øpace of 17. or 18. yeares. Such holines, and merueilous holines no Chri≈øtian may or will a≈ø≈øcribe to any, but true Chri≈øtians, among whome onely ≈øuch holines is to be founde, and with no others. Be≈øides our learned Antiquarie Ioannes Capgrauius, doth freely confe≈ø≈øe, that before she was marryed to Con≈øtantius she was in≈øtructed and taught in the Chri≈øtian Catholike faith, in fide Catholic√¢ in≈øtructa atque edocta, and liued Io. Capgr. Catal. in S. Helena. Chri≈øtian like, reprae≈øentabat in ≈øu√¢ conuer≈øatione glorio≈øa ≈øacri Bapti≈ømatis my≈øteria. And was a greate means, to bring her Sonne Con≈øtantine to be a Chri≈øtian: he ≈øaith further of her, that she was a mo≈øt holy woman, a mo≈øt firme bulwarke or foundation of Chri≈øtian Religion, by her Husband an Empre≈ø≈øe, by her Father a Queene. Helena ≈øancti≈øsima faemina, Chri≈øtianae Religionis Eu≈øeb. de Vita Con≈øtant. l. 3. c. 42. ba≈øis firmi≈øsima, ex marito Imperatrix, ex patre Regina. Eu≈øebius ≈øaith, that Helen the Empre≈ø≈øe was an holy Mother of the holy Emperour, Helena Augusta, pij Imperatoris pia mater. And addeth further, that through all her life she brought forth tho≈øe true fruites of pietie, which the Precepts of our Sauiour pre≈øcribe, and this both in words and deeds. In omnium bonorum affluentia, omne vitae ≈øuae tempus ad extremam v≈øque ≈øenectutem obij≈ø≈øet. Et tum verbis tum rebus ip≈øis veros pietatis fructus, quos Praecepta Seruatoris prae≈øcribunt, extuli≈ø≈øet. Therefore if all her life both in word and deed she liued as Chri≈øt commanded, by the te≈øtimony of this old Authour well acquainted with her, and her Sonne, both he, and all that will receaue him for an able witne≈ø≈øe, mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe she was a Chri≈øtian all her life, for no other doth or can keepe the Precepts of Chri≈øt in word and deed all their life. And whereas the greate≈øt Cae≈øar Baron. Annal. An. 315. Sponc ‚Ä¢ n. ‚Ä¢ b. Seuer. Bin. Tom. 1. Concil. in Ann. in Concil. Rom. ≈øub Sylue≈øt ‚Ä¢ o. obiection again≈øt this hath bene vrged by ≈øome out of the Acts which ≈øome would ha ‚Ä¢ e S. Silue≈øters, where it is ≈øaid that S. Silue≈øter baptized S. Helen, the be≈øt Roman Writers them≈øelues Baronius, Spondanus, Seuerinus Binius, and others proue them to be erroneous, euen in the≈øe particular re≈øpects, concerning this matter, in teaching Con≈øtantine was a Chri≈øtian before Helena. And that she was borne in Bithynia, and shew that S. Helen was neuer ≈øeduced to Iudai≈øme, nor baptized by S. Silue≈øter, but onely confirmed in her Chri≈øtian faith, as all Chri≈øtians pre≈øent were by the Di≈øputation betweene S. Silue≈øter and the cheife≈øt Iewes, publickly, inuincibly, and miraculou≈øly by all mens Iudgments, and their owne al≈øo conuinced by him. And proue how among other euident fal≈øehoods tho≈øe ≈øuppo≈øed Acts contayne the≈øe that followe. Con≈øtantius and Con≈øtans were Emperours in the Ea≈øt at this time. I≈øach was high Prei≈øt among the Iewes. That S. Silue≈øter did abrogate the Fa≈øte of Satterday, and in≈øtituted the Sonday, and that he was ordayned Pope by Melchi≈øedech, with other ≈øuch like mon≈øtrous fictions. Therefore we may not loo≈øe the honour of our Country, and mo≈øt renowned Brittish Chri≈øtian Queene and Empre≈ø≈øe by ≈øuch dreames, and forgeries. The wonderfull and exceeding greate zeale and deuotion of this mo≈øt Noble Lady, her piety and charitie to all with her bountie and munificence to the Church of Chri≈øt, her re≈øtle≈ø≈øe paynes, Pilgrimadges, and labours to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe Idolatry, and aduaunce the true honour and ≈øeruing of God, when she was a free woman, after her Husbands death, I shall entreate in the next Age, when I come to that time. This which I haue ≈øaid will redeeme and ≈øett her free from the calumnies and a≈øper≈øions which ≈øome would laye vpon her Parentage, Country & Conuer≈øation in her young and wedded life.

4. And to giue to Con≈øtantius her husband his due otherwi≈øe, e≈øpecially for his carriadge towards Chri≈øtians and their Religion, con≈øidering tho≈øe ouer≈øwaying times of Pagani≈øme and Per≈øecution again≈øt Chri≈øtianitie allthough he was farre from giuing due to his Noble holy wife Queene Helen, when for feare of the per≈øecuting Emperours Diocle≈øian and Maximian he putt her away, and tooke Theodora a Pagan Concubine vnder the name of a wife, in her place, except this his greate compelled blemish, we mu≈øt needs ≈øay, he was a worthie Prince, and in re≈øpect of Religion, one of the be≈øt of all forreyne Kings, or Rulers, which Britaine had ta≈øted of the Romans Impo≈øition vpon it. For allthough by the vnhappy yelding of Con≈øtantius vnto the per≈øecuting Emperours Diocle≈øian & Maximianus, in, or about the 292. yeare of Chri≈øt, thereby making him≈øelfe a Cae≈øar, to putt away Queene Helen, and take Theodora, he depriued him≈øelfe of that Regall power in Britaine, which he obtayned by his match with Queene Helen, the true Heire and Queene of this kingdome, and ≈øo armed the per≈øecuting Emperors to extend their rage and fury again≈øt the Chri≈øtian Britans, which had bene exempted from that their v≈øurped Tyrany heare, if Con≈øtantius had continued with his Chri≈øtian Eu≈øeb. in Chron. An. 292. Matth. We≈øtm. An. 296. wife Queene Helen and re≈øted vpon her Title, and the conditions betweene the Romans and Britans at that Marriadge, and ≈øo cannot be excu≈øed herein: yet otherwi≈øe their Per≈øecution preuayling in his time, we cannot finde he was any In≈øtrument, or Furtherer, but rather an A≈ø≈øwager, and to his power a Mitigator thereof, euen whil≈øt Theodora lyued with him, being a greate In≈øtrument to procure him to continue a Pagan, as Fau≈øta her Si≈øter was to Con≈øtantine his ≈øonne, and both of them employed by their per≈øecuting Father Maximian Emperour to that purpo≈øe. Eu≈øebius liuing in that time, ≈øaith of him, that he was the mo≈øt renowned of all the Emperours in his time. Fuit Con≈øtantius inter Imperatores no≈øtri temporis facil√® illu≈øtri≈øsimus. And giueth Eu≈øeb. de Vita Con≈øtant. l. 1. c. 8. cap. 9. his rea≈øon: Cum quatuor in Romani Imperij gubernandi ≈øocietate iungebantur, ≈øolus hic faedere amicitiae cum Deo omnium Gubernatore pacto, modum vitae, a caeterorum in≈øtitutis alienum disparemque con≈øectatus e≈øt. Illi Inte≈øtina virorum ≈øimul ac mulierum pietatem maxim√® excolentium caede, Prouincias ≈øuae ditioni ≈øubditas ≈øcelerat√® contaminarunt: when fowre were, at one time ioyned together to Rule the Roman Empire, this man onely Con≈øtantius among them making his leage of friendship with God, the gouernour of all, ledd his life diuers and different froÃÑ the In≈øtitutions of the re≈øt. For they weÃÑt about to pull downe the Churches of God, vtterly to ouerthrowe them, equall them with the ground, and de≈øtroy them. But Con≈øtantius kept his hand, free, and vnspotted from their abhominable, and horrible wickednes, and in no respect behaued him≈øelfe as they did. They pulled out the bowels of men and women, that were the true worshippers of God, and impiou≈øly defiled the Prouinces ≈øubiect to their Iuri≈ødiction, with ≈ølaughter: hic ≈øuam ip≈øius animam a≈øceleris labe vacuam a≈øsidu√® con≈øeruauit. Con≈øtantius kept dayly his ≈øoule free from infection of ≈øin. The others to heape all ≈øins together, with certaine execrable wordes which they v≈øed to poure forth in worshipping their Idols, deuoted fir≈øt them≈øelues, and then all that were vnder their Rule to the cur≈øed worshipping of deuils. Hinc capere coniecturam licet, neque Gallis neque Britannis, qui long√® vltra fines Italiae habitant, neque alijs qui circiter Pyrenaeos ad Oceanum occidentalem v≈øque incolunt, contra leges vi≈øum e≈ø≈øe, Chri≈øtianam Religionem, dum adhuc vita Con≈øtantio, profiteri. And to proue he continued in this true Chri≈øtian affection, and faith euen to his death, an other taking vpon him, onely to be an Interpretor of old Authours, thus relateth his la≈øt Actions: whil≈øt he lay on his death bedd, hearing Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. death to me more wellcome, and my departure hence more plea≈øant: I haue heare a lardge Epitaph, and monument of buriall, to witt myne owne ≈øonne, and one whome in earth I leaue to be Emperour in my place, which by Gods good help shall wipe away, the teares of the Chri≈øtians, and reuendge the crueltie exer≈øed by Tyrants. This I rekon to chance vnto me insteed of most felicitie. And we finde how his body being found at Caernaruon, likely Tran≈ølated thither from Yorke, where by common opinion he dyed, in the time of King Edward the fir≈øt, was honorably Matth. We≈øtm. 1283. Which Chri≈øtian dutie and ob≈øequy would not haue bene performed vnto him, e≈øpecially ≈øo honorably, and publikly in ≈øo Chri≈øtian Catholike a time, without either certaine knowledge, or very probable opinion of his Chri≈øtian Catholike Religion. The Ceremonies, ≈øolemnities, and prayers v≈øed in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, could not in con≈øcience ≈øo be performed, for a man dying in any other Profe≈ø≈øion. The Harris Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. l. 4‚ñ™ c. 2. And they produce Eu≈øebius to te≈øtifie no le≈ø≈øe: Who ≈øpeaking of Con≈øtantius death, and funerall ≈øaith, that he being a mo≈øt holy man, was buryed Eu≈øebius de Vita Con≈øtant. lib. 1. c. 16. with greate pompe, with Hymnes and pray≈øes, as a mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed man. Genitorem ≈øancti≈øsimum cum omni splendore, & maxima pompa extulit: fau≈øtis acclama tionibus, ≈øuaui hymnorum concentu omnes beati≈øsimum illum celebrant. Hunc morum vitaeque pi√® & Religio≈ø√® ad virtutem institutae exitum e≈ø≈øe, in Imperatore Con≈øtantio, vniuer≈øo generi mortalium, qui no≈øtra memoria vixerunt, Deus euidenter mon≈øtrauit.

div.head: THE XIV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: BY WHAT WICKED PLOTTS, PRACTISES, and deui≈øes Diocle≈øian and Maximian began and pro≈øecuted their wicked Per≈øecution of Chri≈øtians in Britaine and how Con≈øtantius was innocent, and free therein

div.p: 1. WHEN Diocle≈øian and Maximian the mo≈øt infen≈øiue Enemies of the faithfull Seruants, & Church of Chri≈øt, inteÃÑded their mercyle≈ø≈øe, and matchle≈ø≈øe per≈øecution again≈øt theÃÑ, the ea≈øilyer to make it as vniuer≈øall, & generall, as it was bloodly, & Tyrannicall; And perceauing that neither Nero, nor any other their Predece≈ø≈øor in that prophane Impietie, had or could before them traÃÑ≈øporte their rage in that kinde ouer our Ocean into this kingdome, protected, and Rampired both by cituation, Sea, Chri≈øtiaÃÑ Kings, & Rulers, or fauourers of Chri≈øtianitie, and Immunities froÃÑ the RomaÃÑ ≈øeuerities in ≈øuch nature, their ≈øtudy and practi≈øe was, fir≈øt to ≈øurpri≈øe & ouerthrowe the≈øe firme Bullwarks, & Forts again≈øt them. And therefore a≈ø≈øuredly knowing that by the Regall clayme, & Title of Britaine Queene Helen was the lawfull and vndoubted Heire, & Owner thereof, that she was a Chri≈øtian & di≈øcended of ≈øuch parents, & ab≈øolute Queene of ≈øuch a Country, the rare vertues & wi≈øedome she was endued with, her potency thereby, with hir Victorious and triumphant husband Con≈øtantius, that they had children to ≈øucceed them in the gouernment and kingdome of Britaine, and ≈øuch, as by credible Antiquities before, were Chri≈øtians, and thereby more likely to enlardge, and dilate, then re≈øtrayne or hinder the profe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øtianitie, they knew the≈øe Impediments to their wiked de≈øignements, mu≈øt be taken away before they could take effect. Wherevpon beginning with the cheife≈øt and principall propugnacle, the Title of Queene Helen, her marriadge with Con≈øtantius, and Loue betweene them, they fir≈øt a≈ø≈øaulted this by pretended di≈øabilitie in that Title & Marriadge. Her lawfull Title by Regall Lineall di≈øcent and Inheritance they fru≈øtrated in their Iudgment, which then had no Iudge on earth, by their pretended, & not to be examined Imperiall clayme, and Preeminencie, taking and reckoning for their owne, what≈øoeuer they could gett, and keepe by force and ≈øword. And their more then Panegyricall Orator Mamertinus ≈øaith plainely in his Oration to Maximian the Emperour, that the Britans were not onely ≈øubiect vnto him, but that he landing in Britaine, The Britans receued him with greate Triumphe, offered them≈øelues to his pre≈øence, Mamertin. orat. Panegyric. ad Maximian. Imper. with their wiues and children, reuerencing not onely him≈øelfe, but euen the ≈øailes and tacklings of that ship which had brought his diuine pre≈øence vnto their coa≈øts: and when he should ≈øett foote on land, they were ready to lye downe at his feete, that he might as it were march ouer them, ≈øo de≈øirous they were of him. That both the Britans, and Nation, adioyning to the boundes of that I≈øle were obedient to his commandements: And giueth nothing to Con≈øtantius, but as in the Right and Title of that Emperour.

2. Like to this: haue ≈øome others of the flattering Roman Writers, by which we ≈øee they went about, vtterly to di≈øable Queene Helen to haue any S. Helenae compelled to departe from Con≈øtantius. Title to this kingdome. This they ≈øo vrged to Con≈øtantius, and ≈øo di≈øgraced his Marriadge with that renowned Lady, that in the end they coÃÑpelled him to putt her away, and take Theodora the Pagan daughter of the per≈øecuting S. Lucius and his Si≈øter S. Emerita banished out of Britaine. Emperour Maximian in her place. Then they bannished S. Lucius and S. Emerita their holy children, and after martyred them, and to make all ≈øure in their prodeedings, detayned Con≈øtantine their other child, afterward Emperour, Ho≈øtage at their commande, and placed heare in Britaine none to be Magi≈øtrates to beare office, but ≈øuch as were Pagans mo≈øt ready to execute the cruell and ≈øauadge Re≈øolutions of that bloody per≈øecuting Tyrant again≈øt the holy Chri≈øtians heare. The≈øe things thus complotted, the State of Britaine by ≈øuch meanes was now brought into the ≈øame condition, for Per≈øecution Eu≈øeb. in chron. An. 292. Ma ‚Ä¢ th. We≈øtm. Chron. & alij. Bal. lib. de Script. cent. 1. in Amphib. Pitzeus l. de Vir. Illu≈øtr. aetate 4. in eod. Stowe & Howes Hi≈øt. Tit. RomaÃÑs in Coill. Hollins. Hi≈øt. of Scotl. in Crathlint Hollinsh. Hi≈øtor. of Engl. l. 4. c. 26. 27. Annal. Winton. Manu≈øcr. with other NatioÃÑs, or rather wor≈øe, the number of Chri≈øtians heare then being farre greater, both in re≈øpect it was a Chri≈øtian kingdome, and ≈øo had both more Chri≈øtian Inhabitants then other Nations, and by the Immunities and Priuiledges it should haue enioyed, many Chri≈øtians of other Regions fledd and re≈øorted hither in hope of quietnes, and ≈øecuritie from Per≈øecution.

3. And allthough the Per≈øecution in Britaine by our Hi≈øtories began about that time Con≈øtantius was compelled to putt away S. Helen and take Theodora, and was therevpon made a Cae≈øar: Yet he did not thereby receaue any Emperiall Power or Authoritie, more then he had before: for the name Cae≈øar in ≈øuch ≈øence died with Nero, and was not renewed vntill the time of Adrian, who adopted Antoninus Pius for Cae≈øar, onely a name of honour and Titular to be Emperour, and not of pre≈øent Power and Authoritie, as it was in, and before the time of Nero. And Con≈øtantius was not at this time in Britaine, but came hither the ≈øecond time, diuers yeares after by our Hi≈øtorians, and after the beginning of Diocle≈øian and Maximian their Per≈øecution heare. And was one of the Con≈øuls at Rome after that taking of Theodora and Per≈øecution begun in Britaine: For as the≈øe Authours ≈øay, he was Con≈øul in the yeare of Chri≈øt 297. All which yeare he mu≈øt needs be at Rome, when the Roman Hi≈øtories them≈øelues confe≈ø≈øe the Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian began long before. And in the next immediate yeare 298. before Con≈øtantius could be tran≈øported into Britaine, they confe≈ø≈øe, that Per≈øecution was dilated into all the Roman Empire. Anno Chri≈øti ducenti≈øsimo nonage≈øimo octauo Per≈øecuti ‚Ä¢ in Christianos milites ≈øaep√® gra≈ø≈øari caepta totum inua≈øit Romanum orbem. And many of our Antiquaries, both in Manu≈øcripts, and other writings, doe con≈øtantly affirme, that S. Alban was Martyred heare long before this time in that Per≈øecution. So te≈øtifie both auncient and late, Catholike and Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians. And of this minde mu≈øt that Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorian Raphael Hollinshed be, which in his Hi≈øtory of Scotland inclineth to thinke that Con≈øtantius had bene a Per≈øecutour in Britaine, except he will contradict him≈øelfe: for in his Hi≈øtory of England he holdeth, and proueth with others, that S. Alban and many others were Martyred heare long before the ≈øecond comming of Con≈øtantius hither, placing diuers yeares betweene them. The old Manu≈øcript Annales of Winche≈øter ≈øay, S. Alban was Martyred in the eight yeare of Diocle≈øian and Maximian. Pa≈øsio Sancti Albani iuxta ciuitatem Verolamium, quae alias Warlamche≈øter ≈øiue Watlingche≈øter √† Saxonibus vocatur, Anno Diocle≈øiani & Maximiani octauo. And yet the ≈øame Antiquitie telleth vs, that
the Monks of Winche≈øter were Martyred by the Officers of Diocle≈øian, ≈øixe yeares before that, in the ≈øecond yeare of his Empire. Interfecti ≈øunt Monachi in Wentan√¢ Eccle≈øi√¢ de≈øtruct√†, √† Mini≈øtris Diocle≈øiani Per≈øecutoris anno Imperij ≈øui ≈øecundo: And their Church then de≈øtroyed. A Prote≈øtant Bishop, as he citeth from ≈øome Antiquities of that Church, ≈øaith: this happened in the yeare of Chri≈øt 289. and addeth, that at this time Diocle≈øian endeauouring to roote out Godwin Catal. of Bishops in Wince≈øter. in Praef. Chri≈øtian Religion in Britaine, not onely killed the Profe≈ø≈øours of the ≈øame, but al≈øo pulled downe all Churches any where con≈øecrated vnto the exerci≈øe thereof. And it is euident by our Scottish Hi≈øtories al≈øo, and others, both that Diocle≈øian per≈øecuted heare in this time, and that not Con≈øtantius, but Quintus Ba≈ø≈øianus Hircius, Alectus, and Gallus were his In≈øtruments therein, as the mo≈øt H ‚Ä¢ ctor Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. lib. 6. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Scotl. Harris Hi≈øt. Manu≈øcr. l. 3. cap. 35. Galfrid. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 5. c. 3. 4. Caxton Hi≈øt. part. 4. f. 33. Manu≈øcript. antiq. Mamertin. Paneg. ≈øup. Hollins. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. Ioa. Lydgat. l. 8. Harding Chron. c. 57. f. 47. principall with others of inferiour Degree, all being Pagans by Profe≈ø≈øion.

4. And Mamertinus the Panegyri≈øt hath auouched to Maximian the Per≈øecutour before, that he was heare in Britaine in his owne par≈øon, which is confirmed by our owne Antiquaries, adding further, that he pet≈øecuted in the≈øe Occidentall parts by commi≈ø≈øion, and warrant from Diocle≈øian, ≈øo te≈øtifieth Ihon Lidgate the Monke of Burie with others. Harding in his Chronicle ≈øaith plainely.

lg.l: The Emperour Diocle≈øian
Into Britaine ≈øent Maximian.
This Maximian to ≈øurname Hercelius
A Tirante fal≈øe, that chri≈øtenty annoyed
Through all Britaine of werke malitious.
The Chri≈øtned folke felly and ≈øore de≈øtroyed:
And thus the people with him foule accloyed,
Religeous men, the Prei≈øts, and Clerkes all,
Women with child, and bedred folkes all,
Children ≈øouking vpon the Mothers happis,
The Mothers al≈øo withouten any pitee,
And children all in their Mothers lappis,
The Crepiles eke, and all the Christentee
He killed, and flewe with full greate crueltee,
The Churches brente, all Bookes, or ornaments,
Belles, Relikes, that to the Church appendes.

div.p:
And ≈øetteth downe S. Alban, Amphibalus, Iulius, and Aaron to haue ≈øuffered Martyrdome vnder this Tyrant Maximian at his being heare in Britaine, ≈øo doth our Brittish Hi≈øtory, Ponticus Virunnius and others, ≈øetting downe this Hi≈øtorie before the ≈øecond comming of Con≈øtantius hither. And our Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians ≈øay, that Dicetus Deane of S. Paules in London doth ≈øet downe this Per≈øecution in Britaine in the yeare of Chri≈øt 287. and interprete Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 5. c. 5. Pont. ViruÃÑ. Hi≈øt. l. 5. Manu≈ø. Ant ‚Ä¢ q. Prot. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. 9. ¬ß. 18. Bed. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 1. c. 6. 7. Abbreu. Chron. M. S. ad An. 280. S. Bede, William of Malmesbury and Ranulphus, that S. Alban was Martyred ≈øoone after this time, their words be the≈øe: about the yeare 293. as we reade in Bede, Malmesbury, Ranulphus and others, Alban with his Teacher Amphibalus were both of them Martyred. And S. Bede ≈øeemeth plainely to be of that opinion. So likewi≈øe doth the Authour of the old Manu≈øcript intituled Abbreuiatio Chronicorum. And mo≈øt certaine it is, out of the receaued Acts of S. Seba≈øtian, and other Martyrs with him, written in that time, and iu≈øtified by many Authorities, that Diocletian coÃÑming to the Empire but in the yeare of Chri≈øt 284. did within 2. yeares after begin his mo≈øt terrible Per≈øecution:
declaring and forbidding by his bloody Edict, that no man should bye, or ≈øell Acta Antiq. S. Seba≈øtiani & alior. Martyr. Baron. Annal. Tom. 2. An. 286. Spondib. Law. Surius. in fe≈øto S. Seba≈øt. die 2. Ianuar. Zachar. Lippol. eod. die. & alij. Gildas l. de Excid. & conque≈øt. Brit. c. 7. any thing except he did fir≈øt offer Incen≈øe to the Statues of the Pagan Gods, placed to that purpo≈øe. And there were Executioners appointed in the Ilands, Villadges, and Waters, that no man should grinde his corne or drawe water, except he fir≈øt offered to their Idols. And the old Roman Martyrologe with others proueth, that S. Seba≈øtian him≈øelfe. though a principall Commander vnder Diocle≈øian, was this yeare with others mo≈øt cruelly martyred, onely becau≈øe they were Chri≈øtians: S. Seba≈øtiani Martyris qui Diocle≈øiano Imperatore cum haberet Principatum primae Cohortis ≈øub titulo Chri≈øtianitatis iu≈ø≈øus e≈øt ligari in medio campo, & ≈øagittari √† militibus, atque ad vltimum fu≈øtibus caedi donec deficeret. And all Hi≈øtories are full of the Martyrdomes and Per≈øecutions of Chri≈øtians vnder Diocle≈øian at that time: and this not onely in tho≈øe remoter places, and Britaine, as I haue cited from our Hi≈øtories, but in the next confining Nations vnto vs euen by the commandement, and execution of that wicked Tyrant him≈øelfe Maximinian, which wrought ≈øuch de≈øolation in this kingdome. For in this very yeare 286. as the old Annals of the Cathedrall Church of Treuers te≈øtifie, all the Inhabitants of that renowned Citie, not one excepted, were martyred for Chri≈øtian Religion. Haec vrbs tempore Maximiani Tyranni Annal. Eccle≈øiae Treuer. & Ga≈øpar Bruch. in Praef. ad eo≈ødem. Anno Domini 288. tota ob Catholicam fidem interempta e≈øt. The earth it≈øelfe was moy≈øt with the blood of Martyrs, the greate Riuer Mo≈øell pa≈ø≈øing thereby was redd therewith ≈øixe miles ≈øpace, and diuers pitts were filled with the bodies of Martyrs. Haec TyraÃÑnis tam fuit crudelis vt tellus ip≈øa maderet cruore, Mo≈øella fluuius per ≈øex milliaria ruberet, acputeos aliquot Martyrum cadaueribus repleuerint. And about this time in the yeare of Chri≈øt 291. S. Mauritius and Manu≈øcr. Gallic. Antiquit. Ann. 286. cap. 28. Annal. Colonien. c. 1. Sur. Tom. 4. Men≈ø. Iul. Lipp. die 22. Septemb. Baron. & Spond. an. 297. Dama≈øus in Vit. S. Marce ‚Ä¢ lini Tom. 1. Conc. & alij. Con≈øtant. Mag. & Eu≈øeb. l. 2. de Vit. Con≈øtant. c. 49. 50. Gild. l. de Excid. & conq. Brit. c. 7. & 8. the whole Theban Legion, con≈øi≈øting of many thou≈øands of Chri≈øtians, 6666. were Martyred by the ≈øame Tyrant in tho≈øe parts, as their Hi≈øtories proue vnto vs. S. Gereon ac tota illo Chrictiana Legio, pro Chri≈øto Martyres facti ≈øub duobus iniqui≈øsimis Tyrannis Diocletiano & Maximiano, anno Domini 291. qui Chri≈øti nomen extirpare funditus, ≈øed frustra ≈øtudebant. And S. Dama≈øus, or who≈øoeuer the auncient Writer of the liues of the Popes, witne≈ø≈øeth in the life of S. Marcellinus the greate encourager of this Chri≈øtian Legion, that there were then within the ≈øpace of 30. dayes ≈øeuenteene thow≈øand Chri≈øtians Martyred. Quo tempore fuit Per≈øecutio magna, ita vt intra 30. dies 17. millia hominum promi≈øcui ≈øexus, Martyrio coronarentur. And both Con≈øtantine and Eu≈øebius are ample witne≈ø≈øes, that Diocle≈øian was a Per≈øecutour from the beginning of his Empire. Therefore ≈øeeing I am a≈ø≈øured by the be≈øt, and mo≈øt auncient Hi≈øtorian we haue, S. Gildas neare≈øt to tho≈øe times, that Diocle≈øian and Maximian their Per≈øecution did la≈øte but 9. yeares in Britaine: V≈øque ad per≈øecutionem Diocle≈øiani Tyranni nouennem: and bilu≈øtro turbinis necdum ad Integrum expleto: And that pre≈øently after Con≈øtantius came hither to gouerne, the Chri≈øtians heare liued in quietnes, and libertie, I mu≈øt needs by Order of Hi≈øtory ≈øet downe as in the proper place thereof the Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian and Maximian heare, in this third Age.

div.head: THE XV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEN, AND BY WHOME, THE PERSECVTION, called Diocle≈øians Per≈øecution, began in Britaine: long before the Martyrdome of S. Alban, and many heare then martyred before him: and in what ≈øen≈øe the Title Protomartyr, or prioritie in Martyrdome is yet duely giuen to him.

div.p: 1. IT is a common opinion among our Antiquaries, that this Per≈øecution, called Diocle≈øian his Per≈øecution, began in this kingdome in that time when A≈øclepiodotus ruled heare, and that Maximian the Tyrant, fellowe in the Empire with Diocle≈øian, was the cheife≈øt and principall mouer and pro≈øecutour thereof, being heare ≈øome time then pre≈øent in his owne par≈øon, about that wicked bu≈øines. This is ≈øufficiently expre≈ø≈øed by Eutropius in the life of Diocle≈øian, Eutrop. in Diocle≈ø. Mamertin. ≈øupr. pan ‚Ä¢ gyr. Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 5. c. 5. Pont. ViruÃÑ. Hi≈øt. l. 5. Mamertinus the Pagan Oratour, euen to Maximian him≈øelfe, our owne Hi≈øtorians, as Harding before cited plainely affirming it; ≈øo hath the Authour of the Brittish Hi≈øtory, ≈øo Ponticus Virunnius: In diebus A≈øclepiodoti orta e≈øt Diocle≈øiani Imperatoris Per≈øecutio, qu√¢ fer√® deleta e≈øt Chri≈øtianitas in tot√¢ In≈øul√¢, quae √† tempore Regis Lucij integra, & intemerata perman≈øerat. Superauerat Maximianus Herculius Princeps militiae praedicti Tyranni, cuius Imperio omnes ≈øubuer≈øae fuere Eccle≈øiae, & cunctae ≈øacrae ≈øcripturae quae inueniri poterant, in medijs foris exu≈øtae. The very ≈øame hath Ponticus, both of them a≈ø≈øuring vs this Per≈øecution was when A≈øclepiodotus had Gouernment heare, and by the procuring of Maximian. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter al≈øo writeth, that Maximian Herculius cau≈øed all this our We≈øterne Per≈øecution, but much mi≈øtaketh the time, as I haue proued before, when he ≈øaith that Diocle≈øian his Per≈øecution began in the 21. and la≈øt yeare of his Empire. Anno gratiae 303. qui est annus Imperij Matth. We≈øtm. An. 303. Diocle≈øiani 21. orta e≈øt Per≈øecutio Chri≈øtianorum po≈øt Neronem decima, qu ‚Ä¢ fere deleta est Chri≈øtianitas per orbem vniuer≈øum. Nam Diocle≈øianus in Oriente, Maximianus Herculius in Occidente, va≈øtari Eccle≈øias, & Chri≈øtianos inter≈øici praeceperunt. And it needeth no further confutation, then he him≈øelfe giueth vnto it, for the la≈øt yeare of Diocle≈øian mu≈øt needs be al≈øo the la≈øt yeare of his Per≈øecution, hauing no Power to per≈øecute, his Empire being ended then, and ≈øo that yeare mu≈øt needs be both the fir≈øt and la≈øt al≈øo of his Per≈øecution, when it is euident before, and by all Hi≈øtories, his Per≈øecution endured many yeares.

2. I will demon≈øtrate hereafter, that as ≈øoone as Con≈øtantius came hither to gouerne, the Per≈øecution cea≈øed, and was eyther quite calmed, and taken away, or ≈øo much as he could, hindred by King Coel his Father in Lawe before. And that A≈øclepiodotus him≈øelfe was no actuall Per≈øecutour, allthough perhaps he gaue more way to the Romans Tyranny in that kinde, not being able to re≈øi≈øt them therein, then King Coel and ≈øome others would haue done. Which together with his iu≈øt Title moued Coel to take Armes again≈øt the Romans,
and him in that quarell. So he was no agent in that Per≈øecution. Therefore Manu≈øcr. Ant. in Reg. Coelo. Ponticus Virun. Britan. Hi≈øt. l. 5. Galfr. mon. l. 5. cap. 5. 6. Theat. of greate Britaine l. 6. c. 9. Stoweand Howes Hi≈øt. Tit. Rom. in A≈øclepiodotus and Coill. Hollinsh Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. cap. 25. 26. Fox. Acts and Monum. Tom. 1. I onely yeeld, that this Per≈øecution heare was in his time. Which is proued before, by our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries al≈øo producing S. Bede, William of Malmesbury, Dicetus, Ranulphus with others, that this Per≈øecution was heare at, or before the 293. yeare of Chri≈øt, about which time A≈øclepiodote ruled heare by the common opinion of Hi≈øtorians. They them≈øelues be of the ≈øame opinion. So are other Prote≈øtants, Stowe, Howes, Hollinshed, and others plainely affirming it to haue bene in his time, and Maximian the cheife Mouer and Maynetayner thereof. And to make his way more ea≈øy and without re≈øi≈øtaÃÑce, he tran≈øported froÃÑ hence into Gallia to doe him ≈øeruice there, both a great number of Artizans, and an Armie of ≈øouldiers, ≈øo weakening his oppo≈øites heare, and fortifying him≈øelfe there again≈øt his Enemies: he maintayned diuers Legions within the kingdome, and an vnmatchable Nauie without, and ≈øo being now ab≈øolute Commander both of See and Land, he began his long intended mo≈øt cruell Per≈øecution in this Nation. Wherein he exceeded the Tiranny of Diocle≈øian his Mai≈øter and Predece≈ø≈øour both in Empire & mo≈øt prophane proceedings again≈øt holy Chri≈øtians in this kingdome. For if we may beleeue Eu≈øebius, liuing in that time, and ≈øaying he will truely Eu≈øeb. Hi≈øtor. Eccl. lib. 8. cap. 1. 2. 3. deliuer the ≈øtate of ≈øuch things therein, he plainely ≈øaith, that euen in the Ea≈øterne Countries and other places, which were vndoubtedly vnder the commande of the Empire, it was the 19. yeare of his Reigne, not two yeares before the end thereof, before his Edict of de≈øtroying Churches, burning holy Scripturs, di≈øgracing Chri≈øtians that were in any place of honour, and depriuing them of libertie, all Bishops and Rulers of Churches were committed to pri≈øon, and all meanes was v≈øed to force them to Sacrifice to the Idols. Agebatur annus decimus-nonus Imperij Diocle≈øiani, men≈øis Dy≈øtros, qui Cap. 3. Romanis Martius e≈øt, pa≈øsim Imperialia Edicta propo≈øita ≈øunt, quibus praecipiebatur, vt Eccle≈øiae ad pauimentum v≈øque de≈øtruerentur, & ≈øanctae Scripturae igni con≈øumptae comburerentur: & qui in honore e≈ø≈øent, de≈øpecti redderentur: Et in familijs con≈øtituti, ≈øi propo≈øitum Chri≈øtiani≈ømi retinerent, libertate priuarentur. Et tale quidem erat primum contra nos Edictum: verum in illis quae po≈øt ≈øub≈øequuta ≈øunt, adiectum e≈øt, vt omnes vbique locorum Eccle≈øiarum Prae≈øides primum vinculis traderentur, deinde quouis conatu ad ≈øacrificandum cogerentur. But the fury of Maximian in Britaine, then que≈øtioned whether vnder the Empire or no, could not be thus confined, but he began his Per≈øecution heare long before this time, as we haue heard already, and farre exceeded the crueltie contayned in tho≈øe Edicts of Diocle≈øian. Fir≈øt hauing brought the Britans to temporall ≈øubiection, or rather Manu≈øcr. Ant. in vita S. Helenae Io. Capgrauius Catalog. in ead. Chronolog. Eccle≈øia≈øticopol. an. 295. Baron. Annal. an. 304. Spondan. ib. Florent. Wigorn. Chronic. an. 293. Iacob. Gordon. Chronic. an. 294. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 302. 297. thraldome, the ea≈øelyer to bring them to ≈øpirituall ≈ølauery to his Deuils and Idols, Con≈øtantius that louer of Britans and Chri≈øtians and by his Father in Lawe and true Lawfull wife a Titler heare, was employed in other places, and affaires of the Empire, as in France, and Germany in tedious and terrible Warrs there ta≈øting both fortunes, ≈øometimes conquering and ouerthrowing, otherwiles conquered and ouerthrowne, euen at that time when Per≈øecution again≈øt Chri≈øtians mo≈øt raged heare. One of our old Hi≈øtorians ≈øetteth downe particularly his imployments there, the ≈øame yeare that Maximianus came hither into Britaine to per≈øecute the Chri≈øtians. So likewi≈øe doe others. Others ≈øett downe his Wars there, when our Per≈øecution was allmo≈øt ended in the yeare 297. when he ≈ølew 70000. Allmans. And all Antiquities keep him out of Britaine vntill Per≈øecution heare was ended, as I shall plainely demon≈øtrate. But Maximian well knowing his crueltie again≈øt our Chri≈øtians
would not, nor could be executed by Britans, that were Chri≈øtians, and in Office and Authoritie, he therefore generally depriued all ≈øuch of coÃÑmand, and Power, & did putt in their places his owne Pagans or per≈øecuting In≈øtruments, throughout this kingdome, as we may ea≈øely and euidently enforme our felues from tho≈øe few Antiquities of tho≈øe times, and affaires that be left vnto vs. For we finde both in old Manu≈øcripts, and other published Hi≈øtories, that in Manu≈øcr. Ant. de Vita S. Albani & S. Amphibali. Capgrau. Catal. in ei≈ødem. Bed. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 1. c. 7 Matth. We≈øtm. An. 303. Manu≈øc. Antiq. Gallic. c. 28. all tho≈øe holy Martyrs of Britaine then, who≈øe names be be≈øt pre≈øerued, as S. Alban, S. Amphibalus, S. Iulius, and S. Aaron, with others, there is not the lea≈øt memory of any Chri≈øtian or friend of Chri≈øtians, King, Iudge or Officer that was agent in tho≈øe things again≈øt them, but all ioyned herein with cruell and per≈øecuting Pagans: and the≈øe in diuers and all places, where any holy Martyr was then per≈øecuted, as at Verolamium, Lichfeild, Caerlegion and others, and all interiacent places betweene them.

3. And in the lamentable de≈øtruction, and ouerthrowing of ≈øo many Cathedrall, and other Churches, and Mona≈øteries, as were at that time in Britaine, and then vtterly ouerthrowne and equaled with the ground, as our Hi≈øtories pitifully relate, none others were, or could be In≈øtruments, Officers, & Agents, in ≈øo fowle and vnchri≈øtian worke, but wicked and per≈øecuting Pagans. And this was one of the next and fir≈øt Tragedyes in this per≈øecution, after the ≈øettling of Pagan Officers, and Magi≈øtrats to deface and vtterly ruinate, and pull downe all Chri≈øtians Churches, Religious hou≈øes, and Oratoryes, where Chri≈øtians liued or a≈ø≈øembled to ≈øerue God, thinking thereby the ≈øooner, and with le≈ø≈øe difficultie to take away all profe≈ø≈øion and profe≈ø≈øors of Chri≈øtian Religion. This is ≈øufficiently te≈øtified by S. Gildas, S. Bede, the Brittish Gildas l. de excid. Brit. c. 7. Bed. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 1. c. 6. Ga ‚Ä¢ frid. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 5. c. 5. Ioa. Lydgate lib. 8. Matth. We≈øtm. An. 303. Manu≈øc. Gallic. Antiq. c. 38. An. 286. Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. apud Godwin Catal. Bish. Winche≈øt. Hi≈øtory Ihon Lydgate, Matthew the Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter, and others, all of them without exception placing the de≈øtruction of Churches va≈øtari Eccle≈øias: incendijs Eccle≈øiarum: de≈øtructae ≈øunt Eccle≈øiae: as the fir≈øt entrance of our Brittish Per≈øecution. And ≈øome Antiquities there be, as the old written Annals of the Church of Winche≈øter, which ≈øett downe this burning and de≈øtroying Churches, and martyring the holy Prei≈øts of them, long time before the Martyrdome of S. Alban, commonly called our fir≈øt Martyr in tho≈øe dayes. A Prote≈øtaÃÑt Bishop thus relateth the Te≈øtimonie of one Antiquitie. The Church of Winche≈øter was hallowed and decicated October 29. 189. by Faganus and Damianus Bishops. About the ≈øpace of 100. yeares, the Church of Chri≈øt had theÃÑ peace in this LaÃÑd, vntill the reigne of Diocle≈øiaÃÑ, who endeauouring to roote out Chri≈øtian ReligioÃÑ, not onely killed the profe≈ø≈øors of the ≈øame, but pulled downe all Churches, and TeÃÑ ples, any where con≈øecrated vnto the exerci≈øe thereof. Amongst the re≈øt, this of Winche≈øter at that time went to wrake, the building thereof being ruinated and made euen with the grouÃÑd, and the MoÃÑkes, & all the Officers beloÃÑging vnto it, either ≈ølayne, or enforced to fly. This happened in the yeare of Chri≈øt 289. An other Manu≈øcript of that auncient Church which beginneth: Paganitas in Britannia, ≈øetteth downe this Manu≈øcr. Antiq. Eccl. W ‚Ä¢ nton. de≈øolatioÃÑ of Churches, & Mona≈øteries heare 6. yeares before the Martyrdome of S. Alban, particularly remeÃÑbring them both, with their ≈øeuerall times. And ≈øaith as the other doth, that there were 100. yeares betweene the building of the≈øe Churches and endowing them by King Lucius, and the ≈øacking and de≈øtroying of them in this Per≈øecution, & reporteth the martyring of their holy Prei≈øts theÃÑ: & coÃÑcerning that Church of Winche≈øter, it relateth, how the MoÃÑkes thereof after an hundred yeares of their placing there in King Lucius time, were now cruelly putt to death, Durauit Chri≈øtianitas in Britannia a primo anno Lucij Regis primi BritannoruÃÑ Chri≈øtiani centum annis, & tam diu Monachi Deo
≈øeruientes praedictum vetus caenobium quiet√® inhabitabant. Interfecti ≈øunt Monachi in Ventana Eccle≈øia de≈øtructa a Mini≈øtris Diocle≈øiani per≈øecutoris Anno Imperij ≈øu ‚Ä¢ ≈øecundo, Longe by all accompts, before the Martyrdome of S. Alban. And it is Anonymus Brit. Script. Vitae S. Albani. Manu≈øc. Antiqu ‚Ä¢ t. in Vita eius. Capgr. Catal. in Eod. & alij. euident by the words them≈øelues of S. Alban to S. Amphibalus, related by the old Writer of S. Alban his life, Capgraue, and diuers other Authours, that there had bene greate per≈øecution of Chri≈øtians heare in Britaine before S. Alban was a Chri≈øtian, and before his harbouring of S. Amphibalus. For at their meeting, he maketh it a wonder how S. Amphibalus a Chri≈øtian could pa≈ø≈øe, and come through ≈øo many per≈øecuting Pagans to his hou≈øe at Verolamium. Quomodo cum ≈øis homo Chri≈øtianus per gentilium fines tran≈øitum habere, & ad vrbem illae≈øus peruenire potui≈øci: And S. Amphibalus did a≈ø≈øcribe his pre≈øeruation to the e≈øpeciall protection of Chri≈øt, among ≈øo many dangers. Dicit ei Amphibalus, Dominus meus Ie≈øus Chri≈ø ‚Ä¢ us filius Dei viui ≈øecurum inter di≈øcrimina me cu≈øtodiuit. This is further euident in that Hi≈øtory, wherein we finde, that S. Alban would not ≈øuffer S. Amphibalus at any time, during their being together, to goe forth of his hou≈øe, but in the night time; And when they were to part one‚ñ™ from the other, would not permitt S. Amphibalus to goe forth, but in the night time he him≈øelfe accompanying and guyding him, and giuing him his owne Coate to weare, which had a Priuiledge and immunitie by the fashion thereof, and dignitie of the Owner from all per≈øecutours. Dans ei chlamydem auro textam qua tutior ab ho≈øtibus redderetur. Ve≈øtis enim huiu≈ømodi Capgr. & alij ≈øup ‚Ä¢ . Mat. We≈øt. 3 ‚Ä¢ 3. tantae tunc temporis apud omnes dignitatis, tantaeque fuit reuerentiae, vt ill√¢ indutus, ho≈øtium Cuneos penetraret illae≈øus. And it is euident by S. Bede, and others, that the≈øe per≈øecutours Edicts were published, pro≈øecuted and executed in Britaine, before this time when S. Alban was ≈øtill a Pagan. Albanus Paganus adhuc, Bed. Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 7. Matth. We≈øtm. An. 303. Martyr. Rom. die 22. Iunij. Bed. V ‚Ä¢ ua ‚Ä¢ d. & Ado eod. die. Capg ‚Ä¢ au. & alij ≈øup. in S. Albano. cum perfidorum Principum mandata aduer≈øum Chri≈øtianos ≈øaeuirent, Clericum quendam per≈øecutores fugientem hospitio recepit. And S. Amphibalus was then actually and particularly per≈øecuted. And S. Alban him≈øelfe when at the fir≈øt S. Amphibalus preached Chri≈øt vnto him, is witne≈ø≈øe that if others of that Citie should know it, they would pre≈øently haue putt him to cruell death for profe≈ø≈øing Chri≈øt. Si no≈øcent viri huius ciuitatis te talia locutum fui≈ø≈øe de Chri≈øto ≈øine mora pe≈øsima morte te occiderent. This is euident, both by the Pagan Magi≈øtrats, immediate and pre≈øent pro≈øecution after S. Amphibalus to putt him to death, and their mercile≈ø≈øe, and mo≈øt cruell martyring of S. Alban for no other cau≈øe, then receauing and concealing a Chri≈øtian Prei≈øt, and he him≈øelfe profe≈ø≈øing the ≈øame Religion. This is made manife≈øt by the Souldiar, which, miraculou≈øly conuerted by S. Alban his Martyrdome, and confe≈ø≈øing Chri≈øt, was pre≈øently for the ≈øame cau≈øe putt to death, and baptized with his owne blood in place of Bapti≈øme with water. The≈øe and ≈øuch Arguments and Authorities doe inuincibly proue vnto vs, that this Per≈øecution again≈øt the Chri≈øtians in Britaine was ray≈øed, and by publick Edicts, and Authoritie, or power of the Tyrant Maximian mo≈øt barbarou≈øly pro≈øecuted ≈øome yeares before the Martyrdome of S. Alban, and many Martyrs heare, as the Monkes and Prei≈øts of Winche≈øter, and others in ≈øo many Churches, and Mona≈øteries, at the ≈øame time, being in the ≈øame ≈øtate de≈øtroyed, and left de≈øolate, did gloriou≈øly obtayne the Crowne of Martyrdome before S. Alban, who≈øe happy names and memoryes being by Iniquitities of times lo≈øt vpon earth, are to be found in heauen, where there eternall glory is.

4. Yet I am farre from detracting any honour from S. Alban, which Antiquitie doth, or can giue vnto him. I doe with humble reuerence allowe him
his Title of our Protomartyr, Primus, Principalis; Praecipuus, fir≈øt, cheife, or principall In What ≈øence S. Alban is coÃÑmonly termed the first Martyr or Protomartyr in Britaine. Martyr, whether we will follow the Greeke, Latyne, or our English phra≈øe, if we re≈øpect his temporall worthines, his ≈øtrange Conuer≈øion, his admirable charitie, ≈øo ≈øoone Learned in Chri≈øtian Religion, to re≈øcue the per≈øecuted & deliuer them, to giue his owne life, to redeeme an other, being but a Neophite to be ≈øo con≈øtant in that mo≈øt greuious Per≈øecution, and with ≈øuch wonderfull patience, and con≈øtancy to endure tho≈øe torments he did, and be ≈øo honorable for Miracles, it is his de≈øerued due, ≈øo to be ≈øtiled: and prioritie of time would be but a litle honour to him. I haue proued before we had diuers Martyrs before this Age, and in this Per≈øecution we did not want tho≈øe that ≈øuffered Martyrdome before him: yet if we ≈øpeake of prioritie in time of Martyrs, who≈øe names are kept in Hi≈øtories, this al≈øo is his owne in that ≈øence in this Per≈øecutioÃÑ: for he is particularly the fir≈øt that is regi≈øtred by name in our Annals, to haue ≈øuffered Martyrdome in this time. For S. Amphibalus, S. Iulius and S. Aaron, and what other ≈øoeuer certainely knowne and recorded to haue bene Martyred in this raging tempe≈øt of Per≈øecution, obtayned their triumphe, and glory of Martyrdome after him. And in this ≈øence and meaning which I haue expre≈ø≈øed, doth our mo≈øt auncient Antiquary call S. Alban, the fir≈øt or cheife Martyr heare reckoning him for his exceeding charitie, con≈øtancy, Miracles and other worthines in the fir≈øt place before the re≈øt: Quorum Gildas l. de excid. Brit. cap. 8. prior: meaning S. Alban fir≈øt named in tho≈øe re≈øpects. Otherwi≈øe both he, S. Bede, the Brittish Hi≈øtorie, Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter and others onely ≈øay that S. Alban ≈øuffered Martyrdome among others heare in that Per≈øecution, but none of them affirmeth he was the fir≈øt in time which then ≈øuffered. Britanniam Gildas ≈øupr. Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. cap. 6. 7. Galfr. Monum. l. 5. Hi≈øt. c. 5. Matt. We≈øtm. an. 303. cum plurima confe≈øsionis Deo deuotae gloria ≈øublimauit, in ea pa≈ø≈øus est Sanctus Albanus. Inter caeteros vtriu≈øque ≈øexus ≈øumma magnanimitate in Acie Christi per≈øtantes, pa≈øsus e≈øt Albanus. And S. Bede maketh it plaine, that the Per≈øecutioÃÑ e≈øpecially about Verolamium, did rather end ≈øoone after S. AlbaÃÑ his death, then begin with him, bringing in the Iudge to be ≈øo much moued with the Miracles wrought at S. Albans death, that he cau≈øed the Per≈øecution to cea≈øe, Tunc Iudex t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ta Miraculorum caele≈øtium nouitate percul≈øus, ce≈ø≈øari mox √† Per≈øecutione Bed. ≈øup. cap. 7. praecepit. And the old Writer of S. Alban his life affirmeth, he was impri≈øoned ≈øixe moneths betweene his apprehen≈øion and death, in which ≈øpace that raging Per≈øecution made many Martyrs heare. And the ≈øame Authour, diuers Manu≈øcripts, and Capgraue te≈øtifie, the Edicts again≈øt Chri≈øtians were long time published, and receaued for Lawes, when S. Alban was putt to death, and produce him thus to proue as much, when the per≈øecutors delayed to proceede to Iudgment again≈øt him. Quid ≈øu≈øtinetis? Si non no≈øtis ferre ≈øententiam, Anonym. Script. Vit. S. Albani Manu≈øcr. in eius Vita & Capgra. in eod. Leges vestras con≈øulite: ciuitatis ve≈øtrae ≈øtatuta requirite: ip≈øa vobis in≈øinuent quid agere debeatis. Quid moras patimini? ≈øciatis vniuer≈øi deorum ve≈øtrorum me grauem exi≈øtere inimicum. Ve Idolis, & ve cultoribus eorum. And then immediately followeth that ≈øo ≈øoone as they heard him thus renownce their Idols, and profe≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe a Chri≈øtian, they pronownced ≈øentence of death again≈øt him, His auditis vnanimi con≈øen≈øu in ≈øanctuÃÑ virum mortis tulere ≈øententiam. And Manu≈øcr. antiq. & Capgrau. in Vita S. Amphibali. Aliud Manu≈øcr. Antiq. an. 286. Girald. Cambr. Itiner. Cambr. l. 1. c. 5. Idolatrie is there termed the Lawe of the Country: cultura Deorum Lex patria. An other old Manu≈øcript ≈øaith, Maximian did almo≈øt de≈øtroye all Chri≈øtianitie in Britaine, and ≈øetteth downe S. Albans Martyrdome afterward, as Capgraue and others in the yeare 286. Maximianus omnem fere de≈øtruxit Chri≈øtianitatem in Britannia, qui interfecit & martyrizauit Sanctum Albanum anno Incarnationis Domini 286. And if we in≈øi≈øt vpon the word Protomartyr, v≈øually giuen to
S. Alban: Giraldus Cambren≈øis giueth it al≈øo to S. Aaron, and S. Iulius. Duo nobiles Maioris Britanniae Protomartyres Iulius & Aaron: meaning by it cheife Martyrs.

div.head: THE XVI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THE WONDERFVLL EXCESSE, AND EXtremitie of this Per≈øecution of the Chri≈øtians in Britaine, in generall, and the mo≈øt greuious torments, mi≈øeries, and afflictions they endured, with their renowned ≈øanctitie, con≈øtancie, and patience.

div.p:
1. THOSE Hi≈øtories and Antiquities which be left vnto vs of tho≈øe times, being ≈øo ≈øparing in relating the particulars of that Per≈øecution, that in probable iudgment where they remember onely the name of one Martyr, they omitte a thow≈øand and more that ≈øuffered in that Tyrannicall time, and ≈øo in other particular afflictions and calamities our holy Chri≈øtians then ≈øuffered: It will be the ea≈øie≈øt and redye≈øt way for vs to come to ≈øome proportionable e≈øtimate and apprehen≈øion of tho≈øe mi≈øeries and per≈øecutions, if together with the malice of the mo≈øt powerable Tyrant, and his Inferior In≈øtruments, raging 9. yeares in tho≈øe cruell proceedings, we breifely recall to minde that Illu≈øtrious glory of Chri≈øts Church in Britaine wherein King Lucius left it, not one hundred of yeares before, as I haue allready deliuered, and compare it with that lamentable ≈øtate and condition, which by our Antiquities, it fell into, by this mo≈øt pitifull de≈øolation. We remember King Lucius left vnto vs 3. Archiepi≈øcopall Sees & Churches, with 28. Epi≈øcopall, be≈øides other inferior ‚Ä¢ hur ‚Ä¢ hes not to be nuÃÑbred, they were all ritchly endowed, & prouided for with renowned Archbishops, Bishops and holy Prei≈øts and other Cleargie meÃÑ. We had our Chri≈øtiaÃÑ Vniuer≈øities, and Schooles, Mona≈øteries for our Religious meÃÑ & women, Britaine was then ≈øo Chri≈øtian in the Inhabitants thereof from the King to the meane≈øt, that ≈øcarcely a Pagan was to be found. Chri≈øts Lawe and the holy Scripturs, with as full & coÃÑmon renuntiation of Pagani≈øme, were heare generally receaued by publike Authoritie. The faith of Chri≈øt being thus publikly receaued did continue with the Britans, as S. Bede is witne≈ø≈øe, inuiolated, and perfect in quiet peace vntill the≈øe times of Diocle≈øian. Su≈øceptam
„Äà‚óä„Äâ . ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cl. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 4. Galf ‚Ä¢ . Mon. Hi≈øt. Reg. Briton. l. 5. c. 5. G ‚Ä¢ ld. l. de excid. c 7. FloreÃÑt. Wigorn. Chron. an. 184. fidem Britanni v≈øque in tempora Diocle≈øiani Principis inuiolatam, integramque quieta in pace ≈øeruabant. So ≈øaith our Brittish Hi≈øtory: Chri≈øtianitas a Tempore Regis Lucy integra & intemerata perman≈øerat. So hath S. Gildas, onely excepting that ≈øome kept it not ≈øo well and perfectly as others did. Praecepta Chri≈øti ab Incolis ≈øu≈øcepta, apud quo≈ødam integr√®, & alios minus v≈øque ad per≈øecutionem Diocle≈øiani Tyranni nouennem perman≈øere. FloreÃÑtius Wigornien≈øis hath the very ≈øame words with S. Bede. So likewi≈øe hath Henry of Huntington: that the Britans kept ≈øound and inuiolate in quiet peace the faith of Chri≈øt which they receaued Hen ‚Ä¢ ic. Huntin. H ‚Ä¢ ≈øt‚ñ™ l. 1. in Marco A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nino. Ve ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . in the time of King Lucius, vntill the Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian: ≈øu≈øceptamque fidem BritaÃÑni v≈øque in tempora Diocle≈øiani Principis inuiolatam integramque quieta
pace ≈øeruabant. Our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries generally con≈øent herein, with the≈øe Antiquites, ≈øo doe our later Catholike Hi≈øtorians.

2. Now lett vs appeale to the ≈øame, our mo≈øt auncient and worthie Antiquaries, to relate vnto vs, ≈øome of the manifold mi≈øeries, and afflictions the Chri≈øtians of this kingdome ≈øuffered in that Per≈øecution. S. Gildas ≈øaith: ≈øubuer≈øae ≈øunt Gild. l. de excid. cap. 7. Eccle≈øiae, & cunctae ≈øacrae ≈øcripturae, quae inueniri potuerunt in plateis exu≈øtae, & electi ≈øacerdotes gregis Domini cum innocentibus ouibus trucidati: ita vt ne ve≈øtigium quidem, ≈øi fieri potui≈ø≈øet, in nonnullis Prouinciae locis Chri≈øtianae Religionis appareret. Diuer≈øis crutiatibus torti ≈øunt, & inaudita membrorum di≈øcerptione lacerati, vt ab≈øque cunctamine glorio≈øi in egregijs Hieru≈øalem veluti Portis Martyrij ≈øui trophaea defigerent. Qui ≈øuperfuerant ≈øiluis ac de≈øertis, abditisque speluncis ≈øe occultauere: The Churches were ouerthrowne, all the holy ≈øcripturs that could be found, were burned in the ≈øtreets, the cho≈øen Prei≈øts of the flocke of our Lord were ≈ølayne with their innocent sheepe, and the Per≈øecution was ≈øo violent, that if the per≈øecutors could haue effected it, in diuers places of the Prouince no ≈øigne or token of Chri≈øtian Religion had bene left. The Chri≈øtians heare were tortured with diuers Torments, and torne in peeces with ≈øuch rending their nembers a ≈øoonder, as was neuer heard of. That the glorious Martyrs might pre≈øently ≈øett vp the trophies of their Martyrdome in renowned gates of Hieru≈øalem. They which were left aliue hidd them≈øelues in woods; de≈øarts, and ≈øecrett caues, ≈øo to ≈øaue their lyues, expeactntes ≈øibi animarum tutamina. Galfridus ≈øpeaketh in the ≈øame manner: ≈øo likewi≈øe doth S. Bede, both expre≈ø≈øing Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. l. 5. c. 5. Bed. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. l. 1. c. 7. 8. the wonderfull Torments, our Chri≈øtian Martyrs heare endured, and how they which e≈øcaped death, were forced to hide them≈øelues in woods, wilderne≈ø≈øes, and ≈øecrett caues in the earth. Diuer≈øis cruciatibus torti, & inaudita membrorum di≈øcerptione lacerati, animas ad ≈øupernae ciuitatis gaudia perfecto agone mi≈øerunt. Fideles Chri≈øti ≈øe tempore di≈øcriminis ≈øiluis ac de≈øertis, abditis ac speluncis ≈øe occultauerunt. Virunnius ≈øaith, the Malice of Maximianus Herculius Virun. l. 5. Hi≈øt. was ≈øo enraged in this Per≈øecution in Britaine, that he did his vttermo≈øt vtterly to blott out the name of God in it, Volebat enim nomen Dei delere. Henry Henr. Hunting. Hi≈øt. l. 1. in D ‚Ä¢ ocle≈øiano & Her. Maximiano. of Huntington hath the ≈øame words with S. Gildas, and S. Bede, and addeth that the per≈øecutioÃÑ was very ofteÃÑ in that extremitie of TormeÃÑts, Haec per≈øecutio crebra erat. So hath the old Manu≈øcript, and Capgraue in the life of S. Alban, both of them ≈øetting downe both the generalitie and extremitie of that Per≈øecution heare, as our Saints and other Antiquaries haue done. So likewi≈øe doth the Authour of the old Manu≈øcript, Abbreuiatio Chronicorum, and the Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory of Rum≈øey: The later ≈øaith, the Britans kept their Chri≈øtianitie, Annal. Manu≈øcr. de Rum≈øey pr. In≈øula i≈øta. which they receaued in the dayes of King Lucius, and Pope Eleutherius, vn≈øpotted very many yeares. Britones Chri≈øtianitatem quam temporibus Lucij Regis eorum & Papae Eleutherij receperant, immaculatam annos perplurimos ob≈øeruabant: Which very many yeares mu≈øt needs extend to this per≈øecution. The former ≈øaith, that from the fir≈øt planting of Chri≈øtian Religion heare, in Britaine it remayned quiet without any troble: But in the time of Diocle≈øian Churches were ouerthrowne, holy ≈øcripturs burned openly in the markets, and the Prei≈øts with the Abbreu. Chron. Manu≈øcr. Ann. 280. in Diocle≈øiano. Chri≈øtians vnder them putt to death: hucu≈øque ≈øine perturbatione quicuit in Britannia Chri≈øtiana Religio. Sed Diocle≈øiani tempore ≈øubuer≈øae ≈øunt Eccle≈øiae, ≈øcripturae ≈øacrae medijs foris exustae, Sacerdotes cum fidelibus ≈øibi ≈øubditis trucida ‚Ä¢ i. The old French Manu≈øcript cited before, ≈øaith, that Chri≈øtian Religion which from the time of Pope Eleutherius and King Lucius had continued vntouched, and pure in the Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. Gallic. c. 28. in Diocle ‚Ä¢ . and Maximian. an. 286. Land of Britaine, was allmost now extinguished there in this Per≈øecution. There by the commandement of Maximian Herculius the Mona≈øteries were destroyed, all
holy Scripturs burned that could be founde, and the Noble Prelats with their ≈øubiects mo≈øt cruelly tormented in all their members and whole bodies and putt to death. This is the time, of which our old Poet is mo≈øt properly to be vnder≈øtood, ≈øaying that the holy Chri≈øtians of Britaine liued in the out Ilands, willderne≈ø≈øes, and Anonymus apud Bal. & Theater of greate Brit. l. 6. c. 9. craggy places e≈øpecially about Wales, and Cornwaile.

q.l: Britannica tellus patribus fuit inclita ≈øanctis,
Qui Neptunicolum campos & Cambrica rura,
Corinea≈øque ca≈øas, loca de≈øolata colebant.

div.p: Of which manner of life of many renowned Chri≈øtians, an other Chri≈øtian Poet thus ≈øpeaketh in this time.

q.l: Tunc plerique Patres ≈øancti, cum tale viderent
Excidium, fugere vrbes, & more ferarum
Per de≈øerta vagi, caecis latuer ‚Ä¢ cauernis.

div.p: Where we ≈øee nothing left, for their either dwelling, or foode, but ≈øuch as wild bea≈øts enioyed a≈øwell as they, all human habitation, dyet, and ≈øu≈øtenance with cloathing, but ≈øuch as they fir≈øt fledd away in, with time con≈øumed, taken from them, they thus left naked to nature, to dwell in darke Dens, and Caues, and feed vpon wild rootes, leaues, hipps, hawes, nutts, crabbs, and ≈øuch like fruits, as the De≈øerts, & litle barren de≈øolate Ilands brings forth. One of the≈øe happy receptacles & refuges then for our holy per≈øecuted Chri≈øtians ≈øeemeth to haue bene the litle Iland beyond Northwales, towards Ireland out of the walke of the Pagan Per≈øecutours, named by the Britans Enhli, and by the Saxons, and English, Berde≈øey, where in the time of Giraldus Cambren≈øis there liued mo≈øt Religeous people, called Culdeis as ≈øuch per≈øecuted Chri≈øtians were then named. Iacet autem extra Lhyn In≈øula modica quam Girald. Cambr. Itiner. Cambr. l. 2. c. 6. Monachi inhabitant religio≈øi≈øsimi, quos Caelibes vel Colideos vocant. Haec In≈øula Enhli Cambrice vocatur & lingua Saxonica Berde≈øey. Et in ea, vt fertur infinita Sanctorum ≈øepulta ≈øunt corpora. Ibique iacere te≈øtantur corpus beati Danielis Banchoren≈øis Epi≈øcopi. In this Iland as the Tradition is, are buryed infinite bodies of Saints: And as they te≈øtifie, the body of S. Daniel Bishop of Bangor lyeth there. By the merits of tho≈øe Saints this Iland hath this miraculous prerogatiue, that in it the olde≈øt doe ≈øoone≈øt die, becau≈øe di≈øea≈øes are there mo≈øt ≈øeldome, and ≈øeldome or neuer any man there dieth, except worne away with long old Age. Haec autem In≈øula ex miraculo ex Sanctorum meritis, hoc mirandum habet, qu√≤d in ea ≈øeniores praemoriuntur, quia morbi in ea rari≈øsimi: & rar√≤ vel nunquam hic nu≈øquam moritur, ni≈øi longa ≈øenectute confectus.

3. The≈øe ≈øo auncient miraculous priuiledges, and ≈øanctitie of that holy Iland, Hector Boeth. Scotor. Hi≈øt. l. 6. Hollinsh. & Georg. Buchan. in Fincom. Harri≈ø. de≈øcr. of Brit. c. 10. Dauid Powel Annot. in Geral. Cambr. Itiner. Camb. l. 2. ca. 6. Capgr. in S. Dubritio. the Eremits termed Culdeis, a denomination appropriate in Hi≈øtories to the Religeous of this Nation in Diocle≈øian his Per≈øecution, and the deuotion that holy Bishop had to be buryed there, long time before the ≈ølaughter of the Monkes of Bangor, when diuers Chri≈øtians fledd thither, as ≈øome write, giue te≈øtimony ≈øufficient to hold, ‚Ä¢ t was a Refuge and receptacle for our holy Chri≈øtians in the Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian, which is more plaine by the old Brittish Antiquities affirming, that many thow≈øand Martyrs and Confe≈ø≈øours bodies lay there. A≈ø≈øerunt Antiquae Britonum Historiae multa Sanctorum Martyrum & Confe≈ø≈øorum millia in illa In≈øula nomine Enhly ≈øepulturam habui≈ø≈øe. Therefore the≈øe old Martyrs mu≈øt needs be in that onely famous time of Martyrdome heare vnder Diocle≈øian, no other ≈øuch to be found in Hi≈øtories, Sainct Dubritius al≈øo with many others liued and died there. The mi≈øeries and wants ≈øuch numbers endured there, may be coniectured by the
the ≈øtreitnes of the Ile, doubtfull whether it hath one Parish Church or no. So Harri≈øon ≈øupr. c. 10. I ≈øay of S. Lides Iland, where a Church is dedicated to him. So of Ile Bree, corruptly Hilbery, renowned for Pilgrimadges thither in auncient times. So Harri≈øon ≈øupr. c. eod. Manu≈øc. antiq. & Capgr. in Vita S. Kebij. of Engl≈øuash or holy Ile ≈øo named of the BritaÃÑs, as a Prote≈øtaÃÑt Antiquarie coÃÑfe≈ø≈øeth of the greate number of holy Saints, who≈øe bodies are buried there, & was al≈øo called Cairkyby of Kyby a Monke that dwelled there, as he confe≈ø≈øeth. This S. Kebius was con≈øecrated Bishop by S. Hilary, and liued there ≈øome time, moued by the auncient holynes of that place. So of the Iles of S. Barri, and S. Dunwen, old Brittish Saints, giuing names vnto them by their liuing there. So of the Hebrides or Euboniae Iles 43. in number. All which belonged William Harri≈øon. de≈øcript. ≈øup. c. 10. Hect. Boet. Hi≈øt. lib. 6. Hollinsh. Hi≈øtor. of Scotl. in Fincomarke. Bal. cent. 1. in Amphibalo. Hect. Boeth. Hi≈øt. l. 6. Ho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ns. Hi≈øt. of Scotl. in Crathl. Georg. Buchan. Rege. 35. to the Iuri≈ødiction of the Bishop in Man at the fir≈øt, as a Prote≈øtant confe≈ø≈øeth, the fir≈øt there being S. Amphibalus in this time. And ≈øo of other out Ilands, vpon the Coa≈øte of this kingdome diuided from Scotland (of which Iles hereafter) then de≈øolate, gaue al≈øo ≈øuch entertaynment to tho≈øe our Saints in that time, who≈øe particular memory is not ≈øo well pre≈øerued. And as our Scottish Hi≈øtorians write, many of them fledd into the Country, now called Scotland, Magnus piorum numerus: No ≈ømall number of the faithfull among the Britans fledd vnto the Scots and Picts to auoyd Per≈øecution. Where, as a Prote≈øtant Antiquary with others confe≈ø≈øeth, they being many of them, renowned both for learning and pietie liued in poore Cells, in ≈øuch au≈øteritie & holines of life, that thereupon they were honoured with the name of the worshippers of God, Culdeis, that name being giuen vnto them, and after their deaths their Cells changed and dedicated into Churches. Multi ex Britonibus Chri≈øtiani ≈øaeuitiam Diocle≈øiani timentes ad Scotos confugerunt: √® quibus complures, doctrina, & vitae integritate clari, in Scotia ≈øub≈øtiterunt, vitamque ≈øolitariam, tanta ≈øanctitatis opinione, apud omnes vixerunt, vt vita functorum cellae in templa commutarentur, ex eoque con≈øuetudo man≈øit apud posteros, vt pri≈øci Scoti templa cellas vocent. Hoc genus Monachorum Culdeos appellabant. And for tho≈øe that liued ≈øtill in that part of Britaine, where the Romans then reigned, they write as our owne Hi≈øtorians haue done before. Euagata e≈øt rabies illa, non Hector Boeth. Scotor. Hi≈øt. l. 6. fol. 100. modo ab oriente in Occidentem, ≈øed etiam per alterum Orbem Britanniam, vnde Christiana pietas truculentis & inhumanis eius ingenij adinuentis plagis concu≈ø≈øa, immani tortorum ve≈øania, ac Per≈øecutionis diuturnitate, tota ferm√® est eiecta: pijs viris ac Religio≈øis per≈øecutionum metu in Eremos ac ferarum lu≈øtra concedentibus, vbi expertes iniuriarum ver√® Mona≈øticam ≈øancti≈øsimamque exegerunt vitam. Where we learne that our holy Chri≈øtians then were put to ≈øuch mi≈øeries, that flying into the woods, and wilderne≈ø≈øes they did rather cho≈øe to liue Hungry and naked in the Dens of deuouring wolues, hoping to find more mercy among ≈øauadge rauening bea≈øts, then the per≈øecuting Pagans allmo≈øt extinguishing Chri≈øtian Religion heare with their crueltie. Which may mo≈øt truely be affirmed, for, to omitte particularities to their place, the vn≈øpeakeable malice of the Per≈øecutours was ≈øo enraged, that without all colour or pretence of iuridicall proceedings, they mo≈øt tyrannically Martyred the holy Chri≈øtians, that were to be founde euen by a thow≈øand, and thow≈øand at a time, in di≈øtinct times and places, as we reade in the Hi≈øtorie of one onely ble≈ø≈øed Martyr S. Amphibalus 2000. at two ≈øeuerall murtherings. So we mu≈øt apprehend of other times and places, Manu≈øcr. Antiq. in Vita S. Amphib ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . ‚Ä¢ apgr. Catal. in eod. otherwi≈øe ≈øo greate and generall a de≈øolation in ≈øo lardge a Chri≈øtian kingdome could not haue bene effected in 9. yeares Per≈øecution. The Antiqua ‚Ä¢ ies of Cambridge tell vs, how among other de≈øolations in this time by Maximian heare, their Vniuer≈øitie and Citie was burned, as al≈øo all Churches were
at that time. Inter caeteras praeclara illa vrbs, Philo≈øophiae parens Cantabrigia, palatijs Io. Caius Hi≈øt. Cantabrig. p. 24. aedificij≈øque pulcherrima ab Herculio Maximiano, homine impio & ≈øanguinario Diocle≈øiani Exercitus Principe, & Imperij ≈øocio exu≈øtae≈øt, vnaque omnia templa euer≈øa, omnes Sacro≈øanctae Scripturae, & bonarum Artium libri, qui occurrebant public√® in foro concremati. And he that was then heare King at the deuotion of
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cobus GenueÃÑ. io Vita S. Albani & Amphibali. Anglic. Antiq. ≈øc ‚Ä¢ iptor. ibid. the Romans, A≈øclepiodotus, whome the Italian Writer, Iacobus Bishop of Genua, and his old Tran≈ølatour into English heare, in the life of S. Alban, and S. Amphibalus call Askepodot, ioyned in this Per≈øecution with Diocle≈øian, and Maximinian, and gaue ≈øentence and Iudgment again≈øt them, and putt them, and diuers thow≈øands of Chri≈øtians then to death, extending his Rge and malice again≈øt the Chri≈øtians in all places he could, as the≈øe and others witne≈ø≈øe: Yet others there be that ≈øpeake otherwi≈øe, & better of King A≈øclepiodotus, as I shall relate hereafter.

div.head: THE XVII. CHAPTER.
