argument.p: OF DIVERS HOLY MARTYRS, MOST CRVELLY putt to death at Winche≈øter, Caerlegion, and other places in Britaine, long before the Martyrdome of S. Alban, with their greate honour and renowne.

div.p: 1. THE fir≈øt Per≈øecution of Chri≈øtians heare in Britaine, which I Annal. Manu≈øcr. Eccle≈ø. Winton. finde in particular, was that which I haue before remembred, out of the Antiquities of Winche≈øter, in which the holy ≈øacred Prei≈øts of the Cathedrall Church being then de≈øtroyed, were putt to death. Interfecti ≈øunt Monachi in Ventana Eccle≈øia de≈øtructa, The Martyrdome of the Monks of Winche≈øter by the Annals of that Church, was diuers yeares before S. Albanus. which by the computation of tho≈øe Annals was 7. or 8. yeares before the Martyrdome of S. Alban: and yet the ≈øame Antiquities doe ≈øufficiently in≈øinuate, that this Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian began in Britaine in the yeare before their Martyrdome. Some before referre the Martyrdome of S. Augulus, Archbishop of our old Augu≈øta London to this time, but not finding that name among the Archbishops of that place, which were ≈øince the Conuer≈øion Much per≈øecution and Martyrdome was in Londen, before this. vnder King Lucius in any Hi≈øtorie, and for other rea≈øons before mentioned, I haue rather made him farre more auncient. Yet it is apparant enough, that London ta≈øted of this Per≈øecution, euen in the fir≈øt ari≈øing thereof; for we reade, that in the time of Alectus, to whome A≈øclepiodotus ≈øucceeded, Pagani≈ø Galfrid. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 5. c. 4. Virun. l. 5. Hi≈øt. Harding Chron. c. 56. Mat. We≈øt. An. 294. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. in Vit. S. Albani. Iacob. Genuen. & Capgrau. in ‚Ä¢ od. me was publikly profe≈ø≈øed there, which could not ea≈øely be done without greate Per≈øecution of Chri≈øtians, e≈øpecially the ≈øacred Prei≈øts of the Arehiepi≈øcopall See in that Citie. And in the Towne of Verolamium, where S. Alban was Martyred, it was a ≈øtrange thing at the time of his death to heare of Chri≈øtianitie, and they which were conuerted by his miraculous death, had neuer bene Chri≈øtians before, but were vnbaptized, as that Hi≈øtory relateth. This Per≈øecution being generall to all Churches, and places, euen in the beginning thereof, came to the Citie of Caerlegion, where the Church being de≈øtroyed, and the Schoole founded by King Lucius ouerthrowne, the holy Prei≈øts and other Chri≈øtians there had their part therein.

2. Among others S. Iulius and S. Aaron were then cruelly Martyred in that
Citie, being by all Citizens and Inhabitants there, Aaron & Iulius Legionum Gild. l. de excid. c. 7. Bed. Hi≈øt. Eccl. lib. 1. c. 7. Galfrid. Mon. l. 5. c. 5. Girald. Cambr. Itin. Cambr. l. 1. c. 5. Henric. Hunting. Hi≈øt. l. 1. in Diocletian. Capgrau. Catal. in S. Alban. Io. Bal. Praef. in l. de Script. & cent. 1. in Amphibalo. Dauid Powell. Annot. in c. 4. Girarld. Cambr. de≈øcr. Cambriae. vrhis ciues, mo≈øt cruelly then torne in peeces with Torments neuer heard of before, pa≈øsi ≈øunt, inaudita membrorum di≈øceptione, in te≈øtimonium Dei excel≈øi. Others ≈øay, it is euident in Hi≈øtories that they were learned meÃÑ, brought vp in the Colledge or Schoole there founded by King Lucius; thus write two of our cheife≈øt Prote≈øtant Antiquaries: Ex Sanctorum Hi≈øtorijs con≈øtat Amphibalum, Aaronem, & Iulium ≈øancti≈øsimos Dei Martyres caelestem Chri≈øti doctrinam apud vrbem Legionum inter litteras tradidi≈ø≈øe. Ex nobili Gymna≈øio vrbis Legionum viri multi ≈øumma pietatis & doctrinae laude con≈øpicui prodierunt, vt Amphibalus, Iulius, Aaron. By which Authorities, and te≈øtimonies, ioyning the≈øe holy Martyrs for education, Schoole, learning, preaching and profe≈ø≈øing Chri≈øt, with that mo≈øt renowned Pr ‚Ä¢ i≈øt and Bishop S. Amphibalus, they incline to hold, and teach, that they al≈øo were Clergy men. And if we remember what I haue ≈øaid before, how S. Alban was not our Protomartyr in re≈øpect of time but otherwi≈øe, and this Per≈øecution at Caerlegion, when the≈øe holy Martyrs were putt to death, was at the de≈øtruction of the Cathedrall Church there, being at the ≈øame time, as the like de≈øolation was at Winche≈øter, loÃÑg before S. The old ≈øchoole of CaerlegioÃÑ brought forth many glorious Martyrs in this time. Alban his Martyrdome, I mu≈øt needs ≈øay the ≈øame of the≈øe Saints, as the Annals of Winche≈øter doe of their Martyrs. And this the rather becau≈øe our Antiquaries before haue told vs, that S. Amphibalus that conuerted S. Alban, was borne, bredd, in≈øtructed in learning, and remayned at Caerlegion, and being there in all probable iudgment, when the≈øe trobles began there, was, as our Brittish Hi≈øtory witne≈ø≈øeth, pur≈øued and in pre≈øent danger to be apprehended by the Per≈øecutours, when S. Alban gaue him fir≈øt entertaynment, and ≈øuccour, and addeth plainely, that when S. Amphibalus thus fledd from Caerlegion, S. Iulius, & S. Aaron, were, ab≈øque cunctamine, pre≈øently Martyred there, S. Iulius and S. Aaron martyred at Caerlegion with many others before S. Alban. Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 5. c. 5. hauing their members ≈øo torne in peeces, as the like had not bene heard of before. Inter caeteros vtriu≈øque ≈øexus, ≈øumm√¢ Magnanimitate in acie Chri≈øti per≈øtantes, pa≈ø≈øus e≈øt Albanus Verolamius, Iulius quoque & Aaron vrbis Legionum ciues: quorum Albanus charitatis gratia feruens, confe≈ø≈øorem ≈øuum Amphibalum √† Per≈øecutoribus in≈øectatum, & iam iam comprehendendum in domo ≈øua occuluit. Caeteri ver√≤ duo inaudita membrorum di≈øcerptione lacerati ad egregias portas Hieru≈øalem ab≈øque cunctamine cum Martirij trophaeo conuolauerunt. The very ≈øame te≈øtimony Gildas l. de excid. c. 8. is giuen hereof by S. Gildas, both for S. Amphibalus then flying the Per≈øecutours, and the Martyrdome of the≈øe Saints at that time, S. Bede al≈øo is witne≈ø≈øe that S. Alban entertayned S. Amphibalus flying the Per≈øecutours: Clericum quendam Per≈øecu ‚Ä¢ ores fugientem ho≈øpitio recepit: And that S. Aaron & S. Iulius were martyred at that time: Pa≈øsi ≈øunt ea tempe≈øtate Aaron & Iulius Bed. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 1. c. 7. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 303. Girald. Cambr. Itiner. Cambr. l. 1. c. 5. Gildas excid. B ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t. c. 8. Legionum vrbis ciues. The like haue others. Therefore Giraldus Cambren≈øis doth worthely call them, our two Noble Protomartyrs in this time, onely in dignitie ≈øecond and next to S. Alban and Amphibalus, but in time fir≈øt and before them Duo nobiles, & po≈øt Albanum & Amphibalum praecipui Britanniae Maioris Protomartyres. The≈øe our two Protomartyrs are wonderfully commended in our Hi≈øtories. S. Gildas ≈øaith of them, that they ≈øtood out in the Army of Chri≈øt with greate≈øt magnanimitie: ≈øumma magnanimitate in acie Chri≈øti per≈øtantes dico. Giraldus Cambren≈øis is witnes, that among the Martyrs of that time, they were the cheife≈øt next to S. Alban and S. Amphibalus. Po≈øt Albanum & Amphibalum praecipui Martyrio coronati Iulius & Aaron. How Girald. ≈øupr. Itiner. Cambr. l. 1. c. 5. they were honoured of the holy Catholike Chri≈øtians of that time with Churches dedicated vnto them, Pilgrimages to the places of their Martyrdome,
and they both there, and in other places honoured, inuocated and The Martyrs then honored with prayers, and Pilgrimages to them. prayed vnto, pre≈øently vpon the cea≈øing of the Per≈øecution, I will declare among other memories of that time, in their place in the beginning of the next Age.

3. Now it will ≈øuffice to conclude with that their Title of glory and renowne, Girald. Cambr. ≈øupr. which the auncient and learned Bishop of their Nation before hath giuen them, as their due and honour to the place of their triumphant death: Iacent hic duo Nobiles Britanniae Maioris Protomartyres, & ibidem Martyrio coronati Iulius & Aaron. Heare lie at Caerlegion the two Noble Protomartyrs of great Britaine, and crowned with Martyrdome there Iulius and Aaron. This Title to be the fir≈øt Martyrs of Britaine in that mo≈øt terrible Per≈øecution, and with ≈øuch exceeding magnanimitie, and Chri≈øtian con≈øtancy, as hath bene before remembred, in enduring Torments neuer vntill then heard of, without any example going before them, but giuing them≈øelues the fir≈øt example heare of ≈øo wonderfull patience, loue of Chri≈øt, and Heroicall true fortitude to ≈øo many thow≈øands, which by their ≈øingular example with inuincible couradge imitated them therein, is the greate≈øt honour we can yeeld to ≈øuch ble≈ø≈øed Saints one earth. Their Fe≈øtiuitie is celebrated by the old Roman Martyrologe vpon the fir≈øt day of Iuly. On which day as Baronius plainely writeth, many Martyr. Rom. die 1. Iulij. others ≈øuffered Martyrdome with them. Iulius & Aaron Martyres cum alijs plurimis in Britannia ≈øub Diocle≈øiano primo die Iulij. So likewi≈øe affirmeth a Cae≈øar Baron. in Indice NominuÃÑ Sanctorum in Iulio & Aarone. Author of Engl. Martyr. 1. Iul. late English Wtiter: And the Roman Martyrologe, which Baronius glo≈ø≈øeth, may well carry that con≈øtruction for ≈øetting downe for a certaine truth, that the≈øe two holy Martyrs were putt to death in Britaine vpon the fir≈øt day of Iuly: Primo die Iulij in Britannia Sanctorum Martyrum Iulij & Aaron qui in per≈øecutione Diocle≈øiani pa≈øsi ≈øunt: it pre≈øently addeth: Quo tempore ibidem, quamplurimi diuer≈øis crutiatibus torti & ≈øaeui≈øsim√® lacerati ad ≈øupernae ciuit atis gaudia con≈øummato agone peruenerunt. At the ≈øame time, in the ≈øame place, very many tortured with diuers torments, and mo≈øt cruelly torne, hauing ended their combate, came to the Ioyes of heauen. And S. Bede ≈øaith, that ea tempe≈øtate, Martyrol. Ro. 1. die Iulij. Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. c. 7. Henr. Hunting. Hi≈øt. l. 1. in Diocle≈ø. Matt. We≈øt. an. 303. Io. Capgr. in S. Albano. & alij. Girald. CaÃÑbren. Itiner. Camb. l. 1. cap. 5. Ranulph. Higed. l. 1. c. 48. Dauid. Powel. Annot. in Girald. ≈øupr. Harri≈øon De≈øcript. of Brit. c. 13. Humfr. Lhuyd. Br ‚Ä¢ uiar. Britan. Et Tho. Twyne ib. f. 82. The glory of Caerleg ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n ‚Ä¢ ur Archie
‚Ä¢ i≈øc ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ all ≈øee before this time. at that time when S. Aaron and S. Iulius were Martyred, diuers others both men and women were putt to death. Alijque vtriu≈øque ≈øexus pa≈øsi ≈øunt ea tempe≈øtate. So hath Henry of Huntington: pa≈øsi ≈øunt co tempore Aaron & Iulius alij quo que plures vtriu≈øque ≈øexus. So haue others. And we cannot probably thinke, that tho≈øe raging Per≈øecutours which in places where there were not in any degree ≈øo many Chri≈øtians as in this renowned Citie an Archiepi≈øcopall See and Chri≈øtian Vniuer≈øitie putt them to death by thow≈øands, ≈øent the≈øe heare by cruell Martyrdome to heauen alone. The≈øe holy Martyrs by all Antiquities ≈øuffered Martyrdome at Caerlegion; and both Giral ‚Ä¢ us Cambren≈øis, Ranulphus Higeden writing at We≈øtche≈øter, as al≈øo our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries of the ≈øame Country plainely ≈øay it was at Caerlegion, in Monmouthshire, which was the Archiepi≈øcopall Citie and Schoole, di≈øtinguishing it from We≈øtche≈øter, by ≈øome called Caerlegion al≈øo. I will onely cite one thus Englished to my hand by a Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorian: In this Region Monmouthshire, is ≈øituated the mo≈øt auncient, and Noble Citie of Legions, which our Countrymen call Caerleon are Wish, that is to ≈øay the Citie of Legions vpon Vsk, for difference ≈øake, betweene it, and the other which is builded in Northwales, vpon the Riuer Dee. Of whome Giraldus writeth thus: The ≈øame was an auncient, and noble Towne, the tokens whereof remayne as yet, an huge Palace, a Giantlike Tower, goodly Bathes, and hotehou≈øes, Reliques of Churches, and
places like Theaters, compa≈ø≈øed with beautifull walles, ‚Ä¢ artly yet ≈øtanding. Al≈øo buildings vnde ‚Ä¢ the grounde, Conducts, ≈øecre ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e pa≈ø≈øages‚ñ™ and Vaultes vnder the earth, framed by wonderfull workemanship. Th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ th two Martyrs Iulius and Aaron which had Churches dedicate ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ . The like and more plainely haue many others, auncient and late, Catholiks and Prote≈øtants. Therefore that Prote≈øtant Bishop which ≈øingularlie ≈øaith, it was at Che≈øter, apud vrbem Legionum, Ce≈øtriam nun vocatam, is much deceaued in this matter. Io. B ‚Ä¢ l. Pr ‚Ä¢ fat. in l. de Scriptor.

div.head: THE XVIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: HOW SAINT AMPHIBALVS A BRITTISH Bishop, and many holy and learned Prei≈øts of the Britans in this Per≈øecution went to the Scots and Picts, were reuerently receaued of them, and preached, liued and continued there in greate Sanctitie, and left greate Succe≈øsion of ≈øuch, there after them.

div.p:
1. VPON this Per≈øecution, and Martyrdome of the≈øe holy Saints, Gildas l. de excid. c. 8. and others at that time, as S. Gildas with others writeth, they which e≈øcaped death hidd theÃÑ≈øelues in Woods, De≈øarts, Dens, and fledd into Ilands, & to the Scots for refuge. Qui ≈øuperfuerant Hector Boeth. Hi≈øt. Scotor. l. 6. f. 102. Georg. Buchan. Rer. Scot. l. 4. in Rege 33. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Scotland. in Crathlint and Fincomarke. ≈øiluis ac de≈øertis, abditi≈ø
que ≈øpelnncis ≈øe occult a ‚Ä¢ ere. Our Scottish Hi≈øtorians ≈øay, a greate number of our Brittish Chri≈øtians to auoide the crueltie of the Per≈øecutours, fledd to the Scots and Picts. Magnus piorum numerus per≈øequentium ≈øaeuitiam declinare cupiens, ad Scotos & Pictos conce≈øsit. They haue pre≈øerued the particular names of diuers of them, whome they recompt among the mo≈øt renowned learned men of that Age, ≈øuch were Amphibalus a Bishop, Modocus, Pri≈øcus, Calanus, Ferranus, Ambianus, and Carnocus, worshippers of God, called in the old Scottish languadge, Culdeis, which by their preaching taught the Religion of Chri≈øt with many labours throughout the Scots Countries. There were then very many more, but the≈øe the cheife≈øt of them who≈øe names came to po≈øteritie. Inter No≈øtrates eadem fuere tempe≈øtate, ≈øacra doctrina pollentes Ampbibalus Ami≈øtes, Modocus, Pri≈øcus, Calanus, Ferranus, Ambianus, & Caroncus Dei cultores, Culdei pri≈øca no≈øtra vulgari lingua dicti, Chri≈øti Seruatoris doctrinam, omnes per Scotorum Regiones concionando multis pij≈øque ≈øudoribus ≈øeminantes. Fuere tunc & alij permulti: ≈øed hij quorum nomina ad Po≈øteros delata praecipui. Many of the≈øe holy Brittish Chri≈øtians liued in poore Georg. Buchan. Rer. Scotic. l. 4. Reg. 35. Hollinsh of Scotl. in Fincomarke. Cels, profe≈ø≈øing the mo≈øt au≈øteere penitentiall cremiticall life, in ≈øo greate ≈øanctitie, that as the≈øe Scottish Antiquaries haue before deliuered, their very Cels were dedicated into Churches after they were dead, and with ≈øuch reuerence ob≈øerued with that Nation, our Prote≈øtants ≈øo confe≈ø≈øing and te≈øtifying, that from the time of tho≈øe holy Brittish Saints, which thus liued there, the old Scots called Churches by the name of Cels, Ex ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ que con≈ø ‚Ä¢ etudo man≈øit apud Po≈øteros, vt pri≈øci Scoti templa Cellas vocent.

2. Among the≈øe, our holy Bishop S‚ñ™ Amphibalus a man of ≈øingular pietie and excellent in diuine learning, Amphibalu ‚Ä¢ Brito vir ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øig ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ pietate, ≈øacra doctrina pollens, preached the word of Chri≈øt throughou ‚Ä¢ the Scots and Picts S. Amphibalus a BritaÃÑ and Martyr, a learned and holy Bishop in Mona Ile with the Scots. Countries, ≈øpeaking and writing much again≈øt the Pagans Religion,
„Äà‚óä„Äâ dogma per Scotorum Pictorumqae Regiones prop ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ do, m ‚Ä¢ l ‚Ä¢ a a contra Ge ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ um Religionem dicendo ≈øcribendoqu ‚Ä¢ . Crathlint then King of the Scots entertayned this holy Bishop, and his company with greate loue, and builded for them a ‚Ä¢ hurch in the Ile of Man, being the fir≈øt Cathedrall Church that was among the Scots, and he the fir≈øt Bishop they euer had, as their owne Hi≈øtorians acknowledge, being placed Bishop there in this time. That Church was dedicated to our Sauiour, Seruatori, Sotheri in Greeke, and therevpon by corruption in time called Sodoren≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
for Sotheren≈øis. This King adorned this Epi≈øcopall Church with mo≈øt ample guifts, Chalices, Patens, Candle≈øtycks, and others the like fitt for the Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, made all of Syluer and gold: with an Altare clo≈øed with Copper, and Bra≈ø≈øe, & appointed Reuenewes out of the places adioyning for the mayntenance thereof. Hos Crathlintus Rex, ad ≈øe confugientes beneuolo affectu ≈øu≈øcepit, & vt in Mona In≈øula con≈øiderent, ≈øacra ibidem aede ip≈øius opera Seruatoris nomine erecta, conce≈øsit. Amphibalus Brito vir in≈øigni pietate, primus Anti≈øtes ibi creatus, Chri≈øti dogma per Scotorum Pictorumque Regiones The holy Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe with ≈øacred ve≈ø≈øels, ornaments and rites then v≈øed in it. propalando, multa contra Gentilium Religionem dicendo, ≈øcribendoque glorio≈øum & Chri≈øtiano viro plan ‚Ä¢ dignum, multa ≈øenectute viuendo fe≈ø≈øus, faelicemque ≈øortitus e≈øt finem. Sed & Chrathlintus Rex, facram Anti≈øtitis aedem, muneribus ornauit ampli≈øsimis, calicibus, patenis, candelabris, alij≈øque ≈øimilibus, ad ≈øacrorum v≈øum commodis, ex argento auroque fabrefactis. Altarique cupro & aere ‚Ä¢ lau≈øo: prouentus ad ea ex agris in ≈øacre aedis vicinia con≈øtituit. Fuit id templum omnium primum Chri≈øtiano ritu, vbi Pontifex ≈øacerque Magi≈øtratus ≈øedem haberet primariam The great ‚Ä¢ zeale and deuotion of King Crathlint of the Scots towards Chri≈øtian ReligioÃÑ, and holy Brittish Prei≈øts, and others flying to the Scots in that time. inter Scotos, cuius no≈øtri meminere Scriptores, dedicatum. Nunc vocant Sodoren≈øe fanum, cuius nominis rationem ≈øicut aliorum complurium rerum & locorum vetu≈øtas ad po≈øteros obfu≈øc ‚Ä¢ it. By this we perceaue the greate zeale, and deuotion of that poore King Crathlint, how to his Power he releeued the per≈øecuted Seruants of Chri≈øt in that time, not fearing thereby to offend their mo≈øt potent Enemies, and Per≈øecutours Emperours one earth, ≈øo he might thereby plea≈øe the King of heauen, and ≈øuccour his afflicted friends. He placed them by probable opinion in one of the mo≈øt worthie and fruitfull Iles he had, at that The≈øe our Brittish Prei≈øts preached then throughout all places of the Scot ‚Ä¢ . time not being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, or at the lea≈øt much intere≈ø≈øed in this greate Iland, Mona then being the fitte≈øt Ile he had for a Bishops See: For which mo≈øt charitable foundation, it remayned afterward vnto Po≈øteritie an Epi≈øcopall Seate. And by this mini≈øtring of his temporall goods, he receaued much greater and ≈øpirituall. The≈øe holy Saints together with our holy Bishop S. Amphibalus preached and taught Chri≈øtian Catholike Religion throughout all tho≈øe Scottish Iles, per omnes Scotorum Regiones.

3. And the Religion which in particular they are remembred to haue The Religion they taught, the ≈øame which Catholiks now profe≈ø≈øe. Their admirable Sanctitie. taught, was the cha≈øte and ≈øingle life of the Clergie, Mona≈øticall and Eremiticall Conuer≈øation, Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe with Altars, Chalices, Patents, and all other nece≈ø≈øaries thereto belonging, honouring of Saints and dedicating Churches vnto them after their death, and vi≈øiting their places of dwelling in this life, with Pilgrimadges and prayers, Ver√® monasticam ≈øancti≈øsimamque exegerunt vitam. And for this manner of life and Religion they were e≈øteemed mo≈øt holy Saints with all men, as Prote≈øtants them≈øelues confe≈ø≈øe, ap ‚Ä¢ d Buchan. & Hollinsh. ≈øupr. omnes, & by a kinde of excellency called then, and with po≈øteritie Culdei, true
worshippers of God, and both their name and Order continued with honour after them, Man≈øitque nomen & institutum. Giraldus Cambren≈øis had te≈øtified Giral. Cambr. Itiner. Camb. l. 2. c. 6. Bal. in Giral. Cambr. cent. 2. l. de Script. before that their Order and name continued in his time in the yeare of Chri≈øt 1190. And the Antiquaries of Scotland, though no enemies of their owne glory, are ≈øparing in Hi≈øtories to make ≈øo honourable a memory of ≈øo many renowned men of their owne in any Age, as they haue done before of the≈øe Brittish Saints, S. Amphibalus, Modocus, Pri≈øcus, Calanus, Ferranus, Ambianus, Hector. Boeth. Hi≈øt. l. 6. ≈øup. and Carnocus Dei cultores, Culdei. And yet they add: fuere tunc & alij permulti: There were then very many ≈øuch holy and learned Britans preaching and conuer≈øing among the Scots and Picts. This is confirmed by diuers English Hi≈øtorians, euen Prote≈øtants, among whome one writeth in this manner: No ≈ømall number of the faithfull among≈øt the Britans fledd vnto the Scots, Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Scotland. in Crathlint and Fincomarke. and Picts to auoyde Per≈øecution. Whome Crathlint receaued for his part mo≈øt louingly. He erected a Temple in the Ile of Man, which he dedicated vnto Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, our Sauiour, wherein the Christians might celebrate their diuine ≈øeruice according to their profe≈øsion. This Church being ritchly endowed, was the fir≈øt Bishops See among≈øt the Scots, and thereupon was taken for the Mother Church of the Realme. Amphibalus a Britan borne, was fir≈øt Bishop of Saint Sauiours Church in Man: This Amphibalus did very much good among≈øt the Scots and Britans in ≈øetting forth the word of life. There were others al≈øo of right famous memory that cea≈øed not in preaching and in≈øtructing the people in the right beleife, as Modocus, Pri≈øcus, Calanus, Ferranus, Ambianus, and Carnocus called by an old auncient name in the Scottish tongue Culdei, that is to vnder≈øtand Cultores Dei, or as you would ≈øay in English, the worshippers of God. An other ≈øaith, that he fled in that Per≈øecution, and went to the Scots and Picts with a greate number of Godly men, and was there the fir≈øt Bishop in the Ile of man, and ≈øetling Chri≈øtian Religion there, returned afterward into this part of Britaine, and to Verolamium, Saeuiente mirum in modum Io. Bal. l. de Scrip. Britan. cent. 1. in Amphibalo. apud Britannos Per≈øecutione ad Scotos & Pictos cum magno piorum numero diuertebat, Apud quos ≈øub Rege Crathlinto, in Mona In≈øula primus Druidum loco Epi≈øcopus con≈øtitutus. Po≈øt multa illic Chri≈øtiano ritu in≈øtituta, in Britanniam reuer≈øus, Virulamij Martyrij compleuit cur≈øum. At this time tho≈øe Scottish Ilands which had not receaued the faith in the time of Pope Victor, or hauing then receaued, it by diuers Pagans comming vnto them, had ≈ølacked therein, were now conuerted, or confirmed by the≈øe holy Brittish Saints, and diuers of them, the Archbishop of Yorke being driuen from his See, were with their Prei≈øts and Pa≈øtours, vnder this their new Bishop, as other Ilands al≈øo of Britaine, namely the Ilands called Euboniae, Hebrides, or We≈øtern Ilands accompted to Will. Harri≈ø. de≈øcript. of Brit. c. 10. Hollinsh. de≈øcr. of Scotl. cap. 10. Hect. Boeth. in Nominib. Region. V. Hebrides. & de≈øcript. Scotiae, f. 4. Harri≈ø. de≈øcr. of Scotl. c. 10. Hect. Boeth. de≈øcrip. Scotiae f. 14. Ha ‚Ä¢ r. de≈øcrip. Brit. c. 10. Boeth. Hi≈øt. Scot. l. 10. be 43. in number, as a Prote≈øtant Antiquarie thus te≈øtifieth thereof: There hath ≈øome time bene, and yet is a Bishop of this Ile, who at the fir≈øt was called Epi≈øcopus Sodoren≈øis, when the Iuri≈ødiction of the Hebrides belonged vnto him; Whereas now he that is Bishop there, is but a Bishops shadowe. And this mo≈øt probable, allthough this man citeth no Authour, this Iland Mona or Man being e≈øteemed one of the cheife≈øt, neare≈øt to greate Britaine, and the auncient Seate of the principall Druids, which ruled tho≈øe Ilands in their Religion.

4. And the auncient and miraculous Altars and Churches of S. Peter and S. Clement in the Ile of Lewyes the greate≈øt of them, who≈øe fir≈øt foundations for their Antiquitie are not remembred in the Scottish Hi≈øtories, and diuers of them yet bearing the names of auncient Saints. So I may ≈øay of the Ile of May, renowned for holy men there inhabiting. So of Iona, honoured both
for the holy Saints there liuing, and Chri≈øtian Kings there buryed vpon that deuotion, Iona tum viris ≈øancti≈øsimis, tam Regum communi ≈øepultura in≈øignis. Fergu≈øius the ≈øecond King of the Scots of that name, was buryed there with Chri≈øtian Rites, Chri≈øtiano Ritu, about the yeare of Chri≈øt 430. & all their Kings long time after. He re≈øtored the bannished Monks, builded a Mona≈øtery there, and Cels, ≈øuch as the Culdeis v≈øed, endowing them, Structis patrio ritu Hector. Boeth. l. 7. f. 123. 126. Cellulis ad vitae nece≈ø≈øaria praedijs donauit. And to come to the Orchades Ilands, they were ≈øo full of Chri≈øtians, when S. Palladius was ≈øent into this Iland by S. Cele≈øtine Pope, that he ordayned and ≈øent thither for their Bishop S. Seruanus. Hect. Boeth. ≈øup. l. 7. f. 133. Bal. ceÃÑt. 1. in Palladio Boeth. de≈øcript. Scot. & in Nominib. Reg. Oppidorum &c. v. Orchades. Harri≈ø. de≈øcript. of of Britaine p. 42. So he ≈øent S. Teruanus to be Bishop, or Archbishop as ≈øome call him, to the Picts, Which were al≈øo ≈øeated in tho≈øe Ilands: as our Scots them≈øelues confe≈ø≈øe. The Bishops See was there at Kirkual in Pomonia the greate≈øt of tho≈øe Iles, Harum maxima Pomonia dicitur, in ea Kirkual Ciuitas vbi Epi≈øcopalis Sedes. So we may conclude of Holy Iland, Hoy or Hij, ≈øo f ‚Ä¢ mous for Religeous Monks of this old Brittish Order, by whome mo≈øt part of the Saxons were afterward conuerted, about the time S. Augu≈øtine was ≈øent hither. For we are a≈ø≈øured by Antiquities, both that this Iland then belonged to the Picts, and they were then conuerted by the≈øe our Brittish Culdeis, and gaue that The Succe≈ø≈øors of them which our Britans then conuerted, did afterward conuert mo≈øt of the SaxoÃÑs heare. Ile vnto them, from whence, and that their holy Order there, ≈øo many renowned Saincts did after proceede. E≈øt In≈øula quae vocatur Hij, quae ad ius Britanniae pertinet, non magno ab ea freto di≈øcreta, ≈øed donatione Pictorum qui illas Britanniae plagas incolunt, iam dudum Monachis Scotorum tradita, eo quod illis praedicantibus fidem Chri≈øti perceperunt. Which by that is ≈øaid before of the Picts B ‚Ä¢ d. Hi≈øt. Eccle ‚Ä¢ . Angl. l. 3. c. 3. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. & Capgr. in Vit. S. Aidani. William Harri≈øon de≈øcr. of Britaine c. 10. Conuer≈øion by the≈øe our Brittish Culdeis and Religeous Prei≈øts, preaching vnto them in this Per≈øecution, maketh it euident, that they conuerted that People, and tho≈øe Scottish Monks being of the ≈øame Order came from them, there liuing, preaching and dying, as is before remembred. For the Scots being al≈øo in≈øtructed then in the faith by the≈øe Monks, the fir≈øt of that profe≈ø≈øion and In≈øtitution there could haue no Monks of that Order, but from them. And S. Bede ≈øpeaking of S. O≈øwald his time, ≈øaith, this Ile was giuen by the Picts to the≈øe Monks, iam dudum, long before, and yet before that, dudum long Bed. ≈øupr. l. 3. c. 3. time that Iland receaued the faith by tho≈øe Monks: illis praedicantibus fidem Christi perceperunt.

div.head: THE XIX. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THE RETVRNE OF S. AMPHIBALVS FROM the Scots to the Britans; his comming to the hou≈øe of S. Alban at Verolamium, and preaching vnto him: the miraculous vi≈øion, and Conuer≈øion of S. Alban, their exceeding zeale and deuotion, and deliuery of S. Amphibalus at that time.

div.p: 1. SAmphibalus and our other holy Prei≈øts and Religeous men, hauing thus happily begun their preaching to the Scots and Picts, and obtayned happy ≈øucce≈ø≈øe therein, allthough this renowned Bishop was ≈øo well, ≈øafely, and honorably prouided for by that mo≈øt worthie King Crathlint, and S. Amphibalus his returne into Britaine from the Scots. knew by ≈øo certaine experience before, both the mi≈øeries which all Chri≈øtians in this our Britaine endured vnder the per≈øecuting Tyrant, and the extreame hatred, they bore vnto him aboue others, endeuouring by all meanes they could, to putt him to cruell death; yet neyther could the≈øe certaine dangers feare or hinder him, nor any honour, quiet, or ≈øecuritie per≈øwade and moue him ≈øo to continue, but as Mo≈øes, who≈øe life being ≈øought in Egipt, and his friends and Countrymen there per≈øecuted, would rather goe to be per≈øecuted with them, then liue in peace and honour with Iethro his Father in Lawe, ≈øaying he would returne thither: vadam & reuertar ad fratres Exod. c. 4. meos in Aegiptum; So S. Amphibalus, allthough God did not ≈øaye vnto him, as to Moy≈øes, that all they which ≈øought his life were dead: Mortui ≈øunt omnes qui quaerebant animam tuam: But he knew the contrary, they were all ≈øtill liuing, and ≈øtill raging in their madd fury‚ñ™ again≈øt him, and all the Seruants of Chri≈øt in this his Country and Egipt. He tooke the be≈øt Order he could, with that greate and high chardge, and honour he had among the Scots, in≈øtructing and directing his holy Prei≈øts, and brethren there, in their ≈øacred labours, & returned hither againe, to comfort the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Chri≈øtians, help to lift them vp againe which were fallen, and conuert the misbeleeuers, and him≈øelfe to ≈øuffer all afflictions, and death, how cruell ≈øoeuer in that mo≈øt glorious cau≈øe. Long and painfull was his Iorney from the Ile of Man, by Sea and Land, to many places which he vi≈øited in that his preaching, and Pilgrimadge, pa≈ø≈øing for the mo≈øt part by, and lodging in the Woods, De≈øerts, and Dens where the per≈øecuted Chri≈øtians then liued, & ≈øu≈øtayned with ≈øuch food, as they liued by, ≈øeldome, and then not without exceeding danger, otherwi≈øe fedd and harboured. For his comfort and company in this his preaching and profe≈ø≈øing of Chri≈øt crucified, and imitating our ble≈ø≈øed Sauiour in his trobles, & torments, he carryed ≈øtill with him a Crucifixe, Imadge of Chri≈øt crucified and fixed to his holy Cro≈ø≈øe, crucem Domini ≈øecum habebat.

2. Matthew the Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øaith, the Roman Hi≈øtories are ≈øilent
euen of the name of this glorious man, which the Brittish Antiquities notwith≈øtanding doe expre≈ø≈øely ≈øet downe: I≈øtius Clerici nomen, licet Romanae Matth We≈øtm. An. gratiae 303. taceant Hi≈øtoriae, in Hi≈øtoria Britonum tamen expre≈øs√® continetur. Which, were Title enough to claime him to be of this kingdome. But this Authour is deceaued herein; for allthough in the Roman Martyrologe there is no more memory of his name, and calling, but onely this, that he was Clericus, a Clergie man: yet Iacobus Bishop of Genua, and ≈øo to be termed of that Citie in Italy, a Roman Writer, and writing foure≈øcore yeares, or thereabouts, before Matthew our Monke, te≈øtifieth that his name was Amphibalus, a Britan of Iacob. Genuen. in Vita S. Amphibali. Harris Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. of Brit l. 3. c. 35. this kingdome, and ≈øonne to a Prince thereof, relating his Hi≈øtory, and life at lardge. But our Monke might without blame be ignorant of that Authour. And this forreyne Bishop addeth, that he went from hence to Rome with Ba≈ø≈øianus in the time of Seuerus, and was there knighted among≈øt that Noble A Mona≈øtory now at Caermerden, and S. Amphibalus a Monk ‚Ä¢ there, and probably Bishop there. company, mo≈øt of this Nation recompted in number 1540. of which S. Alban was al≈øo one; And that S. Amphibalus was there made Prei≈øt by the Pope of Rome, and ≈øent home into this his Country. Giraldus Cambren≈øis ≈øaith he was borne at Caerlegion, the renowned Citie and Schoole in Wales, Fuit Amphibalus hinc Caerlegion oriundus. So haue diuers others. The old Manu≈øcript Antiquitie of the Church of Winche≈øter ≈øaith, he was an holy Monke Girald. Cambr. Itiner. Camb. l. 1. c. 5. Dauid Powell Annot. ib. & in c. 4. de≈øcr. Cambriae. Annal Manu≈øcr. Eccl. Wintonien. and Doctour in the Church of Caermerdin in Wales, Amphibalus ≈øanctus Monachus & Doctor in Eccle≈øia Caermerdin, alias nominata Ciuitas Merlini, in Wallia. And this is the la≈øt certaine place of his Re≈øidency, which that Antiquitie giueth vnto him, before his Per≈øecution and going to the Scots, and ≈øo it ≈øeemeth not vnprobable, but he was al≈øo Bishop of that Citie Caermerdin, or without que≈øtion, of ≈øome other Citie heare. For otherwi≈øe, how he could be con≈øecrated Bishop among the Scots, by who≈øe Annals he is before accompted the fir≈øt Bishop they had re≈øident among them, is not ≈øo ea≈øie to be re≈øolued; except we should coniecture that he was con≈øecrated among the Scots by other Brittish Bishops, then flying vnto them, for which we doe not finde any warrant in Hi≈øtories, to vphold vs in that opinion. And there is a ≈øilence in all Martyrologes, and Authours of that time of any S. Amphibalus, but this our renowned Britan, and both the Scottish and our owne Hi≈øtorians haue proued vnto vs, that he was a Bishop, and of this our Britaine. How reuerend a man he was now for yeares, a≈øwell as for vertue and learning, we may know, if we reflect vpon that, which is ≈øaid before, that he was knighted with Ba≈ø≈øianus, and con≈øecrated Prei≈øt by Saint Zepherine Pope, who was Martyred in, or about the 218. yeare of Chri≈øt, by all accompts: ≈øo that allowing S. Amphibalus then the younge≈øt yeares wherein prei≈øthood may be giuen, and this his and others Per≈øecution heare in Britaine to haue bene in ≈øuch time, as I haue ≈øet downe before, we mu≈øt needs graunt S. Amphibalus now to haue bene allmo≈øt 100. yeares of Age, and much more, if we should with ≈øome deferre his Martyrdome to the begining of the fourth next following Age.

3. But this mo≈øt worthie Bishop thus in all re≈øpects ≈øo reuerend, and now loaden with the burden of many yeares, feeble in body, fainted not in his holy profe≈ø≈øion in preaching Chri≈øt, and being now come ≈øo long a Iorney, as betweene the Ile of Man, and Verulamium, where S. Albans now ≈øtandeth, and by all writers being pur≈øued by his per≈øecutours was driuen thither, being then a Municipall place, all profe≈ø≈øing Roman Pagani≈øme, and then there vpon named Caermunicip, and not without the greate mercy of God and
harbowred by his old acquaintance, and fellowe in Chiualrie Alban a man eminent in that Citie, and de≈øcended from Noble Romans: erat Albanus ciuis verolamius vir eminens in ciuitate, ex illu≈øtri Romanorum Pro≈øapia originem duceÃÑs: he boldly preached Chri≈øt vnto him, though a man in that eminency vnder the Roman Pagan per≈øecutors, that ≈øome, though not perhaps with greate≈øt warrant, haue termed him: high Steward of the Britans. And allthough this Engl. Martyrol. die 22. Iunij. Noble Alban did for old acquaintance, or Ho≈øpitalitie ≈øake courteou≈øly entertaine and releeue him, hic ≈øanctum Virum hospitio benign√® ≈øu≈øcipiens vitae nece≈ø≈øaria S. Amphibalus preacheth at Verolamium to be Alban. mini≈øtrauit: yet when S. Amphibalus began to ≈øpeake of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt the ≈øonne of God, and Incarnate for mans Redemption, he was ≈øo farre off from being a Chri≈øtian, that he had ≈øcarcely heard of Chri≈øt before, but ≈øaid this te≈øtimony of Chri≈øt was ≈øtrange vnto him; Quis e≈øt, inquit, i≈øte filius Dei? quid est quod Deus natus e≈ø≈øe a≈ø≈øeritur? noua ≈øunt haec & mihi hactenus inaudita. And S. Amphibalus more particularly declaring the my≈øteries of Chri≈øt his Natiuitie, Pa≈ø≈øion, Re≈øurrection and A≈øcen≈øion, Alban was yet ≈øo farre from beleeuing, that he told S. Amphibalus, he was madd, to preach ≈øuch things that vnder≈øtanding did not apprehend, nor rea≈øon allowe, and if the CitizeÃÑs of that place did know what he ≈øpeake concerning Chri≈øt, they would mo≈øt cruelly putt him to death, and feared much, that he would fall into troble before he could goe forth of his hou≈øe. Albanus ait quid e≈øt quod loqueris? In≈øanis, ne≈øcio quid dicis. A≈ø≈øertionem tuam non capit intellectus, ratio non admittit. Si no≈øcent viri huius ciuitatis te talia locutum fui≈ø≈øe de Chri≈øto ≈øine mora pe≈øsima morte te occiderent. Ego vero pro te omnino ≈øollicitus, ne quid tibi contingat aduer≈øi, priu≈øquam de domo mea rece≈ø≈øeris vehementer pertime≈øco. But what the preaching of Saint Amphibalus S. Alban his holy vi≈øion to per≈øuade him to be a Chri≈øtian. preuailed not in, his earne≈øt prayer and watching obtained of God for Alban For as the old Brittish Writer of his life, liuing in that time, relateth this Hi≈øtory, S. Amphibalus watching in prayers all the night following, a ≈øtrange and admirable vi≈øion appeared to Alban, with which he being exceedingly terrified, and perplexed, he pre≈øently aro≈øe, and went to S. Amphibalus thus declaring his vi≈øion, and de≈øiring the expo≈øition thereof in this order, and the≈øe words in English. O my Friend, if the things which thou preache≈øt of Chri≈øt, are true, I be≈øeech the be not afrayde to tell vnto me the true meaning of my dreame or vi≈øion. I did atteÃÑd, and behold a man came froÃÑ heaueÃÑ, whome a greate or vnnumerable multitude of men apprehended, and layed diuers kinds of TormeÃÑts vpon him. His haÃÑds were bouÃÑd with cordes; his body worne with whips, and greuiou≈øly torne. His body haÃÑged vpon a cro≈ø≈øe, & his hands ≈øtretched cro≈ø≈øe vpon it. The man which was thus tortured, was naked, and had no shoes vpoÃÑ his feete. His haÃÑds and feete were peirced with nailes, his ≈øide thru≈øt through with a speare, and as it ≈øeemed to me blood and water did flowe out of the wound of his ≈øide, they ≈øet reed on his right hand, and putt a crowne of thorne vpon his head. And hauing done all things which mans crueltie could worke again≈øt him, they began to mocke him with words, ≈øaying vnto him. Haile King of the Iewes, if thou art the ≈øonne of God now come downe from thy Cro≈ø≈øe, and we beleeue thee and when they v≈øed many reuilings again≈øt him, that younge man an≈øweared not one word vnto them. At the la≈øt when they had ≈øaid what they would again≈øt him, crying out with a greate voice, he ≈øaid. √¥ Father into they hands I commend my ≈øpirit, and hauing ≈øo ≈øaid, gaue vp the gho≈øt, his dead body was taken downe from the Cro≈ø≈øe the blood ≈øtill lardgely i≈ø≈øuing out of his wounds, they shutt it n a Tombe of stone, and couered it with a ≈øtone ≈øcaled, appointing watch men to keepe it. And a wonder to ≈øee, his body thus being dead came to life againe, and receauing ≈øtrenght, did goe forth of the Sepulchre, it ≈øtill remaining shutt. How he aro≈øe from death, I did behold with m ‚Ä¢
owne eyes, Men clothed with garments as whyte as ≈ønowe did come from heauen, and taking that man with them, returned from wheÃÑce they came, and an Infinite Army of men cloathed all in white doth followe him, which cea≈øed not in all that Iorney to ≈øing pray≈øes, and coÃÑtinually ble≈ø≈øed a Father, I know not whome, and his ≈øonne, ≈øaying: ble≈ø≈øed be God the Father, & his onely begotteÃÑ ≈øonne. Greate Ioy and vn≈øpeakeable gladnes was among them, ≈øo that none might worthely be compared vnto it. The≈øe and many other things, which I neyther will, nor is lawfull for any mortall man to tell, haue bene shewed to mee in vi≈øion this night, what they doe ≈øignify, I be≈øeech thee not to conceale from mee, be not afrayde. S. Amphibalus hearing the≈øe things, perceauing that his heart was vi≈øited by God, exceedingly reioyced in our Lord, and forthwith pulling out a Cro≈ø≈øe of our Lord, which he had about him, he ≈øaith, behold in this ≈øigne thow maye≈øt manife≈øtly ≈øee what thy vi≈øion this night meaneth, what it ≈øignifieth. For this man comming from heauen is my Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, who did not refu≈øe to vndergoe the punishment of the Cro≈ø≈øe, that he might deliuer vs by his blood from the guilt, wherewith we were held bound by the preuarication of our fir≈øt parent Adam. And ≈øo pro≈øecuting the manner of Chri≈øts Incarnation, life, and pa≈ø≈øion for mans Redemption, and the my≈øtery of the holy Trinitie, which I need not particularly to relate, writing for Chri≈øtian Readers, to ≈øpeake in this old Brittish Authours words againe, Alban greately meruayling vpon the speach of Amphibalus brake out into the≈øe words. The things which thow relate≈øt of Chri≈øt are true, and cannot in any respect he reproued as fal≈øe, for I this night haue euidently knowne, how Chri≈øt ouercame the deuill, bounde him, and thru≈øt him downe to the botome of Hell: I haue ≈øeene with my eyes, how that Horrible one lyeth bewrapped in the knots of chaines, hereby knowing that all things thow hast ≈øpoken are true. I beleeue, an ‚Ä¢ from this time, this is my faith, that there is no God but my Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt who for the ≈øaluation of men, vouh≈øafing to take humanitie vpon him ≈øu≈øtained the Pa≈øsion of the Cro≈ø≈øe. He with the Father and the holy Gho≈øt is one God, and there is no other. And hauing thus ≈øaid, he falleth downe po≈øtrate before the Cro≈ø≈øe, and as if he had ≈øeene our Lord Ie≈øus hanging vpon the Cro≈ø≈øe, the ble≈ø≈øed penitent craueth pardon for his ≈øins. So reuerently he v≈øeth with continuall ki≈øsing of them the feete and places of places of the wounds, as though he had bene layde at the feete of our Redeemer him≈øelfe, whome he had in his vi≈øion ≈øeene to be crucified. Teares mingled with blood, run rownde about his face, and in greate quantitie fall downe vpon the venerable wood of the Cro≈ø≈øe. I, ≈øaith he, renownce the deuill, and dete≈øt all the Enemyes of Chri≈øt, S. Alban his Conuer≈øion, and greate d ‚Ä¢ uotion. beleeuing in him, and commending my≈øelfe to him, who, as thou affirme≈øt, aro≈øe the third day from death. Amphibalus ≈øaith vnto him, be of courage, our Lod is with thee, and his grace will neuer be wanting vnto thee. That faith which other mortall men haue de≈øerued to receaue by the tradition of man, thow ha≈øt not learned it eyther of man, or by man, but by the Reuelation of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. Therefore being now ≈øecure of thee, I determine to goe further to preach vnto the GeÃÑtiles, but Alban entreating him to stay at the lea≈øt one weeke longer, that he might in that time be more perfectly in≈øtructed in the faith of Chri≈øt, he did ≈øo.

4. Thus writeth this old Brittish Authour of S. Alban his Conuer≈øion, which both S. Gildas, S. Bede and others doe in effect, and ≈øub≈øtance al≈øo deliuer, allthough not in ≈øo ample manner. During the time of their abode together Gildas l. de excid. Brit. cap. 8. Bed. Martyr. die 22. Iunij. in S. Albano. Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. Eccl. c. 7. Matth. We≈øtm. an 303. afterward, they ≈øpent the time as S. Amphibalus, by S. Beds relation did before S. Alban his Conuer≈øion in continuall Watchings and Prayers day and night: orationibus continuis ac vigilij ‚Ä¢ diu noctuque, a greate motiue to S. Alban to receaue the faith of Chri≈øt: For euery day towards euening, they withdrew them≈øelues from the Citie, and company of men going to an hou≈øe
which S. Alban had, without the Citie, where they ≈øpent the whole night in ≈øeruing God, Singulis diebus cum iam in ve≈øperam hora declinaret, Magi≈øter & Di≈øcipulus hominum frequentiam deuitantes, ad domum remotiorem, quae tugurium vulgo ≈øolet appellari, ≈øeproripiunt, noctem totam ibidem in Dei laudibus tran≈øigentes. Et haec faciebant, ne ≈øecretum ≈øuum palam fieret Infidelibus, qui cultores Chri≈øtianae Religionis non in fide ≈øequi, ≈øed per≈øequi fideles contendebant. And allthough they ob≈øerued this cautelous diligence, to keepe them≈øelues ≈øecret from the Per≈øecutours, yet it was by a wicked Pagan there reuealed, and told to the per≈øecuting Iudge and Ruler there, which comming to the knowledge of S. AlbaÃÑ, before the Pagan Prince and Per≈øecutour could execute his de≈øignement, as at his fir≈øt receauing of S. Amphibalus, when he was yet a Pagan, as our mo≈øt auncient Hi≈øtories ≈øay, he hidd him in his hou≈øe being pur≈øued by Gild. l. de excid. c. 8. Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. c. 7. Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 5. cap. 5. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 303. his Per≈øecutours, and pre≈øently had not S. Alban ≈øo preuented it, to be apprehended, ≈øo now being a Chri≈øtian expo≈øed him≈øelfe vnto danger of death for him, imitating Chri≈øt, that gaue his owne life for his sheepe, Albanus charitatis gratia feruens, Confe≈ø≈øorem ≈øuum Amphibalum √† Per≈øecutoribus in≈øectatum, & iam iamque comprehendendum primum in domo ≈øua occuluit, & deinde ≈øe di≈øcrimini mortis obtulit, imitans in hoc Christum animam ≈øuam pro ouibus ponentem. For when the≈øe Enemies of Chri≈øt had ray≈øed their Troopes, euen an army magna manu, as our Antiquities terme them to apprehend S. Amphibalus, S. Scriptor. Vitae S. Albani. Manu≈øc. Antiq. & Capgr. in vita eius. Alban in the night before conducteth him forth of his hou≈øe, and pa≈øt danger, and shifting garments with him, to ≈øaue him from all perill, cau≈øed S. Amphibalus to were his garment of dignitie, and priuiledge, in that time free from all trouble and mole≈øtation, dans ei clamidem auro textam quo tutior ab ho≈øtibus redderetur, vestis enim huiu≈ømodi tantae tanc temporis apud omnes dignitatis, tantaeque reuerentiae fuit, vt illa indutus, ho≈øtium cuneos penetraret illae≈øus. And the garment of S. Amphibalus wherein the danger was, (being a Caracalla, a Prei≈øts ve≈øture, as they ≈øay,) hauing bene di≈øcried, he put it vpon him≈øelfe, together with the danger, and ≈øo returned to his owne hou≈øe alone, hauing thus freed his holy Ma≈øter and Tutor in Chri≈øt from that perill.

div.head: THE XX. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE HOLY AND MOST CONSTANT faith, deuotion, charitie, ≈øufferings, miracles and Martyrdome of S. Alban.

div.p:
1. S. Amphibalus being thus at this time deliuered, by S. Alban the King, Prince, or Iudge (for S. Bede, Matthew Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. c. 7. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 303. Iacob. Genuen. in Vit. S. Albani & S. Alphib. Capgr. in S. Albano of We≈øtmin≈øter, and others giue all tho≈øe Titles, to that per≈øecuting Magi≈øtrate) ≈øent his Souldiars to conuent the≈øe two holy Saints; the old Brittish Writer of S. Albans life ≈øaith, there were hor≈øemen with an Army, greate multitude or Power of footemen, which were thus ≈øent about this bu≈øines, Equites cum magna manu peditum √† Iudice mi≈øsi. The rage of the per≈øecuting Iudge and PagaÃÑs again≈øt S. Alban. And S. Alban being ≈øo renowned a man in this kingdome then, and S. Amphibalus ≈øo famous a Prelate, as before appeareth, and ≈øo knowne to the Per≈øecutours, that they pur≈øued him, to the furthe≈øt parts of the Roman Iuri≈ødiction, in the parts now called Wales, and from thence forcibly brought him by Authority to Verolamium againe, there to be Iudged and Martyred, Manu≈øcr. Antiq. in Vita S. Amphibali. Capgr. in eodem. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 303. & alij. which none but the highe≈øt Roman Power heare could doe, make it an opinion ≈øufficiently warrantable, both that ≈øuch forces were leuied for this exploite, and the prime Magi≈øtrate him≈øelfe ≈øupplyed the place of Iudge & Sentencer in this cau≈øe of ≈øo Noble par≈øonadges; the one ≈øpirituall, the other temporall, the greate≈øt that are remembred in our Hi≈øtories to haue ≈øuffered Martyrdome in Britaine in that raging Per≈øecution. The troopes of Souldiers nephandi Principis, of the wicked Prince, cateruatim irruentes, rushing into the hou≈øe of S. Alban by troopes, like madd men efferatis animis, and ≈øearching euery place, and corner, at the la≈øt founde him in his Country hou≈øe, where he v≈øed to watch and pray with S. Amphibalus, Ip≈øum tandem in tugurio reperiunt, The greate deuotion of S. Alban, and his reuerence to the Crucifixe. nudis pedibus ante crucem Domini quam ≈øibi Magister ≈øuus reliquerat precibus incumbentem, bare footed praying before the Cro≈ø≈øe of our Lord, which his Ma≈øter had left with him, wearing his Caracalla or coate vpon him, and ≈øo repre≈øenting S. Amphibalus, who before was conueyed from them by Saint Alban, which they vnder≈øtanding manus ei iniecerunt, rapitur, trahitur, diri≈øque nexibus cathenarum con≈øtrictus, ab alijs ve≈øtibus, ab alijs Bed. lib. 1. cap. 7. Matth. We≈øtm. An. 303. Script. Antiq. Vitae S. Albani. Capgr. in eod. trahitur & capillis: They lay violent hands vpon S. Alban, fetter him with locks, and Chaines, ≈øome of them hayling him by his Coates, others by the haire of his head. And being thus contumeliou≈øly v≈øed, he continually carryed in his hands the Cro≈ø≈øe, which S. Amphibalus gaue him, openly to pronounce and profe≈ø≈øe him≈øelfe a Chri≈øtian. Vt ≈øe ≈øeruum crucis palam cunctis o≈øtenderet, ≈øignum dominicum iugiter in manibus praeferebat. And being thus de≈øpitefully brought before the Iudge, who laboured by all meanes he could, to per≈øuade and induce S. Alban to for≈øake his Chri≈øtian Religion, and Sacrifice to their Pagan Gods. But this was all in vaine, for to ≈øpeake in the old Brittish Authour his words: S. Alban an≈øweared the iudge that his words were vaine and ≈øuperfluous, he did not
repent him for receauing the faith of Chri≈øt, for the miracles wrought in it in re≈øtoring the weake and ≈øick to health, doe teach it by their te≈øtimonie, to be the way of Saluation. He would not Sacrifice to their Gods, and being ≈øupported by the help of God The torturs and longe Impri≈øonmeÃÑt S. Alban ≈øuffered, and the miraculous punishment vpon his per≈øecutors. feared not their threats nor torments. Vpon which words the company gathering together whipped him greuiou≈øly. Who being thus beaten, ≈øaied with a chearefull countenance. O Lord Ie≈øus Chti≈øt, I be≈øeech thee keepe my minde ftom wauering from that ≈øtate which thow ha≈øt giuen mee. O Lord I de≈øire to offer my life an Holocau≈øt, and with effu≈øion of my blood to be thy witne≈ø≈øe. And when the Tormentours hands were weary, the holy maÃÑ was thru≈øt into the bottome of pri≈øon, and there kept ≈øixe moneths, whereupon the Elements them≈øelues did testifie the Iniury done to the Martyr. For from the time of his apprehen≈øion vnto his death, neyther rayne nor dew did f ‚Ä¢ ll vpon the earth, the windes did not blowe. But euery day continuall, the Land was parched vp with most feruent heate of the ≈øunne, and in the nights al≈øo was exceeding and vntollerable heate. Neyther feilds nor trees bore any fruite, the whole world did fight for the iu≈øte one again≈øt the wicked. The Citizens not able to endure this affliction, ≈øaid it was Chri≈øt whome Alban doth worship worketh this, that no gra≈ø≈øe nor corne doth growe vnto vs, and taking pity vpon the Iniuries done to the holy man, by the Iudgment of them all, he is deliuered from his bonds of chaynes. For which S. Alban was very ≈øory, and greately fearing lea≈øt his Martyrdome might thereby be hindred, looking vp towards heauen with groaning, ≈øaid. O Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt ≈øuffer not the malice of the deuill ≈øo much to preuaile, that by his crafty deui≈øes, and a≈ø≈øent of this people, he may hinder my pa≈øsion. And turning him≈øelfe to the people, ≈øaid vnto them: Why doe you ≈øtay? If you know not to giue ≈øentence take Coun≈øaile of your Lawes; examine the ≈øtatuts of your Citie, they will in≈øinuate vnto you, what you ought to doe. Why doe you make delay? Be it knowne to you all, that I am a greate Enemy of your Gods. For how can they be worthie any honour, which are knowne to haue no diuine thing in them, being the Works of mens hands? You your≈øelues are their witne≈ø≈øes, that they ≈øee nothing heare nothing, vnder≈øtand nothing. O greately to be dete≈øted vanity, to hope for life of them, that neuer liued, to pray vnto them, wbich neuer heard, to ≈øeeke health of things, that neuer were well them≈øelues. Wherevpon I ab≈øolutely pronounce, that he which worshippeth ≈øuch is mo≈øt madde. I demande of you, what can be more vnhappy, then that man, ouer whome his owne workes haue dominion? Therefore woe vnto Idols, and woe to the Worshippers of Idols. When they heard the≈øe things, with a generall con≈øent they giue ≈øentence of death against the holy man, and bring him to a place called Holinhirst. Thus farre this old Brittish Writer, Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, Capgraue and others con≈øenting.

2. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter expre≈ø≈øely further addeth, which others doe Matth. We≈øtm. an. 303. in S. Albano. al≈øo ≈øufficiently te≈øtify, that as before his Iudgment, ≈øo now after it, S. Alban often ki≈ø≈øing the Cro≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt which he held in his hand, and worshipping it, he commended his cau≈øe to God. Ip≈øe Crucem Domini, quam manu tenebat, ReuereÃÑce to Cro≈ø≈øes and holy Images. frequenter deo≈øculans, & adorans, cau≈øam ≈øuam Domino commendabat. And continually kept, and reuerenced this Crucifixe vntill his head was ≈øtriken of, when all to be ≈øprinkled with his holy blood, it fell vpon the gra≈ø≈øe, and was ≈øecretly taken vp, and pre≈øerued by a Chri≈øtian there pre≈øent. Crux quam vir ≈øanctus iugiter in manibus ferre con≈øueuerat, faelici iam cruore re≈øper≈øa, ≈øuper herbam decidit, eamque quidam Chri≈øtianus occult√® rapuit, & ignorantibus Paganis ab≈øcondit. This Authour, as he addeth this which the old Britan Writer wanteth, ≈øo he wanteth ≈øome thing before related from him. For whereas the Brittish Antiquarie ≈øaid, that the Citizens of Verolamium vpon ≈øtrange punishments,
wherewith God afflicted them, in the time of the Impri≈øonment of S. Alban, did ≈øet him free, and at libertie, the Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter, as S. Bede likewi≈øe, omitteth this, as al≈øo the mo≈øt con≈øtant profe≈ø≈øion of his faith, which S. Alban then made before them, which they had ≈øet downe before, and now remembred onely how they gaue the ≈øentence of death again≈øt him. Iudex autem & ciues Verolani, plagam huiu≈ømodi non ferentes, Albano crimen imponunt, congregati≈øque in vnum omnibus, ip≈øum ≈øibi prae≈øentari fecerunt. Et dum ≈øtaret in medio multitudinis, omnes vnanimi con≈øen≈øu in Sanctum Dei mortis tulere ≈øententiam. But it is euident by the circum≈øtances of the Hi≈øtory, that they all agree, and the short libertie which they gaue to S. Alban, was onely to ≈øee whether he would in hope of continuance thereof, deny his Religion, or not ≈øpeake again≈øt their Idolatry, which when he ≈øo re≈øolutely as before refu≈øed to doe, they gaue ≈øentence of death again≈øt him.

3. Now therefore to returne to the Brittish Authour, where I left him, Script. Brit. ≈øupr. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. Vitae S. Albani. Beda. lib. 1. cap. 7. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 303. Capgr. in S. Albano Henr. Hunting. l. 1. Hi≈øt. in Diocletian. thus he with others proceedeth in the narration of the Martyrdome of this holy Saint; So greate a company of people re≈øorted to the place of his Martyrdome, that although it was lardge in it≈øelfe, yet in re≈øpect of the greate multitude comming thither at that time, it ≈øeemeth ≈øtreight and litle; and yet the heate of the ≈øunne was ≈øo ardent, that the grounde burned vnder their feete, in their pa≈ø≈øadge to the place there was a mo≈øt ≈øwift Riuer, to pa≈ø≈øe ouer and the multitude ≈øo greate, that they could ≈øcarce before night pa≈ø≈øe ouer, and thronging one an other many fell into the water, and were drowned. Which when S. Alban perceaued, falling downe vpon his knees, thus prayed for their deliuery. O Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, from who≈øe mo≈øt holy ≈øide I haue ≈øeene blood, and water to flowe, grant I be≈øeech thee, that the waters decrea≈øe, and the Ryuer may goe away, that all this people may ≈øafe, and ≈øounde be pre≈øent at my pa≈øsion. A wonderfull thing to behold, while S. Alban thus kneeled, and prayed, the streame was dryed vp, and the teares of Saint Alban left no water in the channell. The Power of his prayer con≈øumed the Ryuer, and made away for the people betweene the waters. And they whome the violence of the Ryuer had taken away, inclo≈øed and de≈øtroyed, were founde in the bottome of the Ryuer without any hurt, hauing no ≈øigne of death in them. The ≈øouldiar which dr ‚Ä¢ w S. Alban to the≈øe torments, ≈øeeing this ≈øtrange miracle, was as ≈øtrangely thereby conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, threw away his ≈øword, and pro≈øtrating him≈øelfe at the feete of the Saint, craued pardon. But the other Pagans drawe S. Alban vp and downe among the bryars, and rough places, ≈øo that the thornes and rootes of trees doe pull peeces of flesh from his feete. And yet this mo≈øt mercifull and miraculous Saint ≈øeeing the people to be afflicted with thir≈øt in the mouÃÑ taine, thus prayed for their releife: O God who did≈øt create man of the ≈ølime of the earth. I be≈øeech thee, ≈øuffer no creature to ≈øu≈øtayne any hurt for my cau≈øe. And pre≈øently a well of water sprung vp before his feete, by which they were refreshed.
4. The Executioner cutt of S. Albanus head, but his eyes fall out of his Hiericus Gallus in Vita S. Germ. owne head therewith: many ≈øo witne≈ø≈øing. Among whome Hiericus Gallus in S. Germans life:

lg.l: Millia paenarum Chri≈øti pro nomine pa≈ø≈øus.
Quem tandem rapuit capitis ≈øententia cae≈øi:
Sed non lictori ce≈øsit res tuta ≈øuperbo:
Vtque caput Sancto, reciderunt Lumina ≈øaeuo.

div.p:
So hath the Brittish Writer of S. Alban his life, then liuing a Pagan, as him≈øelfe Anonym. Britan. Script. Vitae S. Albani. confe≈ø≈øeth, and as may be gathered by his owne narration, pre≈øent at his Martyrdome. For thus he writeth of him≈øelfe in the ≈øame place, Leaste they
which shall come after, may be doubtfull of my name, they shall call me a wretche, and the greate≈øt ≈øinner. And I goe to Rome, that ca≈øting of the error of Pagani≈øme, I may be baptized, and de≈øerue to obtaine pardon of my ≈øins. And this my short Treati≈øe I will offer to the Examination of the Romans. That if any thing hath bene vttered in it, otherwi≈øe then it ought, our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt who lyueth, and reigneth God world without end, may vouch≈øafe by them to amend it. Where we ≈øee the greate honour and reuerence which the Chri≈øtians, and Cri≈øtianly minded men of that Age, euen heare in Britaine, did acknowledge as due to that holy See, that they referred the Examen, and Cen≈øure of their writings, euen of Hi≈øtoricall and practicall things, acted ≈øo farre from thence, to the Iugdment thereof. And thought it their ≈øafe≈øt way, though with ≈øo greate trauaile thither, and danger there, the Popes and Chri≈øtian Romans then aboue all others per≈øecuted, to receaue bapti≈øme, and direction for their ≈øaluation there.

5. But to finish the funerall honour of this our glorious Martyr: allthough we doe not finde any man then, which for feare of the per≈øecutours pre≈øented him≈øelfe to bury his holy body, but the valiant Souldiar, now the Souldiar of Chri≈øt conuerted vnto him, which had boldly before them all reuerenced the Reliks of S. Alban, who there digged a graue, and layed the Martyrs body therein: terram apperiens, humo Corpus Albani operit, & tumulum de≈øuper ip≈øe Matth. We≈øtm. An. 303. compo≈øuit, which was all he could doe then: yet God allmightie in who≈øe ≈øight the death of his Saints is pretious, as he had now glorified his Martyrs ≈øoule in heauen, ≈øo yeelded from thence extraordinary honour to his body ≈øo meanely buryed, making his poore graue more glorious then the ≈øumpteous Tombe of Author Brit. Vitae S. Albani. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. in Vit. eius Capgr. in eodem Matth. We≈øtm. ≈øup. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. in Vit. S. Amphibali & Capg. in eod. any Roman Emperour, his per≈øecutour, or other, for in the next night now following, a Piller of Light was ≈øeene of all the Pagans them≈øelues, to ≈øtretch vp from the graue of the holy Martyr vnto heauen, by which Angels di≈øcending & a≈øcending ≈øpent all the night in prai≈øing God, and among other things which they did ≈øinge, the≈øe words were often repeated and heard. The renowned Man Alban a glorious Martyr: nocte in≈øecuta vi≈øa e≈øt columia lucis √® tumulo beati Martyris caelos penetrare, per quam de≈øcendentes Angeli, & a≈øcendentes, totam noctem in Dei laudibus deducebant. Inter caetera vero quae canebant, vox i≈øta frequentius e≈øt audita, Albanus vir egregius Martyr extat glorio≈øus. Ad hoc ≈øpectaculum Honour of Saints. ≈øubito fieret concur≈øus. And a thow≈øand PagaÃÑs, ad mille homines, were thereby conuerted to Chri≈øt. S. Bede witne≈ø≈øeth, that from the Martyrdome of S. Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. c. 7. Alban vnto his time, cures and ofte Miracles were wrought, in the place of his Martyrdome. In quo loco v≈øque ad hanc diem curatio infirmorum, & frequentium Henric. Huntin. l. 1. Hi≈øt. operatio virtutum celebrari non de≈øinit. So hath Henry of Huntington long after him for his dayes al≈øo.

6. The Cro≈ø≈øe which he had in his hand, when he ≈øuffered Martyrdome, Matth. We≈øtm. an. 303. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. in V ‚Ä¢ ta S. Amphibali. Capgr. in eod. Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. c. 18 Thomas Wal≈øingh. Hi≈øt. Angl. in Eduard. 2. R ‚Ä¢ uerence of holy Reliks. and was thereby ≈øprinkled with his holy blood, was reuerently pre≈øerued by the Chri≈øtians then, and pre≈øented to S. Amphibalus with greate honour. The very ground where S. Alban ≈øuffered, retained drops of his blood when S. German was ≈øent hither by Pope Cele≈øtine, and he carryed part thereof away for a greate Relike. De ip≈øo loco, vbi beati Martyris effu≈øus erat ≈øanguis, ma≈ø≈øam pulueris ≈øecum portaturus ab≈øtulit: in qua apparebat cruore ≈øeruato, rubui≈ø≈øe Martyrum caedem. His Coate, Caracalla, which he had of S. Amphibalus, and wherein he ≈øuffered Martyrdome, was kept for a greate Relicke, and in the time of King Edward the ≈øecond (the King him≈øelfe with many Nobles pre≈øent witne≈ø≈øes) was ≈øo freshly be≈øpotted with this Martyrs blood, as if it had bene done Thom. Wal≈øing. ≈øupr. but the day before. So Miracou≈øly pre≈øerued, as the blood in the place of his
Pa≈ø≈øion. Fas e≈øt credere quod ad honorem Sancti, diuino Miraculo ≈øanguis eius, ≈øic in hac ve≈øte ≈øeruatus, ≈øicut in puluere ≈øui ≈øepulchri per multa ≈øecula legitur con≈øeruatus. Cuius pulueris ma≈ø≈øam, in qua rubebat adhuc ≈øanguis Martyris, Sanctus Germanus Alti≈øsiodoren≈øis Epi≈øcopus ≈øecum ab≈øtulit, & detulit ad natale ≈øecum, capellam con≈øtruens in honorem Martyris memorati. But of Churches and Chappels founded vnto his honour, with Pilgrimadges vnto, and reuerencing, his holy Relicks, I shall ≈øpeake hereafter, when I come to the cea≈øing of this Per≈øecution, and to ≈øpeake of our other Martyrs.

div.head: THE XXI. CHAPER.

argument.p: THE CONSTANT PROFESSION OF CHRIST, by the holy Souldiar Heraclius, conuerted by the Miracles of S. Alban, and his Martyrdome, in, and at the ≈øame time and place, with S. Alban.

div.p:
1. GREATE is the honour which both our owne, both Brittish and English, and forreine Hi≈øtorians al≈øo yeeld to the Souldiar vntill then a Pagan, and being one that ledd Saint Alban to his Martyrdome and conuerted by his Miracles in the way, was then and there al≈øo mo≈øt cruelly Martyred: The old Roman Martyrologe thus remembreth him: one of the Souldiars which ledd S. Alban Martyrol. Rom. die 22. Iunij. to his punishment being conuerted to Chri≈øt in the way, ≈øuffered with him, de≈øerued to be baptized in his owne blood, Pa≈ø≈øus e≈øt etiam cum illo vnus de militibus, qui eum ducebat ad ≈øupplicium, qui in via conuer≈øus ad Chri≈øtum, proprio ≈øanguine meruit baptizari. S. Gildas ≈øaith this Martyr being conuerted by the Miracle S. Alban shewed when by his prayers the deepe Ryuer gaue place to him, and a thow≈øand with him to pa≈ø≈øe ouer, not wetting their feete, the waters on both ≈øides ≈øtanding like walles, as they did to the people of I≈øra√´l to giue them pa≈ø≈øadge, was of a wolfe made a lambe, and did both vehemently Gild. l. de excid. c. 8. de≈øire, and valiantly endure Martyrdome with him, Iterignotum trans Tame≈øis nobilis fluuij alueum cum mille viris ≈øicco imgrediens pede, ≈øu≈øpen≈øis vtrimque modo praeruptorum fluuialibus montium gurgitibus aperiret, & priorem carnificem tanta prodigia videntem in agnum ex lupo mutaret, & vna ≈øecum triumphalem Martyrij palmam ≈øitire vehementius, & excipere fortius faceret. S. Bede relateth, this Hi≈øtory in like manner, yet with more Empha≈øis of his glory, for hauing ≈øpoken of the ≈øame ≈øtrange Miracle, by which this Souldiar was conuerted calling him Carnifex, the de≈øigned Executioner to put S. Alban to death, as S. Gildas and others doe, to shew how wonderfully the grace of Chri≈øt wrought in him, he addeth, that by diuine In≈øpiration he made all ≈øpeede he could to come to S. Alban, and ca≈øting away his ≈øword that was drawne to behead S. Alban, Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. c. 7. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 303. pro≈øtrated him ≈øee before his feete, the whole a≈ø≈øembly beholding it, greately de≈øiring that he him≈øelfe might be worthie to be put to death with the Martyr, or in place of the Martyr, which he was commanded to ≈øtrike, Quod cum inter alios ip≈øe carnifex, qui eum percu≈ø≈øurus erat, vidi≈ø≈øet, festinauit ei, vbi ad locum de≈øtinatum morti venerat occurrere: diuino nimirum admonitus in≈øtinctu, proiectoque en≈øe, quem ≈øtrictum tenucrat, pedibus eius aduo luitur, multum de≈øiderans, vt cum
Martyre, vel pro Martyre, quem percutere iubebatur, ip≈øe potius mereretur percuti. And ≈øo of a per≈øecutour he became a companion in Truth, and Faith, Ex per≈øecutore factus collega viritatis & fidei. Thus writeth Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, and others, allthough with ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing the name of this holy Martyr, which the old Brittish Writer of S. Alban his life, Capgraue and others call Heraclius, and I am now to name him by it: for allthough it was not giuen him in Bapti≈øme, Brit. Script. Vitae S. Albani. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. & Capgr. in eodem. in water, which he wanted, yet his ≈øure≈øt Bapti≈øme in his owne blood for Chri≈øt his holy and mo≈øt courageou≈øly and con≈øtantly ≈øu≈øtained Martyrdome happily made him renowned and honorable thereby.

2. This S. Heraclius hauing re≈øolutely denyed his Pagani≈øme, craued pardon for his error, and confe≈ø≈øed Chri≈øt openly before ≈øo many per≈øecutours, and in the highe≈øt of their Malice, and rage again≈øt S. Alban, fell thereby into the ≈øame degree of Hatred with them: for pre≈øently therevpon, to ≈øpeake in our old Authours words; Inimici veritatis hominem arripiunt, dentes excutiunt & os eius ≈øacrum dilacerant, & omnia eius o≈ø≈øa confringunt, & ≈øi nihil in corpore reman≈øit illae≈øum, fides tamen quae feruebat in pectore, laedi non potuit: The enemyes of truth apprehend him, beate out his teeth, rend his holy mouthe, and breake all his boues, and allthough nothing remayned in his body without hurt, yet his feruent faith remayned without harme. And being thus left ≈øo maymed, lame, and half dead, with all the power and ≈øtrength he could with his hands crept vp to the hill, where S. Alban was Martyred, whome when the Iudge e≈øpyed, he ≈øaid vnto him, ob≈øecra Albanum tuum, pray to they Alban to ≈øett thy bones in order, and lay his head, heare ≈øtricken off, to thy body, and thou shall receaue perfect health from him. Bury him, and lett him cure thee. Heraclius an≈øweared I mo≈øt firmely beleeue, that S. Alban by his merits is able to heale mee, and ea≈øely performe that you mock vs with. Tunc caput Martyris reuerenter a≈ø≈øumens, illudque corpori deuotus apponens, desperatum corporis robur recuperare caepit, ≈øanus effectus. Then reuerently taking the head of S. Alban, and deuoutely laying it to his body, he began to recouer the former ≈øtrenght of the ≈øame despayred before. And being thus miraculou≈ølie recouered and made hole, cea≈øed not in the hearing of all the people to preach vnto them the meritt of S. Alban, and Power of Chri≈øt and digging the earth, buryed the body of S. Alban before them there. Which the Pagans ≈øeeing, ≈øaid among them≈øelues, what shall we doe? This man cannot be putt to death with ≈øword, we haue allready broken his body, and he hath now receaued his former ≈øtrength againe. And apprehending him, with horrible Torment, they teare his holy body in peeces, and la≈øtely cutt of his head. And ≈øo this happy ≈øouldiar per≈øeuering in the faith of Chri≈øt, together with mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Alban de≈øerued to be honoured with the Crowne of Martyrdome.

3. Hitherto the Relation of tho≈øe our renowned auncient Hi≈øtorians; whereby we doe not onely finde an example of Heroicall Chri≈øtian fortitude in generall, but learne euen in particular, the holy and approued doctrine and cu≈øtome of the Primatiue Chri≈øtians of this kingdome, a≈øwell as of others, to praye vnto holy Saints glorified in their Soules in heauen, and reuerencing their ≈øacred Relicks, on earth, thus miraculou≈øly allowed, and approued of God before, and for the euerla≈øting shame and confu≈øion of ≈øo many his Per≈øecutours and Enemies then pre≈øent, and all after commers, that would oppo≈øe again≈øt tho≈øe mo≈øt Catholike doctrines, and practi≈øes of the Church of Chri≈øt, ≈øo publickly and inuincibly confirmed and warranted by his omnipotent and highe≈øt diuine Power, before ≈øuch a multitude both of Chri≈øtians and Pagans ≈øo te≈øtifying: the fir≈øt by that meanes ≈øtrengthned in the true faith: the
others, in greate numbers, as I shall pre≈øently declare, conuerted to Chri≈øtian Religion. And the Iudge him≈øelfe was hereby ≈øo moued and conuinced, that he pre≈øently commanded the Per≈øecution to cea≈øe, Iudex tanta miraculorum Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. c. 7. caelestium nouitate percul≈øus, ce≈ø≈øari mox √† Per≈øecutione praecepit. Iacobus Genuen≈øis, Bishop of Genua, and his old English Tran≈ølatour, ≈øay, this ≈øouldiar, called Iacob. Genuen. Epi≈øc. in Vita S. Albani & S. Amphibal. Anglic. Tran≈ølat. ib. by ≈øome before, Herculius was a knight. And they yeeld a rea≈øon be≈øides their A≈ø≈øertion, which was the noble renowne of S. Alban, who as they ≈øay, was Lord of the Citie of Verolame, and Prince of the knights, and Steward of the Land, and the Iudge dred de for to ≈ølee him, becau≈øe of the greate loue that Emperour had to him, and for reuerence of his dignitie and Power of his kindred, vnto the time that he had informed Diocle≈øian. And therefore when Iudgment was pronounced again≈øt him, the which was deferred 6. Weeks vntill Maximian his comming into Britaine, to ≈øee ≈øuch wicked executions, thus they deliuer it, Than Maximian, and Askepodot gaue finall ≈øentence on him, ≈øaying. In the the time of the Emperour Diocle≈øian, Albon Lord of Verolomie, Prince of knights, and Steward of Britaine, during his life hath de≈øpi≈øed Iupiter, and Appollyn gooddes, and to them hath done derogation, and di≈øworship, wherefore by the Lawe he is iudged to be deed by the hand of ≈øome knight. And the body to be buryed in the ≈øame place where his heade shall be ≈ømitten of, and his ≈øepulchre to be made worshipfully, for the honour of knighthood whereof he was Prince, and al≈øo the Cro≈ø≈øe that he bare. And sklauin that he ware should be buryed with him. And his body to be clo≈øed in a chest of Ledd, and ≈øo layd in his Sepulchre. This ≈øentence hath the Lawe ordeyned becau≈øe he hath renyed our principall Gods. The≈øe Authours ≈øay, Maximian and King A≈øclepiodote gaue this ≈øentence.

div.head: THE XXII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF VERY MANY CONVERTED TO CHRIST, by the miraculous death of S. Alban, and after going to S. Amphibalus to be fully instructed by him, ≈øuffered Martyrdome, and being a thou≈øand in number, were diuers from the 1000. Martyrs at Lichfeild, and tho≈øe neare Verolamium.

div.p:
1. THAT we may take ≈øome notice of the greate numbers, & multitudes of people conuerted by the death and miracles of the≈øe two holy Martyrs, we haue heard from approued Antiquities, that euen many thou≈øands had bene pre≈øent eye witne≈ø≈øes of the miraculous diuiding of the water to giue free, and dry pa≈ø≈øadge to S. Alban, and tho≈øe that were with him at his prayers, when many drowned and lying in the bottome of the deepe Riuer, were eyther miraculou≈øly pre≈øerued from death, or ≈øo re≈øtored to life againe by his interce≈ø≈øion, the waters ≈øtanding one both ≈øides of their pa≈ø≈øadge like walls, after their going ouer pre≈øently ioyned together againe, and returned to their naturall current, and flowing downeward as the propen≈øitie of ≈øuch liquid and heauy
things requireth, the fountayne one the topp of the hill, as ≈øtrangely ari≈øing, the Executioner his eyes falling out of his head vpon the earth, S. Helaclius ≈øo wonderfully cured by S. Albans prayers, and Reliks, the heauenly light ≈øtreaming from S. Albans graue vp to heauen, and the Angels there de≈øcending, and a≈øcending, and ≈øinging all the night, honouring God, and S. Alban, whome the Pagan Per≈øecutours had ≈øo much dishonoured the day before. Such concour≈øe of people there was, which came to ≈øee the Martyrdome of S. Alban, and ≈øo con≈øequently were pre≈øent at the miracles then wrought, that as the old Brittish Writer of his life witne≈ø≈øeth, the place where he was putt to death being lardge and ≈øpatious, which S. Bede and others al≈øo witne≈ø≈øe, that it could ≈øcarcely receaue them that then re≈øorted thither, Tanta congeries illuc confluxerat populorum, vt loca illa ≈øpatio≈øa prae multitudine hominum, angusta videretur. The multitude was ≈øo greate euen of tho≈øe that went out of that Citie be≈øides others from other places, that as S. Bede with others write Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. c. 7. being to pa≈ø≈øe ouer the Ryuer by a Bridge, if S. Alban had not ≈øo miraculou≈øly dryed vp the Ryuer, they could hardly haue gone ouer by the Bridge before night, Ita fluminis occupabat pontem, vt intra vesperam tran≈øire vix po≈ø≈øet. Pilgrimage vnto, and honor of Martyrs. There was ≈øcarcely any left in the Citie, Cunctis pene egre≈øsis. A greate multitude of both ≈øexes, diuers e≈øtates and Ages, came thither by in≈øtinct, Vtriu≈øque ≈øexus conditionis diuer≈øae & aetatis quae ≈øine dubio diuinitatis in≈øtinctu, ad ob≈øequium beati≈øsimi Confe≈ø≈øoris, ac Martyris vocabatur, to doe ≈øeruice to the ble≈ø≈øed Confe≈ø≈øour and Martyr.

2. Therefore ≈øo many of diuers conditions, and Age, being thus called by the In≈øpiration of God to ≈øuch an holy purpo≈øe, we cannot but thinke many of them were conuerted there at that time. And yet S. Bede ≈øetteth this to be done at S. Albans death, before the greate Miracle of Angels appearing and pray≈øing of God, and honouring S. Alban the night following, at his place of buryall. And ≈øo ≈øoone as this Miracle appeared, the Pagans pre≈øently came thither in greate numbers to heare and ≈øee it, publickly profe≈ø≈øing, that the≈øe Miracles were wrought by the Power of Chri≈øt, the ≈øonne of God, and ≈øo being conuerted vnto him, a thow≈øand of theÃÑ at one time tooke their Iorney to ≈øeeke S. Amphibalus in the parts now named Wales, ≈øo farre di≈øtant from Verolamium, where by the help and Intelligence of diuers Chri≈øtians, in their company, as among others him that tooke vp S. Albans Cro≈ø≈øe, which Matth. We≈øtm. An. 303. Manu≈øc. Antiq. in Vita S. Amphibali. Capgr. in eod. & alij. he held in his hands at his Martyrdome, which, all to be ≈øpotted with his holy blood, they pre≈øented to S. Amphibalus, whom they found preaching to the people of that Country, and they were in≈øtructed, catechized and baptized by him in Chri≈øtian Religion, Cum ad hoc spectaculum ≈øubito fieret concur≈øus Paganorum, vnus ex omnibus in hanc vocem prorupit. Haec miranda quae vidimus, Chri≈øtum Dei filium liquid√≤ con≈øtat operari. Eamus & inquiramus virum Dei, quia ≈øicut no≈øtis, Albanum praedicando conuertit ad Christum. Cumque omnibus i≈øta ≈øententia placui≈ø≈øet, ad mille hominum ver≈øus Walliam Iter arripiunt, & virum Dei Amphibalum ibidem inuenerunt, regionis illius hominibus verbum Dei praedicantem. Cui aduentus ≈øui cau≈øam exponentes, Crucem, quam ≈øuo quondam Albano comendauerat, Manu≈øcr. Antiq. in Vit. S. Amphibal. Capgr. in eod. Iacob. Genucn. in Vit. S. Albani & S. Amphibali. cruore re≈øper≈øam obtulerunt. At ille Deo gratias agens, nouis Auditoribus fecit de Religione ≈øermonem. Cui mox illi con≈øentientes, ≈øignaculum quod in Chri≈øto est, ab eius ≈øacris manibus alacriter ≈øu≈øceperunt. The old Manu≈øcript of S. Amphibalus his life, Capgraue and others affirme, that this greate number, a thow≈øand or more, did before their going to S. Amphibalus, moued with the miracles before related, openly dete≈øt their old errours, and preach the faith
of Chri≈øt, Errorem pri≈øtinum dete≈øtantur: Chri≈øti fides ab omnibus praedicatur.

3. The fame of this came quickly to Verolamium, and the Princes knowledge, wherevpon the Pagans thereabouts with the Rulers Authoritie, with all Power they could make, with greate fury and tumult, as though they had gone forth to warre begyn their Iorney to ≈øeeke and per≈øecute S. Amphibalus, and the newly conuerted Chri≈øtians by his preaching: ciues nimio furore commoti totis viribus cum in genti ≈øtrepitu iter ineunt, ac ≈øi e≈ø≈øent ad praelia proce≈ø≈øuri. And after many dayes trauaile, at the la≈øt they finde S. Amphibalus preaching to the≈øe New Chri≈øtians, their carnall friends and Countrymen, for the Renowne of S. Amphibalus, as our Antiquities ≈øay, would not ≈øuffer him long to be concealed. And pre≈øently this Pagan Army or Troope of Per≈øecutours enraged with deuelish fury, diabolica inuecti furia, mo≈øt barbarou≈øly rush vpon the Innocent Chri≈øtians, cutt their bodies in peeces, and with vn≈øpeakeable crueltie putt them to death: The ≈øonne not ≈øparing his Father, nor brother his brother, no man his neighbour or kin≈øman, but without any re≈øpect of Age, kindred, friendship, or any naturall bonde or obligation thus martyr a thow≈øand holy Chri≈øtians, at that time, and place. Onely one man which detayned with infirmitie in the way could not come ≈øpeedily enough to be pre≈øent, e≈øcaping, ≈øine re≈øpectu aetatis, ≈øanguinis, aut reuerentiae, vicini vicinos & Iacob. Genuen. in Vit. S. Amphibali. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 303. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. & Capgr. in S. Amphibalo. amicos neci tradunt, & atrociter in ore gladij mille viros pro Chri≈øto occidunt. Sicque Pater √† filio, fratres √† fratribus, ciues √† ciuibus trucidantur. Ex hoc ≈øacro Collegio, vnus omnino ≈øuperfuit, qui in via corporis infirmitate detentus, ade≈ø≈øe non potuit. And lea≈øt any man reading in our Hi≈øtories of the like number a thow≈øand Chri≈øtians, martyred at Lichfeild in this Per≈øecution, and that Towne in our old languadge therevpon taking and ≈øtill keeping that name, as a Feild of blood, and bearing Armes accordingly should take this to be the ≈øame Martyrdome; this doubt is decided before, when our Hi≈øtorians a≈ø≈øured vs it was in the Country now called Wales, in which Lichfeild neuer was, nor can be accompted, neyther was it the way of the≈øe Per≈øecutours thither, from Verolamium, nor ≈øo long and tedious a Iorney, Iter tam laborio≈øum, as they went. And our Antiquities plainely ≈øay, the Martyrdome of this thow≈øand of Chri≈øtians, was in the vttermo≈øt border of Britaine, and the≈øe Per≈øecutours went thither, and there putt them ≈øo cruelly to death, Dictum e≈øt, quod omnes pro Matth. We≈øtm. An. 303. quibus iter tam laborio≈øum a≈ø≈øump≈øerant, in extremis finibus perierunt. When all men know, Lichfeild to be no bordering, but a midland Towne. So the≈øe were not one, and the ≈øame, but two di≈øtinct Martyrdomes for time, place, par≈øons and other circum≈øtances different, onely in number agreeing. So I mu≈øt likewi≈øe ≈øay, of a third Martyrdome, of ≈øo many Chri≈øtians, neare to Verolamium of which I shall ≈øpeake, when I bring S. Amphibalus thither againe. Who at this bloody Ma≈ø≈øacre, being compa≈ø≈øed round about with the bodies of his Chri≈øtian hearers thus martyred, commended their ble≈ø≈øed ≈øoules to God, Sanctus Amphibalus vallatus corporibus occi≈øorum, beatas animas Domino commendabat.

div.head: THE XXIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THE MARTYRDOME OF S. AMPHIBALVS, and many others with him, or at that time and place; and wonderfull numbers conuerted then to Chri≈øt, by the Miracles then there shewed.

div.p: 1. THe≈øe bloody per≈øecutors hauing thus barbarou≈øly and without Matth. We≈øtm. an. 303. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. in Vita S. Amphibali. Iac. Genuen. & Cap. grau. in eod. all compa≈ø≈øion of Lynage, kyndred, friendship, Country or what≈øoeuer relation of loue or mercy, put the≈øe holy Saints to death, they now powre out the bottome of their malice vppon S.
