Amphibalus, neyther regarding his Noble de≈øcent before remembred, venerable and old yeares, learning or wha≈øoeuer, but binde his armes with thonges, and driue him barefooted before their hor≈øes ≈øo longe a Iorney from the Borders of Britaine, where they apprehended him, vnto the Citie of Verolam, where the Prefect and Lieutenant then was re≈øident, Brachia loris diri≈øsimis coÃÑstringentes, ante equos ≈øuos ver≈øus Ciuitatem Verolamium, nudis incedere pedibus compulerunt. And as they thus contemptibly carried him barefooted and bound, a ≈øicke man lyeing in the way, in the ≈øight and hearing of them all, cried out vnto him, √¥ Thou ≈øeruant of God almightie help mee, that I which lye oppre≈ø≈øed by my owne infirmitie, may be releeued by thy interce≈ø≈øion. For I doe beleeue that by thy calling vppon the name of Chri≈øt, thou art able pre≈øently to re≈øtore my health vnto mee. And forthwith the man which lay thus ≈øicke before the eyes of them all, aro≈øe vp ioyfull and perfectly well.

2. When the≈øe wicked Pagan per≈øecutors had thus barbarou≈øly brought him within the ≈øight of the Walles of the Cytie, as though this holy Saint had bene vnworthie to enter into it, and their troopes ≈øo greate, by that is ≈øaid before, that they could not conueniently be receaued therein, they ≈øtay them≈øelues, as it were pitching their Tents in a place then de≈øart, now called Redburne three miles from S. Albans, throwing downe their sheelds, and ≈øticking their ≈øpeares in the ground, ≈øcuta reclinant, & ha≈øtas telluri defigunt. And thus re≈øting them≈øelues, onely S. Amphibalus re≈øted not, but preached continually the doctrine of Saluation to his enemies. Who in the meanetime gaue notice to the Prince, and tho≈øe of the Citie of their returne, and bringing with theÃÑ the In≈øtructor of S. Alban, and that they had put all tho≈øe Chri≈øtians before ≈øpoken off to death in the vttermo≈øt parts of the kingdome, after their long Iorney thither. Which when the Gouernour heard, he called the people together, and thus exhorted them: Let vs all goe forth, and meete our enemy, that he which offended may receaue reuenge of vs all. And ≈øo ha≈øting forth, ≈øtriuing as it were who should goe fir≈øt, went by the way leading of the North, tendentes per viam, quae de Ciuitate vertit ad Aquilonem, as our Antiquities ≈øay, the better to ≈øet downe the old place, and ≈øituation of that auÃÑcient Citie, which they then left almo≈øt vacant, vrbem fer√® vacuam reliquerunt. And comming in this raging madnes, and multitude, to torment and Martyr this S. Amphibalus Martyred. holy Saint, they finde him all wrapped in chaines, or bonds, vinculis irretitum, and pre≈øently ≈øtripped him naked, ≈ølitt his belly and pull out his Intrals,
tying them to a ≈øtake, which thy had fa≈øtned in the ground, enforcing him to be ledd round about it. And the holy Saint of God shewing no ≈øigne of greife at all among ≈øuch and ≈øo many afflictions, the wicked per≈øecutors more thereby enraged ≈øett him for a marke, as it were, and with their kniues and ≈øpeares pearced and brake the re≈øt of his body. After all which, this holy Martyr ≈øtood with as chearefull a countenance, as if he had ≈øuffered no hurt at all, and more con≈øtant though he now bore the ≈øignes of his Martyrdome in all his body: Giuing a miraculous ≈øpectacle of him≈øelfe, that he could ≈øtill liue after ≈øo great Torments, and ≈øo many kindes of death. Whereupon very many beholding, and more and more wondering at the con≈øtancie of the ble≈ø≈øed Martyr, renouncing their Idols, ≈øubmitted them≈øelues to Chri≈øtian faith, and prayed Many conuerted to Chri≈øt at S. Amphibalus martyrdome. And prayer to martyrs. with a loude voyce to God, that by the merits, and interce≈ø≈øion of the ble≈ø≈øed Martyr, they might be worthie to be partakers of euerla≈øting life. Which when the Prince perceaued and knew, he pre≈øently called for the Tormentors, and commanded all that had reiected, and for≈øaken the worship of Iacob. Genuen≈ø. in Vita S. Amphibali. Manu≈øcriptum Antiq. & Capgr. in eod. their Gods, and embraced the doctrine of Amphibalus, to be put to death.

3. Which ≈øauage Edict the PagaÃÑ ≈øouldiars effected, & killed a thou≈øand ≈øuch, S. Amphibalus beholding it, and commending their ≈øoules to God, and per≈øuading his per≈øecutors to renounce their errors, and be conuerted to Chri≈øt, without whom no ≈øaluation can be had, nothing but Hell and eternall damnation A thou≈øand of the conuerted now to Chri≈øt are martyred with S. Amphibalus. to be expected. But the Per≈øecutors did ≈øtill per≈øeuer in their impietie, not cea≈øing, ≈øo to torment this holy Saint with cruell ≈øtoning him, be≈øides ≈øo many torturs before remembred, that when his body was afterward miraculou≈øly found, there was not one whole bone to be found in it, Nullum ex o≈øsibus eius integrum app√°rebat. Allthough it ≈øeemeth by the Hi≈øtory of his life, that many of his bones were broken with ≈øtones by the≈øe his ≈øo enraged Per≈øecutors, that after his ble≈ø≈øed ≈øoule was ≈øeparated from his body, thus lying ≈øtill bound and tyed, they cea≈øed not to breake it more, with their ca≈øting greate ≈øtones vpon it, Pagani Corpus exanime in vinculis con≈øtitutum lapidibus adhuc obruere con ce≈ø≈øabant. But ≈øo long as he liued in ≈øuch extremitie of Torments, as I haue related, allthough the ≈øtones were ca≈øt at him, as thick as hayle, ≈øaxorum grandine, as ≈øome write, he ≈øtill pre≈øerued in prayer neuer mouing him≈øelfe, on one ≈øide or other, nec in partem alteram declinauit. And being now come to the Periode of his punishments, and to yeeld his ≈øoule to God, looking towards heauen, as an other S. Stephen ≈øaw Ie≈øus ≈øtanding on the right hand of his Father, and heard a con≈øorte of Angels in heauen, and among them knew S. Alban, whome he inuocated to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him. Saying, √¥ holy Alban, pray vnto our God, that he will ≈øend a good Angell to meete mee, that the dreadfull Robber lett mee not, nor the wicked part hinder mee in my Iorney, Inter eos Albanum ≈øuum recognouit, quem ≈øibi in auxilium inuocans. S. Amphibalus prayeth to S. Alban. Sancte, inquit, Albane Deum no≈øtrum depreceris, vt mihi Angelum bonum obuiam mittat; ne mihi praedo truculentus ob≈øi≈øtere, nec Iter meum pars iniqua valeat impedire. And a voice ≈øpake vnto him from heauen in the hearing of all, in this manner: Verely I ≈øay to thee, this day thou shalt be with thy Di≈øciple Alban in Paradi≈øe. And two Angels shining with an heauenly brightnes came downe to him, and taking with them the ≈øoule of the ble≈ø≈øed, re≈øplendant with a wonderfull whitenes, with Hymnes, and pray≈øes carryed it to heauen. Which done to make him both glorious there, and honourable one earth, a Chri≈øtian ≈øecretly conueying away his holy body reuerently buryed it, Quidam fidelis in Chri≈øto, beati Martyris Corpus clam auferens, ≈øub terra reuerenter occultauit.

4. And God him≈øelfe now began to honour him heare, and be reuenged vpon his Enemies and Per≈øecutours. Tho≈øe lipps of theirs which had bene opened before to blasphemies towards God and reuilings to his holy Saint, are now miraculou≈øly drawne awry, that their ≈øpeach is hindered, di≈øtorquentur labia. The tongues which had ≈øo abu≈øed him, now burne, ardent linguae: and the faces of them which had ≈øo deformed him, are made deformed, Varia The ≈øtraÃÑge punishments God layed vpon the Iudge & per≈øecutors of S. Amphibalus. deformitas vultus apprehendit. All their members are ≈øo ≈øtiffe, that the ≈øtoners and tormentours of the holy man could not now lift one ≈øtone from the ground, Omnium membrorum flexibilitas ita repent√® diriguit, vt ne lapidem quidem de terra leuare iam po≈ø≈øent. And the Iudge or Prince him≈øelfe loo≈øing his vnder≈øtanding of rea≈øon, became madd, Iudex ami≈ø≈øo rationis intellectu, amens effectus e≈øt. And how many ≈øoeuer had lifted vp their hand again≈øt our Lord, did of him receaue due reuendge for their demeritts, Quotquot manum erexerant contra Dominum, dignam pro meritis √† iusto Iudice ≈øen≈øerant vltionem. Herevpon, The whole Citie of Verolame conuerted to Chri≈øt by S. Amphibalus miracles and martyrdome. the whole Citie receaued the faith of Chri≈øt, and de≈øired to be baptized. And many by the In≈øpiration of God for≈øaking their goods, goe to Rome, Romam adeunt, bewayle their ≈øinns and confe≈ø≈øe their errours. With S. Amphibalus 9. other Chri≈øtians were martyred, as Matthew of Paris writeth. Neyther is it probable, that ≈øo renowned a Bishop as S. Amphibalus, was apprehended alone, being taken as he was preaching to the people, or ≈øuch Matth. Paris Hi≈øt. p. 179. 180. 181. 182. 183. rage as then reigned in the Per≈øecutours, would yeeld them much more fauour then they did to S. Amphibalus. But their malice being mo≈øt vnto him, and he ≈øo famous, all our Hi≈øtories remember him, allmo≈øt forgotting the others.

5. Yet diuers Manu≈øcripts, and Ihon Capgraue with others write, that at Manu≈øc. Antiq. & Capg. in Vita S. Amphibali. the finding of S. Amphibalus his body, the bodies of two other Martyrs were found in the ≈øame place by him, but not ≈øo broken, and mangled as his body was, aliorum Sanctorum o≈ø≈øa fer√® illae≈øa perdura≈ø≈øent: But S. Amphibalus body was ≈øtoned and broken euen after he was dead, Lapidibus conqua≈ø≈øatus occubuit: & po≈øt eius mortem per≈øecutorum immanitas exanima membra ≈øaxorum ictibus obruit & confregit. He ≈øuffered Martyrdome in the ≈øame yeare, with S. Manu≈øcr. Eccle≈ø. Winton. Author of Engl. Mart. 25. Iune. Matth. Paris Hi≈øt. p. 183. Alban, as the old Manu≈øcript of Winche≈øter relateth: eodem anno pa≈ø≈øus est Amphibalus. But vpon what day, I doe not finde for certaine. For whereas a late Writer ≈øetteth downe the day of his Pa≈ø≈øion to haue bene vpon the 25. day of Iune, Matthew Paris proueth this was not the day of his Pa≈ø≈øion, but Inuention, which being diuers hundreds of yeares after, I am not now to entreate thereof. And this is di≈øproued by the Antiquitie of Winche≈øter before. For if as it teacheth S. Alban and S. Amphibalus were both martyred in one yeare, S. Alban being putt to death as we reade in the approued Hi≈øtory of his life, decimo Kalendas Iulij, which is the 22. day of Iune, S. Amphibalus by that is ≈øaid before, could not po≈ø≈øibly be Martyred vpon the 25. day of the ≈øame moneth in the ≈øame yeare, being but two dayes betweene. And if we deferre it vntill the ≈øame day the next yeare, they ≈øuffered not, eodem anno, the ≈øame yeare, as that old Record affirmeth.

6. Of S. Augulus, S. StepheÃÑ, & S. Socrates, which ≈øome would haue, to haue bene Martyred in this time, I haue ≈øpoken in my fir≈øt Centenary, and dare not deferre their glory to this time. It is no meruaile though few names of ≈øo great numbers, and thow≈øands are left vnto vs, when by ≈øome Writers the Per≈øecution was ≈øo greate in Britaine, that except tho≈øe which hidd them≈øelues, and could not be witne≈ø≈øes of things publikly done, all the Chri≈øtians of Britaine
were then Martyred, Sunt qui tradunt vniuer≈øos in Britannia Chri≈øtianos martyrio Harpesfeld. Hi≈øt. Eccl. Anglic. in 6. primis ≈øoeculis c. 10. p. 17. Gildas lib. de excid. c. 8. Gild. ≈øupr. c. 7. defunctos, ≈øepo≈øitis ijs qui occultis & ≈øecretis locis ≈øe abdidere. And S. Gildas him≈øelfe doth ≈øeeme to affirme no le≈ø≈øe, when he ≈øaith, they which were then left aliue, had hidden them≈øelues in woods, de≈øarts and dens: qui ≈øuperfuerant ≈øiluis ac de≈øertis, abditi≈øque ≈øpeluncis ≈øe occultauere. Yet he tempereth this hard a≈ø≈øertion, where he ≈øaith this Per≈øecution was ≈øo rigorous onely in ≈øome, not all places of this Country, Ita vt ne ve≈øtigium quidem ≈øi fieri potui≈ø≈øet, in non nullis Prouinciae locis Chri≈øtianae Religionis appareret. And tho≈øe parts of Britaine which were then ab≈øolutely vnder the Romans command, were by their mercile≈ø≈øe cruelty in this e≈øtate. So many mutations of times, changes of the names of places, and rages of Infidels, Romans, Saxons, and others haue depriued vs both of the names, and holy Reliks of tho≈øe Martyrs, Lugubri Galfr. Mon. l. 5. Hi≈øt. c. 5. Barbarorum diuortio ciuibus adempta. The Country now called Walles where ≈øo many changes haue not bene, in ≈øome places, will yeeld vs ≈øome memories of ≈øuch things, more then England can, ≈øubiect to ≈øo many and generall allmo≈øt alterations, which it hath ≈øuffered.

div.head: THE XXIV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: HOW BY COILVS BEING KING, AND preuayling again≈øt the Roman Per≈øecutours, and their adherents heare, the Per≈øecution in Britaine cea≈øed.

div.p: 1. NOW to calme the≈øe tempe≈øts of troubles, I ≈øuppo≈øe (by our be≈øt Hi≈øtories) that this Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian, and Maximian heare raged about the ≈øpace of 9. or 10. yeares in the time of A≈øclepiodotus principally, and that now at the Martyrdome of S. Amphibalus, ≈øo greate mi≈øeries and afflictions had bene layed vpon our holy Chri≈øtians heare long time, as their flying from hence vnto other Nations, their aboade there, returne hither againe, and heare continuing no short ≈øpace, before they were putt to death, as is manife≈øt in the ca≈øe of S. Amphibalus, not martyred vntill allmo≈øt a yeare after S. Alban, who was kept in pri≈øon 6. moneths before his Martyrdome, that now thow≈øands were conuerted to Chri≈øt, and the cheife Municipall Cities them≈øelues, where Idolatry ≈øo reigned, that a Chri≈øtian was rare to be then founde in them as in Verolam, were now onely inhabited by Chri≈øtians, fidem Chri≈øti tota ciuitas deuot√® ≈øu≈øcepit, and not a Pagan to be ≈øeene, and this by the omnipotent working of God. And the Idolatrous Iudge or Prince him≈øelfe, that ruled heare vnder the Pagan Romans, and per≈øecuted by their Power euen to the vttermo≈øt bounds of Britaine, was madd amens effectus, that he was vnable to Rule, and gouerne any longer, but needed to be ruled and gouerned him≈øelfe by others. And yet as is manife≈øt before, by his Per≈øecutions in all places of Britaine, in ≈øuch powerfull and tumultuous manner, with greate troopes, and military companies of his per≈øecuting va≈ø≈øals, and In≈øtruments, which none but a Roman Lieutenant, or King heare then could rai≈øe and commande. This Iudge, King and Roman Lieutenant, as the Scottish Hi≈øtorians with others call him, was King A≈øclepiodotus, thus greeuiou≈øly eyther of malice or for feare of the Romans then per≈øecuting, & for ≈øo doing hated of God and man.

2. Therefore King Coel hauing now ≈øuch warrant and way to aduance his true Title to the Crowne of his kingdome, and help to free the afflicted Chri≈øtians thereof, from the mi≈øeries of their ≈øo long and grieuious Per≈øecution (as it ≈øeemeth mo≈øt probable) at this time, and vpon the≈øe occa≈øions he tooke armes again≈øt A≈øclepiodotus reputed King in this Per≈øecution, ≈ølew him, and was crowned King, as our auncient Hi≈øtorians deliuer vnto vs, In tanta autem Per≈øecutione, in≈øurrexit Coelus Dux Caercolun, id e≈øt Colce≈øtriae in A≈øclepiodotum, Pontic. Vir. Brit. Hi≈øt. l. 5. Galfrid. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 5. c. 5. & 6. Manu≈øcr. Gallic. antiq. c. 28. an. 286. Boet. lib. 6. Harding. Chronic. c. 58. f. 47. qui eum interfecit, & Regni diademate potitus. Harding al≈øo plainely ≈øaith, that Coel tooke Armes again≈øt A≈øclepiodotus, by rea≈øon of this greate Per≈øecution.
div.q: For which Duke Coyle againe him ro≈øe full hote,
div.p: Yet he excu≈øeth A≈øclepiodotus, for being any mouer of that Per≈øecution, but ≈øuffering the Tyrant Maximian ≈øo cruelly to pro≈øecute it, and not re≈øi≈øting him therein, which he rather imputeth to want of Power, then will, and de≈øire in him, when he ≈øaith.

l.hi: Who for greate feare ≈øuffered all this payne

lg.l: (Of Chri≈øtians)

l.hi: And dur≈øt nothing againe this Tyrant ≈øteare,
But him withdrew to hyde him, was full fayne.

div.p: Where he doth rather in≈øinuate that A≈øclepiodotus was in IudgmeÃÑt a friend, rather then Per≈øecutour of Chri≈øtians, and him≈øelfe in ≈øome ≈øort per≈øecuted by the RomaÃÑ PagaÃÑs, in that re≈øpect which ≈øeemeth expre≈ø≈øed, in that this Authour ≈øayeth of him, that he was enforced to hide him≈øelfe, from the Pagan Roman Per≈øecutours. Whereof ≈øome may take the rea≈øon to haue bene, becau≈øe he was not ≈øo foreward in per≈øecuting Chri≈øtians heare, as was expected o ‚Ä¢ de≈øired of the Roman Pagan Per≈øecutours: and we finde diuers Antiquities te≈øtifying, that before, there was not any per≈øecution heare again≈øt Chri≈øtians, but their Religion was in peace & quiet, publickly profe≈ø≈øed, & this A≈øclepiodotus to redeeme and pre≈øerue ≈øuch Britans libertie in that and all other priuiledges, warred again≈øt Alectus the Pagan Roman Gouernour, and in ≈øigne of his dete≈øtation of their Idolatrous profe≈ø≈øion be≈øett and a≈ø≈øaulted him, and his Confederats Galfr. Mon. hi≈øt. Reg Brit. l. 5. c. 4. PoÃÑt. Vir. l. 5. Hi≈øt. Matth. We≈øtm. An. 294. when they were doing their greate≈øt and mo≈øt ≈øolemne Sacrifices to their Gods. And preuayling again≈øt him by common acclamation of the people, then Chri≈øtians, to take vpon him the Diademe, was created King: clamante populo, vt diadema caperet, Rex creatur. And this with con≈øent of all the Nobilitie, then al≈øo Chri≈øtians, omnibus Ducibus Britanniae. And thus generally and ≈øolemly crowned King by our Chri≈øtian Britans, did in the time of his Reigne rule in Iu≈øtice, and equitie, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing crueltie and doers of Iniury, as our ≈øame Chri≈øtian Antiquaries deliuer, Tractauit Patriam recta iu≈øtitia & pace decem an ‚Ä¢ is: raptorumque ≈øaeuitiam, atque latronum mucrones coercuit. And was mo≈øt iu≈øt by the ≈øpace of 10. yeares, Rex creatur & per decem annos iu≈øti≈ø≈øimus fuit. Which Chri≈øtians neyther would, nor in con≈øcience could haue written of him, if he had bene all wayes knowne vnto them to haue bene a Per≈øecutour, and Worker of ≈øuch vniu≈øtice, as is practi≈øed in vniu≈øt Per≈øecutions.

3. But I haue made memory before, that A≈øclepiodotus was King heare a farre longer time, then ten yeares, and by ≈øome three times ten, 30. yeares, and th ‚Ä¢ ≈øe Authours them≈øelues with others acknowledge that in the meane time interea, and in his dayes, in diebus ip≈øius, this greate Per≈øecution of Chri≈øtians Galf. Mon. Vir. & Matth. We≈øt. ≈øupr. was rai≈øed heare: oritur ingens illa Chri≈øtianorum Per≈øecutio. And it is
euident before, that how≈øoeuer A≈øclepiodotus in ≈øome part of his ReiÃÑgne heare behaued, and carryed him≈øelfe well, and iu≈øtely to the Chri≈øtian Subiects of Britaine, yet it is vndeniably euident by that I haue written of him before, being by diuers witne≈ø≈øes, both the per≈øecuting King, Lieutenant and Iudge in that cruell Per≈øecution, that how≈øoeuer he was in internall iudgment affected, being externally a condemned Per≈øecutour both by God and man, King Coel might iu≈øtly pur≈øue his right to Britaine, with hope thereby in better manner to redeeme the afflictions of his Country Chri≈øtians, being more potent and able, and likely more willing then A≈øclepiodotus was, not ≈øo foreward in anie iudgments as he should haue bene in defending Innocents, if he had not bene an Actuall Per≈øecutour, which Harding him≈øelfe thus in the≈øe plaine Termes expre≈ø≈øeth.

lg.l: This Per≈øecution, as ≈øome Chroniclers ≈øaine,
The tenne yere was of A≈øclepiodote, Harding Chron. c. 58. f. 47.
For which Duke Coile againe him ro≈øe full hote,
The Duke Cair Colun that hight Coylus,
Which Citee now this day Colche≈øter hight,
Then Crowned was that ≈ølew A≈øclepiodotus,
For cau≈øe he came not forth with all his might
The Tyranute fell to again≈øtande, as he hight,
Wherefore Britains were all full glad and fain,
Of King Coilus that ≈øuccoured all their pain.

div.p: 4. And how≈øoeuer A≈øclepiodotus concurred with the Roman Per≈øecurours, Galfrid. Mon. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. c. 6. Manu≈øcr. antiq. in Vit. S. Helenae. Capgr. in cadem. Pontic. Virun. H ‚Ä¢ ≈øt. l. 5. Galf. Mon. ≈øup. c. 6. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 302. Ga ‚Ä¢ frid. Mon. Hi≈øt. Reg. Briton. l. 5. cap. 6. Vir. lib. 5. Man. Gallic. Antiq. c. 28. An. 286. Harding. Chron. Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. l. 2. in Diocle≈øiano. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 302. Manu≈øcr. Gallic. Antiq. c. 28. Old. Engl. Hi≈øt. f. 38. Hect. Boeth. l. 6. Hellinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 27. Stowe & Howes Hi≈øt. Titul. Romans in Coil. Galfr. Mon. lib. 5. c. 6. Hi≈øt. Reg. B ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t. and plea≈øed them in vexing, and tormenting Chri≈øtians heare in Britaine: yet otherwi≈øe he was very vnplea≈øing to them, per omnia Romanam pote≈øtatem turhauerat: He troubled the Roman Power in all things, and therefore they were glad of his death. Ponticus Virunnius, him≈øelfe a Roman ≈øaith, they did e≈øteeme him their greate enemy, and as for ≈øuch an one reioyced of his death: Romani gaui≈øi ≈øunt tanto hoste interfecto. And this Ioy was not onely of particular Roman Per≈øecutours, but of the whole Senate which ruled cheifely in matters of E≈øtate, Cumque id Senatui nuntiatum e≈øt, gaui≈øi ≈øunt propter Regis mortem, quia per omnia Romanam pote≈øtatem turbauerat. Therefore when our Antiquities a≈ø≈øure vs, that Coel obtinuit Regnum, obtayned the kingdome, Regni diademate ≈øe in≈øigniuit: And Regni diademate potitus, was Crowned, and as an old French Manu≈øcript ≈øpeaketh, reigned ouer Britaine, regna ≈øur Bretaigne, and was thus enabled, and made powerable to redre≈ø≈øe what he found offen≈øiue, and wicked, being ab≈øolute King, and ioyfully ≈øo receaued of the Britans, as our Hi≈øtorian ≈øaid before.

q.l: Wherefore Britains were all full glad and fain,
Of King Coilus that ≈øuccoured all their pain:

div.p:
And he him≈øelfe taking exceptioÃÑ to A≈øclepiodotus, next to his chardging him with v≈øurping the Crowne, for being too barkward in re≈øi≈øting the RomaÃÑ per≈øecutors, would not now fall into the like error with him, but as is proued already, ≈øuccoured all their paine, & vtterly cea≈øed the Per≈øecutioÃÑ again≈øt the Chri≈øtiaÃÑs of Britaine, which were thus Ioyfull of his CoronatioÃÑ, & thereby releiued & redeemed theÃÑ froÃÑ their afflictioÃÑs all his time. Which both by our owne & forreine Hi≈øtoriaÃÑs, Catholikes & Prote≈øtaÃÑts coÃÑtinued to the end of this third huÃÑdred of yeares, the RomaÃÑs hauing no power heare either to per≈øecute Chri≈øtiaÃÑs, or to any other purpo≈øe. But as our Brittish & other Hi≈øtories te≈øtifie, wholy lo≈øt their gouernmeÃÑt heare, vntill after the death of King Coel, or the coÃÑming of CoÃÑ≈øtaÃÑ tius,
his ≈øonne in Law hither the ≈øecond time, very litle before King Coel his death, Recolentes damnum quod de ami≈ø≈øo regno habuerant. Our Scottish Hi≈øtorians ≈øay, that King Coel vtterly de≈øtroyed both the Romans, and all the Britans al≈øo, which were their Fauourers, and ≈øet forth a ≈øeuere Edict, to ≈øearch forth all Romans and Britans, which had followed them heare, and cau≈øed them to be punished and put to death, and ≈øo with mo≈øt ioyfull and generall applau≈øe of the people, Nobles and others, that the crowne of Britaine was thus re≈øtored to the true Heyre of their Regall blood, was crowned King, and Hector Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. l. 6. f. 101. he e≈øtablished the kingdome in the Brittish gouernmeÃÑt againe, Coel Victor factus, A≈øclepiodotum Romanum Legatum cum Romanis Prae≈øidijs, & quibu≈ødam Britanis Nobilibus Romanorum fautoribus interemit. Confectoque praelio, & Britonibus caeteris in fidem receptis, vt ≈øumma pote≈øtas ad regiam progeniem, cui impie fuerat adempta, aliquando rediret, populus omnis laetis acclamationibus, Patribus authoribus, ip≈øum Coelem regnare iubet. Ille Primoribus regni, ac populo quod regnum ≈øibi detuli≈ø≈øent, gratijs actis, vt regnum ≈øibi ≈øtabiliret, atroci iubet Edicto, Romanos, & qui eorum ≈øequebantur partes, quo≈øcunque Britannici ≈øanguinis viros perquiri, & inuentos varijs extingui ≈øupplicijs. So that now, ≈øo ≈øeuere a Lawe being made, and executed, both again≈øt the per≈øecuting Romans, and all ≈øuch Britans, as had ioyned with them again≈øt the Chri≈øtian Inhabitants of this Nation, and all this done by the Authoritie of our King, and with the con≈øent both of the Nobilitie, and people, Primoribus regni, & populo, we mu≈øt needs end the per≈øecution of Chri≈øtians heare, with the beginning of King Coel his Reigne.

5. And it could not be ≈øingular in this point, if we should hold, that King Coel was actually a Chri≈øtian, and not onely a friend to ≈øuch: for fir≈øt, all they, which affirme him to haue bene Kin≈øman, or Heyre to our fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King S. Lucius, ea≈øily proue him a Chri≈øtian, for ≈øuch a man would not leade either child, or any Kin≈øman which by him had that Title, to haue any other theÃÑ Chri≈øtian education. Secondly, by the time of his age, whether he was to King Lucius, ≈øo neare, or no, we mu≈øt needs confe≈ø≈øe, he liued mo≈øt part of his life, when Chri≈øtianitie florished in this kingdome, being an aged man, before Diocle≈øian his Per≈øecutioÃÑ began. Thirdly, our Hi≈øtorians ≈øay, that his daughter S. Helen, which had her education by his direction, was in≈øtructed & taught in the Chri≈øtian faith, in fide Catholica in≈øtructa at que edoÃÑcta. A late writer thus ≈øpeaketh of this with his older Author: Helena was fir≈øt in≈øtructed in the faith of Manu≈øcript. antiq. in Vit. S. Helenae Capgr. in ead. Harris. Hi≈øt. l. 4. c. 4. Petr. de Natal. l. 7. c. 73. Chri≈øt by Coil her father, as Petrus de Natalibus ≈øaith. And yet if we encline to this opinion, we may ea≈øely an≈øweare them, that will obiect, the publike & vniuer≈øall re≈øtitution of Chri≈øtian Religion, as building Churches, Mona≈øteries, and ≈øuch holy Foundations, was not in his time: For by the common opinion, his reigne was short, litle, or not aboue foure yeares. A great part whereof was ≈øpent, in extirpating the Per≈øecutors, and the re≈øt in preparation Matth. We≈øtm. an. 302. Galfrid. Mon. l. 5. Hi≈øt. c. 6. Virun. l. 5. Harding. Chron. c. 60. f. 48. to re≈øi≈øt a new Inua≈øion of the Romans, not reigning in quiet and ≈øecuritie from the≈øe troubles and feares the ≈øpace of two moneths by any Writers. And ≈øo after ≈øo great and terrible tempe≈øt of Per≈øecution, it was a wonderfull comfort, and happines for the Brittish Chri≈øtians, to enter into ≈øuch a calme, and quiet, to liue in ≈øecuritie, and re≈øt, freed from their former mi≈øeries, vnder ≈øo renowned a King, which was all he could doe, or they expect in ≈øuch times and circum≈øtances.
THE ECCLESIASTICALL HISTORIE OF GREAT BRITAINE.
THE FOVRTH AGE.

div.head: THE ECCLESIASTICALL HISTORIE OF GREAT BRITAINE.
THE FOVRTH AGE.
THE FIRST CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE GREATE PEACE, AND QVIET THE Church of Britaine enioyed, during the whole life, and Reigne of Con≈øtantius Emperor, and King heare in Britaine; and Constantine his ≈øonne by Sainct Helen was heare brought vp in Chri≈øtian Religion.

div.p:
1. BEING now to enter into the Hi≈øtory of the fourth hundreth of yeares, we finde the e≈øtate of the world, and Church of Chri≈øt, as we left theÃÑ in the la≈øt Age, S. Marcellinus Pope of Rome, cheife Ruler in the hou≈øe of God on earth, the holy Cleargy and other Chri≈øtians liuing in Per≈øecution, and Diocle≈øian & MaximiniaÃÑ the per≈øecuting Emperors in all places, where they did or could ouer≈øway, afflicting them with mo≈øt cruell mi≈øeries; in Britaine (lately redeemed from their bloody tyranny by King Coel, ≈øtill reigning heare) we liued ≈øtill in re≈øt and quietne≈ø≈øe, free both from Per≈øecution in Religion, and ≈øuch other greeuances, as were ordinarily ≈øuffered vnder the Pagan Romans gouernment. But the Romans greedy of their owne honor, and thereby impatient of our Brittish ea≈øe, and peace (as our Hi≈øtories deliuer vnto vs) began now to bethinke them≈øelues of the lo≈ø≈øe they had of Britaine, which had for≈øaken them: Romani recolentes damnum quod de ami≈ø≈øo regno habuerant, and falling Galfrid. Mon. l. 5. Hi≈øt. c. 6. into deliberation, whom they were be≈øt to ≈øend with their forces hither, to regaine it vnto them againe, concluded Con≈øtantius to be the fitte≈øt Con≈øtantius father of Con≈øtantine the Greate his coÃÑ ming into Britaine and when. man, both for his long experience, and ≈øucce≈ø≈øe in Martiall affaires, being made a Cae≈øar before in the 292. yeare of Chri≈øt, when he for≈øooke S. Helen, and tooke Theodora, and for the greate loue of the Britans vnto him after he married S. Helen, and his kindne≈ø≈øe vnto them, vntill by the compul≈øion of Maximinian he left that his holy true wife; which old loue and liking betweene
them was now mo≈øt like to be renewed and re≈øtored againe, Theodora (the breache and occa≈øion of the di≈øcontinuance thereof) Berengo≈ø. Abbas l. 3. c. 3. de Inuent. & Laude S. Crucis. Matth. We≈øt. an. 302. Galfrid. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 5. c. 6. Pont. Vir. Hi≈øt. l. 5. Hard. Chron. c. 60. f. 48. Matth. We≈øtm. ≈øup. an. 302. Manu≈øcr. Gallic. antiq. c. 23. Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. l. an. 293. 295. 298. 303. 304. 305. Baron. Annal. An. 304. Spond. ib. Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. l. 2. an. 305. being now lately dead. And therefore they ≈øent Con≈øtantius hither to procure the regaining of Britaine vnto their Empire, Romani legauerunt Con≈øtantium qui Hi≈øpaniam aliasque terras quamplures ip≈øis ≈øubdiderat, vt Britanniam Romanae redderet dignitati. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øetteth downe this his ≈øecond comming into Britaine to haue bene in the ≈øecond yeare of this Age, anno gratiae 302. An old French Manu≈øcript al≈øo maketh it much about this time. Marianus Scotus keepeth him out of Britaine a litle longer, and all they which before haue proued, he was in forreine Countries vntill the end of the la≈øt Age, or after, make this vndoubted, and certaine; And ≈øeeing all agree he was ≈øent hither by others of higher dignitie, he mu≈øt needs come into Britaine in this voyadge, when he was a Cae≈øar, and before he was Emperor, which was in the yeare of Chri≈øt 304. Diocle≈øian and Maximinian then relinquishing the Empire, and leauing it to Con≈øtantius and Galerius. Marianus placeth it in the yeare following 305. And it is mo≈øt manife≈øt in this accompt, that Con≈øtantius could not make this his ≈øecond Iorney into Britaine, vntill this Age was entered, and ≈øo was mo≈øt free from our Per≈øecution ended heare before this time. But ≈øo ≈øoone as he now came hither, Amba≈ø≈øadges of peace, without any ho≈øtile Act, were ≈øent betweene our King Coel, and Con≈øtantius. And Con≈øtantius free from all per≈øecution of Chri≈øtians in Britaine. with greate loue and liking on both ≈øides, this honorable peace was concluded, to wit, that King Coel should during his life quietly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe, and enioy the kingdome of Britaine, onely paying vnto the Romans the auncient Tribute, and nothing els: nihilque aliud praeter ≈øolitum Tributum Romanae dignitati Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brito: l. 5. c. 6. Pont. Virun. l. 5. Hi≈øt. Manu≈øc. Gallic. ≈øup. Matth. We≈øtm. Ann. 302. Hard. Chron. c. 60. 61. ≈øolueret. And that Con≈øtantius should take againe his wife S. Helen, daughter and Heire to King Coel, and by her right be King heare after the death of her Father King Coel. By which couenant and Article agreed vpon, and truely executed, as it was, the fir≈øt marriage betweene Con≈øtantius and Helen was euen by Roman Pagan lawes them≈øelues proued, and declared to be true and lawfull, and the children therein begotton legitimate, and the taking of Theodora liuing with her, and children by her to be adulterate, and vtterly The first mariage betweene Con≈øtantius & S. HeleÃÑ true marriage by the RomaÃÑ PagaÃÑ lawe, and the children therein begotten legitimate, that with Theodora adul ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ate. vnallowable in any ≈øence, euen by their owne Pagan Con≈øtitutions. For although tho≈øe PagaÃÑ wicked Decrees did allowe to the Pre≈øidents of Prouinces which were vnmarried without penaltie to keepe Concubins, prophanly thinking (as ≈øome new prote≈øting Chri≈øtians haue done) that men vnmarried could not liue cha≈øt, yet they neuer permitted it to married Prefects and Pre≈øidents, ≈øuch as Con≈øtantius was, as their owne Hi≈øtorians witne≈ø≈øe: vt Prae≈øides Prouinciarum ≈øi vxores non haberent, acciperent ≈øingulas concubinas, quod ≈øine his e≈ø≈øe non po≈ø≈øent. By which Roman Heathnish lawe, Theodora was not onely the Concubine, and no wife of Con≈øtantius, but a Concubine prohibited Aelius Lampridius in Alexandro Seuero. in their owne proceedings, and her children in like ca≈øe of reproach with her.

2. Therefore Con≈øtantius being again≈øt his will by the power of Maximinian before ≈øeperated from S. Helen, his true wife, and a Chri≈øtian from Matth. We≈øtm. Galfr. Monum. & alij ≈øupra. ‚Ä¢ Manu≈øcript. Hi≈øtor. Eccl. Wintonien. Caius Hi≈øtor. Cantabr. Accademiae p. 19. that time euer in his affection, could not but be mo≈øt ready and ioyfull to be ≈øo quietly and honorably reconciled vnto her againe. Which is ≈øufficiently in≈øinuated by our cited Antiquaries, te≈øtifying that Con≈øtantius in all things granted to King Coel his demands, requiring nothing of him for the RomaÃÑs but their old Tribute, Cuius petitionibus adquie≈øceÃÑs Con≈øtaÃÑtius, nihil praeter ≈øolitum tributum ab ip≈øo petebat. Which, as our Antiquaries ≈øay, was 1006. pounds
onely in money. One of our Hi≈øtorians ≈øaith of this matter in this manner: Harding ≈øupr. c. 60.

q.l: Of which Cou≈øtance was glad of his entente
And here abode at prayer of the King.

div.p: Whereby he did ≈øufficiently declare, the greate content and ioy he had of this reconciliation to his wife S. Helen, and her Father, his Father in lawe King Coilus, rather choo≈øing & preferring during his life to make his aboad heare as a ≈øubiect, then now being cho≈øen and de≈øigned Emperor to continue in any other Nation with that greate≈øt temporall glorie, and commaund.

3. Thus he ≈øignified this ≈øo longe and much de≈øired attonement, Helenam Coeli Regis filiam in ≈øocietatem Thori recepit. Which worde, recepit, that Con≈øtantius did at this time receaue Helen againe, if we had no other Argument or authoritie v≈øed by diuers our auncient Antiquaries, proueth, that this was the reconciliation, and not fir≈øt marriage of the≈øe noble par≈øons, which is inuincibly proued already to haue bene aboue 30. yeares before. And vnpo≈ø≈øible it is, that any of the≈øe Authors which ≈øpeake of this vnion, should take it for their fir≈øt Vnion in Marriage; for all of them Matth, We≈øtm. an. 302. 305. Marian. Scot. Ann. 305. 306. acknowledge, that Con≈øtantius died ≈øoone after this reconciliation. The Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øayth within 3. yeares, by Marianus within 2. yeares. By Martinus Polonus the ≈øame yeare. The like haue others, by which accoÃÑpt and Confe≈ø≈øion, Con≈øtantine should either be vnborne, or not aboue 2. yeares old at the mo≈øt when he was King of Britaine, and Emperor al≈øo after his Fathers death: When it is proued before by all Antiquitie, and the be≈øt Hi≈øtorians which haue written of this matter, Greeke, Latine, Catholiks and Prote≈øtants, that he was aboue 30. yeares of age at this time: and his Mother S. Helen, whom Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øeemeth at this reconciliation to call, virginem valde specio≈øam, an exceeding beutifull virgin, and Harding, both good and young, had bene Con≈øtantius his wife 35. or 36. yeares before, and brought him diuers children, whereof Con≈øtantine the Greate now ≈øo old, as I haue remembred, was the younge≈øt. shortly after this comming of Con≈øtantius, & this Attonement betweene him, and King Coel thus made, King Coel died, within fiue weekes, ≈øaith Harding: a moneth and eight dayes ≈øaith Galfridus, Hard. Chron. c. 6. Galfrid. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 5. c. 6. PoÃÑt. Virun. Hi≈øt. l. 5. Harding Chron. c. 61. Emen≈øo men≈øe graui≈øsima infirmit as occupauit Coel, ip≈øumque intra octo dies morte affecit. Virunnius ≈øaith within one moneth, Intra men≈øem emortiur Coelus. So likewi≈øe hath the Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter: Coelus elap≈øo men≈øe vitam finiuit. Harding writeth that CoÃÑ≈øtantius was Emperor before he was King of Britaine:

q.l: But King Con≈øtance of Rome was hie Cheiftain
By the Senate fir≈øt made the Emperour
And after King of Britain and Gouernour.

div.p:
4. And all Hi≈øtorians agree that he was Emperour next and immediately to Diocle≈øian & Maximinian, who as Baronius, Spondanus and others proue, gaue ouer the Empyre in the 304. yeare of Chri≈øt, Marianus ≈øaith in the 305. yeare, when by common accompt before Con≈øtantius was come into Britaine, and continued heare, and not enioying the Empire aboue 2. yeares, if he had then bene fir≈øt marryed to S. Helen, and Con≈øtantine had bene their fir≈øt, or onely ≈øonne or child, he could not haue bene aboue one yeare old at his Fathers death to be both king of Britaine and Emperour. When it is certaine out of Eu≈øebius and others before, that Con≈øtantine was aboue thirty yeares old, and had bene generall of an Army before his Fathers death, which the ≈øame Author further confirmeth, when comparing CoÃÑ≈øtantine the Greate with Alexander the Greate ≈øaying that Alexander liued but 32. yeares, and
reigned litle more then the third part of that tyme; Con≈øtantine was as old as Eu≈øeb. l. 1. de Vita. Con≈øtantini c. 3. 4. Alexander was at his death, when he began to reigne, doubled Alexanders tyme of life, & reigned thri≈øe as longe, At no≈øter hic Imperator, eo aetatis tempore regnum obtinuit, quo ille Macedo ce≈øsit √® vita: illius autem vitae ≈øpatium, temporis propagatione duplicauit: regnique longitudinem triplo reddidit diuturniorem. Therefore Alexander liuing 32. yeares compleate, compleuit duos & triginta annos: Con≈øtantius finding the Chri≈øtian Britans free and quiet at the death of King Coel, ≈øo pre≈øerued them. Con≈øtantine mu≈øt needs be ≈øo old at his Fathers death, when he began to reigne, and ≈øo his Father and mother Con≈øtantius and Helen married together a longer tyme.

5. But King Coel hauing freed the Chri≈øtians of Britaine from Per≈øecution, and now dying, left them thus quiett, and ≈øecuer from tho≈øe vexations to Con≈øtantius. Who during his life continued and maintayned them in the ≈øame or rather in better condition, as I haue ≈øufficiently remembred before not onely in giuing them tolleration and freedome from trouble and mole≈øtation, as Sozomen with others witne≈ø≈øe: Con≈øtantius Con≈øtantini pater permi≈øit Chri≈øtianis Sozomen. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈øia≈øt. l. 1. c. 6 pote≈øtatem libere ≈øuam religionem excolendi, And was not again≈øt the lawe for Chri≈øtians in Britaine to profe≈ø≈øe their Religion in his tyme, Britannis non contra leges vi≈øum e≈ø≈øe, Chri≈øtianam religionem dum adhuc vitae ≈øuppeditabat Con≈øtantio profiteri: But he preferred the mo≈øt con≈øtant Chri≈øtians to the highe≈øt Eu≈øeb. l. 1. de Vit. Con≈øtantini c. 11. offices, and greate≈øt tru≈øt: stipatores ≈øuos, & ip≈øius regni cu≈øtodes con≈øtituit. He him≈øelf confe≈ø≈øed the true God, abolished Idolatrie, Repudiata penitus impiorum in varijs dijs colendis ≈øuperstitione, Deum omnium moderatorem vltro agnouit. And ≈øo con≈øecrated his whole family to God, that his Court was as a Church, wherein were both Cleargie men and godly Chri≈øtians truely ≈øeruing God, Omnem ≈øuam familiaÃÑ vni Regi Deo con≈øecrauit: adeo vt multitudo quae intra regiam ip≈øam coiuerat, nihil ab Eccle≈øiae forma di≈øtare videretur: in qua iner ant Dei Mini≈øtri, qui continuos cultus pro Imperatore etiam tum obierunt, cum piorum hominum genus & ver√® Deo in≈øeruientium, alibi apud Gentilium multitudinem ne nominari quidem ab≈øque periculo poterat. This ble≈ø≈øing and benefite he brought into Britaine and to our Chri≈øtians heare, and publickly maintained it euen in tho≈øe tymes, as this auntient Author is witne≈ø≈øe, when the name of Chri≈øtians in other places was ≈øo odious that without danger it could not be ≈øpoken off. Which he further confirmeth in an other place, where ≈øpeaking in the name of Chri≈øtians he ≈øaith, that among the Emperors of that tyme, onely Con≈øtan≈øtius did neither in any ≈øort per≈øecute Chri≈øtians, or participated with them which did, but kept all them which were vnder him without hurt and ≈øecure from all trouble, neyther pulled downe Churches, or did any other thing Eu≈øeb. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 8. c. 14. again≈øt them, Constantius ≈øolus ex no≈øtri temporis Imperatoribus nec belli aduer≈øum nos prae≈øumpti vllo modo particeps fuit, ≈øed quos ≈øub ≈øe habuit pios, indemnes, & ab omni calumnia ≈øecuros ≈øeruauit, & neque domos Eccle≈øiarum demolitus, nec aliud Idem Eu≈øebius apud Baron. & Spondan. Ann. 304. quippiam contra nos operatus. And els where he teacheth againe, that the parts of the we≈øt Empire did generatly receaue quietnes from Per≈øecution when Con≈øtantius reygned. which allthough Baronius and Spondanus doe not ≈øo well allowe vpon Eu≈øebius his words, in all places of the we≈øt, becau≈øe as they alleidge, Con≈øtantius neither pre≈øently would, nor could be again≈øt the Edicts of the Emperors ≈øtill lyuing, when he him≈øelf remained in Britaine in the end of the world, and Italy was then full of warrs. But Eu≈øebius writeth not this Sozomen. l. 1. c. 6. ≈øingularly, but Sozomen and others te≈øtifie as much: that when the Churches of God were per≈øecuted in all other parts of the world, onely Con≈øtantius graunted libertie of Con≈øcience to the Chri≈øtians vnder him, Cum Eccle≈øiae in
alijs orbis partibus per≈øecutionum fluctibus iactarentur ≈øolus Con≈øtantius Con≈øtantini pater permi≈øit Chri≈øtianis pote≈øtatem liber√® ≈øuam religionem excolendi: And againe generally of all Chri≈øtian Churches in the part of his Empyre, Eccle≈øiae quae erant in e√¢ Imperij parte quae Con≈øtantino parebat, in ≈øumma laetitia vitam egerunt. And were not onely quiet vnder him, but thus liued in greate Ioy, and did encrea≈øe being honored and rewarded by him: creueruntque in dies magis magisque tam beneuoli, tamque pacis & concordiae ≈øtudio≈øi beneficijs ornatae.

6. And relating his experiment to proue con≈øtant Chri≈øtians before remeÃÑ bred, and how he admitted ≈øuch for his neare≈øt friends, and Coun≈øailers, in amicorum atque adeo Con≈øiliariorum numero habere decreuit. He gathereth from hence that the Gaules, Britans and others vnder him were by him exempted from the penall Lawes of the per≈øecutors, he taking them away, and making them fru≈øtrate in his Dominions, Hinc capere coniecturam licet, neque Gallis, neque Britannis, neque alijs, qui circiter montes Pyrenaeos ad Oceanum Occidentalem v≈øque incolunt contra leges vi≈øum e≈ø≈øe Chri≈øtianam Religionem, dum adhuc vita ≈øuppeditabat Constantio, profiteri. And the obiections which Baronius maketh, doe rather proue then improue the quietnes of Chri≈øtians in this Nation, when Con≈øtantius was heare. For fir≈øt the vnquietnes of Italy rather helped, then hindered our peace, our Per≈øecution proceeding from thence, now not able to per≈øecute vs, nor take reuendge of Con≈øtantius for protecting vs. And his being in Britaine, he being ≈øo friendly allwayes to Chri≈øtians as Baronius often confe≈ø≈øeth, mu≈øt much more procure ea≈øe and freedome to our Chri≈øtians, where there was noe man of power to contradict or re≈øi≈øt it, Con≈øtantius being both King and Emperor heare, and the kingdome of Britaine a Chri≈øtian kingdome: Therefore how≈øoeuer his rea≈øons make doubt of ≈øome other places, who≈øe ≈øtate and condition was not like vnto ours, of Britaine Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. c. 8. Galf. Mon. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 5. c. 5. 6. Manu≈øc. Galli. antiq. c. 28. 29. Virun. l. 5. Hi≈øt. Harding Chron. cap. 57. 58. 59. 60. Henricus Hunting. Hi≈øt. l. 1. Socrates Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 1. Eu≈ø. l. 1. Vit. CoÃÑ ≈øtantini c. 9. Theodoret. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 1. c. 24. they doe not moue any que≈øtion of the quiet thereof in cau≈øe of Religion, but e≈øtablish and confirme it. And therefore our owne be≈øt allowed and auntient Hi≈øtorians S. Bede, Galfridus, Henry of Huntington, an old French Manu≈øcript, ViruÃÑnius, Harding, & others ≈øetle Con≈øtantius heare in Britaine after all our Per≈øecution ended, & nothing but all fauour to Chr≈øtiaÃÑs heare in his time, and not onely a tolleration graunted, but publicke profe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øtianitie generally allowed, & by Regall and Imperiall warrant of Con≈øtantius v≈øed, & exerci≈øed, as shall immediatly more plainely appeare in the next Chapter.

7. And if we had rather harken to forreine writers in or neare that time, we haue ≈øufficient warrant, not onely that he recalled him≈øelf from the worship of the Pagan gods, as diuers are witne≈ø≈øes: Con≈øtantius ≈øe √† Deorum Gentilium veneratione auocauerat, But as Eu≈øebius and others te≈øtifie of him, he gaue free power and licence to all vnder him to exerci≈øe Chri≈øtian Religion without any mole≈øtation: illis qui ab ip≈øo regebantur, liberam verae in Deum religionis ≈øine Con≈øtantine the greate first in≈øtructed in Chri≈øtian Religion in Britaine. mole≈øtia excolendae permi≈øit pote≈øtatem. And this as he writeth, when the greate≈øt Per≈øecution was in other places. And had care to in≈øtruct his ≈øonne Con≈øtantine the Greate, which he left his Heyre, in the ≈øame faith as we may ea≈øely conclude, from the words of Con≈øtantine him≈øelfe regi≈øtred by Theodoret: huius Dei adiutus ope, or≈øus ab vltimis Oceani finibus vniuer≈øum orbem terrarum Sozom. Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 5. Chronicon Mona≈øt. Abingdonien. apud Nich. Harpesfeld. Hi≈øt. Eccl. 10. ≈øaecul. p. 203. c. 9. firmae ≈øalutis ≈øpe erexi, that eueÃÑ from the ends of the Ocean (meaning Britaine) he was a≈ø≈øi≈øted by God. And Sozomen ≈øaith, it is euidently knowne vnto all men that greate Con≈øtantine was fir≈øt in≈øtructed in the Chri≈øtian faith amoÃÑg the Britans, Apud Britannos liquid√≤ con≈øtat inter omnes Con≈øtantinum primum religione Chri≈øtiana imbutum. And the Cronicle of Abington neare Oxford te≈øtifieth
he was brought vp in that old Abbey, which we mu≈øt needs a≈ø≈øcribe to his parents Con≈øtantius and Helena. And we find not any other but Con≈øtantius, except we will apply it to King Coel, and then it was receaued and approued by him, who heare in Britaine cau≈øed the per≈øecutors to be putt to death, and the Per≈øecution therevppon cea≈øed, as S. Gildas writeth: emarce≈øcentibus Gild. l. de conq. Brit. c. 8. nece ≈øuorum Authorum nefarijs Decretis: For this mu≈øt needs be applied to Per≈øecutors in Britaine, and not to the Tyrants Diocle≈øian, and Maximinian, the Per≈øecution heare endeed longe before their death, as is proued before, and neither of them nor any other Emperor, but Con≈øtantius hauing power or commaund heare at this time. And herevpon our Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians them≈øelues thus te≈øtify of him, Constantius abolished the ≈øuper≈øtition of the Stowe & Howes Hi≈øt. tit. RomaÃÑs in Con≈øtantius, & Con≈øtantine. Gentils in his Dominians. So that afterward Britaine felt no per≈øecutions. Con≈øtantius renounced the Idolatrie of the Gentils.

div.head: THE II. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE FINDING THE HOLY CROSSE by S. Helen in Con≈øtantius his time. His Chri≈øtian life and death, and crowning his ≈øonne Con≈øtantine Emperour heare in Britaine.

div.p:
1. I Haue shewed before out of S. Gildas and others, a≈øwell that the Per≈øecution, called Diocle≈øians, did not continue ten yeares in this kingdome; in one place he termeth it, Per≈øecutionem Diocle≈øiani Tyranni nouennem: the nine yeares Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian the Tyrant; and in the next Chapter not wholly ten yeares longe, bilu≈øtro turbinis necdum expleto: As al≈øo that it wholly ended Gildas l. de excid. & coÃÑque≈øt. Brit. c. 7. 8. in the time of King Coel, tho≈øe Per≈øecutours then hauing no power or Authoritie heare, and ≈øo together with their other ouerruling and commanding Decrees, the bloody Edicts of per≈øecuting Chri≈øtians heare were vtterly extinct, and made inualidate; and as is euident before neuer being renewed, but alltogether omitted by Con≈øtantius, this greate friend of Chri≈øtians: ≈øuch of this Nation were fully and vndoubtedly thereby re≈øtored to their auncient liberties, Priuiledges, and Immunities in matters of Religion, if Con≈øtantius and Helen our Emperour and Empre≈ø≈øe, King and Queene had then giuen no further and expre≈ø≈øe approbation vnto them: Which we may not rea≈øonably call into que≈øtion, when we remember their ab≈øolute and independing regall right and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion without contradiction, they had in this kingdome, the naturall loue and affection they bore vnto it, and that to them, with their Religious care and de≈øire they had to defend and aduance Chri≈øtian Religion, euen in times, and places when, and where they were not ≈øo enabled, nor drawne therto with ≈øo many and ≈øtrong bands of dutie, and affection. We haue heard before, that other Churches vnder his Empire were endowed by his benefits and munificence, thereby they lyued in greate Ioy, and encrea≈øed; the choy≈øe≈øt Chri≈øtians were his deare≈øt Friends and made his Councellors; His whole Court was like a Church. And except we should with very much boldnes deny the te≈øtimony of S. Eu≈øebius then Pope, affirming that
the holy Cro≈ø≈øe was found in the time of his Papacy, and he in≈øtituted the Eu≈øeb. Epi≈øt. 3. ad Epi≈øcopus Tu≈øcul. & Campaniae Tom. 1. Concil. Gratian. can. Crucis di≈øt. 3. de con≈ø. Martin. Polon. ≈øupputat. col. 67. in Eu≈øeb. Papa. Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. in Con≈øtantio. Florent. Wigor. Chron. in Galer. Regino Chron. an. 243. Fea≈øt of the Inuention thereof, Gratian and Martinus ≈øaying the like, S. Dama≈øus or Learned Ana≈øta≈øius, S. Marianus, Florentius Wigorn: Regino, and diuers others which playnely write, that the holy Cro≈ø≈øe was found in their dayes: ≈øub huius tempore inuenta est crux Domini ≈øub Con≈øtantio patre Con≈øtantini Magni, vt in ge≈øtis Romanorum Pontificalibus habetur, ita ≈øub huius tempore inuenta e≈øt crux Domini 5. Nonis Maij, we mu≈øt not neglect this opinion.

2. And this is not to deny, or que≈øtion that publike, and famous (in Hi≈øtoryes) Solemnitie about the holy Cro≈ø≈øe, in the dayes of Con≈øtaÃÑtine the greate, better allowing ≈øuch Chri≈øtian A≈ø≈øemblyes & Fe≈øtiuities in ≈øo honorable manner, then the times yet permitted, but to reconcile ≈øo many worthie Authours, giue Con≈øtantius and S. Helen their due in their profe≈ø≈øing their loue of Chri≈øtian Religion, before Con≈øtantine either reigned, or was borne; and ≈øome of the≈øe Authours, which I haue Cited, as namely Marianus Scotus, ≈øetteth downe both the≈øe Acts of deuotious as before, and the other in the dayes of S. Helen found the holy Cro≈ø≈øe in the time of Con≈øtaÃÑtius, before the reigne of Con≈øtantine her ≈øonne. Con≈øtantine, after the death of Con≈øtantius, citing diuers Authours for the≈øe di≈øtinct and diuers Actions of Religion. And it is but a weake obiection, derogatorie to the honour of S. Helen, and this Nation which a late writer maketh when he ≈øaith; te≈øte Eu≈øebio libro 3. cap. 46. con≈øtat Helenam po≈øt Con≈øtantinum Chri≈øtianam Religionem amplexatam e≈ø≈øe. Si igitur hoc tempore Eu≈øebij Papae Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. an. 325. col. 300. Con≈øtantinus necdum Christianus fuerit, quomodo Helena DeoruÃÑ adhuc cultrix inueniendae crucis Chri≈øti adeo ≈øtudio≈øa fui≈ø≈øe potuit? as Eu≈øebius witne≈ø≈øeth in the 46. Chapter of his third booke (he meaneth of the life of Con≈øtantine) it is euident,
Obiection.
that Helen embraced Chri≈øtian Religion after Con≈øtantine. Therefore if in the time of Seuer. Binius Annot. in Epi≈øt. 3 Eu≈øebij Papae Tom. 1. Concil. Pope Eu≈øebius, Con≈øtantine was not a Chri≈øtian, how could Helena a worshipper of the Pagan Gods be ≈øo carefull to finde the cro≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt. But Eu≈øebius allthough a ≈øufficient and greater pray≈øer of Con≈øtantine, more then of his Mother (in all An≈øweare. Hi≈øtories a wonderfull holy Saint) ≈øpeaketh there of deuotion, pietate, & not fir≈øt in≈øtruction in Religion, which as I haue shewed before, he receaued from her, and his Father Con≈øtantius in or before Pope Eu≈øebius time, and S. Helen was euen from her youth (as I haue proued froÃÑ Antiquities) in≈øtructed in Chri≈øtian Religion. And if the≈øe ≈øo many and learned Antiquaries should be deceaued in this particular Religious Act of Con≈øtaÃÑtius or Helena, or them both: Yet they yeeld vs ≈øo many Authorities and ≈øo able to be of opinion, that Con≈øtantius a friend and re≈øtorer of Christian Religion in Britaine and other places al≈øo. Con≈øtantius, and S. Helen both were able to giue, and actually gaue their greate≈øt regall both allowance and help for the publike exerci≈øe & aduancement of Chri≈øtian Religion to Britaine, where no impediment or hindederance can be pretended they being ab≈øolute commaunders heare.

3. And diuers euen of this Nation haue before deliuered, that this our now King and Emperour did particularly place S. Taurinus Archbishop in Yorke, wherein allthough they be mi≈øtaken (if they vnder≈øtand S. Taurinus Bishop of Eureux con≈øecrated by S. Clement Pope, neither the time nor place allowing) yet we cannot ≈øafely ≈øay, but he might, or did place ≈øome other of that name there, and if both this should faile, yet ≈øo many more Authorities concurre, that Con≈øtantius gaue con≈øent and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to the publicke re≈øtitution of Religion heare in his time. For this, we haue the warrant of our mo≈øt auntient and approued Antiquaries S. Gildas, and S. Bede, and after them Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter with others. S. Gildas writeth, that before the Per≈øecution had bene heare ten yeares, the wicked Decrees again≈øt Chri≈øtians were annulled and fru≈øtrate, and all the ≈øeruants of Christ, as after a longe winter night with
ioyfull eyes receaue the cleare light of the heauenly ayre, they renew their Churches which were throwne downe to the ground, they found, build and perfect others in honor of their holy Martyrs, and as it were ≈øet forth euery where their victorious en≈øeignes, celebrate fe≈øtiuall dayes, offer ≈øacrifice with a pure heart and mouth, all of them reioyce as children cherished in the lapp of their mother the Church: bilu≈øtro ≈øupradicti turbinis necdum ad integrum expleto, emarce≈øcentibusque nece ≈øuorum Authorum nefarijs decretis laetis luminibus omnes Christi Tyrones qua≈øi po≈øt hyemalem ac prolixam noctem, temperiem, lucemque ≈øerenam aurae coele≈øtis excipiunt, renouant Eccle≈øias ad ≈øolum v≈øque destructas, Ba≈øilicas Sanctorum Martyrum fundant, construunt, perficiunt ac velut victricia ≈øigna pa≈øsim propalunt, dies fe≈øtos celebrant, ≈øacra mundo corde, oreque conficiunt, omnes exultant filij gremio ac ≈øi matris Eccle≈øiae confoti. S. Bede ≈øaith, that ≈øo ≈øoone as the tempe≈øt of Per≈øecution cea≈øed, the Chri≈øtians which had hidden them≈øelues in woods, De≈øarts and ≈øecret Dens pre≈øently came forth and shewed them≈øelues in publick, doing tho≈øe publick works of Chri≈øtian Religion, which S. Gildas before remembred, Vbi turbo Bed. Hi≈øt. Eccl. lib. 1. c. 8. per≈øecutionis quieuit, progre≈øsi in publicum fideles Chri≈øti, qui ≈øe tempore di≈øcriminis ≈øiluis ac de≈øertis, abditi≈øue ≈øpeluncis occultauerant, renouant Eccle≈øias ad ≈øolum v≈øque de≈øtructas, Ba≈øilicas Martyrum fundant, And the re≈øt as S. Gildas before, and writeth plainely, that this was done in the time of Con≈øtantius, and that he died heare, while the≈øe things were thus in Acting, His Temporibus Con≈øtantius, qui viuente Diocle≈øiano Galliam Hi≈øpaniamque regebat, vir ≈øummae man≈øuetudinis & ciuilitatis in Britannia mortem obijt. The Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter hath Matth. We≈øtm. An. 313. the ≈øame words with S. Bede of this publike profe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øtian Religion heare, pre≈øently vppon the ending of the Per≈øecution, during ten yeares, elap≈øis decem annis. And addeth that then the Church of S. Alban was builded to his honor within ten yeares of his Martyrdome, decem annis po≈øt pa≈øsionem eius elap≈øis, and yet temporum Chri≈øtianorum ≈øerenitate in the quiet of Chri≈øtian times heare, which by that is ≈øayd before, mu≈øt needs be in the dayes of Con≈øtantius.

4. Likewi≈øe we find in the Antiquities of the old Church of Winche≈øter, Manu≈øcr. Antiq. Eccl. Winton. Marian. Scot. an. 306. Martin. Pol. An. 307. Manu≈øcr. Ant. Gall. ann. 306. Matth. We≈øt. ann. 305. 307. Baron. & Spondan. an. 306 Gordan. an. 306. Iacob. Grynaeus annot. in c. 15. l. 1. Eu≈øeb. de Vit. Con≈øtantini Anno. 308. Henric. Hunt. l. 1. Hi≈øt. in Diocletian. & Con≈øtantio. Regino Chron. l. 1. in Con≈øtant. an. 253. Stowe & Howes ≈øup. Hi≈øt. in Con≈øtantius. that being de≈øtroyed with the re≈øt in this late Per≈øecution, it was perfectly reedified in the yeare of Chri≈øt 309. and ≈øo either was in building, or warranted to be builded in the dayes of Con≈øtantius, then or ≈øo lately before by all accompts lyuing and reigning heare, that it could not be done without his warrant, or allowance. The like we ≈øay of the Churches of S. Iulius, and S. Aaron, and other Martyrs of that time, and all both Cathedrall Churches, and others de≈øtroyed heare by Maximian that mo≈øt cruell horrible faced man, as Henry of Huntington calleth him: Maximinianus vir crudeli≈øsimus & vultu horrendus, after who≈øe leauing the Empire, Chri≈øtians were quiet heare, as he ≈øaith, and re≈øtored to their former liberties. And as Regino writeth, not onely in Britaine, but generally where he ruled, both Bishops were re≈øtored to their priuate Sees, and many other things graunted for the profit of Chri≈øtian Religion: Constantij Temporibus pace Eccle≈øijs reddita, Epi≈øcopi priuatis ≈øedibus restituuntur, & alia plura Christianae Religioni profutura. And particularly ≈øaith, that the Mona≈øtery of Treuers was begun in his time. Then much more in Britaine, where he was both ab≈øolute Emperour and King to commande, and no man daring to re≈øi≈øt him. To this our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries haue giuen ≈øufficient allowance, when they graunted vnto vs, that Con≈øtantius abolished the ≈øuper≈øtition of the Gentils in his Dominions, e≈øpecially in Britaine, where he now liued King and Emperor, and ≈øo in abolishing the Pagans Rites, and ob≈øeruances
for di≈ølike of them, and loue to Chri≈øtian Religion, mu≈øt needs for his short time be an extraordinary Aduancer thereof. But when he had thus The death of Con≈øtantius in Britaine: & his great loue then of Chri≈øtians and that Religion. happily begun this holy worke in reparing the ruines of the Church of Chri≈øt in this kingdome, and before he could bring it to due, and his de≈øired perfection, he fell ≈øick at the Citie of Yorke, where ≈øoone after he decea≈øed. Yet in this short time of his ≈øicknes, his greate≈øt care was to leaue and commit this his charge both concerning his Empire, and this kingdome to his elde≈øt ≈øonne Con≈øtantine now liuing, ≈øonne of S. Helen, who as he hoped for many rea≈øons, would be mo≈øt ready and willing to maintaine and defend true Religion, and with Iu≈øtice gouerne his ≈øubiects.

5. And to this happy choi≈øe, as both Zonoras and Pomponius Laetus doe Zonaras Annal. Tom. 2. in Con≈øtantino. Pomp. Laet. Rom. Hi≈øt. comp. in Con≈øtaÃÑ tino Max. Eu≈øeb. l. 1. de Vit. Con≈øtantini c. 18. Iac. Grynaeus annot. in eum locum. plainely te≈øtifie before, and Eu≈øebius and others ≈øufficiently in≈øinuate, he was admonished and iu≈øtructed by Gods direction, and an Ange, Ilas is before related. Which is confirmed by the effect and euent it≈øelfe, not onely of the generall e≈øtablishing of Chri≈øtian Religion in the world by Con≈øtantine in the time of his Empire, but his extraordinary and Miraculous pre≈øeruation before he came vnto it, and at this very time of his Fathers ≈øicknes ≈øtrangely e≈øcaping the Tyrants hands in Italy, and comming ≈øafely to his ≈øick Father Con≈øtantius at Yorke in our Britaine, by the greate prouidence of God, as Eu≈øebius noteth, who had often pre≈øerued him, to bringe him hither ≈øo longe and dangerous a Iourney at that very time, to ≈øucceede his Father, Deus omnia eius cau≈øa faciebat, prouide prospiciens, vt in tempore praesto e≈ø≈øet ad Patri ≈øuccedendum. Eu≈øeb. Vit. CoÃÑ≈øt. l. 1. c. 14. And this Authour immediately addeth: for pre≈øently when Con≈øtantine had e≈øcaped the ≈øtratagems of the deceipts, he came with all speed to his Father and Cap. 15. ≈øupr. after a longe ≈øpace of time which he had bene ab≈øent from him, pre≈øented him to his ≈øight at that moment Con≈øtantius was ready to dye: but when contrary to all hope he ≈øaw his ≈øonne, lepinge out of his bedd, he embraced him, ≈øaying, that he had now ca≈øt that out of his mynde, which onely troubled him at the point of death, which was the ab≈øence of his ≈øonne: And therefore did erne≈øtly pray and giue thanks for it to God: affirming that now he rather de≈øired to dye then lyue, and ≈øetting him≈øelfe in the mid≈øt of his children, and in his place lying vpon his kingly bedd, giuing ouer the Inheritance of his kingdome to his elde≈øt ≈øonne departed this life. Thus hath Eu≈øebius then liuing, in that time. Our Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians citing other auncient writers Hollin≈ø. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 28. 27. cit. Eutr. Sext. Aurel. Vict. Niceph. Tripart. Hi≈øt. not differing from Eu≈øebius, thus tran≈ølate and epitomate this Hi≈øtory from them, While≈øt Constantine remayned at Rome, in manner as he had bene a pledge with Galerius in his Fathers time, fledd from thence, and with all po≈øt ha≈øte returned to his Father into Britaine, killing or hewghing by the way, all ≈øuch hor≈øes as were appointed to ≈øtand at Innes, readie for ≈øuch as should ryde in po≈øt, lea≈øt being pur≈øued, he should haue bene ouertaken, and brought backe againe, by ≈øuch is might be ≈øent to pur≈øue him. Con≈øtantius while≈øt he lay on his death-bedd, ≈øomewhat before he departed this life, hearing that his ≈øonne Con≈øtantine was come, and e≈øcaped from the Emperours Diocle≈øian and Maximian, with whome he remained as a Pledge, he receaued him with all Ioy, and ray≈øing him≈øelfe vp in his bedd, in pre≈øence of his other ≈øonnes and Coun≈øellors, with a greate number of other people, and ≈øtrangers that were come to vi≈øit him, he ≈øett the Crowne vpon his ≈øonnes heade, and adorned him with other Imperiall Robes and garments, executing as it were him≈øelfe the ConstaÃÑtius crowneth Constantine his ≈øonne Emperor, and prophe≈øieth how he should aduaunce Chri≈øtian ReligioÃÑ. office of an Herald, and withall spake the≈øe words vnto his ≈øaide ≈øonne, and to his Coun≈øellors there about him: Now is my death to mee more wellcome, and my departure hence more plea≈øant: I haue heare a lardge Epitaph and Monument of buriall, to wit mine owne ≈øonne, and one whome in earth I leaue to be Emperour in my place,
which by Gods good help shall wype away the teares of the Chri≈øtians, and reuenge the crueltie exerci≈øed by Tyrants. This I reckon to chaunce vnto me in ≈øteed of mo≈øt felicity. Thus carefull was this holy Emperour euen at his death, to aduance the honour of Chri≈øt. Thus he did prophe≈øying how his ≈øonne after him should aduance Chri≈øtian Religion, now by his Father declared Emperour, but as Eu≈øebius writeth, longe before de≈øigned to that dignitie by God, King of all, Eu≈øeb. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. l. 5. c. 14. Augu≈øtus multo antea ab ip≈øo Deo Rege omnium declaratus fuit.

6. This renowned Emperour Con≈øtantius died by diuers in the 306. yeare of Chri≈øt, by others in the 307. & by ≈øome in the yeare 308. as is meÃÑtioned before, & by all at ≈øuch time, that as I haue proued already, it mu≈øt needs be he which amoÃÑg the Roman Emperours fir≈øt gaue order and warrant for the re≈øtoring & ree≈øtablishing Chri≈øtiaÃÑ ReligioÃÑ heare in Britaine after the de≈øolatioÃÑ thereof by Diocle≈øian & Maximian, & died happily & mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øedly: faelicem acter Eu≈øeb. ≈øupr. l. 8. c. 14. beatum vitae finem con≈øecutus. And was ≈øo renowned, that euen by the Pagans he was accoÃÑpted a God: ac primus apud eos in numerum deoruÃÑ relatus. And had all Con≈øtantius buried as a Chri≈øtiaÃÑ in Yorke with greate and Emperiall honor. honour after his death giuen vnto him which belonged to an Emperour, Cuncto po≈øt mortem Imperatori debito potitus e≈øt honore. He was mo≈øt honorably and Chri≈øtian like buried, in the Citie of Yorke, Con≈øtantine his ≈øonne the new Emperour pre≈øent at his funerall, going before his corps with an infinite number of people and Souldiars, attending with all honour and pompe, ≈øome Eu≈øeb. l. 1. de Vita Con≈øtantini c. 16. going before, others following with mo≈øt ≈øweete harmony of ≈øinging, Con≈øtantinus paterna purpura indutus magna paternorum amicorum turba eum comitante, funeri praeiuit, patremque produxit: quinetiam populi infinita multitudine, militumque con≈øtipanti agmine partim antecedentium, partim ≈øub≈øequentium, genitorem ≈øancti≈øsimum cum omni ≈øplendore & maxima pompa extulit: fau≈øtis acclamationibus, ≈øuaui hymnorum concentu, omnes beati≈øsimum illum celebrant. This was the Eu≈øeb. ≈øupr. end which God shewed of this Emperours godly and Religious manners and life euidently to all people then liuing, as Eu≈øebius witne≈ø≈øeth then al≈øo liuing: hunc morum vitaeque pie & religio≈øe ad virtutem in≈øtitutae exitum e≈ø≈øe, in Imperatore Con≈øtantio, vniuer≈øo generi mortalium qui no≈øtra memoria vixerunt, Deus euidenter monstrauit. And calleth him, as before, Sancti≈øsimum: mo≈øt holy: which he a learned Chri≈øtian Bishop could not giue to any but an holy profe≈ø≈øed Chri≈øtian, in his knowledge or Iudgment: and therefore atrributeth ≈øo much to Con≈øtantius in this kinde, that he calleth Con≈øtantine the Gre√†te him≈øelfe, (whome he ≈øo extolleth for his Chri≈øtian Religion, & aduancement thereof) Eu≈øebius Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 8. c. 14. a follower of his Fathers pietie in ≈øuch affaires: paternae pietatis Imitator.

div.head: THE III. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE CORONATION AND CHRISTIAN beginning of Constantine the greate Emperour, and the generall re≈øtoring and profe≈øsion of Chri≈øtian Religion in all places of Britaine then.

div.p:
1. CONSTANTIVS hauing thus honorably ended his dayes, & declared Eu≈øeb. lib. 1. de Vit. Con≈øtantini c. 15. Marian. Sco. in Con≈øtaÃÑt. Martin. Pol. in eod. Con≈øtantine his elde≈øt ≈øonne ≈øucce≈ø≈øor in his Empire, his whole Army doth pre≈øently with mutuall con≈øent & Ioy proclaime him King & Emperour. ExteÃÑpl√≤ ≈øecundo & prospero applau≈øu nouuÃÑ Regem Imperatorem & Augu≈øtum ip≈øa prima voce coÃÑtentius praedicant. CoÃÑ≈øtaÃÑtine proclaymed Emperor in Britaine. And all Nations ≈øubiect to his Fathers Empire were filled with incredible Ioy and vn≈øpeakeable gladnes, that they had without intermi≈ø≈øion ≈øo worthie and renowned an Emperour, Omnes gentes quaeip≈øius ob≈øequebantur Imperio, incredili Eu≈øeb. lib. 1. Vit. Con≈øt. c. 16. laetitia efferuntur, & gaudio pene inexplicabili propterea complentur, quod illu≈øtri & praeclaro Imperatore ne breui≈øsimo quidem temporis momento carui≈ø≈øent. Of the comming of this mo≈øt noble Britan to the Empire, e≈øcaping and pre≈øerued from ≈øo many daungers, and difficulties before, ≈øo generally and ioyfully cho≈øen and accepted, and prouing afterward ≈øo happy a Ruler, Eu≈øebius ≈øaith Cho≈øen and de≈øigned thereto by God him≈øelfe. that he was cho≈øen by God him≈øelfe, and that no mortall man could glory of this onely Emperour his aduancement, Con≈øtantinum Principem & Imperatorem, Deus omnium Author, & totius mundi Gubernator, ≈øuo ≈øolum arbitrio delegit: Eu≈øeb. ≈øupr. c. 18. eo con≈øilio vt cum alij omnes Imperatores, hominum ≈øuffragijs, ad eum dignitatis gradum ‚Ä¢ ≈øcendere con≈øueuerint, de hoc Imperatore ≈øolo ad honorem efferendo, nemo mortalis omnino gloriaretur. For allthough he was generally & orderly cho≈øen and accepted by men, yet as the ≈øame Authour writeth, he was Miracoulou≈øly pre≈øerued by God, and by his extraordinary protection brought ≈øafely from all danger to his Father heare in Britaine, old and ready to die, to be inue≈øted in the Empire after him, Con≈øtantius cum ad ≈øummam prope ≈øenectutem prouectus, Eu≈øeb. l. 1. Vit. Con≈øt. c. 12. communi naturae quod debebat, e≈ø≈øet per≈øoluturus, & iam migraturus √® vita, Deus tunc rur≈øus facinus quoddam admirabile eius cau≈øa edidit: qui ei mortem oppetituro ≈øua prouidentia curauit, vt filius eius natu Maximus Con≈øtantinus ad cape≈ø≈øendum Imperium praesto e≈ø≈øet. And ≈øo ≈øoone as he was Emperour, as the ≈øame Authour then lyuing, and well ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ owen vnto, and knowing Con≈øtantine te≈øtifieth, and ≈øo declared by the Armies, as the cu≈øtome was, being cho≈øen of God longe Eu≈øeb. Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. l. 8. c. 14. before to that end, in≈øi≈øted in his Fathers ≈øteps in fauouring and aduancing Chri≈øtian Religion, Huius (Constantij) filius Con≈øtantinus mox atque Imperator Britaine now quiet for Religion. And all holy places ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øtored. perfecti≈øsimus ac Augustus ab exercitibus; & multo antea ab ip≈øo Deo Rege omnium declaratus fuit, paternae erga no≈øtram Religionem pietatis imitator e≈ø≈øe caepit. So that in this part of the world, as Britaine and France, where CoÃÑ≈øtantine ≈øucceeded his Father, and now reigned, there was no Per≈øecution v≈øed again≈øt Chri≈øtians, but all fauour and Indulgence towards them. And that a≈ø≈øertion Eu≈øeb. in Chronic. Floren. Wigorn. in Chron. Mar. Scot. aetat. 6. l. 2. in Con≈øtaÃÑt. of diuers Hi≈øtorians both of this and other Nations, which affirmeth that the Per≈øecution begun by Diocle≈øian and Maximinian, did continue after their for≈øaking the Empire, and vntill the ≈øeuenth yeare of the Reigne of Con≈øtantine,
v≈øque ad annum ≈øeptimum Con≈øtantini, is to be vnder≈øtood of tho≈øe parts, which vntill about that time were not vnder the Rule of Con≈øtantine, but to Galerius, Seuerus and Maxentius Per≈øecutours, and ≈øo Florentius, Marianus and others expownd it. And it can haue no other con≈øtruction to be true: for euident it is in Hi≈øtories that not onely from the beginning of the Reigne of Con≈øtantine, but in his Fathers time, all Chri≈øtians vnder their gouernment were free from Per≈øecution: And ≈øo ≈øoone as Con≈øtantine had conquered Maxentius and was ≈øole and ab≈øolute Emperour, all Chri≈øtians in the world vnder him were deliuered from Per≈øecution, and ≈øett at libertie euen publickly to profe≈ø≈øe their Religion. And from his fir≈øt entrance into the Empire and to be King of Britaine, the Chri≈øtians heare in this Nation did not onely enioy freedome and Immunitie from all penalties, and Per≈øecution again≈øt Chri≈øtian Churches and Mona≈øteries that were ruinated, re≈øtored, and new builded. Religion, but, as in the time of his Father, made, and freely had publike exerci≈øe and Profe≈ø≈øion thereof, as our old Churches reedified, new builded and erected, Bishops, Prei≈øts, and all Cleargie and Religious men re≈øtored to their former quiet, Reuenewes, honours and dignities.

2. Of this we haue diuers te≈øtimonies and examples in particular yet left vnto vs, as out of the old Annalls of Winche≈øter, where we finde of that old Church builded in the time of King Lucius, and de≈øtroyed in the late Per≈øecutioÃÑ, the Church of Winche≈øter builded in the time of King Lucius and hallowed and dedicated Annal. Eccle≈ø. Winton. Godwin Catalog. of Bishop Wince≈øter in initio. October 29. 189. By Faganus and Damianus Bishops, among≈øt the re≈øt at this time of Diocle≈øian, went to wracke, the buildings thereof being ruinated, and made euen with the ground, and the Monkes and all the officers belonging vnto it, either ≈ølaine, or enforced to fly for the pre≈øent time, in the yeare 309. the Church a fore≈øaid was againe reedified, and that with ≈øuch wonderfull forwardne≈ø≈øe and Zeale, as within one yeare and thirty dayes, both it and all the Edifices belonging vnto it, as chambers, and other buildings for the Monkes and officers, were quite finished in very ≈øeemely and conuenient manner. The 15. day of March following, it was againe hallowed and dedicated vnto the honor and memory of Amphibalus, that had ≈øuffered death for Chri≈øt in the late Per≈øecution, by Con≈øtans Bishop of Winche≈øter, at te reque≈øt of Deodatus Abbot of this new erected Mona≈øtery. It is euident by this Relation, and that is ≈øaide before, that this holy worke ≈øo publike and with freedome and zeale was quite finished in the time of Con≈øtantine his being heare before he went hence again≈øt Maxentius. And yet we ≈øee both Bishop, Abbot, Prei≈øts and Religious men publikly and honorably re≈øtored to their former condition. The Church with vn≈øpeakable deuotion builded, and dedicated to that holy Saint and Martyr, which in the late Per≈øecution was mo≈øt hated by the enemies of Chri≈øt. So I ≈øay of the Church of S. Alban, Eccle≈øia, a Church, as S. Bede writeth, mirandi operis, atque eius martyrio condigna extructa e≈øt, a Church Bed. Eccl. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 7. Mat. We≈øt. An. 313. of wonderfull workemanship and worthie of his martyrdome, was builded ≈øo ≈øoone as the Chri≈øtians were heare at quiet, Redeunte temporum Chri≈øtianorum ≈øerenitate. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter hath the ≈øame words, and explaneth this time of the quiet of Chri≈øtians heare, when this Church was ≈øo ≈øumptuou≈øly builded, to haue bene ten yeares after his Martyrdome, decem ≈øcilicet annis po≈øt pa≈øsionem eius elap≈øis: the perfect finishing whereof he ≈øetteth downe to haue bene in the ≈øame yeare, in which Con≈øtantine went from hence towards Rome again≈øt Maxentius. Which was by him in the 6. yeare of Con≈øtantine, and before the generall cea≈øing of Per≈øecution in other places. Con≈øtantine not being ab≈øolute and ≈øole Emperor vntill his victory again≈øt Maxentius, nor the generall quiet then pre≈øently en≈øuing. Both S. Bede and the Monke of
We≈øtmin≈øter write, that in their ≈øeuerall times, often curing of infirmities and Bed. & Matth. ≈øupr. other miracles were wrought there: in quo videlicet loco v≈øque ad hanc diem curatio infirmorum, & frequentium operatio virtutum celebrari non de≈øunt. The old Churches of S. Iulius, and S. Aaron martyred in the late Per≈øecutio ‚Ä¢ , in the Citie of Caerlegion, deriue their auntient Foundation from this time. So doe many others founded in honor of ≈øeuerall Martyrs, then cruelly putt to death, for the name of Chri≈øt. So I affirme of all the Cathedrall Churches Archiepi≈øcopall and Epi≈øcopall which I haue before remembred, with their Particular Sees and Cities founded in the time of King Lucius, and de≈øtroyed in the Per≈øecution of the Tyrants Diocle≈øian and Maximinian, as al≈øo tho≈øe that were not Epi≈øcopall, but ≈øubordinate and inferior ouerthrowne with that tempe≈øt of Per≈øecution: for S. Gildas, S. Bed and others te≈øtifie without exception, that all they which were then pulled downe euen to the ground, were now reedified: renouant Eccle≈øias ad ≈øolum v≈øque de≈øtructas. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter Gild. l. de excid. & conque≈øt. Brit. ca. 8. Bed. Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 8. Mat. We≈øtm. an. 313. plainely writeth that be≈øides the new Churches builded in honor of their late Martyrs of which S. Gildas and S. Bede al≈øo make this memory, Ba≈øilicas Sanctorum Martyrum fundant, con≈øtruunt, perficiunt: The Chri≈øtians heare at this time renewed & builded againe all the Churches dedicated to former Saints, which had bene ≈øo de≈øtroyed and throwne downe to the ground: Sanctorum Eccle≈øias ad ≈øolum v≈øque de≈øtructas renouant.

3. And when we are warranted both by Prote≈øtant and Catholike Antiquaries Matth. Parker. Antiq. Brit. pa. 8. Io. Go≈øcel. Eccl. Hi≈øt. Manu≈øcrip. de Archiep. Can. tuar. prope Init. Manu≈øcr. Gallie. Antiq. cap. 28. al≈øo, that from the beginning of Chri≈øtianitie heare, we had many Abbots, Monkes, and Mona≈øteryes in euery Age, tot tantaque Abbatum, Monachorum, Cenobiorum vetu≈øta nomina quae quouis ≈øeculo extiterunt: And that the≈øe Mona≈øteryes were all de≈øtroyed in Diocle≈øian his Pe≈øecution: we mu≈øt needs a≈ø≈øigne their re≈øtauration to this time, as I haue fir≈øt exemplified before in the old Mona≈øtery of Winche≈øter now reedified with ≈øo greate ≈øpeede and deuotion, the Abbot thereof being called Deodatus. To this I ioyne the Mona≈øtery of Abingdon, allready ≈øpoken of, where this our greate King and Emperour Con≈øtantine, as the old Annalls thereof doe pleade, had his education, when he was young, wherein there where (as it te≈øtifieth further) aboue 500. Chron. Mona≈øt. Abingdon. apud Nich. Harpesf. Eccl. Hi≈øt. ≈øaecul. 10. c. 9. Monkes liuing by the labour of their hands in th ‚Ä¢ woods and De≈øarts adioyning, vpon ≈øon dayes & fe≈øtiuall dayes comming to the Mona≈øtery, be≈øides 60. which did continually abide in the ≈øame, ≈øeruing God there, Quod Monachi ≈øupra quingentos illi fuerant ad≈øcripti, qui per ≈øyluas & loca de≈øerta quae in vicinia fuere, manuum labore victitabant, ad Coenobium ≈øingulis Sabbatis & Dominicis conuenientes, praeter ≈øexaginta qui a≈øsidu√® in ip≈øo Coenobio ver≈øabantur, & quod Con≈øtantinus ille Magnus Abingdoniae educatus fuerit. Therefore we cannot doubt, if we will accept this auntient Record for witne≈ø≈øe, but of all other Mona≈øteries, this greate Emperour had an e≈øpeciall care of re≈øtoring and endowing this his nur≈øing place of education.

4. To this time we may a≈ø≈øigne the reedificing of the noble Mona≈øtery, fir≈øt builded by the Founder Ambrius or Ambry, after called Amsbury in Wiltshire, where at the comming of the Saxons hither there were 300. Religious men, Coenobium trecentorum fratrum in monte Ambrij qui, vt fertur, fundator Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 8. c. 9. eius olim extiterat. Who≈øe foundation being olim, long before the time of the Saxons, argueth it was builded before the time of Diocle≈øian and Maximinian, by them de≈øtroyed, and now re≈øtored. So we may conclude of the Religious hou≈øes both of men and women in Kent and other places renouned heare at the Saxons fir≈øt entrance, euen by our Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians thus
deliuering from Antiquitie: Hengi≈øt ≈ølew the good Archbishop Vocine, and many Stowe & Howes Hi≈øt. Titul. Britans and SaxoÃÑs. in Vortiger. Gul. Malme≈øb. l. de Antiquit. coenob. Gla≈øton. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. Gla≈øton. Eccle≈ø. other Prei≈øts and Religious pur≈øons. All the Churches in Kent were polluted with blood the Nunnes with other Religious par≈øons were by force putt from their hou≈øes and goods. Thus we mu≈øt conceaue of all other Religious hou≈øes, wh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ her of men or women being very many in number, by that which is ≈øaid before, all of them being now repayred and happily againe imployed to their fir≈øt In≈øtitution and holy v≈øe. Whether the old Religious hou≈øe at Gla≈øtenbury is to be accompted in the nuÃÑber of tho≈øe that were de≈øtroyed by Maximinian, and now builded againe by Con≈øtantius and Con≈øtantine, I dare not make ≈øo readie a re≈øolution: likely it is the pouerty of the hou≈øe builded of writhen wands, the penitentiall and eremiticall life tho≈øe Religious there ledd, their place of aboad being ≈øeperate in priuate Cells, and in priuate Cells, and in a wilderne≈ø≈øe, in which kinde of places other Chri≈øtians as before hidd them≈øelues in that Per≈øecution, might both pre≈øerue them in that raging ≈øtorme, and their manner of life con≈øidered now not require reparation. Which both William of Malmesbury in his written Hi≈øtory of the Antiquitie of that holy place, and the old Manu≈øcript Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury ≈øeeme to con≈øent vnto, when they ab≈øolutely deliuer, that from the time of King Lucius vntill the coÃÑming of S. Patrick thither, not ≈øpeaking of the lea≈øt intermi≈ø≈øion or di≈øcontinuance, there continually rema ‚Ä¢ ned a Succe≈ø≈øion of 12. Eremits in that Iland, Multi alij ≈øuccedentes, ≈øemper tamen in numero duodenario per multa annorum curricula v≈øque ad aduentum ≈øancti Patricij Hibernen≈øium Apo≈øtoli in memorata In≈øula perman≈øerunt.

div.head: THE IV. CHAPTER.
