argument.p: OF CONSTANTINE HIS PROFESSION of Chri≈øt, his miraculous victories again≈øt his Pagan Enemies, re≈øtoring and e≈øtablishing Christian Religion, and exalting the Profe≈ø≈øors thereof in all his Empire.

div.p: 1. WHEN Con≈øtantine had reigned but a short time Con≈øtantine in Britaine prepareth Wars again≈øt the Infidell per≈øecutor. in Britaine, and France, and ≈øuch We≈øterne parts, as his Father before him po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, Maxen ‚Ä¢ ius being proclaimed Emperour in Italy, Rome, and other places, and falling to Tyranny and v≈øurpation, putting many Eu≈øeb. l. 1. de Vit. Con≈øt. ca. 20. 21. Socrat. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. l. 1. c. 1. Otto Frigen. Chron. l. 4. c. 1. Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 5. c. 7. Pont. Vir. l. 5. Hi≈øt. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 312. Henr. Hunting. l. 1 Hi≈øt. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. l. 4. c. 28. Stowe & Howes Hi≈øt. in Con≈øtaÃÑt. Harding Chron. c. 62. f. 49. Innocents to death, and exiling many both Chri≈øtians and others, diuers euen of the Nobilitie fledd into Britaine vnto Con≈øtantine for ≈øuccour, and releife, complaining of the crueltie and v≈øurpation of Maxentius, humbly inciting and entreating Con≈øtantine, as vndoubted true Heyre to the Empire, euen of that part which Maxentius had intruded him≈øelf vnto, to take armes again≈øt him, and ≈øolely to enioy the Empire. And he was not onely thus ≈øollicited by the Chri≈øtians and other per≈øecuted re≈øorting hither, but by the Romans, which ≈øtill continued at Rome enduring the Tyranny of Maxentius, as ≈øome write in this manner:

lg.l: The Senators of Rome by letters well endit ‚Ä¢
Prayed him to come to Rome as Emperour
For to de≈øtroy Maxence and di≈øinherit ‚Ä¢
Of Chri≈øten folke the cruell Tormentour
Of Chri≈øten faith the cur≈øed confoundoure
For of his birth they ≈øaide it ≈øet thim ≈øoe
Maxence to ≈øtroy that was his Fathers foe.

div.p: Zonoras, Cedrenus, and other forreine Hi≈øtorians write the like in this matter.

2. Hearevpon Con≈øtantine to reuendge the Iniuries done to holy Chri≈øtians, and vn≈øpeakeable wronges to diuers others, euen the mo≈øt Noble of the Romans, & the enormeous ≈øins of this Tirant, for number not to be recompted, Eu≈øeb. l. 1. de Vita Con≈øtant. c. 27. 28. 29. 30. Socrat. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 1. Otto Frigen. Chron. c. 1. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 312. Eutropius in Con≈øtantino. Eu≈øeb. in Chron. Baron. & Spond. Annal. An. 312. and for their horrible and loath≈øome greuiou≈ø≈ønes, to be ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed with ≈øilence, a≈ø≈øembled a greate Army both of Chri≈øtian Britans, and of other Nations ≈øubiect vnto him (by Eutropius) & others with him in the fift, but by the more common opinion, the ≈øixt yeare of his Empire; Hauing entred into the≈øe affaires, the better to procure the help & a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of heauen, as Eu≈øebius with other ≈øtrangers confe≈ø≈øe, before he had his Miraculous vi≈øions, pre≈øently to be remembred, he re≈øolued to haue that true God whom his Father had deuoutely adored, to be onely worshipped and reuerenced. Wherefore by his prayers, he entreated his help, him he prayed, him he be≈øeeched, to declare him≈øelfe vnto him, and a≈øsi≈øt him in this enterpri≈øe: Deum quem Pater ≈øancte adoraui≈ø≈øet, ≈øolum ob≈øeruaÃÑ dum colendumque ≈øtatuit. Quocirca huius opem precibus implorauit, hunc orauit, Con≈øtantine a worshipper of Chri≈øt before his miraculous vi≈øion. hunc obte≈øtatus est, vt tum quinam e≈ø≈øet, ip≈øi vellet ≈øignificare: tum rebus quas apud animum propo≈øui≈ø≈øet, dexteram velut adiutricem porrigere. Otto Frigen≈øis and others al≈øo ≈øtrangers ≈øay, that Con≈øtantine at this time was a Religious Emperour Eu≈øeb. l. 1. Vitae Con≈øtant. c. 21. 22. Otto Frigen. Chron. l. 4. c. 1. Eu≈øeb. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 9. c. 9. and fauourer of Chri≈øtian Religion, when he prepared him≈øelfe for this warr, as I haue shewed before both by our owne and other Hi≈øtoryes: Con≈øtantinus Imperator Religio≈øus, fautorque Chri≈øtianae fidei bellum parat. Eu≈øebius hath ≈øo witne≈ø≈øed, and plainely ≈øaith, he onely receaued, worshiped and prayed vnto the God of his Father, the God of heauen, and Ie≈øus Chri≈øt the Sauiour of all men: Deo caelorum, illiusque verbo, ip≈øo omnium Seruatore Ie≈øu The miraculous apparition of the triumphant ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe to Con≈øtantine. Chri≈øto, auxilij gratia inuocato. Which none but a Chri≈øtian would or could doe. And Eu≈øebius receauing what he wrote from Con≈øtantine, and ≈øwearing that it was true, thus proceedeth in this Hi≈øtory: Imperatori igitur i≈øta precanti, obnixeque flagetanti vi≈øio quaedam diuina & inprimis admirabilis apparuit: &c. Therefore while≈øt the Emperour prayed & earne≈øtly beeched the≈øe things, a diuine & Eu≈øeb. ≈øupr. c. 22. exceeding admirable vi≈øion appeared vnto him: which if any other had reported he would not haue bene ≈øo ea≈øily credited, but ≈øeeing the Emperour him≈øelfe and Conquerour did loÃÑg time after (when he did vouch≈øafe mee acquaintance, and familiar ≈øpeach with him) both tell mee, and by Oathe confirme what he ≈øaide, this very Hi≈øtory which we now commit to writing, no man can be doubtfull, but the narration is certainely to he beleeued, e≈øpecially when we ≈øee the effect to haue giuen testimony thereto. When the ≈øunne had a≈øcended to the mid≈øt of the heauen, and the day a litle inclining to the afternoone, he ≈øaide, he did ≈øee a ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe, made of the brightnes of light manife≈øtly appearing to his eyes in the heauen, ouer the ≈øunne, with an euident In≈øcription which contayned the≈øe words:
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
‚ñ™ In this thow shalt ouer come, a greate admiration fell vpon him, and his whole Army, all of them beholding this wunder. Con≈øtantine earne≈øtly meditating vpon this vi≈øion, in the night following Chri≈øt appeared vnto him in his ≈øleepe with the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe, which he had Cap. 23. ≈øeene in the heauen, and commanded him to make an other ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe like Cap. 24. He ≈øo ≈øoone as he aro≈øe imparted the vi≈øion vnto his Friends, and ≈øent for Artizans, skillfull Engrauers in gold and pretious ≈øtones, and de≈øcribing the shape of the ≈øigne, which he had ≈øeene, vnto
them, commandeth them to make the like of gold and pretious ≈øtones which Image I my≈øelfe haue ≈øeene, for the Emperour him≈øelfe was plea≈øed to shew it vnto mee. Thus farre Eu≈øebius in the next Chapter lardgely ≈øetting downe the proportion, Eu≈øeb. ≈øupr. c. 25. manner and glory of this En≈øigne ≈øo honorably pre≈øerued in that time.

3. To this Relation if it needed more te≈øtimony, Socrates, Zo≈øomen, Otto Socrat. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. l. 1. c. 1. So≈øomen. l. 1. c. 3. Otto Frigen. Chron. l. 4. c. 1. Stowe & Howes Hi≈øt. Tit. RomaÃÑs in Con≈øtantine. and other old forreine Writers are witne≈ø≈øes. And if any man de≈øireth Prote≈øtants con≈øent herein, tho≈øe of our owne Nation doe thus relate this matter: About noone the day ≈øomewhat declyning, Con≈øtantine ≈øaw in the skie a light≈øome Pillar, in forme of a Cro≈ø≈øe, wherein the≈øe words were engrauen: In this ouercome, the which vi≈øion ≈øo amazed the Emperour‚ñ™ that he mi≈øtrusting his owne ≈øight, demanded of them that were pre≈øent, whether they perceaued the vi≈øion: which when all with one a≈ø≈øent had affirmed, the wauering minde of the Emperour was ≈øetled, with this diuine and wonderfull ≈øight. The night following in his ≈øleepe, he ≈øeeth Chri≈øt, which ≈øaith thus vnto him: Frame vnto thy ≈øelfe the forme of a Cro≈ø≈øe after the example of the ≈øigne which appeared vnto thee, and heare the ≈øame again≈øt thy Enemyes, as a fitt Banner or toaken of victory: he being fully per≈øuaded with this Oracle, commandeth the victorious ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe, which as yet is re≈øerued in the Pallace of the Emperour, to be made, and therewith proceedeth forward with greate courage. Eu≈øebius Eu≈øeb. l. 1. de Vit. Con≈øtant. c. 26. and others ≈øay that pre≈øently vpon this vi≈øion Con≈øtantyne concluded with his Chri≈øtian Prei≈øts to haue onely their God which appeared to him, and no other to be worshipped, Con≈øtantinus admiranda illa vi≈øione ob≈øtupefactus, nullum alium Deum, quam qui ip≈øi apparui≈ø≈øet colendum e≈ø≈øe ≈øtatuens, Dei Sacerdotibus ≈øibi tanquam a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øoribus a≈øcitis, ≈øtatuit Deum qui ≈øibi apparui≈ø≈øet omni genere cultus & ob≈øeruantiae venerari.

4. And thus preparing him≈øelfe with all his Army to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe the Tirant, Cap. 31. hauing God the Gouernour of all things for his Patrone before his eyes, and Con≈øtantine his Miraculous Victory by the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe against his Pagan enimyes. calling vpoÃÑ Chri≈øt our Sauiour and helper, placing the Image of the Cro≈ø≈øe, as a ≈øigne of Victory before his armed ≈øouldiars, and guarde, marched foreward with his wbole Army: Con≈øtantinus omni apparatu militari ≈øe ad delendam tyrannidem armauit. Atque Deo omnium moderatore ≈øibi patrono ante oculos propo≈øito, & Chri≈øto Seruatore adiutoreque inuocato, & ≈øalutari ≈øigno tanquam Victoriae Trophaeo ante armatos ≈øuos & ≈øatellites collocato, cum toto exercitu procedit. And Zo≈øim. l. 2. thus tru≈øting in the help of God, his Army not being more theÃÑ halfe the number of Maxentius, this con≈øi≈øting of 170. thou≈øand foote and 18. thou≈øand Panegyric. 2. Con≈øtan. Baron. & Spondan. Annal. an. 312. Eu≈øeb. l. 1. Vit. Con≈øt. c. 31. 32. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 9. c. 9 Zo≈øimus. Baron. Spondan. An. 312 hor≈øe, and that of Con≈øtantine of 90. thou≈øand foote and 8. thou≈øand hor≈øe, and yet (as an old Panegirick hath) Con≈øtantine not fighting with more then the fourth part of his Army again≈øt 100000. of Maxentius men, he ≈øet vpon the Armyes of Maxentius, three of them, and pre≈øently ouerthrew them, and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øing through Italy hard by Rome where Maxentius was, he ≈øo pro≈øecuted him, that in his flight he was with his greate≈øt forces drowned in the Ryuer of Tyber there, Miraculou≈øly (as Eu≈øebius and others te≈øtify,) like to Pharao and his Egiptians in the read Sea ≈øwallowed vp with the waters, by Con≈øtantine re≈øtoreth and aduanceth Chri≈øtian Religion in all places de≈øtroying Idolatry. his owne Engyne of a new deui≈øed Bridge, which he had made of Botes to entrape Con≈øtantine withall, ≈øtrangely fayeling to his owne mi≈øerable de≈øtruction.

5. So ≈øoone as Con≈øtantine had thus obtayned Victory (as Eu≈øebius, Socrates, and others are able witne≈ø≈øes) he gaue thankes to God, who had ≈øo extraordinarily Eu≈øeb. l. 1. de Vit. Con≈øtant. c. 35. Eu≈øeb. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 9. c. 9. Socrates Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 1. 2. pre≈øerued, and a≈ø≈øi≈øted him, he deliuered the Chri≈øtians from per≈øecution, tho≈øe which were bannished he recalled home, the goods of tho≈øe which were confi≈øcate he re≈øtored, tho≈øe which were put in Pri≈øon he deliuered,
the Churches which were de≈øtroyed he cau≈øed to be reedified, all which he effected with greate care & ≈øpeed. His care was wholly fixed in things belonging to the glory of Chri≈øt, he began to execute all the duties of a Chri≈øtian man: to build Churches, and to adorne them with magnificent and renowned Monuments: to shut vp the Pagans Temples, pull them downe, and abandon the Statues erected in them, Constantinus tam ampla beneficia a Deo adeptus, ea officia, quibus ei qui tam benignus in eum extiterat gratias ageret, ≈øedulo obire caepit. Quae huius generis fuere: liberare √† Per≈øecutione Chri≈øtianos: eos qui patria exulauerant, domum reuocare: occlu≈øos in carcere dimittere liberos, his, quorum bona publicata erant, fortunas restituere: dirutas Eccle≈øias denuo erigere. Quae quidem omnia valde propen≈øo ≈øtudio & voluntate tran≈øegit. Cogitationes ≈øuas in illis rebus quae ad Chri≈øti gloriam ≈øpectabant, penitus defixerat, omnia Christiani hominis officia exequia caepit: aedificare de integro Eccle≈øias, eas magnificis & illu≈øtribus monumentis exornare: gentilium delubra occludere, eaque demoliri: Statuas in illis erectas publicare.

6. Eu≈øebius proceedeth further, and ≈øaith, that pre≈øently vpon this Victory Con≈øtantine making his prayers with thanks-giuing to God, Authour of his Eu≈øeb. l. 1. Vita. Con≈øtant. c. 33. Victory, published vnto all in famous In≈øcriptions and Pillers publickly erected the power of the Cro≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt: and euen in the mid≈øt of the Cytie in Con≈øtantine his greate honor to the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe En≈øigne of his victories. the mo≈øt principall place thereof, erected a greate Trophy again≈øt Enemyes, and cau≈øing this ≈øigne of ≈øaluation to be engraued in it, with Characters that could not be blotted out, did demon≈øtrate it was the Propugnacle of the Romans, and all ≈øubiect to the Empyre: and did openly propo≈øe it to be ≈øeene of all men. And his owne Image being erected in a famous place of the Citie & much frequented holding in his haÃÑd a ≈øpeare shaft like a Cro≈ø≈øe, coÃÑmanded this In≈øcription to be engraued on it, in Latine letters: with this ≈øauing ≈øigne, a true token of fortitude, I haue deliuered your Cytie from the Youke of Tyranny, and ≈øetting the Senate and people of Rome at libettie I haue re≈øtored them to their auncient honour and renowne: hanc In≈øcriptionem Latino ≈øermone in eo mandat incidere. Hoc Salutari Signo, vero Fortitudinis Indicio, Ciuitatem Ve≈øtram tyraÃÑ nidis Eu≈øeb. ≈øup. c. 34. Iugo liberaui, & S. P. Q. R. in libertatem vindicans pri≈øtinae amplitudini & ≈øplendori re≈øtitui. And it immediately followeth in Eu≈øebius that Con≈øtantine hearevpon with greate boldnes did openly profe≈ø≈øe and publishe Chri≈øt the ≈øonne of God vnto the Romans, Pius Imperator ita Crucis victricis confe≈øsione nobilitatus, cum magna dicendi libertate filium Dei ip≈øis Romanis palam diuulgare caepit. He al≈øo published in all places his Edict for re≈øtoring all men to their goods, which had bene vniu≈øtly depriued of them, recalling The wonderfull deuotion, care, and expodition Con≈øtantine v≈øed to e≈øtablish Chri≈øtiaÃÑ Religion, and de≈øtroy Idolatry. Cap. 35. Exils and delyuering Pri≈øoners, Imperatorium pa≈øsim diuulgabatur Edictum, quod quidem & his qui erant fortunis ≈øuis spoliati, conce≈øsit authoritatem rebus ≈øuis & facultatibus potiundi: & eos qui iniquum Exilium perpe≈øsi fui≈ø≈øent, ad proprios lares reuocauit: alios item vinculis, omnique periculo ac metu, quibus per Tyranni crudelitatem vexabantur, penitus eripuit: he reuerenced Eccle≈øiasticall men with honour cau≈øing them to ≈øitt at his table, and goe with him whether ≈øoeuer he weÃÑt, and endowed Christian Churches with greate reuenewes, adorning them with very many monuments. All the≈øe and more of ≈øuch thinges of like Religious Chri≈øtian nature this our noble King and Emperour performed pre≈øently vpon his Victoryes again≈øt Maxentius, commonly taken to haue bene in the ≈øeuenth yeare of his Empire, begun fir≈øt in his Country of Britaine.

7. And ≈øo their opinion which before haue told vs, that the Per≈øecution
continued in ≈øome We≈øterne parts ten yeares from the la≈øt mo≈øt cruell Edict of Diocle≈øian, and vntill the ≈øeuenth yeare of Con≈øtantine, v≈øque ad Annum Marian. Scot. Ann. 306. & alij ≈øupr. Idem Marian. an. 312. ≈øeptimum Constantini, is expounded by them≈øelues, affirming, that this generall peace to all Chri≈øtians in the We≈øterne world was procured and granted vnto them by Con≈øtantine in the ≈øeuenth yeare of his Empire, and after the ten yeares of Diocle≈øian his Edict after pro≈øecuted by Maxentius was ended, Anno Con≈øtantini ≈øeptimo, pax Eccle≈øiae reddita √† Con≈øtantino post decennium Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. Ann. 312. Florent. Wigor. in Chron. ann. 299. 306. al. 321. 328. per≈øecutionis. Florentius Wigornien≈øis writeth, that in this yeare S. Helen Mother of Con≈øtantine, then being heare in Britaine wrote to her ≈øonne to per≈øecute the Iewes which denied Chri≈øt, Scrip ≈øit ei ≈øua mater Helena de Britannia vt negantes Chri≈øtum Iudaeos per≈øequeretur. Helen writeth to her ≈øonne out of Britaine to per≈øecute the Iewes per≈øecutors of Chri≈øtians. gratiae 313. in the 313. yeare of Chri≈øt. Martinus polonus ≈øaith, Con≈øtantine became a Chri≈øtian in the yeare 309. and then, both gaue libertie to Chri≈øtians, and cau≈øed Churches to be builded in honour of Chri≈øt, Anno 309. Con≈øtantinus Magnus dictus, Chri≈øtianus effectus, & licentiam dedit Chri≈øtianis libere congregari, & Ba≈øilicas in honore Marian. Scot. an. 312. Baro. & SpoÃÑ dan. An. 312. Harding. Our Countryman Florentius Wigornien≈øis by Dyoni≈øius his computation ≈øetteth it downe three yeares ≈øooner in the yeare 306, Anno 306. pax no≈øtra a Can≈øtantino reddita e≈øt po≈øt annos decem per≈øecutionis. Our English Prote≈øtant Antiquaries will ea≈øely giue a≈ø≈øent to this. A principall man, and named a Bishop among them ≈øaying, that Con≈øtantine learned his Chri≈øtian faith in Britaine of his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Mother S. Helen, and at his going from hence again≈øt Maxentius, behaued him≈øelfe like a Chri≈øtian in the mid≈øt of the Pagans ≈øuper≈øtitions, and honored them which were profe≈ø≈øed Chri≈øtians, Con≈øtantinus a chri≈øtiani≈øsima matre Helena, Chri≈øti fidem edoctus, eos honorabat praecipue qui in Chri≈øtiana Philo≈øophia vitam reclina≈ø≈øent. Vnde ab Oceani finibus nempe Britannis incipiens, ope fretus diuina Religionis curam in medijs ≈øuper≈øtitionum tenebris caepit.

div.head: THE V. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THE MIRACVLOVS BAPTISME OF CON≈øtantine at Rome by S. Silue≈øter Pope. He was an holy and Orthodoxe Emperour to his death, and both in the Greeke Church and with tho≈øe of the Latine honored and stiled an holy Saint.

div.p:
1. HAVING thus cleared our mo≈øt glorious Countryman, and Emperour Con≈øtantine from the Imputation of his ≈øo long delaying his holy Bapti≈øme, as ≈øome haue pretended, and ≈øo neare as I can and dare, propo≈øed the mo≈øt probable time thereof, I mu≈øt now ≈øpeake though more breifely of the Solemnitie it≈øelfe, and his mo≈øt charitable Religious Chri≈øtian Acts and conuer≈øation which en≈øued therevpon. The common opinion concerning Con≈øtantine before his
Bapti≈øme is the ≈øame which the Scripture witne≈ø≈øeth of Naaman the Syrian Prince, though he was greate, honored, valiant, and ritche, yet he al≈øo was a Leper, vir magnus & honoratus, fortis, & diues, ≈øed lepro≈øus, before he was by direction of the Prophet washed and healed in Iordane. Yet greate difference 4. Reg. 5. there was betweene the≈øe two Lepers, of Syria, and Britaine. The Leper of Syria was magnus: greate, but apud Dominum ≈øuum: with his owne lord the King of Syria, cheife commander of his Armies, Princeps militiae Regis Syriae, and he procured the quiet and ≈øafety of Syria, per illum dedit Dominus ≈øalutem Syriae. He was onely clen≈øed from his corporall Lepro≈øie: But our Brittish Leper was cured both in body and ≈øoule, he was not onely greate with a particular King, but a greate, and the greate≈øt King and Emperour, and ≈øo ≈øtiled, Con≈øtantinus Magnus, and Maximus, that euer was in the worlde. He did not onely bringe temporall ≈øafety and quiet to one kingdome and Nation, but both temporall and ≈øpirituall happines and ≈øaluation to the whole Empire, and to all kingdomes.

2. Con≈øtantine being troubled with this Infirmitie, if I may call that ≈øo, which S. Augu≈øtine ≈øaith is a defect of colour, and not of health or integrity of ≈øen≈øes and members: coloris quippe vitium e≈øt, non valetudinis out Integritatis ≈øen≈øuum atque membrorum, and ≈øeeking remedy, yet finding none among his Aug. Quae≈øt. Euangel. l. 1. c. 40. bodily Phi≈øitians, the Pagan Flamens adui≈øed him to make a Bathe in the Capitole and therin washe his body with the warne blood of Infants, Plyny Edictum Con≈øtantini Tom 1. Concil. Act. Sylue≈øtri Papae. Plin. l. 26. c. 1. Adrianus 1. Epi≈øt. ad Con≈øtant. & Iren. Simeon Metaphra≈øt. in Vita S. Sylue≈øtri. Zonaras in Con≈øt. Menol. Graecor. Kalend. Ianuar. Gregor. Turon. and others writing that this greife hath bene ≈øo healed, which to effect, the≈øe Idolatrous GeÃÑtils prepared a greate nuÃÑber of ≈øuch childreÃÑ, inteÃÑding to kill theÃÑ, and fill the Bathe with their blood, which when Con≈øtantine con≈øidered, and beheld the teares & lamentations of the Mothers for their children, he abhorred ≈øo great crueltie and wickednes, cau≈øing the childreÃÑ to be re≈øtored to their Mothers with rewardes, and meanes to carry them to their dwelling places. In the night following the holy Apo≈øtles S. Peter and S. Paul doe appeare and ≈øay thus, vnto him: O Emperour becau≈øe thow hast dete≈øted to shedd the blood of InnoceÃÑts, we ar ≈øent vnto thee by Christ to teach thee meanes to recouer thy health. Send for Bishop Sylue≈øter, and he will prouide an holy Bath, in which he will baptize thee, and thou shalt be cured froÃÑ thy Lepro≈øie and all di≈øea≈øes. Which Con≈øtantine pre≈øently performed, ≈øending for S. Silue≈øter, who shewed there vnto him the Picturs of The apparition of S. Peter and Saint Paul to Con≈øtantine. S. Peter, and S. Paule, which when the Emperour diligently beholded, he openly before his Nobilitie confe≈ø≈øed, that the≈øe were they which appeared vnto him, and being perfectly in≈øtructed by S. Syluester, was baptized by him, and Miraculou≈øly clean≈øed froÃÑ his Lepro≈øie, an hand from heauen, as he him≈øelfe did ≈øee and testifie, touching him. And when he was thus wonderfully cured and Christned, S. Sylue≈øter mini≈øtred the The Images of the Apo≈øtles then reuerently v≈øed by Chri≈øtians. holy Sacrament of Confirmation vnto him, anoynting and ≈øigning his forehead with ≈øacred Chri≈øme as the Roman Church now v≈øeth: Benedicto fonte, illic me trina mer≈øione vnda ≈øalutis puri≈øicauit po≈øitoque me in fontis gremio, manum de caelo me contingentem proprijs oculis vidi. De qua mundus exurgens ab omni me Leprae ≈øqualore mundatum agno≈øcite, l ‚Ä¢ uatoque me de venerabili fonte, induto ve≈øtibus candidis, ≈øeptiformis The Sacraments of Bapti≈øme and Confirmation how ministred to Con≈øtantine with miracle. gratiae ≈øancti spiritus con≈øignationem adhibuit beati Chri≈ømatis vnctione, & vexillum ≈øanctae Crucis in mea fronte liniuit, dicens: ≈øignat te Deus ≈øigillo fidei ≈øuae, in nomine patris, & filij & ≈øpiritus Sancti, in con≈øignatione fidei. Cunctu≈øque Clerus re≈øpondit, Amen. Et adiecit Prae≈øul, pax tibi. Simeon Metaphra≈øtes a Greeke Writer ≈øaith, that at the time of Con≈øtaÃÑtine his Bapti≈øme by S. Sylue≈øter, a light Sim. Metaphr. in Vit. S. Sylue≈øtri. more bright theÃÑ the ≈øunne, did ≈øodainely shine about all the hou≈øe, Lux repente totam domum circumful≈øit & lucis splendor plu≈øquam ≈øol enituit. And the Emperour
being baptized, his flesh was pure and ≈øound without any hurt or ≈øcarr, and the water wherewith he was baptized was full of ≈øuch filth as came from his ≈øores, like ≈øcales of fishes, exijt Imperator ex diuino Lauacro, habens carnem puram & ≈øanam, neque plaga, nec vlla apparente cicatrice, aqua autem pi≈øcinae erat plena ijs, quae ex vlceribus exciderant, membranis ac pelliculis non ≈øecus ac ≈øquammis pi≈øciuÃÑ. Diuers both Greeke, and Latine Writers ≈øay, that his ≈øonne Cri≈øpus was then babtized with him, Magnus Con≈øtantinus cum Cri≈øpo filio Romae √† Silue≈øtro baptizatus est.

3. The≈øe things being of ≈øo greate note and con≈øequeÃÑce in ≈øo greate a Prince Theophan. Cerameus Chronolog. Platina in Mar. and Commander, and ≈øo concerning all people, were not, nor could be done in ≈øecret. The infirmitie of Con≈øtantins Lepro≈øie was generally knowne, Phi≈øitians had often bene con≈øulted, and done their be≈øt practi≈øe about it, the place of the Capitole where the children should by the Pagans haue bene murdered about it was famous, the gathering them from many places, and Prouinces was knowne of all, the open out-cries and lamentations of their Mothers could not be conceled: the ≈øending and ≈øeeking for S. Silue≈øter were with honour and ≈øolemnitie performed, ≈øo was his entertaiment and conference with the Emperour in pre≈øence of his Nobilitie. The pre≈øent conuer≈øion of Con≈øtantine therevpon, his preparation in penance ≈øeuen dayes before his Bapti≈øme, this ≈øolemnized in the publike Imperiall Palace, and in an holy Fonte ≈øo curiou≈øly prouided, as all Hictories agree, and ≈øo Miraculou≈øly curing his corporall di≈øea≈øe, which no Art of man could heale, made this Conuer≈øion of Con≈øtantine renownedly knowne, and manife≈øt vnto all; To the Chri≈øtians for their vn≈øpeakeable Ioy and comfort; to the Iewes and Pagans to the shame and confu≈øion of their ob≈øtinacy, and ≈øaluation of many of them conuerted by this meanes.

4. And Con≈øtantine him≈øelfe did not onely ≈øend his Imperiall Edicts into all Eu≈øeb. l. 2. de Vita Con≈øtant. cap. 47. & ≈øeq. Bar. An. 324. Acts S. Sylue≈øtri. Nicephor. lib. 7. c. 34. Countryes both Ea≈øt and We≈øt, for embracing Chri≈øtian Religion, but made his publike per≈øuading OratioÃÑs to that purpo≈øe, as namely in the opeÃÑ Church, to the Senate and people of Rome, in Ba≈øilica vlpia. Wherevpon as Nicephorus a Gretian writeth, in the onely Citie of Rome there were conuerted and baptized aboue twelue thow≈øande men, be≈øides women and younger people in the ≈øame yeare. Egbertus from old Antiquities, ≈øicut antiqua nobis ≈øcripta commemorant, ≈øeemeth to deliuer, that all the Senators were then conuerted to Chri≈øt, for he plainely ≈øaith, that Con≈øtantine gaue the honour of the Senate of Rome to the Chri≈øtian Clergie thereof, and he withall the Senators departed from thence to Bizantium, Totius Senatus honorem Clero, qui cum ip≈øo (S. Silue≈øtro) Eckbertus Abb. Flor. Serm. 3. de Incremento & mani≈øe≈øtat. Cath. fidei. erat, tradidit, & ip≈øe cum Senatoribus omnibus de vrbe egrediens Bizantium tran≈ømigrauit.

5. Therefore a wonder it is how ≈øome Greeke Writers, which I haue remembred before, should or could pleade ignorance of ≈øo concerning and memorable a thing, ≈øo publikly acted with ≈øo many circum≈øtances, which could Constantine without all doubt baptized by S. Silue≈øter Pope at Rome. not be concealed in the greate commanding Citie of the world, by the ≈øole Emperour thereof, and S. Sylue≈øter the highe≈øt Ruler in the Church of Chri≈øt: & te≈øtified, by almo≈øt all Eccle≈øia≈øticall Hi≈øtorians too many to be remembred being recompted to be aboue 40. Cla≈ø≈øicall Chri≈øtian Writers for this matter, Iodoc. Cocc. in the ≈øaur. Cathol. Tom. 1. l. 7. art. 9. omitting many of greate name, Antiquitie, and Authoritie. The Pagans them≈øelues euen of the ≈øame Age, as Ammianus, Marcellinus, Zo≈øimus, and others giue plaine Te≈øtimony vnto it, the fir≈øt expre≈ø≈øely ≈øpeaketh of Con≈øtantins Fonte, Con≈øtantinianum Lauacrum in Rome. The other ≈øetteth downe Ammian. Marc. lib. 27. cap. 2.
the whole Hi≈øtory at lardge after his ethick manner. Zo≈øomen al≈øo te≈øtifieth that this Hi≈øtory was common among the Pagan Writers in his time, memoratum Zo≈øom. lib. 2. de Con≈øtantino. Zo≈øom. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. l. 1. c. 5. R. Abrah. leuit. in Chron. Iudaic. R. Abrah. E≈øra in c. 11. Daniel. Michael Glycas part. 4. Annal. √† gentilibus. And the Iewes al≈øo euen their mo≈øt malitious again≈øt Chri≈øtians, as R. Abraham Leuita; and R. Abraham Aben E≈øra doe confe≈ø≈øe and proue the ≈øame. So doe the be≈øt Greeke Hi≈øtorians Theophanes, Metaphra≈øtes, Zonaras, Cedrenus, Glycas, Nicephorus and others. Some of the≈øe as Michael Glycas calling them Arian Heretiks, who ≈øay he was baptized at Nicomedia by the Arian Bishop thereof: Ariani quidam constanter a≈ø≈øerunt eum ab Epicopo Nicomediae baptizatum e≈ø≈øe: and ≈øaith, it is out of doubt that he was baptized at Rome, his Bapti≈øtery there ≈øtill continuing to proue it inuincibly true, Non dubium e≈øt, quin magni Imperatoris huius Bapti≈øterium, quod adhuc Romae con≈øpicitur illu≈øtri ratione veritatem common≈øtret. So haue the re≈øt. And Theop. Ceram. ≈øupr. in Chrono. Theophanes plainely ≈øaith, this was one of the Arian Heretiks fictions and lyes again≈øt Con≈øtantine to ≈øtaine his glory vntruely with. And their Authenticall & publikly receaued Menologion of the Greeke Church doth not onely ≈øay, that S. Sylue≈øter baptized Con≈øtantine at Rome, clen≈øing him both from his Lepro≈øy of Soule and body: Sylue≈øter propter ≈øummum virtutis gradum Menol. Graecor. Kalend. Hic multorum patrator Miraculorum, Con≈øtantinum Magnum ad fidem conuertit, cum animae & corporis Con≈øtantine a Saint with the Greeks in their Menologie. morbos diuino Bapti≈ømate ab eo expuli≈ø≈øet: but it receaueth and enrolleth this Glorious Emperour in the Catalogue of holy Saints, and ≈øo he is generally honoured among them, and in the Latine Church his name was euer enrolled in the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Tables called Dyptica, and publikly recited at Ma≈ø≈øe, Nichol. 6. Therefore he mu≈øt needs be free from all ≈øuch ≈øu≈øpition, wherewith tho≈øe ≈øu≈øpected Gretians haue charged him, the cheife≈øt of them Eu≈øebius, as I haue proued before, contradicting him≈øelf herein, and making Con≈øtantine a profe≈ø≈øed Chri≈øtian, receauing Sacraments many yeares before this pretended Bapti≈øme at his death. Therefore I may worthely ≈øay of this renowned Emperour with our learned and auncient Hi≈øtorian: That he was the flower of Henric. Hunt. Hi≈øt. l. 1. in Con≈øtantino. Harding. Chro. c. 63. f. 50. Britaine, a Britan by blood, a Britan by Country, before whome, and after whome neuer any the like went out of Britaine: Con≈øtantinus flos Britanniae, hic Britannicus genere, & patria, ante quem, nec po≈øt, ≈øimilis e≈øt egre≈ø≈øus de Britannia. And an other in his olde Poeme, of the ≈øame our renowned King and Emperour, fir≈øt te≈øtifing he was baptized at Rome by Pope Sylue≈øter, and there cured of his Lepro≈øie, addeth:

Of May the twentie and one day indede
Vnder shryne buryed and ≈øubumbred
Among all Chri≈øten Kings worthy to be remembred
Who≈øe day and fea≈øt the Greekes haue eche yeare
Sol ‚Ä¢ mply, as for a Saint full clere.

div.p:
Our old English Chronicle al≈øo te≈øtifieth of this Emperour: This Constantine Old Engl. Hi≈øt. part. 4. f. 38. was a glorious maÃÑ and a Victorious in Battayle. In gouerning of the comyn people he was very wi≈øe, and in the nece≈øsitie of byleue he was without compari≈øon deuoute, his piete and his holynes be ≈øo written in the bookes of holy Doctors, that without doubte he is to he nobred amoÃÑg Saintes. And the Greekes ≈øay that in the end of his life he was made a Monke. S. Aldem ≈øaith greate Con≈øtantine was corporally and ≈øpiritually S. Aldelm. lib. de Laudib. Virgin. c. 12. cured in Bapti≈øme at Rome by S. Sylue≈øter: Imperatoris Con≈øtantini diuturna
valetudo & Elephantio≈øa corporis incommoditas, accepto bapti≈ømatis Sacramento a S. Sylue≈øtro citius curata est. And as Niphorus a Gretian writerh, this is Niceph. Hi≈øt. l. 7. c. 35. & l. 8. c. 5. 4. the con≈øent of the whole Church, that he was baptized at Rome by S. Sylue≈øter. Eccle≈øia a Sylue≈øtro eum Romae baptizatum e≈ø≈øe certo praedicat. And againe: nos Eccle≈øiae vinuer≈øali con≈øentientes Romae eum ≈øacro Lauacro tinctum e≈ø≈øe Silue≈øtro administram ei imponente manum diximus.

div.head: THE VI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THAT S. HELEN EVER PROFESSED HER≈øelf a Chri≈øtian: neuer ioyned with, but again≈øt the Iewes. Was in Britaine when Con≈øtantine was baptized in Rome, and after going from Britaine to Rome, was there with Con≈øtantine pre≈øent at the Roman Councell, con≈øenting to the Decrees thereof.

div.p:
1. THIS our Triumphant Emperor, and glory of Britaine, hauing thus victoriou≈øly conquered his ≈øpirituall, a≈ø well as corporall Enemies, and by Bapti≈øme, thus happily made ≈øo glorious, and profitable a member of the Church of Chri≈øt, the ioyfull newes and tydings thereof was ≈øoone diffu≈øed, and knowne to the holy Chri≈øtians, though farr di≈øtant from Rome, as that thing they mo≈øt de≈øired to be effected, and as much reioyced to heare it was ≈øo religiou≈øly performed. And among the re≈øt his ble≈ø≈øed mother S. Helen then lyuing heare in Britaine her natif Contry, after the death of her husband Con≈øtantius dying heare, who as before had in the be≈øt manner she could in≈øtructed her ≈øonne Con≈øtantine in the true Chri≈øtian Religion, and de≈øired nothing more, then to vnder≈øtand he publikly and with ≈øo greate zeale now openly profe≈ø≈øed that, which she had ≈øo often and earne≈øtly exhorted him vnto, was not a litle ioyed with the certaine notice hereof. And with all ha≈øt she could, prepared her≈øelf for ≈øo long a Iorney, by her corporall pre≈øence to be both a more effectuall partaker, and encrea≈øer of ≈øuch Chri≈øtian comforts. And to giue argument of her Ioyes by me≈ø≈øage in the meane time writing vnto him from Britaine, as our Antiquaties affirme, and among other things to expre≈ø≈øe her greate zeale in Chri≈øtian Religion, and to exhort her ≈øonne to the like, vnder≈øtanding of the greate malice of the Iewes again≈øt Chri≈øtians, e≈øpecially at that time, the Emperor being ≈øo ≈øolemnely and miraculou≈øly baptized, per≈øuaded him to per≈øecute tho≈øe Iewes which denied Chri≈øt, Con≈øtantino √† Papa Sylue≈øtro baptizato, ≈øcrip≈øit ei ≈øua mater Helena de Britannia, vt negantes Chri≈øtum Florent. Wigor. Chron. an. 306. & 328. Iudaeos per≈øequeretur. Marianus Scotus writeth al≈øo that S. Helen did write out of Britaine to Con≈øtaÃÑtine when she heard he was baptized by S. Sylue≈øter, Con≈øtantino autem √† Papa Sylue≈øtro baptizato, ≈øcrip≈øit de Britannia ≈øibi ≈øua mater Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. an. 321. Helena. But the prote≈øtant Publisher, as he is charged in many other things by M. Harpesfeild to haue done, either hath mi≈øtaken him, in that which followeth; S. Helen neuer any Iewe or corrupted by ≈øuch, but allwayes an holy Chri≈øtian. or published ≈øome Copy not ≈øo to be approued, for he bringeth in S. Helen in the next words, to reque≈øt her ≈øonne, to deny Chri≈øt, and followe the Iewes: vt negando Chri≈øtum, Iudaeos ≈øequeretur. Which cannot be the words either
of Marianus, or any learned Antiquary, ≈øuch as he was, confe≈ø≈øing S. Helen to haue bene at this time in Britaine as he doth, for neither at this time, nor diuers hundreds of yeares after S. Helen her death there is mention in Hi≈øtories of any Iewes at all to haue bene in this kingdome: Then much more it mu≈øt needs be Hi≈øtorially a thing vnpo≈ø≈øible, and alltogether vntrue, that there should then be one huntred fourtie, and one of the mo≈øt learned of the Iewes heare, and S. Helen should bring them with her to Rome from hence, as ≈øeemeth by ≈øome to be ≈øet downe in the RelatioÃÑ of the Di≈øpute betweene S. Capgrau. in S. Helena. Sylue≈øter and the Iewes before Con≈øtantine and S. Helen in Rome: adduxit ≈øecum Sancta Helena Romam centum quadraginta vnum docti≈øsimos Iudaeorum. But quite otherwi≈øe is proued before, that S. Helen was an holy Chri≈øtian, when she was in this Nation before her going to Rome, & at the time of her writing from hence to her ≈øonne Con≈øtantine there, after his Bapti≈øme. When in the other ≈øence, that S. Helen wrote vnto her ≈øonne to congratulate his Bapti≈øme, encouradge him con≈øtantly and religiou≈øly to profe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øtian Religion, to be a friend to the ≈øeruants and friends of Chri≈øt, and a ≈øuppre≈ø≈øor of Iewes, and who≈øoeuer their Enemies, we haue her owne religious education, and all the Chri≈øtian Cleargie and Nobilitie of Britaine, √† Chri≈øtian kingdome and her natiue CouÃÑtrie ≈øo calling vpoÃÑ her: and neither Iewe nor Pagan of note, learning or power, for any thing we reade, continuing heare, either to hinder her in this, or adui≈øe her to the contrary, to followe and fauour either Iewes or Gentils in their proceedin ‚Ä¢
