2. The like I may an≈øweare to them, which allthough they with the truth S. Helen w ‚Ä¢ nt not forth of Britaine with her ≈øonne Con≈øtantine but after. acknowledge S. Helen to haue bene the daughter of King Coel of Britaine, and borne in this Nation: yet they ≈øay she went hence with Con≈øtantine towards Rome, at what time he went again≈øt Maxentius the Tyrant, and with the children of Con≈øtantine trauailed to Bizantium, and dwelling there was peruerted by the Iewes, and ≈øo hearing of the Bapti≈øme of Con≈øtantine in that Citie of Bithinia, did write to him from thence, commeÃÑding him for renowncing Idolatrie, but reprouing him for reprouing the Iewes Religion, and being a Chri≈øtian. But this is euidently confuted before, when by ≈øo worthie authorities and many arguments it was proued, that S. Helen was in Britaine ≈øo farre di≈øtant from Bizantium at this time.

3. And what man of Iudgment can admitt with any shew of rea≈øon, that if S. Helen ≈øo wi≈øe a Prince≈ø≈øe had left Britaine at that time, the contrary whereof is alreadie manife≈øt, that she would al≈øo haue left her onely liuing child, ≈øo renowned an Emperor, Con≈øtantine and her three Vncles Ioelim, or by ≈øome Leolim, Trahern and Marius with a mo≈øt mightie Army of her CouÃÑtry G ‚Ä¢ lf ‚Ä¢ . Monum. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 5. c. 8. Pont Virun. l. 5. Capg. in S. Helena. Hard. Chron. Britans, cum maximo ‚Ä¢ c forti≈øsimo Britannorum exercitu, vnder the conduct of Con≈øtantine, in his owne Empire, where he triumphed, and she was in ≈øecuritie and honor, to haue liued at Bizantium in Bithinia in the Territories, and commande of a Tyrant, profe≈ø≈øed Enemy to her ≈øonne and her, and many hundreds of myles from any parte of her ≈øonnes Dominions, or if she could haue bene ≈øo carele≈ø≈øe of her owne good, and quiet, would she haue bene ≈øo regardle≈ø≈øe of her mo≈øt beloued ≈øonnes Succe≈ø≈øion, and Po≈øteritie, as to haue carried with her into tho≈øe daungers and troubles all the children of Con≈øtantine Emperor, which should ≈øucceede him, as that Relation ≈øaith she did, and Capgr. Catal. in S. Helena. was at Bizantium per≈øuaded to be a Iewe, Mater eius Helena ≈øancti≈øsima mulier cum fui ‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ epo ‚Ä¢ ibus Con≈øtantini filijs apud BizaÃÑntiam ciuitatem, quae po≈øtea Con≈øtantinopolis appellabatur aliquandiu commorata e≈øt, vbi ab impi ‚Ä¢ s Iudaeis circumuenta,
Iudaicae perfidiae fortius adhaerebat. Would or could ≈øuch a mo≈øt holy woman by the narration it ≈øelf, ≈øancti≈øsima mulier, haue done ≈øo vnholy, and vnadui≈øed an Act? or would CoÃÑ≈øtaÃÑntine ≈øo wi≈øe & louing both ≈øonne & Father haue hazarded him≈øelf to haue bene ≈øo depriued both of mother and children. But to manife≈øt the apparant vntruth of this narration in all, as it is euident before that S. Helen was ≈øtill in Britaine, ≈øo it is farre from que≈øtion in Hi≈øtory that his children were with him in Italy. Pri≈øcus his elde≈øt ≈øonne was diuers times Eu≈øeb. l. 4. Vitae Con≈øtantini. ca. 68. Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. l. 2. in CoÃÑ ≈øtantino. Martin. Polon. in eod. Floren. Wigorn. in Chron. an 309 Baron. & Spond. Annal. Tom. 4. Act. S. Agnetis in Bre ‚Ä¢ iar. die 28. Ianuar. Surius Tom. 1. Zachar. Lipel. Tom. 1. die 21. Ianuar. & al. I. 1. C. Th. de Iudae. Baron. Anna. an: 315. Baron. & Spond. Ann. an. 315. Conc. Rom. ≈øub. Sylue≈øtro. can. vlt. & 1. Con≈øul, and made Augu≈øtus, ≈øo were his other ≈øonnes Con≈øtantinus, Con≈øtaÃÑs and Con≈øtantius. Con≈øtantia al≈øo his daughter was at Rome, and there healed at S. Agnes her Tombe. So we mu≈øt needs ≈øay with our worthie Antiquaries, that S. Helen was in Britaine when her ≈øonne was Baptized, and from thence wrote vnto him to congratulate his Bapti≈øme, encourage him in the profe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt, and to per≈øecute the Iewes his enemies.

4. And mo≈øt probably vpon the≈øe letters and coun≈øaile of S. Helen, her ≈øonne Con≈øtantine ≈øet out that his Edict again≈øt the Iewes remembred both in the Imperiall lawes, and Hi≈øtories, that tho≈øe Iewes which ≈øtoned or per≈øecuted any of their company for being conuerted to Chri≈øtianitie, as then many of them in≈øolently did, should with all their Complices be burned. And if any Chri≈øtians should goe to their Sect, they should be ≈øubiect to the ≈øame punishment. For Baronius him≈øelfe confe≈ø≈øeth that this Edict of Con≈øtantine was made in the 315. yeare of Chri≈øt: hoc anno 315. idem Con≈øtantinus Iudaeorum procaciam Edicto cohibuit: which was abo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the time of his Bapti≈øme, by that is proued before, and about the time of his mothers writing vnto him to ≈øuch purpo≈øe, and vppon her adui≈øe, for if the Edict had bene granted before her writing, she would not haue written and adui≈øed as she did, to per≈øuade him to that, he had performed with ≈øo greate authoritie, and ≈øeueritie before. Againe Baronius holdeth that the Di≈øputation betweene S. Sylue≈øter, and the Iewes before Con≈øtantine, and S. Helen was at Rome in the 315. yeare of Chri≈øt. And the Roman Councell kept in the third Con≈øulship of Con≈øtantine, Both Con≈øtantine and S. HeleÃÑpre≈øent at Rome at the time of the Roman CouÃÑ cell, and con≈øenting to it. ≈øooner rather then after this yeare, is witne≈ø≈øe that both Con≈øtantine and S. Helen, were there at Rome and that Councell. And commonly it is held that the Di≈øpute, was in the time of that Councell, and S. Helen for the greater glory of Chri≈øt might be ≈øome meanes of that Di≈øpute, but in no wi≈øe by that is ≈øaid either a Iewe or doubting in her holy Chri≈øtian Religion: & more confirmed Metaphr. 2. Ian. Glic. Annal. Niceph. l. 7. cap. 36. Cedren. Comp. Capgr. ≈øupr. in S. Helen. Baron. An. 315. Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. l. 2. an. 321. Manu≈øcr. Gallic. antiq. c. 30. by that Di≈øpute, ≈øeeing the be≈øt learned Iewes ≈øo plainely and publickly confuted, that both they, and all the Pagan Philo≈øophers then pre≈øent, were conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt, Omnes Iudaei Iudice≈øque & caeteri omnes conuer≈øi ≈øunt ad fidem. An old French Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory ≈øaith 3000. Iewes were conuerted. Thus farre was this our holy Brittish Queene and Empre≈ø≈øe from approuing the profe≈ø≈øion of the Iewes at any time, that she was the occa≈øion of that Lawe not onely again≈øt them enacted by her ≈øonne, but al≈øo of ≈øuch Chri≈øtians as should receaue Iudai≈øme to be burned, and she her≈øelf had fallen into that danger if she had entred into their Sect. And was further by obtaining or occa≈øioning this Di≈øpute, occa≈øion al≈øo of the greate honor of Chri≈øtians and confu≈øion of both Iudai≈øme and Pagani≈øme whereby both the be≈øt learned Iewes, and Pagans being there pre≈øent were conuerted to Chri≈øt.

5. And becau≈øe this Di≈øpute was by common opinion, at, or in the time of the Roman Councell, and this both called by the help and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of S. Helen and Con≈øtantine, bearing the chardges of the Bishops there a≈ø≈øembled, as is expre≈ø≈øed in the ≈øame Councell, who al≈øo ≈øub≈øcribed vnto it with Conc. Rom. can. 1. 20. & vlt.
284. Bishops be≈øides others, ≈øub≈øcrip≈øer ‚Ä¢ nt 284. Epi≈øcopi & 45. Presbyteri, & 5. Diaconi & Augu≈øtus Con≈øtantinus & Mater eius Helena. Therefore it appertaineth Diuers Catholicke Decrees of the Roman Councell in the pre≈øence of Con≈øtantine and S. Helen vnder S. Sylne≈øter Pope. to the Hi≈øtory of this kingdome to knowe what doctrine concerning vs, was concluded there. In this Councell are ≈øet downe all Eccle≈øia≈øticall Orders and Degrees which the Church of Rome now ob≈øerueth, Ostiarius, Lector, Exorci≈øta, Acolithus, Subdeacon, and the ≈øuperior Deacons, Prei≈øts, Bishops with their peculiar offices, and functions: And a Law, that Subdeacons might not marry: nullus Subdiaconorum ad n ‚Ä¢ ptias tran≈øire praecipimus. Then Can. 7. 8. 9. 11. much more vnlawfull it was for any of the higher Orders to de marryed. In this Councell al≈øo it is decreed, that the Roman See is the cheife≈øt See, and can be iudged by none, neither by Emperour, Cleargie, Kings, or people, but all Can. 2. other Sees are to receaue Iu≈øtice from it, Nemo iudicabit primam Sedem, quoniam omnes Sedes a prima Sede Iu≈øtitiam de≈øideraÃÑt teÃÑperari. Neque ab Augu≈øto, neque ab omni Clero, neque a Regibus ne
que a populo Iudex Iudicabitur. And allthough this Councell was called by the a≈ø≈øent of Con≈øtantine the Emperour, or his Mother S. Helen, cum con≈øilio Augu≈øt ‚Ä¢ vel Matris eius, and they both ≈øub≈øcribed Can. 1. vnto it: ≈øub≈øcrip≈øit Augu≈øtus Con≈øtantinus cum matre Helena Augu≈øta: yet this was not by any claime or Title they pretended to be Iudges in ≈øpirituall Que≈øtions, Can. 7. & 20. but onely to approue by their temporall Power, and Authoritie, what S. Sylue≈øter Pope and the Bishops a≈ø≈øembled did decree and conclude: as is euident by the ≈øame Councell both te≈øtifying that S. Sylue≈øter Pope called the Councell: Sylue≈øter Epi≈øcopus vrbis Romae collegit vniuer≈øam Synod ‚Ä¢ m Epi≈øcoporum: And made the Decrees as appeareth allmo≈øt ineuery Canon ≈øet out in his name: con≈øtituit Sylue≈øter Epi≈øcopus vrbis Romae. And plainely forbad any laye par≈øon to be pre≈øent and intermedle in tho≈øe affaires, voluit vt nullus laicorum Can. 1. Epilog. Concil. Rom. Tom. 1. Concil. ante CoÃÑ cil. Rom. de con≈ø. di≈øt. con≈øulto omnium. 2. quae≈øt. 7. nulius laicus. prae≈øens e≈ø≈øe videretur. But onely a≈ø≈øembled the Bishops and Cleargie to deale in tho≈øe matters, Hos omnes ad examen ≈øanctitatis colligeret: Decreed that the Sacrifice of the Altar should not be offered but vpon a linen cloath hallowed by a Bishop. Omnium con≈øultu con≈øtituit in Synodo vt ≈øacrificium altaris non in ≈øerico panno aut tincto quispiam celebrare prae≈øumeret, ≈øed in puro lineo ab Epi≈øcopo con≈øecrato. And that in the Sacrament of Confirmation by annointing with holy Chri≈øime, and Impo≈øition of Bishops hands, grace of the holy Gho≈øt is giuen by Bishops onely: nemo ni≈øi Epi≈øcopus ≈øacro≈øancto chri≈ømate, per Epi≈øcopalis manus Impo≈øitionem, ≈øancti spiritus gratia confirmaret. And S. Sylue≈øter De Con≈øe. di≈øt. 1. nullus presbyter Mi≈ø≈øas. in the ≈øame Councell with all their con≈øents decreed, that no Prie≈øt should ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe but in places con≈øecrated by a Bishop, Hic in memorata Synodo con≈øtituit omnium cum con≈øen≈øu, vt nullus Presbiter Mi≈ø≈øas celebrare prae≈øumat, ni≈øi in Rob. Barnes in Vit. Pontif. Rom in Sylue≈øtro. ≈øacratis ab Epi≈øcopo locis.

6. The≈øe Decrees our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries them≈øelues doe a≈ø≈øcribe to this holy Pope S. Sylue≈øter, and to haue bene confirmed in this Councell, where our renowned King and Queene, Emperour and Empre≈ø≈øe, Con≈øtantine and B. Helen were pre≈øent, and in which S. Sylue≈øter confuted the cheife Doctors and Rabins of the Iewes, as our learned and auncient holy Bishop S. Aldelm. lib. de laudib. virginitat. cap. 12. S. Aldelme with others witne≈ø≈øe. Sylue≈øter Constantino orbem gubernante ad Synodale Concilium populis cateruatim confluentibus duodenos Iudaeorum Praeceptores, & Phari≈øaeorum Rabbites dira di≈øputationum spicula contra Chri≈øti Tyronem truciter torquentes, diuino confi≈øus clypeo confutauit. Therefore of all Nations we of Britaine by greate≈øt obligation are bound to receaue, retaine and practi≈øe the holy doctrins decr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d in this Councell, whether Catholicks a≈ø≈øcribing Supremacie in ≈øpirituall affaires vnto the Pope, or Prote≈øtants vnto the temporall
king and Prince, both being pre≈øent in, and giuing allowence to the Decrees of this Councell, ≈øo famous in all Contries both in re≈øpect of it ≈øelf, as the confu≈øion of the be≈øt learned Iewes therein, which as S. Aldelme writeth, was knowne in all parts of the world: celeberrimum ≈øpectaculi genus per totos mundi Cardines vulgatum.

div.head: THE VII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE PRESENCE AT, ALLOWANCE AND receauing of generall Councels by our Emperor Con≈øtantine, our Archbishop and other Bishops of Britaine: togeather with the doctrine, then profe≈ø≈øed in tho≈øe Councells and after practi≈øed in Britaine.

div.p: 1. ABOVT this time, and among ≈øuch holy Chri≈øtian workes Matth. We≈øtm. an. 321. Baron. & Spond. Annal. an. 314. Seuerin. Binnius Annot. in Concil. Arelat. 1. Tom. 1. Concil. of Con≈øtantine, or effected by his help and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, the fir≈øt greate Councell of Arles in France, con≈øi≈øting as Nicephorus, Ado and others ≈øay, of 600. Bishops, was celebrated, as Baronius, Spondanus and others from Antiquitie doe gather, in the 314. yeare of Chri≈øt, the 9. of the Empire of Con≈øtantine, and ≈øecond of the Papacie of S. Sylue≈øter. In this Councell was pre≈øent and ≈øub≈øcribed Re≈øtitutus Archbishop of London, and in all probable iudgment diuers others of this our Britaine: for in that ≈øub≈øcription vnto that Councell which is left vnto vs, and Re≈øtitutus is ≈øub≈øcribed, Ex prouincia Britanniae ciuitate Londinen≈øi Re≈øtitutus Epi≈øcopus, there be not the names of 30. of tho≈øe 600. Bishops there a≈ø≈øembled, regi≈øtred and pre≈øerued. And ≈øo Britaine being ≈øo neare vnto the place of this Councell, and replenished with Bishops at this time, as I haue before remembred, may well make claime for a greater number of the Bishops thereof to haue bene pre≈øent there. A Prote≈øtant Antiquary of England, would by this ≈øub≈øcription of Re≈øtitutus inferr, or haue it to be doubtfully thought he was no Archbishop, nor that Title then v≈øed: he writeth not him≈øelf, (≈øaith this Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorian.) Archbishop, and therefore maketh that matter of Archbishops doubtfull, or rather ouerthroweth that opinion. Stowe Hi≈øtor. Tit. Romans in Lucius. But I haue proued this Eccle≈øia≈øticall high dignitie before to haue euer bene in the Church of Chri≈øt, and heare in Britaine from the Apo≈øtles time.

2. And concerning the ≈øub≈øcription to this Councell, where it is mo≈øt certaine, many Archbishops were pre≈øent, not any one ≈øo ≈øub≈øcribeth. In this Councell, as I haue related allready, were pre≈øent for the Pope of Rome S. Sylue≈øter, Claudius and Vitus Prei≈øts, & Eugenius and Cyriacus Deacons, and Con≈øtantine the Emperor. And allthough it was cheifely a≈ø≈øembled for the cau≈øe of Caecilianus Archbishop of Carthage, yet it Decreed diuers other Canons, ≈øome of which concerned euen this kingdome touching things Concil. Arelat. 1. can. 1. Tom. 1. Concil. que≈øtioned by ≈øome of our Prote≈øtant Writers: as namely in the fir≈øt Canon directed to S. Sylue≈øter Pope, it hath that all Churches should keepe the day of Ea≈øter vppon one day with the Church of Rome, and that the Pope of Rome by his letters should giue Order herein, De ob≈øeruatione ‚Ä¢ a≈øchae Domini, vt vno die & tempore per omnem orbem ob≈øeruetur, & iuxta con≈øuetudinem, literas ad omnes
tu dirigas. Where we euidently ≈øee that the Church of Britaine then kept the true ob≈øeruation of Ea≈øter with the Church of Rome, and not with ≈øome Churches of A≈øia erroneou≈øly, as ≈øome of our Britans after did, at the coÃÑming of S. Augu≈øtine hither, and that the Church of Rome then by old cu≈øtome, iuxta con≈øuetudinem, directed both our Brittish and other Churches in ≈øuch things. In the 8. Canon, Impo≈øition of hands, v≈øually called Confirmation, is proued to be a Sacrament, and to giue grace to tho≈øe that are baptized, Si peruiderint Can. 8. Cau. 15. 20. in Patre & Filio & Spiritu ≈øancto eos baptizatos, manus eis tantum imponatur, vt accipiant ≈øpiritum Sanctum. It di≈øableth all but Prie≈øts to ≈øay Ma≈ø≈øe, and appointeth that euery Bishop a ≈øtranger, ≈øo many then there pre≈øent, should haue a conuenient place to offer Sacrifice in, vt peregrino Epi≈øcopo locus ≈øacrificandi detur.

3. Some haue thought this CouÃÑcell was kept about the the ≈øame time wherein the Nicen was celebrated: But Baronius, Spondanus, Sepherinus Binnius Baron. & Spondan. Annal. ann. 314. Seuer. Bin. Annot. in Conc. Arel. 1. Tom. 1. Concil. and others doe directly proue it was kept in the 314. yeare of Chri≈øt, and fir≈øt yeare of S. Sylue≈øter Pope, pre≈øently after the death of Melchiades. Which is al≈øo euident by the Epi≈øtle of Con≈øtantin him≈øelf extant in Eu≈øebius, written to Chre≈øtus Bishop of Siracu≈øas, warning him to be pre≈øent at that Councell, and giueth him power to take of Latronianus his Prefect of Sicile a publik wagan for him and his company, ≈øayeing, that again≈øt the fir≈øt day of Augu≈øt following he had giuen direction for very many Bishops from diuers and innumerable places to a≈ø≈øemble at the Citie of Arles in France, Quamplurimos Epi≈øcopos Epi≈øtol. Con≈øtant. Magni ad Chre≈øt. Epi≈øcop. apud Eu≈øeb. l. 10. Hi≈øtor. c. 5. ex varijs & innumeris locis ad Ciuitatem Arelaten≈øem, Calendis Augu≈øti conuenire iu≈øsimus, etiam tibi ≈øcribendum e≈ø≈øe iudicauimus, vt accepto ab Illu≈øtri≈øsimo Latroniano Siciliae Praefecto publico vehiculo ac vna cum duobus quibu≈ødam ex ijs qui ≈øecundi ordinis ≈øunt, quos tu ip≈øe ≈øeligendos putaueris, quin & cum tribus ≈øeruis qui vobis in itinere ≈øeruire valeant, intra eundem diem ad locum iam dictum accurras. This Epi≈øtle of Con≈øtantine to SuÃÑman this Councell, mu≈øt needs be written in the later end of the yeare of Chri≈øt 313. or in the begining of the yeare 314. for Pope Melchiades died in the Moneth of December the yeare 313. And S. Dama≈ø. in Melchiad. & Sylue≈øt. Seuer. Bin. Tom. 1. Concil. in ei≈ødeÃÑ. Baron. & Spond. an. 313. 114. In appendic. ad Optat. Baron. an. 314. Eu≈øebius l. 4. de Vit. Con≈øtantini cap. 27. Sylue≈øter in who≈øe fir≈øt yeare this Councell was kept was cho≈øen Pope the fir≈øt day of February in the yeare following 314. The like letters and liberties to a≈ø≈øemble other Bishops to this Councell were written and granted at this time by Con≈øtantine, as appeareth in his Epi≈øtle to Ablauius Procon≈øul of Africke. This Councell as others of the holy Bishops of this time, and the whole Age of Con≈øtantine, was approued and priuiledged by his Imperiall authoritie, as Eu≈øebius witne≈ø≈øeth, that no other Prince or Potentate might abrogate and make them inualiditate, Quae ab Epi≈øcopis in publicis Conuentibus editae erant regulae, ≈øua con≈øignabat & confirmabat authoritate: ne reliquarum Gentium Principibus liceret, quae ab eis decreta e≈ø≈øent abrogare, cuiu≈øuis enim Iudicis ≈øententiae, Sacerdotum Dei Iudicium ant ‚Ä¢ ponendum e≈øt. Where it is euident, that the Decrees decreed in Councels were the Decrees of the Bishops a≈ø≈øembled in them, and not the Decrees of Con≈øtantine the Emperor, but onely defended by his Imperiall power, and authoritie from being abrogated by any Ciuill or temporall Prince, or Con≈øi≈øtory, but to be duely reuerenced and ob≈øerued by all par≈øons.

4. Very many there be among which, diuers English Prote≈øtant Antiquaries Matth. Parker Antiquit. Britan. cap. 1. Io. Go≈øcel. Hi≈øtor. Eccle≈øia≈øt. Manu≈øcript. are to be numbred, which affirme it was the ≈øecond Councell of Arles held, as they ≈øay, in the 326. yeare of Chri≈øt, in the time of this Con≈øtantine Emperor where Re≈øtitutus Archbishop of London, was pre≈øent, and ≈øub≈øcribed. Accedit
Arelaten≈øis ≈øecundi Concilij authoritas, in quo di≈øert√® exprimitur, Restitutum quendam Londinen≈øem Epi≈øcopum ei Concilio √® Britannia vocatum interfui≈øse, eiu≈ødemque Decretis ≈øub≈øcrip≈øi≈øse. Thus Matthew Parker the fir≈øt English Prote≈øtant Stowe Hi≈øt. Tit. Romans in Lucius. Archbishop, and Go≈øcelin in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory. An other ≈øaith, I reade of a Bishop of London in the yeare of Chri≈øt 326. to be pre≈øent at the ≈øecond Councell at Arles, in the time of Con≈øtantine the Greate, who ≈øub≈øcribed thereunto in the≈øe words: Ex Prouincia Britanniae ciuitate Londinen≈øi Re≈øtitutus Epi≈øcopus. Diuers others there be, who allthough they doe not particularly name what Councell of Arles fir≈øt or ≈øecond, this our Archbishop was pre≈øent at in France, yet they plainely deliuer, that he was at this ≈øuppo≈øed, to be the ≈øecond in the yeare of Chri≈øt 326. ≈øo a Prote≈øtant Bishop writeth: Re≈øtitutus was Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 29. Godwin Cat. of Bish. London. in Re≈øtitutus 12. pre≈øent at the Councell of Arles in France, the yeare 326. and ≈øub≈øcribed vnto the Decrees of the ≈øame Councell, which he brought ouer with him. That is vtterly and impudently ≈øpoken fal≈øe, which this English Prote≈øtant Bishop and Antiquarie immediately addeth from this CouÃÑcell: one Decree amongst the re≈øt was, that if a Deacon at the time of his ordering did prote≈øt, he intended to marry, It should be lawfull for him ≈øo to doe. Restitutus him≈øelf was married. For in this Councell there is not the lea≈øt mention of any ≈øuch Decree. And it is as boldely affirmed of Re≈øtitutus marriadge without any Author ≈øo te≈øtifying. And this very Councell beareth good witne≈ø≈øe that by the Decrees thereof, neither Re≈øtitutus nor any other Bishop or Prei≈øt might marry, nor any man that was married might be admitted to be Prei≈øt or Bishop, except by con≈øent leauing his wife which he had before, a≈ø≈øumi aliquem ad Sacerdotium non po≈øse in vinculo coniugij Conc. Arelat. 2. Can. 2. con≈øtitutum, ni≈øi fuerit promi≈ø≈øa conuer≈øio. Whereby it is euident, that the ≈øufferance or permi≈ø≈øion which Socrates, and Sozomen and our Prote≈øtants from them vppon the words and per≈øua≈øion of Paphnutius in the fir≈øt Nicen Councell, allowed vnto ≈øome Ea≈øterne Bishops, Prei≈øts, and Deacons which were married before their Con≈øecration, that after their Con≈øecration they might Socrat. Hi≈øtor. Eccl. l. 1. cap. 8. Sozomen. Hi≈øt. l. 2. cap. 22. keepe company with ≈øuch wiues: ab vxoribus quas habebant minime ≈øepararentur, was neuer admitted heare in Britaine, and the≈øe We≈øt CouÃÑtries, is plaine by this Canon of the Councell of Arles, kept in the very next yeare to that Nicen Councell, as our Prote≈øtants with others before acknowledge, & diuers times citing that former Councell defyning the contrary, that no married man, except for≈øaking his wife might be a Prei≈øt.

5. And Socrates be≈øt Interpreter of him≈øelf doth proue, that this permi≈ø≈øion or tolleration was not practized, or executed by the mo≈øt renouned Prei≈øts and Bishops of the Ea≈øt, but they contayned them≈øelues from the wiues they had maryed before, and ≈øaieth, that in ≈øome places, as The≈ø≈øalia, vpon his certaine knowledge, the cu≈øtome was, to degrad ≈øuch Clergie men as would not ab≈øtaine from ≈øuch wiues, Ip≈øe in The≈ø≈øalia con≈øuetudinem inualui≈ø≈øe noui, vt Socrat. Hi≈øtor. l. 5. cap. 21. ibi qui clericus ≈øit, ≈øi cum vxore, quam cuÃÑ e≈ø≈øet laicus ducebat, po≈øtquam clericus factus ≈øit, dormierit, clericatu abdicatus ≈øit: omnes Illu≈øtres presbyteri in Oriente, & Epi≈øcopietiam ab vxoribus ab≈øtineant. Neither is there any ≈øuch licence, or tolleration regi≈øtred in any Canon, or Copy of the Nicen Councell. When in this Councell of Arles ≈øub≈øcribed vnto, and brought into Britaine by our Archbishop, as our Prote≈øtants confe≈ø≈øe before, the coÃÑtinency of Clergie meÃÑ euen froÃÑ formerly maryed wiues, is plainely decreed for a generall Lawe vnto all. So that froÃÑ the beginning, by the≈øe mens grant from this Councell, our Eccle≈øia≈øticall men euer liued in perpetuall cha≈øtitie, both from tho≈øe wiues, and after Con≈øecratioÃÑ were di≈øabled to marry by their owne Authours, both by the Churches
Tradition and the Nycen Councell prouing, that in no parte either Ea≈øt or We≈øt ≈øuch men might marry, but were prohibited by the old Tradition of the Socrates & Sozom. ≈øupr. Church, which being old in that time mu≈øt needs be from the Apo≈øtles dayes: vt qui in Clerum ante a≈øcripti erant, quam duxi≈ø≈øent vxores, hi ≈øecundum veterem Eccle≈øiae Traditionem, deinceps a nuptijs ≈øe ab≈øtinerent. So that our English Prote≈øtants mu≈øt needs confe≈ø≈øe, that Article of their Religion, which is: It is lawfull Prote≈øt. Articles of Religion Articul. 32. for Bishops, Prei≈øts, and Deacons, as for all other Chri≈øtian men to marry at their owne di≈øcretion: to be vtterly fal≈øe both by this holy Councell, the Councell of Neyce, the practi≈øe of our primatiue Chri≈øtian Britans, and the Tradition of the whole Church of Chri≈øt.

6. We reade likewi≈øe in this Councell ≈øub≈øcribed vnto by our Archbishop Arelaten. Concil. 2. Can. 15. Nicen. Concil. c. 14. 18. Arelat. 2. can. 25. Can. 26. Re≈øtitutus, as our Prote≈øtaÃÑts haue told vs before, that the ≈øacred body of Chri≈øt, Corpus Chri≈øti, is giuen to Communicants in the holy Euchari≈øt: and there it receaueth the Doctrine of the Nycen Councell teaching that con≈øecrated Prei≈øts, and ≈øuch onely, offer the body of Chri≈øt in their Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe. It condemneth all them to penance, who after their Vowe of Religious life for≈øake it: Di≈øableth tho≈øe that haue bene twyce married to receaue any Eccle≈øia≈øticall Order aboue Subdeacon. And tho≈øe women which after Vowe of cha≈øtitie doe marry it debarreth from Communion.

7. A late Writer would place this Councell in a later time, after the death of Seuerin. Bin. not. in Arel. 2. Concil. Tom. 2. Concil. S. Syue≈øter, but being therein ≈øingular again≈øt the common opinion both of Catholiks and Prote≈øtants, and finding in the very Councell it≈øelf, that it was kept in the dayes of S. Sylue≈øter in the yeare of Chri≈øt 326. I dare not for ≈øuch rea≈øons as doe not conuince prolonge it to a later Age: But rather thinke with Seuerinus Binnius and others, that our Archbishop Re≈øtitutus was a≈øwell pre≈øent a the fir≈øt, as with the common voyce of Antiquitie, that he ≈øub≈øcribed to the ≈øecoÃÑd, ≈øeeing there was no greater di≈øtance then of 11. yeares betweene them. And this ≈øecond Councell where all agree Re≈øtitutus was, affirmeth that in the former Councell 11. yeares before, Bishops were a≈ø≈øembled out of all parts of the world, Ad Arelaten≈øem vrbem ex omnibus mundi partibus celeb ‚Ä¢ atum Concil. Arel. 2. 1 can. 18. Arelat. Concil. 1. can. 7. fui≈ø≈øe ConciliuÃÑ. In which we finde a Decree for all Nations, that the Pre≈øidents of Countryes being Chri≈øtians were to be at the direction of the Bishops in ≈øuch places, concerning Religion. Which mu≈øt needs, be≈øides that is ≈øaid before, giue vs ≈øufficient Argument, that in this yeare 314. Con≈øtantine was a profe≈ø≈øed Chri≈øtian. I haue ≈øomewhat out of Order of time ioyned this ≈øecond Councell of Arles to the fir≈øt, in regard they were by the common opinion kept ≈øo neare together, in one place, vnder one Pope S. Syluer≈øter, one Emperour of our Country Con≈øtantine, and our Archbishop with others of this kingdome was pre≈øent in them, ≈øuch men as he neuer going alone without others of their Clergie to any Councell Bishops or Prei≈øts: and in this time e≈øpeciall care being taken by our renowned Emperour, as I haue shewed before Epi≈øtol. Con≈øt. ad Chre≈øt. ≈øupr. Concil. Roman can. 1. Hi≈øtor. Tripartit. l. 3. c. 2. l. 2. cap. 3. from his owne publike order, that they should at his charge and co≈øt ≈øo be ≈øafely conueyed with their due Attendance to that place, where the≈øe Councels were to be a≈ø≈øembled: and there al≈øo to be prouided for, during the time of the Councells at his co≈øt, Quibus Augu≈øtus Con≈øtantinus vehicula & annonas prae≈øtari praecepit.

div.head: THE VIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THE GENERALL ESTABLISHING, ENDOWing and honoring of Chri≈øtian Religion, Bishops, Prei≈øts other Clergymen, cha≈øt and Religious par≈øons in all places of the Empire by Con≈øtantine.

div.p: 1. NEITHER did this renowned Emperour confine his loue, and fauours towards Chri≈øtian Religion, vnto the Chri≈øtians of his owne the we≈øt Empire, but vnto all, as God by an holy Angell before reuealed, (both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants ≈øo acknowleding) that Chri≈øtians in the whole world should be at peace, and Idolatry was generally to Bapti≈øt. Mantuan. l. 2. de vita S. Bla≈øij. Io. Bal. l. 1. de Act. Pont. Roman. in Sylu. 1. be ouerthrowne by this Noble Emperour:

q.l: Nunc bonus, expul≈øis Romana in regna Tyrannis
Adueniet Princeps, ≈øub quo pacabitur orbis:
Et finem accipiet veterum cultura Deorum.

div.p: This Noble Emperour and In≈øtrument of God, the more ea≈øily and peaceably to procure and ≈øetle this generall quiet, and ≈øecuritie of Chri≈øtians, Licinius being now Emperour in the Ea≈øt, he married his half Si≈øter Con≈øtantia daughter of his Father Con≈øtantius by Theodora vnto him: she was by common opinion a Chri≈øtian at this time, by which meanes, and at the lea≈øt in re≈øpect of other fauours receaued from Con≈øtantyne, Licinius profe≈ø≈øed him≈øelf a Friend to Chri≈øtians, and ioyned with Con≈øtantine in diuers Edicts, Edicts of Con≈øtantine and Licinius Emperours for Chri≈øtians quiet in all places. Eu≈øeb. Hi≈øtor. l. 9 cap. 9. l. 10. cap. 5. Zozomen Hi≈øto. l. 1. cap. 7. Eu≈øeb. ≈øup. l. 10. c. 5. l. 9. cap. 9. for their quietly enioying and profe≈ø≈øing their Religion, re≈øtoring to them their Liberties, lands, goods, Churches and other freedomes. And that the≈øe their Priuiledges to Chri≈øtians might come to the knowledge of all, they cau≈øed them to be published in all places: vt autem Con≈øtitutionis huius & hone≈øtatis no≈øtrae determinatio omnibus innote≈øcere valeat, haec ≈øcripta no≈øtra pa≈øsim proponi, & ad omnium cognitionem duci conueniet, ne quenquam hone≈øtatis huius no≈øtrae constitutio latere queat. And as Eu≈øebius witne≈ø≈øeth, both Con≈øtantine and Licinus did ≈øend the≈øe their Lawes for the Immunities of Chri≈øtiaÃÑs euen to Maximinus the Tyrant in the Ea≈øt to be ob≈øerued by him: Cum ip≈øe Con≈øtantinus, tum & Licinius Imperator cum eo Deum bonorum omnium Authorem vtrique placantes, vna ≈øententia ac voluntate legem pro Chri≈øtianis perfecti≈øsimam, ac pleni≈ø≈øimam con≈øtituunt, ac ip≈øam legem Maximino, qui adhuc Orienti dominabatur, & amicitiam erga ip≈øos praetexebat mittunt. And he either for loue or feare, cau≈øed it to be promulged, and published by his Authoritie to all Pre≈øidents vnder him. All this was done by Con≈øtantine the yeare next after his Victory again≈øt Baron. Annal. An. 313. Spondan. ibidem. Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. l. 2. an. 309. Maxentius, as Baronius and others write in the 313. of Chri≈øt, but by Marianus ≈øetting downe the death of Maximinus in the yeare 309. it mu≈øt needs be ≈øooner if his accompt be true.

2. But how≈øoeuer, it is euident by Eu≈øebius & others that Maximinus ≈øoone after mouing warre again≈øt Licinius by in≈øtigation of his Idolatrous Prei≈øts, being ouerthrowne & brought to mi≈øery, did put tho≈øe his Seducers to death, Eu≈øeb. Hi≈øtor. l. 9 cap. 10. worshipped the God of Chri≈øtians, and published a mo≈øt ab≈øolute Lawe for
their libertie, and freedome. His Con≈øtitution is extant in Eu≈øebius, & all this was effected, and he mi≈øerably died in the 313. or 314. yeare of Chri≈øt, by Baronius Baron. & Spond. an. 313. & 314. and Spondanus large≈øt reckoning. And by the ≈øame Computators Licinius afterward violating his faith, and falling to warre with Con≈øtantine, and per≈øecuting Chri≈øtians, being brought to di≈øtre≈ø≈øe and de≈øolation‚ñ™ hanged him≈øelf in the yeare of Chri≈øt 318. Con≈øtantine mu≈øt needs be acknowledged Baron. & Spond. an. 318. to haue bene the ≈øole and onely commanding Emperour in the worlde before this time, for Sozomen with others witne≈ø≈øeth, that Licinius the la≈øt, then bearing that name vtterly ouerthrowne both at Sea, and land, by the forces of Con≈øtantine, fir≈øt hopele≈ø≈øe of recouery, fledd to Nicomedia, and ≈øome time Sozom. Hi≈øtor. l. 1. cap. 7. after liued an ob≈øcure and ba≈øe life at The≈ø≈øalonica, before he came to that de≈øperate end, Licinius pede≈øtribus copijs & naualibus ami≈øsis, ≈øe Nicomediam recepit, & postea vitam priuatam The≈ø≈øalonicae ad tempus degens, ibi √® medio ≈øublatus e≈øt.

3. Eu≈øebius from the Te≈øtimony of Con≈øtantine him≈øelf, writeth ≈øtrange Miracles wrought by the Banner of this Emperour, bearing the Cro≈ø≈øe, that Eu≈øeb. lib. 2. Vit. Con≈øtant. cap. 7. 8. 9. in what part ≈øoeuer of the Army it was ≈øeene, the Enemyes fledd, and rane away. And if in any part of his Army, the Souldiars began to faint, pre≈øently The miraculous Banner of Con≈øtantine hauing the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe in it. vpon the bringing of this holy Banner thither, they recouered, and obtained Victory: whereas there were 50. men appointed to attend this Banner, and in turns to beare it, neuer any one of them in executing that office, did mi≈øcary: Among the≈øe onely one which bore it, ≈øeeing the Warre to be greate, and in his Iudgment dangerous, deliuered this En≈øigne to an other, and departing from it, was wounded, and died, but he which tooke the Banner from him, had no hurt at all. And when very many darts were ca≈øt at him, they all mi≈ø≈øed his body, and were Miraculou≈øly receaued in the ≈ølender shaft or ≈øtaffe of the Banner to the exceeding adm ‚Ä¢ ration of all men, Istud omnem plane ≈øuperat admirationem, tum quod tela ab ho≈øtibus iacta ≈øic intra exiguum ill um & angu≈øtum ha≈øtilis ambitum prouolabant, vt in eodem fixa inhaere≈øcerent: tum quod ille qui illud ip≈øum ge≈øtabat, mortem effugeret: imo vero, vt qui hoc mini≈øterium obibant, nihil damni incommodiue aliquando acciperent. Neque certe haec no≈øtra e≈øt oratio, ≈øed ip≈øius Imperatoris, qui praeter alias res, hanc etiam nobis coram memorauit. And the Eu≈øeb. l. 2. Vit. Con≈øtant. cap. 16 glory of this Cro≈ø≈øe, as Eu≈øebius writeth, was knowne ≈øo euidently euen to Licinus the Enemy thereof, that when he was to fight with Con≈øtantine, he commanded his ≈øouldiars not to looke vpon that En≈øigne, but by all meanes they coulde, to auoyde it.

4. Con≈øtantine thus by the greate mercy, and power of God, which had giuen him ≈øo many and greate Victoryes, euen from the Sea of Britaine to the Countryes of the Ea≈øt, a mari Britannico, ad Regiones v≈øque in oriente ≈øitas. And Sozomen. Hi≈øto. Eccl. l. 1. cap. 8. Eu≈øeb. Vit. Con≈øtant. l. 2. cap. 23. Con≈øtantine by publick Edicts a≈øcribeth his victories to Christ and freed Christians. by the ayde and protection of his Fathers Con≈øtantius God, had made all Nations ≈øubiect vnto his Empire, did openly publish vnto them all, that he was the Authour of his Conque≈øts, and ≈øignified ≈øo much to all Nations by his Imperiall Edicts both in Latine and Greeke, Postquam omnes gentes Dei patris virtute Imperatori ≈øubiectae fuerunt, bonorum ≈øibi ≈øuppeditatorum largitorem omnibus palam praedicauit: cumque victoriarum quas e≈ø≈øet a≈ø≈øecutus Authorem agno≈øcere, con≈øtanter te≈øtificatus e≈øt: hocque ip≈øum per Edicta quae literis Latinis Graecisque mandata erant, & ad omnes gentes mi≈ø≈øa, manife≈øto denuntiauit. In the≈øe Decrees he ordained that all Chri≈øtians should be re≈øtored to their former honours, and Sozom. Eccle≈ø. H ‚Ä¢ ≈øtor. lib. 1. c. 8. e≈øtates, all Exiles recalled, all punishments and afflictions impo≈øed vpon them by Per≈øecutors quite remitted. Tho≈øe that had bene put to death, and ≈øpoyled of their goods for Chri≈øtian Religion, their children or next of kindred should
haue them re≈øtored to their v≈øe, and if none of their kindred were liuing, the Church in euery ≈øuch place should be their Heire. And no priuate maÃÑ or Magi≈øtrate should detaine any part thereof: And what ≈øoeuer had bene forfaited in that re≈øpect should be repayed. All which things were pre≈øently decreed by this Emperour, and by Lawe confirmed, and without delay effected, I≈øta vt primum ab Imperatore, vti demon≈øtratum e≈øt, decreta fuere, legeque confirmata, ab≈øque mora ≈øunt ad exitum decorum con≈øentaneumque perducta. For allmo≈øt all Chri≈øtians of the Roman Empire began to beare office, and forbad all men to offer ≈øacrifice to Idols, v≈øe the wicked exerci≈øes and ceremonies of the Gentils, Nam Christiani omnes fere Romani Imperij Magi≈øtratus gerere caeperunt: interdixeruntque omnibus ne de caetero, vel ≈øimulachris immolare, vel diuinationibus nefandis mysterijs vti, vel ≈øtatuas erigere, vel fe≈øta gentilicia celebrare aggrederentur.

5. And concerning Chri≈øtian Churches, they which were lardge enough, How generally & wonderfully Constantine honored and e≈øtablished Religion. and had bene ruinated in the time of Per≈øecution, were repaired, others were builded higher, and with honour made greater, where there were none before, new were erected euen from the foundation, and the Emperour out of his Tre≈øury afforded money therto, and wrote both to the Bishops and Pre≈øidents of euery Prouince; To the Bishops, that what ≈øoeuer they would, they should commande: and to the Pre≈øidents, that they should diligently doe what they commanded. And ≈øo with the pro≈øperous E≈øtate of his Empire, Religion greately encrea≈øed, Quod autem ad ≈øacra templa attinet, quae ≈øatis haberent laxitatis, reficiebantur: alia altius erigebantur, latioraque non ≈øine ≈øplendoris acce≈øsione fiebant. Noua etiam, vbi nulla ante fui≈ø≈øent, ab ip≈øis fundamentis extruebantur. Pecuniam autem ad hanc rem ex Aerario regio ≈øuppeditauit Imperator, ≈øcrip≈øitque tum ad Epi≈øcopos, tum ad Prae≈øides cuiu≈øque Prouinciae: ad illos quidem, vt quae vellent, imperarent; ad hos autem, vt morem gererent Epi≈øcopis, eorumque imperata ≈øtudio≈øe facerent. It aque vna cum pro≈øpero Imperij statu, magnopere creuit Religio. Out of the Lands of his owne Tribute in euery Citie he tooke a certaine Pen≈øion that was accu≈øtomed to be payed into the Tre≈øury, and di≈øtributed it to the Churches, and Clergy and by Lawe decreed that his guift to be perpetuall:

6. He cau≈øed the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe to be made vpon the Armour of his Constantine his honour to the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe. Souldiars, to accu≈øtome them thereby to ≈øerue God. He builded a Church in his Palace, and v≈øed to haue carryed with him when he went to Warre, a Pauilion after the manner of a Church, that both he and his Army being in field might haue a Church to prayer, and praye vnto God, and receaue the ≈øacred My≈øteries: for Prei≈øts and Deacons which according to the In≈øtitution of the Church should execute tho≈øe duties continually followed that Tent. He tooke away by Lawe the old punishment of the Cro≈ø≈øe v≈øed by the Romans. He cau≈øed that ≈øigne to be made on his owne Image, whether impre≈ø≈øed on money, or paynted on tables.

7. And whereas the Romans had an old Pagan Lawe again≈øt the ≈øingle Sozom. ≈øupr. l. 1. cap. 9. How he honored the cha≈øt and virginall life. and vnmarryed, after the Age of 25. yeares, di≈øabling them to make a Will, or their kin≈ømen to enioy their goods by any Legacy, or Te≈øtament, and confi≈øcated halfe their goods, which died without children (this Lawe was made by the olde Romans, to replenish not onely their City, but their whole Dominions with multitude of men, hauing lo≈øt many by ciuill Wars not long before the making of this Lawe (this Emperour perceauing that they which determined to profe≈ø≈øe Virginitie, and liue without children for
the loue of God, by this Lawe to be in wor≈øe condition then others, enacted and published a Lawe that both the vnmarryed, and they which had not children, should enioy equall libertie with others, and further decreed, that they which had vowed virginitie and cha≈øtity, should haue greater Priuiledge then the re≈øt. And which was a mo≈øt greate Argument of this Empeperours reuence towards Religion, he freed all Clergy men in all places from that Lawe, and gaue power vnto all ≈øuch which should be called before ciuill Magi≈øtrats, to appeale to the Iudgment of Bishops; And their ≈øentence should be of force, and haue more Authoritie then of other Iudges, Vetus He exempteth Clergy men from ≈øecular Iudges. erat apud Romanos lex, quae vetuit caelibes, ≈øi annum vige≈øimum quintum praeterij≈ø≈øent, paribus cum his qui nuptias contraxi≈ø≈øent, Priuilegijs frui: iu≈øsitque praeter alia multa, etiam vt nihil commodi, etiam ≈øi genere proximi e≈ø≈øent ex testamento ≈øuorum caperent. Quinetiam eos qui nullos habebant liberos, dimidiata parte bonorum quae erant reliqua mulctauit. Haec lex a veteribus Romanis ≈øancita fuit eo con≈øilio, vt non vrbem Romam ≈øolum, verum etiam caeteram ≈øuam Ditionem hominum multitudine complerent: quandoquidem haud longo tempore ante legem latam, quamplurimos bellis intestinis ac ciuilibus ami≈øerant. Quare Imperator cum videret eos qui & virginitatem excolere, & ≈øine liberis e≈ø≈øe propter Dei amorem, in animum induxi≈ø≈øent, hac de re in deteriort e≈ø≈øe conditione: legem plebi promulgauit, quae iubebat, vt cum caelibes, tum liberis carentes, pari iure cum caeteris omnibus fruerentur: Immo vero etiam decreuit, vt qui ca≈øtimoniae & virginitati ≈øe con≈øecra≈ø≈øent, Priuilegio quodam prae caeteris donarentur. Illud porro est plane maximum reuerentiae Imperatoris erga Religionem argumentum, quod clericos vbique per legem ob eam rem conditam immunitate donari voluit: quodque illis, qui erant in iudicium vocati, dedit pote≈øtatem, ≈øi modo animum inducerent Magi≈øtratus ciuiles reijcere, ad Epi≈øcoporum iudicium prouocandi, atque eorum ≈øententiam ratam e≈ø≈øe, & aliorum Iudicum ≈øententijs plus habere Authoritatis. All the≈øe and more ≈øuch publike Acts, and duties of a Chri≈øtian Emperour, Eu≈øebius, Sozomen, and others Eu≈øeb. l. 2. de Vit. Con≈øtant. c. 39. 40. 41. 42. 43. 44. 45. 46. l. 3. c. 4. 5. 6. 7. 9. Sozom. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 1. c. 8. 15. 16. 17. Ruffin. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 1. Socr. l. 1. c. 2. 3. 4. 5. proue to haue bene done by Con≈øtantine, diuers yeares before ≈øome Roman Writers affirme he was baptized by Pope S. Sylue≈øter in the yeare before the Nicen councell the 324. of Chri≈øt.

div.head: THE IX. CHAPTER.

argument.p: CONSTANTINE DID NOT PROLONG HIS Bapti≈øme ≈øo long as ≈øome write. He was not baptized, by an Arrian Bishop, neuer fell into Arriani≈øme, or any Here≈øie.

div.p:
1. THEREFORE for the honour of this our Emperour, and Country, Baron. & Spond. An. 324. to examine this more particularly: Baronius, Spondanus and others both late, and more auncient Writers doe demon≈øtrate again≈øt ≈øome GretiaÃÑs, not a litle ≈øu≈øpected of that greate ≈øinne, & Here≈øie of Arrius, or Fauourers thereof, with which ≈øu≈øpition they haue not ab≈øtained to ≈øeeme to accu≈øe this our renowned Emperour, e≈øpecially towards his later dayes, that he was both innocent of that crimination, and not baptized a litle before his death at Nicomedia by an
Arrian Bishop, but long before, and ≈øomewhat before that Here≈øie was condemned in the Nicen Councell, & by S. Sylue≈øter Pope of Rome, and in that his then Imperiall Citie, of which I shall more plainely entreate hereafter. Among their Arguments be≈øides Authours of all kindes, Greekes and Latins Pagans, and Chri≈øtians with other inuincible te≈øtimonies, a rea≈øon of cheife importance is, that ≈øo Religious and verruous a Prince and Benefactor, of the Church of Chri≈øt by Religion would not, and in con≈øcience could not ≈øo long hazard his ≈øaluation, by deferring his Bapti≈øme, the dore to enter into ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . The ≈øame Argument by proportion I may v≈øe again≈øt Baronius, and all tho≈øe, that delay the Bapti≈øme of this renowned Emperour vntill the 324. yeare of Chri≈øt, when he had bene Emperour allmo≈øt 20. yeares before, and ≈øo long, and more a Chri≈øtian in Iudgment and affection at the lea≈øt, as I haue inuincibly proued. He that had ≈øought by ≈øo many, and chardgeable meanes, to take away, preuent, and hinder negligences and ≈øins in other Chri≈øtians, in all places of his Dominions, may not be thought ≈øo negligent, and forgetfull of his owne good, and happines eternall, ≈øo many yeares in ≈øo many dangers as he vnderwent to play his ≈øoule at hazard, and tempt God ≈øo long and often in ≈øo high a degree.

2. And the≈øe Authours Them≈øelues ≈øet downe many Chri≈øtian Acts and Baron. & Spond. in Annal. an. 313. 314. 315. 316. 317. 318. 319. profe≈ø≈øions of Con≈øtantine which free him from ≈øuch neglect. In the next yeare to his Victorie again≈øt Maxentius, being the yeare of Chri≈øt 313. he gaue his ≈øi≈øter Con≈øtantia a Chri≈øtian, as the≈øe men ≈øay, wife to Licinius, not then probable that he could be ≈øo mindfull of his Si≈øters ≈øpirituall good; and carele≈ø≈øe of his owne, when e≈øpecially, as all Hi≈øtories te≈øtifie, he made this match for the propagation of Chri≈øtian Religion, Licinus by this meanes Ioyening with him in this bu≈øines, by his procuremeÃÑt. Sylue≈øter, Epi≈øt. Con≈øtant. ad Melchiad, Pap. apud Eu≈øeb. l. 10. Hi≈øt. cap. 5. before remembred is witne≈ø≈øe, how greate reuerence he then bore to the Catholike Church of Chri≈øt, before S. Sylue≈øter was Pope, non later ve≈øtram diligentiam tantum me reuerentiae Eccle≈øiae Catholicae tribuere, vt velim vos nullum pror≈øus ≈øci≈øma vel di≈øsidium aliquo in loco ferre. And concludeth his Epi≈øtle, that God allmightie would pre≈øerue him many yeares, diuinitas magni Dei multis vos annis cu≈øtodiat. This was about the time he ≈øent O≈øius into Africke, and pre≈øently vpon his Victory again≈øt Maxentius, for ≈øo longe as he liued Emperour, Afrike was vnder him, and no part of Con≈øtantine his Empire.

11. Againe it is currant in Hi≈øtoryes, that Maximinus Emperour, or Tyrant in the Ea≈øt mi≈øerably dyed in the 314. yeare of Chri≈øt, yet Con≈øtantine in that Eu≈øeb. l. 4. de vit. Con≈øtant. cap. 32. Con≈øtant. orat. ad Sanct. caet. cap. 22. cap. 23. 19. his renowned worke warranted by Eu≈øebius, and named, Oratio ad Sanctorum c ‚Ä¢ tum, doth ≈øpeake of this Maximinus as then liuing and per≈øecuting Chri≈øtians, where he plainely profe≈ø≈øeth him≈øelfe a true Chri≈øtian, often calling Chri≈øtian Religion, his Religion, nostram Religionem. There he publikely and learnedly more like an old Profe≈ø≈øor, and Doctor thereof, then a Catechumen therein, defendeth and proueth it again≈øt Pagan Philo≈øophers, and all aduer≈øaries, by the Lawe of Mo≈øes, the Prophets, & their mo≈øt certaine and euident Predictions and Prophe≈øies of Chri≈øt, by his owne and his Di≈øciples Miracles, the ≈øanctitie of his life, and Doctrine, the Prophe≈øies of the Sybils & others amoÃÑg the Gentils: the Impietie, In≈øufficiencie or Inualiditie of all other Profe≈øons in Religion, & all v≈øuall Chri≈øtian Arguments in this cau≈øe. Breifely in particular, in the very beginning of this Worke he profe≈ø≈øeth him≈øelfe to celebrate the Fea≈øt of Ea≈øter, and ≈øuch Solemnities of Chri≈øt as the renowned Chri≈øtian Bishops did, in the very fir≈øt words thereof, Salutaris dies festus Pa≈øchalis, qui est velut clari≈øsimum diei & ≈øolis lumen, primordium Re≈øurectionis vniuer≈øae carnis, pignus promi≈øsionis, & ≈øemita ad aeternam vitam deducens, nobis, chari≈øsimi Eccle≈øiae Prae≈øides, reliquique omnes amici, vo≈øque frequentes & beatae Religio≈øorum multitudines, qui ip≈øum Deum Religionis Authorem, tum intimis animi cuiu≈øque ≈øen≈øibus, tum expre≈øsis vocum praeconijs, ≈øecundum ea quae prophetarum oraculis praedicta ≈øunt, ≈øine intermi≈øsione celebratis, nobis inquam ade≈øt, ad ≈øact√® augu≈øt√©que celebrandum. Where he plainely expre≈ø≈øeth, that he celebrated this holy Chri≈øtian Fea≈øt, and Solemnitie with ≈øuch holynes, and deuotion, as the Chri≈øtian Bishops, and other Religious men and people did. And thus proceeding in his whole Worke of 26. Chapters, concludeth as he began: That both he and all which profe≈ø≈øe true Religion, both for their owne ≈øaluation, and pro≈øperitie of the Common wealth mu≈øt giue thanks to our Sauiour, and Cap. 26. & vlt. ≈øupr. obtaine of Chri≈øt by holy prayers & often ≈øupplications, that he will be plea≈øed not to cea≈øe, to be≈øtowe his benefites vpoÃÑ vs. For he is the inuincible DefeÃÑ dor of the Iu≈øt, he is the mo≈øt ≈øtrong propugner, he is the be≈øt Iudge. And finally he is the Captaine, that leadeth to Immortalitie, and giuer of euerla≈øting life. Par e≈øt omnes qui pietatem ≈øectamur, no≈øtrae ip≈øorum ≈øalutis, & rerum publicarum prosperitatis cau≈øa, Seruatori gratias agere, & Christum ≈øanctum ≈øanctis precibus atque orationibus crebris nobis placatum efficere, vt beneficia eius in nos conferre
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
non de≈øinat. I≈øte enim e≈øt Iu≈øtorum Defen≈øor inuictus: i≈øte Progugnator forti≈øsimus: i≈øte optimus Iudex: i≈øte denique immortalitatis dux, & vitae aeternae Largitor. Thus Con≈øtantine him≈øelfe hath te≈øtified in his owne cau≈øe. And Batonius Baron. & Spond. An. 324. Zo≈øimus l. 2. Sozomen. l. 2. Hi≈øtor. Eccle≈øia≈øt cap. 2. Bed. l. de locis ≈øanct. cap. vlt. Glic. l. 4. Zonar. Annal. Tom. 3. Cedren. in Comp an. 18. Con≈øtant. Nicephor. l. 8. ca. 4. with others writeth both from old Pagan and Chri≈øtian Authours, that Con≈øtantine after his Bapti≈øme by S. Sylue≈øter, ≈øtayed no litle time in Rome opeÃÑ ly profe≈ø≈øing him≈øelfe a Chri≈øtian, and before his departure thence be≈øtowed ≈øuch greate Riches and Principalitie vpon S. Sylue≈øter & the Roman Church as many Antiquites te≈øtify, and left the Citie of Rome to S. Sylue≈øter. After which he went to Ilium, where old Troy ≈øtood, intending to make it his Imperiall Citie, 800. miles or litle le≈ø≈øe from Rome, and builded the gates for a Cytie there vpoÃÑ an high hill ≈øtill remaying in SozomeÃÑ his time, as he witne≈ø≈øeth: profestus ad campum pro Ilio ≈øitum, non longe ab Hellesponto vrbis formam & magnitudinem de≈øcrip≈øit, inque praecel≈øo & edito portas extruit, quae adhuc etiam a mari illac nauigantibus cernuntur. And hauing thus farre proceeded therein building a new Citie, was, as the ≈øame Sozomen te≈øtifieth, and Baronius admitteh, admonished by an heauenly vi≈øion to de≈øi≈øt from that worke, and build his intended cheife Citie at Bizantium in Thracia, which he did, and going to this Bizantium ≈øo Miracoulou≈øly a≈ø≈øigned vnto him, began his Magnificent buildings there, as Baronius and Spondanus them≈øelues acknowledge, Baron. & Spond. in Indice Annal. v. Con≈øtantinus an. 324. Iacob. Gedeon. An. 324. Bin. Tom. 1. Concil. in Sylue≈øtro. ‚Ä¢ Cedr. ≈øupr. Conc. Rom. c. 1. in the 324. yeare of Chri≈øt, Con≈øilium inijt de noua vrbe condenda, in quam transferat Imperium, & po≈øt tentatum Ilium, diuinitus eligit Bizantium Anno Chri≈øti 324.

12. Cedrenus ≈øetteth downe this building of Bizantium two yeares ≈øooner, the Roman Councell, Baronius and others ≈øay, that after Con≈øtantine was baptized he ≈øtayed the whole time of that Councell in Rome before he went into the Ea≈øte. And the Donation it≈øelfe of Con≈øtantine after he was baptized is dated in his 4. Con≈øulshipp, which Baronius, Binius and others confe≈ø≈øe to haue bene in the yeare of Chri≈øt 315. Marianus ≈øaith it was in the 312. yeare of Baron. & Bin. ≈øup Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. an. 312. Concil. Roman. c. 1. Barthol. Carranza ante Rom. Concil. Roman. Concil. c. 20. & vlt. his IncarnatioÃÑ. And the RomaÃÑ Councell wherein he, a baptized Chri≈øtiaÃÑ, both as the ≈øame Councell and others te≈øtifie, was pre≈øent, and bore the chardges of the Bishops a≈ø≈øembled there: Con≈øtantinus vehicula vel annonas omni loco prae≈øtari praecepit, was kept, as the ≈øame Councell deliuereth, in the third Con≈øulship of Con≈øtantine, which was by all men before the 315. yeare of Chri≈øt, 3. Kalend. Iunij, Donno Con≈øtantino Augu≈øto tertio & Pri≈øco Con≈øule. By which it al≈øo appeareth, that his ≈øonne Pri≈øcus was lyuing longe after his Bapti≈øme. And ≈øo the opinion of them, which ≈øay he was dead before, is an≈øweared by this Councell, ≈øub≈øcribed vnto by 284. Bishops, 45. Prei≈øts, 5. Deacons and 2. Cap. 10. & 20. Acoluthi≈øts together with Con≈øtantine one Emperour, and S. Helen his Mother after them, as appeareth in all Copies of that Councell, Et ≈øub≈øcrip≈øerunt 284. Epi≈øcopi, & 45. Presbiteri, & 5. Diaconi & duo ≈øcquentes, & Augu≈øtus Con≈øtantinus & mater eius Helena. Therefore this Councell being kept in Rome after Con≈øtantine was baptized, as all agree, and is euident in the ≈øame Councell in expre≈ø≈øe wordes, Con≈øtantinus baptizatus a Sylue≈øtro Epi≈øcopo vrbis Romae, Cap. 1. and in the third Con≈øulship of Con≈øtantine, and this Emperour there pre≈øent in Rome, and two yeares after at the lea≈øt, as appeareth by the Act of his Donation to S. Sylue≈øter granted there before his going into the Ea≈øte, bearing date the yeare of his fourth Con≈øulship and at Rome: Datum Romae Donatio Con≈øtantiniin fine ≈øub tertio Die kalendarum Aprilium Domino no≈øtro flauio Con≈øtantino Augu≈øto quater et Gallicano viro clari≈øsimo Con≈øulibus, he mu≈øt needs be baptized longe before the 324. yeare of Chri≈øt, about the beginning of S. Sylue≈øter his Papacy.
For this Roman Councell is cleare, that he was baptized before the calling thereof, and prouided waggons to tran≈øport ≈øo many Bishops thither, which required no ≈ømall time, diuers of them comming from remote parts and Countryes. Againe there was ≈øo generally a Conuer≈øion of the Romans to Chri≈øt Roman. Concil. can. 1. 10. before this Councell, that the Prefect of Rome him≈øelfe was conuerted, and pre≈øent in this Councell: erat ibi & Calphurnius Chri≈øtianus, Praefectus vrbis. Be≈øides, whereas this Councell te≈øtifieth, that S. Helen our Empre≈ø≈øe was al≈øo there, it proueth a longe time betweene the Bapti≈øme of Con≈øtantine, and then a≈ø≈øembling of this Councell. For our renowned Hi≈øtorians, Marianus and Florentius Wigornien≈øis proue, that S. Helen was in Britaine, when her ≈øonne was baptized at Rome by S. Sylue≈øter, and hearing of it, wrote vnto him froÃÑ hence: Con≈øtantino a Papa Sylue≈øtro baptizato ≈øcrip≈øit de Britannia ≈øibi ≈øua Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. an. 321. Floren. Wigorn. in Chronic. mater Helena. And without que≈øtion had an≈øweare from him againe, before she addre≈ø≈øed her≈øelfe for ≈øo greate a Iorney, and afterward was no short time in that Trauaile. And before we bring either S. Helen, or Con≈øtantine, or any other to this Councell, we mu≈øt, except we will vnrea≈øonably with ≈øome deny that Hi≈øtory, ≈øay that the longe-prouided-for di≈øpute betweene S. Sylue≈øter and the Iewes in the pre≈øence of both Con≈øtan≈øtine & S. Helen was ≈øolemnely ≈øummoned and kept after S. Helen her comming to Rome, and before the beginning of that Councell we mu≈øt allowe no shorte time for ≈øo greate a Councell. And yet Con≈øtantine, by the date of his owne Edict and Donation, was in Rome 2. yeares at the lea≈øt after all the≈øe things ended, which will bring his Bapti≈øme to the time of my former computation. Otto Frigen≈øis, be≈øides ≈øo many others before, doth plainely ≈øay, that Con≈øtantine Otto frigen. Chronic. l. 4. cap 2. was a Chri≈øtian before Licinius ioyned with him for the peace, and Priuiledge of Chri≈øtians in their publicke Edicts, Con≈øtantinus Chri≈øtianus factus pacem Eccle≈øijs reddidit, cui etiam ad hoc Licinius con≈øen≈øum praebuit.

div.head: THE X. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THE VNDOVBTED TRVTH OF THE DOnation and munificent enritching of the Church of Rome by Con≈øtantine the Greate Emperour.

div.p: 1. AMONG other the bounties and magnificences of Con≈øtantine to the Church of Chri≈øt, e≈øpecially the Apo≈øtolike See of Rome, before he departed thence to Bizantium, and the Ea≈øterne Countryes, that which is called his Donation or gift to S. Sylue≈øter, is renowned in Hi≈øtories, and bearing date in the yeare of his fourth time being Con≈øul, except it be mi≈ødated, it mu≈øt needs be granted in the 315. of Chri≈øt, as Hi≈øtorians commonly con≈øent. Diuers, e≈øpecially Prote≈øtants of this Age, haue called the credit hereof into que≈øtion. Yet except we shall di≈øallowe Seuerin. Bin. To. 1. Concil. notat. in Edict. Con≈øtaÃÑt. in S. Sylue≈øtro. both the Te≈øtimony of God, and men of greate credit, and in no ≈ømall number euen of this Nation, be≈øides an allmo≈øt nuÃÑberle≈ø≈øe company of other Countryes, we may not deny the honour thereof to that our Emperour, and this kingdome his natiue ≈øoyle. A Prote≈øtant Bishop with others doe thus cite how this donation was prophe≈øied of before Con≈øtantines time.

lg.l: Adueniet Princeps, ≈øub quo pacabitur orbis,
Et finem accipiet veterum cultura Deorum.
Con≈øtantinus apud Thraces, qu√† Bo≈øphorus aequor
Thracius Euxinis aegeum ingurgitat vndis, Io. Bal. l. 1. de Act. Roman. Pont. in Sylue≈øtro. Bapti≈øt. MaÃÑtuan. l. 2. de Vita S. Bla≈øij.
Con≈øtituet ≈øedem Imperij: Latiumque relinquet
Chri≈øto, & Romuleam ≈øeptem cum collibus vrbem.

div.p: Sainct Bede is a manife≈øt witnes, that long before the dayes brechtus King of the Longabards long before his time the Cottian Alpes and other parts of Italy did belonge to the See Apo≈øtolike of Rome, vntill the LoÃÑ gabards by violence tooke them away, and this King of theirs Herebrechtus re≈øtored them, Herebrechtus Rex Longobardorum multas curtas & patrimonia Alpium Cottiarum, quae quondam ad Ius pertinebant Apo≈øtolicae ≈øedis, ≈øed a Longobardis Bed. de 6. aetatib. mundi. in Tiberio 2. multo tempore fuerant ablata, re≈øtituit iuri eiu≈ødem Sedis. Which long time of the right of the Roman Church to this Patrimony thereof, not finding any other donation of them vnto it, will bring vs to the dayes of Con≈øtantine. Our old English Hi≈øtory ≈øaith, S. Syluester receiued the Patrimony of S. Peter, that is for to ≈øay, the kingdome of Italy, with the Citie of Rome of Con≈øtantine the Emperour, Old. Engl. Hi≈øt. part. 4. fol. 38. and to the whorship of the Church of God he turned it. Harding thus writeth:

lg.l: Con≈øtantine gaue his owne Palays royall
With Rome all whole, and all the dignitee
Through out Romany, with-Sea Imperiall Harding. Chron. cap. 63. fol. 50.
To Sylue≈øter, that had the Papall ‚Ä¢ ea,
He gaue it to him all quite and free,
And to his Succe≈ø≈øours perpetually.

div.p:
2. William of Malmesbury citing S. Aldelmus and others ≈øaith, that herein S. Aldelm. l. de virginit. Guliel. Malmesbur. l. 4. de Regib. Con≈øtantine obeyed Gods commande, paruit Augustus vi≈øioni, profe≈ø≈øus non debere Imperatorem Romae principari, vbi a Chri≈øto principabantur coronati Apo≈øtoli. Henry of Huntington and others ≈øet downe at lardge, an Epi≈øtle of S. Gregory Pope of Rome to King Ethelbert of kent, conuerted by S. Augu≈øtine, wherein he te≈øtefieth no le≈ø≈øe, when he ≈øaith, this greate Emperour Con≈øtantine made the Roman Commonwealth and him≈øelfe ≈øubiect vnto our Lord Gregor. Epi≈øtol. ad Ethelbert. Reg. apud Henric. Hunt. Hi≈øto. l. 3. Matth. We≈øt. an. 335. Manu≈øcript. antiq. in Con≈øtantino. Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, Constantinus quondam pij≈øsimus Imperator Romanam Rempublicam omnipotenti Deo & Domi no no≈øtro Ie≈øu Chri≈øto ≈øecum ≈øubdidit. And Matthew of of We≈øtmin≈øter playnely ≈øaith, that Con≈øtantine gaue by his Donation old Rome, the head of the world, to the ble≈ø≈øed Apo≈øtles S. Peter and S. Paul, Imperator Con≈øtantinus Caput mundi Romam beatis Petro & Paulo ≈øub testamento tradidit. I finde in an old Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtorie principally of this Nation in this manner: Con≈øtantinus omnes dignitatis Imperiales Papae contulit & ip≈øe Sedem Imperialem apud Con≈øtantinopolim constituit, dignitatem tamen ≈øedis Apostolicae apud Romam Succe≈ø≈øoribus beati Petri reliquit. Con≈øtantine gaue all Imperiall dignities to the Pope, and placed his Imperiall Seate at Con≈øtantinople, yet left the dignitie of the See Apo≈øtolike at Rome to the Succe≈ø≈øors of S. Peter. An other written in FreÃÑch thus relateth this matter: Con≈øtantine founded 12. Churches in Rome in honour of the 12. Apo≈øtles, and after, with the Nobilitie of Rome went to Con≈øtantinople, but before his going, gaue his Priuiledge to the Papall See, and his Palace with all the Regalitie to S. Peter Prince of the Apo≈øtles, and to S. Sylue≈øter and his Succe≈ø≈øors for euer, Con≈øtantin fai≈øoit 12. Egli≈øes Manu≈øcript. Gallic. antiq. cap. 30. en la Citee de Rome en l'honneur des 12. Apo≈øtres, & apres que ≈øes nobles de Rome s'en alla √† Constantinoble, & auant s'en aller donna≈øon priuilege du Siege Papale & ≈øon Palais o√π toute la regalit√© √† S. Pierre Prince des Apo≈øtres, & √† S. Sylue≈øtre Abbreuiat. Chro An. 310. & ≈øes Succe≈ø≈øeurs perdurablement. The old Manu≈øcript Abbreuiatio Chronicorum
hath the ≈øame with with S. Aldelmus and William of Malmesbury before. Iohannes Salisburien≈øis ≈øaith, that Con≈øtantine is renowned with Ioh. Salisberien. lib. 4. Polycrat. cap. 6. apud Iodoc. Cocc. Tom. 1. l. 7. art. 10. An≈øelm. l. 4. cap. 32. in Rubric. eiu≈ødeÃÑ apud Coce. ≈øup. Iodoc. Cocc. in The≈øauro Catho lico Tom. 1. l. 7. articul. 10. Abraham Leuita Chron. Iudaic. euerla≈øting ble≈ø≈øednes for founding and endowing the Church of Rome, be≈øides other excellent deeds, Con≈øtantinus Romana Eccle≈øia findata & dotata vt caetera eius taceantur egregie, perpetua benedictione in≈øignis e≈øt. And S. An≈øelm. our renowned Archbishop plainely te≈øtifieth: Con≈øtantinus Imperator Papae conce≈øsit coronam & omnem regiam dignitatem in vrbe Romana, & Italia, & in partibus Occidentalibus.

3. The number of forraine Writers, both auncient and later, which affirme this donatioÃÑ, is much too ample to be cited in Hi≈øtorie, Coccius hath gathered many, but left no ≈ømall company vnremembred. And not onely Chri≈øtians but their mo≈øt profe≈ø≈øed enemyes the Iewes them≈øelues much to their shame, and confu≈øion giue manife≈øt te≈øtimony to this Donation. Abraham Leuita plainely ≈øaith, that Con≈øtantine went from Rome, and gaue it to the Prei≈øts of the Christians, which he termeth Idumaeans, and builded Con≈øtantinople, Ip≈øe exijt Roma, & dedit eam ≈øacrificis Idumaeorum ad hanc diem aedificata Con≈øtantinopoli. R. Abraham Abin E≈øra ad cap. 11. Daniel. Rabi, Abraham, Aben, E≈øra, ≈øaith of Con≈øtantine: decorauit locum Romae, quae erat Sedes eius, & reliquit eam Petro. He adorned the place of Rome, which was his ≈øeate, and left it to Peter.

4. Therefore no man may ≈øay, that this Hi≈øtorie wanteth authoritie, when ≈øo many Writers of greate authoritie affirme it. We may not ≈øay it is a late inuention, many of the≈øe Authors want not antiquitie. And the Epi≈øtle written Epi≈øtol. primitiuae Eccl. apud S. I≈øodor. in collect. Concil. & Tom. 1. Concil. about that time intituled, de primitiua Eccle≈øia, & munificentia Con≈øtantini Magni Imperatoris erga candem, of the primatiue Church and the munificence of Con≈øtantine the greate Emperor towards it, which S. I≈øidor ≈øetteth downe at large, plainely ≈øaith of this Noble Emperor: religio≈øi≈øsimus Con≈øtantinus donaria immen≈øa contulit & Fabricam Templi primae Sedis beati Petri Principis Apo≈øtolorum in≈øtituit, adeo vt Sedem Imperialem, quam Romani Principes po≈ø≈øederant, relinqueret, & beato Petro ≈øuisque Succe≈ø≈øoribus profuturam concederet. That he left his Imperiall Seate among other munificent gifts to S. Peter and his Succe≈ø≈øors. Ioa. Diacon. in Vita S. Gregorij & alij. Gregor. l. 1. Epi≈øt. 73. l. 5. Epi≈øt. 11. l. 2 Epi≈øt. 40. 41. 44. 61. Epi≈øt. 10. 52. 55 l. 1. Ep. 72. 2. 68. 70. 23. 62. l. 5. Epi. 12. Bed. de 6. aetatib. in Tiberio 2. Paul Diacon. de ge≈øt. Longobard. l. 6. Bed. ≈øup. in Ana≈øta≈øio. Paul. Diac. l. 6. ≈øup. Otto Frigens. Chron. l. 4. cap. 3. We finde in the life of S. Gregory the Greate ≈øuch munificent & chargeable almes by him, that argueth the exceeding Ritches of the Church of Rome at that time, euen when the Longobard had vfurped vpon great part of the Patrimony of S. Peter. And this notwith≈øtanding S. Gregory him≈øelfe in his ≈øeuerall Epi≈øtles giueth vndeniable te≈øtimonie, that the Church of Rome then had ample reuenewes in Afrike, Naples, Campania, Dalmatia, France, Sicily, Ital ‚Ä¢ , Sardinia and other Countries.

5. I haue related before how the Cottian Alpes did of auÃÑcient time belonge to the RomaÃÑ Church, and being wre≈øted from it by the Longobards, their King Herebrechtus, or by others Aribertus, re≈øtored them againe, and as both S. Bede, Paulus Diaconus, and others write, ≈øent the relea≈øe thereof to Rome written in golden letters, Donationem aureis ≈øcriptam literis Romam mi≈øit. And Luitprandus did the like, & Otto Frigen≈øis neare in kindred to the Emperors & well acquainted with their affaires, ≈øaith; that from the time of Con≈øtantine his leauing Rome to S. Sylue≈øter, as the RomaÃÑs Hi≈øtorie te≈øtifieth, and going to Con≈øtantinople, the RomaÃÑ Church affirmeth, that the mo≈øt parts were giuen vnto it, as a Right by Con≈øtantine, and in Argument thereof claimed Tribute of them vnto his time, excepting of the French, which had a≈ø≈øi≈øted it in that demand, Vt Romanorum habet hi≈øtoria Imperator Con≈øtantinus in tantum Romanam exaltauit Eccle≈øiam, vt beato Sylue≈øtro eiu≈ødem vrbis Pontifici, in≈øignibus Regni
traditis, ip≈øe ≈øe Bizantium transferret ibique Sedem Regni con≈øtitueret. Exhinc Romana Eccie≈øia Occidentalia regna tanquam ≈øui Iuris √† Con≈øtantino ≈øibi tradita affirmat, in Argumentumque, Tributum, exceptis duobus Francorum Regnis, v≈øque hodi√® exigere non dubitat. Many Arguments and vnan≈øwearable al≈øo there be of this Donation. The freedome of the French Nation from that Tribute for a≈ø≈øi≈øting Regin. in Cronic. Sigebert. Chron. Baron. Annal. in Con≈øtant. Binn. Tom. 1. Concil. not. in Edict. Con≈øt. the RomaÃÑ See to recouer greate parts of the Patrimony thereof, proueth ≈øuch a Donation. The Palace of Con≈øtantine called S. Ihon Laterans, a Noble Church euer in the Popes power froÃÑ that time proueth it. No Emperor ≈øince then hauing either Palace or Re≈øidency in Rome, when before this Donation it was in all Hi≈øtoryes the knowne cheife Imperiall Citie in the world, maketh it manife≈øt. The e≈øpeciall Reuerence and honour which Con≈øtantine euer performed towards the Roman Church aboue all others, compared with his bountie and magnificence to all, beareth no ≈ømall te≈øtimony in this kind. So doe the Examples of other newly conuerted Kings, e≈øpecially of this Nation, as King Lucius, King Ethelbert, and others, all mo≈øt reuerently honoring that See Apo≈øtolike. Therefore our Prote≈øtant Writers them≈øelues, though di≈øliking all Princes, and others Donations and bouÃÑties to the Church of Chri≈øt, the Ritches and honor thereof, doe confe≈ø≈øe this greate gift of Con≈øtantine vnto S. Sylue≈øter. One a late Poet writeth for their common opinion:

lg.l: From Con≈øtantius and Helen proceeded Con≈øtantine
The mo≈øt vndoubted heire Will. Warner. Albions EnglaÃÑd cap. 18.
Both to the Roman Monarchie, and this his Parents Reame.
He turned the Empires ebbing pompe into her fllo ‚Ä¢ ing ≈øtreame,
And was a Prince Religious: yet (with reuerence be it ≈øaid)
If le≈ø≈øe Religious, then not he the Empire had decaid
By large≈ø≈øe to a ‚Ä¢ ponpous Prei≈øt, and ≈øeazed him of Rome.

div.head: THE XI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE SETLING OF THE IMPERIALL Seat at Bizantium, or Con≈øtantinople, and Conuer≈øion of, or ≈øetling the Chri≈øtian faith in many Nations by the helpe of our Brittish Emperor Con≈øtantine: But Ireland not then conuerted.

div.p:
1. CONSTANTINE hauing thus di≈øpo≈øed of his Imperiall Palace in Rome, and be≈øtowed ≈øo magnificent gifts, and reuenewes vpon that holy Apo≈øtolike Church, departed from thence towards the Ea≈øterne Countries, hauing a re≈øolution to ≈øetle his Seate of Empire at, or neare the place of old Troye Ilium, not farre Sozom. l. 2. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. cap. 2. Baron. & Spond. Annal. an. 324. in Indice. Seba≈øt. Mun≈øter. Co≈ømogr. l. 4. in Graecia pag. 937. 938. froÃÑ Helle≈øpoÃÑtus. And as Sozomen with others deliuereth, layde the platforme there of his cheife≈øt Citie, building the Gates vpon an high hill, which remained in the dayes of Sozomen, and were ≈øeene to ≈øuch as ≈øayled vpon that Sea, √† mari illac nauigantibus cernuntur. But was admonished by an heauenly vi≈øion to de≈øi≈øt from that de≈øigne, & build his commanding Citie at Bizantium, in Thracia, which he according to the direction giuen him by God performed, Ei ista molienti Deus noctu vi≈øus, alium locum quaerere iubet: atque cum Bizantium, oppidum Thraciae vltra Calcedonem vrbem Bithyniae ≈øitum, in memoriam ei redigi≈ø≈øet, eam vt habitatoribus complendam, quippe quae nomen Con≈øtantini
mereretur, curaret admonuit. Itaque verbis Dei ob≈øecutus oppidum quod Bizantium vocabatur, dilatare, & maximis ampli≈øsimi≈øque moenibus cingere coepit. This diuine vi≈øion, and direction was, as Sozomen hath plainely te≈øtified before Con≈øtantine went to Bizantium: and after he came thither, and before he layed the foundation of his Imperiall Citie there, he had an other heauenly apparition, and admonition about the ≈øame matter in the Citie of Bizantium, as our owne auncient and approued Antiquaries Sainct Aldelmus a renowned Bishop, and William Malmesbury with others deliuer vnto vs, Imperator in Ciuitate quae Bizantium S. Aldelm. lib. de laudib. Virg. cap. 12. Guliel. Malmesburien≈ø. lib. 4 de Regib. in Gulielmo 2. & alij apud eund. vocabatur cum membra ≈øopori dedi≈ø≈øet, & debitum naturae ≈øolueret. Which vi≈øion was in this manner: A very old woman, decrepite and almo≈øt dead appeared vnto him, whom Sainct Sylue≈øter coÃÑmanded to rai≈øe her vp by prayer: And Con≈øtantine praying the old woman aro≈øe, and became a mo≈øt beutifull youÃÑg woman, who by her cha≈øte looke plea≈øing his Princely ≈øight, he ca≈øt his cloake vpon her, and put a Diademe adorned with gold and pretious ≈øtones vpon her head. And Helena his mother ≈øaid vnto him, she shall be thyne, and shall not dye vntill in the end of the world. Con≈øtantine awaking and troubled with the vi≈øion, ignoraÃÑt of the meaning thereof, gaue him≈øelfe to fa≈øting, and in the ≈øeuenth day of his fa≈øt, in his ≈øleepe ≈øainct Sylue≈øter appeared vnto him, and ≈øaid: The old decrepite woman is this Citie named Bizantium, in which thou now remaine≈øt, who≈øe walles are con≈øumed with Age, and are almo≈øt fallen downe. Ride vpon that thy hor≈øe whereon thou did≈øt ride in thy white ve≈øtures when thou wert baptized in the Citie of Rome, vi≈øiting rounde about the Tombes of the Apo≈øtles, and Martyrs, and carry thy Labaru, or En≈øigne that is embrodered with the ≈øigne of Chri≈øt of gold, and pretious ≈øtones in thy right hand, let the bridle of thy hor≈øe loo≈øe, and goe as the Angell of God shall leade thee. And drawe the point of thy Labarum ≈øo on the ground that it may drawe and leaue a line behinde it, by which trace and circuite shalt tho cau≈øe walles to be builded, & this old Citie, & almo≈øt dead thou shalt ray≈øe to be new, and thou shalt call it by thy name, and make it the Queene of all Cities. The name of Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt shall be magnified in it, and in it Churches of God shall be builded to the honor of all Saints, and thy ≈øonnes after thee, and the ≈øonnes of thy ≈øonnes shall reigne in it, Tu fixam cu≈øpidem Labari in terra ≈øic trahe, vt ≈øemitam faciat tran≈øitus ≈øui, per quam ≈øemitam extrui facias muros, & hanc veteranam ciuitateni, & pene mortuam in iuuenculam ≈øu≈øcitabis: & tui nominis vocabulum ≈øu≈øcitabis, ita vt Reginam illam facias o mnium vrbium. Erit enim in ea nomen Domini Ie≈øu Christi magnificum, & erant in Gul. Malmesb. l. 4. ≈øup. ea templa Dei ad honorem omnium Sanctorum con≈øtructa & filij tui po≈øt ‚Ä¢ te, & filij filiorum tuorum regnabunt in ea. William the Monke of Malmesbury ≈øaith, that the an≈øwere was, that an Imperiall Po≈øteritie should reigne in that Citie for euer Et regnabit in ea perpetuo imperatoria progenies, as we haue ≈øeene many hundreds of yeares performed. And he addeth that Con≈øtantine by fa≈øting and almes deeds procured the ≈øolution of this vi≈øion from heauen, Huius ≈øomnij ≈øolutionem Augu≈øtus ieiunijs & eleemo≈øynis extrahebat √® coelo. And among other rea≈øons did greately ioy al≈øo for this, becau≈øe he borne heare in Britaine a colder Nation, could not ≈øo well endure the heate of the ≈øonne, he was by Gods commandement to build his cheife permanent Citie there, where both the fruitefulne≈ø≈øe of the ≈øoyle, and temper of the ayre were agreable vnto health, Gratumque admodum fui≈ø≈øe ferunt Imperiali animo, vt illic vrbem diuino iu≈ø≈øu fundaret, vbi & ≈øoli vhertas & coeli temperies mortalium ≈øaluti conueniret. Quia enim in Britannia natus fuerat, ardores ≈øolis exo≈øus e≈øt.

2. But the cheife≈øt cau≈øe of his Ioy in this de≈øignment vnto Con≈øtantine was this, to ≈øee his owne will ≈øo to haue concurred with the will of God, and to be thus Miraculou≈øly confirmed, that the greate Liberties & Dononations which he had conferred vpon the Apo≈øtolike See of Rome, and his leauing that his Imperiall Citie to S. Sylue≈øter then Pope and his Succe≈ø≈øors, in honour of S. Peter and S. Paul ruling and Martyred there, and to founde an other for him≈øelfe and his Imperiall Po≈øteritie, plainely expre≈ø≈øed a≈øwell by this our English, as other Authours: paruit Augu≈øtus vi≈øioni procliue, & ciuitatemae quam Guliel. Malme≈ø. ≈øupr. Romae constituit, profe≈ø≈øus non debere Imperatorem Romae principari, vbi a Chri≈øto principabantur coronati Apo≈øtoli. And as S. Aldelme addeth, this worthie Emperour S. Aldelm. l. de laudib. Virgin. cap. 12. ≈øupra. pre≈øently vpon this heauenly vi≈øion, & direction went to the Church, and acquainted the Bishop of that place, an holy man named Si≈øaminus therewith, and offering there gifts vnto God, and receauing the holy Sacrament of Chri≈øts body, tooke his hor≈øe, and Labarum, as he was directed, and went as the Angell of God did leade him, and cau≈øed the foundation to be laide as the marke of the Labarum pre≈øcribed. And the Citie was called the Citie of Con≈øtantine, Con≈øtantinople, in the Greeke languadge to this day, Euigilans Con≈øtantinus ≈øtatim ad Eccle≈øiam perrexit, indican≈øque Epi≈øcopo ciuitatis viro ≈øancto, nomine Si≈øamino, ≈øomnium quod prius viderat, & offerens Deo munera, & communicans Sacramentum Dominicum a≈øcendit equum, & perrexit, quo eum duxit Angelus Domini atque per ≈øemitas Labari, fundamenta creuerunt. Appellata e≈øt autem ciuitas Con≈øtantini, quod Graeco ≈øermone interpretatur Con≈øtantinopolis v≈øque in hodiernum diem.

3. Greate was the honour and glory both temporall and ≈øpirituall of this Citie. William of Malmesbury ≈øaith, the Wall was twenty miles in circuite, Viginti millia pa≈ø≈øuum muro complexa. And thereupon termed by the Turkes as Gul. Malm. ≈øupr. Seba≈øtian. Mun≈øter. Co≈ømogr. l. 4. in Graecia & Con≈øtantinopol. Sozomen. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 2. c. 2. Co≈ømographers haue writen, Stampolei, or Stampolda, id est, ampla ciuitas the greate Citie. Sozomen witne≈ø≈øeth that in all mens Iudgments in his time, it farre excelled Rome both for number of people, aboundance of money and Ritches, Tum frequentia hominum, tum pecuniae & diuitiarum abundantia Romam omnium con≈øen≈øu long√® ≈øuperaret. And for ≈øpirituall Dignitie the ≈øame Authour writeth of this Citie: the faith of Chri≈øt ≈øo increa≈øed there, that very many Iewes, and allmo≈øt all the Gentils there were conuerted to Chri≈øtian Religion. And this Citie being made the cheife≈øt of the Empire at that time, when the Religion of Chri≈øt was ≈øo generally dilated, it did not afterward defilc it≈øelfe either with the Altars or Temples of the Gentils, except onely while Iulian did reigne a short time, the error of the Gentils was renewed, but pre≈øeÃÑtly after extinguished againe. Con≈øtantine placed a Court called a Senate in it, and a≈ø≈øigned to the Senators the ≈øame honours, and Priuiledges, which were giuen to the old Romans, and laboured to make this Citie called by his name equall to Rome, which is in Italy. He adorned it with many and mo≈øt greate Churches, to who≈øe labour herein God him≈øelfe gaue a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, and by certaine vi≈øions confirmed that the Churches founded in that Citie were holy and bringing ≈øaluation, cuius propen≈øo ≈øtudio Deus ip≈øe opem tulit & vi≈øionibus quibu≈ødam confirmauit, Eccle≈øias in ea vrbe aedi≈øicatas, ≈øanctas & ≈øalutares e≈ø≈øe. He ≈øetteth downe one of the≈øe Churches principally to haue bene then in greate reuerence euen with Pilgrims re≈øorting vnto it in pilgrimadge and deuotion, called Michaelium, becau≈øe S. Michael the Archangell appeared there, and in this Church Sozomen him≈øelfe receaued greate help. And diuers others fallen into ineuitable mi≈øchances, and dangers, into di≈øea≈øes and
vnknowne greifes of body ≈øo ≈øoone as they prayed in that place were prefectly deliuered from the calamities where with they were oppre≈ø≈øed. Which would be too long to mention particularly, being ≈øo many, Eam quae in loco qui ve≈øtae ≈øacer obim dicebatur, in maximo honore tum a peregrinis, tum a ciuibus ex illo tempore habitam fui≈ø≈øe constat. Idem locus iam Michaelium nominatur. Loco ver√≤ istud nomen e√≤ impo≈øitum e≈øt, quod pro certo creditur, diuum Michaelem Archangelum ibi apparui≈ø≈øe. Quod etiam ip≈øe equidem non paruum in eodem loco beneficium adeptus, veri≈øsimum e≈ø≈øe confiteor. Atque idica ≈øe habere argumento praeterea e≈ø≈øe po≈ø≈øunt multae aliae res, quas compertum e≈øt ibidem gestas e≈ø≈øe. Nam nonnulli in graues ca≈øus & peric ‚Ä¢ lae quibus nullo modo po≈ø≈øent emergere, alij in morbos aut perturbationes corporis incognitas dilap≈øi, ≈øimul ac in eo loco Deum precati e≈ø≈øent, calamitatibus quibus premebantur, penitus liberati ≈øunt. Verum quo pacto i≈øta, & quibus hominibus euencrint, ≈øingillatim per≈øequi longum e≈ø≈øet.

4. And to giue ≈øome notice to Po≈øteritie what manner of diuine ≈øeruice was v≈øed then in the≈øe holy Churches, to a≈ø≈øuer vs, it was the Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, which was offered there on ≈øacred Altares, and they adorned with Cro≈ø≈øes & holy Images: the ≈øame Authour te≈øtifieth that in this Miraculous Church there was an Altar for offering that ble≈ø≈øed Sacrifice, with Cro≈ø≈øe or Crucifix placed vpon it, Crucis effigies in altari illius Eccle≈øiae ≈øtatui ≈øolet. And that v≈øage and cu≈øtome was confirmed by diuine Miracle, te≈øtifiing that from the time of Chri≈øts ≈øuffering vpon the Cro≈ø≈øe what ≈øoeuer things were done either for the common profit of mankind, or the priuate of ≈øome, either by holy Angels or godly and perfect men, they were not rightly done, without the vertue of the ≈øauing Cro≈ø≈øe, Vi≈øio diuinitus oblata, quandam Crucis effigiem, quae in altari illius Eccle≈øiae ≈øtatui ≈øolet, ante oculos propo≈øuit: declarauitque manife≈øt√©, res quaecunque a tempore quo Chri≈øtus in Crucem actus erat, velad vtilitatem humani generis communem, vel ad priuatam quorundam, ≈øeu a diuinis Angelis, ≈øeu a pijs & perfectis hominibus ge≈øtae fuerunt, non ≈øine virtute Crucis ≈øalutaris rect√® ge≈øtas e≈ø≈øe.

5. Where we finde as greate honour and reuerence giuen to the Cro≈ø≈øe, from Chri≈øt, as after. And this Authour liuing in this fourth hundred of yeares neare the dayes of this Emperour te≈øtifieth, with diuers others, that in the Empire of Con≈øtantine, and by his meanes, the faith of Chri≈øt was not onely dilated throughout the Roman Empire, but into the whole world, Chri≈øti nomen Con≈øtantino rerum potiente, in orbem vniuer≈øum propagatum ≈øit. Chri≈øti Religio etiam ad ip≈øos Barbaros perua≈øit. The Celts, the vttermo≈øt people of the Gaules by the Ocean, the Gothes, and people bordering vpon them, the Inhabitants by I≈øter, Armenians, Perfians, and others were then conuerted to the faith of Chri≈øt. The Kingdome of Ireland by ≈øome Writers not conuerted in the time of Constantine the Greate.

6. Among the Countryes and Kingdomes then conuerted, diuers doe reckoÃÑ the Kingdome of Ireland to haue bene one, and by this meanes and manner, as both Catholike and Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians relate it, Ireland receaued the faith of Chri≈øt in the yeare 335. when as Fincomarc reigned in Scotland, and this happened by meanes of a woman among the Picts, who growing famuliar with the Queene in the yeare 322. preached the Chri≈øtian faith vnto her: the Queene wonne the King, shewing him what had bene preached vnto her. And the King dispo≈øed his people to receaue Edw. Grym≈øton. booke of E≈øtat. in Ireland. pag. 36. ¬ß. 15. Bapti≈øme about the yeare 335.
