Relating this greate miracle there ≈øtill continued, that the place whereon the feete of our Sauiour ≈øtood, when he a≈øcended to heauen could not by any arte or Indu≈øtry be Ioyned to the re≈øt of the pauement: But when and who≈øoeuer attempted to couer it, the marbell ≈øtones did pre≈øently miraculou≈øly bounde again≈øt the faces of the workemen, Illud mirum qu√≤d locus ille in quo po≈øtremum in≈øtiterant diuina ve≈øtigia, c√πm in caelum Dominus nube ≈øublatus e≈øt, continuari pauimento cum reliqua stratorum parte non potuit. Siquidem quaecunque applicabantur,
in≈øolens humana ≈øu≈øcipere terra respueret excu≈øsis in ora apponentium ≈øaep√® marmoribus.

11. This Authour liuing in that Age, addeth further, that the prints of Chri≈øts Feete were ≈øtill ≈øeene in the ≈øande, allthough the Pilgryms re≈øorting thither vpon deuotion in greate aboundance did carry away the earth where Chri≈øt ≈øtood at that time of his A≈øcen≈øion, C√πm quotidi√® confluentium fides certatim Domino calcata diripiat, damnum tamen arena non ≈øentiat: Et eadem adhuc ≈øui ≈øpeciem, velut impre≈øsis ≈øignata ve≈øtigijs, terra cu≈øtodit. Which te≈øtified al≈øo by the auncient Bishop of France Arcuulfus an eye-witne≈ø≈øe thereof in his Arcuulf. & AdaÃÑ nan l. de locis ≈øanctis. Beb. l. 5. Hi≈øt. Eccl. c. 18. Pilgrimage to Hieru≈øalem, our learned Religeous Countryman Adamnanus, S. Bede and others relate, In cuius Eccle≈øiae medio vltima Domini ve≈øtigia caelo de≈øuper patente vbi a≈øcendit vi≈øuntur, quae cum quotidi√® √† credentibus terra tollatur nihilominus manet, eandemque adhuc ≈øpeciem veluti impre≈øsis ≈øignatam ve≈øtigijs ≈øeruat.

12. And they further witne≈ø≈øe, that the Roofe of the Church by which Chri≈øt a≈øcended could not be couered, Interior domus propter Dominici corporis meatum camerari & tegi non potuit. By which pa≈ø≈øage euery yeare vpon the Fe≈øtiuitie of Chri≈øts A≈øcen≈øion, when the Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe is ended, a ≈øtorme of greate winde v≈øeth to di≈øcend and enforceth all that be in the Church to lye pro≈øtrate one the grounde, In die A≈øcen≈øionis Dominicae per annos ≈øingulos Mi≈ø≈øa peracta validi flaminis procella de≈øur≈øum venire con≈øueuit, & omnes qui in Eccle≈øia adfuerint terrae pro≈øternere. Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe and prayer for the dead at an e≈øpeciall Altar of ≈øuch foundation.

13. They affirme that in the≈øe Churches there were many holy Altars, and among the re≈øt in the Church of Golgotha, there was an Altare one which Sacrifice was ≈øpecially offered for noble par≈øons newly dead, their bodies remayning in the ≈øtreete during the time of Ma≈ø≈øe, Infra locum Dominicae Crucis exci≈øa in petra Crypta e≈øt, in qua ≈øuper Altare pro defunctis honoratis Sacrificium ≈øolet offerri, po≈øitis interim in platea corporibus.

14. She builded al≈øo at Hieru≈øalem, but after the building of the≈øe and other Churches in other places pre≈øently to be related, a mo≈øt ample and ≈øpatious Church both for breadth and lenght in Mount Syon. Within the Niceph. Calli≈øt. Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. l. 8. c. 30. Portch thereof, she inclo≈øed round about the hou≈øe, in which the dores being shut the Di≈øciples of Chri≈øt were gathered together for feare of the Iewes, in which Chri≈øts his la≈øte ≈øupper, washing his Apo≈øtles feete, and the comming of the holy Gho≈øt was, and in which S. Iames was ordayned fir≈øt Bishop of Hieru≈øalem. In that Church al≈øo was the Marble Piller, to which our Sauiour was bound when he was whipped. One the left ≈øide whereof the Sepulchre of the Prophet Dauid was magnificently ≈øeated in an high place, In vrbem ≈øanctam reuer≈øa in Sion ampli≈øsimum long√® lat√®que con≈øtruxit Templum, in cuius Po≈øtico domum conclu≈øit, in qua, foribus clau≈øis, propter metum Iudaeorum, Di≈øcipuli fuerunt congregati: In qua etiam ≈øacra caena peracta, ≈øacraque pedum lotio, nec non Spiritus ≈øancti in caenaculo aduentus, in qua primus quoque Hierarcha & Epi≈øcopus Iacobus renuntiatus e≈øt. In eo Templo Marmorea quoque fuit Columna, ad quam cum flagellis caederetur, alligatus e≈øt Seruator. In cuius parte ≈øinistra, diui Prophetae Dauidis ≈øepulchrum magnific√® in ≈øublimi collocatum.

15. She founded an other Church to S. Peter Prince of the Apo≈øtles in the Palace of Caiphas, In Palatio Caiphae, Petro Apo≈øtolorum Principi Templum aliud con≈øtituit. She builded al≈øo Churches dedicated to the holy Infants, which were putt to death for Chri≈øt, and where the Angell brought the gladd tydings
of Chri≈øts Natiuitie, vnto the Shephards and to the Mother of God, and an other to S. Io≈øeph her Husband, Sanctis itidem infantibus, & vbi Angelus Pa≈øtoribus laetum attulit nuntium, in eis ip≈øis locis ≈øacras extruxit aedes: Infantibus videlicet ip≈øis, & verbi puerperae, necnon aliam quoque ≈øpon≈øo Io≈øepho aedem.

16. And going to Bethania where Chri≈øt ray≈øed Lazarus from death to life, she builded a fayre Church to Lazarus the friend of Chri≈øt, Lazaro Chri≈øtiamico in≈øigne aedificauit delubrum. About the Denne where S. Ihon Bapti≈øt ≈øometime had a dwelling place, she erected vnto him a very beutifull Church. And an other at the Cliffe of the Mountayne to Helias Thesbites. In the place where Chri≈øt miraculou≈øly fedd fiue thow≈øand men, she made a Church of twelue Thrones, duodecim thronorum Templum ≈øtatuit. In the places where the miracle was shewed in the Centurian, where the man ≈øicke of the Pal≈øey let downe by the roofe of the hou≈øe was healed, where the miracle by ≈øeuen loues of bread and a few fishes was wrought, where Mary Magdalen was cured, in euery of the≈øe places she founded diuers Churches to the Apo≈øtles, Et quouis loco diuer≈øa Apo≈øtolis con≈øtruxit Templa.

17. In the Citie of Tiberiadis, in the hou≈øe of S. Peter his Mother in Lawe, where she was re≈øtored to health, she builded a fayre Church to S. Peter. So she did in Mount Thabor, where Melchizedech is ≈øaid to haue ble≈ø≈øed Abraham; and an other mo≈øt bewtifull Church in the place of Chri≈øts TraÃÑsfiguratioÃÑ there, to tho≈øe three Apo≈øtles which were then pre≈øent and beholded it, and left much money there for the Inhabitants. Then she went to Nazareth, and in the hou≈øe where the Angell ≈øaluted the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, she erected a very plea≈øant Church to the Mother of God, Dei genitrici peramaenum excitauit Templum. And builded an other in Chana of Galilie where at the Matriage, Chri≈øt did miraculou≈øly change water into wine. She founded an other at the Tree of Mambre, where as certaine fame and Tradition teach, Abraham mett the Angels going to the de≈øtruction of Sodome, and I≈øaac and Chri≈øt al≈øo were foretolde to come, this Church was mo≈øt adorned, ornati≈øsimum Templum, and all the horrible Sacrifices and Ceremonies of the Gentils there practized were quite abandoned.

18. The like she did at Aphaca, at the foote of Mount Libanus. So in Cilicia and other holy places she builded other Churches aboue thirtie in number, Quin & plures Eccle≈øias alias, in ≈øanctis illis locis, ≈øupra triginta, amanti≈øsima Dei faemina Imperatoris Mater condidit, And that she might dayly, whether ≈øoeuer she weÃÑt, euen in the Wildernes it≈øelfe, haue allwayes a Church to ≈øerue God, and haue the ≈øacred My≈øteries therein celebrated dayly, she cau≈øed a Church to be made of diuers linen clothes and carryed about with her, as Moy≈øes did the Tabernacle, non tantum Eccle≈øias √® fundamentis terrae extruxit, verumetiam pro ≈øuo erga Chri≈øtum flagranti de≈øiderio & amore, vt in ≈øolitudine quoque ≈øancta haberet Symbola, aedem ≈øacram ‚Ä¢ varijs linteis fieri curauit, eamque veluti pri≈øcus Moy≈øes, ≈øecum circumtulit.

19. Thus doth Nicephorus and other Ea≈øterne Greeke Writers recompt the Niceph. Hi≈øtor. Eccle≈ø. l. 8. c. 29. 3. Socrat. Hi≈øt. l. 2. cap. 13. Sozom. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 2. c. 1. 2. Eu≈øeb. l. 3. de Vit. Con≈øtantini. Religeous labours and Foundations of this our renowned Queene and Empre≈ø≈øe, a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Authoritie and help of her glorious ≈øonne, and how she al≈øo made other maruaylous workes in the pitt of Hieremias and the well, Siloe in fouea Hieremiae, & ad fontem qui Siloe dicitur, mirifica con≈øtruxit opera. And in all places she de≈øtroyed the Idols and Super≈øtitions of the Gentils. And cau≈øed the Potters feilde meÃÑtioned in Scripture to be prepared for the buriall of
≈øtrangers and Pilgryms, Po≈øtrem√≤ & agrum figuli apparari curauit in aduenarum & peregrinorum ≈øepulturam.

20. But our Latine and We≈øterne Writers better acquainted with the pietie and Acts of deuotion, which S. Helen exerci≈øed in, and neare this Kingdome, where she was borne, then the Gretians and Ea≈øterne Hi≈øtorians ≈øo farre hence, and onely ≈øetting downe, as appeareth before, her labours and holy Pilgrimage in the Ea≈øte, doe recompt her ≈øuch foundations to more then a double number of tho≈øe the Gretians remember. The old Authour of our old English Chronicle ≈øaith: Helena the Queene Modor to Con≈øtantine repayred Old. Engl. ChroÃÑ. part. 4. fol. 38. pag. 2. Antiq. Eccl. S. Gereonis ColoÃÑ. againe the holy Cro≈ø≈øe, and she made 70. Colleges, and she glorified the ≈øtate of all holy Chirche. The Antiquities of S. Gereon his Church in Collen, ≈øay she founded 72. beutifull Religious hou≈øes and Churches, and endowed them with lands: Inuentrix ≈øanctae Crucis almo Pneumate flante ≈øeptuaginta duo Collegia fundat amaena, dotans perpetuo Con≈øtantis Mater Helena. Among the≈øe she founded one a very ≈øtately Church at Collen in honour of S. Gereon, and his Petr. Mer≈ø≈øaeus Catal. Elect. Eccle≈ø. in Annal. Archiep. Colon. & Carmin. in Valu. Eccle≈ø. S. Gereon ‚Ä¢ n≈øculpt. Antiq. fellowe Martyrs there in the Per≈øecution of Diocletian and Maximian; two others she founded at Bonna and Xanctos in Cliueland which were Mona≈øteries, Sancta Helena mater Con≈øtantini Magni inter alias Eccle≈øias, quas in toto orbe condidit, Coloniae permagnificum con≈øtruifecit in honorem diuorum Gereonis ≈øociorumque ba≈øilicam: eadem quoque apud Bonnam & Xanctos in Cliuen≈øium terra in≈øtituit Collegia, quae ‚Ä¢ lim Mona≈øteria fuere. This was longe before her Pilgrimage to Hieru≈øalem, about the yeare of Chri≈øt, as the≈øe Antiquities conceaue 310. And at her being in the Ea≈øte Countries on her Pilgrimage she obtained Annal. Archiep. Treueren. apud Petr. Mer≈ø≈øaeum in Catal. Elect. Eccle≈øia≈øtic. of S. Sylue≈øter Pope of Rome, that S. Agritius Patriarke of Antioch, a man of wonderfull ≈øanctitie & learning, mirandae ≈øanctitatis & doctrinae vir, as she had reque≈øted him in≈øtantia optimae Helenae, ac beati Syluestri Pontificis iu≈ø≈øu, might be ≈øent Archbishop to Treuers, and was Primate of all Germany, and France totius Germaniae ac Galliae Primas, Whome S. Helen furnished for his Iorney with many mo≈øt pretious Reliks, the Coate of Chri≈øt without ≈øeame, one of the Nayles, the knife which Chri≈øt v≈øed at his la≈øt ≈øupper, a greate parte of the holy Cro≈ø≈øe, the body of S. Mathias the Apo≈øtle, and others, and a≈ø≈øi≈øted this holy Bishop further in building other Oratories, and Churches in that Country, and conuerted her Palace which she had at Collen vnto a Church dedicated to S. Peter, Cuius etiam Palatium in diui Petri Templum conuerti fecit.

21. How greate her deuotion and bountie was in executing ≈øuch holy workes in Britayne, her natiue and mo≈øt beloued Country, we may make coniecture, though our lo≈øt Hi≈øtories haue ≈øuffered their names in particular to be without memory, by her vnmatchable zeale and pietie, in this kinde to ≈øo remote and ≈øtrange Nations, ≈øo greate a part of the number recited of her Foundations not found in Hi≈øtories except in Britaine, & the greate number of ≈øtately Churches heare, either new founded or repayred, as I haue before remembred, and ritchly endowed both by re≈øtoring their old reuenewes vnto them, which were confi≈øcate in the Per≈øecution of Maximian and Diocle≈øian, which none but she and her ≈øonne, Empre≈ø≈øe and Emperour heare could doe, and by giuing new lands and maintenance vnto them, which she, Queene of Britaine was be≈øt able to performe, and better in other places in which she mo≈øt honorably effected it, allthough by a≈ø≈øi≈øtaÃÑce of her ≈øonne, ≈øole Franc. Modius. lib. de origine ordinis Eccle≈ø. Emperour, and Commander there, by his Imperiall Election & Title When in Britaine she was Heire and Queene thereof, clayming therein nothing from her ≈øonne, but he from her: She al≈øo was then actually a Chri≈øtian,
and Con≈øtantin not vntill diuers yeares after by common opinion. And Berengo≈ø. Abb. lib. 2. de Inuent. & laude Crucis cap. 11. as Berengo≈øus and others well and truely ob≈øerue, allthough Con≈øtantine had great care in building Churches, and builded many, yet his Mothers care was greater herein then his, she builded more then he, and as one ≈øtarre exceedeth an other in brightnes, ≈øo the Mother exceeded her ≈øonne in meritts, Sicut ≈øtella √† ≈øtell√† differt inclaritate, ≈øic mater √† filio meritoruÃÑ differt enormitate. Si enim ge≈øta vtriu≈øque velimus pen≈øare ≈øubtilius, coram Deo maioris pretij creditur mater e≈ø≈øe, quam filius. Quia po≈øtquam vtrique caele≈øti reconciliati ≈øunt, in con≈øtruendis Eccle≈øijs Dei magna cura filio, ≈øed maior inerat matri. Quamuis enim filius multas Eccle≈øias in Graecia con≈øtruxi≈ø≈øet, ac Roma, quibus in the ≈øauris & allodijs multa regalia contulit dona: mater tamen vt adhuc diuer≈øa Sanctorum te≈øtantur Martyria multo plures Eccle≈øias, in Gallijs aedificauit, ac Syria. And therefore as this learned Authour ob≈øerueth, and experience in all places proueth to te≈øtifie her ≈øanctitie, Churches were founded in all Countryes in honour of her, Quapropter Eccle≈øiae in honoreÃÑ eius Deo vbique ≈øacratae ben√® te≈øtantur, quanta coram Domino polleat ≈øanctitate.

22. Therefore if S. Helen in this kinde of pietie exceeded her ≈øonne, the mo≈øt potent, able, deuoute Emperour, that euer was in building Churches to God, and his holy Saints, as all agree, building mo≈øt ≈øumpteous Churches allmo≈øt in all places, e≈øpecially cheife Cities, in alijs ocis fere omnibus pulcherrima Sozom. Hi≈øt. Eccl. lib. 2. c. 2. Templa Deo aedificauit, tum maxime in vrbibus primarijs; we mu≈øt needs make his holy Mother the mo≈øt excellent, that euer was in ≈øuch deuotions, and be≈øtowe no ≈ømall parte thereof vpon this her mo≈øt beloued Country.

23. With what reuerence she v≈øed the Religeous Nunnes at Hieru≈øalem, I haue before mentioned, and Franci≈øcus Modius and others write, that she Franci≈øc. Mod. lib. de origine Ordinis Eccle≈ø. foonded a Religeous Order of Nunnes called S. Helens Order, ther habite white with a yallowe Cro≈ø≈øe, S. Helenae Ordo in≈øtitutus e≈øt po≈øt Inuentionem dominicae crucis, ab Inuentrice eius Helena Con≈øtantini Magni matre ≈øub Syuestro 1. Pontifice, donatu≈øque ve≈øte alba, & in ea cruce crocei coloris. Thus she per≈øeuered in her painefull Pilgrimages, allmes, holy foundations, deuotions and pietie, vntill about the 80. yeare of her Age, and then returning vnto her ≈øonne, and giuing him many precepts of pietie, and her la≈øt ble≈ø≈øing, went out of this into a better life, His & alijs con≈øimilibus peractis, redijt ad filium, & multis praeceptis Theodor. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 1. cap. 18. Sozom. Hi≈øtor. Eccl. l. 2. cap. 1. Eu≈øeb. l. 3. de vit. Con≈øtant. Socrat. l. 2. c. 13. de pietate filio datis, valedicendique benedictionibus com≈øummatis, ex hac vita in meliorem tran≈øi ‚Ä¢ t. And was not onely rewarded of God with eternall felicitie in heauen, but had ≈øuch honour and renowne al≈øo heare on earth that greater she could not haue: she was Empre≈ø≈øe, the Coine ≈øtamped with her Image, she had power ouer the Imperiall Trea≈øure, to v≈øe it at her plea≈øure, and being gloriou≈øly to dye about foure≈øcore yeares old, left her ≈øonne Emperour, and grand≈øonnes Cae≈øars, and the better to perpetuate her memory on earth, two Cyties were founded of her name, one in Bithinia, the other in Pale≈øtina, Pro quibus rebus videtur dign√® a Deo remunerata e≈ø≈øe. Nam vita quam hic degebat, eius generis fuit, vt neque splendidior, neque illu≈øtrior e≈ø≈øe potuerit. Augu≈øtaitem fuit appellata, eiu≈øque Imagine nummi ≈øignati. The≈øauri quoque Imperatorij pote≈øtatem a filio adepta, eo pro arbitratu v≈øa e≈øt. Mortem gloria≈øam obijt tum, cum & annos circiter octoginta confeci≈ø≈øet, & filium ≈øimul cum nepotibus Cae≈øaribus totum Imperium Romanum gubernantem po≈øt ≈øe relinqueret. Denique nomen eius iam mortuae, obliuione minime obrutum e≈øt: ≈øed ≈øunt duae vrbes: altera in Bythinia, in Pale≈øtina altera, vtraque eius nomine nsuncupata, velut pignus ad illius memoriam perpetuandam aetati po≈øterae relict ‚Ä¢ .

24. At her death her ≈øonne ≈øo greate an Emperour diligently wayted on
her, and held her hands, and ≈øo mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed woman she ≈øeemed vnto wi≈øemen not to dye, but leaue a wor≈øe for a better life, Suo filio tanto tamque eximio Imperatore, ip≈øi prae≈øto a≈øsi≈øtente, ≈øedulo in≈øeruiente, & manus ip≈øius tenente, finem ita viuendi fecit, vt beati≈øsima quidem iure optimo, non mori prudentibus videretur, ≈øed vitam caducam & fragilem cum caele≈øti & aeterna reuera commutare. Her body Eu≈øeb. lib. 3. de vit. Con≈øt. c. 46. Martyrol. Rom. 18. Aug. Socrat. Hi≈øt. l. 2. cap. 13. Niceph. l. 8. c. 31. honored with renowned ob≈øequies, attended with a wonderfull company of wayters on it, was ≈øo conueyed from Rome, vnto Con≈øtantinople, and there layed in an Imperiall Sepulchre, Eius autem Tabernaculum ≈øplendidis exequijs decoratum, nam maxima ≈øatellitum turba ad ciuitatem quae principem locum tenet Imperij, deportatum fuit, ibique regali Sepulchro conditum.

25. As she is glorious in heauen, ≈øo on earth her Fea≈øt in the Latine Church is Martyrol. Rom. ≈øupr. V≈øuard. & Ado. eod. die Menolog. Graec. 12. Cal. Iul. In≈øcript. Antiq. ante valuas Eccle≈ø. S. Gereonis Colon. Petr. Mer≈ø≈øaeus Catal. Elect. Eccl. in Archiep. Colon. Io. Pit≈øeus de Illu≈øtr. Brit. Scr ‚Ä¢ pt. aetate 4. in ≈øancta Helen. Io. Bal. l. Script. Brit. centur. 1. in Helen. Fl√°uia. celebrated the 18. day of Augu≈øt, in the Greeke the 20. of Iune: and in old Monuments propo≈øed for, and mo≈øt honorably and ≈øingularly named a Paterne and Example for greate Kings and Princes, and an Empre≈ø≈øe full of grace: as in the old Church of S. Gereon, in Collen one of her Noble foundations.

q.l: Regibus Exemplum Sacroque Chri≈ømate Plena,
Condidit hoc templum Sancti Gereonis Helena.

div.p:
Con≈øtaÃÑtinus Mana≈ø≈øes calleth her, faeminam beati≈øsimaÃÑ. A late English Writer writeth, that from Chri≈øt to her time there ≈øcarcely was to be found a woman more adorned with all vertues, and learned in all ≈øciences, A Chri≈øto nato v≈øque ad illud tempus vix viderat ≈øol faeminam omnibus virtutibus ornatiorem, & in omnibus ≈øcientijs doctiorem. And to giue vnto her Prote≈øtants prai≈øes, not too lauish in commending ≈øuch holy Saints, they are enforced to confe≈ø≈øe: Helena Augu≈øta Seremi≈øsimi Coeli Regis haeres & vnica filia, Magni Con≈øtantini Cae≈øaris mater, incomparabili decore, fide, Religione, bonitate & pia magnificentia (Eu≈øebio etiam te≈øte) per totum re≈øplenduit orbem. Inter omnes aetatis ≈øuae faeminas, nulla inueniebatur e√¢ in liberalibus artibus doctior, nulla in in≈øtrumentis mu≈øicis peritior, aut in linguis Nationum copio≈øior. Innatam habebat ingenij claritudinem, oris facundiam, ac morum ornati≈øsimam compo≈øitioneÃÑ, hebric√®, graec√®, & Latin√® erudita. Marito Con≈øtantio Chloro Cae≈øare Eboraci defuncto, cum Anna illa Euangelica in ≈øancta viduitate perdurauit ad vltimum vitae diem, tota Chri≈øtianae Religioni dedita. Sunt enim Authores qui narrent peristam ce≈ø≈øante per≈øecutione, pacem Eccle≈øijs datam, ad tantam Philo≈øopbiae cognitioneÃÑ eam ferunt perueni≈ø≈øe, vt ediderit de Prouidentia Dei, Librum vnum. De immortalitate animae, librum 1. &c. The Empre≈ø≈øe Helena Mother of Con≈øtantine the Emperour for her incomparable beauty, faith, ReligioÃÑ, goodnes, and pious magnificence, as Eu≈øebius him≈øelfe witne≈ø≈øeth, was renowned throughout all the world. Among all woman of that Age none was found more learned in Liberall Arts, none more skillfull in mu≈øicall In≈øtrumeÃÑts, none more copious in the languages of Nations. She had a naturall promptnes of wit, eloquence of ≈øpeach, and mo≈øt commendable conuer≈øation in life. Excellenlly learned in Hebrue, Greeke, and Latine. Her husband Con≈øtantius Chlorus Emperour dying at Yorke with holy Anne, ≈øpokeÃÑ of in the Gho≈øpell, she per≈øeuered in holy wydowe hood vntill her death, wholly deuoted to Chri≈øtian Religion. And Authours ≈øay, that by her, peace was giuen to Churches. She is reported to haue come to ≈øo greate knowledge in learning, that she wrote a Booke of the Prouidence of God: one, of the Immortalitie of the ≈øoule: one, the Rule of well lyuing. One of Epi≈øtles to her ≈øonne Con≈øtantin: one of her Reuelations: one to S. Anthony the Abbot: one of Greeke Pontic. Virun. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 5. ver≈øes, extant in Ponticus Virunnius his time, as he writeth, extant adhuc Carmina quae dam graeca quae illius fui≈ø≈øe perhibentur. Thus this glorious Saint and Empre≈ø≈øe
ended her life ≈øo holy & vertuous, as Sozomen writeth, that none could Sozomen. Hi≈øt. Eccl. lib. ‚Ä¢ . cap. 1. be more honorable & renowned then it was: vita quam hic degebat eius generis fuit, vt neque ≈øplendidior, neque illu≈øtrior e≈ø≈øe potuerit.

26. Baronius and the Roman Writers dare not for certaine deliuer, or in Baron. & Spond. Annal. an. 326. particular ≈øet downe the yeare of her death, but ≈øay it is not knowne: quoto anno Domini defuncta fuerit incompertum habetur. But our English Hi≈øtorians both Catholicks & Prote≈øtants are more confident, & ≈øay, she dyed in the 337. yeare of Chri≈øt, being then as others al≈øo te≈øtifie 80. yeares old, Octogenaria Io. Pit≈øeus aetat. 4. in S. Helena Ioh. Bal. l. de Script. Britan. in Helena Flauia. Baron. & Spond. ≈øupr. Sozomen. l. 2. Hi≈øt. cap. 1. Eu≈ø. l. 3. vit. Con≈øt. cap. 45. Eu≈øeb. l. 4. vit. Con≈øt. Baron. & SpoÃÑd. Annal. an. 335. Marian. Scot. aetat 6. an. 385. Eu≈øeb. ≈øupr. cap. 40. Socrat. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 1. cap. obdormiuit in Domino quinto Calendas Septembris, anno Redemptionis humanae 337. And Baronius doth not write to the contrary, but rather inclineth to confirme it, when writing of the yeare of Chri≈øt 326. he boldly affirmeth she liued ≈øome yeares after that time, Haud tamen affirmare dubitamus adhuc aliquot po≈øt haec vixi≈ø≈øe annos. And that she liued vntill the 335. of Chri≈øt, or after, it is euident by Eu≈øebius, Sozomen and others, affirming that she left her three Nephewes, ≈øonnes of Con≈øtantine, Cae≈øars when she dyed. And yet it is manife≈øt by Eu≈øebius and others, that Con≈øtans his younge≈øt ≈øonne was not Cae≈øar vntill the 30. yeare of Con≈øtantine, when his Tricennall Fea≈øt was kept in the 335. yeare of Chri≈øt, the elde≈øt, CoÃÑ≈øtaÃÑtine being created Cae≈øar in the 10. yeare of his Empire at the decennall fe≈øtiuitie, and Con≈øtantius the ≈øecond in the 20. yeare when the vicennall Fea≈øt thereof was celebrated, Cum triginta ip≈øe annos in Imperio compleui≈ø≈øet, filij eius numero tres Cae≈øares diuer≈øis creabantur temporibus. Primus qui Patris erat cognominis decimo paterni Imperij anno honorem hunc adeptus e≈øt. Secundus, Aui nomine appellatus Con≈øtantius vice≈øimo fer√® Imperij paterni anno, quando publicus ≈øolenni≈øque omnium hominum conuentus agebatur, renuntiatus e≈øt. Tertius Con≈øtants ≈øuit, qui trice≈øimo paterni regni anno ad honorem euectus e≈øt. The Age of S. Helen by Eu≈øebius and others about foure≈øcore yeares old, octoge≈øimum fer√® aetatis ≈øuae annum confeci≈ø≈øet, doth proue as much, for as is proued before, she was a young Virgin when she was marryed to Con≈øtantius, about the yeare of Chri≈øts Natiuitie 272. And the Age of Con≈øtantine her ≈øonne, being aboue 30. yeares of Age before he was Emperour, and reigning Emperor no le≈ø≈øe time giueth good allowance vnto it, ≈øuruiuing after her death, by all accompts. To which the reckening of Onuphrius and Onuphr. in Roman. Principib. pag. 57. others, that Con≈øtantine the Greate was borne in greate Britaine in the yeare of our Lord 272. according to my accompt before, giueth more confirmation.

div.head: THE XVI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE HOLY DEVOVTE LIFE OF Con≈øtantine, his Religion in many particulars. His death glorious, and not ≈øo ≈øoone as ≈øome relate it.

div.p: 1. SOME late Writers grounding vpon the Relation and Authorie Socrat. l. 1. Hi≈øt. cap. vlt. 26. of Socrates, doe ≈øeeme to hold, that Con≈øtantine dyed the ≈øame yeare 337. Felicianus and Titianus being then Con≈øuls, Anno Chri≈øti trecente≈øimo trige≈øimo ≈øeptimo Feliciano Baron. & Spond. Annal. an. 337. & Titiano CoÃÑ≈ø≈ø. Con≈øtantinus Imperator ex hac vita migrauit, vt di≈øert√® Socrates te≈øtatur, addens & diem nempe vndecimum Kalendas Iunij. But I cannot a≈ø≈øent either vnto Socrates, ≈øo to thinke nor this Con≈øtantin ‚Ä¢ the Greate died not ≈øo ≈øoone as ≈øome recompt. Interpretation of him, for the rea≈øon for which Baronius and Spondanus a≈ø≈øent vnto him; for that after this yeare, Lawes were rather founde in≈øcribed in the name of his Sonnes, then of Con≈øtantine their Father: Vt Socratis Chronographiae de die & CoÃÑ≈ø≈ø. con≈øentiamus, illud imprimis maxim√® per≈øuadet, quod leges po≈øthac datae nominibus filiorum reperiantur in≈øcriptae poti√πs quaÃÑ ip≈øius Con≈øtantini Patris. Then being with greate ≈øolemnitie brought to the Apo≈øtles Church, where the Prei≈øts and people The Prei≈øts and others pray for the ≈øoule of their Emperor Con≈øtantine decea≈øed. with teares and mourning prayed vnto God for the ≈øoule of the Emperour, Populus frequens vna cum Sacerdotibus non ≈øine lachrymis, & ≈øane magno cum geÃÑ mitu, preces pro animo Imperatoris. Deo fundebant. And ≈øo with ≈øacred ceremonies, and the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and holy prayers he was ioyned to the people Cap. 70. 71. of God in heauen, Licet contemplari ter beatae animae tumulum Apo≈øtolici nominis Ma≈ø≈øe ≈øaid for him decea≈øed. appella ‚Ä¢ ione decorari, & Dei populum aggregari, diuini≈øque ceremonijs & my≈øtico ≈øacrificio ≈øanctarumque precationum ≈øocietate perfrui.

10. Nicephorus writeth, that the holynes and pietie of this renowned Emperour The Relicks of Con≈øtantino worke many miracles: ≈øo his Image. were ≈øo Miraculou≈øly approued after his death, that God gaue ≈øuch an infallible gift of healing and Miracles, both to his graue, and Image; that all di≈øea≈øes what≈øoeuer were certainely cured by the onely touching of them, Magna gloria bonorum conciliator Deus virum eum, veluti fidelem mini≈øtrum accumulauit, Niceph. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 8. cap. 55. ≈øanationum & Miraculorum gratia & vrnae & ≈øtatuae ip≈øius, quae in porpheretici marmoris columna po≈øita e≈øt immi≈ø≈øa, vt deinceps nulla aegri tudo contrectatis eis non cederet, & fides verbi illius Chri≈øti adimpleretur, dicentis: ego glorificantes me, glorifi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ bo. The memorable workes and foundations of Chri≈øtian pietie, Arguments of Con≈øtantine his Religion, the mo≈øt honored Emperor that euer was. Churches mo≈øt ≈øumptuous, Altars, Chalices, Patens, Candel≈øticks and other ve≈ø≈øels of gold and ≈øiluer, which he founded, Priuiledges, Immunities and aimes which he be≈øtowed vpon Religion are innumerable. Eu≈øebius hath writen his life in 4. Bookes, and many others haue entreated of them able in them≈øelues to mini≈øter ≈øubiect of a whole Hi≈øtory; therefore I mu≈øt pa≈ø≈øe them ouer onely, ≈øaying in generall with that Authour of this Noble Emperour, Solus ex omnibus Romanis Imperatoribus, Deum omnium Regem incredibili Eu≈øeb. l. 4. vit. Con≈øt. cap. 75. pietatis ≈øtudio honorauit: ≈øolus omni cum libertate vocis & linguae Chri≈øti verbum per≈øonuit: ≈øolus vt ita dicam Eccle≈øiam eius praeter caeteras ab omni aeuo honoribus effecit. Solus Impium multoruÃÑ deorum ficticium cultum ≈øu≈øtulit, omne≈øque vias Idololatriae refutauit: Igitur & dum viueret, & po≈øtque e≈øt mortuus, his honoribus cumulatus e≈øt, quales neminem aliquando nec apud Graecos nec Barbaros, ≈øed ne antiqui≈øsimis quidem Romanorum temporibus, cum neminem cum isto conferendum vlla vnquaÃÑ ≈øeculorum memoria nobis profuderit, adeptum e≈ø≈øe qui≈øquam commemorare potest. Among all the Roman Emperours Con≈øtantine onely did with incredible feruour of pietie honour God the King of all: he alone with all libertie of voice and tongue ≈øounded forth the word of Christ: he alone that I may ≈øo ≈øay more then all the re≈øt in all Ages endewed his Church with honours. He alone tooke away the feigned worship of many Gods, and refuted all the wayes of Idolatry: Therefore he alone both when he lyued, and after he was dead, had ≈øuch honors heaped vpon him, that no man can make relation that any man at any time eyther among the Greekes or Barbarians, or in the most auncient time of the Romans obtayned the like. It is not found in the memory of all Ages, that any man was to be compared vnto him. He left his three ≈øonnes before remembred to ≈øerue, and reigne, Emperours after him in the S. Con≈øtantia d ‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢ hter to Con≈ø ‚Ä¢ an ‚Ä¢ ine an holy Nunne ‚Ä¢ example to many Noble Nu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . worlde, but his holy daughter S. Con≈øtantia, ≈øome call her Con≈øtantina, he left to ≈øerue God in perpetuall virginitie among ≈øacred Nunnes, who as I haue in≈øinuated before, being infected with Lepro≈øie and going on Pilgrimage to the graue of S. Agnes Martyred in the Per≈øecution before Con≈øtantins
time, and there continuing in prayer all night, was Miraculou≈øly cured of her infirmitie, S. Agnes appearing vnto her, and incouraging her according Ambro≈ø. ≈øerm. 90. de pa≈ø≈øione beatae Aguetis Virg. to her name to be Con≈øtant in the faith and loue of Chri≈øt: ≈øpe recuperandae ≈øalutis venit ad Tumulum Martyris nocte, & preces fideliter fundebat. Quod dum faceret, repentina ≈øommi ≈øuauitate corripitur, & videt per vifum beati≈øsimam Agnetem talia ≈øibi monita praeferentem: con≈øtanter Age Con≈øtantia, & crede Dominum Ie≈øum Chri≈øtum filium Dei e≈ø≈øe Saluatorem tuum, per quem modo con≈øequeris omnium vulnerum quae in corpore tuo pateris ≈øanitatem. Wherevpon as S. Ambro≈øe lyuing in that Age, and others witne≈ø≈øe, Con≈øtantine at the reque≈øt of his cured daughter S. Con≈øtantia, there erected a Church and Tombe to S. Agnes, and Con≈øtantia per≈øeuered in virginitie, & by her, many virgins both meane and Noble and renowned receaued the holy veales, Per≈øeuerauit autem Con≈øtantia Augusti filia in virginitate, per quam multae virgines & mediocres & nobiles & illu≈øtres Sacra velamina ≈øu≈øceperunt. Our holy and auncient learned Countryman S. Aldelmus with mo≈øt honorable Titles remembreth her among the mo≈øt Aldelm. l. de laudib. virginitat. cap. 25. Ado. Vienn. in Chron. Fa≈øcicul. Temp. an. 294. Harris Hi≈øt. Tom. 4. Libell. de munificent. Con≈øtant. Tom. 1. Concil. Baron. & Spond. Annal. an. 330. ≈øacred virgins, ≈øaying that by her per≈øua≈øion, and example, allmo≈øt all the daughters of the Roman Pretors, and allmo≈øt all Noble and beutifull virgins profe≈ø≈øed virginitie, and among the≈øe Attica and Arthemia daughters of Gallibanus, by others Gallicanus mo≈øt potent in the Empire, Quarum genitore Gallihano nullus in Romana Monarchia prae≈øtantior extitit. And citeth the life of S. Con≈øtantie written long before, Quod plenius de conuer≈øatione illius ≈øcripta opu≈øcula produnt. She erected a Mona≈øtery of Nunnes neare the place where she was cured, and there shutting vp her ≈øelfe with many other Nunnes, ≈øerued God with greate deuotion and ≈øanctity of life in the ≈øame place all her life: after her death, her body was buried by S. Agnes. Therefore I may boldly ≈øay The honour of Britayne by the greate Emperour Con≈øtantine. with our Monke of Bury in his olde ver≈øe of this mo≈øt glorius Emperour:

div.head: THE XVII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THAT THE POPES AND CHVRCH OF ROME in this time were of the ≈øame Religion they now are, and all Chri≈øtian Catholiks then profe≈ø≈øed the ≈øame with them, & the Supremacy of that See Apostolike.

div.p: 1. SOME euen of our owne Hi≈øtorians write, and namely the Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter, that S. Silue≈øter continued Pope vntill the yeare wherein Con≈øtantine decea≈øed, and both of them died in the ≈øame yeare 340. That as they had both laboured together in their liues, for aduancing the honor and Church of Chri≈øt, ≈øo they died together Matth. We≈øtm. Anno gratiae 340. to receaue the merited reward of their labors, Anno gratiae 340. magnificus Imperator Con≈øtantinus vitam laudabilem glorio≈øo fine terminauit. Quo etiam Anno Sanctus Syluester, viam vniuer≈øae carnis ingre≈ø≈øus, migrauit ad Dominum. Dignum plane & omnino conueniens, vt qui ≈øimul circa incrementum Eccle≈øiae per≈øeueranter laborauerant, ≈øimul reciperent promeritam pro labore retributionem. And if we should approue the opinion of Baronius and Spondanus ≈øo expounding Baron. & Spond. Annal. an. 314. S. Dama≈øus in S. Sylue≈øtro to. 1. Concil. the old Roman Pontificall in this point, that S. Sylue≈øter entered the Papacie in the yeare of Chri≈øt 314. Anno Chri≈øti trecente≈øimo decimo quarto Calendis Februarij Sylue≈øter Romanus ≈øubrogatus, in locum Melchiadis ≈øedere caepit, and allowe vnto S. Sylue≈øter ≈øo long po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing thereof as the ≈øame Pontificall doth, three and twenty yeares, ten moneths, and 11. dayes: Sylue≈øter ≈øedit annis viginti tribus, Men≈øibus decem, we should conclude in Baronius opinion of the death of Con≈øtantine, that S. Sylue≈øter and Con≈øtaÃÑtine died in one and the ≈øame yeare, Baron. & Spond. ≈øupr. Anno. 337. as Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter affirmeth, although not the ≈øame 340. in number which he hath deliuered. But to followe the other opinion which ≈øeemeth more common, and better plea≈øeth Baronius, Binius, and our Prote≈øtants al≈øo, Baron. Annal. an. 336. 337. Binius annotat. in Marc. & Iul. lib. 1. Hier. in Chron. Marian. aetat. 6. an. 333. Sozom. Hi≈øt. Eccl. lib. 2. cap. 19. that after the death of S. Sylue≈øter before Con≈øtantine dyed there were two othr Popes, Marcus and Iulius, the fir≈øt being Pope a very short time, but 8. Moneths by S. Hierome and Marianus: by Sozomen, a litle ≈øpace, Cum Marcus po≈øt Sylue≈øtrum ad exiguum tempus Epi≈øcopatum Romanum ge≈øsi≈ø≈øet, Iulius in illam Sedem ≈øucce≈øsit. And Iulius was Pope but in the la≈øt yeare of Con≈øtantine, being as the≈øe Authors hold, the fir≈øt yeare of his Papacy. By which accompt, the reckening of our Monke before, that S. Sylue≈øter and Con≈øtantine dyed in the ≈øame yeare, is rather coÃÑfirmed, then infringed. So if, as the≈øe men ≈øay, Marcus was Pope within 15. dayes of the death of S. Sylue≈øter, & continued the Papacie Baron. & Binn. ≈øupr. but 8. Moneths, and Iulius immediatly ≈øucceeded him, but a litle before t ‚Ä¢ e death of Con≈øtantine, it is apparant that S. Sylue≈øter and Con≈øtantine might or did dye in the ≈øame yeare.

2. And to our pre≈øent purpo≈øe, which is to be perfectly ≈øatisfied, and in≈øtructed of what Religion the≈øe Popes were, which liued in this time, when the true Chri≈øtian Religion was not onely permitted, but publikely and with authoritie both ≈øpirituall and temporall, Papall and Imperiall generally profe≈ø≈øed in all Nations, whether the ≈øame which we haue heard of Con≈øtantine before the publike graunt and warrant of the Popes Supremacy, Roman
Religion of the Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, prayer, and erecting Churches to Saints, prayer for the dead, Purgatorie, Pilgrimage, honor to holy Reliks & Images, and ≈øuch other cheife points, as Prote≈øtants now call into Que≈øtion, or the new doctrins of the≈øe men. And it can be no Que≈øtion but the Mai≈øters and Schollers, Teachers and Learners, Catechizers and Catechi≈øed, Baptizers Both Popes, Emperour and all but Heretiks were then of the pre≈øent Roman Religion euen by enemies vnto it, ≈øo te≈øtifying. Io. Bal. l. 1. & 2. de Rom. Pont. in Sylue≈øtr. Mar. co. & Iul. Bal. ≈øup. l. 1. in Sylue≈øt. Robert. Barnes in vit. Pontif Roman. in ‚Ä¢ od. and Bapti≈øed, as their condition was, mu≈øt needs be of one and the ≈øance minde and iudgment in ≈øuch things, they were all Holy men and Confe≈ø≈øors, as our Prote≈øtant Writers are witne≈ø≈øes, and to make them al≈øo to giue both euideÃÑce and iudgment that they were of the Catholike Roman Religion, now profe≈ø≈øed in that our Mother Church, thus they te≈øtifie, and fir≈øt of S. Sylue≈øter, that Pedagoge ad Tutor of Con≈øtantine in the≈øe words, There be very many Decrees of Pope Sylue≈øter of con≈øecrating Chri≈øme, confirming children, adorning Churches, couering Altars, ordaining Ma≈øsing Prei≈øt ‚Ä¢ , annointing & ve≈øting them, of worshiping, adoring, and re≈øeruing the con≈øecrated Ho≈øtes, al≈øo of Deacons ve≈øturs, Albes, Miters, Palls, Sacrifices, Ceremonies, A≈øiles, Extreame vnctions, & other Rites. Huius Sylue≈øtri permulta feruntur In≈øtituta de Chri≈ømate con≈øecraÃÑdo, Ordinibus dandis, pueris confirmandis, templis ornandis, Altaribus tegendis, Mi≈ø≈øatoribus con≈øtituendis, vngendis, ve≈øtiendis, Ho≈øtij≈øque, vt vocant deificandis, adornandis, ≈øeruandis. Item de Dalmaticis, Cappis, Corporalibus, Albis, Mitris, Pallijs, Pannis, Peplis, Sindonibus, Sacrificijs, Ceremonijs, A≈øilis, Extremis vnctionibus, alij≈øque ritibus: How a Prei≈øt should be ve≈øted, when he ≈øayd Ma≈ø≈øe, that no lay man might empleade any of the Clergie. That no Clergy man should be conuented before Magdeburgen. centur. 4. cap. 6. cap. 7. cap. 9. cap. 10. a ≈øecular Iudge. If the Reliks of Saints or Martyrs were to be tran≈ølated from other places they should be brought into Cities and Villages religiou≈øly in ≈øinging; per P≈øalmodias Religios√® acciperentur ac deducerentur. He approued and exerci≈øed the Primacy of the Pope of Rome as all other Popes then did. The cha≈øt and Religious conuer≈øation of Monkes and Nunnes were then v≈øed, and liuers Mona≈øteries of men and women then in Rome. In the Clergie were the≈øe Degrees, Bishops, Prei≈øts, Deacons, Subdeacons, Acoluthi≈øts, Exorci≈øts, Lectors, O≈øtiarij. The Bishops, Prei≈øts, Deacons and Sub ‚Ä¢ eacons were vnmarried, and liued in cha≈øtitie: Epi≈øcopi, Presbyteri, Diaconi, aut virgines eliguntur, aut cert√® po≈øt Sacerdotium in aeternum pudici. That the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe might not be celebrated but in places con≈øecrated by a Bishop, Mi≈ø≈øae celebrationem in nullis praeterquam ab Epi≈øcopo ≈øacratis locis faciendam Concilium Rom ‚Ä¢ num ≈øub Syluestro con≈øtituit. And in the ≈øame Councell to which both S. Sylue≈øter, and Con≈øtantine ≈øub≈øcribed, it is defined, as I haue Concil. Roman. can. 20. before cited, that the Roman See is the cheife≈øt See, Iudge of all, and to be Iudged of none, Emperor, Clergie, Kings or people: nemo iudicabit primam Sedem, quoniam omnes Sedes √† prima Sede iu≈øtitiam de≈øiderant temperari. Neque ab Augu≈øto, neque ab omni Clero, neque √† Regibus, neque √† populo Iudex iudicabitur. The≈øe Prote≈øtants Magdeburgen. c. 6. ‚Ä¢ upr. cent. 4. al≈øo deluer for the doctrine and v≈øe of this time, for penitents to make ≈øacramentall Confe≈ø≈øion of their ≈øinnes, and Prei≈øts to enioyne pennances, and giue ab≈øolution vnto ≈øuch Penitents. Concerning holy Scripturs, the third Councell of Carthage in the beginning of the next Age apprehending the ≈øame Canon of holy Scripturs which the pre≈øent Roman Church now receaueth, Concil. Carth. ‚Ä¢ . can. 47. faith plainely, that it receaued it from the Fathers which were before them, Pro confirmando i≈øto Canone innote≈øcat, quia √† Patribus i≈øta accepimus in Eccle≈øia Augu≈øt. l. 2. doctrin. Chri≈øtian. cap. 7. legenda. And S. Augu≈øtine liuing in this Age is witne≈ø≈øe that the Apo≈øtol ‚Ä¢ ke Sees, Rome the cheife, receaued it ≈øo. How vaine and Idle our Prote≈øtants and their Article of Religion in reiecting Traditions, and onely admitting Scripturs in matters of Religion is euident, in ≈øo many recited Articles,
which the≈øe men haue granted, and yet deny them to be contained in, or to be deduced from Scripturs, as al≈øo their Article and doctrine again≈øt Communion onely in one kinde, contending as though it could not be practized or permitted, when the≈øe Prote≈øtants them≈øelues confe≈ø≈øe, that in this time euen in the Roman Church, Communion onely vnder one kinde was v≈øed, Ambro≈ø. orat. Funebri de morte Satyri. and by the greate≈øt Doctors then in the Church of God, namely S. Ambro≈øe, who ≈øo writeth, and at his death practized it in him≈øelfe, onely receauing vnder the forme of bread, as Catholiks now v≈øe, and his brother Satyrus & others often ≈øo accu≈øtomed, euen when they were in health. Which the≈øe Paulin. in vita S. Ambro≈øij. Prote≈øtants thus confe≈ø≈øe, Peregrinantes ac Nauigantes Euchari≈øtiaÃÑ ≈øecum circumtuli≈ø≈øe Chri≈øtianos, ex Ambro≈øio apparet, ex oratione Ambro≈øij in funere fratris Satyrij. Magdeburgen. cent. 4. cap. 6. col. 429. 430. Ab honorato Eccle≈øiae Vercellen≈øis Sacerdote, Ambro≈øio morituro oblatum e≈ø≈øe corpus Domini, quo accepto, expiraret, Paulinus tradidit in vita Ambro≈øij. The≈øe men al≈øo teach, that the doctrine of the See of Rome and the Fathers at this time concerning freewill, and originall ≈øinne, was the ≈øame with that of the Magdeburgen. cent. 4. cap. 4. cap. 10. Roman Church in the≈øe dayes. So that if any man will compare but the≈øe points of doctrine which S. Sylue≈øter and Con≈øtantine then held, and practized with the English Prote≈øtant Religion, as it is ≈øet downe in the priuiledge Booke of the Articles thereof, warranted by Parlament, Kings Authoritie, Conuocation of their Prote≈øtant Bishops, Oath and Sub≈øcription of them and their whole Mini≈øtery, he shall not finde any one true Article then amoÃÑg them all, which are oppo≈øite to the Church of Rome, and Religion thereof at this time. But whether we are Catholiks placing ≈øpirituall Primacie in the See of Rome then in S. Sylue≈øter, or Prote≈øtants a≈ø≈øcribing it vnto their Chri≈øtian Kings, Con≈øtantine then both King and Emperour heare, we mu≈øt be of this holy Religion, wherein the≈øe two greate Rulers were ≈øo vnited together in all points; e≈øpecially ≈øeeing the≈øe Prote≈øtants haue warranted the≈øe two Princes were holy, and of them≈øelues worthie paterns to be imitated now as the whole Catholike Chri≈øtian world then ioyned with them in doctrine, S. Sylue≈øter Magdeburgen. cent. l. 4. cap. 10. being Pope (≈øay our Prote≈øtants) did faithfully performe his office in teaching, and amended many things in the Clergie, was renowned for working Miracles, and by them conuerted many to the faith, at ≈øeuen Ordinations he con≈øecrated 65. Bishops all ioyning with him in Religion. Sylue≈øter factus Epi≈øcopus, docendi munere fideliter functus e≈øt, & vitio≈øa in ordine Eccle≈øiastico multa emendauit, miraculis claruit etiam, quibus multos ad fidem conuertit. Ordinationibus ≈øacris ≈øeptem perfectis, creauit Epi≈øcopos ≈øexaginta quinque. So likewi≈øe did all other knowne Catholike Bishops in the whole world, either actually a≈ø≈øembled in, or con≈øenting vnto the renowned Councels of ≈øo many hundreds of Bishops of Nice, Rome, Arles and other places, in his time agreeing and con≈øenting together for theÃÑ ≈øelues and the whole Chri≈øtian world committed to their charge in Religion. Like was the ca≈øe of Con≈øtantine ≈øo farre as temporall Prince had to deale in the≈øe affaires. Of all Emperors that euer were he was he greate≈øt in Power, and Dominions, and the greate≈øt Reuerencer, we finde in Hi≈øtories, of the See Apo≈øtolike and Popes of Rome in his time, and all other Godly Bishops, and a≈ø≈øi≈øted all he could the a≈ø≈øembling of tho≈øe Councels, honoring and con≈øenting vnto their Decrees, as the Lawe & Decrees of God him≈øelfe, as appeareth by Eu≈øebius, Socrates, Sozomen, Theodoret, and his owne Imperiall Letters and publike Edicts before cited. And was occa≈øion of preaching the word of life, and the holy Gho≈øpell of Chri≈øt & ouerthrowing Idolatry in all Nations, from one end of the knowne world to the other, erecting Chri≈øtian
Churches, & endowing theÃÑ in all places, as our Prote≈øtants them≈øelues acknowledge, Ab Oceani finibus, nempe Britannis incipions diuinae Religionis curam Magdeburgen. centur. 4. cap. 3. Bal. l. de Script. centur. 1. in Flauio Con≈øtantino in medijs ≈øuper≈øtitionuÃÑ tenebris caepit, ab Occiduis ad Indos innumeras ad aeternae ≈øpe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ vitae erigeÃÑs geÃÑtes, egregius di≈øciplinae Chri≈øtianae praeco, fal≈øoruÃÑ DeoruÃÑ euer≈øor per GraeciaÃÑ, AegyptaÃÑ, Per≈øidem, A≈øiam, & vniuer≈øam ditionem Romanam, repetitis abrogabat legibus, iubens per Edicta Chri≈øtum coli, Euangelium praedicari ≈øacrum, mini≈øtris honores & alimenta dari, atque Idolorum vbique de≈øtrui templa. Eccle≈øijs infinita prae≈øtitit, agros, annonam, ≈øtipem egenis, aegris, viduis, ac Orphanis, pro quibu≈øque ≈øolicitus. Which generall de≈øtruction of Idolatry and planting the true Religion of Chri≈øt the Me≈ø≈øias, ≈øo often and manife≈øtly foretold by the holy Prophets, neuer any other comparable vnto this in any degree, except the late Conuer≈øion of America, and other Nations vnto the knowne pre≈øent Catholike Religion. Io. Bal. lib. 1. de Act. Pont. Rom. in Sylue≈øtr. And in the late Per≈øecution before Con≈øtantine expre≈ø≈øely and plainely foretold to S. Bla≈øius, the glorious Bishop and Martyr, as both Prote≈øtants and others confe≈ø≈øe, that this Con≈øtantine should be the happy man and meanes, by whome, and in who≈øe dayes and Empire, this greate alteration of Religion, in planting the true Religion of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus the Me≈ø≈øias, and confu≈øion of the Pagans ≈øuper≈øtitions, ≈øo often and clearely foretold in holy Scripturs, should be ≈øo generally effected.

lg.l: Nunc bonus expul≈øis, Romana in Regna, Tyrannis Bapti≈øta Mantuan. l. 2. de vit. S. Bla≈ø.
Adueniet Princeps, ≈øub quo pacabitur orbis,
Et finem accipiet veterum cultura Deorum
Con≈øtantinus.

div.p: 4. S. Marke was Pope but a shorte time, yet he continued as our Prote≈øtants Robert. Barn. l. de vit. Pont. Rom. in Marc. & Iulio. Io. Bal. l. 2. de Act. Pontific. Rom. in Marc. & Iul. confe≈ø≈øe, in S. Sylue≈øter his Religion, gaue the Pale to the Bishop of Ho≈øtia a Con≈øecrator of the Popes of Rome, cau≈øed the Nicen Creede to be read in the Church after the Gho≈øpell, he builded Churches & adorned them.

5. Pope Iulius did exempt Prei≈øts from being conuented before any but Eccle≈øia≈øticall Iudges, Maintained the priuiledge of the Roman See, that no Councell might be called without allowance thereof, Hic Iulius acriter reprehendit Orientales Epi≈øcopos, quod ≈øine ≈øua authoritate Concilium indixerant. Ca≈ø≈øiod. in Eccl. Hi≈øt. Tripart. l. 4. cap. 19. & cap. 9. But the Greeke Writers of that Age make this matter mo≈øt euident, that it was not onely the clayme of Pope Iulius, but the old Law and Apo≈øtolicall Rule and cu≈øtome, that no Councell might be called, nothing decreed without the authoritie of the Pope of Rome, Canonibus iubentibus praeter Romanum Sozom. l. 2. c. 9. nihil decerni PontificeÃÑ. And againe, CuÃÑ Regula Eccle≈øia≈øtica iubeat non oportere praeter ≈øententiaÃÑ Romani PoÃÑtificis CoÃÑcilia celebrari. And more manife≈øtly in SozomeÃÑ, That the old Canon of the Church pronownced all ≈øuch Acts to be voyde, which were decreed without the Authoritie of the Bishop of Rome, Legem e≈ø≈øe ad ≈øacerdotij dignitatem ≈øpectantem, quae pronuntiat acta illa irritae≈ø≈øe, quae Sozom. ≈øupr. l. 2. cap. 7. praeter ≈øententiam Epi≈øcopi Romani con≈øtituuntur. And this is plainely confe≈ø≈øed by tho≈øe Arrian Bishops them≈øelues thus reprehended for ≈øuch attempts. For writing to Pope Iulius, they freely coÃÑfe≈ø≈øe the Primacie of the Pope of Rome, and See thereof, being the Schoole of the Apo≈øtles, and Metropolitan Citie of Theodor. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. l. 2. cap. 4. Ca≈ø≈øiod. Hi≈øt. Tripart. lib. 4. cap. 6. pietie euen from the beginning, Literis ≈øuis fatebantur Eccle≈øiam Romanam Primas apud omnes ferre, vtpote quae Apo≈øtolorum ≈øchola, & pietatis Metropolis iam ab initio fui≈ø≈øet. And both Theodoret and Ca≈ø≈øiodorus te≈øtifie, that the Arrians them≈øelues ≈øent their accu≈øations again≈øt S. Athana≈øius to this Pope of Rome Iulius, to be iudged by him, as highe≈øt Iudge, and Pope Iulius according to the Eccle≈øia≈øticall Lawe, commanded both them and S. Athana≈øius one a certaine
day to appeare before him at Rome to receaue ≈øentence, Iulius Eccle≈øiasticam ≈øecutus Legem, & ip≈øos Romae ade≈ø≈øe iu≈øsit, & diem dixit diuo Athana≈øio. And by Ca≈ø≈øiodorus, & venerabilem Athana≈øium and Iudicium regulariter euocauit. So that it is euident, this Supreamacy of the Pope of Rome, was not giuen to that holy See by Con≈øtantine, or any late Pope his claime or challeng, but from the begining. And Con≈øtantine, though a mo≈øt worthie Chri≈øtian King and Emperour, did neither call nor confirme any Councell, as a ≈øupreame Iudge, and Sentencer, but as an A≈ø≈øi≈øtant Temporall, ≈øuch as good Kings are, and should be in prouiding ≈øecuritie, quiet, protection and bodily nece≈ø≈øaries for the Bishops a≈ø≈øembled, as I haue before remembred he did. The calling of the Councells was, as that greate generall of Nyce by the Bishops order, and direction, Ruffinus Eu≈øebius and others te≈øtifie, Con≈øtantinus ex Sacerdotum Ruffin. l. 1. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈øia≈øt. cap. 1. Eu≈øeb. l. 10. Hi≈øt. cap. 1. Cap. 5. ≈øupra. ≈øententia apud vrbem Nicaeam Epi≈øcopale Concilium conuocat. Where we ≈øee both the calling, and A≈ø≈øembly to the Epi≈øcopall, as all others were, and the ≈øentence and Iudgment by them onely, po≈øt diutinum multumque tractatum placet omnibus, ac velut vno cunctorum ore & corde decernitur,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
≈øcribi debere, id e≈øt eiu≈ødem cum patre ≈øub≈øtantiae filium confiteri idque firmi≈øsima omniuÃÑ ≈øententia pronuntiatur. Defertur ad Con≈øtantinum ≈øacerdotalis concilij ≈øententia. Ille tanquam a Deo prolatam veneratur. Cui ≈øi quis tenta≈ø≈øet obniti, velut contra diuina statuta venientem, in exilium ≈øe prote≈øtatur acturum. Where we ≈øee this greate≈øt temporall Commander that euer was in the worlde, was ≈øo farre from v≈øurping, or clayming any ≈øpirituall Power to decide, and iudge of Que≈øtions in Religion, that he was not pre≈øent when they were determined by the Bishops, but leauing all ≈øuch deci≈øions vnto them, as their ≈øeruant, con≈øeruus, as Sozom. l. 1. Hi≈øt. Eccl. c. 18. he calleth him≈øelfe, mo≈øt reuerently embraced, and with his temporall Power executed what they concluded.

div.head: THE XVIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: THE CONSTANCIE OF BRITAINE IN THE true Catholike Religion, before, and after the Nicen Councell, it had Bishops there, con≈øented vnto, receaued, and kept inuiolable the Decrees thereof, not admitting Here≈øie heare.

div.p: 1. WE haue thus farre trauailed, in remembring the greate peace, and glory the≈øe two Noble British Princes the Mother and Sonne, Queene Helen and Con≈øtantine procured to the vniuer≈øall Catholike Church of Chri≈øt in other Nations of the world in ≈øuch manner, that the generall Conuer≈øion of the Gentils ≈øpoken of by Malachy the Prophet, ≈øeemeth to haue bene re≈øerued for the honour of this Nation, by the help and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of tho≈øe two mo≈øt renowned children thereof, ab ortu ≈øolis v≈øque ad occa≈øum, magnum e≈øt nomen meum in Gen Mal ‚Ä¢ ch. 1. tibus, & in omni loco ≈øacrificatur & offertur nomini meo Oblatio munda, quia magnum e≈øt nomen meum in gentibus, dicit Dominus exercituum. For euen from this la≈øte Nation in the we≈øt, then knowne to the furthe≈øt hence in the Ea≈øt, the Gho≈øpell of Chri≈øt was happily by their helpe and in their dayes embraced.

2. Now it is time to returne into Britaine againe, where we shall by the longe ab≈øence of CoÃÑ≈øtantine our King & Emperour froÃÑ hence, & many of our cheife Nobilitie & others atteÃÑding him in his Warrs & Trauailes, finde the ≈øtate of this Kingdome, e≈øpecially in ciuill and temporall affaires di≈øtempered, & „Äà‚óä„Äâ vnquiet, by the te≈øtimony of our owne Hi≈øtorians. Fir≈øt CoÃÑ≈øtantine going heÃÑce towards Rome again≈øt the TyraÃÑt MaxeÃÑtius carried with him froÃÑ Britaine to ≈øerue him in tho≈øe warrs, as our Antiquaries agree, a greate Power of his CouÃÑtry Brittish ≈øouldiars, as mo≈øt true & faithfull vnto him, by who≈øe prowe≈ø≈øe & valor he obtaining Victory, he gaue them in recompence of their loyall and valiant ≈øeruice, as both our owne Antiquaries, and others write, a dwelling and lyuing in the we≈øt part of France, bordering vpon the Sea, mo≈øt probably in litle Britaine, where they coÃÑtinued in his dayes with ≈øome litle difference froÃÑ the Britans of this Kingdome, Con≈øtantinus ab Exercitu Imperator con≈øalutatus, expeditione Gulielm. Malm. de ge≈øt. Reg. Angl. l. 1. c. 1. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. c. 28. in ≈øuperiores terras indicta, magnam manaÃÑ militum Brita ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ orum abduxit, per quorum Indu≈øtriam, triumphis ad vota fluentibus breui rer ‚Ä¢ m potitus, emeritos & laboribus functos in quadam parte Gallia ad Occidentem ≈øuper littus Oceani collocauit: vbi bodieque Posteri ‚Ä¢ orum man ‚Ä¢ ntes immane quantum coaluere, moribus linguaque nonnihil a no≈øtris Brittonibus degenores. And this was the fir≈øt planting of our Britans in that litle Britaine, by the≈øe Authours, longe before the ≈øetling of them there by Maximus: which (to a greate weakening of this Kingdome to haue a greate Army of ≈øelected Souldiars to be carried away, planted in an other Country, and neuer returne againe, as the like in the time of Maximus) occa≈øioned the ≈øpoyling and de≈øolation thereof.

3. The remnant of who≈øe British Souldiars which were left vn≈ølaine, as al≈øo tho≈øe of an other Con≈øtantine after him, went and ioyned them≈øelues with the former Britans in litle Britaine, which went hence with Con≈øtantine the Greate, as the olde Monke of Malmesbury writeth, Copiarum quae illos ad bellum Guliel. Mal ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e≈ø. ≈øupr. ≈øecutae fuerant, pars occi≈øa, pars post fugam ad ≈øuperiores Britones conce≈øsit. But by the common opinion of our Antiquaries, there was an other and Greater occa≈øion of the weakening and di≈øquieting of Britaine about this time, by rea≈øon of dome≈øticall and ciuill warrs in this Land. For Con≈øtantine the Greate at his departure hence leauing the gouernment of this Kingdome, as our old English Hi≈øtorie recordeth to a Noble man, ≈øome ≈øtyle him a King, named Octauian, when Con≈øtantine went from this lond to Rome, he toke all his lond to kepe to the Old. Engl. Chronic. f. 34. p. 1. Earle of Cornewayle that was called Octauian. And anone as this Octauian wi≈øt that his lord dwelled at Rome, incontinent he ce≈øed all the londe into his hands, and therwith did all his will amoÃÑg by and lowe, and they helde him for King. But other Hi≈øtorians both British and English, dome≈øticall and forrein affirme, that Con≈øtantine at his going from Britaine to Rome, committed the gouernment of this Kingdome to the Roman Procon≈øuls, and the named Octauian, or Octauius tooke Armes again≈øt them, ≈ølewe them, and ≈øo obtained to be King heare, Octauius Dux wi≈ø≈øeorum in≈øurrexit in Procon≈øules Romanae dignitatis, quibus In≈øulae regimen Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 5. c. 8. Pont. Vir. Hi≈øt. Britan. l. 5. Matth. We≈øtm. an. gratiae 314. Hard. Chron. c. 63. f. ‚Ä¢ 0. permi≈ø≈øum fuerat, & ≈øolio Regni, ip≈øis interfectis, potitus e≈øt. The Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øaith, this Octauius was a King before, Octauius Geni≈øeorum Rex, a Regulus or Prince of the people in and about Worce≈øtershire. Harding ≈øaith he was Duke of we≈øte≈øex, he mu≈øt meane where the We≈øt Saxons after Ruled, for they came not into Britaine vntill longe after this time.

lg.l: But after his day came one Octauius
Duke of we≈øte ≈øex that crowned was for King
That sl ‚Ä¢ ugh the werdins of Con≈øtantinus
Which that he ≈øette for Britaine gouerning
In his ab≈øence, to kepe it in all thing.

div.p: 4. Be≈øides this, there be other difficulties among the Hi≈øtorians about this Octauius, and ≈øuch as will di≈øcredite him for hauing had any greate cheife and longe command as a King in this Nation. Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øetteth downe his conquering the RomaÃÑ Procon≈øuls heare in the yeare of Chri≈øt 314. when as I haue proued before by diuers more auncient and receaued Hi≈øtorians, that S. Helen our Queene and Empre≈ø≈øe continued heare longe after that time. And her ≈øonne Con≈øtantine Emperour now at the highe≈øt of his glory, power, and Victories, and hauing ≈øo many British Souldiars without employment in France, ≈øo neare vnto vs, cannot be imagined to haue ≈øuffered any Enemy in his owne natiue Country ≈øo to haue preuailed. Or how could ≈øuch a man as this Octauius is ≈øuppo≈øed to be, a≈ø≈øemble ≈øuch an Army in Britaine, where that mo≈øt victorious Emperour was vndoubted King, and whence he had ≈øo greate an Army of Britons ≈øo lately before, that by them, as our Hi≈øtorians write, he vanquished allmo≈øt inmunerable Companies of his mo≈øt potent Enemy, Magnam manum Britonum abduxit, per quorum indu≈øtriam, Guliel. Malm. l. 1. de ge≈øtis Reg. c. 1. triumphis ad vota fluentibus breui rerum potitus. And as the≈øe Relators of Octauius proceedings them≈øelues are witne≈ø≈øes, the power which Con≈øtantine carryed from Britaine was ≈øo greate, that the Romans which came hither vnto him, ≈øeeing his power, ≈øaide no Prince in the world was comparable vnto him for ≈øtrength, Quis Princeps Regi Britanniae conferri queat in fortitudine robu≈øtorum Galfr. Monum. l. 5. c. 7. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 312. E ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ eb. lib. 1. vit. Con≈øtant. cap. 4. Eu≈øeb. libt. 4. de Vit. Con≈øtant. c. 51. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 390. Baron. & Spondan. in Annal. an. 383. Sigebert. Chron. an. 383. militum? by an other, e≈øt tibi robu≈øti≈øsimorum militum maxima multitudo. Where then in Britaine could Octauius gather an Army ≈øo ≈øoone ≈øo encounter & ouerthrowe three Legions of RomaÃÑ Souldiars, be≈øides their adherents, as the≈øe men ≈øay? And Eu≈øebius ≈øaith, that Con≈øtantine him≈øelfe came hither againe, in Britanniam inua≈øit, and was heare longer after this pretended Reuolt: and at his death gaue Britaine, his auncient Patrimony, to his elde≈øt ≈øonne, a≈ø≈øignabat auitam ≈øortem grandiori natu filio. Againe the≈øe men ≈øay, Octauius was King heare vntill Maximus his time, and marryed his onely daughter and Heire vnto him. When it is a common con≈øent in Antiquities, that this Maximus or Maximianus was not King in Britaine vntill after the 380. yeare of Chri≈øt. Therefore he mu≈øt needs be granted to haue bene very youÃÑge, and of too few yeares at the going of Con≈øtantine hence, for him to commit the gouernment of Britaine vnto him, or for him≈øelfe to haue ≈øo ≈øoone v≈øurped it, again≈øt ≈øo righfull and a potent King and Emperour.

5. And our mo≈øt auncient and be≈øt Hi≈øtorians S. Gildas, S. Bede, Marianus, Gild. l. de Excid. & conq. Brit. c. 10. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gebert. Chron. Eutrop. Hi≈øt. Polyd. Virgil. Angl. Hi≈øt. l. 3. p. 49. Stowe & Howes Hi≈øt. in Con≈øtaÃÑt. Con≈øtantius, Iulian. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 4. Fa≈øt. Reg. & Epi≈øc. Angl. Ammian. Marcelli. l. 20. in init. l. 26. 28. Florentius Wigornien≈øis, Ethelwerdus, Henry of Huntington and William of Malmesbury, allthough as diligently as they could, recoÃÑpting our Kings of Britaine, neuer mention any ≈øuch Octauius or Octauian. But the cheife≈øt and mo≈øt auncient of them S. Gildas plainely ≈øaith, that this Iland was at this time, and vntill Maximus or Maximian a Britan tooke vpon him the Empire, a Roman Iland, In≈øula nomen Romanum tenens. And diuers Hi≈øtorians both late and auncient, Catholiks and Prote≈øtants, doe particularly ≈øet downe our Kings after Con≈øtantine the Greate, & Roman Lieutenants heare vntill the≈øe dayes, as Con≈øtantine, Con≈øtantius, Iulian, Valentinian, Gratian, Emperours our Kings: Martinus, Lupicinus, Nectaridius, Theado≈øius, Fraomarius and other Roman Lieutenants, and Gouernours heare. And when the Councell of Ariminum was kept about the yeare of Chri≈øt 360. and the 23. yeare of Con≈øtantius ≈øonne of Con≈øtantine the Greate, it is certaine, that this Con≈øtantius
was our King in Britaine, and bore the chardges of the poore≈øt Bishops of this Kingdome, as then vnder his gouernment, which were pre≈øent there, and he was ≈øo farre from loo≈øing Britaine, or any other Country of his Empire then, that as Sozomen and others te≈øtifie, that Councell thus wrote vnto him at this time, ≈øic tuum creuit Imperium, vt vniuer ≈øi orbis terrar ‚Ä¢ m gubernacula teneas. Epi≈øt. Ariminen. Concil. ad Con≈øtaÃÑtiuÃÑ. Imp. apud Sozom. Hi≈øtor. l. 4. c. 47. His Empire was ≈øo encrea≈øed, that all the world was vnder his Gouernment. This was aboue 20. yeares after the death of the greate Con≈øtantine, in who≈øe time this Reuolt of Britaine from him is thus ≈øuppo≈øed, and aboue twyce ≈øo longe time of the imagined v≈øurpation heare by Octauius. And Zonaras writeth that this Con≈øtantius in the 14. yeare of his Empire bannished, or rather carried with him S. Athana≈øius into Britaine, at his comming hither. Eodem anno 14. Magnus Ath ‚Ä¢ na≈øius √† Con≈øtantio in Britanniam deportatur. Ioa. Zonar. tom. 3. Ann. f. 117. c. de Con≈øtantio & Con≈øtante.

6. Therefore I dare not to a≈ø≈øent, that in this time of the greate≈øt florishing E≈øtate of the RomaÃÑ Empire, & the Power thereof in Britaine, e≈øpecially from whence the glory of it grew to that greatenes, eyther Octauius or any other ≈øo much preuailed heare to barre the Emperours of that honour. But he might towards the time of Maximus or Maximianus, when the Empire had more enemyes and le≈ø≈øe power, preuaile in ≈øome ≈øuch ≈øort, as the≈øe Hi≈øtorians haue writen of him, allthough they differ al≈øo in Maximianus a≈øwell as in Octauius. One ≈øaith, he was the ≈øonne of Trahern vncle to S. Helen, Maximian Harding. Cronc. c. 63. f. 51. Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Reg. Brit. l. 5. c. 9. Pontic. Vir. H ‚Ä¢ ≈øt. l. 5. Matth. We≈øtm. An. 379. Harding ≈øupr. King Traherne his ≈øonne to Con≈øtantine next Heire: others affirme he was ≈øonne of Leolinus an other vncle of S. Helen, greate vncle to Con≈øtantine, Leoninus Con≈øtantini auanculus ip≈øum genuerat. And erat patre Britannus √† Leolmo Con≈øtantini auanculo procreatus, matre vero Natione Romanus, ex vtraque parte regalem originem ducens. And one of them ≈øaith, Octauius was King but 14. yeares ending with the beginning of Maximian his reigne. And ≈øo we may well allowe ≈øuch an Octauius to haue borne the name of a King in Britaine in tho≈øe troble≈øome dayes of the Romans ruling heare, diuers petty Kings being probably at that time in this Nation, a≈øwell by the te≈øtimony of the≈øe Authours, which then make Octauius King, as others. So they terme Conanus a King, & that Maximian tooke his Kingdome from him, cui Regnum Britanniae eripuerat. So was Dionotus King in Cornwayle, Dionotus Rex Cornubiae. So was his Galfr. Monum. l. 5. c. 1 ‚Ä¢ . 15. Pontic. Virun. l. 5. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 390. 392. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. in vit. S. Niniani. Capgr. in eod. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. in Niniano. brother Carodocus before him, Dionothus qui fratri ≈øuo Caradoco in regnum ≈øucce≈ø≈øerat. And yet vnder our cheife King and Emperour Maximian at that time, Cui Maximianus In≈øulae principatum commendauerat. And S. Ninian who lyued Bishop heare in the end of this Age had Kings for his Ance≈øtores, Regali ex pro≈øapia beatus Ninianus extitit oriundus. And yet the greate di≈øtance of the place of his birth from King Coel, and the≈øe remeÃÑbred, argueth he was not of their Line. And all the≈øe Kings or Regents heare were mo≈øt certainely by our Antiquities Catholike Chri≈øtians.

7. Therefore the Temporall State in re≈øpect of any of theÃÑ, could not be any The falling of CoÃÑ stantius Emperor to the Arrian Here≈øie a great hurt to Catholike ReligioÃÑ in many places. hinderance, but rather help and furtherance to the increa≈øe of Chri≈øtian ReligioÃÑ in their time. But it was rather the Here≈øie of Con≈øtantius the Arrian Emperour, which hindered the glory of true Religion then in this Kingdome, as it did in other places and Countries of the world, if it did not ≈øo much florish heare theÃÑ as in his ble≈ø≈øed Father CoÃÑ≈øtantine the Greate his Empire. And yet we may be bold to affirme, that the State of our Brittish Church, euen in The kingdome of Britaine as free as any from the Arrian Here≈øie. tho≈øe di≈øtempered dayes, when the holy Writers of that Age complaine, the allmo≈øt whole Chri≈øtian world to haue bene polluted with the ArriaÃÑ Here≈øie, was as renowned for our Bishops, and Cleargie, and as free from that infection,
as any Nation was. We haue heard before that our renowned Archbishop of London Re≈øtitutus with diuers others Bishops of this Kingdome was pre≈øent at the greate Councell of Arles, celebrated diuers yeares after CoÃÑ≈øtantine went from Britaine to Rome. And allthough we doe not expre≈ø≈øely finde it writen of Britaine, that the Bishops thereof were at the Councell of Nice, bishops of Britaine at the first Nicen Councell, as at others. no more then of diuers other Countries le≈ø≈øe replenished with Bishops at that time, then Britaine was, and yet without que≈øtion had Bishops there to make vp that greate number there a≈ø≈øembled, which the Prouinces who≈øe Bishops are particularly related to haue bene there, could not performe, yet there be many Arguments, and ≈øome of them allmo≈øt plaine euidences, that our Brittish Bishops were there al≈øo, as at other Councels in that time. Fir≈øt it was a generall, and the fir≈øt generall CouÃÑcell, which requireth generall pre≈øence of all Chri≈øtian NatioÃÑs, the Decrees of ≈øuch an A≈ø≈øembly binding all, therefore Britaine being ≈øo greate and glorious a part of the Chri≈øtian world then, and hauing the King thereof borne and declared Emperour in it, ≈øo greate an In≈øtrument of this ≈øacred A≈ø≈øembly, & ≈øo, as much intere≈ø≈øed in that Councell as any Kingdome was, may not be ≈øaid to haue bene ab≈øent. And Eu≈øebius then liuing ≈øaith, Con≈øtantine called Bi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ops thither from all places, Concilium generale, tanquam quendam Dei exercitum in≈øtruens, in vnum locum coegit: & Epi≈øcopos Eu≈øebius l. 3. de Vit. Con≈øt. c. 6. vndique per literas honorific√® ≈øcriptas, vt eo maturarent, acciuit. Therefore of all NatioÃÑs Britaine would, and did mo≈øt willingly embrace and ≈øatisfy tho≈øe letters ≈øent hither into it from their Country Emperour. Againe the ≈øame Authour a liuing witne≈ø≈øe plainely affirmeth, not onely that the Imperiall Edict for calling this Councell was published in euery Prouince of the Empire, ≈øuch as euery Prouince in Britaine then was, but that all the Bishops with all willingnes and ≈øpeed they could ha≈øted to the place a≈ø≈øigned, Vbi Edictum in quaque Prouincia diuulgatum erat, omnes ≈øumma cum animorum alacritate, tanquam √® carceribus ad cur≈øum emi≈øsi, proper√® aduolarunt. And he addeth plainely that the cheife≈øt Bishops of all Churches in all Europe where Britaine is, naming it Cap. 7. ≈øupr. the fir≈øt, A≈øia, and Afrike were there, Ex omnibus namque Eccle≈øijs, quae frequentes in tota Europa, Africa, & A≈øia extiterunt, Dei mini≈øtri, qui facile Primas ferre putabantur, in vnum conuocati. No di≈øtance or ≈øeparation of Country or Nation hindered the Bishops from being there, Non ≈øoluÃÑ qui animorum di≈ø≈øen≈øione erant, ≈øed etiam qui corporibus, regionibus, locis, gentibus longi≈øsim√® di≈øiuncti, Cap. 6. 7. 8. vnum in locum aggregati ≈øunt. The extreame Scythians were not ab≈øent, nec ab hoc Choro Scytha abfuit. All knowne Chri≈øtian Nations had Bishops there, Ex omni Natione quae ≈øub ≈øole e≈øt, quorum domicilia multo longiore locorum interuallo di≈øtabant, e ‚Ä¢ aduentarunt. And no man can be a better witne≈ø≈øe for the pre≈øence of our Brittish Bishops there, their true and holy ob≈øeruation of the Chri≈øtian Catholike Rites and cu≈øtomes, and number of Bishops and Churches heare, then our renowned King and Countryman Con≈øtantine the Greate Emperour, who in his ≈øolemne Oration in that greate Councell expre≈ø≈øely nameth our Britaine with the mo≈øt Noble NatioÃÑs, who≈øe Bishops were in that Councell, profe≈ø≈øed the truth, and had greate≈øt number of Churches, more then Con≈øtantinus Mag. orat. habit. in Conc. Nicen. apud Eu≈øe. l. 3. de Vit. Con≈øtant. c. 18. other Countries at that time, Ip≈øe in me recepi, ve≈øtram ≈øapientiam facil√® a≈ø≈øen≈øuram: vos videlicet quod in vrbe Roma, in Italia, in Africa, in Aegipto, in Hispania, Gallia, & Britannia, in Libia, & vniuer≈øa Graecia, in Diaece≈øi A≈øiatica, & Pontica, in Cilicia denique vna & con≈øentiente ≈øententia con≈øeruatur, hoc ve≈øtram prudentiam lubenter approbaturam: illud ≈øedulo reputantes quod in locis quae modo citaui maior Eccle≈øiarum numerus exi≈øtat. Where we ≈øee Britaine to be numbred with
the mo≈øt florishing Kingdomes, who≈øe Bishops were pre≈øent in the Nicen Councell, to be giuen for a Rule and Pre≈øident to other Nations in Chri≈øtian holy doctrine and pietie, and at that time, in the yeare of Chri≈øt by common accompt 325. to haue bene one of the Principall Countries, which had the greate≈øt number of Churches, and con≈øequently of Bishops and other Cleargie men to ≈øupply their ≈øacred functions in them. And this te≈øtified in open Councell, by him which of all others mu≈øt needs be≈øt knowe the E≈øtate of this his natiue Country vnder his temporall gouernment, is ≈øufficient and abowndant te≈øtimony in this matter.

8. For if he had not expre≈ø≈øely put Britaine in the Catalogue of the cheife≈øt Nations, which had Bishops there, by all Antiquities, but onely ≈øaid, as he clearely doth that Britaine theÃÑ was one of the cheife≈øt places, in which the greate≈øt number of Churches with their Bishops was, euery man would haue infallibly concluded, that this Councell ≈øo generall from all Nations, had diuers Brittish Bishops there. And if Con≈øtantine had bene ≈øilent in this matter, the very ≈øub≈øcription of the Bishops of Nice, as it is left lame and maimed vnto vs, would haue proued a≈ømuch. For although it doth not particularly name any Bishops from Britaine there, no more the ‚Ä¢ the Councell of Sardice ≈øub≈øcription, or the Councell of Ariminum doth, wherein mo≈øt certainely Britaine had diuers Bishops, as diuers al≈øo in the Councell of Arles, and onely one Re≈øtitutus is remembred in it: yet it giueth vs ≈øufficient proofe, that Britaine had Bishops al≈øo at Nice, or el≈øe we shall want very many of the number a≈ø≈øembled there. For it ≈øaith with the common opinion that 318. were there, and thereto ≈øu≈øcribed, & ≈øub≈øcrip≈øerunt trecenti decem & octo Epi≈øcopi qui in eodem Sub≈øcript. Concil. Nicaeni To. 1. Concil. Concilio conuenerunt. And yet ≈øetting downe the Bishops of all other places be≈øides Britaine, remembred by Con≈øtantine before, Italy, Afrike, Egipt, Spaine, France, Lybia, Greece, A≈øia, Pontus, and Cilicia, and 30. others which had Bishops there; it cannot finde out, aboue 225. Bishops from all the≈øe Countries, but leaueth allmo≈øt an hundred wanting of the full number. Therefore we mu≈øt needs ≈øay, that Britaine, there forgotten, did remember, and furnish that The Nicenfaith receaued and daly ob≈øerued in Britayne. ≈øacred Councell with diuers Bishops, which with many others of other Nations are now wanting in that Sub≈øcription.

9. And this greate glory of Britaine for worthines and number of Bishops, and con≈øtancy in that holy faith, which they had con≈øented vnto, and receaued in this Nicene Councell, remayned euer after in this Kingdome vntill the decaying time of our Britans gouernment: As will appeare in the following Hi≈øtory. For the time of Con≈øtantine the Greate, and Con≈øtantius his ≈øoone, that greate friend of Arians & their Here≈øies, it shall ≈øuffice in this place to v≈øe for warrant the te≈øtimony and words them≈øelues of the Bishops of this Nation, ioyning therein with 400. other Bishops in the Councell of Ariminum thus vpbraiding that Arrian Emperour, and pleading their Innocency in their Publike Epi≈øtle vnto him. That his Father Con≈øtantine laboured all he could euen till his dying day, to haue the holy faith of Nice continue ≈øtable, and permanent for euer, and to innouate any thing therein, should be to conteme ≈øo many holy Confe≈ø≈øors and Martyrs which had profe≈ø≈øed it, and the old In≈øtitution and ob≈øeruation of the Catholike Church, continuing vntill his Empire, Cum intelligamus Constantinum Principem omnium Po≈øterorum memoria Epi≈øt. Concil. Arimin. ad Con≈øtant. Imperat. apud Socrat. l. 2. Hi≈øt. cap. 29. po≈øt mortem celebrandum, diligenter elabora≈ø≈øe vt fides illa Nicaae literis prodita, accurati≈øsim√® perqui≈øita, explorataque e≈ø≈øet: ab≈øurdum plane videretur, eo iam po≈øt acceptum Bapti≈ømum vita functo, & ad tanquil ‚Ä¢ itatem ≈øibi debitam profecto,
aliquid in ea nouare: & tot ≈øanc ‚Ä¢ os Confe≈ø≈øores & Martyres, qui huius doctrinae Authores, inuentore≈øque fuerunt, quique vt vetus Eccle≈øiae Catholicae in≈øtitutum po≈øcebat, omnino ≈øen≈øerunt, inque eo per≈øtiterunt perpetuo, pror≈øus contemnere. Quorum fidem ad tui Imperij tempora Deus per Dominum no≈øtrum Ie≈øum Chri≈øtum perduxit. And there earne≈øtly exhort him, that no Innouation be made, but ≈øuffer them to per≈øeuer quietly in the faith of their Predece≈ø≈øors, directed by the holy gho≈øt: and neither to adde nor detract any thing to tho≈øe auncient Decrees, which by his Fathers pietie had bene ob≈øerued and kept ≈øo long vnuiolate, Tuam clementiam obte≈øtamur, vt non permittas quicquam nouari ad eorum contumeliam, qui vita exce≈ø≈øerint: ≈øed nobis facias pote≈øtatem in his quae ≈øunt √† Maioribus quos quidem ingenuos√® & prudenter spiritu ≈øancto illis opem ferente, omnia tran≈øegi≈ø≈øe constat, Decreta ≈øancitaque firm√® per≈øeuerandi. Flagitamus, ne quid veteribus Decretis vel detrahatur, vel adijciatur omnino: ≈øed omnia quae patris tui pietate v≈øque ad hoc tempus ob≈øeruata fuerunt, rata, firmaque permaneant, neque de caetero nobis quicquam de ijs rebus face≈ø≈øus mole≈øtiae, aut a no≈øtris ip≈øorum Eccle≈øijs nos abe≈ø≈øe ≈øinas. By this greate euidence of 400. witne≈ø≈øes both our renowned Con≈øtantine both lyuing and dying, and this Kingdome of Britaine is hitherto free from all ≈øu≈øpition of Here≈øie. Of the continued Innocency of Britaine from that fowle and allmo≈øt generall Infection, I shall ≈øpeake more heareafter; that which I haue ≈øaid before ≈øufficiently excu≈øeth Con≈øtantine. And both Theodoret & SozomeÃÑ doe mo≈øt plainely cleare him: The fir≈øt affirmeth, that he was ≈øo earne≈øt a Profe≈ø≈øor and Patrone of the Nicen faith all his life, that ≈øo long as he liued no man dur≈øt openly deny it, dum vixit Con≈øtantinus, nemo ‚Ä¢ am apert√® reijcere au≈øus e≈øt. The other doth euidently proue, that he was ≈øo grounded in the true Catholike faith, e≈øtablished Sozom. Hi≈øt. Eccl. lib. 3. c. 1. at Nice, that the Arrian Prei≈øt which ≈øeduced his Si≈øter Con≈øtantia, and his ≈øonne Con≈øtantius afterward, being by his Si≈øters meanes pre≈øent with him at his death, and tru≈øted to deliuer his la≈øt Will to his ≈øonne Con≈øtantius, neuer dur≈øt bewray him≈øelfe to Con≈øtantine, that he was an Arrian, much le≈ø≈øe per≈øuade that holy Emperour to that Here≈øie, pe ‚Ä¢ ceauing how firme and con≈øtant he was in the true Catholike faith, non fuit au≈øus palam facere Theodoret. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 2. c. 3. malum ≈øuum, cum videret quanta e≈ø≈øet regiae mentis in re diuina firmitas: But he re≈øerued the vomiting of that his poi≈øon to Con≈øtantius, whome he infected after his Fathers death.

div.head: THE XIX. CHAPTER.

argument.p: HOW BRITAINE HAD MANY BISHOPS at the true greate Sardican Councell: they and the other Bishops, Prei≈øts, and Chri≈øtians heare profe≈ø≈øed the true Catholike faith, and were free from Here≈øie.

div.p: 1. NEITHER was Con≈øtatius ≈øoone after his Fathers death infected with the Arrian Here≈øie, either to endanger Britaine, or any other Nation vnder his Dominion: but con≈øented to the recalling of S. Athana≈øius from Exile, Epi≈øt. Con≈øtantij ad S. Athana≈ø. apud Socr. l. 2. Hi≈øtor. c. 18. & Athan. Apolog. 2. Socrat. l. 2. c. 16. Sozo. l. 3. c. 10. 11. Nicephorus Hi≈øtor. Eccl. l. 9. c. 12 Sozom. ≈øupr. c. 11. Conc. Sardic. ep. to. 1. Conc. Athana≈ø. epi≈øt. ad Antioch. Tom. 1. oper. S. Athan. & apud al. and ≈øome time to his continuing his dignitie at Alexandria. And whether it was for loue of S. Athana≈øius, or feare of his Brother Con≈øtans, writing earne≈øtly vnto him in fauour of S. Athana≈øius, he wrote diuers frendly letters vnto him after this, of which Socrates ≈øetteth downe three, and con≈øented to the calling of the greate generall Councell of Sardyce 10. or 11. yeares after the death of Con≈øtantine the Greate his Father, as Socrates and Sozomen affirme, wherein S. Athana≈øius was proued innocent, and as he then pre≈øent with many others proueth, the Nicen faith was confirmed, and vtterly forbidden to be que≈øtioned, Sancta Synodus quae Sardis conuenit, Decreto ≈øanciuit, ne quid vlterius de fide ≈øcriberetur, & ≈øe≈øe contentos e≈ø≈øe Nicaena fide declarauerunt: vt cui nihil dee≈ø≈øet, & in qua integra & ≈øolida pietas contineretur: neque edendam e≈ø≈øe aliam profe≈øsionem fidei, ne illa quae Nicaae ≈øcripta e≈øt, ≈øuos numeros non habere videretur, neue illis, quibus libido e≈øt, ≈øemper noua statuere, occa≈øio huiu≈ømodi ≈øuppeditaretur, vt iterum atque iterum de fide definiant. Athana≈ø. Apol. 2. contra Arrianos.

2. And at the calling of this Councell, the ≈øame renowned Catholike Doctor calleth this Con≈øtantius, as al≈øo his Brother a knowne Catholike Emperor, Diuers Bishops of Britaine, 5. at the lea≈øt pre≈øent at the generall Councell of Sardice: But probably diuers more. a mo≈øt Religeous Prince, in Magno Concilio Sardico ad EdictuÃÑ Religio≈øi≈øsimorum Principum Con≈øtantij & Constantis. And we are ≈øure, that at this time our Kingdome of Britaine retayned the former glorious e≈øtate and glory of Religion it had before in the dayes of Con≈øtantine, and was ≈øtill free from the Arrian Here≈øie. For the ≈øame glorious Confe≈ø≈øor S. Athana≈øius pre≈øent in that Councell, ≈øaith, that among more then 300. Bishops a≈ø≈øembled there which Sex. Ruf. Breuia. Rer. ge≈øt. po. Ro. ad Valentiniani. Aug. Sigonius l. 4. de Occid. Imperio p. 89. 90. Arnold. Mylius in Antiq. nomin. Region. In≈øular. &c. Sepher. Bin. Annot. in Conc. Sardic. to. 1. CoÃÑc. Baron. & Spond. An. 347. Athana≈ø. Apol. 2. freed him, and profe≈ø≈øed the Nicen faith, the Bishops from the Prouinces of Britaine, ex Prouincijs Britanniarum, were there. And as the RomaÃÑ Writers te≈øtifie, there were from the diui≈øion of the Empire by Con≈øtantine, and as many ≈øuppo≈øe before, fiue Prouinces heare in Britaine, Britanniae quinque, Maxima Cae≈øarie ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s, Valentia, Britannia prima, Britannia ≈øecunda, Flauia Cae≈øarien≈øis. So that if we should allowe but one Bishop out of euery of the≈øe Prouinces, to haue bene at the Sardyce Councell, and there to haue ≈øub≈øcribed for the re≈øt of their Prouinces or Dioce≈ø≈øes, we mu≈øt grant fiue Brittish Bishops to haue bene there, and ≈øupplied this dutie, and office for the re≈øt of Britaine. But we shall finde more by the Rule of proportion, in re≈øpect of the greate nuÃÑber of Catholike Bishops a≈ø≈øembled in that Councell, or in regard of our neighboring Countries, namely France in many places thereof as farre di≈øtant from Sardice
in Thrace where this Councell was kept, now by the Turkes reigning there, named Triadizza or Triaditze, as Britaine is, and farre then from exceeding this Nation for number of Bishops, proportion of quantitie, and Prouinces in them ob≈øerued, for S.
