Athana≈øius pre≈øent at this Councell te≈øtifieth, there were 344. Catholike Bishops there, in vniuer≈øum trecenti & quadraginta quatuor: Yet recompting the names of the Bishops of Italy, Spaine, France, Egipt, Cyprus, Affrike, Pale≈øtina and diuers other Nations pre≈øent in that Councell, in omitting the names of the Bishops of Britaine, and ≈øome other Countries, wanteth aboue 60. of his owne number to be ≈øupplyed from this our Britaine and other places of farre meaner note. And out of France he ≈øetteth downe the names of 34. Bishops of that Nation there pre≈øent, and yet no Antiquitie of that Age doth triple France vnto Britaine either for Prouinces, or Bishops in tho≈øe dayes.

3. Sextus Rufus in his Breuiarie of the Roman ge≈øts to Valentinian the Emperor, Sext. Ruf. Breui. ad Valentinian. Augu≈øtum. findeth in France, diuided from Belgia, and Germany, onely ten Prouinces twice ≈øo many, as I haue alleaged to haue bene then in Britaine, and it will be more then a difficult thing for any man to proue that France then had as many more Bishops as Britaine had. Therefore I cannot finde it any inconuenience or incongruitie to hold, that Britaine ≈øo deuoted to Catholike true Religion, and ≈øo furnished with Bishops then, as is declared, had halfe ≈øo many Bishops thereof at Sardice Councell, as S. Athana≈øius hath remembred from France. And the re≈øt of our Bishops which were not at that Councell, but remayned ≈øtill in Britaine ≈øub≈øcribed vnto, and receaued the Catholike Decrees of that Councell, as is manife≈øt by the Epi≈øtle of that holy Councell to all ab≈øent Bishops ≈øo exhorting them, vos quoque ≈øtudete fratres & commini≈øtri Concil. Sardic. Epi≈øt. omnib. Catholic. Eccl. Epi≈ø. Tom. 2. oper. Athana≈ø. Athana≈ø. ≈øupr. Apol. 2. Vr≈øac & Valens Epi≈øt. ad Athan. To. 2. oper eius. no≈øtri in ≈øacris obe ‚Ä¢ ndis, vt ≈øpiritu prae≈øentes in no≈øtra Synodo ideÃÑ ≈øuffragium conferatis, per ve≈øtras ≈øub≈øcriptiones. Which, as S. Athana≈øius writeth, they performed, Haec ita ≈øcriptis mandata, ≈øacrum Sardicen≈øe Concilium ad eos qui intere≈ø≈øe non poterant, mi≈øit, qui ip≈øi quoque ≈øuis ≈øuffragijs Decreta Synodi approbarunt. And Vr≈øacius and Valens in their Epi≈øtle, written to S. Athana≈øius, freely confe≈ø≈øe, that he was freed by aboue 400. erant plures in hoc numero quam quadringenti, out of all Britaine and other places, ex vniuer≈øa Aphrica, Gallijs, Britannia, &c. And Socrates relating how this generall Councell was called by the Authoritie of Iulius, then Pope of Rome, with the con≈øent of the two Emperors, and Brothers Con≈øtans and Con≈øtantius, de ≈øententia duorum Imperatorum, it was ≈øo generall, that the Bishops of Britaine, & the other we≈øtern NatioÃÑs which were ab≈øent, did pleade no other excu≈øe, but infirmitie of body, and ouer short warning giuen them by Pope Iulius, Alij corporis infirmitateÃÑ can≈øantur: alij de teÃÑporis Socrates Hi≈øtor. Eccl. l. 2. c. 16. prastituti queruntur angu≈øtia, culpamque illius rei in Iulium Epi≈øcopuÃÑ Romanum conferunt. And yet the ≈øame Author proueth that they had a yeeres and an halfe ≈øummoÃÑs or notice, that it was to be, CuÃÑ tamen ex eo tempore quo tuÃÑ Concilium edituÃÑ
Socrat. ≈øupr. fuerat, tum Athana≈øius Concilium expectans Romae commoratus erat, annus & ≈øex Men≈øes praeteri≈ø≈øent. And it is ≈øtiled, and Ecumenicall Councell, greate Synode, plenary Titul. Conc. Sardic. to 1. Concil. Athan. Apol. 2. Aug. Epi≈øt. 162. Sulpit. l. 2. Sacrae Hi≈øt. Socrat. c. 16. Conc. Sard. can. 21. vlt. & in Tit. Councell of all the Church, a Councell gathered out of all the world, and commanding the Decrees thereof to be ob≈øerued in all the world. Oecumenicum CoÃÑcilium. Mana Synodus. Plenarium vniuer≈øae Eccle≈øiae Concilium. Concilium ex toto orbe conuocatum. Generale Concilium. Vniuer≈øa quae con≈øtituta ≈øunt, Catholica Eccle≈øia in vniuer≈øo orbe diffu≈øa cu≈øtodiat. And was approued as the CouÃÑcell it ≈øelfe witne≈ø≈øeth, by 376. Bishops, Approbatum √† Trecentis ≈øeptuaginta ≈øex Epi≈øcopis. Some haue not thought ≈øo reuerently of this greate and holy Councell of Sardice, finding
an A≈ø≈øembly bearing that name to haue bene Hereticall: But this ≈øu≈øpected or The Councell of Sardice Orthodoxall, and Catholike with our Brittish Bishops. rather damned Conciliable was an other quite different, and oppo≈øite to this true and lawfull Councell, by which both that and the Semiarrians therein a≈ø≈øembled were condemned. And this fal≈øe Councell onely kept by a few Ea≈øterne Arrian or Semiarrian Bishops about 76. in number, which ≈øeeing them≈øelues to be in danger to be condemned by the greate holy Councell, ≈øeperated Epi≈øt. Sardicen. Concilij apud Theod. l. 92. Hi≈øt. c. 8. Epi≈øt. Conciabul. Philppen. ad Donat. apud Hilar. in Frag. Baron. Tom. 4. Socrates l. 2. c. 16. Sozom. l. 3. c. 10. Seuer. Bin. Tom. 1. Conc. annot. in Conciliab. Sardicen. Niceph. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 9. c. 12. them≈øelues from thence, as their owne Epi≈øtle to Donatus of Catharge, Socrates, Sozomen, and others witne≈ø≈øe at large, and there conclude their Arrian errors condemning S. Athana≈øius, Ho≈øius, Iulius Pope of Rome, Maximus Archbishop of Treuers, Protogenes Bishop, of Sardice, and Gandentius by name, and all in generall which receaued the holy Nicen faith, and would not communicate with them in Arriani≈øme, but with S. Athana≈øius and the Catholike Bishops which they had bannished, and per≈øecuted. But our holy Brittish Bishops ioyning all with the ≈øacred Councell, degraded the vniu≈øt Accur≈øers of S. Athana≈øius, condemned tho≈øe Arrians, e≈øtablished the NiceÃÑ faith in all things, Po≈øtquam Sardicae conuenerant Epi≈øcopi Orientis, in con≈øpectum Epi≈øcoporum Occidentem incolentium venire noluerunt: dixerintque ≈øe non alia conditione in colloquium cum illis venturos, ni≈øi Athana≈øium & Paulum √® Conuentu expellerent. Epi≈øcopi Orientales confe≈øtim decedunt. cumque ventum e≈ø≈øet ad vrbem Philippi, quae e≈øt in Thracia, priuatum inter ip≈øos Concilium con≈øtituere; de caetero apert√® verbum con≈øub≈øtantiale anathemate damnare: opinioneÃÑ quod filius patri di≈øsimilis e≈ø≈øet, per literas ≈øcriptas vbique di≈ø≈øeminare caeperunt. Epi≈øcopi autem Sardicae coacti, primum i≈øtos indicta & de≈øerta cau≈øa damnare: deinde Athana≈øij accu≈øatores dignitatis gradu dimouere: tum fidei Nicaenae deci≈øioneÃÑ con≈øtabilire: opinionemque qu√≤d filius e≈ø≈øet patri di≈øsimilis, pror≈øus explodere: po≈øtremo verbum con≈øub≈øtantiale multo notius & illu≈øtrius efficere. Nam literas ≈øcribunt illi de ea re, & pa≈øsim ad omnes mittunt. And hauing thus proceeded, they returne home in the ≈øame Socrat. Hi≈øt. Ecc. l. 2. ≈øupr. c. 18. Niceph. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 9. c. 13. minde to their owne Cities, Epi≈øcopi qui Sardicae conuenerunt rebus con≈øtitutis, ad ≈øuas eorum Ciuitates re ‚Ä¢ erterunt. And after that time as Socrates, Nicephorus, and others te≈øtifie, our Bishops of Britaine, and others of the We≈øt ≈øeperated them≈øelues from the Hereticall faction in the Ea≈øt, Deinceps Occidens ab Oriente per ≈øece≈øsionem diui≈øus e≈øt. Non amplius enim Occidentales cum Orientalibus, haud eadem ≈øecum ≈øentientibus, negotij ≈øibi quicquam & coniunctionis e≈ø≈øe voluere. Yet Niceph. cap. 14. ≈øupr. many of the mo≈øt glorious men of the Ea≈øt al≈øo per≈øeuered in the ≈øame Catholike profe≈ø≈øion, as our Brittish and other We≈øterne Bishops did: as Paulus Patriarch of Con≈øtantinople, S. Athana≈øius of Alexandria, S. Anthony, and generally the Monkes of Egypt, Eu≈øebius Emi≈ø≈øenus, Titus Bo≈øtren≈øis, Serapion, S. Ba≈øile, Eudoxius, Acacius, S. Cyrill, Theodorus, Perinthius, S. Ephrem, and others without number. S. hitherto we ≈øee the ≈øtate of Chri≈øts Church in Britaine to haue bene glorious, both for number of renowned Catholike Bishops, and freedome from all contagion and infection of the wicked errors ad Here≈øies of that time.

div.head: THE XX. CHAPTER.

argument.p: HOW BRITTAINE HAVING MANY BIshops at the greate Councell at Ariminum, all were free from Here≈øie; And very few Brittans con≈øented to Arriani≈øme: But were free from Here≈øie vntill that of Pelagius.

div.p: 1. THAT this Country of Britaine after this florished with greate numbers of Worthie Bishops, no Citie then vacant heare of ≈øuch a Pa≈øtor, and Ruler, we may gather from diuers Antiquities, as from the Epi≈øtle of the greate Councell of Ariminum in Italy, not longe after this time written to Con≈øtantius the Emperor, where our Bishops were pre≈øent, te≈øtifying vnto him, that they were a≈ø≈øembled there, forth of all Cities towards the We≈øt, mo≈øt properly and ≈øignificently to be applyed to this kingdome mo≈øt We≈øt from thence, Cuncti Epi≈øcopi ex omnibus Ciuitatibus ad Occidentem ≈øitis, Arimini in vnum conuenimus. And the words, all Bishops out of Epi≈øt. Concilij Arimini ad Con≈øtantium Imperat. apud Socratem l. 2. Hi≈øt. c. 29. Sozom. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 4. c. 16. Seuer. Sulpit. ≈øacrae Hi≈øt. lib. 2. Cap. 21. ≈øupr. apud Sozomen. Lib. Notitia Ep. orb. Chri≈øtiani. ≈øiue Cod. Prouinc. Rom. all We≈øterne Cities, cuncti Epi≈øcopi ex omnibus Ciuitatibus ad Occidentem ≈øitis, cannot carry any other true con≈øtruction, but that our Epi≈øcopall Cities in Britaine were then ≈øo furnished, and many or mo≈øt of them pre≈øent at that CouÃÑ cell. This is confirmed by the number of We≈øterne Bishops aboue 400. as Sozomen and others write, a≈ø≈øembled at Ariminum, ad Concili ‚Ä¢ m Arimini congregati ≈øunt amplius quadringenti Epi≈øcopi, be≈øides 160. of the Ea≈øte at the ≈øame time gathered together at Seleucia in I≈øauria: dum haec geruntur, Epi≈øcopi Orientis numero circiter centum & ≈øexaginta, Seleuciam, quod e≈øt oppidum I≈øauri ‚Ä¢ conueniunt. When it is euident in the old Manu≈øcript Catalogue of Bishops called, Notitia Epi≈øcoporum orbis Chri≈øtiani, or Codex Prouincialis Romanus, that Britaine and all the We≈øterne Nations pre≈øent in that Councell of Ariminum had not at that time, many more then fower hundred Bishops. Therefore we mu≈øt needs grant, that the Bishops of all Cities, as well of Britaine as other CouÃÑtries of the We≈øt, which had not excu≈øable letts, & impediments, were there pre≈øent, in ≈øuch ≈øence, as the Epi≈øtle of that Councell is cited before. And Seuerus Sulpitius Seuer. Sulpit. ≈øacrae Hi≈øt. l. 2. is ≈øufficient witne≈ø≈øe for this our Britaine in particular, that it had many Bishops there; for relating the number to haue bene aboue foure hundred out of the We≈øt, quadringenti & aliquando amplius Occidentales Epi≈øcopi Ariminum conuenere: And the Emperor, the better to encline them to his Arrian faction as it ≈øeemeth, commanded proui≈øion should be made for them all at his co≈øt, quibus omnibus annonas & cellaria dare Imperator praeceperat: But the Bishops of France, Aquitaine, and Britaine refu≈øed it, and rather made choice to liue at their owne chardges, then to be maintained by the Emperour, and this refu≈øall was generall to all the Bishops of Britaine, Aquitaine, and France, except three onely of Britaine, which receaued allowance from the Emperour, and refu≈øed maintenance by the other Bishops, them≈øelues being poore, id Aquitanis, Gallis, ac Britannis indecens vi≈øum: repudiatis fi≈øcalibus, proprijs ≈øumptibus vinere maluerunt. Tres tantum ex Britannia inopia proprij, publico v≈øi ≈øunt, cum oblatam a caeteris collationem re≈øpui≈ø≈øent: ≈øanctius putantes fi≈øcum granare, quam ≈øingulos.

2. This affirmation that all the Bishops of Britaine excepting onely three which were poore, & were profered to be maintained by their fellow Bishops which were generally ritch as I haue declared before in the Foundation of King Lucius giuing them both all the Flamens and Archflamens Lands & Reuenewes. And others doth euidently te≈øtifie, that Britaine had many Bishops at Ariminum, when the number of three is but a tant√πm, allmo≈øt nothing in re≈øpect of the othrs. And the ≈øame Authour there prouing that the Brittish Bishops were both acciti and attracti, Cited and drawne or forced to come to that Councell by the Officers of Con≈øtantius now after his brothers death a profe≈ø≈øed friend of the Arrian Here≈øie, or rather a profe≈ø≈øed Arrian, then reigning in Britaine, maketh it euident, that our Brittish Bishops which could not pleade ≈øufficieÃÑt cau≈øe of excu≈øe, and ab≈øence, were generally pre≈øent there. And if tho≈øe few poore Bishops of Britaine which were not able to beare their owne charges, were drawne thither to be maintained by the Emperour, how much rather mu≈øt we iudge the ≈øame of ≈øo many potent and ritch in this Country which could pretend no ≈øuch excu≈øe. So that we ≈øee no excu≈øe but Harris Eccle≈ø. Hi≈øt. tom. 4. cap. 24. infirmitie, either by Age, or ≈øicknes to haue cau≈øed any Brittish Bishops ab≈øence thence. A late Writer thinketh, Iltutus then as he coniectureth Archbishop of London, the Archbishops of Yorke, and Carleon, the Bishops of Winche≈øter, Cilice≈øter, and Gloce≈øter with others were there. I ≈øee no particular warrant he bringeth more for the≈øe, then any other of ≈øo many Epi≈øcopall Brittish Cities of that time, which I haue before remembred, all of them being in the ≈øame condition for pre≈øence or ab≈øence, but where iu≈øt excu≈øes and letts were ≈øingular to any in particular aboue the re≈øt: for good Authours before haue te≈øtified, that all in generall were vrged to be there, without any exception, or to be expempted. And allmo≈øt all Bishops in the worlde, were then cau≈øed to be either at Ariminum in Italy, where tho≈øe of the We≈øt were, or at Seleucia appointed for the Ear≈øtern Bishops, Interim in Oriente exeÃÑplo Occidentalium, Imperator iubet cunctos fere Epi≈øcopos apud Seleuciam I≈øauriae oppidum Sulpitius Seuer. ≈øacrae Hi≈øt. l. 2. Epi≈øt. Concilij Ariminen. ad Con≈øtantiuÃÑ apud Theod. l. 2. Hi≈øt. c. 19. Seuer. Sulpit. l. 2. ≈øacrae Hi≈øt. Ambro≈ø. l. 5. Ep. 32. ad Valentinianum Imperator. Concil. Arimin. Ep. 2. ad Con≈øtaÃÑ tium Imper. apud Theod. l. 2. c. 20. & alios. Epi≈øt. Arimin. Concil. ad Con≈øtant. apud Theodot. ≈øupr. Socrat. l. 2. c. 29. Sozom. l. 4. c. 17. Niceph. l. 9. c. 40. 41. Sozom. ≈øup. c. 18. congregari. And the command was generall for all Bishops to be pre≈øent, Iu≈øsio generalis, qua omnes Epi≈øcopos ad Concilium cogere iubebantur. This was the Emperours command to his Pre≈øidents of Prouinces to compell all to be pre≈øent. And the Councell of Ariminum it ≈øelfe in their Epi≈øtle to Con≈øtantius the Arrian Emperour te≈øtifieth plainly, that all the Bishops of the We≈øt were there a≈ø≈øembled, Arimini omnes Occidentales Epi≈øcopi conuenimus. The farre greater part of the≈øe were Catholike Bishops, and of the whole number aboue 400. There were not by Seuerus Sulpitius Relation aboue 80. Arrians, Arriani non amplius quam octoginta, Reliqui nostrarum partium erant. S. Athana≈øius ≈øaith, they were fifty and more, quinquaginta & eo plures. And S. Ambro≈øe witne≈ø≈øeth, that the greate≈øt part of the Bishops there confirmed the faith of the Nicen Councell, and condemned the Arrians Errors, Cert√® maior numerus Arimini, Nicaeni Concilij fideÃÑ prohauit, Arriana decreta damnauit. This is te≈øtified by the ≈øame CouÃÑcell in two ≈øeuerall Epi≈øtles to the Emperor, that they neither could nor would ≈øwarue from the Doctrine of the Nicen Councell, Nos tibi ≈øignificauimus nullo modo √† propo≈øito nos di≈øce≈ø≈øuros, quod & ip≈øum iterum his literis docemus. And in their fir≈øt Epi≈øtle they ≈øpeake as though all the We≈øterne Bishops had herein con≈øented, Cuncti Epi≈øcopi ex omnibus ciuitatibus ad Occidentem ≈øitis, Arimini in vnum conuenimus, vt & fides Eccle≈øiae Catholicae fieret illu≈øtrior, & illius aduer≈øarij perspicu√® deprehenderentur.

3. And allthough the Emperour both by his Epi≈øtle to that Councell, and
otherwi≈øe by fraude, and terrors, endeuoured to remoue them from that holy minde, and communicate with the Arrians, they plainely wrote an≈øweare againe, con≈øtantly auerring they would change nothing they had Decreed, and gaue their Legats charge to tell him as much in words, Quibus re≈øcrip≈øit Concilium, con≈øtanter affirmando, ≈øe neutiquam √† decretis quae ≈øtatuerat velle di≈øcedere: idemque Legatis ≈øuis tum ≈øcrip≈øi≈ø≈øe, tum praecepi≈ø≈øe. Et non modo ≈øcrip≈øit, ≈øed id quoque dicere Legatos iu≈øsit. And to make it manife≈øt, that allthough by many Writers diuers of the≈øe Bishops being conuented and ouercome both with the deceipt of the Arrians, and Per≈øecution of the Emperor, did afterward ≈øub≈øcribe to a Materiall error; our Bishops of Britaine were free both froÃÑ imputation and ≈øu≈øpition thereof. Socrates, Sozomen, Nicephorus and others proue, that the Emperor neglecting to returne an≈øweare to their ≈øecond ab≈øolute Re≈øolution and Epi≈øtle, the Councell ≈øtaying ≈øome time for an≈øweare, and hauing none, they all departed to their Countryes and Sees and wholy di≈ø≈øolued that Councell, I≈øta vbi ≈øcrip≈øi≈ø≈øent, & paululum temporis e≈ø≈øent commorati, cum Imperator illis respondere dedignaretur, ≈øinguli ad ≈øuas ip≈øorum Ciuitates reuerterunt. Socrat. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 2. c. 29. Sozomen. l. 4. cap. 18. Niceph. Hi≈øt. l. 9. c. 41. Hilarius l. contra Arrianos & Argent. S. Hilary ≈øaith plainely, this Councell ended religeou≈øly by all, Ariminen≈øis Synodus ab omnibus e≈øt religios√® di≈ø≈øoluta. So our Bishops mo≈øt remote from Ariminum, none being returned home, or ≈øo farre from recalling by any new Edict or ≈øtrategeme of the Emperor, then at Con≈øtantinople very farre from Ariminum, and further from our Bishops Trauayle into Britayne, they could be none of that number, which were circumuented or terrified to ≈øub≈øcribe to the wicked Emperor, and his Arrian Fauourits de≈øignes.

4. Socrates & others make this cleare, by relating the Per≈øecution of CoÃÑ≈øtantius again≈øt the Catholicks, though before de≈øired: Yet now to haue flamed forth, and bene made publicke vpon this occa≈øion of the Councels breaking vp, and di≈ø≈øoluing without his allowance. And thereupon gaue Authoritie to Vr≈øacius to execute what crueltie he plea≈øed again≈øt the Catholike Bishops Socrat. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 2. c. 29. 41. Sozom. Hi≈øt. l. 4. c. 18. of Italy, which could not ≈øub≈øcribe to their erroneons Profe≈ø≈øion, which the Arrians had compo≈øed, Dixit ≈øe ab illis propterea penitus contemptum, qu√≤d contra eius voluntatem Concilium dimi≈øerant. Quocirca Vr≈øacio pote≈øtatem permi≈øit, liber√® contra Eccle≈øias omnia pro arbitratu admittendi: praecepitque vt fidei formula, quae in Concilio Ariminen≈øi perlegebatur, ad Eccle≈øias Italiae mitteretur, & illi qui ei ≈øub≈øcribere nollent, expellerentur ab Eccle≈øijs, alijque in eorum loca ≈øuffic ‚Ä¢ rentur. So that the Bishops of Britayne being departed from Ariminum, before any intelligence thereof could be giuen, and ≈øent from thence to the Emperour at Con≈øtantinople, and he not pre≈øently, but with adui≈øe of his Hereticall Adherents concluding the manner of his Per≈øecution, before the≈øe things could be concluded, and Vr≈øacius and his other per≈øecuting in≈øtruments could come into Italy, our Brittish Bishops mu≈øt needs both be come from thence and returned into Britayne.

5. And it appeareth before, that the cheife and principall malice of the Emperour, and Arrians at this time, was again≈øt Liberius Pope of Rome, and the other Catholike Bishops of Italy. And it is manife≈øt by Socrates and others that Vr≈øacius the cheife≈øt Executioner of this Tiranny came no further into the We≈øt, then Italy, and from thence returned into the Ea≈øt agayne, Vr≈øacius Italia r ‚Ä¢ licta iter partes Orientis capit. Neither is there the lea≈øt mention in Socrat. ≈øupr. Hi≈øtories of any part or particular of this Per≈øecution to haue bene acted in Britayne. And our owne Hi≈øtorians haue made it doubtfull before, whether Con≈øtantius had ≈øo much Power in Britayne after this time, to execute ≈øuch
crueltie in this Country, where they ≈øay he had no commande or Authoritie at all in the≈øe dayes. Be≈øides if Con≈øtantius was King and Commander heare, yet after the ende of the Councell of Ariminum he had no time left to per≈øecute the Bishops of Britaine, ≈øo farre di≈øtant from his Ea≈øterne Re≈øidency; fir≈øt becau≈øe Iulianus, afterward an Apo≈øtata from Chri≈øtian Religion, who had Ammian. lib. 15. Baron. & SpoÃÑd. an. 315. Herm. Sozom. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 5. c. 1. Socrat. Hi≈øt. l. 3. c. 1. Niceph. l. 10. c. 1. Theodor. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 3. c. 2. marryed Con≈øtantius his Si≈øter Helena, was now both Cae≈øar, & by many, Emperor al≈øo both in France and Britayne likewi≈øe (if Britayne was then ≈øubiect to the Empire) & in ≈øuch renowne there for his victories again≈øt the Allmans inuading the Empire, that he was ≈øoone after choa≈øen Emperor, and was ≈øo fauourable to the Catholiks, that ≈øo ≈øoone as he came to be Emperor he recalled and re≈øtored all the Catholike Bishops which Con≈øtantius the Arrian had bannished, as Theodoret and others te≈øtifie, Iulianus Epi≈øcopos qui fuerunt in exilium √† Con≈øtantio in vltima terrarum loca mi≈øsi, ad ≈øuam quemque Eccle≈øiam cape≈ø≈øendam renocauit: And declared Emperor in France and the We≈øt in Con≈øtaÃÑtius his time, when he and his Complices raged mo≈øt again≈øt the Catholike Bishops, ≈øoone after the di≈ø≈øoluing of the Councell of Ariminum, as Sozomen Sozom. Socrat. & Niceph. ≈øupr. Socrates, Nicephorus and others proue, was ≈øo farre from concurring with him or his Agents either in this or any other de≈øigne by his Authoritie or Commi≈ø≈øion, that in all places in the We≈øt, and as he went towards Con≈øtantius in the Ea≈øt he di≈øcharged his Officers, & Commi≈ø≈øioners in all Prouinces, di≈øgracing him in euery Citie, ≈øo that all people reuolted from Con≈øtantius, and ≈øubmitted them≈øelues vnto Iulianus, His rebus pro≈øper√® & faeliciter gestis, Imperator √† militibus declaratur. Iulianus ad hunc modum regnare caepit. Neque Legatos ad Con≈øtantium mittere, neque vt patronum & beneficum colere, ≈øed omnia pro ≈øuo ip≈øius arbitrio agere in animum induxit. Magi≈øtratus in ≈øingulis Prouincijs commutare, Con≈øtantium in quaque Ciuitate infamia notare conatur. Quocircailli omnes ≈øe dedere, √† Con≈øtantio deficere caeperunt.

6. S. Hilarius the be≈øt Calculator of tho≈øe times, & Tragedies, wherein he ≈øuffered ≈øo much, by the Arrians for the Catholike doctrine, can giue the mo≈øt certaine euidence in this bu≈øines; he in his Booke of Synods written to the Bishops of Britaine, Germany, and France after the ≈øummons of the Councell of Hila. l. de Synod. contra Arrianos. Ariminum: cum comperi≈ø≈øem Synodos in Ancira atque in Arimino congregandas, ≈øaith, that he had bene exiled three whole yeares, toto iam triennio. In his Booke offered to Con≈øtantius after the Councell of Ariminum, when he was by him Hilar. l. ad Con≈øtantium Augu≈øtum. Hilar. l. contra Con≈øtantium defunctum. ≈øent home free into France, he iu≈øtifieth he remayned then in communion with all the Churches, and Bishops of France with which our Britans then al≈øo communicated by all Antiquites, Epi≈øcopus ego ≈øum in omnium Gallicarum Eccle≈øiarum atque Epi≈øcoporum communione, licet in exilio permanens, & Eccle≈øiae adhuc per presbyteros meos communionem distribuens. And in his Booke again≈øt CoÃÑ≈øtantius, being then dead he writeth, that after the Bannishment of the Catholike Bishops Paulinus, Eu≈øebius Vercellen≈øis, Luciferus, and Dioni≈øius, fiue yeares before he with the Bishops of France had ≈øeperated him≈øelfe from the Communion of the Arrians, Saturninus, Vr≈øatius and Valens, which two la≈øt were Con≈øtantius choa≈øen cheife In≈øtrumeÃÑts publikly to per≈øecute the Catholiks after the Ariminum Councell ended, Post Sanctorum virorum exilia Paulini, Eu≈øebij, Lucifiri, Dio≈øij, quinto ab hinc anno a Saturnini, & vr≈øatij & valentis Communione me cum Gallicanis Epi≈øcopis ≈øeperaui. And particularly for our Bishops of Britaine, in his Epi≈øtle, or Booke to them, with others directed to the Hilar. l. de Synodis prope I ‚Ä¢ itium. Lords his mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed Brethren, and fellowe Bishops of the Prouinces of Britaine, Dominis & beati≈øsimis fratribus, & Coepi≈øcopis, Prouinciarum Britanniarum
Epi≈øcopis, he te≈øtifieth from their owne letters of their ≈øincere faith, ≈øent vnto him in Exile, beatae fidei vestrae literis ≈øumptis, that they continued vn≈øpotted, and free from all contagion of Here≈øie, were partakers of his Exile, and would not communicate with wicked Saturninus, which had procured his BaÃÑnishment, and denied Saturninus communion all that while, three whole yeares, Gratulatus ≈øum in Domino incontaminatos vos & illae≈øos ab omni contagio detestandae Haere≈øeos per≈øtiti≈ø≈øe, vo≈øque comparticipes exilij mei, in quod me Saturninus ip≈øam con≈øcentiam ≈øuam veritus, circumuento Imperatore detru≈øerat, negata ip≈øi v≈øque hoc tempus toto iam triennio Communione, fide mihi ac ≈øpiritu coherere. And that they had actually reiected and condeÃÑned the Hereticall Decrees of Syrmium, & mi≈ø≈øam proxime vobis ex Syrmien≈øi Oppido infidelis fidei impietatem, non modo non ≈øu≈øcepi≈ø≈øe, ≈øed nuntiatam etiam ≈øignificatamque damna≈ø≈øe.

7. And both after the Ariminum Councell and death of Con≈øtantius and Iulian his short Rule, in the shorter Empire of Iouian, commonly named Iouinian, when that Per≈øecution ended, we haue an other the be≈øt witne≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe dayes; S. Athana≈øius confidently vpon his owne certaine experience, and knowledge auouching to that Emperour, that among many other Countries which he there recounteth, all the Church of Britaine did inuiolably hold the faith of the Nicen Councell, Cogno≈øce Religio≈øi≈øsime Augu≈øte, hanc e≈ø≈øe fidem quae Athana≈ø. epi≈øt. ad Iouinian. Aug. √† condito aeuo praedicanda fuit, & quam Niceae Patres congregati agnouerunt, eiu≈øque Suffragatrices e≈ø≈øe omnes omnibus in locis Eccle≈øias ≈øiue in Hi≈øpania, ≈øiue Britanuia. Omnium enim i≈øtoruÃÑ animos experimentis cognouimus, & ≈øcripta habemus. Thus it is made euident, that our Churches and Bishops of Britaine both before, at, and after the Councell of Ariminum, were free from this infection of the Arrian Here≈øie, euen at that time, when S. Hierome ≈øaith of the whole world be≈øides, that the flame of this Here≈øie had de≈øtroyed it, totum orbem eius flamma populata e≈øt. And ingemuit totus orbis, & Artianum ≈øe e≈ø≈øe miratus e≈øt. The whole world groaned, and maruailed to ≈øee it≈øelfe an Arrian. Which was ≈øoone after the Councell of Ariminum, when ValeÃÑs & Vr≈øacius by the Arrian Emperours Authoritie, and Power v≈øed ≈øuch cunning ≈øtrategems, and violence towards the Catholike Bishops, e≈øpecially in Italy and the Ea≈øterne Countryes, where S. Hier. l. 3. in Epi≈øt. ad Galat. Hier. aduer≈ø. Luciferian. Hierome liued and wrote.

8. Yet neither dare I, or doe I affirme, that Britaine was ab≈øolutely and perfectly free in all the members thereof, Eccle≈øia≈øticall & temporall, or all ≈øuch as were directed hither by the Arrian Emperour, or had ciuill command vnder him heare, were vn≈øpotted with this Here≈øie, and that it did not at all inuade this Kingdome in ≈øome par≈øons and places: it is a ≈øufficient glory, and ≈øingular prerogatiue vnto vs, in ≈øo generall an Inundation, to haue proued our Bishops and their Churches Innocent: for be≈øides diuers te≈øtimonies before, of a common infection in all the world with this Pe≈øtilence, we haue our owne be≈øt and mo≈øt auncient Writers S. Gildas, and S. Bede, who as they doe confe≈ø≈øe, that from the time of Diocle≈øian his Per≈øecution ended, the Church of Britaine was in peace, and quiet, vntill the Arrian Here≈øie: So they bewaile, and complaine that this infecting all the world, ≈øailed ouer the Ocean in this Kingdome, and other Here≈øies followed it afterward, Man≈øit haec in Eccle≈øijs Chri≈øti Bed. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. Gent. Angl. l. 1. c. 8. quae erant in Britannia, pax, v≈øque ad tempora Arrianae ve≈øaniae, quae corrupto orbe toto, hanc ‚Ä¢ ti ‚Ä¢ m In≈øulam, extra orbem tam longe remotam, veneno ≈øui infecit erroris & hac qu ‚Ä¢ ≈øi via pi≈øt ‚Ä¢ len ‚Ä¢ iaetrans Oceanum patefacta non mora, omnis ≈øelues Haere≈øios cuiu≈øque, infulae „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øemper aliquid audire graudenti, & nihil certi firmiter obtinenti in≈øudit. S. Gildas before him writeth to like purpo≈øe, calling that Here≈øie Gild. l. de excid. Brit. c. 9.
in re≈øpect of this Nation, tran≈ømarinum venenum, a forreine and beyonde ≈øea poi≈øon tran≈øported hither, not bred heare, nor naming any one particular Brittish Bishop, Ruler of Church, or Church infected with it. And to grant this Kingdome then to haue bene vnder the Empire, and Emperour Con≈øtantius, then an Arrian, which many of our owne Hi≈øtorians haue before denied, all this will probably argue no more then that I haue yeelded vnto, that ≈øome were infected heare, but not of Bishops and learned Clergie. In which ≈øen≈øe Sozomen, one of the be≈øt Examiners of tho≈øe proceedings ≈øaith, that he thinketh no Nation vnder the Roman Empire was quite free, and cleare of that calamititie, Nulla gens Romano ≈øubiecta Imperio ab hac calamitate, credo, vacua liberaque fuit. And we haue a better witnes for Britaine to keepe it vndefiled Sozom. l. 4. Hi≈øt. c. 26. from this, and all other Here≈øies vntill that of Pelagius, long after this time, for ≈øo te≈øtifieth the old Manu≈øcript Antiquitie of the Church of LaÃÑdaffe, written as it ≈øeemeth by the things therein handled before S. Gildas his time, all being more auncient which plainely ≈øaith, that the Britans neuer changed any point of faith, which they receaued in King Lucius time, nor were infected Antiquit. M. S. Eccl. Landauen. with any ≈øpot of wicked Doctrine vntill Pelagius his Here≈øie aro≈øe, Quam Chri≈øtianae Religionis fidem, ≈øine aliqua praui dogmatis macula ≈øinceram con≈øeruauerunt, v≈øque dum Pelagiana Haere≈øis orta e≈øt. Therefore if the Arrian Here≈øie had any entrance hither, it mu≈øt needs be onely in ≈øome fewe particular men, not in Publike par≈øons and Churches.

div.head: THE XXI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: CHIEFELY ENTREATING OF LIBERIVS Pope and Con≈øtantius Emperour, manifestly clearing S. Liberius, making him an holy Catholike Pope, and Saint: and the Emperour Con≈øtantius a true penitent and to dye a Catholike.

div.p:
1. THE Pope of Rome which ≈øucceeded to S. Iulius, in the Hereticall time and Empire of this Con≈øtantius, was Liberius, and by them which number Saint Faelix ≈øub≈øtituted by the Arrians for Pope Liberius exiled in the Catalogue of Popes, the ≈øame S. Faelix is likewi≈øe reckoned among the Bishops of that See Baron. & Spond. Annal. an. 357. Seuer. Bin. Tom. 1. Conc. Annot. in vit. Liberij. Apo≈øtolike. Diuers euen Catholike Writers doe ≈øeeme to hold, that Liberius being bannished by the Arrian Emperour for refu≈øing to communicate with the Arrian Hereticks, did by troble and vexation yeeld to communicate with them externally, but neuer con≈øented vnto, but euer in iudgment condemned their Here≈øie, and ≈øo make him guiltie of a faulte in fact, but not in faith, in which he euer remained con≈øtant and vnmoueable. And S. Athana≈øius who≈øe te≈øtimony is greate, and on whome they mo≈øt rely in this opinion, allthough he maketh Pope Liberius a mo≈øt excellent paterne, and example of con≈øtanty again≈øt tho≈øe Heretiks, yet in one place he writeth, that either he by violence and threates of death, con≈øented to ≈øome materiall error, by ≈øub≈øcribing, or the Arrians flandered him with ≈øuch a fact, te≈øtifiing Liberius was euer mo≈øt free, euen at this ≈øuppo≈øed time from Here≈øie, and if any fault of fact was committed,
it was to be imputed to the wills of the Arrians, and not of Liberius, and Pope Liberius was no Arrian or con≈øenter to them but an holy Pope. yet Liberius then did not ≈øupply the Papall See, but Felix was by theÃÑ reputed Pope, & by them ≈øub≈øtituted into the Papall See in place of Liberius, being by them exiled, Liberius po≈øt exactum in exilio biennium inflexus e≈øt, mini≈øque mortis Athana≈ø. Epi≈øt. ad Solitariam vitam agentes. Tom. 2. oper. ad ≈øub≈øcriptionem inductus e≈øt. Verum illud ip≈øum quoque & eorum violentiam, & Liberij in Haere≈øim odium & ≈øuum pro Athana≈øio ≈øuffragium, quum liberos affectus habebat, ≈øatis coarguit. Quae enim per tormenta contra priorem eius ≈øententiam extorta ≈øunt, eaeiam metuentium, ≈øed ita cogentium voluntates habendae ≈øunt. Ruffinus Ruffin. l. 1. Hi≈øt. c. 27. leaueth it doubtfull, whether Liberius was re≈øtored becau≈øe he ≈øub≈øcribed, or at the in≈øtance of the Romans refu≈øing to obay any other Bishop, Liberius vrbis Romae Epi≈øcopus Con≈øtantio viuente regre≈ø≈øus est. Sed hoc vtrum quod acquieuerit voluntati ≈øuae, ad ≈øub≈øcribendum, an ad populi Romani gratiam, √† quo profici≈øcens fuerat exoratus, indul≈øerit, pro certo compertum non habeo. By this it is euident, that it could not be proued in tho≈øe dayes, that Liberius made any ≈øub≈øcription or yeelding at all, ≈øuch as plea≈øed or could plea≈øe the Arrian Emperour and his Heretiks. But Sozomen, Socrates, Theodoret, and others comming to more certaine, and prefect Intelligence of the≈øe things, then Ruffinus, confe≈ø≈øeth he had attained vnto, doe more clearely te≈øtifie, that this report of Pope Liberius ≈øub≈øcription, was but the inuention and fiction of the Arrians, who knowing Sozom. Hi≈øtor. Eccl. l. c. 4. 14. the greate Power of him, and his See, and that Con≈øtantius was ≈øo vrged by the Romans, and We≈øterne Bishops to re≈øtore him, that he could not deny it, fathered this lye again≈øt Liberius for the Emperours and their excu≈øe, Imperator compellere tentauit Liberium fateri, filium patri non e≈ø≈øe con≈øub≈øtantialem. In which he could not preuaile, and then they rai≈øed this Rumour and ≈ølaunder: rumorem di≈øsiparunt Liberium verbum con≈øub≈øtantiale reieci≈ø≈øe, a≈ø≈øerui≈ø≈øeque filium patri di≈øsimilem e≈ø≈øe. When this holy Pope at that very time, as the ≈øame Authour proueth, to di≈øproue this ≈ølaunder, int ‚Ä¢ rdicted all which allowed of that error, Confe≈øsionis fidei formulam √† Liberio adduxerunt, quae illis qui filium patri non ≈øub≈øtantia, & caeteris rebus omnibus ≈øimilem a≈ø≈øeuerarent, interdixit Eccle≈øia. Yet the Imperour rather moued by feare, then loue, gaue him leaue to returne to Rome, Emperator dat Liberio pote≈øtatem Romam reuertendi. For the Romans ≈øo loued and honored Liberius for his excellent gifts, and principally for ≈øo con≈øtantly defending the true faith, and courageou≈øly re≈øi≈øting the Arrian Emperour, that they tooke Armes for his exilement, Populus Liberium, tum quod in alijs rebus vir excellens & ≈øpectatus erat, tum quod Imperatori animo adeo excel≈øo & con≈øtanti in fide defendenda contradixerat, tam eximie charum habuit, vt ≈øeditionem plane maximam eius exilij cau≈øa conflaret, re≈øque ad caedem prorumperet.

2. Socrates ≈øaith plainely, that Liberius was re≈øtored, becau≈øe the Romans cau≈øed ≈øedition for his Bannishment, and threwe Felix, whom the Arrians had Socrates l. 2. Hi≈øt. c. 29. putt in his place, out of the Church, and the Emperour therevpon again≈øt his will con≈øented to his returne, Liberius ab exilio reuocatus, ≈øedem Epi≈øcopatus propterea recuperauit, quod populus Romanus ≈øeditione conflata, Felicem Eccle≈øia illa eiecerat, Imperatorque ip≈øe etiam inuito animo illis con≈øen≈øerat. Where we ≈øee, it was rather the Act of the Romans Catholiks, then the Arrian Emperour that Liberius was re≈øtored with the Romans, and again≈øt the Emperours will. Theodoret sheweth, that the Matrons of Rome were al≈øo Agents herein, prote≈øting to their husbands, that if they would not procure the returne of Liberius, they would for≈øake them, and goe vnto him, Cum Romae e≈ø≈øet Con≈øtantius, Magi≈øtratuum & Primariorum ciuium coniuges ob≈øecrant maritos, vt ≈øupplicent Con≈øtantio, pro Pa≈øtore qui re≈øtituatur Eccle≈øiae ≈øuae, ≈øeque ni≈øi impetra≈ø≈øent, de≈øertis
ip≈øis, ad magnum illum Pa≈øtorem deuenturas minantur. And they them≈øelues Theod. l. 2. Hi≈øt. c. 17. went to the Emperour to vrge him hearein, and not to ≈øuffer ≈øuch a Citie to want their Pa≈øtor, and though the Emperour an≈øweared, they had Felix a worthie man, which kept the Nicen faith, and onely communicated with Arrians, this could not content them, iu≈øtifiing that no Citizen of Rome would come into the Church while he was there. And hearevpon the Emperour con≈øented to his returne to Rome, Accedunt laudabiles Matronae ad Imperatorem pretioci≈øsimis ve≈øtibus ornatae, quo magis Imperator nobiles ratus precibus voluntatique ip≈øarum gereret morem. Erat autem deprecatio talis. Mi≈øereri vellet tantae ciuitatis ≈øpoliatae Pa≈øtore ≈øuo, & expo≈øitae Luporum in≈øidijs: ≈øed Imperator Respondit, non illam Pa≈øtore alio indigere quae prudentem bonumque haberet: fuerat autem creatus po≈øt Liberium vnus ex Diaconis illius, vir fidelis, Faelix nomine, qui incurruptam quidem ≈øeruabat Niceae expo≈øitam fidem, ≈øed violatoribus illius coniungi non verebatur: nemo tamen omnium ciuium Romanorum in aedem orationis e≈øt ingre≈ø≈øus, cum ip≈øe intus foret. Quod ip≈øum & matronae tum Regi ≈øignificarunt. Itaque flecti ≈øe pa≈ø≈øus, iu≈øsit optimum quidem Liberium de Exilio reuocari.

3. Therefore ≈øeeing both the We≈øterne Catholike Bishops by their letters & Legates made Interce≈ø≈øioÃÑ for Liberius his re≈øtoring, the RomaÃÑs made Tumults for him, and their wiues did thus vrge his returne, and none of them would communicate with Felix, coÃÑmunicating with the Arrians, and Liberius being re≈øtored did ≈øo much dete≈øt ≈øub≈øcription, or communication with Arrians, that after the A≈ø≈øemble of Ariminum, he did rather and mo≈øt willingly by all Authours cho≈øe to be exiled againe the ≈øecond time, then to ≈øub≈øcribe vnto, or communicate with them. I dare not thinke that ≈øo worthie a man by all witne≈ø≈øes, was euer guiltie of ≈øo foule a fact And Con≈øtantius which had by all meanes tempted his con≈øtancy both by feares and flatteries, would not haue bene vnwilling, but mo≈øt willing with his returne vpon that condition, he whome he and his Arrians put in Liberius place performing no more, but otherwi≈øe ≈øo firmely continuing in the Catholike faith & hating Arriani≈øme, Dama≈øus Sen. Ana≈øta≈ø. in Vit. Faelic. 2. Tom. 1. Conc. Martyrol. Rom. Iulij 29. Bar. Annal. ann. 357. Seuer. Bin. Tom. 1. Conc. in eod. Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. in Con≈øtant. Martin. Polon. Sup. put. in Faelice. Regino Chron. Sozom. l. 6. Hi≈øt. c. 22. that by many Writers and of greate worth, he excommunicated that Emperor for that Here≈øie, and for that ≈øame cau≈øe ≈øuffered Martyrdome vnder him, Hic fuit Catholicus, hic declarauit Con≈øtantium filium Con≈øtantini e≈ø≈øe Hereticum. Et propter hoc ab eodem Con≈øtaÃÑtio capitis decollatione, martyrio coronatus. His Marble Tombe founde in the Church of S. Co≈ømas and Damian had this In≈øcription in old Characters, hic iacet corpus ≈øancti Faelicis Papae & Martyris, qui Con≈øtantium Haereticum damnauit.

4. And concerning Liberius his faith to the end, Sozomen the mo≈øt diligent Relator of his Actions, ≈øetteth downe for his la≈øt memorable Act, that when there was Que≈øtion in Syria, and ≈øome other places, about the con≈øub≈øtantialitie of the holy Gho≈øt with the Father & the ≈øonne, Pope Liberius hauing notice thereof, wrote his Decretall Epi≈øtle to the Ea≈øterne Bishops, that they should with the Bishops & Prei≈øts of the We≈øt confe≈ø≈øe the holy Trinitie. And they all yelded to the iudgment of the Pope Liberius, Quae controuer≈øia cum in dies magis magi≈øque cre≈øceret, Epi≈øcopus Romanus de e ‚Ä¢ certior factus, ≈øcrip≈øit ad Eccle≈øias Orientis literas, vt vna cum Sacerdotibus & Epi≈øcopis Occidentis Trinitatem & con≈øubstantialem e≈ø≈øe, & gloria aequalem exi≈øtimarent. Quo facto, ≈øinguli rebus ab Eccle≈øia Romana ≈øemel indicatis acquieuerunt, haecque controuer≈øia finem habere vi≈øa e≈øt.

5. The Macedonian Heretiks, as the ≈øame Sozomen, Socrates and others te≈øtifie, ≈øubmitted them≈øelues to his Papall ≈øentence. And all the Bishops of the
We≈øt except Auxentius Bishop of Millan, embraced the doctrine and Decrees Sozomen. l. 6. c. 11. Socrat. l. 4. c. 11 Sozomen. ≈øupr. c. 23. of the Nicen Councell, together with Pope Liberius, De doctrina autem, neque Romani, neque vlli alij in Occidente inter ≈øe di≈ø≈øentiebant, ≈øed omnes Concilij Nicaeni Decreta approbabaÃÑt, atque Trinitatem tum honore aequalem, tum potentia cen≈øebant: Auxentio ≈øolo excepto, qui cum e≈ø≈øet eo tempore Eccle≈øiae Mediolanen≈øis Anti≈øtes, vna cum alijs quibu≈ødam res nouas moliri, & contra communem Epi≈øcoporum Occidentis con≈øen≈øum doctrinam Arrianam defendere, & idem cum his qui non filium ≈øolum, ≈øed ≈øpiritum ≈øanctum quoque patri di≈øsimilem (quae controuer≈øia Po≈øteris excitata erat) existimabant, ≈øentire in animum induxit. Therefore haue the Fathers before iu≈øtly called him an excellent renowned man, and inferior to none, vir excellens, ≈øpectatus, optimus. Saint Ambro≈øe calleth him a man of holy memory, Sanctae Ambro≈ø. lib. 3. de Virg. Epiphan. Haere ‚Ä¢ . 75. Ba≈øil. Epi≈øt. 74. Bed. in Martyrol. 8. Cal. Octob. Martyr. Vuandelbert. 23. Septemb. Niceph. lib. 10. Hi≈øt. cap. 1. memoriae. S. Epiphanius, a ble≈ø≈øed man, beatum. And S. Ba≈øile, a mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed man, beati≈øsimum. In auncient Martyrologes he is a Saint. So S. Bede and this Country among others hath receaued, and honored him.

6. Some al≈øo there be, which labour to free Con≈øtantius the Emperour him≈øelfe, from being a formall, and ob≈øtinate Heretike, among whome Nicephoras ≈øaith, he was ≈øeduced by giuing too much credit to the Arrian Bishops conuer≈øing with him, and yet allthough he cau≈øed the word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ con≈øub≈øtantiall, for peace ≈øake to be put out of the Creed, yet he ≈øtill profe≈ø≈øed the true Con≈øtantius Emperor by ≈øome excu≈øed to be no Heretike but a profe≈ø≈øed Catholike a ‚Ä¢ his death. ≈øence and meaning of that word, ≈øaying and holding, that Chri≈øt was the true ≈øonne of God begotten from Eternitie, and was a profe≈ø≈øed and open Enemy to all which dur≈øt call God the Sonne a Creature, Quamuis facilitate ingenij, & illecebris Religionis ab Epi≈øcopis, in quorum pote≈øtate fuit, ≈øeductus ≈øit, &
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
con≈øub≈øtantialis verbum ex fidei Symbolo, ≈øub vnionis coniunctionisque omnium praetextu ≈øu≈øtulerit, ≈øinceram tamen dictionis eius ≈øententiam e≈øt profe≈ø≈øus. Quum etenim Deum verbum germanum filium, & ante ≈øecula ex patre genitum dixit, tum certus, manifestu≈øque eorum qui creaturam illum vocare au≈øi fui≈ø≈øent, ho≈øtis extitit. The like Niceph. l. 9. c. 50. he hath in other places, and citeth S. Gregory Nazianzen to like purpo≈øe, who doth as much, or more excu≈øe him; he ≈øaith he died an holy death, was buried with all honour, and reuerence, with holy Chri≈øtian ≈øinging, Himes and lights: ≈øanctis carminibus nocturnis, himnis, & lucernarum ignibus Chri≈øtiani obitum pium cohone≈øtandum cen≈øent. He calleth him the mo≈øt holy of all Emperours and mo≈øt louing of Chri≈øt, Imperatorum ≈øanti≈øsime, & Chri≈øti amanti≈øsime. He ≈øaith he was after his death glorified in heauen, changing his earthly for an heauenly Empire, Qui ad Deum tran≈ølatus ≈øis gloriae caele≈øtis haeres, & tanto longius a nobis ≈øece≈ø≈øeris, quanto Imperium illud quod cum hoc commuta≈øti, e≈øt augu≈øtius. Thus S. Gregory Nazianzen is cited by Nicephorus: But in his owne workes Greg. Nazien. l. de Laud. S. Athana≈øij. orat. 1. & 2. in Iulian. he is more plaine for the excu≈øe, & coÃÑmendatioÃÑs of CoÃÑ≈øtantius; defeÃÑding him or excu≈øing him in all matters obiected again≈øt him. Which were three things, that he cau≈øed the death of his ≈øonne in Law: the ≈øecoÃÑd for making IuliaÃÑ which proued an Apo≈øtate, Emperor: the third for his profe≈ø≈øing or fauoring the ArriaÃÑ Here≈øie. All which he confe≈ø≈øed at his death, & in his la≈øt words repeÃÑted, Tria haec Greg. Nazian. l. in Laud. Athan. mala Imperio
que ≈øuo & principatu indigna ipsuÃÑ agnoui≈ø≈øe narrant, vnuÃÑ quod generi ≈øuo necem attuli≈ø≈øet: alteruÃÑ quod IulianuÃÑ Apo≈øtataÃÑ Imperatorem nomina≈ø≈øet: tertium quod nouis fidei dogmatibus ≈øtudui≈ø≈øet: ≈øimulque cuÃÑ his vocibus √® vita ai≈øce≈øsi≈ø≈øe. The word narraÃÑt, meÃÑ te≈øtifie, proueth this was the te≈øtimony of others be≈øides S. Gregory, and yet he lyuing in that time, and tho≈øe parts a man of ≈øo greate reno ‚Ä¢ ne, his owne Authoritie if it had bene ≈øingular, is not to be lightly e≈øteemed. Yet diuers others be≈øides tho≈øe witne≈ø≈øes confe≈ø≈øe as much. Zonoras ≈øaith of this Con≈øtantius citing others as much as S. Gregory did, that this Emperour at
his death profe≈ø≈øed him≈øelfe to be penitent for tho≈øe Errors, Con≈øtantius obijt, Io. Zonar. Tom. 3. Annal. in Con≈øtantio. trium, vt aiunt, ≈øe paenitere profe≈ø≈øus, caedis propinquorum, collati in Iulianum Tituli, & mutatae Religionis. And for this cheife point for changing his Fathers Religion, and following the Arrians, Nicephorus ≈øaith, he did not a litle repent Niceph. Hi≈øt. lib. 10. c. 1. him, Quem non parum quod aliquid de paternae fidei profe≈øsione mutauerit, paenituit. And Theodoret one of his greate≈øt Accu≈øers herein, confe≈ø≈øeth as much, and more, affirming he did bitterly complaine, that he had changed his faith, acerbe fuit conque≈øtus, quod fidem immuta≈ø≈øet. And againe, he died with groaning and Theodor. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 2. c. 32. vlt. Theod. l. 3. c. 1. bewayling, that he had chaÃÑged his Fathers faith, CoÃÑ≈øtantius cuÃÑ gemitu, & queremonia, ob mutatam fidem paternam, exce≈øsit√® vita. S. Gregory Nazianzen ≈øaith, that at his death he purged and excu≈øed him≈øelfe both before God, and man in many words, & Deo, & hominibus multis verbis ≈øe excu≈øa≈ø≈øet, atque purga≈ø≈øet, Greg. Nazian. orat. in Iulian. conatuque ≈øuo animique impetu te≈øtacum Chri≈øtianis reliqui≈ø≈øet, quanto pietatis tuendae ≈øtudio impelleretur. Wherevpon this holy learned Father ≈øaith, he had plea≈øure to thinke of his end, Ex po≈øtremis voluptas na≈øcitur. He ≈øaith, this was the Orat. 2. in Iulian. more coÃÑmon opinion quod communius e≈øt, that he died an holy death, pio fine vitam clau≈øerat, he was buried with ≈øuch ≈øolemnities, as Catholiks v≈øe in the Funeralls of them which make an holy end, Publicis laudibus fau≈øti≈øque ominationibus pompi≈øque deducitur, ac Religio≈øis etiam his no≈øtratibus cultibus, nocturnis cantionibus, faciumque ge≈øtationibus, quibus nos Chri≈øtiani pium √® vita di≈øce≈ø≈øum honore pro≈øequi con≈øueuimus.

7. And to confirme the opinion of men with the Authoritie and te≈øtimony of heauen, and Angels, he ≈øaith, it was commonly related, multorum auribus diuulgatum e≈øt, that as his body was with ≈øuch ≈øolemnitie carried to Con≈øtantinople to be buried there, an Angelicall Harmony was heard by many, as a reward of his pietie, Vox quaedam ≈øummis √® locis √† nonnullis exaudiebatur, velue p≈øallentium & pro≈øequentium (Angelicorum, opinor, caetuum) quod pietatis illi praemium erat, funebri≈øque remuneratio. The ≈øame is related by Nicephorus and others. Niceph. l. 9. Hi≈øt. c. 50. Greg. Nazian. orat. 1. in Iulian. Wherevpon the ≈øame holy Father ≈øtileth him the Emperour mo≈øt excellent, mo≈øt diuine, and mo≈øt louing of Chri≈øt, √¥ Imperatorum prae≈øtanti≈øsime, ac diuini≈øsime, Chri≈øtique amanti≈øsime. And confidently affirmeth; he was after his death, ioyned to God, had receaued the Inheritance of the heauenly glory, and departed hence to change his Empire for a better, Qui Deo-coniunctus ≈øis, cele≈øti≈øque gloriae haereditatem acceperis, atque hactenus √† nobis migraris, vt Imperium Greg. Nazian. orat. in laudem Athana≈øij. cum meliore commutares. Which no good and learned man, ≈øuch as this S. Gregory was, could or would ≈øay, of an irrepentant Heretike. Therefore when he ≈øaith of this Emperour in an other place, that ≈øome reported, that he had vnprofitable repentance at his death, inutili vt ferunt, paenitentia in extremo vitae spiritu affectus: he mu≈øt needs ≈øpeake as his owne words, vt ferunt, proue in the opinion of others. And yet there ≈øpeaking of the three things before cited which he repented him of, two of them were theÃÑ remedile≈ø≈øe to wit, the di≈øinheriting of the next Heires to the Empire now being dead, & giuing Title to Iulian, who had then v≈øurped the Empire and by force kept it. But for his owne ≈øaluatioÃÑ, there was no time too late in his life, to haue true effectuall and iu≈øtifiing repentance. And S. Athana≈øius then in exile, farre from the place of Con≈øtantius his death, and writing pre≈øently after that he was baptized by Athana≈ø. Epi≈øt. de Synodis A ‚Ä¢ ia. & Seleuc. Enzoius an Arrian, and not hearing of his repentance after te≈øtified both by men and Angels, as his ≈øilence thereof proueth, might haue probable cau≈øe to thinke and write, that he died as he liued an Arrian, Con≈øtantius Haereticus ≈øuit, ad finem v≈øque permanens in ea impietate. This al≈øo may and very probably
be gathered by his extraordinary fauour and loue towards that greate light of Chri≈øts Church in that time S. Hilary, mo≈øt famou≈øly knowne to be the greate≈øt Propugner and Defendor of the Nicen faith, which was theÃÑ in the world, and had written much again≈øt the Arrians, and among the re≈øt twelue Bookes of the ble≈ø≈øed Trinitie, and openly ≈øtill profe≈ø≈øed him≈øelfe a Catholike, and the Arrians damnable Heretiks, and both dedicated and deliuered this his Profe≈ø≈øion and Apologie in a Booke euen to the hands of Con≈øtantius, and was by him with greate libertie, freedome, and honour re≈øtored, and ≈øent to his Bishoprike in France. And in that his Apologie proueth, that Con≈øtantius of him≈øelfe, but that he was much abu≈øed and violented by the Arrians, had long de≈øired to knowe the true Catholike faith in that Controuer≈øie; Recogno≈øce fidem quam olim, optime ac religio≈øi≈øsime Imperator ab Epi≈øcopis optas audire, & non audis. Hilar. l. ad Con≈øtantium Augu≈øtum. Dum enim a quibus ea requiritur, ≈øua ≈øcribunt, & non quae Dei ≈øunt praedicant: orbem aeternum erroris, & redeuntis in ≈øe ≈øemper certaminis circumtulerunt.

8. And allthough being ≈øodainely taken with ≈øicknes and death, no Catholike Bishop in any probable iudgment being pre≈øent, he was in extremitie baptized by Enzoius an Arrian, as S. Athana≈øius writeth, yet this proueth not, but as S. Gregory ≈øaith, he might be ≈øaued, allthough he had repented before that Bapti≈øme. For the ≈øame S. Athana≈øius granteth in the ≈øame Epi≈øtle, that tho≈øe Arrians, or Seminarrians which Con≈øtantius ioyned with, did then keepe and v≈øe the Catholike forme of Bapti≈øme, in the name of the Father and the ≈øonne and the holy Gho≈øt, Qui in Eccle≈øia credunt & baptizantur in nomine patris & filij & Spiritus ≈øancti ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ nd not that condemned forme, in nomine patris maioris, & filij minoris &c. A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ be≈øides S. Gregory Nazianzen cited before, Theodoret and others te≈øtifice, that allthough Con≈øtantius being deceaued by them which could leade him as they li≈øted, did not admit the worde of Coe≈ø≈øentialitie yet he manife≈øtly confe≈ø≈øed the ≈øence, Chri≈øt to be the naturall ≈øonne of God, begotten of the Father from eternitie, and to be God, vtterly reiecting and condemning them, which dur≈øt call him a Creature; which were they which v≈øed that inualide forme of Bapti≈øme, Et≈øi Constantius non admittebat vocem Theodor. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 3. c. 3. Coe≈ø≈øentialitatis, circumuentus ab ijs qui quouis ducere eum poterant, ≈øignificationem tamen manife≈øte coÃÑfitebatur, quod diceret filium germanum ante ≈øecula ex patre genitum, Deum verbum: pror≈øus abdicatis ijs, qui auderent condituram dicere filium. Thus hath Theodoret. And S. Gregorie, Nazianzen and Nicephorus the ≈øame Greg. Nazian. ≈øupr. Niceph. l. 10. Hi≈øt. c. 1. before, ≈øaying that he profe≈ø≈øed the true and ≈øinceere meaning of the word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , con≈øub≈øtantiall, ≈øinceram dictionis eius ≈øententiam e≈øt profe≈ø≈øus. And declared him≈øelfe an open & knowne Enemy of them who dur≈øt call Chri≈øt a Creature, Tum certus manife≈øtu≈øque eorum qui creaturam illum vocare au≈øi fui≈ø≈øent, ho≈øtis extitit. And add, that in all things he was a paterne of his holy Father, but cheifely in pietie, and worship of God, and in abolishing Idols, error and ≈øuper≈øtition, Is fuit patris ≈øui exemplar in omnibus rebus, maxime vero in pietate & Dei cultu, atque in ≈øimulachrorum erroris & ≈øuperstitionis abolitione.

9. This Con≈øtaÃÑtius was at the time of his death, by Sozomen about 45. yeares old, annos natus circiter quadraginta quinque, full 45. ≈øaith Socrates vixit Con≈øtantius Sozom. Hi≈øt. Eccle≈ø. l. 5. c. 1. Socrat. l. 2. c. 37. vlt. Socr. & Sozom. ≈øupr. Nicephor. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 9. c. 50. Baron. & SpoÃÑd. Annal. Tom. 4. annos 45. be≈øides the time he reigned with his Father, after his death ≈øay, Socrates, Sozomen and Nicephorus he was Emperour 25. yeares, viginti Annos & praeterea quinque po≈øt patris mortem imperauit, he died on the third day the Nones of Nouember, tertio Nonas NoueÃÑbris, by Nicephorus his accompt in the 367. yeare of Chri≈øt, Quum √† Chri≈øto nato trecente≈øimus ≈øexage≈øimus ≈øeptimus ageretur. Some ≈øet downe his death ≈øomewhat ≈øooner, as they haue done his
Fathers before aboue 25. years ≈øoonerthen this Accompt of Nicephorus, of the yeare of Chri≈øt 367. for Con≈øtantius his death: yet grant he was Emperour 25. yeares after his Father died.

div.head: THE XXII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: IVLIAN THE APOSTATA NEVER PERSECVTED the Chri≈øtians of Britaine: But they, during the whole tyme he was Cae≈øar or Emperor, were heare in peace and quiet, both from Per≈øecution, Pagani≈øme, or Here≈øie.

div.p:
1. CONSTANTIVS the la≈øt ouerlyuing ≈øonne of Con≈øtantine being dead, Iulianus Brother to Gallus and ≈øonne of Con≈øtantius Chlorus by Theodora, a man by no Title of di≈øcent Heire or King of Britaine, was acknowledged for Emperour, for allthough this Con≈øtantius la≈øt Emperour by the in≈øtigation and per≈øua≈øion of Eu≈øebia Empre≈ø≈øe made him a Cae≈øar in the Empire, he him≈øelfe not able to di≈øcharge the whole charge for manyfold trobles and Inua≈øions of the Barbarous, as the Romans termed ≈øtrangers, into „Äà‚óä„Äâ places of the Empire e≈øpecially in Gallia, now France; where as Zo≈øimus ≈øaith, they tooke 40. Cities, neare the Riuer of Rhene: Francos, & Alamanos & Saxones quadraginta ≈øitas ad Rhenum vrbes coepi≈ø≈øe, pror≈øus ea≈ødem deua≈øta≈ø≈øe, Ciues & Incolas infinitae multitudinis cum innumerabili ≈øpoliorum copia ≈øecum abduxi≈ø≈øe, and gaue vnto him in Zo≈øimus Hi≈øt. l. 3 Socrat. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 3. c. 1. Ca≈ø≈øiodor. Tripart. Hi≈øt. l. 6. c. 1. Niceph. l. 10. c. 1. Ammianus l. 21. Baron. & SpoÃÑ dan. Annal. ann. 360. Marriage his Si≈øter Helena. And ≈øent him to gouerne the part of the Empire, on this ≈øide the Alpes, po≈øtquam Iulianus in Italiam accer≈øitus adueni≈ø≈øet, Cae≈øarem Con≈øtantius declarat, & Helenam ei ≈øororem in MatrimoniuÃÑ tradit, & ad Nationes Tran≈øalpinas eum dimittit: yet it is euident by Ammianus and others, that he had no child by her, which liued, but she her≈øelfe died before her brother Con≈øtantius Emperour. Neuertheles the Eccle≈øia≈øticall State of Britaine rather gained, then lo≈øt by his being Cae≈øar in the≈øe We≈øterne parts, and Emperour afterward. For allthough Con≈øtantius had married his Si≈øter Helena vnto him, and in that re≈øpect ≈øo longe as she liued might ≈øeeme to haue a care rather to pre≈øerue then de≈øtroy him, yet she dying as before, during her brothers life, that imagined loue of Con≈øtantius could not loÃÑger endure in that re≈øpect: and both Socrates, Ca≈ø≈øiodorus and others te≈øtifie, it was thought that when Con≈øtantius ≈øent him into the dangerous Warrs of Gallia, he did it to haue him ≈ølaine by the cruell and potent Enemies, Dicitur √† nonnullis, Con≈øtantium illum, Socrat. l. 3. cap. 1. Ca≈ø≈øiodor. Tripartit. Hi≈øt. l. 6. c. 1. Niceph. Hi≈øt. l. 10. c. 1. Socrat. ≈øupr. & alij. Ammian. lib. 21. Baron. an. 361. & alij. Socrat. l. 3. c. 1. (Iulianum) contra Barbaros hac de re mi≈øi≈ø≈øe, vt cum illis confligens, ibi interiret. Nicephorus calleth this the common conceipt and opinion, ≈øermonibus vulgatum fuit. And Con≈øtantius limiting his Authoritie to doe nothing without con≈øent of others, dedit illi in mandatis Imperator, vt nihil ≈øine DucuÃÑ con≈øilio moliretur. And not onely this but he ≈øecretly incited Vadomarus King of the Frankes to take Armes again≈øt Iulian; and incited others by his letters, which they ≈øent to IuliaÃÑ for their excu≈øe, to inuade the Romans where Iulian ruled, Illi Legatum ad eum (Iulianum) mittere, literas Imperatoris, quae eos in fines Romanorum ire iu≈ø≈øerant, o≈øtendere
caeperunt. Which when Iulian perceaued, and remembring the old hatred he had borne him froÃÑ his childhood, he requited him with the like mea≈øure, shewing mo≈øt loue and fauour to tho≈øe vnder his gouernment, whome Con≈øtantius hated, or disfauoured mo≈øt; which among Chri≈øtians were the Catholike Bishops and others whome he had per≈øecuted, Iulianus quo pacto populum ≈øibi deuincire, eiu≈øque conciliare beneuolentiam po≈ø≈øet, cogitat. Ad quam rem tali v≈øus e≈øt a≈øtutia. Nouerat pro certo, Con≈øtantium vniuer≈øae illi populi multitudini, quae fidem Con≈øub≈øtantialis amplexabatur, maxime inui≈øum e≈ø≈øe, tum quodillos Eccle≈øijs ip≈øorum exturbauerat, tum quia Epi≈øcopos, qui ad illos ≈øpectabant, pro≈øcriptos, in exilium eiecerat.

2. And this his fauour, and kindenes towards Catholicks had continued with him euen from his fir≈øt being Cae≈øar in the≈øe parts, as euidently appeareth in the ca≈øe of S. Hilary, that renowned glory of Gods Church, who at the ≈øame time he was exiled, by procurement of the wicked Arrians and con≈øent of Con≈øtantius Emperor vniu≈øtly, was by Iulianus, whome he calleth his Lord and Religeous Cae≈øar, adiuged Innocent, and for his loue and defence of S. Hilary did ≈øuffer more reprouch of the Arrian Per≈øecutors, then S. Hilary Hilar. l. ad Con≈øtantium Augu≈øtum. endured Iniury by that Exilement, as he him≈øelfe, the be≈øt witne≈ø≈øe, auouched to Con≈øtantius, Exulo non crimine, ≈øed factione, & fal≈øis nuncijs Synodi apud te Imperatorem pium, non ob aliquam criminum meorum con≈øcientiam per impios homines delatus. Nec leuem habeo quaerelae meae te≈øtem, Dominum meum Religio≈øum Cae≈øarem tuum Iulianum: qui plus in Exilio meo √† malis contumeliae, quam ego iniuriae pertulit. And S. Hilary returning into France, in the end of the Empire Fortun. in Vit. S. Hilarij. Seuer. l. 2 Ruffin. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 31. Socrat. Hi≈øt. l. 3. c. 8. vit. S. Hilarij. Sozom. l. 5. c. 12. S. Anton. ad Didymum apud Sozom. l. 3. c. 14. Vit. S. Hilar. ≈øup. in Breuiar. Baro. & Spondan. An. 369. & al. of Con≈øtantius, and beginning of Iulianus by calling diuers Synods, in which Saturninus and Paternus the cheife Agents of Ariani≈øme there were excommunicated, France was deliuered from that Infection, and Britayne ≈øtill ioyning with S. Hilary and the Catholicks of Gallia, was free from thar venime, Ad hunc modum doctrinam Concilij Nicaeni in ea Imperij parte, quae ad ≈øolem Occidentem vergit, ab Hilario & Eu≈øebio (vercellen≈øi) defen≈øam & propugnatam accepimus. And as S. Seuerus writeth: Illud apud omnes con≈øtitit, vnius Hilarij beneficio Gallias no≈øtras piaculo haere≈øis liberatas. Which mu≈øt needs be in this time of Iulian his being Cae≈øar and Emperor, S. Hilary dying in the yeare 369. anno po≈øt Chri≈øtum natum trecente≈øimo ≈øexage≈øimo nono, Soone after the end of Iulian his short Empyre, hauing commanded others by his in the We≈øt an vnitie in Religion, by many Councells of the Bishops of France and other Prouinces in the≈øe Occidentall parts. Diuers of tho≈øe Councells a≈ø≈øembled after Iulian was Emperor, and had reuolted from Chri≈øtian Religion, the whole time of his Empyre being by no accompt aboue two yeares and 8. moneths. An Argument ≈øufficient that the Per≈øecution which he ray≈øed again≈øt Chri≈øtians did not extend to the≈øe We≈øterne NatioÃÑs, e≈øpecially Britaine, likely by his reuolt from Chri≈øt, and death of his wife Helena, and Con≈øtantius Baron. An. 363. the Po≈øteritie of our S. Helen the Heire of this kingdome, now reuolted from him. But how≈øoeuer this was, Iulian quite leauing the≈øe We≈øterne Nations, before he eyther per≈øecuted Chri≈øtians, or left the Profe≈ø≈øion of their Religion, liuing ≈øo short a time Emperor, not two yeares by two moneths and three dayes, as Baronius thinketh he doth demon≈øtrate, and neuer returning we≈øtward againe, Socrat. Hi≈øt. l. 3. c. 18. Ca≈ø≈øiodor. Hi≈øt. Tripart. l. 6. c. 47. but the≈øe Countryes in tho≈øe dayes ≈øetled in Catholicke Religion, Britayne could not be afflicted by his Apo≈øta≈øie. But rather gayned, then lo≈øt in Religion by him, being all the time he was Cae≈øar a friend to Catholicks, and dying as Socrates, Ca≈ø≈øiodorus, and others write in the ≈øeuenth
yeare, after he was declared Cae≈øar: occubuit anno ≈øeptimo po≈øteaquam a Con≈øtantio Cae≈øar renuntiatus fui≈ø≈øet.

3. So that he was aboue twice as long a friend to the Catholiks in Britayne, as he was a profe≈ø≈øed Enemy to Chri≈øtians in any place. For Ammian. Marcellin. Speed Theater l. 6. c. 47. Stowe Hi≈øt. in Iulian. Harris Theater Tom. 4 c. 26. if we grante vnto ≈øome what they contend, that he ruled in Britayne, and that Lupicinus and Alipius whome he employed to builde Hieru≈øalem in fauour of the Iewes, and their Religion, did gouerne heare as Lieutenants in his time, or Con≈øtantius, this hindereth not the quiet of the Brittish Catholicks in his either Cae≈øarship, or Empire. For the Authors them≈øelues which mo≈øt in≈øi≈øt vpon the≈øe in≈øtances, doe freely confe≈ø≈øe, fir≈øt, that Lupicinus was a very Chri≈øtian man, and Enemy vnto Hereticks. One Harris ≈øupr. of them thus writeth: At what time Iulian was receaued Emperor by the Senate and people, he began al≈øo to Reigne ouer Britayne vnder whome Lupiciniuc Praeter a Chri≈øtian gouerned the Land. And if I be not deceaued this was the ≈øame Lupicinius Epiph. l. de Haere≈ø. Haer. 80. (the name, time, and other circum≈øtances ≈øo pleade) which Epiphanius maketh mention of, who per≈øecuted to death in the time of Con≈øtantius the Ma≈øsilian and Martyrian Heretiks, who denyed the grace of Bapti≈øme, fa≈øting, and many other Ammian. Marcellin. l. 20. cap. 1. Haere≈ø. Speed & Stowe ≈øupr. points of Catholike Religion. And for the other, Alipius, it is manife≈øt by Ammianus Marcellinus, and our owne Hi≈øtorians, euen Prote≈øtants, that he could not mole≈øt the Brittish Catholicks in the Empyre of Iulian, how ≈øoeuer he ≈øtood affected, friend, or foe to their ReligioÃÑ, for he was ≈øent hither by Iulian being Cae≈øar in the time of Con≈øtantius to re≈øi≈øt the Inua≈øions of the Picts, and Scots, into the Marches of the Britanes, Iulian him≈øelfe not daring to leaue Gallia as much infe≈øted by the Almans, and Iulian him≈øelfe at that time (as before is proued) was a friend to the Catholike Chri≈øtians. And Alipius was gone hence, neuer medling in matters of Religion, heare in Britayne, for any thing we finde in Hi≈øtorie, and come to Antioch in the Ea≈øt before Iulian began his Per≈øecution again≈øt Chri≈øtians, and from them was ≈øent by Iulian to Hieru≈øalem, to help the Iewes to build againe their Temple there, which God did ≈øo miraculou≈øly preuent, and hinder, as all Hi≈øtories agree. Storre ≈øupr. One of the≈øe Authors ≈øaith: Iulian ≈øent Alipius who had bene a Lieutenant of Britaine to repayre Hieru≈øalem. Others write: to repayre the≈øe cur≈øed Walles, Speede ≈øupr. again≈øt the prouidence of diuine Iu≈øtice Alipius of Antioch was ≈øent. Therefore both Iulian and he then being in the Ea≈øt, and entreating about this bu≈øines, Socrat. l. 3. Hi≈øt. c. 17. Sozomen. Hi≈øt. l. 5. c. 21. with the Iewes there, as both Socrates, Sozomen and others teach, all of them then being ≈øo farre from Britaine, Alipius could not po≈ø≈øibly beare any office of commande heare after the Apo≈øta≈øie of Iulian, nor ≈øome time before.

div.head: THE XXIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF DIVERS RENOWNED SAINTS HEARE in Britayne in this time, S. Kebius a glorious Catholicke Bishop, a greate and long acquaintance of S. Hilary of France, S. Decumanus and others.

div.p: 1. MANY were our renowned and holy Bishops in this time, as I haue before remembred, allthough in generall termes, not mentioning their names, which continued firme and con≈øtant in the Catholike faith, ioyning with the Popes of Rome, S. Athana≈øius, S. Hilary, and the re≈øt, which confuted and condemned the Arrian Here≈øie. Among the≈øe S. Kebius was one, ≈øonne of Salomon Duke of Cornwayle, who continued heare in Britayne vntill he was about 29. yeares of Age, profiting much and proceeding in learning: then hearing of the fame of S. Hilary, went ouer into France, and ioyned him≈øelfe vnto him, then renowned for Sanctitie, and holy learning. This was the motiue which drew him thither, and from his Country, and not to auoyde the venime of Arriani≈øme then ari≈øing and breeding in this Country, as a late Writer coniectureth Io. Pit≈øeus l. de Illu≈øtr. Britan. Script. aetat. 6. in Kebio Corinio. rather, then proueth, or can be proued: propter tum pullulantem in Britannia Arrianam Haere≈øim, adhuc inuenis in Galliam ≈øece≈øsit. For I haue before freed Britayne from any ≈øuch dangerous infection, and rather France then Britayne was ≈øubiect to ≈øuch danger. And at the time when S. Kebius went into France, the Arrian Here≈øie was not yet ry≈øen either in Britayne, or any part of the world in probable Iudgment. For both by this Writer, and Io. Pit≈ø. ≈øupr. Magdebur. cent. 4. cap. 10. Harr. Hi≈øt. Tom. 4. cap. 32. Io. LelaÃÑd. & alij. others both auncient and late, S. Kebius dyed in the yeare of Chri≈øt 380. an old man, in ≈øenectute bona, operibus bonis plenus, one ≈øaith, diuers yeares ≈øooner, in the yeare 368. And yet the old Manu≈øcript of his life, Capgraue & others affirme, that he conuer≈øed with S. Hilary 50. yeares, tran≈øito mari apud Hilarium Pictauen≈øem Epi≈øcopum per quinquaginta annos manens. Therefore S. Hilary dying in the yeare of Chri≈øt 369. as is proued before, and S. Kebius lyuing with him 50. yeares, he mu≈øt needs be gone out of Britayne before the Nicen Councell, Manu≈øcr. Antiq. de vit. S. Kebij. Capgrau. Catal. in eodem. and Arrian Here≈øie, allthough he had continued with S. Hilary vnto his death, which no Writer affirmeth, but the contrary. And his lyuing Bishop in Britayne after his returne hither many yeares euidently ≈øo conuinceth. So likewi≈øe doth the bannishment of S. Hilary into Phrygia, many yeares before he dyed, by which argument we mu≈øt needs hold, that eyther S. Kebius of Britayne was bannished with him, or followed him in that exile, for which we haue neyther Authoritie, nor warrant of rea≈øon; or ≈øay, that S. Kebius was con≈øecrated Bishop by S. Hilary before his exilement by Con≈øtantius, and then returned into Britayne.

2. And yet it is as vnprobable in my opinion, which the ≈øame Author ≈øeemeth to hold, that this Kebius then a Bishop was at that Councell of Arles in France, wherein S. Re≈øtitutus our Archbishop of London ≈øub≈øcribed, and before
his going thither from Britayne was one of them which re≈øi≈øted Pelagius his Here≈øy heare, Britones Pelagium in Exilium eiecerunt, eiu≈øque doctrinae inter Proaemium vniuer≈ø. in l. de vir Illu≈øtr. Britan. pag. 6. alios re≈øtiterunt Re≈øtitutus Archiepi≈øcopus Londinen≈øis, & Kebius Corinius Epi≈øcopus Mannen≈øis. Qui quoniam in Britannia res turbatae fuerint in Galliam ad ≈øanctum Hilarium Pictauien≈øem Epi≈øcopum: & deinde ad Concilium Arelaten≈øe ≈øecundum, ≈øuper his, & alijs fidei negotijs ≈øe≈øe contulerunt. For I haue proued before, that this Councell of Arles to which S. Re≈øtitutus ≈øub≈øcribed, was long before this time, and before S. Hilary him≈øelfe was eyther Bishop, Prei≈øt, or Clergie man, or of any fame in ≈øuch affayres. And this Author him≈øelfe ≈øetteth downe Pit≈ø. aetat. 5. in Re≈øtituto. the death of S. Re≈øtitutus in the yeare 350. before eyther S‚ñ™ Hilary was Bishop, or Pelagius vented his Here≈øie. Therefore I may choo≈øe the midle, as the ≈øafe≈øt way to walke in, for S. Kebius being made Bishop by S. Hilary, and his returne into Britayne to haue bene about the time of S. Hilary his Exile into Phrygria. For it is euident by S. Hilary him≈øelfe that it was long before he applyed him≈øelfe to the ≈øtudy of Diuinity, or probably was a Chri≈øtian; and by no Author was Bishop 20. yeares. And if we might write by coniecturs Hilar. l. 1. de Trinitate. Baron. & Spond. Annal. an. 355. not wanting probabilitie, we should rather be of opinion, that this holy S. Kebius was one of our poore Brittish Bishops, ≈øpoken of before in generall termes, which were pre≈øent at the Councell of Ariminum, then of Arles, the la≈øt without all probabilitie, but for congruently thinking him to haue bene pre≈øent at Ariminum ≈øo generall an A≈ø≈øembly as is related, we haue the circum≈øtance of time agreeing, that he was familiar with S. Hilary and the Bishops of France, that he was a Bishop of Britayne, and for his longe conuer≈øation in forreyne Countries more fitt then others for that employment now, and further he was a poore Bishop, ≈øuch as Britayne had but few at that time, and yet S. Seuerus Sulpitius hath proued vnto vs, that Britayne had among the re≈øt, three poore Bishops there, Tres tantum ex Britannia, inopia proprij, publico S. Seuer. ≈øacrae Hi≈øt. lib. 2. v≈øi ≈øunt, not able to bare their owne charges. For allthough S. Kebius was ≈øonne of the Duke or King of Cornwayle, and as the Writers of his life affirme, refu≈øed the Principalitie of Cornwayle, due, and offered vnto him: Manu≈øcr. Antiq. & Capgrau. in vit. S. Kebij. Gradu Epi≈øcopali ab Hillario accepto, admonitus e≈øt ab Angelo in ≈øuam patriam remeare. Quo cum perueni≈ø≈øet, rogatus e≈øt vt ip≈øe veniret Regnum Cornubiae ≈øu≈øcepturus. Pote≈øtatem tamen ≈øaeculi prae≈øentis omnino accipere renuit. But lyued a poore penitentiall life with his 10. Di≈øciples, cum decem Di≈øcipulis ≈øuis, which by ≈øome were termed Monkes, monachi ≈øunt, as his Hi≈øtory witne≈ø≈øeth, ≈øome time vnder a Tent, and allmo≈øt vnto his death in a Cottage, or Cell vntill the King of Venedocia moued with his pietie and miracles gaue vnto him a Ca≈øtle, Contulit viro Dei Ca≈øtellum ≈øuum, Deo & ≈øancto Kebio in perpetuum.

3. The miracles which God shewed by him were many, and wonderfull: Caecos illuminauit, lepro≈øos mundauit, paraliticos, mutos & demoniacos ≈øanauit. His mo≈øt aboad and re≈øidency was in Venedocia, now Northwales, and the I≈øle of Mona, Man, and as diuers write, Bishop there; if that Iland is not mi≈øtaken Angle≈øey Iland where S. Kebius both lyued and dyed being auntiently ≈øo called Mona. In this Mona now Angle≈øey is the place called holy head of that holy Bishop: where his Tombe ≈øtill is, or lately was, and vi≈øited with reuerence, as a late Writer confidently, and as by experimentall knowledge thus te≈øtifieth: He dyed at a place called Holy Heade in Wales where his ToÃÑbe Harris Theater. Tom. 4. cap. 32. is yet vi≈øited in Pilgrimage by the Inhabitants of that Country. And as the Welch Writers euen Prote≈øtants doe freely confe≈ø≈øe, that this place of S. Kebius his aboad and death, which the English men call Holy Heade, is by the Welch or
Britans ≈øtill called S. Kebius Citie, becau≈øe he was Bishop there, and of ≈øo greate Sanctitie, Quod illi (Angli) holy heade qua≈øi ≈øacrum caput, nos ver√≤ Caercibi Humfr. Lhuyd in Mona In≈øula: apud Abraham. Ortelium in fine Theatri. Will. Harri≈øon De≈øcript. of Brit. c. 10. in Angle≈øie. id e≈øt ciuitatem Kibij dicimus: Which an other Welch Antiquary a Prote≈øtant al≈øo thus confidently confirmeth, The Welch men call it Tiremone or Mon, and herein is a Promontorye or Byland, called holy heade, which hath in times pa≈øt bene named Cair Kyby, of Kyby a Monke that dwelled there.

4. Yet to make vnion betwene the≈øe Authors, both tho≈øe Ilands ≈øome time of the ≈øame name, ≈øituated in the ≈øame Sea, and neare one to the other, we may, and not vnprobably grant, that this holy Saint was Bishop of them both at the ≈øame time. The names of his holy Di≈øciples in particular I doe not finde for certayne, except of S. Caffo, to who≈øe Sanctitie God gaue this S. Caffo. miraculous te≈øtimony, that in time of need being ≈øent by S. Kebius for fier, and the wicked Smith where he was to haue it, denying it vnto him, except he would carry it in his bo≈øome, which being enforced vnto, he ≈øo carryed it vnto his Mai≈øter, without any hurt to him≈øelfe or his coate, S. Kebius mi≈øit Manu≈øcr. antiq. & Capgr. in S. Kebio. Di≈øcipulum ≈øuum nomine Caffo vt ignem afferret. Qui cum √† quodam Fabro ignem peteret, renuit ip≈øe dare, ni≈øi in ≈øinu ≈øuo portare vellet, & po≈øito igne in ≈øinu ei us reuer≈øus e≈øt ad Magi≈øtrum ≈øuum ≈øine lae≈øione ve≈øtis ≈øuae ignem portans.

5. But Mai≈øter Harris in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtorie, noting the yeare of Chri≈øt Harr. Hi≈øt. tom. 4. c. 33. 370. confidently writeth as hauing Authorie for it, which he citeth not: about this time lyued al≈øo an holy Saint of the Brittish Nation, named Tefredaucus, S. Tefredaucus. in the Ile of Mone, where after his death he had a Church erected and dedicated in his name, of whome Giraldus Cambren≈øis writeth this miracle. In this Ile of Mone ≈øaith he, there is a Church in honour of S. Tefredaucus, the Confe≈ø≈øor, into which on a time when Hugh Earle of Shrewsbury and the Earle of Che≈øter came in by force, and placing their houndes in the Church all night, in the morning they founde them all madd. And the cheife Earle him≈øelfe with in one moneth after was ≈ølayne & dyed a mi≈øerable death. Giraldus thus truely hath this Hi≈øtory, but ≈øpeaketh nothing of the Girald. Cambr. l. 2. Itenerar. CaÃÑbr. c. 7. time when this holy Confe≈ø≈øor lyued: Est & in hac In≈øula Eccle≈øia Sancti Tefredauci Confe≈ø≈øoris, in qua Hugo Comes Slopesburien≈øis, cum ≈øemel vna cum Comite Ce≈øtren≈øi hanc In≈øulam vi ingrederetur, canes nocte quadam po≈øui≈ø≈øet, in≈øanos omnes mane recepit. Et ip≈øemet infra men≈øem mi≈øerabiliter extinctus occubuit. If this Author is not deceaued in the time, we may probably ≈øuppo≈øe this Sa ‚Ä¢ nt Tefredaucus (the circum≈øtances a≈øwell of time, place and profe≈ø≈øion agreeing thereunto) was one of the Di≈øciples of S. Kebius, then ≈øo conuer≈øing, lyuing, and dying in that Iland of Mona or Angle≈øey. The ≈øame Hi≈øtory of this Church, and Saint, with Giraldus hath Humfrey Lhuyed in his Treati≈øe of Mona, onely he differeth, in calling this Saint with a little difference, Saint Fefridaucus, Humfr. Lhuyd. in Mona In≈øula. Druidum. Harris Tom. 4. c. 17. Eccle≈øia Sancti Fefridauci.

6. M. Harris is of opinion, that the holy Eremite and Martyr S. Decumanus lyued in this Age, and before this time, either in, or ≈øoone after the 312. yeare of Chri≈øt. And Capgraue with the old Manu≈øcript of his life doth te≈øtifie, S. Decumanus. that he was of the olde Primatiue Chri≈øtian Britans. This man borne in the Io. Capgr. Catal. in S. Decumano. Heremita & Martyre. We≈øt part of Cambria, of Noble and renowned Chri≈øtian parents euen when he was very younge ab≈øtayning from the plea≈øures & recreations of this life, euen tho≈øe that be voyde of ≈øinne, the more freely & wholly to deuote and dedicate him≈øelfe to the ≈øeruice of Chri≈øt, loue of heauen, and contempt of this world: And knowing how difficult a thing it is, for a man e≈øpecially of Noble and greate parentage, in his owne Country, and among his carnall friends,
Ritches, and delights continually appo≈øing them≈øelues again≈øt Chri≈øtian perfection, to ≈øerue God in ≈øo ≈øecure and holy e≈øtate, in one conflict vanquished and ≈øubdued them, ≈øecretly for feare of being pur≈øued and hindered in his ≈øacred cour≈øe and enterpri≈øe, ≈øtealing away from them, and going into a Wildernes of a ≈øtrange Country, ≈øeperated from his owne, by the Riuer or Sea of Seuerne, where he Miraculou≈øly began his Miraculous Eremites life: for comming to the Ryuer ≈øide, and neither finding Ferry-man, nor boate, and fearing to be ≈øtayed by his friends pur≈øuing him, cutt a greate bundell of wandes growing there, and binding them together in one faget, pa≈ø≈øed vpon them to the other ≈øide, neare Doro≈øtor Ca≈øtle, as Capgraue nameth it, now likely called Dun≈øter adioyning vpon Seuerne Sea, where he landed, Defuit Naulum, defuit & Nauigium, & maturanda erat fuga √® ve≈øtigio ≈øub≈øequentium vir Dei Mi≈øericordia Dei confidens, & nequaquam hae≈øitans de potentia, virgas ≈øecus mare in frutecto quas reperit cre≈øcentes, colligauit in fa≈øciculum, & tali vtens vehiculo mi≈øit ≈øe in profundum. Et ≈øic diuiua gubernante prudentia, prouectus e≈øt ad littus oppo≈øitum prope castrum Doro≈øtorum. This place of S. Decombes or Decumanus either Miraculou≈øly Auth. of Engl. Mart. die 27. Augu≈øt. landing, or liuing is not, as one hath lately written, in Gloce≈øtershire, which neither is adiacent vnto Seuerne Sea, mare Sabrinum, which he pa≈ø≈øed, but onely the Ryuer Seuerne, not hauing in any part of Gloce≈øtershire the name of Seuerne Sea, but ≈øtill the Ryuer Seuerne, nor is oppo≈øite to any part of the Country now called Southewales from whence he came. Nor had his pa≈ø≈øadge ouer a Ryuer in ≈øuch maÃÑner as is related, bene ≈øo Miraculous, as the Hi≈øtory thereof declareth it was. Neither was the part of Gloce≈øtershire adioyning to Seuerne Ryuer, being the mo≈øt plea≈øant and fruitefull part of that Prouince by all de≈øcriptions, and euer mo≈øt inhabited, ≈øuch a craggy, va≈øte, or rude wildernes, and De≈øart as he landed and liued in, Eo tempore quo Sanctus Decumanus diuinitus perductus in AngliaÃÑ venit, erat in eo territorio in quo applicuit vasta Eremi ≈øolitudo, frutetis & vepribus ob≈øita, & den≈øitate ≈øiluarum in longum & latum ≈øpatio≈ø√© porrecta montium eminentia ≈øur≈øum educta, & concauitate vallium mirabiliter interrupto. Haec ei ≈øedes complacuit: haec pio eius propo≈øito videbatur accommoda.

7. Neither is-there any ≈øuch C ‚Ä¢ ≈øtle in Glo≈øter-shire either by Seuerne ≈øide or farre of, named Dor≈øter, or DuÃÑ≈øter or neare to that name whereby he laÃÑded, or any place of, or like to his name, Church, villadge, or any other ≈øuch MonumeÃÑt Speed. & alij in De≈øcrip. Angliae & Comi ‚Ä¢ atus Somer≈øeten. dedicated vnto him, in any Antiquitie. When quite otherwi≈øe in Sommer≈øetshire, we finde all the≈øe things agreeing: it adioyneth to Seuerne Sea, it is oppi≈øite to Southe-wales, it was there abouts longe time de≈øart and vninhabited, as the names of the villadges there now builded, olde Cleue, Wethicombe, and Nettlecombe proue, there is Dun≈øter Ca≈øtle vpon Seuerne Sea, there, very broade, and making ≈øuch a pa≈ø≈øadge there, Miraculous. Within three English Manu≈øcr. Ant. in vit. S. Decumani. Io. Capgrau. in eod. miles of that, is a place called to this daye S. Decombs, with a Church dedicated to his honour, named S. Decombs or Decumans Church. Therefore we may ≈øafely ≈øay, that this place in Sommer≈øet-shire was the holy habitation of this glorious S. Decuman, or Decomb. Heare he liued many yeares by herbes and rootes, and as ≈øome hold on Fe≈øtiuall dayes with the milke of a Cowe which he kept, in ≈øackcloath, fa≈øtings and watchings, vntill by a wicked Pagan much enueying his Sanctitie, hating true pietie, and dete≈øting the ≈øacred name of Chri≈øt, being at his holy prayers, and deuotions, he was beheadded, and martyred, Vir Sanctus patriam commutans exilio, antra de≈ø ‚Ä¢ rti pro fastu palatij, caepit thidem commanere, herbis & radicibus victitare, ieiun ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s & orationibus in≈øi≈øtere,
