carnem cilitio domans, vigilijs paenaliter affligens. Tali ≈øub tenore vitam ducens Heremiticam in iam dicta ≈øolitudine multis vixerat annis. Fertur etiam vaccam habui≈ø≈øe cuius lacte pro nece≈øsitate corporis ≈øaltem praeclaris festiuitatibus magis ≈øu≈øtentaretur, quam aleretur. Cum igitur Sanctus Decumanus multimodis ≈øignorum floreret virtutibus, vir quidam ≈øed & ip≈øe vir Belial, a≈øpide ≈øaeuior, vipera truculentior tanti patris inuidens ≈øanctitati, in odium verae virtutis & in dete≈øtationem Christiani nominis, furiali mente debacchatus be≈øtialiter accurrit, & inter verba orationis & preces ≈øanctae deuotionis, ≈øanctum Domini capitis obtruncatione ad caelestia Regna tran≈ømi≈øit.

8. The ≈øame miracle is written of him, as of S. Denis the Areopagite Saint Pauls Scholler, that his head being ≈øtricken of, his body ≈øtood vpright, and with the Armes carryed the head from the place where it was cutt of, vnto a Fountayne of mo≈øt cleare water, in which when he liued he v≈øed to wash it. Which vnto this day ≈øaith Capgraue in memory and reuerence of him is called S. Decombs well, ≈øweete, v≈øefull and hole≈øome for the Inhabitants to drinke, Truncus laceri corporis ≈øe erexit, & caput proprium rexit pendulis brachijs vectitare √† loco decollationis v≈øque ad f ‚Ä¢ tem limpidi≈øsimi liquoris, in qno caput ≈øuum proprijs manibus abluere pro con≈øuetudine habebat. Qui v≈øque hodie ad memoriam & reuerentiam ip≈øius, fons Sancti Decumani nuncupatur, dulcis, nece≈ø≈øarius & ≈øalubris incolis ad potandum. In quo loco caput ≈øimul cum corpore po≈øtmodum √† fidelibus quae≈øitum & inuentum, ≈øepulturae honorific√® tradebatur. Where both his head and whole body being ≈øought and found by the Chri≈øtians, were honorably buried. And a Church afterward there builded in his memory and honour, called ≈øtill S. Decombs Church, as the Towne or Village al≈øo honorably termed by his name.

9. There is al≈øo and other Church dedicated to him in the Towne of Welles in the ≈øame Shire, ≈øtill ≈øtanding, and pre≈øeruing his name and memory. A ≈øufficient Argument of it≈øelfe, be≈øides ≈øo many others before, that he lyued and dyed in that Country, no other giuing ≈øo much te≈øtimonie vnto him. And the honour and reuerence which at that time and euer after, vntill Prote≈øtants New Religion ≈øo much as it could defaced or ob≈øcured ≈øuch holy memories, was giuen to the ≈øacred Eremites, their Church, and Reliks at Gla≈øtenbury, in the ≈øame Country and neare the place of S. Decombs Heremitage, occa≈øioned him to make choy≈øe of that De≈øart to liue and die in, where or neare ≈øo many renowned Saints had gloriou≈øly triumphed ouer this world, and all Enemies therein, and with who≈øe Religeous Succe≈ø≈øors he might ≈øome times meete for his ≈øpirituall good, and comforte e≈øpecially ≈øeeing, as our Prote≈øtants them≈øelues doe ≈øufficiently acknowledge, Saint Damian or Deruian ≈øent hither by Pope and Saint Eleutherius with Saint Phaganus, had there a Church very neare S. Decombs aboad, by the ≈øame Ca≈øtle or Towne of Stowe & Howes Hi≈øt. Tit. Rom. in Lucius. Dun≈øter, where he landed, True it is (≈øay the≈øe Prote≈øtant Writers) that till this day there remayneth in Sommer≈øet Shire in the Denaery of Dun≈øtor a Parish Church bearing the name of S. Deruuian, as a Church eyther by him founded, or to him dedicated. A ≈øufficient motiue both for him to choo≈øe this place, and commend his choy≈øe thereof, as Capgraue relateth or conceaueth thus he did: Haec Capgrau. in S. Decumano. ei ≈øedes complacuit, haec pio eius propo≈øito videbatur accommoda: adeo vt reip≈øa videbatur dicere: Haec requies mea in ≈øeculum ≈øeculi, hic habitabo quoniam elegi eam. I shall ≈øpeake more of more, ≈øuch renowned holy Britans heare both Bishops, Prei≈øts and others, when I haue fir≈øt ≈øpoken of our cheife≈øt Rulers both Spirituall and Temporall, Popes and Emperors our Kings heare in this Age.

div.head: THE XXIV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: WHEREIN MAXIMVS OVR KING AND Emperor is cleared from many imputations, and ≈ølaunders e≈øpecially concerning true Catholike Religion, which he both profe≈øsed in him≈øelfe, and maintained in others, all the other Emperors and Popes were of the ≈øame Religion the Roman Church now profe≈ø≈øeth.

div.p: 1. IVlian the Apo≈øtata ending his wicked and Tyrannicall Ruffin. Hi≈øt. l. 2. c. 1. Theodoret. l. 4. c. 1. Socrat. Hi≈øt. l. 3. c. 19. Matth. We≈øt. an. 366. life, with a ≈øtrange punishing death, Iouianus a Chri≈øtian was cho≈øen Emperor, and as Ruffinus, Theodoret, Socrates and others te≈øtifie, refu≈øed it, & being thereto taken by the Souldiars again≈øt his will, openly prote≈øted that he being a Chri≈øtian, would not be Emperor ouer Infidels, but all of them confe≈ø≈øing them≈øelues to be Chri≈øtians, he accepted of the Empire, Iouianus ad Imperium delectus illud Iouinian Emperor commended. repudiauit. Et cum √† militibus inuitus raperetur, clamauit ≈øe, qui Chri≈øtianus erat, nolle omnino hominum gentilitatem profitentium Imperium ≈øu≈øcipere. At vbi omnes vna voce confe≈øsi ≈øunt, ≈øe e≈ø≈øe Chri≈øtianos, cape≈øcit Imperium. This Chri≈øtian magnanimitie appeared euidently in this new elected Emperor, before in the time of Iulian, by the ≈øame Authors: For Iulian apo≈øtating, and making a Decree, that Souldiars should either ≈øacrifice to Idols, or leaue the warrs, he being then a Tribune, rather made choy≈øe to for≈øake all hope of temporall preferment, then obay that wicked Edict. Whereupon Iulian then ≈øtanding in neede of ≈øuch A≈ø≈øi≈øtants, retayned him ≈øtill in the number of his Commanders notwith≈øtanding he ≈øo courageou≈øly profe≈ø≈øed him≈øelfe a Chri≈øtian, I≈øte cum e≈ø≈øet Tribunus militum, cumque Iulianus militibus lege data optionem daret, vel Idolis ≈øacrificandi, vel de≈øerendi militiam: balteum deponere maluit, quam impium & nefandum Imperatoris edictum exequi. Attamen Iulianus belli impendentis nece≈øsitate compul≈øus, eum in Ducum numero retinuit. This renowned man was at Ruffin. ≈øupr. one and the ≈øame time, as Ruffinus calleth him, a Confe≈ø≈øor, Emperor, and Extinguisher of Error, Is ≈øub vno, eodemque tempore Imperator, & Confe≈ø≈øor, & male illati extitit depul≈øor erroris. And God wonderfully honored his con≈øtancy euen in this life, not onely in conferring the Imperiall honour vpon him; but in the manner thereof, that being ≈øo profe≈ø≈øed a Catholike Chri≈øtian, the whole Army with one voice did choo≈øe him Imperor, Exercitus Theod. ≈øupr. l. 4. c. 1. omnis vna voce Imperatorem postulat Iouianum. Which ioyned with that is ≈øaid of them before vpon Iouianus refu≈øing to be Emperor ouer Pagans, how with one voyce they all confe≈ø≈øed them≈øelues to be Chri≈øtians, omnes vna voce confe≈øsi ≈øunt ≈øe e≈ø≈øe Chri≈øtianos, ≈øufficiently proueth that eyther the Edict of Iulian to force his Souldiars to Sacrifice to Idols was neuer receaued, or generally ob≈øerued, or they ≈øinned onely in the externall Act of Idolatrie, by that compul≈øion, ≈øtill per≈øeuering in Iudgment and affection Chri≈øtians.

2. This is more confirmed by their vnanimous declaring Valentinian for Emperour, after the short Empire of Iouianus, of ≈øeuen moneths by Socrates, Socrates Hi≈øt. l. 3. c. vlt. 22. Ruffin. Hi≈øt. l. 2. c. 1. Socrat. l. 4. c. 1. ≈øepteÃÑ men≈øes regnauit; eight moneths ≈øaith Ruffinus po≈øt octo men≈øes apud CiliciaÃÑ diem obijt; milites omnes vna voce ValentinianuÃÑ ImperatoreÃÑ declarant. Sacrament of the Altare Chri≈øts mo≈øt holy boby and pretious blood. in the Church Portch, and with teares de≈øired ab≈øolution, Nec po≈øt tantum temporis receptus prius e≈øt, ni≈øi ab Ambro≈øio iterum duriter reprehen≈øus, doloris ≈øui in templi vestibulo, in pauimentum ≈øe deijciens & plorans, certa fecit indicia; ac in loco paenitentium ≈øub≈øistere non recu≈øit. And yet they more plainely and pathetically thus deliuer from many renowned Authors, the greate and au≈øteere Magdebur. cent. 4. cap. 7. cap. 3. Theodor. l. 5. c. 17. Sozom l. 7. c. 24. Paul. Diac. lib. 13. Aug. l. 5. de ciuitate Dei c. 26. humble pennance of this Emperor, before he was reconciled by S. Ambro≈øe, peccatum ≈øuum agno≈øcens, octo luxit men≈øibus, quo paenitentiae curriculo completo ad Templum po≈øtea cum lachrymis redijt, Domino ≈øupplicans, non ≈øtans, nec genu flectens, ≈øed in terram pronum ≈øe pro≈øternens, ac ≈øic cum Dauide orans: adhae≈øit pauimento anima mea, viuifica me Domine ≈øecundum verbum tuum. Surgens ver√≤ manibus barbam & capillos euellit, frontem caecidit, & pauimentum lachrymis ≈øuis con≈øper≈øit, ac veniam tandem petens, receptus ab Ambro≈øio e≈øt populo pro eo deprecante. And yet this mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Catholike and Religious Emperor, as the≈øe Prote≈øtants ≈øtile him, was ≈øo farre from ≈øicking to exempt him≈øelfe from the cen≈øure of S. Ambro≈øe, neither Pope nor Patriarke, but onely Bishop of Millan,
hauing no iuri≈ødiction at The≈ø≈øalonica in Greece, where the offenc ‚Ä¢ was committed, but for Millan where the Emperor then was re≈øident, o ‚Ä¢ di≈øobey S. Ambro≈øe, reiect, or per≈øecute him, as diuers late meaner Princes of the new Sect haue v≈øed higher Prelates, and Popes, that he mo≈øt humbly ≈øubmitted him≈øelfe to his Cen≈øure, religiou≈øly performed his enioyned pennance. And as the≈øe Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians from Antiquitie confe≈ø≈øe, S. Ambro≈øe was of all others the mo≈øt worthie Bishop in Theodo≈øius iudgment, and Magdebur. cent. 4. cap. 10. col. 1169. beloued of all the Emperors in his time, euen Honorius ≈øonne to this Theodo≈øius, Qu√†m charus fuerit quinque laudati≈øsimis Imperatoribus, Valentiniano maiori, Gratiano, Valentiniano Iuniori, Theodo≈øio & Honorio, cum quibus omnibus familiari≈øsim√® vixit, non e≈øt opus commemorare, Theodo≈øium de eo dixi≈ø≈øe, Sozomenus Sozom. l. 5. cap. 18. retulit, no≈ø≈øe ≈øcilicet ≈øe ≈øolum Ambro≈øium dignum Epi≈øcopi nomine. And yet neither Theodo≈øius the Emperor, nor any of the others remembred for S. Ambro≈øe his acquaintance in his time, nor he him≈øelfe did either in the iudgment of any learned Prote≈øtants or others deny or doubt of, but plainely and religiou≈øly confe≈ø≈øed and practized the doctrine of the Supremacy of the Popes of Rome in ≈øpirituall affaires. Three of tho≈øe Emperors Gratianus, Valentinianus Edict. Gratiani, Valentiniani & Theodo≈ø. Impp. l. 1. C. de ≈øumma Trinitate, & fide Catholica. and this Theodo≈øius ioyned together in this Lawe, for all vnder the Roman Empire, among which the Britans heare were contained, to exerci≈øe and profe≈ø≈øe that holy Chri≈øtian Religion, which S. Peter deliuered to the RomaÃÑs, the Popes there had there published, and S. Dama≈øus then Pope did followe, CuÃÑctos populos, quos clemeÃÑtiae no≈øtrae regit ImperiuÃÑ, in tali volumus religione ver≈øari, quam D. Petrum Apo≈øtoluÃÑ tradidi≈ø≈øe Romanis Religio v≈øque adhuc ab ip≈øo in≈øinuata Honorius the la≈øt Emperor that reigned in Britaine. declarat, quamque PontificeÃÑ Dama≈øum ≈øequi claret. Honorius ≈øoÃÑne of Theodo≈øius being the la≈øt Emperor in this Age, & the la≈øt of all which reigned in Britaine, was of his Fathers minde in this dutie towards the Roman See, as is manife≈øt Honour. Imper. Epi≈øt. ad Bonif. Pap. Tom. 1. Concil. Ambro≈ø. ad cap. 3. 1. ad Timoth. both by his Epi≈øtle to Pope Bonifacius the fir≈øt, and S. Ambro≈øe ≈øo beloued of him, who te≈øtifieth that the Church is the hou≈øe of God, and the Pope of Rome then Dama≈øus the Gouernor thereof: Eccle≈øia e≈øt domus Dei, cuius hodie Rector e≈øt Dama≈øus. Such is the doctrine of all the renowned Fathers both Greeke and Latine in this learned Age, S. Gregories Nazianzen, Nicen, S. Ba≈øile, S. Chry≈øo≈øtome, The Popes of Rome then as th ‚Ä¢ Emperors of the ≈øame Religion with the pre≈øaÃÑt Roman Church. S. Ierome, S. Augu≈øtin, Optatus, Prudentius and others.

8. The holy Popes which ≈øucceeded to S. Liberius, and Felix before remembred, in this Age, were ≈øainct Dama≈øus, and ≈øainct Siricius knowne to haue bene famous Profe≈ø≈øors and aduancers, as our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries acknowledge, of that Religion, which with them is termed Papi≈øtry. Dama≈øus, ≈øay the≈øe men, was an holy Confe≈ø≈øor, a diligent Supputator of times, and he ≈øet Io. Bal. l. 1. de Act. Romanor. Pontif. in Dama≈øo. Robert. Barns l. de vit. Pontif. Roman. in Dama≈øo. Magdeburgen. cent. 4. cap. 7. Manu≈øcr. Ant. in Biblioth. public. Cantabrig. Iames l. 1. de Manu≈øcr. B ‚Ä¢ d. Martyrolog. in mul ‚Ä¢ . Pontif. Roman. downe in order the lyues & Decrees of his Predece≈ø≈øors Popes of Rome, and hauing written this worke ≈øent it to ≈øainct Ierome to be peru≈øed, Dama≈øus diligens temporum Supputator, vitas & ≈øtatuta ≈øuorum praedece≈ø≈øorum Romanorum Pontificum ≈øuccinct√® dige≈øsit. Et ≈øcriptum opus mi≈øit Hieronymo cogno≈øcendum. Obijt ≈øanctus Confe≈ø≈øor. A greate credit to that booke by Prote≈øtant Antiquaries, where their Religion by their owne confe≈ø≈øion is ≈øo generally condemned, & the Roman Catholike doctrine as vniuer≈øally approued, and confirmed, to haue two ≈øo holy, learned, and glorious auncient Saints and Doctors of Chri≈øts Primatiue Church and Approuers thereof. Yet ≈øo it is further a≈ø≈øcribed to this ≈øo renowned Pope in our old Antiquities, termed, Ge≈øta Pontificum Romanorum, Authore Dama≈øo, both by our English Catholike and Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians. And ≈øaint Bede which liued aboue an hundred yeares before Ana≈øta≈øius Bibliothecarius, to whom ≈øome attribute this Hi≈øtory, followeth it
in diuers places. They al≈øo confe≈ø≈øe that the holy Scripturs, on which they ≈øo much, or onely rely, e≈øpecially in the Hebrewe, and Greeke tongue being Bal. & Barns ≈øupr. in Dama≈ø. tran≈ølated into Latine by ≈øaint Hierome, were generally approued and preferred by this holy Pope, Hieronymi Tran≈ølationem approbauit. Hieronymi Biblia tum caepta e≈øt primum legi, antea ≈øeptuaginta Interpretum ≈øcripta authoritatem habebant. He al≈øo, as the≈øe men acknowledge, v≈øed and celebrated the ≈øacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and generally appointed the Confiteor to be v≈øed by all Prei≈øts in the beginning thereof, in which there is mo≈øt plaine and vndeniable inuocation and prayer to Saints, and Angels, and their prayer and interce≈ø≈øion for people liuing heare on earth, Precor batam Mariam ≈øemper Virginem, beatum Michaelem ArchaÃÑgelum, beatum Ioannem Bapti≈øtaÃÑ, ≈øanctos Apo≈øtolos Petrum, & Paulum & omnes Sanctos orare pro me, ad Dominum Deum no≈øtrum. They te≈øtifie Magdebur. Bal. & Barns in Siric. Papa. as much of ≈øainct Syricius Pope, and how the vnmarried and cha≈øt life of Cleargie men, was generally commanded by him to be ob≈øerued.

div.head: THE XXV. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF MANY RENOWNED, HOLY, AND LEARNED Bishops, Apo≈øtolike men, and other greate Saints heare in Britaine in this time.

div.p:
1. IN this Age, this Kingdome of Britaine had al≈øo many wrothie men, Bishops and others renowned both for pietie and learning. I haue written of our two greate lights of the worlde the happy Mother and ≈øonne S. Helen and Con≈øtantine, Empre≈ø≈øe and Emperour, before; who be≈øides their other endles, and vnmatchable cares, and labous for the Church of Chri≈øt, allready remembred, are honored in the Cataloges of renowned Writers, for their holy and learned paines in that kinde. S. Athana≈øius al≈øo and S. Hilary tho≈øe two greate≈øt Sigebert. Gemb. Chron. an. 432. Polychronic. lib. 4. cap. 29. Nichol. Harpesfel. Hi≈øt. Eccl. cap. 21. pag. 33. M. S. Antiq. in vit. S. Patricij Capgrau. in eod. Flor. Wigorn. Chron. an 371. & 394. Probus in vita S. Patricij inter opera S. Bedae. Richard. Stanihur≈øt. Sur. & Lippol. die 17. Martij Walrer. Rolwinck. Fa≈øcicul. tempor. an. 423. glories of the Church of Chri≈øt in that time, one in the Greeke, the other in the Latine Church, how much they honored this Nation is allready remembred. To whome I may next add that greate S. Martine Bishop of Tours it France, compared for his worthines by worthie Antiquaries to the mo≈øt glorious Apo≈øtles them≈øelues, who honored this Kingdome with his pre≈øence and aboad heare, and no short time, as we are ≈øufficiently warranted by diuers Arguments, fir≈øt his Si≈øter named Couche was married in this Kingdome and was the happy Mother of that glorious man S. Patrike, Sanctus Patricius, genere Brito filius Couches ≈øororis Sancti Martini Turonen≈øis. So with others writeth Sigebert an old French Hi≈øtorian, where S. Martine was, and dyed an holy Bishop. The old Manu≈øcript of the life of ≈øaint Patrike, and Capgraue confe≈ø≈øe as much when they ≈øay that Couche was his Mother, mater Couche, or Couhos dicta e≈øt. Florentius Wigornien≈øis is mo≈øt cleare that S. Martins Si≈øter Couche was Mother to S. Patrike in Britaine, Sanctus Patricius na≈øcitur in Britannia, ex patre Calphurno nomine, mater autem erat Patricij Couches, ≈øoror Sancti Martini de Gallia. The ≈øame is iu≈øtified by tho≈øe Authours which Surius and Zacharias Lippolous followe, and them≈øelues al≈øo, Calphurnius ducta in matrimonium Couche≈ø≈øa S. Martini Turonen≈øis Epi≈øcopi ≈øorore, vnicum ex ea ≈øu≈øcepit filium,
in maritimo Britanniae Territorio, Patricium. So hath Baronius & Spondanus from Antiquitie, Patricius, vt tradunt, Scotus genere, natus ex ≈øancti Martini Baron. & Spond. Annal. an. 431. Turonen≈øis Epi≈øcopi ≈øorore, ab eo Clericus ordinatus. So haue our late English Writers both Catholiks and Prote≈øtants.

2. Hearevpon if we will calculate the time of ≈øaint Patricius and ≈øaint Martins Io. Pit≈ø. de Illu≈øtr. Brit. Script. aetat. 5. in S. Patricio. Io. Bal. cent. 2. in eodem. Pro≈øper. in ChroÃÑ. Sigebert. an. 402. 399. Baron. & alij Girald. Cambr. Topograph. Hib. c. 17. life and death, we mu≈øt needs gather that ≈øaint Martine was heare in Britaine, his Si≈øter following him. It is the common opinion that ≈øaint Martine died about the 400. yeare of Chri≈øt, as al≈øo that ≈øaint Patricke liued 122. yeares, and yet by Giraldus Cambren≈øis died in the yeare 458. obijt beatus Patricius anno ab Incarnatione Domini 458. But to followe the mo≈øt receaued opinion, that he liued longer, vntill, or neare the yeare 490. and ≈øo be aboue 30. yeares of Age at the death of ≈øaint Martine his Vncle, he was by all accoÃÑpts borne heare in Britaine of ≈øaint Martins Si≈øter diuers yeares before his Vncle ≈øaint Martine was Bishop of Tours, that gift being in the yeare of Chri≈øt 375. as ≈øaint Gregorius Turonen≈øis Bishop there, after Baronius and others, proue. And a farre longer time before Maximus the Emperour went from hence into France, Gregor. Turon. Hi≈øt. Francor. l. 2. cap. 14. Baron. & Spond. an. 375. Veremund. & Hector. Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. lib. 7. fol. 119. and gaue the name to litle Britaine. The Scottish Hi≈øtorians write, that ≈øaint Martine was al≈øo Vncle to our renowned Britan ≈øaint Ninian, and ≈øo by that is ≈øaid, borne of an other Si≈øter of ≈øaint Martine heare, which may be confirmed by the extraordinary honour, and reuerence he, as al≈øo S. Patricke, euer yelded to S. Martine. Which if it be true, will proue S. Martine with his Si≈øters was heare longe before. For I shall demon≈øtrate that ≈øaint Ninian was an holy Bishop in this Britaine in this Age. And therefore many Hi≈øtorians S. Martine Bishop of Tours Vncle to S. Patrike, and S. Ninian, lyued heare ≈øome time in Britaine. haue expre≈ø≈øely deliuered that ≈øaint Martine did not onely liue ≈øome time in Britaine, but was among other his ≈øingular gifts and graces in that time endowed with the ≈øpirit of Prophe≈øie, and thereby foretold vnto the Emperor Maximus heare in Britaine, before his going from hence, the vnhappy end he should come vnto, Martinus Turanen≈øis Anti≈øtes vir pietatis eximae Maximo praedixi≈ø≈øe fertur, quum in Britannia adhuc e≈ø≈øet infelici≈øsimum eius vitae exitum. So Sabellic. l. 9. Ennead. 7. Polydor. Virgil. Angl. Hi≈øt. l. 3. pag. 5. writeth Sabellicus, and Polidor Virgil in the very ≈øame words, and diuers others before them, as the word, fertur, v≈øed by them both ≈øufficiently proueth, for which we may be bold to v≈øe Seuerus Sulpitius, who wrote ≈øaint Martins life, liuing in that time, and familiarly acquainted with him, for witne≈ø≈øe; for he ≈øpeaking of the comming of ≈øaint Martine to Maximus at Treuers, before his attempting any thing again≈øt Valentinian in Italy, that he should at the fir≈øt preuaile, but shortly after be ouerthrowne and perish, he addeth that ≈øaint Sulpitius Seuer. l. de vit. S. Martini cap. 23. Martine Prophe≈øied this vnto Maximus longe before, S. Martinus eidem Maximo longe ante praedixit futurum, vt ≈øi ad Italiam pergeret, bellum Valentini ano Imperatori inferens, ≈øciret ≈øe primo quidem impetu futurum e≈ø≈øe Victorem, ≈øed paruo po≈øt tempore e≈ø≈øe periturum, quod quidem ita vidimus. Which Prophe≈øie vttered by ≈øaint Martine to Maximus, longe before, mu≈øt needs be heare in Britaine; for after ≈øuch time as ≈øaint Martine was thus renowned, Maximus was not longe time before this, longe ante, any where, but in this our Britaine. And were it not, that the Hi≈øtorie of ≈øaint Martine v≈øually read in the Church on his Fea≈øt ≈øaith he was borne in Pannonia, now called Au≈øtria, we might giue no feeble rea≈øons, that he was borne in Pomonia one of our Ilands, for heare we are ≈øure he was, heare was his Si≈øter, or Si≈øters, heare many of his kindred, heare many Churches and Monuments of honor founded in his name, his name and memory farre more celebrated heare, then in Pannonia, now Au≈øtria, or any other Nation what≈øoeuer excepting France, where he was longe time a mo≈øt
glorious and worthie Bishop. Our Iland Pomonia neare tho≈øe places in Britaine, where ≈øaint Patrike the ≈øonne of his Si≈øter Couche, and ≈øaint Ninian ≈øonne of an other his Si≈øter, by the Scottish Antiquities was borne, often entercour≈øe being betweene our Britaine & France at that time, & of our learned & holy men with ≈øaint Hilary Tutor to ≈øaint Martine, which we cannot by any warrant of Antiquitie affirme of Pannonia or Au≈øtria e≈øpecially Sabaria, now Lazius & Abrah. Ortelius de Ant. Regionib. oppid. & alij in de≈øcrip. Au≈øtriae. named Stain or Stein in the furthe≈øt part thereof, ≈øet downe for the place of his birth by Sulpitius Seuerus not allwayes holding the ≈øounde≈øt opinion in all things, and others afterward from him, from his Authoritie.

3. And except we should vtterly and very rashly deny the Authoritie of S. Bede, William of Malmesbury, the old Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory of the life of ≈øaint Ninian, and others, who≈øe Authoritie we may not neglect, or alltogether condemne the be≈øt Scottish Antiquaries in relation of their owne auncient, and Religious affaires and proceedings, which would bring all our Antiquities into que≈øtion, we mu≈øt needs ≈øay, that ≈øaint Martine and his Si≈øters were in Veremund. Hi≈øt. Scot. Willelm. ab Elphin≈øcun. & Hect. Boeth. Hi≈øt. Scot. l. 7. Britaine heare longe before his ≈øeating him≈øelfe in France: for the≈øe Scottish Antiquaries tell vs, that S. Martine was Vnkle to ≈øaint Ninian Ninianus Epi≈øcopus ≈øanctitate & Miraculis clari≈øsimus, ac Ca≈øae Candidae pontificalis in Galdia ≈øedis primus In≈øtitutor, aedem condidit diuo Martino ≈øuo Auunculo ≈øacram. And ≈øaint Ninian wonderfully allways honored ≈øaint Martine, Sanctum Martinum miro M. S. Antiq. in vit. S. Ninian. Capgrau. in eod. Bed. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 3. c. 3. Henric. Hunting. Hi≈øt. l. 3. Gul. Malme≈ø. l. 3. de ge≈øt. Pont. Angl. vit. S. Nin. Capgrau. in eod. Pit≈ø. & Bal. cum alijs in Ninian. Hect. Boeth. Hi≈øt. Scot. l. 6. f. 108. 109. Hollinsh Hi≈øtor. of Scotl. ≈øemper venerabatur affectu. The Hi≈øtorians both of Scotland and England haue warranted vs ≈øufficiently before, that the Picts who≈øe fir≈øt Apo≈øtle was ≈øaint Ninian, as ≈øaint Bede, Henry of Huntington, William of Malmesbury and others write, Nima Natione Brito primus ibidem Chri≈øti praedicationem Euangelizauit, did receaue the faith of Chri≈øt at the lea≈øt in the time of their King Heirgu≈øtus, when he and his people about the yeare of Chri≈øt 369. or 370. were conuerted Chri≈øtians. By which accompt, if it be true that ≈øaint Ninian was borne of a Si≈øter of ≈øaint Martine, marryed to ≈øaint Ninian his Father heare a Noble and holy Chri≈øtian Britaine, this Si≈øter of ≈øaint Martine mu≈øt needs be marryed heare in Britaine before ≈øuch time as S. Martine came fir≈øt into France by Sulpitius Seuerus and other forreine Hi≈øtorians. And it further inuincibly proueth, that ≈øaint Ninian was in this Age many yeares brought vp at Rome, made Bishop there, and by the Pope ≈øent Apo≈øtle vnto the Picts, longe time ≈øooner, then the common opinion of Antiquaries a≈ø≈øigneth to his comming hither. And euident it is, by all Hi≈øtories, that ≈øaint Martine dying, as before, S. Ninian Apo≈øtle of the Picts a Britan ≈øonne of S. Martins Si≈øter renowned in this time. about the 400. yeare of Chri≈øt, was liuing at Tours in France many yeares after ≈øaint Ninian the Apo≈øtle of the Picts was ≈øent vnto them by the Pope from Rome, and had conuerted them al≈øo. Therefore I may boldly with the Scottish Hi≈øtories accompt him among the holy and learned Fathers of this Age, whereof he ≈øpent a greate parte in mo≈øt holy and au≈øteare conuer≈øation of life, preaching the Gho≈øpell of Chri≈øt, and conuerting Infidels to his true Religion, allthough lyuing longe as the Secretaryes of this greate Saint ≈øay, he ≈øuruiued vntill the next Age, where I shall more remember him. In this place I shall onely entreate of him and his proceedings as they belong vnto, and were done in this fourth hundred of yeares.

4. This holy man borne heare in Britaine in the We≈øterne part thereof, where the Sea diuideth England and Scotland, ≈øo now called, his Father was Manu≈øcr. Ant. in vit. S. Ninian. Io. Capgrau. in eodem. a noble Chri≈øtian and ≈øo great, that the old Writer of his life writing pre≈øently after the Saxons ≈øetling there, as his words of Brittish Kings there ruling within the memory of ≈øome then liuing, quorundam memoria comprobatur, doe
≈øufficieÃÑtly proue, calleth him a King, Pater eius Rex fuit Religione Chri≈øtianus. His Mother, as his Neighbouring Antiquaries of Scotland haue told vs, was Si≈øter to ≈øaint Martine, not Couche the Mother of ≈øaint Patrike, being greate difference M. S. Antiq. Laurent. Surius, & Zachar. Lippol. die 17. Martij in S. Patricio & alij. euen in time betweene their births, and ≈øaint Patriks Mother hauing no other ≈øonne but him, as Hi≈øtorians agree Calphurnius ex Couche≈ø≈øa S. Martini Turonen≈øis ≈øorore vnicum concepit filium S. Patricium, but an other, who≈øe name I doe not finde particularly, neither what his Father was called, in any Writter, but onely that he was ≈øo Noble, that he is ≈øtiled Rex, a King, and his ≈øonne ≈øaint Ninian, regali ex pro≈øapia Ninianus extitit oriundus, di≈øcended by his Brittish Parents of Regall Race. Who when he was very young, cum annos pueriles tran≈øegi≈ø≈øet, contemning all worldly things, went on Pilgrimage to Rome, where the Pope, which then was ≈øaint Silue≈øter as it will shew by the time hereafter, committed him to be in≈øtructed in holy learning, and Religion to cho≈øen Tutors in ≈øuch things; he continued in the≈øe ≈øacred Studies at Rome diuers yeares, vntill he was perfectly there indued with the knowledge of Chri≈øtian My≈øteries, Erat Romae regulariter fidem & my≈øteria veritatis edoctus, Bed. Hi≈øt. l. 3. cap. 4. as ≈øaint Bede writeth of him, and by the old Writer of his life, he continued there many yeares in the≈øe ≈øacred Studies, and worthie Conuer≈øation, and perfect pietie, that the Pope hearing there were ≈øome people in the We≈øt parts of Britaine, the Pictish Nation, which had not yet receaued the faith of Chri≈øt, con≈øecrated him Bishop, and ≈øent him for their Apo≈øtle vnto them, pluribus annis in vrbe laudabiliter conuer≈øatus & in ≈øacris Scripturis ≈øufficienter eruditus ad virtutum ≈øumma prouehitur, & pennis charitatis ≈øubuectus ad caelestia contemplanda ≈øu≈øtollitur. Audiens deinde Pontifex Romanus quo≈ødam in Occidujs Britanniae partibus necdum fidem Chri≈øti ≈øu≈øcepi≈ø≈øe, ad Epi≈øcopatus graduÃÑ Ninianum con≈øecrauit, & praemi≈ø≈øae genti data benedictione Apo≈øtolum de≈øtinauit.
