Albinus in an Epi≈øtle to the Religeous men inhabiting there; maketh this memory of the ≈øanctity of that place, and worthines of the miraculous man there buried, as William of Malmesbury citeth him, Scribit Alicuinus in Epistola ad Fratres eiu≈ødem loci (Candidae Ca≈øae) dicens: deprecor ve≈øtrae pietatis vnanimitatem, vt no≈øtri nominis habeatis memoriam in Eccle≈øia ≈øanctiti≈øsimi patris vestri Nimae Epi≈øcopi, qui multis claruit virtutibus, ≈øicut mihi nuper delatum e≈øt per carmina metricae artis, quae nobis per fideles no≈øtros di≈øcipulos Eboracen≈øis Eccle≈øiae ≈øchola≈øticos, directa ≈øunt, in quibus & facientis cognoui eruditionem, & facientis miracula ≈øanctitatem. Where we haue the mo≈øt learned Authour of this Land and his Age an ample witne≈ø≈øe of the learning, holines, & miracles of this renowned Bishop, Apo≈øtle, and fir≈øt Conuerter of the Picts, & by ≈øome of the Southerne Scots al≈øo Io. Pit≈ø. ≈øupr. to Chri≈øt, Omnium primus Pictos & Au≈øtrales Scotos ab Idolorum cultu, ad fidem Chri≈øti perduxit.

10. We finde in this Age al≈øo many others, renowned men and Saints of this Manny Brothers and Si≈øters children of Prince Bragbam Saints in this time. Kingdome. Braghan ≈øtiled King of Brecknocke a Noble BritaÃÑ who had 12. ≈øoÃÑnes, and ≈øo many daughters, all of them holy Seruants of Chri≈øt, and happy Saints, Rex Breghenocen≈øium: Fuerunt Regi illi filij duodecim, & filiae totidem, omnes Deo placentes & vitae ≈øanctae. Among the≈øe ≈øaint Canoch his elde≈øt ≈øonne and Manu≈øcr. Ant. in vit. S. Keinae Virg. Capgrau. in eadem. Manu≈øcript. & Gapgrau. ≈øupr. & in S. Cadoco. & in S. Gundleo. Heire for≈øaking his wordly honor, and glory, gaue him≈øelfe wholly to the contemplatiue and Religeous life and e≈øtate, therein long liuing, and dying a glorious Saint. His elde≈øt daughter S. Gladus or Gladu≈øa was married to King Gundleus al≈øo a Saint, and they were the happy Parents of that our Illu≈øtrious Eremite, Monke, Bishop, and Martyr ≈øaint Cadocus. The ≈øecond daughter named Melari or Melaria was Mother to ≈øaint Dauid our greate and renowned Archbishop his Father. An other of the holy daughters was ≈øaint Keina who liuing a ≈øacred virgin in a mo≈øt ≈øtrickt and au≈øteare cour≈øe of life, was Miraculous at her birth, in her whole life, at and after her death. The re≈øt of the≈øe holy children are not ≈øo well remembred in our Hi≈øtories, but ≈øo in generall, as I haue related. King and Saint Gundleus husband of the elde≈øt daughter and Father of ≈øaint Cadocus, leauing his Rule and dignitie to his ≈øonne ≈øaint Cadocus, S. Gundleus how holy & Religeous. who shortly after al≈øo re≈øigned it, for the loue of the heauenly Kingdome, builded a Church, and there liued in greate au≈øteritie and penance all his life, many yeares: his foode was bread of Barley the third part of Ashes, and water: his inward cloathing, ≈øackcloth, he hauing for≈øaken all, & ≈øo much as the State of ≈øuch a King, neuer receaued any thing from others but liued by his labour, euer at midnight ri≈ø≈øing; and diuing him≈øelfe in the cold water, Regale Palatium de≈øeruit, & regno Cadoco filio ≈øuo commendato, ad monticulum ≈øibi ab Angelo nuntiatum peruenit, & Eccle≈øiam con≈øtruxit, & ibi in magna ab≈øtinentia & vitae ≈øanctimonia viuere caepit: Vtebatur autem cilicio & pane hordeaceo & cinere in tertia parte admixto, aquamque potare con≈øueuit, nocte vero media ≈øurgens in aquam frigidam ≈øe immer≈øit, & nihil de alieno ≈øumens, proprio labore vitam duxit. And thus M. S. Antiq. & Capgr. in S. Cadoco. Caradoc. in vit. S. Gildae Capgr. in eod. & S. Dauide M. S. & Capgrau in S. Carautoco. per≈øeuered to his death, being very old in the next Age, where I shall ≈øpeake more of him, and his holy ≈øonne S. Cadocus, who in this Age al≈øo began to be famous.

11. So was S. Gildas Albanius both a renowned Preacher and Miraculous man in this time. S. Carautocus al≈øo Sonne and Heire to king Kederic, hearing that his Father being very old, intended to re≈øigne his Rule and gouernment
vnto him, fledd ≈øecretly a way in poore atty ‚Ä¢ e and embraced the Relig ‚Ä¢ ous life, and proued ≈øo excellent a man, euen in this time, that he preached in Ireland 30. yeares before S. Dauid was borne, who≈øe birth was in this time. T ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ginta S. Gildas and S. Caratocus were now renowned. annis ante natiuitateÃÑ ≈øanct. Dauid Epi≈øcopi in Hibernia co ‚Ä¢ uer≈øari ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ pit. Multos populos in Hibernia ad fidem coÃÑuertit. And it ≈øeemeth by the old Writer of S. Cadoc his life, that he was euen in this Age a renowned man, hauing be≈øides S. Cadocus now renowned. his holy conuer≈øation and preaching in Britaine, both in the part now named EnglaÃÑd, as that called Scotland 7. yeares. He went on Pilgrimage three times to Hieru≈øalem, ≈øeuen times to Rome, and once to the holy Relicks of S. Andrew, newly brought hither in this Age by S. Regulus, as I shall ≈øet downe So S. Goudwall an holy Bishop or Archbishop. heareafter, where he was admonished by an Angell to ≈øtay and preach 7. yeares. S. Gudwall al≈øo was renowned in this Age both in Britaine and other place Gudw√†lus BritaÃÑniae finibus ortus ex nobili pro≈øapia, of Noble pareÃÑtage, he was Manu≈øcr. Ant. de vit. S. Gudwal. Capgrau. in eod. Sur. Tom. 3. Molan. add. ad V≈øuard. Franc. Haraeus 6. Iun. Auth. of Engl. Martyr. die 22. Febr. & 6. Iunij. brought vp in learning, was con≈øecrated Prei≈øt, and after Bishop, and by ≈øome an Archbishop in this Kingdome. And that he might more quietly giue him≈øelfe ouer to the contemplatiue life, placing a worthie Bishop and Succe≈ø≈øor in his Pa≈øtorall charge, and place, went into a Mona≈øtery within his Dioce≈ø≈øe, hard by the Sea, and there with an hunded and four≈øcore Monkes liued a mo≈øt holy and Miraculous life. He and his holy company in ≈øeuen ships went ouer into Flamders, and preached there, where, by ≈øome, he died, and was fir≈øt buryed at BlaÃÑdine neare GaÃÑt; but Capgraue with the Antiquities which he followeth, affirmeth his body was buryed heare in Britaine, in an Ile called then Plecit, where it re≈øted with greate honour, vntill the Chri≈øtian Britans, bannished out of their Country by per≈øecuting Pagans, carried his holy Relicks with them, and buryed them in that Mona≈øtery of Blandine, Peractis annorum multorum curriculis ob infe≈øtationem Barbarorum & Paganorum gens Britannica magn√¢ ex parte hinc & inde disper≈øa relictis ≈øedibus per orbem diffu≈øa e≈øt. Hinc fratres a≈øsuÃÑpto corpore ≈øancto mare tran≈øeuntes Franciam adeunt, & apud Clarum montem in Mona≈øterio Blandinion locum perpetuae reliquiarum ≈øanctarum quietis eligunt. It is agreed by all, that he died on the ≈øixt day of Iune, ≈øexto Idus Iunij. A Engl. Martyr 6. Iunij. late writer ≈øaith in one place, he finally repo≈øed in our Lord, about the yeare of Chri≈øt, foure hundred and three. Through forgetting him≈øelfe, or, mi≈øtaken by his printer, in an other place he writeth, full of venerable olde Age, in greate ≈øanctitie and Febr. 22. holines of life, he re≈øted in our Lord, about the yeare of Chri≈øt, three hundred and fourtie, and was one of the fir≈øt of our Iland that preached the Chri≈øtian faith in Flanders. But by all, this Age is the time of his holy life.

12. We finde al≈øo in the authenticall life of S. Dauid v≈øed in his Eccle≈øia≈øticall Breuiar. Eccle≈ø. Sarisb. in Fe≈øto‚ñ™ S. Dauidis lect. 6. Office in the Brittish and English Church, that Eluueus was Bishop of Meneuia, after called S. Dauids, before S. Dauid was borne, and had the honor to bapti≈øe that renowned man, when he was new borne and for his performing Elueus Bishop of Meneuia in this Age. that holy office, a mo≈øt cleare Well neuer appearing before ≈øprang vp to bapti≈øe him in, ad ip≈øius baptizandi mini≈øterium fons limpidi≈øsimae aquae emanauit, qui nunquam antea vi≈øus fuit. And this Bishop at that time was newly returned out of Ireland, cum baptizaretur ab Eluueo Meneuen≈øi Epi≈øcopo redeunte de Hibernia. And ≈øo had gone thither as it ≈øeemeth about ≈øome Epi≈øcopall bu≈øines belonging Men ‚Ä¢ uia probably an Epi≈øcopall See before S. Dauids time. vnto his chardge and office there. Which approued te≈øtimony ≈øufficiently proueth vnto vs, that Meneuia was an Epi≈øcopall See longe before S. Dauid his ≈øetling the Archiepi≈øcopall See there. And if this Bishop S. Eluueus had then charge in Ireland, that it was euen then the See Epi≈øcopall, the Archbishop ≈øome time re≈øideÃÑt there, ≈øome time at Caerlegion. I shall ≈øpeake more
of more both of this, & our other Archiepi≈øcopall Sees, of other Bishops heareafter. And heare now al≈øo may I probably place S. Liephard a Brittish Bishop, S. Liephard a Bishop of Britaine a Martyr in this Age. Saint, and Martyr, glorious euen in forreine Countries. For it is reade of him, that being borne heare in Britaine, and con≈øecrated Bishop in our Primatiue Church, and going on Pilgrimage to Rome, in his returne from thence in the Territory of Cambray in Hennalt, at a place called HuÃÑcourt, foure miles from the named Citie, was put to death by Pagan theeues; and his Fea≈øt is celebrated in the Church of Cambray on the fourth day of February. That he was a Molan. addit. ad v≈øuardum. Index SS. Belgij. Hereb. in fa≈øtis SS. Engl. Martyrolog. 4. Febr. Bishop in our Primatiue Church of Britaine, and put to death by Pagans in that Prouince, where Pagans will not ea≈øily be founde in later times, will giue ≈øome warrant to place him in this Age.

div.head: THE XXVI. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF THE HONORABLE TRANSLATION OF the Relicks of S. Andrew Apo≈øtle from Achaia to Britaine by S. Regulus. The greate reuerence both Princes and others heare gaue vnto them, and ≈øuch, and profe≈ø≈øed in other matters the Religion, which Catholiks now doe.

div.p: 1. AS this our Britaine was made happy in the time of the Apo≈øtles, with the pre≈øence, and preaching of the cheife Apo≈øtles S. Peter and S. Paule: So now in this Age and time, ≈øo longe after their deaths, and the re≈øt of tho≈øe cho≈øen di≈øciples of Chri≈øt, to teach vs that they which be happily decee≈øed out of this mortall, and entered into the heauenly life, and triumphant Church, may and doe by many meanes help, a≈ø≈øi≈øt, and comforte his militant Seruants, and Souldiars in this worlde, it plea≈øed his diuine Maie≈øtie, Miraculou≈øly, as our Antiquaries and Arguments vndeniable proue vnto vs, to honor this Nation and greate Iland with Epiphan. Haere≈ø. 51. the ≈øacred Relicks of that glorious Martyr and Apo≈øtle S. Andrew, by naturall birth elder brother to S. Peter.

2. And to te≈øtifie how greate a Iewell they and ≈øuch are, he cau≈øed theÃÑ to be tran≈øported ≈øo farre and longe a ≈øpace and di≈øtance, as betweene the place of Eu≈øeb. l. 4. vitae Con≈øtant. Socr. l. 1. cap. vlt. Hier. de Script. Eccle≈ø. in Luc. aduer≈ø. Vigil. in Chron. Chry≈øo≈øt. Or. quod Chri≈øtus ≈øit Deus. Veremun. Hect. Boeth. Scot. Hi≈øt. l. 6. Hollin. Hi≈øt. of Scotl. in Fethelmacus. his Martyrdome in Achaia, to the remote parts of this Kingdome, and in this order. Con≈øtantine the greate Emperour fouÃÑding at Con≈øtaÃÑtinople the Church of the 12. Apo≈øtles with their Images, and memoryes, and his owne place of buriall betweene them, as Eu≈øebius, Socrates, S. Hierome and others are worthie witne≈ø≈øes, and prouiding to tran≈ølate many of their holy Relicks thither, hoping thereby to procure greate profit to his ≈øoule, quamplurimum vtilitatis illorum memoriam animae ≈øuae conciliaturam exi≈øtimans. Neque vo ‚Ä¢ a eius expectationemque fefellit Deus: AmoÃÑg others employed in this Religious worke S. Regulus an holy Abbot, and Father of many vertuous Monkes at Patras in Achaia, where S. Andrew was Martyred, multorum verae pietati addictoruÃÑ in Patris ciuitate Pater atque Praeceptor, and his ≈øacred Relicks kept with greate reuerence,
who watching and praying at S. Andrewes Shrine th ‚Ä¢ re, being the cheife≈øt man, which by the Edict of the Emperour were ≈øent to worship tho≈øe Relik ‚Ä¢
Relicks of Saints reuerenced. of the Apo≈øtle, which the Emperour him≈øelfe meruailou≈øly reuerenced, ex ill ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ praecip ‚Ä¢ us, qui Imperatoris Edicto, diui Andreae Apo≈øtoli Reliqu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s venerationi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øain quos ip≈øe mira d ‚Ä¢ cebatur pietate a≈øsi≈øterent, fuerant de≈øtinati, was ‚Ä¢ dmonished from heauen, to take parte of tho≈øe holy Reliks, a bone of the arme, three fingers, and three Toes of that Apo≈øtle, & bring them decently into the Iland of Albion, in the remote parte of the world, that the people there deuotely reuerencing ≈øaint Andrew, might by the goodnes of God by his Ieterce≈ø≈øion obtaine both earthly and heauenly ble≈ø≈øings, Cum ≈øacras ad Scriniolum ageret vigilias ≈øuperne monitus e≈øt, vt accepto ≈øacrati brachij o≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ , tribus digitis, totidemque alterius pedis articulis, ac in va≈øculum decenter repo≈øitis, Albionem In≈øulam in extremo orbis rece≈ø≈øu ≈øitam peteret: futurum enim vt illie aliquando, populus pia veneratione, in diuum Andream ductus, Dei beneuolenti√¢ & terrena & caele≈øtia, eius ≈øuffragio a≈ø≈øequeretur chari≈ømata.

3. By which direction S. Regulus taking the holy Reliks with diuers other very holy men for his A≈ø≈øociats, tooke this long Iorney in hand, and after many dangers landed with the≈øe holy Relicks, and his companions in that part of this Iland now called S. Andrewes, from that time of his holy Reliks taking that name of honor, then a poore Village in Pictland, now in the diui≈øion of Scotland. The fame hereof being ≈øpreed through the Country of the Picts, very many re≈øorted to vi≈øit and reuerence the≈øe holy Reliks, & from all places thereabouts, brough gifts to offer to the holy Apo≈øtle, ConfluxeruÃÑt illuc vndique donaria Christi Apo≈øtolo offerentes. Among the≈øe was Heirgu≈øtus King of the Picts, whom S. Regulus and his Religious company entertained with a ioyfull maner of Proce≈ø≈øion, in Hymnes and Canticles. The King Pro≈øtrating him≈øelfe vpon the ground ki≈ø≈øed the ≈øacred Reliks, with greate reuerence, and after Ma≈ø≈øe, whereof the King was mo≈øt ob≈øeruant, ended, he gaue his owne Palace to S. Andrewe, S. Regulus, and the Prei≈øts, to ≈øerue God Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, with ve≈øtiments and ornaments beloÃÑging to Prei≈øts at Ma≈ø≈øe. there. And he builded an other Church not farre off dedicated to S. Andrew the Apo≈øtle. Which he did endowe with mo≈øt ample gifts, as Chalices, Lauatories, and other ve≈ø≈øels of gold, and ≈øyluer with very co≈øtely Prei≈øtly, and Church Ornaments to continue for euer, belonging to the holy Sacrifice, ornauit & id templum Donarijs ampli≈øsimis, pateris, cyphis, calicibus, peluibus, laxacris ex argento auroque, ac alia praetio≈øa ≈øupellectili in ≈øacrorum v≈øum quae≈øita ≈øacerdotibus ad diuina perpetuo exequenda ibidem costitutis. This example of King Heirgu≈øtus was long time followed by the Kings of the Picts, ≈øo long as they continued there, and by the Kings of the Scots after po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing tho≈øe parts, honoring S. Andrew for the Patron of their Country, Heirgusti exemplum longa Regum ≈øeries primo, Pictorum deinde Scotorum, qui deletis Pictis ea loca tenuerunt religio≈øe e≈øt in≈øequuta, Diuum Andream pro numine habentes tutelari. Which the Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians them≈øelues, both Scots and others, doe freely and plainly confe≈ø≈øe, as being a certaine and vndeniable true Hi≈øtorie, agreeing both in Boeth. l. 6. fol. 109. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Scotl. ≈øupr. the time, place, and other circum≈øtances of the miraculous ≈øending and tran≈øporting the≈øe holy Reliks into this kingdome in the place remembred, from Patras in Achaia about the yeare of Chri≈øt 369. and the greate deuotion, & reuerence, wherewith they were receaued and pre≈øerued heare.

4. The fir≈øt Religious men which were placed in this new Mona≈øtery with Culdeyes the old Monkes heare, mo≈øt holymen. S. Regulus and his company, were tho≈øe which the Scots and Picts for their ≈øingular pietie and Religion honored with the Title Culdeis, Sacerdotes Deicultores
vulgo appellati, Prei≈øts commonly called Worshippers of God, the≈øe were fir≈øt placed in it, Fuere in eo √† primae ‚Ä¢ a eius conditione primum Sacerdotes Dei cultores vulgo appellati. The≈øe Culdeis were Britans of tho≈øe parts, where the Romans ruled, and the Per≈øecution of Diocle≈øian extended it ≈øelfe and raged, which fled to the Scots not ≈øo ≈øubiect to the Romans, for ≈øuccour in that raging time, and many of them after the Per≈øecution ended, continued there ≈øtill preaching vnto the Scots, many of the≈øe conuerted, ioyning with them in that holy Religious life, and remayned there to many generations in greate honor and Sanctitie reuerenced both of Kings & Subiects, as all Antiquaries euen Prote≈øtants thus confe≈ø≈øe in the Reigne of King Finchormach, or Finchomarke a litle before this time, and diuers hundreds of yeares after, Scoti liberati Georg. Buchan. Rer. Scoticar. l. 4 in Reg. 35. Finchomarcho. Holinsh. Hi≈øtor. of Scotl. in Fincomarke. curis externis, nihil prius habuerunt, quam vt religionem Chri≈øtianam promouerent, occa≈øione illinc orta, qu√≤d multi ex Brittonibus Chri≈øtianis, ≈øaeuitiam Diocletiani timentes, ad eos confugerant: √® quibus complures, doctrina & vitae integritate clari in Scotia ≈øub≈øtiterunt, vitamque ≈øolitariam taÃÑta ≈øanctitatis opinione apud omnes vixerunt, vt vita functorum cella in templa commutarentur, ex eoque con≈øuetudo man≈øit apud Po≈øteros, vt pri≈øci Scoti templa cellas vocent. Hoc genus Monachorum Culdeos appellabant: Man≈øitque nomen & institutum, donec Monachorum genus recentius eos expulit. By which te≈øtimonie of Antiquaries euen Prote≈øtants, it is both proued, that our auncient learned and Religious Britans, as S. Ninian and his A≈ø≈øociates, and our Brittish holy Prei≈øts, and Culdies were principall in≈øtruments in conuerting, as well the Scottish, as Pictish Nations to the faith of Chri≈øt, and that the Pope of Rome which directed S. Ninian Religion then heare, the ≈øame with that of the pre≈øent Roman Church. hither, he, and the Picts whom he conuerted, our British Prei≈øts and Culdeis, and the Scots receauing in≈øtruction in Religion from them, and the Church of Greece with who≈øe Monkes all the≈øe ioyned, were Profe≈ø≈øors of one and the ≈øame Catholike faith in the Sacrifice of Ma≈ø≈øe, and Ceremonials thereof, prayer and inuocation to Saints in heauen, their protection towards men on earth, worshipping their Reliks, Pilgrimages to holy Places, Religious Mona≈øticall life, and ≈øuch others before expre≈ø≈øed by them. From the≈øe Monkes and Culdeis the Bishops of tho≈øe parts were cho≈øen vntill Pope Cele≈øtine ≈øent Boeth. l. 7. f. 133. S. Palladius hither, Antea ex Monachis & Culdeis Pontifices a≈ø≈øumerentur. And they preached and taught the Lawe of Chri≈øt throughout all the l. 6. f. 102. Scots Countries, Chri≈øti Seruatoris doctrinam per omnes Scotor ‚Ä¢ m Regiones concionando multis pij≈øque ≈øudoribus ≈øeminantes.

5. And although this Hi≈øtory of S. Regulus in comming ≈øo longe a iorney with tho≈øe ≈øacred Reliks, and the greate reuerence the Northren parts of this Kingdome then gaue vnto them, may ≈øeeme ≈øtrange to men not well affected to ≈øuch holy duties, and ignorant in the deuotion and Religion of the≈øe times: yet they may learne this was not ≈øingular to the Gretians, Picts, and Scots, but to all other Chri≈øtan Nations, e≈øpecially the Britans, not to ≈øeeke further then belongeth to their Hi≈øtory. For as S. Regulus brought tho≈øe holy Reliks Pilgrimages to holy Reliks of Saints. out of Greece, ≈øo our Britans in the≈øe times went into Syria, as farre as Antioch on Pilgrimage to S. Simeon Stellita to worship ≈øacred things there, & tooke it for a greate happines & ble≈ø≈øing to bring froÃÑ thence any litle peece Nicen. Concil. 2. Theod. Hi≈øt. Sanctorum Patrum in S. Simeone. Euagr. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 1‚ñ™ c. 13. of a Thong cutt from his leather Coate, and in Rome it≈øelfe they thought it to be a greate protection, to haue but a litle Image of him to ≈øtand at the entries of their hou≈øes, as both the ≈øecond Nicen Councell, and Theodoret are ample witne≈ø≈øes, Non ≈øolum confluebant qui no≈øtram habitant Regionem, ≈øed & I≈ømaelitae & Per≈øae & Armenij qui ≈øunt eis ≈øubiecti, & Iberos & Homeritae, & qui illis ≈øunt
interiores. Venerunt autem multi quoque qui habitant extrema Occidentis, Hi≈øpani inquam, & Britanni, & Galli, qui quod est intermedium occupant. De Italia enim ≈øuperuacaneum e≈øt dicere. Aiunt enim Romae, quae e≈øt long√® maxima, eum fui≈ø≈øe adeo omnium ≈øermone celebratum, vt in officinarum omnibus ve≈øtibulis & Porticibus ei paruas po≈øuerint Imagines, hinc ≈øibi prae≈øidium & tutelam parantes. Cum ergo venirent innumerabiles, conabantur omnes contrectare, & ex pelliceis illis ve≈øtibus aliquam percipere benedictionem. Where we ≈øee yet the Religion & deuotioÃÑ not of Manu≈øcr. Antiq. & Capgr. in Vit. S. Cadoci Epi≈øcopi & Martyris. a few, but many Britans then, multi Britanni to goe ≈øo farre on Pilgrimage to holy par≈øons, places and Reliks: among tho≈øe, our glorious, Monke, Abbot, Bishop and Martyr S. Cadocus went thri≈øe on Pilgrimage to Hieru≈øalem, ≈øeuen times to Rome, and to the≈øe Reliks of S. Andrew in Scotland, ≈øtaying preaching there ≈øeuen yeares, as is al≈øo before remembred.

div.head: THE XXVII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF MANY RENOWNED ARCHBISHOPS OF all our Archiepi≈øcopall Sees heare, many other learned and holy Bishops and Apostolike men heare in this time: and their Religion, the Catholike Religion.

div.p: 1. WE reade in this time there was a learned Bishop, or as Trithemius ≈øtileth him, Archbishop of the Scots, called Hildebertus, Tutor, and In≈øtructor of that renowned learned Father of this Nation Caelius Sedulius, Sedulius Hildeberti Scotorum Archiepi≈øcopi ab ineunte aetate Di≈øcipulus. Io. Trithem. l. de Script. Eccl. in Sedulio. Ioa. Bal. lib. de Scrit. Britan. in Caelio Sedulio. Others giue him onely the Title, a very learned Bishop of the Scots, Hildebertus eruditus Scotorum Prae≈øul. But if we vnder≈øtand this in that common ≈øence, and meaning as Bishops and Archbishops of places are taken, and vnder≈øtood, that Hildebertus should be Archbishop of any See or Citie among the Scots, ≈øainct Palladius being by all Antiquities ≈øet downe to be their fir≈øt Archbishop, excepting the Archbishops Hildebertus the learned Tutor of Caelius Sedulus probably Archbishop of Yorke. of Yorke, and he ≈øent by Papall and extraordinary Authoritie, as Apo≈øtle to that Nation, I dare not ioyne with them further in opinioÃÑ herein, then ≈øay he was in this Age one of our Archbishops of Yorke, and by that right & Title Archbishop of all, Scots, or what≈øoeuer Chri≈øtian people in the North parts, and Ilands of this kingdome Britaine vnder that Archiepi≈øcopall Iuri≈ødiction, by Pope Eleutherius fir≈øt order and In≈øtitution.

2. Which I may further confirme by the authoritie of all them which call him Archbishop of the Scots, they al≈øo teaching that he was In≈øtructor of Author. apud Bellarm. lib. de Script. in Sedul. Io. Trithem. in Caelio Sedul. Bal. in eod. cent. 1. Iodoc. Cocc. in Catal. Scriptor. Sedulius in his youÃÑger yeares, √† tenera aetate, and tho≈øe that write of Sedulius the time wherein he florished and died; ≈øome place his deth vnder CoÃÑ≈øtantius ≈øonne to Con≈øtantin the Greate, ≈øome in the 430. yeare of Chri≈øt, others in the yeare 460. by none of the≈øe Accompts could Hildebertus be otherwi≈øe called Archbishop of the Scots, then in that meaning I haue deliuered. At the time of the fir≈øt accompt, the Scots were not in this kingdome, as I haue made manife≈øt before, and before Hildebertus could be Tutor to Sedulius by either of the later reckonings, the Scots were probably driuen out of Britaine by
Maximus, about the yeare 379. when Sedulius being long time Scholler to this Bishop, mu≈øt needs be old in the 430. of Chri≈øt and much older, neare an hundred yeares old, if he liued vnto the yeare 460. yet he is not by any Writer noted for an old man. We cannot ≈øay, that this Hildebertus was Archbishop of the Scots in Ireland; for although diuers hold, that diuers of the Scotish Irish had receaued the faith of Chri≈øt before ≈øaint Palladius, or S. Patrike were ≈øent vnto that Nation by Pope Cele≈øtine, yet it is made plaine by the old Writer of the life of ≈øainct Modwenna and others, that at the comming of ≈øainct Patrike thither, the Irish people there were eyther Pagans for the mo≈øt part, or not well in≈øtructed in Chri≈øtiaÃÑ ReligioÃÑ: gentes illae partim Paganicis erroribus M. S. Antiq. de vit. S. Modeuen. Virg. Capgrau. Catal. in eadem. inuolutae, partim fidem nondum plen√® intelligebant. Which could not be probably truely ≈øaid of any Nation hauing ≈øo learned an Archbishop, as Hildebertus is proued to haue bene, with other Bishops, Prei≈øts, and Cleargie men as that greate dignitie inferreth, and bringeth with it. And the Antiquaries not onely of this, but other Nations agree, that ≈øainct Palladius was the fir≈øt Archbishop, or rather Bishop that was euer ≈øent into Ireland in the time of Pope Io. Trithem. l. de Script. Eccl. fol. 26. in Pallado. Cele≈øtine, and by him long after this Age, Palladius Britannorum ≈øeu Scotorum In≈øulae Hibernien≈øis √† Caele≈øtino Papa primus ordinatus Epi≈øcopus. Where Trithemius calleth him the fir≈øt Bishop, no Archbishop of that people, yet he confe≈ø≈øeth that ≈øainct Patrike was immediatly after, & by the ≈øame Pope made Archbishop there, Po≈øt quem ≈øanctus Patricius genere Brittus √† ≈øancto Caele≈øtino Papa con≈øecratus in Archiepi≈øcopum Hibernien≈øem.

3. I doe not find the names of any others, either certainely, or probably remenbred in Hi≈øtories to haue bene Archbishops of Yorke in this Age, except Archbishops of London in this time. Taurinus ≈øpoaken of before, did in the beginning thereof ≈øupply that place of dignitie there. The names of the Archbishops of LondoÃÑ haue bene better pre≈øerued, amoÃÑg which in this CeÃÑtenary of yeares we finde fir≈øt S. StepheÃÑ, commonly Will Harri≈øon. de≈øcript. of Engl. Stowe Hi≈øt. in Lucius. Godwin. Catal. of Bishop London. Harris Hi≈øt. Manu≈øcr. l. 4. cap. 7. by our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries accounpted the ≈øeuenth Archbishop there, to which ≈øome Catholike Hi≈øtorians, as M. Harris in his Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory ≈øeemeth to agree: But ≈øeeing I haue proued S. Augulus our holy Archbishop, & Martyr, whom they pa≈ø≈øe ouer to haue bene Archbishop there, ioyning with Theanus, Eluanus, Cadar, Obinus, ConaÃÑ, & Palladius, all which they place & reckoÃÑ before StepheÃÑ, there be fouÃÑd ≈øeuen Archbishops there before him, and he cannot be the ≈øeuenth, but the eight in that See. Next to StepheÃÑ they accoumpt in this Age, Iltut or Iltuta, after him Re≈øtitutus, which was at the Councell of Arles ≈øpoken of before, then Dedwyn, Theodwyn, Tadwyne Tatwyne or Tacwyne, then Thedred Tidred or Theodred. An old Manu≈øcr. Hi≈øt. Gallic. an. 427. Gennad. in Catal. honor. ib. Philip. Berg. Hi≈øt. Io. Trith. l. de Script. Eccl. in Fa≈øtidio. French Manu≈øcript Hi≈øtory te≈øtifieth, that one named Gouncelyn was Archbishop of London about this time. And whereas both Gennadius, Honorius, Philippus Bergomen≈øis, Trithemius and other ≈øtrangers tell vs, that Fa≈øtidius about this time was a Brittish Bishop very learned, a deuoute and worthie both Preacher and Writer, and therefore by them regi≈øtred among the holy Writers of his time: Fastidius Epi≈øcopus Britannorum in Scripturis ≈øacris eruditus, & verbi Dei Praedicator egregius, vita quoque & conuer≈øatione illu≈øtris, ≈øermone Fa≈øtidius not improbably Archbishop of London. & ingenio clarus, ≈øcrip≈øit nonnulla deuota opu≈øcula: ≈øome of our owne Writers ≈øay, he was Archbishop of London, which the recited Authors rather approue, then impugne, when they ≈øtile him Bishop of the Britans, meaning Io. Bal. l. de Script. Brit. cent. 1. in Fa≈øtid. Pri≈øc. Io. Pit≈ø. aetat. 5. in eod. by that phra≈øe properly ≈øpoaken, that he was cheife or Archbishop of them, Fa≈øtidius Epi≈øcopus Londinen≈øis Metropolis, &, ad Archiepi≈øcopatum Londonen≈øem euectus. Aluueus ≈øpoaken of before, that baptized S. Dauid, Tremaunus vrbis
Legionum Archiepi≈øcopus, and Amaloers, are thought to be Archbishops Galfr. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 8. c. 10. of Caerlegion. Very litle memory be≈øides their names of tho≈øe of London is left except tho≈øe I haue ≈øpoaken of before. Yet by good Arguments though Archbishops of Caerlegion in this time. more generall, both from auncient forreine, and dome≈øticall Writers, we are a≈ø≈øured they were learned and holy Catholike Archbishops, gouerning the people vnder them in vertue, and true beleife. This is confe≈ø≈øed by Prote≈øtant Antiquaries before, making the Britans both Cleargie and others orthodoxe, true beleeuers, and good people longe after this Age, by our Brittish Hi≈øtories in the greate≈øt ≈øway of libertie, and wickedne≈ø≈øe heare by the Saxons entry, the Archbishops Bishops and others of the Cleargie. Heare were holy and truely Religious, and ≈øo continued ≈øo longe as their temporall gouernment continued, in ≈øo much that when ≈øainct Augu≈øtin came hither The Bishops of Britayne now learned, truely Catholike, and holy men. and there was then but one Archbishopricke, and ≈øeuen Bishopricks left by the Pagan Saxons, they were all furnished with mo≈øt Religious Prelats, In parte Britonum vigebat Christianitas, quae √† tempore Eleutherij Papae habita, nunquam inter eos defecerat. Augustinus inuenit in eorum Prouincia ≈øeptem Epi≈øcopatus & Archiepi≈øcopatum religio≈øi≈øsimis Pr ‚Ä¢ ≈øulibus muni ‚Ä¢ os, & Abbatias complures Galfrid. Mon. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 11. cap. 12. Bed. Hi≈øt. l. 2. cap. 2. Io. Go≈øcelin. Hi≈øt. Eccl. Parker l. antiq. Brit. p. 8. in quibus Grex Domini rectum ordinem tenebat. And S. Bede al≈øo te≈øtifieth, the≈øe Bishops and others of the Brittish Cleargie were mo≈øt learned men, Septem Britonum Epi≈øcopi & plures viri docti≈øsimi. And other our Hi≈øtorians euen Prote≈øtants doe proue, that not onely in that Age, and this we haue now in haÃÑd, but in euery other, in quouis ≈øaculo, Britaine had ≈øuch learned Prelats. And for forreine Writers, euen tho≈øe which were mo≈øt renowned in the world in their dayes euen in this very time, they witne≈ø≈øe as much of our Brittish Bishops. I Britaine now an holy and Religious kingdome. haue cited S. Hilary for the Latine, and S. Athana≈øius for the Greeke Church before, to ≈øuch proofe and purpo≈øe. S. Chry≈øo≈øtome often ≈øpeaketh of the Chry≈øo≈øt. Tom. 4. Hom. 28. coÃÑm. in c. 18. Epi≈øt. 2. ad Corinth. apud Speede Theat. of Brit. l. 6. Serm. de Pentec. Tom. 3. greate deuotion and Religion of our Britans, how firme they were in the true faith of Chri≈øt, builded Churches, and Altars, & offered the holy Sacrifice on them, and not onely our Prelats and Prei≈øts were thus Religious, but our Kings them≈øelues did lay downe their Crownes at the Church dore, and made the ≈øigne of the Cro≈ø≈øe on their forehoods, Reges ingredientes Limen Eccle≈øiae deponunt coronam, & Crucem Christi depingunt in ≈øuis frontibus. And name our two Kings and Emperors Theodo≈øius the Father, and ≈øonne, for Paterns of Ba≈øilius Epi≈øt. ad Occidentales Epi≈øcopos. in fine Tom. 3. edit. Ba≈øil. 1565. ≈øuch Religion, Theodo≈øius pater, filius Theodo≈øij, religione ac pietate in≈øignes. The Epi≈øtle of S. Ba≈øile to the We≈øterne Bishops, OccideÃÑtalibus, tran≈ølated by Wolefangus Ma≈øculus the Prote≈øtant, in which our Brittish Bishops were comprehended, proueth that our Bishops then were knowne vnto all the world, to be men in≈øtructed and endued with the grace of God, vn≈øpotted in matters of faith, and keeping the Apo≈øtles Tradition, Vos cunctis mortalibus praedicamini viri gratia Dei in≈øtructi, qu√≤d in fide illibati permaneatis, & Apo≈øtolorum depo≈øitum Our Brittish Bishops not onely renowned heare and in the≈øe We≈øterne Nations, but in the Ea≈øterne al≈øo, there teaching true R ‚Ä¢
ligion, and condeÃÑ ning Her ‚Ä¢ ≈øi ‚Ä¢ . illae≈øum ≈øeruetis. And therefore mo≈øt earne≈øtly entreateth them, as he did in other Epi≈øtles, to come into the Ea≈øt Countries afflicted with Here≈øie to confound the Heretiks, and comfort others, Ob≈øecramus vt nunc tandem manum Orientalibus porrigatis Eccle≈øijs, quae iam velut in genua depre≈ø≈øae inclinant: ac viros aliquos mittatis, qui illas de praemijs admoneant, quae patientiae, ac pa≈øsionibus pro Christo toleratis re≈øeruantur. Vos √≤ dilecti, ac de≈øiderati fratres, ≈øitis vulneratorum medici, & eorum qui adhuc ≈øani exi≈øtant Praedotribae, quod morbidum e≈øt curantes, & quod ≈øanum ad pietatem in≈øtruentes. Therefore hauing proued by mo≈øt worthie witne≈ø≈øes before, that not onely among the We≈øterne Nations, but all others in the then Chri≈øtian world, this Kingdome of Britaine was mo≈øt free
from Here≈øie, and by S. Ba≈øils iudgment a≈øwell in that re≈øpect, as that our Bishops were learned, and trauayled into remote Countries, euen to Councels, and as Theodoret hath te≈øtified, multi Britanni, many holy and learned Britans went in that time to the Ea≈øterne Countries, whether S. Ba≈øile ≈øo exhorted them to come, and where ≈øo greate nece≈ø≈øitie was then of their helpe, and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance in ≈øo greate and important affaires, we may not doe that wrong to our Noble Nation, but acknowledge that diuers of our learned Britans tooke in hand and performed tho≈øe worthie offices, as S. Ba≈øil ≈øo vrgently de≈øired. And among the≈øe we may boldly name and place Coelus Sedulius, a very Sigebert. & Bo≈øtius apud Bal. cent. 1. in Coelo Sedul. Io. Trith. l. de Scrip. Eccle≈ø. in eod. Conr. Ge≈øner. Bibliot. in Caelio Sedul. Magdeb. cent. 5. c. 10. Henric. de Erford. hi≈øt. Sedul. in Princ. lib. Epi≈øtol. learned man, and by Sigebert, Bo≈øtius, Trithemius, and others, a Bishop for one. He being brought vp vnder our Archbishop Hildebertus heare in our Britaine though he him≈øelfe, as he and others write, Scotigena, come of the Scottish Nation, proued a man of greate, and extraordinarie knowledge, in all kind of learning, e≈øpecially diuine, and trauayled into tho≈øe Ea≈øterne Countries, Italiam perlu≈øtrauit & A≈øiam, postremo Achaiae finibus excedens, in vrbe Roma mirabili doctrina clarus efful≈øit. And did not onely by his words and preaching confirme the Catholiks confounding Heretiks, but by his many learned Writings refuted all Here≈øies of tho≈øe times, and places, as is plainly extant in them, leauing vnto Po≈øteritie an vndeniable te≈øtimony, in his owne Par≈øon of his labours and written Bookes, that all Countries then where he The≈øe our Bishops of Britaine agreeing with all Catholike Churches, profe≈ø≈øed the ≈øame faith with the Church of Rome now. liued, Britaine, France, venit in Franciam, Italy, Rome where he was ≈øo famous, and the Ea≈øterne Churches agreed in ≈øuch holy doctrine as he preached, and committed to writing, being the very ≈øame as Prote≈øtants them≈øelues confe≈ø≈øe, which the Church of Rome now profe≈ø≈øeth, condemning the opinions of Prote≈øtants, as he had any cau≈øe to ≈øpeake of ≈øuch points, beginning with the fir≈øt and cheife Article of their Religion Iu≈øtification, by faith, as they confe≈ø≈øe, ≈øolam fidem ad ≈øalutem ≈øufficere negat. So of others. And yet they ≈øay he had mo≈øt diligently read, and agreed with the Fathers of this Age, the mo≈øt learned, Patres diligenti≈øsim√® legit Originem, Augu≈øtinum, Hieronymum, Ambro≈øium, Eu≈øebium, & Gennadium. Nam ex horum interpretationibus, ≈øuarum ip≈øe in Paulum explicationum collectanea conge≈øsit, & ex alijs proculdubio, And agreed with them in matters of Religion.

4. Therefore this our renowned Doctor agreeing in all this with the be≈øt learned Magdebur. cent. 5. cap. 10. col. 1284. Sedul. in cap. 5. ad Ephe≈ø. 5. ad Phil. 3. & 4. ad Rom. Magdebur. cent. 5. c. 4. col. 505. in that Age, both of the Latine and Greeke Church, with the Pope and Church of Rome where he was of ≈øo greate fame, mirabili doctrina clarus, as al≈øo in the other both Ea≈øterne, and We≈øterne Chri≈øtians, where he had trauailed and preached, and ≈øo glorious. that the Prote≈øtants them≈øelues acknowledge, he was mo≈øt rare for gifts of learning, his works approued by Pope Gela≈øius, ≈øome of theÃÑ receaued & ≈øtill v≈øed in the publike Church ≈øeruice and he ≈øtiled by that learned Pope, as S. Bede after was for the like worthines, venerabilis, venerable. Vir erat faeli ‚Ä¢ i ingenio praeditus, acri iudicio, & facuÃÑdia indicibili. Breuiar. Roman. Hym. ad Laud. in Natiuitate Domini, & Epiph. & ad Ve≈øper. Epiphan. Sedul. Hymn. de Chri≈øt. l. 1. cap. peperi≈ø≈øe Chri≈øtum. Neque minus ei cognita extitere diuina quam humana. Adeo vt in Decretis, Di≈øtinct. 15. Gela≈øius Pontifex, venerabilem Sedulium eum vocauerit, eiu≈øque non mediocri laude commendauerit ≈øcripta. The Hymnes which the Catholike Church ≈øtill v≈øeth in the publike Seruice thereof at the Laudes in the greate Fe≈øtiuitie of Chri≈øts birth, and vigil of the Epiphany, beginning, A ≈øolis ortus cardine, ad v≈øque terrae limitem Chri≈øtum canamus principem, natum Maria virgine, and that of both the EueÃÑ≈øongs of the Epiphany which beginneth, ho≈øtes Herodes impie, Chri≈øtum venire quid times, non eripit mortalia, qui regna dat caele≈øtia, were compo≈øed by him, part of his workes, and from him thus generally honored in the
Church of Chri≈øt, as that in honor of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, Salue ≈øancta pareÃÑs enixa puerpera Regem, Qui caelum terramque tenet per ≈øaecula. cum virginitatis honore, nec primam ≈øimilem vi≈øa es, nec habere ≈øequenteÃÑ ≈øola ≈øine exemplo placui≈øti femina Chri≈øto. Be≈øides his greate trauailes, and paines in preaching, he wrote much. Our Prote≈øtant Hi≈øtorians and others a≈ø≈øcribe aboue 40. bookes to him. Aldus Manutius who published diuers of his works aboue 100. yeares fince in the yeare of Chri≈øt 1501. or 1502. giueth many rea≈øons, that he lyued aboue 1100. yeares before that time, Sedulium ab hinc mille & centum annos, ac plus eo fui≈ø≈øe colligimus; Ald. Manut. Epi≈øt. ante opera Iuuenci Sedulij. &c. Sedul. Epi≈øt. ad Macedonium Presbyterum. and to haue liued in the ≈øame time with S. Hierome, puto Hieronimum & Sed ‚Ä¢
lium ei≈ødem fui≈ø≈øe temporibus. Which Sedulius him≈øelfe in his Epi≈øtle to Macedonius ≈øeemeth ≈øufficiently to proue, ≈øpeaking therein of S. Hierome, as then liuing, and writing, as al≈øo of ≈øome holy par≈øons then in life to whome he wrote. Therefore I place him in this Age, yet not denying but he might liue to the beginning of that which followeth. This our Sedulius much e≈øteemeth in that Epi≈øtle Vr≈øinus a Bishop, Vr≈øicinus, Laurentius & Gallicanus Prei≈øts, and Faelix whome according to his name, he nameth a truely happy man, vere Faelicem, for his contempt of this world, cui mundus crucifixus est. And others doe ≈øay, they were his familiar friends, and worthie men, as he and they likewi≈øe doe Magdeburgen. centur. 1. of this Macedonius to whome he wrote. Therefore not finding any Hi≈øtorian clayming the≈øe or any of them for any other Nation, and hauing heard before, that many Britans then went into tho≈øe parts, that they were entreated thereto, and be≈øides our owne, forreine Antiquaries write that in tho≈øe dayes our Arnold. Merm. Theatr. conuer≈ø. gent. Britans did often goe on Pilgrimage to the holy Land and Rome, and preach euery where as they went, Britanni olim dum terram ≈øanctam, aut Apo≈øtolorum Limina vi≈øitarunt, pa≈øsim Euangelio praedicando ≈øeruiebant, we may & not vnprobably pre≈øume, that the≈øe, or ≈øome of them were al≈øo of this Kingdome. And ≈øome write that ≈øaint Fridolin a Princes ≈øonne of this Country, ≈øome ≈øay a Scot, S. Patrike very renowned in this Age. did in this Age, wheÃÑ ≈øaint Hilary was Bishop of Poicters, apud Pictauos Hilario Epi≈øcopo, preach in Belgia, Argentine, Chur, Rhetia, Burgundy, Ba≈øile, Sigebert. Chron. an. 394. Fa≈øcicul. tempor. ad An. 384. Nen. Hi≈øt. M. S. Floren. Wigorn. an. 490. Probus in vit. S. Patricij. Capgrau. in eod. Genebr. Chron. Sigebert. Chron. an 491. Fa≈øcicul. tempor. an. 423. Marian. Scot. aetat. 6. an. 491. Sur. & Lippol. 17. Mart. Baron. not. Mart. eod. die. Io. Bal. cent. 1. in Patric. Io. Pit≈ø. in eodem. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 491. FloreÃÑc. Wigorn. Chronic. an. 372. and other places, and founded many Mona≈øteries by the Ryuer Rhine. I may al≈øo ioyne ≈øaint Patrike borne in Britaine heare in this Century, wherein he was not onely borne, but liued in mo≈øt holy conuer≈øation many yeares, both in this his natiue Country, & Ireland, whether he was by Pagan Scottish Irish Pirats, with his Chri≈øtian Si≈øters and others violently carried hence, & there ≈øold to ≈øerue. Sigebert ≈øaith, this was in the yeare of Chri≈øt 394, Sanctus Patricius in Hibernia cum ≈øuis ≈øororibus veÃÑditur, vbi cum e≈ø≈øet Regis Porcarius, Angeli ≈øaepe alloquio fruitur. The Author of Fa≈øciculus Temporum ≈øaith, he was ≈øold thither with his Si≈øters ten yeares ≈øooner, and they were reuerenced there, An. 384. Patricius magnus pater Hibernorum Apo≈øtolus circa haec tempora in Hibernia veneratur, cum ≈øuis ≈øororibus, Angeli ≈øaepe colloquio fruitur.

5. But if we calculate, and compare the yeares of his life and death, we shall certainely finde, that he was ≈øolde into Iereland from hence, longe before either of the≈øe times, and was aboue 30. yeares old in this Age. All Hi≈øtorians agree, that as he liued 122. yeares, ≈øo he died in the yeare 491. by which accompt he mu≈øt needs be borne in the yeare of Chri≈øt 368. or 369. and be aboue 30. yeares old in this Age. Marianus Scotus, Probus, Capgraue, and others write, he was 16. yeares old, when he was carried into Ireland, and was kept there in ≈øeruitude 6. yeares, Cum e≈ø≈øet annorum 16. venditus est: ≈øex annis vixit in ≈øeruitute. So he returned into Britaine being 22. yeares old, about the yeare of Chri≈øt 390. Florentius Wigornien≈øis agreeth in the yeares of his Age 122.
that he died in the yeare 491. and was borne in the yeare 372. and that he was carried Pri≈øoner into Ireland in the 16. yeare of his Age, as others doe, & ≈øaith, An. 410. that his two Si≈øters ≈øtolen away with him, were named the one Lupuit, and the other Tigris. He was ≈øold to Miluc called a King in the North of Ireland, & his Si≈øters into an other part; but he placing his death in the 491. yeare, & ≈øayin An. 491. the was theÃÑ compleate 122. yeares old, Anno 491. Sanctus Patricius Hiberniae Archiepi≈øcopus annorum 122. beati≈øsimo fine obijt, doth mi≈ø≈øe his calculation, and mu≈øt ≈øay as I haue written before, that he was borne in the 369. or 368. yeare of Chri≈øt.

6. There where diuers other Chri≈øtian Pri≈øoners carried hence at that time with him into Ireland by tho≈øe Pagan Pirats, Cum e≈ø≈øet annorum ≈øexdecim cum caeteris in captiuitate ducitur. Who≈øe vertuous behauiour there made ≈øuch way and di≈øpo≈øition to that wilde Pagan Nation, that theit Conuer≈øion after by ≈øaint Patrike was made more ea≈øie. For to ≈øpeake cheifely of this holy YouÃÑge man, allthough he was borne of a Noble Linage, Caphurnius vir & morum hone≈øtate con≈øpicuus, & diuitijs ac honoribus inclitus, being his Father, & his Mother Si≈øter to the renowned ≈øaint Martine Bishop, yet now ≈øold among Pagans and put Probus in S. Patric. M. S. in vit: eius. Capgrau. in eod. Surius. & Lippom. die 17. Martij. to the ≈øeruile office of keeping Swine, though he began thereby to forget his Noble carnall birth, yet of his ≈øpirituall Natiuitie in Chri≈øt he was ≈øo mindefull, that euery day and night he prayed an hundred times, Centies in Die & centies in nocte Deum exorabat. By which greate and extraordinary deuotion we may gather, though not otherwi≈øe expre≈ø≈øely remembred in what piety, and Religeous conuer≈øation he had bene brought vp heare by his holy Parents, Nennius Hi≈øtor. Briton. in S. Patricio. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 491. & he exerci≈øed in Britaine before he was carried Pri≈øoner heÃÑce. NeÃÑnius our old Brittish Writer, Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, and diuers others compare him vnto Moi≈øes, e≈øpecially in foure re≈øpects: fir≈øt, for the Angell appearing vnto Mo≈øes: ≈øecondly, for his fa≈øting 40. dayes and 40. nights: Thirdly, for the yeares of his Age 120: fourthly, for his graue and ≈øepulchre vnknowne. The fir≈øt of the≈øe of the holy Angell often times appearing vnto, and comforting ≈øaint Patrike keeping his cattaile, as vnto Mo≈øes, was perfectly and in an excellent manner performed, not once or ≈øeldome but often times declaring his name, Victor, Conqueror conuer≈øing with him: victor Angelus ≈øaepe loquebatur cum eo. And FloreÃÑt. Wigorn. Chronic. ≈øupr. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. & Capgrau. in S. Patricio. te≈øtifying vnto him how acceptable his prayers and fa≈øtings were in heauen, and he should shortly be deliuered from his Captiuitie, Apparuit ei Angelus Domini Victor nomine qui frequenter eum Vi≈øitans dixit, bene ieiunas, cito exiturus ad patriam tuam. And brought him money for his Ran≈øome. The Writer of S. Patricks life te≈øtifing that in his time the prints on the earth where the Angell ≈øtood, were ≈øtill coÃÑtinuing, Stetit Angelus ≈øuper terraÃÑ, & v≈øque hodie manent ve≈øtigia eius. And allthough I dare not ≈øet downe his fa≈øt of 40. dayes and 40. nights which Nennius relateth to haue bene on the topp of the hill Eile, Quadraginta diebus totidemque noctibus in cacumine montis Eile ieiunauit, Wherein he ≈øecondly compareth him to Moi≈øes, to haue bene at this time; yet we haue heard his fa≈øting now was ≈øuch, that the Angell commended it, bene ieiunas. Yet the old M. S. Antiq. de vit. S. Patricij. Io. Capgrau. in eod. Writer of his Hi≈øtory, Capgraue and others are witne≈ø≈øes that he fa≈øted together in this time 30. dayes, neither eating nor drinking, and yet was well and merry, Man≈øit Patricius diebus triginta non manducans, neque bibens, hilaris tamen per≈øeuerabat. The other two things wherein they compare him to Moi≈øes for his Age of 120. yeares, and his place of buirall vnknowne mu≈øt be re≈øerued to their time at, and after his death, when they chaÃÑced Onely this heare I add, that whereas Nennius giueth vnto him onely with Moi≈øes 120. yeares, others 122.
or 123. the old Manu≈øcript of his life, Probus with others ≈øay, he liued 130. or 132. yeares, completis √† Natauitate ≈øua annis centum triginta migrauit ad Dominum. Which giueth me more warrant to place a greate part of his life in this Age. M. S. & Capgr. ≈øupr. Probus in vit. S. Patricij Baron. & Spond. an. 491. For the≈øe Authours are ≈øo farre from making his Natiuitie later then I haue done, that they ≈øay in the yeare of Chri≈øt 425. he was. 64. yeares old, Anno Domini quadringeÃÑte≈øimo vice≈øimo quinto hic erat annus aetatis ≈øuae ≈øexage≈øimus quartus. and ≈øo 39. yeares old in the end of this Age. Neither did S. Patrike in tho≈øe his often and continuall prayers, day and night, centies in Die & centies in nocte, Prayer to Angels and Saints, and their protection of lyuers one earth. die nocteque precibus intentus, pray onely to God, omitting his Angels and Saints, but vnto the≈øe al≈øo, to his Angels by their often vi≈øiting and a≈ø≈øi≈øting, and to his Saints, as namely to Elias, to help and deliuer him, again≈øt the deuill tempting and afflicting him, who heard his prayers, and ≈øo freed him that the deuill confe≈ø≈øed he should neuer haue any power ouer him, Patricius vocauit Heliam bina voce in adiutorium: venitque Helias & liberauit eum, & ait ad eum, diabolus, ab hac die non habeo Pote≈øtatem in te, v≈øque ad diem mortis tuae.

7. The old Irish Writer of ≈øaint Patrike his life called Probus, whome≈øome Probus in vita S. Patricij Tom. 3. oper. Venerab. Bedae. doe vntruely take to be ≈øaint Bede, the Booke being placed amoÃÑg his Workes, the Authour di≈øclo≈øing therein both his name Probus, and Country Ireland, affirmeth, that ≈øaint Patricke was three times taken Pri≈øoner, and ledd Captiue, and the ≈øecond time al≈øo Miraculou≈øly deliuered, and re≈øtored to his Country Britaine. Where he was diligently in≈øtructed in learning, by the be≈øt Profe≈ø≈øors thereof, optimus v≈øus praeceptoribus, among whome ≈øaint Martine his Vncle Probus ≈øupr. Sur. & Lippom. die 17. Martij. Bar. & Spond. in S. Pa ‚Ä¢ ric. Bal. cent. 1. in Patricio Pit≈ø. in eod. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Ireland. was one, ≈øtaying with him foure yeares vntill his death, as it ≈øeemeth by the time thereof before related. A late Writer then bringeth him to Gla≈øtenbury, and to haue liued there many yeares, aboue thirtie, ≈øaith this Authour, in Religious habite, in patriaÃÑ redieÃÑs, ad Gla≈øconieÃÑ≈øe Mona≈øteriuÃÑ ≈øece≈øsit & ibi in vita & habitu Religio≈øo caele≈øtia conteÃÑplans plu≈øquam annis triginta vixit. Hauing bene ≈øome time with ≈øaint German, and after this went to Rome to S. Cele≈øtine Pope. But this belongeth to the next Age, where it shall be more fully entreated. Onely, heare I ≈øay, that his liuing at Gla≈øtenbury before his going to Rome, Guliel. Malm. l. 2. de ge≈øt. Pont. is no incredible thing in Hi≈øtory, euen by the be≈øt Writer of the Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury William of Malmesbury. For after he had written that booke, he di≈øcrediteth ≈øaint Patricks liuing and dying at Gla≈øtenbury after his CoÃÑuer≈øion Gul. Malm. l. de Antiq. caenob. Gla≈øt. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. Gla≈øton. in Tab. ligneis M. S. Gallic. Antiq. cap. 39. of Ireland, making it vnworthie of credit: ≈øi credere dignum. And in his Manu≈øcript of Gla≈øtenbury, citing others for the ≈øame, and the Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury ≈øay, he was borne of Couche Si≈øter to ≈øaint Martine Archbishop of Tours in the yeare of Chri≈øt 361. by that accompt leauing him time ≈øufficient to haue liued 30. yeares at Gla≈øtenbury before his going to Rome. Which if it may be admitted for good, will ≈øalue very many difficulties which are in the other opinion.

8. An old French Manu≈ø. Hi≈øt. thus ≈øetteth downe S. Patricke loÃÑge before he was Bishop in they eare. 427. amoÃÑg the worthies of the Chri≈øtiaÃÑ world, In this Hi≈øtor. Gallic. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. an. 427. time S. Patricke √† BritoÃÑ by NatioÃÑ ≈øonne to Conches, Si≈øter to S. Martine of Tours was renowned for holines, & miracles & learning. Our Prote≈øtaÃÑt Hi≈øtorians theÃÑ≈øelues confe≈ø≈øe as much, ≈øaying that before he went to Rome he was renowned through the Latine Church for his wi≈øedome, vertue and skill. He was borne in the Marches betwixt Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Irel. pag. 53. Pit≈ø. aetat. 5. in S. Patric. EnglaÃÑd & ScotlaÃÑd in a towne by the Sea ≈øide called Eiburne (in Pembroke shire by ≈øome) his Mother named Conches, was Si≈øter to S. Martine that famous Bishop of Towers in France. Patrike of a child was brought vp in learning, and well in≈øtructed in the faith, and much giuen to deuotion. And relating his captiuitie, and deliuerance
from it, as I haue done, they add, as affliction commonly maketh men Religeous, the regard of his former education printed in him ≈øuch remor≈øe and humilitie, that being thenceforth weaned from the world, he betooke him≈øelfe to Contemplation, euer lamenting the lacke of grace and truth in that Land: and hearewith not de≈øpayring, but that in continuance ≈øome good might be wrought vpon them, he learned their tongue perfectly. And alluring one of that Nation to beare him company for exerci≈øe ≈øake, he gott him into France, euer hauing in his minde a de≈øire to ≈øee the Conuer≈øion of the Irish people, who≈øe babes yet vnborne ≈øeemed to him in his dreames from out of their Mothers wombs to call for chri≈øteÃÑdome. In this purpo≈øe he ≈øought his vncle Martine, by who≈øe meanes he was placed with Germanus the Bishop of Auxerre, coÃÑtinuing with him as ≈øcholler or Di≈øciple for the ≈øpace of 40. yeares. All which time he be≈øtowed in like ≈øtudy of holy Scriptures, prayers, & ≈øuch godly exerci≈øe. At the Age of 62. yeares being renowned through the Latine Church for his wi≈øedome, vertue and skill, he came to Rome bringing letters with him in his commendation from the French Bishops vnto Pope Celestine, to whome he vttered his full minde, and ≈øecret vo ‚Ä¢ e, which longe ≈øince he had conceiued touching Ireland. Cele≈øtine inue≈øted him Archbishop and Primate of the whole Iland. The≈øe men in this Narration approue and followe much Giraldus Cambren≈øis in his Topographie of Ireland, by many much commended and if his opinion is as much to be allowed about the time and dayes of S. Patrike, we shall finde that he was come to this renowne, and ≈øpent the mo≈øt part of his life in this Age. For he maketh him with others 120. yeares old at his death, and to haue dyed happily in the yeare of Chri≈øt 458. obijt beatus Girald. Cambr. Topograph. Hibern. c. 17. lib. ad Reg. Henric. 2. di≈øt. 2. Tit. de mirac. Hibern. Harpesfel. Hi≈øt. Eccl. p. 32. Theater of great Brit. l. 6. c. 9. ¬ß. 9. Patricius & in Domino quieuit anno aetatis ≈øuae 120. ab Incarnatione Domini 458. ab aduentu Hibernen≈øiuÃÑ 1800. Our English Prote≈øtaÃÑt Writers of the greate Theater of Britaine, whome I dare not allowe, make him farre more auncient then this time. That which our Prote≈øtants haue before ≈øet downe of S. Patrike, that the babes yet vnborne ≈øeemed to him in his dreames from out of their Mothers wombes to call for Chri≈øtendome, is te≈øtified more plainely and credibly by olde and better Authours, that it was a true vi≈øion, and calling of S. Patrike to be the Apo≈øtle of that Nation. In a vi≈øion an Epi≈øtle was repre≈øented vnto him, and the beginning of it was, this is the voice of the people of Ireland, haec e≈øt vox Hibernen≈øium. And reading this beginning of that letter, at the ≈øame in≈øtant, and moment of time the voice of Infants from their Mothers wombs in diuers Contries of Irelande crying as it were with one mouth, √¥ holy Father we be≈øeech thee, that thou wilt come and walke amonge vs. By which extraordinary vocation S. Patrike was most certainely a≈ø≈øured, that God had called him thereby to be the Apo≈øtle of that Nation, to conuert it to Chri≈øt: gratias egit Deo certi≈øsim√® ≈øciens quod Dominus voca≈ø≈øet eum ad ≈øaluandos illos qui ip≈øum inuocabant. The old Writer of Script. vitae S. Dauid is apud Capgrau. in eod. Manu≈øcr. Antiq. Britannic. the life of S. Dauid, ≈øpeaketh of this, or the like vi≈øion to haue bene made to Saint Patrike, when the birth of that glorious man S. Dauid, to be ≈øo renowned in the Country now called wales, was reuealed vnto him, which was as tho≈øe Antiquities ≈øay 30. yeares before S. Dauid was borne, filio nondum nato, nec ni≈øi peractis annis 30. na≈øcituro. Yet S. Dauid, as I shall proue hereafter, was born ‚Ä¢ in this Age. Therefore an old Brittish Antiquitie ≈øaith, S. Patrike liued 153. yeares, Vixit annis centum quinquaginta & tres.

9. Our old English Hi≈øtorie which the Continuator of Florentius Wigornien≈øis Continuatio Flor. Wigorn. in Geneologia Reg. We≈øt-Saxonum. aboue 400. yeares ≈øince doth ≈øeeme to cite by the Title Chronica Anglica; doth tell vs o ‚Ä¢ an Archbishop of London called Ternekin, which is not found in any Cata ‚Ä¢ oge o ‚Ä¢ the Archbishops there, neither haue I before made memory of him, he liued Archbishop as that Authour te≈øtifieth, in the beginning
of the Reigne of Aurelius Ambro≈øius, by which Accompt, although it is not probable that he was Archbishop there in this Age, yet not vnlike ‚Ä¢ y but Old English Hi≈øt. fol. 44. he was a worthie man of renowne, in, or not longe after this time. So I may ≈øay of Guitelinus and S. Vodinus glorious Archbishops of that See, famous in our Hi≈øtories. But of the≈øe as al≈øo of S. Patrike I shall ≈øpeake more in the next hundred of yeares. We finde memory of an other renowned Bishop in this Age, Aluueus ≈øpoken of before that baptized S. Dauid, and at his Bapti≈øme, Vit. S. Dauid Epi≈øcopi. and in the place thereof a Miraculous Well ≈øprang ≈øodainely vp at that time curing di≈øea≈øes. Whether this Bishop peculiarly a≈ø≈øigned to bapti≈øe this Infant, ≈øo prophetically and Miraculou≈øly longe before foretold, was one of the Archbishops of Caerlegion, who≈øe names are not remeÃÑbred, as I haue ≈øaid before, and the re≈øt, I leaue to others to decide. Our Hi≈øtorians relating the life and Hi≈øtory of S. Patrike ≈øay, he was con≈øecrated Bishop in the≈øe parts, by one Antiq. Script. in vit. S. Patricij. Capgrau. in eod. Nennius Hi≈øt. Manu≈øcrip. Matth. We≈øt. An. 491. the principall among his Con≈øecrators, named by ≈øome Amatus, but by Nennius, Matthew of We≈øtmin≈øter, and others, Matheus or Amatheus. Nennius calleth him Amatheus, & mirabilis ≈øummus Epi≈øcopus Rex, an admirable highe Bishop and King or Prince. The Monke of We≈øtmin≈øter termeth him Matthaeus and ≈øaith he was an Archbishop, & relateth S. Patrike his Mi≈ø≈øion from Pope Cele≈øtine, how he preached both to Britans and Scots, by that Commi≈ø≈øion, and that he was made Bishop by this Matthaeus, or Amatheus in the≈øe parts afterward, Patricius, Theodo≈øio & Valentiniano Imperantibus √† Papa Cele≈øtino ad partes Occiduas mi≈ø≈øus e≈øt, vt vexillum ≈øanctae crucis gentibus praedicaret. Cumque ad Britanniam perueni≈ø≈øet, praedicauit ibi verbum Dei, & √† gentibus Incolis gratanter e≈øt ≈øu≈øceptust deinde ad Scotos ≈øe conferens praedicauit verbum Dei. Tandem √† Matthaeo Archiepi≈øcapo ad Epi≈øcopalem gradum permotus. Wherefore ≈øeeing we finde that he was con≈øecrated Bishop in the≈øe parts by ≈øuch an Archbishop, and finde that Archbishop named for no other Nation, and being a≈ø≈øured by Antiquities that Caerlegion had diuers Archbishops, who≈øe names are not remeÃÑ bred in Hi≈øtories, I may name this, Amatus, Matthaeus or Amathaeus a coÃÑfe≈ø≈øed Arch bishop to haue bene one of them, & a renowned maÃÑ, if not Archbishop in this Age. And this the rather becau≈øe whereas this Archbishop is called Rex a King, we had heare diuers Kings or Heires to ≈øuch litle Kings which for≈øooke their temporall ≈øtates, and honors to be Religeous and Clergy men, and were Manu≈øcript. Ant. in vit. S. Dauid. Capgrau. in eod. & S. Carantoco. renowned in Eccle≈øia≈øticall Order, at, and before the time, when S. Patrike was con≈øecrated Bishop. Such as I haue proued before were the worthies of this Nation, S. Cadocus, S. Canochus, and Carantocus. To whome I add King Keredick Father to S. Carantocus and S. Dauid voluntarily leauing and renowncing their earthly Kingdomes, for the loue of Chri≈øt, and to be crowned in heauen.

div.head: THE XXVIII. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF VERY MANY AND RENOWNED MOna≈øteries and holy Mona≈øticall par≈øons in Britaine in this Age.

div.p: 1. IN this Age al≈øo we had heare in Britaine very many Mona≈øteries, and Religious hou≈øes, both of men and women, euen as the Prote≈øtant Antiquaries of this Nation, profe≈ø≈øed enemies of ≈øuch holy Monuments and profe≈ø≈øion, with others doe freely confe≈ø≈øe, Monachorum, Io. Go≈øcel. Hi≈øt. Eccl. Matt. Parker. Antiq. Britannic. p. 8. Antiq. Gla≈øt. Capgr. in Vit. S. Patricij. Guliel. Malmefb. lib. de Antiquit. Caenobij Gla≈øton. AbbatuÃÑ, Caenobiorum, SediuÃÑque nomina permulta extiteruÃÑt, no Catholike Hi≈øtorian calleth it into Que≈øtion, but all ≈øuch are witne≈ø≈øes, that as in other Chri≈øtian NatioÃÑs, ≈øo heare in Britaine there were many Religious hou≈øes in this time. Our old Religious hou≈øe of Gla≈øtenbury continued in this Age, as in the former hauing twelue Religious men Eremites belonging vnto it dwelling in the places and Cells of the fir≈øt 12. in the time of S. Io≈øeph of Arimathia, and very often dayly re≈øorting to the old Church to performe their publike ≈øeruice and deuotions. This is te≈øtified by the old Manu≈øcripts of that place, & William of Malmesbury in his Booke of the Antiquitie thereof, witne≈ø≈øing that the≈øe holy men in the number of twelue ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely thus liued and ≈øerued God there vutill S. Patrike his comming thither, Sic multi alijs ≈øuccedentes ≈øemper tamen in numero duodenario per multa annorum curricula v≈øque ad aduentum Sancti Patricij Hibernen≈øium Apo≈øtoli in memorata In≈øula perman≈øerunt, Which ≈øome before haue placed in this Age. The≈øe Religious men were of ≈øo greate Sanctitie in this time, as the Epi≈øtle a≈ø≈øcribed to S. Patrike te≈øtifieth, that he, ≈øuch a wonder in the world for pietie, confe≈ø≈øed, he was not worthie to vntie the Latchets of their Shoes, Non dignus eram ≈øoluere corrigias calceamentorum eorum. The names of the 12. then liuing there in this holy Order are thus Regi≈øtred, Brunbam, Dyregaan, Viwal, Wenreth, Bamtonneweng, Adeloobred, Loyor, Wellias, Breden, Swellwes, Hinloermus and Alius. All of them di≈øcended of Noble Families, rather preferred this poore penitentiall Eremiticall life then worldly honor, Hij cum e≈ø≈øent Nobilibus orti natalibus, nobilitatem ≈øuam fidei opibus ornare cupientes, Heremiticam vitam ducere elegerunt.

2. The Antiquities of Gla≈øtenbury further witne≈ø≈øe, that about this time there was new founded, or renewed an other litle Religious hou≈øe in honor of S. Michael the Archangel and particularly to honor and pray to him, Vt honorantes inuocent adiutorium Archangeli Michaelis. And that Arnulphus, and Ogmar, two Religious holy men were the fir≈øt, which ≈øupplied that office and dutie there.

3. I haue ≈øpoaken of the auncient & famous Mona≈øtery of Wince≈øter in the beginning of this Age, how it was de≈øtroyed in the Per≈øecution of DiocletiaÃÑ, and with greate deuotion, State, and Magnificence reedified, when that TeÃÑ pe≈øt cea≈øed, in the ≈øpace of one yeare and thirtie dayes, and dedicated to S. Amphibalus lately martyred before. This Mona≈øtery now florished, and long
after this time, vntill the time of Cerdic the Saxon, and fir≈øt Pagan King of that Nation ouer the We≈øt Saxons, as the old Manu≈øcript Antiquitie of that place Antiquitat. Eccl. Wintonien. proueth, being 210. yeares from the death of Diocle≈øian, Monachi ≈øic introducti inhabitaÃÑt Eccle≈øiam Wintoniae in quieta pace √† morte Diocle≈øiani v≈øque aduentum, Cerdicij Saxonici & Pagani ac We≈øt≈øaxonum Regis primi, hoc e≈øt 210. annis. So Matth. We≈øtm. in Chron. FloreÃÑt. Wigorn. in geneolog. Reg. We≈øtsax. Fa≈øt. Reg. & Epi≈øcop. Angl. Gildas l. de Excid. Brit. Stowe Hi≈øtor. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 433. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 445. Galfr. Monum. Hi≈øt. Brit. l. 6. c. 5. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Engl. l. 5. Hardin. Chron. c. 65. 66. that Cerdic not being King there by the common opinion vntill about the yeare 519, this Mona≈øtery florished in quiet all this, and the next Age al≈øo, it being the yeare of Chri≈øt 495. when Cerdic fir≈øt landed heare, and ≈øo long after before he was King. And our mo≈øt auncent Hi≈øtorian S. Gildas, & others after him, are witne≈ø≈øes, that in the time of King Con≈øtantine there was a glorious Abbey and holy Abbot there, Sancti Abbatis, complaining how ≈øacrilegiou≈øly this King killed one of the ≈øonnes of Mordred betweene the holy Altars, intra ip≈øa ≈øacro≈øancta Altaria, flying thither for Sanctuary and ≈øauegard, and he him≈øelfe hauing three ≈øonnes Con≈øtans, Aurelius Ambro≈øe, and Vtherpendragon, perhaps for remor≈øe, and in ≈øatisfaction for that impietie deliuered his elde≈øt ≈øonne Con≈øtans, to be a Monke in that Abbey, Con≈øtantem Primogenitum tradidit in Eccle≈øiam Amphibali intra Guintoniam, vt Monachalem ordinem ≈øu≈øciperet, and there, he was a Monke, Vbi Monachalem ordinem ≈øu≈øcepit. And ≈øo continued vntill Vortigerne tooke him by force out of his Cloi≈øter, and made him King without the peoples con≈øent, becau≈øe he was a Monke, Vortigernus perexit Wintoniam, & Con≈øtantem Monachum, Con≈øtantini filium de Clau≈øtro extractum duxit Lundonias, & eum vix annuente populo eo qu√≤d Monachus e≈ø≈øet, erexit in Regem.

4. There were then diuers Mona≈øteries in London, and Con≈øtantine mutthered an other youÃÑg Prince in one of theÃÑ, Vnum Wintoniae in Eccle≈øia S.
