Among, which one aboue the re≈øt in the Hebrides Ilands in the Ile of Iona was mo≈øt renowned, both for holy Monkes, and Nunnes where the common funerall place was of the Scottish Kings. There was an other ≈øuch Mona≈øtery in the Ile of Mona, where S. Briget euen by our Prote≈øtant Antiquaries Io. Bal. cent. 1. in Brigida Lagm√©≈øi. Hector. Boeth. Scotor. Hi≈øt. l. 9. Capgr. in S. Brigida. with three other Virgins at one time became Nunnes being profe≈ø≈øed by Machillas then Bishop of Soder, or Soter, this was when she was but 14. yeares olde, Brigida ≈øancti≈øsima virgo decimo quarto anno vix ≈øuperato ad Sodoren≈øem Epi≈øcopum in Monam Iu≈øulam paternis fortunis, quae ampli≈øsimae erant, contemptis, aufugit, precibus non ≈øine lachrimis petens vt perpetuae virginitati, Pontificia authoritate addiceretur. Which time being compared with that of her life, being very old at her death, and that she had bene fir≈øt buried in Mona, and her body tran≈ølated to Dune in Ireland in the yeare 518. mu≈øt needs proue vnto vs, that there was a Religeous hou≈øe in Mona in this Age.

12. And not onely in Mona, Iona and the Hebrides Ilands, but in other out Ilands and places the≈øe Scotish Monkes made aboad, and had Cels, or Mona≈øteries in this time. For our Scotish Hi≈øtorians deliuering vnto vs, how they were all by Maximus bannished with the other Scots out of the Country now called Scotland, confe≈ø≈øe al≈øo that there came but a part, allthough a greate part, for the nearnes and conuenieÃÑcy of tho≈øe Ilands into the Hebrides, Veremund. & Hect. Boeth. l. 6. Scot. Hi≈øt. Georg. Buchan. Rer. Scoticar. l. 4. in Rege 39. Quorum magna pars in Hebrides delata. The others then mu≈øt needs haue other re≈øting places, which the Antiquaries of Scotland euen Prote≈øtants confe≈ø≈øe, ≈øaying that the Scottish Prei≈øts and Monkes, then held in greate honor & reuerence, were di≈øper≈øed into all Countries, rounde about, and many of them came into Iona, Ne ‚Ä¢ √† Sacerdotibus & Monachis qui tum in ≈øummo erant honore, Picti, & ≈øi public√® Christianis institutis imbuti, Iniuriam ab≈øtinuerunt. Illi vero profugi cum in omnes circumcirca Regiones di≈øpergerentur, multi in Ionam Aebudarum vnam deuenerunt, atque ibi in Caenobium collecti, mag ‚Ä¢ am ≈øuae ≈øanctitatis & eruditionis ‚Ä¢ amam ad Po≈øteros tran≈ømi≈øerunt. Some of the≈øe Scots went into Ireland, in Hiberniam, from whome came the Irish Monkes ≈øo famous afterward, and ≈øome of our Brittish Monkes al≈øo preached there in this time, as I haue proued of S. Carantocus called by the Irish Cernath, before. And when in the beginning of the next Age the Scots came into this Iland againe, the Monkes of Iona and Mona continuing there ≈øtill, there came ≈øo many Scottish Monkes in ‚Ä¢ o the part called Scotland, in the time of Fergu≈øius their King the ≈øecond of that name, from their places of Bannishment in ≈øo greate a number Veremund. & Hect. Boeth. Scotor. Hi≈øt. l. 7. by the Scottish Writers, that their King Fergu≈øius founded and endowed for them, being a vertuous Prince, many Cels, or Mona≈øteries, Re≈øtituit Fergu≈øius templa dirut ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ut populi defectu neglecta, ≈øacris ministris ad Dei cultum, ≈øacerd ‚Ä¢ tij ‚Ä¢ donatis. Qui ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ularant Monachos, redu ‚Ä¢ es mira charitate amplexus, vt popu
‚Ä¢ um vera im ‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢ r ‚Ä¢ nt ‚Ä¢ ietate, ≈øtructis ad id patrio ritu, Cellulis quibusdam, ad vitae ne
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øari ‚Ä¢ prae ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s don ‚Ä¢ uit. Where be≈øides the Prei≈øts and their Churches we ≈øee
many Religeous hou≈øes founded, and endowed for the exiled Monkes, returning in the begining of the next Age. Not vnprobable but diuers of the≈øe Boeth. ≈øupr. Georg. Buchan. l. 4. 5. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Scotl. in Fergu≈øio. 2. Monkes came with him from Scandia and Denmarke where he was borne, and whether the Scotish Monkes with others fledd in the time of Maximus, and other adiacent Contries and Ilands, they then being di≈øper≈øed into all parts about this Kingdome, in omnes circumcirca Regiones. And yet at the time of this di≈øper≈øion of the Scotish Monkes, the Brittish Monkes with their Cells and Mona≈øteries were in quiet in the Country now termed Scotland, as I haue proued before, and were many.

13. The ≈øame is euident of the Religeous people of the Pictish Nation, now being Chri≈øtians, the exilement by Maximus onely extending to the Scots. Among the≈øe ≈øome about ≈øaint Andrewes were famous. One had bene the Palace of the Kings of Picts, and at the comming of ≈øaint Regulus thither with the Reliks of ≈øaint Andrew the Apo≈øtle, Heirgu≈øtus their King conuerted it to a Church or Mona≈øtery, Heirgu≈øtus Regium Palatium amplis structuris, vti ea patiebatur aetas, ornataÃÑ diuo Andreae, Regulo, ac Sacerdotibus ibidem deinceps optimo Maximo Deo famulaturis liber√® erogauit. An other Mona≈øtery was that, which the ≈øame King founded neare to the ≈øame place, Struxit & haud procul √† palatio ≈øacram aedem diuo Apo≈øtolo dicatam: And furnished them both with pretious Ornaments and holy Ve≈ø≈øels of gold and ≈øyluer, Ornauit & id templum donarijs ampli≈øsimis, Pateris, Cyphis, Calicibus, Peluibus, Lauacris ex argeÃÑto auroque, ac alia pretio≈øa ≈øupellectili in ≈øacrorum v≈øum quae≈øita, Sacerdotibus ad diuina perpetu√≤ exequenda ibidem con≈øtitutis. A third Mona≈øtery was founded there, or very neare the ≈øame place, either in this Age, or the beginning of the next by our renowned Brittish Abbot ≈øaint Manu≈øcr. Antiq. in vit. S. Cadoci. Capgr. in eod. Cadocus after Bishop and Martyr, who going one Pilgrimage to the Reliks of ≈øaint Andrew in Scotland, ≈øtayed preaching there 7. yeares, and founded a Mona≈øtery. I haue ≈øpoken of ≈øaint Gudwal and his 180. Monks before, who founded diuers Mona≈øteries heare in this Age.

div.head: THE XXIX. CHAPTER.

argument.p: OF CERTAINE HERETICKS AND HERESIES, the Trimothian and Pelagian Britaine in this time.

div.p:
1. BVT as Britaine had many glorious Saints and Martyrs in this Age, ≈øo it wanted not ≈øome Heretiks, to di≈øturbe the peace and quietnes of Chri≈øts Church, both in this and other Nations. Timotheus the name giuen to the Timotheani Heretiks, was as Sigebert with others writeth, of this kingdome, & held that the Diuine Nature in Chri≈øt was changed into his Human Nature, and by a shew of Continency and Religion deluded many, In Britannia Timotheus quidam Continentiae & Religionis imagine multis illudeÃÑs, eos in errorem ≈øuae Haere≈øis induxit, dicens, Chri≈øtum verum quidem Deum & verum hominem de Virgine Maria natum fui≈ø≈øe, ≈øed mentiens dicendo, quod Diuina Natura conuer≈øa ≈øit in HumanaÃÑ
Naturam. The Collectors of our auncient Writers affirme; that our Country man Leporius Agricola did write a Booke again≈øt him ≈øtill extant, and confuted Aug. in l. de Haere≈øibus in fine Haer. 89. in exeÃÑ plari Gembl. Sigeber. Gembl. Chron. an. 428. Harpesfeld. Hi≈øt. Eccl. in 6. primis ≈øaecul. c. 18. Ioan. Bal. cent. 1. in Leporio Agricola. Io. Pit≈ø. de Vi ‚Ä¢ . Illu≈øtrib. in Lepor. Agricola. his Here≈øie. In ≈øome Copies of ≈øaint Augu≈øtin his Booke of Here≈øies, this Here≈øie called the Timotheans is ≈øet downe in the end thereof, and there affirmed, that one Timotheus was Author of it, and he then liued an exile in Bithinia at Biza there, Timotheani dicunt filium Dei verum quidem hominem ex Virgine Maria natum, ≈øed non ita vnam reddidi≈ø≈øe per≈øonam, vt non in vnam ≈øit redactus naturam: conflatorium quoddam volentes fui≈ø≈øe interiora Virginis, per quod duae naturae, id est, Deus & homo, in vnam re≈øolutae & compactae Ma≈ø≈øam, vnam Dei & hominis exhibuerint formam. Et ad confirmanda huiu≈ømodi impietatem, quae Deum a≈ø≈øerit √† ≈øua ver≈øum natura cogunt Euangeli≈øtae te≈øtimonium dicentis: Et verbum caro factum e≈øt, quod ita interpretantur: diuina natura in humanam ver≈øa e≈øt. Huius impietatis initium, Timotheus apud Bizam Bithiniae modo exulans ciuitatem. His confuting heare, and bannishing hence, ≈øeeme to make him ≈øo litle remembred in our Antiquities, if he was a Britan. Veremund. Hi≈øt. Scotor. Hector. Boeth. Hi≈øt. l. 9. f. 179. p. 1. Georg. Buchan. Rerum. Scot. l. 5. Reg. 52. p. 160. Holinsh. Hi≈øt. of Scotl. in Frequahard pag. 112. Aug. Epi≈øt. 106. Bed. Hi≈øt. l. 1. c. 10. Henr. Hunting. Hi≈øt. lib. 1. Matth. We≈øtm. Chron. an. 404. Floren. Wigorn. Chron. an. 413. ali. 435. Marian. Scot. aetat. 8. l. 2. An. 414. Pro≈øper. in Chron. Sigeb. Gembl. an. 404. Regin. Chron. an. 350. Hacluyt. p. 3. 4. in Pelagi. Bal. de Script. Brit. cent. 1. Io. Pits. in S. Keb. in not. M. S. antiq. de Vit. S. Dauid. Capgrau. Catal. in eod. Girald. Cambr. Itinerar. Camb. l. 2. c. 4. Dauid Powell annot. ib. Gennad. & Honor. de Scriptor. Eccl. in Pelag. Ioan. Bal. centur. ‚Ä¢ . in Pelag.

2. The Here≈øie of Pelagius, and he the fir≈øt Author, and Name-giuer vnto it, haue giuen the greate≈øt ≈øtayne and blemish in that kinde to this Nation, and in this time. For as his Here≈øies were mo≈øt pe≈øtilent, dangerous, and infectious, ≈øo they tooke fir≈øt roote, and afterward fixed them≈øelues ≈øo deepely in this Britaine, that they were not rooted out, vntill after the comming of ≈øaint Augu≈øtine hither aboue 200. yeares after, notwith≈øtanding we had ≈øo many and worthie men heare both of our owne Nation, and others, diuers of them ≈øent hither by the Apo≈øtolike Roman See, Power, and Authoritie thereof, to oppo≈øe, and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe it, as both our Scottish and English Writers, Catholiks and Prote≈øtants doe te≈øtifie. It is the common con≈øent of the Hi≈øtorians both of this and forreyne Countries, that this Pelagius was a Britan of this kingdome. Diuers of our Antiquaries not onely Catholiks but Prote≈øtants hold, that he was a Monke, and Abbot after in our old renowned Mona≈øtery of Bangot. Which is made more probable, both in re≈øpect that Leporius Agricola his Scholler and follower in his errors a long time, though after recanting them, was a Prei≈øt and Monke of the ≈øame Mona≈øtery: Factus e≈øt Sacerdos & Monachus in celebri Banchoren≈øi Caenobio. And of all places in Britaine, the parts thereabouts were mo≈øt infected with that Here≈øie, raigning there long after the time of ≈øaint Germanus and Lupus ≈øent hither by Pope Cele≈øtine to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe it, & was in a Sinod of all the Bishops, Abbots, & cheife Clergy men of Cambria there confuted and confounded by ≈øaint Dauid. And as I haue mentioned before, diuers Clergy men in that Country were longe after ≈øaint Dauids death, in the time of King Frequahard of Scotland ≈øtill infected therewith. All Authors agree this Pelagius was very learned, and the Title Archereticke, Here≈øiarches, which is commonly giuen vnto him doth ≈øo te≈øtifie. So doth his di≈øper≈øing his Here≈øies into ≈øo many learned Nations, venena ≈øuae perfidiae longe lateque di≈øper≈øit. So doe the greate number of Councels a≈ø≈øembled in diuers places to condeÃÑne him. So doe the particular be≈øt learned men in tho≈øe dayes, ≈øaint Augu≈øtine, ≈øaint Hierome, ≈øaint Innocentius, Oro≈øius, Gennadius and others which wrote again≈øt him. So doe they which write of learned Writers, both auncient and later Catholiks and Prote≈øtants, witne≈ø≈øing that he wrote many and learned Catholike Bookes before he fell into Here≈øie. By which we may gather, that this Nation in ≈øuch troble≈øome and tempe≈øteous times had Schooles to breede vp learned men, by whome ≈øo ≈øoone as Pelagius was fallen into Here≈øie, and noted thereof
he was bannished from hence, into forreine Countries, neuer returning hither againe. His Here≈øies are ≈øet downe by ≈øaint Augu≈øtine in diuers places of his Works, (e≈øpecially in his Booke of Here≈øies among which this of Pelagius Aug. l. de Haere≈ø. Haer. 88. l. 2. de pecc. origin. c. 11. Epi≈øt. 106. l. 2. de pecc. orig. c. 8. 9. 14. l. 2. Retract. c. 47. Hier. Epi≈øt. 79. & ad Alip. Dial. Contr. Pelag. Pro≈øper. de Ingrat. is commonly ≈øet there downe for the la≈øt heintreated of,) by ≈øaint Hierome, Pro≈øper, and other auncient approued Authors, by diuers holy Councels a≈ø≈øembled again≈øt him & his Errors, e≈øpecially the Dio≈øpolitan Councell, where many of them wherewith he was chardged, are recorded and condemned, and by him≈øelfe renownced and anathematized, haec omnia Pelagius anathematizauit, as al≈øo by the be≈øt Hi≈øtorians of this Nation before cited, and in tho≈øe places cited, be≈øides many others Manu≈øcripts and printed Catholike and Prote≈øtant Antiquaries all agreeing in the ≈øub≈øtance of his Here≈øies, allthough ≈øome doe more breifely, others more largelie deliuer them in the Dio≈øpolitan Councell, where he was charged pre≈øently to renownce his errors, or to be excommunicated, and condemned, quae ni≈øi remota omni tergiuer≈øatione anathematizaret ip≈øe anathema ≈øit factus.

3. The≈øe following are the Articles obiected again≈øt him to hold, and which he was compelled to renownce, Primo, obiectum e≈øt, cum diceret, Adam mortalem Pelagius his Here≈øies, and renounced by him. factum: qui ≈øiue pecca≈ø≈øet, ≈øiue non, mortuus e≈ø≈øet. Fir≈øt, hew as charged to hold that Adam was made mortall, and should haue died whether he had ≈øinned or no. Secondly that his ≈øin did onely hurt him≈øelfe, and not human kinde. 3. That Infants new borne are in the ≈øame ≈øtate, wherein Adam was before his fall. 4. That by the death and preuarication of Adam, all mankinde doth not die, nor all man kinde ri≈øe againe by the Re≈øurrection of Chri≈øt. 5. Children may haue eternall life, though they be not baptized. 6. Ritch men that be baptized, except they renownce all their goods, if they are thought to doe any good thing, it shall not be reputed to them, neither can they haue the Kingdome of God. 7. That the grace and helpe of God is not giuen to euery act, but it is from freewill, or in the Lawe and Doctrine. 8. That the grace of God is giuen, according to our owne meritts. 9. That men caÃÑnot be called the children of God, except they be alltogether without all ≈øinne. 10. And that it is not freewill, if it wanteth the help of God: becau≈øe euery one hath in his owne will to doe any thing, or not to doe it. 11. That our Victory is not from the help of God, but from free will. 12. That to them which ≈øeeke pardon, pardon is not giuen according to the grace and mercie of God, but according to the merits and labour of them, which by penance are worthie of mercy.

4. S. Augu≈øtin in diuers places ≈øpeaketh of this Councell, and ≈øetteth downe Aug. l. Epi≈øt. Epi≈øt. 106. l. 2. Retract. c. 47. l. 2. de pecc. orig. contr. Pelag. & Cel≈øum c. 11. Aug. & Hier. apud Baron. ann. 415. Binius to. 1. Conc. Annot. in Conc. Dio≈øpolit. Hilar. Epi≈øt. ad Aug. inter Ep. Aug. Epi≈øt. 88. Aug. l. de Haere≈ø. Haer. 88. the≈øe very Articles, whereof Pelagius was charged, and recanted by Pelagius, though di≈øseÃÑblingly for feare, as appeared by him afterward, Haec omnia Pelagius ≈øic Anathematizauit. So doe diuers others, and add more errors, which he held, as that before Chri≈øt, man was without ≈øinne. Prayer is not nece≈ø≈øary. Man is able by the Power of freewill not onely not to ≈øinne, but not to be tempted. That women ought to ≈øing in the Church. That all men ought to be cloathed as Monkes. S. Augu≈øtine addeth: That man might not ≈øweare at all. Non debere iurare omnino. The life of iust men in this life to be altogether without ≈øinne; And that the Church of Chri≈øt in this world con≈øi≈øteth of ≈øuch. Vitam iu≈øtorum in hoc ≈øaeculo nullum omnino habere peccatum, & ex his Eccle≈øiam Chri≈øti in hac mortalitate perfici. He denied that the Church should offer prayers eyther for Infidels, and ≈øuch as re≈øi≈øt the doctrine of God, that they might be conuerted vnto him: or for the faithfull that their faith might be encrea≈øed, and they per≈øeuer in it. De≈øtruunt orationes quas facit Eccle≈øia, ≈øiue pro Infidelibus & doctrinae Dei re≈øistentibus, vt conuertantur ad Deum: ≈øiue pro fidelibus, vt augeatur eis fides, & per≈øeuerent in ea. Their wicked grownd whereof was this, becau≈øe he held, that men receaue not the≈øe things from God, but haue
them of them≈øelues, and that the grace of God, by which we are deliuered Hect. Boeth. l. 9. Scotor. Hi≈øt. fol. 179. Hollinsh. Hi≈øt. of Scotl. in eod. 52. Reg. & Buch. in eod. Henric. Hunting. Hi≈øt. l. 3. Augu≈øt. l. 3. contra Pelagian. fere in initio c. 1. from impietie, is giuen by our owne merits, Haec quippe non ab ip≈øo (Deo) accipere, ≈øed √† ≈øeip≈øis homines habere contendunt, gratiam Dei qua liberamur ab impietate dicentes ≈øecundum merita no≈øtra dari.

5. From which wicked and damned Here≈øie he al≈øo denied the vertue and nece≈ø≈øitie of holy Sacraments, a≈øwell Bapti≈øme as the re≈øt, as is euident in our Brittish Pelagian Hereticks ≈øprung from him, and particularly denying the Sacrament of Confe≈ø≈øion to a Prei≈øt and Penance, as our Hi≈øtorians te≈øtifie in King Frequard of Scotland ≈øonne of Eugenius, & diuers Brittish Prei≈øts, therevpon noted and condemned of Pelagian Here≈øie. Thus Pelagius at the lea≈øt before his falle, as S. Augu≈øtine te≈øtifieth, was both a learned and holy man, and his workes e≈øpecially vpon S. Paules Epi≈øtles much commeÃÑded, Legi Pelagij quaedam ≈øcripta, viri vt audio ≈øancti, & non paruo profectu Chri≈øtiani, quae in Pa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Apo≈øtoli Epi≈øtolas Expo≈øitiones brcui≈øsimas continereÃÑt. And writeth further, that he was, ca≈øta vita, moribusque laudabilis, Of a cha≈øte life, and laudable conuer≈øation of life, and doubted not to doe as Chri≈øt commanded the ritch man, reque≈øting coun≈øaile to obtaine eternall life, ≈øaying, he had fulfilled all Augu≈øt. ≈øupr. lib. 2. cap. 16. Hier. in Praef. l. 3. in Hieren. I≈øodor Pelu≈øiot. Epi≈øt. 314. Augu≈øt. l. de peccat. Origin. c. 5. 6. lib. 2. cont. Pelag. c. ‚Ä¢ . de peccat. Orig. c. 8. 22. & Epi≈øt. 157. Pro≈øper. contr. Col ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t. Caele≈øtin. Epi≈øt. ad Epi≈øc. Galliae Gomad. de Eccl. Dogm. Po≈ø≈øid. in vit. S. Aug. c. 18. Marian. Scot. aet. 6. l. 2. an. 419. Martin. Polon. Supput. an. 413. Matth. We≈øtm. an. 415. Bal. l. de Script. Brit. cent. 1. in Pelagio Haere≈øiarca. Gennad. & Honor. de Script. Bal. ≈øup. Io. Pit≈ø. aetat. 5. de vir. Illu≈øtr. Brit. in not. pag. 84. Bed. Hi≈øt. Eccl. l. 1. c. 10. Matth. We≈øtm. Chron. an. 404. the commandements of the Lawe, that he should ≈øell all he had, and giue it to the poore, and traÃÑsferre his Trea≈øure into heaueÃÑ. Yet to free our Kingdome now England and Wales al≈øo of giuing life to ≈øuch a man, S. Hierome ≈øaith he was by Nation a Scot, progeniem haberet Scoticae gentis, and a voluptuous MoÃÑke, voluptuo≈øus Monachus as I≈øidorus Pelu≈øiota noteth. Both which may be reconciled, if we ≈øay, he was borne among the Scots, and bredd in our greate Mona≈øtery of Banger in Britaine, and there longe time an holy Monke, but after falling both into Here≈øie, and lewdenes of life, he was often condemned both by the Popes of Rome, S. Innocentius and others and in diuers Councels in A≈øia, Afrike, and Europe, whither he had ≈øpredd his Here≈øies, and not perfectly in him ≈øome times teaching and maintaining, other whiles excu≈øing or denying them, vntill in the time of Pope Zo≈øimus, about the yeare of Chri≈øt 418. being by him finally condemned both he and his followers were driuen into Exile by Honorius the Emperour. And that Here≈øie condemned in all the worlde, Concilio apud Carthaginem habito 214. & eo amplius Epi≈øcoporum, ad Papam Zo≈øimum Sinodi Decreta perlata ≈øunt, quibus probatis, per totum mundum Haere≈øis Pelagiana damnata e≈øt.

6. Yet after this it aro≈øe againe euen in Britaine, and was then and there condemned by Pope Cele≈øtine and his Legats, as now it was by Pope Zo≈øimus and the remembred Councell of aboue 214. Bishops, approued by him, and by other Councels, which ≈øome Writers euen of this Nation, and Protete≈øtants terme generall Councels, Condemnatus per Epi≈øcopos in Ephe≈øino, Carthaginen≈øi, & Milleuitano Concilijs generalibus. Before his Here≈øie he wrote many Workes agreeing with Catholike doctrine, and for them 25. in nuÃÑber, as they are recompted by ≈øome, is placed by them among Catholike Writers, euen tho≈øe of Britaine his owne Countrie, which in the fir≈øt beginning of his falling into Here≈øie, did ≈øo dete≈øt and abhore it, not hauing bene infected with Here≈øie before that time, that it pre≈øently by ≈øome Authors bannished him from hence, Vt videtur, Britones Pelagium eiu≈øque ≈øequaces in exilium eiecerunt, ip≈øis mali principijs matur√® occurrentes. Which ≈øeemeth to be confirmed by ≈øainct Bede and others, te≈øtifying how in a very short time he ≈øpred his errors very farre, venena ≈øuae perfidiae long√® lat√©que disper≈øit, and yet v≈øed no coadiutors that were Britans, for anything we finde in Antiquities, but on ‚Ä¢ ly
≈øtrangers of remote Nations, an Argument that his owne Country had condemned and exiled him: otherwi≈øe that famous Mona≈øtery of Bangor where he had his education, ≈øo much florishing with learned men, and Monkes, as all Authors that write thereof agree, and he being Abbot and Commander among them, and Britaine ≈øo abounding with learning at that time, as our very women, as ≈øaint Helen & ≈øaint Vr≈øula are thereby glorious in the world, ≈øome would haue followed him in tho≈øe errors, preached and published them as he did. Which is confirmed by their carriage, afterward when Leporius Agricola reuiued tho≈øe errors heare, when by rea≈øon of warrs and tumults, learning was much dacayed by the Infidell Saxons, yet our Britans would not theÃÑ admit of Pelagius his Here≈øie, but by all meanes they could re≈øi≈øted it, Britanni ≈øu≈øcipere dogma peruer≈øum, gratiam Christi bla≈øphemando nullatenus vellent. And the Reuiuer of that Here≈øie heare Leporius Agricola did in Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. c. 17 Matth. We≈øtm. Chron. an. 442. Pits. aetat. 4. p. 85. Bal. l. de Script. cent. 1. in Pelag. a Booke written and published thereof vtterly recant and condemne it, emenda ‚Ä¢ us correctionis ≈øuae librum vera fide Catholica compo≈øuit. A greate honour to this Nation, that it had ≈øuch learned men, that euen one of them falling into error, did ≈øo much preuayle and dilate it both in Europe, Afrike, and A≈øia, and yet in his owne Country could nothing preuayle, but was at the fir≈øt conuinced, reiected and exiled, and did onely endeuour to infect Britaine his Natiue Country, but could not effect his de≈øire therein, In Britannia Pelagius execrabili Sigebert. Gemb. Chron. an. 404. doctrina Eccle≈øiam Chri≈øti maculari nititur. And therefore as Hi≈øtorians te≈øtifie he tooke others of other Nations, as Cele≈øtius and Iulianus to vent his errors, Hac tempe≈øtate Pelagius Brito, dogma nominis ≈øui contragratiam Chri≈øti, Marian. Scot. l. 2. aetat. 6. an. 414. Bed. ≈øupr. l. 1. c. 10‚ñ™
Cele≈øtio & Iuliano adiutoribus exerit. Therefore as ≈øainct Chry≈øo≈øtome noteth of all in generall, which with≈øtood, him, that they de≈øerued greate Crownes of honour, ≈øeeing many holy and godly men were deceaued by him: Quot quantisque coronis digni≈øint qui forti animo in acie ≈øteterint, cum viri tam pi√® ac Chry≈øo≈øt. Ep. 4. Baron. & Spond. Annal. an. 405. ≈øanct√®, tantaque cum tolerantia viuentes abripi, at que in fraudem impelli cernerentur. So we mu≈øt needs giue the greate≈øt glory to our Britaine, which from the beginning ≈øo contemned his errors, and kept it≈øelfe free, and vn≈øpotted from that ≈øo violent and common infection, neuer defiled with it, vntill Leporius Agricola long after reuiued it, and ≈øoone recanted it. Which our old Hi≈øtorians writing of this Here≈øie, thus further and plainely confirme, Ab hac & ab alijs pe≈øtibus Haereticis immunis ≈øemper extitit Anglia, cum in alijs mundi partibus tot pullularint Haere≈øes. Et quidem haec In≈øula cum propter Guliel. Neubrig. Rer. Angl. l. 2. c. 13. incolentes Britones Britannia diceretur. Pelagium in Oriente Haere≈øiarcham futurum ex ≈øe mi≈øit, eiu≈øque in ≈øe proce≈ø≈øu temporis errorem admi≈øit: Ad cuius peremptionem Gallicanae Eccle≈øiae pia proui≈øio ≈øemel & iterum beati≈øsimum direxit Germanum. And ≈øaint Pro≈øper him≈øelfe ≈øetteth downe the fir≈øt ri≈øing of the Pelagian Here≈øie in Britaine to haue bene in this time, in the yeare 432. Pro≈øp. in Chron. an. 432. Bed. l. 1. Hi≈øt. c. 17 Stowe Hi≈øt. in Theodo≈øius. Io. Bal. l. de Script. Britan. cent. 1. in in Leporio Agri. when it had reigned diuers yeares in other Countries. And ≈øaint Bede is plaine, it was brought hither by Agricola: Haere≈øis Pelagiana per Agricolam illata: And our English Prote≈øtant Antiquaries doe plainely thus acknowledge: The Pelagian Here≈øie was brought into Britaine by Agricola about this time, the yeare of Chri≈øt 446. as they plainely calculate, and expre≈ø≈øe in their commonly receaued Hi≈øtories. And the old Manu≈øcript of Landaffe plainely teacheth, that the Britans kept their holy faith, which they receaued Manu≈øcr. Antiq. de primo ≈øtatu Landau. Eccl. in the time of King Lucius, inuiolable, without any ≈øpot ‚Ä¢ of wicked doctrine, ≈øine aliqua praui dogmatis macula, vntill the Pelagian Here≈øie began to ri≈øe heare, and that was not vntill a litle before ≈øaint Germanus and Lupus
came hither, out of France to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe it, and the Britans did not then Parker. Antiq. Brit. p. 6. 45. 46. Bal. l. 2. de act. Pontif. in Greg. 1. & l. de Script. Brit. cent. 1. in Aug. Dionotho. Godwyn. Conuer≈ø. of Britan. Powel annot. in 2. l. Girald. CaÃÑb. Itiner. Cambr. c. 1. Foxe Act. Monum. p. 463. edit. an. 1576. Holins. Hi≈øt. of Engl. c. 21. con≈øent vnto this wicked Here≈øie, prauae doctrinae Haereticorum non adquie≈øcebant. Our English Prote≈øtant Antiquaries in greate number affirme our Britans to haue bene free not onely from the Here≈øies of Pelagius, in his time, but both from that, & all other Here≈øies, and Errors in Religion, during all the fir≈øt ≈øixe hundred yeares of Chri≈øt, two hundred yeares or there abouts, after the ri≈øing vp of the Pelagian. Here≈øie.

div.p: Note gentle Reader that the first number in the Index directs thee to the Page, the ≈øecond to the Paragraph. And becau≈øe ≈øome Pages by the Printers negligence are fal≈øe ciphered, I haue for thy greater facilitie ≈øett downe in this Index both the true and fal≈øe Number of the Pages cited, in this ≈øorte, 444. 3. or 445. 3. the fir≈øt number whereof is true, the ≈øecond fal≈øe.
